https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.print_headline: STUDY SAYS U.S. CURBS ON SOVIET TRADE DON'T WORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.body_text: **********American advocates of doing business with the Soviet Union have charged in a new book that Government restrictions have damaged the reputation of the United States as a reliable trading partner and have been self-destructive. **********The book, which includes contributions by businessmen and former United States Government officials, was prepared by the American Committee on East-West Accord, a nonpartisan group based in Washington. **********Robert D. Schmidt, vice chairman of Control Data Corporation, the computer maker, and president of the Washington committee, said in a foreword, ''It is high time to look at our trade with the U.S.S.R. without emotion, with utilization of the best information possible and with an honest effort to correct the errors of the past.'' **********Mr. Schmidt said the study, titled ''Common Sense in U.S.-Soviet Trade,'' was intended to present what he called the realities of commerce between the two countries. **********''One reality we all should recognize,'' he said, ''is that there is no advantage in not doing business. Another is that we are not going to insure peace by trade alone. **********''But the strategic relationship is such that we either must live with the Soviets on this planet or die with them. There is no point in aggravating our relations by punitive trade policies which are politically ineffective and economically self-destructive.'' **********The allusion appears to be to disputes between the United States and its allies, which have often supplied Moscow with goods embargoed at various times by Washington. **********The volume of trade with the Soviet Union carried on by such countries as West Germany, Japan, France and Italy has long exceeded American trade with the Russians. **********The trade study was written before a South Korean airliner was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane on Sept. 1 and does not deal with the repercussions. Trade with Moscow has again emerged as an issue since the incident. **********Last month an interagency advisory group in the Reagan Administration recommended that some 17 oil and gas exploration products be placed under tighter export controls supervised by the Pentagon. The recommendation led to the resignation in protest by William A. Root, the State Department's top official for trade with Communist countries. **********On Oct. 4 it was disclosed that the Administration had decided to ignore the recommendation of the interagency group. The Government was evidently reluctant to impose additional curbs on trade with the Russians and hoped to avoid new frictions with the allies. **********The Administration decision, in turn, gave rise to reports that Lawrence J. Brady, an Assistant Secretary of Commerce and a hard-liner on the issue of trading with the Russians, might now leave the Government. **********The book issued by the Committee on East-West Accord contends that American trade sanctions have proved ineffective because Moscow can circumvent them by obtaining embargoed goods elsewhere. The study also argues that contracts, once signed, should not be breached by suspending export licenses for policy reasons.  Among the authors, aside from Mr. Schmidt, are business leaders who have had experience in dealing with the Russians, including Donald M. Kendall, chairman of PepsiCo Inc.; James H. Giffen, a corporate vice president of Armco Inc., and Michael V. Forrestal and Harold B. Scott, former presidents of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, a New York-based trade promotion group. **********A gas industry executive, Jack H. Ray of Tennessee Gas Transmission, noted that the Reagan Administration adopted a futile course last year in opposing construction of the gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe. The project was favored by the Western Europeans, and the laying of pipe on the 2,800-mile Soviet segment was completed in August. **********The 173-page soft-cover book is available for $5 from the American Committee on East-West Accord, 109 11th Street, S.E., Washington, D.C. 20003.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/23/busin.body_text: **********Trading in telephone company stocks dominated the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, accounting for almost 8 percent of all shares that changed hands and helping to push up stock prices in general. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 7.01 points, to 1,275.81 after having climbed 17.78 points the day before. **********Trading in the shares of the ''old'' and ''new'' American Telephone and Telegraph Company totaled just over 9 million. Total Big Board volume was 117.6 million shares, the largest since Oct. 6 when 118.3 million shares were traded. **********On Monday, volume in the two stocks represented 11.5 percent of that day's turnover of 97.7 million shares on the Big Board. The stocks of the ''new'' A.T.& T. and the seven regional companies that are to come into existence on Jan. 1 began trading Monday on a ''when-issued'' basis. In all, 1.6 billion new shares were listed, the largest listing ever of new stock in a single day. **********Some Blue Chips Do Well **********In the overall market, 998 issues advanced in price on the New York Stock Exchange, while 658 declined. Some blue chips and technology issues again were strong.  The volume leader for the second consecutive session was the ''when- issued'' shares of the ''new'' A.T.&T., the company that will remain after its regional operations are spun off. The stock rose 5/8, to 18 5/8, on a turnover of about 5 million shares. **********Most analysts believe that the surge of trading in the stocks of the ''new'' and ''old'' A.T.& T. will continue for a few days more and then drop after professional speculators and arbritgers lose interest. They have been the principal buyers and sellers, seeking to make quick profits as the prices of the shares fluctuate in the initial trading. **********The stock of the still-existing, or ''old,'' A.T.& T., which will continue to trade through mid-February under the divestiture plan, were up 1, to 64 1/2. The stock was the second most- heavily traded with 4.1 million shares changing hands. **********Most Regionals Lower **********Most of the seven regional telephone companies finished lower yesterday in moderate trading. Bell South lost 1 1/4, to 89; Pacific Telesis was off 1/2, to 54 5/8; Southwestern Bell eased 1/8, to 61 3/8; U S West, 1/8, to 59, and Bell Atlantic, 1/4, to 70. On the upside, Ameritech gained 1 1/4, to 66 3/8, and Nynex, 7/8, to 63. **********Robert H. Stovall, director of investment policy of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said equities were buoyed by a Commerce Department report that durable goods orders for October rose 3 percent, its biggest gain since a 7.6 percent rise in June. **********Another favorable factor for the market was the Government's revised report that the gross national product in the third quarter increased by 7.7 percent, instead of the 7.9 percent rise previously announced. **********Mr. Stovall said the slower growth of the economy would lessen pressure on interest rates and thus tend to spur stock prices. He said that early indications are that fourth-quarter G.N.P. gains will be the same or less than in the previous quarter. **********The market's impressive gain on Monday was spurred by the Commerce Department's report of a gain of 1.2 percent in personal income in October, which was its biggest monthly advance since August 1981, and a small decline in interest rates in the credit markets. Bond yields again fell modestly yesterday. **********Other Indicators Gain **********The two other major market indicators also ended higher yesterday. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks rose 0.41, to 96.33, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues gained 0.79, to 166.84. **********Charles S. Comer, vice president of Oppenheimer & Company, said that while the market's recent strength is encouraging, ''the absence of broader participation in the secondary issues detracts from the prospects for a continuation of the advance.'' **********Long Island Lighting was actively- traded yesterday and fell 1 3/4, to 12 5/8, after it was reported that Governor Cuomo of New York will not act to help open the company's troubled nuclear power plant in Shoreham, L.I. The company said the fate of the plant's license is in the hands of the Federal Government. **********The biggest loser among the 15 most-active issues was International Business Machines. The company yesterday increased its interest in Intel Corporation to 16.3 percent of Intel's outstanding stock. I.B.M. had previously announced that it has agreed to acquire no more than 30 percent of Intel's stock. Intel, which trades in the over-the-counter market, rose 3/4, to 42 1/2 bid. **********In the stronger blue-chip category, American Brands advanced 2 1/2, to 58 1/4, while gains of a point or more were registered by Union Carbide, General Foods and U.S. Steel. **********The biggest gainers among the technology stocks were Honeywell, which rose 1 3/4, to 134 1/2, and Digital Equipment, 1 3/8, to 72 7/8. Computervision added 1 1/8, to 46 1/8, and Hewlett- Packard, 1, to 40 3/4. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index was up 0.71, to 221.02. CDI Corporation rose 2 1/2, to 29 1/4, after reporting that its profits in the quarter ended Oct. 31 climbed to $1.04 a share from 19 cents. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index increased 1.50, to 284.55.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/05/world.body_text: **********The Voice of America is increasing broadcasts to the Soviet Union in an effort to get the story out about the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Russian warplane, a spokesman said today. **********The spokesman for the United States Information Agency, which runs Voice of America, said the radio station began adding 56 transmitter hours of broadcasting daily after the crisis began. **********''The Soviets are giving their own people even less than they are giving us,'' Charles Z. Wick, the U.S.I.A. director, said.

Paine Webber also had no comment. **********The shares were offered for sale early this month by The Reliance Group Holdings, which sold about 1 million, or the equivalent of 7 percent of the big brokerage firm's stock. **********At its Greenwich, Conn., headquarters, an American Can spokesman said, ''We are not commenting on that rumor.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/busin.body_text: **********A dramatic drop in temperatures and heavy snowfalls have hit northern Kazakhstan, one of the Soviet Union's prime grain-growing areas, the official press agency Tass reported today. **********It said that over the weekend the thermometer plunged in a matter of minutes from 63 degrees Fahrenheit to 18 in the Karaganda, Tselinograd and Dzhezkazgan regions. **********An Arctic cyclone that hit the area brought heavy snow and strong winds, felling power lines, the report added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/25/busin.body_text: **********AFTER an extensive search for an agency to handle its big corporate advertising campaign, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has decided on D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York. Plans call for a budget of $12 million. **********The other finalist was Benton & Bowles.  Not involved in the assignment are the large insurance company's projects at Isidore & Paulson, which ''until further notice'' will remain where they are, according to Mel Gregory, senior vice president, corporate communications, of Equitable. **********Alvin Hampel, chairman of D'Arcy/ New York, was anxious to note that the assignment means that the shop has received one new piece of business a month for the past five months, which adds far more billings than were lost by the departure of Thomas's English muffins and the resignation of the Heublein business. **********According to Mr. Gregory, Equitable has not run any major corporate advertising for six or seven years.  Could its decision to make a major spending commitment signal the beginning of a turnaround in corporate thinking generally concerning corporate ad spending? This area is usually hit hard by bad times. **********One of the sources of information in this area is the Journal of the Public Relations Society of America, which does a major feature on the subject each Novmber. Last November it reported that total spending in six major measured media for 1981 was $442 million, while the chilling effects of the economy seem to have caught up in the first half of 1982, when the figure dropped to $78.1 million. **********Leo Northart, the editor, took an advance peek at the data to be used next November, which showed that total 1982 spending came to about $172 million, a 61 percent drop from the previous year. These figures come from Leading National Advertisers, which does not include spending in newspapers or spot radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/11/busin.main_headline: IS THE SURGE IN OIL STOCKS OVER?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/11/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; IS THE SURGE IN OIL STOCKS OVER?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/11/busin.body_text: **********FOR the last five months, as the ecstacy of a bull market began to die down, the stocks of the nation's oil companies, drilling equipment manufacturers, and oilfield service concerns have enjoyed a bull market of their own. And it was a welcome reversal of roles. Last year, these were the stocks that were shunned by Wall Street - sold off by large institutional investors and left to flounder throughout the fall and winter. **********Analysts now point to March 31 as the beginning of the upturn for oil stocks. Since then, Standard & Poor's composite index of oil stock prices has risen more than three times as much as the S.& P.500. **********The question now facing investors is whether the oils are priced too high. Can current prices be justified in face of abundant oil and gas inventories, hundreds of idle drilling rigs and refineries running way below capacity? Indeed, analysts maintain the oil industry has serious problems to overcome, and their assessments of the oil stocks have become increasingly cautious in recent weeks. **********Charles C. Cahn of Sanford C. Bernstein offered one of the most skeptical views. Mr. Cahn said he would not recommend that investors buy any stock in the group at current prices and thinks that it would take ''something like a 20 percent increase in the gross national product,'' and the resulting increase in demand for oil and gas, for him to change his mind. **********Other analysts retain a more positive position than Mr. Cahn, but they say they have become far more selective about which oil stocks they are recommending. ''The easy stuff is behind us,'' said Rosario Ilacqua of L. F. Rothchild. **********Despite the caution, most Wall Street analysts who follow the oil and gas industry continue to recommend a select number of oil stocks. Among the stocks on the buy lists of these analysts last week were Amerada Hess, Mobil, Schlumberger and Dorchester Hugoton Ltd., a small gas producer. **********The rally in oil stocks began some two weeks after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached a long awaited agreement in mid-March to lower the price of its crude oil by 15 percent and set production quotas to prevent a worsening of the worldwide oil glut. **********Although the accord was widely regarded as good news for oil companies, Wall Street's response was delayed because of doubts that the agreement would hold. ''The market responded only when it decided OPEC was acting with discipline, and stock prices continued to rise as the market became more convinced that the discipline would be maintained,'' Mr. Cahn said. **********In recent weeks, oil stocks have been bolstered even further by concern that the three-year-old war between Iran and Iraq, both major producers, will flare up. France has recently supplied Iraq with sophisticated jet fighters and heat seeking missiles, and analysts speculate that Iraq could begin to use them against oil tankers at Iran's oil port. If that happens, many believe the war could engulf Saudi Arabia and other Middle East producers, creating a major oil disruption. **********If the Iran-Iraq war does not escalate sharply, analysts agree that oil supplies will be plentiful and prices roughly unchanged for at least two years. Thus, the earnings performance and growth of American oil companies will not benefit from OPEC-imposed price increases. Rather they will rise or fall on the success of their exploration programs, the efficiency of their refining and marketing operations, and the impact of changes in government regulations. **********Amerada Hess ranks high on several analysts' lists of recommended stocks because its oil production in the North Sea is expected to expand rapidly. The First Boston Corporation estimated that Hess's North Sea oil production, which averaged 24,370 barrels a day last year, would increase to 80,000 barrels a day by 1986. **********Thomas Petrie of First Boston also said he expects Hess to benefit from exploration in the Gulf of Mexico and Alaska's Beaufort Sea, where it acquired a promising oil production lease from the Department of the Interior this year. With the cash generated by its North Sea oil, Amerada ''has a very good inventory of future opportunities and the horsepower to explore them,'' Mr. Petrie said. **********Several analysts pick Mobil as another company that will benefit from expanding production. Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, is bringing several new wells into production in the North Sea and Indonesia. **********MR. ILACQUA of L. F. Rothschild, one those who favor Mobil, said the company's earnings will also be broadened this year because it is paying less for the oil it buys from Saudi Arabia. As part of the March OPEC accord, the Saudis lowered their crude price to $29 from $34 a barrel. As one of the four American oil companies that are partners in the Arabian American Oil Company, or Aramco, Mobil is currently increasing its purchases at the lower price. **********The oilfield services industry has yet to recover from the rapid decline in drilling last year. After a slight but steady increase in drilling activity this summer, there were only 2,445 rigs in operation in the United States and Canada last week - slightly more than half of those that were operating in December 1981. **********But analysts expect the business of some oilfield service concerns to get better. Several pick Schlumberger, a maker of tools that are used by oil drillers to detect, or ''log,'' underground geological formations. **********Schlumberger has taken a lead in computerized logging equipment, which allows drillers to chart formations more accurately. ''Even with surplus capacity'' in the oil drilling industry, ''the technologically advanced companies will prosper, and Schlumberger heads that list,'' said Elizabeth Peek of Wertheim & Company. **********Many speculative investors, meanwhile, believe that money can be made by acquiring the stocks of natural gas production companies because of the possibility of changes in government regulations. Analysts maintain that decontrol of natural gas prices - a highly controversial proposal before Congress - would sharply increase the earnings of some of these companies. **********Kurt H. Wulff, of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, picks Dorchester Hugoton. The company has large reserves, but its gas can only be sold at extremely low prices under Federal price controls. Mr. Wulff says the company is selling its gas for an average of 30 cents per thousand cubic feet, or one-tenth the industry average of $3 per thousand cubic feet. **********Thus, while the company faces severe problems now, it would benefit greatly from changes in government regulations. Even without price decontrol, Mr. Wulff said the company would gain from proposed changes in state regulations in Kansas, where most of its gas reserves are. The proposal in that state would allow Dorchester to sink one additional gas well for each of the wells it already operates, and charge far higher prices for the gas produced in the new wells.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from Administration statements on United States objectives in Lebanon:  Sept. 29, 1982 **********Letter from President Reagan to Congress on the Marines in Lebanon: **********Their mission is to provide an interposition force at agreed locations and thereby provide the multinational presence requested by the Lebanese Government to assist it and the Lebanese armed forces. **********In carrying out this mission, the American force will not engage in combat. It may, however, exercise the right of self-defense and will be equipped accordingly. **********These forces will operate in close coordination with the Lebanese armed forces. Our agreement with the Government of Lebanon makes clear that they will be needed only for a limited period to meet the urgent requirements posed by the current situation. Although isolated acts of violence can never be ruled out, all appropriate precautions have been taken to ensure the saftey of U.S. military personnel during their temporary deployment in Lebanon. **********I believe that this step will support the objective of helping to restore the territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence of Lebanon.   Sept. 25, 1982 **********Letter from the United States Ambassador to Lebanon, Robert Sherwood Dillon, to Deputy Prime Minister Fuad Butros of Lebanon: **********I am pleased to inform you on behalf of my Government that the United States is prepared to deploy temporarily a force of approximately 1,200 personnel as part of a multinational force to establish an environment which will permit the Lebanese armed forces to carry out their responsibilities in the Beirut area.   Jan. 16, 1983 **********Statement on the marines in Lebanon by Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman: **********We recognize that it is a situation that is not completely free of danger, but then again, it is not fraught with danger. We don't anticipate any major conflict because they have been there for three to four months without any major incident. And they are in a situation where they are not in conflict, not in contact with anybody that could produce a major incident.   Aug. 30, 1983 **********Letter from President Reagan to Congressional leaders after marines had come under mortar fire in Lebanon: **********I believe that the continued presence of these U.S. forces in Lebanon is essential to the objective of helping restore the territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence of Lebanon.   Sept. 21, 1983 **********Statement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the House Foreign Affairs Committee: **********From the beginning, we have had essentially three policy objectives in Lebanon: the withdrawal of all external forces from Lebanon; a sovereign independent Lebanon dedicated to national unity and able to exercise its authority throughout its national territory, and security for Israel's northern border, so that the inhabitants of northern Israel can live in saftey and without fear of artillery and rocket attacks. The latest outbreak of fighting should not cause us to lose sight of these objectives.   Oct. 19, 1983 **********Remark by Mr. Reagan at a news conference: **********The Marines will always defend themselves, and we will provide that defense.   Oct. 23, 1983 **********Remarks by Mr. Reagan after the bombing of the Marine barracks in Lebanon: **********I think we should all recognize that these deeds make so evident the bestial nature of those who would assume power if they could have their way and drive us out of that area; that we must be more determined than ever that they cannot take over that vital and strategic area of the earth, or for that matter, any other part of the earth. **********5thSUB STATEMENT for carla: to fix oct. 23 ONLY/ ignore rest of sub type Recent U.S. Military Involvement in Lebanon Source: Associated Press    1982 1983 August September October November December January February March April May June July August Septem ber October Aug. 25 800 marines land in Beirut to help evacuate Palestinian guerrillas after Israeli forces capture the city.  Sept. 10 Marines leave Beirut after evacuation of 8,000 Palestinian guerrillas.  Sept. 29 1,200 marines land again on the shores of Lebanon as part of an international peacekeeping force. They are stationed around Beirut International Airport.  Sept. 30 First marine killed, three others injured while setting off a cluster bomb at airport.  April 18 63 people killed in the bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Beirut.  Aug. 29 Two marines killed, 13 wounded when mortar shells and rockets land in airport compound during clashes between Lebanese Army and Shiite Moslem and Druse militias.  Sept. 4 Israeli forces withdraw from central mountains. Rival Christian and Druse militias intensify battles.  Sept. 6 Two marines killed, two wounded by mortars and rockets.  Sept. 7 Marines fire artillery for first time in response to continuing attacks.  Sept. 8 U.S. Navy Frigate Bowen opens fire on artillery positions in response to attacks on marines.  Sept. 18-19 Naval bombardment on artillery positions continues.  Oct. 14 Marine killed, another seriously injured by sniper fire.  Oct. 15 Marine killed, three wounded in sniping and grenade attack. Marines also admit for first time that they shot and killed snipers.  Oct. 23 Terrorist drives truck packed with explosives into building full of sleeping marines and sailors, killing scores of them. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.body_text: **********Some 680 anti-Government guerrillas abandoned their jungle bases and surrendered to the authorities today in a ceremony in southern Thailand. **********The state radio said 471 Moslem separatists, 165 Communist insurgents and 44 members of the Communist Party of Malaysia from five southern provinces surrendered at a military camp in Pattani province, near the Malaysian border. **********A military official in Bangkok said it was the largest number of insurgents ever to surrender in the region. They were taking advantage of an amnesty program under which they and their families receive land and money to build homes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; 2 Publications Aimed At Special Interests
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.body_text: **********As examples of how specific special interest magazines have become, only people who move or families worth more than $1 million may be interested in two new publications. **********One of the two, a magazine named New Connections, is intended to ''reach new movers at the right time.'' Beginning in Philadelphia in December, the magazine will come free to residents who request a telephone from their local telephone company. **********''Part of the moving-in process is stocking up on household supplies and establishing new shopping patterns in unfamiliar territory,'' said Kent Dreyfuss, manager for product development for the publisher. Published through an agreement between Donnelley Marketing and Reuben H. Donnelley, a publisher of business Yellow Page directories, the magazine will be available in major cities by the end of 1984. Both Donnelley companies are subsidiaries of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. **********Circulation is expected to be nearly four million in the first year, and seven million in three years. **********Even more special is the new national version of Palm Beach Illustrated, a good life magazine for readers with incomes of more than $200,000 a year. Yesterday, Falcon Publishing announced its acquisition of Palm Beach Illustrated for an undisclosed price. Falcon, based in Boston, previously concentrated on the publication of trade-show catalogues and marketing brochures and the promotion of third world conferences, especially in Saudia Arabia. **********Frank Lennon, president of Falcon, said that the September/October issue, the first of the national issues, will be available next week at $3 a copy. The company will publish six regular issues and two special issues a year. Total circulation is expected to be about 50,000 for the initial issues. **********The first issue, called Newport Illustrated and dedicated to the activities surrounding the America's Cup summer in that Rhode Island resort, will be mailed to a specially selected readership next week. The magazine will continue to show the good life, Mr. Lennon said. ''Our market is the Rolls market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/19/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; Mechanic's Lien for Brokers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/19/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; Mechanic's Lien for Brokers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/19/busin.body_text: **********JUST before leaving office, Governor Carey signed a bill designed to solve what the real estate industry here considers one of its thorniest problems. **********Richard M. Rosan, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, explained that there had been a growing problem in recent years with building owners who refused to pay commissions to brokers for their work in finding tenants for commercial buildings. The real estate board, the industry's most prominent trade organization, counts as members both owners and brokers. **********Aaron Gural, vice president of the board's brokerage division, adds that the problem has existed for 20 years but has lately grown to serious proportions. **********The result is a bill that protects brokers by allowing them to place liens on a building when a commission has not been paid.  Passage of the legislation, Mr. Rosan said, was one of the major accomplishments of the real estate board last year. **********Every state has enacted some form of ''mechanic's lien'' law, which allows those who furnish labor or materials to impose liens against a contractor or property owner. Owners cannot sell a property or change the financing when there is a lien on the property. Officials here believe New York has become the first state that includes brokers in the mechanic's lien law. **********Instead of litigating, which can eat up a third or more of a commission, the broker now has the option of placing a lien on the property. **********A survey by the real estate board in the fall of 1981 found brokers and owners disputing $16 million in commissions over a fiveyear period. The survey looked at 75 Manhattan brokers who had 284 cases of disputed commissions. In 54 percent of the cases, the disputes involved the commission on the sale of a property. **********The amounts of the disputes ranged from $800 to $2.5 million.  Large commissions are usually paid in stages over several years, sometimes as long as five years. Most brokers are totally dependent on commissions for their income, although some do receive an additional regular salary. **********The new law covers only leasing commissions and only those commissions where the broker has a written contract with the owner.  The legal and logical questions about disputed commissions on sales are more difficult and as a result the bill was limited to leases, according to Mr. Rosan. **********The real estate board's report estimated that about $10 million in disputed claims had been settled. Brokers reported ''concrete losses'' of $4.9 million in the settled cases. ''Most settlements occur though negotiation,'' the report said, ''probably because, in 76 percent of the cases settled through litigation, legal fees absorbed at least one-third of the cash received by the broker. Under these circumstances, brokers negotiate low settlements rather than invest time in litigation only to see one-third of the settlement go to legal fees.'' **********Mr. Gural, who is chairman of Newmark & Company Real Estate, said problems in collecting commissions had recently become worse because there is a ''new type of owner'' in the city. Newmark started as a brokerage firm 50 years ago and has expanded to other areas of real estate, but Mr. Gural is also an owner. **********He said that the number of ''foreign owners'' was growing and that many of the newcomers ''are people not used to the way of paying bills.'' He added, ''Frankly, some of these owners are not aware that brokers' commissions have to be paid on time and properly.'' **********Mr. Gural also said the problem had been exacerbated by the fact that many new owners were not real estate professionals but people in other unrelated busineses who owned only one building. Mr. Rosan agreed, adding that sometimes the disputes arose when a building changed hands. **********Sometimes the broker who is still owed money for placing a tenant in the building becomes trapped between the old and new owner. Mr.  Rosan said problems were also generated by ''faceless people and offshore companies'' that were buying Manhattan properties in great numbers these days. **********Larry Silverstein, one of the major owners of the city, who is chairman of the real estate board and one of bill's biggest supporters, had a slightly different explanation of the problem. **********''Most owners are very responsible people,'' he said. ''They fulfill their responsibilities to the broker. In many instances - not the major buildings, but in many instances where properties are less significant - the broker has not been able to collect.'' **********Mr. Silverstein said he agreed that the problem had been growing, but he attributed the cause to more difficult economic times.  Skeptics believe that the new law may be a disappointment for brokers. Owners, the skeptics said, may now simply refuse to give brokers a written contract to lease space, thereby avoiding the possibility of a lien.

The death brought to 557 the Israeli losses in Lebanon since the invasion of June 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/busin.body_text: **********The Venezuelan economy, once the most robust in South America, has entered its second month of paralysis, waiting for the Government to formulate a strategy to offset falling oil profits and renegotiate its foreign debt. **********The halt in activity has been caused by the suspension on Feb. 20 of foreign exchange rates and the failure to come up with a definitive substitute. Instead of moving toward a national consensus that almost every sector of Venezuelan society has been calling for in broadcast appeals and newspaper advertisements, the Government has shunned consultation, and the two key members of its economic team have fallen into an open quarrel. **********Import restrictions are being issued periodically, and their application has appeared erratic. Some, for instance, have been directed at life-supporting medical equipment while an announced ban on whisky is apparently being reconsidered. **********The dispute between the two men is considered so damaging that the leadership of President Luis Herrera Campins's Social Christian Copei Party has called for the resignation of one of them, Leopoldo Diaz Bruzual, the central bank president, and has pledged to submit him to an embarrassing party disciplinary procedure if he does not step down. Pay Raise Criticized **********Mr. Diaz Bruzual, commonly referred to by Venezuelans as ''the buffalo'' because of his physically intimidating manner, further alienated critics by taking a 94 percent pay increase while demanding austerity from the nation. Word also emerged that he had received a $500,000 loan from the central bank credit union, the bulk of it at 4 percent interest over 25 years. **********The other principal in the dispute, Finance Minister Arturo Sosa, returned from New York tonight after discussing with bankers the refinancing of more than $9 billion in short-term debt. The Government still has not determined the total, according to economic analysts here. ''Each day they keep finding more,'' one said. **********Banking sources cited by the management newsletter Veneconomy said they thought the current renegotiation was only a prelude to a formal restructuring of the nation's entire $24 billion foreign debt. This would begin, the publication reported, with the declaration of a ''standstill,'' under which no principal payments would be made for three to six months while a new repayment schedule was worked out based on oil income projections. **********Before leaving Caracas Thursday night, Mr. Sosa estimated that Venezuela's anticipated oil income for this year would fall by $2.8 billion because of the new production quotas agreed upon at the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in London earlier this month. Petroleum industry sources however, said they thought the reduction could run as high as $5 billion. Spending Cuts Urged **********Many economists are saying that a cut of up to 20 percent in Government spending is needed, but the Government has shown no disposition to make such a move. It is widely acknowledged that the present crisis has its roots in the huge increases in public spending during the years of the oil price boom. **********The federal bureaucracy has grown in the past decade to 1.2 million people from 300,000, and Government spending in that period has risen to $22.6 billion from $3.5 billion. The participation of the state in total production of goods and services has grown to 65 percent from 32 percent 20 years ago. **********Along with its apparent reluctance to attack state spending, the Government has devised a three-tiered exchange rate that has nearly doubled the debt burden of private companies while maintaining for the public sector access to cheaper dollars. **********Total private debt in Venezuela is $6 billion to $8 billion. Under the exchange rate program, the Government can continue to buy dollars at the longtime rate of 4.3 bolivars, but private companies have to purchase them either at 6 bolivars or at a floating rate as high as 9 bolivars. An Exchange Windfall **********By purchasing dollars at the lower rate and selling them at the higher one, the Government stands to obtain a windfall of bolivars.  By contrast, leaders of business said that thousands of companies would go bankrupt if the decree stood. **********This procedure aroused such controversy that President Herrera amended it. In his televised annual address to Congress on March 9 he disclosed that the preferential dollar rate would be extended to private businesses. And Mr. Sosa said that businesses could qualify if they were able to convert their short-term obligations into longer ones. **********That evening, however, Mr. Diaz Bruzual said he had heard nothing of the plan and did not necessarily go along with it. This remarkable public disagreement has been allowed to continue. **********Imports, on which all strata of the Venezuelan economy are heavily dependent, have stopped while traders await word on which dollar rates to use for transactions. Consecomercio, the country's largest retail trade organization, said it would resort to a one-day protest strike if the indecision persisted. Prices Frozen **********There is a certain irony in the threat since the level of business activity in Venezuela has already been sharply reduced. Many companies are using emergency inventories, while others are holding back supplies in anticipation of higher prices. The Government froze prices in February until April 28. **********The crisis began to build with the decline in oil revenues and a concomitant flight of capital out of the country. Central bank reserves, which stood at $20.1 billion at the beginning of 1982, were down to $8.6 billion and falling rapidly at the beginning of this month. The bank has stopped publishing the figure, an indication that they have reached dangerous levels. **********Two steps taken by the Government to build reserves also had the effect of eroding investor confidence and caused more money to leave the country. The Government revalued its gold reserves from $35 an ounce to $400, and it nationalized the reserves of the state oil monopoly. **********On the last day of dollar trading before the exchange halt, $230 million left Venezuela.  The dormant economy did receive one piece of good news in the past week, however. Citing the exchange controls as the reason, banks said they would lower interest rates on April 1 by 3 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Mattel Studying Public Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Mattel Inc. is considering a public offering of stock in its toy division, a company spokesman said, because the unit has enjoyed a record year. **********For the six months ended July 30, the company as a whole had a loss of $179.4 million, substantially wider than the deficit of $31.2 million a year earlier. But the toy division earned $42 million, up from $39.9 million the year before. Toy sales rose to $286.8 million, from $253.1 million. **********The electronics group lost $201.1 million in the first half, reversing a profit of $50.2 millon the year before.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.body_text: **********A class action suit was filed in state court in Delaware against Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the management of the Amstar Corporation in connection with their proposed leveraged buyout of the big sugar refiner. The deal calls for the buyers to purchase all of Amstar's common stock for $47 a share and all of its preferred stock for $8 a share. The plaintiff is demanding that the defendants pay Amstar stockholders the fair value of the company's $500 million in borrowing power that would allow the acquisition to occur.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/01/busin.body_text: **********KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said it plans to modernize 10 of its 16 Boeing 747 aircraft and speed up the delivery of a previously ordered Boeing 747-300 by 16 months, in a deal worth $200 million. **********The modernization involves upgrading the 10 Boeing 747-200's, to 747-300's, which have longer upper decks and 45 more seats. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/busin.body_text: **********G. William Miller, who as Treasury Secretary directed the Government's $1.5 billion Federal rescue of the Chrysler Corporation, has written his successor to urge that the Government not release the company from any of its obligations. **********''I felt at the time, and feel now, that the terms and conditions - including the issuance of warrants to the U.S. Government -were fair and equitable,'' Mr. Miller said in a letter to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. **********''It would be a matter of grave public concern and an ill-advised precedent if the U.S. Government - and hence the U.S. public - did not receive full benefit of rights received as consideration for the loan guarantees,'' Mr. Miller, now a merchant banker, declared. **********Chrysler has approached the board to discuss, among other things, the retrieval of all or part of the 14.4 million stock-purchase warrants it gave the Government three years ago. Each warrant carries the right to buy Chrysler stock at $13, about half the current market price. The Government's potential profit is more than $200 million. **********Mr. Miller, who as Treasury Secretary was also chairman of the Chrysler Corporation Loan Guarantee Board, sent copies of his letter to nine Senators and Representatives; Chrysler's two top officials, Lee A. Iacocca and Gerald Greenwald, and the two other voting board members, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, and the Comptroller General, Charles W. Bowsher. **********''Many constituencies made sacrifices'' to save Chrysler, Mr.  Miller said, with the Government assuming ''substantial financial risks.'' **********''No one would indemnify the Government in case of Chrysler's inability to repay the guaranteed loans,'' he continued. ''No one should surrender the benefits accruing to the Government from the success achieved.'' **********Mr. Miller said that although it might appear that the warrant issue was onerous, Chrysler under no circumstances would have to make payments ''of any kind to anyone.'' He noted that if the warrants were all exercised, the company would receive $188 million, money that could be used to strengthen its balance sheet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Faced with rapidly declining currency reserves, extensive foreign debts and a drop in income from oil exports, the Government today announced foreign exchange controls. **********The Government is also expected to set multiple exchange rates, so that those seeking foreign currency for ''nonessential'' activities will pay a higher rate than those exchanging currency to pay off the Government's foreign debts or private debts incurred abroad before Tuesday. **********Exchange controls have not been imposed here since the early 1960's, and the Venezuelan bolivar, nominally worth 23 cents in United States currency, has undergone only slight changes in value over the past decade. **********During recent months, however, rumors of impending controls or devaluation of the bolivar caused a crisis of confidence. Large sums of money, mostly in dollars, were exported even though Venezuelan banks offered depositors higher interest rates than those available in the United States or Europe. Controls Effective Monday **********In announcing the Government measures early this morning, Minister of Finance Arturo Sosa Jr. said that a temporary ban on all sales of foreign currency, which ended at midnight Tuesday, would be extended through Friday. The currency controls, drawn up this week after heated debate among Government officials, will go into effect Monday. **********The central bank will monitor and control all purchases and sales of foreign currency. Individuals or companies in a variety of categories will be able to purchase dollars at the current rate of 4.3 bolivars. In addition to those repaying foreign debts, these categories include importers of essential imports - not yet defined - and those studying overseas. **********Although other exchange rates have not yet been announced, it is expected that the Government will set rates at a higher level for several ''nonessential'' categories such as tourism and profit remittances by foreign companies. **********Reaction among business executives and bankers was generally favorable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/01/busin.main_headline: U.S. GRANTS BRAZIL AND MEXICO AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/01/busin.print_headline: U.S. GRANTS BRAZIL AND MEXICO AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/01/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration went ahead today with a plan to provide trade assistance to Brazil and Mexico despite a Congressional subcommittee's unanimous appeal for delay. **********Subcommittee sources said the decision could turn a few critical votes against the Administration's stalemated proposal before Congress to raise the Government's contribution to the lending resources of the International Monetary Fund by $8.4 billion. **********''They're spending a lot of time shooting themselves in the foot and shooting their friends, too,'' said an aide to the House Banking Committee's 12-member International Trade subcommittee. ''It's not helpful over here politically.'' **********Congressional approval of the trade assistance is not required, but the Senate supported the aid last week in a bill reauthorizing the Export-Import Bank, which provides the assistance.  Guarantees to Banks **********Ignoring a key House subcommittee's objections, nevertheless, can endanger other Administration proposals in Congress. ''I think the vote has achieved its effect,'' another aide said. ''It's really put them on notice.'' **********The aid is in the form of insurance and other guarantees to American banks that would make loans of $1.5 billion to Brazil and $500 million to Mexico. The borrowers would then use the funds to purchase American goods. The Export-Import Bank would make actual payments only if the customers defaulted on the banks' loans. **********The assistance is a vital part of an $11 billion, multinational agreement in principle to aid Brazil that was reached this week at the annual meeting here of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. It is intended to help Brazil out of a debt-repayment crisis and a three-year recession. Brazil owes more than $90 billion to foreign creditors. **********Mexico, now believed to be recovering from a similar crisis, is still receiving assistance under agreements reached last year. Mexico's foreign debts total about $80 billion.  Package for Brazil **********The Brazil agreement, which will not become effective until various contingencies are met, consists of $6.5 billion in loans from commercial banks for Brazil to make payments on its foreign debt, postponement of $2 billion in debt payments to the governments of industrial nations and $2.5 billion in trade assistance. The part that the subcommittee sought to delay is the American portion of the trade assistance - the $1.5 billion - as well as the guarantees for Mexico. **********The trade subcommittee only asked for a delay in granting the assistance. But in a letter to William H. Draper 3d, president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank, the subcommittee raised questions about singling out individual countries for such assistance and said doing so sets a precedent that the panel opposed. **********Mr. Draper answered the subcommittee in a letter today, defending his decision to proceed immediately with establishing the so-called loan facilities. He said they were necessary to help recovery of American exports to Brazil and Mexico, that they were a vital element in the multinational effort to assist Brazil and that a decision had to be made now because the bank's authority to set up the facilities under the fiscal year 1983 budget ends today, with the close of the fiscal year. **********For the fiscal year 1983, Congress set a ceiling of $9 billion on trade insurance and loan guarantees, and until today's decision the bank had used only $6.2 billion of the total.  Meeting of Bankers **********Meanwhile, Brazil's bank advisory group began a series of meetings today in New York to complete the agreement in principle to extend the $6.5 billion in commercial loans to Brazil over the next 15 months. **********Bankers attending the meeting, which began at 9:30 A.M. at Citibank's headquarters and ran into the evening, could not be reached for comment. **********But interviews earlier this week in Washington with Affonso Celso Pastore, the new president of Brazil's central bank, and other bankers attending the World Bank and I.M.F. meeting indicated that the initial talks would cover Brazil's short-term credit needs; the structure and terms of the new $6.5 billion credit, and ways to market it to a group of well over 800 commercial banks around the world, many of which are skittish about considering additional increases in Brazilian exposure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.main_headline: SOVIET TIGHTENS THE POLITICAL REINS ON UNIFORMED POLICE FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.print_headline: SOVIET TIGHTENS THE POLITICAL REINS ON UNIFORMED POLICE FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union, in an unusual move, has introduced a system of political commissars into the uniformed police force. **********The system, which appears to be part of the campaign for greater discipline in all walks of life under Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, is similar to one that has long existed in the Soviet armed forces. It is intended to insure greater political reliability of policemen, especially as more and more young recruits are joining the ranks. **********The introduction of political commissars to the police was announced Nov. 25 in the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia in the form of an interview with a high police officer, Maj. Gen. Viktor I. Gladyshev, who will be the chief commissar. **********General Gladyshev, when asked why the new institution was needed, said the effectiveness of police work depended to a large extent on the ideological convictions and what he called the ''political maturity'' of policemen. **********''There are still shortcomings in this regard,'' he said. ''An important task will be to indoctrinate all policemen, especially rookies, in the old revolutionary traditions of the party.'' **********He did not elaborate on the extent to which the political awareness of policemen had fallen short of expectations.  General Gladyshev said a stronger political presence was also needed because policemen, in their fight against crime, had been coming into broader contact with the public and because an increasing number of civilian members of the party and of the Young Communist League were now serving in auxiliary police units. **********As in the armed forces, political commissars and police officers will form teams at all levels of organization, with the commissars looking after ideological and political issues and the officers concerned with actual police work. **********In the past the Interior Ministry, which is in charge of the police, had a Political Education Administration that was supposed to look after the level of political conviction among policemen. But there was no organized system for insuring party supervision at all levels of the police hierarchy. **********General Gladyshev, who will head a new Political Administration within the Interior Ministry, was previously attached to the staff of the party's Central Committee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/31/world.body_text: **********The Government announced today that, beginning next March 1, blacks paying income tax in South Africa would no longer have to do so at higher rates than whites. **********With few exceptions, the Government said, the change will mean that black taxpayers will be paying less than before. The announcement was made by Finance Minister Owen Horwood in presenting the Government's annual budget to Parliament in Cape Town. **********The Government decided in principle several years ago to eliminate the differing tax rates. The change was originally due to be put into effect this year, but the date has now been put off until next March 1. **********Under the system being phased out, blacks have been taxed under a different law from that applying to whites, Asians and so-called colored people, those of mixed race. The main points of difference have been that blacks start paying tax at a lower income level and they receive no deductions for families. The actual tax rates have also differed. **********As a result of these differences, a single black male has paid less tax than a single white male at the same income level, but a married black with children is taxed more heavily than a white with a similar-sized family in the same income bracket. **********Another feature of the system due to be abolished next year has been that the only deductions allowed to blacks in determining taxable income have been contributions to pension and retirement annuity funds. White, Asian and colored taxpayers have been permitted a wider range of deductions. **********Mr. Horwood announced, however, that pensions paid by the state to the aged and disabled would continue to be graduated according to race. He said the maximum pension payable to a white would rise by the equivalent of $12.80 to approximately $138.70 a month, while those for an Asian or colored person would increase by $9.13 to $84.86. A black will get an increase of $7.30 to a maximum of $52 a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/11/world.print_headline: U.S. STILL FAVORS LATIN PEACE TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/11/world.body_text: **********A State Department spokesman said today that the United States still believed that talks among nations in the Central American region ''offer the best possibility to resolve the problems of the area.'' **********The spokesman, who declined to be identified, said this would be the only immediate reaction to a report that a proposed meeting of five Central American countries and other nations in the region had been indefinitely postponed. **********Debate is scheduled to resume at the Organization of American States here Monday on a proposal by Honduras for a meeting ''as soon as possible'' to discuss regional problems. **********The regional tensions center on Nicaraguan support for leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, and United States support for insurgent Nicaraguan forces trying to overthrow the Sandinist Government. 'Clearly Breaking the Law' **********Criticism in Congress of the Reagan Administration's approach of training, arming and supplying intelligence data to these forces mounted today as Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, charged that the Administration was ''clearly breaking the law'' that prohibits efforts to t overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. **********He called for legislation tightening the law by barring ''any funding by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Department for any paramilitary group operating in Central America.'' **********He also said he would propose this week that the entire Senate meet in closed session ''so that we can find out exactly what our Government is doing, who we are supporting and how far we intend to go'' in Central America. Congress, he said, should also consider ''cutting off military assistance to El Salvador.'' **********Mr. Dodd, who was interviewed on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' is a member of the Foreign Relations Committee and has been a consistent critic of Administration policy toward Central America. **********His remarks capped a week in which some Republicans as well as Democrats in Congress displayed a markedly increased willingness to challenge the Administration's covert intelligence operations against the Sandinists and to consider tightening the law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: I read with interest and disbelief Prof. Herman Schwartz's letter (April 17) on natural gas deregulation.  I am a small producer of natural gas who gets $1.85 per thousand cubic feet before payment of state insurance taxes. You bet I want total deregulation. Why should others get $10, $5, or whatever for the same product? What other commodity market operates in a similar manner?  MACCALLUM RIENHOFF **********Englewood, Colo., April 17

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.main_headline: SIGNS OF PRIVATE INVESTING IN HARLEM HOUSING SEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; SIGNS OF PRIVATE INVESTING IN HARLEM HOUSING SEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.body_text: **********Since World War II, almost all housing development in Harlem has depended on investing government dollars. Only in recent years have community leaders been able to take steps to attract the private investment that is necessary to lift the community above the level of subsistence. **********Their capacity to even begin this process results from the success of the government-sponsored housing programs. But it also stems from the perception that loading a community with subsidized housing is inimical in the long run to that community's revitalization. **********George Brooker holds this view. He is president of Webb & Brooker, a Harlem-based real estate firm that manages several major commercial properties and more than 8,000 apartments throughout the city. **********''Although government housing programs have done tremendous good, we can't afford to blanket the community with subsidized developments,'' Mr. Brooker said in a recent interview. **********''A healthy community is one that's economically integrated,'' he continued. ''We need the kind of housing that will make the middle class want to live here and lure further private investment.'' **********That this can occur is not merely wishful thinking, despite the continued severity of Harlem's housing problems. **********The town-house market in Harlem is attracting greater interest. A coalition of city and community leaders is trying to put the finishing touches on a comprehensive plan - based on participation by the private sector - to spur residential and commercial development. And signs of private investment in Harlem's vast multifamily housing stock are beginning to occur. **********One example is the new partnership formed by Mr. Brooker's firm and the Georgetown Company, a real estate consulting and development concern. Its president is Edgar Lampert, former president of the Community Development Corporation. **********His company is a subsidiary of the Georgetown Group, a diversified real estate and financial services company headed by Marshall Rose, former president of the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation. **********This joint venture brings together four men - Eugene Webb is the other principal of Webb & Brooker - with considerable expertise in real estate matters. **********Their first project has been to purchase a 236-apartment building at 345 West 145th Street from the Bowery Savings Bank. They paid ''in excess of $2 million,'' Mr. Brooker said. **********The 14-story rent-stabilized structure at the corner of St. Nicholas Avenue was built by the bank in 1956 and is called the Bowery Building. It occupies a prominent place in Harlem - and not just because the elevation of 145th Street at that point affords a view of most of the community. **********The Bowery Building has been a well-maintained property since its opening, Mr. Brooker said. Webb & Brooker has managed the 164,000- square-foot property since 1969. **********It contains a branch of the bank and 10 stores on the ground floor, and its residential tenantry is solidly middle class. **********The Bowery was looking to sell the building. Because the bank intended to maintain its branch there, however, it wanted to have confidence in the new owners. **********That is why the bank itself brought together Webb & Brooker, which wished to make equity investments, and the Rose-Lampert combine, with whom the bank has a separate joint- venture relationship. **********''They know us both well,'' Mr. Rose said, referring to the bank, ''and they know our feelings about the building and the neighborhood.'' **********The new owners plan some minor renovations but nothing drastic. Rather, Mr. Lampert said, they want to assure that the building remains a bulwark of one of Harlem's most stable neighborhoods. **********That neighborhood, which includes the campus of City College, is formally called Hamilton Heights. In colonial times much of it was Alexander Hamilton's homestead; now a big section is a historic district. **********Since the 1920's the area, which has a large stock of town houses and a sizable middle class population, has been known as Sugar Hill. **********''There's a great potential for building an even stronger community here,'' Mr. Lampert said, referring to numerous residential and commercial renovations in the neighborhood. ''This building has always helped anchor the area, and we want it to continue to do so.'' **********He added that the building, which the two firms own as equal partners, embodies the purposes of their joint venture: to acquire and manage income-producing properties in inner cities across the country - and thus help improve these areas - by combining the financial resources of the Georgetown Group with the management expertise of Webb & Brooker. **********''We both have qualities that we hope will attract private capital into areas that in the past have almost totally relied on government and insitutional subsidies,'' Mr. Brooker said. ''We can offer a new route to development in these communities.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/busin.body_text: **********Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banking house, has purchased between 2.5 million and 3 million shares of the Superior Oil Company within the last two weeks, Wall Street arbitragers said yesterday. **********Reports circulated that most of the shares had been bought on behalf of T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. Mr. Pickens, who refused to confirm or deny the reports, has developed a reputation for profiting in takeover battles that he eventually has lost. **********He bought shares in the Cities Service Company last year as part of a takeover bid for the company but eventually sold them back to Cities Service for a $31 million pretax profit. Earlier in the year, he made a bid for the General American Oil Company of Texas. He lost to the Phillips Petroleum Company but showed a pretax profit on the deal of some $43 million. **********Stock Prices **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Superior closed at 35 1/4, off 1/4, while Mesa ended at 12 1/8, up 3/4. Based on yesterday's closing price, Superior's 127.3 million shares outstanding are valued at nearly $4.5 billion, but they might bring $6 billion or more if a battle developed. **********Analysts noted that Superior has vast natural gas reserves, substantial assets in Canada and a contract drilling company, all the types of holdings that Mesa, a much smaller company, has sought to acquire in the past. **********Others noted that two factions of the Keck family, founders and major stockholders in Superior, have been feuding, a development that could favor a takeover. Still others said that a takeover would be difficult without the support of Howard Keck, former chairman of Superior, who controls a substantial block of shares. **********Jerry Carlton, a Los Angeles attorney for Wilametta Keck Day, said his client was challenging trustee's fees sought by Howard Keck, her brother. She is also sponsoring a resolution at the annual meeting that takeover bids be reviewed by outside directors. Superior oil declined comment on the stock purchase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/busin.main_headline: BIGGER ROLE IN LENDING FOR JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/busin.print_headline: BIGGER ROLE IN LENDING FOR JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/busin.body_text: **********The Western trading partners have tentatively agreed to a Japanese request that it become the second-largest shareholder in the World Bank after the United States, according to diplomatic sources. **********The shift, which would displace Britain from the No. 2 spot, would recognize Japan's emergence as the second-largest non-Communist economy in the world after the United States. The move would increase Japan's influence over World Bank lending decisions and add to its prestige, especially among third world countries. **********In return, Japan would be expected to increase its payments to the International Development Agency, the World Bank's arm that provides low- cost loans to developing nations, these sources said. Talks on funding for the agency for the next three years are scheduled to open here Dec. 9. **********U.S. Plan for Ceiling **********An increase in Japan's subscription to the fund will become particularly important, officials say, if the Reagan Administration sticks to its present plan of putting a ceiling of $750 million annually on the American contribution to the agency's next three-year budget. **********Since the United States has agreed to pay 25 percent of the agency's budget, this would limit the organization's total resources for the three years to $9 billion. That is far less than other aid-giving countries think is needed to finance cheap loans for very poor countries that cannot afford to borrow at normal market rates. **********Japan has asked for the added voting power on the bank's executive board because it has such a large economy and is contributing the second-largest amount to the agency. **********Japanese Production **********The latest figures from the Organization of Economic Coooperation and Development put total Japanese output last year, as measured by the gross national product, at $686.4 billion, which is only about a third of the United States output but still comfortably ahead of the next three biggest Western economies - Germany, France and Britain. **********Meanwhile, Japan is currently providing 14 percent of the agency's resources, a figure second only to the 25 percent given by the United States. **********Yet while the United States accounts for 20 percent of the combined voting power of the World Bank's executive board, Japan occupies fifth place with a shade under 4.5 percent of the votes. It lags Britain, which has a 5.1 percent share, Germany, with 4.6 percent, and France, with 4.5 percent. **********This discrepency has come about because shareholdings in the World Bank and its sister institution, the International Monetary Fund, still largely reflect individual countries' relative wealth and power after World War II and have never been fully adjusted for subsequent changes. **********A bigger World Bank shareholding would not cost the Japanese Government much, officials say, because only a small part of the bank's capital is actually paid in - most takes the form of a government guarantee on loans the bank makes. **********Higher Level of Funding Sought **********In return, however, other Western donors want Japan to help assure that the I.D.A. is refinanced next month at a substantially higher level than the Reagan Administration appears to want. The last time the agency's resources were replenished, in 1979, the loan agency was given $12 billion to spend over three years to aid the world's poorest countries. **********At this next replenishment, the World Bank is asking donor countries for $16 billion, to compensate for inflation and to allow for the fact that China, which only joined the World Bank in 1980, will become fully eligible for I.D.A. assistance. Last summer, finance ministers of the European Economic Community agreed jointly to support a minimum replenishment of $12 billion, with some ready to go to $16 billion. **********But the Reagan Administration still wants to limit the United States contribution to $750 million over three years, which, because of the funding formula involved, would reduce I.D.A. total funding to $9 billion. Over the last two years, however, Congress has shown greater support for the agency by appropriating $945 million annually. **********Difficult Political Choice **********If the United States sticks to its planned contribution, other Western donors face a difficult political choice, officials say. On the one hand, they believe a larger amount is necessary for the development and stability of the poorest countries, many of which are in sensitive strategic locations. But they are reluctant to abandon the principal of sharing the burden in international organizations, whereby members divide up the cost according to their wealth, by paying in more money themselves and letting America's contribution fall under the agreed 25 percent share. **********The United States currently accounts for 33 percent of the total economic output of all nations that donate to the agency, suggesting that its planned share of the organization's budget is already low. If it is allowed to fall futher, European officials fear it will set a dangerous precedent that could encourage the United States to reduce its contribution to other international organizations. **********The dilemma might be avoided, or at least reduced, officials say, if Japan agrees to increase its share of the I.D.A.'s budget above the present 14 percent. It could justify this by pointing to the small amount of bilateral aid it gives the third world and also by its special interest in promoting economic development in China, which would mainly benefit Japanese industry.
