https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/busin.body_text: **********Skender Ghilaga has been named president of R.H. Sanbar Projects Inc., the company that recently completed the Dag Hammarskjold Tower, a luxury condominium in Manhattan. **********Mr. Ghilaga, 46, succeeds E.J. Sharp, who returns to London for a new assignment within the R.H. Sanbar Group, the parent. **********Sanbar Projects is one of several companies under the control of the group's American holding company. Mr. Ghilaga was also named an executive vice president of the American holding company. **********Sanbar Projects, a real estate developer, ''is looking at properties in Dallas, Atlanta and other possibilities here in New York,'' now that it has completed the Hammarskjold Tower, Mr. Ghilaga said. **********Mr. Ghilaga, a native of Albania, graduated from Robert College in Istanbul, Turkey. He came to the United States after college and for the past 25 years worked for Syska & Hennessy, a New York engineering firm. For the past 10 years, he was a senior vice president and director in Syska's international division. **********Along with real estate development, the Sanbar Group's operations in the United States are in financial and technical services. The value of current Sanbar projects in this country is $400 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/13/world.main_headline: TWO AFRIKANERS ON TRIAL FOR TREASON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/13/world.print_headline: TWO AFRIKANERS ON TRIAL FOR TREASON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/13/world.body_text: **********Two young Afrikaners, members of South Africa's dominant white group, went on trial here this week accused of supporting the most prominent of the outlawed, black nationalist movement opposed to the system of racial separation that has become synonymous with Afrikanerdom in general. They are charged with high treason, an offense that carries a possible death sentence. **********The hearings in the Rand Supreme Court have provided a rare glimpse into the world of South Africa's secret police and its operations against foes of apartheid. **********Moreover, the disclosures at the trial seemed designed to create suspicion and mistrust among South African dissidents because they have highlighted the authorities' ability to undermine the nationalist movement by planting spies and informers in its ranks. **********From evidence so far not only did a South African agent penetrate the cell in which the two defendants were purportedly involved, but the police, through its ''mole,'' also effectively ran the dissident unit and was privy to its secrets.   Charges Are Denied **********The defendants, Carl Niehaus and Johanna Lourens, have denied treason charges and other associated accusations. Many of the witnesses, appearing for the prosecution, have been friends and associates prevailed upon to turn state's evidence. The most illuminating testimony has been that of Robert Whitecross, whom they were said to regard as a trusted accomplice. **********On Wednesday Mr. Whitecross was introduced to the court as a security agent recruited in April 1980 while a student by Maj. Craig Williamson, reportedly a key figure in the Security Police Department, which deals with infiltration of the ranks of those perceived as enemies. Major Williamson is said to be a former agent himself.  Mr. Whitecross's task was said to be to keep tabs on university people with nationalist or Communist ties. **********In evidence, Mr. Niehaus has been accused of seeking to recruit fellow whites as agents for the African National Congress, which is banned in South Africa, and of helping four young blacks flee into exile. **********Mr. Niehaus was also, according to Mr. Whitecross, entrusted with the task of obtaining photographs and plans of the Johannesburg City Council gas works as a possible target for sabotage by the African National Congress. To obtain the photographs, Mr. Niehaus is said to have enlisted the help of Mr. Whitecross, the policeman.   Police Took Photographs **********Thus, when he needed a vehicle to get to the gas works, he asked Mr. Whitecross to obtain one. Mr. Whitecross said in court Wednesday that after consulting what he called his handler in the Security Police, he had agreed to do so the African National Congress sympathizer and the secret policeman, thus, drove together to the gas works in a pickup supplied by the Security Police. **********As Mr. Niehaus took the photographs of the gas works, the police took equally clandestine pictures of him. Mr. Whitecross said he had then been asked to insure that the film was developed. He did so, at the Security Police headquarters. **********The photographs, and a hand-drawn plan of the gas works were to have been taken by courier to neighboring, black- ruled Botswana on Aug. 26, but Mr. Niehaus was arrested three days before then. At that time Mr. Whitecross had been associated with Mr. Niehaus for 18 months. **********By producing Mr. Whitecross in court, and identifying him as an agent, the Security Police seemed to have calculated that it was worth blowing his cover in return for the uncertainty created in dissident groups. The question the Security Police seems to be inviting among its opponents is: How many ''moles'' are there and who are they?   Convulsed With Laughter **********Mr. Whitecross said he had shared a commune with Miss Lourens and Mr. Niehaus. The disclosure in court of his identity seemed to stun not only the two accused but also many of their friends in the public galleries. But security policemen outside the courtroom were reportedly convulsed with laughter at their dismay. **********The state case against the two Afrikaners reinforces a Security Police nurtured image of omniscience, but does not obscure the fact that its effectiveness is not total. **********While African National Congress officials themselves acknowledged that the group was a target for penetration and had been infiltrated in the past, the nationalist movement nonetheless claimed responsibility for the most dramatic act of urban warfare in South Africa in recent years: last May's car- bomb blast outside a military office building in Pretoria. Nineteen people were killed and more than 200 were wounded. **********The African National Congress said at the time that the bombing represented a stepping up of that protracted and largely low-key campaign, but since then there has been little indication of significantly stepped-up activity.   Vote on a New Charter **********Several small bombings punctuated a referendum here last week on limited constitutional change but caused no major damage or injuries. Two elderly white people were attacked by armed men described by the authorities as ''terrorists'' in a remote area of the Northern Transvaal on Wednesday. The four attackers were killed Thursday by the army, according to a military statement. **********The Security Police is only one branch of South Africa's intelligence networks, seemingly dealing with day- to-day surveillance and other activities. The National Intelligence Service, formerly called the Bureau of State Security, is thought to have a wider, more strategic role, while in recent years the military intelligence department has assumed significant influence. **********The intelligence establishment is supported by a large body of legislation, including the Internal Security Act and the Defense Act. The Internal Security Act provides for virtually unlimited detention without trial, and both measures place restrictions on press reporting of what are viewed as sensitive subjects. **********Public trials thus enable an unaccustomed degree of reporting of security matters for the South African press. **********The fact that the two defendants are whites has also attracted public attention, particularly since the accused are of the same Afrikaner stock as the hierarchy that has ruled since 1948 and that has molded apartheid into the landscape. **********But the history of Afrikanerdom in the 20th century is dotted with occasional figures who have pursued a limited small-scale revolt against their leaders. Radical whites have also been frequently associated with the African National Congress, and the South African authorities assert that the organization's head of military planning is a white South African named Joe Slovo.

Analysts said the increase was more likely an aberration linked to the rise in the Federal gasoline tax, rather than any revival of inflation. (Page A1.) In the New York area, prices were up 1.1 percent, the sharpest rise since October. (D6.) **********A House panel has given the Justice Department data that apparently contradict a former Reagan official's assertion that he was not seeking a job with Comsat while working to clear the way for sale of the nation's weather satellites to the concern. Comsat insisted no conflict was involved, however. (A17.) **********New-car sales by the Big Three auto makers fell 5.4 percent in mid-May. Ford's and Chrysler's sales were up 5.8 percent and 31.4 percent, respectively, but G.M.'s dropped 14.3 percent. (D4.) **********The Senate Finance Committee is now seeking repeal of the withholding tax on interest and dividend payments. It may tie the repeal proposal to legislation implementing President Reagan's Caribbean Basin program. (D8.) Markets **********Stock prices soared, apparently buoyed by traders' belief that interest rates will continue to fall despite a recent increase in the money supply. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.48 points, to 1,219.04. The other major indexes also closed higher. (D1.) **********The credit markets posted modestly higher prices. (D9.) The dollar rose against other major currencies, while gold prices fell $1.25 an ounce, to $436.25, in New York. (D14.) Livestock and meat futures prices declined. (D14.) International **********Planning for world economic growth will be the first priority at the Williamsburg, Va., summit meeting this weekend, according to two Reagan Administration officials. (D1.) **********Trafalgar House, which owns the Cunard Line, bid more than $450 million for control of Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation. The company promptly rejected the bid as too low. (D1.) Companies **********Superior Oil conceded victory in a proxy fight to its founder's daughter, Wilametta Keck Day, who wants the company to consider takeover bids. (D1.) **********R.J. Reynolds introduced a new cigarette that will be sold in packs of 25 instead of the usual 20. Analysts said the new marketing approach amounts to price-cutting. (D4.) **********The Supreme Court upheld a patent infringement award against G.M., ruling that the lower courts had correctly assessed the $11 million penalty. The amount of interest in the case exceeded the amount of royalties for which G.M. had been found liable. The report, filed with the S.E.C., has been given to two House panels studying the transactions. (D5.) **********Deere reported a loss of $11.3 million in the April 30 quarter, while the net income of Litton declined 24 percent. (D7.) **********Dan River stockholders voted to sell the concern to its employees and management rather than risk a takeover by Carl Icahn. (D5.) **********Martin Marietta plans a secondary offering of up to 1.9 million of its treasury shares, using the proceeds to acquire a similar number of its shares now held by the Allied Corporation. The move would cut Allied's stake in Martin Marietta to about 20 percent. (D9.) Today's Columns **********The Federal Reserve is far less enthusiastic about banks' rapid expansion into new lines of business than the Administration. Because the banks perform special functions, it reasons, they must be protected against excessive risk-taking. Economic Scene. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/14/busin.body_text: **********When it comes to advertising, the United States is indeed the land of plenty.  While various countries shift in and out of second place in total advertising spending, advertising per capita and advertising spending as a percent of gross national product, No.1 in each is always the United States. **********Hooper, of Mamaroneck, N.Y., in cooperation with the International Advertising Association, showed that in 1981 total spending for advertising in this country came to $61 billion, while Japan was a far-off second with $11 billion. Per capita spending here was $266, ahead of Switzerland, with $196, while as a percent of the G.N.P., the United States number came to 2.29 percent, with Argentina second with 1.99. Japan, No.2 in spending, does not even get into the top 9 for percent of G.N.P., with only 0.89 percent. **********World Advertising Expenditures 1982, which is selling for $85, with $10 off for I.A.A. members, also contains the information that 1981 world spending rose 6 percent from the previous year, to $118.5 billion, but when the increase of the value of the dollar in 1981 in the top 25 markets is taken into account, the true figure is probably $128 billion, which means an increase of 14 to 15 percent. **********Then there is the $25 billion to $30 billion being spent by the newly advertising aware Communist bloc and the third world. It's enough to send a body back on vacation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/11/world.main_headline: POLICY: SHIFTING DIPLOMACY MADE TROOPS 'SITTING DUCKS'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/11/world.print_headline: THE MARINE TRAGEDY; POLICY: SHIFTING DIPLOMACY MADE TROOPS 'SITTING DUCKS'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/11/world.body_text: **********Colonel Geraghty was a ''cool-as-ice Marine commander'' who seldom raised his voice, another officer in his unit said, but on the morning of Sept. 19 he was shouting. **********The colonel and his men had been through a hellish month. Four marines had been killed in the almost-daily sniper and artillery fire that had pounded their airport compound since mid-August. And that morning an aide to Robert C. McFarlane, the United States special envoy in the Middle East, was on the secure radio, ordering Colonel Geraghty to request United States Naval bombardment of Druse militiamen in the nearby mountain town of Suk al Gharb. **********Colonel Geraghty protested, according to officers familiar with the conversation. ''He was violently against it,'' one of the officers said. ''We were supposed to be neutral peacekeepers, and now we were going to start shelling one of the factions.'' **********Fear of Retaliation **********American ships had shelled Moslem militiamen before, but only when the militiamen had fired on American positions first. This timethe Druse were in battle with the Lebanese Army, not the Americans. The Naval shelling was to help the Lebanese Army.  ''Our feeling was it was going to change our role here,'' one Marine officer said. ''And Geraghty was afraid it would open us up to the full brunt of retaliation from the Moslems.'' **********According to one account of the radio conversation that morning, Colonel Geraghty shouted, ''We're sitting ducks down here! Take that into account before firing. I feel we are going to take substantial casualties because of this.'' **********Colonel Geraghty was overruled. The shelling was ordered, partly because Administration officials felt that the fledgling Lebanese Army could not easily recover from a defeat at Suk al Gharb.  In Washington, officials acknowledged that the naval bombardment significantly broadened the United States role in Lebanon. Days earlier, President Reagan decided to permit the forces in Lebanon to fire in support of the Lebanese Army and not just in self-defense.   Feelings Toward the Marines **********Some Marine officers and others in Lebanon believe the shelling of Suk al Gharb helped create the hostile feelings toward the Marines that led to the truck- bomb attack a month later. **********No one can say for certain if that is true. But the incident seems to illustrate how the marines' mission has been linked to United States diplomatic-policy decisions from the day they landed in Beirut.   'No Longer Neutral' **********General Kelley, testifying before Congress, said of the shelling, ''Unfortunately, some could conclude that it may have increased the Moslem perception that our marines were pro- Christian and no longer neutral.'' **********An officer in one of Beirut's Moslem militias who is not hostile to the marines said the shelling had changed the marines' image among all Lebanese Moslems. ''After that, they were not neutral anymore,'' he said. **********A high-ranking United States military officer in Lebanon, not a marine, agreed. Still, he said, that did not excuse the marines for their vulnerability at their headquarters on Oct. 23. **********''It's the job of the commander to make sure his men are secure from attack, no matter what the other people do,'' he said. **********In answer to that, many marines say they felt constrained when devising defenses for their compound. More formidable barriers, they said, would have interfered with their stated mission.   'We Would Have Been Criticized' **********''We had to be present, to be seen by the Lebanese people,'' General Kelley told Congress last month. **********Major Jordan, the Marine spokesman at the time of the bombing, said, ''We would have been criticized for building massive defenses.'' **********But diplomats and Administration officials said the marines took the political aspect of their mission too seriously and censored themselves. **********General Mead said: ''I would say to you that at no time was there any finger pointing from the diplomatic side that you will perform this way for this reason. We just had a sensitivity to their mission and knew what they needed.'' **********A top-level State Department official who was directly involved with Lebanon matters said: ''I don't think anybody would have objected if the marines told us they needed to build sophisticated defenses around their compound.''  Debate Over Restraints **********Former Ambassador Dillon said: ''If the marines had deemed it necessary to build a 12-foot wall around their compound, then working it out with the Lebanese authorities would have been necessary. But it could have been done.'' **********Part of the problem was that the marines' role in Lebanon changed gradually from a largely ceremonial posture to one that was distinctly more aggresive. One Marine officer in Beirut said, ''They changed our role politically without letting our role change militarily at the same time.'' **********He added, ''We used to sit around the hooch, 11 or 12 of us officers,'' from every section of the unit, ''and we'd debate the ramifications of all the political restraints.''  An Effort to Be Respectful **********Initially, the marines were instructed ''not to be warlike,'' General Mead said, ''to be respectful to the local population.''The orders were for peacetime rules of engagement, ''the infamous rules,'' as the marine officer called them. ''They were force-fed to all of us, over and over, on the ships all the way across the Atlantic,'' he said. And they were printed on cards that every marine was required to carry. **********The rules stipulated that marines were to carry their weapons unloaded and were not to load and return fire unless they were attacked first by ''effective fire,'' the Marine officersaid. **********''There was always a lot of debate about what is effective fire,'' he said. ''Is it effective if it hits the dirt in front of you? Is it effective if it blows off your arm?''  First, an Order to Stop **********A sentry guarding the temporary United States Embassy in downtown Beirut last month described the prescribed procedure for stopping a suspected car-bomber rushing at him: **********''First you shout, 'Stop!' '' the sentry said. ''Then if he doesn't stop, you can load your weapon and shoot at the vehicle and try to hit the tires. If that doesn't stop him, then you are allowed to shoot at the driver.'' **********A Marine sentry at the compound described what he believed went through the mind of the sentry whose rifle was unloaded the morning of the truck bombing. **********As the truck rushed past, ''First you had to load your weapon,'' he said, demonstrating. That took three or four seconds. ''Then once you're loaded, you have to stop and think about the rules of engagement and whether or not you're allowed to fire.'' By then, he said, ''You'd be lucky to get off a shot.''  'Clearance to Get Killed' **********''Around here,'' he added, ''you've got to get clearance to get killed.'' **********The Marine officer recalled the time, last summer, when ''one of those big bully marines - you know one of those guys who weighs 285 pounds - was on patrol in a Moslem section when a Lebanese walked up to him and slugged him in the chest. Hit him hard. **********''Later, I asked him: 'You hit him back, didn't you?' He said, 'No sir. I've been ordered not to touch any Lebanese individuals.' '' **********One officer wrote a letter to Colonel Geraghty complaining that the rules of engagement and other instructions were being so strictly interpreted that the marines felt they were not allowed to defend themselves. He never received an answer, one officer said. **********Several officers said the rules of engagement and their interpretation by the men may have encouraged the truck bombing, because the marines had demonstrated that they were slow to fight back.   Rules on Arms Amended **********The rules were amended after the bombing. Sentries now carry loaded weapons. **********General Mead, who helped draft the initial rules, said: ''Really, they were to protect the men, because if you start shooting the Shiite Moslems, the shooting is going to increase, not diminish. And therefore you increase the threat to you.'' **********The Marine officers also felt constraints when they considered how their compound should be defended.  To illustrate, one officer recalled that at the end of February, ''we received some intelligence that said we had to be careful of the vendors.''  A Warning on Vendors **********The airport parking lot just south of the Marine compound - the one the terrorist truck driver circled to gather speed before crashing through the fence on Oct. 23 - was a favorite gathering spot for Lebanese. Salesmen carrying various goods often wandered from there up to the Marine positions, and in February, intelligence reports suggested that some of the vendors might be carrying bombs, the officer said. **********''I wanted to put in some concertina wire,'' the officer said. ''I said to my commander, 'Sir, I know this won't sit well with a lot of people, but we need concertina 250 yards out.' **********''It took forever to get a decision,'' he said, ''and in the end we were only allowed to put it 250 feet out.'' **********General Mead said: ''That's true, and it's a good example. We could have put the fences literally anywhere we wanted to. We could have taken the entire parking lot.   'A Fortress America' **********''But we had to balance that against the mission and the perception of all the people around the area. One, we didn't need a Fortress America. And two, we recognized that the Lebanese needed certain spaces.'' **********Colonel Anderson, second in command under General Mead last spring, said he wanted to place mine fields around the compound after the embassy bombing, ''but we couldn't do it.'' **********''We kept running into these conflicts; there were constraints,'' he said, and indicating puzzlement, he added, ''but I can't tell you where they were coming from.'' **********General Mead said, ''What a lot of people are having a hard time coming to grips with is that every time we did something, we had to balance the mission against the threat and the safety of the men.'' **********''The thing that we felt we could not do,'' said Colonel Geraghty, was to ''be holed up here because that ran counter to our mission.'' **********From his vantage point in London, Admiral Holcomb said, he and his staff made it ''a matter of continuous, almost daily discussion that, to do the peacekeeping mission, we were forced to expose the marines to a hostile environment.'' **********He added, ''We all understood the risks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/busin.main_headline: Sears P.L.C. Plans Mail Order Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/busin.print_headline: Sears P.L.C. Plans Mail Order Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/busin.body_text: **********Sears Holdings P.L.C., a British holding company with interests in retailing, engineering and real estate, said it had proposed forming a new British mail order company through a merger between Empire Stores (Bradford) P.L.C. and Grattan P.L.C., backed by a nearly $40 million capital injection from Sears. **********If the plan is accepted by Empire and Grattan, former Grattan shareholders would hold 44.2 million shares, former Empire shareholders, 32.6 million, and Sears, 20 million, leaving 3.2 million unissued. With its existing holdings in Empire and Grattan, Sears would hold 24 percent of the new company's equity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/30/busin.main_headline: Technology; Bubble Policy: Pros and Cons
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/30/busin.print_headline: Technology; Bubble Policy: Pros and Cons
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/30/busin.body_text: **********SINCE 1979, when the Environmental Protection Agency adopted its ''bubble'' policy, a number of companies have avoided costly changes at their plants to meet air quality standards. While the economic advantages to private companies are clear, not everyone is pleased with the way the policy is being applied. **********Instead of enforcing limits on each source of air pollution within an industrial facility, the E.P.A., under the bubble policy, allows one overall reduction target for each pollutant type - as if the entire complex were covered by a bubble. If a company can achieve the goal through some innovative procedure, it is encouraged to do so. **********Several companies responded eagerly to the policy when it was announced. The first, Armco Inc. in Middletown, Ohio, avoided controls on particulate matter from some of its steelmaking processes through dust-reducing actions, such as paving roads, within the plant. The trade saved the company more than $10 million in capital costs and $2.5 million a year in operating costs. **********The New England Electric System, at its two side-by-side power plants in Providence, R.I., traded the requirement to burn low-sulfur oil at both for periodically burning high-sulfur oil at one and natural gas at the other. The bubble has saved the company $4 million to date in fuel costs. **********The Du Pont Company built what a spokesman calls the ''granddaddy'' of bubbles at its Chambers Works chemical plant in Deepwater, N.J.  Instead of lowering the emissions of ''volatile organic compounds'' - precursors of smog - by 85 percent from each of the plant's 112 stacks, it reduced the compounds from the plant's seven largest stacks by 99 percent through incineration. The trade not only saved the company $10 million, says Bob Bonczek, Du Pont's director of environmental affairs; it also achieved better overall pollution reduction, with the average per stack now 90 percent. **********Michael Levin, chief of the E.P.A.'s Regulatory Reform Staff, says that the agency has been directly involved in 38 such bubbles and that 180 more are being developed at the state level, representing total savings of $600 million in capital and first-year operating costs. If all potential bubbles came into being, he estimates, this ''tip of the iceberg'' could grow to annual savings of $1 billion. **********Yet there is still considerable criticism of the policy, from environmentalists and industrialists.  David D. Doniger, an attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, suggests that bubbles generally reflect the letter of the Clean Air Act but violate its spirit. Most of the controls implemented under bubbles, he says, should have been the baseline - the ''reasonably available control technologies'' - that bubbles would improve on. But companies have been claiming ''bogus credit,'' he says, for basic pollution-reduction processes they would have, or should have, installed anyway. **********''The stated purpose of the bubble was to encourage innovation,'' Mr. Doniger said, ''but instead it rewards the recalcitrant.'' And although he asserts that some companies, under inadequate state regulation, have milked the bubble's advantages to the limit and sometimes beyond -with dubious or incorrect numbers that purport to establish ''ambient equivalence'' of proposed actions with what should have been - it is really the E.P.A.'s vision that is most in need of expansion. The agency's policy, Mr. Doniger says, is to make ''an awful situation'' a little less awful. **********Some industrial observers are similarly dissatisfied but for opposite reasons. They also assert that the bubble concept is a belated effort at tinkering. From their perspective, however, the problem is not that the Clean Air Act is being insufficiently implemented, but that it is fundamentally flawed and should be replaced altogether. **********One prominent business representative, who asked not to be named, cites a common industrial concern: the national air-quality standards required by the act. These numbers - the targets that the bubble and other regulatory approaches are supposed to meet - are ''arbitrary and irrational,'' he says. A more sensible approach, he adds, would correlate pollution-control costs with environmental benefits. **********Du Pont's Mr. Bonczek asserts that the bubble concept can deflect criticisms from both sides. ''It's easy to demand controls across the board,'' he says, but, because bubbles generally deliver ''more environmental cleanup for less dollars,'' they are surely in the spirit of the Clean Air Act. And the selection of sources for control is indeed a rational process, he says, based as it is on cost-effectiveness criteria. **********Mr. Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council acknowledges a legitimate role for the concept, especially for such problems as acid rain. In that case, bubbles could include entire states. But while geography is not a limiting factor, he says, issues of fairness, timeliness, appropriateness and completeness certainly are. **********Most agree, in other words, that the bubble and related ''emissions trading'' concepts, as the E.P.A. now calls them, are useful tools.  But they are no replacements for more fundamental Federal policies that would aim for either the elimination of much more pollution or much less.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/world.body_text: **********Former President Jimmy Carter said today that his deep religious belief had led him to a commitment to the existence of Israel as a Jewish state. But he urged Israelis to seek a peace with justice for the Palestinians. **********Mr. Carter, on a tour of the Middle East, spoke at Tel Aviv University after receiving an honorary doctorate. His remarks followed a day spent in the occupied Gaza Strip, meeting with Palestinian Arabs there, and in a colloquium with Israeli scholars. **********''God has ordered and ordained the existence of the state of Israel as a permanent homeland of the Jews,'' said the former President, who is a Baptist. ''This is my deep religious belief.'' 'Justice for All' **********But he added that ''the right of the Palestinians to have a voice in the shaping of their own destiny, the resolution of the Palestinian issue in all its aspects,'' was essential. ''I am convinced that permanent peace without justice for all is not possible,'' he said. ''Some courage, some sacrifice will be needed.  An open mind will be needed. An understanding of others who are alien, and perhaps feared, will be needed; a searching attitude will be needed.'' **********Mr. Carter met this morning with Rashid Shawa, who was dismissed by the Israeli authorities nearly a year ago as Mayor of Gaza. According to an official who was present, the former President told Mr. Shawa that the Palestinians must do their own negotiating and not depend on Egypt and the United States as intermediaries. **********Mr. Shawa reportedly replied that the United States should use its influence on Israel to stop construction of Jewish settlements. Mr.  Carter was said to have answered that if Israel wished to build settlements, it would do so with or without American pressure. Mr.  Shawa suggested that American aid be cut off, and Mr. Carter explained that that was politically impossible. 3 Soldiers Hurt in Attack Special to the New York Times **********JERUSALEM, March 10 - Three Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded today, a military spokesman said, in stone throwing that continued for a second day as youths in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem protested Mr. Carter's tour. **********Two universities and three secondary schools were ordered shut and tear gas was fired to disperse high school demonstrators in the Bethlehem area, the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/21/busin.main_headline: A Creditor Plan Filed by Lionel
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/21/busin.print_headline: A Creditor Plan Filed by Lionel
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/21/busin.body_text: **********The Lionel Corporation, operating under Chapter 11, said it had filed a reorganization plan that would give its unsecured creditors an initial payment of $70 million in cash. **********Under the plan, filed in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, Lionel would also give its unsecured creditors $10 million in Lionel convertible preferred stock, which would pay an 8 percent annual dividend and be convertible into two million Lionel common shares. **********Unsecured creditors also would get 3.8 million common shares, or about 35 percent of the company's stock to be outstanding after the reorganization, and $45.5 million, payable without interest in annual installments through 1984. Lionel has no secured creditors. **********If the reorganization plan is approved, Lionel said it would have a new, seven-member board of directors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today proposed rates for international telex and data transmission that undercut those offered by companies now specializing in such overseas service. **********In filing its rate proposals, A.T.& T. made it clear that it was prepared to move quickly after the Dec. 8 ruling by the Federal Communications Commission authorizing its entry into the field. **********It has been barred from this sector since 1964. **********A.T.& T. said it wanted to begin offering data services March 16 - using the same rates it uses for private telephone circuits - then reduce those rates on April 6. **********As examples of its proposed charges, it said the rate for a standard private half-circuit between New York and London would be $3,400 a month; from Washington to Frankfurt, $3,600 a month, and from San Francisco to Tokyo, $4,300 a month. **********According to Maryanne Swindler of ITT World Communications, international record carriers are charging rates of about $3,710, $3,710 and $4,369, respectively, for those three circuits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/12/world.print_headline: IN A PELL-MELL RACE FOR WEALTH, NIGERIA STUMBLES; The Talk of Lagos
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/12/world.body_text: **********A doctor here likes to tell a story about the women of the white, foreign community who frequent his private practice. **********In the past, he says, he has treated them for all kinds of esoteric woes but, of late, they have been arriving in numbers seeking the banal: ointment for burns, stitches for cuts, balm for sundry indignities. The reason, the doctor says, is that previously the women all depended on their stewards from Ghana and Benin and elsewhere to do the household chores. The servants, largely, are gone now, victims of Nigeria's decision to expel illegal immigrants, and so the women must cope with forgotten challenges: overheating stoves and undisciplined carving knives. There has even been a run on washing machines in the local market now that human launderers have departed. **********The physician's business is growing but when Nigeria counts the cost of its decision to expel the foreigners the balance sheet will be less monochromatic and a question will intrude: After all the years of multibillion-dollar oil revenues, what has been achieved if the nation - black-ruled Africa's wealthiest and the self-appointed standard-bearer of the continent's democracy - needs to take draconian measures to stay afloat? **********If cities bare their souls through their architecture, then Lagos is a place that grasps, and wastes, and goes forward without reference to the esthetic. In the city center, for instance, there is the great stadium built by the military during their years in power from 1966 to 1979. Columns soar and the prancing of huge horses is frozen in bronze. But it celebrates a strange glory because it is surrounded and engulfed by a chaotic city of rundown office blocks and open sewers and the decaying semiantiquity of older houses, erected during a colonial era and caught up later in the oil-fueled rush for modernity. **********In the wealthy suburbs, such as Victoria Island, the homes built these days reflect no sense of self-adornment. They fit the city, for they provide only a roof to sleep under, walls and bars to ward off unwanted outsiders and air-conditioners to chill the process of accumulating wealth. Lagos is a place to come to seek riches and then leave behind. **********Wealthy Nigerians are commuters and Lagos is a transit halt, suspended in its grubbiness between a distant home village and the airline flights that take the rich to London or New York for a weekend's shopping, or a vacation, or a medical checkup -escape, that is, from the pressures created by wealth and its distribution between patron and petitioner. **********''People have to get away,'' a businessman said. ''If you don't you find your time is never your own.'' Where has all the money gone? It has not noticeably gone to schools, for even in those states where education is free, teachers need to be bribed for places, textbooks must be bought, donations must be made to school funds. And it has not gone to health care. **********''If you go to hospital, then you have to bribe a doctor to see you,'' a foreign resident said.'' There are no drugs, so you have to send someone out to find them for you. There's a children's home here where nearly all the disabled kids have had polio: they'd all been vaccinated, but the vaccine had not been kept properly so it was useless.'' **********''The middle class,'' the foreigner said, ''go to private clinics.  The rich go abroad for medical treatment. It's part of their calendar. There are no loboratories for tests. Conditions are getting worse, and it's happening in a cutthroat society: Look after No. 1 is the motto.'' **********Nigerians do not like to hear criticism from foreigners, so when the Western press condemned the manner of the aliens' expulsion Nigeria's newspapers bridled. What, editorialists wrote, about the treatment of Turks in West Germany?  And what about the policies of Britain, the former colonial power that is the object of a love-hate sentiment? Was it not the British who invented the ''virginity test'' for Asian women immigrants - so what cause do the British have to refer to human rights in Nigeria? Typically, the belief among officials here was that press condemnation reflected a campaign inspired by Western governments to belittle Africa's self-enthroned giant. **********Nigeria's achievements are less tangible. Just about everybody in this country lost somebody or suffered in other ways in the civil war of 1967 to 1970 when the Ibo tribal nation seceded from the federation and made a separatist state called Biafra, whose ultimate demise was bloody. Yet there has been a remarkable reconciliation. **********The forgiveness was symbolized last year by the pardoning and return home of Emeka Ojukwu, the man who led the Biafran forces. Mr.  Ojukwu has joined the ruling National Party of Nigeria, so that, when elections are held next August, his role will be to split the Ibo vote and enhance President Shehu Shagari's chances for a widely forecast second term. But some resentments linger. **********''They'll have to play the Ojukwu card very delicately,'' a Western diplomat said, referring to President Shagari's political strategists. ''A lot of people feel he should not be in politics. And it is inconceivable that he should attain a position of state power that would oblige his old enemies in the army to pay homage to him.  They would not do that.'' **********As usual, the 130,000-strong military is a force in Nigerian politics.  There are many calculations about whether it will take power again, ending Nigeria's greatest recent achievement - the retention of a rough-and-tumble democracy that, through unassailable presidential power and a system designed to share the nation's wealth among the three rival nation-tribes, has survived Nigeria's inherent tensions and pressures. ''If Nigeria has achieved anything,'' a Westerner said, ''it lies in the aftermath of the civil war - forgiveness and the evential reinstatement of democracy.'' **********It is as a model of democracy that Nigeria asserts itself as blackruled Africa's leader. But that image, these days, is tainted by the expulsion of the foreigners.  Whatever its justifications in economic and political terms, a Nigerian official said, it has nonetheless left the mental imprint of a nation treating fellow Africans in a manner it would not countenance in others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.main_headline: How U.S. Would Act In Airspace Invasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.print_headline: How U.S. Would Act In Airspace Invasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.body_text: **********United States Air Force officials said today that there were no circumstances in peacetime under which American military aircraft would shoot down a foreign commercial airliner that had strayed from its flight plan in United States airspace, even if attempts at communication were unsuccessful. **********Air Force procedures for dealing with such situations are classified, but Pentagon officials said American pilots would need permission from the highest levels of the Defense Department, or even the White House, to fire upon a foreign military plane, unless fired upon first. **********Lieut. Col. Mark Foutch, an Air Force spokesman, said interceptors would be dispatched to investigate the situation, and, if necessary, escort the plane down. **********''The situation would have to be assessed on a case-by-case basis,'' he said. ''But it certainly would not be up to the pilot to decide what action to take. Depending on the circumstances, that decision would have to be made at the Pentagon or at an even higher level.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/14/busin.body_text: **********A marketing plan was in place. Former Braniff International employees had been interviewed for jobs. New cloth for uniforms - and some new airplane seats - had already been purchased. **********That was how confident PSA Inc. was that its deal with Braniff would stand up and that by summer it could begin a long-planned thrust into the Sun Belt. But then a Federal appeals court threw out the agreement, and, in the words of Paul C. Barkley, the president and chief operating officer of PSA, ''We're looking at five years of expansion that collapsed in one deal.'' **********PSA, which owns Pacific Southwest Airlines, has been eager to expand for many years, ever since it reached a limit to its growth in its home market - mostly the Los Angeles-to-San Francisco corridor.  Once before the airline's expansion plans were frustrated when, four years ago, a jump in fuel prices forced it to concentrate on reequipping its fleet instead. New Pressures to Expand **********Lately, given deregulation and increasing competition at home, the pressure to enter new markets has been building. The Braniff deal offered a quick, relatively inexpensive way to break into the rapidly growing Sun Belt market. But now, Mr. Barkley said, PSA will have to proceed slowly and piecemeal - and at much greater cost. **********''Even picking our best opportunities,'' he said in a telephone interview from PSA's headquarters at Lindbergh Field in San Diego, ''it will take several years to get anywhere near what we were talking about.'' **********Under the Braniff-PSA agreement, PSA would have leased 30 planes from Braniff and hired 2,200 of Braniff's 8,500 laid-off employees.  In addition, PSA would have had the use of 200 Braniff landing slots, mostly in parts of the Southwest that PSA does not serve, and many of them in the lucrative Dallas-Fort Worth market. Court Objects to Transfer **********For PSA and Braniff, which filed for protection from its creditors last May, the agreement was a logical one. But on March 2 the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans overturned lower court approval of the deal. The appeals court objected in particular to the transfer of the landing slots, which, it said, were not Braniff's to distribute. **********The agreement was a major element in Braniff's reorganization plan, and without it, industry analysts have said, the airline may be forced into liquidation. Some hope remains that the deal might be revived if Braniff comes up with a plan that the court will accept.  But Mr. Barkley is doubtful. **********In any event, he observed, a slower expansion will involve less risk for PSA. ''You can reassess your plans step by step,'' he said.  ''With Braniff, we would take one big leap into the corner.'' **********The Braniff venture offered PSA a strikingly low cost for entering a new market. For example, to buy 30 new planes - such as the McDonnell Douglas Super 80 - would cost about $700 million. PSA would have gained the use of Braniff's 727's for $70,000 a month per plane plus about $30 million to help start the division. 'Pretty Cheap' Cost **********''That's pretty cheap,'' said Harry Harwood, the airline analyst for Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. of Los Angeles. **********PSA has been hoping that a market expansion would lead to a repeat of its early success, which was based on a strategy of offering low fares and frequent service on no-frill flights. From carrying 5.1 million passengers with a net profit of $3.6 million in 1970, the carrier reached its peak in 1979 when it carried 8.7 million passengers and posted a net profit of $23 million. **********But Pacific Southwest, like the rest of the airline industry, was staggered in the late 1970's by the jump in fuel prices. Meanwhile, in August 1978, the carrier and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation signed an initial agreement that eventually called for the delivery of 29 Super 80 aircraft for a total price of more than $600 million. **********A 53-day strike by PSA's pilots at the end of 1980 and a delay in the delivery of the new planes compounded the financial problems. Profit to Loss **********From an operating profit of $30.4 million in 1979, the airline since 1980 has had operating losses totaling $17 million. Only by generating profits from other businesses, such as the maintenance of jet engines, aircraft leasing and the sale of tax credits on the new aircraft, was the company able to show a profit of $19.5 million last year. **********Its debt-to-equity ratio in 1982 stood at 73 percent debt and 27 percent equity. ''That's way too high,'' George M. Shortley, senior vice president of finance and chief financial officer of PSA, conceded in an interview. ''We intend to bring it down under 60 to 40.'' The current long-term debt totals $395 million. **********Despite the heavy debt burden, the upgrading of the fleet of aircraft has enabled PSA to bring its costs down, to 7.8 cents per available seat mile last December from 8.3 cents in December 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/21/world.body_text: **********The United States' refusal to grant political asylum and temporary residential status to Salvadorans has stirred a wave of letters and protests from members of Congress and church groups, who say the lives of many of the Salvadorans would be in danger if they returned home. **********The American Civil Liberties Union and a group of 88 members of Congress, as well as church and community ganizations, have pressed the Administration in recent months to adopt an informal administrative procedure that would allow Salvadorans to remain in the United States for an indefinite period. The Immigration and Naturalization Service estimated that the number of Salvadorans in the United States, many of them illegally, might be as high as 500,000. **********Diana Bell, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Political Asylum project, said the organization had urged the State Department to seek ''extended voluntary departure status'' for Salvadorans in the United States. 'Problem Is Very Simple' **********''The real problem is very simple,'' Miss Bell said. ''Are we deporting people to their death?'' Miss Bell said it was ''very difficult'' to determine if any Salvadorans had been murdered after being deported from the United States. But she said that Salvadoran newspapers had reported two such deaths and that affidavits had been signed by people ''saying that they heard of deportees being killed.'' Last year, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 5,566 Salvadorans were deported on grounds of illegal entry. **********At the same time, the Immigration and Naturalization Service denied political asylum to 1,067 Salvadorans, and 74 Salvadorans were given asylum. Many of the asylum applicants who were rejected are appealing the decision. **********Miss Bell said Salvadorans deported from the United States faced special dangers ''because they are often identified as subversives since they fled Salvador in the first place.'' She said deported Salvadorans were often identified at the airport in San Salvador as soon as they returned home. **********In asylum cases, State Department officials said, the department deals in a case-by-case review. Extended voluntary departure status would enable the Salvadorans to remain here for anywhere from 90 days to 6 months or longer. Currently, arrivals from Afghanistan, Ethiopia, Poland and Uganda remain in the United States in that status. Abrams Defends Policy **********Elliott Abrams, head of the State Department's Bureau of Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, said in a telephone interview that one of the main arguments against granting extended voluntary departure status to the Salvadorans was that ''there are an extremely large number in the United States illegally who are here for reasons that are purely economic.'' **********''A substantially large number are not leaving violence or seeking asylum,'' he said. ''Virtually all of them come up through Mexico, a country at peace. If all they wanted to do is flee violence, they would have stayed in Mexico.'' **********He added: ''To grant extended voluntary departure would be to say to all Salvadorans here seeking to escape political persecution and all Salvadorans seeking jobs could stay. What we want to do is use the asylum process to pick out those who are seeking to avoid persecution and let them stay.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/world.print_headline: MANY POLES LOSE BIDS FOR ASYLUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/world.body_text: **********The applications of hundreds of Polish nationals for political asylum in the United States have been rejected by Federal authorities trying to clear a backlog of applicants. **********Most of the Polish nationals have claimed an association with the Solidarity union movement and contend they would face persecution if they were sent back to their homeland. **********The immigration authorities say there are no statistics at the State Department, the Justice Department or the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service on the exact number of rejections. However, applicants in several parts of the country reported a flurry of recent rejections. **********In New York City, for example, Lydia Savoyka of the United States Catholic Conference, which helps exiles of all nationalities in this country, said that ''85 percent of our applications for asylum are being denied.'' She said the applications of 300 to 400 of the 1,500 Poles with applications for asylum pending were denied in recent months. **********Some private agencies in the United States that help refugees say the rejection rate seems to be more stringent than it was two or three years ago, before action on the applications of Polish exiles was essentially postponed because of the chaotic political situation in their home country. **********Poles have been excluded from deportation proceedings since 1981 under a six-month Immigration Service directive that has since been renewed every six months. Verne Jervis, chief spokesman for the Immigration Service, said there was no indication whether the directive would be renewed again when it expires at the end of this month. **********Poles whose asylum petitions have been initially rejected and wish to stay in this country may file appeals. It can take two or more years for an applicant to exhaust all appeals. **********Although none of the applicants will be required to leave the country immediately, the rash of denials has sent shock waves through Polish exile communities around the country. Some say they perceive a tougher United States attitude toward exiles seeking asylum from Communist countries for political reasons. **********Mr. Jervis said in a telephone interview, ''There was no policy change to be tougher.'' However, he added, ''We are trying to reduce the backlog by accelerated processing of the cases.'' **********''I'm aware only that it is to reduce the backlog,'' he said, adding that each case was decided on individual merit. **********Mr. Jervis said that at the end of October of this year there were 1,822 applications from Polish nationals for political asylum in this country. But the actual number of individuals involved is far higher, perhaps more than double, because many applications are for families. In September 1982, the last time individual applicants were counted, 4,906 Poles had asked for asylum.   Typical Case Cited **********Typical is the case of Jerry W., a man in his late thirties who friends say was a ''notorious'' trade unionist in his home town in Poland. He now lives in Texas. He came to the United States on a visitor's visa in mid-1982, bringing with him his wife and one child, but forced to leave another child behind. **********He asked not to be identified, as have other Poles seeking asylum here, either because they have relatives still in Poland or because they fear retribution if they are forced to return. His lawyer, Jonathan Lamb, of Houston, said Jerry W. had been warned by other dissidents allied with Solidarity that he might face reprisals for sponsoring union meetings at his place of business and supporting a strike at a local mill. **********In September 1982, after six weeks in this country, Jerry W. filed for political asylum. His application joined a backlog of pleas for asylum from 170,000 other aliens, 115,000 of them Cubans and 5,500 Haitians, who have filed similar petitions with the Department of Immigration and Naturalization. For eight months he heard nothing. **********Finally, after the intervention by Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, his hearing was held. Although Jerry W. had no card proving his membership in Solidarity - he said he feared trying to leave Poland with it in his possession - he presented affidavits from two men who swore to his membership in Solidarity and his activities in its behalf. **********About two weeks ago, he received a letter that said his application for asylum had been denied. It gave him 15 days to return to Poland voluntarily or face deportation proceedings. **********In considering applications for asylum, the United States does not take into account economic conditions in the applicant's home country, only the possibility of political persecution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/world.main_headline: SLOWER INFLATION LEADS O.E.C.D. TO URGE GROWTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/world.print_headline: SLOWER INFLATION LEADS O.E.C.D. TO URGE GROWTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/world.body_text: **********French-American differences pose a barrier to taking unified economic action. News analysis, page D4. **********PARIS, May 10 - The chief industrial countries can now safely promote faster economic growth because of progress in reducing inflation, finance and foreign ministers from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. **********Their stand, announced at the end of their annual two-day meeting here, represents a major shift: For the first time in a decade, the 24 O.E.C.D. members collectively agreed that the top economic priority for the most prosperous nations was reducing unemployment, rather than fighting inflation. **********In their final communique the ministers said: ''In a number of countries, accounting for about 70 percent of O.E.C.D. gross national product, inflation is approaching the level of the 1960's.  Confidence has strengthened; progress has been made in tackling structural imbalances,'' and activity has started to pick up. **********''For such countries,'' the communique went on, ''ministers agreed on the importance of taking advantage of the room that has emerged for increased output and employment.'' **********These nations must now make ''sus-tainable noninflationary growth'' their major priority ''in order to reduce the present very high levels of unemployment.'' **********At a closing news conference, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said: ''The U.S. has been, remains and will continue always to be interested in world economic growth. We are glad to be aboard and leading the charge.'' **********The United States and the other industrial countries also used today's final sessions with reporters to express reservations about President Francois Mitterrand's call Monday for a conference to reestablish fixed exchange rates between major world currencies. **********While accepting the eventual need to ''discuss in more detail monetary problems and currency fluctuations,'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said of the French leader's proposal, ''I don't think the time is ripe.'' **********The West German Finance Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, conceded that the present international monetary system ''doesn't work very well.'' But he said the fault lay not with ''the lack of fixed exchange rates, but with the lack of internal discipline by countries operating the system'' - an implied criticism of the French Socialists, whose inflationary economic policies have resulted in three franc devaluations in two years. **********In the O.E.C.D.'s view, the countries in which inflation is now so firmly under control that governments can afford to concentrate on promoting expansion are the United States, West Germany, Britain, Canada and Japan. In all of them, inflation is now running at rates well below the average for the 1960's, O.E.C.D. officials say. **********A second group of countries, chiefly made up of France and Italy and accounting for about 20 percent of the O.E.C.D. gross national product, must still concentrate on reducing inflation, the communique said. Consequently, this group will have ''less growing room in the near term.'' In the remaining countries inflation-fighting remains the top economic priority, the ministers agreed. **********This week's meeting avoided any outright call for stimulative measures, such as increased public spending or big tax cuts. In the past the group's secretariat, with the support of France and many smaller members, has tried without success to persuade countries with good inflation records to expand their economies rapidly in order to serve as ''locomotives'' that could pull the rest of the world out of recession. **********But such thinking has been generally discredited through the staunch opposition of the United States, West Germany, Britain and other conservative members, who have argued that stimulative tactics are self-defeating because they merely result in higher inflation.  Instead, they believe that output will start expanding of its own accord as inflation is brought under control, with only marginal help from Governments. **********As a result, the policy recommendations aimed at encouraging faster growth that were approved at today's meeting are phrased in cautious terms and placed firmly in a medium-term perspective. **********The communique urged countries where the threat of future budget deficits ''looms large'' to take urgent action to reduce that portion that does not involve recession-linked social benefits, in order to bring down interest rates. Although no members are mentioned by name, officials say that the meeting had the United States in mind. **********The other low-inflation countries were told to be cautious in reducing that part of their deficit.  In addition, low-inflation countries are warned against futher reducing their monetary growth targets to reflect the expected drop in inflation caused by weaker oil prices. **********The meeting also made a strong commitment to rolling back protectionist measures taken during the recession, as unemployment rose. It asked the organization's Secretary General to propose specific plans for doing so. **********Delegates generally agreed that the prospect of more growth in the world, together with the growing recognition that the battle against inflation is finally being won, helped make this year's meeting an unusually cooperative and peaceful one. In particular, there was little evidence in the communique of the kind of divisive quarrels between conservatives and liberals that marked earlier meetings. **********Nevertheless, divergent currents of thoughts could be discerned in the speeches and private comments of individual ministers. The French Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, was skeptical about the strength of the economic recovery in the United States and made clear that he favors more aggressive stimulation by the low-inflation countries. Several Scandinavian countries supported him. **********Another difference of viewpoint emerged over trade and interest rates. Mr. Regan argued strongly that the best way to sustain and broaden the present recovery is by rolling back protectionist measures so that world trade can increase and deeply indebted third world countries can earn enough to service their debts. But many of the smaller European countries argued that a rapid reduction in United States interest rates and a fall in the dollar's value would have a more immediately beneficial effect on the world economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration and Congressional officials today denied a report published in The Sunday Times of London that the United States knew a massacre was under way in two Palestinian refugee camps last September a day before the killings ended. **********Senior intelligence officials said that the Government first learned about the killings on Saturday, Sept. 18, the day the killings ended. **********The London newspaper, quoting unnamed American intelligence officials, said that word of the killings first reached the American Government on the evening of Thursday, Sept. 16 and that members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee were informed the following morning. **********Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate Intelligence Committee, said today that neither committee had learned of the massacre until Sept. 18. **********A staff member on the Foreign Relations Committee, who asked not to be identified, recalled that one of his colleagues told committee members late on Sept. 17 that he had heard rumors of a massacre in Beirut. When the committee asked the State Department about the matter, the staff members said today, the department responded that it too had heard rumors and was trying to find out if they were true. **********Neither the department nor the committee, however, learned that a massacre had taken place until Saturday, Sept. 18, the staff member said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.main_headline: PRICE OF NEW SHARES - MYSTERY TO THE LAST MINUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.print_headline: PRICE OF NEW SHARES - MYSTERY TO THE LAST MINUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.body_text: **********For months, one of Wall Street's biggest questions about the new American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the seven regional holding companies has been: At what price will the shares trade on the opening bell? **********The answer will not come until moments before trading in these eight new securities begins Monday morning. And for most of the individual shareholders, who are not expected to jump into the trading activity immediately, the opening price will help decide what they will eventually do with their new shares. **********For many professional traders however, especially the arbitragers who make their money on small price shifts in large blocks of shares, the opening prices and their fluctuations through the day hold the potential for big profits or losses. **********No Trading History **********It is not often that exchange officials have to pick a price for a stock with no trading history. Most stocks have traded the previous day, and even new issues have a price at which they were first sold. **********The exchange, however, does have established procedures for picking an opening price. When trading in an issue is suspended because major news is forthcoming - not an uncommon event - the exchange must pick a price at which to reopen trading. **********On Monday, the process will begin when the exchange opens its computers to receive buy and sell orders at 8:30 A.M., a half-hour earlier than usual. The computers have been reprogrammed to accept orders of up to 30,099 shares, up from 5,099 shares. **********During the next hour, each specialist who supervises trading in a new telephone stock will examine the prices at which investors are offering to buy and sell the new shares. Helping the specialists with the analysis will be the exchange's floor governors, who are generally among its most experienced members. **********Range of Prices **********At 9:30 A.M., each specialist will release a range of prices, perhaps with a spread of several dollars. This information will move on the exchange's ticker and be disseminated through the news services that provide stock prices to the public. **********If the prices have changed significantly, another range will be released at 9:45 A.M. **********After more conferring, the specialists will open the stocks ''as soon as it is practical after the bell rings'' to open trading at 10 A.M., Samuel A. Alward, the exchange's executive vice president for operations and administration, said at a news conference yesterday. He called the procedure ''well in place and well proven.'' **********All seven regional companies have also decided to trade on at least one regional stock exchange. However, A.T.& T. has requested that trading in the regionals open first on the New York Stock Exchange.
