https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Twenty-one percent of those asked said they know someone who cheats on his or her income taxes, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll. The percentage is up slightly in the last five years, for only 17 percent said they knew a cheat in 1978. **********Among college graduates, fully 39 percent said they knew someone who cheated on taxes, up from 26 percent in 1978.  The poll also indicated that despite changes in tax laws and reductions in rates, there was no basic change in Americans' perceptions of the fairness of the tax system. Forty-one percent of those polled said the system was either quite fair or reasonably fair, a share statistically indistinguishable from the 43 percent who gave that answer in 1978.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.main_headline: FUN AND NOVELTY LIFT SALES OF BUBBLE GUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.print_headline: FUN AND NOVELTY LIFT SALES OF BUBBLE GUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.body_text: **********Bubble gum is big business - ask Ada Cantavero. **********''We sell a lot of it,'' acknowledges the grandmotherly proprietor of Ada's, a neighborhood variety store in Riverside, Conn. ''We always have. It's something that never goes out of style.'' **********Indeed, bubble gum may be one of the nation's few truly recession-proof industries. Experts estimate that sales of the confection, in a variety of artificially colored sticks, wads, chunks, flakes, nuggets and powders, have probably tripled in the last decade, approaching $500 million last year. **********Still, bubble gum remains a product subject to the whims of a market dominated by knee-high customers. ''I like to change all the time,'' Mrs. Cantavero says. ''And they usually come out with things that are fun, like gum shaped and colored as hamburgers, tacos and waffles. That really sells.'' **********Enter the industry's latest innovation: bubble gum in a tube. On Aug. 11 - within an hour of each other - both the Topps Chewing Gum Company and Wm. Wrigley Jr.'s subsidiary, the Amurol Products Company, introduced toothpaste-like tubes filled with a little more than a pack's worth of the familiar soft gum. The products, expected to reach stores next month, will retail at about 59 cents.  'Secret Project' **********There was no lack of accompanying fanfare. Topps cited the culmination of a two-year ''secret project'' aimed at packing the right mix of ''bubbleability, chewability and, of course, squeezeability'' into a 1.5-ounce plastic tube. Wrigley hailed its Tubble Gum as ''the biggest innovation in the bubble gum industry since soft bubble gum.'' **********This is unlikely. When Nabisco Brands' Life Savers Company (then a Squibb subsidiary) brought out Bubble Yum - a gum considerably softer, tastier and longer lasting than its traditional Bazooka and Double Bubble counterparts - in 1974, ''it revolutionized the bubble gum industry,'' said Lou Lassus, editor of Candy Marketer Quarterly, a trade magazine. ''Sales increased tremendously, mainly because it attracted a wider age group than bubble gum had previously.'' **********In fact, analysts say, Bubble Yum was largely responsible for the boom that saw bubble gum sales balloon by up to 10 percent a year before tapering off in 1979. **********Bubble Yum is still the favorite, commanding more than 20 percent of total bubble gum sales; Bubblicious, made by the Fleer Corporation (of Double Bubble fame), Wrigley's Hubba Bubba - the first nonstick variety - and Topps's soft Bazooka together account for another 50 percent of industry sales.  Industry's Earnings Up **********Soft bubble gum has increased profits industrywide. Topps, whose products are almost all bubble gum-related, has seen earnings soar since a disastrous loss in 1980: the Brooklyn-based company reported net income of $5.9 million on sales of $69.7 million last year. **********Nabisco's confectionery division, buoyed by Bubble Yum sales, posted operating income of $47 million last year on $528.5 million in revenue. **********Wrigley declines to break down figures for bubble gum sales, but analysts say its Hubba Bubba and novelty products have produced consistently high profits. **********No one, save Topps and Wrigley publicists, expects bubble gum in a tube to approach Bubble Yum's success. But experts differ on whether the innovation will become a lasting standard, or just attract the fleeting attention and revenues gained by the industry's many novelty products.  'A Very Faddish Industry' **********''It's an unusual idea, and it's probably going to sell like crazy,'' said one trade association executive. ''But it's a question of how long. Kids' candies do peak and then tend to go on a downward trend. It's a very faddish industry, especially when you're dealing with children.'' **********Novelty bubble gum takes on dozens of shapes, colors and sizes designed to grab the fancy of the youthful consumers. Topps, the leading novelty manufacturer, sells Gold Rush, a tiny canvas prospecting bag filled with yellow gum nuggets, Video Arcade Gum, miniaturized, gum-filled versions of Donkey Kong and Zaxxon, and Smurf Rocks; last year's hottest product was Wrigley's Big League Chew, gum flakes in a scaled-down tobacco pouch. And despite their faddish nature, analysts say, this relatively small segment of the market has shown surprising growth in the last five years. **********Such products, it seems, transcend the pure food value of the basic bubble gum. ''Many years ago, we considered ourselves to be in the gum business,'' said Arthur T. Shorin, chairman of Topps. ''Since then, we've come to consider ourselves in the business of entertaining children. The motivation behind a lot of our products is fun.''  Profit Margins Higher **********But novelties are as much profit as fun: Smurf Rocks, Gold Rush and the like typically sell at profit margins at least 10 percent higher than those for Bubble Yum and other standard packages. **********Part of the markup reflects the risks of catering to ever-changing preteen-age tastes. ''In the novelty business,'' said William Piet, a Wrigley spokesman, ''you have to look for higher margins because you never know what the product life will be. If the life is only six months, you have to put a lot of money up front, and the price reflects that.'' Even if risk were not a factor, Topps's Mr. Shorin observed, ''I think you're entitled to be recompensed for some modicum of genius.'' **********And so it is with bubble gum in a tube: Its proponents hope the unusual packaging and high ''play'' factor will make it a natural success, and a big profit center. **********''There's great receptivity on the part of these kids,'' said A. G. Atwater Jr., president of Amurol.  ''They go over to the counter and they're always looking for something new. If there's something that catches their fancy, they'll pick it up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/world.body_text: **********Two months after their defeat in the general election, and two months before they meet in Brighton to choose a new leader, there are signs that the ranking figures in Britain's Labor Party are finding unity as elusive a goal as it was during the election campaign. **********As a result, many people prominent in the party say they believe that it could be relegated to the outer fringes of British politics. **********In this week's episode in the long- running story of internal warfare, Denis Healey, the party's deputy leader, who has already said he would not stand for re-election, let it be known he would withdraw from the leadership altogether if the party lurched farther to the left. **********Mr. Healey indicated he would not seek a place in the shadow cabinet if Neil Kinnock and Michael Meacher, both left-wingers, were chosen as leader and as deputy leader respectively. **********Left-Winger Is Front-Runner **********It is generally assumed in the party and in the press that Mr. Kinnock, an eloquent, red-haired Welshman, will easily defeat Roy Hattersley and Peter Shore, both right-wingers, in the contest for leader on Oct. 2. **********The right appears prepared reluctantly to swallow such a result, although many right-wingers think it would make victory in the next general election very difficult. **********Their willingness is based on the hope that Mr. Hattersley, if chosen as deputy leader, would provide ideological balance. **********But Mr. Meacher could win the second spot. If he did, said Giles Radice, an M.P. allied with Mr. Healey, ''it would be electorally disastrous for the party.'' **********Mr. Hattersley and Mr. Shore have lined up so little support in the leadership contest that the engineers' union, one of the biggest right-wing groups, decided last week to boycott the election on the ground that a Kinnock victory is a foregone conclusion. **********Unions cast 40 percent of the votes in the electoral college that picks a leader and a deputy; local parties and M.P.'s each cast 30 percent.   Party's Fate at Stake **********The continuing squabbling may threaten Labor's existence as a major party. In the June 9 voting, it polled only 20.1 percent of the total electorate - less than the percentage that stayed at home. It ran second in only 132 constituencies, whereas the new Liberal- Social Democratic alliance was the runner-up in 312. In much of the country, the alliance now constitutes the main opposition to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government. **********One measure of the disaster that engulfed the Labor Party is the number of seats where it forfeited electoral deposits as a penalty for having failed to poll at least 12.5 percent of the total vote. **********In the 11 general elections between 1945 and 1979, there were only 82 such forfeitures; in this year's election alone, there were 119. **********A confidential analysis of the party's situation, circulated among Labor M.P.'s during the last month, argues that the shift of votes from Labor to the alliance constituted an ''earthquake'' of major proportions. **********It asserts that if the party does not reestablish itself soon as the second party - in early by-elections, local elections next May and voting for the European by-elections next June - Labor will enter the next general election in third place.   'A Steady Erosion' **********The author, David Cowling, a respected party researcher, wrote: **********''Unless we have broken the back of the alliance within 12 months, we face the real prospect of a steady erosion of our already massively depleted votes. Unless we understand and accept the sheer scale and nature of our defeat, there is not the slightest chance of us winning the next general election.'' **********In the only by-election held since the general election, the Labor showing underlined Mr. Cowling's warning. **********In balloting on July 28 at Penrith and the Border, Labor's share of the vote plummeted to 7.4 percent as the Conservatives narrowly held the Lake District constituency represented for 28 years by William Whitelaw, now Viscount Whitelaw. The alliance nominee, Michael Young, polled 44.6 percent. **********Mr. Hattersley has argued vigorously that Labor fared poorly in June largely because its economic policies were ''literally incredible'' to the British public, and because its commitment to unilateral nuclear disarmement had cost it dearly. **********The voters, he said, overwhelmingly rejected ''the notion that we might give up our nuclear protection if others did not do the same thing.'' **********But Mr. Kinnock, the clear front-runner with the backing of most of the big unions and most of the local parties, insisted last month that the party did not ''have to shift ground.''  'Timetable Can't Be Dictated' **********It may be necessary to change public perceptions of some policies, he added, but disarmament must proceed regardless of what the Soviet Union does because ''the timetable can't be dictated by other people.'' **********''The main body of our policies must not be jettisoned,'' he said. **********Although both Mr. Kinnock and Mr. Hattersley have insisted that there is no bad feeling between them, tensions between left and right exploded at a private meeting of Labor M.P.'s last month, with Mr. Hattersley's trading bitter words with Michael Foot, the outgoing leader, who is backing Mr. Kinnock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Six years ago, when Mexico's economy was last in trouble, large oil discoveries beneath the swamps surrounding this city announced the country's imminent recovery. And in the oil boom that followed, nowhere was growth wilder or faster than in Villahermosa. **********But today, Mexico's new, more severe economic crisis has reached here. Shops and restaurants that opened in prosperity now cry out for customers, several half-finished buildings await completion and work on a new highway to nearby Coatzacoalcos has stopped. There even seem to be fewer people around. **********Perhaps most surprising, given Mexico's continuing dependence on its oil exports, the state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, is also facing budget restraints. One-quarter of the country's daily oil production of 3 million barrels still comes from the region, but the company has been forced to lay off 10,000 construction workers in recent months as oil output here has shrunk from the 1978 record of a million barrels a day. 'Like Rest of the Country' **********''Many contractors have left, many migrant workers have returned to their hometowns, even peasants who found jobs in Petroleos Mexicanos are going back to their plots,'' said Eduardo Utrilla, who handles community relations here for the oil company, which is called Pemex.  ''Now we're more like the rest of the country.'' **********The slowing of the pace has thus brought some relief to a longsleepy farming region that never quite adjusted to the industrial revolution that exploded in its midst. **********''This gives us time to balance the relationship between Petroleos Mexicanos and Tabasco,'' said Enrique Gonzalez Pedrero, the new Governor of the state of Tabasco, of which Villahermosa is the capital. ''Our aim is to balance the economic development brought on by oil with the social development that got left behind, particularly in outlying rural districts.'' **********Oil was first struck a few miles south of here in May 1972, but it was only in 1977 that the true dimension of the region's hydrocarbon wealth became known - 20 billion barrels of proved reserves. And it was then that the metamorphosis of Tabasco began. Billions of Dollars Spent **********In a matter of months Pemex focused its entire expansion effort on Tabasco, spending billions of dollars, importing hundreds of Mexican and foreign engineers and technicians and attracting thousands more peasants and workers searching for high-paying jobs. But money - more than Tabasco had ever dreamed of - soon strained the state's social fabric. **********''The attitude and mentality of the locals were not adapted to the new rhythm and new customs of those who came here,'' Mr. Utrilla recalled. ''The newcomers drove big cars, they went to bars, they filled restaurants, the red light district expanded. It was a tremendous shock for Tabasco.'' **********The cattle-ranchers who had long dominated the state's economy found their farmhands leaving to work for Pemex. Shopkeepers and small-business operators were unable to pay the salaries necessary to dissuade secretaries and accountants from flocking to the oil company. **********With insufficient residential housing available, local homeowners saw an opportunity to raise rents to levels three times higher than the national average and more. This, in turn, pushed rents and house prices beyond the reach of local families. And for several years, inflation here was consistently 10 to 20 percentage points higher than elsewhere in Mexico. Rush Toward Exploration **********The greatest impact, though, was felt in the rural areas where Pemex was actually drilling. Because the Government owns the subsoil, Pemex could take over land that it required. But while compensation was paid, disagreements over the price frequently provoked angry incidents. **********Further, in its eagerness to find and exploit the region's oil wealth as rapidly as possible, Pemex often paid scant attention to environmental questions, and farmers began complaining that their animals and crops were being harmed by water and air pollution. **********After indignant peasants began blocking roads to oil wells in order to put pressure on the Government to act, even the then governor of Tabasco, Leandro Rovirosa Wade, felt forced to denounce Pemex in public, arguing that the state had become a victim rather than beneficiary of the boom. **********At that point, Pemex apparently recognized a potentially explosive problem and responded accordingly: it offered to share the cost of building and repairing local roads, started its own homebuilding program and agreed to pay a special tax to Tabasco equivalent to 6 percent of local oil production. It also set up a commission to deal with the complaints of local farmers. Using Funds From Pemex **********With the additional funds, Villahermosa, whose population has tripled to 300,000 in less than a decade, was able to carry out urgently needed urban improvements to appease long-time residents and increase the compensation paid to peasants affected by Pemex operations. **********Even now, Pemex is blamed for most of the ills that befall the rural population. But company officials respond that local residents have merely discovered an easy way to make money. **********''If it rains, it's Pemex's fault, and if it doesn't rain, it's Pemex's fault,'' said Guillermo Diaz, who is in charge of the company's local environmental protection office. ''We were even blamed by some peasants when the Chinchonal volcano erupted near here last year.'' **********Nevertheless, during a visit to Villahermosa last December, Pemex's new director-general, Mario Ramon Beteta, conceded that the oil boom had brought economic, environmental and social problems to the region. **********''The appearance of the oil worker or technician beside the peasant often seems like an intrusion that generates turbulence and imbalances,'' he said. ''We do not ignore that this confrontation is often painful and erodes community values that are worthy of the utmost respect.''

He added that Harvester would have been required to record more than $1 billion of unfunded pension liabilities as debt if the farm machinery operations were sold. **********The Tenneco source said such a move would have increased Harvester's negative net worth to more than $1 billion, placing it in default of current loan covenants with its major creditors. **********If Harvester had agreed to sell the business, Tenneco, which is based in Houston, would have consolidated it into its J. I. Case Company subsidiary, the source said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/01/busin.body_text: **********If there was ever a sure thing in marketing, diet Coke seems to be it. After six months in the New York area, the soft drink went national in January and is clearly living up to its promise. **********''It is the hottest-selling soft drink in the shortest amount of time ever,'' said Jesse Meyers, editor of Jesse Meyers' Beverage Digest, a publication of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. ''If diet Coke is well marketed, in a very short time it will be No. 3. Even if it is marketed badly, it will be No.5.'' The No. 1 soft drink is Coke, followed by Pepsi and 7-Up. **********As new products go, diet Coke has all the advantages: the Coke name, a budget of $50 million, and a distribution network capable of getting the product to 155 countries. The Coca-Cola Company was so sure that diet Coke would be a success that it was never even testmarketed in stores. After a gala introduction at Radio City Music Hall last July, diet Coke went straight to consumers. A Supportive Name **********''The Coca-Cola name supports that of diet Coke - and diet Coke reinforces Coke,'' said Brian Dyson, president of Coca-Cola U.S.A. **********Another spokesman, Anthony Tortorici, put it more directly.  Referring to crucial store shelf space, he declared: ''You've got to get facings.'' **********That has been all but automatic for diet Coke, because merchandisers respect Coca-Cola's marketing clout and because the special arrangements between distributors and retailers create loyalty. **********''Nobody is going to jeopardize his relationship with Coke by not giving diet Coke space,'' said a New York supermarket chain executive who asked not to be identified. **********Coca-Cola made itself into a corporate giant, with revenues last year of $6.2 billion, on the successful marketing of Coke. The Small 'd' Strategy **********But although Coca-Cola has had dozens of soft drinks, diet Coke is only the second to bear the Coke name. To market the new drink, the parent chose a package that uses the Coke label as a point of departure, de-emphasizing its dietetic attribute by using a lowercase ''d.'' The strategy was to attract a broader market than traditional diet drinks, one that would include men. Coca-Cola also wanted to insulate its other great seller, Tab, from new competition. Tab, the industry's No.1 diet drink, has its own look and has been marketed to women. **********Nonetheless, the company had expected that 48 percent of the sales of diet Coke would come at the expense of its own products, especially Coke and Tab. However, it has apparently been so successful in positioning the new drink that it has now lowered that estimate to only 40 percent. And analysts said it is closer to 30 percent. A Lot of Fanfare **********During the first few weeks of diet Coke's national introduction, analysts estimated that the drink sold at least as well as Pepsi, primarily because diet Coke was treated with such fanfare and excitement. For its part, Pepsico is not willing to concede that it has lost any market share to the new product. **********Coca-Cola treated the introduction of diet Coke like a news event.  Coca-Cola generated so much advance press coverage - all without spending a cent on advertising - that a survey conducted by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company showed than 29 percent of a sample group knew about diet Coke before it had been announced. **********The competition for shelf space -facings, as it is known in the industry - is particularly acute for colas, the largest segment of the soft drink business and the fastest-growing. Over the last six months, new colas have been added at the rate of one a month. At the beginning of 1982, there were eight. So far in 1983, there are already 14, with the possibility of more, especially if Coca-Cola decides to produce decaffienated soft drinks to compete with the new ones introduced by Pepsico Inc. and Philip Morris Inc's Seven-Up unit last summer. **********Caffeine-free colas constitute less than 8 percent of the market right now. But Coca-Cola said that if it enters the competition, the market would grow to 15 percent. **********''If Coca-Cola decides caffeine free is important, I think you will see a caffeine-free version in all of Coca-Cola's products,'' said Lawrence Adelman, senior vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Coca-Cola executives will say only that they are considering a decaffeinated Coke. A Hard-to-Ignore Potential **********Coca-Cola is not expected to move as slowly into decaffeinated soft drinks as it did into diet sodas. Tab, introduced in 1963, was its main entry in the diet drink category until the market showed the kind of growth potential that Coca-Cola could not ignore. Diet drinks, which now account for about 20 percent of the market, are expected to grow at a rate of nearly 12 percent over the next few years, three times the growth anticipated for the rest of the industry. **********Now that there are two Cokes, there may be three or four before long.  ''But only if Coca-Cola is sure that it is No.1 in every category,'' said Mr. Meyers of Harcourt Brace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/15/busin.body_text: **********A provincial judge, a politically cowed military and the ire of foreign bankers are all part of an international tug-of-war that threatens to put Argentina into default Thursday. **********That is the due date for repaying $300 million on a loan that Argentina received last December from a syndicate of 263 foreign banks. **********If the country does not come up with the payment, it will technically be in default. This means that, if just one of the 263 banks in the syndicate formally declares default, all the banks involved must stop all loans to Argentina. Such a step would be financially disastrous to the country. **********The administration of President Reynaldo B. Bignone has asked to put off the payment as long as 30 days. Argentina, with $40 billion of foreign debt, is already in arrears and cannot meet the payment, foreign bankers and Government officials agreed in interviews.  'The Banks Are Just Fed Up' **********The foreign bankers said they had refused the Government's request for a postponement. The bankers said they were angered by the Government's refusal for nearly two years to amend an Argentine bankruptcy law that discriminates against foreign creditors. They also hope to force the Government to modify its unilateral refinancing of more than $5 billion in private foreign debt last May. **********''It's a scandal,'' one key banker said of the Government's measures, ''and the banks are just fed up.'' **********What finally set off the bankers was a ruling two weeks ago by a judge in the river port of Rosario, 170 miles northwest of Buenos Aires. The judge, Enrique Mullen, invoked the bankruptcy law in restructuring the debt of Celulosa, a pulp and paper manufacturer. **********Celulosa, one of Argentina's largest private corporations, had declared a cessation of payments in February 1982. Hurt by cheap imports and high interest rates, it applied to Judge Mullen for relief on the $300 million it owed to bankers and suppliers.  Out-of-Court Accord Sought **********Of its nearly 800 creditors, about 50 are foreign, and they hold $110 million of the debt. **********First, the creditors tried to reach an out-of-court settlement. Unanimity is necessary under Argentine law, but an agonizingly small number of the creditors - three - refused to go along. Judge Mullen refused to extend his deadline for an out-of-court settlement. **********Citing the bankruptcy law, the judge then ruled that the foreign creditors could no longer vote in the debt negotiations and would be subject to waiting 12 years before repayment. That period may be extended for 24 more years - without interest. **********It is now up to the Argentine creditors to agree on a repayment schedule to present to the judge. They could vote to share their repayments, but that is considered unlikely. **********Argentina's discriminatory bankruptcy provision was adopted by an earlier military Government in 1972 as a nationalistic measure. Banks Start Chain Reaction **********The foreign banks, most of them based in the United States, Canada and Europe, have retaliated by setting off a chain reaction. **********Representatives of many of the banks involved in the various syndicates for loans to Argentina have been meeting in New York, and similar meetings have taken place here. **********Besides refusing to grant a delay of Thursday's payment, the banks are also holding back on what had been scheduled as the signing today of a $230 million restructuring loan by a syndicate of nearly 40 foreign banks for Aerolineas Argentina, a state- owned airline. The loan is meant to be the model for restructuring more than $6 billion in public debt. **********By not signing the airline loan, the banks have prevented Argentina from receiving the first disbursal of $500 million from a $1.5 billion loan that was arranged last month. An agreement on the airline restructuring was a condition for the disbursal.  Key $300 Million Is Withheld **********Without the disbursal, Argentina is unable to pay enough of its arrears - estimated at $1.2 billion by a Western diplomat - to meet a condition set by the International Monetary Fund before it would disburse $300 million of a loan agreed upon last year. **********Argentina was planning to use that $300 million to meet the payment that is due to private banks Thursday. **********''There would never have been a better moment to pressure Argentina,'' one American banker said. **********The military Government's Legislative Advisory Commission met today to consider proposals to amend the bankruptcy law, Argentine officials said. **********The commission, which drafts legislation for the Government, has turned down previous proposed amendments. It does not want to look as though it is conceding anything to foreign bankers, particularly with national elections scheduled for October, an Argentine official said. Civilian political leaders have accused the military of being ''allied'' with foreign banks. **********''The military is afraid,'' said an Argentine close to the proceedings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices closed mixed yesterday as year-end sales for tax losses diminished and bargain-hunting increased. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 5.38 points on Friday, gained 2.44 points yesterday, to 1,244.61. The blue-chip indicator has tumbled 42 points since Nov. 29, when it closed at a record 1,287.20, primarily because of rising yields in the credit markets and heavy tax sales. **********The overall market, however, finished lower, with stocks that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering those that rose, 886 to 744. **********Analysts said that the market firmed somewhat yesterday in part because prices of some issues were so depressed that investors found them attractive. There was nothing in the economic news to spur equities. **********Turnover Is 75.2 Million **********Turnover on the Big Board yesterday contracted to 75.2 million shares from 81 million on Friday as institutional interest slackened. **********Analysts said many investors remained on the sidelines because of apprehension that the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Open Market Committee, which meets today, might decide to tighten credit and thus send interest rates higher. **********The two other major stock market indicators ended with small losses. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common issues eased 0.06, to 93.80, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 equities was off 0.07, to 162.32. **********''Concern over interest rates continues to spook equities,'' said Ralph Bloch, vice president of investments of Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc. He said the weakness in the overall market and in the more broadly based major market indicators was a strong indication ''that investors are worried over the market's near-term outlook.'' **********Tymshare Tumbles 5 3/4, to 19 1/8 **********Tymshare was a big loser in heavy trading and tumbled 5 3/4, to 19 1/8, after its negotiations with McDonnell Douglas to buy Tymshare at $31 a share were broken off. Neither company gave a reason for the end of the talks. McDonnell Douglas rose 1 3/8, to 57 7/8. **********Southland Corporation fell 1 1/8, to 37 1/2, following its loss of the same amount on Friday. On Friday, the company said its Citgo unit was lowering the price it would pay for domestic crude oil by $1.50 a barrel because of the steady drop in retail demand. **********Capital Cities Communications gained 1 3/4, to 139, in active trading. The stock has been strong since Thursday, when it announced plans to repurchase up to 300,000 of its own shares. **********Several of the technology issues ended higher. Gains of a point or more were posted by Motorola, Computervision and Digital Equipment. International Business Machines, an institutional favorite that had been under pressure recently, rose 3/8, to 121 1/4. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mostly lower, with the market-value index down 0.95, to 218.67. Horn & Hardart led the most- active list and fell 1 7/8, to 19 3/4, on profit taking. The issue has been strong since early December, when it announced it expected record profits for the fourth quarter. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index was down 0.43, to 275.58. Computer Language rose 1 1/4, to 24 3/4 bid, after reporting it planned to acquire Microcomputer Systems for stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.main_headline: LIFE AND DEATH IN TIBET: THE PAST CLINGS FIERCELY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.print_headline: LIFE AND DEATH IN TIBET: THE PAST CLINGS FIERCELY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.body_text: **********A large yellowish bird of prey glided down on powerful wings and landed a distrustful distance from a solitary horseman who was leading his laden pack ponies along the twisting mountain road. **********The dusty rider had an old army carbine slung over his back, but he did not menace the bird, a lammergeier, which belongs to the vulture family and is respected here for its function in ceremonies known as ''sky burials.'' **********In Tibet, the dead are still taken to isolated hilltops at dawn and yielded up to the vultures. Burial is difficult in ground studded with rocks and frozen much of the year. There is not enough firewood for cooking, let alone for cremation, and rural villages often must rely on dried yak dung for fuel. **********The Tibetans, whose fervent Buddhism fused long ago with an older animism called Bon, believe that upon death the soul leaves the body, to be reborn 49 days later in another form. They look upon the extent to which the vultures dispose of the body as a sign of how well the deceased will fare in reincarnation. For Most Tibetans, the River **********Under the old feudal theocracy, only the wealthy could afford the time-consuming ritual of a sky burial. Ordinary Tibetans were more often dumped into the fast-flowing rivers when they died. **********This may be one reason why Tibetans retain an aversion to eating fish. Last autumn, a Chinese economic journal reported that Tibet's rivers and lakes were teeming with fish, which the local population would not consume ''because of religious and economic limitations.'' **********Sky burials are closed to outsiders, and even the relatives usually leave them to others. Lamaist monks used to perform the ceremony. But as the monks' numbers declined, some local farmers and herdsmen have picked up the skills to supplement their livelihood. They can earn up to $30 a day for each sky burial. **********At the capital of Lhasa, sky burials take place on a hill above the Sera Monastery, about four miles from town. The Han Chinese, one of whom showed revulsion in discussing the practice, have set up a crematorium. Mending the Buddha **********Another tradition is Buddhism. When King Songtsen Gampo unified Tibet 13 centuries ago, he cemented relations with his neighbors by taking two royal wives, from China and Nepal, who helped introduce Buddhism. The Nepalese princess brought with her a bronze Buddha more than five feet high. **********After China's Cultural Revolution was launched in 1966, Maoist radicals ransacking the Tibetan temples broke the priceless statue in two and sent the pieces off to be melted down. **********The lower half was eventually rescued from the scrap heap of a local factory. The upper half was found in Peking. This spring, the ancient Buddha was mended and restored to the Jokhan Temple in Lhasa. **********Ten thousand other relics from Tibetan monasteries that were destined for melting have been returned from Gansu Province. They included more than 3,000 statues of Buddha, some dating from the 4th century. Such treasures became targets of the Maoist campaign against the ''four olds'' - old culture, old ideas, old customs and old habits. Irrevocably Lost Relics **********Despite the Peking Government's recent efforts to repair the damage of the Cultural Revolution, the majority of such relics have been irrevocably lost. Legislation passed last November now forbids the export of any surviving Tibetan antiques that predate 1959. This was the year that Chinese troops put down an armed revolt, opening the way to the desecration of Tibet's heritage. **********In the old markets of Lhasa and Xigaze, where the animated haggling encompasses everything from wooden saddles to animal pelts and colorful felt boots, young vendors sidle up and furtively offer tourists small statues, pieces of prayer boxes, religious amulets and the like. Most of them are overpriced and nearly worthless.  Nevertheless, unsympathetic customs officials have prevented them from leaving Tibet by confiscating them from tourists who have bought them. **********At the Drepung Monastery outside Lhasa, a husky Tibetan displayed a few trinkets from inside his sheepskin coat while his wife stared wide-eyed at an American visitor without breaking the cadence of her Buddhist chant. **********His wares were refused, but the young man wanted to prove that he was no shyster. He proudly pulled from his belt an onionskin certificate in Chinese. It attested that the police had caught him previously selling antiques to tourists. Folk Medicine Endures **********And another tradition is folk medicine. A wiry herdsman walked into the downtown hospital in Lhasa carrying a deer's antler, which he wanted ground into medicine. The hospital, which specializes in Tibetan folk medicine, attracts 700 to 800 patients a day. **********Like Chinese traditional medicine, Tibetan medicine relies heavily on herbs, which are gathered mostly in eastern Tibet. Gunga Pingzuo, the hospital's chief physician, said acupuncture and massage had been adopted lately from the Chinese. **********Dr. Gunga, a patriarchal 78-year-old with a wispy white beard, learned traditional medicine as a young monk. He said that, although Tibetan medicine has a history of 2,000 years, its ''way of treatment is simple.'' The doctor, he said, examines the face, blood pressure and urine of the patient and then prescribes from more than 300 herbal medicines. Blood Pressure and Altitudes **********Dr. Gunga said the most common complaints involved high blood pressure, which he attributed to living at high altitudes, and stomach ailments, which he said were from eating raw meat. Serious illnesses are referred to a Chinese hospital with Western medical equipment across town. **********Traditional medicine departments have been added to the 80 town and county hospitals in Tibet, and a reference book on Tibetan medicine was published in Chinese earlier this year. **********Tibet's rugged living conditions have made modern medical care almost impossible in some remote areas, where patients must walk for days or even weeks to reach a hospital. A Han physician said that in one region of southern Tibet, 20 percent of the babies died within a month after birth. He also found that intermarriage in isolated villages had created genetic problems. **********A common form of marriage used to be fraternal polyandry, in which the eldest brother took a wife and all his younger brothers automatically became her husbands too. The offspring of such a multiple union were considered the elder brother's. The tradition hangs on in a few back areas today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/19/busin.body_text: **********No news is bad news.  So it is in Akron, Ohio, where the nation's $1 billion-a-year paper recycling industry has mounted a drive to preserve its sources of supply -largely newspapers - against threatened inroads from government. **********Akron, worried that its new $80 million waste-to-energy incinerator might not have enough raw material to burn, has laid claim to every newspaper disposed of within the city limits. It does not matter whether they are collected by municipal employees or by private haulers: As soon as paper waste is discarded, it immediately belongs to the city. **********Controversial Ordinance **********''It's a compelling interest to be able to operate the plant,'' says Edward J. Riegler, Akron's law director, in defending the city's so-called flow-control ordinance, one of the country's first.  But those are fighting words to haulers and recyclers, who have already pursued their case to the Supreme Court, and to their ally, J. Rodney Edwards, a vice president of the American Paper Institute. **********''We think the collector should have the right'' to take paper waste where he wants and not be forced to take it to be burned, Mr.Edwards says. ''Basically the question is, who owns the garbage.'' **********The contest has raised several issues, including whether the city is violating Federal antitrust laws by authorizing a practice in restraint of trade. Pending a final legal ruling, the city has so far refrained from enforcing its flow-control law. **********Although municipal incineration is largely inspired by the rising costs of burying waste, the Akron case also illustrates how some energy-producing projects inspired by the oil shortages of the 1970's are colliding with other measures to make more efficient use of resources. Some environmentalists, for example, wonder whether too many streams have been dammed by small hydropower projects or whether too many trees are being sacrificed for firewood or electricity generation. **********''Recycling of energy from waste potentially conflicts with recycling of materials from waste,'' observes Jonathan C. Gibson, a former Sierra Club official who is now manager of the Rutland County Solid Waste District in Vermont. ''Some of us are beginning to ask some pretty hard questions of ourselves.'' **********Akron's example in asserting control over the stream of waste within its borders is being followed by many of the dozen other communities that are now building their own waste-to-energy plants and the 175 more that plan to do so. Unless the courts intervene, it is likely that even New York City will follow suit. New York Legislation **********New York State has passed legislation allowing the city to enact flow-control authority after 1985. **********Recycling of paper is big business. Most of the nation's 700 paper and paperboard mills use some waste as a raw material and more than 200 of them rely exclusively on it. In all, about 18 million tons of paper products, about a quarter of United States consumption, are recycled each year. The pickup price ranges from about $20 a ton for newspapers to $150 for computer ''tab'' cards. Baling and processing doubles the mills' cost. **********A major question in the growing debate is whether ''waste'' should be defined as anything put out for disposal or, as the American Paper Institute would have it, whether recyclable materials should be excluded. **********This week, Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican, introduced a bill to amend the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act to require that waste-burning plants be designed so that they do not rely either on materials now being recycled or those that might be in the future. 'Critical' Carton Problem **********Although newspapers are probably the best-known source of recycled paper, Mr. Edwards says the ''most critical'' problem involves corrugated boxes from stores and supermarkets. While it is still permissible for store owners in Akron to separate their waste for private sale or donation, the city insists that even one banana peel in a truckload of boxes would subject the whole load to its control law. **********The Supreme Court has not yet ruled on the Akron case. Instead it sent it back to Federal District Court in Cleveland for rehearing based on the Court's ruling in a cable TV franchise case. That decision said that the grant of home rule by a state legislature to a municipality does not carry with it automatic immunity from Federal antitrust prosecution. **********It is doubtful that a decision upholding Akron-type flow-control laws would put many of the nation's 1,500 wastepaper dealers out of business. Rather, says Mr. Edwards, paper would simply become more expensive as collectors would have to travel farther afield to collect supplies. **********Added Paul D. Casowitz, New York City's deputy sanitation commissioner: ''There is more than enough paper out there. The question is how much you have to pay people to bring it to you.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; American Can Realigns Some Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/29/busin.body_text: **********The American Can Company, which has been moving out of some basic industries into financial services, announced yesterday that it had formed an office of the chairman intended to strengthen management. **********William S. Woodside, 61 years old, chairman and chief executive, will be joined by Frank J. Connor, 52, president and chief operating officer, and Gerald Tsai Jr., 54, the executive vice president, who will now have the title of vice chairman. **********The announcement puts Mr. Tsai in the top management rank and puts both men in a position to eventually succeed Mr. Woodside.  ''This is an important role and a promotion'' for Mr. Tsai, Mr.  Woodside said yesterday. ''There is no change for Mr. Connor, except that each will get a chance to work in areas of the business where they haven't.'' **********Mr. Woodside was the architect in 1981 of American Can's strategy to take a new direction. The company sought to balance some of its slow-grow th, capital-intensive industries with what they believed would be more profitable businesses. **********American Can, which has headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., has now sold off some $550 million of businesses, including most of its paper operations. It has redeployed that money into financial services and the companies it has bought are growing and generating income, Mr.  Woodside said. The company has labeled the asset redeployment a success. **********Mr. Tsai, who was an extraordinarily successful stock picker in the bull market of the 1960's, sold his mutual fund company in the late 1960's and controlled the Associated Madison insurance companies. He liked American Can's redeployment plan and suggested that it buy his insurance operation, which it did for $140 million in 1981. Mr. Tsai then became head of American Can's financial services. **********Mr. Woodside said yesterday that 65 was the obligatory retirement age at American Can and that he would leave at that time unless there was a special request from the board for him to stay. Mr. Tsai and Mr. Connor are ''obviously two prominent contenders'' for the top spot, he said.
