https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.main_headline: TURKS PLACE BAN ON OPINION POLLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.print_headline: TURKS PLACE BAN ON OPINION POLLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.body_text: **********Turkey's military rulers have banned all public opinion polls until after Sunday's national elections, apparently because the party they favor is shown to be running far behind. **********Polls published so far have shown the independent conservative Motherland Party, headed by Turgut Ozal, the architect of the Government's economic recovery program, to be comfortably ahead of the army-backed Nationalist Democracy Party, which is led by a retired general, Turgut Sunalp. The percentage of the undecided vote, however, is said to be high. **********President Kenan Evren, the general who led the military takeover three years ago, has carefully refrained from publicly backing any of the three political organizations officially authorized to take part in the Sunday elections. **********Nevertheless, the Nationalist Democracy Party has sought to give the impression that it has the backing of the military leadership. Reinforcing such an idea, the Prime Minister, Adm. Bulend Ulusu, and five Cabinet members are running under the banner of the Nationalist Democracy Party, which is widely referred to in Turkey as ''the generals' party.'' **********The third group in the race is the Populist Party, an officially inspired organization that has apparently been expected to serve as an opposition. It is led by Necdet Calp, a former under secretary to the Prime Minister.   A Generally Quiet Campaign **********It has been a generally quiet campaign, although some interest seems to have been stirred by the television appearances of the three party leaders in the last 10 days, with Mr. Ozal confident and relaxed. **********The main reason for the general mood of indifference, political experts say, is a widespread feeling that, with all candidates and party programs carefully screened by the military leadership, no real choice is being offered and little change can be expected, at least in the immediate future. **********Turkey's big business establishment, based in Istanbul, and some other conservative groups are said to feel relieved over what they view as the prospect that whoever wins the election is likely to pursue the general policies laid down by the military regime - tight control of law and order, strong support of private enterprise and restrictions on labor. **********At the same time, former politicians and the press have expressed impatience over the restrictions. A prominent Turkish editor, who asked not to be identified, said it was increasingly clear that the results of the balloting would be ''only the beginning of the transition period, which could last another five years, until the next parliamentary elections.'' **********The military leaders who seized power Sept. 12, 1980, with the declared aim of putting an end to political chaos, are continuing to focus on security problems and do not appear to be ready to take any chances. They have indicated that whatever the outcome of the election, martial law will be in force for some time.   Polls Published **********Last week, the independent daily newspaper Milliyet published a poll showing 37.7 percent of those questioned in favor of Mr. Ozal's Motherland Party, with the Populist Party second with 25.1 percent and the Nationalist Democracy Party last with only 14 percent. **********Last weekend, another popular daily, Gunaydin, published the results of a straw vote showing the Motherland Party well in the lead. The following day, the paper was suspended indefinitely. **********On Tuesday, the mass daily Hurriyet prepared to publish a scientifically prepared nationwide survey showing the Motherland Party ahead with 44 percent, the Nationalist Democracy Party second with 34 percent and the Populists third with 22 percent. But the military barred publication of the Hurriyet and any other surveys. **********Political commentators have refused to make predictions, noting that the former Justice and Republican People's Parties, which represented Turkey's traditional conservative and Social Democratic voting majority for 40 years, had been excluded from the elections. In addition, their leaders have been barred from politics for 10 years. **********No one claims to know what the supporters of these two parties will do on Sunday. Organizations called the True Path Party and the Social Democracy Party have been formed to replace the two traditional groups, but they are not being allowed to take part Sunday. **********A nationwide television debate last weekend showed the three officially sanctioned parties agreed that that Turkey's pro-Western foreign policy and its domestic policy of strict law and order measures should be continued. Leaders of all three parties also spoke out in favor of a free market economy with only slight differences of emphasis.   A Contest of Personalities **********It appears that the elections on Sunday will turn out to be a contest of personalities. Mr. Ozal is generally regarded as the most charismatic leader, with Mr. Sunalp appearing to stand for continuity of military rule. Mr. Calp, political experts says, tries hard to look like a Social Democrat. **********A large turnout is expected, in part because those not voting are liable to a fine of more than $10, not an insignificant sum for most Turks. A key question, political experts say, is how many blank or invalid ballots will be cast.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/24/world.main_headline: ARAFAT AGREES TO A TRIPOLI PULLOUT PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/24/world.print_headline: ARAFAT AGREES TO A TRIPOLI PULLOUT PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/24/world.body_text: **********A spokesman for Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestinian leader had agreed in principle to Saudi Arabian and Syrian proposals that he and all guerrillas, the insurgents as well as those loyal to him, leave Tripoli and its environs. **********But the spokesman, Ahmed Abdel Rahman, said that Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, insisted that the proposals must first be ''guaranteed'' at a meeting to be held at once by leaders of the P.L.O. and of some principal Arab countries, among them Syria, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Tunisia and Algeria. **********The proposals were also said to have called for an indefinite cease-fire between the two warring groups and for an agreement to save the unity of the P.L.O. by an understanding among all parties to end the armed conflict and to end the current crisis through ''democratic dialogue.'' **********(A rebel spokesman, Mahmoud Labadi, said in a broadcast from Damascus that the plan did not apply to the insurgents because they were not inside Tripoli, United Press International reported. Mr. Arafat then predicted at a news conference that the Palestinian rebels would invade the city in 24 to 48 hours.) **********Preparations Continue **********Both Arafat loyalists and foes continued to erect earthen barricades and reinforce their positions around downtown Tripoli today, in preparation for another possible round of heavy street fighting. **********Mr. Rahman said the P.L.O. leader received details at 3 A.M. of the plan to end the Tripoli crisis worked out in Damascus by the Syrian Foreign Minister, Abdel Halim Khaddam, and the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal. **********Two of Mr. Arafat's senior aides, Khalid al-Hassan and Rafiq Natshe, were in Damascus this evening working with Saudi and Syrian officials on the specific details for carrying out the plan, according to Arafat aides. **********The plan falls short of the conditions Mr. Arafat demanded 10 days ago for his withdrawal, so his conditional acceptance of it would seem to indicate a recognition on his part of his precarious military situation, as well as a desire to end the killings here.   Lull in the Fighting **********There was almost no fighting in Tripoli today, as the rebels gave more of the city's residents a chance to clear out in advance of any house-to-house fighting, as well as an opportunity for the Arab diplomatic efforts to run their course. The Arab countries, particularly Saudi Arabia, are understood to be desperate to save Mr. Arafat, not because they necessarily like him, but because they fear his death could set off widespread demonstrations and instability within their own countries. **********Reto Meister, the head of the Tripoli office of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said today that, according to data compiled by his staff a total of 438 people had been killed in the Tripoli fighting since it started Nov. 3 and 2,100 wounded. These figures include both civilians and combatants on both sides. **********Ahmed Jabril, who heads the Syrian- backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, has emerged in the last three weeks of fighting as the top rebel military commander. The other senior rebel officer, Col. Saed Musa, appears to have faded into the background, at least for the time being. **********Mr. Jabril indicated that he was not interested in any formula that would provide Mr. Arafat with an honorable exit or a chance to retain his leadership of the Palestinian movement through any ''democratic dialogue.''  Arafat Called 'Wanted Man' **********''We want to get Arafat out of Tripoli,'' said the 48-year-old Mr. Jabril, ''because we have decided in the Palestinian revolution to finish Arafat politically, militarily and symbolically.'' **********Once Mr. Arafat is out of Tripoli, Mr. Jabril said, ''he should be presented to a revolutionary tribunal that would take account of all his political and moral deviations during the last 18 years.'' **********Mr. Jabril added that, even if Mr. Arafat left Tripoli alive, he would remain ''a wanted man.'' **********Asked how the Palestinians living in the Beddawi refugee camp just northeast of Tripoli were accepting the rebels, Mr. Jabril hinted that there were some problems. **********Some indication of what he was talking about may have been given by an encounter between some of Mr. Jabril's guards and two women from the camp that a few reporters witnessed by accident. **********The two women, both of whom appeared to be in their late 20's, walked up to the gate of two small apartment blocks that were once the home of senior pro-Arafat officials in the camp but are now being used by Mr. Jabril's men as a barracks and command center.   'Shame on You!' **********One of the women told the guards that her apartment was on the ground floor of one of the buildings and that she had come to see how it had survived the last three weeks of combat. At first the guard told her to go away, but after some argument he agreed to let her go in and look around, provided she did not remove anything. **********After about a minute, one of the women returned, sobbing and shrieking at the guards. Her apartment had been looted and trashed. **********''Shame on you! Shame on you!'' she screamed. ''You tell me not to remove anything - there is nothing left to remove. For 10 years we worked - 10 years. For what? For this? Everything is gone!'' **********The guards sat stony-faced and the woman, her fists clenched in anger, screamed: ''We are not Jews! We are not Jews! Why did you do this to us?'' **********Finally, one of the guards, who was cradling a Kalashnikov, jumped up and said: ''Look, it's not only your home. I can take you to my home, too, and you will see it destroyed. You should just thank God that you're alive.'' **********Tears streaming down her cheeks, the woman wailed: ''It would be better if I were dead. I worked 10 years for that, and now there is nothing.'' **********U.N. Urges a Cease-Fire **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 - The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution tonight that deplored ''the considerable loss of human life'' caused by the fighting in northern Lebanon and called on the warring parties ''immediately to accept a cease- fire.'' **********It was the first diplomatic action taken by the United Nations since the fighting began in northern Lebanon. France requested the meeting. **********The resolution, sponsored by Algeria, Egypt, France and Jordan, did not mention either the Palestine Liberation Organization or Syria and was described by Security Council members as so moderate in its language that it was achieved in a brief meeting without speeches. **********Lebanese officials sought to toughen the resolution by insisting on language emphasizing ''the strict respect for the sovereignty, political independence and territorial integrity'' of their country. A member of the Lebanese Mission said the position of his Government remained clear, ''To solve the problem you need the withdrawal of all unauthorized foreign forces.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/world.main_headline: OLD FRENCH FEUD IS BACK: WHO WILL RUN SCHOOLS?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/world.print_headline: OLD FRENCH FEUD IS BACK: WHO WILL RUN SCHOOLS?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/world.body_text: **********From Lille in the north to Marseilles in the south, thousands of people have taken to the streets in protest in recent weeks. But not, as in Britain and West Germany, against cruise missiles and Pershing 2's. A commentator here said, ''It's just another battle in France's oldest war.'' **********The argument, which goes back 200 years to the French Revolution, is over who should educate French children and how. **********On Oct. 22, some 100,000 people marched in Nantes in support of private schools. A month later, in the same city, almost as many marched against private schools. In Paris, in Marseilles, in Toulouse, in Rodez, in Lille, the story has been the same. **********The French are hoping, finally, for a showdown over national educational policy. They probably will be disappointed. ''Ecole libre,'' or ''Free school,'' has been a Socialist rallying cry since Jules Ferry, the founder of the modern French educational system and himself a Socialist, decreed in 1882 that primary education in France would henceforth be ''free, nonclerical, and obligatory.'' It is a goal that has yet to be realized. The Roman Catholic Church and conservative groups have never permitted the private school system to disappear. **********Just after the May 1981 elections, when the Socialists captured not only the presidency but also the National Assembly, it looked as if the old goal was finally within reach. But the Government of Francois Mitterrand put education on a back burner while it pursued economic goals.   Education Plan Published **********A preliminary school plan was made public last December and a final version was published in October. Called the Savary project, after its author, Minister of Education Alain Savary, it is a long way from the fiery anticlerical talk of the summer of 1981. **********For one thing, polls indicate that 71 percent of the French people support the dual educational system of both public and private schools. For another, a series of local elections around the country in recent months have shown a strong movement away from the left. The Socialist Goverment's time for radical change may have passed. **********Most notably, the Savary project in no way signals an end to the private school system. It talks instead of education being ''national without being uniform,'' and proposes an extended program of changes in which the easiest problems, such as conflicting school calendars, will be solved first and fundamental differences, such as how teachers will be paid, will be left until 1986. **********Bruno Frappat, writing in Le Monde, went so far as to say the plan ''renounces the old ideal of one single school system.'' **********The Savary project has pleased no one and has particularly irritated the strongest supporters of the public school system, including two powerful teachers' organizations and various unions that have banned together under an umbrella group called the National Committee for Lay Action. They have accused the Government of backing off on its promise to nationalize the private education sector as forcefully and dramatically as it did the major banks.   Freedom From Control **********The defenders of the dual system, principally the Catholic church, have adopted the ''Ecole libre'' slogan, but to them it means freedom from bureaucratic harassment and control. **********This move brought a bitter response from Michel Bouchareissais, secretary general of the National Committee for Lay Action. For the private schools, he said, ''free means that they are free to reject immigrants, free to refuse atheists and divorcees, free to dispose of public funds with no controls whatsoever.'' **********The moderate tone of the Savary project has heartened the private schools considerably. The Rev. Paul Guiberteau, secretary general of the National Committee for Catholic Education, while noting that the text of the plan is ''complex and ambiguous,'' acknowledged that it did provide grounds for discussion.   Millions in Private Schools **********As of last fall, about one-sixth of France's student population, or just over two million students, were in private schools, from the preschool level through the French equivalent of high school. In general, they pay no tuition. Of the two million, about 93 percent were in Catholic schools. The rest are mostly in academically demanding secondary schools or in schools run by other religious denominations. There are, for instance, 50 Jewish schools in France with a total of about 13,000 students. **********The reason most often advanced by parents for switching children to private school is much the same as that usually given in the United States: lower standards in the public schools. **********The French Government pays salaries and benefits for all teachers, in both private and public schools. Teachers in private schools are paid under two formulas. Under the ''simple contract,'' they work for the school; under the ''contract of association,'' they work directly for the state, as do the public school teachers. The contract of association applies to schools that fulfill ''a recognized educational need,'' such as being the only school in a specific area. **********The operational costs of private schools are borne by the schools themselves under the simple contract, although the local governments often contribute. Under the contract by association, the local governments pay operating costs for elementary schools and the national Government pays for secondary and vocational schools. The more exclusive private schools, which are not part of the system, pay their own way. **********The system theoretically gives the Government wide powers in setting standards for teachers and the material they teach. In practice, opponents of the private schools say, public funds are turned over to the private institutions, mainly the Catholic church, with virtually no strings attached. **********The Savary project would give the Government more say in appointing the directors of all schools, public and private, a system the private schools find unacceptable. ''They have something similar to that in the Netherlands,'' a Jewish spokesman here said. ''Consequently there are Jewish schools where the headmaster is not even Jewish.'' The Savary project would provide for simple changes such as correlating the school calendars of public and private schools and for fundamental changes in the training and continuing education of private-school teachers. It would require that experiments and new methods being tried in public schools be tried out in private institutions as well. **********All of which embitters the militant laicists, as the opponents of private schools are called. For them, the solution to France's educational problems is the end of all public support for private schools.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/world.main_headline: POLES TO FREE 476, BUT STILL HOLD 60 LABOR ACTIVISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/world.print_headline: POLES TO FREE 476, BUT STILL HOLD 60 LABOR ACTIVISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/world.body_text: **********The Justice Ministry said today that it was releasing 476 political prisoners under the limited amnesty, but that 60 Solidarity figures would remain in prison. **********The United States has said that the release of prisoners jailed for political reasons would be its main test in determining whether economic sanctions imposed after the martial law takeover on Dec. 13, 1981, should be eased. **********The amnesty was announced as part of the end of martial law on July 21. But the Roman Catholic Church, the underground opposition and Solidarity's founder, Lech Walesa, have charged that new, repressive legislation took the place of martial law and that the amnesty was incomplete. **********The situation has been confused by fragmentary Government announcements. Today the television news said, for example, that 6,000 people had ''benefited'' from the amnesty. **********Deputy Justice Minister Tadeusz Skora, who is administering the program, said in an interview this week that, while 3,578 people had been ''covered by the amnesty'' as of Tuesday, the total number released was 781. Today's news broadcast put those released at 795. **********The terms of the amnesty cover those convicted of ''unpremeditated common crimes'' as well as those charged with what are regarded as political offenses. Mr. Skora said the common crimes were mainly traffic violations that led to serious accidents. **********The amnesty is not a total forgiveness, but closer to what would be considered probation. If a prisoner who has been given amnesty repeats the original act, the person will be returned for the rest of the sentence in addition to being charged with a new offense. **********The total figures are incomplete since the program will run until Aug. 21, Mr. Skora said. **********When asked about the 60 Solidarity activists who would not be given amnesty, Mr. Skora said that an example would be a person who might have led a strike in the Katowice steel mills. Others who appear to be in this category would include Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, the captured underground leader from Wroclaw, and the organizers of Solidarity's clandestine radio. **********In addition the Government will proceed with the trials of seven Solidarity leaders and five dissident intellectuals on charges of trying to overthrow the system. **********The 781 people released from jail so far, Mr. Skora said, include 124 political prisoners who were granted full amnesty, 23 political prisoners who had served the length of terms that had been reduced by amnesty and 29 political prisoners serving out misdemeanor sentences. **********The group also included 135 common criminals granted full amnesty, 16 common criminals who had served out reduced sentences and 47 common criminals let out on humanitarian grounds, according to ministry figures. **********The remaining 407 people had been held under investigation or awaiting trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.main_headline: LEBANESE ARMY FIGHTS A 3D DAY AT FRENCH POSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.print_headline: LEBANESE ARMY FIGHTS A 3D DAY AT FRENCH POSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.body_text: **********For a third successive day, Lebanese Army units battled today with Moslem militiamen opposing their takeover of positions abandoned by the French around Shatila, a Palestinian refugee camp on the southern edge of the capital. **********Mortars, rockets and tank fire shook the southern suburbs, and buildings were set ablaze. Estimates of the death toll over the last three days ranged from 20 to over 50. **********A cease-fire was supposed to have been arranged this afternoon, but the firing did not ease until dusk. It was not clear how long the truce would hold. **********How Fighting Began **********The fighting started on Saturday when French units of the multinational force pulled out of two areas after bomb and sniper attacks on their positions. **********The French handed the areas over to the Lebanese Army, which the Shiite Moslem militiamen controlling much of southern Beirut regard as allied with one of their principal foes, the Christian Phalangist militia. The Shiites fear, Arab officials and analysts said, that the army's advance into areas under their control will enable the Phalangists to expand their zone of influence.  In an interview tonight that underscored an atmosphere of gathering crisis among the Shiites, one of their leaders, Nabih Berri, asserted that his Amal militia had not opposed the army's takeover of the French positions and that the army had started the clashes. Speaking of the fighting today, he said his followers were attacked and ''I decided to answer.'' **********Mr. Berri said he saw the latest Lebanese Army maneuver as a possible preliminary to a major attack on the Shiite-dominated southern suburbs. ''I do not have any intention to attack, but if they do it, I will fight,'' he said. **********An aide at his headquarters, Hussein Fawaz, said that if the army stormed the southern suburbs, ''We will defend ourselves and the whole country will be destroyed.'' **********He said the French and American contingents in the four-nation force were behind the Lebanese army tactics. France and the United States are training Lebanese Army units to try to strengthen the central Government and help it extend its control to areas of Beirut and the hills surrounding it that are under the influence of militias. **********Apart from the recent fighting, the Shiites say they have been unsettled by a steady buildup of Lebanese Army forces close to their positions. **********''They are moving tanks toward us,'' Mr. Fawaz said. A reporter who visited Mr. Berri's heavily guarded West Beirut residence tonight saw a convoy of the Lebanese Army's American-built armored personnel carriers moving south through the city. Their destination was not known. **********Shiite Buildings Under Fire **********Lebanese Army units used barrages of tank and heavy machine-gun fire today on buildings occupied by Shiite militiamen, and the Shiites fired mortars from apartment buildings at Government positions. **********During one army drive to reinforce forward positions, troops crouched low over their weapons as they advanced through nearly empty streets until sniper fire forced them to take cover. Smoke billowed from buildings attacked in the contest. In Shiite areas, apartment dwellers fled to their basements, pressing together in the gloom seeking safety. **********The fighting is said by many residents to be the worst in the Beirut area since the army and Shiite militiamen fought a three-day battle in September. ''The army's advance into Shatila has strengthened their position and the Shiites don't like that,'' one Arab diplomat said. **********Italian troops from the international force were pinned down in their positions at Shatila and its neighboring refugee camp, Sabra, an Italian spokesman said, but the 1,800 marines in the United States contingent were not involved in the fighting. **********''There was some spillover from the east but we did not return the fire,'' a Marine spokesman said. The marines are guarding Beirut airport and have taken sporadic stray fire at least twice in the last three days. **********Among the many incongruities of this city, civilian aircraft from Lebanon's Middle East Airlines continued to land and take off within earshot of the battles despite the fact that a shell hit a runway. **********Airline officials said there were few passengers today because the road to the airport was too dangerous for most travellers. **********Close to the airport, military officials said, a Lebanese Army truck was ambushed. The casualties were not known.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/busin.body_text: **********THE economic outlook for 1984 is good here at home and in the world economy generally. **********But there are clouds on the horizon. **********The Center for Business Cycle Research at Columbia University reports that the leading indexes of business activity are rising at annual rates of 19 percent in Canada, 16 percent in the United States and 13 percent in Japan and France. They are rising at a more moderate 8 percent rate in West Germany, 5 percent in Italy and 3 percent in Britain. **********Interpreting these numbers, the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization, forecasts the growth rates of the six foreign countries to level out at an annual rate of about 7 percent, and the United States to slow to a 4 to 5 percent rate. Those figures are roughly consistent with the expectations of the Reagan Administation, which is forecasting United States economic growth, adjusted for inflation, of 4.5 percent in 1984 as the basis for its coming budget. **********In other countries, a group of 22 financial editors and writers, surveyed by Robert Bendiner for World Press Review magazine, also expects better economic conditions next year. Three-fourths of the financial journalists said they were ''more hopeful'' about world economic prospects than they were a year ago. **********But, when asked whether the recent upturn in the United States had increased their confidence in President Reagan's economic policies, 55 percent said no and 45 percent said yes. B. Kamau Kaniaru of The Daily Nation in Nairobi, Kenya, said: ''President Reagan has done only what any other President should have done - stop the rot from getting worse, at least in the United States. But he seems quite oblivious to economic disaster in the rest of the world.'' **********''The problems and dangers of his deficit-spending policy are still relevant,'' said Hartmut Froels, executive editor of the business weekly Wirtschaftswoche of D"usseldorf, West Germany. Anne Bower of The Financial Post of Toronto said: ''Looking back, there must have been a better way to bring inflation down than to kill so many jobs.'' **********Stephen Mulholland, editor of the of The Financial Mail of Johannesburg, was more enthusiastic about Mr. Reagan's economic policies. ''Based on the swing away from demand management and welfarism and toward supply-side economics,'' Mr. Mulholland said, ''I expect that we will see a prolonged upswing in the 80's.'' **********The darkest cloud hanging over the world economy, according to the financial journalists, is the debt burden in the third world and Eastern Europe. **********Many business economists also say the world debt is the No. 1 problem. F. Taylor Ostrander, economic consultant to AMAX Inc., told a recent minerals conference in Washington that, in the face of the gravest threat to world financial stability since 1931, the International Monetary Fund was trying ''valiantly'' to exert discipline on the debtor countries and to use ''the medicine of money to enforce what a pragmatic family physician might prescribe for economic ills.'' **********But he warned that the I.M.F.'s resources were limited and had just missed being undermined by a populist reaction in the United States Congress. **********The other major threats to the world economy, the journalists said, were the strong American dollar resulting from high interest rates; the spread of protectionism; technological unemployment; strains between the United States and the Soviet Union, and concern over future energy sources. **********The greatest negative factor in the United States economy, they said, was the high level of military expenditures, followed by the disparity between wages and labor productivity, the low proportion of private savings to personal income, recent Federal tax cuts and the increasing costs of social services. **********While there is strong consensus among the financial journalists and business economists that the American economy will continue expanding in the coming year, many are worried about its sustainability beyond 1984. ''The surprising strength of the recovery and Washington's inability to curb huge deficits cast a shadow upon the 1984 economy,'' says Francis H. Schott, chief economist of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. He thinks interest rates are likely to rise by late 1984 to the point where a cyclical setback in 1985 is probable. **********Similarly, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development expressed reservations on whether the recovery could be sustained in the United States and Europe, with a major question mark the ability of the United States to reduce its fiscal and external imbalance. **********Thus there is widespread confidence that the upswing in the business cycle will continue in 1984 and equally widespread concern that it will run into trouble if this country does not do something about its outsized budget deficits. **********So, here's to a happy '84 and, to keep it rolling, a healthy budget plan for the fiscal years '85 to '89!

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.main_headline: 79 FEARED LOST ON U.S. SHIP OFF CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.print_headline: 79 FEARED LOST ON U.S. SHIP OFF CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.body_text: **********A United States oil drilling ship that broke its moorings in a typhoon and disappeared early Wednesday in the South China Sea has apparently been found sunk with no survivors spotted so far, Western oil industry sources said here today. **********The ship, the 5,930-ton Glomar Java Sea, had been leased by the Atlantic Richfield Corporation to look for oil under a contract awarded by China. Its last position given was southeast of the Chinese island of Hainan. **********The New China News Agency, in confirming reports of the ship's disappearance, said Thursday that 79 persons were aboard the drilling ship. Other sources have put the number at 80 or 81. **********The ship was spotted 300 feet below the surface of the water, the sources said. A lifeboat was also seen, but there was no indication that it held any of the crew. **********Richard Vermier, a spokesman for the Global Marine Drilling Company, which owns the ship, said in Houston Thursday that 42 Americans were aboard. But the industry sources today said about 25 were Chinese, suggesting that the number of Americans might have been higher. **********The ship, which had stopped drilling before it was hit by the tropical storm, reported in its final radio message on Wednesday that it was listing to 15 degrees starboard. A vessel from Singapore subsequently reported picking up a faint distress signal, which indicated that the ship was about 60 miles off course. **********The Chinese had mounted an extensive search for the vessel, dispatching 11 naval and commercial ships as well as some aircraft. They were joined by at least one United States Navy reconnaissance plane from the Philippines. **********The location where the drilling ship apparently sank has not been disclosed, but the industry sources believed it was near the 3,500-square- mile block that China awarded to Arco for drilling 13 months ago. The New China News Agency suggested yesterday that the ship might have been carried by winds and currents toward the waters claimed by Vietnam southwest of Hainan. **********The 400-foot ship, which is capable of drilling to a depth of five miles, was dispatched to Chinese waters after Arco in September 1982 became the first United States oil company to be allowed by the Chinese to drill for offshore oil. It crossed the Pacific and arrived last January. **********The Chinese press reported earlier this week that in the last six months, Arco completed two exploratory wells south of Hainan, one of which was expected to yield 1.2 million cubic meters of natural gas a day. **********The China National Offshore Oil Corporation was quoted by the New China News Agency Thursday as saying that the drilling ship had disappeared in ''a typhoon of hurricane force.'' **********''Judging from the wind and water flow at the time, it said, the American drilling ship most probably has drifted west of the Yingge Sea,'' the New China News Agency reported. The Yingge Sea is the Chinese name for the waters south of Hainan and west of Vietnam. **********China decided to invite Western oil companies in to explore for offshore oil to accelerate its modernization drive and generate more hard currency. Over 40 foreign oil companies have done exploratory work off China's coast though not all have been awarded contracts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/07/world.main_headline: STATE DEPT. AIDES SAID TO QUESTION ACTS IN NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/07/world.print_headline: STATE DEPT. AIDES SAID TO QUESTION ACTS IN NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/07/world.body_text: **********High-ranking State Department officials raised questions in White House meetings last week about the legality of United States involvement in covert military operations against Nicaragua, according to Reagan Administration officials. **********By law, the Administration is barred from taking any actions ''for the purpose of overthrowing the Government of Nicaragua.'' The questions were raised by policy makers and legal experts high in the department hierarchy. Their point was said to be that, contrary to law and to agreed Administration policy, guerrilla actions in Nicaragua supported by the Central Intelligence Agency and the United States military had gone beyond efforts to block supplies from Nicaragua to Salvadoran insurgents and could be seen as intended to overthrow the Sandinist Government in Nicaragua. **********U.S. Directly Involved **********These concerns, along with more vigorous charges by a number of senators, were brought to the attention of the White House in several meetings last week. But according to Administration officials, no decisions were made to curtail the operations. **********The concern in the State Department seems to have been provoked by reports about covert operations in Nicaragua and warnings by several key senators over possible violations of the law. **********One senior official said the danger that the operations might take on ''larger proportions'' should have been foreseen but was not.  Another said that the spillover effect was understood at the outset, at least by some officials, and that they had suggested that the Administration oppose legislation that would bar efforts to overthrow the Sandinist Government. This suggestion was rejected because it would have been too controversial, the official said. U.S. Involvement Confirmed **********According to the official, this in effect put the United States in the position of protecting the Sandinist Government if operations were restrained, or possibly violating the law as operations inevitably expanded. **********The officials confirmed a report last week that the Central Intelligence Agency and the American military were directly involved in planning, arming and advising paramilitary forces based in Honduras and were providing them with intelligence data. **********They said the State Department officials had not argued that the C.I.A. and the American military were deliberately acting contrary to policy. Rather, they suggested that in carrying out the policy at this stage, it was almost impossible not to cross the bounds of legality from the interdiction of arms supplies to the destabilization of the Nicaraguan Government. Activities Stepped Up **********The policy approved by the President, the officials said, was to block supplies from Nicaragua to the Salvadoran guerrillas, to attack Cubans and the Cuban ''infrastructure'' in Nicaragua and in general to increase the costs to Nicaragua of backing the insurgency in El Salvador. Earlier this year, the State Department endorsed a decision to step up the interdiction, the officials said. **********Another complicating factor, according to the officials, is the attempt to control the operations of the contras, as the anti-Sandinist guerrillas call themselves. ''The contras' aims and actions may not be the same as ours,'' one key Administration official said. C.I.A. Officials Concerned **********The prohibition against efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government is laid out in an amendment to a catchall appropriations bill approved by Congress last December. ''None of the funds provided in this act,'' it says, ''may be used by the Central Intelligence Agency or the Department of Defense to furnish military equipment, military training or advice, or other support for military activities, to any group or individual, not part of the country's armed forces, for the purpose of overthrowing the Government of Nicaragua or provoking a military exchange between Nicaragua and Honduras.'' **********A number of C.I.A. officials are also said to have expressed concern that the covert operations might have gone beyond the limitations stated in Presidential documents and in intelligence briefings to Congressional committees. By law, the President is required to notify House and Senate Intelligence Committees of covert actions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.main_headline: U.S. Accuses 4 of Real Estate Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.print_headline: U.S. Accuses 4 of Real Estate Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.body_text: **********A Federal grand jury today indicted four men accused of mail, securities and tax frauds that the indictment says cost some 250 investors more than $5 million. **********United States Attorney Peter F. Vaira said the charges resulted from an 18-month investigation, jointly conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Internal Revenue Service. **********The four men indicted were all officers or employees of the bankrupt Fidelity America Finance Company or its subsidiary, the Federal America Mortgage Company, also bankrupt. They were charged, among other things, with running a fraudulent real estate limited partnership tax shelter. **********Among the people who lost money, according to the indictment, were Robert Armstrong, chairman of the Revlon Corporation, and three professional hockey players, including Ron Greschner of the New York Rangers. **********Indicted were Howard I. Green of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., who was president of the finance company and chairman of the mortgage company; John Berg of Blue Ball, Pa., who was president of the mortgage company; Eugene O'Donnell of Haverford, Pa., who was an employee of the mortgage company, and Gilbert Tucker of Tamarac, Fla., a business consultant. **********Mr. Vaira said the Federal America Mortgage Company sold limited partnerships in a Philadelphia apartment complex to 18 investors in 1979, including Mr. Armstrong and the hockey players. But the firm did not purchase the property by the end of the year, Mr. Vaira said, even though it provided the investors with details that helped them to claim a tax shelter on their 1979 tax returns. The investors did not realize the information was fraudulent, he said. **********The apartment complex was actually purchased in 1980. But it was transferred in 1981 to American Real Estate Associates, a company controlled by Mr. Berg. The indictment said the purpose of the transfer was to avoid scrutiny when the mortgage company declared bankruptcy. **********Richard Oppenheim, a financial adviser from Morganville, N.J., and Harvey P. Murray Jr., formerly a vice president of the mortgage company, have pleaded guilty in the case and are awaiting sentencing. **********Mr. Berg, Mr. Green and Mr. O'Donnell were also charged with fraudulent misrepresentations in the sale of $891,000 worth of industrial revenue bonds. According to the indictments, the bonds were never approved by the industrial development authorities, although the Fidelity America Finance Company said they were.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/01/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Gunmen in Colombia Kill 2 American Bus Riders
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/01/world.body_text: **********A band of armed men stopped a bus in northeast Colombia on Tuesday, dragged three Americans off the vehicle and killed two of them and wounded the third, the police said today. A police spokesman said the murders appeared to have been committed by drug traffickers. **********The incident occurred east of here on a highway between Riohacha and Santa Marta, the authorities said. A United States Embassy official in Bogota confirmed the two deaths. **********The two killed were Gerald Burgion, 26 years old, and Charles Krauskrap, 27. The wounded American was identified as James McKenzie, 25, who was recovering at a hospital here. **********The police spokesman said the bus had been stopped by four men in a jeep, who then dragged the three Americans from the vehicle and shot them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Unusual Spotlight For Clarendon Aide **********Throughout the Federal court hearings to determine the tax liability of the company once owned by the fugitive commodity trader Marc Rich, Peter F. Ryan, the 43-year-old chief financial officer of Clarendon Ltd., the company spun off from Marc Rich, has been the only United States- born senior officer of the concern in court to talk about the Rich group's elaborate dealings. **********Last week, Judge Richard Owen accidentally referred to Mr. Ryan as Mr. Rich, an error Mr. Ryan quickly corrected. For Mr. Ryan is not on trial and has not been accused of any illegal activity but, like Marc Rich, he enjoyed a low public profile prior to this case. **********During cross-examination Mr. Ryan has had to disclose facts that persons in the commodity trading business normally do not discuss with strangers. For instance, he said he is paid $275,000 a year by Clarendon and in January his company bonus added $200,000 to that. In addition, he owns nine shares of the 14,000 outstanding in the Switzerland-based company of Marc Rich A.G., shares he valued at between $150,000 to $200,000. He also owns nine of 14,000 outstanding shares in the Guam Oil and Refining Company, another Marc Rich company. Moreover, he is president of three concerns affliated with the Marc Rich network - Richco Grains, Richco Sugar and Richco Capital - and vice president of the Brownstone Commodities Corporation, the commodity futures trading arm of Marc Rich. **********Before joining the Rich group in April of 1980, Mr. Ryan spent about 10 years in various positions at Chase Manhattan Bank, which has the operating account for Clarendon. While at Chase, Mr. Ryan was responsible for one-third of the business in the commodity financing department, which he said had a profit of about $25 million before he left. **********But Mr. Ryan's financial career path has not always been vertical. The Williams College graduate interrupted his term at Chase, which began in 1962, to buy a farm in Rutland, Vt., where he spent his time ''farming and doing some real estate investment.'' When he quit farming, he went to South Carolina and joined a textile trading company owned by his family. He left that job in 1972, came back to New York and worked in the Bureau of the Budget of the City of New York and was an assistant administrator for management in the Parks Recreation, Cultural Affairs Adminstraion before rejoining Chase in 1974.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/09/world.print_headline: LEBANESE REACTION MUTED; DAMAGE TO TALKS IS FEARED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/09/world.body_text: **********Lebanese reaction to the report by an Israeli commission on the killing of Palestinians at two camps in Beirut in September was muted but there was concern among officials here over possible repercussions on the negotiations on the withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign forces from Lebanon. **********The Lebanese Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan, said he would let the world judge Israel for the massacres at Sabra and Shatila.  Government officials said privately they were worried that the commission's conclusions would upset political life in Israel to such an extent that the United States-sponsored talks under way between Lebanon and Israel since December would be affected. Another round of talks was held today by Lebanese, Israeli and American representatives in Beirut's southern suburb of Khalde. **********Phalangist Refuses Comment **********Palestinians were generally skeptical about the findings of the three-man Israeli panel headed by Justice Yitzhak Kahan, and demanded that Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, whose dismissal the report recommended, be put on trial. **********A spokesman for the Christian Phalangists, who were responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Palestinian men, women and children at Sabra and Shatila, refused to comment on the report. **********The spokesman, Radi Hayek, said he was waiting for results of investigations by the Lebanese authorities. ''This is what concerns the Lebanese,'' he said. **********The man in charge of the Lebanese investigation, Assad Germanos, the military prosecutor, said today that he expected his report to be ready in March or April and that it would be up to the Government to decide whether to make it public. Mr. Germanos, who has been conducting a criminal investigation into the killings, refused to discuss the Israeli inquiry's conclusions. Residents Appear Unimpressed **********The Israeli commission pinned direct responsibility for the massacres on the Phalangist-controlled Christian militiamen known as the Lebanese Forces, but cited the negligence of several Israeli military and political figures as having in part led to the massacre. **********Inhabitants at the two camps appeared unimpressed by the findings of the Israeli investigating team. Abu Isam, a 45-year-old grocer, said it was a cover-up and that if there was justice, both Mr. Sharon and Prime Minister Menachem Begin would be tried for mass murder and executed. **********A 50-year-old housewife who said that two of her teen-age sons were murdered on Sept. 16 called Mr. Begin ''another Hitler,'' and Mr.  Sharon ''worse than the Nazis.'' She added, ''The report is not going to bring my children back.'' **********In Amman, Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said the inquiry conclusions were important but incomplete. Mr. Arafat, who is holding talks with King Hussein of Jordan, said they did not include a decisive condemnation of Prime Minister Begin and members of his Government ''who are involved, with American support, in the shameful massacre.'' Sharon 'Terrorized' and 'Bullied' **********Mr. Arafat's remarks were carried by Wafa, the P.L.O.'s press agency. In an interview on British television, Mr. Arafat had said an international court ought to be set up to try Israelis and Americans for the massacre. **********A Lebanese newspaper editor said no one would be sorry to see Mr.  Sharon go. ''He has terrorized the Moslems and Palestinians, and bullied the Christians,'' said the editor, who did not want to be identified. **********Mr. Sharon is hated by the Moslems for ordering the six-week siege and bombardment of Moslem West Beirut during the Israeli invasion last summer. **********Now he is being attacked by the Christians whom he had considered Israel's allies in Lebanon.  Al Amal, the daily organ of the Phalangist Party, charged in an editorial today that Mr. Sharon had ordered his troops to help Druse in the mountains east of here against the Christians. Minister Blamed for Defeat **********The newspaper blamed him for the defeat of Christian militiamen in the town of Aleih nine miles east of Beirut two days ago at the hands of the Druse. **********It linked the development to a meeting the Israeli Defense Minister had 10 days ago with the Phalangist Party chief, Pierre Gemayel, the father of Amin Gemayel, the President of Lebanon. **********Mr. Sharon was reported to have warned the Phalangist chief that unless the Lebanese Government cooperated with Israel at the talks on the withdrawal of foreign troops, the Israeli Army would end its support for Lebanese Christians and leave them to their fate. **********Camille Chamoun, a former President who heads the Christian Lebanese Front, called Mr. Sharon ''the evil genius'' of the Israeli Government. Mr. Chamoun's daily newspaper, Al Ahrar, has been attacking the Israeli Defense Minister in daily front-page editorials. Today it accused him of collusion with Syria in schemes to partition Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/19/busin.main_headline: MIDAS LEADS GROWTH IN REPAIR OF MUFFLERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/19/busin.print_headline: MIDAS LEADS GROWTH IN REPAIR OF MUFFLERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/19/busin.body_text: **********The Midas International Corporation, propelled by rising auto costs, motorists who are keeping their cars longer, and the public's disenchantment with the old-style repair industry, has become the McDonald's of muffler retailers. **********With a vast chain of repair shops offering clean, quick service to the public and a good profit to its franchise owners, Midas has captured 26 percent of the highly competitive $1.3 billion American exhaust repair market. **********The 27-year-old company manufactures its own mufflers and exhaust pipes and maintains 1,714 outlets worldwide, including 1,300 throughout the 50 states. **********Nearest Competitors **********Midas's nearest competitors, Meineke Discount Mufflers and Speedy Muffler King, have 460 and 346 shops, respectively. **********And there is apparently room for everyone. The United States, according to the companies, is about to experience a muffler shop explosion. Midas plans to open 700 new shops in the next five years, and Meineke is planning another 200 in half that time. **********In 1982, Midas, a subsidiary of IC Industries, a consumer products, real estate and railroad conglomerate, reported earnings from continuing operations of $31 million on sales of $246 million. **********The growth of Midas and the industry has been spurred in part by a trend in which consumers are increasingly relying on specialty shops to repair their cars. According to some industry estimates, 36 percent of exhaust repairs now take place in specialty muffler shops compared to 24 percent in 1976. And many Midas shops are now offering brakes and shock absorber repairs and replacements. The average bill, company officials say, runs about $75. **********Operating costs are lower and vehicle turnover higher in shops that do these kinds of repairs, compared to those that do tune- ups, overhauls and other more elaborate work. Brake, shock absorber and muffler work can be performed relatively quickly and they do not require sophisticated electronic equipment. The training of mechanics is easier than for general repairs and salaries are commensurately lower. **********.''Its lucrative, anyone can install a muffler, with very little training, and make a lot of money at it, said Jay Steinfeld, vice president of Meineke. **********In the aftermath of the 1973 Arab oil embargo, many gasoline stations either went out of business or dropped their repair services to concentrate on selling gasoline. Meanwhile, rising prices of new cars and high interest rates have prompted many automobile owners to hold onto their cars longer, requiring that they spend more money on repairs. **********Furthermore, Midas officials estimate that between 13 and 30 percent of the cars on the road will need exhaust work each year. In Chicago, where cars are exposed to a fair amount of cold, snow and salt, between 20 to 25 percent of the cars will need muffler repairs this year. **********Meineke, a low-cost muffler chain that opened its franchise operation in 1974 sold about 150 franchises this year, at an average price of $65,000 each. A Midas franchise costs an average of $145,000. **********Speedy Muffler King, a unit of Chicago area-based Tenneco Automotive that primarily operates in Canada and the Northeast, also expects to expand its network of company-owned sites, but its officials declined to release estimates. **********Midas introduced the franchising concept to muffler repairs in 1956 at about the same time that Ray Kroc, in the Chicago suburbs, began his chain of fast-food restaurants under the McDonald's name. At the time, Nate Sherman, the son of the head of a family-owned muffler manufacturing concern, was looking for a way to bypass distributors and sell directly to consumers. **********Part of the success of Midas has been its apparent ability to overcome customer dissatisfaction with existing repair shops. Consumer surveys continually show that many car owners do not understand the mechanics of their car and often believe that repair shops overcharge for their work, do sloppy or inadequate work and often perform unnecessary repairs. **********In contrast, Midas began offering clean, well-lit repair shops with large windows so that customers could see their cars being worked on. Customers were allowed to inspect underneath their cars and were given a written estimate beforehand so they understood the extent of the repair work. **********''We have a 'show and tell' marketing program,'' said John R. Moore, president and chief executive officer of Midas. ''We try to get the customer involved with the decision. We show him what's wrong with the car.'' **********Mr. Moore also said that exhaust repairs, well done, can inspire customer confidence and create an opportunity for additional repair work. ''When a muffler or tailpipe is gone, you know it,'' said Mr. Moore. ''And when it is fixed that, too, is obvious.'' **********Midas was the first exhaust repair shop to offer free replacement of its installed mufflers as long as the customer owned the car. Mr. Moore said that the guarantee helps reinforce the idea that Midas is offering a quality muffler, and virtually all the major chains now offer a similar guarantee. Only 17 percent of mufflers installed by Midas are replaced under the guarantee, Mr. Moore added. **********The guarantee also serves another purpose in that it brings back the customer to the Midas shop if anything goes wrong with the exhaust system, a Midas spokesman explained. And once a car is back in the shop, the mechanic might spot other problems that need repairs offered by Midas, such as shock absorbers and brakes. Executives at other muffler shops said that they offered the guarantee for the same reasons. **********In contrast to Midas and Speedy Muffler King, Meineke's advertising stresses its discount prices. Mr. Steinfeld estimates that the concern's outlets can install mufflers for about 20 percent less than Midas. Mr. Moore believes that prices at Midas are ''comparable'' with the discount shops. **********The difference in marketing approaches, however, is readily apparent in the television commercials each runs. The latest Midas ads are shot in soft tones and emphasize the shop as an understanding and efficient friend that makes good on its guaranteed mufflers, even far from home. **********Meineke's commercials purposely have a low-budget quality to them and have as a feature a young woman proclaiming that Meineke ''shatters'' muffler prices as she smashes a large window. ''It's made to look like it was filmed on a shoestring budget,'' Mr. Steinfeld said. ''That commercial gets our message across.'' **********In order to keep its costs down, Meineke uses less expensive universal mufflers that can be adapted at the shop to fit a number of cars. Midas and Speedy Muffler King use replacement mufflers that are similar to the original equipment and are designed to fit a specific car or family of cars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.main_headline: Walesa Says Prisoners Are Freed Temporarily
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.print_headline: Walesa Says Prisoners Are Freed Temporarily
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.body_text: **********Lech Walesa said today that Polish political prisoners released by the Government at the request of the Roman Catholic church have only been given a temporary leave and will have to return to prison. **********Mr. Walesa, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity union movement, said the men from Gdansk who were among the 30 detainees released had been ordered to surrender to prison authorities on Jan. 10. **********A spokesman for the Roman Catholic primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, declined to comment on Mr. Walesa's statement. The Government also refused to discuss it. **********Cardinal Glemp announced the releases during a Christmas Day mass at St. John's Cathedral in Warsaw but gave no indication they were temporary. **********The Cardinal and Archbishop Bronislaw Dabrowksi, secretary of the Polish Bishop's Conference, discussed the action by the Government authorities after the service. They would not identify the men involved. **********The church leaders said they were also negotiating with the Government for the release of 11 more political prisoners whom they did not name. **********There were reports that they were referring to four members of a dissident group known by its Polish initials, KOR, and seven former senior officials of the Solidarity union who are awaiting trial on charges of plotting to overthrow Communist rule.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/busin.body_text: **********A Federal jury today upheld last year's acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company by the United States Steel Company. **********The jury decided that Marathon officials acted properly in accepting the $6.2 billion takeover bid by U.S. Steel.  A group of shareholders had tried to prove that an offer by the Mobil Corporation would have paid them more per share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/busin.main_headline: Former Avis Chief At British Airways
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former Avis Chief At British Airways
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Colin M. Marshall, a 49-year-old former chief executive of Avis Inc., has been named chief executive officer of state-owned British Airways, the troubled international carrier that the Government is trying to slim down and sell. He will take over the new post on Feb.1 from Roy Watts, who will retain his title of deputy chairman and concentrate on policy issues. **********The moves were announced by Sir John King, chairman, who has overseen several key management changes since he was brought in two years ago by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to prepare the airline for ''privatization.'' **********Last October, British Airways reported a loss of about $870 million for the year ended March 31. Some of the losses reflected accounting moves made to concentrate the losses in the 1981 fiscal year in hopes that the airline could report a profit this year. **********It now appears that the airline will report a profit of $80 million to $125 million in the current fiscal year.''My role will be to run the airline as a commercially viable airline, regardless of who the shareholders are,'' Mr. Marshall said.  He reportedly will receive a salary of about $126,000, although some estimates are lower. The figure attracted attention in Britain because it would be double the salary reportedly earned by his predecessor. **********Mr. Marshall returned to his native Britain from Avis in 1981 to become deputy chairman and deputy chief executive at Sears Holdings, a retailing conglomerate best known for its Selfridges department stores and shoe store chains. His main task at Sears, which has no connection with Sears, Roebuck & Company, was to pare down and restructure its engineering and automobile-related businesses. **********Mr. Marshall expects his years at Avis to stand him in good stead in his new post. ''The demographics of the customers for rental cars and airlines are almost exactly the same,'' he said. ''The big difference is that an airline has a small number of very expensive assets.'' **********Mr. Marshall began his business career as a purser for a British shipping line, before moving to the United States in 1958 as a management trainee with Hertz. He returned to Britain as a Hertz executive in 1961 and moved to head Avis's British operations in 1964. He moved back to the United States as chief operating officer in 1971. He became Avis's president in 1975 and its chief executive a year later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.main_headline: COMMODITIES Common Themes Link Three Falling Metals
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES Common Themes Link Three Falling Metals
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.body_text: **********During the past week, gold, silver and copper prices have been acting like three parachutists in a team jump. **********Gold, which is at a 14-month low in Europe, has fallen despite the crises in Grenada and Lebanon. Silver, dropping more than a dollar an ounce this week, has plummeted to its lowest level in a year.  And just when people said copper could not fall any further, it has continued to slide. **********''The conditions in each of the markets are different,'' said Robert H. Lesemann, a vice president with the Commodities Research Unit. ''But in the eyes of a lot of speculators, they are sort of limping together. When you get speculators bailing out of one of those markets, it tends to produce an overflow in the others.'' **********The three metals are different in how traders approach them. Gold is for the most part a speculator's metal, silver is both an investor's metal and an industrial metal, and copper is mainly an industrial metal. **********Actions in Third World **********Despite these differences, actions - or fears of actions - in the third world have helped drive down prices of all three. **********Analysts say that investors fear debt-ridden developing nations are already selling gold - and will be selling more - to help repay their debts. **********Silver plummeted this week in large part because Peru announced that it is selling an estimated $70 million of the metal to raise cash. **********And, to the chagrin of domestic copper companies, Chile, the world's largest copper exporter, has stepped up production despite the depressed prices. Analysts say that this, too, was to obtain foreign currency. **********Ronald M. Hersch, vice president and manager of metals for Shearson/ American Express, sees another reason for the joint decline. ''Large speculators in the Mideast are distressed by the fact that the metals market hasn't responded to the international crises,'' he said. ''Therefore, they've liquidated their holdings, thinking that the price is going to go much lower, so they might as well buy it back when it's much cheaper.'' **********Margin Calls Cited **********Some analysts say another reason is that there have been some margin calls, which have triggered efforts to sell the three metals. **********Despite expectations that this week's crises would push up gold prices, gold slid until late yesterday. In London, it fell $10.10 an ounce Wednesday and $4.80 yesterday, to $383.50, a 14-month low. **********Later yesterday, in New York, gold for current delivery slipped 40 cents, to $386.20 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange of New York. For the 4 P.M. quote at Republic National Bank, it had edged up 50 cents, to $386. Metals trading in London closes at 10 A.M. New York time, while copper trading on the Comex ends at 2 P.M., and gold trading at 2:30. **********Silver fell by 56.5 cents an ounce, to $8.72, in London yesterday and by 30 cents, to $8.80, on the Comex. Silver has been hurt by the same speculators' actions that have hurt gold, but it has been dragged down by other factors, too. **********Silver is used heavily by the electronics and photography industry. ''The economic recovery has not been as strong worldwide as expected,'' said Mr. Hersch. ''There hasn't been as much demand as we expected, and some companies are delivering excess silver in their inventories to the Comex.'' **********Copper prices, too, have been held down by the failure of other nations to recover as strongly as the United States. This, coupled with the overheated production of copper in third- world countries in need of hard currency, has depressed copper prices. Copper rose by three-tenths of a cent yesterday on the Comex, to 62.7 cents a pound. This is less than half its price in early 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/busin.body_text: **********The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that the diversity of its product line helped net income in the fourth quarter of last year to rise 15.7 percent, to $112.8 million, or $1.78 a share, from $97.5 million, or $1.51 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. Revenues edged up to $3.54 billion, from $3.51 billion. **********For the full year, the big Hartford-based technology and aerospace concern increased earnings 16.6 percent, to $533.7 million, or $8.74 a share, from $457.7 million, or $7.71 a share, in 1981. Revenues eased to $13.58 billion, from $13.67 billion. **********Results for the year included the cumulative effect of a previously announced accounting change for investment tax credits of $66.6 million in the first quarter and a $40.2 million tax-free extraordinary gain resulting from an exchange in the second quarter of common stock and cash for United Technologies' debentures. **********Excluding the accounting change and extraordinary gain, net income in 1982 fell 6.7 percent, to $426.9 million, from $457.7 million.  Harry J. Gray, chairman, president and chief executive, said the company had ''held its own in 1982 in the face of the roughest economy in decades'' while its diversity of business and strong market positions softened the impact of lower volume and substantially higher research and development investments. **********''We expect that our military business will increase and we anticipate modest improvements in several of our industrial areas,'' Mr. Gray added. **********The company's most familiar products are Pratt & Whitney jet engines, Carrier air-conditioners, Otis elevators, Sikorsky helicopters, American Bosch fuel-injection systems and Mostek semiconductors. **********John G. Fitzgerald, a spokesman for United Technologies, said that costs incurred last year in association with the corporation's involvement with the Bendix Corporation's unsuccessful attempt to avoid being taken over by the Allied Corporation had ''virtually no effect'' on United Technologies' earnings. Burroughs The Burroughs Corporation reported yesterday that financial adjustments had caused the company to show a loss of $15.6 million in the fourth quarter. This contrasted to earnings of $62.9 million, or $1.51 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 9.8 percent, to $1.12 billion, from $1.02 billion. **********The Detroit-based producer of data-processing and business equipment said that for the full year, and after reflecting the adjustments, it earned $117.6 million, or $2.80 a share, down 21 percent from $148.9 million, or $3.58 a share, in 1981. Revenues rose 22.9 percent, to $4.19 billion, from $3.41 billion. **********Before the adjustments, earnings in the latest period amounted to $65.4 million, or $1.56 a share, a 4 percent gain. For the full year, they were $165.9 million, or $3.95 a share. **********The major adjustments consisted of charges of $84.1 million in 1982 relating to changes in inventory valuations, which were partly offset by a $17 million credit stemming from a change in the treatment of taxes associated with certain exports. Burroughs also made an accounting change amounting to $32.9 million in additional earnings that related to engineering costs. **********The results for 1982 include those of the Memorex Corporation, which Burroughs acquired in December 1981.  ''Operating results in 1982, although 10 percent higher than in 1981, were less than we had hoped,'' said W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman and chief executive. ''They reflect the difficult worldwide environment and the continued strength of the U.S. dollar which prevailed throughout 1982.'' He added that the performance of Memorex had exceeded expectations. **********According to the Value Line Investment Survey, Burroughs's longterm success will depend upon its ability to penetrate high-growth markets for less expensive goods while maintaining its large customer base. ''A warm reception for products like the B20 desktop computer is vital,'' Value Line maintains. Uniroyal **********Uniroyal Inc. announced yesterday that it had a loss of $6 million in the fourth quarter, contrasted to earnings of $300,000, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales shrank 15.8 percent, to $470 million, from $558 million. **********For the full year, net income dropped 50 percent, to $26 million, or 78 cents a share, from $52 million, or $1.52 a share, in 1981.  Sales declined 12.8 percent, to $1.97 billion, from $2.26 billlion. **********Uniroyal cited the devaluation of the Mexican peso and the expiration of a favorable contract for the purchase of natural gas used in its production of chemicals. Northwest Industries **********Northwest Industries said yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 plunged 97.1 percent, to $6.6 million, or 48 cents a share, from $228.2 million, or $8 a share. Sales tumbled 56.3 percent, to $389.3 million, from $891.7 million. **********For the full year, net income dropped 56 percent, to $184.6 million, or $8.75 a share, from $419.3 million, or $14.20 a share, in 1981. Sales dropped 26 percent, to $2.31 billion, from $3.12 billion. **********The company said it suffered a sharp decline in its third and fourth quarters mainly because of the effects on its largest operating company, the Lone Star Steel Company, of the steep reduction in domestic oil and gas drilling and excessive industry inventories of tubular goods for drilling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/busin.body_text: **********A Japanese kerosene heater manufacturer is suing Kero-Sun Inc. for $55 million, claiming the American company breached a contract by refusing delivery and payment for more than 200,000 heaters. **********Toyotomi Kogyo Company Ltd. filed the suit Monday in United States District Court in Hartford. A spokesman for the Japanese company said it lost $47 million because Kero-Sun told it on Dec. 31, 1982 that it was unable to pay for 230,000 units that Toyotomi was ready to supply. **********Last winter, Kero-Sun's sales fell short of expectations and it laid off half its 230 employees. Kero-Sun has not commented on the lawsuit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/14/world.print_headline: REBEL SALVADOR COLONEL MAY GET PLUM POST IN U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/14/world.body_text: **********The former commander of the northern province of Cabanas, who prompted a national crisis by refusing to obey transfer orders from the Minister of Defense, is likely to be sent to the Inter-American Defense Council in Washington for a year of study, according to a person familiar with the plans of the Salvadoran high command. **********Although the former commander, Lieut. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, has agreed to leave the country, his ability not only to avoid punishment but apparently to receive the prestigious Washington appointment would be considered a victory for him. **********The outcome of the crisis leaves in question the position of the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, who was the target of the colonel's rebellion. **********As a further indication that Colonel Ochoa managed to survive the standoff with some strength, a Salvadoran military source said that Colonel Ochoa's replacement would be Roberto Rodriguez Murcia, who was a classmate and friend of Colonel Ochoa's and is now director of the traffic police. Agreed to Step Down **********When he began his rebellion last Thursday night the colonel said he would not budge from his post until the Defense Minister resigned.  After six days of negotiations Colonel Ochoa agreed to resign at the order of the country's provisional President, Alvaro Magana, who is also commander general of the armed forces. **********The confrontation and its resolution produced a new round of assessments today of General Garcia's role and his future.  General Garcia is viewed by American diplomats here as being a major force in keeping the country's land reorganization program alive. However, there is a consensus among a large number of middlelevel commanders that the Defense Minister has been ineffective in managing the war. **********Westerners here said they did not necessarily believe that General Garcia had been the problem. But the Defense Minister is in charge of appointing the commanders of the country's seven brigades, most of whom are described as ''ineffective'' by both Western officials and local military officers. Close to Retirement Age **********One person who is close to the situation said: ''It seems to me what has happened is that there has been a no-confidence vote on General Garcia, and it would not be surprising if after an acceptable amount of time Garcia resigns.'' **********By some counts, however, General Garcia reaches the traditional retirement point of 30 years of service next month, which could provide a graceful way for him to step aside. Mr. Garcia is also suffering from an eye disease that has made it difficult for him to work. **********Last month all the Government ministers handed in their resignations to Mr. Magana. The President said at a news conference Wednesday that General Garcia was in the same position as all other ministers. Asked whether the general might retire soon, he said with a laugh, ''You should confirm his retirement date with him.'' **********General Garcia has been under attack from rightist political forces for his management of the war, which they say has increased the guerillas' ability to do constant damage to the economy. Leaflets appeared in San Salvador today that condemned General Garcia and announced a demonstration for Friday in San Salvador. Leaflet Talks of Corruption **********''This is the hour to clean up the corruption and opportunism,'' the leaflet said. ''Mr. Garcia has facilitated the course of subversion without regard to the patriotic lives that have been valiantly lost on the battleground.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/busin.body_text: **********The Hartford Fire Insurance Company announced that it has completed the first part of its plan to acquire a 25 percent share of Piper Jaffray Inc., a regional securities firm based in Minneapolis. **********The insurance company announced that it had received tenders for about 167,000 shares, and will buy 38,000 shares on a pro-rata basis. Hartford Fire will increase its Piper Jaffray holdings to about 271,000 shares though additional purchases from the company, members of management, the employee stock ownership trust, and a major shareholder. The investment in the securities firm follows an agreement last month whereby Piper Jaffray's offices will sell life insurance products of Hartford Fire.
