https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.body_text: **********Polish Newspaper Hails Appointment of Glemp **********WARSAW, Jan. 6 (AP) - The newspaper Zycie Warszawy said today that the elevation of Archbishop Jozef Glemp to Cardinal ''authoritatively and effectively rebuffed'' speculation about Vatican displeasure with the Polish Primate. **********''The cardinalship will enhance further Primate Jozef Glemp's already high prestige in both Poland and the international arena,'' it said. **********Archbishop Glemp succeeded the late Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski as head of the Polish church in July 1981. He was elevated on Wednesday, when the Pope appointed 18 new cardinals. **********The newspaper said that those who speculated on the Pope's dissatisfaction with Archbishop Glemp were ''extremist groupings'' seeking ''to undermine the prestige of Poland's Primate.'' **********Militant clerics have criticized Archbishop Glemp for taking what they view as too moderate a stance toward Poland's Communist Government. ---- **********WARSAW, Jan. 6 (UPI) - Before an overflow congregation of 6,000 people, Cardinal Glemp today again urged patience with Poland's military rulers as the only solution to the nation's crisis. **********In his first public appearance since his elevation to Cardinal, he said, ''Dialogue can take place on the national and international planes, despite the difficulties it encounters.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/busin.body_text: **********The ITT Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income slipped 10.9 percent compared with the period last year, largely because of a one-time gain last year of $33 million. **********The 1982 benefit came from the favorable settlement of an antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. ITT said that, excluding the extraordinary item, earnings in the third quarter would have risen 23.5 percent. **********ITT said that net income in the latest quarter dropped to $105.6 million, or 70 cents a share, from $118.5 million, or 80 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. **********Revenues for the period were off 5.8 percent, to $4.9 billion, from $5.2 billion. Included in those revenues are ITT's insurance operations, which totaled $1.5 billion in both the 1983 and 1982 third quarters. **********''We were looking for 70 cents a share,'' said Carol Neves, analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. ''For the full year we expect earnings to be in the range of $4.40 to $4.50 a share.'' **********Miss Neves said, however, that she was looking for another advance in earnings in 1984, when ITT will benefit from gains from its telecommunications operations worldwide and also from the improved economic environment as it affects the company's industrial areas. **********''Earnings per share to be reported for 1983 are expected to be down about 5 percent from the 1982 earnings,'' said Rand V. Araskog, chairman, president and chief executive of ITT. Earnings per share amounted to $4.75 a share in 1982 and included a gain of 82 cents a share from the sale of ITT's majority holding in Standard Telephone and Cable P.L.C. **********''I think they will come in at $1.90 a share in the fourth quarter,'' said Larry Baker, an analyst at E. F. Hutton Group Inc. ''The fourth quarter is seasonally strong and the general economic environment has also improved.'' ITT earned $1.84 in the fourth quarter of 1984. **********Earnings from operations improved during the third quarter, Mr. Araskog said, ''and we expect these earnings for the full year to show considerable improvement over last year's performance.'' **********Mr. Araskog added that excluding divested units and the translation effects of foreign exchange, sales and revenues for the latest third quarter increased 6.2 percent. **********MGM/UA **********The MGM/UA Entertainment Company, a major film producer and distributor, reported that its net income in its fourth fiscal quarter ended Aug. 31 plunged 59.4 percent, to $11 million, or 21 cents a share, from $27.1 million, or 54 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues for the period dropped 13.9 percent, to $217.6 million, from $252.7 million a year earlier. **********MGM/UA, which is based in Culver City, Calif., said that the decline in earnings in the latest quarter was primarily because of an unusually strong fourth fiscal quarter in 1982.  That quarter included earnings from two movie successes, Poltergeist and Rocky III, and earnings from the Chips television series that went into syndication in August of last year. **********For the full fiscal year ended Aug. 31, MGM/UA said that net income rose 52.4 percent, to $41.9 million, or 83 cents a share, from $27.5 million, or 55 cents a share, in the preceding fiscal year. Revenues for the 12 months fell 10.3 percent, to $723 million, from $806.3 million in the preceding fiscal year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs said he had purchased shares of the RCA Corporation, but would not disclose the amount. ''My holdings are under 5 percent,'' he said, declining to say whether he intended to purchase more. **********Published reports indicated that Mr. Jacobs had purchased approximately 1 million shares of RCA common stock, about 1.2 percent of the outstanding. RCA's stock closed at $33.75, up $1.25, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. **********Separately, Thornton F. Bradshaw, chairman of RCA, said in an interview released yesterday that the company was in a strong position and was not in danger of a takeover, and that it did not intend to sell its National Broadcasting Company subsidiary. RCA recently agreed to sell its C.I.T. Financial Services unit to the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation for $1.5 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/15/world.body_text: **********The Salvadoran military met little resistence from guerrilla forces as it moved to occupy Chinchontepec Volcano in the central province of San Vicente and to secure the towns at the base of the volcano, according to military officers. **********The leftist opposition has long used the 7,100-foot volcano as a base from which to attack the towns. **********The occupation of Chinchontepec, which is in the western central part of San Vicente, was the army's first objective in an offensive that began Friday. In the next week the Government plans to begin redevelopment programs in the towns around the volcano. **********Military officials in San Vicente were cautious about making too much of the success. One American adviser said that most of the guerrillas left before the army arrived and have probably moved to base camps in the north and south of the province. Some Guerrilla Diversions **********''They'll probably meet a lot of resistence in the north,'' said an American military adviser, one of 17 American trainers stationed in San Vicente. **********The guerrillas have created some diversions. Since the begining of the week, they have attacked a bridge in the eastern part of the province and an electric substation six miles south of San Vicente. **********The test of the operation's success will be whether the army leaves enough forces behind to keep the volcano clear of guerrilla camps so that the redevelopment program can proceed. **********In its move to occupy the volcano, the army found several abandoned camps, two 2 1/2-ton trucks, communications equipment and medical supplies, according to military sources.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/busin.body_text: **********Orders to factories for durable goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, with strong gains by some industries mostly offset by a big drop for military hardware, the Commerce Department said today. **********Excluding the decline for military capital goods, new orders rose 3.5 percent, the Commerce Department report said. Automobiles, primary metals and nonmilitary capital goods all showed gains. **********Economists said that while the report reinforced the view that the pace of the recovery had moderated, the increase in orders for capital goods - the equipment used in production - signaled that healthy growth would continue. **********For July, the report showed a revised decline of 2.9 percent, an improvement over the 3.5 percent initially reported. Orders had surged 7.6 percent in June. **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said orders, now standing 25 percent above a year ago, have shown ''impressive growth'' since the recession's low point. **********''As is typical when a recovery matures, the upward pace in ordering may moderate in the months ahead,'' he said. But he added that the lower level of inventories compared with shipments, and the larger backlog of unfilled orders, would ''keep durable goods production advancing.'' **********The report said the total value of new orders was $88.5 billion last month compared with $88.2 billion in July. And shipments totaled $87.1 billion compared with $85.6 billion in July. **********Durable goods such as as cars, heavy machinery and refrigerators are items expected to last three or more years. The military category often rises and falls sharply - it was down 37.4 percent last month after falling 13.1 percent in July and rising 66 percent in June - because each order is for so much money. **********Orders of nonmilitary capital goods rose 5.9 percent, in what the Commerce Department's chief economist, Robert Ortner, said was ''perhaps another sign that capital spending is really beginning to turn upward.'' **********Such spending, which usually lags behind in a recovery, appears to be ''participating in the recovery in a normal way,'' Commerce Under Secretary Robert Dederick said earlier in the day. **********Joe Carson of Merrill Lynch said the August durable goods report ''reinforces that the economy was downshifting. And that will be more evident in coming reports.'' **********These were among the other details of today's announcement: **********- Military capital goods orders totaled $4.3 billion last month compared with $6.9 billion in July. Non- military capital goods rose to $22.9 billion from $21.6 billion. **********- Metals orders increased 3.4 percent, to $10.8 billion, mostly reflecting gains in the steel category. **********- Transportation equipment orders rose 5.1 percent, to $21.5 billion, after falling 12.6 percent in July. Such orders have averaged $20.3 billion a month this year compared with $16.9 billion last year. **********- Orders for machinery, which gradually have been increasing all year, fell 2.6 percent, from $29.6 billion in July, to $28.8 billion in August. **********- Orders for household durable goods fell 6.8 percent, to $5.2 billion, from $5.6 billion. **********The figures are adjusted for normal seasonal variations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.main_headline: U.S. IS TARGET AT NICARAGUA TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.print_headline: U.S. IS TARGET AT NICARAGUA TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.body_text: **********Third world nations began a weeklong ministerial meeting here today seemingly aimed at giving Nicaragua a strong vote of support in its dispute with the United States. **********A draft final declaration, prepared by Nicaragua and Cuba, which is president of the 96-nation movement of countries professing nonalignment, calls specifically for condemnation of United States support for anti-Sandinist groups based in Honduras. **********Diplomatic sources said the Reagan Administration had lobbied with ''its friends'' in the movement in the hope of weakening the declaration. As a result, they said, some of the wording of the draft would be toned down, although United States policy in the region would nevertheless be criticized. **********The main purpose of the meeting, though, appears to be to draw international attention to Nicaraguan charges that the United States is intent on disrupting the three-year-old revolution. **********Nicaraguan officials were particularly cheered by a weekend statement from the foreign ministers of Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama calling for negotiations between Nicaragua and the United States and between the warring factions in El Salvador. **********All four governments sent delegations to this week's meeting here, which was called to discuss the situation in Latin America and the Caribbean in advance of the seventh meeting of the nonaligned nations to be held in New Delhi in March. **********The meeting is also expected to focus attention on Argentina's dispute with Britain over the Falkland Islands. Nicaraguan officials said that, before this week's visit by Argentina's Foreign Minister, Juan Ramon Aguirre Lanari, the Bueno Aires regime had withdrawn a group of army officers who had been advising anti-Sandinist rebels in Honduras. **********Substantive debate was delayed this morning, however, by a long procedural squabble over the agenda, with Peru anxious to limit discussions to the situation in Central America, the Caribbean and the South Atlantic rather than all of Latin America. Diplomatic sources said that Peru was hoping to avoid analysis of pending territorial disputes with Equador and Bolivia. **********The draft declaration, though, concentrates almost entirely on the situation in Central America, noting in an indirect reference to the United States that ''the principal external factor that aggravates the regional crisis is the behavior of those who seek to impose solutions that permit them to maintain their hegemony over the region.'' **********More specifically, it condemns United States ''provocation'' of Nicaragua as well as its military assistance to Honduras.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/12/world.print_headline: CITY IN ARGENTINA LIVES UP TO ITS REBELLIOUS IMAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/12/world.body_text: **********Argentines call it el Cordobazo, the big Cordoba blow, accenting how this interior city is known as the nation's center of revolt. **********It was in Cordoba, the country's second largest city, where popular uprisings in 1955 and 1969 led to the overthrow of two Governments; where three years ago local military garrisons went on the march in a failed mutiny, and where the revolutionary Ernesto (Che) Guevara was raised. **********It was also in Cordoba in late October that Raul Alfonsin, now the President- elect, led a civic revolution, handing the long dominant Peronist party its first election defeat in nearly 40 years. Peronists here conceded just two hours after the polls closed; it was the first sign that a major political upset was in the making. Mr. Alfonsin went on to win 52 percent of the nation's vote and 60 percent of Cordoba's. **********''When Cordoba moves, the country moves,'' said Rodolfo Dragun, a gruff 51-year-old auto worker at the sprawling Renault plant. His was a boast common among Cordobeses, as the city's one million people are called.   A Blend of Detroit and Boston **********Behind their rebelliousness is their city's image as a place of brawn and brain, of auto factories and universities, that have combined to make it an Argentine blend of Detroit and Boston that in many ways mirrors and leads the nation's interior. **********The city is a symbol that there is another Argentina outside Buenos Aires, the capital, which holds 40 percent of the nation's 28 million people and touches 70 percent of its economic activity. The rest of Argentina, one third the size of the United States, is largely uninhabited. **********''Capitolismo'' is what Cordobeses call that domination. The term reflects a chip on their shoulder that is partly behind their readiness to buck it. **********''It's not resentment, but resigned resistance,'' Marcelo Lozada, 53, one of the city's leading lawyers, said in an interview.   Striking Colonial Architecture **********A city of striking colonial architecture, Cordoba sits on an edge between the fertile pampas and the arid Cordoba Sierras. Its geography blesses it with verdant plazas, a dry climate and extraordinarily deep blue skies. **********Legend has it that even the city's beginnings were ornery. Jeronimo Luis de Cabrera was sent by the Spanish crown in 1573 to found a capital of the northwest province of Salta; he founded Cordoba instead. **********The story may be apocryphal, but it highlights immigration patterns that made Cordoba and much of the Argentine interior very different from Buenos Aires. Spanish colonizers mostly pushed across the Andes from Peru to develop the Argentine interior before Italian and other European immigrants came by sea in the 19th century to greatly expand Buenos Aires, a seaport. Italian-Argentines, though the majority in the capital, are still called ''gringos'' here. **********Where the way of life in the capital is racy, here there is a bent for tradition, down to the two downtown convents that still hold cloistered nuns.   Tradition 'Not Frozen' **********Preserving much of the heritage today are many young people like Juan Manuel Bergallo. A 33-year-old bearded architect, he returned in 1980 after six years in Europe to take over the city's programs to conserve the Spanish colonial churches and buildings that are a contrast to the 19th-century Italian and French architecture of the capital. **********''I wanted to do things in Cordoba and for Cordoba,'' he said earnestly on a walking tour of the city. ''There is so much tradition here, but it's a tradition that is always renovating. It's not frozen.'' **********The city's social transformation grew with its industry. Today Renault, Fiat and the Government's airplane company are among the factories here. Growing alongside them were powerful unions. It was an independent break by rank and file with Peronist union leaders that greatly aided Mr. Alfonsin, who attacked the power of the old-line leaders. **********''I like his ideas about democracy,'' Enrique Roldan, 43, said, stepping back from the Renault assembly line. ''You cannot work if you are not Peronist, and that's not right.''  Revolt on the Campus **********The most far-reaching revolt here was educational. Restiveness in 1918 at the National University of Cordoba, one of the three oldest universities in the hemisphere, won total independence from the Government. The changes quickly spread throughout Latin America, creating a double- edged effect of academic freedom and politicizing of campuses. **********Argentine military and civilian Governments for the last 40 years often reacted by intervening in the universities. Quality has suffered. **********At the National University, where students crammed for exams recently amid lush, 17th-century colonnaded patios, were signs of decadence such as broken glass panes and splintered desks. Mr. Alfonsin's education aides have vowed to re-establish university independence. **********So much stress is put on education here that Argentines elsewhere often call a Cordobes el docto, meaning the doctor. **********It is a milieu that gave rise to a medical student, Che Guevara, though old running mates of his at a dinner party one night still called him Ernesto. They said he was socially sensitive but not particularly radical before he left nearly 30 years ago to tour Latin America. He ended up helping lead the Cuban revolution and dying in 1967 in a Bolivian jungle. **********''He was happy - a lover of life and women when we knew him,'' said Eduardo Diaz, a 54-year-old contemporary. Che Guevara might be distressed to know that most of his friends and even his longtime college sweetheart are politically conservative today.   The Voice of the Interior **********If Cordoba's rebellious spirit has a target, it is not an ideology but provincial rights. Capturing a longstanding demand by local leaders for decentralization of the country's political and economic power is even the name of the city's sole newspaper: The Voice of the Interior. **********Mr. Alfonsin and his party, the Radical Civic Union, were helped by Victor Martinez, now the Vice President- elect, a popular former Mayor of Cordoba who was put on the ticket because of the city's importance. But Eduardo Angeloz, the 52-year-old Radical Governor-elect, said he intended to press even Mr. Alfonsin on provincial rights, such as industrial incentives and promotion of provincial exports. **********He said in an interview, ''We're raising the flag of federalism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.main_headline: SPAIN SHOWS INTEREST IN PLAYING LATIN PEACE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.print_headline: SPAIN SHOWS INTEREST IN PLAYING LATIN PEACE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.body_text: **********There are signs that Spain's Socialist Government is interested in playing a role in bringing about peace talks in Central America. **********The interest, officials here say, can be detected between the lines of carefully worded official statements, in meetings with Latin American envoys and in articles in the Spanish press. **********Today Mexico's Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, arrived here for talks with Spanish officials. Cuba's Foreign Minister, Isidoro Malmierca Peoli, is expected here next week. **********Recently El Pais, the respected Madrid daily, said Mexico, Panama, Colombia and Venezuela were promoting a plan for a peace conference in the region and had asked the Spanish Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, to intercede to get United States backing for it. **********The article, which referred to a meeting held by the four nations on the Panamanian island of Contadora in January, gave the impression that the mood in favor of such a disarmament conference - and for a Spanish role in it -was building throughout Latin America. **********In response to speculation, the Government spokesman, Eduardo Sotillos, told reporters last week that Mr. Gonzalez was ready to cooperate in a search for peace in Latin America provided that the initiative for talks came from the democracies there. 'Question of Assistance' **********This official stance - that Spain is willing to intervene only if it is asked to do so - appears designed to take into account Latin American sensitivities over involvement by a European and ''excolonial'' country. The Spanish Government is going to great lengths to avoid the impression that it is trying to impose itself as a mediator in the region, even though some officials believe that linguistic and historic ties should give Madrid special leverage. **********''It's not a question of mediation but of assistance,'' said Elena Flores, who heads the international department of the Socialist Party. ''Spain is willing to help but it all depends on if they ask us and what they ask us to do.'' Speaking as an official of the party, not the Government, Mrs. Flores said she saw a ''great prospective'' for Spanish-Latin American cooperation that would avoid ''the temptations of hegemony because of our limited resources.'' **********''We have a common language, a shared tradition, a common sensibility for understanding problems, and with the consolidation of democracy here, I believe that we can do things together,'' she said. **********The surge of interest in Latin America here springs from several causes. One is the assertion of a special affinity for the third world that accompanied the Socialists in their rise to power and formed a plank in their foreign policy platform in the October elections. It centers around the idea that Spain's peaceful transition from dictatorship to democracy could serve as a model for Latin America. Fight Off 'Cultural Aggression' **********Some believe that Spain should be the champion of the Hispanic world. Recently Luis Yanez, president of the Institute of Iberoamerican Cooperation, told a Senate panel here that Spain should create a ''pole of autonomous culture'' for the Spanish-speaking community to fight off ''cultural aggression'' from North America and France. **********Another is the idea, not often directly stated, that a leadership role in Latin America could enhance Spain's overall prestige and serve as a powerful bargaining chip in its still unsettled relationships with the rest of Europe and the United States. **********Spain's top priority is to join the European Economic Community, overcoming the resistance of France, which fears that its own agricultural products will be undercut in price. The Government appears unwilling to run the risk of a rupture with Washington by withdrawing from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but is searching for near neutrality in the general conduct of foreign affairs. **********A third reason for Spain's interest in Latin America lies in the personal predilections of its 41-year-old leader, Mr. Gonzalez. He has had a longstanding familiarity with the region and knows many of the leaders through his position as vice president of the Socialist International, where he was in charge of Central American affairs. **********Mr. Gonzalez has several times publicly advocated what he calls a ''mini-Helsinki'' conference on security and cooperation in Latin America that, like the 1975 conference in Europe, would bring together all of the countries. Its goal would be to end hostility between Honduras and Nicaragua and the fighting in El Salvador and draw up agreements to curb arms imports and enhance overall security. **********Unlike the conference recently proposed by Costa Rica, Honduras and El Salvador, the Spanish version would not exclude the United States. Madrid views American participation as essential to the success of any major peace agreement. Says U.S. Should Recognize Cuba **********Mr. Gonzalez also believes that the United States should recognize Cuba. ''Twenty years of practicing isolation hasn't resolved the problem,'' he said in an interview in December. ''Maybe they should open another chapter and try a new road that would allow Cuba to participate in a plan of peace and security in the region.'' **********Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, has accepted an invitation to visit Madrid later in the year, according to Foreign Ministry officials.  The cordial relations between Madrid and Havana - Mr. Castro is said, for example, to supply cigars for Mr. Gonzalez - has caused speculation that the Spanish Prime Minister might someday serve as an important bridge between the United States and Cuba. Madrid would clearly cherish such a role. **********Last month Thomas O. Enders, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, came here for discussions with Mr. Gonzalez and his Foreign Minister, Fernando Moran. The trip was in itself one more sign of Spain's increasing visibility in Latin America. **********At a news conference afterward, Mr. Enders said he had ''profited'' from hearing Spain's views, but he also indicated that Washington did not need Madrid as a go-between with Cuba. He said the ''possibility of contacts'' already existed through the Swiss Embassy in Havana.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.main_headline: KISSINGER CALLS PRINTING OF PENTAGON PAPERS PROPER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.print_headline: KISSINGER CALLS PRINTING OF PENTAGON PAPERS PROPER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.body_text: **********Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has stated that the press did nothing improper by publishing the Pentagon Papers in 1971 although he was ''outraged'' by their appearance in public at the time. **********In an interview with American Heritage magazine, Mr. Kissinger discussed international relations, diplomacy and the secrecy required during sensitive negotiations like the ones he was then conducting to end the war in Vietnam. Mr. Kissinger was national security adviser to President Richard M. Nixon and, he said, ''most intensely concerned with controlling leaks'' that could compromise those talks. **********But he says in the magazine's August-September issue: ''I do not believe that it is the press's job to discipline itself about what information it receives, or to reject information it can obtain, on the ground that it might harm a negotiation. The media are in no position to make such a judgment.'' **********At the same time, Mr. Kissinger remained critical of government officials like Daniel Ellsberg, the former Government official who helped compile the 47-volume study on United States involvement in Southeast Asia from World War II to 1968. **********Mr. Ellsberg passed on the secret study to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in 1969. He later said he was the one who gave the documents to the press. **********''If the press broke into a Government office, I would think that highly improper,'' Mr. Kissinger told Robert Bendiner, the author, who interviewed him for American Heritage. ''And I have contempt for individuals in government who turn over to the press classified documents in their trust. But I don't have contempt for those in the press who receive it.'' **********Mr. Kissinger said he found the receipt of stolen information by the press deplorable.  ''But,'' he added, ''I do not think the media should censor themselves with respect to information that has come their way, provided they did not commit the act of theft or get somebody else to steal it for them. But if somebody takes a document and gives it to them, however ill I think of the thief, it is not the media's responsibility to police themselves in that regard.'' **********Mr. Bendiner then observed that, in other words, it was all right for the press to publish the papers but that Mr. Ellsberg should not have made them available. **********''At the time I was outraged by the whole procedure, which seemed to me to threaten vital and delicate negotiations in which we were engaged,'' Mr. Kissinger responded. ''On sober reflection I would go along with the distinction I have just made.'' **********When The Times began to publish its series of articles based on the Pentagon study, along with documents contained in it, the Nixon Administration went to court to prevent their publication. But the United States Supreme Court issued a benchmark ruling that this would violate the free-press guarantees of the Constitution. **********The Government charged Mr. Ellsberg with espionage, theft and conspiracy only to have the indictment thrown out by a Federal judge on the ground of improper government conduct against the defendant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.body_text: **********Four Central American nations, declaring that they must ''solve their own problems,'' issued an eight-point peace plan today to reduce strife and the threat of war with Nicaragua through negotiations. **********The proposals ended two days of talks among the foreign ministers of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica. **********Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman of Nicaragua was invited but said he could not attend because of celebrations Tuesday marking the fourth anniversary of the Sandinista revolution. **********The four foreign ministers said in their statement that ''Central American countries should solve their own problems'' and they pledged their ''staunch intent to continue discussing the priority tasks that should be developed to overcome the Central American crisis.'' **********The peace plan mirrors parts of a proposal Sunday by the presidents of the Contadora group, made up of Mexico, Panama, Columbia and Venezuela, and an independent plan announced by Nicaragua on Tuesday. **********The talks here were attended by Eduardo Castillo Arriola of Guatemala, Fidel Chavez Mena of El Salvador, Edgardo Paz Barnica of Honduras and Fernando Volio Jimenez of Costa Rica. **********Their plan calls for an end to the arms race, the ''decrease or withdrawal of foreign advisers'' in Central America and the establishment of ''international mechanisms'' to control arms traffic. They also urged countries in the region to strengthen trade and economic ties and promote free elections. **********They called for a ban on ''logistical and other support'' for ''terrorism and subversion'' in the region and ''immediate measures to promote and protect human rights and for the solution of the refugee problem that is overwhelming some of the countries of the region.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/10/world.body_text: **********A Danish fisherman appealing a conviction for illegal fishing off Britain's coast was allowed today to take his case to the European Court in Luxembourg. **********The fisherman, Kent Kirk, a trawler captain and conservative member of the European Parliament, is challenging the legality of his $45,000 fine for breaching the 12-mile offshore fishing limit introduced by Britain Jan. 1. **********At the time, Denmark was holding out against the European Economic Community's new fishing policy. Since then, it has reached agreement with the nine other community members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/07/world.main_headline: BRITAIN'S UNIONISTS MOVE TO THE RIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/07/world.print_headline: BRITAIN'S UNIONISTS MOVE TO THE RIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/07/world.body_text: **********Struggling to halt an erosion in influence and power, leaders of British trade unions today gave the conservative wing of their troubled movement control of the governing council and authorized it to talk to the Government about proposed anti-union legislation. **********The grudging vote came a day after Frank Chapple, the departing president of the group, which is known as the Trades Union Congress, warned in a blunt opening speech, ''We will have to stop wishing that the world was like it once was and face up to what it is.'' **********The changes that have weighed on the union leaders meeting here in this seaside resort north of Liverpool have included the crushing defeat of the Labor Party in the June 9 national election. That defeat not only left Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party entrenched for five years with an overwhelming majority in Parliament but also exposed shifting voting patterns among the working class that give the Labor Party scant hope of winning the next election. **********Another factor has been a decline in union membership at the rate of 500,000 members a year since 1980, primarily because of recession. Although unemployment fell slightly in August to just under three million, about 12.5 percent of the work force, the trend is still upward and industries with established unions are among the worst off.   Militancy Has Been Sapped **********The congress still claims more than 10 million members in 102 unions, just over half the work force. But militancy has been sapped by the unwillingness of many in the rank and file to risk jobs in strikes and by legislation imposing fines and jail terms on union members who strike in support of other unions. **********The congress's 51-member General Council elected today is the first based on a new voting system that gives more influence to the growing service-sector unions. Their increased role comes at the expense of large manufacturing- and engineering-sector unions whose members have usually been more militant on most issues than the more middle-class white-color unions. The large unions now have automatic seats but are excluded from voting for those seats to be filled by 83 smaller unions. **********The left wing fared better in the voting than had been expected. It is estimated that the conservative margin in the new council will be 6 to 10 votes, with several members labeled ''too hard to define.'' **********''The result will certainly be a move to the right - there is no argument about that,'' said Moss Evans, secretary general of the Transport and General Workers, with 1.5 million members the largest group in the congress. **********There has been speculation that a move to the right by the trade unions will strain the congress's relations with the Labor Party. The unions founded the party and are still both its major source of funds and a key bloc in determining its policies and leadership.   No 'Conscripts or Puppets' **********But many union leaders were dismayed by the disastrous squabbling among party leaders in the last campaign. Others are worried about the Labor Party's policies - and those of the more left-wing unions - which are thought to be out of touch with an increasng number of union members. They are painfully aware of polls showing that about one-third of all trade unionists voted for the Conservatives while others favored the Liberal-Social Democratic Party alliance. **********''We are not in command of an army of conscripts or puppets,'' Len Murray, the congress's general secretary, warned in debate today. **********One major threat to ties between the unions and the Labor Party is the Government's effort to capitalize on disaffection with the Labor Party by introducing legislation allowing union members to opt out of contributions to the party. Norman Tebbitt, the Government's Employment Minister, has asked the Trades Union Congress to suggest how to put the proposal into effect, a move that many labor leaders find galling. **********The disputes within the union movement on how it should respond to the political weakness of the left and the unflagging Government effort to chip away at union power were highlighted this morning in debate about whether the unions should talk to Mr. Tebbitt about legislation that would force uniform election procedures on the unions and require ballots before every strike. **********Mr. Murray and like-minded union leaders believe that the congress's refusal to discuss the legislation with the Government makes unions look unnecessarily recalcitrant, particularly since polls show that many union members support some of the voting reforms embodied in the legislation.   'As Baffled as I Am' ''I am sure that the majority of our members are as baffled as I am that some trade union leaders will travel halfway across the world to sympathize with Communist dictatorships, yet seek to prevent the T.U.C. from talking to the elected Government of Britain,'' Mr. Chapple said in a scathing reference to Arthur Scargill, the outspoken Socialist president of the mine workers. Last week, on a trip to Moscow for a convention, Mr. Scargill attacked Western defense policies. **********Mr. Scargill and others who oppoose talks with Mr. Tebbitt argue that there is no chance of influencing the Government to soften its attack and a grave danger of compromises that will simply make it more effective. **********In response to the proposal for talks, they introduced amendments calling for resistance rather than cooperation. One proposal threatened a nationwide strike in the event unions were fined or leaders imprisoned for refusing to obey the laws. Conservative leaders dismiss the proposal as an empty threat and ''a first step to oblivion'' because it is unlikely that most union members would heed a strike call on the issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/30/busin.body_text: **********The Tandy Corporation, the world's largest retailer of consumer electronic products and one of the most profitable, got that way emphasizing price, distribution and service. **********It owns and operates more electronics stores than anyone with its worldwide Radio Shack chain. Its employees are generally knowledgeable; its products are widely regarded as inexpensive and reliable. **********''We consider ourselves a distribution system for the products of technology,'' says its chairman, John V. Roach. **********Today, Tandy begins perhaps the most severe test to date for that distribution system, and indeed for its entire marketing strategy. **********In Las Vegas, at Comdex, the premier trade show of the personal computer industry, Mr. Roach is to introduce Tandy's strongest entry into the business computer market, a machine designed to be competitively priced with the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer and which is expected to be compatible, or very nearly so, with I.B.M.'s machine. **********Analysts differ over the prospects for Tandy's new product, which faces a host of I.B.M. lookalikes already on the market. David Bunnell, president of PC World Communications, a trade publisher in San Francisco, said such a machine from Tandy ought to make even I.B.M. nervous, thanks to the thousands of Radio Shack outlets. **********''Others have better technology,'' he added, citing the Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston, ''but they'll never get that kind of distribution.'' **********And Harry Edelson, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation of New York, says that the lookalike is the only way Tandy could hope to regain its lost market share in microcomputers. ''It's worth a shot,'' he said. ''Going the I.B.M.-compatible route minimizes the risk in a very hazardous business.'' **********''Tandy won't be wildly successful in market share with its PC,'' predicted David Lamb, an analyst with Link Resources in New York. ''But it will do fine in profits.'' **********The company, named after its founder, Charles David Tandy, who died in 1978, has traditionally done fine in profits. When Mr. Tandy acquired the bankrupt Boston-based Radio Shack 20 years ago, his primary business was leather goods retailing, not consumer electronics. But by 1975 the chain was doing so well that he spun off everything except Radio Shack. **********In the latest fiscal year, ended June 30, 8,868 Radio Shack outlets racked up more than $2.5 billion in worldwide sales. Earnings, totaling $278.5 million for the latest year, have risen at an average compounded rate of 30 percent a year in the last decade. Gross margins have remained in the 58 to 59 percent range in the last five years, at least 20 percentage points higher than the average for competitors, analysts say. **********A good deal of that growth has come from microcomputers, an industry Tandy helped found back in 1977. Although Radio Shack stores offer an assortment of goods, from batteries to toys to stereo sets, in just six years microcomputers and related products have become the company's biggest-selling items, accounting for some $875 million, or 35.3 percent, of total volume in the 1983 fiscal year. **********Radio Shack's microcomputer offerings include everything from a low-end home machine, the Color Computer, to powerful, multi-user business systems with five-figure prices as well as pocket computers and the popular Model 100 portable. **********While other microcomputer makers are either awash in red ink, have filed for bankruptcy or left the business altogether, Tandy says it has made money because it manufactures most of its products and controls distribution. **********In any case, analysts agree that Tandy's vast distribution network has enabled Radio Shack to maintain its profits by staying out of the vicious computer price wars that its competitors began last year. It has, however, cut the price of its home model, the Color Computer. **********Tandy, however, has paid for its profits with a steep loss of market share. In 1979 Radio Shack accounted for 40.5 percent of sales in the industry, according to the International Data Corporation. Last year, Radio Shack's share was estimated at a mere 8.6 percent. **********And although today's introduction of its new product would indicate that the company is in microcomputers to stay, analysts such as Mr. Edelson of First Boston predict that Tandy will not be a major force in the market unless it alters the way it does business. **********He says, for example, that Tandy may be overestimating the advantage it gets from its distribution system. Customers crowded Radio Shack stores as recently as three years ago because only Apple Computer and a few other companies made microcomputers and they were hard to find in other stores. Now Radio Shack competes with Computerland, K Mart, Sears, Roebuck and a host of local specialty retailers. **********Mr. Edelson estimated that at least one rival manufacturer, Commodore International Ltd., may have topped Tandy by securing 10,000 retail outlets for its products. And, he added, there are so many home and personal computers out now, that consumers prefer to shop where they can compare the prices and features of different models, something they cannot do at Radio Shack's one-line stores. **********''Let them shop elsewhere and then come to us,'' countered Bernard Appel, Radio Shack's executive vice president for marketing. ''We don't want to be in the brand name business. We don't want the competition setting our prices.'' **********A trained sales force and widely available service are other ways Radio Shack can stay competitive and polish up what Mr. Bunnell of PC World Communications called ''a shlock image'' that it only recently has begun to shed. **********Tandy, in fact, is stepping up its sales force training programs and designates one staff member at each of its computer centers as responsible for maintenance and repairs. **********Such moves, along with the introduction of new products, are costly, however, and are some of the factors behind a warning at the last annual meeting from Mr. Roach, the company's chairman, that Tandy would not experience the same rate of earnings this fiscal year that it has seen in the recent past.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/09/world.main_headline: 96 Are Dead in Turkey In 'Worst' Mine Accident
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/09/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 96 Are Dead in Turkey In 'Worst' Mine Accident
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/09/world.body_text: **********Rescue workers dug out more bodies today from the rubble of a northern coal mine where gas explosions and rockfalls killed 96 men on Monday in Turkey's worst mining accident. **********About 24 hours after the accident at the Armutcuk mine near the Black Sea town of Eregli, a total of 231 miners had been rescued, provincial officials said. **********Government officials said the death toll stood at 96 and the number of injured at 89. Energy Minister Fahir Ilker called the tragedy ''the biggest mining accident in Turkey's history.'' **********The rescue operation, suspended Monday night after seven hours and resumed at dawn, was speeded up after the discovery of two bodies at a depth of 1,300 feet. **********Two hours before the explosion, witnesses said, a fire had swept through the mine. Before it could be extinguished properly, the miners were ordered back into the fume-filled shaft by their employers, according to the witnesses. **********A small blast about 1,150 feet underground followed by an explosion touched off rockfalls, burying men in tunnels, said Galip Demirel, Governor of Zonguldak Province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/world.main_headline: SOVIET HANDS OVER DEBRIS FROM KOREAN PLANE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/world.print_headline: SOVIET HANDS OVER DEBRIS FROM KOREAN PLANE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union handed over to United States and Japanese authorities today five wooden boxes containing debris from the South Korean plane shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1. **********No bodies were said to have been included in the transfer, nor any sensitive material such as the in-flight data and voice-recording systems that United States and Soviet ships are searching for in the northern Sea of Japan. All 269 people aboard the Korean plane were killed. **********Most of the 76 items handed over today appeared to be similar to wreckage from Korean Air Lines flight 007 that has been floating ashore along the northern rim of the Japanese island of Hokkaido. Soviet officials told the Americans and Japanese that all the debris had been found in the water or washed up on two Soviet-controlled islands north of Japan - Sakhalin Island and the small Moneron Island, 30 miles to the southwest. **********There were women's slacks, a windbreaker, newspapers, pieces of metal, oxygen bottles, seat cushions, a life raft, a Boeing 747 technical manual and an application for a course at Tsukuba University in Japan.   Traveled to Soviet Port **********The Americans and the Japanese traveled to the port of Nevelsk on the western shore of Sakhalin to bring back the material. It was the first time that the Soviet authorities had relinquished any items from the plane and they reported finding nothing else. **********''They said it was everything, but do you believe in Santa Claus?'' said a member of the United States delegation, which was headed by Lynn Pascoe, Deputy Director of the State Department's Office of Soviet Affairs. **********Skepticism was also expressed by the chief Japanese delegate, Minoru Tamba, Director of the Soviet Affairs Division of Japan's Foreign Ministry. **********''We do not vouch for the authenticity of these items,'' Mr. Tamba said. **********''When you see them, you can't say they amount to very much,'' he said. ''As for the contents, they are only a small part of what was on the plane. I can't say how helpful they will be in our investigation. I have my doubts.''  Transfer Marked by Formality **********The transfer of the five boxes of debris from the plane was marked by great attention to formality and detail. Only a few representatives from each country were permitted to attend and only two members of news-gathering organizations - photographers from the Associated Press and the Japanese news agency Kyodo. **********The delegations set out for Nevelsk Sunday on a Japanese service ship, the Tsugaru. Starting out from Otaru on western Hokkaido, they took more than 15 hours to reach their destination, described by one of the visitors as a ''somewhat dilapidated'' port that did not seem busy. **********The Soviet team was headed by Maj. Gen. A. I. Romanenko of the Soviet border force for Sakhalin and the Kurile Islands to the east. **********Accompanied by interpreters, they met in the Nevelsk Port Authority building, which, judging from the smell of it, had been freshly painted, according to one of the Americans.   'Businesslike' Meeting **********''The main discussion was not jolly or overly tense,'' said an American on hand. ''It was businesslike.'' **********Mr. Tamba said the Russians had been pressed hard on whether they had recovered bodies from the downed airliner. **********''The Soviets told us on the 20th of this month they had no bodies or body parts to return,'' he said. ''We asked Romanenko persistently, and I looked him straight in the face and asked if they really hadn't found any. Romanenko said the Soviets had found no human remains whatsoever.'' **********The Tsugaru stayed at Nevelsk for five hours, then started back to Otaru, a journey that should take until early Tuesday morning. There was a stopover tonight at Wakkanai at the northern tip of Hokkaido, to give reporters a chance to view the debris. **********Officials said the material would be taken to the Hokkaido prefectural capital of Sapporo, where some 450 items recovered on Japanese beaches have also been stored.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/busin.main_headline: REFRACTORY MAKER STAKES ITS SURVIVAL ON A RESTRUCTURING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/busin.print_headline: REFRACTORY MAKER STAKES ITS SURVIVAL ON A RESTRUCTURING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/busin.body_text: **********When American steel production began a free fall in 1980, the General Refractories Company and others that make refractory tiles for lining steel furnaces had a choice: shrink or die. **********Two years later General Refractories of nearby Bala-Cynwyd chose retrenchment, and scheduled the closing of five of its twelve domestic plants. Today, despite the improvement in orders for some steel products, the company is still struggling. **********On Tuesday, General Refractories got some help from its lenders when four banks in the United States and one in Canada agreed to restructure and extend for three years $29.5 million in loans. The financial package was based on the company's restructuring efforts, which began in February 1982. **********''When this program is completed, we will have a smaller and leaner company with considerably less debt,'' said Robert W. Smith, the president and chief executive officer. ''We plan to focus our resources in those product lines and geographic areas where we have the best profit potential.'' **********The company reported a loss of $63.5 million for 1982, compared with a loss of nearly $19 million in 1981. The 1982 loss included a one-time charge of $43.8 million from the cost of restructuring the company and write-downs of investments for affiliates. Sales dropped to $340.8 million in 1982 from $409.8 million in 1981. **********Russell Sheldon, a senior economist with the Mellon Bank, who follows the refractory business, does not expect refractories - and the steel industry to which they are tied - to regain their pre-1980 peak. But he does think there is reason for optimism among refractory producers, and predicts that domestic refractory shipments will grow by 18 percent in physical volume and 23 percent in dollar terms in 1983. **********Mr. Sheldon said such growth would put General Refractories, one of the top five domestic refractory concerns, on a better footing to survive. Pay Cuts and Layoffs **********The retrenchment aims in that direction. In February 1982, the first step was a 20 percent pay cut for all domestic salaried employees. By last January, 850 people of a total domestic work force of 2,100 had been laid off. The company has also announced that it will close its headquarters in Bala-Cynwyd and relocate administrative employees to the refractories division in Pittsburgh. **********In addition, General Refractories plans to sell its three building product plants, which manufacture insulation, and its building board business. **********The other major players in the refractory industry are Harbison Walker, which is owned by Dresser Industries; North American Refractories, owned by the Allied Corporation; Basic Refractories, owned by Combustion Engineering Inc., and Kaiser Refractories, owned by Kaiser Industries. General Refractories is the only independent in the group. **********General Refractories, founded in 1922, had easy success in that decade, as did many enterprises that fed the steel industry. The company started shedding its peripheral and nonprofitable businesses in 1979, when it sold the Ohio Lime Company, a limestone producer; two small electrical equipment businesses in Michigan; an industrial cleaning company in New York, and its half interest in a construction concern. **********The plan of the restructuring was to concentrate resources on its thermal control products - refractory and insulation products - and its mineral filtration products. Nearly 70 percent of the company's sales are derived from refractory products. The company sells about two-thirds of those products in foreign markets, and until recently it was able to rely on foreign sales to pull it through slumps in the steel industry in the United States, and to count on its domestic sales to balance overseas slumps. **********But as the steel industry in both the United States and Europe has not recovered from the recession, General Refractories has been pulled down by both markets. **********With little hope for an upturn, the company's chairman, John P.  Sachs, devised and executed the survival plan. Mr. Sachs is president of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, a privately held, New York-based producer of industrial carbon material that owns 26 percent of General Refractories' common shares. **********Last July he replaced four resigning members of General Refractories' 11-member board with specialists: a banker, an accountant, a steel industry executive, and an individual with years of experience in the Federal Government and in advertising. **********''We were faced with having to restructure some credit agreements and to adjust our market share in the shrinking refractories industry,'' Mr. Sachs said. ''These were professionals with many years of expertise and know-how that could help us reach that aim - drastically restructuring the business.'' **********In September, General Refractories' president and chief executive, John Hartshorn, retired and was replaced by Mr. Smith, 66 years old, who had spent 44 years with the United States Steel Corporation, retiring in 1981 as executive vice president. **********With the housecleaning mostly done, Mr. Smith envisions a slow recovery. He says General Refractories will not return to its 1981 revenue level of $409 million until at least 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Clash in Chad Breaks Lull in Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.body_text: **********Chadian forces clashed with anti-Government rebels at the northeastern outpost of Fada today to break a weeklong lull in the civil war, Information Minister Mahamat Soumalia said. **********But he told reporters that the engagement was ''not very violent'' and gave no indication of the outcome. **********(The Associated Press quoted Mr. Soumalia as having said that the Reagan Administration's decision, announced Tuesday, to send $10 million in nonlethal military equipment to the central African country was ''not a lot, but better than nothing.'') **********Skirmishing outside Fada apparently began Tuesday between retreating rebel columns and the Government forces pursuing them.  According to today's report, the combat has now reached the isolated town, which lies in a mountain range about 560 miles northeast of the capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/11/world.body_text: **********Five people were shot and five others injured with clubs and chains during political clashes in Kalamai, on the southern coast of Greece, Saturday night, the police reported today. **********They said the shootings occurred during clashes that broke out as supporters of the conservative opposition New Democracy Party painted slogans on walls shortly before their leader, Evanghelos Averoff, addressed a rally in Kalamai. He said members of the ruling Panhellenic Socialist Movement were responsible for the incidents. **********Mr. Averoff said a total of 16 people had been injured. The wounded were taken to a hospital but were not in serious condition, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.body_text: **********ATLANTA HE is best known as ''Captain Courageous'' - the skipper of the yachts that won the 1977 America's Cup and the stormy 1979 Fastnet race, off the south of England, in which 15 other sailors drowned. At Fastnet last week, Ted Turner tried for another victory at sea. But the waters were calmer this year, and another boat came in first. **********If Ted Turner thrives in stormy weather, it is not only at sea. While the rest of the cable industry is going through a shakeout, R. E. (Ted) Turner, television's bad boy, and his company, Turner Broadcasting System Inc., appear to be on the verge of turning a profit for the first time since 1978. **********After losing $3.4 million last year on revenues of $165.6 million, TBS has reported a profit of $6.3 million for the first half of this year - roughly equivalent to its loss in the period a year ago - and is estimating a $20 million profit for 1983. **********Compared with the three major networks, that is a modest sum, but it contrasts quite favorably with the three networks' experience in cable. In the past year, CBS Cable and RCTV - which was half-owned by NBC's parent, RCA - have gone under, and ABC's services are foundering. **********''Everybody decided the ship was sailing and they'd better get on,'' the 44-year-old Mr. Turner said in an interview at TBS headquarters here. ''It's a highly competitive environment right now.'' He and TBS are responsible for much of that competition. If cable has a single pioneer, it is arguably brash, outspoken Ted Turner. The so-called ''Mouth of the South,'' Mr. Turner has shaken up the television industry repeatedly since he entered it in 1970 with the purchase of a failing Atlanta UHF channel, which in 1976 he turned into a superstation - beaming its signal via satellite to cable television systems across the nation.  While he is still a controversial and perhaps unpopular figure in broadcasting, there are few who would quibble with his claim - widely publicized in his trade promotions - that ''I was cable before cable was cool.'' Cable is ''cool'' now, and so is Mr. Turner.  After creating his superstation, WTBS, Mr.  Turner broke new ground with Cable News Network, a 24-hour-a-day all-news cable channel that has forced the broadcasters to increase their late-night news programming. Most recently, he has been talking up an ad hoc fourth network of broadcast stations to which TBS would transmit shows - from sports to the 1983 Miss World contest - that were once the automatic property of the big three.  For the past two years, TBS has taken in about half of the entire cable industry's advertising revenues, which were $241.8 million last year, according to Paul Kagan, the cable industry analyst. Most of the sales have been generated by the superstation, WTBS, which today offers a diet mainly of old movies, reruns and sports, and goes into 26 million homes.  CNN, which was begun in 1980, is now received in 20 million households via satellite relay.  Its spinoff, CNN Headline News, television news in 30-minute formats akin to all-news radio, is offered in 4.5 million cable households and, in addition, is carried by 131 broadcast stations.  ''This place has the opportunity to be very profitable by 1986 or 1987,'' said Robert Wussler, the former president of the CBS television network who is executive vice president of TBS and president of WTBS. Conceivably, some TBS executives say, its revenues could match any one of the big three networks by 1990. **********It is a considerable boast. Last year, both CBS and ABC's broadcast divisions had revenues of more than $2 billion. Other Turner executives remain more skeptical. In terms of advertising, ''the networks are still the only game in town,'' said one. ''We're not replacing the networks, we're supplementing them.'' **********TBS has significant perils ahead. Perhaps the most worrisome is the potential programming shortage, in the view of Bonnie Cook, an analyst with J. C. Bradford & Company who follows TBS closely. ''I see these big combinations taking place in the entertainment industry,'' she said, and they will increasingly compete for programming. The most noteworthy example is Tri-Star Pictures, the new movie-making consortium of CBS, Columbia Pictures and Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, which has more subscribers than any other pay cable service. **********COMPANIES will have an edge if they have their own production company, she suggested, ''and that's one thing Turner doesn't have, with WTBS.'' While the company is making some original programming, it may not be enough to fill its enormous appetite in the long term, Miss Cook said, particularly if the networks are able to syndicate shows. **********And in the short term, Mr. Wussler and others at TBS recognize, the company's flamboyant chairman and president could well have an idea that would jeopardize the company's newfound profitability. Each time that TBS has appeared to be entering a period of financial stability, it seems, Mr. Turner has headed into uncharted and risky waters - first with CNN, then with CNN Headline News. **********Now, Mr. Turner talks of making movies for families, and even building a studio in Atlanta. According to Mr. Kagan, TBS is contemplating a joint venture with Home Box Office to set up a satellite programming delivery service. While TBS management declined to comment on the report, it acknowledged that anything was possible. ''Ted's always going to be that way,'' Mr. Wussler said. ''I wait every day for Ted to call me in and say, 'Here's what we're going to do.' '' **********All those ventures are tangential to TBS's real business, in Mr. Wussler's view. ''We're in the circulation business,'' he said. ''The future is getting WTBS and CNN into as many homes as possible.'' **********Mr. Turner, for his part, said that he has no new ventures planned that would upend the company. ''I hope not to be in the red again,'' he said. Due to the company's hard-won financial stability, he said at a party in June to celebrate CNN's third birthday, TBS was no longer looking for a merger with another television network. **********In fact, his widely reported talks earlier this year with the three major networks have been interpreted as an effort by Mr. Turner to put a value on his holdings; he owns 87 percent of TBS, which is traded over-the- counter. A merger would thus have made him a substantial shareholder in one of the three major networks, but none of the major networks apparently took him seriously.  ''I said that I wanted a merger, I didn't want to sell,'' Mr. Turner recalled. ''It was all or nothing.'' **********Even if Ted Turner does not go off on another speculative venture, WTBS's and CNN's circulation - and thus their future - is under challenge. For one thing, the news services are facing competition from the Satellite News Channel, a joint venture of the Westinghouse Corporation - which owns Group W Cable - and ABC Video Enterprises. Introduced a year ago with bonuses of up to $1 per subscriber to system operators, SNC has signed up 7.3 million households and is projecting that it will be in more than 10 million by year-end. **********''SNC is absolutely eating into our market, they're costing us a large fortune,'' Mr. Turner complained. What's more, according to TBS, they are doing it illegally by withholding Group W cable franchise systems, including the one in New York. Accordingly, TBS is suing Group W for monopolistic practices. **********''Ted Turner does not react very well to competition,'' acknowledged Dan Ritchie, Group W's chairman. Group W, which denies the charges, has counter-sued, accusing CNN and WTBS of unfair competition. Mr. Richie noted that 87 Group W systems carry CNN, another 103 carry SNC and 72 carry both. The reason that Manhattan's Group W does not carry CNN, he said, is that, with 26 channels, it does not have the room for an additional service, and the system operator opted for SNC. **********Another threat to WTBS are the significantly higher copyright royalty fees that cable system operators must pay now for each distant signal. So far, WTBS has lost only 300,000 subscribers, but the fee increase could make it more difficult to add subscribers in new systems. Since most of those systems are in major urban areas, that could limit WTBS's potential viewing audience. The fees are ''confiscatory,'' said Mr. Turner, who is lobbying to change the copyright agreement. **********THE royalty fees are worrisome **********mainly because the superstation **********is TBS's only guaranteed moneymaker. Last year, WTBS contributed $96.6 million to revenues and $31.2 million to operating profits. That was an impressive profit margin, but the sum was not enough to make up for the losses of the news channels and the Turner baseball and basketball teams, the Atlanta Braves and Hawks. ''WTBS continues to be the locomotive of the corporation,'' said Mr. Wussler. WTBS ''is all we've got,'' said William Bevins, TBS's chief financial officer. **********CNN was actually profitable between last October and May, Mr. Bevins said, but the ink reddened again this summer with the renegotiation of contracts with systems operators. With SNC offering an alternative, systems operators reduced their per-subscriber payment to TBS to 10 cents from 15 cents, ''and it's going to go on down,'' said Mr. Bevins. (Such fees are important, as CNN sells only 40 percent of its commercial time. WTBS sells the same percentage over all, but it sells between 65 and 70 percent of its commercial prime time, for which advertisers pay a higher rate than for daytime.) This year, as in 1982, he said, CNN will probably lose $6 million and CNN Headline News will lose another $10 million. **********While CNN Headline News may be profitable next year, he said, ''it's too early to say if CNN will be profitable. We could make it profitable if we cut back service, but that's not in the cards.'' Instead, money is being plowed into the news-gathering operations, with two more overseas bureaus - Paris and Mexico City - opening next year. **********The sports teams, even the high- flying Braves, are also a drag on profits, said Mr. Bevins, ''but for us, the ball clubs are a program. If the club performs well, we have a free program, one of our best-rated. We will make a lot more from televising them than the clubs will lose.'' The Braves games, along with 4,200 movies under license, give WTBS a reliable source of supply. **********''We don't need to buy or make a thing 'til 1987,'' said Mr. Wussler. In fact, the company will have to acquire additional programming, he conceded, but ''I know where to get the others,'' he added. ''I see no reason why we can't have a steady stream of programming. We provide a very good national marketplace for programs that have been around home once or twice. There's no better marketplace for a third or fourth or fifth syndication.'' **********Still, TBS has spent more than $20 million in the past year or so to make or acquire programming. It has given $6 million to Jacques Cousteau for a series on the Amazon, which will run on WTBS next spring and be syndicated worldwide, and which nobody expects to pay its way. ''Someone had to keep Cousteau going, and it's a prestige thing to do, like a loss leader in the supermarket,'' said Mr. Turner. **********THE plan is to build up a substantial syndication business with **********the Cousteau show, other original programming and acquisitions that include some British family series, the Miss World contest and ''Centennial,'' the miniseries based on the James Michener novel. Some of the shows will be fodder for a fourth network; others will be sold outright for cash. But whether WTBS has the expertise for syndication is debatable. ''I'm not sure you can run something like that out of Atlanta,'' said one television executive. ''You need to be on the streets of Los Angeles or New York.'' **********''If you buy it right, you make money,'' said Henry Gillespie, a veteran programmer who is in charge of syndication at TBS. ''If you buy it wrong, you don't. We've done it more wrong than right. We're trying to become the best bidder.'' **********''More than ever'' is how Mr. Turner describes his commitment to cable and TBS, and branching out into original programming and syndication may be enough to occupy him for a while. But it is unclear how much longer he will be satisfied. **********What interests Ted Turner, according to Mr. Wussler, only partly in jest, is ''saving the country, saving the world,'' and there has been speculation that his next step will be to enter politics. In any event, the television industry would be mistaken to relax. ''His habit has been to keep putting his reach beyond his grasp,'' said Paul Kagan, the cable industry analyst. ''It's his style to go for the next brass ring.'' **********PROGRAMMING:THE TURNER WAY **********If Turner Broadcasting System is going to create more original programming, the likelihood is that it will be relatively high- toned, family-oriented and in keeping with Ted Turner's personal brand of morality and politics - ''archconservative with some big liberal holes,'' in the view of Robert Wussler, executive vice president of TBS and head of WTBS. **********Accordingly, the shows that WTBS has originated to date tend to be patriotic and upbeat. There is ''Portrait of America,'' a five-year project that has vowed to take an in-depth look at each of the 50 states. Another is ''Nice People'' which, as the publicity notes, focuses on ''unsung heroes who, as ordinary people, do extraordinary things for the well-being of others.'' Next week will bring the debut of ''Good News,'' a nightly news- format show that will recap the happier events of the day. Is that a Ted Turner inspiration? ''They're all his inspirations,'' said Mr. Wussler. **********Not all the shows are so light- hearted. There have been documentaries on world over-population, the capacity to grow food and youth unemployment. Such subjects rarely find favor with advertisers, but they do with Mr. Turner, and so they run on WTBS. ''He's able to do that because he owns the place.'' Mr. Wussler noted. ''Ted's a big fan of documentaries.'' **********''We'll stay in the positive programming area as much as we can,'' Mr. Turner promised in an interview last month. That, he added, is in marked contrast to network products such as CBS's ''Dukes of Hazzard'' - ''which dramatizes reckless driving and paints the law as bumbling, corrupt officials.'' **********But some WTBS programming is aimed at advertisers. The series on which WTBS is pinning some of its biggest hopes is ''Starcade,'' a video arcade- style game show aimed at the hard-to-get teenage audience. ''It will not win any Emmys or Peabodys,'' said Henry Gillespie, a veteran programmer who is in charge of syndication at TBS. ''In some cases, we might even say, 'that's not ours.' But it will be an important commercial entity on WTBS and in syndication.'' **********'''Starcade' is a kids' show,'' said Mr. Turner. ''It's not particularly uplifting.''
