https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/busin.body_text: **********HELD instrument, regarded as important in the growing commercial practice of sorting consumer goods with bar-code laser scanners, was patented this week for its manufacturer, Symbol Technologies Inc. of Hauppauge, L.I. The device weighs only a pound and can be plugged into electronic cash registers. **********Jerome Swartz, the principal inventor and the chief executive officer of the company, said it was the first truly portable, handheld, trigger-actuated laser scanner that reads the familiar black and white lines appearing on many consumer products sold today. **********Patent 4,387,297 was granted Mr. Swartz, Edward Barkan, a staff member, and Shelley A. Harrison, a former employee. The device is being marketed under its trademark, LS-7000. **********The use of bar-code identification is widespread. The Defense Department has directed its use by military contractors, sports officials use it to record marathon runners and others use it as the ''eyes'' of robots. Symbol Technologies said it expects that a number of new applications will be developed as the use of the portable scanner becomes more widespread. **********Walter Gardner, chief financial officer and general counsel of the company, has announced that orders for new scanners now total about $4 million. The company, which will report a loss for the quarter ended May 31, expects to show operating profits beginning in June.  The list price of the device is about $1,600, with discounts for bulk orders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.body_text: **********A week ago the State Department rejected visa applications from Nicaragua's Interior Minister, Tomas Borge, and Roberto d'Aubuisson, the President of the Salvadoran Constituent Assembly. **********A White House official explained that the Government had denied a visa to Mr. Borge, a leading official of the left-wing Sandanista Government, because it did not want to give him ''a propaganda platform'' in the United States. Mr. d'Aubuisson, leader of the right-wing party known as Arena, was said to have been kept out because of the Administration's concern over terrorist death squads to which he has been linked. **********The action has prompted questions on whether - and under what circumstances - the Government should deny visas solely on political grounds. The White House was reported to have been sharply divided from State Department officials on the decision to deny entry to Mr. Borge and Mr. d'Aubuisson. **********Defenders of the Government's action argue that the denial of such visas is an important instrument of foreign policy and that the Government has broad rights to determine who can enter the United States. **********Opponents of the Government's action argue that a refusal to grant visas on political grounds denies Americans access to information that might contradict a given Administration's position. They also argue that such denials are inconsistent with the country's tradition of civil liberties and tarnish the United States' image abroad. **********The Background **********Under Section 212 (a) 27 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Government can exclude foreigners ''whose activities would be contrary to the public interest.'' **********Section 212 (a) 28 of the act permits the Government to exclude foreigners who are members of Communist or anarchist organizations, as well as those who are not members but ''write, publish, circulate, display or distribute any written or printed matter advocating or teaching opposition to all organized government'' or ''advocating and teaching the economic, international and government doctrines of world Communism.'' **********The law, known as the McCarran- Walter Act, was enacted in 1952 and includes many other grounds on which the Government can keep foreigners out of the United States, whether they want to live here or simply visit. It has frequently been invoked to exclude not only foreign government officials but also artists, writers and opposition politicians. **********Aryeh Neier, a law professor at New York University and vice chairman of the Fund for Free Expression, an organization that tries to promote free speech around the world, opposes any exclusion of foreigners on ideological grounds. But he said that ''the courts have always differentiated between what one may do to Americans inside the country and what one may do to outsiders who want to come in. **********''The courts,'' he continued, ''have held that noncitizens outside the country do not enjoy the same First Amendment rights as do citizens or even noncitizens who are inside the United States.''  Degree of Discretion at Issue **********Few people - most of them ardent libertarians - say the Government should open America's borders to all comers. The differences on the issue are over how much discretion the Government should have to keep foreigners out and whether political reasons are ever sufficient grounds for excluding either those who want to move to the United States or those who simply want to visit. **********The Argument For Political Exclusion **********Most of those who argue that the government should be able to keep out foreigners on political grounds acknowledge that the issue is a sensitive one and that the Government should use its power with discretion. **********But they contend that it is a power the Government should nonetheless have in reserve for certain cases. **********''Is there never, ever a foreign policy reason for refusing entry to a foreigner, especially a foreign government official?'' asked Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs. ''My own view is that there are definitely dangers of abuse, but there are at least a few circumstances when we might send the wrong message by letting someone in - for example, by letting in a political figure who had violated human rights.'' **********''We're not keeping anybody's views out,''' Mr. Abrams added. ''Views are admitted to the United States without visas. We are keeping out certain officials for certain foreign policy reasons.'' **********Charles Fairbanks, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Human Rights, said: ''If you can't keep out Goering, there would be something wrong with the law. '' He added: ''My mind goes back to the 30's because there were all these high-ranking Nazi missions that went around the world to convince the public in countries where rearmament efforts were going on that Germany was not dangerous and was not violating human rights. And I would think that there would be circumstances that you would want to send the diplomatic signal that such a mission cannot proceed.''  Borge Decision Defended **********Mr. Fairbanks said that in denying a visa to Mr. Borge, the Government was not trying to ''keep out what Borge has been saying,'' since Nicaragua's position on the conflicts in Central America and the United States' role there had been widely reported in the American press and on television. **********''It's because it's a high official and because the decision has a diplomatic character,'' Mr. Fairbanks said of the decision to deny Mr. Borge a visa. ''We're at an important and delicate situation in managing our relations with Nicaragua and in the Contadora project and we might want to send some kind of diplomatic signal by keeping Borge out.'' He was speaking of the Contadora group of Latin American nations - Mexico, Panama, Colombia and Venezuela - that is trying to resolve the conflicts in Central America. **********Juliana Pilon, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research institute in Washington, said she believed the power to deny visas should be used ''very, very seldom,'' but that the power nonetheless constituted ''a form of political warfare or diplomatic warfare.'' **********''There is definitely something to be said for denying visas to people who would use this country as a platform for propaganda,'' she said, ''or for people whose very presense in the country would be seen as symbolic.'' **********The Argument Against Political Exclusion **********Arthur Helton, director of the political asylum project for the Lawyers' Committee for International Human Rights, another group that lobbies for freedom of expression, said that opponents of political exclusion recognized that ''there are legitimate national security interests the U.S. can have.'' **********He said he and most other opponents of exclusion on political grounds could support keeping would- be visitors or immigrants out ''if there's specific reason to belive that someone may engage in terrorist activities.'' **********But the existing law, he said, contains provisions that ''sweep far too broadly'' and permit the Government ''too much discretion so that the political climate can influence the decision-making process as to who will be admitted.'' **********He added that as a practical matter, ''people who wish to do nothing more here than present ideas'' can always find other ways to get their views across to the American people, so that exclusion, he contended, did not even accomplish the Government's goals. **********''They can write their ideas and send them here,'' he said, ''or even just telephone them over the border.''  Old Law Is Attacked **********Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, has introduced a bill to repeal many of the provisions of the McCarran-Walter Act that give the Government a broad basis on which to exclude visitors. **********''The assumption should be that anybody can come here to visit unless they are going to be violent, going to overthrow the Government, are terrorists, have an infectious disease, are ex-Nazis or are so mentally ill that they might cause problems because they are out of control,'' Mr. Frank said. **********Mr. Frank said that refusing visas on political grounds damaged the country's image abroad. ''It's degrading, the spectacle of the United States being afraid of these people,'' he said. **********He cited as especially disturbing the United States' decision last March to deny a visa to Hortensia Bussi de Allende, the widow of the Chilean President, Salvador Allende Gossens. Mrs. Allende was refused a visa, ''because her entry to make various public appearances and speeches has been determined to be prejudicial to U.S. interests,'' a State Department official said at the time. **********''Here we are yelling at the Russians, as we should because they do not have an open society,'' Mr. Frank commented, ''and then we say that Salvador Allende's widow can't come and make a speech.'' **********The Outlook **********The existing provisions allowing the Government to deny visas on political grounds have survived previous legal tests. In 1972, for example, the Supreme Court upheld the decision to deny entry to a Belgian Marxist scholar and journalist who had been invited to speak before academic and other groups. **********The Court said that the ''plenary government power to make policies and rules for exclusion of aliens'' prevailed over the First Amendment rights of Americans. **********Mr. Helton, however, said he expected new legal challenges to the McCarran-Walter Act's exclusion provisions, possibly involving the cases of Mr. Borge and Mr. d'Aubuisson. **********In the meantime, there appears to be no overwhelming sentiment in Congress to repeal or modify the act's provisions, and the the Government will probably continue to have broad power to deny admission to the United States for political or diplomatic reasons. **********But Representative Frank said Congress would hold hearings next year on his and other proposals to modify the law, and that some of his colleagues in Congress had expressed interest in limiting the grounds on which visas and admission can be denied. Under Mr. Frank's proposal, the broad list in the McCarran-Walter Act would be narrowed so that only criminals, suspected terrorists, the dangerously insane, the infectiously ill and former Nazis could routinely be denied visas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/world.main_headline: Arens Says Syrians Bombed Marines' Building in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/world.print_headline: Arens Says Syrians Bombed Marines' Building in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel today accused Syria of bombing the United States Marine headquarters in Beirut and attacked the Syrians as a group with ''subhuman moral standards.'' **********''Nobody else could have done it,'' he said in a television interview from Israel that was broadcast on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation.'' Mr.  Arens said there was little doubt the Syrians were to blame. **********''The reason we know it's the Syrians, first of all, it's got to be a group with that kind of subhuman moral standards, and that's the Syrians,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Senate Democrats today proposed a broad economic program intended to counter what they called the ''aimless drift'' of President Reagan's policies. **********The program includes establishment of a national council with labor, business and government members, and Federal programs that range from stimulation of joint research and development to community service jobs for displaced workers. **********In addition, the proposal calls for improved training, better education programs, federal assistance for state development programs and temporary protection for struggling industries. **********The Democratic senators emphasized that their program did not include the government intervention in the economy that has become associated with the term ''industrial policy.'' **********Referring to the new plan, Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts said: ''It will be remembered as the first time the Democratic party turned away from central planning. This is an attempt to work with the private sector, not dictate.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Seven Russians were granted a patent this week for a method of growing diamonds. **********Patent 4,406,871, which was awarded to Mikhail I. Samoilovich and his dozen co-inventors, says the process may be advantageously employed in the manufacture of diamonds for use in the tool-making industry and in solid-state, or semiconductor, instruments. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.body_text: **********Thailand and Malaysia have begun major coordinated military assaults on Communist guerrillas based along their common border, a Thai military officer said today. **********About 2,000 Thai troops supported by artillery and helicopter gunships Tuesday surrounded three villages in Yala province, 525 miles south of Bangkok, the officer said. **********Malaysian troops conducted attacks from their side of the border to trap the insurgents, he said. **********He said the area is suspected to be the base of the 12th regiment of the Communist Party of Malaysia, with some 200 guerrillas operating from the base.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.main_headline: AS GRENADA EXODUS BEGINS, HAVANA COUNTS 27 DEATHS, AT MOST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.print_headline: AS GRENADA EXODUS BEGINS, HAVANA COUNTS 27 DEATHS, AT MOST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.body_text: **********The Government said today that 27 Cubans, at most, were killed last week in the American invasion of Grenada. **********The toll was announced as the Government began bringing home hundreds of diplomats, construction workers and military personnel from Grenada. **********Charles A. Gillespie, the United States Ambassador to Grenada, said Thursday that he thought the number of Cubans killed was about 25, or about half the number previously reported by the United States. The American death toll in the invasion has been put at 18. **********The repatriation of the Cubans, 11 days after United States troops first invaded the tiny eastern Caribbean island, came after long negotiations between United States and Cuban officials that ended at 5:15 A.M. today.   Greetings From Castro **********The first plane, an Aeroflot Ilyushin 62, arrived shortly before midday carrying 53 diplomats and their families from Cuba, the Soviet Union, North Korea, Bulgaria and East Germany. It was greeted at Jose Marti Airport by Fidel Castro, members of Cuba's Politburo, a military honor guard and band. **********Mr. Castro warmly embraced the Cubans as they stepped off the ramp and shook hands somewhat more formally with the diplomats from the Eastern bloc. The diplomats left the airport by bus, traveling along roads lined with workers and schoolchildren who had been released from their normal routines to bid them welcome. **********The diplomats left Grenada soon after midnight and stopped in Merida, Mexico, before heading to Havana. With their arrival the Government said all its diplomats had been removed from Grenada except ''the minimum we consider indispensable to remain there until the evacuation of those fallen in combat and the solution of other pending problems.'' Among those remaining on the island was the Cuban Ambassador, Julian Torres Rizo. **********The Government published a list today of 679 Cubans who it said were alive on Grenada and awaiting transportation back to Cuba. It published a separate list of 38 Cubans whose fates it did not know. It said, however, that it knew 9 Cuban citizens were in the Soviet Embassy, making 27 the maximum number that could have been killed in last week's hostilities. **********Counting the 57 wounded Cubans and 10 medical personnel who returned earlier this week, the total number of Cubans on the island at the time of the invasion would be 784. **********The Cubans had hoped to evacuate all personnel as quickly as possible, using their own aircraft. But a diplomatic note from the United States interest section in Havana said that ''the airport facilities in Grenada are currently not in condition to receive aircraft.'' **********Under a plan accepted by the Cubans this morning in what they said was an effort ''to avoid delaying in the least the return of our comrades,'' it was agreed that United States planes would shuttle the prisoners from Grenada to Barbados and Cuban aircraft would take them from Barbados to their homeland. Because of delays involved in this procedure, the process of evacuating all Cuban personnel is expected to take several days. **********The first plane sent under the negotiated plan left Cuba at 7:12 A.M. today and was to arrive here this evening. Cuban officials said this evening that they did not know how many passengers would be on board. **********The Cuban Government also included in one of its communiques today what it called the ''surprising news'' that it had not yet been decided on Grenada whether to rupture diplomatic relations with Cuba. **********The communique, citing an Agence France-Presse report, quoted the island's Governor General, Sir Paul Scoon, as saying that he had asked only ''that the Cuban mission be reduced to a minimum, pending the decision the provisional government adopts.'' The Cubans said earlier this week that they had been given 24 hours to remove all their diplomatic personnel from the island, a demand they had refused.   Wounded Cubans Interviewed **********Thursday night, the Government made interviews available with the wounded and ill Cubans who returned here Wednesday. Looking cleaner and calmer than when they arrived, most did not fit the image of the well-trained military men who the Pentagon said had offered stronger than expected resistance in the first phases of the invasion. **********Of five who were interviewed, four said they were construction workers and had been sleeping when the attack began and had no arms available to them. The fifth was a first lieutenant in the Cuban infantry, Emilio Montoya Garcia, who showed a small, ugly wound that he said was the result of shrapnel. **********One of the construction workers, Miguel Adama Gay, a 44-year-old steamroller operator who worked on the Point Salines airport, said he had not seen any Cuban military personnel in that area. ''They never came down there,'' he said. **********The four civilians offered few complaints about their treatment after capture on Grenada, although each said he had been questioned twice - once by a man in military dress who spoke fractured Spanish and a second time by a man in civilian dress who spoke Spanish fluently. **********They said that some of their colleagues had reportedly been asked whether they wanted to defect but that they knew of no one who had decided to do so. ''They didn't ask me, I'm too old for them to went me,'' said Ramon Rodriguez, a wizened, 60-year-old electrical engineer. **********The military man, Lieutenant Montoya, painted a different picture. He said he and several others had been kept out of doors after their capture from Oct. 25 to Oct. 27, in blistering heat by day and downpours by night, and that their treatment improved only after visits from Red Cross personnel. **********He also said that he had been subjected to ''psychological pressure,'' such as assault troops threatening him with rifles, and that he had for a time been prohibited from speaking with his colleagues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.main_headline: Danish Captain Is Fined For Fishing Near Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Danish Captain Is Fined For Fishing Near Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.body_text: **********An English court convicted the captain of a Danish trawler today for his ''flagrant and deliberate breach'' of new British laws banning Denmark from fishing inside a 12-mile zone and fined him $51,200. **********The captain, Kent Kirk, had sought his conviction to contest Britain's new fishing laws in the European Court of Justice. **********He said he would appeal his case through the British legal system first. **********As he left the court in this North Sea fishing port, Captain Kirk was cheered by a small crowd of mostly young people.  ''It has been a most pleasant trip,'' he said. ''The British people welcomed me and gave me wonderful support.'' Captain Kirk pleaded not guilty before three local magistrates. He was charged with violating British fishing rules imposed Jan. 1 after a Danish parliamentary committee rejected a Common Market fisheries compromise. **********Only Denmark is banned from the 12-mile fishing zone because it failed to put its own fishing measures into effect when the Common Market fishing policy expired Jan. 1. Other Common Market nations have agreed on fish shares within the zone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/02/busin.body_text: **********A strike by Local 122 of the United Automobile Workers at a Chrysler Corporation stamping plant in Twinsburg, Ohio, could halt all Chrysler's car-making operations by the end of this week, company officials said today. **********Baron Bates, Chrysler's vice president for public relations, said that if an agreement was not reached, ''this company closes down on Friday.'' **********Another spokesman confirmed that two of the company's eight assembly plants would shut down after operations today, idling 6,300 hourly workers, because of a lack of parts that the stamping plant provides. **********If the strike continues, only Chryser's two truck-making facilities, which are supplied by other stamping plants, could continue production. **********Talks between the company and the local broke down after an all-night negotiating session and the workers walked off their jobs this morning. **********Chrysler and the U.A.W. agreed on a national contract, covering about 56,000 Chrysler workers nationwide, last Labor Day, concerning basic economic issues and working conditions. The company also negotiates an agreement with each local covering details unique to each plant. **********At issue, according to local union officials who declined to go into detail, are safety conditions and work practices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Contentiousness is commonplace here at Notre Dame, the home field of the Gipper. And when dozens of business leaders, theologians and academics lined up against each other at the university this week, the debate over the economy was fought as hard as any gridiron encounter. **********More than 250 people packed the sessions of a three-day symposium on ''Catholic Social Teaching and the American Economy.'' Many hoped to influence and to help shape a pastoral letter on the economy, whose first draft is expected from the American Conference of Catholic Bishops in the fall of 1984. **********Containing the first economic pronouncements by the American branch of the Roman Catholic Church in 65 years, the letter is expected to generate even more controversy than the bishops' recent letter on nuclear war. **********The organizers said, however, that the topics reflected the bishops' concern about equity. ''That concern surfaces when there're enough unemployed people clamoring for people to listen to their cries,'' said the Rev. Oliver Williams, who teaches ethics in Notre Dame's business school. **********''The first question after that is, 'What do the bishops know about the economy?' '' he continued, ''And the answer is not a heck of a lot. But they 're learning. That's what this conference is about.''  Forum for Views Within Church **********The symposium, attended by the five bishops who will draft the letter, was actually a public forum for various views within the church. It is the only public hearing scheduled on the letter's contents. **********There appeared to be a widespread agreement on the need for Government policies that encourage continued economic growth. But that consensus broke down on matters of equity. Topics such as a guaranteed minimum income, materialism, industrial policy, union membership and full employment often pitted businessmen and conservative economists against theologians and social activists. **********''I came here with some trepidation, but I wanted to see where they were coming from,'' said John B. Caron, president of Caron International, a New York-based manufacturer of knitting yarn. He took to the floor to object when one cleric suggested that the letter contain a section on rights to union membership. He told of a Caron plant in Kentucky that might be forced to close without union concessions.  Symposium's Main Topics **********Lay business leaders have been questioning the wisdom and fairness of such a statement ever since the bishops made their intentions known last month. And the symposium's main topics - economic planning, employment, the poor and the disadvantaged, and trade with developing countries - did little to allay their fears that the document would be excessively liberal, or even leftist.  Charges of unfairness to business greeted the bishops' last letter on the economy, in 1919. Business leaders labeled as socialistic its call for health care, a minimum wage, Social Security and unemployment insurance, church historians said. **********The bishops are sensitive to these doubts and have postponed the publication of the final draft of their letter until after the Presidential election. But Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee promised the debate would affect 1984 politics. ''It would be naive to think what we are considering does not have political implications,'' he said at a news conference. **********Organizers invited to their forum people with various shades of opinion. Marina Whitman, chief economist at the General Motors Corporation; Peter G. Peterson, chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, and Michael Novak of the American Enterprise Institute were some representatives of the conservative viewpoint. **********Liberals on the various panels included F. Ray Marshall, Graciela Olivarz and C. Fred Bergsten, all former Carter Administration officials. **********The attempts at even-handedness left some of participants a little frustrated. ''I have a feeeling we haven't captured the sense of urgency among the poor,'' Bishop William K. Weigand of Salt Lake City said at one point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/29/world.body_text: **********AROUND THE WORLD; U.S. Rejects Soviet Plan For Nuclear-Free Zone **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (Reuters) - The United States today rejected a Soviet proposal for a nuclear-free zone in Central Europe, saying such plans are neither realistic nor effective. **********Moscow called Thursday for a zone 310 to 370 miles wide along the border between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and the Warsaw Pact nations. **********The zone would include nearly all of East and West Germany.  John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, said proposals for such zones had been advanced in various forms in the past and carefully studied by the NATO allies. **********''We consistently have found that such proposals are not realistic or effective,'' he said. ''We believe that they would not contribute to security and stability in Europe.'' **********Mr. Hughes said proposals such as that made by Moscow diverted attention from efforts being made in nuclear weapon talks in Geneva and conventional forces negotiations in Vienna. ---- **********LONDON, Jan. 28 (Reuters) - British opposition leaders today welcomed Soviet proposals for a nuclear-free zone and accused Western governments of allowing the Soviet Union to take the initiative on disarmament. **********Denis Healey, the Labor Party's spokesman on foreign affairs, condemned Western leaders for ignoring a similar plan put forward by Sweden last year. **********Former Foreign Secretary David Owen, deputy leader of the Social Democrats, described the Soviet suggestion as important but said Moscow should not be allowed to seize the initiative. **********A Foreign Office spokesman said the Soviet plan represented nothing new.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Bossard Consultants, France's largest management consulting firm, plans an expansion in the United States and has hired Frank D. Rich for the new job of president of United States operations. **********Mr. Rich, 55, most recently was a principal of Case & Company. **********He has been a principal and partner in other consulting firms, as well as president of Fry Consultants Inc. **********At Bossard, Mr. Rich will concentrate on expanding the company's business with American companies. Michel L. Morin, general manager of the New York office, has been named senior vice president and will be responsible for French and other European companies doing business here. **********Mr. Rich is a grandson of the founder of Rich's department store in Atlanta. The business was sold to Federated Department Stores in 1975. Mr. Rich said he is a general management consultant and does not specialize in retailing, although he has opinions about the field. **********''The department stores that have done well and survived,'' he said, ''have been those that have had the sense to foresee a need to get into mass merchandising - into more of a middle market,'' he said. He called department stores that have not made any moves to change ''dinosaurs.'' **********Mr. Rich will be the first American to lead the United States operations, which are partly owned by the Worms Group, a European holding company. Asked whether Socialism would hamper French companies' interest in the United States, he said, ''I am not fully in sympathy with the Socialist Government, but as it relates to French investment abroad, the Government has been helpful and supportive and has provided good incentives for companies seeking investments in hard-currency countries.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Castle & Cooke Inc., the Honolulu- based food, real estate and manufacturing conglomerate, wants Dr Pepper for its summertime earnings and management expertise in the soft- drink industry, company officials and securities analysts say. **********The Hawaiian company made its $560 million bid for the Dallas-based Dr Pepper Monday through a new investment group, the DPCC Acquisition Corporation. The initials stand for Dr Pepper and Castle & Cooke. It was undeterred by a definitive takeover agreement for $512.5 million that Dr Pepper had signed with another investment group the day before. And it apparently was not put off by a decline in Dr Pepper's earnings in the last year, as it slipped from third to fourth place nationally behind Seven- Up, Pepsi and Coke. **********Sam Schneider, a spokesman for Castle & Cooke at its Honolulu headquarters, said the company was interested in Dr Pepper for the same reason that it had been interested in the A&W root beer business, which ''was acquired through a similar type of arrangement in August.'' **********Mr. Schneider said Dr Pepper would help to provide ''a steady flow of year-round earnings, particularly in the summertime when our earnings have tended to be weakest.'' **********For its part, Dr Pepper is not saying no. It indicated that the leveraged buyout agreement it had with a group led by the Wall Street investment firm of Forstmann Little & Company was not enough to stop it from considering the new offer. **********''Virtually every definitive agreement has certain outs that, if another proposal is better for the shareholders, you can go ahead and study that offer and the first offer becomes null and void,'' said L. Dan Thompson, Dr Pepper's treasurer. **********DPCC said yesterday that it had obtained nearly all of the financing for the deal, which amounts to $24 a share, from six unidentified banks. The offer expires next Monday. **********The Forstmann Little agreement amounts to $22 a share. **********Dr Pepper closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $22.125, up 87.5 cents. **********Forstmann Little did not indicate whether it might submit a higher bid, instead attacking what it called the ''highly conditional and incomplete nature'' of the DPCC plan. Theodore J. Forstmann, a general partner, cited ''the uncertain nature of virtually every element in their financing scheme.'' **********If DPCC is successful in acquiring Dr Pepper, its bid could be even more costly because of a provision in the Forstmann Little agreement. That contract gives the investment firm the option to buy 4.15 million shares of Dr Pepper at $22 a share under certain conditions. **********If Forstmann Little were to exercise its option and then resell the stock to DPCC for $24 a share, it would make a profit of $2 a share, or $8.3 million. **********DPCC said that Drexel Burnham Lambert, the securities firm, was one of the investors in the venture, but declined to identify any of the other participants. Castle & Cooke said that it would own 40 percent of Dr Pepper if the leveraged buyout transaction went through. In such a buyout, assets of the company being acquired are used to secure financing for the purchase. **********Commenting on Dr Pepper's attraction for Castle & Cooke, Lawrence Adelman, a securities analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds, said: ''Somebody approaching Dr Pepper has to take into consideration that it has the marketing prowess, financial resources and belief that can drive the volume up.'' **********An official of Drexel Burnham, who requested anonymity, asserted that Ian R. Wilson, Castle & Cooke's president and a former senior official of the Coca-Cola Company, ''is widely recognized as one of the most knowledgeable people in the beverage business.'' The official added, ''We believe he can make Dr Pepper a very exciting thing for us to be owners in.'' **********For the first nine months of 1983, Dr Pepper earned $14 million on volume of $423.5 million, compared with net income of $16.5 million on sales of $392.4 million in the period a year ago. In the first quarter of its fiscal year ended Oct. 8, Castle & Cooke earned $3.2 million on revenues of $472.6 million, compared with a loss of $64.6 million on revenues of $401 million in the comparable period a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/08/busin.body_text: **********Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 37.9 percent, to $459.4 million, or $1.31 a share, on the strong performance of the merchandising group of Sears and its growing array of financial subsidiaries. **********The earnings for the final quarter compared with $333.1 million, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the period rose 11.3 percent, to $8.9 billion, from $8 billion. **********Analysts said the merchandising operations of Sears turned in the most impressive performance, with improved earnings coming as much or more from cost-cutting as better sales. **********''Merchandising has shown an impressive turnaround because of strong management controls,'' said Allen Nadler, vice president and senior security analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company. **********The Sears board yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 38 cents a share of common stock from 34 cents, payable April 1 to shareholders of record on Feb. 24. **********For the full year, Sears reported net income of $861.2 million, or $2.46 a share, on revenues of $30.02 billion, including a loss of $41.7 million in the conversion of foreign currency earnings from operations abroad. These results compared with 1981 earnings of $650.1 million on revenues of $27.36 billion. **********The merchandising group's fourth-quarter earnings rose 23.4 percent, to $310.4 million, from $251.6 million, on revenue of $6.4 billion, up 3.1 percent from a year earlier. For the full year, the merchandise group earned $432 million, up 51.6 percent from $285 million in 1981. Group revenue rose 2.3 percent, to $20.7 billion. **********Sears's Allstate Insurance Group's fourth-quarter earnings rose to $141.4 million, from $98.9 million a year earlier. For the full year Allstate earned $500.4 million, up from $406.3 million in 1981. Dean Witter Financial Services Group contributed $22.6 million to net income in the fourth period. **********At yearend, the merchandise inventories of Sears were up 3.3 percent for the 831 stores in the chain. This year, the company plans to open 14 new stores, including five in new markets. Among the company's plans are an expansion of its business systems centers that operate in 23 cities. The stores carry a broad line of electronic equipment for the needs of small businesses under Sears and other brand names.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.body_text: **********The Polish Government denounced as inadequate today the United States' announcement on Wednesday of ''two limited steps'' toward easing economic sanctions imposed after the 1981 declaration of martial law. **********The protest came in a note handed to the United States charge d'affaires and immediately made public. The Government said the United States move, which was accompanied by a sharp attack on what Washington called the continuing abuse of human rights here, constituted an ''unfriendly and unlawful act'' and an ''inadmissible interference in the affairs of our country.'' **********The American envoy, John R. Davis Jr., was summoned to the Foreign Ministry to receive the long note, which denounced the two steps as being ''merely of an illusory nature.'' The note said that unless economic and financial restrictions ''and other unfriendly actions'' were ended, ''further deterioration of relations may become inevitable.'' **********Making Good the Damages **********Poland, the note said, ''expects the Government of the United States of America to take the necessary steps to make good on the damages suffered by the Polish economy and by the people of Poland.'' Meanwhile, Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity union, said he would send his wife, Danuta, to Oslo, Norway, next month to receive his Nobel Peace Prize. Mr. Walesa had expressed concern that if he left Poland, the authorities would not let him back in. **********He said Mrs. Walesa would be accompanied by their eldest son, Bogdan, 13 years old, and Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a senior Solidarity adviser and editor of the union's newspaper. **********(A spokesman for the Government, which has condemned the award as an effort to heighten East- West tensions, said, according to The Associated Press, that it had not decided whether Mrs. Walesa would be allowed to leave the country.)  Fishing and Debt at Issue **********The White House announcement said the Reagan Administration would ease restrictions on fishing in United States waters and take steps toward rescheduling Poland's $25 billion debt to the West. But it said the Administration would continue a ban on the Polish airline, restrictions on high-technology sales and a freeze on credits to the Polish economy. **********The foundering economy depends heavily on imported raw materials and spare parts. Most-favored-nation trading status was withdrawn after Solidarity was outlawed in October 1982. **********The American moves appeared to have little immediate impact. This year's allocation of fishing quotas has already been closed. Any allocations of fish next year, the White House said, would be directly dependent on ''the Government's action on human rights.'' **********Poland's Western creditor nations, including the United States, have already begun discussions on rescheduling Poland's debts. **********Diplomatic sources here privately characterized the American actions as the minimum steps possible in moving toward a change in the strained relations with Poland. But they said it appeared that the American actions might have been designed with the hope of achieving a series of conciliatory moves. **********There was, for example, speculation that a countergesture from the Polish Government might be the elevation of the American envoy here to the status of ambassador. Poland has refused to accept an American ambassador for more than a year and, in the past, has suggested to the State Department that such acceptance was contingent on some conciliatory gesture such as restoring fishing rights or flights by Lot, the Polish airline. **********In addition, diplomats said, the Americans appeared to be attempting to maintain leverage over the Polish Government's actions by making any future relaxation dependent on actions by the Polish authorities. **********The Polish Government had hoped that the visit of Pope John Paul II last spring, followed by the highly publicized formal scrapping of martial law in July, would bring an end to sanctions and international isolation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/world.main_headline: REAGAN DECLARES 'YOU BET' HE'LL STICK WITH ADELMAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/world.print_headline: REAGAN DECLARES 'YOU BET' HE'LL STICK WITH ADELMAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/world.body_text: **********President Reagan emphatically defended Kenneth L. Adelman, his nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, today and said Mr. Adelman's Senate critics were ''smaller than the person they're attacking.'' **********''You bet I'm sticking by Mr. Adelman,'' the President said in response to a question at a brief White House news conference.  The nomination has been bogged down in the Senate by weeks of controversy about Mr. Adelman's qualifications, with Democrats and Republicans charging that his private memos contradict his Senate testimony on the subject of a possible personnel purge at the disarmament agency. **********'Excellently Qualified' **********''I think he is excellently qualified,'' the President said of his nominee, ''and I think that the fuss that has been raised about him is, smacks of people smaller than the person they're attacking.'' **********On a second question the President, asked whether he would soon offer a proposal for an interim reduction in medium-range nuclear missiles, said, ''Tune in next week.'' He plans to make a speech on the subject next Thursday in Los Angeles. **********This was the second time in four weeks that Mr. Reagan has complained of the delay and controversy in the Senate's consideration of Mr. Adelman. Last month, the Senate Foreign Relations committee forwarded the nomination to the Senate floor with a recommendation that it be rejected. The President then denounced Senate critics of the nomination as ''irresponsible'' and defended his right to choose his own nominee to run the arms agency. **********The latest dispute over Mr. Adelman focuses on his testimony that he had not thought ''at all'' about personnel changes at the agency.  Private memos by Mr. Adelman, subsequently released, depict him as having begun an inquiry for more qualified personnel at the agency and having referred to a memo received from Edward L. Rowny, the chief strategic arms negotiator, that called for a ''housecleaning'' at the agency. 'Perfectly Natural' **********President Reagan, commenting on those memos today, defended Mr.  Adelman's behavior as ''perfectly natural.'' ''How someone can be hung out to dry for having received a letter from someone else,'' the President said. ''He didn't write the letter, he received it.'' **********''Isn't this natural,'' the President continued, ''that someone who is in the position of assuming the directorship of an agency or a department or commission or whatever it might be, is going to make inquiries of people on the scene with regard to personnel and so forth? And it was perfectly natural - I've done it myself - that when the letter came he passed it to an aide, or one who is collecting all the information, that he would have to deal with it when he was in the job.'' **********Mr. Adelman, complaining that he was being ''unfairly maligned,'' has said that reception of Mr. Rowny's memo was ''unavoidable'' but that otherwise he has deferred all personnel decisions until after Senate confirmation. The Senate, which is still looking into the matter, has put off debate and vote on Mr. Adelman's nomination until next month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Fizzling Investment **********The investment boom that was to result from the ''supply-side'' tax cuts has been postponed and may be as far away as the end of 1984.  The Commerce Department reported last week that investment by companies in plants and equipment will plunge 5.2 percent this year, after inflation, to $315.7 billion, marking the fourth consecutive sluggish year for capital goods. **********The fact is, abundant supplies are the economy's problem right now and not its cure. Business slashed excess inventories at a record rate in November, the twelfth decline in 13 months. And industrial production continued its descent in December, leaving one-third of the nation's production capacity idle. **********Economists do not expect investment to recover until most excess capacity has been put back to work.  ''Barring some random event, capital spending is going to come back very slowly,'' said Lee W. Haskins, chief economist of Pittsburgh National Bank. ''There will be only minimal gains early next year and no boom until the end of 1984.'' Upturn in Commodities? **********The slump in commodity prices, aggravated by surplus supplies of just about everything, persisted long after the stock and bond markets took off last summer. But even when commodity futures began to improve slightly in the fall, analysts remained skeptical that they were foreshadowing an economic rebound. The weakness in cash prices lasted through December, and forecasters like to see both futures and cash prices moving in the same direction before they announce a trend. **********Finally, cash prices inched forward enough last week for some commodity experts to proclaim an end to a two-year decline. ''The hints are there that we're in the early stages of an upturn,'' said William Jiler, president of the Commodity Research Bureau. **********The change reflects a bull market in silver and industrial metals.  Lumber is headed up, thanks in part to the housing recovery. Cocoa, coffee and sugar are weak, but corn, soybeans and wheat prices have risen somewhat. **********A recovery of commodity prices would be a bad omen for inflation, because futures prices are eventually reflected in consumer prices.  ''What the markets are really telling us is that the politicans are going to inflate again,'' said Mr. Jiler. Investing in Bankruptcy **********Bankruptcy, the ultimate dread of corporate managers, can offer the daring investor the opportunity to earn handsome returns by buying the shares of selected companies soon after they file their insolvency petition. That may be what Bear Stearns had in mind at year-end when it bought 34 percent of Revere Copper & Brass, in bankruptcy proceedings since October. Bear Stearns then watched the stock almost double in the next few days. **********Standard & Poor's, in a report on speculating in companies that have filed for bankruptcy, suggests looking at companies that file early, before their assets are dangerously depleted. Companies with large portions of unsecured debt are favored, too, because unsecured creditors are often willing to forgive part of their claims. New management is also a plus, the report said. It predicts that HRT Industries, Lionel and Wickes, in addition to Revere, should do well as they restructure in bankruptcy proceedings. Hoping for Soviet Trade **********Trade between the United Sates and the Soviet Union hit a peak of $4.5 billion in 1979. Since then, the figure has been dropping fast because of embargoes and sanctions. **********Export-minded executives, following the mid-November journey of 250 American merchants to Moscow, are trying to forge a movement to increase Soviet trade. Last week in Chicago, 150 people turned out for a pro-trade conference sponsored by local business groups. Most panelists predicted the Soviet Union would increase imports this year because of a crash program to build up its energy sector and because the nation's new leaders want to accelerate growth. **********Promising areas include machinery, farm equipment, computers, chemicals and petrochemical equipment and food processing equipment.  Some optimists predict that, if the United States were to change its policy, trade could grow to $10 billion by 1985 and $35 billion by the end of the decade. **********A number of participants would like the United States to extend credits and most-favored-nation trading status to the Soviet Union.  But they doubted that such sweeping changes would come soon. **********Winston Williams,Chicago

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.main_headline: ISRAELI WARPLANES STRIKE AT PALESTINIAN TARGETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.print_headline: ISRAELI WARPLANES STRIKE AT PALESTINIAN TARGETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.body_text: **********Israeli warplanes attacked Palestinian positions in the hills east of Beirut today hours after a truck bomb attack on an Israeli compound in Tyre. Some reports said the planes also attacked Syrian positions. **********According to Lebanese police sources, four Israeli Kfir fighter bombers, escorted by 12 United States-built interceptors, carried out two air strikes on targets in the areas of Aleih, Bhamdun and Sofar near the Beirut- Damascus Highway and from 6 to 12 miles from Beirut. **********The radio station of the Lebanese Christian Phalange Party, the Voice of Lebanon, said the Israeli planes also struck at Syrian positions at Sofar, knocking out 16 Soviet-built T-54 tanks. **********The radio said up to 60 people were killed and 100 wounded in the Israeli air strikes in the three areas. Among the dead and wounded, it said, were three Syrian officers and 16 Syrian soldiers.   Guerrilla Headquarters Hit **********The broadcast said that a headquarters of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, a guerrilla organization backed by Syria and Libya, was destroyed and that the second in command of the group was killed. The radio did not give his name. **********The guerrilla group is led by Capt. Ahmed Jebril, a Palestinian who had served in the Syrian Army and who is a strong opponent of Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Captain Jebril's men have been fighting against guerrillas loyal to Mr. Arafat in the Tripoli area for the last two days. **********All the Palestinian positions in the Aleih and Bhamdun areas are reportedly held by anti-Arafat rebels within Al Fatah, the main guerrilla organization in the P.L.O. **********According to broadcasts by some private Lebanese radio stations, Mahmoud Labadi, a spokesman for the Palestinian rebels in Damascus, acknowledged that guerrilla positions in the hills east of Beirut were targets of the Israeli air strikes today. The raids were the first by Israeli planes against Palestinian guerrilla positions in Lebanon in 10 months.   Two Attacks Reported **********An Israeli military communique said only that the planes made two attacks, one at noon and the other three hours later, on ''terrorist'' bases, scoring direct hits and returning to base safely. **********In Damascus, the official Syrian press agency quoted Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam as saying Syria was prepared for another confrontation with the Israelis. **********Aleih and Bhamdun are in mountain districts from which Israeli troops withdrew on Sept. 4 to take up positions farther south along the Awali River. After the withdrawal, the districts were seized by Syrian-backed Lebanese Druse militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas. **********Sofar has been held by Syrian troops since they and Palestinian guerrillas were forced out of Beirut by invading Israeli forces last year.   Druse Protest Israeli Strikes **********The guerrillas have tried to avoid publicizing their presence in the Aleih and Bhamdun areas, which are supposed to be entirely under the control of the Progressive Socialist Party of the Druse leader, Walid Jumblat. **********Mr. Jumblat, who is attending the Lebanese national reconciliation conference in Geneva, issued a protest today over the Israeli strikes into the territory held by his supporters, saying that his men had nothing to do with the explosion in Tyre. **********There is said to be no evidence to show that Palestinian guerrillas were involved in the attack on the Israeli compound in the southern Lebanese port city. **********Telephone callers claiming to represent a group calling itself Islamic Jihad said that their organization was responsible for the attack in Tyre.   Same Group in Marine Attack **********The same group had claimed responsibility for the suicide bombing attacks of Oct. 23 on the United States Marine headquarters at Beirut airport and the French military garrison and for the blast that destroyed the United States Embassy in Beirut last April. It is believed to be made up of Moslem Shiite fanatics with links to Iran. **********Witnesses to today's Israeli air strikes said they saw jets dive to fire their rockets and drop their bombs on their targets. Israeli pilots were also said to have loosed orange colored balloons apparently as decoys against surface-to-air missiles. But the witnesses said no missiles were fired as far as they could see. **********The Phalangist radio said that Soviet-built Syrian MIG fighters flew over Syrian concentrations in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, forming a protective umbrella for Syrian positions there. But the radio said the Syrian aircraft did not try to challenge the Israeli planes, whose targets lay west of the Bekaa. **********The Syrians are known to have set up SAM-6 surface-to-air missiles along their border with Lebanon. They did not re-introduce surface-to-air missiles into Lebanon since their batteries on Lebanese territory were knocked out by the Israeli Air Force during last year's invasion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Western Airlines announced a series of agreements today indicating that its major lenders believe the airline has weathered the worst of its troubles. **********It also announced that Neil G. Bergt, whose desire to continue as chairman had been in doubt, agreed to continue in the post.  The airline, the nation's 10th largest, said it had received a $30 million loan, plus $12.5 million from the private placement of subordinated convertible debentures. **********The six-year loan, bearing an interest charge two percentage points above the London interbank offered rate, is secured by six of the airline's jet aircraft. The debentures are to yield 12 percent. **********Andre C. Dimitriadis, senior vice president-finance, added that the company had received a $30 million credit line, bearing a rate of 1.5 percentage points above prime, from a group of banks headed by Citibank. **********He asserted in an interview that the new financing agreements prove that Western was correct to make Salt Lake City a service hub and that the airline had succeeded in paring operating costs. However, he added, the airlines does not expect to report a profit for the 1982 calendar year. **********The airline also said it is leasing two 737-200 aircraft for 12 years from Alaska International Air Inc. That company, which is controlled separately by Mr. Bergt, bought the aircraft last week from the Boeing Company, the airline said. **********Elsewhere in an official statement, Mr. Dimitriadis said the airline's 1,650 mechanics and other employees represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had agreed to a 10 percent pay cut for one year and granted ''other significant work rule concessions.'' In addition, Western's 1,230 pilots, represented by the Airline Pilots Assocation, agreed to extend their 10 percent pay cut through 1983. **********The union also agreed to the elimination of one of two pilot pension plans, a step that will give the company $23 million.  Western lost $73.4 million in 1981 mainly because of high interest rates and route restructuring, but narrowed the loss to $4.4 million, on $806.8 million in revenues, in the first nine months of 1982. It reported a profit of $3.4 million in the third quarter ended Sept. 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Suriname Regime Seizes 15 More as Plotters
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/world.body_text: **********Fifteen more people have been arrested for supposedly plotting to assassinate Suriname's military leader, Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, the country's official radio reported today. **********''Last night, at about 11 P.M., an attempt was discovered on the life of the Commander in Chief,'' it said. Among those arrested was Maj. Roy Horb, a top-ranking army leader, the broadcast said. **********The radio said two Cabinet ministers were under house arrest. They were identified as John Harjoprajitno, Minister of Culture and Sports, and Jan K. Sariman, Minister of Agriculture. **********The military regime arrested 15 Government opponents Dec. 8 and killed them soon after. Colonel Bouterse said they were shot while trying to escape.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/world.main_headline: U.S. JEWISH STUDENTS PROTEST ISRAELI POLICY IN A LETTER TO BEGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/world.print_headline: U.S. JEWISH STUDENTS PROTEST ISRAELI POLICY IN A LETTER TO BEGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/world.body_text: **********Jewish students at three leading American law schools, in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, have protested Israel's invasion of Lebanon and its treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories. **********A total of 133 law students from Harvard, Yale and New York University signed the letter, which voiced their ''strong opposition to recent Israeli Government actions.'' **********The letter was delivered late Friday to the Israeli Mission to the United Nations. A spokesman for the mission said there would be no comment until Yehuda Z. Blum, the Israeli delegate, had read the letter. **********The letter acknowledged that Israel's northern border had been threatened by guerrilla attacks but argued that they ''did not justify Israel's large-scale invasion of Lebanon'' last June. The students contended the border could have been made secure ''without the death and destruction'' created by the Israeli attack. They did not say how. Halt to Settlement Urged **********The students accused Israel of practices in the occupied territories that reduce the Palestinians there ''to permanent second-class citizenship.'' The letter said such an approach ''conflicts starkly with the Israeli commitment to the human right of democratic political participation.'' **********The document urged Israel to stop creating new Jewish settlements in the occupied areas and halt other measures that ''alter the legal character of the West Bank and Gaza.'' **********A spokesman for the signers, Eric Schwartz of Syosset, L.I., a student at N.Y.U. Law School, said both the growing number of settlements and the application of Israeli law to the territories were changing their legal position. **********The letter urged Israel to negotiate an accord ''based upon the exchange of land for peace and security guarantees.'' The message sidestepped the politically delicate question of whether Israel should negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization or Jordan. **********The letter began, ''As American Jewish law students, we are deeply committed to the existence and security of Israel.'' It described its differences with Mr. Begin as an effort to ''strengthen ties between our two countries.'' **********Of the 133 signers, 63 were from Harvard, 53 from N.Y.U. and 17 from Yale. Mr. Schwartz estimated that 10 to 25 percent of the Jewish students at the three schools had joined in the protest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The Spanish Government said today it would expropriate banks and other property belonging to Rumasa, the country's largest holding company. **********The decision was announced after a weekly Cabinet meeting. **********Rumasa, which controls 18 banks and about 400 other companies, was involved in a dispute with the Government over an independent audit of the company that had been undertaken at the request of Spain's deposit-guarantee fund. **********Eduardo Sotillos, a Government spokesman, said a banking holiday had been decreed for Thursday. He also said trading of Rumasa shares would be suspended. **********''The Government has taken this decision in order to fully guarantee the banks' deposits, the jobs and shareholders rights, which we consider to be seriously threatened,'' Mr. Sotillos said. **********He did not specify how many companies in addition to the banks would be covered by the decree.  The dispute between Rumasa and the Government broke into the open last Friday when Miguel Boyer, the Economy Minister, said that if Rumasa interrupted the audit, being performed by Arthur Andersen & Company, he would send in inspectors from the central bank. **********Jose Maria Ruiz Mateos, president of the company, said Tuesday that the audit had faced working difficulties. He accused the fund of exerting undue pressure for the audit to be completed within four months. **********He also denied that the group's solvency was in any way threatened. Withdrawals over the three previous days, he said, had been ''without significance in banking terms.'' **********Banking sources said the Government was anxious about the extent to which Rumasa's banks were involved in the group's industrial and commercial concerns. The holding company has 60,000 employees and is involved in food, beverages, property, shipping and tourism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/17/world.main_headline: WHAT IF LAND WAR CAME TO EUROPE?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/17/world.print_headline: WHAT IF LAND WAR CAME TO EUROPE?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/17/world.body_text: **********Military   Analysis **********CASTEAU, Belgium, Oct. 12 - The North Atlantic alliance's annual exercises are moving toward their end, and staff officers here are reviewing tactics and strategy in the light of the lessons learned. One basic military fact has emerged: the Alliance is stuck with a forward strategy. **********The term means that if a crisis developed between the alliance and the Warsaw Pact, North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces would move out of their peacetime deployments to positions near the frontier between East and West Germany. **********The strategy has been criticized by many military men in the West and by civilian students of West European defense. They argue that to put the bulk of the West's forces so far forward invites a single Soviet smash through one of the two main corridors into West Germany - at Fulda and Hof - which, if successful, would burst into NATO's rear areas and would be followed by attacks on the alliance's flanks. **********NATO has been wedded to this forward strategy since West Germany joined the alliance in the 1950's.   'Political Imperative' **********Allied staff officers argue that the strategy is a ''political imperative'' because it protects West Germany, the strongest continental military power, from invasion. **********As the alliance has developed, so have strong military reasons for retaining the strategy. As staff officers emphasized, there is little depth in Western Europe behind the prospective front. A Soviet breakthrough would put allied air bases, ammunition and fuel depots at immediate risk. **********Another geographical factor in assessing the defense of Western Europe is that any eruption of Warsaw Pact forces, if successful, would spill out into a much wider land mass in which the Soviet forces would be able to use their numerical superiority. **********The alliance's answer has been to organize ground and air forces powerful enough to halt the main Soviet attack and destroy the leading formations, or, to use a favorite NATO military word, to ''attrit'' the enemy. This goal is in sight, according to staff officers. Over the last two years there has been a steady improvement in the quality of weapons, training and logistical support. **********The allies' stated strategy remains a defensive one. Nevertheless there are developments within supreme headquarters that point to an important strengthening of the alliance's ability to punish not only the attacking Russian forces but those of the second echelon. These are the troops that would follow after an initial attack was launched. **********Although little attention has been paid to these developments outside military circles, some sources here regard them as promising the most significant change in the alliance's military potential in the last 20 years.   Precision-Guided Munitions **********The Warsaw Pact's potential to reinforce any breakthrough with divisions drawn from the military districts of central Russia is a longstanding allied problem. But both the military and their scientific advisers here see in non-nuclear precision-guided missiles, fired either from the ground or from aircraft, a weapon capable of interdicting these reinforcing divisions. **********The United States, Britain and France are developing such weapons but not on the scale required in a war. The allies also are developing special bombs and missiles to destroy hostile air fields. The electronic jamming of Warsaw Pact communications also is emphasized. **********''Everything comes down to money,'' one staff officer said. Costs for research, development and production of the new weapons will add to defense expenditures that many of the smaller member nations already view as excessive. Other officers point out that even if parliaments raised military expenditures, there would be no assurance that the funds would be spent on the most vital weapons systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/08/busin.main_headline: Campbell-Mithun Gets The Jockey for Her Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/08/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Campbell-Mithun Gets The Jockey for Her Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/08/busin.body_text: **********Campbell-Mithun, the Minneapolis subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has been named agency for Jockey for Her, a recently introduced line of women's panties from the same people who have been supplying males with Jockey shorts over the years. **********Jockey International in Kenosha, Wis., announced in September that it was going into three markets - Dallas, Los Angeles and Milwaukee -with the brand, which includes bikinis, hipsters and full panties.  Bozell & Jacobs, which continues as agency for the men's line, was the original agency for the women's. **********Campbell-Mithun is promising print and TV advertising by spring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/world.body_text: **********Winter cruise visits to Grenada by the luxury liners Queen Elizabeth 2 and Cunard Countess have been canceled because of problems in connection with the United States-led invasion of the island, the Cunard Line said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/05/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********President Reagan asked Congress for authorization to restrict imports from countries that sell to the Soviet Union or another Communist bloc nation in violation of an American trade sanction. The proposed legislation would be the first to restrict imports during East-West trade disputes. (Page D1.) **********The Supreme Court left standing a ruling that Texaco had overcharged its customers by about $1 billion for crude oil sold in the mid-1970's. The company said, however, that it would press its case. (D1.) The Court also ruled that a job-bias plaintiff does not have to produce direct proof of intentional discrimination. (A23.) **********Discounting brand-name fashions has become such a force in the retail market that some of the biggest department stores are entering the field. The move has angered manufacturers. (D1.) Companies **********Baldwin-United has asked its banks to postpone repayment of $700 million in short-term debt, according to a top executive. He said the company is near accord with its creditors on a ''standstill agreement.'' After his statement, the price of Baldwin-United's shares climbed by $1 a share on the Big Board. (D1.) **********The CBS television network began the first national, over-the-air electronic information service even though the necessary decoding equipment is still not available. The company said it hopes thereby to develop a market for the service. The move came just four days after the F.C.C. authorized teletext transmissions. (D5.) **********John Z. DeLorean gained his release from jail through ''fraud,'' according to prosecutors in his drug conspiracy case. They said that for bail, the auto entrepreneur posted already encumbered property.  They asked an increase in bail, saying they had information that he might flee. Mr. DeLorean's attorney denied the charges. (A20.) **********Internorth and Belco Petroleum announced that they are considering a deal in which Internorth would acquire Belco for as much as $700 million. The merger, if consummated, would create an energy concern with revenues of about $4.5 billion a year. (D17.) **********CSX reported a 26.1 percent drop in net income for the first quarter. Kaufman & Broad had a profit of $2.2 million in the quarter ended Feb. 28, contrasted to a $4.6 million loss a year ago. (D6.) **********Apple Computer said it had cut prices of its Apple III personal computers by up to 23 percent, and that production of one Apple III model would by discontinued. (D5.) Energy **********Columbia Gas said it has told producers it is invoking force majeure clauses in its contracts in a bid to cut supplies. (D1.) **********Saxon Oil reported its fourth-quarter loss had widened to $41 million. Because of unresolved problems in restructuring its debt, the company said, its auditors were unable to assess its financial condition. MGF Oil also reported a fourth-quarter deficit, one of $58.5 million. Analysts said similar problems are jeopardizing hundreds of such concerns in the Southwest.
