Dome, which owes about $6.5 billion in Canada and abroad, is seeking an alternative to the plan. (D4.) Markets **********Stock prices closed slightly lower, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 2.42 points, to 1,127.61. (D12.) Interest rates were mixed in quiet trading. (D11.) A $160 million issue of A-rated Philadelphia water and sewer refunding bonds was tentatively priced to yield 10.013 percent for 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2006. (D11.) Gold prices rose $10.50 an ounce, to $426.50, in New York, while the dollar fell. (D16.) Petroleum futures prices were mostly higher.  (D16.) Today's Columns **********The rapid growth of corporate legal staffs seems to be over, a casualty of recession. In recent years, law firms had been losing work to the expanding in-house departments, but new data indicate the expansion has stopped. Business and the Law. (D2.) **********Brokerages are offering highly elaborate stock ratings nowadays.  Various grading systems are used, often incorporating different time frames, and the result is a kind of shorthand that summarizes a broker's advice on a company. Market Place. (D12.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.main_headline: Thai Prime Minister Won't Quit After All
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Thai Prime Minister Won't Quit After All
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has reconsidered his surprise resignation announced Tuesday and is ready to accept nomination for another four-year term, political officials said today. **********They said the general had reversed his decision to leave politics after an appeal from Thailand's elder statesman and former Prime Minister, Kukrit Pramoj. **********The sources said General Prem agreed to make himself available to head another coalition government after Mr. Kukrit, leader of the Social Action Party, persuaded him that no civilian coalition government could survive without him. **********The Kurit party and its main political rival, the Thai Nation Party, have almost equal support in the 324-seat House of Representatives. **********The two parties have in the past week fought for the right to form a new government under the leadership of General Prem, regarded as the ideal compromise between Thailand's army and the country's elected politicians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices plummeted as concern spread about the outlook on interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 15.77 points, to 1,202.98. On the overall market, declines outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 1. Analysts cited Friday's report of a recent surge in the basic money supply, which could prevent the Federal Reserve Board from encouraging lower interest rates. (Page D1.) Yields on long-term bonds rose sharply and prices fell, while in the short-term market Treasury bill yields rose very slightly. The Treasury auctioned $7.4 billion in three- and six-month bills instead of the $12.4 billion usually sold each Monday. (D13.) The dollar rose to a new high of 7.4138 against the French franc in U.S. trading.  Gold prices declined $2.50 an ounce, to $438, in New York. (D18.) Prices of Treasury bond and bill futures fell sharply. (D18.) **********International **********Moscow is seeking to expand East-West trade while warning it will retaliate against any American efforts to impose restraints, a senior Soviet official suggests. He voiced doubt that the U.S. would win a tougher Soviet-trade policy at the economic meeting in Williamsburg, Va., this month. (D1.) The French are adopting positions that make a confrontation likely at the meeting. (D19.) **********Many companies operating in Common Market countries will have to publish consolidated annual financial statements. (D8.) The Economy **********President Reagan accused Congress of violating its pledge to cut spending. He was responding to Congressional pressure for tax increases to reduce prospective deficits. In an address before the nation's home builders, the President promised an additional $5 billion in Federal mortgage insurance for home construction. (A1.) **********The Government will encourage industry to build and operate expendable rockets in competition with its own space shuttle, the White House announced. It said the plan is to strengthen U.S.  launching capacity and develop a major new industry. Analysts said the move might turn out to have a far-reaching impact. (D1.) **********The Supreme Court upheld Federal rules meant to force utilities to cooperate in the development of alternative, competing sources of energy. (D5.) And the Court agreed to define Federal environmental obligations in leasing of offshore oil and gas tracts. (D27.) **********Factory use rose to 71.1 percent of capacity in April, the highest rate in more than a year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. The increase of 1.3 points over March was the fifth in a row. (D12.) Companies **********Sears told shareholders it is thinking of acquiring more savings and loan institutions to build ''a nationwide deposit base.'' It said it will also start a program under which home buyers using its realty arm will get discounts on furniture and appliances. (D1.) **********I.B.M. introduced a new general purpose computer as an eventual replacement for its System/34 model. (D4.) **********J.C. Penney reported an 11.5 percent rise in net income in the first fiscal quarter. Carter Hawley Hale's net rose 17 percent, and Zayre's more than tripled. (D6.) **********Martin Marietta said it has agreed to acquire all outstanding stock of Mathematica for $30.8 million in cash and securities. (D4.) Today's Columns **********Many experts feel insider trading penalties are too weak, and a new bill with stiffer penalties has gained wide support in Congress. The trouble with the bill is that it does not define the abuse, long the subject of heated debate in the courts. Business and the Law. (D2.) **********Problems at CBS's broadcasting division are affecting other broadcast stocks. The network, guessing wrong on recovery, has a lot of advertising time available for sale at a time when the economy is just beginning to gain strength. Market Place. (D14.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.body_text: **********G.M. and Toyota have agreed to produce a subcompact car jointly in the U.S. For G.M., seeking help from an outside manufacturer marks a turning point. Analysts viewed the agreement as a concession to Japan's reputation for superior quality and low-cost production.  (Page A1.) For innovative Toyota, the joint venture is a relatively low-cost, low-risk way to start producing in the U.S. (D5.) **********Bank regulators should exercise greater supervision over foreign lending, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a Senate panel. The Secretary was testifying in behalf of a plan to increase American support of the I.M.F.'s lending resources. Mr. Regan said the American contribution would create jobs in the U.S.(D9.) **********Falling oil prices have alarmed Kuwait and the other small oil exporters on the Persian Gulf. For the first time since 1974, they can't count on rising oil revenue. (A1.) Texaco USA and three other refiners cut by $1 the price they pay for domestic crude. (D1.) Markets **********Stock prices surged to a new high, led by technology issues.  Analysts said the gain was fueled by small investors who had been wary of the rising market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.60 points, to 1,097.10. Its previous high, 1,092.35, was set Jan.  10. Three other major indexes also reached new highs. (D1.) **********Interest rates were mixed in uneventful trading. (D9.) The Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia is selling $100 million of electric revenue bonds. (D9.) The dollar fell. Gold prices rose $4.50 an ounce in New York, to $507.50. (D14.) Corn futures prices rose.  (D14.) Companies **********United American Bank of Knoxville was closed as insolvent, and, in bidding conducted by the F.D.I.C., was sold to the First Tennessee National Corporation, the state's biggest bank holding company. The Knoxville bank, the fourth-largest commercial bank to fail since the 1930's, is reopening today under its new ownership. (D1.) **********Companies bypassed many Southern communities as sites for new plants in the 1960's and 1970's because of their large black populations, experts said. The companies apparently felt that black workers were less reliable and skilled than white workers. (A14.) **********International Thomson plans to acquire American Banker and The Bond Buyer from the estate of Charles Otis for $58 million. The move will end the family's role, which began in 1910. (D6.) **********Eastman Kodak reported a 15.5 percent rise in net earnings for the fourth quarter. Dresser Industries said it lost $7.4 million in its first fiscal quarter, in contrast to a profit of $76.9 million a year ago. (D6.) Coca-Cola's fourth-quarter net rose 14.2 percent. (D6.) **********Tiger International said it had ''temporarily'' halted payments on some loans. (D10.) **********Two men accused of conspiring to steal computer equipment from Nixdorf went on trial in Cambridge, Mass. (D4.) **********Eight of the largest companies in the recording industry have sued 130 distributors of records and tapes, claiming that they were selling counterfeits. (D15.) The Economy **********Congressional Democrats said they would accept a $4.3 billion emergency jobs bill proposed by the White House. But they plan to try to add about $1 billion in extra jobless benefits. (A1.) President Reagan asked corporate leaders to join him in building ''a new economic era'' based on high-technology industries. (A14.) **********Businesses reduced inventories by 0.6 percent in December, despite poor sales, by curbing production. The inventory-to-sales ratio rose to 1.52 from 1.51. (D2.) Today's Columns **********Signs of recovery are emerging in the steel industry, although 1983 will still be a relatively poor year, according to Thomas C. Graham, chief of Jones & Laughlin. Talking Business. (D2.) **********T. Rowe Price, the mutual fund, has made a sweeping change in its strategy. It is now emphasizing companies that will benefit from unit demand growth rather than relying on energy and other companies that formerly prospered from inflation. Market Place. (D10.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/world.main_headline: Rioters in Brazil Protest Economic Conditions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Rioters in Brazil Protest Economic Conditions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/world.body_text: **********The police drove back a mob attacking the governor's palace today, but rioting over unemployment and the high cost of living continued here into the night. It was the second day of violent protest. **********The police with tear gas dispersed groups of looters who had broken into jewelry stores and fashion boutiques, but they quickly formed again to attack other targets. The police said they had no estimate of the damage. **********The deputy police chief, Joao Pessoa Nascimento, said 620 riot policemen and thousands of regular patrolmen were on the streets trying to contain the violence. **********Gov. Andre Franco Montoro of Sao Paulo state made a plea for calm on radio and television. He said the problem of widespread unemployment ''cannot be solved in half an hour.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/busin.main_headline: U.S. SPLIT ON LOAN TO KOREA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/busin.print_headline: U.S. SPLIT ON LOAN TO KOREA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/busin.body_text: **********In an unusual intervention, the Commerce Department has asked the Export- Import Bank to turn down a loan of more than $100 million that the bank is considering to finance sales of American-made equipment for a South Korean steel works. **********In a letter to the bank, Lionel H. Olmer, the Under Secretary, said he was acting because of ''serious oversupply worldwide'' in steel and because ''increased Korean steel exports would be aimed primarily at the U.S.,'' increasing demands for trade protection by workers and industry in the United States. A similar appeal has been made by organized labor. **********It was the first time an Administration official has openly sought to influence decisions by the Government lending agency, and shows a growing sensitivity to the problems of the domestic steel industry as an election year approaches. **********The Export-Import Bank, which will be 50 years old next year, lends money to foreign purchasers of American goods. In the battle for world markets, its aid is considered essential to complete a sale. Practically all exporting countries have similar agencies. **********The rationale behind the Ex-Im Bank is that exports create jobs. The proposed sale of equipment to South Korea is expected to generate several thousand jobs at the supplier's plants. These suppliers were to be the General Electric Company plant at Salem, Va., the Dravo Corporation of Pittsburgh and Air Products and Chemicals of Allentown, Pa. **********They are seeking to supply equipment for the new Pohang Iron and Steel Company complex at Kwangyang Bay. **********The proposed loan to Pohang has already incurred the wrath of the trade union movement. **********One labor representative, Rudy Oswald, economics director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, contended that it is illegal for the Ex- Im Bank to make the loan because of worldwide steel overcapacity. He cited a 1979 law that he said prohibits use of the bank's money for expansion of exports if the commodity to be produced is likely to be in surplus in world markets. **********Ex-Im Bank officials took issue with Mr. Oswald's interpretation of the 1979 statute and said their interpretation was that the bank only had to take such factors as oversupply ''into consideration.'' **********The next meeting at which the financing may come up is scheduled for Jan. 4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda announced unexpectedly today that he was retiring from politics and would not accept a second term. **********The Prime Minister's decision, which he disclosed this morning at Government House, threw new uncertainties into a months-old debate over whether to amend the Constitution to preserve the military's role in the Government. **********In nationwide general elections on April 18, no party won a majority in the House of Representatives. General Prem, a popular army officer known also as a supporter of parliamentary democracy, had been widely proposed in recent days as the most suitable leader of a new coalition government, the only obvious candidate acceptable to both sides in the debate. Jockeying for Power **********Soon after his announcement today, the new House of Representatives indicated that a relatively pro-military group had already gained the edge in the post-election jockeying for power. By a vote of 164 to 159, a coalition led by the right-wing Thai Nation Party elected Uthai Pimchaichon as Speaker of the House. **********Thai Nation, which placed second in last week's vote, gaining 73 of the 324 House seats, has since won the support of several smaller parties that want to revive the appointed Senate's major powers, allow serving military officers to hold political and cabinet posts, and preserve an electoral system of many small parties and constituencies. All three of these temporary constitutional provisions expired Thursday. **********About 60 percent of the 243-member Senate is made up of military officers, either serving or lately retired.  General Prem became Prime Minister and Minister of Defense in March 1980. He said today of his retirement, ''I made up my mind after the opening ceremony of Parliament yesterday.'' He added that he hoped the new Government would be elected in accordance with the Constitution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/world.main_headline: AFRICANS ASK U.N. TO ACT ON NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/world.print_headline: AFRICANS ASK U.N. TO ACT ON NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/world.body_text: **********A long line of African foreign ministers and diplomats came to the Security Council this week to condemn South Africa and its control over South-West Africa. **********Nearly every envoy made the same points on the territory, which is also known as Nambia: Five years have passed since the Council agreed on a plan to give Namibia its independence but South Africa is still in charge, and the Council must act now to punish Pretoria through an embargo on South Africa's trade. **********But the Africans knew, as several acknowledged, that there was little prospect that the Council would impose sanctions. The United States and Britain would veto any move against trade, although both did vote for an embargo on arms in 1977. **********The more outspoken Africans directly accused the United States of blocking independence for Namibia, by tying it to a withdrawal of Cuban troops in Angola. The more moderate did not single out the Reagan Administration, but deplored what they termed the introduction of ''linkage'' or ''parallelism,'' which they called irrelevant. Both words are diplomatic shorthand for Washington's insistence that independence for Namibia be tied to the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola. Debate to End Next Week **********The debate is scheduled to end next week with a resolution that calls on Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to consult South Africa and the guerrillas fighting for independence, the South-West Africa People's Organization, to carry out the Council's plan. **********In private, some Africans said they recognized that the Council debate was unlikely to bring Namibia's independence any closer.  Some Western diplomats said they were surprised at the restrained tone that many Africans took toward the United States, since Washington had not only linked the issues of independence and the Cubans, but had taken the leading role in negotiations with Angola and South Africa. As a result, they said, there had been expectations that Washington would be criticized almost as much as Pretoria. **********But many Africans believe the best prospect for a relatively peaceful transfer of power in Namibia lies in the influence the United States can bring on South Africa. Question Plan for Elections **********Zaire's Foreign Minister, Kamanda Wa Kamanda, did not point to the United States, but talked of the so-called Western contact group, which comprises the United States, Britain, West Germany, Canada and France. **********Mr. Kamanda asked whether the group's plan, announced five years ago, for elections supervised by the United Nations was ''designed to lull the vigilance of Namibians and Africa if not to hoodwink them.'' **********The leader of the guerrillas, Sam Nujoma, was more critical, charging that the Reagan Administration has ''publicly embraced that racist state'' of South Africa ''as a friendly ally,'' delaying Namibia's independence and prolonging ''the suffering of our people for the sake of the global ambitions of the U.S. How selfish and how hypocritical that is.'' **********In response, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate, insisted that Washington was devoted to Namibia's independence and regretted that it had not yet been achieved. South Africa Responds **********She did not address the linkage issue, saying, ''We share the concern that the factors relating to the regional situation in southern Africa, outside the scope of the mandate of the contact group, have not yet permitted implementation of the U.N. plan.'' Diplomats interpreted her remarks to mean that it is unfortunate the Cuban troops are still an obstacle to a settlement. **********The Council is one of the few United Nations bodies that will still hear South Africa. Its delegate, Kurt R.S. von Schirnding, spelled out what Mrs. Kirkpatrick implied, saying, ''There is an unquestionable de facto linkage between the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola and the settlement of the South-West Africa question.'' **********South Africa, he went on, will ''not permit surrogate forces to influence developments in our region and we shall not tolerate the expansion of Soviet imperialism on our borders.'' **********The Angolan Foreign Minister, Paulo Teixeira Jorge, said in his speech to the Council that his country ''rejects most categorically this so-called linkage.'' **********Only Angola can decide when the Cubans leave, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.main_headline: SOVIET SAYS KOHL RECEIVED NO MANDATE ON MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.print_headline: SOVIET SAYS KOHL RECEIVED NO MANDATE ON MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union issued a series of news commentaries today warning the West German Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of retaliation if it took its victory in Sunday's elections as a mandate to proceed with the deployment of American nuclear missiles. **********The commentaries followed a barrage of anti-Kohl articles during the campaign that led Bonn to charge Soviet interference. Moscow backed the opposition Social Democrats, saying that their support for a Soviet-American accord on medium-range missiles was the only way for West Germany to avoid the ''nuclear gallows.'' **********Western diplomats had said that a victory for Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats and their Free Democratic coalition partners would spur a more accommodating Soviet line. But the articles, instead of seeking to mollify Chancellor Kohl, questioned his mandate on the missile issue and threatened unspecified countermeasures if the deployments went ahead. **********The articles said Mr. Kohl had won the election by using the ''psychological pressure'' of unemployment and that the results did not constitute more popular support for deployment. **********In fact, the articles said, opinion polls showed a majority of West Germans opposed deployment. The Novosti Press Agency, a Soviet feature syndicate, said it would be ''an act of utter irresponsibility'' for Bonn to turn its back on the proposals put forward by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. These proposals, rejected in the West, would require the cancellation of the American missile deployment in return for sharp cuts in the number of mediumrange missiles the Soviet Union maintains in Europe. 'Irrefutable Arguments' **********Spartak Beglov, a Novosti commentator, said that the new Bonn Government ''cannot ignore the irrefutable arguments'' of Moscow, which views the 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in the deployment plan as ''a Europe-based first-strike weapon against the vital centers of the U.S.S.R.'' **********''From this basic line it is not hard to guess the Soviet reaction if the newly formed Government of the Federal Republic of Germany attempts to shield itself from a drastic and mutually acceptable solution of the problem with some 'intermediate options' being prepared in Washington,'' Mr. Beglov said. **********He was referring to the possibility of a compromise under which the United States would reduce its deployment in return for a cut in existing Soviet missiles. **********Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, said Mr. Kohl now has ''every opportunity'' to demonstrate the sincerity of his pledge during a pre-election interview on the West German radio that war would never again be launched from German territory. **********The agency said that the situation was ''all the more dangerous'' since the United States might fire its missiles against the Bonn Government's will. **********''Thus, the population of West Germany becomes, as it were, a hostage of the Pentagon, which would decide its fate,'' Tass said.  ''At the same time Washington would turn West Germany into a target for a retaliatory nuclear strike.'' ---- Proposal on the Baltic Sea **********STOCKHOLM, March 7 (UPI) -Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov, a Soviet spokesman on arms control, said today in an interview with a Swedish television reporter in Moscow that a Soviet offer for a nuclear-free zone in northern Europe might be extended to the Baltic Sea. **********He said that the inclusion of the Baltic Sea in such a zone would require the withdrawal of the six Soviet submarines armed with medium-range nuclear missiles now stationed there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.main_headline: ARGENTINA REPORTS THE KILLING OF TERRORIST LEADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.print_headline: ARGENTINA REPORTS THE KILLING OF TERRORIST LEADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.body_text: **********A man described as a leading terrorist was killed Saturday in a gun battle at a farmhouse outside the provincial capital of Cordoba, Argentine officials say. **********The provincial police in Cordoba and the Third Army Corps, which has its headquarters there, said in communiques over the weekend that the man killed was Raul Clemente Yaguer, reputed to be the chief of staff and possibly the No. 2 man in the leftist Montonero terrorist group. **********The Cordoba police also said they uncovered a cache of grenades, revolvers, terrorist manuals and blank Argentine and foreign documents in a raid on a suburban house Sunday. It was unclear if the death of Mr. Yaguer led to the raid. Cordoba, 400 miles northwest of here, is Argentina's second largest city. **********Mr. Yaguer is the first reputed terrorist to have been killed in Argentina in at least three years. The military, which took power in a coup in 1976, ruthlessly wiped out subversion by the Montoneros and other leftist groups. **********Military leaders, however, have warned that some terrorists who fled into exile are sneaking back. The federal police said last week that they had found a cache of small arms in a suburban house in Avellaneda, an industrial town bordering Buenos Aires. **********Today hundreds of people lined up outside an Interior Ministry office on a back street here seeking information about relatives who disappeared during the fight against the terrorists in the 1970's.  The Government said in a nationally televised report on the ''dirty war'' last week that information on the missing would be made available today, but those waiting were given appointments for later in the week. **********According to the official reports, Mr. Yaguer was driving on the outskirts of the city on Saturday when he realized he was being followed by undercover police agents. He tried to elude the police by going into a farmhouse.  Policemen and army intelligence agents surrounded the house and ordered Mr. Yaguer to surrender, the reports said. Mr. Yaguer refused, opened fire and was killed in the ensuing gunfight, they said. **********The reports said he was carrying $5,150 in cash, false identity cards and documents of a ''subversive nature'' that police officials told Argentine newspapers could help uncover other terrorists. **********An army dossier on Mr. Yaguer, a 39-year-old chemical engineer and former university professor, says he began his terrorist career as a student agitator in 1966. The dossier lists a number of bombings, robberies and attacks on military installations that it said he was involved in before fleeing the country in 1977. **********In 1979 he signed a Montonero statement claiming responsibility for blowing up the home of Guillermo Walter Klein, the Deputy Minister of Economics, in one of the last major terrorist acts. He rose to be chief of staff in 1981, the dossier says. **********Mario Firmenich, the head of the Montoneros, lives in Havana, but often shows up at meetings of leftist Central American leaders in Nicaragua and Mexico. **********The Montoneros were founded as a youth branch of the Peronist Party around 1970, but turned leftist and were expelled from the party in 1974 by Juan Domingo Peron.  The Montoneros, who specialized in urban terrorism, were the largest of the three leftist terrorist groups in the 1970's. Membership of the three totaled 15,000, the military said in its report last week. ---- Spain Criticizes Report **********MADRID, May 2 (Reuters) - Spain tonight rejected the Argentine military's report on thousands of people who disappeared during its campaign against leftists. ''The Government expresses its deep concern and rejection at the assertion that almost all the disappeared were terrorists, particularly those 35 of Spanish nationality and 174 children and grandchildren of Spaniards on whose fate Spain has inquired,'' the Prime Minister's office said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Yields were increased about one-eighth percentage point yesterday for a $280 million issue of electric revenue bonds of the Florida Municipal Power Agency, rated A/A, according to the underwriters, led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********Prices of other tax-exempt bonds declined yesterday, so higher yields were needed to attract investors to the Florida bonds. **********They are obligations of 16 Florida municipalities that own 8.81 percent of St. Lucie No.2, a nearly completed nuclear power plant. The Florida Power and Light Company will run it. **********The agency's bonds are now priced with a maximum yield of 9.42 percent for bonds due in 2012. Yields for other maturities range from 7 percent in 1988 to 8.9 percent in 1996, 9 percent in 1998, 9 1/4 percent in 2003 and 8.85 percent for bonds with a 5 percent coupon offered at a discount price of 58.7.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.main_headline: Foreign Money Futures Are Moderately Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES; Foreign Money Futures Are Moderately Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Foreign exchange currency futures prices closed moderately higher yesterday, despite some late selling. Brokers said that most of the selling was caused by an unexpectedly small rally in the dollar's value among interbank foreign exchange dealers. **********Most foreign currency traders in both the cash and futures markets have been selling the dollar short recently through the purchase of actual foreign currencies or futures, thebrokers noted. Because many of these traders now have large paper profits, the slightest rally in the dollar tends to provoke profit taking. **********Peter Feuerstein, foreign exchange economist at Conticurrency, a unit of Conticommodity Investor Services, said that the late rally in the dollar was caused by an upturn in prices of Treasury securities. 'Bullish' on Foreign Currencies **********''We can expect some more profit taking by the currency futures traders, which should take the dollar up a bit in the next few days or so before the key foreign currencies resume their advance,'' Mr.  Feuerstein said. ''All current signs point to a further weakening of the dollar, which is why the majority of futures traders and trading houses have been so bullish on the key foreign currencies.'' **********Yesterday, despite the profit taking, the spot March futures in the West German mark rose 6 points, to 41.77 cents; the Japanese yen also rose 6 points, to 0.4292 cent, and the British pound, 5 points, to $1.5415. But the Swiss franc dipped 2 points, to 50.18 cents, and the Canadian dollar futures closed unchanged at 81.71 American cents. **********David M. Schoenthal, senior vice president and manager of foreign exchange trading at Shearson/American Express Inc., attributed some of the market's nervousness to technical factors. **********''A week ago, all technical systems were basically short foreign exchange futures,'' he said. ''Perhaps it was because profit taking was indicated after the advances of late December and January.'' **********Early this week, the followers of computerized trading systems were told to buy major foreign currencies on signs that their prices had hit lower level resistence points. Mr. Schoenthal said, ''Our technical and other calculations tell us foreign currency futures, particularly the Swiss franc, West German mark and Japanese yen, could go much higher from here in the next few weeks.'' **********John Coffin, an executive vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said the most important development in the currency futures market recently was the increased participation by banks. **********''For years, the banks pretended they didn't know these futures markets existed, preferring to handle the exchange business among themselves,'' Mr. Coffin said. ''Now the banks know and so do the foreign exchange arbitragers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/14/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY SENATOR GLENN ABOUT MIDDLE EASTERN ISSUES Following are excerpts from a speech by Senator John Glenn to a meeting of the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at the Hilton Hotel:
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/14/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY SENATOR GLENN ABOUT MIDDLE EASTERN ISSUES Following are excerpts from a speech by Senator John Glenn to a meeting of the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at the Hilton Hotel:
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/14/world.body_text: **********The time has come for Arab leaders to face some simple facts. The first of these is that Israel's right to exist is neither open to doubt nor open to question. She is one of our strongest friends and surest allies. Our morality and our national security alike demand that we protect and defend her. So let us say it clearly and let us say it frankly. America's commitment to a free and independent Israel will never fail and never falter. Not for an hour. Not for a minute. Not for an instant. **********And that commitment - coupled with the drive and ingenuity of the Israeli people themselves - is why the passage of time will never erode Israel's ability to defend herself. So delaying or abstaining from the peace process will not serve the interests of the moderate Arab states. But a fair and comprehensive peace negotiated under the Camp David process will - and such an agreement is more feasible now than it will be in the future. **********As for the P.L.O., it is time they shed their delusions and discarded the politics of fantasy. Since the war in Lebanon, they have become militarily irrelevant. And unless they stop disrupting the peace process at the expense of more realistic Arabs, they will become politically irrelevant as well.   An 'Evenhanded' Policy **********And that brings us to the so-called rejectionist states. So long as they persist in undermining conciliatory measures like the Israeli-Lebanese agreement and the Reagan peace initiatives, they will increasingly weaken their position. **********In the meantime, the United States must do a better job of promoting the peace process. And in my judgment, we have unwittingly sown confusion in the Arab world by endlessly proclaiming our fidelity to an ''evenhanded'' Middle East policy. Of course, we do want good relations both with Israel and the Arab states. But in practice, so-called evenhandedness has all too often meant a tilt away from Israel. **********We need leaders who truly understand the interests of both our countries - and who are willing to stand up and express them frankly. **********And just what are these interests? The first and foremost is our unshakable commitment to Israel's security and prosperity. **********And let me also say that it's time this Administration stopped its use and abuse of sanctions against Israel in the mistaken belief that they will somehow advance the peace process. By now, we should have learned that sanctions don't address the fundamental problem of Arab intransigence. **********A second interest we have in the Middle East is to encourage Arab acceptance of Israel's right to exist and Israeli acceptance of legitimate Palestinian aspirations. But let there be no misunderstanding. The P.L.O. has proven itself to be little more than a gang of international thugs. And until they abandon the use of terror and renounce forever their oath to destroy Israel, the United States should neither recognize nor negotiate with them. **********Arab nations must understand that the United States cannot and will not deliver Israeli concessions to them. At the same ime, Israel should refrain from actions that may undermine the Camp David process. But on one point, let there be no uncertainty: Jerusalem is the capital of Israel. And when the Camp David negotiations are completed - or if the Camp David process irretrievably breaks down - I believe the United States should be prepared to more its embassy there. And let me say that I hope we never see that city divided again.   Better Ties to Arabs **********Another interest we have in the Middle East is deterring the threat posed by aggressors like Syria, Libya and the Soviet Union. **********Our fourth and final interest in the Middle East is improving U.S.-Arab relations. We share many economic and strategic ties with those countries - and we must pursue them in an atmosphere of friendship and cooperation. **********But even if the United States does all the things I have suggested today, peace in the Middle East is by no means guaranteed. The process will likely be long - and progess will likely be slow. It will call for all the wisdom we have and every ounce of patience we've got. We can point the nations of that region in the direction of peace - and we can remove some of the hurdles that stand in their path. But in the final analysis, they must be willing to make the journey themselves.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/world.main_headline: NICARAGUA SAYS HONDURAN FIRED ON BORDER POSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/world.print_headline: NICARAGUA SAYS HONDURAN FIRED ON BORDER POSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/world.body_text: **********The Foreign Ministry charged today that a 15-member Honduran patrol fired on two Nicaraguan border posts late Sunday afternoon and briefly tried to cross into Nicaragua. **********No casualties were reported in the action, which was said to have been directed at the El Suspiro and El Espino border posts near Somotillo, about 80 miles northwest of Managua. **********There were reports today of more sporadic fighting in the last few days in northern Nicaragua between Government troops and Nicaraguan exiles based in Honduras. But it was unclear whether there had been any clashes today. **********Honduras made no immediate comment on the Nicaraguan charge.  But a Government spokesman in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, asserted that some Nicaraguan soldiers violated Honduran territory Saturday in an attempt to smuggle arms to guerrillas in El Salvador. **********The only specific action reported here today as having occurred between Nicaraguan troops and exiles was an attack on Saturday in which exiles said they killed 20 Government soldiers. According to the Nicaraguan rebels' radio station, a guerrilla group killed the soldiers while ambushing a 20-truck convoy in Nueva Segovia Province in northwestern Nicaragua. It said three insurgents were wounded. **********The broadcast added that attacks on Nicaraguan troops continued this week in northern Nueva Segovia and Matagalpa Provinces.  On Monday night, a Nicaraguan Government spokesman said guerrillas ambushed a Red Cross ambulance Sunday night in the northwestern border region and killed the driver.  He said the army was keeping troops off the highways in the area after 5 P.M. to avoid casualties in ambushes. Rebel Attacks Seem to Increase **********Reporters have been unable to travel to the areas to check the reports. The sporadic attacks by members of the rebel Nicaraguan Democratic Force have apparently intensified in northwestern Nicaragua in the last two weeks, but there has been no indication that the fighting is a serious threat to the Government. A Government spokesman estimated last week that 2,000 counterrevolutionaries were inside Nicaragua, which is believed to have about 22,000 soldiers and 40,000 militiamen. **********The Nicaraguans said the firing by the Honduran patrol on Sunday was in support of United States-backed Nicaraguan exiles. The Foreign Ministry said it would protest to Honduras, as it has many times after reports of skirmishes near the border. **********The Honduran Government spokesman made his charge about Nicaraguan arms smuggling to El Salvador in a meeting with reporters. He said Honduran security forces intercepted 12 Nicaraguan soldiers carrying a ''large quantity'' of weapons on Saturday at Nacaome, more than two-thirds of the way across the 70-mile neck of Honduran territory between Nicaragua and El Salvador. **********''That is why we can say with certainty that Nicaragua is violating Honduran territory by sending small groups of soldiers and weapons to El Salvador to strengthen and supply the guerrillas in that country,'' he said. **********He said Honduran security agencies ''estimate that Nicaragua is using various alternative routes'' through Honduras to supply the Salvadoran guerrillas. ''Those shipments take place every 48 or 72 hours,'' the spokesman said. Nicaragua Doesn't Respond **********Nicaragua's leftist Government did not comment on the Honduran charge, but it has repeatedly denied charges by the United States and El Salvador that it is funneling Soviet and Cuban weapons to the guerrillas. **********It is estimated that there are 26,000 Nicaraguan exiles in Honduras, most of them in refugee camps along the border. They include 5,000 former members of the national guard under President Anastasio Somoza Debayle. They escaped after the Sandinists drove the President into exile in July 1979. The exiles also include 15,000 Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indians who fled to Honduras after Nicaragua put them out of their villages on the Caribbean coast. **********Honduras has repeatedly denied that the Nicaraguan guerrillas operate from its territory, and the United States has refused to answer Nicaragua's charges that it arms, trains and otherwise supports them. **********The Reagan Administration cut off all United States aid to Nicaragua in 1981, charging that the Sandinists were aiding the guerrillas in El Salvador. **********The anti-Government Nicaraguan guerrillas are said to have formed a crescent of outposts in northwestern Nicaragua.  Government spokesmen said last week that the exiles had been infiltrating Nicaragua in small contingents.  Defense Minister Humberto Ortega termed their action ''not serious'' but said their intent was to provoke confrontations that might lead to war with Honduras. **********In a statement covering what it denounced as ''aggressions against Nicaragua'' in January and February, the Government said the first occurred Jan. 16 when, it said, 60 guerrillas attacked more than 200 farm workers, killing 2 children and wounding 14 others. **********Other attacks in January, it said, included ambushes of trucks and other vehicles, attacks on farms and a border port.  It said 73 guerrillas were killed on Jan. 29 by Nicaraguan forces. **********Similar attacks were said to have continued in February.

Richard De Rosa, president and chief executive of the Mission Insurance Group of Los Angeles, said yesterday that he would resign by Jan. 31. **********Mr. De Rosa, who is 60 years old, has been president of the company for 20 years. He will stay in his posts pending the selection of a successor. **********The American Financial Corporation has a 20 percent stake in Mission. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/19/world.body_text: **********The French police, investigating the bombing at Orly Airport that killed 6 travelers and wounded 56, rounded up 51 people today for questioning and confiscated what an official called ''a significant number'' of guns, explosives and radio communication sets. **********French officials described the raids as a major blow against a terrorist group, the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia, which took responsibility for the bombing at the Turkish Airlines counter on Friday. **********The majority of those picked up by a force of 150 policemen in raids in and around Paris were Armenians from Turkey, the police said. **********Others, they added, included five Armenians of French nationality and some people from Syria and Iran. Link to Arms Sales Speculated **********France is a major supplier of arms to Iraq in its war with Iran, and French officials have speculated that both Iran and Syria might have an interest in assisting the Armenian aroup. **********Officials said that most of those picked up today arrived in France this year. They were under police surveillance and had been identified as activists in Armenian nationalist politics, the officials added. **********According to an Interior Ministry communique, no one among those arrested has yet admitted any connection with the terrorism at Orly. **********The weapons seized in the raids included about a dozen manufactured abroad - machine guns, pistols and others. Explosives Unlike Those at Orly **********The police also found explosives, about a dozen detonators and a communications system. They said that the explosives did not appear similar to those used at the Orly Airport. **********There were reports today that a leader of the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia, Agop Agopian, was alive, although the organization said he was killed a year ago during fighting in Beirut. **********Liberation, the Paris daily, said that Mr. Agopian was photographed by policemen and counterespionage officials in April, when he came to Paris. His trip, according to the paper, was for the purpose of rebuilding the Armenian underground organization. **********Western diplomats agreed that there was evidence Mr. Agopian was alive. French officials did not arrest him during his April visit, according to these reports, because they were wary of provoking terrorist reprisals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Stock market prices rose sharply yesterday, mostly on renewed expectations that interest rates will decline. Two of the three major market indicators closed at record levels. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, composed of 30 prominent companies, soared 20.33 points to 1,087.75, within striking range of its record close of 1,092.35 on Jan.10. **********The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks gained 1.31, to a record 85.10, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also closed at a new high, 147.50, up 2.50. **********The advance was broadly based, with stocks that gained in price outscoring those that declined by more than a 5-to-2 ratio. Turnover on the Big Board expanded to 93.5 million shares, from 84.5 million shares on Wednesday, as buying by pensions funds, insurance companies and other institutions increased. Report Spurs Market **********Analysts said the market's upsurge was spurred by a news agency report that the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, its policymaking arm, had decided to leave monetary targets unchanged this year, a step that analysts said could result in lower interest rates. **********In the credit markets yesterday, yields for both long- and shortterm issues fell sharply. (Page D7.) The stock market was also helped by a statement by Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, who said that a reduction in crude oil prices was inevitable. A lower price for imported oil might help some American oil companies increase profit margins, analysts said. **********Six of the 15 most actively traded issues yesterday were stocks of oil producers. Exxon, the volume leader, rose 3/4, to 30 1/8; Phillips Petroleum advanced 1 7/8, to 32 1/2; Mobil, 1 3/8, to 28 1/2; Atlantic Richfield, 1 1/8, to 46 3/4; Standard of California, 1 5/8, to 35 1/4, and Amerada Hess, 1/2, to 26 3/8. **********The strength in the energy group spilled over into the oil-service stocks. Schlumberger jumped 1 7/8, to 45 1/4, although it reported lower profits for the fourth quarter, while Halliburton and Sedco each rose more than a point. 300-Point Gain Since August **********The market's strong performance, which has seen the Dow climb more than 300 points since mid-August, has been powered by heavy buying by institutional accounts. **********However, in the first two sessions this week, the overall market declined as interest rates rose slightly, with the Dow falling almost 20 points on profit-taking. **********William M. LeFevre, market strategist of Purcell, Graham & Company, cautioned that if further cuts in interest rates do not materialize, ''the stock and bond markets may plunge in the next few weeks.'' **********Even the news announced by the Commerce Department at 2:30 P.M.  yesterday - that retail sales in January rose only one-tenth of 1 percent -did not halt the market's upsurge. Retail sales last month were expected to rise between 1 to 1.5 percent. A Nasdaq Record **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market also rose sharply yesterday. The Amex market-value index climbed 5.53, to 376.06, while in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index jumped 3.39, to a record 254.77. **********Among the bigger gainers in the blue-chip issues yesterday on the Big Board, American Express rose 2 5/8, to 66 1/4; United Technologies, 2, to 62 1/2; International Business Machines, 1 7/8, to 96 3/8, and Du Pont, 1 1/4, to 41 7/8. **********The stronger technology stocks included Motorola, which climbed 3, to 110. Computervision was up 1 7/8, to 43 1/8; NCR, 2 3/8, to 97 1/2; Honeywell, 2 3/8, to 91, and Digital Equipment, 3 1/2, to 120 1/4. **********On the Amex, Gould Investors Trust gained 1 1/4, to 19 7/8, after the company reported a large increase in profits for its first quarter ended Dec.31. **********The big mover in the over-the-counter market was Western Maryland Railway, which jumped 18 1/2 points, to 50 bid. CSX Corporation, which trades on the Big Board, said it will acquire all of the stock of Western Maryland that it does not already hold, for $55 a share in cash or an equivalent amount in CSX stock. The latter rose 1 1/2, to 55.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/busin.body_text: **********The Tosco Corporation said today that its president and chief executive officer, Morton M. Winston, had relinquished those posts to take the title of chairman and consultant to the company's directors. **********The unexpected shift by Mr. Winston, who had been chief executive for seven years, and president since 1971, came as negotiations with the company's lenders continued on delayed payments on a $700 million revolving credit agreement. **********George Hobgood, a Tosco spokesman, said he could not comment on whether the lenders had forced Mr. Winston from the company's chief executive post as a condition for continuing negotiations on the debt repayment. He added: ''He participated in all the meetings that have gone on.'' Mr. Hobgood added that he was not certain whether Mr. Winston would continue working full time at the company, which he joined in 1964. Tosco lost $46.6 million in the first quarter. **********The company said Matthew J. Talbot, who is 45 years old, replaced Mr. Winston, 53, as ''acting'' president and as chief executive. Mr.  Talbot, a Tosco director since 1975, was an executive vice president and chief operating officer of its Controls and Services Division. **********Isadore M. Scott, chairman, took the title of vice chairman to make room for Mr. Winston. But the company spokesman, Mr. Hobgood, said he could not say what shift in duties the change would mean for Mr.  Scott. **********Tosco, based in Century City, is the nation's largest independent petroleum refiner. Its operations, which primarily serve West Coast gasoline marketers, have been depressed because of price competition in California this year. A year ago, its participation in a synthetic fuel project in Colorado was dissolved when the Exxon Corporation exercised an option to terminate the project. **********Mr. Hobgood said he did not know where Mr. Winston, the principal architect of Tosco's investments in shale oil development, could be reached.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.main_headline: EAGLE STAR ATTRACTS 2D ROUND OF BIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.print_headline: EAGLE STAR ATTRACTS 2D ROUND OF BIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Allianz Versicherungs A.G. and B.A.T Industries, competing for Eagle Star Holdings, Britain's sixth-largest insurance company, raised their bids today within 15 minutes of each other. Both valued Eagle Star at just over $1.3 billion, meaning the takeover would be the biggest ever in Britain. **********Allianz, West Germany's largest insurance company, offered $:6.50 a share, equal to about $9.50. It bid $:5 Oct. 19. B.A.T, the tobacco and retailing giant, responded by raising its offer to $:6.60 a share, bettering Allianz's bid by 10 pence. B.A.T had bid $:5.75 a share when it entered the contest started by Allianz. **********Record Figure by Far **********B.A.T's offer values Eagle Star at $:914 million, far above the $:660 million paid in the most expensive British takeover to date, the acquisition of Thomas Tilling early this year by BTR P.L.C. **********The first round of bidding closed with Eagle Star dismissing Allianz's bid and accepting B.A.T's. Today, Sir Dennis Mountain, Eagle Star's chairman, said the company's board was ''considering the situation'' and would advise shareholders as soon as possible. **********Allianz described today's announcement as its final offer. But after B.A.T's offer was announced, Allianz said it would consider further moves. Such a move is not expected before B.A.T shareholders vote Thursday on whether to approve the company's new bid. **********The new offers are good for three weeks and any higher bids would have to be made by Dec. 30, according to securities law. **********Both would-be acquirers have strong reasons for pursuing Eagle Star. **********Allianz has little room for expansion in its home market. It was attracted to Eagle Star two years ago and acquired a 29.9 percent holding before beginning the takeover attempt. Its offer was widely seen as a reaction to fruitless efforts to work out cooperative ventures with the British company and to gain representation on its board. Allianz's paper profit on its Eagle Star holding is well in excess of $200 million. **********An Expansion for B.A.T **********B.A.T, Britain's third-largest industrial concern, sees Eagle Star as the foundation for making financial services a new and important leg of its empire. B.A.T shares were unchanged today on the London Stock Exchange, at $:1.54. **********The Government has told the companies that it does not object to either bid on antitrust grounds. The British Insurance Association, however, has tried to discourage Allianz. Last week, it told the Government it had ''grave misgivings'' about allowing a foreign company to bid for Eagle Star. **********Allianz contends that the acquisition would make it one of the seven largest insurance companies in the world and that it would strengthen London's role as an insurance center.  The offers today were roughly in line with expectations. Eagle Star shares traded at $:6.54 Friday. They rose to $:6.70 today, exceeding the rival bids and indicating that some shareholders were counting on still higher offers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/busin.main_headline: Thrift Unit Inflows Soared In January
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/busin.print_headline: Thrift Unit Inflows Soared In January
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/busin.body_text: **********American savers, attracted by the new money market deposit account, put a record $14.5 billion more into savings and loan institutions in January than they withdrew, the Government reported today. **********The surge in deposits marked a sharp turnaround in money flow to the institutions, which, until December's introduction of the highpaying account, had been recording monthly losses for much of the last two years. **********In its new report, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said the 3,331 federally insured thrift institutions reported balances in January of $76.5 billion in the new account, with $42.9 billion deposited in January alone. The $2,500-minimum account was introduced Dec. 14 to give banks and thrift institituions a chance to compete better with money market mutual funds. **********A second account, the ''Super NOW'' check-writing account, was introduced Jan. 5, and the bank board said it drew $4.5 billion during that month. Both accounts are free from federally mandated interest rate ceilings. **********Reflecting the shift of money from low-paying accounts to the money market ones, the bank board said balances in many other savings accounts fell in January. The amount of money in passbook savings accounts and old fixed-rate certificates plunged $8.8 billion. **********Over all, savings and loans institutions received $85.6 billion in new deposits and lost $71 billion in withdrawals. When interest was credited, the net deposit gain was $16.6 billion, the report said. **********The bank board also said the thrift units closed $5.1 billion worth of mortgages in January, down from $8.3 billion in December.  The institutions' net worth dipped a bit in January to $25.3 billion after rising in the three previous months. It was $25.4 billion in December, the report said. Net worth is the excess of assets over liabilities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/busin.main_headline: WITHHOLDING TAX ON WAGES DECLINES TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/busin.print_headline: WITHHOLDING TAX ON WAGES DECLINES TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/busin.body_text: **********The third and final stage of President Reagan's income tax cut, the keystone of his economic program, becomes effective Friday. It is expected to save taxpayers $30 billion over the next 12 months. **********Paychecks will start to look different in the next week or two as employers adjust withholding to reflect the final 10 percent cut in income tax rates. The extra take-home pay is expected to stimulate consumer spending and the nation's economic recovery in the second half of this year. **********Amounts Involved **********In most cases, the reduction in withholding will be about 10 percent. For single taxpayers, the increase in weekly take-home pay will run from 10 cents (for those earning $82 a week) to a maximum of $16.20. **********For married taxpayers, the weekly withholding reduction will run from 20 cents (for those earning $140 a week) to a maximum of $21.60. The maximums apply to single taxpayers with salaries over $35,000 a year and married taxpayers with salaries over $50,000 a year. **********For most families and single people, however, the extra amount in their paychecks will be not much more than $2 to $7 a week. The Third Stage **********The first stage of the reduction in individuals' income tax rates was a 5 percent cut on Oct. 1, 1981. The second was a 10 percent cut on July 1, 1982. Now comes the final cut of 10 percent. Although the three steps add up to 25 percent, the overall reduction is actually about 23 percent, because the cuts in the second and third years are on a lowered rate. **********''The tax cut is one of the reasons to be optimistic in the second half of the year,'' said Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, who just this week supported upward revision of the Administration's economic forecast. **********Walter W. Heller, who was chairman of the council in the Kennedy Administration and a sometime opponent of the tax cut, said ''it is one more element in the consumer reawakening'' that is propelling the economic recovery. **********The expectations for this final installment of the tax cut are much higher than those for the 10 percent cut that was effective last July 1. At that time high interest rates, a rising unemployment rate and the wary mood of consumers combined to offset the stimulus. High interest rates made houses and cars too expensive, and the gloomy outlook for the economy made people want to hold onto their cash. Questions About Effects **********But Mr. Feldstein, Mr. Heller and other economists say the tax-rate cut won't result in a sudden economic spurt. They say they have already factored the tax cuts into their earlier forecasts of growth in the economy this year at a slightly lower rate than the average in the early months of previous recoveries from recessions. **********Lawrence Chimerine, chairman of Chase Econometrics, an economic consulting firm, doesn't think the tax cut is so vital. ''If there were no tax cut on July 1, this recovery would continue,'' he said, ''and at only a slightly slower pace.'' **********Mr. Chimerine added: ''To the extent that we are getting more consumer spending from the tax cut, and we will, we will lose some of the stimulus because the tax cut means higher deficits and higher interest rates. So the net stimulative effect is there but it is not extremely large.'' **********Some consumers may have been spending the tax cut in advance, according to Robert Ortner, the chief economist at the Commerce Department. He said that a rise in retail sales in March, April and May could have been reflected anticipation of the July increase in takehome pay. What Consumers Will Do **********Mr. Ortner reflects the Administration's hope that the consumer will spend, rather than save, most of the tax cut when he says: ''Consumers are already spending the money, and they need the tax cut to continue. The economy needs it. The unemployment rate needs it.'' **********This exhortation to spend is a far cry from the call for increased savings that was the rationale of the President's supply-side economics when he pushed for enactment of the three-year across-theboard tax cut in 1981. **********Mr. Heller, noting the change, said the recovery was now being propelled by ''good old demand management,'' the kind of stimulative economic policy that President Reagan said he wanted to get away from. **********Mr. Feldstein agreed, but he said that the reduction in tax rates would spur work incentives and savings in the future. Overall Data **********Including the first phase of the tax cut on Oct. 1, 1981, the maximum decline in weekly withholding now comes to about $40 for single people earning about $35,000 or more and about $44 for married people earning more than $50,000. **********The reason that the withholding stops at a maximum of $16.20 for single taxpayers and $21.60 for married taxpayers is that the maximum withholding rate remains unchanged at 37 percent, as it did a year ago. This means that single people with salaries above $35,000 and married people with salaries above $50,000 do not get a full 10 percent reduction in their withholding. **********Treasury officials said that the 37 percent withholding rate was not being reduced because people at these income levels are already under-withheld since tax rates go as high as 50 percent of adjusted gross income. But people at this level can increase their take-home pay by an additional amount by increasing the number of allowances or exemptions they claim. **********There will also be a group of lower income people in the bottom income tax bracket - under $10,000 for married taxpayers and under $5,000 for single taxpayers - who will get no reduction in their withholding this July. **********According to the Treasury Department, these people got the full three-year reduction withholding a year ago when their new withholding rate was rounded down to avoid a fraction. In other words, a year ago their withholding tax was cut more than 10 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/23/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Platte River Bonds Yield 5% to 9.2%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/23/busin.body_text: **********A $398 million issue of re-funding revenue bonds of Colorado's Platte River Authority was tentatively priced with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 9.2 percent in 1996. Among longer-term bonds, those due in 2003 were tentatively offered to yield 9 3/4 percent, while 9 7/8 percent bonds were offered at slight discounts to yield 9.92 percent for the 2013 maturity and 9.95 percent for the 2018 maturity. **********The underwriters, led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said proceeds of the issue, rated A-1, would be used to retire outstanding 14 percent and 14 1/8 percent bonds, sold by the authority when interest rates were much higher. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/world.main_headline: Soviet Delegate Admits Error in Plane Incident
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/world.print_headline: Soviet Delegate Admits Error in Plane Incident
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/world.body_text: **********A Soviet delegate to an international conference here acknowledged today that Soviet pilots made a ''mistake'' in the downing of a South Korean airliner. He said they wrongly identified it as a military reconnaissance plane and wouldn't have shot it down if they had known it was a commercial flight. **********He repeated the allegation that the Korean Air Lines jet was on a spy mission. **********It was the first Soviet admission of error in the destruction of the Boeing 747 Sept. 1. All 269 people aboard are believed to have been killed after the plane was intercepted and shot down over the Soviet island of Sakhalin. **********''Of course, it was a mistake in the sense that the pilots took this plane for a reconnaissance plane,'' the official, Viktor Linnik, said in English in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation. The BBC identified him as an adviser to the Soviet leadership and one of the nine members of the Soviet delegation to an Edinburgh University conference on East-West relations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Nakasone's Party Defeated in 2 Races
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/11/world.body_text: **********Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party was stung by two major defeats in gubernatorial races but cemented its control over the nation's local governments in elections Sunday. **********Opposition Socialist and Communist parties said victories by their candidates in the Fukuoka and Hokkaido provinces were a stiff rebuff to the four-month-old Government of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. **********Conservative and centrist candidates backed by the Liberal Democrats won 11 of 13 gubernatorial races. In Tokyo, the incumbent governor, Shunichi Suzuki, easily defeated Hideo Matsuoka, a political commentator who ran on a ''stop Nakasone'' platform. **********The Liberal Democrats appeared to have boosted their majorities in the provincial assemblies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/busin.body_text: **********The Government today lowered the maximum interest rate on federally backed home mortgages to 13 percent, from 13.5 percent. **********The reduction in the closely watched rate halts a trend of increases that began in early June, when it stood at a three-year low of 11.5 percent. The new 13 percent rate is effective on single-family home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration. **********Economists and housing officials said today that the small reduction might help stabilize the floundering housing market. **********'Move Should Help' **********''It's a positive move that should help the market at a time when home sales are falling,'' said Harry Pryde, president of the National Association of Home Builders. But, he added, ''We need to get F.H.A.-V.A. rates back in the 12 percent range to keep this recovery going at a healthy clip.'' **********However, Mark J. Riedy, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said the action might be an ''another example of political decision-making entering the process of setting F.H.A. rates.'' **********The Government moved awfully quickly, he added, ''and I think they may be shooting from the hip.'' **********Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said the decision to lower the rate ceiling stemmed from recent improvements in the credit markets. **********''The slowing in the money supply growth and the moderation in retail sales and durable goods orders have reassured the credit markets that the economic recovery will not reignite inflation,'' Mr. Pierce said. **********Opening the Market **********Secretary Pierce said he was ''especially pleased'' to announce the lower F.H.A. rate, ''because it opens the market to many potential buyers who were effectively shut out of the home ownership market by the higher rate.'' **********The half-point reduction, which is effective on Tuesday, lowers the monthly interest and principal payment on a typical 30-year, $75,000 mortgage by $29.25 a month, to $830.25. **********The Government also dropped the rate on graduated-payment mortgages to 13.5 percent, from 13.75 percent. The average rate for conventional mortgages not backed by the Government is about 13.75 percent. **********Mr. Pierce said the Government decided to move now because a ''perception has developed'' that the surge in long-term interest rates late last month resulted from an ''overly pessimistic misreading'' of the extent to which the Federal Reserve Board tightened credit last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/11/busin.main_headline: U.S. TRADE GAP CALLED A THREAT TO THE ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/11/busin.print_headline: U.S. TRADE GAP CALLED A THREAT TO THE ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/11/busin.body_text: **********The United States deficit in foreign trade, which has widened to record levels, is a serious threat to the economy and the threat is unlikely to diminish as the economy recovers, officials in the Reagan Administration now believe. **********The gap between imports and exports is expected to contribute to persistently high unemployment and continuing troubles for many industries. **********Government officials predict that imports of merchandise will exceed exports by $60 billion or more this year, a gap that would be 50 percent wider than last year's record deficit. Trade in Services Off, Too **********And nonmerchandise trade is not helping any. For years, the country relied on gains from other international business activities, such as banking, insurance and travel services, to compensate for shortfalls in the export of goods. But that advantage, too, has faded, widening the overall deficit in the balance of payments. **********Robert J. Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, said the deficit on this overall basis, which is known as the current account, could reach $25 billion this year, far exceeding the record current account deficit of $15 billion in 1978. **********''It certainly looks alarming,'' he added.  ''With the recovery under way, we don't want to delude ourselves that the problem will go away,'' said Patricia E. Barrett, director of trade policy at the New York-based National Foreign Trade Council, an association of leading trade-oriented businesses. ''Indications are it's going to get worse before it gets better.'' **********The principal cause of the merchandise trade deficit is the strong dollar, which makes imports a bargain in American stores and American goods more expensive for shoppers abroad. But there are other aggravations as well. **********These include the financial plight of the developing countries, the slow pace of recovery in Europe, the deteriorating finances of oilexporting countries, the bountiful crops in food-exporting countries and an increasingly aggressive international competition for sales. **********And oil imports could become a problem again. As the recovery strengthens, American industries, utilities and automobiles are burning more fuel, and according to the Department of Energy, imports have risen from 3.4 million barrels a day in January to 4.3 million for the week ended July 1. **********Last year, the United States recorded a merchandise trade deficit of $42.7 billion, slightly larger than the previous record, set in 1978, of $42.4 billion. Current Account Deficit **********The surplus normally recorded by trade in services has often offset the merchandise deficits in the overall, or current account, calculation. But after showing surpluses in 1980 and 1981, the current account had a deficit of $11 billion last year. ''It's a leakage of business activity. The growth in demand in this country is being met by foreign sources,'' Mr. Ortner said. **********Deficits and surpluses in trade were once unimportant to the United States, a country that through most of its history could depend on its vast internal market for growth. But in the past 20 years, foreign industries have discovered that vast market, too, while American industry was less successful in developing foreign markets. **********Mr. Ortner, of the Commerce Department, said American exports represent 8 percent of the country's total output of goods and services, almost twice the level of 1970. ''If you go beyond the industries that actually export goods, to all the other industries that support them, that figure could more than double,'' he said. **********All those industries represent jobs. A Commerce Department study says that export-related employment fell from 6.2 million jobs in 1980 to 4.9 million in 1982, a drop that represented 40 percent of all the American jobs lost in the two years. The weaker trade performance is a major reason why the overall unemployment rate, 9.8 percent in June, is considered unlikely to fall below the 6 percent that the Government now considers the rock-bottom level in a strong economy. The Lofty Dollar **********Most executives and economists single out the dollar as the chief reason for the weakness of American exports. ''The British pound is down 35 or 40 percent against the dollar,'' said Thomas A. Holmes, chairman of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, a leading American exporter of compressors, pumps, mining equipment, oil drilling equipment and other gear. **********''That differential means we have to drop our prices by that much or raise our productivity by that much,'' he said. ''This is a major problem for us. It has taken us 100 years to gain our positions in these countries, and we're not anxious to abdicate them.'' **********To compete, Mr. Holmes said, an American manufacturer has to buy more and more parts for equipment abroad, with strong dollars, to close the currency differential. **********Most economists attribute the dollar's strength to the Federal budget deficits, now running at up to $200 billion annually. They contend that the deficits force the Treasury to compete with consumers and industrial borrowers for funds. With more demand for dollars, their cost - interest rates - has to rise. **********The higher interest rates, in turn, lure foreigners to sell their currencies and buy dollar investments, easing demand for those currencies and putting a premium on the dollar. **********Even without the dollar problem, American industry is hard put to find foreign customers.  Walter K. Joelson, chief economist at the General Electric Company, said even the oil-producing countries offered little promise.  Nigeria, Venezuela and Indonesia have all but ceased their ambitious development plans, with the drop in oil prices. **********Europe is beginning to recover from the world recession, which in normal times would signal a revival of European purchases of American goods. But many economists expect nothing more than a tepid recovery there. Hard-Pressed Customers **********In addition, Mr. Joelson said, European nations have record unemployment, while their governments face constraints on spending to create jobs. So Europe, like the United States, looks to the third world to provide business for its industries. **********Many of the developing countries are big borrowers from the West.  But because of the recession and other factors, some have had to reschedule their debt payments and promise to cut spending of hardto-get Western currencies on imports. **********Now there is a new restraint, said Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. Normally, an American company would go to its bank for 120-day supplier credits, or loans, to give a foreign customer to help it make the purchase. **********''Supplier credits probably accounted for half our trade with Mexico,'' he said. But now banks have become reluctant to extend the credits, he said, and the loans ''have slowed down to a trickle.'' **********Such restraints have had a telling effect on trade. Mr. Olmer said that Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela bought 40 percent less in American goods during the first four months of this year than in the first four months in 1982. **********In addition, Mr. Olmer said, with import restrictions, the developing nations can buy only those goods essential to their survival, energy and food. He said: ''That means they're not going to import capital goods, like machinery and aircraft. And what do we export? Capital goods.'' **********Such restrictions are showing signs of becoming counterproductive.  ''Mexico,'' Mr. Olmer said, ''has done a dramatic job in stopping imports, but that's beginning to have an effect on its ability to export, because they can't buy the commodities they need to make goods for export.'' **********These problems, Mr. Olmer thinks, are probably transitory. But other problems are likely to linger. World markets have become vastly more competitive, said Dean D. Thornton, a vice president for marketing at the Boeing Company in Seattle. **********''There's been a fundamental change,'' Mr. Thornton said. ''U.S.  commercial aircraft manufacturers dominated the world market. They made well over 90 percent of the world's jets. There were three companies - Boeing, Lockheed and Douglas. The only question was which one got the sales.'' **********Then, he said, France, West Germany and Britain collaborated in the formation of Airbus Industrie, now a leading competitor. The European company, he said, gets a great amount of government support. ''We'd like to have a more supportive policy from the U.S. Government.''
