https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/world.main_headline: TRAVELERS STRANDED IN SOVIET SEEK NEW WAYS HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/world.print_headline: TRAVELERS STRANDED IN SOVIET SEEK NEW WAYS HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/world.body_text: **********Travelers from around the world lined up at ticket offices here today in search of new routes home as Western restrictions on flights in and out of the Soviet Union went into full effect. **********Two weeks after a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean airliner over the Sea of Japan, the repercussions could be seen at hotel counters, airline offices and embassies. Westerners caught by canceled flights lined up to extend hotel bookings and renew expiring visas, but their principal concern lay in plotting new dog-leg routes home. **********Generally, the mood seemed to be more of weariness and frustration than despair. Although actions by foreign governments, pilots' associations and labor unions have suspended or restricted air connections between Moscow and at least 16 countries, several thousand travelers who were booked on canceled flights seemed generally to be finding other ways home, many of them on routes through Eastern Europe. **********''We'll get out of here, even if it does take a day or two,'' said a retired physician from California, returning to his hotel room with his wife after visiting an office of Aeroflot, the Soviet carrier, in the lobby. The couple, part of a group that had been touring Soviet Central Asia, declined to give their names. ''No sense in having people worry,'' the doctor said. **********The main concern for many Westerners was whether Aeroflot would accept their tickets for rerouted journeys aboard the Soviet carrier and other airlines still flying. On Wednesday Aeroflot reservation clerks began refusing tickets issued by United States airlines, but there were signs today that the action was being extended to tickets issued by carriers from other Western nations involved in the boycott. **********At one point a group of angry Americans and Western Europeans gathered around the Aeroflot desk in the Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel, the most modern in Moscow, after clerks had rejected tickets issued on Lufthansa, Scandinavian Airlines System and other Western carriers, including some United States lines. Like the travelers affected by the rejection of American tickets on Wednesday, the travelers were told they would have to buy new tickets from Aeroflot, paying with cash or credit cards, and claiming refunds on their original tickets later. **********The action against holders of United States airline tickets was originally explained by an Aeroflot spokesman as retaliation for restrictions imposed on Aeroflot this week by the United States Civil Aeronautics Board, which acted at President Reagan's request.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/world.print_headline: REAGAN TO BLOCK F-16'S TILL ISRAEL LEAVES LEBANON; Transcript of speech, page A8.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/world.body_text: **********President Reagan said today that until Israel withdraws its forces from Lebanon, he will not permit the transfer of some 75 F-16 fighter jets that have been held up since last summer. **********''We are forbidden by law to release those planes,'' Mr. Reagan said.  He implied, but did not state explicitly, that Israel had violated the terms of an arms supply agreement with the United States stating that American military equipment can be used only for defensive purposes. Under the Arms Export Act, the President has discretionary authority to cut off military sales to any nation found in substantial violation of such an agreement. **********The President's remarks were in response to questions after a televised speech in Los Angeles that was devoted to arms control. In the speech he offered his most extensive critique to date of the proposal in Congress for a nuclear freeze resolution. **********Mr. Reagan appealed to supporters of the measure to put aside ''partisan politics'' and unite behind his Administration's arms control proposals to the Soviet Union. (Page A8.) **********The President's comments on Israel caught the State Department by surprise, since for eight months the Administration has refrained from saying Israel had violated the agreement by its invasion of Lebanon. In addition, officials have declined to give a reason for delaying the release of the F-16's to Israel. **********Some concern was expressed that Israel might react strongly to Mr.  Reagan's comments and prove more recalcitrant in the negotiations now going on over its withdrawal from Lebanon. **********Mr. Reagan said the effort to bring about the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces from Lebanon had been ''a frustrating experience.'' Until this is achieved, he said, it is impossible to proceed ''with the general subject of overall peace.'' **********Philip C. Habib, Mr. Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, was on his way back to the United States today after another round of inconclusive talks. And Yasir Arafat, the head of the P.L.O., arrived in Amman for talks with King Hussein of Jordan that are supposed to be crucial to whether the King goes along with Mr. Reagan's call for expanding the Middle East peace negotiations. Some officials have said that King Hussein will not agree to enter the talks until Israel agrees to terms for pulling out of Lebanon. A Previous Delivery Delayed **********After Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor in the summer of 1981, Mr. Reagan held up delivery of fourteen F-16's and two F-15's, informing Congress that Israel might have violated an arms sales agreement. But on Aug. 17, 1981, the delivery was allowed after a new cease-fire and discussions with Israeli officials. **********In June 1982, Israel invaded Lebanon and carried out repeated air attacks on Beirut and other locations. Without any formal notification to Congress, the Administration held up the delivery of the 75 F-16's now at issue. The official reason given was that the delivery required a Presidential authorization. **********Privately, officials said then that the planes would not be released as long as Israel was attacking targets in Lebanon with American planes. But the planes were not released even after the fighting stopped. Matter Was 'Under Review' **********As questions were raised on Capitol Hill and elsewhere as to whether Israel had violated United States law and agreements in using American equipment in Lebanon, the State Department said only that the matter was ''under review.'' **********More recently, however, the Pentagon went ahead with the sale of Sidewinder missiles to Israel and Israel agreed to share with the United States intelligence information gathered from the war in Lebanon, particularly its success against Soviet-made aircraft and anti-aircraft missile systems. **********The Israelis, arguing that the installation of Soviet-made SA-5 antiaircraft missiles in Syria had increased their need for more planes, have requested the release of the 75 F-16's. Officials have said that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has argued against turning the planes over before Israel pulls out of Lebanon. 'Letting Lebanon Be Lebanon' **********Mr. Reagan was asked in Los Angeles today why the planes were not released, given the Soviet buildup in Syria. He replied, ''You must realize that under the law - the law exists now - those weapons must be for defensive purposes, and this is, again, one of the obstacles presented by the stalemate in Lebanon. **********''While those forces are in the position of occupying another country that now has asked them to leave, we are forbidden by law to release those planes,'' he said. ''They're F-16's, the planes that are on order. And it's as simple as the other forces returning to their own countries and letting Lebanon be Lebanon.'' **********Mr. Reagan also said, ''Israel can only know real security if it doesn't have to remain an armed camp far beyond what its size warrants.'' **********He said it should ''know the security of being surrounded by neighbors that recognize its right to exist as a nation and have signed peace treaties with it.'' He said the goal of his Middle East policy was ''to create more Egypts,'' or Arab states that would live in peace with Israel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/world.main_headline: Arafat Criticizes West At Geneva Conference
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Arafat Criticizes West At Geneva Conference
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/world.body_text: **********Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, criticized the United States and other Western countries today for not taking part in the United Nations conference here on Palestinian rights. **********Mr. Arafat, speaking at the conference, said the nonparticipating countries had refused to ''meet their responsibilities,'' and he asked the 134 nations present to take all the action required to assure Palestinians a ''just peace and the right to live in dignity in their homeland.'' **********The United States and Israel are boycotting the session on the ground that its sponsors wanted it only as a platform for ''one-sided judgments'' in support of the P.L.O. The major West European powers have sent only observers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/busin.body_text: **********The MCI Communications Corporation, the first to take on the giant Bell System in the long-distance telephone business, is to take on the Postal Service, Western Union, Federal Express and other giants in the message delivery business, industry sources said yesterday. **********Next Tuesday, they said, the company will introduce an electronic mail service allowing customers to send messages written on their computers or word processors. **********The messages either could be delivered over MCI communications lines to other computers or be printed out and delivered through the mail or by courier. The sources said Purolator Inc. would handle courier deliveries. **********MCI officials, while acknowledging that the company would announce a data communications service Tuesday, declined to provide details. But the company has made little secret of its desire to expand beyond voice communications into fast-growing data communications. **********Analysts said MCI would make a strong entry because of its reputation for going after the highest-volume markets first, offering low prices and marketing services with savvy. **********''I think they will put an incredible amount of price pressure on the couriers and an incredible amount of service pressure on Western Union,'' said Paris Burstyn of the Yankee Group, a telecommunications consulting and market research firm in Boston. **********In entering the field, MCI will face a host of entrenched competitors.  Companies such as the GTE Corporation's Telenet and Tymshare's Tymnet already offer computer-to- computer communications. Western Union's Mailgram and the Postal Service's E-COM service deliver printed messages generated by computer. And Federal Express, the leader in the overnight document delivery business, is moving into electronic delivery, probably through facsimile transmission. Market Is Put at $1 Billion **********Stephen A. Caswell, editor of Electronic Mail and Message Systems, a trade publication, said that there were numerous competitors in the electronic message market, which he put at $1 billion, including telex service. Despite the competition, he said, the quality of MCI's management should give the company an edge. **********Analysts noted that a data service would help MCI to better utilize the communications lines it already has in place for its long distance service. **********Sources said that MCI had an agreement with the Dow Jones News Retrieval Service, a leading provider of computerized information services. The Dow Jones service's subscribers will automatically be able to use MCI's electronic mail service. **********To use the MCI mail service, customers would tie into a special MCI data communications network that the company had built by Bolt Beranek & Newman, a Cambridge, Mass., communications concern. It is believed that there would be local connections to the network in 35 cities and toll-free numbers for those outside the cities. **********The messages could then go through the network to the recipient's terminal if the recipient also subscribed to the service. If not, the messages could be printed at one of 15 printing centers set up by MCI.  Sources said the company would charge on the basis of what it calls MCI Mail ''ounces,'' with an ounce being 7,500 characters, or three or four pages of text. Sending a message directly from one computer to another will cost $1 an ounce; sending to a printing center for onward delivery by first-class mail would cost $2 for the first ''ounce.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.main_headline: CYPRIOTS DEBATE U.S. USE OF BASE FOR BEIRUT FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.print_headline: CYPRIOTS DEBATE U.S. USE OF BASE FOR BEIRUT FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.body_text: **********The United States is using Cyprus's largest civilian airport to supply American troops in Lebanon, prompting opposition within the Cypriot Government. **********The operation is well known on Cyprus, but apparently has not attracted much attention elsewhere. **********Spyros Kyprianou, the Greek Cypriot President of Cyprus, has so far resisted demands by the Communist Party, a partner in his coalition Government, to curtail the Americans' use of Larnaca Airport in addition to Britain's use of one of its bases on Cyprus to supply contingents of the international force in Beirut. **********Several Western diplomats and military officials here said that pressure against the supply operations could increase if the four-nation force's stay in Lebanon became prolonged or if a cease-fire there collapsed and the political situation deteriorated. **********Political Strains on Cyprus **********In addition, some analysts said the Turkish Cypriots' decision of last Tuesday to declare their northern third of Cyprus a sovereign, independent state could eventually jeopardize the use of Larnaca. Political strains could develop, officials said, if Cyprus pressed the United States to use economic sanctions and tougher measures against the Turkish Cypriot state and nations that recognize it. **********The United States is unlikely to support sanctions against Turkey, which, like Greece, is a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and a strategically located ally. As a result, the officials said, Greek Cypriots might be tempted to withdraw permission to use Larnaca, which is on the Greek side of the island. **********The United States has had the supply operation here for more than a year. **********In August 1982 the Reagan Administration entered an agreement with the Cypriot Government to permit the use of Larnaca Airport for sending military personnel, mail and such general cargo as food and medicine through Cyprus to Lebanon. Officials said both Governments had assumed that the force's stay in Lebanon would be short and, therefore, that the supply operation would be temporary. **********Now, 15 months later, the number of American servicemen in Beirut has grown from 1,200 to about 2,000 at times and cargo shipments from Cyprus involve about seven or eight flights a day. The flights are by fixed-wing C-130 and C-141 transport planes, which land at Beirut airport, near the Marine outpost in Lebanon. Also flying from Cyprus are some helicopters that carry cargo to and from Navy warships off the coast of Lebanon. **********In September, described as a ''banner month'' for Larnaca, 650 flights carrying 1.25 million pounds of cargo and more than 900 military passengers left the Cyprus airport bound for Lebanon, according to American figures. **********Larnaca and one of the British bases were also used to transport wounded marines to hospitals on Cyprus and elsewhere in Europe after the suicide bombing attack last month on French and American forces in Beirut.   Could Get Along Without It **********Military officials say that if Larnaca were not available, cargo would probably have to be sent through Suda Bay, in Crete, and probably by sea. Greece, another site of American bases, has refused to allow any support - even permission to overfly the country - for the international force in Lebanon, American officials said. **********''We could get along without Larnaca,'' an American military spokesman here said, ''but supply would be far more costly and far slower.'' **********Military experts extimated that the United States has spent slightly more than $1 million on fuel, landing and parking fees at Larnaca. **********Western diplomats said the United States had adopted a very ''low key'' approach to its use of the airport. American military personnel, for example, are required to use a back entrance to the airport that is closed to the public. The American Embassy in Nicosia has issued no publicity about the use of the airport. **********American Embassy officials discuss Larnaca at least once every four or six weeks with Cypriot counterparts, who are kept ''promptly and fully informed'' of transport activities, American officials said. **********Still, the Communist Party's opposition to the supply operations has prompted the Cypriot Government to insist that the United States not use Larnaca to provide any type of support to the Lebanese Army or to any other faction in Lebanon other than occasional shipments for the French and Italian contingents.   Radio Request Rejected **********The Cypriot Government also recently rejected an American request to install special radio antenna at the airport to improve communication between air controllers and pilots of cargo planes. The Cypriot Government feared that this would create an impression that the use of Larnaca was permanent, a Western official said. **********Britain's supply of its 110-man force in Beirut is provided through Akrotiri, one of its two sovereign bases here where about 10,000 British servicemen and dependents are stationed. Because the British retain sovereignty over the bases under the 1960 agreements that gave Cyprus its independence, they can use the bases at they choose, a spokesman said. Given local opposition to continued British presence here, however, Britain, too, has kept Cypriot officials ''fully informed'' of activities on the bases, the spokesman added. **********A few months ago, a British decision to permit Italy to station fighter planes at Akrotiri for protection of the Italian contingent in Lebanon touched off a major political debate here. It was defused when Italy announced that tension in Lebanon had lessened and the planes were no longer needed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.main_headline: OFFICIAL TIES CUBA TO U.S. DRUG TRAFFIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.print_headline: OFFICIAL TIES CUBA TO U.S. DRUG TRAFFIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.body_text: **********Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, asserted today that he ''would find it very difficult to believe that the Cuban Government itself is not involved'' in drug trafficking in the United States. **********The evidence, Mr. Eagleburger said, is ''really quite clear that there is major Cuban involvement in the drug traffic in this country,'' including a role by the Castro Government. **********But a senior State Department official said later that Washington had not yet been able to prove actual personal involvement by Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader. **********Four Cubans Indicted **********Last November four high-ranking Cuban officials, including Adm.  Aldo Santa Maria Cuadrado and Rene Rodriguez Cruz, another member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cuba, were indicted here on Federal charges of smuggling narcotics into the United States. **********The Cuban Government has strongly denied the accusations in the indictments and other statements by United States officials implicating Cuban authorities with aiding and abetting narcotics traffickers. **********Mr. Eagleburger's comments, on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' came in reponse to questions about charges made Saturday at a Senate hearing in Miami on Cuban ties to drug trafficking. **********At the Miami hearing James H. Michel, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, said the United States ''has developed new evidence from a variety of independent sources confirming that Cuban officials have facilitated narcotics trafficking through the Caribbean.'' **********''We have a report,'' Mr. Michel said, ''that the Communist Party Presidium and specifically Fidel Castro, in early 1979, considered a scheme to begin dealing with narcotics smugglers using Cuba as a bridge and support base for the networks to the United States as a means to aid Cuba economically, and to contribute to the deterioration of American society.'' **********Mr. Michel was one of several witnesses at the hearing presided over by Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida. Also present were Senators Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, Jeremiah Denton, Republican of Alabama, and Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. **********Also testifying Saturday were three Cuban refugees, whose faces were concealed by black hoods and who described what they said was the use of Cuban facilities by narcotic traffickers on the way to the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/busin.main_headline: GTE Names a Director For New Office in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; GTE Names a Director For New Office in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The GTE Corporation, a major telecommunications and electronics company, yesterday indicated its growing interest in the markets of Japan and other nations of the Far East. **********David M. Fleming, 60, was named president of GTE Communications Products-Asia and will head GTE's first Japan-based office to market high technology in the region. **********The office, which will be in Tokyo, will direct activities in Japan, China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia. **********''The opening of the Tokyo office reinforces our commitment to doing business not only in Japan but throughout this important area,'' said Thomas A. Vanderslice, president and chief executive of GTE, who is in Tokyo with Mr. Fleming to meet industrial and political leaders. **********Mr. Fleming joins GTE after 22 years as chairman and president of International Management Consultants in Alexandria, Va., which he founded in 1961. He also founded and served as director of several international trading companies and held marketing positions with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation. **********In 1982, foreign operations accounted for about 29 percent of GTE's sales, with only a small percentage coming from the Far East and from Japan, where the company's main operation is GTE Lighting Products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/28/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Budget Deficits And Realism
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/28/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Budget Deficits And Realism
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/28/busin.body_text: **********IS President Reagan's new realism for real? That depends on how one defines realism.  As the term is used by modern writers and artists, realism means looking at life as it is, without being visionary or idealistic.  Thus, an ashcan is an ashcan, a jobless worker is a jobless worker, not a heroic, if drafted, soldier in the fight against inflation. The President now, realistically, sees a string of deficits in the $200 billion to $300 billion class stretching far into the future unless painful surgery on the budget is performed; once, he envisioned a balanced budget, first in the current, 1983 fiscal year, then in the 1984 fiscal year. **********But, as used in philosophy, realism is also the doctrine that abstractions are objectively actual. This was opposed to the medieval doctrine of nominalism, which held that all universal or abstract terms, such as ''justice'' or ''government,'' were mere necessities of thought or conveniences of language, and therefore existed as names only. **********President Reagan appears, oddly enough, to be a realist in both the medieval and modern senses. In the medieval sense, he praised his Civil Rights Commission as ''an ongoing part of the struggle for justice'' and sent the Democrats into wild applause by asserting that government ''must take the lead in restoring the economy,'' a doctrine that appeared to contrast sharply with his earlier, apparently nominalist position that ''government is not the solution.'' **********However, the President might be defended against the charge of having switched from nominalism to realism by pointing out that what he actually said was ''we in government,'' presumably referring to himself, Vice President Bush, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and other actual people who would lead the economy out of the recession, rather than referring to the abstraction of ''government.'' Hence his statement may not have been philosophically ''realistic.'' **********The heart of the economic issue is whether the Reagan team has set forth a program that, both nominally and realistically, can restore prosperity. The economic assumptions underlying the President's budget projections are that ''nominal'' gross national product will rise 6.7 percent in 1983 and 9.4 percent in 1984, while ''real'' G.N.P. is forecast to rise only 1.4 percent in 1983 and 3.9 percent in 1984. In economics, ''nominal'' means ''without correcting for inflation,'' and ''real'' means ''after correcting for inflation.'' **********Such slow rates of real growth imply a very slow decline of unemployment. In fact, unemployment, which averaged 9.7 percent in 1982 (and wound up the year at 10.8 percent), is expected to average 10.7 percent in 1983 and 9.9 percent in 1984, a Presidential election year. **********The Democrats and even many Republicans may be unable to contemplate such awful numbers or the longer-term economic projections. The Administration foresees an increase in real G.N.P.  of 4 percent a year from 1985 through 1988. And it forecasts that inflation, as measured by the G.N.P. deflator, will decline from 4.9 percent in 1985 to 4.4 percent in 1988. **********At those rates of growth in real G.N.P., the Administration projects unemployment at 9.1 percent in 1985, 8.2 percent in 1986, 7.4 percent in 1987 and 6.6 percent in 1988. And, based on its ''cautious'' economic assumptions, the Administration derives the huge ''baseline'' budget deficits it foresees if Congress does not give the President the savings proposed in his fiscal 1984 budget. **********Those baseline deficits are projected to climb to $231 billion in the fiscal year 1984. Then they will climb to $253 billion, $271 billion, $292 billion and finally to $300 billion by the fiscal year 1988 - a total of $1,347,000,000,000 - doubling in five years the national debt contracted over 207 years of United States history. The President's proposed savings would cut that five-year, $1.3 trillion increase in the national debt to a mere $790 billion. **********A stronger recovery would also scale back the prospective deficits. A rate of real economic growth greater than now forecast, the Administration estimates, would shrink the deficit $20 billion a year, leaving a $90 billion deficit in 1988. **********And a further increase of 1.33 percent in real G.N.P. in each of the next five years would result in a balanced budget by 1988. But that would necessitate real growth's averaging an historically high 6.33 percent from 1985 through 1988. **********An alternative route to balancing the budget would be through a faster rise in nominal G.N.P., even with no greater rise in real G.N.P. But since that spells inflation, neither Republicans nor Democrats dare consider it; there are limits to both nominalism and realism. Yet, whatever the formally stated philosophies, with such levels of unemployment and deficit in prospect, inflation could happen as a phenomenon of political nature.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/30/world.body_text: **********President Reagan invited the Soviet Union today to present its newest arms proposals officially in Geneva and called on Moscow ''finally to negotiate seriously'' on limiting medium-range nuclear missiles. **********With several American proposals already made at Geneva and barely more than a month before American medium-range missile deployments in Europe are to begin, the President contended that ''all of the elements for a mutually advantageous agreement are on the table.'' **********''The Soviet Union has now advanced some additional proposals of its own,'' he said in his weekly Saturday radio broadcast. ''We will study these proposals and will address them in the talks in Geneva.'' **********Other senior Administration officials said that proposals publicly suggested by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, in a Pravda interview on Wednesday have not been put forward officially by Soviet negotiators in Geneva. Mr. Andropov offered to accept a total of 140 missiles in the European theater, a somewhat lower total than previously; a limit on deployments of SS-20 missiles in the Far East, and flexibility on a ceiling on nuclear-armed bombers.   No New Proposals The President's broadcast contained no new proposals or hints of any potential diplomatic breakthrough in the arms talks. **********Both Mr. Andropov's move and the President's response today, which highlighted a decision Thursday by Atlantic alliance defense ministers to remove 1,400 short-rage tactical nuclear weapons in Europe over the next five years, seemed intended partly to influence European public opinion in the final weeks before the American missile are scheduled for deployment. **********In the face of Mr. Andropov's threat to halt the medium-range missile negotiations once the American deployments begin, Mr. Reagan asserted, ''We will stay at the negotiating table for as long as necessary to achieve such an agreement.'' **********Other Senior Administration officials pointed out that for the last two years the Geneva talks have continued while the Soviet Union was deploying more SS-20 missiles aimed at Western Europe and charged that it was unreasonable for Moscow to break off the talks when American deployments began. **********In the tone of his comments, the President seemed intent on underscoring the possibility for agreement, although some American officials and many Europeans have become skeptical. But Mr. Reagan did point to the main remaining problem: Moscow's insistence that the United States forgo deploying any missiles.   NATO Reduction Emphasized **********''Unfortunately, the Soviet proposals permit them to retain SS-20 missiles while not allowing NATO to deploy its own,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********His main emphasis, however, was on the approval of the plan to dismantle and destroy 1,400 short-range tactical nuclear weapons in Europe. **********''This step stands in stark contrast to the actions of the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Reagan said. Once this step is carried out, he said, the United States will have reduced its European nuclear arsenal by one-third since 1979. In that period, he contended, Moscow has added more than 200 SS-20 missiles, carrying 600 warheads. **********''The comparison of Soviet actions with NATO's reductions and restraint clearly illustrates, once again, that the so-called arms race has only participant - the Soviet Union,'' he said. **********Administration officials said the President had decided to stress the NATO decision as a way of rebutting public criticism that the Administration was participating in a ''mindless piling up of arms.'' **********''After this reduction is completed, we will have fewer nuclear weapons in Europe than at any time in the last 20 years,'' one American official said. **********In 1979, orders were given to reduce the American arsenal of nuclear warheads from 7,000 to 6,000 by retiring some of the older tactical weapons. The new decision will reduce the total to 4,600 over five years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/world.body_text: **********Toll in Lebanese Blast Is Estimated at 15 to 30 **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 (Reuters) - Rescue workers abandoned hope today of finding anyone else alive in the ruins of a Palestinian guerrilla headquarters that was demolished by a car bomb Friday.  Estimates of the death toll varied from 15 to 30. **********(A motorcycle rider threw a grenade at a French military truck in Beirut, wounding a French marine, The Associated Press reported. It quoted a spokesman for the French contingent as saying the marine was slightly wounded in the left shoulder by shrapnel from an antitank grenade hurled at the back of a troop-carrying truck by the motorcycle's rear rider.) **********A Palestinian commando officer in Shtaura said rescuers had worked all night and had found a man alive at dawn but since then had found only bodies. **********''There is no hope,'' he said as stretcher bearers lowered a blanket-covered body into an ambulance.  A group calling itself the Front to Liberate Lebanon From Foreigners took responsibility for the explosion.  Lebanese civil defense officials here said about 30 bodies had been recovered by Friday night, but the Lebanese police in Shtaura said they believed that the figure was more like half that. **********The Palestinian guerrilla officer and others at the scene said they had no accurate figures for the number of dead and wounded because they had been taken to several hospitals in eastern Lebanon and Syria. **********The guerrilla officer said the three-story building had housed several offices belonging to Yasir Arafat's Al Fatah guerrilla group, a small Palestinian faction called the Popular Struggle Front and a Lebanese leftist militia known as the Lebanese Arab Army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.main_headline: THE REAL END OF THE RECESSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.print_headline: THE REAL END OF THE RECESSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.body_text: **********For months, economists and Wall Street pundits have been saying a recovery is under way. Yesterday, the nation's main arbiter in such matters made it official: The recession ended late last fall. **********The National Bureau of Economic Research - a private, nonprofit research organization whose pronouncements on economic booms and busts are considered the final word by many economists - announced that the trough of the downturn came last November. **********The recession began in July 1981, the bureau said, making the 16-month slowdown one of the longest two of the nine recessions since World War II. The other 16-month recession ran from November 1973 to March 1975. **********''We think of the economy as being cyclical - that is, as having business cycles,'' said Donna L. Zerwitz, a spokesman for the bureau's Business Cycle Dating Committee, a group of leading forecasters who met Thursday night. ''The trough of the most recent cycle occurred in November.'' **********What some say is noteworthy about the bureau's declaration is that it differs from the consensus among leading economists. Many, including some in the Administration, think the economy touched bottom last December or January. **********Why the difference?  ''The economy still appeared to be weak in December and into 1983,'' said Allen Sinai, a senior economist at Data Resources Inc., a Lexington, Mass., forecasting concern. ''The recovery was so narrowly based that it didn't show up in a broad-based way in a lot of statistics.'' **********Miss Zerwitz ascribed the difference to the various ways in which the bureau and outside economists gauge the economy.  The selection of November as the trough reflected what the bureau called the ''central tendency'' of some vital economic statistics to turn around either just before, during or after November. **********Real personal income, for example, and sales by manufacturers and in the trade sector both touched bottom in October. Industrial production and hours worked both reached their low point in November. In December, employment among nonfarm workers bottomed out, and unemployment peaked at 10.8 percent. **********In a purely statistical sense, the most recent downturn has been less severe than the typical post-World War II recession. On average, real gross national product, the value of goods made and services supplied after adjustment for inflation, has declined 2.8 percent in post-war slumps from the peak to the trough, compared with 1.1 percent in the recent recession. Industrial production, which on average has slid 11.4 percent, was down 7.6 percent this recession. **********But Mr. Sinai of Data Resources said the numbers understate the severity of the recent downturn because, unlike other dips, this recession was caused by extremely high interest rates that nearly crushed key industries that depend on credit, and thus some key industries such as automobiles, housing and home appliances suffered much more than the average. In addition, Mr. Sinai said, the recent slump followed almost immediately on the heels of another recession, a six-month downturn in 1979-80. **********When considered together, Mr. Sinai said, the recessions of 1979-80 and 1981-82 represent the worst economic decline in the United States since the Great Depression. **********''It really was, in many parts of America, a depression,'' Mr.  Sinai said. ''The fallout in terms of unemployment, business failures and failures of financial institutions devastated industries and whole geographic areas of the country. It was without precedent since the 1930's.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/20/world.main_headline: REPORT SEES DROP IN U.S. ROLE AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/20/world.print_headline: REPORT SEES DROP IN U.S. ROLE AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/20/world.body_text: **********A report last month by a private research organization contends that United States influence in the United Nations has declined and that part of the reason is that the percentage of Secretariat employees who are Americans has declined.  The report has been challenged by some American employees here. **********The report, ''Americans at the U.N.: An Endangered Species,'' was published Feb. 13 by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington research group. The report's author, Juliana Geran Pilon, suggested that the decline in the American share of professional posts here, from 14.6 percent in 1972 to 12.6 percent today, made it more difficult to deal with anti-American stands. **********''Almost constantly outvoted in the General Assembly and in nearly every U.N. agency, the U.S. is also deprived of sufficient control of the administrative and policy posts to ameliorate the U.N.'s anti-U.S. and anti-Western pronouncements and resolutions,'' Mrs.  Pilon wrote. **********In 1972, Americans held 925 of the 6,333 professional posts in the Secretariat. In 1982, Americans held 984 of the 7,790 posts. 'You Can't Tell From a List' **********Asked for comment, many Americans working in the Secretariat took issue with Mrs. Pilon's conclusions.  Jay Long, principal officer in the office of William B. Buffum, the Under Secretary General for Political and General Assembly Affairs, said: ''I don't share the view that the influence of Americans has declined in the Secretariat. You can't tell from a list who influences whom or who has the ear of the Secretary General. Some of his closest advisers are American, and the same can't be said of - what shall I call them - our opposite numbers.'' **********Mrs. Pilon commented in a telephone interview, ''Americans are highly respected, but that does not translate into United States influence.'' Noting that Mr. Buffum, the highest ranking American on the United Nations staff, is an Under Secretary General, she said his ''post is far less significant'' than a similar one occupied by Ralph Bunche in the 1960's. **********Other officials here objected to Mrs. Pilon's statement that the United States was isolated and almost always outvoted in the General Assembly. **********One recalled that the chief United States delegate, Jeane J.  Kirkpatrick, said at a news conference in December that the United States had won some victories in the last General Assembly session, among them the rejection of an attempt to expel Israel. He said there was ''no correlation between the numbers of Americans working and the control or influence they exert.'' One Reason for Decline **********Several American officials here noted that the United Nations had tripled in size since its founding and said this meant the United States share of staff positions had to decline. **********Bradford Morse, the director of the United Nations Development Program, said, ''The question is not American influence but the influence of individual American officials who are international civil servants operating under the U.N. Charter.'' **********Another American official said he was pleased by the publication of Mrs. Pilon's report and its call on the United States ''to pay attention to the staffing of international organizations.'' He said the United States had ''a great deal at stake.'' **********Mrs. Pilon's report also touched on the percentage of Americans employed as officials in some specialized United Nations agencies based in Europe, saying it was smaller than the 12.6 percent in the Secretariat. She said it did not rise above 12 percent in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization or the United Nations Industrial Development Organization. **********At two offices in New York, however, a higher percentage of Americans was reported. James P. Grant, the executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund, said, ''The United States makes up more than 17 percent of my staff.'' Mr. Morse, the director of the Development Program, said his agency had 110 Americans on its professional staff of 580, or nearly 19 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.main_headline: ALLIES BACK STAND ON GENEVA TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.print_headline: ALLIES BACK STAND ON GENEVA TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.body_text: **********The NATO allies said today that they would stand firm in their negotiating positions at the two sets of arms talks in Geneva and in their deployment of new American missiles in Europe. **********The vows were made in the face of the Soviet Union's decision last month to suspend medium-range missile talks and its refusal today to set a new date for the resumption of negotiations on limiting strategic nuclear weapons. **********Foreign ministers from the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization member nations met in closed session today. Spokesmen for several delegations said they stood by the communique, issued on Wednesday by the allied defense ministers, that said they ''reemphasized their support for the United States position in the talks, on which they have been kept fully informed,'' and welcomed the ''American initiatives to move the talks forward.'' **********As to the suspended negotiations on medium-range missiles, a special NATO consultative group issued a white paper that covered in detail the history of the negotiations to back up the West's contention that it was negotiating in good faith when the Russians walked out of the negotiations last month.   Merger Is Ruled Out **********Richard Burt, Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian affairs, who is chairman of the consultative group, said at a news conference that at their meeting today, the allies decided that there was no point in the West's making any special concessions to lure the Soviet Union back to the negotiating table, that the proposals already made were sufficient. **********Mr. Burt specifically ruled out any merger of the medium-range talks with the strategic weapons negotiations, an idea voiced privately by some officials. He said the difficulty with the Russians was not over the style of the talks, but over the substance. He said the main obstacle was Moscow's refusal to accept any accord that would allow the United States to deploy any new missiles. **********The alliance, he said, was ''unanimous in regretting this unjustifiable and unfortunate action, and strongly hopes that the Soviet Union will reconsider and resume negotiations as soon as possible.'' **********Mr. Burt said the Russians had steadily built up their force of SS-20's in Europe and Asia even as negotiations took place. In recent weeks, he said, 9 new missiles were deployed in Asia, giving Moscow now 369 of the three- warhead missiles, for a total of 1,107 warheads.   No Startling Disclosures **********There were no startling disclosures in the white paper, since the substance of each side's position has been made public in the course of the talks, which began in 1981. The report said the Soviet Union had never advanced a proposal that ''would meet the minimum security requirements of the alliance.'' **********The Soviet Union has threatened to deploy additional missiles to counter the American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles now beginning to be deployed in West Germany, Italy and Britain. Regarding those threats, the white paper said that ''any effort by the Soviet Union to characterize such long- envisaged measures as a legitimate reaction to NATO modernization would be utterly unfounded.'' **********The allies said they had to deploy 572 new American missiles - 108 Pershing 2's in West Germany and 464 cruise missiles in West Germany, Britain, Italy, Belgium and Netherlands. The first batch, of 9 Pershings in West Germany and 64 cruise missiles in both Britain and Italy, is being installed under a schedule to last through the end of 1988. **********The white paper repeated a pledge that the alliance would ''halt, modify or reverse deployments'' if an agreement on equality could be reached with the Russians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/19/busin.body_text: **********New Johnson Shampoo Is Its First in 30 Years **********Toward the end of the ''baby boom'' in 1953, Johnson & Johnson went to market with its Baby Shampoo, which was quite a success, especially when adults began to latch onto it. **********Now as that crop is ripening, the company is introducing Affinity, its first new shampoo product in 30 years, and it is specifically for over-40 females. **********''Now, there's no age limit to looking good,'' will be the endearing theme. **********Television and magazine advertising by SSC&B, which has a bunch of J.& J. baby products including the Baby Shampoo, will begin in February and couponing and sampling in March. **********Like most other package goods companies, this one does not disclose its advertising spending plans. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/28/busin.main_headline: WESTERN ELECTRIC PLANS SHUTDOWN OF JERSEY PLANT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/28/busin.print_headline: WESTERN ELECTRIC PLANS SHUTDOWN OF JERSEY PLANT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/28/busin.body_text: **********The Western Electric Company, the huge manufacturing and supply arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that it would shut down its Kearny, N.J., plant, eliminating 4,000 jobs. **********The decision, which also affects 2,700 employees at two other locations, is part of a companywide plan to reduce idle capacity.  It reflects the severe impact of the recession on Western's multitude of telephone and telecommunications products. It also reflects a desire to make the company more efficient as A.T.& T.  moves into a competitive arena, stripped of the 22 local telephone company subsidiaries that have long purchased almost all of the equipment produced by Western. **********A.T.& T. said the Kearny plant would be closed in stages, probably over a two- to three-year period. In addition, 2,300 jobs are to be eliminated at Western Electric's Baltimore Works, which employs about 4,800, along with 400 out of 4,400 jobs at the Hawthorne Works in Cicero, Ill. **********The three plants are Western Electric's oldest, and the jobs to be eliminated represent 5 percent of the company's workforce.  ''The decision was related to the fact that our utilization was dropping as a result of the recession and some of the technology changes, and as we looked to the future, we couldn't see anything that would improve it,'' Paul Zweier, Western's senior executive vice president, said in an interview. **********He explained that as recently as 1979, Western was using 90 percent to 100 percent of its plant space and machinery, a ratio that has plummeted to about 60 percent. And he noted that demand for most Western products has fallen 30 to 35 percent since 1979. **********''It becomes a serious corporate problem when you have a lot of corporate investment and corporate machinery that isn't being used,'' he said. ''Something had to be done about it.'' **********Mr. Zweier, who worked as an engineer at Kearny for 13 years, said the company expected additional retrenchment as part of an effort to bring Western back to using 90 percent of its capacity within the next three to four years. **********Although the company expects that a number of workers will have to be laid off, it said that it hoped to reassign many of the affected employees and to eliminate some jobs by attrition. **********''It's extremely painful to take these actions,'' Donald Procknow, Western's president, said in a statement. ''We must, however, face realities in order to remain the best in our field. Increasing competition requires that we continue efforts to reduce overall costs and improve efficiencies.'' Challenge of Divestiture **********A.T.& T., under the settlement of the Justice Department's antitrust suit against it, must shed its 22 operating companies, which account for 80 percent of the nation's intracity telephone service, by Jan.1, 1984. **********Western's mission has been to manufacture or buy virtually all of the telecommunications equipment used by the Bell companies, which have accounted for 95 percent of its sales. In this new climate, Western faces the challenge of remolding itself into a company that can hustle for business against a growing number of rival manufacturers bidding for the business of the soon-to-be independent Bell subsidiaries. **********Founded in 1925, the Kearny Works is the second-oldest Western plant and is thought to be the largest employer in Hudson County. The plant consists of seven buildings along Central Avenue in the industrial section of the city, which is situated near Jersey City and has a population of 36,000. The Kearny Works mainly makes systems to convert commercial power to run various telecommunications equipment. That work is to be transferred to Western's more modern Dallas plant. **********The Baltimore plant makes protectors and connectors for cable and wire, work scheduled to be reassigned to Omaha. At the Hawthorne plant, the pulp cable operations will be shifted to Phoenix.  Hawthorne, Western's oldest plant, became renowned as the laboratory for the Hawthorne Studies, the landmark work-environment investigations of the 1920's, which found that if management merely paid attention to workers, productivity would improve. **********To reflect the planned moves, Western took an after-tax write-off of $317.6 million in the fourth quarter of last year. Even without the charge, however, Western suffered from both lower earnings and lower revenues in 1982. According to preliminary figures, Western said, it earned $337 million last year on sales of $12.4 billion. In 1981, the manufacturer earned $711 million on sales of $13 billion. Lower-Margin Products **********Ernest Liu, a telecommunications analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the decision to cut back operations appeared to be a response to dwindling demand for Western products as well as reflecting a desire to make Western more competitive by reducing capacity for its more ''mundane'' products. **********He said Kearny made ''dull staple products'' that produced lower margins than more technologically advanced items like digital electronic and fiber optics products. **********Mr. Zweier acknowledged that advances in microelectronics and in silicon chips had created new products that have siphoned away demand from some of the labor-intensive products made at Kearny. **********Western employs 135,000 at 22 major facilities. Its workforce has been steadily shrinking over the years. Last year alone, 14,000 Western workers were laid off and 5,000 more jobs eliminated due to attrition or other reasons. During the past several years, Western management has offered many of the company's workers early retirement incentives in an effort to trim the workforce. **********Western last closed one of its principal plants in 1975, when it shut facilities in Buffalo and Greensboro, N.C.   Economic Impact Special to the New York Times **********KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 27 - Workers got word that 4,000 jobs would eventually be eliminated at the Kearny Works at 10 A.M. today in letters from Donald E. Procknow, the company's president, and Ronald Butterfield Jr., general manager of the plant. **********The phase-out, they said, would take ''several years'' and some of the job loss could be absorbed through attrition. ''Some layoffs are expected,'' Mr. Procknow's letter said. **********''The workers are totally bewildered,'' said Adam Papasavas, director of research and education for Local 1470 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. ''The one word I can say is shock. Our motto has been that Kearny is alive and well, and we would make it.'' **********''There'll be a lot of economic ripples spreading from this,'' said Kearny's Mayor, Henry J. Hill, who retired three years ago as the plant's manufacturing manager after 41 years with Western Electric. **********Mayor Hill said that a ''very small portion'' of the workforce lived in Kearny. But the plant is one of the town's biggest taxpayers. Last year it was assessed at $23.9 million, about 7.3 percent of Kearny's total tax base of $325.7 million. Its real estate taxes were $1.6 million in 1982. **********Mayor Hill said officials hoped to offset the loss of the $1.6 million by drawing new industry as the Western Electric plant was phased out. **********Last month, the company appealed to Kearny officials for tax relief. They agreed to reduce the assessment to between $17 million and $18 million for 1983 after Western Electric demolished an idle building in the complex, according to Ronnie Connors, assistant tax assessor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.main_headline: CHINA INSISTS TAIWAN'S FATE IS NO BUSINESS OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.print_headline: CHINA INSISTS TAIWAN'S FATE IS NO BUSINESS OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.body_text: **********China denied today that its commitment to a peaceful solution of Taiwan's future was a condition for ending United States arms sales there and accused President Reagan of distorting the communique on the issue signed last August by China and the United States. **********The Chinese Foreign Ministry also released a ''new'' proposal to Vietnam offering to discuss improving relations after Hanoi began a phased withdrawal of all its troops from Cambodia. The offer, which Vietnam seemed unlikely to accept, appeared timed to enhance Peking's image at the new round of Chinese-Soviet consultations in Moscow and the forthcoming summit meeting of nations professing nonalignment in New Delhi. **********Both matters were raised by Qi Huaiyuan, the director of the ForeignMinistry's information department, at a briefing for foreign newsmen here. Mr. Qi's criticism of Mr. Reagan followed a protest sent to the American Embassy and a critical commentary by the New China News Agency last week. **********The Chinese challenged Mr. Reagan's contention in an interview with the weekly magazine Human Events that there was a linkage between Peking's policy of peaceful reunification with Taiwan and Washington's promise to phase out its arms deliveries to the Nationalist regime on Taiwan. **********The Foreign Ministry spokesman said: ''I wish to stress here that the Taiwan question is an internal affair of China and we brook no foreign interference in how China solves the Taiwan question so as to achieve the reunification of the motherland. **********''If China's peaceful solution of the Taiwan question is taken as a prerequisite for the gradual reduction and cessation of United States arms sales to Taiwan, it would amount to recognition of the United States' right to interfere in China's internal affairs indefinitely. The Chinese Government and people can never agree to this.'' **********Peking and Washington have conflicting interpretations of the communique that was signed Aug. 17 after long negotiations to end tensions over American military sales to Taiwan. **********In one section, the communique noted that China had on two formal occasions announced that it would strive ''for peaceful reunification of the motherland.'' In a subsequent section, the communique said the United States, taking China's position into account, ''intends to gradually reduce its sale of arms to Taiwan, leading over a period of time to a final resolution.'' **********China has since objected to the contention that the two aspects are linked. While it has publicly discarded its old commitment to a military takeover of Taiwan, it has insisted that this is unrelated to its demand that the United States stop supplying arms to Taiwan. **********The Chinese spokesman also expressed unhappiness over Mr. Reagan's comments before the American Legion on Feb. 22, where he stressed friendship with Taiwan. **********''The Chinese people deeply deplore his remarks,'' Mr. Qi said.  Today's appearance by Mr. Qi was the first of what the Foreign Ministry has said will be periodic press briefings for foreign reporters, who have asked for more regular access to officials.  Today's briefing involved the reading by Mr. Qi of statements on selected issues, with no questions allowed. **********The ''new'' five-point proposal to Vietnam on Cambodia seemed to be the one that was made to the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Leonid F. Ilyichev, when the first round of Chinese-Soviet consultations started here last October. It said that Vietnam should announce its unconditional withdrawal of troops from Cambodia and that the Soviet Union should end its support of the military occupation. **********After the first batch of Vietnamese troops left Cambodia, the proposal said, China would resume talks with Vietnam to normalize their strained relations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.main_headline: DAMAGE IN MOZAMBIQUE RAID LOOKS SURPRISINGLY LIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.print_headline: DAMAGE IN MOZAMBIQUE RAID LOOKS SURPRISINGLY LIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.body_text: **********In both scope and impact, South Africa's reprisal raid here Monday does not seem to equal the act it purported to avenge. **********South Africa sent its warplanes into a suburb of the Mozambican capital to exact retribution for a car bombing in Pretoria last week that killed 18 people and wounded almost 200. The African National Congress, the most prominent nationalist movement opposed to the white minority Government in Pretoria, said Monday that it was responsible for the attack. **********The congress is represented here in various ways, and South African statements soon after the raid laid great emphasis on assertions that the warplanes had struck installations used by the movement to plan guerrilla tactics and had also knocked out a Mozambican missile base. **********To judge by the damage displayed by the Mozambican authorities today, the result was less decisive. 3-Hour Tour of Target Areas **********Mozambique, South Africa's radical neighbor and ideological foe, has little obvious interest in seeking to hide or disguise the effects of an attack that it depicts as aggression, despite the economic ties between the two nations through the use of Mozambican ports by South Africa. In three hours of touring the places where South African planes struck, accompanied by Information Ministry officials, a correspondent gained the impression today that Pretoria's aim - or at least achievement -represented less than total vengeance. **********Casualties - 6 dead, including 2 children, and 26 hospitalized - were not so great as were caused in an earlier South African raid here in 1981, or as could have been caused by Pretoria's military machine. Damage, too, was not of the magnitude that could have been wreaked. If the tour by the Informations Ministry showed all there was to see - as the Mozambicans insisted it did - those buildings that were hit show little evidence of any current connection with the African National Congress, although some clearly had provided sanctuary for the exile movement in the recent past. **********Moreover, the scar on the city's psyche is probably less deep than that the car bomb caused in Pretoria. Mozambicans seem more resigned to their vulnerability and so, a day after the attack, the capital itself and the Matola suburb where the attack took place were tranquil. **********A tour of Matola with Information Ministry officials began in Rua Ingineira Pinto Texeira, a leafy street where rockets had plowed holes in an orange grove by an old Portuguese villa, scattered some shrapnel that wounded a girl, but left a chicken yard unscathed. **********The evident target of the rockets was a factory just behind the villa that produces jams and grapefruit juice. Three people died there Monday, battered by the blast of an exploding rocket channeled down a narrow alleyway. There was no evidence of any overt link with the African National Congress. 2 Children Hit by Shrapnel **********Then correspondents were taken to the home of an advertising executive, Francisco Morgadinho, who was not there when rockets wrecked a corner of the building. Just beyond his villa, however, and relatively undamaged, was another house that had been used until a year ago by South African exiles. Two children were wounded there because, a relative said, they went to look when they heard the planes and were hit by splinters of shrapnel. **********The place that came closest to fitting the description of a base for the congress was a house in a part of Matola called Liberdad, where rockets had plowed through a garden but had done little damage to a building whose inner walls were decorated with the slogans of the congress's military wing. **********''At this hour of destiny your country and your people need you,'' said one slogan, embellished by a drawing of a Soviet-type assault rifle. ''The future is yours.'' Another said, ''Umkhonto We Sizwe - the People's Army,'' a reference to the congress's guerrillas. The slogan was faded, not newly painted, and a neighbor said the exiles who had lived there moved out three months ago. **********Their departure, Western diplomats and Mozambican officials said, may have been part of a campaign by the Mozambican authorities to disperse concentrations of South African exiles and move them to the north of the country for security reasons following the 1981 South African raid. Nonetheless, diplomats said, there are probably several hundred South African exiles living in the Maputo area. **********A Ministry of Information spokesman said that the areas visited today represented ''all the places attacked by South Africa.'' If that is true, the inference is that the South Africans refrained from deploying the forces they might have used, for a variety of reasons. Raid Seen as a Warning **********First, a senior Mozambican official said, the intention may have been simply to cause fear and uncertainty as a warning to Mozambique and other African countries harboring South African exiles that retribution can be exacted swiftly, with impunity and possibly without restraint. **********In addition, the Mozambican argument runs, the attack was intended to satisfy a white minority constituency in South Africa clamoring for vengeance and for assurance that the homeland is not so vulnerable as Friday's bombing in Pretoria might suggest. As evidence of this theory, Mozambican officials cite the speed and efficiency of the public relations effort that surrounded it in South Africa. **********''This is a first answer'' to the Pretoria attack, a senior official said, ''but not the whole answer. Maybe they came to test our defenses or do reconnaissance for a later strike. But this was not a military attack against military targets.'' ---- Pretoria Says 64 Were Killed Special to the New York Times **********JOHANNESBURG, May 24 - In an official communique, the South African military said today that it had ''confirmed'' intelligence reports that 64 people had been killed in Monday's reprisal raid on Maputo, Mozambique. **********According to the statement, 41 of those killed were members of the underground African National Congress. Seventeen others, it said, were Mozambican soldiers. The statement said six civilians had died.  Commentators in the pro-Government Afrikaans press asserted today that it was a common ''terrorist'' tactic to conceal casualties. **********The military communique said, ''This was a clinical, finely planned operation directed against proven hiding places of the A.N.C. and was successfully carried out by professional people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/18/busin.body_text: **********By dawn it was apparent for miles around that the long-awaited day had finally arrived.  Clouds of bluish-white smoke billowed from the carbon-caped stacks. And gleeful but skeptical workers, some returning from months of unemployment, asked, ''How did it go?'' as they ambled through the plant gates. **********For the first time in 21 months, one of the aging blast furnaces at the United States Steel Corporation's Edgar Thomson Works is smelting iron ore, coke and limestone into pig iron. Shortly after 4 o'clock this morning, dozens of workers on the graveyard shift gathered around the furnace to watch the lighting, hoping they were witnessing the start of a lasting recovery in the feeble steel industry. **********''I'm happy and I'm surprised,'' said Arthur Williams, an employee of 17 years who returned to work Tuesday after 15 months of forced idleness. ''I thought they were going to keep it shut down for good.'' **********But Mr. Williams's optimism was tinged with caution: ''We may be back three weeks, three months or three years - you can't tell anymore about the economy.'' **********Steelworkers in the Monongahela Valley, the homeland of American steelmaking, have had good reason to fear for their jobs. Old plants here in the industrial satellite towns around Pittsburgh have suffered disproportionately from the shutdowns of recent years. **********The Edgar Thomson Works were once the most advanced of their time, but that time was 108 years ago, when the mill was built by Andrew Carnegie and named for a president of the Pennsylvania Railroad. **********About 20,000 steelworkers in the valley - half the total - are still without work. Only two of the valley's eight blast furnaces are working. Workers at nearby Weirton Steel in West Virginia are buying their plant to save their jobs. Even the steelworkers union has laid off scores of workers at its headquarters. **********But 1983 ushered in better times. The modest revival in auto sales and the buoyancy in the housing industry, and hence in appliances, have increased orders so quickly that the industry is now using 54 percent of its capacity; at the end of December, the furnaces were producing at less than 30 percent of their potential. Thirty-one thousand workers have been recalled throughout the industry. **********''There are going to be more recalls and more facilities put back into production after inventories are worked off,'' predicted Charles Bradford, metals analyst for Merrill Lynch. He figures there are enough orders in hand to justify production at 61 percent of capacity. Concessions by Unions **********Despite the improving economy, the valley's steelworkers are convinced that the timing of the relighting and the recall of 300 of the plant's 1,700 laid-off workers had more to do with labor concessions. **********The new contract, reached at the beginning of March, takes away one week of annual vacation. It freezes payments under the cost-ofliving allowance and reduces hourly pay by $1.25 an hour. A special vacation of 13 weeks every five years was abolished. **********''I thought we would have to give up something, but we gave up too much,'' said Clarence Sabol, a pipefitter with 33 years on the job.  He was recalled several days ago after being out of work for eight months. But two of his sons-in-law are still furloughed. **********Younger workers, however, tend to view the concessions more favorably. ''We make a lot of money,'' said Thomas Groark, a pipefitter for six years. ''I love to work. Giving up a few dollars isn't so bad to keep a job. And we still make a lot of money.'' Pervasive Caution **********Fear that the economy will falter is as much a concern as the company's stance toward the union. In an interview last month, David M. Roderick, chairman of U.S. Steel, was himself unusually guarded about the outlook. **********''One thing you learn in this industry is not to raise false hopes just because you see a little blip,'' he said, talking about the increase in orders. ''Business is still extremely depressed, and we think it will stay that way for the rest of the year.'' **********The strength in steel orders at the beginning of the year came in part from users concerned about the possibility of a strike and price increases. As these fears have faded in the past two weeks, orders have dropped dramatically. **********Poor business aside, U.S. Steel's need to reopen factories will be lessened by its decision to diversify into oil and chemicals. Signs of the shift away from investment in the steel industry are abundant. **********Next to the relighted furnace stand several towers covered in gleaming, unsoiled metal, part of the rebuilding of another blast furnace at Edgar Thomson. But the contractors were dismissed last summer when the company ran into financial trouble as a result of its acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company. Offices Are Empty **********Several hundred yards away, at the plant's administration building, many offices are empty, with wastebaskets and disconnected telephones strewn about. Paint is peeling throughout. **********''I don't believe anything they say about keeping this plant open,'' said Nathaniel Thomas, an 18-year veteran in the plant's foundry. **********Because the steel industry seems to be shrinking, workers with low seniority are looking elsewhere for jobs.  ''A lot of guys with less than 10 years' experience have the feeling that they are never going to be called back,'' said Lena Franklin, a placement specialist with the county's Jobpower Department. **********The department's headquarters, a converted eight-story department store, is jammed each day with local residents seeking training and job referrals. Mrs. Franklin said some women who made as much as $30,000 a year in the mills are training for clerical jobs that pay $5 an hour. Other steelworkers are training to become electronics technicians and nurses, leaving the valley for job opportunities and elsewhere. The Side Effects **********Just as renewed vigor in housing, appliances and autos is helping steel, so too is steel's rebound stirring hope in other businesses. **********''We're just hanging in there,'' said Betty Sandowski, speaking of the her family's retail furniture business on Braddock Avenue, the main business thoroughfare. About the blast furnace relighting, she shrugs. ''It's a beginning. We can only hope it leads to more and more,'' she said. **********But many small businesses may not be able to stick it out.  Braddock Avenue already looks like an economic disaster zone, with vacant shops and rundown hotels. **********And the windows of another business, Lincoff's Credit Jewelers, are plastered with signs reading: ''Closing our doors forever - final sale.'' The owner of the shop, a white-haired man who despite his gregariousness would not give his name, said the relighting at Edgar Thomson would not change his plans. ''There are always rumors that the company is going to do something with the plant, and nothing ever happens,'' said the man, who has been in business here for 58 years.  ''It's like crying wolf. How many times can you cry wolf?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; LONG-TERM RATES ARE UP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/busin.body_text: **********On the eve of the largest Treasury financing ever, the outlook for interest rates is more uncertain than any time in the past year. **********While securities dealers are smarting from large losses during the last few months, investor interest in the Treasury's $15.75 billion package of notes and bonds has been weak. Consequently, prices on outstanding issues have fallen sharply, and long- term interest rates are at the highest levels since last September. **********According to many analysts, the performance of the nation's economy will be the most important guide to changes in long-term yields. Now that real growth has replaced the recession, analysts are unsure to what exent business and consumer credit demands and inflation will rise along with the economy. **********Inflation declined faster than expected, but doubts about the future are widespread. The lack of confidence that inflation rates will remain low is reflected in the 12 percent yield on long-term Treasury bonds - an extremely high level compared with inflation forecasts for the coming year of about 5 percent. **********Volcker Sees 'a New Test' **********Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, commented on inflation before a Senate subcommittee last week, saying, ''We are facing a new test - whether those trends can be extended into and through a period of recovery.'' **********Investor concern about fundamental, long-term concerns such as inflation and the clash between business and Government credit demands have overshadowed developments in Federal Reserve policy. Thus, long-term interest rates have continued to rise, even though the Federal Reserve seems to have stopped raising short- term rates. **********For example, the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, which the Fed can control in a narrow range, has hovered around 9 3/8 percent for two weeks. But yields for notes and bonds have risen sharply. On July 22, yields in the Treasury market ranged from 10.95 percent for 3-year notes to 11.42 percent for 10- year notes and 11.47 percent for 30- year bonds. By late Friday, dealers were offering yields of 11.26 percent for the three-year notes to be auctioned Tuesday, 11.87 percent for the 10-year notes to auctioned Wednesday and 11.91 percent for the 30-year bonds to be auctioned Thursday. **********Change in Yields Since May **********The increases in note and bond yields have been even greater if measured from early May when overnight rates were around 8 3/4 percent and the Treasury sold 3-, 10- and 30-year issues at average yields of 9.48 percent, 10.16 percent and 10.29 percent respectively. **********Victor Chang, director of marketing and planning at Ehrlich-Bober Government Securities Inc. said, ''The rise in short-term rates is not likely to cut short the economy's momentum, but more worrisome is the increase in long-term rates, which could threaten momentum in the housing market.'' Currently, many Fed watchers say the central bank is holding its policy stable after a modest tightening move that began in May and raised the Federal funds rate slightly less than a percentage point, to about 9 1/4 to 9 1/2 percent. **********''Typically, after a tightening move, the Fed pauses,'' said Albert Gross, chief economist and senior vice president of Refco Inc., a securities concern. He said that a steady Fed policy in coming weeks was an important reason why note and bond prices might be near their lows. After the steep price declines since May, he said, ''a technical rally'' looms. **********Deficits a Major Problem **********Many people on Wall Street agree with Mr. Volcker that huge Federal budget deficits are the ''most serious obstacle'' to economic recovery, lower interest rates and lower inflation. The reductions in budget deficits estimated recently in the Administration's mid-year budget review were not convincing evidence that deficits are headed lower, some analysts said. **********Economists at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, which deals in Government securities, said in a recent publication that the estimate of $179.7 billion for the fiscal year 1984 ''appears too low'' because it assumes that Congress will approve $20.7 billion of deficit reduction measures and because the scheduled withholding tax on interest and dividends has been repealed. **********At the Treasury Department, officials estimated earlier this month that they would need to borrow $60 billion to $65 billion in the quarter ending Dec. 31, about the same amount as was borrowed a year ago. **********''This suggests,'' the Lanston analysts said, ''that the Administration is working with a fiscal 1984 budget deficit total which is reasonably close to the one it anticipates for the current year - $209.8 billion.''
