Monday **********Construction Spending(data for June)Tuesday **********Factory Orders(June)Wednesday **********New-Car Sales(July)Thursday **********None scheduledFriday **********Unemployment(July)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/world.main_headline: Iraqi Opposition Group Sets Up Military Base
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Iraqi Opposition Group Sets Up Military Base
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/world.body_text: **********An Iraqi group opposed to the Baghdad Government has set up its first military base on territory in northern Iraq captured by Iranian forces, the Iranian national press agency has reported. **********The agency's report, monitored in London Saturday night, said the base had been set up by the Supreme Assembly of the Islamic Revolution of Iraq, based in Iran, in the Haj Omran area of the Kurdish Mountains close to the border with Iraq. **********The report said an assembly meeting Friday called on ''all Moslem combatants of Iraq to report to this military base.'' A resolution passed at the meeting called for armed struggle against the Government of President Saddam Hussein and said an Islamic republic would be established in Iraq. **********The assembly is headed by a Teheran-based dissident Iraqi clergyman, Mohammed Baqer Hakim. Several members of his family in Iraq have been executed and a number of others arrested.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.main_headline: Barbie Defense Angers Leaders of Resistance
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Barbie Defense Angers Leaders of Resistance
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.body_text: **********Outraged former French Resistance leaders demanded today that the lawyer for Klaus Barbie, the Nazi war criminal, prove assertions that an underground hero killed himself after comrades betrayed him to the Germans. **********Mr. Barbie is in a prison in Lyons awaiting trial on charges of ''crimes against humanity.'' **********His lawyer, Jacques Verges, said Saturday that Jean Moulin committed suicide after being arrested on June 21, 1943, when Nazis raided a meeting of underground leaders outside Lyons. He said he would prove the assertion later. **********Postwar tribunals convicted Mr. Barbie in the death and ordered him executed. France has since abolished the death penalty and he cannot be retried for the same crime. **********Former Prime Minister Jacques Chaban-Delmas, a Resistance leader, denounced Mr. Verges's assertion as ''abominable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/27/busin.body_text: **********A high- level Japanese minister said today that the question of restraining auto exports to the United States ''is a completely clean slate,'' indicating that Japan may reconsider its decision not to renew the limits a fourth year. **********The current quotas are to expire next March 31. **********Although he earlier reported no need to continue the quotas, Sosuke Uno, head of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said the issue was still open. He noted continued high unemployment in the United States and Japan's desire to maintain ''continuing harmonious external trade relations.'' **********But Mr. Uno said Japan had not received an official request from the United States to extend the curbs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/busin.body_text: **********WITH much excitement, Grey Advertising recently extended an invitation to ''see something new'' that it had created for the Olin Corporation, which was added to the client list last August. **********Edward H. Meyer, president and chief executive, was in the board room for the screening. There was coffee and danish cut in quarters.  After a talk on the marketplace for pool chemicals and an explanation of Olin HTH Pool Chlorinator's dominance therein, the house lights were dimmed and the screen came alive with the picture of an attractive woman in a swimsuit on a chaise under an umbrella, obviously at poolside with a convenient 100-pound drum of HTH at her side. **********And as the voice-over announcer intones the sales message, which has to do with a test designed ''to prove how easy it can be to have the most crystal-clear water,'' the woman rubs her hands together as she prepares to apply the sun cream, then applies it. **********Nothing ''new'' or startling so far. **********Suddenly, almost explosively, bubbles pour out of her mouth and as the viewer realizes with surprise that he has been looking at an underwater scene, she springs for the surface trailing even more bubbles, and the 30-second spot is over. **********An advertising agency had delivered on a promise. And the client, represented on this occasion by James W. Paine, business manager of HTH, and Franklin B. Lang, advertising manager, had a commercial that would demonstrate the benefit in a pool cleaner that research showed the consumer most wants: crystal-clear water. To get there, however, was no breeze. The three TV production companies who were asked to bid, as is the custom, declined to without a test because the request was without precedent. **********EUE/Screen Gems, which finally did the job, shot it in its own Burbank, Calif., pool, which was once graced by Esther Williams and is now used by ''Fantasy Island.'' **********Denise McKenna, the actress who had been auditioned under water, played her wordless role with weights in the seat of her suit as well as in her pony tail and a special job was created to brush the bubbles out of her hair each time she descended to the bottom. And since Miss McKenna was wet anyhow, a new ending for the spot was shot for use next year. Instead of her bubbling to the surface, the 1984 version will have her joined by a bubbling young man. **********HTH is, quite simply, the chemical calcium hyperchloride, which Olin introduced 50 years ago and which now has 80 percent of the calcium hyperchloride pool cleaner market and 32 percent of the total market, which is about $300 million at retail. The competition is so diverse, according to Mr. Paine, that there is no clear No.2 brand. **********The product is where it is thanks to a large degree to advertising. And Olin expects to keep it there the same way. The budget is $2.5 million, all of which will be spent in two months on TV, with equal investments in network and spot. **********The network (only NBC and ABC will be used) advertising breaks May 23 and, since the product purchaser is generally a male, the programming will be prime time and late night as well as sports. The spot starting dates differ with the geographical regions since pool interest changes with the coming of summer. The Northeast, which surprisingly enough has the greatest pool-ownership concentration even if they are above ground, begins May 16. Watch for that woman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/busin.main_headline: BRAZIL TO RECEIVE $11 BILLION IN AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/busin.print_headline: BRAZIL TO RECEIVE $11 BILLION IN AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/busin.body_text: **********The International Monetary Fund announced tonight that agreement had been reached to provide Brazil, the world's largest debtor, with $11 billion in loans and credits for the rest of this year and all of 1984. **********Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the Fund, announced the accord after talks here involving the I.M.F., Brazil's principal lenders among more than 500 banks, governments of the major industrialized countries and international financial agencies. **********Brazil is the focal point of a crisis in international finance that is the subject of the joint annual meeting here of the I.M.F., which aids nations in dealing with short-term financial crises, and the World Bank, which provides financing for development. A Victory for Reagan **********At sessions earlier today, finance ministers representing most of the world gave the Reagan Administration a victory in acting to reduce the amount developing countries can bor- row from the I.M.F. next year. The United States had pressed for the cutback, to conserve the I.M.F.'s resources and to help gain passage by Congress of legislation authorizing an increase in the United States subscription to the fund. **********''It sure isn't going to help if we give away an awful lot of the funds that we haven't even raised yet,'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said at a news briefing. ''And it certainly isn't going to help if the I.M.F. isn't seen as a responsible organization.''  Uncertainty About Congress **********Overhanging the finance ministers' session and other meetings here at the 38th annual meeting of the I.M.F. and its affiliated lending agency, the World Bank, is uncertainty as to whether Congress will approve the $8.4 billion American portion of an overall $42 billion increase in the fund's resources. **********That increase for the I.M.F. of roughly 20 percent was agreed to by the 146 member countries last February, but it needs ratification by the parliaments of individual members to go into effect. Only in the United States is there doubt about approval. **********Tuesday the annual meeting of the fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as the World Bank is officially known, will be formally opened by President Reagan. He is expected to address Congress over the heads of the delegates and appeal for passage of the funding legislation. The House and the Senate have both passed a version of the bill, but reconciliation of the two measures by a conference committee is tangled, among other things, in heated partisan politics. **********According to White House aides, the President will emphasize general support for the International Monetary Fund, concern over the world economy and the importance of the I.M.F. in resolving the international debt crisis. **********The $11 billion package for Brazil is an example of the role the Fund plays in the crisis. The financing it has worked out will involve $6.5 billion from private banks, led by Citibank of New York. Of the rest, $2 billion will come from the treasuries of leading industrialized nations, known here collectively as the Club of Paris, and the remaining $2.5 billion would be provided in the form of loan guanantees from official agencies to facilitate Brazilian exports. **********About $8.5 billion of the package represents new funds. Early this year, Brazil obtained a $4.4 billion loan from the I.M.F., but after Brazil fell in arrears the I.M.F. stopped its quarterly payments. Commercial banks had also stopped lending. **********The $11 billion, an I.M.F. spokesman said, will allow Brazil to ''close the gap'' in meeting its internatinal payments on which the country had begun falling behind in May. Brazil owes banks and official lenders approximately $90 billion. **********To obtain the money, Brazil has agreed to arduous restraints on its domestic economy that include balancing its budget by 1984, forcing its 150 percent inflation rate down sharply and slowing the rate of wage increases for the labor force. **********Brazilian workers, like the rest of the economy, have been protected against inflation by getting raises equal to the inflation rate. Under the new agreement, they are allowed only 80 percent of the rate. **********The I.M.F.'s demands for restraints has caused turmoil in Brazil and led directly, on Sept. 1, to the resignation of the head of the country's central bank, Carlos Langoni. He was succeeded immediately by Affonso Celso Pastore. **********Since the beginning of the I.M.F.- World Bank meeting here, Mr. Pastore and Ermane Galveas, Brazil's Finance minister, have been meeting privately with leading American and West German bankers and with I.M.F. officials. **********Tonight Citibank held a black-tie dinner at Meridian House, an elegant former private home that now serves as a center for Washington's internatinal community. Mr. Pastore and Mr. Galveas were there but could not be reached for comment on the loan agreement. ''No one here will talk,'' the man answering the phone said. Borrowing Based on Quotas **********The earlier decision on the borrowing cutback, reached just after 1 A.M., following 15 hours of negotiations by the Fund's 22-member policy-making Interim Committee, relates to complex I.M.F. rules allowing members to borrow on the basis of quotas, or deposits, that each member makes in the common pool. **********Quotas for the entire membership were increased last February by $42 billion, or 47.5 percent, to slightly under $100 billion. Members now may borrow as much as 150 percent of their quotas annually over a period of three years, for a total of 450 percent. **********The United States wanted this cut back to 102 percent a year, or 306 percent for three years, to save resources. The 102 percent would provide access to an equal amount of money in the larger pool, the Americans maintained. But developing countries wanted the present access levels maintained. This would have given them access to larger amounts of cash from the I.M.F., which they said was needed because of the economic crisis. **********All loans made by the International Monetary Fund are conditional on seeking economic adjustment or austerity programs in the borrowing countries. All loans are approved by the executive board, where the United States has a veto on major decisions. **********Finally, in today's early morning hours, a compromise was put on the table by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, in which there would be a two-tier access formula. In most cases there would be a 102 percent ceiling. But access could go as high as 125 percent of the quota.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/busin.body_text: **********For several years, Edwin Z. Gabriel has been working on computer laboratories that could be used by educational institutions. **********The work has been done at his home in Ocean Grove, N.J. He is aware that students experimenting in such laboratories have difficulty making and maintaining electrical connections. **********This week, he was granted patent 4,384,752 for a method of attaching wires to terminal posts with horseshoe-shaped magnets to maintain electric contact. The terminal posts may be coiled springs or hollow tubes. **********The inventor is producing some of the horseshoe connections and would like to license their manufacture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/busin.main_headline: ITALY PREPARES FOR TALKS ON MONETARY REFORM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/busin.print_headline: ITALY PREPARES FOR TALKS ON MONETARY REFORM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/busin.body_text: **********The major Western industrial powers will begin discussing new proposals for reforming the international monetary system at a series of meetings starting next month, European monetary officials indicated today. **********The basic aim of the proposed reform, which at this stage is largely of Italian design, is to make currency values more stable and realistic by strengthening the International Monetary Fund's influence over the economic policies of the big industrial countries. The plan would also give these nations more control over the creation of international reserves. **********The new reform effort will be presented as a low-key affair in contrast to earlier efforts, officials say. **********Key Role in Controlling Talks **********Italy is the key player in this new monetary reform effort, officials say, because it currently heads the Group of 10 - the secretive body bringing together the world's 10 richest countries plus Switzerland, both at ministerial and expert level - and thus effectively controls its discussions. G-10, as the body is usually called, traditionally serves as the forum in which the major financial powers debate monetary changes. **********Italy's central bank is quietly drawing up specific reform proposals to serve as the basis of discussion by the experts of the Group of 10. **********The Reagan Administration will have a chance to express its own views later this month when Beryl W. Sprinkel, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, visits Rome for talks with the Italians. **********Meeting Set in Paris Nov. 17 **********The new round of monetary reform talks opens in Paris Nov. 17, when Lamberto Dini, deputy governor of the Bank of Italy, convenes a meeting of G-10 deputies to draw up a work plan for completing a program of international monetary studies that the I.M.F. ministers requested at their annual meeting in September. **********These studies will examine whether the world needs to create additional monetary reserves to finance economic recovery by issuing more special drawing rights, the artifical reserve unit sometimes known as paper gold, whether volatile exchange rates are affecting trade and investment flows and whether the I.M.F. can do more to coordinate more effectively the economic policies of the major industrial countries. **********2 Specific Reforms Sought **********The Italians apparently want to use the studies as a means of pushing the major Western countries toward agreement on two specific reforms by next March when they hope to convene the finance ministers of the Group of 10 to consider the results of the deputies' work. Besides Switzerland, the Group of 10 consists of the United States, Italy, Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden. **********The first Italian objective is to reach an agreement to create a modest new S.D.R. issue equivalent to about $3 billion a year for three years. **********Although the Reagan Administration and West Germany fear that any futher expansion of international liquidity would be inflationary, the Italians argue that world reserves are now falling fast as countries in payments deficit find they can no longer borrow money from private banks to finance their imports and are forced to spend reserves. **********Help for Trade Recovery **********From a peak of $378 billion in 1980, total world reserves fell to $354 billion at the end of last year and currently stand at $325 billion. Those who favor a new issue of S.D.R.'s say it would help finance the recovery in world trade that is just beginning. **********But officials say the Italians are planning in the longer term to start discussing a more ambitious program. That plan would turn special drawing rights into a major international currency by allowing the I.M.F. to fund itself by creating these units at will and lending them out to countries in payments trouble instead of relying on subscriptions of national currency from its member countries. **********The reformers' second objective is to set up a new system of I.M.F. surveillance over the economic policies of the major Western countries to assure that they are compatible. **********U.S. Fiscal Policy Blamed **********European monetary officials argue that hopes that a convergence in inflation rates alone would stabilize currencies have proved unfounded. **********The blame for this is put on America's fiscal policy that has forced up interest rates and the dollar. Officials in favor of reform argue that the I.M.F. has showed itself powerless to influence economic policy in major countries in the past.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/05/busin.body_text: **********BRITAIN'S blunt-spoken Employment Minister, Norman Tebbit, declared on a news program last week that ''the Government has always been committed to unemployment.'' Quickly catching himself, Mr. Tebbit added, ''I mean improving unemployment.'' **********Curiously, there is a large dose of truth in both Mr. Tebbit's gaffe and his correction. From its first day in office, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government has been dedicated to economic policies that have forced Britain's unemployment rate to record levels. The goal has been to control inflation, an achievement the Conservatives say is the prerequisite for the kind of economic recovery that will lead to a long-term improvement in Britain's employment figures. **********It was a risky strategy, but pollsters here say it looks like it is succeeding politically. Despite a host of economic ills that historically would have spelled electoral disaster for an incumbent British Government, Mrs. Thatcher and her party appear headed for a comfortable, perhaps overwhelming victory in Thursday's general election. **********If the polls are right, the political repercussions are bound to be felt throughout the industrial world. ''Thatcherism'' shares a great deal with the economic policies preferred by President Reagan, and he and his advisers are sure to view a Thatcher victory as a positive sign as he weighs running for a second term in 1984. **********The heart of Thatcherism is to make the fight against inflation the nation's highest economic priority. Curbs on growth in the money supply and on spending are the Government's main weapons in that fight, reliance on the free market to bring efficiency to industry is its creed, and high unemployment in the near term is the price it is willing to accept. **********Mrs. Thatcher is well aware of the close connections between her economic thinking and that preached, if not practiced, by leaders in other major industrial nations. Recently, after her return from the Williamsburg economic summit meeting, she attacked opposition critics with the observation, ''We should stop and ask ourselves whether it is likely that the Labor Party and the Liberal-Social Democratic Party alliance have got it right and the whole of the industrialized world has got it wrong.'' **********Both politicians and analysts agree that the major parties are more split than ever on fundamental policy issues. Both the Conservatives, on the right, and Labor, on the left, are now dominated by ideological thinking that is extreme by the standards of recent British politics. **********Conservatives, arguing that the basis for sustained recovery has been laid by the fight against inflation, claim that still more private enterprise and tighter controls on government spending are needed to make the nation economically competitive. **********The Labor Party wants to increase Government spending dramatically to lift employment; reintroduce exchange controls and force banks to cooperate in domestic investment programs; renationalize the stateowned companies sold to private investors; extend nationalization into new sectors, and take Britain out of the European Economic Community. **********The Liberal-Social Democratic alliance, attempting to convince voters that it should be taken seriously in its first national campaign, has staked out a middle ground calling for a modest increase in spending, continued membership in the E.E.C. and a general freeze in the nationalization-denationalization balance. **********Such divisions have made the economic issues in this election unusually clear-cut.  ''We believe this election will have a more significant effect on the future of industry and the economy than any since the war,'' said Walter Goldsmith, director general of the Institute of Directors, a nonaligned but overwhelmingly conservative association of top business executives. ''We believe that the present Government has broken the mold of British politics.'' **********Mrs. Thatcher's campaign has been aided by disarray among her opponents, widespread doubts about portions of the Labor Party's defense policy and admiration for her strong leadership during the Falklands conflict. But voters have been telling the pollsters that economic issues are the most important ones in the election. And clearly, her campaign has been helped by the failure of the opposition to persuade voters that her policies have made a shambles of the economy. **********IT'S not for want of ammunition.  During four years of Conservative rule, unemployment has tripled, t o just over 3 million people by the Government's own estimates, moret han at any time in British history. Some opposition leaders say thata ctual unemployment is far higher, and the Government acknowledges t hat the underlying trend is still rising. The official unemployment r ate stood at 12.8 percent for May, after changes in reporting that u nderstated the figure compared with previous months. **********Vast portions of the engineering sector have been decimated while others, such as shipbuilding and coal mining, remain uncompetitive.  While inflation dropped in April to an annual rate of just over 4 percent -down markedly from a peak of 21.9 percent in May 1980 - the underlying rate is still higher than the level in such important trading partners as West Germany, the United States and Japan, and it is expected to begin rising again later this year. **********Mrs. Thatcher's tenure in office also has seen a 19 percent decline in industrial production, the steepest in the industrial world, and a sharp drop in Britain's already low level of manufacturing investment. **********To make matters worse, the Government was unable to deliver on its promise to cut spending, and its increase in value added taxes - the British equivalent of a sales tax -wiped out the benefit of income tax cuts for all but the wealthy. **********However, the Labor Party and the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance have been unable so far to draw political blood with such bleak statistics. One reason is that many voters believe most of Britain's economic troubles were inevitable, no matter who was in power. **********''Part of British masochism is that we expect to perform worse than other economies,'' said Gavyn Davies, chief economic analyst at the investment house of Simon & Coates. **********More significantly, though, many voters have accepted the Conservatives' arguments that the problems reflect decades of mismanagement and that Britain's economic plight will be still worse if Mrs. Thatcher is not allowed to continue her programs. **********''I think that people have a feeling that it is not right to blame Mrs. Thatcher for what has happened,'' said Timothy O'Dell, an economist at the investment house of Phillips & Drew. ''There is a sense that it is medicine that had to be taken.'' **********One telling sign of the impact of such arguments is that the latest polls indicate that one-fourth to one-third of the more than 3 million unemployed themselves will vote Conservative. **********And the arguments are buttressed by positive signs that the ''medicine'' may be working: productivity is up, new businesses are being founded at a record rate, interest rates have come down and, according to a survey by the Confederation of British Industry, business confidence is at the highest level since 1978. **********Moreover, the 87 percent of the work force with jobs has fared well under the Conservatives by many measures. Real pay increases have substantially outstripped inflation and work hours lost to strikes have fallen. **********But another aid to Mrs. Thatcher's campaign has been the very difficulty of determining what her impact has been. ''It isn't possible to net out her effect from that of the world economic recession,'' Mr. O'Dell said. **********''She has had more of an impact during a world recession than she would have had in better times,'' said Lord Harris, general director of the Institute of Economic Affairs, a conservative think tank.  ''This Government has accelerated a lot of delayed adjustments.  There's no doubt that any other Government would have tempered the wind. You would have to call it the nerve factor.'' **********LORD Harris's view reflects the widely held belief that leaders in the other parties, and in the more liberal wing of the Conservatives typified by former Prime Minister Edward Heath, would have backed away from a full-scale assault on inflation as it accelerated the rise in unemployment. **********As for her impact on British business, Mrs. Thatcher is best known for her vocal opposition to powerful trade unions. After a false start in which she kept a 1979 campaign pledge that granted inflationary pay increases to public workers, she has assembled a team of ideologically committed Cabinet officials and trusted executives such as Ian MacGregor at the Government-owned British Steel Corporation, who have presided over severe cutbacks in employment, changes in work practices and tough wage bargaining in state-owned industries such as steel, coal and shipbuilding and in the health-care and transport sectors. They, in turn, have encouraged private business to take a tougher stance. ''I have never heard so many businessmen saying that they will not go back to the old ways,'' Lord Harris said. **********Conservatives and most of the business community say that this change in climate has led to productivity improvements and innovations that will make British industry competitive in the future and will eventually produce more jobs. **********Mrs. Thatcher's critics, on the other hand, charge that her confrontational approach has created an illusion of progress that will disappear in a wave of strikes once recovery restores some of the working class's bargaining power. **********''She is the archangel of conflict,'' said Roy Hattersley, the Labor Party's employment spokesman.  That is not to say that Mrs. Thatcher never lets politics influence economic decisions. Last fall, for instance, she quietly rejected the recommendation of Mr. MacGregor that British Steel close Ravenscraig, the last integrated steel mill in Scotland, after Scottish conservatives lobbied against the move. Nor is her approach to the economy entirely hands-off. By the Government's own count, there are 100 different programs to encourage small or new businesses financially. **********But in this campaign, neither the Conservatives nor their opponents seem interested in pointing out such deviations from pure Thatcherism. Both sides apparently feel they have a stake in proving that the Prime Minister has made as much difference as the rhetoric would imply. FOILING AMONETARIST EXPERIMENT LONDON **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came to power in 1979 as a confirmed monetarist, dedicated to the propositions that controlling the money supply was the key to winning the battle against inflation and that monetary restrictions could be imposed without damaging long-run economic growth. The foundation of her economic policy was to be a reduction in the growth rate of sterling M-3 - sterling deposits of British residents plus notes and coin. **********Like President Reagan, she quickly came to grief when a conflict developed between her tight monetary targets and an expansive fiscal policy. Her campaign promise to accept pay increases for public workers - a raise recommended by a commission appointed by the previous Government - forced the civil service wage bill up 24.5 percent, an inflationary wave that rolled through private sector bargaining contracts as well. In addition, interest expenses rose sharply as the Bank of England raised minimum lending rates by 5 percent in order to meet the monetary growth target. **********Finally, to keep the nation's deficit from overwhelming the monetary targets, the Government was forced to adopt various taxes that wiped out the benefits of income tax cuts for all but the wealthy. Thus it undercut its own effort to test the theories of ''supply-side'' economists who argued that tax cuts would actually increase private spending and stimulate economic recovery. **********These developments, and the growing importance of North Sea oil, sent the pound up sharply, catching British manufacturers in a squeeze between high financing costs, falling consumer demand and crushing foreign competition. They also undermined confidence in the validity of M-3 as a measure of monetary growth, since this measure by 1980 was showing a rapid expansion at a time when other monetary measures, interest rates and the exchange rate suggested that money was tight. **********A civil service strike in late 1981 made it impossible to track M-3 or the Government's borrowing requirements accurately, and gave the Government an excuse to reassess its policies at a time when it had become clear that no single money supply measure was proving an accurate predictor of inflation or economic performance. **********The result, concluded a Morgan Guaranty Trust Company report early this year, was a shift to several different monetary targets, with no commitment as to which would be considered most important. **********This pragmatism may be based more on political judgments than economic ones, according to City of London economists. Analysts here have noted that the Government has exceeded both fiscal and monetary targets this spring in an effort to spur the fledgling recovery and they have warned investors to watch for a quick tightening if the Conservatives win by a large margin. One immediate effect would be to drive the pound up again and undo the effect of a 15 percent decline from last November through March - a prospect that worries many businessmen who feel the recovery is still on shaky ground.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/07/busin.body_text: **********William L. Weiss had ample **********reason to hope he would one **********day become chairman of the **********whole of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The current chairman, **********Charles L. Brown, and his **********predecessor, John D. deButts, **********had used their positions as head **********of Illinois Bell to catapult themselves into the top job. **********Instead Mr. Weiss, 54, will be **********moving from Illinois Bell to the **********chairmanship of Ameritech, **********fourth-largest of the seven **********holding companies. Leaving **********the vineyards of regulated business, he says, will carry him **********back in a sense to his entrepreneurial roots. Growing up in western Pennsylvania, his parents ran a grocery store. He was coming of **********age when the onslaught of the **********supermarket chains began, **********teaching him his first lessons in **********competition and survival. After that battle, it was off to **********Penn State for engineering **********training. He joined Bell of **********Pennsylvania in 1951 right **********after graduation and left there **********25 years later as vice president **********of staff operations. He never wandered far from **********Ma Bell, however, becoming **********first a vice president of Wisconsin Telephone, then president **********of Indiana Bell in 1978. He was **********named president of Illinois Bell in 1981 and chairman in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/12/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices generally rose yesterday in slower trading. Although the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.25 points, to 1,086.50, two other leading market indicators closed at record levels for the second consecutive day and advancing issues outpaced decliners by 899 to 665. **********The blue-chip average, which had soared 20.33 points on Thursday, rose to 1,093.65 in the first 17 minutes of trading yesterday, surpassing its former closing record of 1,092.35 set on Jan. 10.  However, the 30 issues that comprise the Dow average were weakened over the remainder of the session by persistent selling pressure. **********Setting new records, the New York Stock Exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks rose 0.08, to 85.18, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 0.13, to 147.63. **********Volume on the Big Board dropped to 86.7 million shares from 93.5 million shares the day before.  The market's early enthusiasm yesterday was fostered by the Labor Department's report before the opening that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods fell 1 percent in January, the largest monthly decline for the index since its introduction in 1947. **********Despite the early enthusiasm, however, ''The market continues to encounter selling pressure when the Dow approaches the 1,100 level,'' observed Michael Metz, vice president of Oppenheimer & Company. **********Mr. Metz said that accumulating evidence of an economic upturn plus moderating inflation ''should stimulate investor interest in the basic industrial and other cyclical groups of stocks such as papers, steels and chemicals.'' **********The computer and technology issues, which made large gains on Thursday, again were the best performing group yesterday.  Teledyne advanced 3 5/8 points, to 149 5/8; Digital Equipment added 3, to 123 1/4; NCR Corporation, 2 1/8, to 99 5/8; Texas Instruments, 2 1/8, to 166, and Datapoint, on the most-active list, gained 2 5/8, to 25 1/8. **********General Instrument climbed 2 3/8, to 62 5/8, after introducing what it called the first microchip that recognizes and responds to voice commands. Milton Bradley Company, which jointly developed the chip with General Instrument, rose 1 1/4, to 38 5/8. **********Suave Shoe fell 1 1/8, to 9 1/4, following its report that earnings for the December quarter dropped to 2 cents a share from 42 cents a share a year earlier. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 1.46, to 377.52. Among the larger gainers, The New York Times Company's class A stock rose 1 7/8, to a new high of 60 1/8; Computer Consoles 1 1/2, to 39 1/2, and Ryland Group 1 1/2, to 43 1/2. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.87, to close at a record 256.64.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/busin.body_text: **********At the end of this month, President Reagan is to present a budget to Congress, an annual exercise that alarms many credit market analysts over the size of Government deficits and Treasury borrowings. **********In the current fiscal year, ending next Sept. 30, analysts such as Elliott Platt at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette expect a deficit of about $190 billion, with the Treasury needing to borrow more than $200 billion. A similar deficit is forecast for the next fiscal year. **********A record deficit did not keep interest rates from falling in the last year, when three-month Treasury bills declined to 7.6 percent from 12.2 percent and 30-year Treasury bonds dropped to 10 1/2 percent from 14 3/8 percent. Forecasts of still lower rates are widespread, on the theory that weak credit demand from businesses and consumers will leave plenty of room for huge Treasury borrowings without driving interest rates up. **********''I'm not so concerned about the deficit now as I am about the outlook for a few years from now,'' commented George Collins, president of the T. Rowe Price New Income Fund. Without changes in Federal tax and spending practices, he said, the deficits are ''structural - not temporary'' and could pose a risk to investors in future years. Pressures in Future Years **********''Rates can come somewhat lower,'' Mr. Collins said, ''though most of the run is out of the way.'' Because huge deficits in future years leave open the possiblilty that the Federal Reserve will try to ease the strain on the economy and buy a large portion of the debt, Mr.  Collins and others are unsure wether the recent declines in inflation and interest rates can be sustained. **********Allan C. Lerner, an economist at the Bankers Trust Company, warned that budget uncertainties were discouraging potential buyers of Treasury notes and bonds. ''Cuts in the entitlement programs'' would be the most credible signs of budgetary reform, he said. **********For now, ''a weak economy is serving to keep a check on rates,'' Mr. Lerner said, but he added, ''Clear signs of an economic uptrun will flash a warning signal to fixed-income investors, who are well aware of the Treasury's future demands.'' **********Various other analysts are more optimistic, saying that deficits may not be as much of a problem as some people fear.  ''There are now signs that the Administration is finally adopting a more realistic attitude about prospects for economic growth,'' said Aubrey H. Zaffuto, vice president and economist at the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company. Such a realistic appraisal, he said, will add to the credibility of economic policy makers and help the prospects for fiscal policy ''become a bit brighter.'' Outlook for Fears on Deficit **********Because the economy may peform better than expected, ''fears regarding the Federal deficit are likely to lessen as 1983 unfolds,'' said Frank Mastrapasqua, an economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********Although many analysts agree that the slowing of inflation means that the fundamental direction of interest rates is downward, there are several opinions as to when the decline may occur this year.  Several analysts, for example, expect most of the rate drop to occur in the next few months, while others say it may not come until the second half of the year. **********Those expecting rates to fall soon say it could happen when the Federal Reserve announces further reductions in the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institions. Further declines in interest rates are required to sustain the economic recovery, economists have said. Analysts at Money Market Services, a consulting firm, said the recent strengthening of the automobile and housing industries was based on pent-up demand from the last few years and would not continue without further declines in interest rates. Some Suggest Rise in Rates **********Economists at Citibank and Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a securities firm, are among those who have said that interest rates might go higher before they decline later this year. **********Analysts at both firms said it is possible that the economic recovery early this year, combined with too rapid growth in the money supply, would cause the Fed to begin making credit less available to the banking sytem rather than supplying all the needs of the banks as in recent months. That would lead to a temporary increase in interest rates. **********In the first-quarter version of their United States Economic Forecast, Citibank economists said the Fed's commitment to lowering inflation and keeping money supply growth under control makes them ''basically bullish on the bond market over the longer term.'' Bond yields should be lower at the end of 1983 than at the end of 1982, they said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/busin.body_text: **********The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the first of the nation's major oil companies to report first-quarter earnings, said yesterday that net income fell 15.1 percent, to $399 million, or $1.36 a share, largely because of falling gasoline prices. **********John E. Swearingen, chairman and chief executive officer, said that ''competitive gasoline market conditions'' had affected Indiana Standard's United States refining, marketing and transportation operations. **********They ''suffered from severely depressed margins'' between gasoline prices and the costs of crude oil, refining and marketing, he said. **********The first-quarter results compared with net income of $470 million, or $1.60 a share, in last year's quarter. Revenues rose 4.2 percent, to $7.5 billion, from $7.2 billion. **********The profit decline was in line with drops of 15 to 25 percent that are expected for most of the major oil companies, according to analysts. **********Eugene Nowak, a petroleum analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the results were ''attributable to weakness in gas prices.'' He added that ''the very unfavorable performance in the domestic downstream business registered a loss of $56 million for the quarter, as compared to a gain of $13 million last year.'' **********Standard of Indiana, the nation's sixth-largest oil company, is an integrated operation whose reserves, refining and marketing are mostly in the United States. The downstream refining and marketing loss account for $69 million of the $71 million decline in net income, Mr. Nowak said. Union Oil **********The Union Oil Company of California reported a 23.9 percent drop in first-quarter net income, to $128.3 million, or 74 cents a share, from $168.5 million, or 97 cents a share, in the 1982 period.  Revenues totaled $2.47 billion, nearly as much as the $2.48 billion in last year's period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/26/world.body_text: **********News   Analysis **********MOSCOW, Nov. 25 - In the aftermath of the Soviet withdrawal from the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles, Western diplomats here say they believe that whatever chance there was of a settlement may have fallen victim to the leadership uncertainties in the Kremlin. **********Principal among the uncertainties is that Yuri V. Andropov appears to be slipping in authority because of illness. As a result, diplomats say they doubt there has been any voice in the Politburo strong enough to argue for more flexibility in Geneva.  Developments in the missile talks this week have followed a script set out months ago by Moscow. Mr. Andropov and other leaders had long warned that once deployments of new American missiles in Europe began, there would be no ground for continuing the Geneva negotiations. **********They had also laid out in general terms the series of countermeasures that Mr. Andropov announced Thursday, including deployment of new seaborne nuclear missiles against the United States, additional placements of SS-20 medium-range missiles targeted on Western Europe and accelerated deployment of smaller tactical and battlefield nuclear weapons in Eastern Europe.  Some Western envoys say they believe that the Kremlin decided from the outset of the Geneva sessions two years ago that it would never sign an agreement licensing the deployment of new American nuclear missiles ''on the threshhold of our house,'' as Mr. Andropov put it in his latest statement. **********In this view, the Soviet leadership was united in its conviction that the Pershing 2 and cruise missiles pose a threat to the Soviet Union as great as any they have faced since the American nuclear monopoly ended more than 30 years ago. **********But there is another view that attributes the walkout in Geneva in part to Mr. Andropov's health, a political vagary in Moscow that could scarcely have been foreseen at an earlier stage of the talks. The Soviet leader, who as late as August appeared to be swiftly consolidating his power, has been out of public view for more than three months, and there are reports that he has a kidney ailment and has spent at least part of his absence in the hospital. **********Diplomats generally agree that Mr. Andropov relied heavily on military support when he was chosen to succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev a year ago, and that military influence in the Kremlin has probably never been higher since World War II. **********Statements by Soviet marshals have demonstrated their implacable opposition to the deployment of any American missiles in Europe, and any chance that they could be won over to a more flexible view almost certainly depended on Mr. Andropov's gaining clear primacy within the ruling group. **********Whether Mr. Andropov would have persuaded the military chiefs, diplomats admit, is unknowable, but their conclusion is that without him, a last-minute compromise that could have stopped the American deployments became highly improbable.   Format Could Be Different **********By the same token, the diplomats say they believe that it could be some time, if at all, before the Kremlin agrees to resume negotiations. And they say the probability is that if Moscow is to join negotiations again, it will have to be in a different format, possibly at a new forum that would merge the talks on medium-range weapons with the parallel set of negotiations on strategic arms, also being held in Geneva. **********Before Mr. Andropov's statement Thursday, Soviet officials had privately acknowledged that there would be some logic in this, in light of their own insistence that the American nuclear missiles in Europe constitute a strategic threat to their own armory that their medium-range missiles do not pose to the United States strategic force. Westerners who have pressed the Russians on this, however, have found them evasive, and there was nothing in Mr. Andropov's statement to give encouragement about new talks. **********The Russians proved unyielding in their refusal to ''give our blessing'' to any new American missile deployments, no matter how far reduced from the original deployment plan. **********One Western envoy who has dealt directly with the Kremlin on the issue described this as ''the impossible condition'' for the United States, since it would have left Moscow with a monopoly in Europe of modern land-based missiles.   'Answer Is Self-Evident' **********The envoy, closely involved in arms negotiations with Moscow for a decade, said the Soviet position was unusually unyielding, even by the tough standards of Soviet negotiators, and added: ''You have to ask yourself who in the hierarchy here could set such a condition and insisted on it? I think the answer is self-evident - the military.'' **********Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov and other high-ranking officers have described the missiles as the embodiment of American plans for a ''nuclear blitzkrieg'' on Soviet command and communication centers. **********Some diplomats say they feel the Soviet leadership may now focus less on this issue because their pronouncements on the American missiles have raised profound fears across the country, to the point that ordinary Russians frequently ask Americans here why President Reagan is planning a nuclear war. **********What diplomats say they expect now is a variant of the previous Soviet strategy, without the negotiations. While the negotiations were going on in Geneva, Soviet leaders never abandoned hope of achieving their goal of blocking the United States missiles on the political battleground of Western Europe, and it is there that efforts are likely to be concentrated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/world.body_text: **********Peasants in a central Andean village told reporters today that they were following police orders to kill strangers when they attacked and killed eight Peruvian journalists last week. **********Several hundred people, including family members, a representative of President Fernando Belaunde Terry and delegations from Parliament were at the airport today to meet an air force plane that brought the bodies of six of the eight journalists back to Lima. **********The air force jet brought the bodies from Ayacucho, 220 miles southeast of Lima and capital of the department where the eight journalists were beaten to death last week by about 100 peasants with machetes, clubs and stones. **********''They told us to kill any stranger that appeared,'' an unidentified peasant in the town of Uchuracay said of the police.  The peasants said the police had told them any strangers in the region were probably members of the Shining Path guerrilla group.  About 50 journalists flew to Uchuracay Sunday to help military rescue squads recover their colleagues' bodies. The reporters interviewed the peasants and made public the statements in Lima today. **********Uchuracay is a remote town in the north part of the Ayacucho department, 220 miles southeast of Lima, where the guerrilla group has concentrated for three years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/busin.body_text: **********The Storage Technology Corporation usually has proved itself lithe and resourceful, dancing in the shadow of the computer industry giant, the International Business Machines Corporation. **********But the company took a nasty fall last year when a bad batch of disk drives caused computer system failures at several big corporations. ''We ended up on the bleeding edge of technology, instead of the leading edge,'' one computer systems executive at a major bank said sarcastically. **********The $17 million bill to remedy the situation contributed to Storage Technology's first drop in annual profits since 1974. They had grown at an average yearly rate above 40 percent for the last 10 years. Perhaps worse, though, was the damage to the company's reputation for sound engineering at an especially portentous time. **********Storage Technology is about to ship its new thin-film disk drive, the 8380, nearly 10 months after I.B.M. established a lead with its 3380. The 8380 is a glamour entry among a half-dozen new products on the way - products that Jesse I. Aweida, chairman and chief executive, is counting on to contribute about another $1 billion in sales at Storage Technology in 1985. A Cool Reception **********That is a tall order, considering that the company passed $1 billion in total revenues - at $1.1 billion, a 17 percent gain over 1981 - for the first time last year. Net income, at $64.7 million, or $1.88 a share, dropped 21 percent. With customer demand still tepid, the company said on March 14 that it was laying off 500 of its 8,100 workers here, mainly in its administrative staff. **********Yet analysts expect the market for thin-film disk drives to exceed $5 billion in two years, up from $2 billion this year. If its 8380 catches on this spring, Storage Technology could capture 20 percent of the thin-film disk business by 1984, and 25 percent by 1985, according to Stephen T. McClellan, a technology analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. **********He wrote in a recent report that the 8380 is smaller, faster and easier to manufacture than the 3380 thin-film disk drive that I.B.M.  began to ship late in 1981. If he is right, Mr. Aweida's sales projection may turn out to have been conservative. **********At the moment, however, many chastened customers and unimpressed analysts have adopted a cautious attitude. ''We're giving it a cool reception because we want somebody else to work the bugs out,'' a computer systems manager in a major aerospace company said. Stock Outlook **********It does not matter that Storage Technology continues to spend heavily on research and is said by some to be ahead of I.B.M. in developing an inexpensive storage disk based on laser science. The price of its slumping shares is not expected to rebound this year unless the 8380 succeeds. **********Mr. Aweida, 52 years old, a self-assured former product manager at I.B.M. who co-founded Storage Technology in 1969, acknowledged as much. **********''The question in a lot of people's minds is whether we can make it, ship it and have it work well,'' he said. ''We feel very good about it. The evidence will probably be there no later than July.'' **********Storage Technology shares, which closed Friday at $20.875, unchanged, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, slipped from a peak of $40.25 in 1981. Mr. Aweida compares the slump to 1978, when Storage Technology was readying several new products but was out of favor on Wall Street. **********He is moving cautiously in an effort to perfect the 8380 manufacturing system well before Storage Technology pushes into heavy production. He plans to ship 100 of the units, priced at nearly $100,000 apiece, through the summer. If all goes well, the rate will go to 900 units in the fourth quarter, he said. **********Meanwhile, I.B.M. shipped more than 5,000 of the 3380 disk drives last year and is expected to add as many as another 15,000 this year, according to Frank R. Gens, a senior research analyst with the Yankee Group, a data processing and telecommunications research and consulting concern based in Boston. **********He and some other analysts pointed out that I.B.M. has stepped up the pace of its new product introductions. That gives competitors like Storage Technology less time to recoup their investment on their equipment that plugs into I.B.M. mainframes. **********One analyst, who asked not to be identified because Storage Technology is one of his customers, said I.B.M. is readying a disk drive with 2,500 billion bits of memory storage capacity - more than twice the 1,000 billion bits of memory in the 3380 -that it could announce as early as next fall. The storage capacity in 1,000 billion bits is roughly equal to 125,000 typewritten pages. **********''That is what is holding Storage Technology's stock down,'' he said. I.B.M.'s Innovation Rate **********Beyond that, I.B.M.'s increasingly rapid rate of product innovation, coupled with aggressive price-cutting, has cast a cloud over most plug-compatible manufacturers, according to Ulric Weil, an industry analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Other analysts, however, doubted that I.B.M. would move so quickly to bring a new disk drive to the market, since an announcement that soon would discourage potential customers from buying its 3380 or agreeing to long-term leases, both of which the company is encouraging. **********Mr. Aweida said Storage Technology also is developing a version of the 8380 with double storage capacity, which he expects to ship sometime next year. Customers have told his sales staff that the I.B.M. sales force is hinting about an enhancement of the 3380, but Mr. Aweida indicated he doubts that it will be announced this year. **********In addition to Storage Technology, the other so-called plugcompatible manufacturers of peripheral equipment for I.B.M.  mainframe computers principally include the Amdahl Corporation, the Control Data Corporation and the Memorex division of the Burroughs Corporation. **********I.B.M., of course, is the leader in the plug-compatible industry.  Among the independents, Storage Technology does about two-thirds of the plug-compatible business, according to Mr. Aweida. **********These are not simply ''me too'' products, copies of I.B.M.  originals, Mr. Aweida asserted. For instance, Storage Technology just introduced a controller, called Sybercache, a plug-in accessory which speeds the entry and recall of data between a range of I.B.M.  mainframe computers and information storage units. **********''That's a good product,'' said Thomas J. Crotty, director of research for the Gartner Group, a research arm of Dillon, Read Inc.  Then, too, programs for certain I.B.M. computers, including the 3081 series as well as the 3082, 3083 and 3084, do not have to be altered when the Storage Technology 8380 disk drive is added, according to Ted Costello, a technology analyst with Sutro & Company, in San Jose, Calif. Oddly, changes in programs are necessary to run I.B.M.'s 3380 disk drive. **********''Who needs the headaches of reprogramming?'' Mr. Costello said.''With the arrival of the 8380, Storage Tech will be more compatible with I.B.M.'s market than I.B.M. is.'' Second-Half Rebound **********Storage Technology spent about $75 million on research and development last year, up from $50 million in 1981. Mr. Aweida said he plans to keep the figure at about 7 percent of sales again this year. Beyond that, the company has raised $250 million through limited partnerships in 1981 to finance its first mainframe computer, which is due for initial delivery in about a year. **********Mr. Aweida is telling Wall Street not to expect a rebound in profits at Storage Technology during the first half of 1983, but he is optimistic that a pickup in the economy will give the 8380 and other new products a lift in the second half. **********Analysts who expect the company to repeat past successes think its shares are an uncommon bargain among high-technology stocks, many of whch have doubled in price since last August. **********''Once they get their product cycle back on track, they should be off to the races,'' said Joseph R. Kapka, a technology analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., in Santa Clara, Calif. **********''All the bad news is already in the stock,'' Mr. Costello, of Sutro & Company, added. ''Once they ship this new generation of disk drives, it won't take long to find out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/13/world.body_text: **********A stadium guard enraged by soccer fans' jeers fired a shotgun into the stands today, killing one person, the police said. Twenty-five others were reported injured by gunfire or by other spectators fleeing the gunman. **********The police said the guard, Angelo Grasso, 54 years old, fired five or six rounds into the crowd at the Cibali Stadium before being captured by paramilitary police. He was then jailed. **********Officials said one of the victims, a 28-year-old man, was struck in the head and chest by a shotgun blast and died on the way to the hospital. **********They said 25 other spectators at the game, which had not started when the shooting began, were rushed to three hospitals for treatment, but that it was not immediately clear how many were wounded by shotgun fire and how many were hurt in the rush to escape.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The United Brands Company said yesterday that it would take a $100 million charge against fiscal third-quarter earnings from the restructuring of its United Fruit Company division. United Fruit is the world's largest importer of bananas, which are sold under the Chiquita label. **********The company, based in New York, said it was restructuring to ''better match the company's supplies with demand for its product in selected markets.'' **********The United Fruit unit will scale back banana production in certain locations, reduce long-term contractual commitments to purchase bananas and realign transportation and distribution accordingly, the company said. **********The Value Line Investment survey notes that United Fruit has been hit hard by the weakness in banana prices brought on by oversupplies. The survey says, ''Cutting back on its own distribution eventually will help restore prices, but withdrawing from contracts with growers could prove costly.'' **********Because of the special restructuring charge, United Brands said it expected to report a substantial loss for the quarter and nine months ended March 31, 1983. It will announce final results for the period at the end of June. **********United Brands reported sales of $812.5 million in the fiscal second quarter, down 17.5 percent from $985.2 million a year earlier. Its stock closed at 12 7/8 yesterday, down 5/8, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The company also said the restructuring would prevent declaration of the regular quarterly dividends normally payable on June 1 and June 30 for three issues of preference and preferred stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/01/world.main_headline: DYING BONN PARTY SHOWS SIGNS OF LIFE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/01/world.print_headline: DYING BONN PARTY SHOWS SIGNS OF LIFE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/01/world.body_text: **********At the start of the campaign, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Deputy Chancellor and the longest-serving Foreign Minister in the West, was reduced to luring pensioners with beer and free pea soup into half-filled taverns or addressing listless crowds from a special train. **********His Free Democratic Party looked as if it was heading for political extinction.  But in the biggest turnaround of this campaign, the crowds are now thronging to the Free Democrats' rallies. One week before the election Mr. Genscher, perspiring as he rasps through one speech after another, senses that he is going to save both his endangered party and his job as Foreign Minister. **********''I think when we get to the end of an election people are obliged to see the importance of the F.D.P. in the political system,'' the Foreign Minister said in an interview. ''I make the assumption that we will now be in the Bundestag -that is without doubt. I am also of the opinion that the Greens will be in the Bundestag too - weaker than us, but they will be there.'' Party Left Schmidt Coalition **********A month ago few would have bet on the Free Democrats' getting the 5 percent of the popular vote needed to get back into Parliament. By deserting Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic-led coalition in September, Mr. Genscher was stigmatized as a ''traitor.'' His small party had been shut out of state legislatures in Hamburg, Hesse and Bavaria and had sunk to about 2 percent of the popular vote. **********The comeback has been slow, painful and hardly certain. Mr.  Genscher has traveled frantically on diplomatic missions abroad, guaranteeing himself prime television coverage at home. He has even been praised by Brigitte Bardot for opposing the import of baby seal pelts. **********The Free Democrats have not aroused great public enthusiasm despite their claim to be running a ''happy'' campaign. Polls still show Mr.  Genscher to be the most unpopular politician in the country, and he has been obliged to share the party limelight with the witty, toughminded Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, who has pushed the Free Democrats to the right of their Christian Democratic partners on fiscal policy. **********If the Free Democrats slip back into Parliament next Sunday, it will largely be because one bloc of voters fears that the Christian Democrats alone cannot win a clear majority of seats and because another bloc fears that such a majority would make Franz Josef Strauss, the right-wing Bavarian, Foreign Minister. The Free Democrats' role as an all-purpose coalition-maker would then be ratified. Playing the Anti-Strauss Card **********In meetings Mr. Genscher leaves it to lieutenants to play the anti-Strauss card. An overflow gathering of 2,500 people in this southern city was told today that only three men could be the next Foreign Minister: Mr. Genscher, the volatile Mr. Strauss or Egon Bahr, whom the Government has tried to tar as a Moscow mole in the Social Democratic Party. **********Mr. Genscher is an unexciting speaker, and he resorts to straining his vocal cords, almost shouting, for dramatic effect. But he gets in some sharp jabs at the Social Democrats, saying they abandoned a common foreign policy in the eight years he served as Mr. Schmidt's Foreign Minister. **********He mocks Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democratic candidate for Chancellor, for saying he alone can force Moscow and Washington to negotiate an arms agreement. ''I would be happy,'' Mr. Genscher says, shaping his hands into a vise, ''if he could force his own party to come together on security questions.'' **********The United States is the guarantor of West Germany's freedom, he continues, to hearty applause. A coalition between Mr. Vogel and the antinuclear, anti-NATO Green Party, he says, would make West Germany ''a wanderer between worlds'' and a ''plaything'' in international politics. A Change in Image **********In going from coalition with the Social Democrats to coalition with the Christian Democrats, the Free Democrats have lost their image as the country's foremost champion of civil liberties. In his speeches Mr. Genscher now puts little emphasis on such pet issues as the rights of Turkish and other foreign ''guest workers'' in Germany. **********Joining the Christian Democrats last fall, the weakened Free Democrats had to abandon the Interior Ministry to Mr. Strauss' man in Bonn, Friedrich Zimmermann, who just recently encroached on the Foreign Minister's turf by making a speech about recovering once-German territories in Poland. Mr. Genscher does not talk about recovering the Interior Ministry for his party in the next government. **********What remains of the old message is mainly an open appeal to the country's upper-middle classes to vote Free Democratic to prevent the Christian Democrats from overtaxing them. The Free Democrats are also appealing for West Germans to split their two votes -one goes for local candidates, the other for a party - giving the junior coalition partner the second. **********Chatting in a hotel bar between speeches, Mr. Genscher said he felt the ''overwhelming majority'' of West Germans ''support integration with the West.'' **********''You noticed the reaction today -you can see it in any gathering - when I contrast the difference between the stationing of American troops here to the Soviet troops in Poland, you can feel how the people really think and feel,'' he said. **********He said he welcomed the campaign debate on medium-range missiles, which he deals with in public by saying a return of the Bonn coalition to power will help persuade the Russians to reduce their nuclear arsenal. ''The missile question really does arouse the people,'' he said. ''I am of the opinion that the discussion of this subject in this election campaign has advantages; it works off emotions. And that is a gain for us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The board of the cash-short Washington Public Power Supply System voted today to put 3,900 workers on a four-day week at its headquarters and a nuclear power plant construction site to save money. **********The executive board also adopted a resolution stating it has no intention of declaring bankruptcy in order to get out of its obligations on two plants on which construction has been stopped. **********If the board had not acted, by May 1 the system would have had only enough money left in its construction budget for the No. 3 Satsop plant to cover outstanding bills, Mr. Peterson said. The plant is 70 percent complete and scheduled to come on line in late 1985 or early 1986. **********Washington Public Power, the construction arm of 88 Northwest public utilities, originally planned five nuclear power plants in Washington. Two were terminated in January 1982 because of rising costs and doubts about the need for their power. A third plant has been mothballed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/04/world.print_headline: POPE PLOT TRIAL IS LIKELY IN '83
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/04/world.body_text: **********The magistrate investigating the shooting of Pope John Paul II said today that the trial of Bulgarians and Turks accused of complicity should begin by the end of the year. **********''I hope the investigation will be finished before summer, and, if all goes well, the trial will begin by the end of the year,'' Magistrate Ilario Martella said in an interview. **********Two Bulgarian officials and four Turks have been charged with complicity in the attack by a Turk, Mehmet Ali Agca, on the Pope in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981. One of the Bulgarians and two of the Turks are being held in a Rome jail, but the others will probably be tried in absentia. **********Both the Bulgarian and Soviet Governments have vigorously denied Italian and American press reports that the Bulgarian Government organized the assassination attempt. **********The police in Milan are investigating another Turk, Mustafa Savas, who was arrested Wednesday after a suspected Italian drug dealer told them that Mr. Savas offered him $210,000 to shoot the Pope during a visit to Milan in May. The police said they were going to confront the informant with Mr. Savas, who denied the accusation. **********Magistrate Martella said he had questioned about 50 witnesses in Italy, Australia, Switzerland, West Germany, the United States and Turkey during his investigation. Judicial sources said he might also accept an invitation from the Bulgarian Government to question two former members of its Rome Embassy staff implicated by Mr. Agca.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.main_headline: FORD POSTS A PROFIT IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.print_headline: FORD POSTS A PROFIT IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company, continuing the series of better-than-expected third-quarter earnings reports in the automobile industry, today reported a profit of $333 million, or $1.83 a share, compared to a loss of $325 million a year earlier. Analysts had been estimating that Ford would earn about $250 million. **********The four domestically based auto companies thus had a combined profit of $1.16 billion for the quarter, against a combined loss of $218 million in the comparable 1982 period. Earlier this week, the General Motors Corporation reported a profit of $737 million and the Chrysler Corporation reported one of $100 million. Only the American Motors Corporation, by far the smallest company in the group, had a loss, of $9.1 million. **********Ford attributed its improvementto ''a strong level of profitability in Ford's car and truck business in North America, higher industry volumes and a more profitable product mix in Europe, and productivity improvements worldwide.'' **********The company reported that its United States operations, which had been the core of Ford's recent financial problems, were profitable in the quarter, earning $231 million, compared to a loss of $321 million. Overseas, Ford reported a profit of $102 million, compared to a loss of $4 million.  Ford's dollar sales increase in the quarter exceed the growth in unit sales, an indication of consumer preference for more expensive models. The company's sales in the period totaled $10.3 billion, an increase of 28 percent from $8.05 billion, while sales of cars, trucks and tractors were 1,135,000 units, up 22 percent from 926,451. **********For the nine months, Ford had total earnings of $1.09 billion, compared to a loss of $422 million in the comparable 1982 period. Sales in the three quarters of 1983 rose to $32.05 billion, from $27.9 billion. **********A statement by the company noted that Ford had reduced its worldwide debt by $1.2 billion since the third quarter of 1982, to $3.6 billion, and increased its cash balance by $800 million, to $2.2 billion. However, the company still is operating with a negative working capital of $789 million. **********The company also tempered its upbeat report with a note of caution: ''While these results are satisfying in the short run, long-run success requires continuing progress. Further improvements in financial results are necessary to support future investment plans. The Japanese cost advantage must continue to be attacked through additional productivity improvements.'' **********Since all four of the car companies have scheduled a high level of production for the rest of the year, fourth- quarter results are expected to exceed the third quarter. Analysts have estimated that G.M. could earn up to $3.5 billion for the year, with Ford earnings estimated at $1.3 billion and Chrysler $900 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The big third-quarter loss reported late Friday by the Interfirst Corporation of Dallas surprised many of the 11,000 bankers here for the annual convention of the American Bankers Association. **********But it evidently did not surprise top officers at the bank holding company. They indicated in an interview here that they had spent the days before the announcement assuring their colleagues in the industry that Interfirst was sound. **********Not only was the $194 million net operating loss the biggest ever reported among American banks, but Interfirst long had been considered to have been one of the best run and most profitable banking organizations in the United States. **********The typical reaction was, ''Is it possible?'' But it was possible, and Interfirst's two senior officers came here to explain their case. **********The men, Elvis L. Mason and Robert H. Stewart 3d, have been considered among the best bankers in the business, locked in an amiable rivalry. Mr. Mason is Interfirst's chairman and chief executive officer; Mr. Stewart formerly was a chief executive officer and most recently chairman of the executive committee. **********But in announcing the loss, the bank also said it had dismissed William D. Breedlove, who had been chairman of the Interfirst Bank in Dallas, which accounts for about half of the group's total assets. Mr. Stewart replaced Mr. Breedlove as chairman of the Dallas bank. **********''The financial markets have complete confidence in Bob,'' Mr. Mason said in an interview here. **********So highly regarded have Mr. Mason and Mr. Stewart been that they were often considered to be among the top candidates for some of the choicest banking jobs in the country. For example, when the First National Bank of Chicago was looking for a new chief executive officer a few years ago, both Mr. Mason and Mr. Stewart were among the top candidates. The job eventually went to Barry Sullivan, formerly of the Chase Manhattan Bank. **********Most of the problem loans were to the energy industry and Mr. Mason said that such problems were endemic to Texas banking, where most banks are heavily engaged in financing the energy industry. ''No bank in Texas has found it easy to come to grips with credit problems,'' he said. **********Many Texas bankers here at the convention were predicting that other banks in the state would eventually report comparable losses, though much smaller in actual size because most banks are far smaller than Interfirst. In some cases, the problems are not merely in energy lending but also in agriculture. **********To reassure the banking community, Mr. Mason and Mr. Stewart flew into Honolulu Saturday and attended receptions given by other banks. In an interview this morning, they said they planned to leave this afternoon after attending a meeting of the Reserve City Bankers, to which only chief executive officers of the nation's biggest banks belong. **********Even before their brief trip to Hawaii, and before the announcement about the loss, Mr. Mason and Mr. Stewart were seeking to shore up support among the nation's biggest bankers just in case the Dallas bank needed help in raising money - an unlikely prospect considering the company's still unusually strong capital position. But early last week, Mr. Mason began meeting with major bankers in New York to let them know of the extent of the problems and to reassure them of Interfirst's basic strength. **********''It was an effort to be certain that the heads of some of the biggest banks in the country were not surprised,'' Mr. Mason said. ''We thought it important to brief them in advance. We didn't expect to have any trouble raising money, but we wanted to be sure other banks understood our position.'' **********Mr. Mason stressed that the big provision for loan losses - $430 million - was taken to make sure that there would be enough to deal with any unforeseen problems in the future. And he indicated that the company might even recoup some of the $334 million in loans it charged off during the quarter, mostly in the oil and gas sector. **********Mr. Mason said that a ''substantial portion'' of the problem loans were concentrated among 40 or 50 credits. But he added that despite the loss of almost $200 million, Interfirst's primary capital, at 6.2 percent of total assets, is among the strongest of the nation's 15 largest banks. Its reserve for loan losses, a cushion to protect against future bad loans, stands at 1.84 percent of total loans, also about the highest among the big banks.
