https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The report, in The (Nashville) Tennessean, said Federal officials were investigating Mr. Lance's failure to report most of those loans to the Government. The officials said he still could file an amended list of loans without penalty. Mr. Lance could not be reached for comment, and did not return phone calls. **********The newspaper said that Mr. Lance received $2.1 in loans from Jake Butcher's United American Bank of Knoxville, which failed on Feb. 14, becoming the nation's third-largest bank to collapse since the Depression. **********Of the $2.1 million, $1.3 million was in personal loans and $809,000 was a loan to the Kris Company, a defunct concern headed by one of his sons, The Tennessean said. **********Mr. Lance, now chairman of the Democratic Party in Georgia, failed to list the loans from UAB-Knoxville, as required by the Federal Government, the newspaper said. UAB-Knoxville was a correspondent of Mr. Lance's Calhoun First National Bank in Calhoun, Ga. Mr. Lance resigned from the Carter Cabinet in 1977 because of reports of irregularities in obtaining loans. **********The Tennessean said Mr. Lance also had loans from C. H. Butcher's C & C Bank of Knoxville County - one for $75,000 and another for $350,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/20/busin.body_text: **********A new agreement by industrial countries to make more funds available to nations in economic straits will not be used until the International Monetary Fund exhausts its own resources, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today. **********Representatives of 11 major industrial countries agreed in Paris on Tuesday to triple the money kept in a special fund, known as the General Arrangement to Borrow, to about $19 billion. **********In the past, only contributors were allowed to borrow from the special fund. But with the growing debt crises in third-world countries, the 11 nations decided to allow others to use it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/world.main_headline: U.S. OFFICIAL CALLS SOVIET ARMS OFFER A DISAPPOINTMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/world.print_headline: U.S. OFFICIAL CALLS SOVIET ARMS OFFER A DISAPPOINTMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/world.body_text: **********A senior Administration official said today that the United States was disappointed by Yuri V. Andropov's latest arms control statement. **********The official said the Soviet leader, in an interview in Pravda made public on Friday, had made one forthcoming statement - that Moscow would destroy and not just relocate any missiles it agreed to reduce from its force of missiles in the European part of the Soviet Union. **********''The difficulty in his remarks, however,'' the official said in an interview, ''is that they don't address the two basic problems in the negotiations.'' **********Problem of American Missiles **********The official, who is involved in arms control policy and asked not to be identified by name, said the first problem was Mr. Andropov's continuing insistence that no new American missiles, either Pershing 2 or cruise missiles, should be deployed in Europe as planned by the Western alliance. Mr. Andropov repeated that the Soviet Union would reduce its force level in Europe to match the total of French and British missiles there - some 162. But he stressed again that there could be no new American deployment. **********''Until he acknowledges that the United States has the right of parity with the Soviet Union on missiles, there will be no deal,'' the American official said.   Missiles in Asia **********The second problem, he said, dealt with the renewed American insistence that any agreement on limits on the Soviet SS-20 mobile missile system be ''universal,'' meaning that any limits be imposed not only in Europe but in the Soviet force in Asia as well. This is to prevent the Soviet Union from agreeing to tight limits on the size of its force in Europe while continuing to build new missiles in Asia, or retaining large numbers of missiles in Asia that in an emergency could be moved quickly to Europe. **********There are about 350 SS-20 missiles, each with three nuclear warheads, in the Soviet Union, of which about 250 are in the European part and the rest in Soviet Asia. **********Until Friday, the Soviet side had left open the possibility of making cuts in its European force and moving the remainder to the Asian area. Mr. Andropov said on Friday that those cut would be ''liquidated.'' The senior official said there was considerable speculation within the Administration that Mr. Andropov's remarks were only the start of what will be a concerted Soviet effort to appear increasingly forthcoming as the date for deployment of the American missiles grows near, while at the same time warning that the deployment will cause a new chill in relations.   'Seek a Delay in Deployment' **********''They will do their best to get the West Germans to seek a delay in deployment, to give more time for negotiations,'' the official said. The first deployment of some Pershing 2 missiles is to begin in West Germany, with cruise missiles to be deployed later in Britain, Italy, and West Germany, and perhaps in Belgium and the Netherlands. **********Another official said the chief American negotiator at the talks on medium-range missiles, Paul H. Nitze, has told aides in Washington that he does not expect any substantial progress until the first missiles are actually deployed and Moscow realizes it cannot prevent the step. **********In a formal comment on Mr. Andropov's latest proposal, the State Department said on Friday night: **********''We have seen the reports of General Secretary Andropov's comments. We have long asked the Soviets whether they intended to destroy missiles or merely relocate them, and have made clear that mere relocation would not be a serious arms control measure. If the Soviets were to confirm this position at the negotiating table in Geneva, we would consider it to be a positive sign.'' **********''Unfortunately, however, the Soviets continue to claim a right to match independent British and French nuclear forces,'' the department said. ''Thus there does not appear to be any change in the Soviet pursuit of an unequal outcome that would allow them to maintain most of their existing SS-20 forces while blocking NATO from deploying a U.S. deterrent to that force, and thus maintaining a Soviet monopoly in these systems.''  Talks Resume Sept. 6 **********''Moreover, the Soviets continue to seek an agreement that would be limited only to Europe,'' it said. ''The sizable Soviet SS-20 force in Asia apparently would remain unconstrained and could continue to grow, as it currently is doing. Because of the range, mobility and transportability of the SS-20, these missile would continue to pose a threat to Europe as well as Asia.'' **********The department said the United States would explore with the Russians any possibility of progress when the negotiations resume on Sept. 6 in Geneva. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz is also due to meet in Madrid that week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. They will be there for the closing ceremonies of the East- West meeting on the Helsinki security and cooperation conference. And they will meet again later next month in New York. The missile question is likely to be raised both times. **********When the negotiations on medium-range missiles began in 1981, the United States said it would cancel plans for deployment of the 572 missiles only if Moscow agreed to the destruction of all of their missiles in the same category, and added that the SS-20's had to be dismantled even if they were based in Soviet Asia. **********Earlier this year, under pressure from the European allies, the United States modified its proposal and said it would agree to a compromise by which the United States and the Soviet Union would agree to an equal number of missiles, fewer than the 572, and more than zero. American officials have said the Soviet Union has refused to discuss any compromise that would allow the United States to deploy any missiles and has also rejected the earlier proposal for the abolition of all such missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.main_headline: Diasonics Lists Changes In Fischer Acquisition
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Diasonics Lists Changes In Fischer Acquisition
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Diasonics Inc., a growing maker of high-technology medical equipment, said yesterday that Albert S. Waxman, its co-founder, would become chairman and plans to give up the presidency. **********Diasonics, of Milpitas, Calif., last week announced plans to acquire Fischer Imaging, a Denver-based maker of vascular X-ray systems. **********Terms were not disclosed. **********Fischer's current president and chief executive, Morgan Nields, will become Diasonics' president and chief operating officer upon completion of the acquisition, expected near the end of the third quarter, Diasonics said in a statement. **********Mr. Waxman, 43, will replace Arthur Rock as chairman. Mr. Rock will become chairman of the board's newly established executive committee. Mr. Rock is a San Francisco venture capitalist who helped finance Mr. Waxman. **********The company was founded five years ago to make computer-driven equipment that uses sound waves to allow physicians to see images of the body's organs. **********Diasonics, situated in California's Silicon Valley area of hightechnology companies south of San Francisco, was somewhat technologically crippled yesterday. The company was not able to take calls because a power shortage had knocked out the electricity and phone lines, according to a woman who answered a phone that was running on emergency power.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********The Swan Brewery Company Ltd. (Australia) has arranged the first speculative-grade debt offering in the United States by a foreign borrower. **********A $125 million issue of 14 7/8 percent subordinated debentures were offered yesterday through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. at a price of 99.253 to yield 15 percent to maturity. **********The debentures were rated B-2/B by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Standard & Poor's Corporation, respectively. In the past, foreign governments and Canadian utilities with investment-grade ratings have been active issuers of long-term debt in the American market, while most foreign companies have limited their borrowings to short-term commercial paper or bank loans. **********Although the debentures have a final maturity of 1998, the average life of the issue is reduced to 10 1/2 years because of sinking fund payments beginning in 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The Republic Bank of Clearwater, Fla., a seven-branch bank in upper Pinellas County, said it would distribute $1 million of stock to its employees over a 10-year period, thus becoming what it said is the first bank in the United States to be wholly owned by its employees, officers and directors. **********Republic also said it would annually donate 10 percent of its after-tax profits to community, educational and charitable instutitions. **********The bank, which earned $540,041 in 1982, on assets of $48 million at year-end, said it would give employees a total of 490 shares in the first distribution, with the number for each employee determined by seniority and job ranking. Republic has 66 employees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/world.body_text: **********President Reagan arrived here this afternoon as he began a seven-day trip to Japan and South Korea designed to strengthen economic and political ties with both countries. **********Immediately after his plane landed at Tokyo's Haneda Airport, Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, boarded a helicopter that took them to the Geihinkan, the state guest house popularly known as the Akasaka Palce. There, he was to be welcomed at a ceremony conducted by Emperor Hirohito, the 82- year-old figurehead from the vanished era of Japanese militarism. **********After an audience with the Emperor at the Imperial Palace, the President was scheduled to begin an hourlong dicussion with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. **********As he left Washington on a 15-hour flight, Mr. Reagan expressed hopes for stronger economic relations with Japan and South Korea and offered ''grim reminders'' of the Soviet Union's deployment of new missiles and its downing of a Korean civilian jetliner.   'We Live in a Dangerous World' **********''We live in a dangerous world,'' said the President, who embarked on a visit in which he will address the legislatures of both nations and visit the demiliarized zone in Korea. **********''We can foresee vastly expanding economic, political and cultural bonds with these countries,'' Mr. Reagan said during a refueling stop in Anchorage, Alaska, where he again cited the Soviet Union's ''brutal downing'' of the Korean Air Lines plane Sept. 1 in which 269 people perished. **********Balancing the themes of military security and economic equity, Mr. Reagan praised Pacific allies for their ''hard work'' and enthusiasm for technology and innovation. 'Yankee Spirit' Hailed **********''They have the Yankee spirit we once called our own,'' he told a crowd gathered at Elmendorf Air Force Base in Anchorage. ''We are in the midst of recapturing that spirit.'' **********The President, making the third major international trip of his Administration, declared as he left the White House Tuesday morning, ''Japan, Korea and America are nations of the future; we are builders of tomorrow.'' **********Mr. Reagan has been emphasizing the need for improved commercial ties, particularly with Japan, whose restrictions on American exports have stirred retaliatory pressures in Congress for greater protectionist measures. **********In an interview with Fuji Television on the eve of his departure, Mr. Reagan referred to the ''dangerous imbalance'' in trade with Japan, currently running at about $20 billion in Japan's favor. A related concern on the agenda with Prime Minister Nakasone is the state of the Japanese yen, which officials of both nations feel is undervalued.   Emphasis on Accommodation However, accommodation, not controversy, is the expected mood in the planned talks. ''We will travel a good distance, but I know we will meet with many good friends who feel close to America,'' the President said in leaving Washington. **********The trip will not produce major new agreements, according to Administration officials, but it is replete with various events that appear aimed at depicting Mr. Reagan, a presumed candidate for re-election, as an active, world- traveling President. **********The visit will offer political opportunity, too, for Mr. Nakasone, whose outspoken commitment to a stronger military posture endeared him to Mr. Reagan in earlier meetings. **********On the issue of great concern to the South Korean Government, military preparedness, President Reagan already has said, in an interview Monday with Korean journalists, that the American troop strength of 40,000 in Korea was adequate, but that it might be increased if tensions should increase. His visit to the demilitarized zone at the border with North Korea on Sunday is intended to demonstrate graphically the continued United States commitment.   Bombing Laid to North Koreans **********President Reagan has endorsed the finding of the Burmese Government that it had ''firmly established'' that the Oct. 9 bombing in Rangoon in which high-ranking South Korean officials were killed was the work of saboteurs operating on behalf of the North Korean Government. **********North Korea in turn has used some strong statements in repeatedly denouncing President Reagan's visit as ''a very dangerous war junket.'' One effect of this has been that Mr. Reagan will be escorted through Tokyo and Seoul in what will probably be the most elaborate and heavily manned security arrangements of his incumbency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/busin.body_text: **********Prices farmers get for raw products rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the third consecutive monthly increase, matching levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. Higher prices for beef cattle, tomatoes, corn, eggs and wheat were mostly responsible for the increase, but lower prices for hogs, oranges and broilers partially offset the gains for the other commodities, the department said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the 44-nation Commonwealth said today that efforts to win independence for South- West Africa were being obstructed by United States insistence that there should be a parallel withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola. **********This position was supported by Britain and Canada, which together with the United States, France and West Germany belong to a United Nations contact group that has been trying since 1977 to find a way to end South African rule over South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. **********According to Patsy Robertson, a spokesman for the Commonwealth conference here, the heads of Government and other delegates expressed ''sadness, puzzlement and a certain amount of dismay'' over what they perceived to be ''mistaken American policies based on misconceptions of the real principles at stake.'' **********Mrs. Robertson said that, in the view of the Commonwealth leaders, the American ''misconceptions'' stemmed from the ''total preoccupation'' of the United States with East-West relations. She said the participants in the conference here spoke with ''complete unanimity'' in accusing the United States of holding up progress on Namibia.   Economic Group Formed The participants decided today to establish a 10-member Commonwealth consultative group ''for the purpose of promoting consensus'' on economic issues. The group, to be drawn from both the industrialized and developing worlds, is charged with working with other international groups to help improve world economic institutions. **********''We share a common belief,'' the Commonwealth leaders said in their economic statement, ''that the Bretton Woods institutions need to be adapted and better equipped to help cope with the full magnitude of the global crisis.'' They referred to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference held at Bretton Woods, N.H., in 1944 that resulted in the creation of the International Monetary Fund to promote international monetary cooperation. **********The Commonwealth leaders suggested that a new international conference, like the one at Bretton Woods, should take place. **********Mrs. Robertson said the conference, meeting in a closed session, adopted a ''comprehensive rejection'' of the United States position on Angola and Namibia.   Britain Opposed to U.S. Stand **********Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada did not take part in today's discussions on southern Africa because he was in Peking, on another leg of an international mission he has undertaken to try to lessen East-West tensions. But Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was said to have emphasized Britain's opposition to the American stand. **********Soon after President Reagan took office in 1981, his Administration said there should be a direct linkage between South African withdrawal from South-West Africa and Cuban withdrawal from neighboring Angola.  From the start, three members of the five-nation contact group - Canada, France and to a lesser extent West Germany - questioned the wisdom of such a linkage. **********As a result of this and other criticism and of Angola's refusal to link the two steps directly, the Reagan Administration said it was seeking ''reciprocity'' instead of linkage. **********The Commonwealth conferees' position, Mrs. Robertson said, was that Cuban troops are in Angola ''at the invitation of a sovereign state to protect it from attack'' and that this has nothing to do with the question of Namibian independence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Beneath northern Alberta lies an oilman's dream: three times more oil than the Middle East has - and not a chance of drilling a dry hole. **********This is Canada's oil sands, and some companies are inching ahead in an attempt to exploit the resource despite the plunging energy prices and inflation that resulted in the cancellation or postponement of many big oil sands projects. **********At a time when conventional oil reserves are being steadily drained, the potential of Alberta's oil sands - containing more than 1,000 billion 42-gallon barrels of oil - has barely been scratched.  ''This is the future of the oil industry,'' said Randall G. Gossen, production manager here at the oil sands pilot project of Imperial Oil Ltd. **********Imperial is near a final decision on whether to proceed with a smaller oil sands project at Cold Lake than a previously abandoned ''megaproject.'' The British Petroleum Company and Petro-Canada recently announced a 7,000-barrel-a-day plant. And the oil industry is pressing ahead with plans for some 60 pilot projects. Production Costs Reduced **********Moreover, production costs have been reduced at both of Alberta's existing oil sands plants, which together account for 10 percent of Canada's petroleum production. **********At one plant Syncrude Canada Ltd., a joint venture involving private companies and the Canadian and Alberta governments, has reduced its operating cost to $19 to $20 a barrel. In some months it has been as low as $12.50. **********At the other plant Suncor Inc., a unit of the Sun Company, has overcome technical problems that previously made it an achievement just to operate continuously as long as eight hours. Both the Syncrude and Suncor projects are near Fort McMurray, Alberta. **********But future progress will not be easy. Oil from the sands is thicker than molasses, so it requires expensive upgrading if it is to be used for much besides asphalt. **********A key question is how much bitumin, as oil from the sands is called, can be sold in existing markets, mainly refineries in the northern tier of the United States. After such markets are saturated, the bitumin will have to be upgraded into much higher-quality crude oil before it can be sold. Most companies are trying to avoid the cost of upgrading it until it is absolutely required. Mining or Steam Injection **********Moreover, there are few natural underground pressures that would force the heavy oil to the surface. So it must be either mined as if it were a mineral or coaxed from the earth through such expensive techniques as steam injection. The consequence is a production cost estimated to be 20 times that of Saudi Arabia's gushers. **********''It isn't all sweetness and light getting the stuff out,'' said G.E. Courtnage, vice president of Esso Canada Resources, an Imperial subsidiary. **********Further, Alberta and other producing areas are currently unable to sell all the conventional oil they pump. Investment in alternative fuels has been sharply curbed by lower oil prices. Expectations of future price rises have diminished in magnitude, and prospects for big offshore finds overshadow oil sands, in the opinion of many analysts. **********A major result has been the cancellation or postponement of the bigger projects intended to tap the tar sands, as the deposits are sometimes called. The most prominent were Alsands, a Shell Oil project that was meant to produce 137,000 barrels of top-quality oil a day near Fort McMurray, canceled last year, and a 140,000-barrel-aday Imperial plant here that was shelved in 1981. Wary of 'Megaprojects' **********Both companies withdrew from the project because of the combination of inflation, high interest rates, plunging oil prices, shifting government policies and the immense capital cost. **********''Big is ugly - people are scared of the megaprojects,'' said Ian Doig, an independent Calgary oil analyst.  Donald K. McIvor, chairman of Imperial, recently said that carrying through the originally planned Cold Lake project, with a cost estimate that had surged to $12 billion, from $7 billion in 1977, would be equivalent to ''betting the company'' on one investment. **********Accordingly, Imperial (which is 70 percent owned by the Exxon Corporation) and other companies are responding to capital limitations by adopting more modest projects that could later be expanded. An example is the plan recently announced by British Petroleum and Petro-Canada. The companies will spend $200 million on a 7,000-barrel-a-day oil sands plant at Wolf Lake, Alberta. They expect to put $750 million more into the project over its 25-year life. **********The Wolf Lake endeavor is aided by royalty concessions from Alberta's provincial goverment and tax cuts by Ottawa. After capital in the project has been recovered plus a 10 percent return, full payments to the governments are to be reinstated. Plants to Get World Price **********In addition, the national Government is allowing all oil sands plants to receive the world price for their product, something Suncor attained only in 1981. Unlike the United States, Canada still has price controls on crude oil. **********Both the Cold Lake and Wolf Lake projects would involve pumping the heavy oil to the surface through wells. To facilitate this process, steam is injected - at first in bursts and then continuously. **********This method differs from that of Syncrude and Suncor. They use strip mining to extract the oil sands, from which the oil is then squeezed. Less than 10 percent of Canada's oil sands can be mined, while wells must be used for the rest. Of the 1,000 billion barrels of oil believed to be trapped in the sands, about one-fifth could be recovered with present technology. **********The Canada Center for Mineral and Energy Technology, a federal research arm, is now advocating smaller plants producing about 25,000 barrels a day rather than the 100,000-barrel giants previously considered necessary to take advantage of scale economies. The shorter construction time and smaller initital investment, the center calculates, mean that companies can get back their investment in 15 percent less time. Decision on Further Outlay **********Imperial will probably decide later this summer whether to spend $400 million to build 20,000 barrels of additional daily capacity.  That would be in addition to the 13,000 barrels a day now produced in a pilot project. Further 10,000 barrel-a-day increments would then follow as needed. **********But development depends on oil prices. Financially struggling Venezuela, which boasts trillions of barrels of exceptionally heavy oil, has recently postponed exploitation of its rich Orinoco oil belt as a result of declining prices. **********''If prices took another $5-a-barrel drop, it would take the fun out of it,'' Imperial's Mr. Courtnage said of the Cold Lake project.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/busin.main_headline: FIRST CHICAGO IN PACT FOR AMERICAN NATIONAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/busin.print_headline: FIRST CHICAGO IN PACT FOR AMERICAN NATIONAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The Walter E. Heller International Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its American National Corporation, owner of the American National Bank and Trust Company, to the First Chicago Corporation, owner of the First National Bank of Chicago, for $275 million. **********The sale would leave the Heller organization with an estimated $490 million in cash or cash equivalents but no operating companies. It would also narrow the gap between Chicago's two largest banks. **********American National, with assets exceeding $3 billion, is the fifth-largest bank in Chicago, while First National, with $35 billion in assets, ranks second. The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, remains on top with assets of $41 billion. **********Heller stock yesterday closed down 50 cents, to $31.125, while First Chicago stock was unchanged at $24.50, both on the New York Stock Exchange. Liquidation Urged **********Earlier in the year, before Heller had begun disposing of its holdings, the Orion Capital Corporation of New York, as a big stockholder, had been urging the company to sell the bank. Two months ago, after Heller agreed to sell its two finance companies to Fuji Bank Ltd. for $425 million, Orion again urged Heller to sell the bank and then liquidate the company. **********Orion recently sold its 778,200 shares, or 6.5 percent, in Heller to the Belzberg family of Canada for $31.25 a share, or $24.3 million, nearly double its cost of $17.50 a share. The Belzbergs have interests in finance and real estate, and said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they wanted the Heller shares for investment. More Market Penetration **********Barry F. Sullivan, 52 years old, chairman and chief executive of First Chicago and First National, said in an interview that his bank already dealt with medium-sized corporations with sales approaching $500 million a year. ''This gives us much more penetration,'' he said, ''with companies having sales between $5 million and $115 million a year.'' **********Earlier, in a news conference in Chicago, Mr. Sullivan said that his company had also bid for the troubled First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago but had not yet heard from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which invited bids earlier in the year. Other bidders for First Federal are understood to include Citicorp of New York and Sears, Roebuck & Company of Chicago. **********On completion of the Fuji and First Chicago ventures, Heller would have $700 million in cash, plus an estimated $30 million in earnings from its holdings until the deals are closed next year. After deducting $240 million in debts, Heller would have about $490 million remaining, or the equivalent of about $35 a share on the basis of Heller's 14 million shares. No Decision on Liquidation **********Robert L. Meyers, treasurer of Heller, said, ''Heller hasn't announced whether it will liquidate and give the stockholders a final dividend or redeploy the cash into other assets.'' **********Once the Fuji deal is completed, it said, Heller plans to change its name to the Amerifin Corporation. American National would continue to operate as a separate bank under its own name.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/29/busin.body_text: **********The Osborne Computer Corporation, which pioneered the market for portable personal computers, said that it had reduced the price of its most basic machine in a move some analysts said reflected further cash-flow problems at the company. **********The company said that the Osborne 1 machine, which retailed for $1,995, would be reduced immediately to $1,295. **********''We once were all alone in this business and now have several competitors,'' said Mike Sanchez, a company spokesman. ''We want to shake up the market again, like we did when we introduced the machine.'' **********''The company has lost substantial market share to Kaypro and others,'' said David S. Lawrence, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. He was referring to the Kaypro Corporation, which markets a popular portable. **********The company has also reportedly been hurt by the recent chaos in the low end of the computer market, which has hit Warner Communication's Atari unit and Texas Instruments Inc. most severely.  Both companies recently reported record losses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.main_headline: Dow Retreats 5.67, to 1,087.43; Other Major Indicators Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.print_headline: Dow Retreats 5.67, to 1,087.43; Other Major Indicators Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.body_text: **********Despite some encouraging economic news, the stock market yesterday ended moderately lower in slower trading as investors cashed in some of their recent gains. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the day, closed down 5.67 points to 1,087.43. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that rose by 927 to 671. **********On Tuesday, the blue-chip barometer, comprising 30 prominent companies, dropped 4 points after having edged above the 1,100 level briefly. It was the second time this year that the Dow average had penetrated the 1,100 level and then closed below it. The Dow ended at a record 1,097.10 on Monday, and since mid-August the average has soared more than 300 points. Early Gains on Output Report **********The market opened higher yesterday when the Government reported that industrial production in January rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, its biggest gain in almost a year. **********Shortly thereafter, in testimony before Congress, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated that the Fed was leaning toward lower interest rates. That further strengthened stock prices for a short period, but by 11:30 A.M., when the Dow was ahead more than 4 points, prices began easing. **********''The market needs a blockbuster announcement, such as a discount rate cut, before it breaks through 1,100 for any length of time,'' commented Larry Wachtel, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The discount rate - what the Fed charges its member banks for loans - has been 8 1/2 percent since Dec.13. **********Robert Grossman, portfolio strategist of Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company, was more optimistic. He said that the Dow average should continue to advance to over the 1,100 level soon, with the recently strong technology issues leading the upswing. **********Turnover on the Big Board yesterday contracted to 82.1 million shares, from 89 million shares on Tuesday. Other Major Indicators Retreat **********The two other major market indicators, which set new highs on Monday, also finished lower for the second consecutive day. The Big Board's composite index of 1,500 common shares was down 0.50, to 85.18, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 0.87, to 147.43. **********However, in the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index closed at a new high of 259.07, up 0.01. On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 0.94, to 383.78, after making a new closing high on Tuesday. **********Warner Communications, the volume leader on the Big Board yesterday, fell 2 3/8 points, to 29 1/8, on a turnover of 1.6 million shares. The company reported a decline in its fourth-quarter profits and said its first-half net this year ''will fall far short of the results of the year before first half.'' **********Among the weaker technology issues, Teledyne lost 2 1/2, to 148 1/2; Digital Equipment was off 2, to 123 3/4; Hewlett-Packard 2 3/8, to 83 3/8, and Texas Instruments 1 5/8, to 168 3/8. **********The big gainer in the over-the-counter market was Homestead Financial, which climbed 5 3/4 points, to 26 bid. The company said that it expects its first-quarter profits to be much higher than in the period last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.main_headline: UGANDAN GENERAL DIES IN AIR CRASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.print_headline: UGANDAN GENERAL DIES IN AIR CRASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.body_text: **********The Chief of Staff of the Ugandan Army, a confidant of President Milton Obote, has been killed in a helicopter crash, the Uganda radio reported today. **********A spokesman for a guerrilla group, the National Resistance Army, said its forces had shot down the helicopter, but the report could not be confirmed. **********A statement signed by Vice President Paulo Muwanga, who is also the Defense Minister, announced the death of Maj. Gen. David Oyite Ojok in a broadcast. The state-run radio, monitored here, then canceled scheduled programs and broadcast solemn music. **********The radio said the crash occurred Friday night and killed five other army officers and three unidentified people. It gave no further details. **********General Ojok, who was believed to be 49 years old, was widely regarded as a potential successor to Mr. Obote. Mr. Obote was returning today from a Commonwealth meeting in New Delhi. **********General Ojok was the No. 2 man in the Ugandan military, under Lieut. Gen. Tito Okello. He was a graduate of Britain's Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst and was a senior military officer when Idi Amin seized power from Mr. Obote in January 1971.   Role in Ousting Idi Amin **********In the ensuing dictatorship, General Ojok lived in neighboring Tanzania. He spearheaded a force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian regular troops that ousted the dictator in April 1979. **********A guerrilla spokesman said in a telephone call to a reporter in Nairobi that rebels shot down the helicopter as it flew from Bombo army barracks, about 20 miles north of Kampala, to the capital. **********Besides General Ojok, the guerrilla spokesman said, the helicopter was carrying the chief of military intelligence, a major named Agwa, and the commanders of the Bombo and Kampala army barracks. He had no names for those officers. **********The rebel group is the most active in Uganda. It is led by Yoweri Mseveni, who was Defense Minister in interim administrations after Idi Amin was ousted. **********Last September Mr. Mseveni's guerrillas said they had shot down a Ugandan military helicopter near Kampala. There has been no confirmation of the report. **********Since February 1981 Mr. Obote has been faced with a threat from guerrilla groups that say he rigged the 1980 elections with the connivance of Tanzanian forces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.main_headline: THE RUSSIAN'S JOY AND ANGUISH OF CAR OWNERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.print_headline: THE RUSSIAN'S JOY AND ANGUISH OF CAR OWNERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.body_text: **********Family motorists hitting the road are a certain sign that the Russian summer has arrived.  After winter hibernation in storage parks, swarms of small cars emerge from covers of plastic, canvas or cardboard to undergo preparations for the open road. **********Readying a Zhiguli, Moskvich or Zaporozhets for a trip to the dacha can be taxing. With spare parts in pitifully short supply, replacing items that have been pilfered can take weeks of hunting, often ending only with the payment of a bribe. Cars that have survived the winter intact must be cleaned and tuned lest they fall foul of regulations authorizing police officers to pull dirty or noisy vehicles off the road. **********Hazards on the Highway **********On the highway, there are fresh problems. Police officers lurk in every hollow with the scourge of Soviet drivers, the pocket holepunch. Jumping a light, speeding or giving the officer an argument can result in a license's immediate perforation. After three punches the license is seized, obliging the offender to spend months requalifying at driver's school. **********About 50,000 people die in accidents every year, which is more than the 1982 traffic death toll in the United States, where there are many times more vehicles. Even major highways are strewn with potholes after the six-month winter, and long stretches lack even a center line. Road signs are erratic, and routinely ignored. Drunks staggering into the road are a hazard day and night. **********It's small wonder Russian drivers say that owning a car brings joy twice in an owner's life - when it is picked up and when it is sold.  In between, they say, there is only torture. **********The travails are the greater for the passion that attaches to driving. Mass production of private cars was virtually unknown until the 1970's, and the result has been car craze of the kind that flourished among Americans in the days of the Model T. Even now output runs at barely 1.4 million cars a year, about one-sixth of the Detroit figure; and a third of these are exported, the bulk to Eastern Europe. Languishing on the Waiting List **********At least two million people languish on the waiting list. Full payment is demanded in advance, and delivery can take years. For many the only shortcut is a bribe, sometimes as cash payment that can double prohibitive sticker prices. **********The most expensive of the six basic models on the market, the Volga, a four-cylinder sedan about the size of a midsize Ford, runs about 15,000 rubles, more than $20,000 at the official rate of exchange. The most popular, the Zhiguli, a copy of a 10-year-old Fiat 124, comes in four versions that start at $9,000. The cheapest model, a Zaporozhets, about the size of an English Mini, costs $5,700. **********At prevailing wage rates, an industrial worker would have to commit about 43 months' cash income to buy a top-of-the-line Zhiguli, about 10 times as much as his American counterpart would have to put toward a comparable car. Nor does he have any assurance that the vehicle delivered will be in sound running order, as the volume of outraged letters to the Soviet newspapers attests. **********Readers writing to Sotsialisticheskaya Industriya told last year of new cars that had to be towed off the lot because of missing batteries, improperly assembled gearboxes and other woes. One Zaporozhets owner told how he had had his new car replaced on the warranty twice, but had not turned a wheel in four years because of defects. 'A Pig in a Poke' **********A man described the scene as his wait for a new Zhiguli ended: ''After filling out the documents, the store officials wheeled the car out and said, 'Take it away.' The car was filthy, and even from a cursory inspection it was not ready for delivery, some parts being missing. When I asked why the pre-sale service had not been carried out, they made fun of me and advised me to take it as it was, or others would take it. Our family saved money for many years and bought a pig in a poke.'' **********Obtaining parts is a nightmare. The state runs a network of special over-the-counter stores, but the hoarding of parts for black market sale causes most of the supplies to be re-directed to the service centers run by manufacturers, where customers are supposed to prove their need for an item. **********This creates new opportunities for unscrupulous service mechanics, who take payoffs of up to 10 times the state price to ''find'' a needed part in the stores or charge a fee to move customers' cars to the head of the line. An owner can wait months for attention.  Although the number of mechanics has increased from 6,000 to 10,000 in a decade, the number of private cars has risen even more swiftly, to 8.5 million, and service centers are swamped. **********One official estimated that 5 of every 10 cars are fixed ''on the side'' by free enterprise repairmen operating illicitly in backstreet garages, usually with stolen parts. **********Customers who persist at the official centers risk having their vehicles cannibalized by mechanics who substitute faulty parts for good ones, a practice so common that most centers now itemize removable objects before accepting a machine for service. One Moscow official estimated that less than a quarter of the demand for the most frequently needed Zhiguli parts can be met from state supplies.  The balance must be made up by the street-corner market in stolen parts, most of them taken from parked cars. Pride in Washing and Polishing **********For all their troubles, dedicated motorists outnumber those who sell their cars. With public transport erratic and overloaded, private cars have given new freedom to families looking for a weekend in the country or a picnic at a secluded spot out of town. **********In the spring it is common to see squads of Zhigulis and Moskviches lined up by a lake or a river as proud owners wash and polish them to an impressive shine. But the motorist can never relax. If he escapes the attentions of the police he has to keep a wary eye on other drivers, whose rudeness is a subject of frequent criticism in the press. ''Drivers, fenced off from the rest of the world, are becoming less sensitive to others of their kind, and to everything living,'' Sovetskaya Rossiya complained last year. **********The paper suggested that many problems could be averted by restricting drivers' licenses to ''good decent people,'' but it added disconsolately that the idea, though just, was perhaps naive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/busin.body_text: **********The production capacity of the nation's steel industry is likely to shrink at least 10 percent over the next two or three years, analysts say. The first of a new wave of plant closings and write-offs, they predict, will be announced by the United States Steel Corporation later this month. **********In addition, the company resulting from the proposed merger of the Republic Steel Corporation and the LTV Corporation, the parent of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, is expected to close several major facilities early next year. **********Industry analysts, steel company executives and even union officials say the industry will cut back to reduce costs and make domestic steel more competitive with lower-cost imports. The domestic industry is still operating at less than 60 percent of capacity, even though the economic recovery is a year old. **********Cut of 15 or 20 Million Tons **********''The big thing that's going to happen in the next few years is the industry's restructuring,'' said Peter L. Anker, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation. ''I think that 15 or 20 million tons will be cut in the next three years.'' **********According to the American Iron and Steel Institute, domestic steelmaking capacity totals 153 million tons of raw steel. Many analysts say, however, that because of such recent moves as Armco's shutdown of its Houston Works and the closing of facilities in Lackawanna, N.Y., by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the capacity is actually more than 10 million tons below that figure. **********For months, officials from U.S. Steel, the nation's largest steelmaker, have said they are studying a reconfiguration of their operations and will announce their decisions in the fourth quarter. **********Analyst Meeting Put Off **********Speculation that large write-offs will be announced later this month increased last week when U.S. Steel postponed until after the year-end a meeting with financial analysts that was scheduled for today. The company said it wanted to hold the meeting only after its restructuring decisions are disclosed. **********John C. Tumazos, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, predicts that U.S. Steel will announce as much as $1 billion in write-offs after its board meeting, tentatively scheduled for Dec. 27. The anticipated write- offs, analysts said, would be the company's largest since it shut 13 facilities and laid off 13,000 workers in 1979. **********Mr. Tumazos said that with U.S. Steel opening a state-of-the-art pipe mill in Fairfield, Ala., it will likely shut its 2.9 million-ton-a-year National Duquesne Works in Duquesne and McKeesport, Pa. **********Tin Can Market **********With tin plate capacity far above demand because of aluminum's erosion of the tin can market, Mr. Tumazos and other analysts predict the company will permanently write off its already shut tin mill and possibly other facilities at its Fairfield Works. **********Although U.S. Steel now says there is a good chance it will build a much postponed rail mill at its South Works in Chicago - that is, if it wins further government aid and union concessions - Mr. Tumazos and other analysts say the company will still write off the South Works' 2.2-million-ton- a-year basic oxygen furnaces and its plate and structural finishing mills. **********Frank Valenta, director of the Cleveland district of the United Steelworkers of America, said the company will likely close its Cuyahoga Works in Cleveland, where rod and flat-rolled steel are made. He said company officials told him that they would close the mill unless the union accepted further concessions. According to Mr. Valenta, the plant's 500 workers have voted against new concessions. **********'A Lost Year' **********''I'll be very surprised if they don't move this quarter to take their write- offs,'' said Charles A. Bradford, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, about U.S. Steel. ''The industry sees 1983 as a lost year, so they figure they might as well take their write-offs now and look forward to an improved 1984.'' **********A U.S. Steel spokesman declined to say which facilities, if any, the company plans to close. Nor would he say whether there will be an announcement later this month about his company's efforts to import 3 million tons of semifinished slabs a year from Britain for its mill in Fairless, Pa. **********Analysts also predicted that if the Department of Justice and shareholders approve the proposed merger of Republic Steel and LTV, the merged company will soon move to close inefficient or redundant facilities. **********Peter F. Marcus, an analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, predicts that the merged company will reduce its capacity to 19 million tons, from 24 million.   Likely Targets **********The most likely targets for permanent write-offs, analysts say, are Jones & Laughlin's mill in Alquippa, Pa., which makes flat-rolled products, and Republic's Buffalo mill, which makes bars. **********Another facility that many analysts predict will be written off is the pipe mill that the National Steel Corporation, now a subsidiary of National Intergroup Inc., built in Liberty, Tex., in 1976 at a cost of $60 million. A spokesman said National is looking to sell the already closed mill, but with pipe demand as depressed as it is, analysts said the company may not be able to find a buyer. **********Edmund Ayoub, chief economist for the steelworkers union, agreed that capacity will be cut because of the industry's low operating rate. He said dropoffs in domestic production have been caused by downsizing of automobiles, greater use of aluminum and thinner steel in automobiles and increased imports of steel and of goods that contain steel. **********Sharp Reduction in Employment **********Shipments of finished steel by domestic steelmakers dropped from 100 million tons in 1979 to 61.6 million last year, with industry employment plummeting from 453,000 to 289,000 during that time. Shipments are expected to be 68 million tons this year and 78 million next year. In the United States, 100 tons of raw steel produce on the average 80 tons of finished steel. **********''The prospects for substantially improving shipments are unlikely,'' said Mr. Ayoub, ''unless there is a major capital goods boom or massive investment in the nation's infrastructure, neither of which appears to be in the offing.'' Like the American Iron and Steel Institute, his union supports a temporary quota on imports to protect the industry so it can modernize and compete better with foreign producers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/busin.main_headline: STATUS OF NEW YORK TENANTS' RIGHTS TO SUBLET IS HAZY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; STATUS OF NEW YORK TENANTS' RIGHTS TO SUBLET IS HAZY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/busin.body_text: **********A recent decision in a New York sublet case seems to have added to the confusion over who the courts believe should have the right to control the choice of new occupants when tenants move out of rental apartments. **********In the case, called Vance v. Century Apartments Associates, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court appears to have stepped away from the view that the applicable state statute, known as Section 226b, confers broad powers upon tenants to select their successor tenants through a sublease or assignment. **********The purpose of Section 226b, the majority in the Vance case said last week, was to prevent a landlord from withholding consent ''to a legitimately proposed assignment or sublease to a financially responsible assignee or subtenant.'' The law's purpose, it added, ''was not to create a new class of landlord.'' **********But an earlier Appellate Division ruling, in Conrad v. Third Sutton Realty, opened the door to that very result in the opinion of many apartment owners and managers. Apparently either a test case will have to reach the Court of Appeals or the Legislature will have to act before it becomes clear to tenants and owners alike just how far tenants' rights go. **********In a sublet, the prime tenant retains all rights in the apartment.  In an assignment, the prime tenant yields those rights to the assignee. **********Part of Section 226b says: ''A tenant renting a residence in a dwelling having four or more residential units shall have the right to sublease or assign his premises, subject to the written consent of the landlord given in advance of the sublease or assignment. Such consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. If the landlord unreasonably withholds consent for such sublease or assignment, the landlord must release the tenant from the lease upon request of the tenant.'' **********The law also states the procedure and timing for all of this to be done. **********The Legislature approved Section 226b in 1975. For years landlords interpreted it to mean that, if they denied a tenant's request for a sublease or assignment, the tenant was merely released from his obligations under the lease without penalty. But, it was thought, the tenant could not proceed to sublet or assign without consent. **********Then came the Conrad case. The building's owner, Third Sutton Realty, denied consent to sublet but did not say why. The court found that its failure to provide reasons for rejection amounted to consent. It even described Section 226b as intended to give tenants ''a valuable right and asset, to offset an owner's ability to obtain vacancies for the purpose of reletting.'' Later lower court decisions extended the Conrad philosophy to assignments as well as sublets. **********But what are ''reasonable'' grounds for rejection? That has yet to be established. In one case, Kreitman v. Einy, the Appellate Division ruled that the existence of a waiting list for an apartment is not reasonable ground to deny a tenant the right to assign his lease. **********If the Kreitman case or any similar case gets to the Court of Appeals, it may become the vehicle for more definitive judicial guidance. It could also give the state's highest court an opportunity to distinguish between sublets and assignments in deciding when it is reasonable for an owner to withhold consent. The two are quite different relationships because an assignment creates a new prime tenant, while a sublet does not. **********Finally, the Court of Appeals might clarify the tenant's remedy if he is refused permission to sublet or assign.  The issues are particularly pertinent because of cooperative conversions. Many prime tenants who want to move may try to sublet their apartment, mainly to preserve their right to buy at the favorable insider's price if there is a co-op conversion. **********In the Vance case, Patrick Vance and his wife, Connie, sought permission through a lawyer to sublet their apartment at 25 Central Park West for a term 15 days shorter than the term of their lease while they moved to a larger apartment in Pelham, N.Y. **********The landlord rejected the request, saying there was no reason to believe the Vances ever intended to reoccupy the apartment or had any intention of maintaining it as their primary residence. It ''would appear that they are trying to keep a connection with this apartment, for reasons known only to themselves, perhaps for reasons of financial gain,'' the landlord said. **********The Appellate Division majority that found for the landlord consisted of Presiding Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr., Theodore R.  Kupferman and Fritz W. Alexander. The dissenters were Justices Arnold L. Fein and Bentley Kassal. Justice Kassal, in his dissent, said the statute clearly gives the tenant the right to sublet regardless of whether he intends to maintain the apartment as his primary residence in the future. **********The landlord in the case was represented by Jeffrey R. Metz of Finkelstein, Borah, Schwartz, Altschuler & Goldstein. The tenant was represented by Menachim J. Kastner of Parker, Chapin, Flattau & Klimpl.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.main_headline: 4 REFINERS TO PAY $1 LESS FOR OIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.print_headline: 4 REFINERS TO PAY $1 LESS FOR OIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.body_text: **********One major oil company and several smaller ones yesterday announced dollar-a-barrel reductions in the prices they will pay for domestic crude. Analysts said other major refiners could join the move within a week, in the second round of price cuts in less than a month. **********The move was touched off by Texaco USA, a division of Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company. The company announced in Houston that it had lowered its buying prices by $1 for all domestic crude purchased in Texas, New Mexico, Louisiana, Kansas and Illinois. The price cut, the second such reduction since Feb.1, put the price for West Texas Intermediate Sweet at $30 a barrel. **********Following the Texaco announcement, the Phillips Petroleum Company, Husky Oil Ltd. and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said they were also reducing the prices they would pay for crude by a dollar. Part of Global Pattern **********The announcements underscored the downward pressure on the price of oil worldwide. With demand weak and members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in disarray over production policies, refiners have been purchasing much of their oil on the spot market, where crude continues to be sold at a substantial discount from OPEC's basic level of $34 a barrel for Saudi Light. **********In telephone interviews, spokesmen for several other major oil companies, including Exxon, Mobil and Gulf Oil, said they had not lowered their prices and for competitive reasons would not comment on possible future decisions. **********The first wave of price cutting, which reflects continued weak demand for heating oil as well as seasonally low demand for gasoline, was started by the Gulf Oil Corporation on Jan.31, when the company cut its prices by a dollar. Within days, the rest of the industry followed. Pressures on Profits **********''Product prices have been slipping,'' said Adam Sieminski, an energy specialist at the Washington Analysis Corporation, a subsidiary of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., ''and unless crude oil prices drop, there will be more red ink spilled all over the refining industry.'' **********There is a ''good chance,'' Mr. Sieminski said, ''that the other companies are also feeling the same bottom-line pressures, and could follow Texaco's lead within a week or so.'' **********Reaction in the oil futures markets was muted, according to Maureen Lynch, director of research at the New York Mercantile Exchange. The prices of heating oil and gasoline contracts for delivery in March rose slightly, but prices on contracts with later delivery dates declined.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.main_headline: LIBYA ACCUSES U.S. SHIPS AND PLANES OF JAMMING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.print_headline: LIBYA ACCUSES U.S. SHIPS AND PLANES OF JAMMING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.body_text: **********The Libyan Government of Col. Muammar el-Q@addafi charged today that United States espionage planes and warships were jamming Libyan communications. It said the Gulf of Sidra would become a bay of ''blood and fire'' if the carrier Nimitz from the Sixth Fleet entered its waters. **********The Tripoli Government also said Libyan jet fighters intercepted and forced a foreign plane to withdraw from skies over Libyan waters Wednesday. It denied American and Sudanese charges that Libya was massing jets and troops near the Sudan's borders. **********Libya's official press agency, in a broadcast monitored here, said thousands of Libyans took to the streets today to protest military ''provocations'' by the United States. **********The United States sent four Airborne Warning and Control System craft to Egypt this week because of concern over apparent Libyan military threats toward the Sudan. The decision coincided with the movement of the Nimitz toward Libya. Reagan Administration officials said Friday that two Libyan MIG-23's were chased away from the carrier by its F-14's. **********The Libyan press agency said that demonstrations occurred in Tripoli, Benghazi, Tobruk, Sebha, Kufra, Jaghbub, Derna, Misurata and Sirte, and that protesters burned pictures and effigies of President Reagan, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan. **********The broadcast by the Libyan agency said the protesters were angry over the ''overt terroristic provocations of the U.S. Sixth Fleet.'' The press agency said United States Navy vessels and Awacs started ''jamming civil communications'' in Libya on Friday. It gave no other details. **********The Libyan dispatch said that on Wednesday ''an aerial target made an incursion over our territorial water 80 kilometers from the city of Benghazi, but our air force intecepted it and forced it to retreat.'' Eighty kilometers is about 50 miles. **********Benghazi is on the coast of the Gulf of Sidra, a wide bay in the southern Mediterranean that Libya calls its own but that the United States considers international water. **********Two jets from the Nimitz downed two Libyan fighters over the gulf in August 1981 after the Libyan planes fired missiles at them.  The Libyan press agency gave no further details of the latest encounter and did not specify the nationality of the aircraft. But it seemed likely the Libyans were referring to an American plane since the dispatch dealt solely with what it called ''U.S. aggression'' over the gulf.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve System yesterday reported a $300 million rise in the basic measure of the nation's money supply for the week ended July 13, a development that surprised the financial markets and caused a surge in interest rates. A drop of about $1 billion had been expected. **********Some economists predicted that the spurt in interest rates by more than a tenth of a percentage point for some short-term securities would lead to an increase in prime rates at banks, on which loans to most businesses are based. **********A higher prime rate ''would not be surprising,'' said Charles Lieberman, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''We did get Marty Feldstein's blessing for it.'' Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, testified before Congress this week that an increase in the prime rate might be warranted. The prime rate currently stands at 10 1/2 percent. **********Watching Federal Funds **********''If the Federal funds rate gets above 9 1/2 percent, and if it hits 10 percent on any day, that might be enough to push up the prime,'' said Edward H. Boss Jr., vice president and economist of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. **********The rate on Federal funds, which are overnight funds that banks trade among themselves, is the rate that is most directly affected by Federal Reserve policy. Changes in the Federal funds rate often foreshadow movements in other interest rates. **********When the money supply grows more rapidly than desired by the Fed, the central bank often reduces the amount of money available to the markets, driving up the Federal funds rate. Markets Chagrined **********For that reason, the money markets were chagrined by the Fed announcement yesterday. The Government's 30-year bond dropped more than a point in price following the money supply announcement, to 89.22 from 90.27. That was on top of a steep decline earlier in the day. The full day's decline from Thursday amounted to almost 2 1/4 points. **********Short-term rates also climbed sharply following the Fed announcement. The rate on three-month Treasury bills rose 14 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 9.25 percent, and six-month bills rose 14 basis points, to 9.36 percent. **********The reaction was not only to the $300 million increase in the basic money supply, but also to an upward revision of $200 million for the previous reported week, ended July 6. That made last week's money supply increase $6 billion instead of $5.8 billion. **********M-1, the basic money supply, is supposed to reflect money that is readily available for spending. It consists of currency in circulation and balances in check-like accounts in banks and savings institutions. **********Earlier in the year, M-1 grew far more quickly than the Federal Reserve had wanted, and this week Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, announced that a new base had been established for money growth, because any attempt to bring M-1 into line with the original targets would have imperiled the economic recovery. Mr. Volcker also said that the growth rate for M-1 would be widened to a range of between 5 percent and 9 percent, up from a range of between 4 percent and 8 percent. Some Bankers Are Unruffled **********Some economists said they thought the markets had overreacted to the money supply figures. Cengiz Israfil, for example, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said that Mr. Volcker, in his testimony before Congress, had stated that the Fed would deemphasize M-1 in formulating policy. ''There seems to be no further tightening from what already had been announced,'' Mr. Israfil said. **********Under the new targets, M-1 can rise by somewhat more than $800 million a week. Thus, with the $300 million rise announced yesterday, the money supply, at $514.6 billion, is only $2.4 billion above its new target, Mr. Israfil said. 'Pleasant Surprises' **********And Philip Braverman, vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, predicted that ''there will be pleasant surprises announced on Monday that should temper today's bearishness in the money markets.'' **********Mr. Braverman said that the Administration will announce that, because of the stronger-than-expected economic recovery, the budget deficit will be smaller than predicted and that Government borrowings this quarter would be $5 billion below the $55 billion that had been expected. Lower borrowing demands by the Government relieve pressures in the credit markets and can lead to lower interest rates.
