Reliance is a private company owned by Saul P. Steinberg. **********The agreement provides for a newly created Reliance subsidiary to make a cash tender offer for any and all shares by thisFriday and to merge with Pargas following completion of the tender offer. **********Pargas said its board had terminated an agreement with Forstmann Little & Company for the acquisition of Pargas for $35 a share in cash. **********Pargas also announced that it had entered into an agreement to sell its coal unit to a group of individuals for $30 million in cash.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/busin.body_text: **********A committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is to meet here Thursday to discuss the group's apparent inability to keep its oil output within self-imposed limits. **********The market monitoring committee said at its last meeting in September that the world oil market was not strong enough to permit OPEC to exceed an output ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day set last March. **********The committee was concerned that the excess output was going into oil company reserves and did not reflect an increase in consumer demand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/world.body_text: **********West Germany's Green Party concluded a two-day convention today by confirming that its opposition to the deployment of American medium-range missiles will be the main plank in its platform for parliamentary elections in March. **********Petra Kelly, the American-educated Green leader, announced to loud applause that she would hold a ''war crimes tribunal'' next month in her parliamentary constituency of Nuremberg to condemn the United States, the Soviet Union and other nuclear powers for possessing ''first-strike weapons.'' **********Miss Kelly said she had invited survivors of the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz and Japanese who lived through the American bombing of Hiroshima. ''We want no military pacts!'' shouted Miss Kelly, who like other Greens would like to see West Germany leave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********Rock Banks to Aid Greens **********A major asset to the Green campaign was unveiled Saturday when Udo Lindenberg, a highly popular rock singer, said that he and other ''big bands'' would work for the Greens. **********''Then I hope that when we get into the Bundestag on March 6 we can make a lot of music,'' said Mr. Lindenberg. A series of antinuclear rock concerts for the Greens will wind through West Germany as the campaign picks up. **********Conscious that their last party convention in November descended into procedural disorder that harmed their image, the mostly youthful Greens made an effort in Sindelfingen, a town nine miles southwest of Stuttgart, to impose discipline on their discussions. **********A group known as the Indian Commune who believe children should not be educated were gently eased out of the range of television cameras, and long-winded orators were frequently called to order. Pledges to Working Class **********With public-opinion polls showing the Greens close to the 5 percent of the vote that would put them in the Parliament, they were eager to demonstrate to skeptical working-class voters that their ecological, no-growth views will do something about unemployment. **********On the economics debate, as on other matters, the rising influence of Marxist groups that have moved into the Green Party was perceptible. These ''traditional'' leftists, who are particularly strong in Hamburg and West Berlin, have moved the Greens away from the almost anarchist view that combating unemployment is wrong because it strengthens the capitalist order. **********Thomas Ebermann, the Greens' Hamburg chief, forcefully persuaded the overflowing auditorium to adopt positions that would permit the Greens to compete with the entrenched West German trade unions. **********The Greens' deepest electoral concern is that the Social Democratic Party under Hans-Jochen Vogel is moving so swiftly in their direction, notably on ecological matters and missile deployment, that they could be pushed under the 5 percent vote cutoff. Criticism of Social Democrats **********Rainer Trampert, another Hamburg leftist who is a party spokesman, warned that Mr. Vogel was out to steal the Greens' issues and voters. He said sarcastically that the Social Democrats' historic role had been ''to gather in opposition elements in order to better lead bourgeois society.'' **********But other Greens, many of whom at times hanker for the apocalyptic collapse of industrial society, charged that leftists like Mr.  Trampert were leading the party in the direction of eventual cooperation with the Social Democrats in Parliament. **********Should no party win a majority in March, the Greens are against supporting a Social Democratic minority government unless Mr. Vogel agrees to reject the NATO missiles and take steps toward dismantling West Germany's nuclear-energy system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.main_headline: A TOP ANGOLAN IS SAID TO MEET SHULTZ IN U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.print_headline: A TOP ANGOLAN IS SAID TO MEET SHULTZ IN U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.body_text: **********The highest-ranking Angolan official to visit Washington held an unpublicized meeting this afternoon with Secretary of State George P. Shultz to discuss South Africa's occupation of South-West Africa and the presence of Cuban troops in Angola, Administration officials said. **********The officials said the visitor, Lieut. Col. Manuel Alexandre Rodrigues, held talks with State Department officials and might meet Vice President Bush on Thursday or Friday. Colonel Rodrigues, who is Interior Minister, is regarded as the No.2 man in Angola. **********The United States and Angola have no diplomatic relations, and the possibility of establishing ties after a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola was also discussed in the last few days, officials said. **********Minimum of Publicity **********This is the 11th round of Angolan-American talks in two years, officials said, and the first in Washington. Other sessions have been held in Luanda, the Angolan capital, at the United Nations and in other cities abroad.  Like this round, they have been held with a minimum of publicity. **********The last session, between Colonel Rodrigues and Frank G. Wisner, the Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs, was held on March 15 and 16 in Paris. **********The Angolans asked the United States then to hold the next meeting in Washington. This led to hope within the State Department, officials said, that Colonel Rodrigues would carry with him a detailed proposal for parallel Cuban and South African withdrawals as a way of ending the stalemate. 25,000 Cubans in Angola **********But the officials said the Angolan had not made such a proposal.  He has indicated in conversations, however, that Angolan officials understand that it will be impossible to achieve the independence of South-West Africa, commonly known as Namibia, unless there is an agreement on some kind of parallel action to end the presence of the 25,000 Cubans in Angola and the 15,000 South Africans in Namibia. **********The United States has also told Angola that until there is agreement on troop withdrawals, it will not be possible to normalize relations between Washington and Luanda. **********The United States and four other Western nations - Britain, Canada, France and West Germany - have been negotiating with Angola and South Africa on conditions for the independence of Namibia within the framework of United Nations Security Council Resolution 435. **********That resolution calls for a cease-fire, South Africa's withdrawal from the territory, the deployment of United Nations forces and observers, and elections. **********The South Africans, backed by the United States, have said they will not leave Namibia until they are sure the Cubans have left neighboring Angola. The United States, which backed the losing side in the 1975 Angolan civil war, has also made the withdrawal of Cuban forces a condition for diplomatic ties. **********The Angolans have repeatedly rejected any formal attempts at directly linking the South African withdrawal from Namibia with the Cuban withdrawal from Angola. The Angolans have noted that the Security Council resolution said nothing about the Cubans. An Understanding Reported **********But American officials said that although there was no direct link, the Angolans had made it clear that they understood there had to be a parallel withdrawal during roughly the same time period for there to be an accord. **********Mr. Shultz, at a news conference on Tuesday, said, ''We and others have been working long and hard to bring about an independent Namibia, and we find that in order to do that - it is obviously not an integrated part of the negotiation - but in order to bring it off, we have to see some sort of program for the withdrawal of foreign forces, Cuban forces in this case, from the area so that South Africa will have confidence that it is not being surrounded or having on its borders the Soviet proxy forces.'' Cloaked in Secrecy **********Colonel Rodrigues's trip here has been cloaked in secrecy. Upon arrival in New York last weekend he was taken to a house in suburban Connecticut for preliminary talks with American officials, and then flown to Washington. His meeting with Mr. Shultz was not on the Secretary's official schedule. **********First word of his presence in this country came from a dispatch by Agence France-Presse from Luanda that was confirmed by State Department officials when reporters asked about the article. **********According to American officials, Colonel Rodrigues is the senior Angolan official in charge of the security forces, and is the principal liaison with the Cubans. He also has been in charge of the talks with the United States and has been involved in the recent talks between Angola and South Africa on establishing a cease-fire. **********Only President Jose Eduardo dos Santos is regarded as more important in Angola than Colonel Rodrigues, officials said.  American officials refused to predict today if the sides were any closer to an agreement. One official said he thought the Administration was overly optimistic in the past about an early accord, and it would be better now to avoid setting any more target dates. Last year senior officials predicted a breakthrough by the end of 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/26/busin.body_text: **********The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's larget steelmaker, reported yesterday that it lost $363 million in the fourth quarter and $361 million for all of 1982, the largest one-year loss in its history. **********The losses were attributable primarily to the weak performance of the company's steel operations, which suffered, like others in the industry, from one of the lowest levels in demand for steel since World War II. **********U.S. Steel's latest figures contrasted with earnings of $101.8 million, or $1.13 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981 and $1.08 billion, or $12.07 a share, for all of 1981. Sales in the latest quarter were $4.3 billion, up from $3.3 billion a year before, while sales for the full year totaled $18.9 billion, up from 1981's $13.9 billion. **********A Different Kind of Market **********The company's 1981 earnings, achieved in spite of lower sales revenues, were primarily attributable to the profitability of tubular piping that year, according to Charles Bradford, a steel analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. U.S. Steel is the largest producer of tubular piping, which is used in energy exploration, and the product was ''extremely expensive'' in 1981, Mr. Bradford said.  An oversupply of oil on world markets and declining petroleum prices dampened oil and natural gas exploration last year. **********The company reported that its steel operations showed an operating loss of $852 million last year as its shipments of steel dropped to their lowest levels since 1938. Last year U.S. Steel shipped 10.3 million tons of steel products, down from 16.6 million tons during 1981. **********The big steelmaker was spared harsher losses last year by the performance of its nonsteel operations, which David M. Roderick, the company's chairman, said were profitable ''despite the severity of the recession.'' U.S. Steel, which acquired the Marathon Oil Company last year, said that oil and gas sales accounted for 51 percent of its total sales in 1982, while steel accounted for 28 percent. A Good Year at Marathon Oil **********The company had told analysts last November that it expected a loss for 1982. It lost $82.4 million in the third quarter of last year after earning $4.3 million in the second quarter and $79.9 million in the first. **********Like most other steel companies, U.S. Steel has sought to diversify and thus reduce its dependence on steel. About 40 percent of its assets are now in Marathon. **********Mr. Roderick described Marathon as having had a ''very good year.'' Marathon's operating income, before foreign taxes, was $1.2 billion, its corporate parent said. **********But Mr. Bradford said that figure was ''very, very misleading.'' He explained that taxes would probably shrink Marathon's contribution to U.S. Steel's overall 1982 results to about $350 million. **********He also noted that yesterday's financial report showed that U.S.  Steel's cash and marketable securities had declined in value drastically, to $500 million, from $2.4 billion at the end of 1981. **********Shares of U.S. Steel ended yesterday's trading at 19 7/8, up 1/8, on the New York Stock Exchange. Wheeling-Pittsburgh **********The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninthlargest steel producer, continued the pattern of steel company losses in 1982. The company reported a fourth-quarter deficit of $33.2 million, in contrast to a profit of $13.6 million, or $3.19 a share, a year before. Sales fell to $157 million from $246.8 million. **********For the full year, the company lost $58.8 million on revenues of $755 million, against 1981's profit of $60.1 million, or $7.03 a share, on sales of $1.15 billion. **********Dennis J. Carney, chairman and chief executive officer, said Wheeling-Pittsburgh expects ''continuing very low levels of operation and losses during the first half of 1983,'' with any recovery in the second half of the year dependent on ''an upswing in the U.S. economy and a reduction in the record volume of steel imports.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/world.main_headline: 1,300 RALLY IN ISRAEL TO PRESS FOR SOVIET EMIGRATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/world.print_headline: 1,300 RALLY IN ISRAEL TO PRESS FOR SOVIET EMIGRATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/world.body_text: **********In the midst of the tightest restrictions on the emigration of Soviet Jews since 1970, about 1,300 delegates from 32 countries, including many prominent Americans, have gathered here for a three-day conference to help the morale of Soviet Jewish activists and generate pressure on the Soviet authorities. **********The World Conference on Soviet Jewry, which begins Tuesday, is the third such meeting since the emigration movement began in 1971. The first two were in Brussels in 1971 and 1976. **********The conference is meant not as a strategy and working session but as ''an international demonstration,'' according to Theodore R. Mann, chairman of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry. He said one of its goals would be to dramatize to the United States Government the broad American interest in the issue. **********Mr. Mann had both praise and criticism for the Reagan Administration's efforts. ''I think it's in the consciousness of the President and the Secretary of State,'' he said, noting that Secretary of State George P. Shultz had raised the issue with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union. **********But the general state of Soviet-American relations worked against relaxation of the restrictions, he said. ''I don't see the point in being uncivil in relations between nations,'' Mr. Mann said, speaking of some of President Reagan's harsh comments about the Soviet Union.  ''I don't think calling them liars and cheats and an evil empire is proper discourse among superpowers in a dangerous world. I think this has something to do with the Soviet Union's treatment of human rights issues the United States thinks important.'' Mrs. Kirkpatrick Disagrees **********Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States representative at the United Nations, disagreed. She said at a news conference here that it was impossible to read the minds of Soviet leaders. ''The Soviets turn on and off the flow of emigration,'' she said, ''and they've been doing it for some time. None of us is quite sure what the causal relationship is at a given time.'' **********Since 1971, about 270,000 Jews have emigrated from the Soviet Union, about 10 percent of the Soviet Jewish population, according to Jerry Goodman of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry. Of those, he said, about 170,000 have come to Israel, with most of the rest going to the United States. The rate of emigration has plummeted in recent years, down from a high of about 4,000 a month in 1979 to just 81 in January and 125 in February. **********''We had more Jews come out of Ethiopia in January than out of the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Mann said.  Last week, a 16-member delegation from the American Jewish Committee visited Leningrad and Moscow, talking with 25 to 30 poeple who have been refused exit visas and gathering impressions of what they portrayed as a hardening Soviet policy. The Soviet Position **********Maynard I. Wishner, president of the committee, said at a news conference today that many of those applying for permission to emigrate were being turned down without being given reasons and that the authorities appeared to be intercepting official invitations mailed by relatives abroad. Soviet procedure requires such invitations as evidence that emigration is being sought to reunify a family. **********Soviet officials have adopted the argument that all those who wanted to leave have left, Mr. Wishner reported, and that those few remaining have been held because of special technical reasons, such as their possession of state secrets. **********''I'm here to tell you that's a lie,'' Mr. Wishner declared, saying many Jews wanted to leave but could not. Nobody can say with certainty how many, he said, although another member of his party said that approximately 300,000 requests for family invitations had been received in the West from Soviet Jews. **********Mr. Wishner also conveyed reports of a surge of anti-Semitism. In Leningrad, he said, his group was told by Jewish activists of a game called concentration camp that is played by some children of early high school age. Number Instead of a Name **********''A child is given a number,'' Mr. Wishner explained, ''and invariably, we are told, it is a Jewish child who's given a number and by his school comrades is referred to by that number over the next period of days - called not by name, but by that number.'' **********Tuesday's opening session is to be addressed by Mrs. Kirkpatrick, President Yitzhak Navon of Israel, and Simone Veil of France, former President of the European Parliament. **********The meeting has drawn about 500 American delegates, Mr. Mann said.  Among those scheduled to attend are Newman Flanagan, District Attorney of Boston and President of the National Association of District Attorneys; Elizabeth Holtzman, District Attorney of Brooklyn; Mario Merola, District Attorney of the Bronx; Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers; the Rev.  Robert F. Drinan, head of Americans for Democratic Action; Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Queens; Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey; Donald R. Manes, Borough President of Queens; Stanley Simon, Borough President of the Bronx, and Howard Golden, Borough President of Brooklyn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.body_text: **********A Government spokesman says an official estimate of casualties in a series of clashes between black students and the police in 1976-77 was slightly lower than one cited in a recent article in The New York Times. The Times's figure was based on compilations by journalists here. **********The official said the official estimate came from the police and from two judicial commissions that reported on conditions that gave rise to the clashes. The commissions concluded that 575 people were killed in disturbances that began with protests against the system of segregated schooling known as Bantu education. An article in The Times on Dec. 19 described the dead as numbering more than 600 and said that they were mainly students. **********The spokesman noted that an official body, called the Cille Commission, concluded that 134 of the 575 it said were killed were under the age of 18. **********It was commonplace at the time for black students to continue in secondary school for two or even three years after reaching the age of 18, so the tally of 134 may have underestimated the number of students who died. The spokesman acknowledged this, but said it was highly unlikely, in light of the findings of the commission, that most of those killed were students. **********A group called the Rabie Commission also reported on the clashes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The managers of New Hampshire's largest electric utility are wagering the company on what many analysts call a long shot that grows longer every day: the Seabrook Station nuclear power project. **********Despite major cost increases, extended completion schedules, uncertain future financing and a torrent of criticism, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the lead participant in the two-reactor, 2,300-megawatt project, has vowed to proceed. So far, the company has been able to hold up its end of an increasingly heavy financing burden, and has retained the support of a majority of the project's other owners. **********But cracks have appeared in the once united front. A growing minority of the power companies with equity shares in the Seabrook project want the second reactor, now about 15 percent finished, either canceled or delayed while work continues on Seabrook 1, which is more than half completed. **********At an owners' meeting last month, however, the dissidents were easily outnumbered by a roughly 4-to-1 margin, with votes cast in proportion to the shares of ownership in the project, which is intended to supply electricity throughout New England.Costs Up Sharply **********One of the larger opponents was the New England Electric System, a Massachusetts-based utility holding company and the owner (through a subsidiary) of 10 percent of the project, whose cost estimate now ranges from $5.24 billion to $8.5 billion, up from less than $1 billion. ''We came to the conclusion that, due to a combination of factors, Seabrook 2 was no longer in the best interests of our customers,'' said Guy W. Nichols, New England Electric's president and chairman. **********It would take an 80 percent vote to cancel the project, so Public Service of New Hampshire, which owns 35 percent of Seabrook's shares, holds veto power. The company took the May vote as a ringing affirmation of the project. ''I don't see any cracks in the foundation,'' said Robert J. Harrison, president of the utility. ''I see one or two or three companies that felt it would be better to slow down.'' **********New England needs Seabrook, Mr. Harrison said, contending that calls for a delay or cancellation reflect short-sightedness among dissenting utilities. ''There will be a need for this capacity, and more, by the mid-1990's,'' he said. Critics disagree. They say that other sources and conservation - some of which may be the inevitable result of large rate increases that Seabrook will bring -will eliminate the need for Seabrook 2.Hundreds Jailed in Protest **********The Seabrook project has had its enemies since it was first proposed in 1972. Some of the fiercest environmental and political battles in the electric industry have been fought over the project.  One of the most memorable antinuclear demonstrations occurred in 1977 at the Seabrook plant site, an hour's drive from Public Service headquarters in Manchester, N.H., when hundreds of protesters were jailed for trespassing. **********But what the Clamshell Alliance, the principal organizer of the demonstration, could not accomplish, a cash-flow squeeze might. For the project, like other nuclear plants constructed in recent years, has seen vast cost increases that have caused increasingly difficult problems for its owners, particularly those whose shares are large relative to overall assets. **********Seabrook originally was to cost less than $1 billion. Today, because of regulatory changes, increases in construction costs and other factors, according to Public Service, the general contractor puts the cost at $5.24 billion, a figure called far too low by almost everyone familiar with the project. Even Public Service, ''for planning purposes,'' acknowledges that Seabrook may be more expensive than current official projections. Estimates by analysts range to more than $8.5 billion. **********Such numbers add up to problems for the owners, who anxiously await completion of the first reactor so it can be listed as an asset on which companies can earn a rate of return, thereby producing not only power but also cash flow. The New England states generally do not allow utilities to put unfinished plants into rate bases. **********When will Seabrook 1 be ready to go into operation? Public Service's contractor puts the date at December 1984; the company, which officially goes along with that estimate, nonetheless said last week that for financial planning purposes it would assume a start-up date of July 1985. Many analysts, however, doubt the plant will be ready before 1986.Utility's Bonds Downgraded **********Of all the owners, Public Service faces some of the most vexing problems, largely because of the huge size of the Seabrook investment compared with the company's other assets, roughly a 5-to-1 ratio upon completion. That, along with increasing costs and what Wall Street perceives to be unfriendly regulatory treatment in New Hampshire, worries many in the financial community. Moreover, by a number of financial yardsticks, the company compares poorly with 116 other investor-owned utilities across the nation, according to a study by Dean Witter Reynolds Capital Markets. And Moody's and Standard & Poor's have downgraded the company's bonds to ''speculative'' and ''very speculative.'' **********''Public Service Company is leveraged more than is prudent,'' said Jeff Hoffman, chief utilities analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''There is no question that Seabrook turned out to be more expensive than anyone thought it would be.'' **********Investors, however, continue to like Public Service. The company has confounded its critics, not to mention some of its friends, by showing a consistent ability to obtain capital financing even in tough markets, albeit at a premium. Public Service shares closed yesterday at $18.125, unchanged, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The company's financing acumen will be more severely tested in the next several years, however, whether Seabrook 2 is canceled or not, because more than $400 million will have to be raised annually.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Peter S. Willmott, president and chief operating officer of the Federal Express Corporation, announced plans yesterday to resign to become president and chief executive of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago department store owner. **********Mr. Willmott, 45, will succeed Carroll Ebert, 59, who will remain chairman at Carson Pirie. Mr. Ebert said that for the past two years he had been concentrating on assimilating Carson Pirie's new airline catering business into the company and the recruitment of ''an able young chief executive officer.'' **********He had to look no further than his board, where Mr. Willmott has had a seat since 1981. Mr. Willmott said yesterday that he was changing jobs because of the ''opportunity to be c.e.o of a sizable New York Stock Exchange company.'' **********Carson Pirie Scott operates 24 department stores and specialty stores in Illinois and Indiana. The Dobbs airline catering division operates flight kitchens at 42 airports, among other activities. **********Mr. Willmott will continue on the board at Federal Express, which has its headquarters in Memphis. Frederick W. Smith, chairman, chief executive and founder of the overnight air express pioneer, will take over the title of president. James L. Barskdale, 40, was named executive vice president and chief operating officer. **********Federal Express started operations 10 years ago this week, Mr.  Willmott said, and he joined the company a year later, participating in its growth. ''It's been a tremendous experience,'' he said. **********Before that, he was in charge of operations and finance at ITT Continental Baking, a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. **********In a statement, Mr. Smith expressed his appreciation for Mr.  Willmott's ''invaluable contributions to the success of this company.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/world.print_headline: SHARON QUITS AS DEFENSE CHIEF AFTER ISRAELI CABINET ACCEPTS MASSACRE; PANEL'S FINDINGS,16-1
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/world.body_text: **********The Prime Minister's office said today that Ariel Sharon had submitted his resignation as Defense Minister in the wake of the Cabinet's vote Thursday night to accept a state commission's recommendations that he and three top army generals leave their posts. **********The Cabinet vote was 16 to 1, with only Mr. Sharon dissenting. It came after three days of intensive political negotiations and an evening of street violence, both in reaction to the commission's report that Israeli leaders bore ''indirect responsibility'' for the killings of Palestinians in Beirut last September by Lebanese Christian Phalangists. **********As the ministers were deliberating, a hand grenade exploded in a group of anti-Government demonstrators outside the office of Prime Minister Menachem Begin. One man was killed and nine people, including two policemen, were wounded. The demonstrators had been heckled, taunted, shoved and punched by mobs of Government supporters as they paraded from the center of Jerusalem. (Page A10.) **********Sharon Said to Refuse to Quit **********Emerging from the meeting, which continued after the blast, Mr.  Sharon denounced the grenade attack as ''lunatic.'' When asked whether he was still Defense Minister he walked away. **********''I have no intention to react to the Government's decision, which speaks for itself,'' Mr. Sharon said, ''and I don't intend to say anything about my future steps.'' **********This morning, however, he submitted his resignation to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, effective Monday. Israel Radio said Mr.  Begin was likely to act as temporary Defense Minister. **********Mr. Sharon was reported to have told the Cabinet Thursday night he would refuse to resign. In turn, Mr. Begin was said to have told political associates that he could not bring himself to dismiss Mr.  Sharon. **********The possibility had been mentioned that Mr. Sharon might be retained in another Cabinet post, or as a minister without portfolio, with continued policy-making influence. Today, there were conflicting reports about whether he had resigned from the Cabinet or would remain in another capacity. Both Despised and Loved **********The Defense Minister has been the chief architect of Israel's strategy in the Lebanon war and of the Begin Government's policy of Jewish settlement on the West Bank. He has brought considerable friction to relations with the United States. **********A former general and war hero, he is both despised and loved in Israel. Many respect his tough, determined approach to complex problems, but others regard him as dangerous. One general who worked closely with him described him as having ''no moral brakes.'' **********The Government's decision, made on a motion by Mr. Begin and announced by the Cabinet Secretary, Dan Meridor, made no mention of early elections, which had been discussed by the six political parties that make up Mr. Begin's coalition. It was not clear whether these were a possibility or whether Mr. Begin might simply dissolve his Cabinet and form a new government from the present Parliament.  Most of the small parties oppose elections now, fearing they would lose seats. **********Mr. Begin and his Likud bloc, however, would do well, according to public opinion polls taken before the commission report.  The Prime Minister had opposed establishing a commission to investigate the massacre, arguing that Israel was not to blame. But enormous demonstrations and an uproar in the country, even within some of his coalition parties, forced a reversal. **********The result was a three-man panel that included the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Yitzhak Kahan, as chairman, plus Supreme Court Justice Aharon Barak and Yona Efrat, a retired major general. **********The commission's report said at least 700 died in the Beirut refugee camps, although no exact figure could be ascertained. Begin's 'Indifference' Condemned **********The commission found Mr. Begin accountable for showing ''absolutely no interest'' in the actions of the Phalangists after they had been ordered into the camps by the Israeli Army. This ''indifference'' deserved to be condemned, the panel concluded. **********Mr. Sharon was assailed for failing to anticipate the probability of a massacre by the Phalangists. ''No prophetic powers were required to know that concrete danger of acts of slaughter existed when the Phalangists were moved into the camps without the I.D.F.'s being with them in that operation and without the I.D.F. being able to maintain effective and onging supervision of their actions there,'' the commission said, using the initials for the Israel Defense Forces. **********''The sense of such a danger should have been in the consciousness of every knowledgeable person who was close to this subject,'' it said, ''and certainly in the consciousness of the Defense Minister, who took an active part in everything relating to the war.'' The panel said that this ''humanitarian obligation'' was paramount, but that ''this consideration did not concern him in the least.'' Three Generals Censured **********The three generals who came in for the strongest censure from the commission were the Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan; the Director of Military Intelligence, Maj. Gen. Yehoshua Saguy, and the division commander in the Beirut area, Brig. Gen. Amos Yaron. **********General Eytan is due to retire in April; otherwise, the commission said, it would recommend his resignation or dismissal. He ignored reports he was getting of murders in the camps and allowed the Phalangist forces to remain there, the panel found. **********General Saguy, although long opposed to the close Israeli ties with the Phalangists, failed to give adequate warning of the potential for a massacre, the commission said. General Yaron, who opposed Israel's entry into West Beirut, received reports of civilians being killed, the panel found, but did not pass them to his superiors and did not halt the Phalangist operations after receiving the reports. **********The head of Northern Command, Maj. Gen. Amir Drori, was also criticized, but his dismissal was not recommended. Attention Deflected From Begin **********One effect of the Cabinet deliberations in recent days has been to deflect attention from Prime Minister Begin as one of those accountable. The commission reported that Mr. Begin did not know beforehand that the Phalangists were being sent by his army into the camps. Nor did he learn of the massacre from his own officials; he first heard about it while listening to a news broadcast of the British Broadcasting Corporation late in the afternoon of Saturday, Sept. 18, hours after the Phalangists had left the camps. **********If, after learning that the Phalangists had gone into the refugee camps, he had taken an interest in what they were doing, the commission said, this ''would have increased the alertness of the Defense Minister and the Chief of Staff to the need to take appropriate measures to meet the expected danger.'' **********''The Prime Minister's lack of involvement in the entire matter casts on him a certain degree of responsibility,'' the report said.  There has been no indication, however, that Mr. Begin will suffer politically. Many of his most vocal supporters have made it clear that they are still behind him.

Since crude oil is priced in dollars, profit margins on products sold for European currencies have narrowed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.body_text: **********An East German press commentary accused West Germany today of returning to the cold war in its protest over the deaths of two travelers at the East German border. **********The commentary was carried by the Government press agency A.D.N.  for publication Tuesday in the party newspaper Neues Deutschland. **********It said relations between Bonn and East Berlin had worsened since Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition won elections March 6. **********Last week, Erich Honecker, the East German leader, canceled plans for a visit to West Germany.  ''A worsening of relations with East Germany is being sought through massive distortions, slander and shrill tones,'' A.D.N. said.  Strauss Is Accused **********The commentary said the April border deaths were being ''manipulated and played up'' by Franz Josef Strauss, the Bavarian leader, and others. **********Two West Germans, Rudolf Burkert, 45 years old, and Heinz Moldenhauer, 68, died in recent weeks while being questioned by East German border guards. East Germany said both men had died of heart attacks, and today's commentary said the incidents ''have been abused for political reasons.'' **********The Bonn Government said Mr. Moldenhauer had died of heart failure and found no evidence of foul play.  Suspicions that Mr. Burkert might have been beaten arose after his body was returned to West Germany bearing obvious cuts and bruises to the head and neck. The East Germans said he had hit his face on a radiator when he toppled dead from his chair. **********West German authorities have not ruled on Mr. Burkert's death. A medical report said his injuries might have resulted from acts of violence, but a fall also could have caused his death.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/24/world.main_headline: LEGILATORS SAY REAGAN MUST REASSESS U.S. ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/24/world.print_headline: LEGILATORS SAY REAGAN MUST REASSESS U.S. ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/24/world.body_text: **********In the aftermath of the attack on the American marines in Beirut, legislators from both parties said today that the Reagan Administration must redefine and clarify the role of its troops and their long- range mission in the Middle East. **********Shock and anger over the devastating assault moved some Congressmen to call for the rapid withdrawal of the remaining marines from Lebanon. **********This was not the dominant reaction today, but many lawmakers warned that support for the Administration's policy had been seriously weakened and could deteriorate further in coming days if the President does not succeed in justifying his position to the Congress and thr public.   'Back to the Drawing Board' **********''It seems to me,'' said Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, ''that we ought to go back to the drawing board and say, 'Mr. President, what are the marines doing there and under what terms would they be withdrawn?' '' **********At the same time, many lawmakers expressed deep frustration at the situation in Lebanon and said that at least in the short run, the United States seemed to have no promising policy alternatives. Senator Alan Cranston of California, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, spoke for many colleagues when he called the situation ''a total mess.'' **********''There is no clear way out,'' Senator Cranston said. ''We cannot retreat under fire and if we were to declare war we wouldn't know who to declare war against.'' **********The 1,600-man Marine Corps contingent has been stationed in Lebanonunder a compromise agreement worked out last month between Congress and the White House. The President won permission to keep the troops in the region for 18 months, well past next year's elections. In exchange the President signed the resolution passed by Congress while asserting that he was not necessarily bound by the restrictions of the War Powers Act.   Distinctly Different Views **********The agreement defused, at least temporarily, a potential Constitutional collision between the executive and legislative branches. But during the debate both sides voiced distinctly differentviews over what would happen should the situation change in Lebanon anforce new decisions about the size and scope of the marines' role. **********Under considerable pressure from Capitol Hill, Mr. Reagan said he would ''seek Congressional authorization'' if circumstances required ''any substantial expansion in the number or role of U.S. armed forces in Lebanon.'' But he and his assistants also insisted that Congress could not restrict the President's flexibility to act as Commander in Chief. **********Today Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., a Maryland Republican who contributed critical support for the President in last month's debate, warned Mr. Reagan he had to coordinate any future decisions with Capitol Hill. **********''The President has got to look at that narrow margin of victory as a limit on the unbridled exercise of Presidential prerogative,'' Mr. Mathias said.   Public Opinion a Factor **********To many lawmakers public opinion is another limit on President Reagan. The most recent New York Times/ CBS poll reported that by a margin of 2 to 1 those surveyed compared the United States involvement in Lebanon to the way it became entrapped in Vietnam two decades ago. For the first time since Mr. Reagan took office, those who disapproved of his handling of foreign policy outnumbered those who approved. **********An aide to the Senate Republican leadership said many lawmakers backed President Reagan's policy last month because they ''wanted to give the Administration a chance'' and did not like the idea of America ''turning tail and running.'' But they did not believe in the commitment of Americans troops, he added, and the tone on Capitol Hill is now likely to change. **********''A lot of people have been waiting for something to happen so they can say what they really feel,'' the aide said. **********During the debate over the War Powers Resolution, many lawmakers argued that the Reagan Administration had not adequately defined the role of the marines in Lebanon, and Senator Nunn dubbed their assignment ''Mission: Impossible.'' Today those complaints were repeated more loudly than ever. **********For example, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democratic leader, said in a statement: ''The Administration should talk with the other parties in the multinational force and reassess our reasons for being there, and these reasons should be clearly explained to Congress and the American people. The role of our marines has not been clearly defined. At present our people are just sitting ducks in a defenseless situation where they don't even know who is attacking them.'' **********These concerns were echoed by Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, when he said on the ABC News program ''This Week'': ''I think these forces right now don't have a mission. I don't think it is clear what we are trying to achieve in Beirut.'' **********But if many lawmakers were alarmed by the situation in Lebanon, they disagreed sharply today over what course the President should take next. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said it was clear that ''our forces cannot adequately be protected in that country'' and called for a withdrawal within 60 days. **********Senator Nunn agreed that the troops should leave, but said they had to be replaced by United Nations forces. ''Our forces in Lebanon now are not a deterrent, they're hostages,'' the Georgian said. **********Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, another contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said Mr. Reagan was left with two choices: reduce the contingent substantially, or increase it to the point where the marines can defend themselves and ''clear out and clean out a buffer zone'' around their positions. **********Senator John Glenn of Ohio, who is also seeking the Democratic nomination, called for ''internationalizing the situation'' by the use of United Nations forces and said it was essential to avoid any further direct conflict between the United States and Syria. **********CONGRESS can bite

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/busin.body_text: **********''We move with blinding speed,'' said Arnold C. Greenberg, president and chief executive officer of Coleco Industries. ''And we never try to be the lowest-priced competitor.'' **********For Coleco, a Hartford-based video game maker, that strategy has paid off handsomely. Last fall, its Colecovision game system, which can play software made by other manufacturers as well as its own, put the company in direct competition with Atari and Mattel for the first time. When the dust cleared in the second quarter of this year, Coleco was the only one of the big three video game producers to emerge with a profit. It earned $9.1 million, up from $7.4 million in the 1982 quarter. And for all of last year, profits soared to $44.9 million from $7.7 million in 1981. **********Despite its record, many investors and analysts remain nervous about Coleco as it poises for its next major dash, this time into the home computer market. Although the company has shown marketing savvy in toys and games, it has yet to prove itself in the computer big leagues, they say. **********This nervousness surfaced Wednesday, when Coleco's stock, an otherwise star performer in the bull market, fell 4 points on the rumor that the International Business Machines Corporation would introduce its long-awaited Peanut home computer on Sept. 1. The stock closed at 34 1/2 Friday, down 4 points for the week. **********Coincidentally, perhaps, Sept. 1 is when Coleco's Adam, a powerful, single-package home computer, is scheduled for shipment to merchandisers. **********Mr. Greenberg remains undaunted. ''The Peanut can't come quickly enough,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''All I.B.M. can do is lend stability to this industry.  A good product like that will focus attention on the Coleco solution.'' **********Coleco's solution, as Mr. Greenberg sees it, is a mass-market computer costing under $600 and combining what Coleco believes are the two primary uses for home computers - word processing and game playing. The Adam will be shipped with a word processing software program for the first use and a Buck Rogers-Planet of Zoom video game for the second. **********Among the Adam's prime competitors will be Commodore International, whose Commodore 64 unit begins at about $200. A Commodore package that is equivalent to Adam, however, would cost about $800 to $900. **********But as Coleco has proved with its games, price is not the only means to success. ''It's the marketing that's important,'' said Richard P. Simon, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''Coleco is more at home selling consumer products than technology, and that might be to their advantage.'' **********Strong Marketing A strong mass-marketing strategy focusing on quality and a centralized decision-making process have been the company's dominant characteristics since Mr. Greenberg took charge in 1973, analysts say. **********More recently, since it entered the electronic game business in the late 1970's with hand-held and tabletop games, Coleco has demonstrated an ability to move new products rapidly into the market, although sometimes, analysts say, the company has set deadlines it cannot meet. **********Coleco - an acronym for the Connecticut Leather Company, a leather tooling concern founded by Mr. Greenberg's father in 1932 - has gone through numerous phases in its trek toward high technology. Although video games and toys dominate the company, swimming pools and outdoor products still account for nearly 14 percent of sales and 8 percent of profits. Most of its second-quarter profits, however, were a result of the continuing strength of its home video game business, the flagship of which is Colecovision, the relatively powerful game-player unit that can be upgraded into a home computer system. **********Since its introduction last fall, Colecovision has sold about 1.4 million units, according to the Video Marketing Game Letter, an industry newsletter. Of that total, about 900,000 were sold this year, compared with 800,000 units by Atari and 300,000 by Mattel. **********That gives Coleco a far smaller customer base than Atari, which has sold about 9.3 million game player systems since the late 1970's. However, Atari has lost much of the software market. **********By contrast, Colecovision has so far been the exclusive maker ot its software. And because Coleco has had some of video's biggest hits, notably Donkey Kong, its software business has been a major source of profits.  That exclusive role was eroded last month, however, when two companies began shipping games playable on Colecovision. Other competitors are moving in, too. **********Mr. Greenberg argued that the availability of more software will encourage sales of the system, and that any lost market share in software will be made up in hardware sales. **********Another area of potential difficulty centers on the production of Adam. Coleco has said it will begin shipping Adam at the end of August, and have it in stores by Labor Day. However, a working prototype has yet to be demonstrated, according to several companies contracted to produce software for the machine. **********Mr. Greenberg said that some features of Adam would be altered from a model shown at the Consumer Electronics Show held in Chicago in May, but he insisted that the alterations were ''minor and subtle.'' **********''Our priorities are on utility, simplicity and value,'' he said. ''We concentrate on perceived consumer need. I think we've got what they want.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/29/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials acknowledged today that they were doing nothing to dispel the impression that the United States is covertly supporting anti-Sandinist forces fighting in Nicaragua. **********One official said that by allowing this impression to persist, the Administration hoped to cause problems for the Nicaraguan leadership and to persuade it to diminish its backing for guerrilla forces in El Salvador. **********Amid repeated press reports and Nicaraguan Government allegations of Central Intelligence Agency backing for anti-Sandinist forces operating principally from Honduras, the State Department has steadfastly refused to deny or confirm American involvement. 'A Longstanding Practice' **********But Administration officials conceded that the pointed refusal of the Administration to deny United States involvement has had the effect of seemingly substantiating the reports. **********''It is a longstanding practice of this and other Administrations not to address allegations of this sort,'' Alan D. Romberg, a department spokesman, said today. **********Mr. Romberg said he was authorized to offer a statement suggesting that the problems faced by the Nicaraguan Government were caused by its own internal opposition and its own repression. By implication, this was meant to suggest that the anti-Sandinist forces were a kind of local opposition. **********''It is a fact,'' Mr. Romberg said, ''that over preceding months there has been rising opposition to the Government of Nicaragua, including within Nicaragua itself, and clearly these opposition elements are making their pressure felt both outside and within Nicaragua itself. **********''And it is not surprising,'' he went on, ''that the Sandinists are trying to convince their public and the outside world that there is not an internal problem in Nicaragua when there is.'' He said the ''opposition'' ranged from ''disillusioned public sectors to ethnic groups such as the Miskito Indians and includes former National Guardsmen and former Sandinists.'' **********Mr. Romberg, summing up the state of the opposition in Nicaragua, said it was ''diverse, nationalist and independent.'' Some 'Psychological Warfare' **********An Administration official acknowledged that there was ''a bit of psychological warfare here.'' The United States, the official said, is interested in raising doubts in the minds of Nicaraguan leaders about the extent of Washington's involvement in the hope that this will force the Nicaraguans to agree to stop their aid for the insurgents fighting in El Salvador against the American-backed Government. **********In this ''psychological warfare,'' the State Department seems to be repeating what the Nicaraguans say about the situation in El Salvador. The Nicaraguans have said that the guerrillas in El Salvador are acting on their own and reflect opposition to the regime. **********A reporter for The New York Times visited a camp Saturday inside Honduras where there were armed people, one of whom said they were all Nicaraguans. The reporter described crates in the camp that were labeled as United States-made armaments. **********Two Honduran soldiers stationed nearby described the people in the camp as Nicaraguans fighting to overthrow the Sandinist Government.  When asked about this today, Mr. Romberg said he would ''not address it one way or the other.'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz, when he was on Capitol Hill last week testifying on aid to El Salvador, refused to answer when asked whether the United States was involved in support for Nicaraguan insurgents. He said the matter was being handled in secret with the Intelligence Committees of the House and the Senate. **********The Honduran Government has denied that any anti-Nicaraguan forces are using its territory, despite The Times's account of the camp some eight miles from the border. ---- Honduras to Study Report Special to the New York Times **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 - Honduras said today that it would appoint a commission of inquiry to determine whether a camp of anti-Sandinist guerrillas had been established in the province of El Paraiso.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.body_text: **********The Soviet-installed Government of Afghanistan has announced that all female prisoners and some male prisoners will be freed to mark Wednesday's fifth anniversary of the coup, a Western diplomat here reported today. The diplomat said there were at least 100,000 people in Afghan prisons. **********The diplomat also said he had heard of new Government attacks on rebel positions around Kabul, the capital, and gains by the insurgents in the east.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/world.body_text: **********Outside the village of Yojoa, Napoleon Velazquez brought his mule to a halt by the highway. **********''I'm glad the gringos are coming,'' said the 58-year-old peasant. ''There will be construction and jobs.'' **********As eight months of military exercises directed by the United States began in Honduras, dozens of people interviewed in both countryside and city said they hoped that the arrival of United States servicemen would bring military and financial security. **********By the end of next week, 2,000 United States personnel will have arrived to participate in the exercises, known as Big Pine II. That number will double in the coming months.   Enthusiasm Not Shared **********According to a United States Embassy official, the Americans will spend between $10 million and $30 million, ranging from personal expenses to contracts to local labor. Given the temporary nature of the exercises, however, the money will not have a long- term effect on the Honduran economy, the official said. **********Many middle-class Hondurans do not share the enthusiasm shown for the arriving Americans. These Hondurans say they fear that the exercises will bolster the strength of the Honduran military while weakening international efforts to reduce regional tensions. **********The Americans will improve existing military installations in three parts of the country and train Honduran troops in conventional and counterinsurgency tactics. They will also provide logistical support and field exercises. **********Gen. Gustavo Alvarez, commander of the Honduran armed forces, said at a recent news conference that the maneuvers would help Honduras to improve its defenses and military preparedness in the event of a Nicaraguan attack, whether direct or through subversion.   Seek More Aid **********Two days later the Honduran Army presented three men as proof that the threat of subversion existed. They said the men had received military training in Cuba before they were sent to the Olancho province to recruit volunteers for a guerrilla force. **********General Alvarez also spoke of the need for economic aid, a theme which businessmen here continually emphasize. They would like to see the United States follow military aid with loans and an easing of credit. The Honduran economy is in trouble with over 50 percent of the work force, according to Government figures, either unemployed or underemployed, and the annual per capita income is the lowest in the region after Haiti. **********Miguel Facusse, a wealthy industrialist who is a friend of President Roberto Suavo Cordova, said military aid alone would not help Honduras. **********''You'll never make a democracy consolidate itself without improving social and economic conditions,'' Mr. Facusse said. Honduras, he said, needed $400 million in loans in the next three years.   Fears of War **********''We are fighting for free enterprise, democracy and all that stuff,'' said Mr. Facusse. **********This year the United States provided $96 million in economic aid and about $40 million in military assistance. **********Those Hondurans who disagree with the exercises divide their anger between what they see as the Reagan Administration's insensitivity to Central America's difficulties and the Suazo Government's acquiescence to a policy that could lead to war. **********''Reagan's policy will make this country a platform for war,'' said Victor Meza, director of a political research center in Tegucigalpa. **********''The only solution the Reagan Administration wants is a military one,'' Mr. Meza said. ''If the United States wants to defeat the Nicaraguans and can't do it with the contras, it must involve Honduras in a war,'' he said, referring to the anti-Sandinista guerrillas in Nicaragua. **********The critics contend the Reagan Administration's policy encouraged Central American governments to reduce political dissent to a basic ideological level: Communism or anti-Communism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Campaigns By L'eggs And Atari
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/busin.body_text: **********THE three-hour Emmy awards show on the NBC-TV network last night also served to introduce new ad campaigns for both Atari home computers and L'eggs Sheer Energy pantyhose, and each was a radical departure from past efforts. **********Atari's ads mark the debut of the actor-director-writer Alan Alda, star of ''M*A*S*H,'' who is beginning a five-year-relationship with the Warner Communications subsidiary. **********It will run four spots during the three- hour program. **********L'eggs ran three of the four 30-second commercials so far produced by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample that condense much of romance, passion, confusion, cliches and non sequiturs of a half-hour soap opera. **********Mr. Alda is, incidentally, a whiz at computers and has admitted, according to the agency, Wells, Rich, Greene, that ''I am just one step ahead of Everyman.'' He will be the spokesman for the company in all media under a contract that will also have him advising on public relations and products. **********W.R.G. has produced 11 commercials in both 60-second and 30-second lengths in which the actor tries to allay consumer fears of not being able to master the machine. The tagline in the advertising is, ''You'll do more with Atari home computers.'' **********As for L'eggs, a division of Consolidated Foods, it will be attempting to keep its lead position in the pantyhose marketplace with the help of Dancer Fitzgerald and four new commercials that should easily get your attention by making the 30-second commercials feel like half-hour soap operas. **********The mini-plots are there, the romantically named characters are there and the settings are there. In each of the four commercials a female character says something about walking or running to give the announcer the opportunity to come in and make a pitch for Sheer Energy, the support hose that is never so identified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/busin.main_headline: G.M. AND FORD CUT RATE ON SOME LOANS TO 9.9%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/busin.print_headline: G.M. AND FORD CUT RATE ON SOME LOANS TO 9.9%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/busin.body_text: **********With sales of its small cars languishing, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it was cutting its auto loan rate to 9.9 percent from 11.9 percent for consumers who purchase its compact and subcompact cars and light trucks. **********The Ford Motor Company quickly responded with a comparable program. The Chrysler Corporation, G.M.'s other major domestic competitor, is expected to follow G.M.'s lead in the next few days.  The G.M. and Ford programs, covering loans of any term, are available beginning Friday on 1983 models delivered by May 31, when the program ends, or ordered by April 30. **********New-car loan rates at banks have declined from 15 percent or more last year to between 12 and 14 percent now. That was close enough to cut into the effectiveness of the 11.9 percent financing rate that has been offered by most auto makers since January to promote sales. No Recovery **********The continuation of sales incentives was seen by analysts as tacit acknowledgment from the auto makers that an economic recovery has not taken hold. Industry executives have repeatedly said they would drop the costly incentive programs once car sales strengthen. **********One industry analyst said the new program could help sales a bit, but was not a cure-all.  Chrysler has extended its 11.9 percent program, along with cash rebates, until April 10, and the American Motors Corporation extended its 11.9 percent financing program on most A.M.C. Renault and Jeep vehicles through Tuesday. Models Included in Program **********G.M.'s new 9.9 percent financing covers Chevrolet Chevette and Cavalier, Pontiac 1000 and 2000, Buick Skyhawk and Oldsmobile Firenza subcompacts, the company's Chevrolet Citation, Pontiac Phoenix, Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Omega compacts and the Cadillac Cimarron. The financing will also be available on Chevrolet S-10 and G.M.C. S-15 light-duty trucks. **********The Ford program offers 9.9 percent financing or a $300 rebate on Ford Escort and EXP models, and Lincoln-Mercury Lynx and LN7 models, and on Ford Ranger light-duty pickup trucks built after Dec.1. Ford also said it will offer 11.9 percent financing for 36-month loans and 12.9 percent financing for 48-month loans on Ford Mustang and LTD, Mercury Capri and Marquis and Lincoln Continental, Town Car and Mark VI models, as well as on Ford Ranger pickup trucks built before Dec.1, the F-series pickup trucks and Ford Bronco and Bronco II utility vehicles. Consumers will be able to choose a $300 rebate instead of the reduced loan rate on the Mustang and Capri. **********Industry sources said that G.M. plans to inform its dealers that similar financing will still be available on car lines not covered by the new plan. A G.M. spokesman confirmed that it will offer its dealers $200 incentives for selling its troubled front-wheel-drive Xcar models, which have been subject to adverse publicity because of extensive Federal investigations and safety-related recalls in recent months. Slowdown in X-Car Sales **********G.M. dealers said that the incentives were needed to sell the Xcars. ''There has been a slowdown, yes,'' said Gerald Stautberg, owner of Jerry's Chevrolet in Baltimore. ''Any time you get enough bad publicity you get a slowdown.'' Chevrolet dealers report a 101-day supply of Citations, the Chevrolet X-car, while Pontiac dealers have a 117-day supply of Pontiac Phoenix models, nearly double the normal inventory. **********Industry analysts said they were not surprised at the program.  Lower fuel prices have sparked a surge in the sales of larger models, at the expense of the smaller ones. **********David Healy, automotive analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York, said the program probably would not make much difference.  ''It's an attractive rate, but by itself it won't turn the industry around,'' he said. ''I suppose it will help a little bit because it breaks the psychological barrier of 10 percent interest rates, but it's not enough to spur a recovery.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.print_headline: CAIRO DAY OF ATONEMENT: 10 MEN ARE HARD TO FIND
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.body_text: **********Michael Salem, a 21-year-old Egyptian Jew, entered the nearly empty Shaar ha-Shamayim Synagogue early Saturday morning to pray. **********An hour earlier, President Hosni Mubarak, surrounded by hundreds of security men, had worshiped at Al Hussein Mosque, which was packed with Government officials and other faithful. **********Both men were observing their respective religion's holiest days. This year, the start of Islam's Eid al-Adha, or Bairam Courban, as the four-day holiday is known, and Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, coincided. **********Egypt's Jews, once among the largest and wealthiest groups of Jews in the world, are now few and mostly old. Islam, by contrast, appears more dominant by the day. **********The concurrence of the Moslem and Jewish holidays, which occurs about once every 35 years, has enhanced a sense of religious and political isolation for many Egyptian Jews.   Home of Philo and Maimonides **********It was Egypt that produced the scholars Philo and Saadia ben Joseph al-Fayumi and the biblical prophet Jeremiah. Rabbi Moses ben Maimon, or Maimonides, revered by many as the foremost interpreter of Jewish law and philosophy, spent more than half of his life in 12th-century Cairo. Today, the roof of the synagogue where he wrote his codes and intepretations has collapsed. There is talk of renovation but no money for such a project, Jews say. **********The city's 1,100-year-old Ben Ezra Synagogue is closed for repair, which is proceeding at a tortoise's pace. Only 2 of the city's 15 synagogues are in use. Of these, only Shaar ha-Shamayim, a cavernous, recently restored building in the heart of Cairo's business district, functions regularly. **********As recently as 1948, there were about 100,000 Jews in Egypt. After the United Nations voted to partition Palestine, many Egyptian Jews were coerced into leaving. Egypt's wars with Israel spurred anti-Jewish campaigns, which included internments, expulsions and confiscation of property. By the time President Anwar el-Sadat came to power, there were only a few hundred Jews left; the vast majority had voluntarily or involuntarily gone to Israel. **********Now, most of Egypt's Jewish population, estimated to be 120 in Cairo and a few more than that in Alexandria, is old and widowed.   Last Rabbi Left in '71 **********Since the last rabbi left Egypt in 1971, the Jews have been without spiritual leadership. There are no kosher butcher shops and no functioning Jewish schools. The Jewish cemetery, like the famed Islamic city of the dead, has been occupied by squatters. The graves stand desecrated and neglected. **********The leader of the Egypt's Jews, gravely ill for several years, now lives in Paris. The acting president, Joseph Dana, did not return to Cairo for the holidays this year. His five children are in school in Israel. **********Ernest Stock of the political studies department at Israel's Bar-Ilan University said in a recent newsletter that ''with almost no young people or families with school-age children remaining, all the signs point to contiuning attrition and eventual disappearance of Egypt's Jewish community.''  The Moslems Feasted **********While the Jews fasted on Saturday to atone for sins of the last year, Egyptian Moslems feasted. **********The feast of sacrifice coincides with the climax of the annual pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia, a trip that hundreds of thousands of Egyptian Moslems make each year. The feast commemorates God's command to Abraham, or Ibrahim, as Moslems call him, to sacrifice his son as a test of faith. Once Ibrahim agreed to do so, God sent a lamb to be killed instead. **********On Saturday morning, millions of Egyptian families killed sheep and cows to commemorate Ibrahim's obedience to the Lord and God's mercy. As the sun rose over Cairo, butchers roamed the strangely quiet city streets offering their services for the sacrificial slaughter. **********The holiday continues for four days and offices will remain closed. **********''At least both Jews and Moslems will not be working today,'' said one of the 19 Jews who attended synagogue in downtown Cairo.   'Must Have Overslept' **********At 8:30 Saturday morning, Moshe Levy Latti, a rabbi and shoe merchant sent by Israel for the service, paced nervously in the empty synagogue. **********''Everyone must have overslept,'' he said, glancing anxiously at his watch. **********Two French Jewish tourists arrived at 9. An Englishman from Manchester entered soon after. **********At about 10, six Egyptian Jews, including Michael Salem, arrived. The rabbi sighed with relief. **********''At last, a minyan,'' he said, referring to the 10-man quorum needed for communal prayer. **********Minyans, Mr. Salem acknowledged, are increasingly hard to obtain in Cairo. During Rosh ha-Shanah, he said, two Israeli diplomats had to coax an Israeli security guard into the synagogue before services could begin. **********Mr. Salem said growing up as a Jew in Egypt had been difficult. ''I didn't even feel Jewish until a few years ago,'' he said.   A New Awareness **********For Mr. Salem, as for other Egyptian Jews, Egypt's peace with Israel in 1978 rekindled an awareness of Jewish culture and heritage. But it has not altered the demographic facts. **********The number of Israeli diplomats in Cairo now rival in size the city's Egyptian Jewish population. In fact, more Israeli diplomats, many of whom are of Egyptian Jewish origin, attended a Yom Kippur service on Friday night in suburban Maadi than did Egyptian Jews in downtown Cairo. **********The Maadi synagogue, which functions infrequently, is also endangered. It is cared for by Becky Salama, who says she is 64 but, according to friends, is actually 10 and maybe 20 years older. She sells mangoes from the synagogue garden to maintain the building. **********''I'm old and very sick,'' Miss Salama said. ''I don't know what will happen to the place when I die.'' **********If there is any hope that Egypt's Jews can be saved from extinction, it lies in two Jewish families who, until recently, feuded like Shakespeare's Capulets and Montagues.  Michael Salem's brother fell in love some time ago with the daughter of the rival clan, the Rousseaus. Her father forbade the marriage, because, it was said, the Salems were only second-generation Egyptian Jews of Iraqi origin. But love, apparently, has triumphed. The two are to marry next summer.
