https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.main_headline:
Business Forum;
WHY FREE MARKETS AND BANKS DON'T MIX
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.print_headline:
Business Forum;
WHY FREE MARKETS AND BANKS DON'T MIX
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.body_text: **********FINANCIAL crises in recent years attest to a growing interdependencya nd vulnerability within the financial services industry. The p roblems that faced Bache and Paine Webber in 1980, Drysdale, L ombard-Wall and Penn Square in 1982 and the international banks t oday with respect to their loans to third world countries, i llustrate the point. They are examples of how, with increasing f requency, the difficulties of a single financial institution t hreaten to set off a chain reaction, extending well beyond those c ompanies immediately involved. **********This situation calls for a re-examination of the way in which the industry is regulated.  There are two central approaches to bank and financial services regulation today. The first is regulation that assures soundness of an institution -avoiding illiquidity or insolvency. The second is regulation that provides a mechanism to protect customers in the event of a failure. **********Soundness regulation includes restrictions on how financial intermediaries such as banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies can compete in the market place, as well as restrictions on how portfolios can be managed. Post-failure mechanisms include the deposit insurance and similar loss-guarantee funds. **********Increasingly, those critical of our traditional regulatory system are speaking out. Some urge greater reliance on those institutions that insure and guarantee investors' funds, while apostles of deregulation would substitute disclosure and the discipline of the free market for the heavy-handed restrictions that soundness regulation has traditionally imposed. **********Those advocating that all financial services be deregulated and that free market forces be unleashed offer a seductive alternative.  Yet, the growing interdependence of financial intermediaries should give pause to policy makers tempted by the siren song of Adam Smith. **********My thesis is that: 1) Market discipline can only assure soundness in an environment where institutions are permitted to fail. 2) The links among financial intermediaries are often too extensive to prevent one failure from setting off others. 3) Therefore, the consequences of failures often impose unacceptable costs to our financial system. 4) Thus, to assure soundness, a new system of government regulation is needed - a system broad enough to encompass all financial intermediaries and flexible enough to enable the forces of full disclosure and market discipline to do their share of the job. **********Recent efforts of bank regulators to increase the amount of public information available about the financial condition of banks should be applauded. As a general proposition, accurate and up-to-date disclosure provides for the most efficient flow of capital among competing investments and deters excessive risk-taking by those seeking to attract that capital. **********There is no reason why disclosure should not have the same salutary effect on financial institutions as it does in other sectors of the economy. Relying on market discipline as a substitute for direct regulation, however, is an idea that should give us pause. **********For market discipline to operate efficiently, financial institutions must be fully exposed to the risk of failure. Indeed, if market discipline is to operate efficiently, banks and other financial intermediaries must be permitted to fail. But the growing interdependence among financial institutions and the resulting vulnerability makes a failure - at least among the larger ones - unacceptable. **********Yet, the expectation of government intervention in the event of a failure prevents the free market place from operating efficiently.  If large bank depositors and creditors are not exposed in the event of a bank failure, they lack the incentive to insist that the bank avoid excessive risk. Unrestrained, the bank is free to take risks beyond what would be compatible with soundness. **********WHILE the F.D.I.C. and others are seeking ways to alter the assumption that depositors and other creditors at the larger banks enjoy implicit protection of 100 cents on the dollar, that assumption will be hard to erode. And even if it were eroded, the belief in government's unwillingness to suffer large failures would persist. **********The current international lending situation illustrates the problems of permitting the free market to regulate financial institutions. The international banks seem to have miscalculated the long-term risks of huge lending to third world countries. But to let the banks suffer the full consequences of these miscalculations could create intolerable losses. And one cannot separate our domestic banking and credit system from the international system. Of the $268 billion in outstanding loans by private banks to the developing countries as of June 1982, more than 36 percent, or $98.6 billion, were claims of American banks. **********The expanding links among financial intermediaries are, in large part, a function of technological advances. Computers permit highspeed, low-cost data processing, which in turn fosters aggressive money management and vastly increases the number and velocity of money transfers. **********At the same time, the increasing velocity at which funds move contributes to the vulnerability of the financial system. When the objective is to get the highest return in the shortest time, cash reserve cushions are often reduced and the response time to delivery failures is shortened. **********These problems should show us that a new system of regulation by the Government is needed.  Before deciding how to secure the soundness of our financial system, we must draw a circle around those financial activities that must be protected against failure. Placement of the circle is difficult. In banking, for example, some would circle only the bank itself, others, the bank and its subsidiaries, and still others, the entire bank holding company structure. But as the lines of distinction between banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies continues to erode, drawing the circle becomes even more of a challenge. **********The interdependency problem also suggests the need for a government safety net to supply swiftly liquidity for financial intermediaries and act in other ways to protect the stability of the nation's financial system. At the present time we lack an adequate system. Too much today is left to chance and the serendipity of having adequate leadership in place when needed to cope with a crisis. Turnover in government is too rapid. We lack a coherent structure to house both the necessary tools and the institutional memory needed to enable new hands to use those tools wisely. **********As a point of departure for developing such a system, it would make sense to study the Federal Reserve Act. The Federal Reserve Board continues to be the most logical source of regulation and emergency funds. As many critics have observed, however, the act is archaic and inflexible. We need to amend the act to create a flexible framework within which the Federal Reserve Board, perhaps with the input from the President and Congress, could move to avert and arrest financial crises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.body_text: **********New orders for durable goods fell 3.6 percent in July, the first decline since February, the Government reported today. **********The Commerce Department report said the slide in July orders ''was concentrated in the capital goods industries,'' which manufacture the equipment companies use to expand and modernize operations. Orders for household goods, primary metals and electrical machinery all increased, the department said. **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the overall drop was not surprising in view of the ''dramatic spurt'' in orders the previous month. Today's report revised June's figure to show a gain of 7.6 percent instead of the previously reported 5.5 percent. **********Even with the July decline, Mr. Baldrige said, orders ''remain 24 percent above their trough level'' of last October, generally considered to be the worst month of last year's recession. **********Michael Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a consulting concern, said the July decline was ''even stronger evidence than expected'' that high interest rates were forcing a slowdown in the economy. Durable goods, consisting of such major purchase items as cars, heavy machinery and refrigerators, are typically bought on credit, making interest rates influential in their purchase. **********Capital spending normally lags in a recovery as businesses hold off on expansion until they are convinced the rebound will last, Mr. Evans said. But by now, he added, orders at least ought to ''be getting up a full head of steam.'' **********He said that today's report, along with other recent reports showing a slowdown in the housing rebound and in consumer spending last month, ''point in the direction of a reduction'' in economic growth to an annual rate of about 5 percent to 6 percent. **********Mr. Baldrige said that an increase in the backlog of unfilled orders during July, along with rising factory use rates and low inventories compared with sales ''should encourage a resumption of growth in orders.'' **********Today's report said that military capital goods orders fell 14.5 percent in July after increasing a revised 66 percent in June. Orders for nonmilitary capital goods dropped 11.6 percent after rising 9.3 percent the previous month. **********Military orders, which can rise or fall sharply from month to month because single orders are so large, have risen most months in the last two years in line with the Reagan Administration's efforts to rebuild the armed forces. **********The Commerce Department said that the value of all new durable goods orders in July was $87.6 billion, a $3.3 billion decline from June. Shipments of manufactured goods declined five-tenths of 1 percent, to $86.2 billion, the department added.  July's decrease in new orders was the first since a 6 percent drop in February and the second since last October, when orders reached the recession low of $70.7 billion, the report said. **********The report also showed that orders for transportation equipment fell 13.9 percent, to $20.2 billion; metals increased 4.8 percent, to $10.6 billion; machinery orders rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $29.1 billion, and household durable goods orders rose to $5.6 million from $5.53 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.body_text: **********Five former national guardsmen were ordered today to stand trial for the 1980 murders of four United States churchwomen, a Salavdoran judge announced. **********The judge, Bernardo Rauda Murcia, said all five were charged with homicide in the Dec. 2, 1980, deaths of three Roman Catholic nuns and a churchworker. The women were driving from the international airport to San Salvador when they were stopped and killed. **********It is the second time that Judge Rauda of the First Criminal Court in Zacatecoluca, 35 miles southeast of San Salvador, has ordered the guardsmen be tried. **********He issued his first trial order last November but an appeals court in San Vicente, 12 miles north of Zacatecoluca, ruled that the record was incomplete and returned the case to Judge Rauda for further investigation. The defense is expected to appeal today's decision.   Van Was Burned **********All five defendants are also charged with aggravated damage for burning the women's van. **********Two of the men - Carlos Joaquin Contreras and Sgt. Luis Antonio Colindres Aleman - are charged with stealing material from the van and Mr. Contreras is accused of raping one of the women. **********The churchwomen were Sisters Ita Ford, 40 years old, and Maura Clarke, 49, of New York, both Maryknoll nuns; Sister Dorothy Kazel, 41, an Ursuline nun from Cleveland, and Jean Donovan, 27, a missionary also from Cleveland. They were found in a shallow grave two days after the slayings. **********They had been doing social work in El Salvador that angered right-wing extremists. **********Mr. Contreras, in testimony this week, admitted raping one of the women. He said he was following the orders of Sergeant Colindres, who he said also ordered the women killed and told him he was acting on instructions from higher officials.   The Next Step **********The other guardsmen will not be tried on rape charges for lack of evidence, although earlier testimony indicated three of the four women had been raped.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Corporate profits deteriorated further in the fourth quarter of 1982. Particularly affected were the cyclically depressed steel, oil, auto and forest products industries. Analysts forecast that, over all, after-tax profits for the quarter should be down 20 percent from a year earlier, to $116 billion. (Page D1.) **********Purchasing managers reported higher output and better order levels for January. It was the first time since June 1981 that the share of purchasers reporting improvement in these areas exceeded those who said conditions were worse or unchanged. (D1.) Companies **********MGM/UA named Frank Yablans vice chairman and chief operating officer in the latest corporate upheaval in Hollywood. (C13.) **********Delaware's Supreme Court has limited the rights of shareholders who oppose mergers of subsidiaries into parent companies. The court ruling in effect bars most class action suits in such cases and will change how stocks involved are valued. (D1.) **********Tamper-resistant packages for drugs must be used from today under Federal rules drawn up after seven people died last fall from cyanide-contaminated Tylenol. (D1.) Bristol-Myers hopes to recoup the cost of its expensive new canisters through higher sales. (D4.) International **********Mexico's economic woes are illustrated by the plight of Villahermosa, once a leading beneficiary of the country's oil boom.  Despite Mexico's rising need for oil, the industry is laying off workers and tightening its budget. (D1.) **********China's tropical island of Hainan is being used to lure foreign investors under Peking's more relaxed economic development policy.  Hainan not only offers a pleasant environment, but is also potentially rich in oil and other resources. (D1.) Today's Columns **********Martin S. Feldstein, the President's top economic adviser, sings a happier tune in his recent outlook. But his newer, more optimistic forecast for economic growth is annoying some who had pushed for such a forecast earlier, during the budget process, but had been overruled by Mr. Feldstein. Washington Watch. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/busin.main_headline: Prudential Realty Issues New Mortgage Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Prudential Realty Issues New Mortgage Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/busin.body_text: **********Prudential Realty Securities Inc. introduced a new kind of mortgage-backed security yesterday with a $300.2 million issue of zero-coupon bonds due annually from 1984 to 1997. **********The bonds, which are offered by Salomon Brothers and Prudential-Bache Securities, are backed by a pool of conventional home mortgages that were originated by the Prudential Insruance Company of America in the 1960's. **********Because the securities are overcollateralized by the home mortgages, the Standard & Poor's Corporation deemed the issue worthy of a triple-A rating. **********Unlike mortgage pass-through securities, which pay principal and interest monthly, the new zero-coupon issue will not pay any interest. The investors' return will come at maturity when the securities are redeemed at face value. **********The price for the zero-coupon bonds ranges from $91.477 for the 1984 maturity, which will yield 9.6 percent, to $42.686 with a yield of 11 percent for the 1991 maturity and $22.902 with a yield of 10.85 percent for the 1997 maturity. **********The repayment of the mortgages comes solely from the cash flow of the mortgages and other eligible investments. The eligible investments, which would be acquired with proceeds of mortgages that are prepaid plus monthly payments of principal and interest, may include other mortgages and Treasury securities. **********Daniel Kearney, a managing director at Salomon Brothers, said the new type of securities might be imitated by other institutions, such as savings and loan associations that hold low-interest-rate mortgages. Packaging existing mortgages as zero-coupon securities could ''allow them to liquidate their portfolios without incurring an immediate loss,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/12/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Greeks Protest Over NATO Games
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/12/world.body_text: **********The Greek Government said today that a protest had been sent to the United States Government over what it termed a series of violations in recent days and in some cases ''blatant infringements'' of Greek airspace by American jetfighters during NATO maneuvers in the eastern Mediterranean. **********The United States Embassy said it was studying the Greek complaint, but indicated that it had rejected them in part. **********The Greek Government spokesman, Dimitrios Maroudas, speaking at a press briefing, said the protest asserted that 33 violations of Greek airspace had occurred in the eastern Aegean by jetfighters belonging to the aircraft carrier Eisenhower. **********Greece withdrew last week from NATO's maneuvers after the alliance refused to include the Greek frontier island of Limnos. **********Turkey has long demanded that the island be demilitarized, and Athens argues that NATO is indirectly supporting Ankara's claim when not including Limnos in maneuvers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/04/busin.main_headline: ECONOMY UP IN MARCH, PURCHASING STUDY FINDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/04/busin.print_headline: ECONOMY UP IN MARCH, PURCHASING STUDY FINDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The economy expanded again in March, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers. The study was released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management. **********The signals were not uniformly positive, however, as a seasonally adjusted composite index made up of five components from the survey declined from February levels. The five components are new orders, production, employment, vendor performance and inventories. **********Forty-three percent of those reporting said that production levels rose last month. And new orders, which have been improving steadily since the beginning of the year, registered a sharp increase, to 48 percent of those polled. **********That total is the highest since May 1977, said Charles T. Haffey, chairman of the purchasing managers' business survey committee. Since new orders generally lead further increases in output by a month or two, the sharp rise suggests that production should continue to rise. **********Aside from the rise in new orders, the survey (which is based on replies from about 250 industrial companies) contained additional evidence that the economy is recovering. Inventory Shrinkage Slower **********Inventory liquidation continued last month, but the rate of decline was the smallest in the last 18 months. The number of companies reporting lower employment was the smallest since June 1981. And more than half of those surveyed said they felt optimistic about the course of the economy over the next 12 months. Last November only 25 percent were optimistic about the economy's prospects. **********There was a decline in the organization's composite index, which dipped to 54.7 percent last month from 56.6 percent in February. In spite of that drop, however, the index is still above 50 percent, the level the association says indicates that the economy is in an expanding phase. **********''The report is clearly good news for the American economy,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities, ''but the drop in the index comes at a time of the year when business generally starts to pick up.'' **********Mr. Yardeni said the decline in the index was consistent with recent reports of drops in factory and new car orders, evidence that suggests the recovery is not as robust as some people had initially expected. **********''You can make a pretty convincing case we are still recovering,'' he added, ''but it is not straight up. The purchasing managers are seeing better times, but they are not that great yet.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/busin.print_headline: BRAZIL ASKS NEW LOANS; OUTLAYS UP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/busin.body_text: **********Two months after securing a multibillion-dollar rescue package through international financing, Brazil, the world's largest debtor nation, is seeking to borrow more money. **********The country's spending in the first quarter of 1983 has grown far beyond the guidelines established with the International Monetary Fund, which sponsored the rescue package along with the United States Treasury and a consortium of European and American banks, and an I.M.F. official from Washington is in Brasilia, the capital, asking for explanations. **********''The program really only got started in March, and the I.M.F. may have overlooked the fact that it takes time for exports and payments of this type to generate cash surpluses,'' said Antonio Gebauer, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the principal American banking figure in the international operation of assistance to Brazil. Alarm on Public Deficit **********He added, however, that the country would have to get ''tougher'' with the giant state companies whose debts have swollen the public deficit to a point that has alarmed the I.M.F. **********Brazilian officials are telling their creditor banks that they require at least $1.5 billion to overcome cash-flow problems between now and June. More pessimistic estimates in the banking community put the country's needs at $3 billion to $4 billion. **********''Brazil can't get through to June without doing something, and it will depend on how effective it is in getting banks to pay up and how the trade balance goes,'' a New York bank representative said, asking that his name and his bank's name not be used. Goal Is $6 Billion Surplus **********The key determinate in figuring the final total will be the degree of success Brazil has in meeting its goal of a $6 billion trade surplus this year. After a slow start at the beginning of the year, the country registered a $514 million surplus in March, and Government officials are hoping for a $700 million positive balance in April. **********The trade figures have been greeted with some skepticism, however.  There are rumors that Brazil bought petroleum on credit and sold it for cash as a March export to make its exports column look better. **********Against this backdrop, calls for a formal moratorium on debt repayments are growing, particularly from the political opposition in Brazil that was newly enfranchised last November by the first gubernatorial elections allowed by the ruling military in 17 years.  The opposition is arguing that recent riots in Sao Paulo are a sign that social conditions do not permit Brazil to impose austerity on the country to reduce its estimated $88 billion foreign debt. **********Among those supporting a repayment moratorium are Tancredo Neves, governor of the state of Minas Gerais and the most widely respected figure in the opposition Brazilian Democratic Movement Party. An official party statement on the economic situation called the I.M.F.'sprescription for the country ''suicidal and unacceptable.'' **********While the Government is discouraging talk of a formal moratorium, it is also withholding payments on many overdue foreign debts because of a lack of funds. These delayed payments reached a total of $999 million by the end of March, according to Jose Carlos Madeira Serrano, International Director of the Central Bank. Inflation, Public Sector Debt **********Two factors, soaring inflation and public sector debt, are drawing particular attention from Ana Maria Jul, the I.M.F. monitor who has returned to Brasilia two months ahead of her scheduled visit. Though the country pledged to bring inflation down to 90 percent from last year's 99.7 percent, first-quarter inflation registered 38 percent, which, projected annually, would produce a rate of 162 percent. **********Jose Milton Dallari, the Government's secretary of supply and prices, said he was still predicting a year-end figure of 90 percent. Joseph O'Neill, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo, however, said that member companies were operating on assumptions of 150 percent year-end inflation. **********The debt figure for the first quarter has not been made public, but Government officials concede it has greatly exceeded the $6.4 billion foreseen in the I.M.F. accord. In the period, the Government was $950 million over budget in outlays for subsidies for oil, wheat and sugar and special Banco do Brasil coverage for delayed payments on the foreign debts of state companies. New Formula Asked **********The country had agreed to reduce the deficit this year from 16.9 percent to 8.8 percent of gross national product. It is now asking the I.M.F. to replace this formula with one that would allow the country to establish a fixed numerical goal rather than one tied to its gross national product. It is arguing that the percentage formula was based on a 90 percent inflation prediction and could not take into account a 30 percent devaluation decreed Feb. 18 that had the effect of increasing public debt. **********The funds that Brazil is seeking abroad are supposed to go toward trade-related and interbank credits, but if there is resistance to that approach, the country may have to try to put together another jumbo loan. Those two categories were known as Project Three and Project Four of a four-part plan that Brazil put to international banks in December in New York. Project One, a jumbo loan of $4.4 billion, and Project Two, the rescheduling of $4.7 billion in amortization payments for the year, were signed on Feb. 28. **********Brazil had originally sought $10.6 billion in interbank credits but then lowered the goal to $7.5 billion. The country has only succeeded in attracting $6.2 billion. As for export financing, bankers say that an additional $1.5 billion is needed. **********Officials argue that the liquidity crunch will start to end in June with the accumulation of foreign currency from its trade surpluses.  The original part of the rescue package had been $600 million in bridge loans from American banks in answer to the original liquidity crisis in September. Then in December the United States Government and the Bank for International Settlements, representing European central banks, each granted Brazil loans of $1.2 billion. **********The American loan has been repaid, but the Bank for International Settlements loan is still being repaid with $450 million of each $511 million quarterly draw down from the I.M.F. One foreign banker pointed out that this obligation in effect was negating the purpose of the I.M.F. mission, which was to restore the country's liquidity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/15/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Executive Assails Commercials on Radio
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/15/busin.body_text: **********Radio apparently suffers from the same handicap as magazines - the very best agency creative people only want to make television ads.  Or in the words of Philip B. Dusenberry, vice chairman and executive creative director of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, ''The answer is simple: A great many creative people just don't give a bloody damn about radio.'' **********Those, you must admit, were pretty strong words for the keynote speaker at the annual Association of National Advertisers/Radio Advertising Bureau. **********He observed that over at the agency, when viewing a rough cut of a TV commercial that really contains a spark, someone will say it's got magic. **********''Well, in radio,'' he noted, ''the magic is missing. Instead we're pummeled into an insolent melange of shouts and screams at a decibel level that's enough to put your teeth on edge and have you reaching for a Valium. We hear a gridlock of commercial messages - sometimes five in a row - one pancaked atop the other in a Crazy Eddie confetti - an audio-graffiti that has you longing for the blessed silence of a lonely room.'' **********In truth, he said, radio commercials are the real test of an advertising writer since it is a solo flight without the friendly cooperation one gets from an art director and producer when working on a TV ad. **********''It's still one of the few creative jobs where the writer goes back into the spotlight,'' Mr. Dusenberry said.  As usual, Miles David, vice chairman of the Radio Advertising Bureau, had lined up an impressive roster of important radio users from the advertising community who were willing to go on record about their successes. All of them were welcomed by Charles B. Fruit, chairman of the Association of National Advertisers' radio committee and vice president, corporate media, of Anheuser-Busch Companies. **********Anheuser-Busch's $40 million in annual radio advertising spending makes it the second-biggest user of the medium after the Chrysler Corporation, which was also represented yesterday in the person of Joseph L. Hickey, manager of corporate advertising. **********Mr. Hickey said that the way the troubled automobile manufacturer used heavy radio advertising ''proved to us that radio worked.'' ''It's no wonder that Miles invited me to speak,'' he went on.  ''Chrysler was the client that drew more attention to massive, strong use of radio than anyone else. Maybe Chrysler should be credited with making radio 'Red Hot.' '' He was alluding to the theme line of a Radio Advertising Bureau ad campaign. **********Also on deck were a pair representing the New York State Lottery, Russ Gladieux, executive deputy dirctor, and Paul Goldsmith, executive vice president of the agency, Rumrill-Hoyt. Mr. Gladieux said that 60 percent of the $4 million advertising budget goes into radio and has since 1981, when the lottery people made the change in the interest of ''efficiency and economy and at the same time to reach as many of our potential customers as frequently and effectively as possible.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/busin.main_headline: PatentsStacy V. Jones Ads on TV And Radio Edited Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/busin.print_headline: PatentsStacy V. Jones Ads on TV And Radio Edited Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON **********A CIVIL engineer was granted a patent this week for what he calls a television- and radio- commercial killer. The system is designed to recognize from its memory commercial terms and to blank out the picture and sound until the advertising section of the program is over. **********Albert P. Novak of Floral Park, L.I., received patent 4,420,769, which is entitled ''Device for the Automatic Editing, at the Receiver, of Unwanted Program Material From Broadcast Electrical Signals.'' **********Under the system, a substitute for the eliminated material can be inserted if that is desired. Existing receivers can be used. The equipment includes a synchronization clock that times the sampling of broadcasts, and a comparison unit for detecting commercial aspects. **********The operator can press a button to record any phrase or picture that he does not want repeated. This is assigned a number in the unit's memory and brings a cancellation if it reappears. Similarly another number is assigned to the end of the commercial and the device, upon recognizing that number, will return to the normal broadcast receipt mode. **********Mr. Novak hopes to license production of his machine. In 1981 he patented a telephone device that will identify a caller before the telephone is answered. It can be programmed to remember which callers will be welcome and at what time of day, and to ring the bell only for those acceptable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/world.main_headline: UNREST IN CHILE BRINGS PINOCHET FIRST TOUGH TEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/world.print_headline: UNREST IN CHILE BRINGS PINOCHET FIRST TOUGH TEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/world.body_text: **********For the first time since he seized power nearly 10 years ago, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is being seriously challenged, according to supporters as well as opponents. **********Western diplomats and even many of the general's advisers say that the newfound willingness of hundreds of thousands of Chileans to defy the Government with protests and strikes in the last six weeks reflects a fundamental political shift in the country in favor of democracy. The general has said that there will be no elections until at least 1989. **********The Chilean ruler, who took over in 1973 in a violent coup that led to the death of the democratically elected President, Salvador Allende Gossens, is not about to be toppled, the officials and diplomats said. But they said the labor unrest had coincided with grumblings in the army over rumors of corruption in the general's family and his handling of the growing dissent. The army is General Pinochet's base of power and he could not survive the loss of its support, they said. **********'Reaching a Turning Point' **********''Pinochet is reaching a turning point,'' one Western diplomat here said. ''It's all part of a general movement to force a definition of the transition to democracy.'' **********But blocking the movement has been the stern personality of the 67-year old general himself, according to some of his advisers, who have been suggesting he open up the Government to allow more participation by the opposition. **********One senior official said the President does not want to appear to be giving in to pressure. An adviser outside the Government, as well as prominent Chileans who know the President, said his instinct has been to crack down on the dissent, not open up to it. State of Siege Considered **********The officials said that until a week ago, when he returned from a trip to northern Chile, General Pinochet was determined to declare a state of siege, suspending all civil rights. They said he was soothed by his aide, Brig. Gen. Santiago Sinclair, on the way from the airport and finally talked out of it by advisers such as Foreign Minister Miguel Alex Schweitzer Walters and Interior Minister Enrique Montero Marx. **********''Basically, he doesn't believe in democracy,'' one adviser said, pointing to a speech 10 days ago in which General Pinochet criticized politicians as being irresponsible and said that democracy was the ''culture dish'' of Communism. **********The general is said to be obsessed with Communist infiltration, even writing books about it, but Western diplomats and Government officials said the Chilean Communists are politically weak today. **********''It looks like a slow-moving Greek tragedy,'' a Western diplomat said. ''You have a personality and world view which is fixed and coming into increasing clash with political reality.'' 6 Killed in Protests **********The clash has led to six deaths in the two recent nationwide protests. Many Chileans fear the violence will worsen as militant political and labor leaders vow to continue the protests monthly. **********Union calls for a national strike last week failed as the Government arrested many of the leaders. But copper workers and truck owners struck in protest for the first time in 10 years and union leaders said they were uniting for future strikes.  Tonight the unions and the truck owners formally called off their strike. **********General Pinochet is scheduled to stay in office until at least 1989 under a Constitution approved overwhelmingly in a plebiscite three years ago. Since last year many supporters, such as business groups and conservative intellectuals, have recommended that he begin taking transitional steps such as holding municipal elections or ending the five-year-old state of emergency, which bans political activity. **********General Pinochet's response was to create a study commission in March and, two weeks ago, end prior book censorship, allow some exiles to return and publish the internal debates of legislative commissions. **********''It was too little, too late,'' one Government official said. Strong Line Recommended **********The isolation of the general is such that when Brigadier Montero, the Interior Minister, invited leaders of the right-wing National Party and the centrist Social Democratic Party to join the Government at secret meetings in the last two weeks they refused, advisers to General Pinochet said. **********Government hard-liners such as Economy Minister Manuel Martin Saez, one of the general's few close friends, have recommended he be tough. But Federico Willoughby, a right-wing former presidential spokesman, discounted the need for the advice. ''There is no one to the right of Pinochet,'' he said. **********General Pinochet has given only limited rein to the soft-liners, although in a Cabinet shuffle this year he gave them most top Government posts. His advisers said it was a way to keep their support and typical of a political acumen that had served the general well until now. Long a Popular Leader **********General Pinochet was popular among Chileans as late as six months ago, according to even his opponents. He was widely seen as a tough but honest leader who brought prosperity and peace after the chaos under Dr. Allende. **********But the country is gripped in a two-year old economic depression.  Unemployment is around 20 percent, according to the Government, and 13 percent of the work force are in emergency public works programs. **********Criticism formerly directed at his economic team's monetarist policies has now been turned on him. According to advisers outside the Government, his approval rating in secret Gallup polls commissioned by the Goverment has dropped from highs of around 70 percent three years ago to 18 percent today. **********They said said the general is now playing for time, six months or so, hoping the economy will revive. One option, they said, is a switch to populist, expanionist policies, but he is hemmed in by an agreement with the International Monetary Fund limiting spending in exchange for refinancing of an $18 billion foreign debt. Officers Reported Upset **********Meanwhile, many military officers are upset by reports that one of the general's daughters has received lucrative state contracts for her insurance brokerage business and a son-in-law has grazed his cattle on Government lands, Western diplomats and Chileans close to the military said. **********General Pinochet has listened to complaints by officials about his family, his advisers said. But the general, who is said to suffer personally over minor scandals and divorces among his five children, has not acted on the complaints as much as many officers say they would like. **********The army is intent on maintaining public order, but officers are uncertain if toughness by General Pinochet is the answer or the problem, one officer said.  A letter calling for a change of ''helmsman'' is reportedly circulating inside the army. **********But a military rebellion is unlikely any time soon, Chilean and foreign analysts said. The Chilean military is strongly hierarchical, is led by officers chosen by General Pinochet himself and traditionally has not engaged in coups. It took two years of chaos before the military overthrew Dr. Allende.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Cuba Labor Chief Denies Death Sentences on 5
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/16/world.body_text: **********The head of Cuba's trades unions has denied reports that five people were sentenced to death for attempting to organize a trades union in Cuba on the lines of Poland's banned Solidarity movement. **********But Roberto Veiga, who leads the Cuban Trades Union Federation, disclosed in a letter made public today that 33 Cubans have been given prison sentences for counterrevolutionary activities. **********In his letter to Ibrahim Zakaria, secretary general of the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trades Unions, based in Prague, Mr. Veiga strongly denied charges by some Western human rights organizations that five of those in jail had been sentenced to death for trying to organize a ''Solidarity type'' trade union in Cuba. **********''They never thought of defending trades union rights or of organizing a trades union,'' the letter said.  Mr. Veiga added that the 33 jailed had carried out ''numerous and continued acts of sabotage'' such as burning down work centers, setting fire to crops and planning attempts against the lives of Cuban leaders. **********''This is a group of persons who, under the inspiration of the Cuban counterrevolution located in the United States, with the support of the C.I.A. and the encouragement of Reagan, aimed at interrupting the peaceful construction of socialism,'' he said.
