https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/30/world.main_headline: 1,200 MARINES TO QUIT ISLAND FOR BEIRUT DUTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/30/world.print_headline: 1,200 MARINES TO QUIT ISLAND FOR BEIRUT DUTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/30/world.body_text: **********Defense Department officials said today that most of the 1,200 United States marines in the 6,000-member Grenada invasion force had been replaced by Army troops and would head for Lebanon in the ''next few days'' to relieve the Marine force stationed there. **********Marines made up the major part of the force in the early hours of the operation. As soon as initial objectives had been achieved, 5,000 Army paratroopers from the 82d Airborne Division began moving in to relieve them. **********Most of the 700 Army Rangers who participated in the initial assault also have been relieved, the Pentagon officials reported. **********The officials said the relief action by the 82d paratroopers not only would free the marines for use in Lebanon but also would give one of the Army's premier units combat experience. The relief of the Rangers was necessary, they added, because Rangers are too lightly equipped for sustained combat. **********Fleet Diverted for Invasion **********The marines, members of the 22d Marine Amphibious Unit, operate from a fleet of five support ships. In all, there are 1,800 marines on the ships, 1,200 of whom went ashore in the invasion.  According to Pentagon officials, the fleet was at sea and headed across the North Atlantic toward Lebanon when it was diverted to take part in the Grenada invasion. **********''Now they're about to resume their journey,'' a Defense Department spokesman said today. ''They'll leave in the next few days and should arrive there in about two weeks.'' The marines currently in Lebanon are members of the 24th Marine Amphibious Unit, which is part of the multinational force that is trying to keep the warring factions in Lebanon apart. They have been under considerable military pressure and lost more than 200 men when a terrorist bomb exploded in their barracks.   Relief Scheduled Before Invasion **********Their relief by the 22d Marine Amphibious Unit was scheduled well before that incident, however, and, despite the diversion by the 22d to Grenada, apparently will take place just about as scheduled. Marine Corps plans call for relief of units assigned to Lebanon every six months. **********A few hours before the start of the Grenada invasion, Pentagon spokesmen insisted that the 22d Marine Amphibious Unit was still headed across the Atlantic toward Lebanon. The spokesmen have since said that they were never informed by the Pentagon's operations room that there had been a change of course. **********Defense Department officials would not discuss whether the carrier battle group that accompanied the marines to Grenada also would sail east with them to Lebanon to relieve the carrier group that is supporting the marines in Beirut. The group includes the carrier Independence, a guided missile cruiser and four destroyers and frigates.   Cuban Ship at Anchor **********In another development, Navy officials reported that a Cuban ship that was asked to leave St. George's harbor when the invasion began was still anchored 12 miles off the island. **********''We're not sure what it's doing there,'' one official said. ''She left when requested. But she dropped anchor the minute she reached international waters and there's not much we can do about that. She could be serving as a radio relay station, though there's not much Cuban radio traffic left.'' **********The ship is the Vietnam Heroico. According to Navy records, she is 430 feet long, has a capacity of 13,000 cubic feet of cargo and 218 passengers, and made a number of trips to Angola during the early Cuban military involvement there. **********The Navy officials said they did not known when the ship arrived at St. George's or what it carried. United States intelligence sources have reported some military equipment was brought to Grenada by ship shortly before the invasion, but they have not specified which vessel was involved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/world.main_headline: A.P. SAYS ITS SHULTZ CAPTION WAS MISLEADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/world.print_headline: A.P. SAYS ITS SHULTZ CAPTION WAS MISLEADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/world.body_text: **********The Associated Press said yesterday that it supplied a misleading caption Wednesday with a picture of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. **********The picture, which showed the Secretary with his hands over his face while Gen. Paul X. Kelley, the Commandant of the Marine Corps, gave testimony, was distributed Wednesday and published Thursday by a large number of the news agency's 900 member newspapers across the country, including The New York Times. **********The A.P. caption, on which The Times's caption was based, said: **********''Secretary of State George Shultz covers his face as Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Paul X. Kelley refers to the troops 'who were sent to Vietnam a year ago,' and corrected himself to say 'into Lebanon' while testifying before a House Foreign Affairs Committee on the presence of U.S. Marines in Lebanon. Kelley's misstatement caused a few gasps in the room. He called the remark 'a Freudian slip.' '' **********A CBS News videotape of the incident, broadcast Thursday, showed a lapse of about seven seconds between General Kelley's misstatement and Mr. Shultz's gesture, which might have been one of weariness rather than, as the caption implied, a reaction to the general's words. **********Hal Buell, The A.P.'s executive news photo editor in New York, said yesterday that the caption had erred in saying Mr. Shultz had covered his face ''as'' the general made the misstatement. He also said ''something was lost'' when the photographer who took the picture spoke to the Washington bureau staff member who wrote the caption. **********''An attempt was made to make it as accurate as possible, but the precision just slipped a little bit,'' Mr. Buell said. ''The picture is a good one and the caption just kills it. The fault is that the caption lacks precision.'' **********The New York Times asked The A.P.'s Washington bureau about the caption at 3 P.M. Wednesday and was given assurances of its accuracy. **********Mr. Buell said ''a couple of dozen'' other news organizations made inquiries about the accuracy of the caption Thursday, after CBS News broadcast the videotape, and that The A.P. then distributed a corrective article and a substitute caption. **********John Hughes, a State Department spokesman, said at a news briefing yesterday that Mr. Shultz had expressed no reaction to the photograph and was ''taking it all rather lightly.'' He said he did not think Mr. Shultz had put his hands to his face out of surprise, and noted that the gesture had come after ''rather a long day of testifying.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/12/busin.body_text: **********International Thomson Business Press is proving that just because it usually buys existing magazines that does not mean it cannot start one from scratch. **********The three-year-old, Canadian-owned publishing company, already the owner of 35 magazines, 19 newsletters, 18 directories, five data bases and a few lines of books, on Sept. 1 established International Thomson Technology Information. **********And on May 1 that unit under the presidency of Daniel A. McMillan is scheduled to bring forth Management Technology, a paid-circulation monthly covering office and information technology. **********And, according to F. Douglas DeCarlo, the publisher, the issues covered may be all computer-based, but they will arise from high technology. **********Mr. DeCarlo was co-founder of Information Age magazine with Robert B. Forest, now the editor of Management Technology. James M.McGrane, the new director of marketing, was founding partner of Data Sources magazine. **********Ad rates for the new publication, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., start with a one-time black-and-white page going for $2,675 and a four-color for $3,745. Three subscription prices are currently being tested, but the cover price is already set at $4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/world.main_headline: Senate Panel Approves Radio Marti Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/world.print_headline: Senate Panel Approves Radio Marti Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/world.body_text: **********The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 13 to 4 today to authorize a proposal for United Statessponsored radio broadcasts to Cuba, to be known as Radio Marti. **********A similar bill was approved by the House in the last Congress and was approved by the same Senate committee but did not come up for a vote in the full Senate. **********The project would operate under the Board for International Broadcasting and would be similar to Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. **********The bill, which now goes to the full Senate, says the broadcasts should ''serve as a consistent and authoritative source of accurate, objective and comprehensive news,'' particularly about Cuba. The program is named after the 19th-century Cuban patriot Jose Marti. **********Sponsors of the proposal, which is backed by the Reagan Administration, say it is important for Cubans to know, for instance, of their Government's military activities in other nations. **********But Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, said the plan was ''ill-conceived'' and the station was ''likely to become a propaganda organ of the anti-Castro exile community.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/13/world.main_headline: WRITER BIDS SOVIET LET HIM EMIGRATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/13/world.print_headline: WRITER BIDS SOVIET LET HIM EMIGRATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/13/world.body_text: **********After a series of K.G.B searches, interrogations and threats, Georgi N. Vladimov, recognized as one of the Soviet Union's finest postwar writers, asked today to be allowed to emigrate. **********In a personal and sometimes bitter letter to Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, Mr. Vladimov traced his passage from a literary celebrity in the 1960's to a denounced outcast in the 1970's, and finally to recent threats of arrest against him and his wife, and demands that he write a letter by Jan. 20 disavowing his ''anti-Soviet work.'' **********''I am ready to accept the already familiar thorns of a Russian writer and walk under the vaults of Lefortovo Prison,'' he said, declaring that he would not write such a letter. **********But the K.G.B. security police has also threatened to arrest his wife, he said, and he would not permit another to suffer because of him. **********Another Solution Proposed **********''I propose another solution, less damaging to our Government's prestige,'' he wrote. ''I am ready to quit Russia. To be forced to this is painful and humiliating for us. We have already proved our love for Russia by the patience with which we endured persecution, repression, humiliation.'' **********The Vladimovs' Moscow apartment was searched in February 1982 and again on Dec. 28, when most of his manuscripts and correspondence were seized. Last week, Mr. Vladimov was interrogated by K.G.B.  agents for two days, and his wife, Natalya Kuznetsova, for three days. The questioning was purportedly about two dissidents facing trials, but the Vladimovs said the interrogators had also threatened them. **********The letter Mr. Vladimov was ordered to write was to include a listing of his purported anti-Soviet activities and of foreign contacts, and a promise to work only through official channels. **********Neither Mr. Vladimov nor his wife was given any indication that they would be allowed to emigrate. On the contrary, the writer said, one interrogator, Lieut. Col. Aleksei G. Gubinsky, said, ''We don't let criminals leave.'' Invitations From Abroad **********In his letter to Mr. Andropov, Mr. Vladimov said he had received invitations from the French chapter of the P.E.N. club, an international writers association, from French publishers and from West German institutes in Bonn and Cologne that could serve as pretexts for his departure. **********The decision to seek emigration seemed a wrenching one for Mr.  Vladimov, who is 51 and suffered a heart attack two years ago.  ''Well, I have raised the white flag,'' he said in a preface to his announcement that he had sent the letter to Mr. Andropov. ''I have thought of leaving for many years, since 1971. We all do. You think about reasons for leaving every morning, and every afternoon you think of reasons for staying. No one wants to leave, no one wishes it. The question is only whether to give in or not, or to suffer a bit longer. Aksyonov, Zinoviev, Kopelev, Voinovich, they all left in grief, were forced to leave.'' **********Vasily Aksyonov, Aleksandr Zinoviev, Lev Kopelev and Vladimir Voinovich are among the Russian writers who found themselves incapable of writing within the strictures of Soviet literature and ended up abroad. One of Last Dissident Writers **********Mr. Vladimov is one of the last noted dissident writers, not jailed, but outside the orbit of official literature.  In explaining his delay in asking to leave, Mr. Vladimov said: ''I always expected there would be some change, that after Brezhnev's death the stagnation would lift, that there would be fresh air.'' **********Then his scarred face, a part discolored from birth, broke into a smile.  ''In any event,'' he continued, ''if there is change, we will return.'' In his letter to Mr. Andropov, Mr. Vladimov described the acclaim that in 1961 greeted his first novel, ''Bolshaya Ruda''(''Big Ore''). The 30-year-old author was ushered into the Writers Union, with its status and perquisites. But Mr. Vladimov's next work, ''Three Minutes of Silence,'' turned the literary establishment away from him. From Guard Dog's Perspective **********It depicted Soviet fishermen in the northern seas as a despondent and selfish lot, without hope. And then came ''Faithful Ruslan,'' the underground classic told from the viewpoint of a guard dog let loose after a labor camp is closed. The dog unwittingly turns on a trainload of workers who, to the dog, seem a group of rebellious inmates. **********The story, Mr. Vladimov said, was based on his mother's recollections. A teacher, she was swept up in Stalin's purge of 1952 and served three years. His father disappeared in a war prisoners camp in Nazi Germany in 1943. **********Unable to have ''Faithful Ruslan'' published at home, Mr. Vladimov sent it abroad and it was published in the United States in 1979 by Simon & Schuster. Meanwhile, Mr. Vladimov had left the Writers Union and become head of an unofficial chapter of Amnesty International, the rights group. **********Mr. Vladimov notes that national chapters of Amnesty do not report on rights violations in their own country and he denies being a dissident. It is a title, he says, that ''they force on you.'' **********''Every writer who writes anything in this country is made to feel he has committed a crime,'' he said. ''You finish and wonder, will they forgive me? It is impossible to work like that. A writer cannot work here. They take your manuscripts, typewriter, copies, drafts.  You never have a complete draft, you write a few pages, copy them and quickly hide them. You can never read the work in progress to your wife, and, if you give it to a friend, you have 'spread anti-Soviet slander.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/world.main_headline: FOR AMERICANS IN PARIS, THE 'REAL' BICENTENNIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/world.print_headline: FOR AMERICANS IN PARIS, THE 'REAL' BICENTENNIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/world.body_text: **********''America's real Independence Day is Sept. 3, not July 4,'' said Joan K. Challinor, who teaches early American history at American University in Washington. ''That was when King George formally recognized the 13 colonies' independence by signing the Treaty of Paris.'' **********Dr. Challinor, who is founder and chairman of the National Committee for the Bicentennial of the Treaty of Paris, was speaking at City Hall here against a background of black three- cornered hats, stacked flintlock muskets, 18th-century uniforms, long dresses, lace caps and the twang of American accents. **********Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris, was giving a reception for the 500 or so American history enthusiasts who this week have been celebrating the treaty that ended the American War of Independence 200 years ago, by marching around Paris dressed up as soldiers from the American Revolutionary army and the French expeditionary force that helped it to victory. **********The ceremonies marking the anniversary of this momentous yet almost forgotten event are proving a curious mixture of the sacred and the profane, delighting bystanders and infuriating taxi drivers but also reminding the French of their deep historic bond with the United States.   A Mass at Notre Dame **********Today the colorful American force, codenamed Expedition Liberte, filled the nave of Notre Dame Cathedral for a mass in memory of those who died in the American War of Independence. The mass was offered by Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger, the Roman Catholic Primate of France. **********In his sermon the Cardinal struck a solemn note, calling the American Declaration of Independence the first true ''declaration of the rights of man'' and urging his audience to ''safeguard man's inalienable rights in today's difficult world.'' **********Afterward the troops marched off toward City Hall to the sound of fife and drum, the blaring of police sirens and the honking of angry motorists. A little over half the men were in the uniforms of regiments of the old United States Continental Line, the rest in those worn by the French forces of the Duke de Lauzan. **********''I'm for French-American friendship, but can't it be more restrained - we've been stuck here 30 minutes!'' a taxi driver said as he waited for the parade to pass.   'This Is Most Moving' **********''For me this is most moving; only Americans could have organized something like this,'' said Count Michel de Rochambeau, a direct descendant of the commander of the French forces that went to the aid of the Americans. **********''It may be true that self-interest encouraged France to take advantage of the troubles its old rival England was having in America, just 20 years after expelling us from there,'' Mayor Chirac said at his reception. ''But it was an act which sealed an alliance founded on fraternity.'' **********This week the American force has laid wreaths at the tomb of Lafayette, before a statute of Rochambeau, at a square commemorating the decisive battle of Yorktown and at 56 Rue Jacob in Paris's Latin Quarter. That is the site of the old Hotel de York, where at 10 A.M. on Sept. 3, 1783, Benjamin Franklin, John Adams and John Jay signed the historic peace treaty with David Hartley, representing England. **********Saturday morning, the anniversary of the signing, the American force will march with fixed bayonets up the Champs-Elysees before laying a wreath on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier under the Arc de Triomphe, a rare privilege for foreigners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/21/world.main_headline: PAPANDREOU RENEWING GREECE'S TIES TO WEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/21/world.print_headline: PAPANDREOU RENEWING GREECE'S TIES TO WEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/21/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist Government, which took office in October 1981, is approaching midterm with a reputation of independence but with a record of having renewed Greece's traditional ties with the West. **********The Socialists have not put into effect the pledges they made, during the election campaign, to close down the American military bases in Greece and withdraw from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Economic Community. **********Instead, the Papandreou Government recently concluded a five-year agreement with the United States for continuation of the bases. It has assumed the presidency of the Common Market for a six-month term and obtained vital economic aid from the market. It has established almost normal working relations with NATO and has even begun to talk to the nation's chief adversaries, the Turks, mainly on cultural and trade exchanges. **********At the same time, however, Mr. Papandreou has urged Western Europe to take a strong stand against United States involvement in Central America, and he has backed the idea of a freeze in nuclear weapons. **********There has apparently been some erosion of the Socialists' popularity, particularly among members of the radical left, especially the Communists, whose leaders have accused the Government of abandoning its program of ''change'' and remaining in the Western camp. **********A series of strikes has also indicated growing public impatience with what is viewed as the Government's failure to come to grips with the serious problems of unemployment and inflation. Unemployment stands at 10 percent and is rising, and inflation is now running at an annual rate of 21 percent. **********In the latest action, about 70 percent of the nation's bakers shut down for ''long summer holidays'' during the month of August in a protest over Government control of bread prices. **********Apparently in response to such discontent, Prime Minister Papandreou said recently that the Government would concentrate on the economy now that the negotiations over the United States bases were out of the way. **********Despite complaints, a majority of Greeks still seem to like the Papandreou blend of Socialist theory, nationalism and pragmatic politics, according to Western diplomats. Mr. Papandreou's party, the Panhellenc Socialist Movement, has a comfortable margin in Parliament, and the main opposition party, the conservative New Democracy, whose leaders are at odds, appears to be in no position to present an alternative to the Government, according to the diplomats and opposition politicians. **********The main challenge has come from the Communist Party, with its ability to organize protest demonstrations through the large measure of control it exercises in labor unions. **********Mr. Papandreou's hard bargaining with Greece's allies may have produced some positive results but it has also fostered a climate of uneasiness, particularly in conservative business circles, as to where the country is headed, according to Greek and foreign businessmen and the Western diplomats. **********Doubts were reinforced by official talk about ''socialization.'' The economy, already in difficulty because of the world economic crisis, has suffered from the uncertainty this created. Although the Government has avoided nationalizations and gone out of its way to encourage private enterprise, investment has remained stagnant. **********Meanwhile, under the rotation system, Greece took over the presidency of the European Economic Community on July 1, and it has made every effort to project an image of competence and responsibility. **********Today, Greece pledged ''full support'' to Portugal in its efforts to gain admission into the Common Market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.body_text: **********Newsweek magazine, in the cover article of its current issue, carries a ''special report'' on the purported diaries of Hitler. The report includes some brief excerpts from the diaries and says that, if they are genuine, scholars will ''learn a great deal'' from them, but at the same time it raises questions about their authenticity. **********In its report, Newsweek quotes an academic expert on Hitler, Prof.  Gerhard L. Weinberg of the University of North Carolina, as saying, ''on balance I am inclined to consider the material authentic.'' But, the article goes on, he said that further authentication would be needed to ''make the verdict airtight.'' **********Professor Weinberg says in a separate article accompanying Newsweek's cover article that he looked at some of the materials for two hours in a bank vault in Zurich and that during his examination he was able to scan about 5 percent of each of 15 to 20 volumes. **********''The new find should be read with a giant saltshaker at hand,'' Professor Weinberg wrote. ''There is still room -however unlikely - for suspecting that the whole thing is a hoax. An obvious motive would be money. Another would be an attempt to rehabilitate Hitler.''  'Are They Genuine?' **********On the magazine's cover is written: ''Hitler's Secret Diaries: Are they Genuine? How They Could Rewrite History; Hitler and the Jews.'' Newsweek ran a full-page advertisement in The New York Times and The Washington Post yesterday publicizing its coverage of the purported diaries. ''These controversial papers could rewrite the history of the Third Reich from Hitler's rise to power to his suicide in the ruins of Berlin,'' the advertisement says. **********''They shed new light on his character, his plans for war, Munich, the miracle of Dunkirk, the flight of Rudolf Hess, his military campaigns, his relations to his lover, Eva Braun.'' **********''Are they real? Are they a whitewash?'' the advertisement asks.  ''Newsweek carefully considers both questions.'' Asked why Newsweek had published a cover article on the Hitler diaries without final authentication, a spokesman for the magazine, Gary Gerard, said, ''We felt, very frankly, that the find in itself was a major event.'' Doubts About Authenticity **********''We make it clear that there are some doubts'' about the documents' authenticity, he added.  ''In the end,'' the magazine's cover article says, ''Newsweek editors decided not to buy rights to the diaries, principally because they wanted more systematic and authoritative authentication.'' The article also says that Newsweek disagreed with the plan of the German magazine Stern, which offered publication rights to several United States news organizations, ''to publish installments of the diaries in small batches over a long period of time - as much as 18 months.'' **********There are reports that Newsweek offered $3 million to Stern for the rights to publish the Hitler diaries. Stern, however, demanded a fee higher than Newsweek was willing to pay, according to editors at Newsweek, and after the failure of the two magazines to agree on a price, Newsweek decided to disclose some of the materials it had been allowed to see during the negotiations, they said. Timetable Advanced **********Mr. Gerard, the Newsweek spokesman, said that the magazine preferred not to disclose the amount of its bid for the rights to publish the dairies. ''The Times of London broke an embargo and Stern moved up its timetable,'' he said, ''so we no longer felt compelled to abide by any kind of confidential agreement that may have existed.'' **********A spokesman at Time magazine, Brian Brown, would not say whether or not Time had bid for the rights to publish the purported diaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.main_headline: AMEX OPTIONS SUIT BY GOLDEN NUGGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.print_headline: AMEX OPTIONS SUIT BY GOLDEN NUGGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Attorneys for Golden Nugget Inc. have sued the American Stock Exchange and the Options Clearing Corporation in an action they say could set a precedent for all companies with options trading on a securities exchange. **********The suit charges that the two defendants issued and listed put and call options without the permission of the company. Golden Nugget owns and operates hotel-casino complexes in Las Vegas and Atlantic City. **********Jayson Burton Lumish, a lawyer for the company, said in an interview over the weekend that the Amex and the options corporation ''are using the Golden Nugget name to create a product - the options - being marketed to the public without our approval and without the payment of any compensation to the company.'' **********The options corporation, which is based in Chicago, serves as a subsidiary for all four exchanges that list options for trading. In addition to the Amex, options are traded on the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Philadelphia Exchange and the Pacific Exchange. **********Effect on Other Options Is Seen **********''If we win this case,'' Mr. Lumish said, ''it will mean that every company with options listed for trading on an exchange will have the right to approve or disapprove the listing and, at the very least, can demand compensation for the use of its name.'' **********The suit was filed last month in the Federal District Court in Las Vegas. Mr. Lumish is a member of Rifkind, Sterling & Levin, a Beverly Hills, Calif., firm that specializes in securities law. **********Options permit their holders to buy or sell shares of the underlying stock within specified time periods at a set price. Golden Nugget is an actively traded issue listed on the New York Stock Exchange and its options have become a popular vehicle on the Amex, where they first began trading on Aug. 17. **********Golden Nugget is seeking the recovery of damages - as yet undetermined - and whatever profits it can prove that the defendants have derived. In part, Golden Nugget charges ''a profound and adverse effect on the reputation and goodwill'' of its name. **********The attorney said that depositions in the case are scheduled for mid- November in Chicago and New York, where the Amex is based. **********Golden Nugget's common stock, recently split 5-for-1, closed Friday on the Big Board at $14.875, unchanged. The stock, which does not pay a cash dividend, sold for as little as 50 cents a share in 1976 and traded earlier this year at a record price of $19.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/world.body_text: **********President Reagan says that he can foresee a meeting sometime this year with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, but that there are no plans for such a session. **********Mr. Reagan made the statement in an interview Friday with The Sunday Times of London that was made public today. He told the newspaper he strongly believed that despite differences between the United States and the Soviet Union ''peace is achievable.'' **********As to a meeting with Mr. Andropov, he said he was not setting any conditions except that there be advance certainty of ''some significant results.'' **********'In Touch Constantly' **********''We are in touch constantly,'' Mr. Reagan said of Mr. Andropov, ''seeking areas of discussions for a meeting that could be beneficial to both sides.'' **********Senior Administration officials confirmed today that there were no plans for a Reagan-Andropov meeting. They said they expected that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko would have to meet first and that no Shultz-Gromyko meeting was set. **********In other matters, Mr. Reagan said he was ''very hopeful'' of progress in the Middle East.  Referring to talks last week in Washington with Israeli and Lebanese officials, Mr. Reagan said that ''we're optimistic'' an agreement will be worked out by Philip C. Habib, the special envoy, for achieving the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces from Lebanon. **********''I believe that once that's accomplished,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''King Hussein will offer himself as the negotiator to continue the peace negotiations involving all the other Middle East problems.'' **********King Hussein of Jordan has been urged by the United States to enter into negotiations with Israel and Egypt on Palestinian rights in the occupied territories, but he has been waiting for approval of such a move by the P.L.O. and by other Arabs, as well as signs that Israel will leave Lebanon. **********The King, in a news conference in London on Saturday, said that he would meet with Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader, in Amman in coming days and that ''possibly within a short time'' he would clarify his position. **********King Hussein met with Mr. Habib in London on Saturday night, but there was no word available here on the results of those talks. 'What I Would Resist' **********Asked if he could foresee a meeting with Mr. Andropov sometime this year, Mr. Reagan replied: ''Yes, I can see that, though there are no immediate plans. I think what I would resist is a kind of get-acquainted meeting because, I think, such a meeting raises people's expectations so high that then we'd just be able to say, 'Well, we got acquainted and said hello' and not have any results.'' **********He said there should never be conditions for such a meeting, except to determine ''in advance the subjects that should be discussed, to be certain there will be some significant results.'' **********Mr. Reagan's last discussion of a summit meeting, however, included a clear condition for the signing of a treaty on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles. This occurred in an open letter at the end of January in which he invited Mr. Andropov to meet with him to sign an agreement banning all medium-range nuclear missiles, the so-called zero option for dealing with those weapons. **********The Soviet leader rejected the invitation. since it was conditioned on acceptance of the zero option.  In a recent speech in Orlando, Fla., Mr. Reagan alarmed some Europeans by depicting Moscow as representing the forces of evil in the world. This led to some interpretations that he was not interested in pursuing agreements with the Soviet Union. **********But Mr. Reagan said all he was trying to do was to face up to the differences between the two countries and not ''sweep the differences under the rug and pretend they don't exist.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.body_text: **********French and American differences over trade with the Soviet Union have spilled over into plans for a sevennation dinner that Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Bill Brock, United States trade representative, have scheduled for Paris next month. **********The French Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, told European Economic Community foreign ministers in Luxembourg Monday that France, angered by the Reagan Administration's efforts to tighten East-West trade controls, would refuse to join the Americans at the dinner on May 10. Despite a rebuff by France, the United States is going ahead. **********''If the French decide not to come,'' said Ann Dore McLaughlin, Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs at the Treasury, ''it would mean that they would not participate, of their own choosing, in what we hope will be fruitful discussions.'' More Restrictions Anticipated **********According to reports from Europe, the French and several other countries fear the American aim is to press them toward a more restrictive approach on East-West trade before the economic summit meeting on Memorial Day weekend in Williamsburg, Va. **********However, Mrs. McLaughlin said the dinner was not related to the summit meeting and represented the first structured effort to have an in-depth exchange on the links between world monetary and trade problems. **********Other American officials discovered that the French had really not decided about whether to attend the dinner, and some analysts said that France seemed to be embarked on what they said is a periodic maneuver of calculated mischief. **********Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkel was told by Michel Camdessus in the French Finance Ministry that President Francois Mitterrand had still not made a final decision, according to officials here. **********Meanwhile, the French Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, who has strongly criticized American economic policy, has canceled a visit to Washington on Thursday, in what was seen as another display of pique. **********He had been expected for talks with Treasury Secretary Regan and other finance ministers gathered for a meeting of the joint development committee of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Mr. Camdessus is to attend instead. **********The official explanation was that Mr. Delors had to be in Paris Friday for a Cabinet meeting on the economic program.  Mr. Delors, in recent remarks before the National Assembly in Paris, accused the United States of ''contempt and insensibility'' toward its allies by not checking the high exchange rates of the dollar. Exchange rate disorder, he said, is complicating France's plans to deal with domestic economic problems. **********The Treasury said the invitation to the working dinner May 10 and a further meeting May 11 had already been accepted by several of those invited, including Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the heads of the I.M.F., the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Organization for Economic Coopertion and Development. **********They were asked to attend along with trade and finance ministers of the countries attending the meeting: the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and Canada.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from the final communique of the ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, as contained in the English-language text distributed Tuesday by the 24-nation organization: **********At its meeting on 9th-10th May, the Council of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development at ministerial level agreed on a medium-term approach to sustaining and broadening the economic recovery now under way. They agreed that increased sustainable noninflationary growth in the O.E.C.D. countries must be aimed at in order to reduce the present very high levels of unemployment. **********Ministers recognized that the powerful economic linkages among countries and regions imply a collective responsibility to shape policies so as to strengthen the international trading, monetary and financial systems. **********Accordingly, their governments intend to: **********- Take advantage of room for growth, which is now emerging in an important part of the O.E.C.D. area, to promote job creation and higher employment. **********- Make use individually and collectively of the favorable conditions provided by economic recovery to reverse protectionist trends. **********- Work to resolve international debt problems in a trade expansionary way as recovery and adjustment by debtor countries proceed. **********- Provide more effective help to the poorer developing countries. Concern Over Unemployment **********Ministers welcomed the further achievements in reducing inflation.  They are very concerned, however, about the high and rising levels of unemployment. It is therefore encouraging that signs of an upturn have now emerged in several O.E.C.D. economies. While uncertainties and risks remain, ministers agreed that prospects for continuing recovery are better than they have been for several years, and that insuring the transition to sustained noninflationary growth and higher unemployment is the central task of policy. **********Ministers agreed on the following policy principles for all member countries: **********- Policies need to be set firmly in a medium-term framework to make clear the steadiness of policy intent. **********- It is important for the consistency of policies that each member country take account of the international implications of member countries' policies taken together. **********- The achievement of greater exchange rate stability, which does not imply rigidity, is a major objective and commitment to be pursued. Easing of Interest Rates **********As regards monetary policy, monetary aggregates should allow for output growth which is sustainable over the medium term, with continued control of inflation, permitting a continued easing of interest rates. Current monetary policies are generally consistent with this approach. Targets for monetary aggregates should not be lowered in response to lower oil prices. Similarly, monetary policy should not accommodate any resurgence of inflationary wage and other income claims. **********Structural budget deficits need to be reduced to make room for the investment needed to sustain growth and employment. Where future structural deficits loom large, it is important to act now to insure that deficits on this scale will not materialize, thus permitting interest rates to ease. Adherence to Monetary Policies **********In some other countries, accounting for about 20 percent of O.E.C.D. gross national product, further progress against inflation is required and structural impediments to better performance are more pronounced. As a result, growing room in the near term is less.  For such countries, ministers agreed that perseverance with nonaccommodating monetary policy is required and structural budget deficits must be reduced further as part of a consistent medium-term approach. **********In the remaining member countries, despite serious efforts, inflation remains very high, while the international recession and chronic structural problems mean high rates of unemployment and underemployment. In such countries, ministers agreed that limited flexibility of markets, structural imbalances and differences in monetary and fiscal management are central problems, which must be addressed at their core. **********Ministers noted that during a period of severe and persistent economic and social difficulties, the world trading system has essentially been preserved. They recognized, however, that there has been a continuation, and even extension, of protectionist trade and domestic support measures to shelter weak industries and companies from the full impact of the recession. A return to sustained growth requires more positive adjustment policies, more reliance on market forces and more productive investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Toshiba Gains, Mitsubishi Up **********TOKYO, Oct. 27 (AP) - The Toshiba Corporation and the Mitsubishi Electric Company, two leading Japanese makers of semiconductors, office equipment and other electronic products, said today that their fiscal first-half earnings rose modestly from a year earlier. **********Toshiba said net income edged up 1.1 percent, while Mitsubishi reported a 3.3 percent increase. **********Toshiba said profit for the six months ended Sept. 30 rose to $107.4 million, from $106.2 million a year earlier, while sales grew 6.6 percent, to $4.03 billion, from $3.78 billion. Sales rose sharply for semiconductors, office-automation equipment, medical-electronics equipment and color picture tubes, giving its entire communication-electronics equipment division a gain of 22 percent. **********Mitsubishi said first-half profit edged up to $52.6 million, from $50.9 million, and sales rose 5.2 percent, to $3.04 billion, from $2.89 billion. Exports rose 4.6 percent and accounted for 24 percent of total sales, it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/01/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Copper Shares' Price Outlook
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/01/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Copper Shares' Price Outlook
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/01/busin.body_text: **********NEARLY two months ago, David Healy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.  accorded a ''neutral'' rating to copper issues. ''At least for now,'' the analyst told his clients, ''these stocks seem uninteresting, and we would suggest other areas for new investment.'' **********Swept along with the rising tide of stock prices, all three issues - Asarco, Phelps Dodge and Newmont Mining - thereupon proceeded to score creditable gains. **********But Mr. Healy has not changed his mind about prospects for these companies. In an interview last Thursday, he said flatly, ''I would use the three stocks as a source of funds.'' In Wall Street parlance, that means he thinks money invested in these securities could be put to better use elsewhere. **********Basic factors affecting the copper industry, according to the analyst, have not changed. ''Despite the economic revival, copper's 'supply side' seems more than ample,'' Mr. Healy stated in his basic study. ''Mine capacity is still rising, and production, despite a good deal of shutdown capacity in the United States, is still outrunning demand. **********''Meanwhile, inventories, at the highest level since 1978, are still rising. The last three years of sluggish or nonexistent growth in the industrial countries have left copper demand less than supply, so even a vigorous economic recovery may not be sufficient to create a copper shortage.'' **********In yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Asarco fell 5/8, to 41. Phelps Dodge, also down 5/8, closed at 31 1/4, while Newmont Mining eased 1/4, to 57. Last week, all three issues edged higher. **********Prices of these stocks have been climbing since the spring or summer of 1982, following sharp drops in earlier months. The shares of Asarco Inc., for example, have ranged between 18 3/4 and 44 1/4 during the last 52 weeks. They underwent a sustained decline for more than a year after the price topped out in the low 50's in late 1980.  The company is a leading producer of copper, silver, lead, zinc and other nonferrous metals. **********The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the largest independent domestic producer of copper, has seen the price of its shares fluctuate between 18 1/4 and 34 over the last 52-week period. In April 1981 the stock sold as high as 48 1/2. **********Shares of the Newmont Mining Corporation, a leading copper producer in the United States, have ranged between 27 5/8 and 62 during the last 52 weeks. This issue traded as high as 79 1/4 in August 1981. **********Meanwhile, a potentially negative signal for Newmont Mining's stock has turned up in the latest issue of Flow Watch, a summary of market indicators issued every two weeks by Salomon Brothers. During the 10 trading days ended May 20, Newmont Mining gained 1 3/8, to 56 3/4, although the Salomon computers detected a net money outflow of $10.4 million in trading of the stock. **********Flow Watch tracks the movement of money into and out of stocks.  These flows, when correlated with price changes, can indicate whether selling or buying pressure predominates. Although money flows are not an infallible indicator of future price action, a sign of ''selling on strength,'' as exhibited in recent trading of Newmont Mining, can represent a potentially negative investment situation, according to Salomon Brothers. **********At Drexel Burnham Lambert, Mr. Healy has constructed earnings estimates for the three copper companies by using certain price assumptions for the metal. He has also factored into his estimates the impact of an ''assumed'' copper strike lasting six weeks after the current labor contracts expire June 30. **********His estimate calls for Asarco, which suffered a loss in 1982 as a reflection of cyclical weakness in metal prices, to earn 75 cents a share this year, then $2.35 a share in 1984 and $3.60 a share in 1985. **********Projections call for Phelps Dodge, which also lost money last year, to show a much smaller deficit in 1983. The analyst estimates that the company then will earn $2.35 a share in 1984 and $3.35 a share the next year. **********Newmont Mining had a profit equal to $1.76 a share in 1982. Mr.  Healy projects earnings at $3.50 a share this year, followed by $6 a share in 1984 and $6.90 a share in 1985. **********''Based on our current outlook,'' he summarized, ''the copper issues look rather amply priced and seem unlikely to outperform the market over the medium term.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Senior executives of Tiger International Inc. met with committees of its major bank and institutional lenders today in the first stage of negotiating extended repayment on $900 million of its $1.8 billion debt. **********''There is not going to be any Chapter 11 filing,'' a spokesman, Rosanne O'Brien, said. **********''Absolutely not.'' She reiterated that Tiger's suppliers were being paid on schedule. **********The diversified air cargo, truck and rail transportation company, which lost $82.3 million in the fourth quarter, announced after a meeting with 200 bank and institutional lenders on Monday that it had halted payments on interest and principal on a portion of their loans. Miss O'Brien declined to identify Tiger's major banks and institutional lenders. A spokesman for the First Interstate Bank of California, however, confirmed that the bank is one of Tiger's lenders. **********Tiger's largest shareholder is the Reliance Group, which owns 23 percent of Tiger's 17 million common shares, with court permission to acquire up to 35 percent of the stock. Its chairman, Saul P.  Steinberg, acquired the shares for $77 million, or an average of $20 a share, according to a published report. **********Tiger's shares closed at 5 3/4, down 1 3/8, on the New York Stock Exchange today. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.main_headline: ISRAEL DESCRIBES DECISION ON F-16'S AS 'REGRETTABLE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.print_headline: ISRAEL DESCRIBES DECISION ON F-16'S AS 'REGRETTABLE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that President Reagan had made ''a regrettable pronouncement'' in announcing that the United States would not give final approval for the sale of 75 F-16 fighter planes to Israel until it withdrew from Lebanon. He said the statement came just as Israel and Lebanon were ''close to agreement'' on an Israeli withdrawal. **********Interviewed on Israeli television, Mr. Shamir particularly criticized the President's statement that the planes could not be sold to Israel while its forces were ''occupying another country.'' The proposed sale called for delivery of the planes to begin in 1985 at the earliest. **********Expressing surprise at Mr. Reagan's choice of words, Mr. Shamir said Washington knew that Israel entered Lebanon last June not to ''capture or occupy'' its territory but to ''disperse and destroy the terrorist'' guerrilla forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Progress in Talks Reported **********''It was a regrettable pronouncement,'' Mr. Shamir declared.  The Foreign Minister and other Israeli officials said the President's remarks, made Thursday, came as Israeli and Lebanese negotiators were making progress at a session in the northern Israeli town of Qiryat Shemona. **********Mr. Shamir declined to expand on his assessment that an agreement was near. But he said the talks, which began at the end of December, were protracted because of Israel's insistence on insuring that there never again would be guerrilla attacks on its territory from Lebanon. **********(In Lebanon, the Beirut radio quoted Foreign Minister Elie Salem as saying there had been ''some progress,'' but ''no final agreement on any of the issues currently under discussion,'' The Associated Press reported. Mr. Salem was said to have added, ''If this progress continues next week, then we will definitely be on the right track for a comprehensive agreement.'') Border Area Is Issue **********Some officials close to the Israeli-Lebanese negotiations said the two sides had narrowed their differences over how much Israeli military involvement would be permitted in southern Lebanon after a troop withdrawal. Israel has been demanding joint patrols of the area with Lebanese troops. **********The informants said the two sides agreed in principle Thursday to set up what they described as ''joint supervision teams.'' The sources gave no details, however, on what the specific duties and composition of such teams might be. **********An Israeli official said it would be ''overoptimistic'' to conclude that the security problems had been solved.  While Foreign Minister Shamir would not define areas of agreement, he did say Israel would continue its surveillance flights over Lebanon after it withdrew its 30,000 troops. **********President Reagan's remarks, made in response to questions after a speech in California on arms control, included an expression of frustration at the slow pace of the withdrawal talks.  It followed recent expressions of annoyance by Administration officials over Israel's rejection of an American package of security proposals for southern Lebanon. These are said to fall short of Israeli demands for a residual military presence in Lebanon. Israeli Demands Opposed **********Since the talks began, Lebanon and the United States have opposed such Israeli demands. Israel has suggested several forms of military involvement in a security zone, extending about 25 miles north of the Israeli-Lebanese border. **********Israel, convinced that the Palestine Liberation Organization will try to re-establish military positions in southern Lebanon, originally asked for five Israeli-manned outposts in Lebanon. These small bases, staffed by a total of about 750 Israeli soldiers and intelligence agents, would have monitored the area, searched for P.L.O. guerrillas and coordinated with local Lebanese militias in maintaining security. **********Neither Lebanon nor the United States accepted this, arguing that it would give Syria a pretext for leaving its forces in northern Lebanon and the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley. **********Israel is reported to have stopped insisting on the outposts without formally withdrawing the demand. Instead, the Israeli negotiators are said to be concentrating on daily patrols with Lebanese troops, close communications and intelligence links with a southern brigade of the Lebanese Army and the stationing of Israeli Army advisers with Lebanese troops. Role for Major Haddad **********In addition, Israel wants Maj. Saad Haddad, a former Lebanese Army officer, named as the commander of the southern Lebanese brigade.  Since the mid-1970's, when he left the army, Major Haddad has run a militia trained and supplied by Israel in a narrow buffer strip on the Lebanese side of the Israeli border, giving Israeli troops free access to the territory for artillery positions and as a staging area for strikes against P.L.O. emplacements. **********Lebanon has reportedly agreed to integrate Major Haddad's militia into the army, making it the basis of a southern brigade. But the Government has objected to Major Haddad's becoming its commander because he is technically a deserter. **********Agreement on the other major area of negotiations, the question of normalizing Israeli-Lebanese relations, is said to be near. Israel, which originally demanded a formal agreement on an open border, has reportedly compromised and agreed to Lebanese pleas for a de facto open border after Israeli withdrawal, pending the beginning of formal negotiations about six months later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/17/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********Regulation is so unpopular today that it is a handy scapegoat for every economic ill. John Sawhill's mixture of non sequiturs and nonfacts about our natural gas price crisis (''The Deregulation of Natural Gas: The Reagan Plan Is Not Enough,'' March 23) is a good illustration. **********For example, Mr. Sawhill doesn't bother to explain when he writes that ''regulation is driving prices up at a time when competition should be forcing them down.'' And for good reason: It is not regulation that has caused the soaring prices but rather deregulation of ''high cost'' gas; an increasing share of total gas sales attributable to higher priced gas, and a producer-dominated Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that has reached for every opportunity to increase producer prices and to condone industry abuses. **********Only by ignoring a commission policy statement was an administrative law judge able to impose some minimal controls on Columbia Gas Transmission for numerous buying abuses, such as paying its producing subsidiary $10 per thousand cubic feet while refusing to take independently produced $2 gas. **********Perhaps most important are the take-or-pay and price escalation contract clauses that pervade the industry, and that would drive prices up even if they were not controlled, as they did in the early 1950's, before wellhead prices were brought under regulation. **********As to Mr. Sawhill's claim that deregulation won't drive up prices, numerous Energy Department and other studies refute that. A General Accounting Office study issued this February concluded that decontrol could produce price increases ranging from 18 to 110 percent, with 88 percent the most likely figure. According to a Dean Witter Reynolds analysis in 1981, accelerated decontrol would raise prices from a 1981 average of $1.70 to $4.50 in 1986. **********Deregulation of old gas - which is really what this controversy is about - could put $21 billion to $48 billion into the pockets of the big oil companies that own most of the ''old gas'' reserves and, incidentally, have little interest in gas exploration. As always, the residential consumer would pay, since industrial customers switch to residual fuel oil. **********Mr. Sawhill tries to minimize the burden on the householder by asserting that 80 percent of sales ''are to areas covered by more than one pipeline,'' implying options for the consumer. But 95 percent are served by only two pipelines - that rarely compete - and most of the major markets, including New York, Chicago, Washington and Baltimore, are served by only one. **********The ''flurry of mergers and other acquisitions that has characterized other industries moving through deregulation'' is something Mr. Sawhill seems to anticipate cheerfully. Does he really want more fiascos like Mobil-Montgomery Ward, Exxon-Reliance, Occidental-Cities Service and Pan Am-National, to mention but a few? Does he really think the Braniff bankruptcy and the current weakened and chaotic condition of the airline industry are good things? **********Gas prices are set not by a competitive ''free market'' but by following industry-administered oil prices that are many times the $1 to $2 cost of production, and far above the $10 to $14 a barrel that a truly competitive market would produce. What we need is not decontrol but better recontrol that will cover both the intrastate and interstate markets, and not exempt the so-called high cost gas.  The onerous take-or-pay and escalator clauses should also be voided (as the Federal Power Commission did in 1962) and there should be tight controls on pipeline abuses. **********Incentives for production are vital. A recent Energy Department study shows that drilling costs are falling and that $3 to $3.50 per thousand cubic feet is more than enough. In that case, we don't need to guarantee two Mercedes SL 380's in every gas producer's garage while millions freeze.   HERMAN SCHWARTZ, Professor of Law, American University, Washington, April 11 **********Professor Schwartz was chief counsel to the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee from 1979 to 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/world.body_text: **********South Africa's Roman Catholic Church today denounced the Government's campaign for a new constitution, saying the proposal failed with regard to justice, truth, love and freedom. **********A pastoral letter from the country's Catholic bishops, read out in every Catholic church today, said it was a serious moral failure that the proposed constitution disregarded blacks, who make up more than two-thirds of South Africa's 27 million people. **********''It is an affront to the people concerned and insures that racial discrimination will continue,'' the message said. **********About 10 percent of all South Africans are Catholics and the message is likely to be seen as a clear signal to the whites among them to vote against the proposal in a crucial whites-only referendum on Nov. 2. **********The new constitution would allow limited power-sharing for Indians and people of mixed race but exclude the black majority, has also been condemned by most liberal political leaders and the powerful Methodist Church.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.main_headline:
ANTITRUST CHIEF'S MID-TERM REVIEW;
BAXTER'S CONFUSING SIGNALS TO BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.print_headline:
ANTITRUST CHIEF'S MID-TERM REVIEW;
BAXTER'S CONFUSING SIGNALS TO BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.body_text: **********PRESIDENT Reagan's appointment of William Baxter to head the D epartment of Justice's antitrust division in April 1981 was hailed b y some and decried by others - basically for the same reason. The p erception was that the appointment of Mr. Baxter - a former Stanfordl aw professor known for his conservative philosophy - signaled a t urning away from previous enforcement policies in favor of what was b illed as a more ''pro-business'' line. As one observer put it at t he time, the nomination was a ''message appointment.'' But two yearsl ater, the message seems more confusing and not as helpful as many h ad expected or hoped. **********To a large degree, the Administration has courted a ''soft-line'' reputation on antitrust through pronouncements by the division on various theories of antitrust law, such as its statements favoring so-called ''vertical'' restraints, including vertical price-fixing.  While this move, as well as others, may represent a departure from previous enforcement philosophies, the real question is not how drastic the changes are, but whether they are truly beneficial for American business. Over all, there is substantial ground for doubt. **********Certainly, some of the policies instituted under Mr. Baxter have benefited business and the public. And not all of these constitute ''softness'' in antitrust enforcement. For example, the program of terminating obsolete antitrust consent decrees should be applauded.  Even the most hard-line antitrust prosecutor cannot argue that a consent decree should be kept alive after any competitive need for it has expired. Similarly, the settlement of the A.T.& T. monopolization case, which will restructure the telecommunications industry, can be expected to have significant pro-competitive benefits. **********But the danger inherent in much of the Baxter program is that, far from being beneficial to corporate America, it creates confusion and uncertainty in the business community and generally among the public about the antitrust laws.SINCE 1890, interpretation of Federal antitrust laws, which the S upreme Court has called the ''Magna Carta'' of our economic f reedom, has been the province of the Federal courts. These courts h ave been careful to identify certain areas where flexibility is d esirable, and to apply a ''rule of reason'' test to gauge those p ractices. At the same time the courts have built a degree of c ertainty into antitrust by banning some practices - such as p ricefixing - in their entirety. As a result, while not all the p arameters of the antitrust laws have always been delineated by sharpl ines, American businessmen have generally been able to discern what c onduct is permissible and what is not. However, when the Government s ends out new - and often conflicting - signals, the possibility thatb usinessmen could be misled is real and fraught with risks. **********Vertical price-fixing is a good example. Since 1911, this practice -sometimes called resale price maintenance - has been considered a per se violation of the Sherman Act. While the Department of Justice has let it be known that it now considers such price maintenance to be generally pro-competitive, no businessman could prudently engage in such conduct since the courts, acting upon a challenge by a private party (such as a franchisee, customer or competitor), may disagree and award millions of dollars in treble damages. Moreover, members of Congress, which repealed the fair trade laws sanctioning resale price maintenance in 1975, have made it abundantly clear that the Baxter approach lacks widespread legislative support. **********Along the same lines, until - and unless - the courts change their interpretation of the antimerger law, acquisitions that are challenged in court, such as in hostile takeovers, are likely to be scrutinized under rules established over a period of decades, and not under the criteria in Mr. Baxter's new merger guidelines. **********This duality of standards is troublesome, revealing an inconsistency that in turn leads to confusion and chaos in this area.  No one disputes that new approaches to antitrust enforcement are often necessary and useful. For instance, over the past decade, economics has played an increasingly important role in antitrust and that evolutionary trend should continue. Likewise, it is clear that antitrust enforcers cannot stick their heads in the sand while American businesses are confronted with increasingly vigorous foreign competition, often operating outside the restraints of our laws. Nor should the antitrust laws operate as a deterrent to United States companies competing abroad or pooling resources so as to enter or participate more fully in world markets. But vigorous, consistent law enforcement is not at odds with any of these aims. **********Government antitrust prosecutors are charged with the faithful execution of the laws. They cannot condone what Congress and the courts have branded illegal or simply declare their own criteria of unlawfulness, whether it be ''pro-business'' or ''anti-business.'' Development of the antitrust laws has been an evolutionary process, now more than 90 years old. Interference with that process could mean no one will know either the state of the law or where it is headed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Early Retirements At Bank in Illinois **********The human aspect of corporate misfortune was well illustrated yesterday, when two top officers of the Continental Illinois Corporation and of its flagship subsidiary, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, announced that they would take early retirement. **********The two are John H. Perkins, president, and Donald C. Miller, vice chairman. The 62-year-old Mr. Perkins joined the bank, the biggest in Chicago and the nation's seventh largest, 37 years ago. The 63-year-old Mr. Miller joined Continental 25 years ago. **********Both men have had illustrious careers. Mr. Perkins, for example, was president of the American Bankers Association in 1978, and Mr. Miller is a past chairman of the A.B.A.'s chief financial officers division. **********Until the summer of 1982, the greatest achievement of their careers had been their membership in a team that had turned Continental into a profitable, highly competitive and fast- growing bank. **********But that vision was shattered following the failure of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City in July 1982. Continental had purchased more than $1 billion in loans from Penn Square and many of those loans turned bad, causing the bank to report a quarterly loss. And things got worse. As a result of the recesssion, many other large loans that Continental had made during its period of aggressive expansion also ran into trouble. **********Neither Mr. Perkins nor Mr. Miller had responsibility for the problem areas. And both had worked to mitigate the problems. Mr. Perkins campaigned to bolster the company's image, while Mr. Miller raised billions of dollars to keep Continental solvent, following huge deposit outflows. The situation has been stabilized, but both men were tainted by association. **********Now, with their likely successors - David G. Taylor, 54, now vice chairman, and Edward S. Bottum, 50, executive vice president - having been named last summer, Mr. Perkins and Mr. Miller have decided to leave quietly, without fanfare. **********No reason was given for their departures, except that it was ''personal.'' The announcement was made through a bank press release and neither Mr. Perkins nor Mr. Miller would comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.main_headline: MOSCOW WILL TRY AGAIN TO WIDEN THE POWERS OF FACTORY MANAGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.print_headline: MOSCOW WILL TRY AGAIN TO WIDEN THE POWERS OF FACTORY MANAGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.body_text: **********The Soviet leadership today announced a package of economic experiments intended to show that the way to invigorate the country's largely stagnant industry lies through greater autonomy for individual plants. **********The initiative, announced in the form of a joint decree of the Communist Party's Central Committee and the Government, appears to be a renewed attempt to relax the traditionally tight central controls over the nation's Government-run industry. **********Earlier efforts to broaden the powers of factory managers, dating from the mid-1960's and generally identified with the then Prime Minister, Aleksei N. Kosygin, bogged down amid bureaucratic resistance and inertia. **********Today's decree said that, beginning Jan. 1, plant managers in selected industries would be given wider authority over their budgets, with discretion in matters of investment, wages, bonuses and profit retention that are now closely regulated by the central planning agencies and supervisory industrial ministries in Moscow. **********Technological Innovation Sought **********In addition, an effort is to be made to spur technological innovation by loosening bureaucratic controls on the introduction of new processes. Managements will have authority to reward innovative engineers and workers and will have access to additional government subsidies for that purpose. **********Perhaps most important, the criteria by which factory performance is measured are to be simplified to emphasize the ability to produce goods that will sell, particularly in foreign markets. **********This will mean lower priority for the traditional performance indicator in Soviet industry, the overall value of output, which has encouraged factories to turn out large volumes of production regardless of the quality of goods or the needs of the market. **********The new measures are intended in part to stimulate labor productivity, which remains far below Western levels. In addition, the leadership hopes to spur ''enterprise, initiative and technical progress'' and ''to heighten a factory's responsibility for the end results of its work.'' **********The initiatives were the first major economic moves since Yuri V.  Andropov became the Soviet leader eight months ago on a pledge to improve the performance of factories and farms, which have turned in a steadily less impressive performance in recent years. Overall industrial growth last year was less than 2.8 percent, the lowest in decades. **********Western diplomats said the new moves appeared to reflect lessons learned from previous experience. Instead of trying to introduce changes all at once throughout the economy, as in the past, the authorities will limit the new experiments at first to a few industries to reduce confusion while offering a showcase for ideas that some Soviet economists have been advocating for years. 5 Ministries Selected for Test **********The five industrial ministries selected to test the new ideas are two national agencies -- responsible for the manufacture of heavy and transportation machinery and of electrical equipment -- and three ministries under the jurisdiction of some of the 15 republics that make up the Soviet Union: the food industry of the Ukraine, light industry of Byelorussia, and local industry of Lithuania. **********The announcement followed months of expectancy spurred by Mr.  Andropov's early speeches, criticizing overcentralization, bureaucratic inertia and slackness in the work force. **********When the speeches were followed by police roundups of shirkers and little else, there was speculation that the Soviet leader was facing opposition from bureaucratic interests with allies in the ruling Politburo. **********Western diplomats who analyzed today's announcement said it appeared to be a careful first step toward applying ideas that Mr.  Andropov discussed with workers at a Moscow machine-tool factory earlier in the year and on other occasions. Concessions to Conservatives Seen **********While the measures probably involve some concessions to Politburo conservatives, the diplomats said, they also reflect a widespread recognition that economic change can be effected only piecemeal if the party's power is to be sustained. **********The decree said the new measures, in addition to giving plants greater autonomy, were ''intended to strengthen centralized economic management.'' **********Diplomats said the apparent contradiction was a measure of the leadership's wariness of a bureaucracy with a vested interest in arrangements that have officials in Moscow making decisions usually within the prerogatives of plant managers in the West. **********Among the most important experiments in today's package is the decision to cut back on the number of indicators by which a plant's performance is judged and to assign new priorities among those that remain. **********While managers previously had to focus on meeting centrally decreed goals for the value of output, labor productivity, fuel savings and perhaps a dozen other areas, plants under the new plan will be able to give greater emphasis to the marketability of goods. Managers will have to pay close attention to demand instead of fulfilling quotas that often had little relationship to market requirements. To keep Greater Share of Profits **********Those Government plants that perform well under the new criteria would be able to keep an increased share of profits instead of handing them over to the central treasury. **********They would also be able to increase the amount of money allocated to wage and incentive funds, and thus to raise individual wages and bonuses. **********One sensitive point, management's freedom to reduce the often inflated work force, was kept vague, but the decree said the measures were intended to enable plants to meet their quotas ''with a minimum of manpower, material and fiscal resources.'' **********Exportability will move products well up on the scale of performance. With the country facing a hard currency squeeze as a result of slack energy prices and heavy imports of machinery and grain, the Kremlin has been laying new stress on breaking into Western markets with Soviet technology. **********Soviet exports consist mainly of crude oil and refined products, natural gas, timber and other raw materials. Manufactured goods accounted for only 12 percent of exports last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/14/world.body_text: **********Two Egyptian Cabinet members implicated in the corruption scandal of Esmat el-Sadat, the half-brother of the late President Anwar el-Sadat, have been removed from office. **********President Hosni Mubarak made the decision after meeting with Prime Minister Ahmed Fuad Moheiddin, and is to swear in the new ministers of the 33-member Cabinet on Monday. **********Ahmed Nouh, the Supply Minister, is to be replaced by Ahmed Nagey Shetla. A 160-page report by a special court last week accused Mr.Nouh of ''collusion or at least gross error'' in what it said was his approval of Esmat Sadat's importation and sale of rotten meat and tomato sauce. **********The Industry Minister, Fuad Abu Zaghla, who was said to have allowed Esmat Sadat and his sons more than normal amounts of iron and steel, is to be replaced by Mohammed el-Sayed el-Ghoroury. **********The Communications Minister, Soliman Metwalli Soliman, also accused in the report of helping to procure some of Mr. Sadat's 100 telephone and telex lines, apparently remained at his post. **********Esmat Sadat and three of his sons were convicted on Feb. 12 on a wide array of corruption charges.
