https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Opposition is mounting to a campaign by beer distributors for an antitrust exemption that would permit exclusive distribution rights in a territory. **********The proponents, who also include brewers and the teamsters, began lobbying Congress last session for such a bill, following the lead of the soft drink industry, which won such an exemption in 1980 after a long fight. Initially it looked as if the beer interests might have it easier. **********But last year's session ended without action, and now the industry is locked in battle with tavern and food store owners, as well as consumer groups, who contend that the bill would lead to higher prices. The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission have also opposed the bill as anticompetitive. **********If passed, the legislation would allow a brewery to designate a single distributor in a territory, in which no other distributor could compete for the distribution of that beer. The practice of exclusive territories is already widespread in the industry. Nineteen states have laws mandating the exclusive arrangements. One state, Indiana, prohibits exclusive territories, and the rest of the states are silent on the matter. **********Supporters of the bill say that it would merely codify existing practices in the industry and would protect distributors from what they consider to be nagging antitrust lawsuits. **********''The exclusive territories have been the system in the beer industry for the past 50 years,'' said Robert Sullivan, the president of the National Beer Wholesalers Association. ''All this piece of legislation would do is to make people more secure. We'd like to get to the point where it's easier to handle at the courts.'' **********Opponents charge that the law would stifle competition among distributors and raise beer prices, and add that the distributors are actually trying to change the antitrust laws. **********''Their bill creates a whole new standard,'' said Lars Peterson, legislative assistant for the Food Marketing Institute, an association of grocers, chain stores and wholesalers. **********Since a Supreme Court ruling in 1977, the courts have applied what is known as the rule-of-reason in judging exclusive contracts between producers and distributors. In a challenge to such an arrangement, the court would weigh all the evidence to see if the result is anticompetitive. **********The proposed bill ''does not mention the rule-of-reason at all,'' Mr. Peterson said. **********Fewer Sponsors **********Last year, tthe bill had more than 200 co-sponsors in the House of Representatives and 65 in the Senate before the first hearings. But after a last- minute lobbying effort by the retail and consumer groups and several newspaper editorials opposing the bill, the Senate and House Judiciary Committees did not act before the session ended. **********In addition, both the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission opposed the bill. Abbott B. Lipsky Jr., then Deputy Assistant Attorney General in the antitrust division, testified that ''the malt beverage industry is a textbook example of those very special circumstances in which widespread use of exclusive territorial arrangements might have anticompetitive effects.'' **********This year the retailers and consumers seem to have already produced a standoff, and the bill's chances are not viewed as favorable. Despite the fact that there is a beer distributor in nearly every Congressional district, the main sponsor in the House, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, has only been able to muster about 70 co-sponsors. Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, introduced it in the Senate with six co- sponsors. **********Industry Determined **********But the beer industry is determined. ''There will probably be a major effort in 1984 to convince the Congress of the propriety of the bill,'' said Henry B. King, the president of the United States Brewers Association. ''It took the soft drink industry nine years to get their bill passed.'' **********It is the price of beer that is the key concern for the millions of beer drinkers in the United States. Jay Angoff, a lawyer for Congress Watch, a consumers group, said, ''The best argument the beer guys make is that the price of beer hasn't gone up as much as other things in the past few years. That's true, good, and that's why we want to keep the law the way it is.'' **********But there are no clear statistics about the impact on prices of the exclusive arrangements, and little evidence that people can point to from the soft drink industry. **********Jerry Murphy, from the National Licensed Beverage Association, which represents the tavern owners, asserted that the price of soft drinks has gone up since 1980, but he said he was not sure whether how much of the increase was due to the legislation. However, he contends that the beer bill would be more likely to lead to price increases. **********Effect on Prices in Indiana **********The effect on beer prices of Indiana's ban on the territories is not clear. A report from the Indiana Alcoholic Beverage Commission showed a 20 percent drop in the price of beer, and a survey by The Indianapolis Star in November 1982 showed that beer was cheaper where there were no exclusive territories. **********But at a hearing in July, Richard B. Willett, a partner in an accounting firm, Alexander Grant & Company, testified that there was no noticeable change in price where there was a rule against exclusive territories. **********Regardless of how the two sides see the issues, Judiciary Committee members are concerned that, if they pass an antitrust exemption for beer distributors, they will be flooded with requests from other industries. Indeed, the wine industry has already said it is interested.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/06/world.main_headline: BAKER SAYS EFFORT TO MODIFY TAX CUT FACES SENATE LOSS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/06/world.print_headline: BAKER SAYS EFFORT TO MODIFY TAX CUT FACES SENATE LOSS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/06/world.body_text: **********Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the leader of the Republican majority in the Senate, predicted today that Reagan Administration forces there would defeat any Democratic attempt to modify the 10 percent income tax cut scheduled for July 1. **********On Monday the Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas P.O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, is expected to propose limiting the cut to $700 for each individual taxpayer or couple. Mr.  O'Neill has promised that the House would send such a bill to the Senate. Support For Paul Volcker **********On the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' and later in a telephone interview, Senator Baker made these statements: **********- He repeated and strengthened his earlier support for the reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Alternatively, Senator Baker said, he would like to see the job go to Alan Greenspan, the New York economic consultant, who was chief economic adviser to President Ford. **********- He said ''the future of Central America, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras and others will be decided in Moscow and Washington,'' not ''in San Salvador and Havana,'' and that he hoped President Reagan would ''engage in meaningful conversation with the Soviet Union'' on the possibility of reciprocal restraint. **********- He said that ''the appropriations process was going to be the big issue for the rest of the year'' and therefore it was unlikely that the President would veto the pending bill to repeal tax withholding on dividends and interest. Although Mr. Reagan has promised to veto the bill, ''he can invest only so much in certain issues,'' Senator Baker said. Summit Meeting Suggested **********Senator Baker, who has said he will consider running for President if Mr. Reagan decides against a second term, used the word ''opportunity'' several times in the interview with respect to jobs and the economy and with respect to achieving an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union. ''There is a real chance we're going to see progress in this field soon,'' he said of the arms control issue. **********He voiced the hope that Mr. Reagan would meet the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov. ''These two leaders owe the obligation to the rest of the world to get together and get to know each other,'' the Senator said. **********The possibility of a summit meeting was discussed last week by Presidential advisers after allied Western leaders informed Mr.  Reagan at the Williamsburg conference that Mr. Andropov was interested in meeting him. **********Regarding budgetary matters, Mr. Baker referred to the 12 appropriations for the executive branch and said: ''It's going to be a donnybrook for each one. It will be a struggle to keep it within the President's budget.'' Even Odds on Resolution **********Mr. Baker linked the possibility of ''a siege of Presidential vetoes of spending bills'' - ''and I would cheer him on in that respect,'' he said - with his appraisal that ''the odds are no better than 50-50'' that the Republican-controlled Senate and Democratic House will agree on a Congressional budget resolution for the 1984 fiscal year, which starts Oct. 1. A House-Senate conference to resolve differences in the resolutions from the two chambers is expected to start this week. **********''If you don't get a budget, you don't get a budget,'' Senator Baker added. ''The Government doesn't stop, but it would be too bad because I think it would call into question the efficiency of the budget process and our will and determination to get the budget under control.'' **********Under the 1974 Congressional Budget Act, a Congressional budget resolution is an attempt to impose a discipline on total spending and spending for major functions, such as the military, health and agriculture. The fear is that without a resolution, the individual spending bills may become swollen. **********Echoing threats by Mr. Reagan, Senator Baker said that in the absence of a budget resolution, the President might have to veto individual money bills as too big. Republicans have said that would be part of a strategy of blaming the Democrats for big budget deficits, which the Democrats attribute to the three-year Reagan tax cut enacted in 1981. Thanks Offered to Democrats **********Mr. Baker took pains in the television interview to portray himself as optimistic about America's future and as generous toward the political opposition. **********He thanked Mr. O'Neill and other House Democrats for having already sent two appropriations bills to the Senate, months earlier than has often been the case. Consequently, he said he was dropping his earlier plan to have the Senate recess from the Fourth of July until Labor Day, inasmuch as it would have a batch of money bills to consider in July. Both houses are scheduled to recess Aug. 5, until after Labor Day. **********Senator Baker said he hoped Congress could adjourn for the rest of the year by Oct. 1. ''I have a deep-seated belief that the Congress does not profit from being in session all year long, and that we ought to adjourn and go home and find out what's going on,'' he said. He has said he would not run for re-election in 1984. **********On Central America, Mr. Baker said he opposed the dispatching of American combat troops, ''but I would also be opposed to withdrawing the assistance we are now giving them.'' As for the region's future being ''decided in Moscow and Washington,'' Mr. Baker was reluctant to be drawn out after the television program, but confirmed that he hoped Mr. Reagan and Mr. Andropov could agree on mutual restraint. **********On the reappointment of Mr. Volcker, which he urged on the Senate floor in May, Mr. Baker said the Federal Reserve chairman was ''a known quantity'' and ''extremely qualified.'' **********''His reappointment would signal continuation of present policies, which include the probability of a gradual further reduction in interest rates, and I think it would have a calming and tranquilizing effect on the world economy,'' he said. **********Then, picking up a line uttered last week by Administration officials, a remark some in Washington heard as a hint that Mr.  Volcker would be dropped, Mr. Baker said: ''What I have just said to you doesn't say as well that he's the only man in the world that can do it, and the President could make a choice with other good men and women.'' He added, ''Alan Greenspan's name comes to mind.'' **********The Senate must confirm either Mr. Volcker's reappointment or the appointment of a successor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.main_headline: IRAQIS FACING NEED TO WIN IN GULF SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.print_headline: IRAQIS FACING NEED TO WIN IN GULF SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.body_text: **********Senior military analysts and diplomats say they believe that Iraq, fearful of losing a war of economic attrition with Iran, may try to widen the war by forcing Iran to take military action to close the Persian Gulf.  A senior official of the Baghdad Government said recently that Iraq had already fired Soviet-made surface-to-surface missiles at Kharg Island, the Iranian oil terminal at the head of the gulf, and neutral military analysts believe that there will be further attacks from missile sites in Iraq. **********The type of missile supplied by the Soviet Union to Iraq, known as SCUD B in the West, has a range of 187 miles and is capable of hitting Kharg Island and other targets in Iran from sites deep in Iraq. Recently these missiles have hit cities 125 miles into Iran. However the SCUD B, which can carry either a nuclear or a non-nuclear warhead, is not an accurate missile and informed opinion in London is that the Iraqis might fire as many as 10 without hitting the Kharg Island terminal. **********Some analysts and officials here say they believe that the French-made Exocet missiles fired from super-Etendard fighter bombers, also French- made, would be equally ineffective against the terminal largely because their guidance systems are built to register on ships rather than stationary targets like Kharg Island, which at any time could be masked by tankers loading oil.   Danger From Exocets **********Exocets might sink one of the ships, the sources said, but the oil terminal probably would continue to function. **********The prevailing opinion, however, is that in time the Iraqis, using a combination of SCUDS and Exocets, will sink a foreign tanker in the gulf and force Iran to retaliate by closing the gulf to international shipping through naval action. **********The military analysts said, however, that Iran has neither the mine-laying capacity nor the command and control system to mine the Strait of Hormuz which runs from the Persian Gulf to the Arabian Sea and the Indian Ocean. **********Some sources believe that Iran will take the step if Iraqi attacks on gulf shipping become intolerable. They predicted that the oil-exporting nations of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates will demand escorts for tankers and that these could be provided by the United States, Britain and perhaps France.   Need for Air Cover **********Military sources also believe that the tankers and their escorts would require air cover to protect them from the Iranian Air Force, which is now thought to have about 75 aircraft operational. The estimate here is that approximately 45 of these are American-made F-4's and F-14's. The presence of the F-14's at bases in southwestern Iran, analysts said, explains the Iraqi Air Force's reluctance to press home bombing attacks on Kharg Island, since the F-14 is faster and more maneuverable aircraft than anything in the Iraqi inventory. **********Air cover could be provided by planes from American or British carriers in the Arabian Sea or as a last resort from Oman's Masira Island base. By closing the gulf Iran would create difficulties for the other gulf nations and weaken its position in the economic war. At present Iran is able to export far more oil than Iraq by using Kharg Island and ports at the eastern end of the gulf. **********Qualified sources here believe that Iran is not prepared to fight a naval war against Iraq or an international force. The Iranian destroyer Artemis, which is going through trials after expensive repairs due to war damage, is the only major Iranian combatant in the gulf and the navy's force of 12 missile-and gun-armed fast attack craft has been reduced to about six ships by Iraqi action. **********Iran's last option to meet growing Iraqi air and naval pressure in the gulf is to strengthen its offensive on the northern battlefront opposite the Iraqi oil-producing center of Kirkuk and the southern terminal of Iraq's only pipeline to the Mediterranean.   Support for Iraq's Economy **********The pipeline now carries about 800,000 barrels a day as a result of the introduction of chemicals to thin the oil and increase the flow. This and the subsidies from Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations have enabled Iraq to maintain its war economy. **********Iran's northern offensive, military analysts said, thus far has done little more than recapture some territory seized by Iraq at the start of the war in September, 1980. This area lies north and east of the town of Penjwin. **********A successful drive on Kirkuk and the pipeline would require more men, munitions and air power than Iran could mobilize in that area without seriously weakening its strength on other fronts, analysts said.  In any case, one analyst pointed out, a severed pipeline or a damaged pumping station can be quickly repaired. Iraq's lines of communication joining the fronts in the north, at Mandali northeast of Baghdad, Missan to the southwest and Basra near the Shatt Al Arab, suffice to insure rapid reinforcement when the Iranians attack at any point on the front. **********But the best estimates here are that Iraq cannot win a defensive war against a more populous Iran, which exports much more oil. Baghdad's only hope may be the intervention of outside powers to protect oil shipments and the eventual military as well as financial aid from the other gulf nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/world.main_headline: THE U.N. AND THE CITY: OBLIGATION, OPPORTUNITY AND IRRITATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/world.print_headline: THE U.N. AND THE CITY: OBLIGATION, OPPORTUNITY AND IRRITATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/world.body_text: **********With mutual suspicion, misunderstandings and occasional hostility, the United Nations and its host, New York City, have pursued an elusive goal of peaceful coexistence for 37 years. By all accounts, the results have been a mix of love, hate, tolerance and indifference. **********As perceived by many New Yorkers, diplomatic immunity has meant a kind of license for United Nations personnel to park illegally, ignore bills and legal summonses, scoff at lawsuits, walk away from criminal charges and behave with haughty insensitivity. **********As perceived by many United Nations diplomats, the cosmopolitan city has been surprisingly xenophobic, a place of noise, dirt, discourtesy, crime, outrageous prices and discrimination ranging from landlords who refuse rentals to racial slurs and bumper stickers proclaiming: ''Get the U.N. out of the U.S.'' **********But the city and its international diplomatic community have also brought each other mutual benefits whose loss, if the United Nations were to leave New York, would have a ''devastating impact,'' in the opinion of Gillian Martin Sorensen, who heads the New York City Commission for the United Nations. **********'Ups and Downs' **********''We've always had our ups and downs, our moments of strain and tension,'' Commissioner Sorensen said yesterday. ''But removing the U.N. from New York would make about as much sense as moving the Vatican out of Rome or the Pyramids out of Egypt. We belong together. Despite the strains, we nurture each other in very important ways.'' **********The nadir in relations between the city and the United Nations came in 1975, when the General Assembly passed a resolution equating Zionism with racism. Mayor Abraham D. Beame called the vote ''a sickening act,'' and there was talk in the City Council of closing the city's United Nations liaison office. **********The United States contributes 25 percent of the world organization's budget, which was $722 million last year and is expected to be $784 million this year. The United Nations, as a major purchaser, builder and employer, contributes $700 million a year to the city's economy. **********''There are a great number of stores and shops in the United Nations area that depend on diplomatic-related clientele,'' Commissioner Sorensen said. In addition, theaters, hotels, restaurants and other businesses receive the patronage of the diplomatic community.   Mutual Cultural Benefits **********But beyond financial considerations, she said, are mutual cultural benefits. ''New York wants to consider itself a world headquarters in commerce, finance, the arts, and being the world headquarters for the diplomatic community is also very important,'' she said. ''We've always played that unique role.'' **********Many diplomats, the commissioner said, ''are happy in New York - they enjoy the city, its options and energy, and the fact that the phones and the elevators work.'' The city, for its part, has also been proud of its role as home to the United Nations, a role that has added to the city's reputation for diversity and tolerance, she said. **********Over the years, since the founders of the United Nations agreed to build their headquarters on a parcel of donated land on Manhattan's East Side riverfront, the relationship between the city and the United Nations has been an uneasy balance of obligation and opportunity strained by immunities, privileges and costs.   Diplomatic Immunity Laws **********Some of the irritants - indifference to local parking rules, unpaid bills, the privilege of driving away from a minor car accidents - have eased to some extent in recent years by the passage in 1978 of Federal laws to limit diplomatic immunity in such matters to ambassadors and their families and other top- level staff members. Low- and middle-level diplomats lost such immunities. **********In addition, most of New York City's expenses for the protection of diplomats are now being paid by the Federal Government. Those costs had been the topic of an oft-heard complaint of New Yorkers. New York City still loses about $15 million a year in property and other taxes and in the costs of police protection, Commissioner Sorensen said. **********''But compared to the $700 million in benefits, the city is way ahead - no question,'' the commissioner said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/08/busin.body_text: **********Another Supreme Court Justice declined Saturday evening to block the $1.07 billion takeover of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation by the CSX Corporation. **********Saturday's denial of the petition of the Water Transport Association came from Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. **********On Friday, Justice William J. Brennan rejected a similar appeal. **********The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Thursday lifted its July 8 order, issued at the request of the barge industry, that held up the merger and said CSX would be free to start buying Texas Gas shares Saturday. **********The barge industry had said the merger would violate the 1912 Panama Canal Act that prohibits one transportation company from acquiring another company with a competing transportation line. CSX is the holding company for the major Eastern rail system, and Texas Gas owns a barge line. CSX said it would put the shares of the barge line into a trust until all antitrust questions are resolved. **********CSX offered $52 a share last month for more than 90 percent of Texas Gas shares. By late Saturday, a spokesman said, it had purchased 72 percent of the outstanding stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.main_headline: REAGAN BACKS BETTER EMERGENCY LINKS WITH SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.print_headline: REAGAN BACKS BETTER EMERGENCY LINKS WITH SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.body_text: **********President Reagan, saying he was seeking to reduce the possibility of ''unintended war,'' endorsed a series of proposals today for improving emergency communications with the Soviet Union, including direct transmissions between the nations' military generals. **********''I encourage the Soviet Union to carefully examine these proposals,'' the President said in a ceremony in the White House Rose Garden. ''Extending the range of rapid communications between the United States and the Soviet Union would make an important contribution to stability.'' **********The proposals, which the Administration calls ''confidence building'' measures, would improve the existing hot line between the White House and the Kremlin by installing a high-speed facsimile transmission machine for the exchange of graphic material and large amounts of electronic data. **********The measures were submitted to Congress last month by the Pentagon in response to a request for a report on possible new initiatives for reducing the risk of nuclear war by miscalculation or accident. No legislative action is necessary on the proposals, which President Reagan formally adopted today. **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger briefed the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, on the proposals last month and said the envoy had promised to forward them to Moscow for comment.  So far, there has been no reaction from the Soviet Union, White House officials said. Hot Line 20 Years Old **********The existing hot line is a teleprinter link, set up 20 years ago after the Cuban missile crisis; it works at the rate of 60 words a minute - a relatively slow pace for the modern missile age. The machinery Mr. Reagan proposes would permit nearly instantaneous exchanges of block messages and maps. **********The proposals would also establish direct links between Soviet and American military leaders to parallel the hot line. The President said this could be used for ''the rapid exchange of technical military information, thereby preventing misunderstanding in a crisis.'' **********The White House would also use it for a previously proposed measure by which the two powers would exchange advance notice of ballistic missile tests and military exercises. **********Two other proposals would improve electronic communications with the nations' embassies in Moscow and Washington and provide for international consultation in the event ''a nuclear incident is precipitated by an individual or group.'' The President said he saw no increasing risk of such a possibility but considered it prudent to be prepared should ''the unthinkable happen.'' Rose Garden Ceremony **********Mr. Reagan announced his endorsement at a ceremony in the Rose Garden that included a bipartisan group of senators who have been closely involved in the Administration's effort to win approval of the MX missile in Congress. White House officials denied that Mr.  Reagan's remarks, in which he said the proposals would add momentum to the arms-control process, were timed to win additional support for the MX. **********''They add new dimensions to our communications efforts,'' the President said of the proposals, ''allowing us to contact each other rapidly at political, military and diplomatic levels, improving our capability to contain crisis situations.'' **********Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, who attended the Rose Garden session, said later that the proposals, if put into effect, , could lead to ''crisis control'' centers in both countries and could prevent terrorist groups from being the catalytic agents of a nuclear war. **********After the ceremony, the President had lunch privately with former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.  ''I feel basically optimistic about the possibilty of negotiating with the Soviets,'' Mr. Kissinger said later in discussing the President's arms-control proposals, ''and I think we're more or less heading in the right direction.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; O.E.C.D. Deciding On Top Economist
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/08/busin.body_text: **********A British economist with a moderate approach to Government intervention is expected to take over the top economic job at the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. **********Although the appointment has not been announced officially, diplomatic sources say the decision to offer the post to Prof. David Henderson of London University was made by the O.E.C.D.'s appointments board earlier this week. In a telephone interview, Dr. Henderson confirmed that he is negotiating with the O.E.C.D. about taking the job and said, ''I hope it works out all right.'' He hopes to start work in January. **********Professor Henderson would replace Sylvia Ostry, who resigned earlier this summer to return to government service in her native Canada. Officials say he would be taking up what is potentially one of the most sensitive and important international economic posts at a time when the O.E.C.D. appears to be losing influence over its member governments' policies. **********Twenty-four nations are members of the O.E.C.D., including the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan. **********Traditionally, the O.E.C.D.'s secretariat has been dominated by Keynsian economists who believe governments can and should influence the level of economic activity by varying their fiscal policy. **********But conservative governments in the United States, West Germany, Britain and Japan have preferred to follow the advice of monetarist economists, who believe that economic growth will revive spontaneously once inflation has been brought under control by strict control of the nation's money supply. **********Professor Henderson, 56 years old, by reputation holds a middle position between Keynsians and monetarists. Although he has advocated a slightly more expansionary policy in Britain, he also favors reduced government intervention in the economy and has criticized subsidies for money-losing industries and prestige projects such as the Concorde supersonic airliner. **********Before joining London University, Professor Henderson served as director of the World Bank's economics department and as an economic adviser to the British Treasury and the British Ministry of Aviation. He has also taught at Oxford University and at Harvard.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;  Reynolds Metals Backs 7 1/2% Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********A $42.23 million issue of 7 1/2 percent pollution control revenue bonds of the Reynolds Metals Company was tentatively priced at 100 by an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. **********The bonds have a final maturity in 2013 and will pay 7 1/2 percent for the first five years. **********After five years the company will announce a new interest rate for the bonds. In 1988, and annually thereafter, holders of the bonds may put them back to the issuer at a price of 100. **********Although the bonds are issued by the Puerto Rico Industrial, Medical and Environmental Pollution Control Facilities Finance Authority, they are backed by Reynolds Metals. Additional security for the bonds is provided by a letter of credit by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Because of the bank's backing, the bonds were rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/20/world.main_headline: SALVADOR ARREST REPORTED IN KILLING OF AMERICANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/20/world.print_headline: SALVADOR ARREST REPORTED IN KILLING OF AMERICANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/20/world.body_text: **********The national police were reported to have arrested a Salvadoran Army captain today in connection with the 1981 slayings of two United States land- redistribution advisers. **********United States Embassy and police officials refused to comment on the report. **********The officer, Capt. Eduardo Alfonso Avila, was picked up during the day on the south side of the capital, according to his brother. The brother said he had no other details. **********''All we know,'' said the brother, Julio Enrique Avila, ''is that the arrest was made at the instance of the F.B.I. through the American Embassy.'' **********The two United States advisers, Michael Hammer and Mark Pearlman, were shot dead by gunmen Jan. 3, 1981, in the coffee shop of the Sheraton Hotel. Slain with them was Jose Rodolfo Viera, head of the Salvadoran land redistribution agency. The gunmen escaped.   Superiors' Orders Cited **********Two national guardsmen, Jose Dimas Valle and Santiago Gomez Gonzalez, were arrested and charged with murder in the case. They said in pretrial testimony that Captain Avila and Lieut. Isidro Lopez Sibrian of the national guard had ordered them to kill the three men. **********A police spokesman said he had ''no information on the subject.'' **********A United States Embassy spokesman said: ''We do not know if Captain Avila was arrested. If he was, the F.B.I. has nothing to do with it. It has no power to arrest anyone here.'' **********Mr. Dimas Valle and Mr. Gomez Gonzalez are still awaiting trial. Captain Avila and Lieutenant Lopez Sibrian were held for a few months but a court ordered them released in October 1982 for lack of evidence. **********Both are widely believed to be friends of Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Constituent Assembly Speaker, a cashiered army major who was nominated Sunday by the rightist National Republican Alliance to run for president.   Rightist Death Squads **********The United States-financed land redistribution program, aimed at breaking up this country's big estates and distributing parcels to landless peasants, has angered many of the wealthy families it affects. **********A number of Salvadoran exiles in Miami are known to have financed rightist death squads that have been killing and intimidating peasants and officials of the land redistribution program during the past three years. **********Earlier this month, the United States told El Salvador that it must crack down on death-squad activity or lose millions of dollars in aid. But in late November, President Reagan pocket- vetoed a bill that would have made United States aid contingent on regular certification to Congress that El Salvador is improving its human rights record. **********After his first detention, Captain Avila was retired from active military service and sent to Costa Rica as an attache to the Salvadoran Embassy. Costa Rican authorities expelled him a few months later, saying he had taken part in a plot.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's political and military opposition has called repeatedly since October for ''direct dialogue without prior conditions'' with the Government as the best way to end the threeand-a-half-year-old guerrilla war there. **********The proposal was quickly rejected by Salvadoran officials, particularly those on the right. **********The Salvadoran interim Government, backed by the United States, agreed only to discuss ways of having the opposition left participate in elections. The guerrillas' political leaders, however, have rejected the idea of discussing elections, preferring to discuss a broader political role. **********This week the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted 36 to 1 to provide more military aid for El Salvador but added a requirement that the Salvadoran Government make ''active preparation'' for an ''unconditional dialogue'' with the opposition within 90 days of the legislation's enactment by Congress. **********The opposition proposal - The guerrillas' Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and their political allies in the Democratic Revolutionary Front sent their proposal to Salvadoran officials early last October. The broadly-worded statement, made public at a news conference Oct. 26 in Mexico City, asked that negotiations begin quickly with witnesses, that a group be formed to coordinate the discussions and that the participation of other organizations, such as business, labor and the church, be considered. **********Reaction - The President of the Constituent Assembly, Roberto d'Aubuisson, called the guerrillas' proposal ''absurd'' and ''vile traitorship'' but could not get the Assembly to bar negotiations. **********The State Department reiterated that it favored the idea of political reconciliation but criticized the opposition plan for not saying whether the guerrillas would stop fighting and ''peacefully enter the ongoing political process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.main_headline: West Bank Censorship Is Criticized in Report
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.print_headline: West Bank Censorship Is Criticized in Report
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.body_text: **********A report issued yesterday said that it had found ''pervasive'' censorship of Arab publications in the occupied West Bank that ''mirrors the larger struggle between Palestinians and Israelis.'' **********The 167-page study was commissioned by the Fund for Free Expression, a New York-based affiliate of the Helsinki Watch and America's Watch, groups that monitor civil liberties. **********The author of the report is Dr. Meron Benvinisti, a former Deputy Mayor of Jerusalem who is also an activist in the Israeli peace movement. **********According to the report, Israeli censors do not merely suppress ''supposed national security secrets.'' **********''Rather,'' it says, ''the primary concern is to eradicate expression that could foster Palestinian nationalist feelings, or suggests that Palestinians are a nation with a national heritage.'' **********The study said all materials must be submitted to the censors, including photos, advertisements and crossword puzzles. The report said that of 1,077 English-language items by one newspaper last year, 367 were suppressed and 214 more where partly censored. **********A spokesman for the Israeli Embassy, Victor Harel, a press counsellor, said he had not seen the report and could not comment until he did.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********A state panel today urged a $750 million cooperative effort by business, labor, government and academia to create 60,000 new jobs by 1990. **********The plan, proposed by the Strategic Development Commission, calls for rebuilding some of Rhode Island's traditional industries, such as jewelry and textiles, while creating new industries for international markets. **********The commission consists of members of the business community and leaders of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. as well as representatives of educational institutions and government research institutions. Its chairman is J. Terrence Murray, chairman of the Fleet Financial Group, the largest banking institution in Rhode Island. **********Under the plan, $250 million of government funds would be spent on the program, and about $500 million would come from the business sector as a result of various incentives. The plan will be submitted to voters in a referendum next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/16/world.print_headline: Journalists Slain in Honduras Killed by Land Mine, U.S. Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/16/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that the two United States journalists who died in Honduras last month were killed by a United States-made land mine planted on the Honduran side of the border by Nicaraguan military forces. **********The department released its report on the June 21 deaths of Dial Torgerson, a correspondent for The Los Angeles Times, and Richard Cross, a photographer on assignment for U.S. News & World Report magazine. **********''Although absolute proof of responsibility for this tragic incident is not now available, and may never be, the full weight of the available evidence leads us to the conclusion that Torgerson and Cross were killed by a mine planted by Nicraguan forces,'' the report said. **********Initial reports said the newsmen were killed by a rocket-propelled grenade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/busin.body_text: **********Garban Ltd., a major broker of United States Treasury securities, will be acquired by Mills & Allen International P.L.C., a Londonbased company, under an agreement announced yesterday. **********Mills & Allen in 1982 acquired Garvin Guy Butler, a broker of foreign currencies and money market instruments that was half-owned by Garban. The British company also owns Euro Brokers, an investment banking company with New York offices that has a broker business in money market instruments such as bank certificates of deposit and overnight bank loans. **********Mills & Allen is a diversified company that has money brokering, advertising, printing and film studio operations.Garban was formed in 1974 and was closely held. The major shareholders were Kevin Seits and his mother, Anita. According to Mr. Seits, the company was sold for $26 million. **********Brokers such as Garban are little known to the general public. But they are indispensable to bankers, who use them daily to arrange billions of dollars of overnight loans with other banks, and to traders of currencies and United States Government securities. Most Treasury securities trades among dealers are arranged through brokers like Garban rather than through direct contact between two securities firms. **********Securities dealers are linked with a handful of brokers by video screens displaying the amount and price of securities available for sale or purchase. By thus displaying the merchandise it wants to sell or buy, a securities dealer can quickly reach a large number of other dealers. **********In the case of Garban, only the largest Government securities dealers are eligible to use its service. Smaller firms and the public must route their transactions through the dealer, which may or may not use the broker to find a buyer or seller. The broker acts only as a middleman and does not actually buy or sell the securities. The broker's earnings come from a small fee that depends on the size and type of each transaction. **********Several other United States securities dealers and brokers are owned by foreign companies. For example, Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C. of London recently announced plans to acquire Oppenheimer & Company, a New York-based securities firm. Since 1972 Mercantile House has owned Lasser Marshall Inc., a broker in foreign currencies, Euro-deposits and Federal funds; Fundamental Brokers Inc., a broker in Government securities, and Rouse Woodstock, a broker in commodities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Deloitte Haskins & Sells, one of the Big 8 accounting firms, announced senior management changes yesterday, including the naming of its first chairman. **********Charles G. Steele, who heads the firm as managing partner, will continue in the No.1 post, but with the titles of chairman and chief executive. **********''We haven't had anyone designated as chairman before,'' Mr. Steele said yesterday. ''I have been the managing partner and also chief executive, although we didn't call it that. Now I will be chairman and chief executive, but I will be staying in essentially the same position.'' **********C. Howard Kast, partner in charge of United States operations, was named managing partner and chief operating officer, also a new designation. Mr. Kast, 61, will be in the job until May 1984, when he will leave at Deloitte's retirement age of 62. **********J. Michael Cook, 40, partner in charge of the firm's Miami office, will succeed Mr. Kast next year as the firm's No.2 executive. Mr.  Cook, a graduate of the University of Florida, has been with the firm since 1964. For the next year he will work in New York on organization and strategic planning. **********Several other changes were announced. Robert D. Arnett, partner in charge of the Middle Western region, will become partner in charge of management advisory services. Jerry W. Kolb was named partner in charge of professional services, Raymond Spinola was named partner in charge of marketing and specialized services and Millard E. Smith was named partner in charge of accounting and auditing services. **********Mr. Steele said the changes, effective May 29, were the results of retirements. ''We are also taking a new look at our organization and strategic planning,'' he said. Mr. Steele, 57, has been managing partner for five years. He has been with the firm for 32 years, much of the time in California and later as head of the Chicago office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Richard Tufaro was sure that the uncooperative witness had changed his story. Mr. Tufaro was questioning the man in Los Angeles in a bankruptcy case, and knew the witness had contradicted himself in a deposition several weeks before. **********But instead of spending hours wading through the 3,000 pages of the witness's testimony, Mr. Tufaro had an associate put the witness's name and the subject of his testimony into a computer connected to Mr. Tufaro's law office in New York. In seconds, the lawyer had what he needed on the computer screen in Los Angeles, a contradiction that helped him settle the case. **********Mr. Tufaro is with Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCloy, and his case is only one example of the ways in which computers are helping lawyers do their work more efficiently. **********'Revolutionizing Legal Practice' **********''The use of computers is clearly revolutionizing legal practice,'' said Francis H. Musselman, an attorney at Milbank Tweed and former chairman of the American Bar Association committee on the economics of law practice. **********One result is a reduction in the mountains of paper that threaten to bury most lawyers. Another is a cut in the time needed to prepare routine documents and to pore through bulky volumes to find pertinent cases. **********All of this, for now, is not cheap. Even a system for a modest law office can start at $20,000. The large firms would require a more formidable investment. **********Milbank Tweed has two 4341 Model II I.B.M. mainframes, and associated equipment; 220 terminals; 20 display writers, and two separate personal computers. **********Cost Is $3 Million a Year **********It leases the equipment for about $2 million a year. Operating expenses add another $1 million a year. To purchase the equipment, Milbank's administrator estimates, would cost about $6 million in capital costs, and about $2 million a year to operate - more expensive than the lease arrangement because of a different depreciation write-off. **********The use of computers by lawyers has created an intense competitive scramble among suppliers of hardware and software - especially between the two providers of computerized legal research systems. **********Mead Data Central, a division of the Mead Corporation, was first with its Lexis legal research system in 1973 and now puts more than 48,000 new cases and judicial orders into it each week. Lexis still dominates the field with an estimated 9-to-1 edge in sales. But its competition, the West Publishing Company, a leading publisher of law books, is making inroads. One attraction of West's computer research system, Westlaw, was that unlike Lexis it was accessible through most law firms' word processing equipment. **********Law School Discounts **********This fall, West began to offer big discounts to law schools, most of which now train students to use one or both of the computer research systems. The company also signed a five-year contract recently to provide computerized research to the Federal courts. **********Lexis has fought back by making its products increasingly compatible with other systems. In fact, software being developed by Inslaw Inc. for several New York law firms, including Milbank Tweed and Sullivan & Cromwell, will make various functions - for example, accounting, attorney timekeeping, and legal research - available on the same terminal, whether it is made by Lexis or the International Business Machines Corporation. **********Conducting computer research also does not come cheap. Both the Lexis and Westlaw systems cost law offices about $2 to $4 a minute, depending on the amount of use. **********In the next several years, annual sales of specialty equipment and software for law firms are expected to triple, to $1 billion, according to James F. Rabenhorst, chairman of the law firm services group at Price Waterhouse. **********At Milbank Tweed, which is considered a front-runner in computerization, every secretary has a terminal, and nearly half of the 240 attorneys have terminals. Davis Polk & Wardwell has a staff of 15 just to service its computer system. **********Small Firms Involved, Too **********But the use of computers is not limited to large firms. Phil J. Shuey, who runs a one-lawyer office in Denver, uses a computer to store standard legal forms and maintain his client timekeeping records. **********Two basic types of computer hardware are used in law offices. One is a terminal connected to computerized law libraries like Lexis and Westlaw so lawyers can do legal research without opening a book. The other is a standard personal computer that uses software designed specifically to perform a variety of legal tasks. **********For Mr. Tufaro, a personal computer solved a type of problem lawyers confront almost every day: how to pinpoint a particular fact or legal principle among reams of documents or thick volumes of court decisions. But computers can do more. They can eliminate much tedious work - the drafting of routine motions, pleadings and other legal documents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.body_text: **********News Analysis **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz's swing through the Middle East is something of a diplomatic risk for the United States, but one that Israel is betting on heavily to rescue the Israeli-Lebanese negotiations from their impasse. **********It will be the first time since last summer that a senior policymaker in the Reagan Administration has met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and it constitutes the most dramatic American intervention in the talks so far. Mr. Shultz, now in Cairo, is expected to arrive in Jerusalem Wednesday, proceed to Beirut Thursday, then possibly return to Israel after consulting with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. **********In essence, the United States is being used by countries in the Middle East, with each party looking to the Americans to put pressure on its adversary. **********Israeli officials are hoping that Mr. Shultz will push President Gemayel to accept Israeli demands concerning security in southern Lebanon. Israel is convinced that the Lebanese are putty in American hands and that an agreement can be concluded quickly if Mr. Shultz bears down on Beirut. Similarly, the Lebanese are said to be certain that Israel will compromise if Washington tells it firmly to do so. **********Move by Soviet Feared **********Some Israeli officials, however, regard the American operation as an overreaction to relatively minor reverses. They see too much American prestige being attached to resolving the Lebanon situation, and they worry that creating such a big stake for Washington may induce the Soviet Union to react by trying to spoil the success. This Moscow could do by pushing its client, Syria, to refuse to withdraw its troops from Lebanon's Bekaa region. **********The Russians have been rearming Syria at a rapid rate, more than replacing what the Syrians lost to Israeli attacks in the war in Lebanon that began last June, according to officials here. **********Modern Soviet-built weapons, including the T-72 tank, the MIG-25 fighter plane and the long-range SA-5 antiaircraft missile have been introduced, and the number of Soviet military technicians and advisers in Syria has risen to 4,000, up from about 2,500 before the war, according to Defense Minister Moshe Arens. **********Syria has recently redeployed some troops and armor, has called up some crack reserve units and has put standing units and hospitals on alert, officials here say. Some of the redeployment is seasonal, coming after the end of the winter rains, when muddy areas dry out and permit freer movement of tanks, artillery and other heavy weapons. Israel is also taking up new positions, and the Israeli press has carried reports of units being placed on alert. Warning From Moscow **********The military movement has increased tension, with Damascus and Moscow warning against any Israeli attack. Some Israeli officials, who insist that no such attack is planned, believe that the Soviet resupply and the warnings were to be expected from the Russians after their foremost client in the region took a beating. **********One theory holds that the Russians, figuring that Israel would not attack, warned it not to do so, thus enabling Moscow to take credit for preventing something that was unlikely to happen anyway. **********Mr. Shultz's priority is expected to be the faltering Israeli-Lebanese talks on troop withdrawals from Lebanon. The negotiations were going fairly well until last Thursday, officials say, when the Lebanese delegation seemed to back away from several positions already agreed upon. These included details of the size and timing of proposed joint military patrols in southern Lebanon and elements of an accord on an open border with Israel. **********There has been Lebanese resistance all along to the demands by the Begin Government for some Israeli military presence in a southern Lebanese security zone after an Israeli troop pullout. But compromises by both sides in recent weeks had reportedly brought an accord within close reach. Israel had scaled down its demands, and Lebanon appeared to have agreed to the kind of partnership and close cooperation Israeli officials felt was needed to minimize the possibility of Palestinian guerrillas' return to the area. Differences Narrowed **********Both sides have been annoyed by the other's negotiating tactics.  Still, there has been a substantial narrowing of the differences. The Begin Government began by demanding five outposts in southern Lebanon, to be manned by 750 Israeli soldiers and intelligence agents. The idea has been informally dropped, though it remains technically on the table. **********Now, officials say, Israel wants two headquarters for a southern brigade of the Lebanese Army, where Israeli officers would be stationed to coordinate joint patrols of Israeli and Lebanese troops. President Gemayel, who fears that an Israeli presence would be used by Damascus as an excuse not to withdraw the Syrian Army, contradicted his negotiators recently by saying that joint patrols were unacceptable. **********Both sides have apparently agreed that the bulk of the southern brigade would comprise the 1,800 troops of Maj. Saad Haddad's local militia force, which has received Israeli arms and training since the 1975-76 civil war. The problem remains what to do with Major Haddad himself, who is technically a deserter from the Lebanese Army. **********Israel wants him to be the southern commander; Lebanon, which did not want him at all, has reportedly agreed to make him deputy commander. **********Mr. Shultz's mission in the coming days is to bridge the gaps.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/29/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Margin Debt's Recent Growth
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/29/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Margin Debt's Recent Growth
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/29/busin.body_text: **********ALTHOUGH the market timing skill of people who buy stocks on credit is a subject of recurring debate, one thing is certain: Lately they have been purchasing equities in record numbers. **********The margin debt of customers at member firms of the New York Stock Exchange rose $1.6 billion last month, to a new high of $17.9 billion. Meanwhile, the head count of customers with margin accounts increased by 30,000 to reach 790,000, also a record. In the three months ended June 30, margin debt expanded by $3.8 billion while the number of margin accounts climbed by 80,000. **********The trend of margin debt usually tracks stock-price movements, and the current bull market has borne this out so far. Rising equity prices also set records last month. The Dow Jones industrial average reached its closing high on June 16 at 1,248.30. **********''The upswing in margin debt during the last several months, from a technical standpoint, has confirmed the market's advance,'' Standard & Poor's Outlook said in mid-June. **********A customer with a margin account is borrowing money from his broker, and the stock is used as collateral for the loan to help pay for the shares. The percentage of cash a person must put up to open a margin account is fixed by the Federal Reserve Board. This margin requirement has remained at 50 percent since 1974. **********Buying on 50 percent margin provides leverage, since it allows a person to invest up to twice as much money. But this strategy is suitable only for people who can afford the risks. The leverage principle works against the customer if stock prices decline. In extreme cases, it can even lead to margin maintenance calls requiring the client to deposit additional cash or securities in the account. **********The pattern of margin account activity can also provide hints as to the possible direction of stock market movements.  ''One textbook example of a market bottom would show cash-account customers buying stock at the same time margin-account customers are selling,'' said Richard McCabe, manager of the market analysis department at Merrill Lynch. ''A glaring exception to this general rule, however, occurred last summer when stock prices reached their lows. Both types of accounts were selling in that period, which meant that only one-half of a market bottom signal was given.'' **********At the end of June 1982, margin debt of customers at Big Board firms - which includes money borrowed to purchase exchange-listed securities and also qualifying issues traded over the counter - totaled $11.54 billion. This debt declined slightly, to $11.47 billion, during July. **********The bull market in stocks began the second week of August. But between the end of July and the end of September, margin debt continued to slip, contracting by $520 million to reach $10.95 billion. Since then the debt has climbed each month, moving in gear with the general pattern of rising stock prices. **********As one tool in its technical analysis, Merrill Lynch constantly monitors activity of its margin-account and cash-account customers.  ''In recent months,'' Mr. McCabe said, ''margin accounts have been moderate net buyers, while cash accounts have been light net sellers.'' **********Deviations in margin debt can sometimes provide a clue to impending changes in the stock market, according to Joseph A. Feshbach, chief technical analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. **********''In the late spring of 1981, when the tone of the market still appeared pretty healthy and the Dow industrials were above 1,000, margin debt started to level off and that flashed a caution signal,'' he said. ''In June 1981, margin debt topped out at $14.87 billion and then dropped all the way to $10.95 billion last September.'' **********Meanwhile, the industrial average turned downward and reached a 27-month closing low last Aug. 12 at 776.92.  As for the argument that margin-account buyers are poor market timers, Mr. Feshbach observed, ''A lot of margin players have made a fortune in this bull market.'' **********Currently, however, in light of the stock market's sharp drop in the last two days, margin buyers are facing an old problem: Is this the time to take profits and run?

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The Zenith Radio Corporation reported today that it made a profit of $8.9 million in the first quarter, compared with a $2.4 million loss in the period last year. **********Company officials cited cost-reduction programs and increased shipments of cable television products and components as major factors in the improvement. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; O.& M. Divulges Its 11 Commandments
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Insiders at Ogilvy & Mather International call it the ''true church,'' William E. Phillips, chief executive, confided at the beginning of the company's annual meeting yesterday. **********And as the slide projector threw the picture of a beautiful stained glass window against the screen behind him, he confessed, ''There are a lot of analogies between Ogilvy & Mather and a religious order.'' **********Although he failed to explain just what they are, he then delivered O.& M.'s 11 commandments. And they were designed cleverly enough to allow him to show 17 commercials from the vast reaches of his empire and also get in the fact that in the last 10 days the domestic operation had racked up more than $80 million in new billings from but four assignments. **********And the 11th, which certainly lacked the brevity of the original 10, was ''Thou Shalt Strive to Solve the Perceived Conflict-of-Interest Problem With Competing Accounts.'' **********To that controversy Mr. Phillips added philosophically: ''Good agencies have a lot of conflict problems because they are in demand.  Bad agencies have no conflict problems because no one new wants them.'' **********He said he thought the problem was easing before the recession, then added, ''However, clients under severe financial pressure are less tolerant in all matters including conflict of interest.'

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/world.body_text: **********The explanations offered by the Argentine military for the disappearance of thousands during its campaign against leftist terrorists in the 1970's were roundly rejected today by many Argentines. **********A wide range of political and labor leaders as well as church officials, intellectuals and major human rights groups said in separate statements that the military's television broadcast to the nation Thursday failed to give details of what happened to the people, estimated at more than 6,000, who had disappeared or to say how many were dead. **********Most of the officials acknowledged the gravity of the leftist threat in the mid-1970's, but many accused the military of having used ''state terrorism'' to counteract the threat. **********Despite widespread expectations after the broadcast, the Government did not give details today on the fate of any of the missing people.  About 20 families, in response to the broadcast, went to the Interior Ministry this morning to look at a list the Government promised to provide of those who are missing. They were told to come back later. **********Late Thursday night the junta, which is made up of three service chiefs - Lieut. Gen. Cristino Nicolaides of the army, Adm. Ruben Franco of the navy and Brig. Gen. Augusto Jorge Hughes of the air force - issued a decree saying that the military was responsible for the operations against the leftists. **********That decree, and a proclamation in the report that said the actions of all soldiers and the police in the campaign were ''acts of service,'' appeared to set the ground for a law the junta has been considering. The law would require any prosecution related to the campaign to be handled by military courts. **********Many military officers are known to be fearful of retributions by a future civilian government.  Former President Jorge Rafael Videla, who as army chief and President led much of the antileftist campaign, broke his silence since stepping down to laud the report as ''an act of love.'' **********He said the military had made errors but added: ''Justification is not asked, because you cannot justify something unethical.  Understanding is asked.'' Political and Union Chiefs Critical **********The leaders of almost every political party, large and small, and many union leaders charged that the report failed to tell the whole truth, leaving the issue as a burden for the next government. **********Italo Luders, a leading presidential candidate of the Peronist Party, the country's largest, took issue with the report's use of the state of siege and of decrees he helped draw as head of the Senate in 1975 as a basis for legalizing the military's unconventional tactics. **********He said it was ''obvious'' the measures were meant to be carried out ''within the law and with respect for military regulations and the norms of humanity.'' **********Francisco Manrique, leader of the right-of-center Federal Party, was one of the few to offer any suppport for the statement, saying it was perhaps ''the most that can be said about this terrible qustion.'' Bishop Calls Statement 'Immoral' **********The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, in a statement a week ago, called for both truth and forgiveness concerning those who disappeared, and several bishops said today that the military's accounting was not true. **********Bishop Miguel Hesayne of the central province of Rio Negro said the report was ''immoral'' because ''it justified the criminal means used in the repression.'' **********At least six human rights groups issued harsh statements. The Permanent Assembly for Human Rights, an umbrella group, said 80 percent of the disappeared had been kidnapped from their homes and public places, though that percentage could not be confirmed. ---- Comment in Washington **********WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) - A State Department spokesman said today that United States officials had not seen the Argentine Government's report on its campaign against leftists. **********''Based on the press reports, however, we note that human rights groups and others in Argentina have apparently found it inadequate,'' the spokesman, Alan D. Romberg, said. ''We would hope that through these groups' communication with the Government of Argentina that at least some of these misgivings could be resolved.'' **********He added, ''We have consistently encouraged Argentine authorities to make available whatever information they may have to the families of the missing.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/busin.main_headline: MERRILL TO STOP MAKING MARKET IN SOME STOCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/busin.print_headline: MERRILL TO STOP MAKING MARKET IN SOME STOCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. said yesterday that it would stop making markets in certain exchange-listed stocks because the technology for execution of the orders was not efficient and the rules slowed the process. **********John McCarthy, vice president of over-the-counter trading at Merrill, said the firm would end its market-making experiment begun two and one half years ago within two weeks. Several brokerage firms participated in a project to determine whether additional competition in making markets for stocks would improve the market. But only a few firms are still involved, and they are trading in only a small number of stocks. **********In 1975, Congress mandated that a national market system be created, and firms were allowed to trade off the floor of the exchanges in stocks listed after April 1979. Merrill originally made markets in 27 stocks but had recently cut back to trading in 11.  Among the actively traded stocks in which Merrill made markets were Wendy's and NCNB, a North Carolina bank company. **********Previously, this activity was handled exclusively by specialist firms that acted as buyers and sellers for selected stocks traded on the floor of the exchanges. Merrill said the firm had experienced no trouble with specialist firms in executing orders.Processing Orders a Problem **********Mr. McCarthy said the problem was in the way orders were processed. When a dealer has an order for a stock, it is sent through the Intermarket Trading System computer network connecting five stock trading exchanges. If the order is not executed within two minutes, it is canceled, and to re-execute the trade a new quote must be obtained. **********On busy days, when the exchanges are swamped with orders, the orders sit. Mr. McCarthy said this was not because they were being ignored, but that they were being manually processed after being received and this physical handling created delays. He described the present system as ''order routing, not order execution.'' **********''If there is to be a market system, we have to have the type of technology where all orders can meet in the same electronic environment so customers can get the best price,'' Mr. McCarthy said. He added that he did not think the technology would be in place any time soon because of the expense involved in changing the system. **********He said Merrill would prefer to make markets in over-the-counter stocks because the computer network was such that an order can be placed and executed simultaneously at the quoted price on the terminal linking all the market participants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/world.print_headline: SALVADORAN TEST OF WILLS; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/world.body_text: **********The three-month-old campaign to remove El Salvador's Defense Minister is building into a crisis that could culminate in a test of wills between the minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, and the head of the Air Force. **********The United States has also become involved in the growing criticism of General Garcia. The Defense Minister's strong support of the country's social and economic development won him the support of the United States last year. But since January, even American officals have come to agree with Salvadoran officers that major changes are needed in the military command structure if El Salvador is to win the three-year-old civil war. **********Both American and Salvadoran officials have criticized the Defense Minister for mismanaging the war and naming inept departmental commanders to lead the country's troops. **********In an interview this week, General Garcia firmly denied that he will resign. But even as he spoke, Col. Juan Rafael Bustillo, the chief of the Air Force, was completing his plans to challenge the authority of the Defense Minister if he does not resign by Friday. Commander's Political Skill **********The 48 year-year-old Air Force commander, who has the full support of his officers, said in an interview on Wednesday that the Air Force could refuse to recognize the authority of General Garcia if he refuses to step down by Friday. **********His ability to retain his position, military and political sources said, is both a measure of his own political skill, and the difficulty the country's provisional president has had in finding an acceptable successor. **********Colonel Bustillo, described by officials as a ''patriot'' and an ''excellent'' commander who is politically to the right of the Defense Minister, believes that if major changes are not made soon the war situation will continue to deteriorate. Military sources said he that agonized for weeks over his decision to challenge the Defense Minister's authority and that he views it as his patriotic duty to take decisive action against General Garcia. **********What form his challenge will take is unclear. Military and political sources said Colonel Bustillo could cut communications with the headquarters of the armed forces, and begin to manage the war from his office at the Ilopango Airport, which is on the outskirts of the capital. Degree of Support Unclear **********Historically, field commanders in El Salvador have kept in close contact with the Air Force, and the Air Force, in turn, has passed on the information to the high command in San Salvador. **********Military officials said the war room at Ilopango is far more comprehensive than the same room at the Armed Forces headquarters.  ''They have nothing compared to the Air Force,'' said one military source who has spent time at both places. **********It is unclear what support Colonel Bustillo has among other commanders. The colonel said he has not sought any support, and no commanders could be reached for comment. The colonel commands 1,500 men including about 60 officers. **********American and Salvadoran officials are hoping that Colonel Bustillo's threat to disregard the Defense Minister's authority will be enough to persuade the provisional President Alvaro Magana that it is time to ask for the Defense Minister's resignation, or at least to demand that the minister make considerable changes in the military command. Many Crises for Garcia **********General Garcia, the last military officer from the 1979 junta to participate in the Government, has managed to ride through so many crises that some officials are betting that he will once again salvage his job by agreeing to make changes in the departmental commanders. **********One military officer said that once Colonel Bustillo makes his ultimatum there will likely be a meeting of the high command that will result in ''compromises'' from all of the parties. **********One of the problems in the crisis is that a successor acceptable to the United States, rightist Salvadoran politicans and moderate forces here has been difficult to find. **********The name mentioned most frequently is that of Colonel Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, the director of the National Guard. However, Colonel Vides has been reluctant to take a position that will last only until the presidential elections in December, according to a Salvadoran lawyer who knows him well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; THURSDAY, MAY 26, 1983; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Oil companies bid a record $3.47 billion for exploration rights on 656 Federal tracts in the Gulf of Mexico. The previous record, $2.7 billion, was set in 1980 on 147 tracts. The response by industry to the offering was hailed by Interior Secretary James G. Watt. (Page D1.) **********The Senate Finance Committee voted to attach a package of unrelated measures to a bill repealing tax withholding on income from dividends and interest. The rider included President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative as well as a trade reciprocity bill.  Advocates of repeal declared that the package, put together by opponents, would so clutter the measure as to threaten its passage.  (D1.) **********Net sales of mutual funds climbed to a record $3.5 billion in April, from the previous peak of $2.69 billion in March. (D5.) International **********The I.M.F. will hold up some $411 million in loans to Brazil for at least a month, according to monetary sources in Washington. They cited doubts that Brazil is complying with economic goals set out as a condition for the loans. Delaying the loans would automatically delay loans of some $635 million from private lenders. (D1.) **********The President has received tutoring in world economic affairs for the last six months in preparation for next weekend's summit meeting in Williamsburg, Va., according to his aides. The role he has chosen - as host, chairman, moderator, note-taker and reporter of the talks - will be an unusually ambitious one, and marks a shift from Mr.  Reagan's preference for delegating responsibility. (A1.) **********The U.S. and China will open talks next Wednesday on a treaty laying out rules for settling disputes stemming from investments between the two countries. (D15.) Markets **********The stock market registered its third consecutive advance in one of the heaviest trading sessions of 1983. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.97 points, to 1,229.01, as investors reacted to news of a new high in mutual fund sales for April. Turnover climbed to 121.1 million shares, the fourth-highest this year. (D1.) **********Interest rates rose slightly as credit market participants worried about shrinking investor demand. (D8.) **********Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts rose last week, to 8.15 percent, after declining for several weeks. (D9.) **********New York City sold $100 million of general obligation bonds in its first competitive offering since 1975. (D8.) **********The dollar declined against other major currencies, while gold prices rose $2.75 an ounce in New York, to $439. (D14.) Sugar and coffee futures prices posted strong advances. (D14.) Companies **********A Washington State judge is to decide on Friday how long to restrain Chemical Bank of New York from declaring the Public Power Supply System in default. The utilities group is expected to miss payments next Tuesday on $2.25 billion in bond debt for two abandoned nuclear power plants. (D7.) **********Federal regulators invited bids for five Tennessee banks left shaken by the collapse of Jake and C.H. Butchers' banking and finance holdings in the state, according to sources in Washington. (D15.) **********AM International reported a profit for its third quarter. The company has been operating under Federal bankruptcy law. (D7.) **********Louisiana Land's management has won a proxy battle against dissidents led by Delo Caspary, a Texas oil millionaire. (D6.) **********Muriel Siebert opened a branch in the First Women's Bank, a new twist in the growing ties of banks and discount brokers. (D6.) Today's Columns **********New systems will allow individuals to hold televised conversations from their desks rather than from special rooms. This is a return, in a way, to the Picturephone, which failed commerciall 20 years ago.  Technology.
