https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.main_headline: EMBATTLED ECONOMIC ADVISER: MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; EMBATTLED ECONOMIC ADVISER: MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.body_text: **********Few American economists of his age - 44 last week - could have brought as rich a reputation to the chairmanship of the Council of Economic Advisers as Martin S. Feldstein did last year, and few of his predecessors have brought more criticism from his employers in the White House.  The sniping took on an unusually nasty edge Wednesday, generating widespread speculation that Mr. Feldstein would have to resign. The President's spokesman, Larry Speakes, joked about Mr. Feldstein's limited role in policy making and even mocked the pronunciation of the man's name, alternating between ''Feld-STINE,'' which the economist prefers, and ''Feld- STEEN,'' which many members of the White House staff tend to use. **********It is differences over tone and style as well as the substance of economic policy that divide Mr. Feldstein from the White House and Donald T. Regan's Treasury Department. All sides agree that Federal budget deficits are a problem, and all allow that taxes might have to be raised to lower the deficits.  Mr. Feldstein, however, has been talking more about Mr. Reagan's cuts in taxes and increases in military spending as components of the deficit than have other Administration officers, and most of the Administration wishes he would not. **********''They know the deficits are their Achilles' heel, but they would prefer that he emphasize recovery,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, who was chief economist in the Office of Management and Budget early in the Reagan Administration and is now a consultant here. **********Martin Stuart Feldstein was appointed chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in August 1982 following the resignation of Murray L. Weidenbaum, who returned to teaching at Washington University in St. Louis. **********At the time, Mr. Feldstein was a professor at Harvard and head of the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., a private organization into which he had breathed new purpose and energy. **********Alternatives to Keynes **********Mr. Feldstein was at the front of a wave of youthful conservative economists who won wide recognition for alternatives to Keynesian theories. Those theories had governed economic policy-making since adoption of the Employment Act of 1946, but they had fallen into disrepute in the face of the high inflation and recurrent recessions - stagflation - of the 1970's. Mr. Feldstein has emphasized the importance of savings and capital investment as dual pistons of economic growth. **********Initially, he resisted joining the Council of Economic Advisers. With Mr. Reagan's election in 1980, rumors spread that he would be called to head the council. He deflected them by making it known to the new President's staff - even before they approached him - that he was involved in research projects that precluded joining the Administration. A year later, however, the work had been completed and he was ready. **********Mr. Feldstein has never become as close an adviser to the President as most of his predecessors and colleagues. In his concern over the deficits, however, Mr. Feldstein has important allies, notably on Capitol Hill. His views are also consistent with those of the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker. And within the Administration, his allies include the budget director, David A. Stockman. **********But Mr. Stockman has kept his views of the deficit within the Administration councils, and Mr. Feldstein has not. And with the Administration likely to campaign on tax cuts - not tax increases - and the recovery's unexpectedly strong recovery and the sharp decline in inflation, Mr. Feldstein's persistent public warnings have become particularly inopportune. **********Why Mr. Feldstein continues to harp on this point baffles other economists. ''There's always been the suspicion that he's playing to Harvard, the Charles River crowd,'' Mr. Kudlow said, ''that he's more interested in protecting his academic integrity than the President's programs.'' **********Mr. Feldstein's manner, too, suggests that he may feel closer to Cambridge than Washington. He has a professor's precision in explicating complicated issues, though he is never patronizing. And through all the furor, he has maintained an air of being bemused that his sober economic analyses should ignite such firestorms. **********His quarters in the Old Executive Office Building beside the White House also convey that he has never fully made himself at home on Pennsylvania Avenue. While elegantly furnished with reproduction antiques, the corner office lacks the framed pictures and other personal effects that imbue an office with the identity of its occupant. **********In similar circumstances, many previous council chairmen have kept their dissent to themselves once they lost debates with the Administration. ''I was very fortunate in the sense that I found myself on the same side as President Ford almost all the time,'' said Alan Greenspan, who was chairman of Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford. **********''But when there were exceptions, I just exempted myself,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''I would not testify on certain bills. And when I was asked questions about them, I would stipulate that the President believes such and such, and when asked what I believed, I said that was not relevant.'' **********''I feel I have my credibility to protect, too,'' said a senior Administration economist who asked not to be identified. ''But no one has forced me to speak out on something I had strong reservations about. When you disagree and you lose, you just have to remain silent. I don't go out on the speaking circuit.'' **********Military Spending Noted **********Although Mr. Feldstein is now portrayed as a critic of Administration spending and fiscal policy, he has not, in fact, openly criticized the rise in military outlays, and people close to him say he supports the military program. In a speech Wednesday analyzing the deficit and in comments earlier this week, he simply noted the rise in military spending along with other changes in discussing the budget deficits.  Mr. Feldstein, a bespectacled man of five foot nine inches, is married to the former Kathleen Foley, also an economist. Before he came to Washington, they wrote a joint newspaper column on economics topics. **********The Feldsteins have two daughters, Margaret, 13, and Janet, 11. For the duration of Mr. Feldstein's public service, the family has moved from its Belmont, Mass., home near Cambridge to a rented house in the Georgetown section of Washington. **********Mr. and Mrs. Feldstein often attend the theater, ballet and opera. Last month, they saw two productions of the Washington Opera Company, Cos i fan Tutte and Rigoletto.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.main_headline: REAGAN'S LETTER TO LATIN PEACE GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.print_headline: REAGAN'S LETTER TO LATIN PEACE GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.body_text: **********Following is a letter from President Reagan to the so-called Contadora group, which is made up of Panama, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela and is trying to foster a settlement of the conflicts in Central America: Dear Mr. President, Thank you for the letter which you and the Presidents of Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela have sent to me concerning the meeting held in Cancun on July 17 to review the current situation in Central America. **********I would like to congratulate you on the efforts which the Contadora Four are making to promote dialogue among the countries of Central America. My Government has consistently expressed strong support for the Contadora process. The Cancun Declaration, by articulating the crucial issues which must be treated to reach an effective and enduring resolution of the Central American conflict, is an important contribution to advancing that process. **********Four Points **********I continue to believe that a solution to the crisis in Central America must encompass four basic principles: First, it is essential that democratic institutions be established and strengthened as a means to resolve political differences within the Central American states. Only by insuring free and open participation in the democratic process can the peoples of Central America achieve reconciliation within their societies. **********Second, there must be respect for the principle of nonintervention, including a ban on support for subversive elements that seek to destabilize other countries. **********Third, the conflict in Central America must be removed from the context of an East-West confrontation through such measures as the verifiable withdrawal of all foreign military and security advisers and a certifiable freeze on the acquisition of offensive armaments. **********And finally, the countries of Central America must work among themselves and with their neighbors to achieve and sustain a level of economic growth that will guarantee the basic needs of their people. **********I am pleased that the Cancun Declaration recognizes the importance of these fundamental principles. These issues are inextricably interrelated and must be addressed on a comprehensive, regional basis which treats simultaneously the concerns of all the states affected by the Central American conflict. An attempt to resolve these issues sequentially, or on a piecemeal basis, will not achieve the goal we all share of a lasting peace for all of Central America. Role for O.A.S. **********Equally important is the need to insure that all undertakings assumed by the Central American states be fully reciprocal and subject to comprehensive, fully adequate verification. Clearly, no initiative can bring true peace to Central America if one state is permitted to take unjust advantage of its neighbors through failure to abide by peace conditions which bind the others. The Charter of the Organization of American States makes clear that it should be the purpose of the O.A.S. to either prevent unjust acts committed by one state against another or to provide for common action on the part of the members in the event of difficulties. I believe the O.A.S., as this hemisphere's regional forum, is the appropriate mechanism to insure that those who make commitments comply with them. **********The problems of Central America are complex, and their solution demands untiring efforts. The activities which you and your colleagues in the Contadora group have undertaken are proof of your sincere dedication to the goal of a genuine and lasting peace throughout the region. My own efforts in this regard have been to dispatch my special emmissary to the region and establish a bipartisan commission to examine the problems of Central America and to propose solutions. You have my prayers and those of my countrymen as you continue your work.  Sincerely, RONALD REAGAN

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.print_headline: 21 Israelis Wounded In Ambush Near Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.body_text: **********Gunmen ambushed an Israeli military bus south of Beirut today, wounding 21 Israeli soldiers.  The Israeli command in Tel Aviv said the gunmen fired small arms and bazookas at the bus two miles east of the village of Kfar Sil. **********It said most of the injuries were slight. **********The command, which did not identify the assailants, said Israeli troops chased them and killed one. The attacks brought the number of Israeli casualties in Lebanon to six dead and 25 wounded in three weeks. **********The Christian-operated Voice of Lebanon radio said the ambush occurred between the Christian town of Hadath and the Druse town of Shuweifat about three miles south of Beirut. **********The broadcast said concentrations of Israeli troops and armor were seen near Hadath firing sporadically in the direction of olive groves near Shuweifat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.main_headline: AS OIL REVENUE FALLS, KUWAIT TIGHTENS ITS BELT AND WORRIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.print_headline: AS OIL REVENUE FALLS, KUWAIT TIGHTENS ITS BELT AND WORRIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Falling world oil prices are sending tremors of apprehension through this tiny state at the head of the Persian Gulf.  Kuwait's alarm is shared to varying degrees by all the other small oil exporters along the Gulf, from Bahrain down through Qatar and the United Arab Emirates to Oman. **********For the first time since the big price explosion in 1974, the conservative, pro-Western rulers of these vulnerable Arab nations are learning that they can no longer count on constantly rising revenue to buy social peace at home. The Nation's Riches **********Kuwait, like the other states, remains wealthy, with huge assets and few people to support. Its population of 1.4 million is sitting on 10 percent of the world's known oil reserves, and the Government has $70 billion to $100 billion invested overseas. **********But, says one Western ambassador, ''Of course any change makes people nervous in a tiny, defenseless country with immense riches that is surrounded by covetous neighbors.'' **********Despite a 40 percent decline in oil revenue over the past year, the Government is under pressure to maintain spending. These pressures are illustrated by the following recent developments: **********- The collapse last summer of Kuwait's unofficial stock market under a $90 billion mountain of bad checks threatens to ruin so many Kuwaitis that the Government has agreed to bail out thousands of small investors - defining ''small'' as anyone whose losses are under $66 million. Some estimates suggest that the Government has already committed about $5 billion to avoid widespread bankruptcies. **********- With the flare-up in the Iraq-Iran war, Kuwait is again being asked to lend money to Iraq. Although Iraq claims Kuwait's oilfields, Kuwait has preferred to help finance Iraq, to the tune of $6 billion so far, rather than risk a victory by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's revolutionary forces, because Iran is committed to the overthrow of the conservative Gulf rulers. **********- The war has also ruined Kuwait's lucrative trade with Iraq and Iran. There are nearly 5,000 idle trucks here, most bought on credit.  ''It's a difficult time,'' acknowledges Hamza Abbas, governor of the central bank. ''But we Kuwaitis will find a way out. We always do.'' **********In economic terms, Kuwait's reaction to falling revenue has been to try to shield the population from the impact by maintaining spending this year at $10.5 billion, roughly unchanged from 1982. ''The assumption is that the oil price will strengthen soon,'' Mr. Abbas says. Changes in Plans **********Expensive plans to relocate the university and beautify the seafront are being ''stretched out,'' not canceled. But a new power station is going ahead. Gasoline prices have just been raised to 50 cents a gallon, from 15, but electricity is heavily subsidized. **********The price of maintaining Government spending will be Kuwait's first sizable budget deficit, probably $2 billion to $3 billion this year.  Like other Gulf states, Kuwait is secretive about oil production and earnings. But the central bank says oil revenue tumbled 40 percent in the third quarter of last year, to $1.7 billion, from $2.5 billion a year earlier. This suggests annual earnings this year of at most $7 billion. **********Low oil prices worldwide are one reason for the fall in revenue.  But more important, daily oil production, which as recently as 1979 was more than 2 million barrels, has fallen to about 700,000 as a result of weak demand. At this level, Kuwait is producing so little natural gas as a byproduct of oil that it was forced to cancel supply contracts with Japan last year and has switched its own gas-fired generating plants to fuel oil. **********Financing the budget deficit seems easy, because Kuwait can draw on the $8 billion to $10 billion annually that it earns in interest and dividends from its investments. But doing so for long is politically unpopular: Much of this money belongs to the Fund for Future Generations, a nest egg that Kuwait is putting aside against the day the wells run dry. The fund is not supposed to be touched before 2000. **********''We can get by like this for a while,'' says Mohammed W. Khouja, economic adviser to the Government-controlled Kuwaiti Real Estate Investment Consortium, ''but not if the price stays weak for two or three years. Then it will be felt.'' Spreading the Wealth **********Western diplomats and bankers here believe Kuwait has done a better job than many other oil exporters in distributing its wealth. Less Government spending could weaken the social cohesion that wealth has created in Kuwait's ethnically diverse society. **********Foreigners attracted by the lure of oil make up more than half the population of Kuwait, with Palestinians accounting for half the foreigners. There is also a sizable contingent of Shiite Moslems from Iran who might accede to the revolutionary rhetoric next door if times become difficult. **********Thus, the aid that Kuwait gives Iraq is also intended to buy peace at home. While Iran is confined to its own borders, Kuwaitis feel they do not have much to fear. But if Iran succeeds in its drives toward Basra, which commands the road to Kuwait, Teheran would be in a position to influence domestic Kuwaiti politics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.body_text: **********APRODUCT'S marketing position is where it lives. If advertising t ells consumers an item is a kitchen cleanser, they won't think to u se it in the bathroom. Similarly, in the case of a magazine, p ositioning defines the audience it appeals to. **********For years, for example, Redbook was positioned to reach the young mothers of the 18-to-34 age group. But that has become a rather crowded neighborhood, taking in such popular publications as Cosmopolitan and Self. Thus, when advertisers interested in that specific age group had to trim their magazine schedules because of a worsening economy, Redbook started to find itself running fourth in a field of three. **********The solution, arrived at by Alan M. Waxenberg, the new publisher installed by Hearst Magazines, the new owner, and Richard Sarno, associate publisher and advertising director, was to find a less crowded readership neighborhood that would still appeal to a large block of advertisers. **********They found their answer in the syndicated audience-research data - the 25- to 44-year-old group of women who make up 46 percent of Redbook's total audience of 13.2 million. It is an age group of women that turns to Redbook more than any other major publication, and they snuggle down nicely between the younger audience of Hearst's Cosmopolitan and the older audience of its Good Housekeeping. **********A one-time ad in all three magazines, Mr. Waxenberg said, would deliver 40 percent of the nation's 18-to-49 women, and a 12-time schedule would hit 90 percent. **********The next step for Redbook, of course, is to make advertisers and their agencies realize how important their 25- to 44-year-old readers are as a group of consumers. **********As Mr. Sarno pointed out with flip charts, they are the baby boom that is now working its way through the nation's demographic profile as the biggest ''population bubble.'' It is a population segment that will grow 27 percent by 1990, and that portion of American womanhood that Gilbert Maurer, president of Hearst Magazines, lovingly characterized as ''the pig in the python.'' **********The process of highlighting the group's life styles and buying habits begins on Monday via a $1 million advertising campaign that springs from the hands of Ron Rosenfeld and Len Sirowitz, co-chairmen of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson. **********The reasons for selecting Valentine's Day for the debut will be readily apparent. The ad campaign will picture the group as jugglers, women who juggle three lives as wife, mother and worker. But even more important to advertisers will be the advertising theme line, ''At the Red Hot Heart of the Market.'' **********Do you get the anatomical drift? This may help: The headline that will appear on Monday on full-page ads and spreads will be ''Redbook Is Going for the Juggler.'' **********The rest of the campaign will be in a similar vein.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/04/busin.body_text: **********Geers, Gross Advertising has been named agency for Hebrew National Kosher Foods, which has also named Levy, Flaxman & Associates to handle its recently acquired fresh chicken and turkey operation. **********The main account should be billing $3 million, and fresh fowl, $1 million. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.main_headline: LEANING TOWER OF PISA IS LEANING A BIT MORE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.print_headline: LEANING TOWER OF PISA IS LEANING A BIT MORE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.body_text: **********The Leaning Tower of Pisa leaned another five one-hundredths of an inch last year, and city officials say it is doomed to collapse unless a way is found to halt the ever-increasing tilt. **********The Italian Government is spending $10.5 million to stabilize the 180-foot-tall marble monument, but the cause of its slant remains a mystery and Pisa officials are skeptical whether the rescue effort will succeed. **********''It's bound to fall some time if we can't find a way to control it, though we don't know when it's going to happen,'' said Giuseppe Toniolo, chairman of the city committee responsible for the tower. **********'Might Be Much Sooner' **********''It could take a hundred years to fall,'' Mr. Toniolo said, ''or it might be much sooner.'' The tower is 16 feet off the perpendicular, giving some visitors vertigo as they walk up the 293 spiral stairs of the campanile, or bell tower. **********Scientists observing the tower's movements said the increase in its lean last year was five one-hundredths of an inch, compared with three one-hundredths of an inch in 1981, which was the smallest increase in tilt in 15 years. **********Mr. Toniolo said the angle of slant might be affected by water lying 50 yards underground beneath the tower. Scientists have noted that the tower tilts faster when the water pressure below is weak and remains steady when pressure is high. Movement 'A Mystery' **********''Last year it rained less than the previous year,'' Mr. Toniolo said, ''and that may be the answer.'' But he said that no one was sure and that the movement of the tower was ''simply a mystery.'' **********In February, the Italian Parliament approved $10.5 million for a four-year project to stabilize the 12th-century structure, including an electric pump to maintain the pressure of water in the underground pools. **********Money will also be spent to reimburse the city for entrance fees that it will lose when the tower is closed to the public while work is under way. **********Mr. Toniolo said, however, that he and other experts feared the effort would fail.  ''The last major intervention in 1934 caused a very large increase in the lean,'' he said. ''Nobody can say what will happen this time.'' **********In 1934, some 900 tons of concrete were pumped into holes dug under the low side of the tower in an effort to stop the increasing lean.  Construction of the tower in this Italian commercial center 150 miles northwest of Rome began in 1173, and the monument had already started to lean after 35 feet had been completed. **********The last three stories and a belfry were added in 1350, when the tower was already 10 feet off the perpendicular. Efforts to straighten higher stories during construction failed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/world.main_headline: INDIA BORDER IS NO BARRIER TO BANGLADESH MIGRANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/world.print_headline: INDIA BORDER IS NO BARRIER TO BANGLADESH MIGRANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/world.body_text: **********The weathered low concrete pillars marking the boundary between India and Bangladesh are difficult to spot from the bumpy dirt road that runs along the frontier. **********There are no border patrols in sight, no fences, no walls. A oneminute walk through harvested rice fields where farmers rest in the shade of bamboo thickets while watching their cattle and a visitor is in Bangladesh. **********It is that simple to cross the 300-mile-long frontier in parts of the northeastern states of Meghalaya and Assam. Local officials and Assamese activists say hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants have crossed into India here. **********The issue was at the center of the agitation during elections in Assam in February when more than 3,000 people died in ethnic and religious rioting. Violent incidents and bomb explosions continue to be reported. Expulsion of Aliens Demanded **********The violence occurred after a student-led protest movement, demanding the expulsion of illegal aliens, tried to block or disrupt the elections. Fighting erupted between the Assamese nationalists and tribal groups, who are mainly Hindu, and Bengali-speaking Moslems, some but not all from Bangladesh. **********''It is impossible to patrol the border at some places,'' an Indian border security official said. He said the problems resulted from a British civil servant's hasty demarcation of the frontier during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent into India and Pakistan. **********In the absence of any visible boundaries, the location of the frontier is often left to the imagination. The short pillars are frequently obscured by shrubs, hillocks, thick jungle, streams and rice fields. They zigzag in bewildering fashion across the countryside, and many patches of Indian or Bangladesh territory are surrounded on three sides by land of the other nation. **********Border officials said many residents of the frontier areas were poor farmers who often slipped across the border to visit relatives or cut bamboo for fuel and construction work or even illegally harvested crops on the other side and carried the produce home. Incidents Are Frequent **********Incidents are frequent. An Indian official said 24 Bangladeshis had been killed in the last six months while trying to cross illegally into the Garo Hills district in western Meghalaya. **********Although Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, has existed as a nation for 12 years, the word ''Pak'' - short for Pakistan - is still carved on scores of boundary pillars. East Pakistan became Bangladesh in 1971 after a civil war in which many thousands were killed.  Bangladeshis, though Moslem, had fought to preserve their ethnic and linguistic separateness as Bengalis. **********An Indian official said 30,000 illegal migrants had moved into this border district since 1971. He said the total population of the district was 400,000. **********The Bangladesh nationals are difficult to identify, the official said, because they look like the Bengali-speaking Moslem settlers who came much earlier and dress and talk like them. **********''Often they slip into the home of a relative or a friend who has lived here for years and begin by working in their fields,'' he said. He said that after some years they would travel farther into Assam and settle along the Brahmaputra River where earlier immigrants live in squatter colonies. Town Is 'Transit Point' **********''If you suspect someone and ask him when he came,'' the official said, ''he'll say that he was born in India, had come here some years ago from another part of Assam and produce a score of witnesses to support him.'' He said the Government was helpless in such cases unless police informers in the squatter colonies gave specific information. **********Tek Chand Aggarwalla, a prosperous Hindu businessman whose family has lived at Mankachar, on the Assam-B@angladesh border, for 100 years, said the town was frequently used as a ''transit point'' by Bangladeshis who travel farther up the valley. **********The anti-immigration protesters fear that the Assamese, who are predominantly Hindu and have their own language, will be swamped by Moslem immigrants and other Bengali speakers. **********Nari Rustomji, who has held several top administrative posts in northeast India, said, ''The root of discontent on the frontiers is clearly the apprehension of cultural annihilation.'' **********In calling for an election boycott, the Assamese movement said local politicians had placed many illegal immigrants on voter rolls over the years. The Assamese nationalists are particularly critical of the ruling Congress Party, which, they say, sought to create ''vote banks'' that could be relied upon to support it in elections.  In turn, the nationalists say, the migrants were assured they would not be troubled or investigated. **********The situation is reported to be still tense in parts of the state, and intelligence sources said it would take at least three or four months for the region to return to normal. It is estimated that 280,000 people are homeless and surviving on Government doles. **********Meanwhile, the Assamese students announced that they were suspending the agitation. They said they would organize rehabilitation work and food distribution and repair damaged homes, roads and bridges. **********Some said they had lost control of the agitation during the elections when hard-liners committed to violence reportedly took part in the bloodbath. **********An intelligence official gave support to that view by saying in an interview that about 60 people had been arrested in connection with the worst massacre surrounding the election violence in February. He also said that that massacre, at Nellie, may have been organized by members of Assamese tribes who were former members of the army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/world.body_text: **********Iraq said today that its troops had repulsed a new Iranian attack along the border east of the Iraqi town of Amara. **********The Baghdad radio did not say when the Iranian attack took place.  It said an unspecified number of Iranian soldiers were killed or captured. **********Iranian artillery today shelled the border towns of Mandali and Zurbatiyeh, causing damage to several civilian installations, it said. **********According to Iraqi accounts, Iran opened a new offensive 10 days ago on the Al Shib front, where the latest action occurred. Iraqi helicopter gunships carried out 28 combat missions today to chase remnants of the defeated Iranian troops in the Shib area, a high command communique said tonight.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/busin.body_text: **********For Florida orange growers, who produce more than 75 percent of the nation's orange crop each year, the vicious cold that swept their groves this weekend could not have come at a worse time. **********Although the state's orange harvest normally starts by September, this year's crop has been small and late in maturing, so 90 percent of it was sitting on trees still waiting to be picked. **********''I don't know of a single processing plant that was working during the holiday weekend,'' said Larry Miller, vice president for finance at Orange- Co., a large Florida orange grower and juice processor. As a result, he said, even those growers who were aware of the freezing weather approaching were reluctant to pick their oranges on Friday or Saturday. **********Now Mr. Miller and his colleagues are rounding up every worker they can find to try to get the fruit picked before the temperature returns to its normal, 60-degree winter average, when the frozen oranges would begin to rot on the trees. They say it may still be possible to save most of the crop and that other states and other countries might be able to take up the slack if shortages do develop. **********Meanwhile, there are predictions of shortages and price increases, although their extent and timing are not at all clear. **********''People are comparing this year's damage to 1981, but it's just too early to tell,'' said Ernest Neff, a spokesman for Florida Citrus Mutual, a growers' cooperative. The most destructive Florida freeze in recent years occurred in January 1981, when about one-seventh of the state's orange crop, then expected to fill 207 million 100-pound boxes, was destroyed. **********The result in that year was a serious shortage of oranges and a swift increase in prices. In the first six months of 1981, the wholesale price of 12 six-ounce cans of frozen orange juice concentrate rose to $4.45, from $3. Since then, the price has gradually declined to $3.95. **********''It's safe to say prices will go up, but nobody can say at this point how much, or when, they will rise,'' Mr. Miller said. Others say such talk can turn to self-fulfilling prophecy with prices increasing all along the chain that includes the grower, processor, distributor and retailer, even though the extent of the crop damage may not justify it. **********Indeed, Earl Wells, a spokesman for Florida Citrus Mutual, said he did not expect the price of processed orange juice to rise much because the domestic orange crop can be supplemented by increased imports from Brazil. Brazil, which has become a major exporter of orange juice concentrate in recent years, sold 70 million gallons of it to United States marketers last year. **********Roughly 90 percent of Florida's orange crop is made into concentrate or other processed products. So consumers will see the effects of this freeze, if indeed there are any, in higher prices for frozen juice concentrates and the ready-to-drink products. Oranges for eating and squeezing into fresh juice also come from California and Texas. **********Tropicana, a unit of Beatrice Foods Inc., and Minute Maid, a division of the Coca-Cola Company, are the nation's leading producers of the ready- to-drink products. These, and other fruit processors, operate plants throughout central Florida, the area where most of the state's orange groves are situated and where temperatures sank below 28 degrees over the weekend. **********But while consumers and the growers may be understandably nervous about all this, commodities traders will no doubt see an opportunity. On the the New York Cotton Exchange, where contracts for frozen orange juice concentrate are traded, prices rose rapidly yesterday. Spot prices for the contracts for delivery this month rose 5 cents a pound, the daily limit, to close at $1.2925 a pound. **********Seth Diamond, a commodities analyst for Shearson/American Express, said one reason the price of orange juice contracts rose rapidly yesterday was that traders were not sure that the destroyed Florida oranges could be entirely replaced by Brazilian imports. ''Brazil has the capability, but they also have commitments to sell to other countries,'' he said. **********Temperatures Still Cool **********Yesterday, temperatures throughout Florida ranged in the 40's, still far below normal and cool enough to preserve most of the fruit for picking. But growers ''are scurrying like mad to harvest,'' Mr. Neff said. A spell of more normal Florida weather ''would mean trouble,'' he added. **********One problem for some orange growers, experts said, is finding enough workers for the speeded-up harvest. Ronald Billella, director of the Florida Division of Labor, Employment and Training, said his agency began a statewide effort yesterday to identify the growers that needed additional workers and to recruit those workers. **********Meanwhile, most of the state's orange juice processing plants have geared up rapidly to handle the increased volume. ''After a freeze, they run seven days a week, 24 hours a day,'' said Warren Savant, an official of the Florida Citrus Processors Association, a trade group. **********Another impact of the freeze could be lower profits for the orange juice processing companies. The largest are Minute Maid, Tropicana, Orange- Co. and American Agronomics. **********''None of the four should be seriously hurt, but they may find profit margins narrowed a bit because they can't pass through all of a price increase'' on the oranges they buy, said David Liebowitz of the American Securities Corporation. **********And while Florida's orange crop is far and away its biggest, it is not the only agricultural product that has been hurt by the freeze. The state's strawberry crop, which in recent years has produced more than $25 million in annual sales, may have been totally destroyed. **********A spokesman for the Florida Strawberry Growers Association said yesterday that ''at this point, everyone we've talked to said damage was 100 percent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.main_headline: SOUTH KOREA'S AIRLINE AND ITS PILOTS HAVE REPUTATION OF BEING AGGRESSIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.print_headline: SOUTH KOREA'S AIRLINE AND ITS PILOTS HAVE REPUTATION OF BEING AGGRESSIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.body_text: **********Korean Air Lines, whose off-course 747 carrying 269 people was shot down by the Soviet Union, has a mixed reputation among aviation officials, industry executives and pilots. **********But all seem to agree that the Korean flag carrier is ''extremely aggressive'' in its quest for rapid growth, its bargain-basement pricing of tickets and its willingness to assume huge debts to finance its ambitious plans. **********According to some airline officials and pilots, the corporate inclination toward aggressiveness is seen in the flying practices of Korean Air Lines pilots, nearly all of whom are alumni of the South Korean Air Force. **********For example, there is a practice some pilots use to land their plane before others. Since ground control radar can reach only about 200 miles, a pilot will give a false position to the control tower from outside its tracking range, indicating that the plane is closer or better positioned for landing than it is. **********Pilots Fond of Jumping Line **********Sometimes the control tower will then give that pilot's plane priority for landing when other planes are ahead of him. Pilots call this ''jumping the line.'' **********If it works, the ploy can save fuel and shave several minutes off a flight that otherwise might have been late. **********Until recently, Korean Air Lines pilots had a reputation for being particularly fond of jumping the line.  ''As you can imagine, they didn't win the love of their peers for that,'' one pilot said. ''But the Koreans have reformed on that score in the last couple of years.'' **********South Korea imports nearly all its fuel and the airline has long struggled to break even, so Korean pilots are also known as tenacious fuel savers. **********There has been speculation that the pilot of the plane that was shot down on Sept. 1 near the Soviet island of Sakhalin flew over Soviet airspace to take a more direct route from Anchorage to Seoul to conserve fuel. But foreign pilots say it is all but inconceivable the pilot would have flown over Soviet territory intentionally.   No Evidence of Pilot Error **********There are no solid clues to why the plane was so far off course and no evidence that pilot error was to blame. **********''As individuals, some of the Koreans are tough, hard-edged characters,'' one longtime American pilot said. ''That's the reason they have had a reputation with some people for being kind of macho pilots, guys with more guts than brains. But to suggest that the Korean pilots take risks with passengers' lives is unfair and untrue.'' **********Indeed, the safety record of Korean Air Lines has been excellent. In 1978, a Soviet jet shot at another Korean airliner, killing two passengers and forcing the aircraft to land on a frozen lake near the Russian city of Murmansk. **********Crashes are rare, however. The most recent one was in November 1980 when a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 landed short of the runway at Kimpo International Airport in Seoul. A fire broke out and 16 people were killed, including the pilot. **********Growth Since 1969 **********Extraordinary growth has been Korean Air Lines' hallmark since the Government, in 1969, decided that it should be placed in private hands and chose the Hanjin Group to do the job. **********Hanjin, a diversified transportation company, is headed by two brothers, Cho Choong Hoon and Cho Choong Kun, and their hard-driving notion of corporate management is characteristic of many of South Korea's industrialists. **********The elder brother, Choong Hoon, or Harry as he is known to friends and colleagues, is 63 years old. He received a big boost for his fledgling operation from the Korean War, hauling drinking water by truck to United States troops. The company also did contract hauling for the United States forces in Vietnam. Hanjin trucks, it is said, would deliver ammunition to areas where other haulers were reluctant to go.   130 International Flights a Week **********When Hanjin took over in 1969, the revenues of Korean Air Lines were $6.8 million and its work force was about 500. Except for a few flights to Japan, it was a domestic airline and its fleet consisted of one jet and seven smaller propellor planes. **********In 1982, Korean Air Lines revenues reached $1.1 billion at recent exchange rates, nearly 180 times the 1969 level. The payroll had about 10,000 workers, 20 times the number in 1969. As of last December, it had 41 aircraft in its fleet including 14 Boeing 747's and eight A-300's, the so-called European airbus. **********Today, among its 130 international flights a week, K.A.L. flies to New York, Los Angeles, Honolulu, Paris and Zurich, as well as the Philippines, Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan and Hong Kong. It also flies regularly to the Middle East, where Korea's construction companies are engaged in several large projects. **********Yet in the pursuit of growth, the company has piled up huge debts and priced its fares so cheaply that profits are scant. At the end of 1982, the company's debt burden was $1.1 billion.   Can Charge Any Fare It Likes **********Last year, Korean Air Lines posted a profit of $6 million. But that followed two losing years in which the cumulative losses were $47.8 million. **********However, K.A.L. has sacrificed profitability by pricing its fares cheaply to increase its share of the market. For example, many of the passengers on the flight from New York to Seoul were headed for Japan. Many travelers fly the extra distance to Seoul and then back to Tokyo because it is so cheap. **********A Tokyo travel agent said that with various discounts offered by K.A.L., a one-way coach fare New York-Seoul- Tokyo could be as cheap as $938. The regular Japan Air Lines fare from New York to Tokyo is about twice that price. **********Under a Korea-United States agreement, Korean Air Lines can charge any fare it likes for its trans-Pacific runs. Its two United States rivals, Pan American World Airways and Northwest Orient Airlines, generally match those fares. **********Competitors complain that K.A.L. offers rebates to travel agents, which they call a shady practice and do not match. **********In an inteview with a trade magazine last year, Cho Choong Kun called the accusations ''invalid.'' ''Maybe some salesman who wants to make his quota will underbid,'' he said. ''But we have to make money and we aren't going to give away seats for nothing. There is a lot of talk against us by others who have dirt on their pants yet criticize us for not being clean.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/04/world.body_text: **********Vice President Bush said today that a breakthrough was possible this summer in the Geneva nuclear arms talks with the Soviet Union, according to Danish officials. **********Mr. Bush's assessment of the American-Soviet negotiations came in talks with Prime Minister Poul Schluter in Copenhagen. **********''The Vice President assured us the United States is working energetically for a result in the negotiations, and it is not unlikely the results will come at the end of the summer,'' Mr.  Schluter said after two hours of talks with Mr. Bush. **********In a speech tonight at an official dinner given by the Danish Government, Mr. Bush referred to dissent within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the issue of deploying 572 new cruise and Pershing 2 missiles in Western Europe later this year. **********''Although our common commitment is being tested today,'' Mr. Bush said, ''I am confident this test will only strengthen our commitment to the alliance.'' **********Mr. Bush flew to Copenhagen from Helsinki, Finland, early today on the sixth leg of a European tour.
