https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/19/busin.body_text: **********Like any country, Brazil has its own ways of doing business. When appointments are made, each party expects the other to be half an hour late. Telephone messages are often not returned. ''They're just a reminder that you called before you call again,'' said a secretary in Rio. **********Trust, in Brazilian business, is the written word. ''Vale o que esta escrito'' - only trust what is written down - is a cardinal rule of business. **********''You can have a conversation with your boss and talk for a long time and feel that he will take care of your problem,'' said a manager at the Brazilian subsidiary of an American company in the southeastern town of Cruzeiro. **********''But the only thing that matters is what he puts on paper,'' he said. ''That's the important thing, not the talking but the writing.'' **********The Brazilian Government's most popular security is a five-year ORTN, which stands for readjustable national treasury bond. Like most securities and much else in the Brazilian economy, it is indexed to inflation. It pays a rate known as monetary correction - 146 percent through October this year - plus 8 percent. **********But this bond also offers an alternative return based on the decline in the value of the cruzeiro against the dollar. Through October, the cruzeiro had plunged 280 percent, so buyers of the bond are getting that, plus 8 percent, rather than the lower, monetary-corrected return. **********''It's the best inflation hedge possible, and it should not be issued,'' said Olavo Setubal, chairman of Banco Itau in Sao Paulo, the country's second-biggest private bank. **********Jose Mindlin is head of one of Brazil's most successful companies, Metal Leve, which makes pistons for automobile and aircraft engines. The company prospers, he said, because, unlike the Government, it never borrows. But the bond is such stiff competition for Brazilian equities that it has become very difficult for Metal Leve to sell its stock. **********''It offers safety, profitability and liquidity,'' he said. ''Normally if you want two of the three, you have to be satisfied with less of the third. The Government bonds offer all three. You can't compete against that.'' **********Ivana is 27 years old and from Salvador, on the Atlantic coast north of Rio. She has a 3-year-old boy. One week a month, she said, she leaves her child with her parents and comes to Rio with her sister. **********They stay in an inexpensive hotel and spend their afternoons on the beach. At night they go to a ''boite'' in Copacabana, a nightclub of sorts and one of many that range from elegant, with upholstered couches and a band playing American jazz, to dimly lit establishments that smell of beer.  Most of the patrons of the boites are women. **********Ivana says her ''honest life'' is in Salvador and her other life, of prostitution, is in Rio. She said she is in the process of getting divorced from a man who has fled Brazil. She said that she used to be a typist but that with a recession throughout Brazil, she could not find work. So to support her child she comes to Rio. ''Every woman here is a mother,'' she said of the women in her boite. **********Brazil has not yet had the resources to build much of a safety net for the economy's losers. There are no unemployment benefits. Employees with regular jobs and their employers, however, contribute monthly to a security fund that the worker can cash in when he leaves the job. **********In various ways, the Government attempts to help the most impoverished of the population, the more than 20 million people who live in the drought-plagued northeastern region of the country. **********''We have two or three doctors in small cities there now,'' said Clovis Cavalcanti, a social economist at the Joaquim Nabuco Foundation in Recife, the capital of the northeastern state of Pernambuco. **********''But they can only deal with simple cases - a broken leg, a treatable disease. There's little equipment, so they do most of their examinations with an instrument we call the eye- ometer.'' **********To an outsider, Brazil, like much of the developing world, seems an economy in a time warp. Some Coca-Cola comes in cans, but much comes in thick returnable bottles with pry-off caps. The Volkswagen Beetle, still made in Brazil, is the nation's second most popular car, after General Motors' Chevette. Kolynos is a leading tooth paste.  The most prominent name in home appliances is Philco. The economy is dominated by foreign labels of products made in Brazil. **********Multinational companies account for 31 percent of the sales of the country's 500 biggest companies, and most of the foreign companies are American. The Japanese are there, with motorcycles and some consumer electronics goods, all of which are made in Brazil - there are virtually no imported consumer goods. The Japanese are a relatively small presence among foreign-owned companies in Brazil, but they are the fastest growing. **********Until a couple of years ago, the foreign companies reinvested more of their profits in Brazil than they sent home, but the flow has been reversed. **********The head of the General Motors plant near Sao Paulo, Clifford J. Vaughan, attributes the decline in investment to the Government's austerity program and the recession. But G.M., he said, is there to stay. **********''We're still governed by the marketplace,'' said Mr. Vaughan. ''If the fellows at Ford bring in a big new car, I'm not going to ignore it. I've got to respond.'' **********Brazil is an economy that is turning mean. **********At the open-air cafe/restaurants of Copacabana, disheveled children steal in and stare back and forth from the customer to his food, waiting to be handed some. Middle-aged women trail customers out the door, asking for cigarettes while trying to caress the watches off their arms.  The shoeshine boys who work the Atlantic Avenue boulevard of Copacabana approach passing men saying, ''Shine mister, shine?'' When a man rejects the offer, the boys persist. Then they say, ''Look, mister, look!'' By a well-rehearsed sleight of hand, the boy has poured a discoloring slime on the toes of the quarry's shoes. **********The police of the state of Rio de Janeiro report that citizens with no official gun-toting function have nevertheless registered 1 million firearms, doubling the number of a year ago. The police assume that most have been bought by people who want to protect something, not take something. **********People still have an edge on machines in Brazil. Even a relatively well-paid automobile worker gets only $4 a hour. The minimum wage works out to less than 50 cents an hour, and that covers about a fifth of the working population. **********Probably half the office buildings in Rio, Sao Paulo, Brasilia and provincial cities like Recife and Campinas have automatic elevators. But the elevators come with a seat, because the buildings still use people to push the buttons. **********Many office buildings in the major cities have an armed guard on each floor, as well as a receptionist, someone to escort visitors and someone to serve coffee. **********The Bank of Brazil has imposed restraints on the economy to conserve dollars and to narrow the international payments deficit. Business is affected in numerous ways. The problems of Peter Landsberg are an example. **********Mr. Landsberg was chairman of Brazil's biggest privately owned company, Shell Oil of Brazil, until he retired two years ago, at 60. He then offered to buy the country's biggest shipbuilder, a Dutch-owned company, Verolme Estaleiros, of which he is now president. **********The parent company is bankrupt, he said, and a court in the Netherlands has ordered the assets sold. Mr. Landsberg has settled on a price of about $62 million, which he said is about a third of the real value. **********''The only problem I have is getting the money out to the creditors,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/12/world.main_headline: TIDE OF CHANGE LAPS AT THE THAMES'S SOUTH BANK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/12/world.print_headline: TIDE OF CHANGE LAPS AT THE THAMES'S SOUTH BANK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/12/world.body_text: **********''The English suffer from a particularly disabling disease,'' Cedric Price said the other day, letting his architect's mind frame each word into a construction that he admired as it took shape. ''Once something has lost its purpose we immediately romanticize it. That's the trouble with the Thames.'' **********Price's reputation as an iconoclast precedes his counsel but these are clearly impudent words to the English. As the Seine is to Paris, the River Thames - Holy Father Thames - is generally regarded as part of London's fabric, and to suggest that it serves no purpose falls on some ears as heresy. **********The evidence, however, is abundant, Mr. Price says.  All one needs to do, he says, is look at the condition of the southern side of the river as the Thames wiggles through London. While the northern bank cradles the great monuments and architectural delights of the capital, he points out, the southern bank and its environs are regarded as a virtual wasteland clotted with undistinguished office buildings and urban patchworks of commerce and decay. **********After a six-month study, Mr. Price will make recommendations to the Greater London Council this month on ways to rejuvenate a large section of the drab South Bank.   'Just a Patch of Water' **********''Unlike the Seine in Paris,'' Mr. Price observed in an interview, ''the Thames has never really been treated as a cultural part of the city. Actually, at the moment it's just a patch of water that's not used.'' **********A tourist's heart may leap at the first sight of the Thames as it cuts through the heart of London because of the spectacle of massed totems such as Parliament, Whitehall, St. Paul's Cathedral and the Tower of London that rise majestically near it, and the 15 small bridges inside the city that cross the waterway bearing storybook names and images: Westminister, Waterloo, Blackfriars, London Bridge and Tower Bridge. **********But nearly everything worth the price of a snapshot to take back home to Peoria or Hamburg sits on the northern bank. The South Bank is a pastiche of gray concrete buildings that in the view of many Londoners has become a towering monument to failed postwar planning. **********If one draws a circle with a one-mile radius on a map of London, using Parliament as the center, the northern semicircle will encompass some of the loveliest and most expensive real estate in the world: Mayfair, Buckingham Palace, Hyde Park, museums, stately government offices and the West End theatrical district. The southern hemisphere will yield, beyond a few structures of merit encrusting the riverbank, a dreary wasteland of aging buildings and sagging spirits.   Greenery Is Meager **********Only a few restaurants overlook the Thames from either side of the river; it is difficult to find an attractive pub along its banks. Very few Londoners or tourists try to stroll along the South Bank, and much of it is walled off to pedestrian traffic by a hodgepodge of buildings, busy roads and commercial structures. Trees occasionally pop out of the concrete. Grass or other greenery are meager dots on the map. **********For centuries the River Thames had two main functions and neither had much to do with esthetics. **********From London's earliest days it served as a sewer and as a port. Generally, the stench was blown to the south and east, away from the seats of power and royalty on the northern bank, though a change in wind direction could introduce a pungent democracy to some of the best addresses. During the 1860's the river was so pervasively foul that Parliament was closed during wind shifts in a period that came to be known as the Great Stink. Modern sewer lines and the banking of the river to cover malodorous mudflats did much to eliminate the problem but by that time the south side of London was for those who did not have the good sense or the resources to live elsewhere. **********Historically, this attitude was established by the practice of putting unsightly or objectionable services necessary to the life of a capital - warehouses, power plants, breweries, brothels, actors and playwrights - on the far side of the river. It is for this reason that London's best beer and Shakespeare's plays were both brewed near the Southwark waterfront.   Dockyards Fall Into Disuse **********German bombers and the containerization of shipping put an end to the usefullness of the London dockyards by the mid-20th century, and failing to find a new purpose, the South Bank slumped into prolonged decay.  An area on the South Bank formed by a bend of the Thames within the shadow of the Big Ben tower was cleared for the 1951 Festival of Britain, a renewal project that created the nucleus of a permanent cultural center that later added the National Theater and the Hayward Gallery. Thousands stream every evening into these buildings, which are more renowned for the excellence of the performances staged inside than for the quality of their exteriors. Yet during the rest of the day the cultural oasis is a urban desert, devoid of life and movement save for tens of thousands of commuters streaming across the bridges on foot to and from Waterloo Station. **********''It's a pity the area got frozen into such lumpy buildings,'' Sir Hugh Casson, president of the Royal Academy, who served as architectural director of the Festival of Britain, said in an interview. ''The Hayward Gallery should have a marvelous river view but it's a blind building with no windows.'' **********''Buildings always look best with their toes in the water, but the ones on the South Bank are set back so far, in fact, it's difficult to even see the river,'' he said ''They also have a leaden municipal feel about them, gray and heavy, done in a period when it was fashionable to be heavy.'' **********Lady Wynne-Jones, head of the South Bank Committee, a conservation group that seeks to protect the Thames from ill-considered projects, is sharply critical of the elephantine designs that wall off the riverfront.   Architects Called a Menace **********''What the German Luftwaffe didn't do British greed has finished,'' she said. ''In Christopher Wren's time architects were artists. Now they are businessmen and no profession is more of a menace to London.'' She and others campaigned unsuccessfully for a bill in Parliament that would have established a six-mile zone where the Thames flows through the heart of London to safeguard it against haphazard development. **********At present, 17 independent London boroughs share responsibility for what goes up along the riverfront with several public authorities. While there is no master plan for the Thames, the Government can intervene in the public interest through its Department of Environment if a controversy arises. But the laissez-faire mood of the present Convervative Government, Lady Wynne-Jones said, has left unopposed a plan by a Kuwaiti-owned corporation to build a half-mile-long wall of Dallas-style mirror glass office buildings on the riverbank opposite the Tower of London. **********There is a trend under way to build new housing in the abandoned dockyards on the east side of the city, although there is political opposition to ''elitist'' investors who want to develop an upper-middle-class market there. **********But the South Bank can claim one asset not available on the other side. The view from it is magnificent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Kero-Sun Inc., the company that pioneered the kerosene heater business in this country, said it would lay off 150 workers, or half its work force, on Friday. **********It blamed increased competition from imports, a crowded market and a warm winter for forcing the move. **********Kero-Sun's annual sales last year exceeded $150 million on about one million units, giving it the largest single share of the estimated $1 billion market for portable kerosene heaters. Kero-Sun's two most popular heaters retail for $289 and $249 while imports sell for as much as 30 percent less.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.main_headline: IT WAS A RESCUE MISSION, REAGAN SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.print_headline: IT WAS A RESCUE MISSION, REAGAN SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.body_text: **********President Reagan said today that he had conducted a rescue mission, not an invasion of Grenada, and that no comparision was possible with the warfare being waged in Afghanistan by the Soviet Union. **********The President, speaking to reporters in the White House briefing room, smiled as he dismissed the United Nations General Assembly vote Wednesday that deplored armed intervention in Grenada. ''It didn't upset my breakfast at all,'' he said. **********He beamed as he announced that ''our objectives have been achieved and as soon as the logistics permit, American personnel will be leaving.'' **********Mr. Reagan appeared in the briefing room nine days after first announcing the operation in which 18 Americans, 20 Grenadians and about 50 Cubans have been killed. In responding to questions, he dismissed the General Assembly condemnation of the Grenada invasion as no surprise, saying the majority of the nations ''have not agreed with us on just about everything that's come before them where we're involved.''  'You Shouldn't Either' **********Asked about Nicaraugua's assertion that the Administration might be planning an invasion there, the President said, ''I haven't believed anything they've been saying since they got in charge, and you shouldn't either.'' **********He was then asked whether the United States might have lost ''moral high ground'' by invading Grenada. ''Well, for heaven sakes,'' he responded, frowning and expressing exasperation with ''anyone who would link Afghanistan to this operation.'' **********He denounced the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, accusing the Russians of ''every vicious form of warfare, including chemical warfare, the killing of women and children.'' **********''Incidentally, I know your frequent use of the word invasion'' he said, referring to Grenada. ''This was a rescue mission.'' While objecting to the word invasion, Mr. Reagan himself used that term on the morning the operation was announced. **********When asked whether he would take similar military action in other countries, the President said he could not foresee the same combination arising of endangered Americans and concerned neighboring governments. ''If all the conditions were the same,'' he added, ''I don't see why our reason would be any different, but I don't foresee any similar situation.''  He Praises U.S. Troops **********The President praised the 6,000 troops involved in the operation and hailed the dead and wounded as ''heroes of freedom,'' saying they had put down a ''potential threat to all the people of the Caribbean.'' **********''After viewing the massive hoard of Soviet weapons found on that island, who knows what evil the liberation of Grenada achieved for us,'' the President said, then immediately corrected himself, ''or averted in the years ahead.'' **********The White House took care to denounce the General Assembly vote of 108 to 9 that included many of the United States' traditional allies in the majority. The chief White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, pointedly announced the breakfast - ''one poached egg, strawberries, bananas and coffee'' - that the President said was not disturbed by the vote. **********Mr. Speakes also read a statement contending that the vote was actually a comment on the state of affairs at the United Nations ''We find it sad,'' he said, ''that the U.N. sees fit to deplore actions'' taken to ''save innocent lives and protect human rights, in full accord with the principles of the U.N. Charter.''  Differences in Afghanistan **********In pointing out the differences between the operations in Grenada and Afghanistan, Mr. Reagan contended that the Russians had installed their choice as of head of state, ''murdered'' the American Ambassador and used tactics in fighting Afghan rebels that have led Russian soldiers to desert. ''They're still there after a long period of time,'' the President said, ''longer than I've been in this office.'' **********The Grenada operation, he said, was at the invitation of neighboring governments and involved the evacuation of American students. ''It was a successful rescue,'' he said, adding that ''the Grenadians that have been liberated are down there delighted with and giving every evidence of appreciation and gratitude to our men.'' **********Mr. Speakes was again asked for some of the captured documents the Administration has said support its charge that a Soviet-Cuban bastion was in the works on Grenada. He replied that the evidence would be convincing ''when and if'' the documents are released.  Asked whether they might not be released, Mr. Speakes said that the documents were under review and that at least some would be released. ''I can assure you,'' he said, that the documents ultimately released will be a ''damning'' representation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/world.main_headline: SALVADOR TOWN DANCES TO ITS OWN TUNE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/world.print_headline: SALVADOR TOWN DANCES TO ITS OWN TUNE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/world.body_text: **********The moon was high, the band loud, the beer running freely, and no one wanted to miss the dance celebrating the first graduation of students at the new high school. **********The woman who sells thick tortillas, stewed meat and rice in La Palma's main square was under pressure to close early so her assistant could get to the dance. A young woman dressed in a school uniform quickly purchased onions in the square so she could get home and persuade her mother to let her go to the dance. **********No one was sure if the leftist insurgents who move freely in the town of 16,000 would attend, but no one seemed to mind the possibility that they might. **********In most of El Salvador, people fear the constant battles between Government troops and the leftist insurgents. In La Palma, a former resort in the high piny country of northern Chalatenango province, the residents have not worried, for the military has abandoned their town. Some Support for Rebels **********An American military adviser said the guerrillas ''draw a lot of their strength'' from Chalatenango, perhaps one of the few places where the opposition has gained tacit support. **********The support is not direct, and, whenever it wanted, the army could probably retake the town, which is known for its artisan cooperatives. But, unlike other places in El Salvador, where people seem to maintain a studied apathy and just want to be left alone, the people in La Palma acknowledge some moral support for, or at least a more tolerant attitude toward, the guerrillas. **********No one indicates a willingness to take up arms against the Government. However, a 26-year-old farmer said that, ''inside their hearts,'' 75 percent of the people support the cause of the left. **********When asked why, he answered: ''When a soldier comes to town he comes up to you, and he ...'' and here the young man approached the reporter making the rat-a-tat-tat noise of a gun. When the guerrillas come to town, he said, they ask ''What do you think?'' **********''The truth is,'' said a teacher. ''the people in La Palma are different. We have learned to adjust to our situation.'' ''At times we think they are right,'' said a young woman, ''but it is only the violence that makes us think like that.'' In December and January, the guerrillas and the army took turns capturing and recapturing La Palma. But the army has not been back in four months because the province is not considered economically important. Meanwhile, the guerrillas use it as a base to stock up on supplies before returning to camps in the nearby mountains. They control about two-thirds of the province. **********At a spot along the winding road up to La Palma, which is only seven miles from the Honduran border, a banner strung across two high pines calls on the youth of Chalatenango to join the left. **********The number of young men in the town indicates that while the leftists have some moral support, they have not been very successful in gaining recruits. Most young men interviewed said they were more interested in staying out of the fighting and waiting to see who won or in pursuing their studies. **********A local teacher estimates that 500 ''important'' people, such as the woman who owned the largest pharmacy in town, moved away because of the battles in December and January. **********And when the town tried to have two dances in the same week, it found that the people could not afford both.  The first dance was planned for a Wednesday night to present candidates for the queen of the graduating class. A committee selected three candidates, but their families did not want their daughters to participate. ''They could not afford the gowns,'' the director of the school said. **********Fearing that the dance would cost more than it would earn, the director canceled it in favor of another that was planned for Saturday to celebrate the high school graduation. **********On Wednesday night a truck full of young men had rolled into town only to learn there would be no dance. But on Saturday everything went as planned, sort of. **********At 7:30 that night, the coordinator of the dance, a teacher at the school, was busy directing three boys to write out tickets for beer, sandwiches and soft drinks. Already, nearly 100 young men and women had gathered behind the barbed wire set up at one end of the school's courtyard. **********A seven-member band from San Salvador, Espiritu Libre, a group that has also played in Houston, Dallas, Honduras and Guatemala, started up at 8:30. The courtyard filled with young women wearing pumps and dresses and men with their shirts neatly tucked in, and all danced to the sounds of Stevie Wonder and some Espiritu Libre originals such as ''Don't Stop.'' **********Many of the guerrillas who make this their base were 30 miles to the south outside the town of Suchitoto, battling Government troops, and so not many were around to attend the dance. The few rebels walking around La Palma never showed up. Maybe, a teacher suggested, the dance ''was not their thing.'' **********Some young men and women stayed outside and peered through the barbed wire to watch the dancing. No one, however, wanted to admit not being able to afford the price of admission: $2.60 for men, $1.60 for women. **********''I can't dance,'' one man said.  ''I'm going to watch now and go in later,'' said another.  The dance, actually, was just getting started around 9:40 when, after the band had finished a song with the lyrics ''everybody needs a little time away,'' something happened that often does in La Palma and most of El Salvador: The power went out. There was a chorus of groans, then the couples waited for a while. But by 10:30 people began to trek down the hill back to town.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Borden Inc., producer of a wide variety of foods, dairy products and chemicals, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1983 rose 13.8 percent while sales edged up 1 percent. **********Eugene J. Sullivan, chairman and chief executive of Borden, told the company's annual meeting in Flemington, N.J., that net income in the first quarter benefited from ''healthy gains'' by the company's consumer products division and a ''recovery'' by its chemical division. **********Borden said that net income in the first three months advanced to $39.6 million, or $1.38 a share, from $34.8 million, or $1.20 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 1 percent, to $937.3 million. **********Mr. Sullivan said that first-quarter income included an after-tax gain of $17 million from cash payment by Texaco Inc. as part of a settlement of a lawsuit involving Texaco's failure to deliver under a low-cost natural gas contract. **********In the 1982 quarter, net income included an after-tax gain of $17.6 million from the sale of three Pepsi-Cola franchises and provisions for losses from the disposal of other operations. Southland **********The Southland Corporation, operator and franchiser of 7-Eleven convenience stores disclosed that earnings in the first quarter dropped 18.9 percent, to $7.7 million, or 21 cents a share, from $9.5 million, or 27 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues increased 11 percent, to $1.71 billion, from $1.54 billion. **********''Our 7-Eleven stores and most other operating groups produced stronger results than in the same quarter a year ago,'' said John P.  Thompson, chairman of Southland. ''Interest income was substantially lower due to our decision to use previously invested cash to fund capital expenditures.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.main_headline: New Study Planned On College Campuses
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; New Study Planned On College Campuses
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Simmons Market Research Bureau, which already issues syndicated reports on the media habits and product usage of the general population and also of teen-agers, is now in the field attempting to put a dimension on that elusive but high-spending crowd on college campuses. **********The company hopes to avoid the failures that have plagued research companies in the past by making its collection effort - done with mailed questionaires - a joint venture with Jon D. Miller, director of the Public Opinion Laboratory of Northern Illinois University in DeKalb, who has written the letter on university stationery that accompanies the questionnaire. **********William R. Monat, president of the university, wrote the letter to his counterparts at other universities to get names and addresses of students. Both letters make the Simmons involvement quite plain. **********Half of the material in the 41-page questionaire will be used by Professor Miller for a book he is planning. The rest helps Simmons.  The study, based on 2,000 questionaires, should be ready for distribution around the end of June.  Magazines that will use the results to sell advertising space pay $18,000 to subscribe; agencies, from $2,000 to $5,000 depending on their billing, and advertisers, $6,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.body_text: **********Hardening the sentences handed down last year by a military tribunal, the Supreme Court increased the jail term for a ringleader in the 1981 unsuccessful coup from six years to 30 years today. **********The seven-member court changed the conspiracy charge on which Gen.  Alfonso Armada Comyn was convicted to one of military rebellion. The mandatory 30-year term it carries is the highest permitted under Spanish law. **********The general once served as tutor and aide to King Juan Carlos.  At the same time the court, ruling on appeals by both the Government and the convicted, confirmed 30-year sentences for two other coup leaders, Lieut. General Jaime Milans del Bosch and Lieut.  Col. Antonio Tejero Molina. **********It also increased the sentences for 13 other army and civil guard officers, in some cases doubling them, and overturned the acquittals of eight others. These received one- and two-year prison terms instead. Troops Storm Parliament **********All were involved in the dramatic plot of Feb. 23, 1981, in which troops stormed the Parliament and held members hostage for 17 hours.  The botched takeover was the gravest threat so far to the new democracy that has been setting down roots since Francisco's Franco's death in 1975. **********The verdict today represented the first time since the 1936-39 civil war that civilian courts have ruled on military crimes, which throughout the Franco dictatorship were jealously regarded by the honor-conscious Spanish military as matters for the military alone to decide. **********Immediately after the 15-week trial before the Supreme Council of Military Justice that ended last June, the Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo then in power expressed its unhappiness at the leniency of most of the sentences and said it would appeal. **********Government officials and others were astounded that junior officers - a major, a captain and eight lieutenants - who were in most cases actively involved in kidnapping members of Parliament could be let off. **********The coup fell apart when the King made a dramatic television broadcast against it. No evidence has emerged that the King was in any way aware or supportive of the coup, and this defense - that he somehow knew of it - was rejected by both the military tribunal and the civilian court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/18/world.main_headline: U.S. AND LEBANON TO SEEK FORMULA ON SYRIA PULLOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/18/world.print_headline: U.S. AND LEBANON TO SEEK FORMULA ON SYRIA PULLOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/18/world.body_text: **********Senior Administration officials said today that they hoped to work out with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon this week a new formula toward ending the impasse with Syria over the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon. **********But Lebanese and United States officials offered differing evaluations of the likelihood of any early movement toward a solution of the problem. **********Foreign Minister Elie Salem of Lebanon, who is in Washington in advance of Mr. Gemayel's arrival on Wednesday, expressed optimism today that Syria's adamant refusal so far to negotiate a withdrawal was only a temporary, tactical move. No Fear of Partition **********Mr. Salem also said he had no fear that either Israel or Syria had plans for any permanent partition of his country.  ''I am confident that we will break the stalemate and then we will have progress and phases that will show encouragement and then we can regain a momentum that I think we have lost in the past two months,'' Mr. Salem said. **********While acknowledging Israel and Syria both had ''some gains'' from being in Lebanon, Mr. Salem said, ''I do not believe that there is any serious plan on the part of either Israel or Syria to partition Lebanon or to annex any part of Lebanon.'' He made his comments on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation.'' **********Administration officials said while they were serious about seeking a new approach, they had no reason to be optimistic about an early breakthrough in the situation. One senior official said the Syrians seemed ''dug in'' in rejecting a pullout. But he said it was necessary ''not to appear as if we've given up hope. ''We have to keep the effort alive and most importantly maintain the morale of the Lebanese Government, so they don't cave in to Syrian pressure,'' the official said. **********United States officials agreed with Mr. Salem that neither Israel nor Syria wanted to divide up Lebanon permanently, but they said they could not predict when there would be a troop withdrawal. **********The lack of American optimism is due, in part, to the frustrations that Secretary of State George P. Shultz felt in his visit to Syria this month. **********Last May Mr. Shultz worked out an agreement by which Israel would pull its troops out of Lebanon in return for certain security and political concessions from Lebanon. The Israelis are not obliged to pull all of their forces out of Lebanon, however, until Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization agree to do the same. **********Mr. Shultz was told by President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in May and again this month that Syria was so opposed to the Israeli-Lebanese agreement that it would not pull its troops out, since that would seem to be giving status to the Israeli-Lebanese accord and allow Israel to be rewarded for its invasion of Lebanon last summer. **********United States and Lebanese officials said they expected Mr.  Gemayel, in his talks with President Reagan and Mr. Shultz, to agree on an approach that makes as little mention as possible of the Israeli-Lebanese accord. The thrust of the American thinking, which seemed to be shared by Mr. Salem today, is that Lebanon should officially inform Syria that Israel is prepared to leave, and that Lebanon wants Syria to do the same. **********Lebanon should assure Syria that it is willing to negotiate an accord to take account of any Syrian security concerns and that asserts that Lebanon remains a member of the Arab League and has no intention of allowing its territory to be used by Israel or the United States, Administration officials said. **********At the same time, the United States, through ''working groups'' set up during Mr. Shultz's most recent visit to Damascus, should discuss overall problems in Syrian-American relations and give assurances to Syria that Lebanon's independence was not being impaired, the officials said. **********Mr. Salem said Lebanon and the United States ''are trying to find a new approach to discuss with President Assad the withdrawal of all the foreign forces from Lebanon without necessarily applying it to the agreement.'' **********The Lebanese Foreign Minister held a preliminary session on Saturday with Mr. Shultz at the State Department, and follow-up meetings will be held on Monday and Tuesday bofore Mr. Gemayel's arrival. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel is scheduled to arrive in Washington on July 26 for talks with President Reagan and United States officials. Golan Heights Issue **********A major problem, Administration officials said, is that the United States has little leverage on Syria. They said the Syrians would be interested, for instance, in any promises the United States could make about Syria's regaining the Golan Heights from Israel. But since the Israelis in effect annexed the Golan Heights in 1981 United States officials see no point in introducing the issue into the discussions about Lebanon. **********Mr. Salem said he believed Syria was using ''its tactical position'' in keeping its 45,000 troops in eastern Lebanon ''to negotiate, particularly with the United States right now, to regain some land it has lost to Israel.'' **********''The Syrians have major concerns that only the United States can address,'' the Lebanese Foreign Minister said. ''Their concern is whatever relates to Israel, they can only discuss with the United States. For example, the prospect of war and peace between Syria and Israel, the status of the Golan Heights and all the other problems relating to Israel or to the solution of the Middle East problem, the question of the Palestinians.'' **********The Israelis have said that in the absence of a Syrian agreement to withdraw their troops, they will redeploy and withdraw some of the 15,000 Israeli forces in Lebanon. Mr. Salem said that Lebanon would not negotiate with Israel on a partial withdrawal, but that if Israel does pull some of its troops out, the Lebanese Army would move in to fill the vacuum, and that it would receive logistical support from the United States, British, French and Italian forces in the Beirut area. **********United States officials said they expected a major part of Mr.  Gemayel's talks in Washington to concern additional steps to strengthen and enlarge the Lebanese Army. Mr. Salem said Lebanon had in the past three months increased its army from 20,000 to 32,000 and that it would soon be 60,000. **********''If necessary,'' he said, ''we will go over 100,000.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/busin.main_headline: A.T.& T. LEADS BROAD MARKET DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/busin.print_headline: A.T.& T. LEADS BROAD MARKET DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the second consecutive session in heavy trading, although a late rally enabled the market to cut its earlier sharp losses. **********The main reason for the market's weakness was American Telephone and Telegraph's announcement after 1 P.M. that its third-quarter profits had tumbled to $1.51 a share, from $2.32 the year before. **********The utility's stock fell 1 1/8 points, to 63 1/8, and was the most actively traded, with a turnover of 5.9 million shares. The stock hit a low of 59 before recovering. **********At the conclusion of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 4.06 points, to 1,246.75, after being off almost 13 points at 3 P.M. Analysts said the late upturn resulted primarily from bargain-hunting. **********On Tuesday, the widely followed indicator fell 17.89 points, mainly because Digital Equipment, a leading computer manufacturer, projected poorer earnings for its latest quarter. **********In the overall market yesterday, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored winners by more than 2-to-1. Turnover on the Big Board climbed to 107.8 million shares, from 91.1 million the day before, as institutional participation continued to increase. **********Among the other major market indicators, the exchange's index of 1,500 common stocks lost 0.65, to 96.16, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.08, to 166.73. **********Robert L. Thomas, executive vice president of Advest Inc., said investors had become extremely cautious in the past few days because of the poor earnings announced or projected by A.T.& T. and Digital. He predicted that until there was some resolution of the current interest rate jitters, the market would not attract many investors. **********Analysts said they were surprised by the size of the A.T.& T. profits drop and by the timing of a $5.2 billion write-off the company said it would take. One block of 1.48 million shares in A.T.& T. was crossed by Jefferies & Company for various customers at prices ranging from 59 to 61. **********Digital Equipment, the second- most-active issue yesterday, fell 6 7/8, to 72 3/8. On Tuesday, the stock dropped 21 points after the computer maker said its earnings in the fiscal first quarter ended Oct. 1 would drop 25 to 35 cents a share, from $1.02 a share in 1982's first quarter. **********Reflecting the Digital nnews, some of the other technology issues ended lower again. Tektronix was down 3 1/4, to 78 3/4; Texas Instruments dropped 2 5/8, to 116 3/8; Hewlett-Packard, lost 2, to 39, and Control Data dropped 1 1/2, to 46 1/2. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index lost 3.17, to 220.76. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.77, to 279.85.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; RATES MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; RATES MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates were mixed and little changed yesterday as activity in the credit markets remained subdued. **********''There is still tremendous resistance by portfolio managers to extending maturities,'' said Robert Shomaker, national sales manager for Government and mortgage-backed securities at Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. **********Other securities dealers added that only limited investor demand exists for notes and bonds due in more than five years. ''Buyers of bonds still exist, but it is done by appointment only,'' one dealer quipped. **********After trading in a narrow range for most of the day, the closely watched 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013 were offered late in the day at 102 3/4, down 2/32, to yield 11.66 percent. The 11 3/8 percent Treasury notes due in 1989, which were auctioned earlier in the week at an average price of slightly less than 99 29/32, fell about an eighth of a point and were offered at 99 30/32. **********Cash Management Bills **********A flurry of Treasury cash management bill auctions, totaling $10 billion this week, seemed to be easily absorbed. After selling $5 billion in bills on Wednesday, the Treasury yesterday sold another $5 billion of 17-day bills due Dec. 22 at an average rate of 8.88 percent. **********Among outstanding T-bills, the bid rate for the three-month issue fell to 8.85 percent from 8.90 percent, while the six-month issue moved to 9.03 percent from 9.02 percent. **********Meanwhile, the market for Government National Mortgage Association pass- through certificates, known as Ginnie Maes, was in confusion yesterday after President Reagan signed legislation on Wednesday night eliminating interest rate ceilings on home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration. **********The change creates questions about the interest rates on Ginnie Mae pass- through certificates, which are backed by pools of F.H.A.-insured mortgages. **********Mortgage bankers, who originate the home mortgages, typically contract to sell Ginnie Maes to securities firms at whatever price is required to produce an agreed-upon yield. Now that the F.H.A. will no longer specify the maximum interest rate on home mortgages, however, dealers are concerned that they could be expected to honor their contracts to buy Ginnie Maes next year at a possible loss. **********The mortgage-backed securities subcommittee of the Public Securities Association, which represents securities dealers in that market, said the abolition of F.H.A. maximum rates raises ''serious questions'' about $15 billion of existing G.N.M.A. purchase contracts. **********In the future, securities dealers said, their forward contracts with mortgage bankers would specify a coupon rate on Ginnie Mae issues as well as their yield. **********Tax-Exempt Yields Higher **********In the tax-exempt market, a sharp fall in prices in the last week prompted underwriters to increase the yields available on this week's two largest issues. The yield on the Intermountain Power Agency's $424.5 million of A1-rated term bonds due in 2022, the largest part of a $600 million financing, was raised to 11 percent from the 10.93 percent proposed earlier in the week by underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. **********Similarly, the yield on a $450 million issue of 30-year, Aaa-rated bonds of the Government Development Bank of Puerto Rico was raised to 10 percent from the initially proposed 9.85 percent by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********Also yesterday, J.J. Kenney & Company introduced a new index for long-term tax-exempt bonds. The index, to comprise 250 long-term issues rated A or better, will be compiled daily. No more than 15 percent of any single type of issue and no more than 15 percent from any single state will be listed in the index. **********The bid price for each issue will be compiled or estimated daily. The index will be revised every quarter to eliminate the 50 most seasoned issues and to include the 50 largest qualified issues sold in the most recent quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/29/world.main_headline: South Africa Denies Its Police Raided Lesotho
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; South Africa Denies Its Police Raided Lesotho
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/29/world.body_text: **********South Africa denied charges by neighboring Lesotho today that members of its police force attacked a military barracks in the mountain kingdom last weekend. **********South African Law and Order Minister Louis Le Grange said in a statement: ''The South African police has absolutely no knowledge of an attack of any nature in Lesotho. **********It is well known that Lesotho is constantly subjected to internal strife in which firearms and explosives are freely used, and it is absurd to blame the South African police for this state of affairs.'' **********Radio Lesotho, meanwhile, quoted the Police Commissioner, Maj. Gen. S.R. Matela as saying seven South African policemen who had been detained in connection with reported sabotage attempts had been released without his knowledge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/busin.main_headline: New Chief Chosen At R.J. Reynolds
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Chief Chosen At R.J. Reynolds
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/busin.body_text: **********The cloudy succession picture at R. J. Reynolds Industries cleared yesterday with the announcement that J. Tylee Wilson had been elected chief executive. **********Mr. Wilson, who is 52 years old and currently the company's president, succeeds J. Paul Sticht, who remains chairman. Mr. Wilson was one of several executives at Reynolds said to be in line for the chief executive post. **********Mr. Sticht was to have retired last April; the traditional retirement time for Reynolds chairmen has been the annual meeting following their 65th birthday. But the board decided last October to allow him to stay on indefinitely until it picked a successor. **********His service was extended, the company said, ''to assure continuity of senior executive management as the company dealt with structural and organizational issues brought about by the acquisition of Heublein'' last year. **********Yesterday, a statement by Mr. Sticht said that those issues were ''now largely behind us and the board's action today is an affirmation of the good progress that has been made.'' **********Other candidates for the post were said to be Joseph F. Abely, vice chairman, and Edward A. Horrigan Jr., an executive vice president. Hicks B. Waldron, chairman of Heublein and an executive vice president at Reynolds, was also said to be on the list but has since left to become chief executive of Avon Products. **********Mr. Abely has been appointed to head a panel studying the possible sale of Reynolds's ocean transportation operation, Sea-Land Industries Investments Inc. If a spinoff is approved, Mr. Abely would become head of a separate $1.6 billion Sea-Land company. **********John Maxwell Jr., an analyst at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, called Mr. Wilson ''a top man.'' **********John S. Pickler, an analyst at Wheat, First Securities of Richmond, saw the choice of chief executive as logical, ''Horrigan is running the largest operation in the company,'' he said, adding that Mr. Abely's responsibilities apparently took him out of the running. ''Maybe it followed that Wilson would have been the person.'' Mr. Horrigan runs the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. **********Mr. Wilson, who was not available yesterday for an interview, has been president since 1979, after joining the company in 1974 as president of RJR Foods Inc. Reynolds, with headquarters in Winston-Salem, N.C., had revenues last year of $13.1 billion with its varied operations, including tobacco, foods, liquor and wines. **********Mr. Wilson was previously group vice president at Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. and has worked for Procter & Gamble and the Scott Paper Copmpany. He is from Teaneck, N.J., and is a graduate of Lafayette College in Easton, Pa. **********Mr. Sticht began full-time association with Reynolds in 1972, when he was named chairman of the board's executive committee. He had been a director since 1968. Mr. Sticht previously was president of Federated Department Stores and vice president of Campbell Soup. He is a graduate of Grove City College in Grove City, Pa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The Martin Marietta Corporation disclosed yesterday in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it would sell in a secondary offering up to 1.9 million shares of common stock held in its Treasury and use the money raised to acquire a similar number of shares held by the Allied Corporation. The transaction would reduce Allied's stake in Martin Marietta to about 20 percent. **********Allied acquired 39 percent of Martin Marietta's stock outstanding as a result of a complicated takeover battle involving Marietta and the Bendix Corporation last year. Thomas G. Pownall, Martin Marietta's president and chairman, conceded that the takover battle had hurt the company by running up its debt, but he said the company could recover through divestitures, debt restructuring and sale of securities. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Martin Marietta closed at $55.75, up 62.5 cents. Based on that price, the 1.9 million share offering would be valued at $105.9 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Hitachi Ltd. has conceded that the operating software used in its supercomputer infringes on copyrights held by the International Business Machines Corporation. **********As a result, Hitachi has announced that it has asked Tokyo University, the only purchaser thus far of the high-speed computer, to switch its software contract to I.B.M. from Hitachi. **********A Hitachi spokesman said the supercomputer software issue ''basically isn't a major problem,'' and added that Hitachi plans to develop independently alternative software for its supercomputer by next March. Supercomputers, which cost millions of dollars, process complex data at high speeds. **********However, it was Hitachi's first admission linking its S-810-20 supercomputer to its recent out-of-court settlement with I.B.M. over I.B.M.'s charges that Hitachi sought to steal technological secrets from the United States concern. A Hitachi spokesman said Tokyo University is one of 20 customers affected, and confirmed that the operating software in question is one that I.B.M. contends infringes on its software. **********Hitachi is Japan's fourth-largest manufacturer of data-processing equipment while I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., is the world's largest computer maker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.main_headline: U.S. INTELLIGENCE IN THE DARK ABOUT ANDROPOV
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.print_headline: U.S. INTELLIGENCE IN THE DARK ABOUT ANDROPOV
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.body_text: **********Government officials said today that Western intelligence agencies were in the dark about the reasons for the absence of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. **********''There is intense interest at the highest levels here on Andropov,'' one State Department official said. ''This has led many analysts to write all sorts of stuff that obfuscates the one sentence on which they would all agree: We just don't know.'' **********An intelligence specialist on the Soviet Union said: **********''No matter what you may read, the truth is that no one really knows what has happened to Andropov. It is a weird comment on that country that such a prominent man can be out of action since late August or late September - we are not even sure of that - and no one has a sensible, coherent explanation.'' **********A Central Intelligence Agency official said that there was no ''inside dope, just a lot of speculation.'' **********There have been various reports that Mr. Andropov is suffering from respiratory, circulatory or kidney ailments, that he is disfigured, crippled or mentally disturbed, one official said, ''and none of it can be verified.'' **********A State Department policy-maker said: ''The whole experience of trying to track Andropov has been a sobering reminder that that bloody place is a total secret. It is absolutely terrifying to me that a group of people have in their hands the capacity to destroy mankind and we know virtually nothing about them.'' **********The last time Mr. Andropov was seen in public was on Aug. 18 when he was visited by nine American senators, who then said he seemed in good condition. Film clips of the meeting were shown on Soviet television. **********Mr. Andropov told the senators that he was about to go on vacation in the Crimea, the traditional summer vacation area for Soviet leaders. **********On Sept. 28, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said he had conferred with Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani, the President of Southern Yemen. The location of the visit was not given and no photographs were published. **********About a week later, intelligence officials said, it was reported from Bulgaria that Mr. Andropov would visit there on Oct. 25. But there was no customary official announcement a week or so before the visit, leading to speculation that by mid-October he was incapacitated. Soviet officials said he had a bad cold. **********Western diplomats in Moscow said that they saw his limousine and security escorts driving from his apartment house to the headquarters of the Central Committee in late November, leading to speculation that he was better. But no one actually saw Mr. Andropov himself. **********About that time, the date for a session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, was announced for Dec. 28. This led to speculation that he must be well enough to attend the event, which was to approve the 1984 budget and economic plan, and the Central Committee meeting that precedes it. **********In early December, Armand Hammer, the industrialist, who has good personal relations with the Soviet leaders, went to Moscow, thinking he would meet with Mr. Andropov. But when he arrived, he was told that he was not able to see him. Likewise, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the Prime Minister of Canada, planned to go to Moscow to see Mr. Andropov, but was told that he was not receiving foreign visitors. **********Officials said they were unsure whether Mr. Andropov had recovered from his earlier incapacity and was planning a more vigorous schedule this month when he was again stricken, or whether he has been suffering throughout with the same problem. **********''We have gone over the possibilities, and have come up with nothing solid,'' one intelligence official said. ''Some have said that he may be disfigured somehow, paralysis, or an accident.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.main_headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES TARGET OF U.S. SUIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.print_headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES TARGET OF U.S. SUIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The president of American Airlines tried to enlist his counterpart at Braniff Airways, a major competitor, in a plan of ''collusive monopolization,'' the Government charged today. **********In an unusually revealing civil suit filed in Federal District Court in Dallas, the Justice Department said Robert L. Crandall, American's president, violated the antitrust laws by proposing a scheme under which each of the airlines, then engaged in a fierce price war, would raise certain fares 20 percent. The department asked that Mr. Crandall be barred from the airline business for two years. **********American Airlines, which was also charged, said in a statement that the complaint was based on a ''novel'' theory of law and that it and its president would vigorously defend the suit. **********Telephone Call Described **********According to the Government, Mr. Crandall made an overture to Howard D. Putnam, Braniff's chairman, by telephone on Feb. 1, 1982, and was promptly rejected. **********''I have a suggestion for you,'' the complaint quotes Mr. Crandall as having told Mr. Putnam. ''Raise your goddamn fares 20 percent.  I'll raise mine the next morning.'' This came, the complaint said, after a heated exchange between the two men about the drastic farecutting and the two airlines' route overlapping. **********Mr. Putnam is said to have responded, ''We can't talk about pricing.'' Mr. Crandall, according to the Government, then said: ''Oh, (expletive), Howard. We can talk about any goddamn thing we want to talk about.'' **********The Justice Department would not disclose how it learned of the phone call. In quoting the conversation, it said Mr. Crandall ''uttered the following words or words to the following effect.'' American Airlines, in its statement, said they were recorded by Mr.  Putnam. **********American declared that the complaint was based ''on one isolated incident'' and resulted in no harm to any airline or to the public.  It said its board of directors had expressed ''full confidence'' in Mr. Crandall. **********The basis of the complaint, American said, is ''a few words spoken'' by Mr. Crandall during the telephone conversation with Mr.  Putnam that it said took place in late January or early February. It occurred a few months after Braniff had initiated ''below cost'' fares, American said, and as a result both lines were suffering ''staggering'' losses. Last spring, a few weeks after the phone conversation, Braniff quit flying and filed for court protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. **********American said Mr. Crandall had called Braniff to discuss what he thought was a misleading Braniff advertisement and that Mr. Putnam returned the call after secretly arranging to record the conversation. **********''After a discussion of the ad, Putnam complained about the competition resulting from American's initiation of service over routes which Braniff served,'' American said. ''The discussion next turned to the disastrous financial results both airlines were experiencing. At this point, according to the Government, Mr.  Crandall stated that Braniff's below-cost fares were the problem and that Braniff should raise its prices - an observation which has been made publicly by many leaders and analysts in the industry.'' **********American added, ''The Government admits that there was no further discussion of prices, that there was no agreement regarding prices and that nothing happened as a result of the conversation.'' **********The Justice Department is not accusing Mr. Crandall and American of price-fixing, which is prohibited by Section 1 of the Sherman Antitrust Act, because of what Mark Sheehan, a Justice Department spokesman, said was the ''unilateral'' nature of the attempt. Rather, the charge is that there was an effort at illegal monopolization since the airlines together could have exercised monopoly power over certain routes. **********Mr. Sheehan said the case was civil, not criminal, because ''only in the most extraordinary and unusual circumstances'' had criminal cases been brought under Section 2 of the Sherman Antitrust Act, which bars monopolization. If criminal penalties had been sought, Mr. Sheehan said, Mr. Crandall upon conviction would have faced up to three years in prison and a $100,000 fine while American would have faced a $1 million fine. **********American contended that the Government had formulated ''a novel and unsound theory of law - unprecedented in the history of antitrust laws - which reflects a lack of understanding of the vigorous competition in the airline industry.'' Both companies, American said, faced actual and potential competition throughout their systems and thus did not have the monopoly power necessary to raise fares above competitive levels. **********William F. Baxter, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said that when an agreement to fix prices would result in unlawful monopolization by two or more dominant companies, it is illegal even to make such an attempt. **********The complaint noted that capacity at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport, which served as a hub for both airlines, was limited at the time of the executives' conversation because of special regulations growing out of the air traffic controllers' strike. The limited availability of landing ''slots,'' the complaint said, acted as a significant barrier to competition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/world.main_headline: HOUSE PANEL VOICES DISCORD ON NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/world.print_headline: HOUSE PANEL VOICES DISCORD ON NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/world.body_text: **********The State Department official in charge of African policy met some strong Congressional criticism today while defending Reagan Administration policy on southern Africa. **********The official, Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, told a House panel that the presence of Cuban troops in Angola represented the main security problem in southern Africa and remained the key issue in efforts to negotiate independence for South-West Africa. **********Mr. Crocker said that prospects for a settlement in the protracted diplomatic efforts to negotiate independence for South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, were ''reasonably good.'' Criticism from Congressmen **********Mr. Crocker, who has repeatedly voiced optimism about prospects to bring independence to the territory, which is still controlled by South Africa, then came under sharp criticism from several members of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. **********''For two years we've been having hearings and frankly I'm no better informed,'' said Representative George W. Crockett Jr., Democrat of Michigan. The legislator said that the State Department official had been ''saying absolutely nothing.'' **********The chairman of the panel, Representative Howard E. Wolpe, Democrat of Michigan, suggested to Mr. Crocker that it was the Reagan Administration - not South Africa - that linked the issue of independence for South-West Africa with the withdrawal of 15,000 to 20,000 Cuban troops in Angola. **********Mr. Crocker responded that ''Cuba has been an issue since 1975,'' and it was ''obviously the most important issue'' for South Africa.  He said, however, that the United States had ''raised a new proposition'' by formally linking Cuban troop withdrawal from Angola to the Namibia independence issue. Five Nations Seek Settlement **********Five western nations, working with the United Nations, are seeking to work out a settlement with South Africa that would create an independent, black majority government in Namibia, an area about the size of Texas with a population of about one million. **********South Africa, which has administered the former German colony since the end of World War I, has indicated that it was prepared to pull out its 20,000 troops provided a United Nations force could guarantee free elections to draw up a constitution. The South African forces have been fighting guerrillas belonging to the South-West Africa People's Organization. **********South Africa has also insisted that the Cuban troops in neighboring Angola depart once the South African troops leave South-West Africa. ''The South Africans regard the Cuban troop issue as fundamental to their security concerns,'' said Mr. Crocker. **********''Security, of which the Cuban troop issue is an integral part, has always been a prerequisite for agreement on Namibian independence,'' said Mr. Crocker. ''As a practical diplomatic matter, it will not be possible to obtain a Namibian independence agreement without satisfactory regional security assurances.'' Refuse to 'Choose Sides' **********Mr. Crocker defined the Reagan Administration policy in southern Africa as one of ''constructive engagement with all the states of the region who wish the same with us.'' **********Responding to congressional and other critics who assert that the Reagan Administration has failed to exert influence on South Africa and its apartheid policies of strict racial segregation, Mr. Crocker said: **********''We do not approach the region with the belief that our task is to choose sides; on the contrary, our desire for strengthened relations with all the states of the region that enables us to play a role in working for regional security, development and peaceful change.'' **********''In southern Africa, as in the Middle East, it is not by choosing sides that we shape events or resolve conflicts,'' the State Department official said. **********''Public posturing and the passing of judgment, however gratifying to those who do it, is not usually the most helpful way to deal with the root causes of disputes,'' Mr. Crocker said. ''We seek results.  Our effectiveness depends on our ability to be a credible partner of all who wish our partnership.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Pennsylvania Notes Are Offered At 6.75%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania sold $600 million of tax anticipation notes due June 15, 1984, which were offered at a yield of 6.75 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Pittsburg National Bank. By late in the day, underwriters said, the issue was more than 95 percent sold. **********Moody's Investors Service rated the notes MIG-2, the second highest rating for short-term notes. The financing was the first part of $975 million of short-term cash flow borrowings the state estimated it needs during 1983-84. **********Although the notes are not backed by the state's full faith and credit, they are backed by pledges of tax revenues that are set-aside in a special account in the state treasury. According to Moody's Bond Survey, payment of the notes has priority over all other expenditures of the state's general fund. **********As a leading steel producing state, Pennsylvania's economy was hurt by the economic recession. For the year ended June 30, its general fund had a deficit of $234.7 million. In the current fiscal year, projections are for the deficit to be eliminated through increased personal income taxes and accelerated tax collections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/busin.body_text: **********Finance ministers of developing countries called today for a major infusion of money and credits to bolster their economies and help them repay mounting debts. **********During a conference of the International Monetary Fund, the ministers urged a doubling of lending resources in the 146-nation agency and said they would seek another allocation of special drawing rights, used by countries to pay bills. They met as the Group of 24, a body that represents most of the developing world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/busin.main_headline: OIL LEASE BIDS IN GULF SET RECORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/busin.print_headline: OIL LEASE BIDS IN GULF SET RECORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Seventy-eight oil companies bid a record $3.47 billion today for the right to explore for oil and natural gas on tracts leased from the Federal Government in the Gulf of Mexico. **********One thousand oilmen, gathered in the Superdome, whistled in awe at some of the bids at the lease auction, which covered 39.8 million acres in the Gulf, more than total the acreage offered in all previous Gulf lease auctions combined. **********Interior Secretary James G. Watt, attending his first offshore lease sale, donned a scarlet jacket - an auctioneer's traditional garb - and announced the high bids at the end of the bidding. **********''Today, we've allowed industry to explore and evaluate and inventory 40 million acres of offshore territory,'' Mr. Watt said at a news conference. **********Industry Vs. Bureaucracy **********''We felt the expertise of industry was better than the expertise of the bureaucracy in Washington,'' he said. ''We have demonstrated that the marketplace is the right place for decisions to be made regarding allocation of natural resources.'' **********The record response was in large part a result of a change in procedure for offshore oil exploration leases. In the past, bidding was limited to a specific number of tracts, typically 75 to 175, selected by Interior Department officials from nominations by the oil companies. Under new rules, first used to lease tracts off the Middle Atlantic coast last month, companies may bid on any unleased tracts in designated areas, without limits. **********The oil industry had become reluctant to bid at recent semiannual sales because of the worldwide oversupply of oil and stiff competition for the relatively few tracts offered. Promising Tracts Sought **********But today's auction attracted considerable interest, despite the oversupply, because many oil companies believed that the most promising tracts still left in the area would be auctioned today. Any future auction, some said, will involve only tracts not as likely to yield oil and gas. **********The former auction record for offshore Gulf leases was $2.7 billion, set in 1980 on 147 tracts. Today's sale offered 656 tracts.  Today's auction was part of the Government's accelerated leasing program, intended to make more American drilling acreage available to reduce reliance on foreign oil. **********The top bid today was $92.3 million offered for a tract in the Ship Shoal area about 75 miles south of Louisiana's Terrebonne Parish. It came from a consortium of Mobil Oil, Exploration and Producing, Southeast Inc., the Kerr-McGee Corporation and the Sohio Petroleum Company. **********The second highest bid was $75.1 million from a group led by the Kerr-McGee Corporation.  A total of 78 companies, bidding separately and in combinations, offered 1,015 bids on 656 tracts, second only to the 1,045 bids received on 651 Gulf tracts in 1970. Those 651 tracts, however, covered far less acreage. **********The 39.8 million acres offered today are from 2 to 200 miles off Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. Deep-water leases, for tracts in 2,800 feet of water or more, are for 10 years. Shallow-water leases are for five years. **********In addition to the lease payments, the Government receives royalties on any oil and natural gas that is produced from the tracts. **********The Interior Department has the right to reject any bids that it feels are not up to the potential of the tracts.  Lease winners are expected to complete seismic work on their most promising areas in one year, but drilling is not expected to produce oil or gas for four or five years. **********James R. Lesch, chairman and chief executive officer of the Hughes Tool Company, said the sale came at a time when the number of oil rigs actively drilling has dropped to about 1,800 from the 1981 high of 4,500. He noted that 150,000 people in the oil industry are out of work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/03/world.main_headline: U.S. AND LEBANON MOVE TO BOLSTER RELATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/03/world.print_headline: U.S. AND LEBANON MOVE TO BOLSTER RELATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/03/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and Lebanon had agreed to set up joint economic and military committees to provide ''more structure and coherence'' to their efforts to unify Lebanon and bring about the withdrawal of all foreign forces. **********Speaking to reporters at the end of two days of talks with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon, Mr. Shultz said both nations felt ''a genuine sense of urgency'' about the deteriorating situation in Lebanon. He said the new committees emphasized ''the strong working partnership that has been forged here.'' **********Mr. Shultz held out no new prospect, however, for an early agreement by Syria on the withdrawal of foreign forces. But, he said, ''speaking at least on my own part, I have a renewed sense of confidence that we are going to succeed in Lebanon.'' **********It was unclear what led him to speak optimistically. But other officials suggested it was important for the United States to enhance the morale of the Lebanese Government, which faces strong internal opposition as well as continuing pressure from Syria.  'Some Very Important Things' **********Mr. Gemayel, who spoke briefly, said he hoped ''we'll be able to accomplish some very important things within a few weeks,'' but he was not specific as to what. **********In announcing the formation of the new economic and military committees, Mr. Shultz did not say what they would accomplish. But a White House official said the economic committee would serve as the basis for discussing what foreign aid and investment were needed in Lebanon and would discuss where to seek the funds. The military committee would deal primarily with Lebanon's growing military aid requests and would discuss what kind of equipment could best be used by the Lebanese Army. **********By setting up formal committees, the Administration was signaling its continuing commitment to the survival of the Lebanese Government. **********The United States set up a political-military committee with Israel during the visit here of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, but the two sets of committees are quite different. The Israeli-American group is primarily a coordinating body to plan military strategy and exercises, while the Lebanese-American groups are meant to carry out Lebanon's aid requests.  Lifting of Siege **********What seemed to emerge from the statements on Thursday and today was that at American urging, the emphasis was now being placed on trying to accomplish concrete but limited goals in Lebanon aimed at broadening the political base of the Lebanese Government and widening its army's control over the countryside. One of the first planned measures was the lifting of the Druse siege of a Christian village in the Shuf Mountains. **********Foreign Minister Elie Salem indicated that the Lebanese Government was still looking for ways to replace the May 17 agreement worked out by Mr. Shultz between Israel and Lebanon on the terms for Israeli withdrawal. The Syrians have said they will not agree to pull out their forces from Lebanon until that accord is abrogated. **********But the United States and Israel have told the Lebanese that they stand by the accord and will not agree to cancel it because of Syrian pressure. **********The Americans told the Lebanese that as a result of their talks with Mr. Shamir and other Israeli officials they were convinced Israel would be willing to cooperate with Mr. Gemayel if the Lebanese followed a more active policy. **********Specifically, the Lebanese were urged to discuss with the Israelis the possibility of sending Lebanese Army units into areas in southern Lebanon controlled by Israel. If the Israelis became convinced that the Lebanese could effectively protect the northern borders of Israel, they might work out with Lebanon some partial withdrawals, even in advance of some Syrian decision to do so.  Talks With Israel Rejected **********But Mr. Salem seemed to reject the idea of talking to the Israelis about extending Lebanese control to southern Lebanon. **********''Such innocent questions are asked from time to time,'' he said. But he said Lebanon could not risk antagonizing other Arab nations by talking to the Israelis. The Lebanese, however, have held talks with the Israelis in the past on the terms for the withdrawal agreement and on other subjects. **********The United States officials told Mr. Gemayel, a White House aide said, that it was important for him to act ''presidential,'' to be assertive and to take into account the needs of his country's Shiites, who make up the most disadvantaged group in Lebanon and who as a result are the most hostile to the Lebanese Government.
