https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/07/busin.body_text: **********The leader of the American delegation to a major trade conference said today that industrial nations were unlikely to approve the requests put forth by the developing nations. **********The requests, presented at the opening session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, include steps to stabilize commodity prices and to increase aid for developing nations. **********The aim is to inject an $70 billion into the third world during 1984 and 1985 to finance an increase in economic growth to 5 percent a year. This would reverse their downward trend of growth, which fell from an average of 2.5 percent in 1980, to six-tenths of 1 percent in 1981, to a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent last year. **********4,000 Delegates from 160 Nations **********The United Nations group meets once every four years to review international aid efforts. Nearly 4,000 delegates from more than 160 nations are attending the session, which runs to June 30. **********In an interview today, Gordon Streeb, Deputy Secretary of State for International Economic and Social Affairs and leader of the American delegation, said: ''It is unrealistic to believe that anything significant will result from this meeting in the way of a sizable resource transfer to the developing countries or agreement on the immediate action program they have presented.'' **********European officials appeared to be broadly in agreement. Delegates from the 10 European Common Market countries today approved a speech that Finance Minister Otto Lambsdorf of West Germany will make tomorrow, effectively rejecting most of this program. Third World Proposals **********Developing nations have drafted a five-point program to seek recovery: **********- A series of commodity agreements to lift world prices of 10 raw materials above the levels prevailing in 1981-82. Exporting countries would agree to withhold supplies from the market to force up prices. **********- The creation of at least another $30 billion worth of special drawing rights within the International Monetary Fund, to be given to developing countries to finance industrial imports. **********- New powers for the United Nations trade conference to monitor ''disguised restrictions'' on imports from third world countries. **********- An agreement to provide automatic debt relief to developing countries on pre-arranged terms. **********- Increased aid from the World Bank and some easing in the terms on which the International Monetary Fund gives credits.  Mr. Streeb commented: ''We don't shy away from a debate about world economic problems with the developing world here, which can be useful. But Unctad's pitfall in the past has been to exceed its competence and try to forge artificial agreements.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/30/busin.body_text: **********National Gypsum President Retiring The National Gypsum Company, a major producer of building products, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Edward J. Killian, planned to retire early next year for health reasons. Mr. Killian, 63 years old, has been with the company since 1948 and was named president in June 1982. **********The company, based in Dallas, said it would not name a successor until just before Mr. Killian retires. **********It did, however, name James R. Voisinet, 51, to the newly created post of executive vice president for operations, a position that apparently puts him in line to succeed Mr. Killian. **********National Gypsum, with revenues approaching $1 billion annually, makes gypsum building products, cement, glass and metal products. It is a defendant in lawsuits alleging damage to health from exposure to its asbestos products, but a spokesman said it had divested itself of most asbestos operations and had not been ''one of the major players.'' **********Mr. Killian has worked throughout the National Gypsum organization, mostly in manufacturing posts. He has been president of its Gold Bond building products division and he became president of the corporation when John P. Hayes, 62, moved up from president to chairman and chief executive last year. **********Mr. Voisinet joined the company as a sales engineer in 1962 at Buffalo, where the company had its headquarters until 1976. He has been in charge of four National Gypsum divisions. He was a vice president for corporate development, handling acquisitions and mergers, before he was named group vice president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/busin.main_headline: CLASS ACTIONS PAY FOR SOME LAWYERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/busin.print_headline: CLASS ACTIONS PAY FOR SOME LAWYERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/busin.body_text: **********For Melvyn I. Weiss, every corporate mishap is a new opportunity. **********Take the mess over the Washington Public Power Supply System. For bondholders, last July's $2.25 billion default has been an unmitigated horror, in which the paper they were holding dropped to a fraction of its former value. **********But for Mr. Weiss and others in the small circle of lawyers who specialize in securities class actions and shareholder derivative suits, the Washington Power debacle was a fertile area for litigation even before the default. **********''We recognized the enormity of the problem a long time ago,'' said Mr. Weiss, whose law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Specthrie & Lerach, has joined with others to bring a bondholders' class action against the supply system. **********''Cases like this are a long-term effort and require significant resources to put together,'' he said. ''Since your fees are strictly contingent on recovering something, it took a major investment by several firms to put together a case.'' **********The action filed by the Weiss group parallels a suit later brought by Chemical Bank in its capacity as trustee for the system's bondholders, seeking to recover money for those who held bonds at the time of the default.  Mr. Weiss' class action, however, covers those who sold their bonds before the default as well as those who held on to them. **********''We are suing on behalf of all the people who bought bonds all the way back into the 70's, when there was not full disclosure of the system's problems,'' said Mr. Weiss. ''Many of the current bondholders are speculators who bought at a discount after the problems developed. I don't think they have the same kind of claim to damages as people who invested before they knew of any problems.'' **********Lawyers for some of the power system defendants objected to the class action because it would duplicate Chemical's efforts, but last week a Federal judge in Seattle rejected those arguments. **********''I want the case for bondholders prosecuted by the best lawyers on the street,'' said United States District Judge Richard Bilby. He pointed out that while Chemical ''will get paid, win, loss or draw,'' if Mr. Weiss and his colleagues lose their case, they will get ''a big zero. It will not have cost the public anything.'' **********A Private Watchdog **********Mr. Weiss, who may be the nation's leading lawyer in the field of shareholder class actions, sees his work as a much-needed complement to the Securities and Exchange Commission's Enforcement Division. He considers himself an enforcer, one whose successes help deter corporate misbehavior - and compensate those who suffer from such misbehavior. **********''I've always been a believer that it's only private enforcement that brings about real change,'' said Mr. Weiss, a deliberate, solidly built 48- year old. ''Accountants have been given the vital role in protecting the user of public companies' financial statements, and I'm sorry to say that they haven't been terribly good at carrying out that role. It is the advent of class actions, and not what the accountants do in their auditing, that has caused the enormous changes that have taken place.'' **********Corporate Ambulance-Chasing? **********Although Mr. Weiss sees his calling as a noble one, there are those who think stockholder class actions are just a form of ambulance-chasing. **********''Mel Weiss is exceptionally good, but there are some problems with the whole shareholder class action and derivative action field, '' said Dennis Block, a New York lawyer who often defends large corporations against shareholder suits. **********''There's a lot of frivolous litigation, and the cost of defending can be so enormous that even if there is no merit to the charges, the defendants almost have to settle. The system breeds a lot of nuisance settlements.'' **********Indeed, there is a kind of bounty- hunting aspect to the whole plaintiff's class action bar. Cases are handled on a contingency basis, and plaintiffs' lawyers are usually awarded 20 percent to 25 percent of the judgment or settlement, based on the judge's perception of the amount and quality of the work they put in and the risk they took in accepting the case. **********''Plaintiffs' class action lawyers are investing in a piece of litigation,'' Mr. Weiss said. ''It usually takes three and a half to four years to get back any compensation for the time and money you've put in. And then, of course, you are always running the risk that you will lose and get no return at all.'' **********If Milberg Weiss has been bullish on litigation in recent years, the investment strategy has paid off. **********Firm Has 29 Lawyers **********Together with allied firms, Milberg Weiss's 29 lawyers - 19 in the New York office at Penn Plaza and 10 more in California - have won a $40 million settlement in a case involving the Itel Corporation; $40 million in a case involving elderly people who lost their life savings in the bankruptcy of a United Methodist Church-sponsored retirement home that had sold them prepaid life-care contracts; $50 million in a case involving U.S. Financial Inc.; $15 million in a case against Arthur Andersen & Co., the accounting firm, and the directors of Viatron Computer Systems Inc., and more than $2 million in a case involving the Franklin National Bank. **********The firm has had its failures, though. Last year, it went to court with a class action on behalf of Jeep owners - not those who had been injured by an alleged defect that might cause the vehicle to roll over, but those whose only harm was a possible economic loss due to the possible defect's effect on the Jeeps' value. The case was thrown out. **********The firm's current docket of cases is ambitious. In addition to the Washington Power case, it is now either lead counsel or co-lead counsel in class actions involving AM International, Wickes Companies, Nucorp Energy, Lionel, Pepsico, Warner Communications, Seafirst National Bank and Merrill Lynch & Company. **********Uncertain Cash Flow **********All but about 20 percent of Milberg Weiss's work is on a contingency basis, which leaves the firm in an uncertain cash-flow position. Because of the financial uncertainties, firms that specialize in contingency-fee work have traditionally remained small. **********''It would be very dangerous to get too big from a financial point of view, since we depend on a relatively small number of cases per lawyers,'' Mr. Weiss said. ''If there's any delay, we can end up with no cash flow, which has happened within the last six months, and is very frightening, since it means that we have to draw on our own resources. In the Itel case, someone filed what we say was a frivolous appeal, which got settled. If it had gone on, it might have tied us up for years. But I don't want to give anybody any ideas.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.body_text: **********The Scott Paper Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its foam division to General Felt Industries. In addition, it will put up for sale its Brown Jordan division and 240,000 acres of timberland in Washington. **********The sales are expected to net the company ''hundreds of millions of dollars,'' if all are completed, Philip E. Lippincott, Scott's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. Terms of the agreement on the foam division were not disclosed. **********The company said the divestitures were part of its plan to streamline and increase the profitability of core paper product divisions. In the first six months of this year, Scott earned $52.2 million, or $1.13 a share, up 9 percent from a year earlier. **********Some analysts said the move could also represent an attempt by the company to resist further attempts by Brascan Ltd., the Canadian company that holds 23.7 percent of Scott, to increase its stake. **********Under a standstill agreement between Brascan and Scott, Brascan cannot increase its stake in Scott to more than 25 percent before the end of 1985. But Brascan has indicated an interest in renegotiating that accord so that it could increase its holdings to 50 percent. **********An analyst who follows Scott said, ''This may in part be a defensive measure to make Brascan reach higher for an increased stake in the company.'' Scott's shares closed yesterday at $26.625, up 50 cents. **********The foam division, which makes polyurethane foam for such uses as carpet cushioning and mattress cores, posted a 25 percent earnings increase for last year on record sales. Sales in the Brown Jordan division, which makes high-quality leisure furniture and lighting fixtures, dropped 16 percent in 1982, but are running at record levels this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/busin.body_text: **********A late rally, led by some of the blue-chip and technology issues, gave the Dow Jones industrial average a solid gain yesterday. The overall stock market, however, advanced only slightly in continued sluggish trading. **********The Dow average, which was up less than 1 point at 2:30 P.M., closed with a rise of 10.07 points, at 1,1124.52. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outnumbered declining stocks by 840 to 730. **********Analysts attributed the late surge mostly to bargain-hunting. They said there was no economic news to account for the advance. Last week, as the Dow dropped 23 points, many of the technology issues had sharp losses. **********The two other major market averages also finished in the plus column yesterday. The Big Board's composite index of 1,500 common stocks rose 0.23, to 87.22, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 0.53, to 151.36. **********Turnover on the Big Board amounted to 62.4 million shares yesterday, up a bit from Monday's 61.9 million shares.  The market shrugged off the Federal Reserve's morning report that industrial production in February rose three-tenths of 1 percent, its third consecutive monthly gain. 'Low Conviction Levels' **********''The dull trading pattern and erratic action of recent sessions is symptomatic of the low conviction levels among market participants,'' said Michael Metz, vice president at Oppenheimer & Company. **********Mr. Metz said that questions about whether the pace of the economic recovery will quicken and whether oil prices will remain stabilized ''remain unanswered.'' He predicted that if both occur, ''the market could stage another sharp advance.'' **********On Monday the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to reduce oil prices and to set lower production levels to avoid a price war. But many industry analysts are wary about whether the OPEC's plan will work. **********Among yesterday's stronger blue-chip issues, Allied Corporation rose 2 1/2 points, to 42 7/8; Eastman Kodak 1, to 85 1/4; Aluminum Company of America 1 1/8, to 34, and Procter & Gamble 7/8, to 56 3/4. **********The technology issues scored even larger gains. NCR rose 3 1/4, to 106 3/4, after the company introduced a new computer system that occupies only two cubic feet of space. Digital Equipment, one of the strong issues in this sector, climbed 2 3/8, to 129; Teledyne 2 1/4, to 157; Motorola 1 5/8, to 105 1/8, and Honeywell 1 3/4, to 95 1/2. News Buoys Auto Stocks **********Shares of auto makers ended higher, helped by the news that new car sales rose 2.6 percent in the first 10 days of March from a year earlier. General Motors advanced 1, to 60 1/8; Ford 1/2, to 39 1/2, and Chrysler 1/2, to 16 1/2. **********Towle Manufacturing fell 1 7/8, to 26 3/8, after the maker of silverware and cutlery disclosed that its earnings last year dropped to $1.16 a share from $2.55 a share in 1981. The company said it expects record results this year. **********One of the bigger losers yesterday was Baldwin-United, which was on the most-active list and dropped 4, to 23 1/2. After the market closed, the company said it was still trying to negotiate an extension of a credit agreement. **********Federal Express, which reported flat earnings Monday and dropped 3 1/4 points, rose 3 1/4 points yesterday, to 77 1/2.  Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended lower, with the market-value index down 0.27, to 383.15. Adobe Oil and Gas advanced 1 3/8, to 17 3/4, on news that the company's operating net rose to 44 cents a share in the fourth quarter from 39 cents a share a year before. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.09, to 264.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.main_headline: BLOCK SEES NO '84 PLAN TO CUT FEED GRAIN CROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.print_headline: BLOCK SEES NO '84 PLAN TO CUT FEED GRAIN CROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, citing extensive drought damage to this year's corn and sorghum crops, expressed further doubts today that there would be another payment-in- kind program next year for corn and other feed grains. **********Appearing briefly on a United States Chamber of Commerce television program, Mr. Block indicated that the 1983 crops of corn and other feed grains would not be large enough to provide excess grain for farmers who reduce their planted acreage next year. **********The drought, however, has had little effect on this year's wheat crop and Mr. Block has already announced a 1984 acreage reduction program for wheat that will include a payment-in- kind option. But department policy makers do not expect payment-in- kind programs on next year's cotton or rice crops, William Lesher, the department's chief economist, said. **********Large Carry-Over Cited **********The Agriculture Secretary noted that, despite a 1983 corn crop that is expected to be at least 38 percent smaller than the 1982 record production of 8.8 billion bushels, there was a large carry-over from last year and there would be no shortage of grain after the harvest ends in October. **********''But the drought is making it more unlikely,'' he said, ''that we will have enough to offer feed grain growers a payment-in-kind program on the 1984 crop.'' Mr. Block expressed similar doubts last week after a tour of the major corn-producing areas of the Middle West. **********A final decision on the question will be made after the August corn and sorghum estimate is disclosed on Sept. 12, an Agriculture Department spokesman said. **********Plan's Two Objectives **********The payment-in-kind plan, offered for the first time this spring to farmers who grow wheat, corn and sorghum, cotton or rice, had two objectives: a transfer from Government ownership to individual farmers of the record surpluses of these crops the Agriculture Department was storing under earlier price-support loan and subsidy programs, and a major reduction of acreage planted in these crops. **********The plan was accepted by most of the farmers growing these basic crops. They agreed to leave idle this spring nearly 83 million acres, a total area half the size of Texas. The largest portion of this total, 21.3 million acres, came from corn farmers, who planted a total of only 52.5 million acres, the smallest area seeded in corn since 1965. **********Even so, in early July the department was expecting a 1983 corn crop of at least 6.3 billion bushels. Since then the rains have stopped and record high temperatures have seared the developing corn plants. **********Sharp Cut in Surplus **********In its Aug. 11 crop estimate, the department reduced its corn production forecast to 5.24 billion bushels. With exports and use of corn by United States livestock raisers expected to exceed 7 billion bushels in the coming 12 months, a 1983 crop of 5.24 billion bushels would mean a sharp reduction in the surplus now on hand. **********The 1984 wheat acreage reduction program that Mr. Block announced earlier this month would require farmers who wanted to be eligible for price-support aid to leave idle 30 percent more wheat land than they planted this year. **********If they agree to leave idle another 10 to 20 percent of their normal wheat acreage, they will be given in-kind payments of wheat from Government-controlled stocks, receiving 75 percent of the past average yields on those acres.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/17/busin.body_text: **********Erickson in the same city. **********The international group of franchised real estate brokers, with 6,500 offices and 75,000 employees in the United States alone, is spending $22 million on national advertising this year in this country and expects to go to $25 million next year. That's a lot. **********According to Robert L. James, vice chairman in charge of domestic operations of McCann, the assignment will bring to $85 million the amount of new billings the Interpublic Group of Companies subsidiary has added this year to last year's $550 million. **********Some 10 months ago, Century 21, an independent company until it was acquired by the Trans World Corporation in 1979, had an ad agency review in which six major agencies participated, including the incumbent. **********Although it decided at the time to stay with W.R.G., Bruce Oseland, vice president, marketing and advertising, said yesterday from his Irvine, Calif., office that at the time management was very impressed by McCann, which he described as ''the shining star in that group.'' **********And, he noted, since Century 21 has 27 regional offices that are frequently in need of advertising services, the larger McCann with its field service abilities, honed on Coca-Cola bottlers, was considered ''superior.'' **********You can bet that Mr. James in his year-and-a-half pursuit of this advertiser played up that strong point since he has not forgotten that, while he was head of Interpublic's Marschalk, it was just such a strong suit that helped him win the Bonanza fast-food account that was at W.R.G. **********If you recall, 1979 was that crazy time when airlines and their agencies were playing musical chairs. It was in March of that year that Mary Wells Lawrence, chairman of Wells, Rich, resigned the account of Trans World Airlines, a subsidiary of the Trans World Corporation, which was to acquire Century 21 later that year. **********About the same time, T.W.A. was resigned, Wells, Rich was in competition with Ogilvy & Mather for the Century 21 business, which since its beginning in 1972 had been served by Ramon H. Townsend's Townsend & Associates in Newport Beach, Calif. **********As a condition to getting the account, the winning agency had to acquire the smaller Townsend shop, which was in danger of losing the client because the assignment was getting too big to handle, an attitude that some Trans World officials obviously also had more recently about W.R.G.'s abilities. **********Kenneth Olshan, chairman of the W.R.G. domestic company, said that, although losing business was never pleasant, his real concern was for Mr. Townsend, currently chairman of the W.R.G. Los Angeles office, who goes back to the very beginnings of Century 21, having helped Art Bartlett, the founder, sell franchises. **********Last year, W.R.G., in an attempt to strengthen its grasp on the business, dismantled its small Newport Beach office where Century 21 was served and moved everything into the larger Los Angeles office.  To no avail.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Euphoria swept over the economy last week. Investors, bond traders and Government officials decided - at least for the time being - that plummetting oil prices meant better times ahead. And they became even more enthusiastic over news that the nation's leading indicators had climbed 3.6 percent in January, the largest monthly gain since July 1950. An 8.9 percent rise in construction spending during the month - the biggest since March 1946 - and a 9.9 percent increase in single-family home sales seemed proof positive that the recession was over. **********The stock market marched higher. The Dow Jones Industrial average set records almost every day on the strength of high-tech, bluechip, retail-store and rebounding oil stocks. It finally closed Friday at 1,140.96, up 20.02 points on the week. Even gold stocks recovered from the losses they suffered after bullion fell $100 an ounce on fears that slumping oil revenues would force Arab nations to sell their gold. Though the soaring economic barometers were warmly welcomed, falling oil prices still carried the day. Said one Wall Street analyst of oil's decline: ''It's the most important economic event of the year.'' **********The bond market agreed. Prices remained firm on the belief that lower oil prices equaled lower interest rates which equaled lower inflation - possibly as low as 2 percent this year. Fed Chairman Paul Volcker gave the market an extra push when he said that further rate declines were in the offing. Sam Nakagama, in his economic letter, declared that a powerful bond market rally - one that could push Treasury bond yields down to 8 percent from their current levels of 10.5 percent by year's end - was ''now getting under way.'' **********Even Martin Feldstein was optimist, proclaiming that the Reagan recovery had arrived. The President's chief economic adviser and resident bear saw signs that economic growth this year would exceed the 3.1 percent rate he forecast only a month ago. But he couldn't help noting that those big Federal deficits seemed destined to rise further as lower oil prices reduced the Government's take from the windfall profits tax. **********The Commerce Department was less reserved. It said that the economy would grow at a real annual rate of at least 4 percent in the current quarter - up from the earlier White House estimate of 1 percent - and 5 percent from the final three months of 1982 to the fourth quarter of this year. **********There was barely a whimper from OPEC in all this. The cartel still hasn't officially announced a price cut, and it feverishly tried to bring together its troops in meetings in Paris and London in hopes of staving off a price war - one that some analysts said could bring oil prices down to $20 a barrel. Much to its own chagrin, OPEC even sought Britain's help in holding the line on prices. With weaker oil prices pushing the pound down five cents, to a record low of $1.50, Britain was not turning a deaf ear to its Middle East counterparts. **********Brazil took comfort in the I.M.F. The lending agency finally approved a $5.5 billion loan to help rescue the world's largest and most troubled borrower. The U.S. chipped in another $400 million for good measure. Brazil is looking to falling interest rates and declining oil prices for additional relief. And it will no doubt get both. A. Gary Shilling & Company, the economic consultants, said that plunging oil prices would save Brazil $2.6 billion. And the Argus Research Corporation estimated that Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and South Korea - the Big Four - would save $8 billion in interest costs as rates on their floating rate loans fall to 11 percent this year from 17 percent in 1982. **********American steelmakers will find their savings in a contract settlement with the United Steelworkers. The workers accepted a 9 percent wage reduction - they rejected an 18 percent cut last November - in return for a pledge from the companies to invest money from these concessions in steel operations rather than in oil and savings banks and the other businesses that Big Steel seems to find more attractive. The accord will certainly help the industry, but not enough to bring costs below those in Japan. **********Norfolk Southern's attention was also on investments - and Santa Fe Industries. It bought 5.01 percent of the railroad's stock for ''investment purposes.'' But some believe that, given the I.C.C.'s penchant for big rail mergers, the $100 million transaction could lead to the nation's first singly owned transcontinental system.  Norfolk Southern knows about big deals. It was created through a combination of the Norfolk and Western and the Southern Railway and holds a chunk of Piedmont Aviation. **********Security Pacific spent $400 million to gain a stronger foothold in the commercial credit business. It agreed to acquire two finance subsidiaries from Walter E. Heller. With one of those units facing a $1.3 billion antitrust suit, Heller decided - and the stock market concurred - that it might be best to quit now. **********Federal Banking regulators also know when enough is enough. The Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee postponed new banking deregulation until June 28 so that financial institutions could catch up with rapid-fire moves to ease curbs on savings and checking accounts - and to prepare for those that lie ahead. **********A.T.&.T. isn't wasting any time returning to the well. After completing a $1 billion stock offering - the largest in U.S. history - only three months ago, Bell Telephone is coming to market for another billion dollars. It plans to use part of the proceeds to spruce up the balance sheets of its 22 local operating units, which have been under a cloud ever since Ma Bell's antitrust settlement with the Government. The Supreme Court removed some of that uncertainty when, in only four words, it approved a settlement that was eight years in the making. **********Braniff and PSA also got a quick ruling, but their's was unfavorable. A Federal court rejected an agreement that would have allowed PSA to set up a low-cost division using Braniff employees and equipment. The court said the plan required bankrupt Braniff to go through normal reorganization proceedings. Liquidation now seems more likely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/world.main_headline: NICARAGUA OFFERS TO JOIN IN TALKS ON REGIONAL PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/world.print_headline: NICARAGUA OFFERS TO JOIN IN TALKS ON REGIONAL PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Government, marking the fourth anniversary of its revolution, announced today that it was willing to participate in international talks to achieve peace in Central America. **********It also called for negotiations on other points previously raised by the United States, including arms supplies and military support for the leftist rebels battling the Government of El Salvador. **********The announcements were made by Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the coordinator of the governing junta, in the main anniversary address.  He said the Nicaraguan decision to enter into international talks was aimed at ending ''the excuses used against Nicaragua'' and would ''permit concrete steps'' by those interested in peace in the region. **********A Reversal of Position **********The decision appeared to be a reversal of the Government's previous position and also a response to the call for diplomatic moves made by four regional Presidents in Mexico last weekend. **********The four countries of the so-called Contadora Group - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela - have attempted to mediate in Central America since January. But no significant progress has been made because Nicaragua, supported by Mexico and Colombia, had said it favored direct talks with Honduras to reduce tensions along their common border, while the United States and Honduras insisted on a broader framework and the inclusion of other nations in the region. **********Today Mr. Ortega called for immediate international talks on a nonaggression pact between Nicaragua and Honduras, a freeze of all arms shipments to El Salvador and an end to the use of foreign territories to attack countries with internal conflicts. U.S. Concerns Addressed **********While this would cover United States backing for the Salvadoran Government and the anti-Sandinista rebels based in Honduras, it also addresses, more emphatically than before, Washington's concerns over Cuban arms supplies to Nicaragua and Nicaraguan arms shipments to the insurgents in El Salvador. It also, more emphatically than before, addresses Washington's concerns. **********(In Washington, a White House spokesman, Larry M. Speakes, said there would be no comment until the Administration had read the full text of Mr. Ortega's address.) **********Some diplomats saw Mr. Ortega's call today for ''an absolute end to all arms supplies by any country to the parties in El Salvador'' as a first tacit recognition that Nicaragua has been involved in supplying the guerrillas there. Emphasis on Congress **********The apparent reversal of Nicaragua's attitude toward talks comes a day after the disclosure that the Reagan Administration is planning two large military exercises in Central America and is considering the possibility of a military quarantine around Nicaragua.  It also precedes this week's debate in Congress on Central American issues, including a proposal to cut off covert aid to rebels in Nicaragua. **********In recent interviews, senior Nicaraguan officials have said they believe that Washington is preparing a military intervention to overthrow them and that only United States public opinion and Congress can prevent this. **********Besides being less aggressive in tone against the United States than most official addresses here, Mr. Ortega's speech contained several conciliatory gestures aimed not only abroad but also at home. Contacts between the United States Embassy and the Nicaraguan Government have recently improved after a period of virtual standstill. At home the Government has stepped up land distribution and is discussing a general salary raise. **********Speaking in the historic city of Leon, 60 miles west of the capital, Mr. Ortega said the Government would cancel all debts of peasants serving as reservists or in the militia and of members of militarized cooperative farms in charge of their own defense. He said that the debts of other farmers would be partly pardoned and that unjustified invasions of farmland would have to stop. **********He repeated the Government's pledge to hold general elections in 1985, but contrary to wide expectations here gave no date.  Aware of these expectations, the Government has been prodding the Council of State to hurry its present debate on laws governing political parties and electoral proceedings. In an apparent gesture to show that it is serious about elections, the Government has sent several commissions to Europe and to other countries in Latin America to study electoral systems there. **********Citing achievements of the revolution, Mr. Ortega said that more than a million young people and adults were enrolled in more than 2,600 new study centers and more than 1,200 new schools and that important improvements had been made in the country's health care.  But he also criticized health workers for their ''bad service'' and said that shortages of medicine were serious. Warns of More Fighting **********Yet a growing feeling here that war may be coming could also be sensed in today's official ceremonies. Already the conflict with rebels along the northern and southern borders has caused the death of 600 people in Nicaragua this year and losses of $70 million, Mr.  Ortega said. **********He told the crowd to prepare for more fighting. The civilian militia is being reorganized into a more professional fighting force and last Friday the Government announced that national military conscription would soon go into effect. **********The mood here is most felt in the slogan painted everywhere and chanted today by the crowd, ''Arms to the people'' - a reference to the official warning that everyone will be armed to fight in case of an invasion. **********Mr. Ortega declared today that while Nicaragua had no expansionist ambitions, ''our revolution is irreversible.'' ---- Sandinistas Accused **********WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) - The United States delegate to the United Nations, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, told an anti-Sandinista group today that there was no truth to the doctrine of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the late Soviet leader, that Marxist revolutions are irreversible. **********''The Brezhnev doctrine rests on the will and determination of some people,'' she said. ''It can be overturned by the will and determination of some other people.'' **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick will serve as President Reagan's representative on his new commission on the problems of Central America.  Addressing the Ad Hoc Committee for Democracy in Nicaragua, she accused the Sandinistas of systematically failing to fulfill promises to establish a pluralistic democratic order with respect for human rights and the rule of law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/world.body_text: **********Residents of Moscow have been forbidden to go to certain forested areas around the capital because a long, dry spell has greatly increased the risk of forest fires, local papers reported today. **********The newspapers also listed several regions in which there is a ban on lighting camp fires and burning rubbish because of the danger to the thick forests of birch trees that make up a large part of the countryside around the city. **********Eastern Europe has had dry weather, with temperatures averaging over 75 degrees, for more than two weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Lucas Industries P.L.C. will soon complete a licensing agreement with a major United States automotive company to use a Lucas process that enables the use of lighter steels in vehicle components, a Lucas spokesman said. **********The treatment process, called nitrotek, permits the use of thinner steels by improving tensile strengths and surface hardness. Lucas is also considering a partnership with a major European concern specializing in steel heat treatments, he said. **********The spokesman declined further details but the Lucas 1982 annual report said the process is already being used to make a fan motor now being supplied to a major United States manufacturer and licensing negotiations are in hand with about a dozen major international industrial companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.main_headline: SOLIDARITY RALLIES TURN INTO CLASHES WITH POLISH POLICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.print_headline: SOLIDARITY RALLIES TURN INTO CLASHES WITH POLISH POLICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.body_text: **********Despite efforts by the Government to show that the outlawed Solidarity union was finished, tens of thousands of pro-Solidarity, anti-Government demonstrators turned out today for unauthorized May Day rallies in 20 Polish cities and towns. **********In each case, the police quickly moved in to break up the rallies.  Many of the protests were marked by rock- and bottle-throwing episodes and the use of water cannons and tear gas. The police had been deployed in force in an effort to discourage the protests, which were called to counter Government May Day parades. **********The largest demonstrations were in Gdansk, where crowds estimated at 20,000 or more battled the police as they tried to march to the home of Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, and in Warsaw, where crowds of more than 10,000 rallied only a few blocks from the Government's parade. **********Walesa Did Not Participate **********Mr. Walesa himself did not participate in the demonstrations, returning home after going to church this morning. But his apartment, in a sprawling gray housing project, became a focus of the day's activities in Gdansk. **********The protests had been called by Solidarity's underground leadership committee. The committee is made up of a handful of key activists who escaped the general roundup of Solidarity supporters when martial law was imposed on Dec. 13, 1981. **********The state television reported tonight that there had been disturbances in 20 localities and showed film of demonstrators hurling rocks and bottles at the police in the steel-mill city of Nowa Huta. In the industrial Silesian city of Wroclaw, the police used water cannons, armored vehicles and barrages of tear gas grenades to break up a march of several thousand people. Clashes were also reported in Cracow, Szczecin, Gdynia and other cities. Setback to Government **********The large turnout nationwide was seen as a setback to the Government, which had sought to portray May Day as a showdown that would prove that Solidarity was no longer a viable organization. **********Today's demonstrations were the largest since widespread rallies last Aug. 31 marking the anniversary of the founding of Solidarity in 1980.  In the past, the Government has warned that continued outbreaks of demonstrations could endanger the planned visit of Pope John Paul II in June. **********''I am very happy,'' Mr. Walesa said of the demonstrations in a telephone interview this evening from his home in Gdansk.  ''Physically, we did not have much chance, but it is a great gain.'' **********Mr. Walesa, who was released in November from 11 months of internment, announced last month that he had met secretly with the fugitive Solidarity committee members and had agreed with them on a joint strategy for today's demonstrations. **********As the day began, Poland's military leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, delivered a speech to Communist Party followers in which he said that those who wanted to ''sow chaos'' were now ''only a miserable margin without any chance for success.'' **********In his speech, General Jaruzelski said, ''If in the coming days and months there are no disturbances and peace is consolidated, there will be a real possibility for lifting martial law and adopting follow-up actions.'' Letter From Bishop Read **********In St. Bridget's church in Gdansk, the parish of the workers of the Lenin shipyard, worshipers heard a letter read from Bishop Lech Kaczmarek criticizing what he termed human rights violations in Poland. ''No man can be transformed into a beast of burden,'' the letter said. **********The Government had mounted an extensive campaign over the past few weeks to discourage participation in the Solidarity rallies, including an unprecedented request to the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy from a member of the Communist Party Politburo to cancel Sunday morning masses. **********The crowd leaving the church moved toward the monument of three crosses erected by Solidarity near the shipyards' gate to honor workers killed protesting food price increases in 1970. There they merged with other demonstrators, some of whom had apparently split off from the official celebration. **********The police, swinging truncheons, charged into the crowd three times, trying to break it up, according to reports from Western correspondents on the scene. Part of the crowd was chased through the narrow streets of the town's old district amid barrages of tear gas.  Other parts of the crowd re-formed and tried to march north toward Mr. Walesa's home, according to reports reaching Warsaw, and there were clashes, with stones hurled at the police along the way. Police Use Water Cannon **********At the housing project itself, a crowd gathered in front of Mr.  Walesa's building, cheering when he appeared on a balcony. The police used a water cannon to drive them away. **********In Warsaw, where red banners were hung for the official commemoration of the workers' holiday, the police and armored vehicles surrounded the Old Town district early this morning. **********Leaflets had called for demonstrators to gather at Castle Square on the edge of the district, to go to 10 A.M. masses in the nearby Roman Catholic churches and then to hold an independent May Day demonstration. **********The 4,000-seat Gothic cathedral of St. John the Baptist was jammed, its wooden pulpit draped with a Solidarity banner, and thousands more packed the narrow, cobblestoned street in front and spilled out into the spacious Old Town square. Solidarity Flags Hung **********Red and white Solidarity flags were also hung from the buildings, along with red bunting for the official celebrations. The crowd chanted the names of jailed or fugitive Solidarity leaders and of Mr.  Walesa. They looked nervously at the gray-uniformed policemen with helmets and shields, who sealed off the streets in the area. **********After nearly an hour the police ordered the crowd to disperse.  When it did not move, water cannons opened up from both ends of the narrow street, sending jets of blue-dyed water cascading through the crowd. Then the police charged, wielding their riot sticks. **********But the demonstrations continued until midday, with the crowd being broken up, re-forming and being broken up again.  An NBC News televsion crew was detained by authorities for two hours and all of their videotapes of the protests in Old Town confiscated. Other photographers were turned away from the area or had their equipment seized. (The Associated Press reported that a reporter and a translator for the news agency were detained by the police in Gdansk, but were later released.) **********The Government's parade in Warsaw, which lasted four and a half hours, passed within a few blocks of the Solidarity demonstration.  Although the Government and Communist Party had been putting pressure on factories and schools to insure a large turnout, the procession of factory delegations, old soldiers, nurses in uniform and Communist Party functionaries appeared listless, and there was none of the usual chanting of Communist slogans. There were few spectators. **********---- Reagan Supports Solidarity **********WASHINGTON, May 1 (Reuters) -President Reagan said in a statement today that the United States would continue to support the efforts of the Polish people and the outlawed Solidarity movement to restore human rights in Poland. **********Mr. Reagan, in a message read to a rally in support of Solidarity in Washington, repeated an offer to help Poland solve its economic problems if the Government took meaningful liberalization measures.  The message was read by a State Department official at the rally in Lafayette Park, next to the White House. **********''We want the Polish people to know that the future of Poland and free trade unions is a matter of deep concern not only to the Administration but to the American people,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''We pledge our solidarity with them and our vigilance for the restoration of human rights in that country. **********''We salute the courage of the Poles who daily face intimidation and harassment,'' the statement said. ''Their heroic resistance to their Government's attempts to suppress Solidarity serves as an inspiring display of the indomitable desire for freedom in the hearts of men and women everywhere.'' **********---- Pope Defends Workers' Rights **********ROME, May 1 (Reuters) - Pope John Paul II spoke out strongly today in defense of workers' rights and called for ''solidarity, fraternity and liberty'' in his weekly noon blessing to an estimated 50,000 people in St. Peter's Square. The Pope made no direct reference to events in Poland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/31/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Your unduly pessimistic article about Detroit's Renaissance Center (July 3) would have left your readers better informed had it told them about the following positive outcomes of Henry Ford's decision to invest in downtown Detroit: *********** Detroit's downtown restaurant trade is the best in memory and far outshadows the suburbs from the standpoint of quality and variety.  This includes the refurbished ''Bricktown'' area in the shadow of the Renaissance Center, which is now several blocks of attractive restaurants, offices, and boutiques and which used to be flophouses and vacant buildings. **********The ''Greektown'' area has quadrupled in size since the groundbreaking for the Renaissance Center. *********** The $77 million Riverfront West project will include more than 600 apartments, a marina, restaurants, and a health club when it is completed in mid-1984. Future plans include a hotel and a condominium tower. *********** Construction is beginning this summer on the two-tower Millender Center, which will contain 250 hotel rooms and 312 apartments. It will be connected to the Renaissance Center by a skywalk. *********** Just upriver from the Renaissance Center, downtown-based Stroh Brewery will convert some old factories into a mixed retail, office and residential complex with rooftop parking. And the downtown-based American Natural Resources Company, a major natural gas and pipeline company, has received approval to build 1,500 condominiums. *********** After years of wrangling, the political leadership of the suburban counties north of Detroit have come together behind a regional transit package that will feature light rail transit lines into downtown from the north and northeast. *********** The Poletown auto plant is being worked on steadily and is programmed to build the replacements for General Motors' popular Seville-Toronado series of luxury cars.  JAMES A. BUSH **********Detroit, July 17

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/world.print_headline: Pope Refuses to Cut Number of Holy Days
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II made last-minute changes in the revised code of canon law, rejecting a recommendation that the Roman Catholic Church reduce the number of holy days of obligation from 10 to two, church sources reported today. **********The Pope signed and promulgated the new code of 1,752 canons, or laws, on Jan. 25, but no text was made available to the public until Tuesday, when the official Latin version went on sale at the Vatican bookstore. **********In earlier news briefings, Archbishop Rosalio Jose Castillo Lara, president of a 74-member commission that drafted the code, had said the changes the Pope made were only of ''a technical nature.'' **********The Latin text retains the requirement that Roman Catholics attend mass on 10 holy days of obligation, but adds a provision allowing local bishops to appeal to the Holy See for the dispensation of some of the holy days or approval for observing them on nearby Sundays. **********The 10 holy days are the Feast of Solemnity of the Mother of God (Jan. 1), the Assumption of Our Lady (Aug. 15), the Feast of Immaculate Conception (Dec. 8), the Feast of the Ascension of Our Lord, which comes 40 days after Easter, All Saints' Day (Nov. 1), Christmas, the Feast of Sts. Peter and Paul (June 29), the Feast of Corpus Christi, in June, St. Joseph's Day (March 19) and Epiphany (Jan. 6).

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/world.body_text: **********Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, in an apparent attempt to mend relations, hailed Pope John Paul II today as an ally in an anti-Communist crusade to build a ''new Guatemala.'' **********The statement from the Guatemalan leader, who is an Evangelical Christian, came two days after he allowed the execution of six men despite a Vatican plea to spare their lives. **********The Government described them as subversives. **********General Rios Montt, a former Roman Catholic, is a member of a Pentecostal sect called the Church of the Word.  In San Jose, Costa Rica, the Pope issued a signed statement sent to Guatemalan bishops in which he expressed his ''immense pain'' over the executions and said he hoped his visit to Guatemala on Monday would ''promote respect'' for human rights. **********General Rios Montt said in his statement that his year-old regime had restored honesty and reduced violence and he denounced ''atheist Marxism'' and ''materialist consumerism.'' **********''For all this, the visit of Pope John Paul II is opportune, because it comes when we are building the foundation of a new Guatemala,'' he said. ---- **********WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -John Hughes, the State Department spokesman said Friday that ''we are naturally disturbed'' about reports that six men in Guatemala had been executed after a secret trial. He said the United States was not able to render a legal judgment on the fairness of the charges or of the final verdict.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.body_text: **********The Briggs & Stratton Corporation, maker of engines and automotive locks, announced a recall of 800 hourly employees beginning next Monday in response to increased demand for lawn and garden equipment. **********''The spring selling season in the southern United States has been encouraging, and our orders have increased,'' Frederick P. Stratton, Jr., president, commented. ''We are optimistic about holding this rate of production.'' **********Briggs & Stratton, with headquarters in Milwaukee, is one of the largest employers in the state, employing about 9,000 people normally at its five Wisconsin facilities. The company said that about 1,200 employees would remain on layoff status.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the General Motors Corporation said that he anticipates the corporation will report a profit of more than $2 billion in 1983. **********''I am hopeful that we will earn a profit sufficient to share with our hourly rate employees,'' Roger B. Smith told the annual stockholders meeting. **********Profit sharing with factory workers is a provision of G.M.'s 1982 contract with the United Automobile Workers union. Under the terms of the contact, Mr. Smith said, the company has to earn an annual profit of more than $1.9 billion before the distributions to workers begin. **********Mr. Smith also indicated that the company is not likely to seek concessions from the union in next year's negotiations as it did in 1982, despite the advantage Japanese auto makers have in labor costs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/world.main_headline: Death Toll Rises to 7 After Terror at Orly
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Death Toll Rises to 7 After Terror at Orly
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/world.body_text: **********The mother of a teen-age boy killed in last Friday's bomb attack at Orly Airport has died, officials announced today, bringing to seven the total dead in the explosion at a Turkish Airlines counter. **********The death late Wednesday of Jacqueline Kirschner, a Frenchwoman whose 19-year-old son died instantly in the explosion, made the Orly attack the most costly in human life since the days of the Algerian war in the early 1960's. Five of the 55 people wounded in the attack remain in critical condition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.body_text: **********The State Department disclosed today that it expelled two Soviet diplomats from this country last month, charging them with espionage. **********A State Department official said the expulsion of the two Russians might have been the reason for the announcement in Moscow today that an American vice consul in Leningrad and his wife had been ordered to leave the Soviet Union on similar charges. **********A State Department official said that on Aug. 17, Anatoly Y. Skripko, an assistant attache, was ordered to leave the United States after being ''caught in the act of handing over money for a classified document he had just received.'' **********Two days later, the official said, Yuri P. Leonov, assistant air attache, was expelled after being ''apprehended in possession of a briefcase with a classified document inside.'' **********No publicity was given to those expulsions, an official said, in an effort to avoid retaliation by Moscow. **********In announcing that the two Soviet attaches were expelled last month, Mr. Romberg also said the United States had ''vigorously protested'' what he said was the physical mistreatment of Lon D. Augustenborg, the American vice consul, and his wife, Denise, in Leningrad. **********State Department officials did not disclose any more details on the expulsion of the Soviet attaches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/busin.body_text: **********ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES of Troy, Mich. has developed low-cost methods of producing semiconductors that have proved useful in solar equipment and which show promise for use in computer memories and logic circuits. **********Stanford R. Ovshinsky, president, and Arun Madan, a former staff member, obtained patent 4,409,605 for the company this week, extending the range of a related patent the two men were granted three years ago. **********The patent covers what a spokesman describes as a broad new range of amorphous alloys and devices useful in semiconductor manufacturing and other applications. **********One item covered by this week's patent is a semiconductor film. The company has developed a process by which a coating of amorphous silcon alloy is bonded to a roll of thin stainless steel 1,000 feet long and 16 inches wide. Slices of the sheet are then used to make photovoltaic devices, which convert sunlight into electricity through a chemical process. **********Mr. Ovshinsky is widely known in the scientific community for his theories and work in energy conversion. Although he has no college degree, he is regarded as the guiding light of a company that employs some 65 Ph.D.'s. ''Ovonic,'' a combination of his name and the word electronics, has entered the language in recent years to define the process that amorphous materials undergo when they become semiconductors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/world.body_text: **********Tripoli, the northern Lebanese port city, was the scene of renewed clashes today between pro-Syrian and anti-Syrian Moslem militiamen. Thousands of civilians have been forced into shelters and essential services have been seriously disrupted. **********Reports from the city, Lebanon's second largest, with a population estimated at half a million, said the militia factions were heavily bombarding each other, including residential areas on both sides, with artillery fire. Large sections of Tripoli were without electricity, telephone communication and basic food, such as bread, according to the reports. **********There have been sporadic outbreaks between the militia forces since last February. The fighting in the last few days was said to be the most severe since then. The Factions and the Issues **********The struggle is essentially between Moslem factions favoring and disdaining the Government of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.  Tripoli is overwhelmingly Sunni Moslem and many of the Sunnis do not regard the Alawite Moslem Government of Mr. Assad as genuinely Moslem. The Syrian Alawites are a minority but control Syria, and that is another source of friction. **********The factional strife is further complicated by groups in Tripoli that look favorably on Moslem fundamentalists and are believed to have ties with the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood, a major foe of the Assad Government. **********In addition, there are elements in Tripoli favoring the pro-Iraqi Baath Party, a direct enemy of the Syrian Baath Party headed by Mr.  Assad. These and other splinter groups provide the ingredients for the volatile situation in Tripoli. **********Syria still controls Tripoli and is estimated to have as many as 30,000 soldiers in the area. The clashes have been primarily between two Moslem groups - the pro-Syrian Arab Democratic Party and an anti-Syrian group called Popular Resistance. **********Casualty reports vary and are unverifiable. Forty people were said to have been killed in the latest exchanges and many more wounded.  Local hospitals have appealed for essential medical supplies. **********The exchanges have forced many civilians into basement shelters and caused the closing of bakeries and food stores.  A local Sunni Moslem leader, Rashid Karami, a former Lebanese Prime Minister, left today for Damascus to ask President Assad to intervene to end the violence. **********Today the coastal road to Tripoli, about 50 miles north of Beirut, was cut more than 20 miles from the entrance to the port.  There are also armed Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas in the area, but it was not known if any were involved in the fighting. **********The rightist Phalangist Christian radio station here reported that the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, who has been at odds with President Assad, had said in Sana, Yemen, that Syrian soldiers were attacking Palestinian refugees in a camp near Tripoli. A Call to Damascus **********Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan telephoned his Syrian counterpart, Abdel-Raouf al-Kassem, on Monday to ask for ''some Syrian security measures to help end the tragic situation in Tripoli.'' **********''It boils down to the fact that the people of Tripoli don't want the Syrians there anymore,'' a senior political analyst said here tonight. **********Lebanese state television today quoted a commander of a Sunni Moslem militia, Farouk Mokaddam, as saying that the latest round of fighting was ''a blood bath, a massacre committed piecemeal.'' **********Another local leader, Mohammed Ali Dannawi, has urged Syria to remove its forces from the center of the city to the outskirts.  ''What's the purpose of keeping the Syrian forces inside the city?'' he asked. ''If the purpose is for insuring security, security could not be any worse.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.body_text: **********IT isn't only the personal computer companies that are raiding the packaged goods manufacturers for marketing and advertising executives. The cable systems and programmers are also signing up promoters of soap and soda pop. **********Alumni of Pepsico (whose beverage unit's president, John Sculley, recently became president and chief executive officer of Apple Computer), Standard Brands - now Nabisco Brands - and a number of advertising agencies are popping up at Showtime and its parent, Viacom International, at the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Corporation, at Group W Cable and at other system operators and cable services. **********''Packaged goods people are going into cable as it's market-driven,'' said Gary Knisely of Johnson, Smith & Kniseley, an executive recruiter who has placed a number of packaged goods marketers in cable. **********''I frankly don't see any difference between selling this and selling Heinz pickles,'' said Charles Townsend, vice president of marketing and programming for Denver-based United Cable. Mr. Townsend, who left Pepsico's new-product development group two years ago to go into cable, has also worked at Heinz and Philip Morris, which recently contributed James Morgan to Atari. **********The reason that cable has been recruiting long-time marketers, experts say, is that the industry's growth curve and optimistic projections have flattened. **********''As an industry matures and its growth slows, companies find that whatever they're selling is not too dissimilar, or that the differences are not understood by consumers,'' said Robert Catlin, who became senior vice president of marketing and creative services for Showtime last year. Mr. Catlin, a long-time marketing and advertising agency executive who previously worked at Benton & Bowles and N.W. Ayer, likens cable to the airlines, which were among his accounts. **********In both cable and packaged goods, marketing people say, the task is to discern the needs of, and communicate with, the consumer. But Mr. Catlin, for one, distinguishes between the marketing needs of the cable systems and those of the services. Like the airlines and car rental companies, he said, the system operators deal directly with the public. ''Some people coming in from packaged goods marketing have to learn that,'' he said. **********However, the Pepsico alumni find that their soft-drink experience prepared them for marketing cable systems. For one thing, they say, the cable systems, with their scores of franchise operators across the country, are like Pepsico and its network of bottlers. At Pepsico, ''we had to complement their efforts,'' said Stephen Ste. Marie, who also worked at Standard Brands and is now vice president, marketing, at Viacom's cable division. In both cases, he added, ''the ultimate beneficiary is the subscriber; if we don't keep that in mind, we will have very little chance to grow the way we like.'' **********To grow, said Mr. Townsend, cable operators have to answer two key questions: Why do only half the homes in cable areas subscribe, and why do only one-third add pay tiers? **********''Packaged goods training is perfect for figuring out why half the families don't buy cable,'' he added. His conclusion is that the holdouts are light television viewers, who do not realize that cable offers news, sports and health features as well as movies and specials. He is going to woo those viewers with four vignette-style commercials, to be test-marketed this month in markets served by United Cable. ''I suspect it will work,'' he said. **********For the marketers, one unfamiliar problem is the acute shortage of cable data, compared with the masses of information compiled by packaged goods companies. Thus, another talent of the packaged goods marketers, on which cable is drawing, is their expertise in spending money. **********Until two years ago, according to Mr. Townsend, all system operators had probably spent, cumulatively, less than $100,000 on market research. Now, he estimates, ''we're doing $1 million a year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.body_text: **********The oil spill in the Persian Gulf has caused ''catastrophic pollution'' that threatens to cause lasting damage to fresh water supplies and marine life, a World Wildlife Fund report said today. **********It estimated that oil had spilled at a rate of 1,200 barrels a day from three wells in the Nowruz field off Iran since last March and said that efforts to cap them had been thwarted by the Iranian-Iraqi war. **********The scientists have not been able to make a detailed examination of the environmental damage, the report said, but they have spotted about 50 dead sea cows on eastern gulf beaches, believed to represent almost the entire gulf population of the marine mammal. **********The report said the scientists had also recorded unusually high numbers of dead marine turtles, dolphins, fish, sea snakes and birds on the beaches, presumed to be victims of the spill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Poor OPEC ...  Lucky World
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Poor OPEC ...  Lucky World
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/busin.body_text: **********THE Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is very much chastened. It has cut prices for the first time in its history, lowered the ceiling for oil production by its members and proclaimed its ''belief and confidence that OPEC remains the major force for oil market stability, beneficial to both consumers and producers.'' **********The tender solicitude for consumers demonstrated by the group after its meetings in London was also a historic first. After having run the price of crude oil up to a peak some 20 times higher than its pre-1973 level, OPEC members said they would now like to get together with oil consumers to stabilize prices. They also expressed their solicitude for non-OPEC oil producers such as Mexico, Britain and Norway, which they would like to join their club so that they too could have quotas set on how much oil they could produce. But, like Groucho Marx, the non-OPEC oil countries fail to see why they should join any club that would have them. **********OPEC's newly discovered concern for the welfare of other countries, whether oil consumers or non-OPEC oil producers, is accompanied by a concern for its own weaker members, such as Nigeria, Indonesia and Algeria, which are in deep financial straits. They got into trouble by acting in accordance with Parkinson's second law, which states that outgo rises to meet income. Indeed, OPEC as a whole is suffering from this Parkinsonian disease. **********The huge rise in oil earnings during the 1970's was matched by a rising outflow of money to pay for development and consumer goods.  Now that oil earnings have slumped, several OPEC countries are unable to pay their bills, just like the poor oil-importing countries of the third world. **********OPEC, never a generous contributor to third world countries, was asked in London to become a Salvation Army for its own ailing members. It responded cautiously by allowing the weaker countries to expand their output within the overall ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day. **********For instance, Nigeria, whose production had fallen to 800,000 barrels a day in February, was given a quota of 1.3 million and allowed to reduce its price differential to $1. Similarly, Algeria, Libya, Indonesia, Ecuador, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and Iraq all got quotas higher than their recent production levels.  Iran, refusing to accept a price cut, although it has sold oil below official prices in the past, said it would accept a quota of 2.4 million barrels a day. **********Saudi Arabia alone received no quota. It has been cast in the role of ''swing'' producer - the flywheel to balance supply and demand in the market within the overall limit. **********But it remains doubtful whether that ceiling is low enough to sustain the new $29-a-barrel benchmark price of OPEC oil. The ceiling is 3.4 million barrels a day higher than actual production last month. In fact, it is more than a million barrels a day higher than OPEC pumped in April 1982, before the world recession reached its lower depths. **********Furthermore, OPEC members may lack the will to abide by the quotas. If they do not, OPEC does not have a means of enforcement. Should the world market remain soft and some members exceed their quotas, Saudi Arabia would be unable to lower output enough to absorb the difference and stabilize oil prices. **********Saudi Arabia has recently been producing only 3.8 million barrels a day, far below its 10 million level of three years ago. Obviously, the kingdom cannot produce negative barrels of oil, and eliminating its entire current output might still not balance the market.  Realistically, the kingdom could not be expected to cut production to less than 2 million barrels a day, just 1.8 million barrels less than its recent rate of production. Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, has put the ''practical'' minimum much higher: 4.7 million. **********OPEC must now pray for what it once disdained to consider: the health of the world economy. Revival of world demand is essential to its future. **********With the United States leading the way, world economic recovery could get under way this year. But the rest of the world is lagging well behind the United States, and it probably will take several months at least before demand revives enough to prevent further erosion of oil prices, especially with hard-pressed non-OPEC producers striving to retain or increase their market shares. **********Oil buyers, not yet convinced that OPEC has set a price that will hold, are still declining to make long-term commitments. And, just as businesses, homeowners and car drivers ''topped off'' their tanks when oil prices were rising and supplies were tight, now, with declining prices and an oil glut, consumers are holding down inventories, depressing the demand for oil. No one knows how long the drawing on inventories can go on. **********OPEC's ill wind will blow much good for the United States and the world economy. Lower oil bills for both the developed and developing oil-importing countries, which greatly outnumber the oil producers, will mean: lower balance of payments deficits; lower inflation and inflationary expectations; lower interest rates and an improved ability of debtor countries to service their debts; a shift of payments from oil to consumption of durable goods, housing, productivity-increasing investment in new plant and equipment. All this should help restore equilibrium and growth to the world economy, whatever the pains to OPEC.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Two job-support proposals floated in recent days by France's Socialist Government are being viewed by bankers here as thinly disguised measures to bring the country's remaining private banks, most of which are foreign owned, under state control. **********The measures, one a confidential proposal to the French Bankers Association and the other a publicly proposed change to the country's bankruptcy laws, are designed to protect jobs by guaranteeing credit to financially troubled companies. The first would make it difficult for France's private banks to cut off credit to ailing companies while the bankruptcy proposal would prevent all French banks, whether nationalized or private, from foreclosing on loans to businesses. **********The proposed new measures, foreign bankers here say, thus fit into the Socialists' declared aim of extending political control over the supply of credit within the economy. That was their major justification for nationalizing most privately owned French banks, when they came to power, along with 11 of the country's biggest industrial groups. **********Tie to Lending Pools **********Sources here say that the proposal put before the French Bankers Association would lock the country's private banks into unattractive loan agreements by preventing them from leaving the multibank lending pools that are formed to meet corporate credit needs in this country. **********The proposal, backed by the French Finance Ministry, would permit banks to withdraw from a lending pool only if 75 percent of the other pool members agreed. But in practice, these sources say, foreign and privately owned French banks would not be permitted to withdraw because a majority of the banks in every such pool are now statecontrolled. **********Sources at the association say the Finance Ministry has made clear that it would prefer the banks to adopt the code on a voluntary basis rather than see it imposed by the Government. Foreign Banks' Opposition **********However, the approximately 130 members of the Foreign Bankers Association here have strongly protested the plan. Arguing that it would amount to de facto nationalization, they have warned that they will formally oppose the proposal if it is brought to a vote inside the association. No vote has been called so far, although the proposal remains on the table. **********American and other foreign diplomats here are closely watching the maneuvering over the proposed new rules, and say that any attempt to curtail foreign banks' freedom in France could lead to reprisals against French banks operating abroad. But as yet no formal protests have been registered with the French authorities, these sources say. **********Meanwhile, French banks have acted in unison in opposing a recent proposal by the French Justice Minister, Robert Badinter, to reform the country's bankruptcy laws. **********A key provision of Mr. Badinter's proposal would automatically cancel any guarantees or collateral given a lender by a borrowing company. Bankers argue that the proposal, like the planned changes in bank pool rules, renders the whole concept of risk assessment meaningless and would turn all French banks, whether private or state-owned, into machines for financing companies the Government wants to keep alive. **********''After abolishing the death penalty for murderers, Badinter now wants to abolish the death penalty for companies,'' said one senior American banker here. **********The proposed new bankruptcy law is also arousing opposition from the very French industrialists it is intended to help keep in business, bankers say. This is because banks provide only about onethird of the total credit extended to business in France, with the remaining two-thirds coming from other concerns in the form of supplier credits. But guarantees or collateral given companies providing goods on credit could also be invalidated if the new law comes into force.
