https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/world.main_headline: SNIPER IN LEBANON KILLS U.S. MARINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/world.print_headline: SNIPER IN LEBANON KILLS U.S. MARINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/world.body_text: **********One United States marine was killed and another wounded today when Marine positions at Beirut International Airport came under sniper fire from neighboring Shiite Moslem quarters, a Marine spokesman said. **********The spokesman, Maj. Robert Jordan, said the marine who died was struck in the chest by sniper fire from the Shiite areas of Hayy al Sollum and Burj al Brajneh. The wounded man was hit in both legs. **********Another spokesman, Warrant Officer Charles Rowe, said the sniper fire was part of a series of attacks in the last few days apparently aimed at provoking the Marines to retaliate. **********The violence erupted hours after two Lebanese Moslem groups, the Shiite paramilitary organization called Amal and the mainly Druse Progressive Socialist Party, announced that they were suspending their membership in a committee of Lebanese factions that has been overseeing the 18-day-old cease-fire in the Beirut area.   Lebanese Come Under Fire **********Lebanese Army positions in Burj al Brajneh also came under fire, a military spokesman said. Lebanese soldiers at the same time exchanged rocket and artillery fire with anti-Government militiamen at Araya, a hilltop village a few miles east of here along the main Beirut-Damascus highway. There were no immediate reports of casualties. **********Today's American casualties raised to 5 the number of marines killed and 43 the number wounded since the current wave of violence began at the end of August. A sixth marine was killed when he stepped on an unexploded cluster bomb shortly after the Marine contingent arrived here in September 1982 as part of the international force. The force, consisting of 5,400 members, also includes French, Italian and British troops. In addition to the sniper fire from nearby buildings, the Americans have come under artillery fire from the hills overlooking their positions. **********In announcing Thursday night that Amal was taking its representative out of the cease-fire committee, the group's president, Nabih Berri, said the action was in protest against measures that undermined the status of the truce. He did not elaborate. **********But Shiite sources said Amal objected to arrest warrants issued for Shiite soldiers and officers for having failed to report to duty. An army spokesman, however, denied such warrants had been served.   Some Refused to Fight **********Several hundred Shiite and Druse servicemen had declared themselves ''conscientious objectors'' and refused to fight against their co-religionists when Lebanese Moslem militiamen battled with the Christian-commanded Lebanese Army last month. **********The Progressive Socialist Party, led by Walid Jumblat, declared its support for Amal and suspended its own membership in the secutity committee until further notice. **********Both factions reiterated their adherence to the cease-fire. But their temporary withdrawal evoked concern about the effectiveness of the committee, which also includes delegates from the Lebanese Army and the Lebanese Front, a Christian group. **********The move appeared to dim hopes for early progress in the proposed national reconciliation conference of representatives of the Lebanese Government and the nation's warring factions. An agenda for the conference, which has been scheduled for next Thursday, was agreed upon at preparatory talks held here on Thursday. Attacks on U.S. Base **********Before the cease-fire was agreed upon on Sept. 26, the United States base at Beirut airport came under frequent bombardment from positions held by anti-Government forces in the hills east of the runways. **********Thursday night a marine was slightly wounded in the left leg while on guard duty outside the consular section of the new building housing the United States Embassy in mainly Moslem West Beirut. The wounds were caused by a grenade thrown from a speeding car. **********A Marine spokesman said that a hand grenade was thrown on an airport runway the night before but that no one was hurt. Five days ago two marines were slightly wounded by sniper fire from nearby areas. **********Describing today's incident, Major Jordan said a company of marines on the northeastern perimeter of the airport came under fire from small arms and rocket-propelled grenades in the morning. **********The two marines were hit while driving separate jeeps. One, identified as Sgt. Allen Soifert, 25 years old, of Nashua, N.H., was shot in the chest. He reportedly died while being flown by helicopter to a hospital aboard the amphibious assault ship Iwo Jima, lying off Beirut. The other marine, who was not immediately identified, was also taken to the shipboard hospital. **********While the casualties were being evacuated from the Marine base at the airport, gunmen fired at the landing pad. **********Reagan Offers Condolences **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) - President Reagan today telephoned the parents of Sgt. Allen Soifert, the marine killed in Lebanon, to ''express his regrets,'' a Presidential spokesman reported. **********He said the President spent three minutes on the telephone with Abraham and Joan Romer of Nashua, N.H. Mr. Romer was the sergeant's stepfather. **********The President also said in a statement issued by the White House, ''We are deeply concerned that our marines continue to come under fire and are saddened by the death today of another marine.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/11/world.main_headline: REAGAN URGES JAPAN TO JOIN U.S. IN A GLOBAL 'PARTNERSHIP FOR GOOD'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/11/world.print_headline: REAGAN URGES JAPAN TO JOIN U.S. IN A GLOBAL 'PARTNERSHIP FOR GOOD'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/11/world.body_text: **********President Reagan, addressing the ''good and dear friends of Japan,'' called on this nation and its Parliament today to join the United States in ''a powerful partnership for good.'' **********Mr. Reagan, the first American President to address Japan's national legislature, said the two countries     Excerpts from speech, page A7.    should work together to eliminate the world's nuclear weapons and to increase its economic freedom. **********In Washington Thursday, the United States and Japan announced an agreement under which the two countries will take steps to strengthen the value of the yen against the dollar in an effort to reduce the American trade imbalance with Tokyo. (Page D1.) **********In one of the most dramatic moments of his visit here, Mr. Reagan, speaking as the head of the only nation ever to use nuclear weapons in war, spoke of nuclear conflict to the only nation ever attacked with nuclear weapons. **********''I believe there can be only one policy for preserving our precious civilization in this modern age,'' he said.  ''A nuclear war can never be won and must never be fought.'' **********''Together, there is nothing Japan and America cannot do,'' he said. **********Closes Out His Visit **********Mr. Reagan was closing out a three-day visit here that mixed promises for economic advance with security cautions about ''an adversary bent on aggression and domination.'' **********The President was well received by Parliament, particularly when he used their own language to tell the lawmakers, ''Japanese-American friendship is forever.'' The Parliament hall echoed with applause. **********''We intimidate no one,'' the President said in drawing repeated contrasts between the Soviet Union and regional tensions here, on one hand, and Japanese and American cooperation on the other. ''And we will not be intimidated by anyone.'' **********''We cannot escape our global responsibilities,'' Mr. Reagan added. **********Mr. Reagan, who has ordered the production of a new generation of nuclear weapons in what the United States has described as an attempt to prod the Soviet Union into arms reductions, addressed Japan's parallel concern that the nuclear tensions of Western Europe were gradually spilling over to the Pacific basin as Soviet SS-20 missiles are deployed eastward. **********''Let me make one thing very plain,'' he told Parliament. ''We must not and we will not accept any agreement that transfers the threat of longer-range nuclear missiles from Europe to Asia.'' **********The members of Parliament responded at more than a dozen points with strong applause. In particular, they welcomed Mr. Reagan's references to arms control and the horror of nuclear war. They also applauded his denunciation of the Soviet Union for ''cold-bloodedly'' shooting down the Korean airliner Sept. 1.  The President blamed Moscow ''for blocking the dramatic reductions the world wants,'' but promised he ''will never walk away from the negotiating table.''  Profuse Praise From Reagan **********Mr. Reagan's speech was a blend of considerable praise for Japan's human virtues and economic canniness, leavened with polite urgings to ease trade restrictions and shoulder more of the ''shared burden'' of military defense. **********The President, in both his address and in another day's round of picturesque visiting, praised Japan profusely. ''Japanese-American friendship is forever,'' he said at the start of a day that included a visit to the Hirai High School, lunch with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone at his country retreat 70 miles outside Tokyo and a farewell visit to Emperor Hirohito. The days have been long and Mr. Reagan shows some weariness, but his aides say he is ready for the next stop, South Korea. **********''To all those who lack faith in the human spirit,'' he told Parliament, ''I have just three words of advice: Come to Japan.'' **********He used praise of Japan as a device for denigrating the Soviet Union. ''Come to a country whose economic production will soon surpass the Soviet Union's, making Japan's economy the second largest in the entire world,'' he said. **********Mr. Reagan also used his praise of Japan to strike back at Congressional critics in Washington now trying to enact higher taxes to help close record budget deficits. ''They would ignore the lessons of Japan,'' he said, noting that this nation's tax rates are ''dramatically lower'' than those of other industrial nations. **********Mr. Nakasone, in issuing a friendly summary of his talks with the President, cited the need for the United States to lower interest rates. But he did not mention the budget deficit as an aggravating factor. **********The Prime Minister and the President summarized their talks in statements Thursday that sketched plans to continue with existing accords for dealing with such difficult problems as trade restrictions and the undervalued status of the yen. As expected, the two leaders joined in setting up new consultative groups on the issues of the yen- dollar exchange rate and the easing of restrictions on purchases of stocks and bonds by nationals of each country in the other. **********Differences Acknowledged **********The statements, studded with stark denunciations of terrorist activities in the world, were amicable expressions of well-known economic differences and existing attempts at improvement. Mr. Nakasone, for example, singled out Japan's problems with the growing tendency of American states to tax local Japanese companies on their global assets. Mr. Reagan once again warned about Japanese trade barriers and the political pressures they create for him back home. **********''I have vigorously opposed quick fixes of protectionism in America,'' the President told Parliament this morning. ''We need your help in demonstrating free trade to address concerns of my own people,'' he said, telling Japan that Americans ''believe your markets are less open than ours.'' **********''If we each give a little we can all gain a lot,'' he said. **********Mr. Reagan's overall theme was that whatever the differences with Japan, they are being subjected to decent compromise and are minor in the face of a common enemy, the Soviet Union. **********''The real quarrel is not with us,'' he said. ''It is with those who would impose regimentation over freedom; drudgery over dynamic initiative; a future of despair over the certainty of betterment, and the forced feeding of a military Goliath over a personal stake in the products and progress of tomorrow.'' **********President Reagan told the Japanese that they were at the heart of ''the most exciting region of economic growth in the world today.'' **********''I welcome this new Pacific tide,'' he said. ''Let it roll peacefully on.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.main_headline: MOSCOW VETOES U.N. CRITICISM IN PLANE AFFAIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.print_headline: MOSCOW VETOES U.N. CRITICISM IN PLANE AFFAIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union today vetoed a resolution by the Security Council that deplored the Russians' destruction of a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1. **********Nine nations, a bare minimum required to adopt a resolution, voted for the document. Poland joined the Soviet Union in voting against it. Four nations - China, Nicaragua, Zimbabwe and Guyana - abstained, thus weakening the United States' attempt to demonstrate that most of the world condemned the Soviet deed. **********In Washington, Senate Democratic and Republican leaders introduced a resolution in Congress ''condemning the brutal behavior'' of the Soviet Union for the destruction of the South Korean plane, but many liberals and conservatives in both houses pressed for something stronger than words. (Page A10.) Humiliation Avoided in U.N. **********The result of the voting in the United Nations Security Council spared the United States what had threatened to become a political humiliation. As late as this morning, there were only eight certain votes for the resolution. Had that total gone unchanged, the document would have failed and the negative Soviet vote would not have counted as a veto. **********But a ninth Council member, Malta, was persuaded to abandon its reservations and join the majority, providing the critical vote. **********Malta's delegate, Victor J. Gauci, said much the same thing as several of those who abstained - that the circumstances surrounding the airliner's destruction ''have been clouded with too much uncertainty.'' **********Even so, he voted along with the United States, Britain, France, the Netherlands, Pakistan, Jordan, Zaire and Togo. **********The crucial section in the resolution ''deeply deplores the destruction of the Korean airliner and the tragic loss of life.'' In an effort to gain the maximum number of third-world votes, the resolution only once referred to the Soviet Union and avoided condemning it. **********The direct reference was in the preamble, the section setting out the facts of an issue, which noted that the South Korean plane ''was shot down by Soviet military aircraft.'' **********Today's was the 115th Soviet veto compared to 36 by the United States. The United States has been casting more vetoes than the Soviet Union in recent years, largely because the membership of new African and Asian nations has often deprived the United States and its allies of a majority. **********Since the end of 1979, the United States has exercised its veto 15 times, mostly over issues affecting Israel and South Africa, while the Soviet Union has cast only three. The previous Soviet veto, in January 1980, stopped a resolution to impose economic sanctions against Iran, which was then holding American hostages. **********Today the American and Soviet delegates engaged in harsh exchanges. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick of the United States said the Soviet Union ''has demonstrated an attitude that is contemptuous of the truth and callous toward human life.'' **********She said that the Russians had committed ''a deeply shocking act'' and, ''instead of admitting error, insisted no error was made.'' Indeed, the Soviet Government has ''emphazised it would have done the same thing over again,'' she said.   Russian Affirms Spying Charge **********Oleg A. Troyanovsky of the Soviet Union said the airliner, with 269 civilians on board, had been engaged in a spy mission. ''No doubt remains,'' he said. **********He accused the United States of staging a ''propaganda spectacle'' in the Council and said that ''ruling circles in the United States make use of this tragic event to heat up an already dangerous'' world situation. **********While the Soviet Union pursues peaceful initiatives, Mr. Troyanovsky said, ''the United States intends to continue to heighten its confrontation with the Soviet Union.'' **********Several of the four abstaining nations said they were concerned over the safety of civil aviation and would welcome the investigation called for by the resolution. But they said either that the text was one-sided or that too many questions over the episode remained unanswered. **********Ling Qing of China said he was abstaining ''in view of the serious dispute over certain aspects of this incident.'' Asian diplomats said China had also held off because the resolution favored South Korea, and China is allied with North Korea. **********Noel G. Sinclair of Guyana, another abstainer, said the sponsors of the resolution - the United States, Britain, France, South Korea, Japan, Canada and Australia - had breached the Council's practice by not negotiating the text with other members. **********Mr. Sinclair also observed that ''what was being advanced as hard evidence is now being revised.'' This was an allusion to Washington's new transcript of the remarks of one of the Soviet fighter pilots, tending to support Moscow's contention that he had fired warning tracer bullets before destroying the plane with his missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.main_headline: COSTA RICAN OFFICIAL,RESIGNING, ASSAILS VOTE AT U.N. ON GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.print_headline: COSTA RICAN OFFICIAL,RESIGNING, ASSAILS VOTE AT U.N. ON GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.body_text: **********Costa Rica's Foreign Minister, Fernando Volio, said today his country's United Nations vote condemning the United States invasion of Grenada last month prompted him to resign from his post. **********Mr. Volio resigned Sunday and is due to leave his post at the end of the month. **********''This was the straw that broke the camel's back, this was what provoked my resignation,'' he told reporters. **********Costa Rica joined the vast majority of United Nations members on Nov. 2 in censuring the United States invasion of Grenada. Only Israel, El Salvador and six Caribbean nations voted with the United States.   Leading Foe of Nicaragua **********Mr. Volio was a leading opponent of accommodation with neighboring Nicaragua, a position which brought him in conflict with President Luis Alberto Monge and most of his Cabinet. **********Government sources said candidates to succeed Mr. Volio included the Justice Minister, Carlos Jose Gutierrez, and the Interior Minister, Alfonso Carro, both proponents of cooperation with Nicaragua. **********Mr. Volio often echoed the views of the Reagan Administration in charging that the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua was the source of most trouble in turbulent Central America. **********Mr. Volio told reporters today his authority as Foreign Minister had been undermined by ''those who wanted to give'' Costa Rica's foreign policy ''a different direction.'' **********Foreign Ministry officials said Mr. Volio had been taken aback by President Monge's decision to exclude him from a recent trip to Mexico and instead ask Costa Rica's delegate to the United Nations, Fernando Zumbado, to accompany him. **********The officials added that Mr. Volio had also been kept out of discussions on the peace initiatives of the Contadora group of Mexico, Panama, Colombia and Venezuela. **********La Nacion, a conservative newspaper, ran a front-page editorial today urging Mr. Monge to explain his position in the Volio case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/busin.body_text: **********Bonanza for Depositors **********Consumers, in a rare change, have been getting far higher yields on their deposits than big corporations, thanks to the deregulation of interest rates. Last week, when corporations were lucky to earn 8 1/2 percent on short-term deposits, many consumers were earning 11 percent or more. **********The bonanza, however, is unlikely to continue. In California, where competition for consumer accounts is especially keen, interest rates offered on the new ''money market'' accounts have dropped substantially. The Bank of America, which competed aggressively for the new accounts, offering 11 1/4 percent plus bonuses ranging from $25 to $100, had cut that to only 10 percent last week, with no bonuses. **********In New York, Chase Manhattan Bank has been setting the pace, offering 11 percent. But, according to Carl D. Gustavson, senior vice president, this week Chase will lower the rate to 10.1 percent. **********Bankers predict that rates on money-market accounts will drop to slightly above the yield on money market mutual funds, which stood at 8.3 percent last week. **********''Logic says that shortly rates will trend down to approximately the real market value of the funds, and that would be somewhere near eight percent,'' said William J. Heron, senior vice president of Citibank. But Not for Borrowers The interest rates individuals must pay on loans, meanwhile, are higher than ever above what banks pay for funds. Automobile companies and at least one airline have had to steeply undercut the banks at their own game in order to stimulate badly-needed sales. The auto makers have been offering 11.9 percent loans on new-car loans, while the banks have been asking as much as 18 percent. **********If banks keep consumer loan rates far higher than their cost of funds, more companies, as well as nonbank competitors, can be expected to enter the market. **********The question is how long the banks can maintain high rates without losing their customary markets. Not long, perhaps. Citibank is expected to announce this week that it will reduce the rate it charges for four-year loans on new cars to 16 percent, from 18 percent. Other banks are expected to follow. Platinum Stands Out **********Unlike most commodities, platinum is in a bull market. From a low of $238 an ounce last June, the price reached $485 last week, with most of that coming in January. Many speculators say this is only the beginning. **********Donna Fried, a technical analyst with the brokerage firm of Sal Calcaterra, predicted that once platinum passes the $490 mark, it will climb rapidly to $520 an ounce, with $640 the next resistance level. **********At Sinclair Global Brokerage Corporation, Robert Farley forecast that ''all precious metals will be traded up.'' He said he is bullish about the platinum group because of its importance to military contractors. The group includes paladium, rhodium, iridium, ruthenium and osmium. **********A factor behind the price rise has been a perception that the Soviet Union, a leading producer, has been holding platinum-group metals from the market. Another reason, analysts say, is the growing belief that the world economy has begun to recover, increasing industrial demand. Still another bullish factor is platinum's price in relation to gold. In a rising market, the price of platinum usually exceeds that of gold. With gold approaching $500 an ounce, platinum is selling at a substantial discount, even after its recent rise. Calmer Nerves About Oil **********Bankers, at first shaken by the prospect of plummeting oil prices, have regained their composure. While a decline could worsen the financial problems of some oil producers, it would also mean a drop in world prices overall, they said. This, in turn, could lead to a faster economic recovery and make it easier for all debtor countries to meet their financial obligations. **********Interest rates, the bankers say, would decline too, reducing the debt-servicing costs of all borrowers.  The critical question, bankers say, is whether the price will drop below $25 a barrel, the level at which most big banks based their loans to the oil industry. Richard O'Brien, an economist with the American Express International Banking Corporation, contends that at $25, demand would increase to push the price up again.  Robert A. Bennett

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.main_headline: A TEST FOR DIPLOMACY: BROOKLYN VISITORS AT THE U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.print_headline: A TEST FOR DIPLOMACY: BROOKLYN VISITORS AT THE U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.body_text: **********The question was direct, a bit angry: ''Why do the African countries always vote with the Arabs against Israel?'' **********The question was asked by a visitor from Brooklyn, one of 150 people here at the United Nations today for a special tour that included frank and even at times confrontational talks with diplomats. **********An answer came from a man who sat across the table from them, Joseph Legwaila, the permanent representative of Botswana at the United Nations. **********''We think the attitude of the African countries will change as soon as the attitude of Israel changes,'' he said. ''My country believes that the Arabs are wrong. **********''I'm saying that both sides are wrong. If both sides cling to their extreme views, you can't have peace in the Middle East.''  Kirkpatrick Urges Toughness **********The visitors were guests of Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democratic Congressman who is serving as a member of the United States Mission to the United Nations during the current session of the General Assembly. **********The visitors from Mr. Solarz's congressional district had no moments of confrontation in their meeting with the United States representative, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick. She argued that the United States needs to be tough in defense of its values. **********The Brooklyn visitors also saw representatives from Israel and Pakistan. They asked a lot of questions, the majority of which suggested a feeling among Mr. Solarz's constituents that the United Nations was one-sided and unfair. **********''There's absolutely no doubt,'' Mr. Solarz said of his constituents, ''that virtually everybody who came today saw the U.N. as a place where duplicity and double standards are the rule rather than the exception.''  Fairness and Justice **********Among the questions asked by today's visitors were these: Do United Nations diplomats really listen to the arguments made by opposing delegates? Should the United Nations be helping Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization evacuate its forces from the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli, where they have been besieged by guerrillas opposed to Mr. Arafat? And doesn't the United Nations ''debase itself'' by turning into a debating society that pays little attention to fairness and justice? **********At the same time, the visitors from Brooklyn gave a vote of confidence to the United Nations itself. Asked by Mr. Solarz to vote on whether the United States should take part or withdraw, the sentiment in favor of participation was unanimous. **********Still, through their questions, the guests repeatedly brought up the problem of Israel at the United Nations and the tendency of the majority of the countries at the world body to voice anti-American views. On these matters they encountered different explanations and arguments from different diplomats. **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick said that the ''scapegoating of Israel'' had come about, at least in part, because of the ''condescension and indifference'' of member countries who did not try to stop it from happening.   Breaking Bad Habits **********''Countries failed to make clear early on, in the beginning of this pattern, that we take it very seriously,'' Mrs. Kirkpatrick said. ''It's harder to break bad habits and bad practices once they're entrenched than to prevent them from becoming entrenched.'' **********Aryeh Levin of the Israeli Mission said the United Nations, in attacking his country, demonstrated a ''despicable double standard.'' He voiced the fear that in time, the constant polemic attacks on Israel could result in the ''delegitimization'' of the country. **********When the Brooklyn visitors spoke to the representatives of Botswana and Pakistan, they heard about some of the animosity and frustration felt toward the United States by representatives of the third world. **********Mr. Legwaila of Botswana said that, in essence, Africans were ill disposed toward Communism. **********''You have to work very hard to turn an African into a Communist,'' he said. But he said feelings of frustration had been generated by the failure of the West to bring about any change in the apartheid system of racial separation in South Africa or to achieve independence for the disputed territory of South- West Africa, also known as Namibia.   Looking for AK-47's **********''Those failures have got people so frustrated that they go to Moscow looking for AK-47's,'' Mr. Legwaila said, referring to a Soviet rifle commonly used by guerrilla groups in southern Africa.  Riaz Mohammed Khan of the Pakistani Mission said the third world as a whole was not one-sided in its treatment of the superpowers. He pointed out, for example, that third world countries had criticized the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia. **********''It's a matter of perception,'' Mr. Khan said. **********Later in the corridor, one of the visitors, Bertha S. Goldstein, a retired schoolteacher, told Mr. Khan, ''You have a very shallow view, my friend.'' **********''The Palestinians have been played a dirty deal - listen to me - by their Arab brothers,'' she said. ''They have been left to rot in those refugee camps.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/23/world.body_text: **********The newly appointed secretary general of Liberia's ruling People's Redemption Council has been relieved of the job and dismissed from the army for setting conditions on his appointment, the Monrovia radio reported today. **********Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa had refused to take up the post assigned to him last Sunday ''until certain concerns had been addressed,'' the radio said in a broadcast monitored here. It gave no details of his demands. **********''The council is convinced that the behavior displayed by Brigadier General Quiwonkpa is an act of gross disrespect to the head of state, the People's Redemption Council and the entire nation,'' the radio said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.print_headline: Saudi Confers in Syria On Accord in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.body_text: **********A special Saudi envoy met today with President Hafez al-Assad, reportedly to try to soften Syria's opposition to the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement. **********Sheik Abdul-Aziz al-Toweijary, one of King Fahd's leading representatives on Arab issues, brought Mr. Assad a letter from the King and received a reply, the sources said. **********The sources said the Saudis were offering their good offices to overcome Syrian hostility to the accord and to persuade Syria to agree to withdraw its 40,000 soldiers in northern and eastern Lebanon simultaneously with the Israeli departure. **********But one Arab diplomat here said the Saudis were not unsympathetic to the Syrian position. He said Saudi Arabia and the other nations along the Persian Gulf ''have reservations concerning some clauses of the Lebanese-Israeli agreement.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/busin.main_headline: Business and the LawTamar Lewin Gray Area For Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/busin.print_headline: Business and the LawTamar Lewin Gray Area For Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/busin.body_text: **********ON black market goods, those that are stolen or counterfeited, the law is black and white. But on gray market goods - trademarked goods purchased abroad, imported into this country, and sold, usually without a warranty, for a lower price than those made for the United States market - the law is much less clear. **********The gray market in cameras, watches, perfumes and electronic goods has been growing rapidly for the last few years, as more and more discount stores scour the globe for odd lots of brand- name items they can offer at cut rates. **********While this produces bargain prices for buyers, it also produces trouble for the authorized United States distributors, not only because of the loss of sales, but also because of the loss of good will for their brand when something goes wrong with the camera or watch and the buyer asks for free repairs. **********Those who are fighting gray market imports have found themselves in a legal quagmire, as is apparent from the continuing battle over the importing of Japanese-made Mamiya cameras. **********The owner of the Mamiya trademark in this country has for some years been the Bell & Howell: Mamiya Company, which gets its cameras from Japan's Mamiya Camera Company by way of Mamiya's worldwide distributor, J. Osawa & Company. Bell & Howell: Mamiya - now known as Osawa - is the exclusive authorized distributor of Mamiya cameras in the United States. **********The same cameras, however, have also been imported into this country by the Masel Supply Company, which buys them from an international dealer in Hong Kong, who in turn has gotten them, perfectly lawfully, from Osawa. Last year, Bell & Howell: Mamiya won a court ruling blocking Masel's imports on the ground that the imports caused ''a substantial likelihood of confusion.'' **********''The business of selling Mamiya goods in the United States is the plaintiff's business,'' said United States District Judge Edward Neaher. ''It is plaintiff that defines the warranty and provides the repair services for the cameras it sells. It is plaintiff's warranty and assurances of quality that are signified by the Mamiya marks in this country.'' **********That victory was short-lived, though. Last month, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, overturned that ruling. ''There would appear to be little confusion, if any, as to the origin of the goods and no significant likelihood of damage to Bell & Howell: Mamiya's reputation since thus far it has not been shown that Masel's goods, which have a common origin of manufacture with Bell & Howell: Mamiya's goods, are inferior to those sold by Bell & Howell: Mamiya and are injuring Bell & Howell: Mamiya's reputation,'' the appeals court said. **********''Further, it does not appear that the lack of warranties accompanying Mamiya cameras sold by Masel amounts to irreparable injury, since the consumer can be made aware by, among other things, labels on the camera boxes or notices in advertisements as to whether the cameras are sold with or without warranties.'' **********Bell & Howell: Mamiya has asked for a rehearing. ''Confusion isn't the only issue,'' said John Kidd, a lawyer for Bell & Howell: Mamiya. ''You worry about what this is doing to the good will of your name. You don't want people deciding Mamiya is a bum brand because of problems they've had with cameras you didn't sell them.'' **********In other cases, though, the decisions have gone against gray market sales. ''The courts are not giving consistent answers,'' said Nick Allard, a Washington lawyer who is following the issue. ''It's an extremely uncertain area right now.'' The courts are not the only forum in which the gray market question has arisen, though. The Treasury Department is the object of intense lobbying by those who want it to adopt a new policy for Customs Service handling of gray market imports. **********The question of which gray market imports should be excluded revolves around the identity of the American trademark owner. If the owner of the United States trademark has bought the distribution rights from an unrelated foreign manufacturer, the law allows the American company to get an exclusion order from the Customs Service, forbidding any gray market goods to be brought into the country. **********According to Mr. Kidd, Bell & Howell: Mamiya has the only such exclusion order from the Customs Service. Lawyers for Masel, however, say the exclusion order should not have been issued, since Bell & Howell: Mamiya is closely connected with Japan's Mamiya and Osawa, and American subsidiaries of foreign manufacturers are not covered by the law. **********''Bell & Howell: Mamiya, Osawa and Mamiya are financially interlocked,'' said Nathan Lewin, the Washington lawyer who represents Masel. ''They are essentially the same company, and they shouldn't be able to get Customs Service protection. The law was designed to protect an independent American trademark owner who has invested money in promoting a brand, and becomes identified with that brand in this country, so that the value of the rights he bought would be undercut if someone else began selling the same goods in the United States. It's not supposed to cover the American subsidiary of a foreign manufacturer.'' **********Mr. Lewin says that, if the lower court's decision in the Mamiya case had been upheld, or if the Customs Service routinely issues exclusion orders in cases such as the Mamiya case, any foreign manufacturer would be able to set up an American subsidiary that would be able to keep out unauthorized goods and set unduly high prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/17/busin.body_text: **********UNTIL now, Compton Communications' advertising for Dexatrim, a weight-reduction aid, has been built on testimonials from users. The approach has been successful, helping the Thompson Medical Company product push to the top of its class and to double sales of the class in three years. Now a second prong is being added to the attack - the recommendation of pharmacists. **********Unlike the testimonial effort, which began in earnest on TV in 1979, the survey of pharmacists will run only in magazines. It will feature a smiling man in high-necked white coat holding up a box of Extra Strength Dexatrim that promises ''Lose Weight Fast,'' over the headline ''More Pharmacists Recommend Dexatrim to Help You Lose Weight.'' **********It should not have been too difficult for Thompson to line up support from the nation's pharmacists, since it has great strength among the drug chains. Since its start about 30 years ago, most of the company's marketing activity has been at the retail, rather than the consumer, level, with all sorts of trade deals that include merchandising allowances. Thompson brands are also known at retail for high profits per unit, or, as the trade calls it, ''high ringup.'' **********But according to Donald E. Lepone, Thompson's vice presidentmarketing, who was visiting the other day with Thomas P.  Lom, Compton's senior vice president-management supervisor, the contented and communicative users of Dexatrim all but forced the company into starting a consumer-advertising program. **********''When you get a letter from a consumer that says something like, 'Hey, your product has changed my life,' '' Mr. Lepone said, then you begin thinking that you ought to be telling people about the response. **********That was Compton's response, too, when it was invited to take over the assignment early in 1979 from Ted Bates & Company.  ''Compton is probably the leading real-people agency in the country,'' Mr. Lepone said, referring to the genre of advertising that it frequently creates for such clients as Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson. Indeed, its first TV spots for Dexatrim featured still photos of users and their voice-over comments. **********The ingredient that makes Dexatrim and its major competitors work as an appetite suppressant is the drug phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, which Mr. Lepone describes as ''the first truly effective drug available for weight loss without a prescription.'' **********Despite Thompson's enthusiasm for PPA, however, the United States Food and Drug Administration has not yet finished its own assessment of the drug. Although an agency panel cleared the drug for over-thecounter sale in 1979, it called last year for more research into PPA's possible link to high blood pressure. **********And Dr. William Gilbertson, director of the F.D.A.'s division of over-the-counter drugs, stressed recently that even though PPA had been declared safe by two panels, it was still under review by the agency. **********When the first panel cleared PPA in 1979, Thompson Medical was in a very good position to move. It was already firmly entrenched at retail, where it had installed racks, each identified as an ''Appetite Control Center,'' that displayed Dexatrim above competitive products. In addition it had strong co-op and point-of-sale advertising programs in place. **********Another help to sales came when Dexatrim, which was originally sold only in tablet form, took advantage of years of advertising for the Menley & James Contac cold remedy and introduced a timed-release capsule. But in 1980, Menley & James, a SmithKline subsidiary, capitalized on its own expertise and brought out Dietac, a similar product. Spending about $10 million for advertising that starred Bill Bixby, it quickly moved into second place in the category behind Dexatrim, which was spending only about $7 million or $8 million.  That sort of extravagance has ended. **********''They helped stimulate the category,'' said Mr. Lepone, whose own product has been stretched into line extensions - Extra Strength, Extra Strength Caffeine Free and Extra Strength Plus Vitamins. **********Meanwhile, the category, an estimated 90 percent of which is made up of PPA-based products, went from about $80 million in annual retail sales in 1978 to between $200 million and $250 million now. **********And in that same period, Dexatrim's wholesale sales and earnings more than tripled, from $30 million, and $2.7 million, to $91 million and $11.9 million. Nobody said that Thompson was also looking for a thin wallet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/world.main_headline: FIVE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES CRITICIZE REAGAN FOR AIR STRIKES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/world.print_headline: FIVE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES CRITICIZE REAGAN FOR AIR STRIKES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/world.body_text: **********Five Democratic Presidential candidates criticized the Reagan Administration today for the United States air strikes on Syrian positions in Lebanon. **********Former Senator George S. McGovern reacted to the air strikes and the killing of eight marines in Beirut by saying that ''step by step the United States is approaching war with Syria.'' **********''Ronald Reagan is compounding his mistakes in Lebanon rather than facing his original mistake of assigning marines to a sitting-duck role at the Beirut airport,'' Mr. McGovern said. **********''He has virtually consigned our marines as hostages of the Arab-Israeli conflict,'' the South Dakota Democrat declared. ''Those who have survived should be brought home immediately before they too fall victim to President Reagan's mishandling of American policy in that region.'' **********More Casualties Foreseen **********Mr. McGovern first called for bringing the marines home in September. The former senator said today that Marine casualties ''will grow as strikes and counterstrikes escalate. **********''Step by step, the United States is approaching war with Syria,'' he said. **********Earlier in the day, Senator Alan Cranston characterized President Reagan's approach to foreign policy as ''trigger-happy and reckless'' after learning of the attacks by carrier- based American aircraft on Syrian positions in Lebanon. **********Mr. Cranston said in regard to the attack on Syrian positions, ''When we are fired upon, it may be necessary to strike back, but we should not be in places where we invite attack.'' **********President Reagan's ''trigger-happy and reckless approach to foreign policy has landed us in more wars at once,'' the Californian said. He said he was referring to the presence of American troops in Lebanon and Grenada and to United States involvement in conflicts in Nicaragua and El Salvador.   Withdrawal of Marines Urged **********Mr. Cranston, who made his remarks at a forum for female state legislators in Coronado, Calif., said the marines should be withdrawn from Lebanon. He said that there was a ''U.S.-Soviet equation'' in the Middle East and that the United States bombing of Syrian positions posed a potential for conflict between the two countries because of the presence of Soviet advisers in Syria. **********Another of the candidates, Senator John Glenn of Ohio, said the United States ''should exercise the utmost caution and measure our response to this extremely dangerous situation very carefully.'' **********He added that he did not favor withdrawing the marines ''at this time or under these circumstances.'' **********''For nearly a year,'' Mr. Glenn said, ''I have warned against allowing the situation in Lebanon to deteriorate into a direct Syrian-American confrontation. I have called for clearly defining our mission. If the Administration considers a large and protracted battle with the Syrians in Lebanon an option, let them present their plan to the Congress and the American people. **********''If an American war in Lebanon is not the Administration's intention,'' he went on in a statement issued in Washington, ''then let's stop stumbling toward it.''  Hart Fears More Fighting **********Senator Gary Hart of Colorado said, ''It's almost inevitable that there will be an escalation of the conflict the longer we remain on Lebanese soil.'' **********''Our role in that country cannot and must not be a military role,'' said Mr. Hart, whose comments also came at the meeting in Coronado, Calif. ''It should be diplomatic and political. I'm deeply concerned that the Administration will increase the level of hostilities, particularly with the Syrians. I don't think its healthy.'' **********He also said the marines should be removed from Lebanon, adding, ''There are those in the Administration who invite conflict.''  Jackson Wants Marines Out **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson said the American presence ''is not neutral enough to be a peacekeeping factor.'' **********In an appearance on the NBC News program ''Meet The Press,'' he called for a United Nations force or a nonaligned force to replace the marines. ''We should not withdraw unilaterally,'' he said, ''but it is very clear, to me, that our presence there can only serve no good end.'' **********''This apparent escalation of tensions in the Middle East, a kind of declaration of war, is unwarranted,'' Mr. Jackson said. ''It is provocative. It adds to the further destabilization of the region. **********''I do not feel that it's justified, nor do I feel that we have the whole story,'' he went on. ''We simply, unless we intend to go much deeper into Lebanon militarily, should get out as quickly as we possibly can, before we find ourselves in a quagmire and cannot get out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/world.main_headline: SHULTZ SAYS U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD WON'T HURT JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/world.print_headline: SHULTZ SAYS U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD WON'T HURT JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/01/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz promised Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan today that the United States would never negotiate an agreement with the Soviet Union on reducing medium-range missiles in Europe at the expense of the security of Japan and other non-European countries. **********John Hughes, Mr. Shultz's spokesman, said Japan's concerns over a compromise developing at the Geneva arms control talks that might lead to a shift in Soviet missile strength from Europe to Asia played a major part in the talks that Mr. Shultz held with Mr. Nakasone and with Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe. **********Japanese officials, alarmed at reports that some West European leaders are seeking an interim solution that would lead to a reduction, but not a dismantling, of all Soviet SS-20 missiles, have become increasingly outspoken against any accord that would permit Moscow to redeploy SS-20's in Soviet Asia. **********Mr. Hughes said that Mr. Shultz ''made the point that the United States would never agree to something that might appear good for Europe but was bad for the rest of the world.'' **********Strong Support for 'Zero Option' **********''The United States approached arms control on an international basis, with its global responsibilities in mind,'' Mr. Shultz told Mr. Nakasone, according to Mr. Hughes. **********Japanese Foreign Ministry officials said after Mr. Nakasone's hourlong meeting with Mr. Shultz that the Prime Minister thanked the United States for its understanding of Japan's concern and that he was very pleased and satisfied. **********Mr. Nakasone told Mr. Shultz, the Japanese officials said, that he strongly supported the ''zero-zero option'' first proposed by President Reagan in November 1981. **********Under that approach, which is officially endorsed by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the United States has offered to forego the deployment of 572 new medium-range missiles in Europe, due to begin late this year, if the Soviet Union agrees to dismantle all of its approximately 340 SS-20's and some 260 older SS-4's and SS-5's. **********The SS-20, each of which has three warheads, is a mobile missile, meaning it can be moved easily from place to place. Of the 340 SS-20's, about 250 are in European parts of the Soviet Union and 90 in the Asian regions. The Japanese have backed the ''zero option'' because if it were agreed to by Moscow, it would mean the elimination of the 90 SS-20's in Asia as well as the larger numbers in Europe. Upset by Nitze Approach **********Mr. Hughes said that Mr. Shultz assured Mr. Nakasone and Mr. Abe that the United States stood by the zero approach and would not agree to anything that would lead to an increase in Soviet missile strength in Asia. **********One Foreign Ministry official said Japan was upset at reports that Paul H. Nitze, the chief American negotiator at the talks on mediumrange missiles in Geneva, had informally worked out an understanding last summer by which the Soviet Union would reduce to 75 its missiles in Europe and freeze the number in Asia, thereby seeming to allow the Russians to have a more powerful force in Asia than in Europe. **********The strong support by Japan for the zero option has complicated the arms control picture, because Vice President Bush is in West Europe to listen to West European leaders who are urging Washington to move away from the zero approach to one that would lead to some American missiles being deployed and the Soviet level in Europe sharply reduced. **********The Japanese, who will not allow any nuclear weapons on their soil, now appear at odds with the Europeans.  But Mr. Hughes was careful to state that Mr. Shultz did not promise not to reach a compromise, only not to secure an accord that would worsen the security situation in Asia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Hewlett-Packard introduced the first personal computer with a touch screen two weeks ago, it was a major vote of approval for a technology that had been around for more than a decade without much success. **********''I had a companywide celebration last Friday,'' said Arthur B. Carroll, chief executive of Carroll Touch Technology in Champaign, Ill., a manufacturer of touch screens and a pioneer in the field. ''I struggled for 10 years to get the stamp of approval on touch technology and they just did it.'' **********Mr. Carroll said Hewlett-Packard's decision had already sparked interest in touch technology from other computer makers and would bring growth to the touch screen business, which, he said, has less than $10 million a year in sales. **********But others say the outlook is still touch and go. The same drawbacks that have hurt touch screens in the past might doom Hewlett-Packard's screen to being merely the gimmick of a company that wanted to distinguish its product in a crowded market. **********Touch screens allow the user to perform tasks by touching words, boxes or pictures on the screen, rather than having to type commands. On the HP 150, for instance, changing the shading of a wedge in a pie chart entails pointing to the bar and pointing to a box containing the desired new shading. **********Hewlett-Packard made its screen touch-sensitive by lining its edge with tiny infrared light emitters and detectors, so that the front of the screen is crossed by an invisible grid of beams. The computer can determine the position of the finger on the screen by seeing which horizontal and vertical light beams are blocked. **********Other techniques are used by other companies. One is to coat the screen with a transparent membrane that contains wires or conductive coating, so that pressing the screen completes a circuit at a particular point. Another is to measure the time it takes sound signals to travel from the edge of the screen to the finger and back. **********Pointing can be a more natural way of using a computer than typing commands. ''Although it may not be polite, we've all had a lot of practice pointing,'' said Jimmy Sutton, a Hewlett-Packard software engineer. **********But those who are doing word processing or financial calculations on a spreadsheet have to type the text or numbers anyway and might find it bothersome to leave the keyboard to touch the screen occasionally. That is especially true as they gain experience. A novice using the Visicalc spreadsheet program might find it easier to touch a box on the screen labeled ''exit'' than to type ''/SQ.'' But once someone learns the command it is easier to stay on the keyboard. **********''Frequent users would rather type six or eight characters, even, than reach up and touch the screen and come down again,'' said Ben Shneiderman, head of the Human/Computer Interaction Laboratory at the University of Maryland. **********There are other drawbacks as well. The pointing hand obscures the text, and the finger is too bulky to pinpoint single letters. The Federal Aviation Administration, which tested touch screens for use by air traffic controllers, found yet two more problems: weary arms and dirty screens. **********''Your arm gets pretty tired; after a couple of hours of use, the guys who were testing it complained,'' said Gerard Spanier of the agency's Technical Center in Atlantic City. Also, he said, finger oil ruined the delicate films the F.A.A. put on its screens to prevent glare. **********Touch screens have plenty of competition. Apple's Lisa uses a mouse, a handheld device that slides along a desk. As the mouse moves, the cursor on the screen moves accordingly. A user can point to much smaller objects with a mouse than with a finger, the screen is not obscured, and the arms do not get as tired. But the mouse has its own drawbacks, not the least of which is that a clear space is needed next to the computer. Using a mouse also requires leaving the keyboard, and also might require taking one's eyes off the screen. **********Another approach is the touch tablet, in which the user slides a finger or points to particular spots on a separate pad. This allows some of the advantages of both the touch screen and the mouse. The Gavilan portable computer uses such a pad. Koala Technologies and the newcomer, Chalk Board Inc., make touch tablets geared toward home computer use by children. **********''In the short term, you're more likely to see those appear than you are a touch screen,'' said Robert R. Highfill, marketing and sales manager for Elographics Inc. of Oak Ridge, Tenn., which makes both touch screens and touch pads. **********Touch screens are finding uses where the computer is used for short durations by novices, such as the computerized public information displays at Walt Disney's Epcot Center. They might also be useful for education, especially for young children. Control Data's Plato computerized education system was a pioneer in touch screen use. **********Touch screens can also allow someone in a high stress situation to go through a sequence of actions quickly without taking his eyes off the screen. At the American Stock Exchange, a specialist can execute a trade by touching the order as it comes up on the screen. A list of possible prices appears and he touches a price. Then a list of brokerage firms appears and he touches the name of the buyer or seller. **********Hewlett-Packard is confident that touch screens will catch on for general use. It has wisely assured that anything that can be done by touching the screen can also be done by typing on the keyboard, so that the touch screen does not become a nuisance to experienced users. It has also managed to get many popular programs, such as Wordstar and Visicalc, modified to take advantage of the touch features. In the long run, the success of touch screens is likely to depend on the continued development of software that takes advantage of touch features.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/world.main_headline: INVASION TROOPS TRAINED TO MAKE SURPRISE RAIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/world.print_headline: INVASION TROOPS TRAINED TO MAKE SURPRISE RAIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/world.body_text: **********The United States troops who invaded Grenada early this morning consisted of marines and Army Rangers, units trained for such operations. Rangers are soldiers specially trained to fight in small groups and to undertake surprise raids in any terrain or weather. **********Government officials said in press briefings today that about 700 Rangers and 1,200 marines of a Marine amphibious unit landed in the island. The officials said some of the Rangers parachuted into the Point Salines area near the southern end of the island. If so, this would be the first combat jump by United States airborne troops since the Vietnam War, when such jumps were a sparingly used tactic. **********The marines were landed by helicopter in a more conventional air-mobile assault, officials said. Some Rangers were taken in by planes after the Point Salines airstrip had been secured by paratroops. About 600 marines remained in reserve on the helicoper carrier and amphibious ship Guam.   2 Ranger Battalions **********There are two operational Ranger battalions in the United States Army, the First Battalion stationed at Fort Stewart, S.C., and the Second Battalion stationed at Fort Lewis, Wash. Together, the units make up the 75th Ranger Regiment, which represents all the operational Ranger troops in the Army. **********Many other officers and enlisted men in the Army go through the nine-week Ranger training course and are then assigned to more conventional units. There are also mobile Ranger training teams that give special training to troops in infantry and armored divisions. **********The Rangers' name is derived from Roger's Rangers, a group of expert woodsmen commanded by Maj. Robert Rogers in the French and Indian Wars. The term was subsequently applied to United States military units from time to time in the Revolutionary War and in the 19th century. **********In World War II, six Ranger battalions were formed to undertake operations similar to those of the British commando units. Ranger companies were reactivated in 1950, but then for a time Ranger-trained troops were scattered throughout regular units rather than in Ranger units. **********The Rangers are light infantry who carry little in the way of heavy support weapons. All are jump-qualified parachutists. Those in Ranger units or training units wear a distinctive black beret when not in combat. **********The Marine amphibious unit that is fighting in Grenada had been scheduled to go to Lebanon and relieve the Marine unit in Beirut. An amphibious unit has five tanks, five 155-millimeter howitzers, eight 81-millimeter mortars and four Cobra helicopter gunships. The infantry companies are also equipped with amphibious armored personnel carriers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1983; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan, in his second Economic Report, voiced strong support for the Federal Reserve's efforts to foster recovery, rejecting charges that the Fed's current policy is inflationary. His chief economic adviser, Martin S. Feldstein, said recovery appears to have begun. (Page A1.) The report asserted that U.S. trade problems were not the result of other countries' unfair trade practices.  (D19.) **********Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Fed, said that new I.M.F. lending resources for debtor nations constitute a ''bail-in,'' not a ''bailout.'' Answering Congressional critics of the role of banks in the third world debt crisis, Mr. Volcker said a boost in the fund's lending authority would help assure recovery in the U.S. (D1.) **********Sporadic violence continued in the independent truckers' strike, with more than 150 vehicles reportedly hit by gunfire. Meanwhile, the first delays began to appear in supplies of fresh produce. But a spot check showed that most truckers were still on the job. (A1.) **********The Administration suspended an auto tire grading standard that gives consumers data for comparing the durability of tires. Officials agreed with industry that the system was unscientific. (A1.) **********Local steel union leaders approved new bargaining proposals suggesting that concessions may be necessary. (A16.) International **********A $30 million loan to Nicaragua is sure to be approved soon over U.S. objections, according to Inter-American Development Bank delegates. They said Argentina and Chile, which sided with the U.S.  twice before when the loan was blocked, will now back it. (D1.) **********Trade between the U.S. and China fell 5.5 percent in 1982, to $5.2 billion, according to American figures released in Peking as Secretary of State George P. Shultz met with Chinese officials.  (D11.) After seeing Mr. Shultz, Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian referred only obliquely to current trade friction between the two nations.  (A6.) Companies **********Exxon and Mobil said they are reducing by $1 a barrel the amount they are willing to pay for domestically produced oil. This brings all of the largest American concerns to $31 a barrel. While the companies held the move was needed to maintain profits, analysts said the lower prices might be passed on to the consumer. (D1.) **********Punitive damages of $300,000 were assessed by a Federal jury against Aetna Casualty for having wrongfully refused to pay an insurance claim to Source Commodities. It was believed to be the first time an insured had won such damages against an insurer. (D1.) **********Lockheed reported earnings of $62.9 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a $360.5 million loss in the 1981 period. TRW's net rose 17.1 percent. Hanna Mining lost $65.3 million, versus earnings of $4.2 million a year ago. (D4.) **********Allied Van Lines cut its rates 9 percent, a move that could trigger price wars in the troubled industry. (D4.) **********The United States Satellite Television Corporation said the Prudential Insurance Company of America invested $45 million in it, becoming U.S. Satellite's largest investor. (D17.) **********Official Airline Guides demonstrated a new data bank that displays on any desktop computer terminal the latest air fares and flight times for every route in the world. (D5.) **********The S.E.C. accused 13 people of making an illegal $700,000 profit by using insider information while trading in Phoenix Resources stock. The defendants included the former chairman of Texas International and the University of Oklahoma's football coach. (D6.) Markets **********Stock prices closed slightly higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 2.85 points, to 1062.64 (D8.) Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply, while yields for notes and bonds declined.  (D13.) (D13.) The dollar was mixed, while gold prices rose $3.50 an ounce, to $506, in New York. (D14.) Silver futures prices soared.  (D14.) Today's Columns **********The Mercedes air-bag system has functioned flawlessly in Europe since 1980, with just one user reported hurt in an accident, and he was not wearing a seat belt. The full procedure - impact-detectioninflation-deflation - takes less than a second.  Technology.
