https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.main_headline: HARD-HIT SONY GIRDS FOR A FIGHT IN THE AMERICAN ELECTRONICS MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.print_headline: HARD-HIT SONY GIRDS FOR A FIGHT IN THE AMERICAN ELECTRONICS MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.body_text: **********TOKYO NOT long ago, the Sony Corporation seemed the ultimate consumer electronics company and the darling of Wall Street, and its pioneering Betamax video cassette recorder promised to lead the industry's glamorous new video sector. **********But a bad economy, tough competition on its home turf and a misreading of the video cassette market has changed all that. Today the company, armed with a host of new products and an expanded research and development budget, is fighting hard to regain its corporate confidence - and its American market share. **********It will not be a battle easily won. Sony reported that profits in the first half ended April 30 plunged 66 percent from a year earlier, to $45 million. The drop was due mostly to severe price-cutting and sagging sales overseas, particularly in the United States, which accounts for more than 25 percent of Sony's total revenues. The disappointing showing followed an even steeper decline in net income in the last quarter of 1982. **********While Sony predicts that earnings will improve in the second half of this year, profit for 1983 will be well below that of a year earlier. As one Sony executive acknowledged: ''The damage has never been this severe'' - a comment reflected in a company proposal to freeze managers' wages and suspend customary bonuses to senior executives. **********Yet, on the record, most Sony officials maintain that the recent troubles are cyclical and that the company is well on its way to recovering its former vigor. ''Sony will come off the bottom,'' asserted Kimio Okura, a managing director at the company's headquarters here. ''We are not so anxious about the future of our operations.'' **********That there are any doubts at all has particular significance for a company long regarded as the consummate innovator in consumer electronics. Sony - perhaps more than any other company - has been responsible for transforming the American view of ''made in Japan'' from the code phrase for shoddy merchandise that it was in the 50's to the seal of distinction that it is today. **********It was also a symbol - to Americans in particular - of the strengths of Japanese industry: Its ability to make high-quality, ingenious, affordable products, and, by inference, the weaknesses of many companies in the United States, which in recent years have been unable to do the same. Besides the Betamax, its sales mainstay, Sony is probably best known for its Walkman portable radio and its Trinitron color television set. **********DESPITE Sony's heritage, however, some analysts maintain that its present difficulties have done permanent damage to its future competitiveness, especially in the United States. Ominous signs are already apparent. Sony's overall American market share in video cassette recorders has fallen to 13 percent in 1982 from 14.2 percent a year earlier; in 1978 it commanded 27.5 percent of the then-embryonic business. **********Meanwhile, worldwide sales of Beta recorders by all makers - led by Sony - have also declined. Beta machines, which accounted for almost 62 percent of Japanese video cassette production six years ago, now represent just 28 percent of total video cassette sales. At present, Betamax recorders account for a sizable 42 percent of Sony's sales. **********Sony's slump comes at a time when sales of video cassette recorders in general are rebounding strongly. According to the Electronic Industries Association, a trade group, sales in the United States are expected to reach a record 4 million - nearly a 100 percent increase over last year's figure. **********How much of this expanding American market Sony will garner, however, is much in question, especially in light of increasingly fierce competition from powerhouse companies, such as Matsushita, and a move in consumer interest toward lower-priced video cassettes. Most analysts agree that new business will come mostly outside Japan from sales of less expensive models. (Sales of audio products in Japan fell about 35 percent last year, to $4.4 billion.) **********Sony, which makes mainly higher priced models, so far has not been able to increase sales volume enough to make up for the lower prices it has set for its Betamax line. This year, for example, the company reduced some prices as much as 40 percent. **********The move has prompted some to wonder whether Sony is still a growth company. ''It's over for Sony,'' declared one analyst at a large Japanese securities firm. ''The company's best days are behind it.'' **********Such a comment would have been nearly unthinkable just a few years ago. The technological leader, Sony was able to command a premium for its wares in the marketplace and refrain from price-cutting, allowing it to keep its profit margins up. While those days may be over, Sony's initial position had won it an enduring following not only among foreign investors, who hold 43 percent of the company's stock, but also among the American buying public. **********To help regain its former stature, Sony, which does 70 percent of its business outside Japan, has a diverse product assortment to offer consumers over the next few years. This includes a modified video cassette recorder with improved sound quality and a camera that can record up to three hours of home movies. **********But the fast pace of technological development, especially in Japan, is diminishing the value of Sony's traditional strength: being first. Although Sony may still be the innovator of the industry, giant Matsushita Electric, considered the I.B.M. of con sumer electronics, appears to have the muscle to dominate any sector it enters. **********So it went with the Betamax. Sony was first to offer a video cassette recorder for home use, in 1975, but Matsushita was soon in the game with its less expensive - and incompatible - VHS format. Matsushita and Japan Victor, of which it owns 52 percent, easily made rapid gains in the market. **********One reason was that the two companies, unlike name-proud Sony, had no qualms about offering their equipment for relabeling and resale by numerous American and European companies, a route that also spared the two VHS producers from marketing, distribution and inventory costs. **********Today, Matsushita, which now controls 17.5 percent of the United States video cassette market, supplies recorders sold under such American brands as General Electric, Magnavox, GTE-Sylvania, J.C. Penney and Curtis Mathes. And VHS systems by all makers hold 70 percent of the market. By contrast, Sony - which supplies equipment to only one American company, Zenith - has seen its share rapidly plunge. (The RCA Corporation is now the biggest presence in the American market, with 22 percent.) **********In addition, the VHS manufacturers kept updating their equipment - with longer playing time, for example. Sony was slow to react as demand for its Betamax slackened. In fact, it kept production going at full speed for almost a year after its competitor had throttled production back to recession levels, in the expectation that its premium product would just naturally regain its market dominance. **********''Unfortunately for Sony, the gamble did not pay off,'' said Darrel E. Whitten, an analyst for Prudential Bache Securities Inc., Tokyo. **********Sony was forced to that conclusion itself last fall, after a disastrous fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, saw net income dip 85 percent, to $10 million from $66 million in the 1981 period. Revenues also declined, to $1.1 billion last year from $1.2 billion in the previous year. **********The company applied the knife, slashing production of video cassette recorders in November and December to half its capacity, 100,000 units a month. Inventory was shrunk 25 percent, to $1.1 billion. ''That is a very proper level of inventories, about three months worth of sales,'' Mr. Okura said. ''The adjustment is complete.'' **********That Sony did not make this adjustment sooner may reflect corporate thinking that has been lulled by success. **********''Sony is still definitely a growth company,'' insisted Mark Hassenberg, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. But Mr. Hassenberg believes that it will take some time for Sony's roster of new products to offset the declining profitability of the video cassette recorder business. **********Sony, however, has not given up the fight yet. It still hopes to regain the lead in video cassettes by leapfrogging into the next generation of technology. The device of the future will use eight-millimeter tape rather than the current half-inch width. This is by agreement among more than 100 companies that met last March in an effort to avoid the confusion of formats that developed in the half-inch market. **********Once again, Sony was the front-runner in developing the eight-millimeter device. And industry analysts expect Sony to be the first to market an eight-millimeter video camera and recorder - which they expect eventually to replace the present recorders - possibly as early as 1985. **********Sony may have sacrificed some of its edge in waiting for the standards. But the alternative is one it can no longer consider: Without agreed-on standards, Matsushita once again could effectively set them itself, owing to its heft in the marketplace. In 1982, Matsushita's worldwide sales were $14 billion. **********''The problem with Sony has been Matsushita,'' Michael Connors, an analyst for Jardine Fleming Investment Services Inc., said flatly. **********Sony will try to keep up sales with two new video products, Betamovie and Beta Hi-Fi. The Betamovie is a camera unit, weighing five-and- a-half pounds, that can record more than three hours of home movies, which then may be played back on a Betamax set. Betamovie, which uses conventional half-inch tape, is just coming on the market in Japan and will be introduced in the United States and Europe in the fall. In America, the unit will cost $1,500. Sony says it already has back orders for 30,000 Betamovie sets in Japan. ''We can't keep up with demand,'' Mr. Okura said. **********BUT analysts believe that Betamovie is essentially an interim product, before the eight-millimeter camera and recorder, and given its high price and bulkiness one that will probably have a limited market. **********Beta Hi-Fi, also introduced in the past few months, is a video cassette recorder with improved sound quality selling for $1,500 a set. Matsushita and Victor are expected to respond soon with VHS versions of recorders with enhanced audio performance. **********At the same, Sony has yet another product up its sleeve: the compact audio disk. The 4.7-inch silvery disks are said to produce sound of unusual clarity. The disks employ beams of light, instead of conventional needles, to replay recorded music. Sony developed the product jointly with N.V. Philips of the Netherlands, it was introduced in Japan last October, and sales are running ahead of the early expectations. **********Sony is bringing its compact disk player to market in the United States this summer, with its CDP 101 model priced at $900. The disks will cost about $15 apiece, considerably more than records. Hindering the popularity of the compact disk players at the start will be the shortage of recorded disks. Today, there are 530 titles available and, Sony officials say, there will be 1,000 by the end of this year. To increase the number of titles, CBS/Sony, a joint venture of the two companies, plans to begin manufacturing disks next year at a plant in Terre Haute, Ind. **********Most analysts say that the long- range potential for the disks is huge, since they will probably replace conventional records. Still, there are several Japanese companies that now have disk players of their own. Just how the market will be carved up remains to be seen, analysts stress. **********The same caveat applies to other fields in which Sony has been an innovator. In August 1981, for example, Sony created a stir by announcing an electronic still camera, called Movica, that uses no photographic film. Last April, 20 companies, including Sony, agreed on specifications for the magnetic disk to be used in such electronic cameras. Most analysts agree that this will be a sizable market. But how well Sony will fare against such companies as Canon and Eastman Kodak is uncertain. **********At Sony's Tokyo headquarters, 1983 is a year of ''correction and investment'' that will lay the groundwork for future growth, according to executives there. Despite the profit drop, research and development spending will increase 20 percent this year. Sony's research and development budget, at 8.5 percent of sales, is twice the industry average. ''We're operating this company on a long- term basis,'' said Sumio Sano, a general manager in the executive office. **********For the short term, things have brightened somewhat. The American economic recovery came through with an increase in demand, And in response, Sony has kicked production back up to 250,000 video cassette recorders a month from 150,000 the year before. Sony production this year should reach nearly 2.3 million units, up from 1.9 million in 1982 - although that is not enough to offset Sony's share of a market that is increasing at a much faster pace. **********In any case, Sony's second half will be better than the first half of fiscal 1983 because the inventory correction has been completed. Still, Prudential- Bache estimates that for 1983 Sony's net income worldwide will be off 40 percent, to $115 million, at recent exchange rates. Sony officials see a decline of 35 percent. Whatever the outcome, Sony probably will not be able to surpass its record profit of $289 million, reached in the year ended Oct. 31, 1980, until 1985. **********Some analysts say this may well be a good time to buy Sony's stock, for those investors with patience. They recall that in the late 70's, before the company introduced the Walkman, industry watchers also said that Sony's management had become ingrained and questioned the appeal of its new products. The stock closed Friday at $13.25, unchanged from Thursday's close. During the past year, it has traded in a range from $11 to $17.25. **********''Buy on the weakness would be our recommendation for long-term accounts,'' said Takeshi Tanikawa, general manager of institutional research at the Daiwa Securities Company here. **********But many believe it is time to rethink Sony's image. ''Sony will be in there as a solid competitor in the future,'' said Mr. Whitten of Prudential-Bache. ''But the conventional view of Sony was that it was a high- growth company, and that will change.'' **********AT A GLANCE Sony    All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data Three months ended April 3019831982 Revenues$1,082,000$1,123,000Net income21,00047,000Earnings per share$0.09$0.20 Year ended Oct. 3119821981 Revenues$4,578,000$4,863,000Net income186,000307,000Earnings per share$0.81$1.34 Main Lines of Business Contribution to 1982 revenues Videotape recorders 27%Television sets 24%Audio equipment 23%Other 11% Total assets, Oct. 31, 1982 $5,042,000Current assets *3,472,000Current liabilities *2,678,000Long-term debt *231,000Stock price, August 12, 1983Y.S.E. consolidated close 13 1/4Stock price, 52-week range 11-17 1/4Employees, Oct. 31, 1982 43,126Headquarters Tokyo

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM EDITORIALS ON THE BOMBING OF MARINE HEADQUARTERS IN ; BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM EDITORIALS ON THE BOMBING OF MARINE HEADQUARTERS IN ; BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.body_text: **********The Philadelphia Inquirer **********Tragically it is time to recognize that there are honorable tasks on this earth that cannot be completed. That if there were 16,000 U.S. Marines committed to peacekeeping in Lebanon - instead of the 1,600 who were there before 6:20 Sunday morning and those who now remain alive - they could not impose order, political stability, on the warring, hating, barbarous factions that are there. Nor, finally, could 160,000. **********The Boston Globe **********Whatever comes of investigations, grieving American families know only that their loved ones died in a helpless way in a seemingly hopeless cause. **********The Central Maine Morning Sentinel, Waterville, Me. **********All the choices are bad, but we think those which include leaving the Lebanese to fend for themselves are worse than those in which we stay. **********The Kansas City Times **********If the President cannot outline the need for American troops in Lebanon and explain why they must stay there for a while in the light of the present rate of sacrifice, then the Marines might as well come home now. What happened in Vietnam a decade ago has not been forgotten by forces in the world that would gain immensely from American isolationism. The country waits on Mr. Reagan for information, reassurance and direction. **********The Milwaukee Sentinel **********The opportunity for an honorable withdrawal may, in fact, have passed. It is tragic folly, however, to leave our men in Lebanon under the vulnerable circumstances that now exist. Practically speaking, the proximity, numbers and experience of Israeli forces give them a much better chance to put a lid on the current situation in Lebanon. And given the history of U.S. assistance to the Israelis, it is only fair that they be called upon to assist our Marines. **********The St. Louis Post-Dispatch **********Sending in the Marines was a gamble that could only pay off in the original terms of helping to establish a peaceful Lebanon, if indeed that is possible. At this point, the administration ought to be clear on what it really wants in that tragic little country. **********The Atlanta Constitution **********If the choice is to pack up and leave, then the consequence easily could become a Syrian-Israeli war over Lebanon - in the short term less costly of American lives, of course, but risking in the long run an extremely dangerous U.S.-Soviet confrontation in which neither superpower feels it can afford to see its regional client humiliated, or even frustrated. And in the course, Lebanon would be even more grievously bloodied than it already has been. In such set of bad choices, and active U.S. role would appear to be more responsible, not least for the Lebanese, who otherwise face the prospect of interminable, multisided civil war and probable partition. **********The Lincoln (Neb.) Journal **********For the mourning moment, with flag at half-staff, it is steady as she goes for the United States and the Reagan Administration. But the urgency for diplomatic progress is now in sharper focus than ever. **********The Minneapolis Star and Tribune **********Despite the sorrow, the peacekeepers will continue - for a time - trying to maintain an island of reason in Lebanon's seas of madness. But Sunday's tragedy adds bloody weight to the argument that the time should be short. **********The Washington Post **********For a power with America's responsibilities, it is inconceivable to hand the bombers the victory they sought by pulling the Marines out. American influence throughout the region could collapse. **********USA Today **********We are caught in a cruel vise. We cannot flee Lebanon and leave it to the vultures who now rejoice over the torn flesh of our fallen troops. Nor can we turn our Marines into warriors killing in the name of peace. We must, of course, continue to press for the involvement of a United Nations peacekeeping force that would allow us to withdraw. **********The St. Paul Pioneer Press **********We're not ready yet to join the chorus of those calling for the President to bring back the Marines. With reconciliation dialogue expected to begin soon in Geneva, there remains hope that the warring factions can at least begin to lower the tensions and move toward a stable government. **********The Baltimore Sun **********Any U.S. withdrawal under pressure from Lebanon could unleash conflicts and upheavals beyond prediction. Therefore, the Reagan Administration must redeploy and protect the Marines in Beirut in ways that constitute a show of strength, not weakness - and in ways that reassure a troubled people. **********The Sacramento (Calif.) Bee **********The tragic death of more than 200 U.S. Marines and French soldiers emphasize anew the need for the White House to spell out clearly to Congress and the American people just why the Marines are remaining in a dangerous, exposed defensive posture that will inevitably cost more lives. **********The Anniston (Ala.) Star **********Should the Marines remain in Beirut? Only if the situation allows the international force to perform its original function. The Lebanese factions are scheduled to meet in Geneva this week to try for some sort of national reconciliation. If this process begins and seems to hold some hope for peace and unity the Marines should remain and help. If, however, the meeting doesn't take place, or fails in its purpose, the Marines should come home. They can make no contribution during continued civil war in Lebanon. **********The Greensboro (N.C.) Daily News **********If the President does not change course he risks a Vietnam-style commitment. Instead of using the Marines to help carry out his Middle Eastern policy, he may begin to shape his Middle Eastern policy around the Marines. The President can avoid that tragic state by extricating the Marines from Lebanese soil as quickly as it can honorably be done.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/07/world.print_headline: KOHL AND HIS COALITION WIN DECISIVELY IN WEST GERMANY; U.S. AIDES FEEL REASSURANCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/07/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition won a decisive mandate Sunday to govern West Germany for the next four years. **********In a parliamentary election that turned to a considerable extent on the question of steadfastness to the Atlantic alliance, Mr. Kohl's pro-American Christian Democrats captured 244 seats in the 498-member lower house with 48.8 percent of the popular vote. **********According to the official provisional results announced by the Federal Election Office, the small Free Democratic Party, the junior partner in the Kohl Government, took 34 seats with 6.9 percent of the popular vote, guaranteeing the coalition a solid majority. Severe Setback for Socialists **********The opposition Social Democrats, who had accused Mr. Kohl of seeking a mandate to station American medium-range missiles in West Germany, suffered what is regarded as their most humiliating setback since 1961, winning only 38.2 percent of the vote for 193 seats. **********The four-year-old Green Party, which favors withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and opposes deployment of any new American missiles in West Germany, won representation in Parliament for the first time, with 5.6 percent of the vote, just above the 5 percent requirement. It will have 27 seats in the house. **********Under the country's proportional representation system, the razorthin success of the Greens prevented the Christian Democrats from winning an absolute majority in Parliament. But, led by the affable Mr. Kohl, the Christian Democrats fell only narrowly short of Konrad Adenauer's majority landslide in 1957, which has never been matched. Parliament's Size Increased **********As a result of the shape of Sunday's vote and the distribution of so-called first and second ballots, the size of the lower house was increased from an originally projected 496 members to 498. It is not unusual for the chamber's size to change this way in the course of an election. **********''Honest politics is persuasive politics,'' said the 52-year-old Mr. Kohl, beaming as his supporters surged around him in the Christian Democrats' Bonn headquarters. ''I can say that our citizens are a lot more clever than many of our politicians.'' **********Later, on national television, Mr. Kohl explained the sweep in these terms: ''The people of our country have put their hopes in the coalition of the middle, that we can turn the economy around. **********''The second thing is that we have a believable politics,'' said the Chancellor, who took office five months ago as a result of a parliamentary switch of allegiances. ''We have only promised what we can deliver. We have spoken the bitter truth.'' **********Hans-Jochen Vogel, the 57-year-old Social Democratic leader, conceded the loss, a harsh reversal for a party that until last fall had governed West Germany for 13 years in coalition with the Free Democrats. **********''This is a defeat,'' said the urbane Mr. Vogel amid the gloom at his party's headquarters. ''As our candidate I am in great measure responsible for this defeat.'' He said that ''massive help'' from West German industrialists had contributed to the Christian Democrats' triumph, as had popular belief that the economy was on the upswing. Coalition to Continue **********For Mr. Kohl the continuation of the coalition with the Free Democrats has considerable advantage. A Christian Democratic majority in Parliament would have made it virtually inevitable that Franz Josef Strauss, the ambitious right-wing Bavarian, would be given the key portfolio of foreign affairs. **********Even so, Mr. Strauss, bolstered by an impressive 60 percent of the popular vote in Bavaria, appeared likely to demand concessions at the expense of the Free Democrats led by Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Foreign Minister. **********Asked by a reporter in Munich if he was coming to Bonn as a Cabinet minister, Mr. Strauss remarked jokingly: ''I am flying to Bonn tomorrow.'' But neither he nor Mr. Kohl allowed himself to be drawn into discussions about what promise to be difficult Cabinetbuilding talks in the days ahead. **********Though the issue of stationing a new generation of medium-range missiles played an important role in the campaign, opinion polls and other indicators suggested that the sharp swing to the Christian Democrats had grown largely out of a conviction that the conservative coalition could stimulate business confidence and economic growth. Unemployment at Record Level **********Both the Christian Democrats and the Free Democrats told voters that a return of the Social Democrats to power, most likely in coalition with the Greens, would cause panic among industrialists and lead to a big increase in unemployment, which now stands at a record 2.5 million. Peter Glotz, the Social Democrats' party secretary, charged angrily Sunday night that businessmen had put pressure on their employees to vote for the coalition. **********The extent of the Christian Democrats' victory was suggested by returns from the the industrial heartland of the Ruhr, where Mr.  Kohl's party outpolled the Social Democrats, usually the strongest party there. The Infas polling organization said that nationwide some two million voters who normally supported the Social Democrats had switched to Mr. Kohl's party. **********The Social Democrats, who dropped 4.7 points from their 42.9 percent of the popular vote in the 1980 elections, were handicapped by Mr. Vogel's relative obscurity at the center stage of national politics. The former Justice Minister was named as his party's candidate for chancellor only last October after Helmut Schmidt's Government was toppled. **********Mr. Schmidt was returned to Parliament Sunday from his Hamburg district with 55.6 percent of the vote. Election Post-Mortems **********In the aftermath of the election defeat, some Social Democrats suggested that their party had too openly flirted with the anti-NATO Greens, by hinting during the campaign that a coalition with them was thinkable. Georg Leber, a former Social Democratic Defense Minister, said Sunday night that Mr. Vogel's campaign had ''fully miscarried'' because he had failed to separate the party from the Greens. **********Despite their reputation as defenders of farmers, forests and rivers, the Greens polled their greatest number of votes among young people in big cities. One analysis indicated that they had drawn about 8 percent of the vote in metropolitan centers and half that in small towns and rural areas. **********As the early returns filtered in Sunday night, it appeared that the Greens would slip below the 5 percent level needed for representation in Parliament, giving the Christian Democrats an absolute majority. Angrily, Otto Schilly, a Green leader, declared to cheers from followers that ''extraparliamentary activity is more important to us than parliamentary activity.'' Drive Against Missiles Planned **********But when computer projections showed the young party stabilizing at above 5 percent, Green spokesmen announced that they would use their platform in Parliament to campaign against the planned stationing of American missiles here starting at the end of this year. **********After having been excluded from a pre-election television debate with major party leaders, the Greens were welcomed Sunday night to participate in a post-election discussion that included Mr. Kohl, Mr. Genscher and Willy Brandt, the Social Democratic party leader. **********Representing the Greens at the roundtable talk, Rainer Trampert, who was elected from Hamburg, said his party had a ''mandate'' to oppose the stationing of the missiles in what he called ''this year of decision.'' **********On the same program, Chancellor Kohl said that his next government would lend its ''trust and European support'' to the United States so that it could come to an agreement in the Geneva arms limitation talks with the Soviet Union that would ''make peace with fewer weapons.'' Shift in U.S. Stance Sought **********Throughout the campaign, the Christian Democrats and the Free Democrats supported, though without vehemence, the necessity to station Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in West Germany if the Geneva talks remain stalemated. The Social Democrats, by contrast, demanded that the Reagan Administration respond to what they called Soviet ''concessions'' at Geneva. **********President Reagan was reported Sunday night to have telephoned Mr.  Kohl and, in an eight-minute conversation, to have congratulated him on his victory. **********After deserting Mr. Schmidt's coalition in September, the Free Democrats fell in popularity to a record low, and throughout the campaign the small swing party fought for its political existence.  Its performance today was its second worst since West Germany held its first national elections in 1949. **********Mr. Genscher's party appeared to have collected votes Sunday from Christian Democrats and others who wanted to prevent Mr. Strauss from becoming Foreign Minister, and others who support its rightist economic policies. **********According to the provisional results, 89.1 per cent of the country's 43.4 million eligible voters over the age of 18 cast ballots - the third highest turnout in the nation's history.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/19/world.body_text: **********A bomb exploded in the American Embassy in Beirut today, killing at least 33 people and wounding more than 80 others. **********Both the Lebanese police and American officials said there was evidence suggesting that the explosion may have been caused by a car packed with TNT driven up to the embassy's front door and detonated in an suicide attack. **********A secretive pro-Iranian Moslem group called the Islamic Jihad Organization said it was responsible for the bombing, in a telephone statement to the Beirut office of Agence France-Presse. The same group said it was responsible for the grenade attack against a group of American marines on March 16 in which five men were wounded. **********Precise Cause Still Unconfirmed **********The precise cause of the explosion, as well as final casualty figures, will not be confirmed until rescue workers finish clearing away the ruins of the eight-story embassy. Most of the center part of the horseshoe-shaped structure collapsed from the blast in a grotesque avalanche of concrete chunks, pieces of office furniture and dead bodies. Rooms in the other sections of the seafront embassy were either gutted by fire or torn apart by flying steel and bricks. **********Civil defense workers guarded by a ring of United States marines from the multinational peacekeeping force worked through the night under floodlights to pull away the rubble in search of more bodies and clues to the explosion. Many Casualties Were Lebanese **********Most of those killed or wounded were Lebanese members of the embassy staff, pedestrians on the fashionable Mediterranean esplanade that runs in front of the American mission and Lebanese civilians who were packed into the groundfloor consular office applying for visas to visit the United States. **********However, among the 33 people reported dead by the state-run Beirut radio were two United States Marine guards and some diplomats. Other American diplomatic staff may still be buried under the debris along with an undetermined number of Lebanese, police sources said. **********(In Washington, Administration officials said that so far, there were six Americans known dead and two others missing and presumed dead.) **********The American Ambassador, Robert S. Dillon, was in his eighth floor office when the explosion tore through the embassy at 1:05 P.M., just as many staff members were sitting down for lunch in the cafeteria, which was completely destroyed. The Ambassador managed to escape safely through a back set of stairs, as did almost everyone else who walked out alive. The American envoys, Philip C. Habib and Morris Draper, were at the Presidential Palace in Baabda when the explosion hit. **********Wearing a purple warm-up jacket and a red T-shirt, the American Ambassador explained to reporters outside the gutted embassy how he got out alive, suffering only minor cuts. **********''I was standing in my office with my telephone in one hand and a T-shirt in the other, getting ready to go out for my afternoon jog,'' Mr. Dillon said. ''All of sudden there was an explosion and my office collapsed. I couldn't move. **********''My secretary and deputy Robert Pugh came in and pulled the rubble off of me,'' the Ambassador said. ''We crawled through an open window, around the ledge to the back and then down the stairs.'' **********Asked how a bomb could be placed in the always tightly guarded driveway of the embassy, where only the Ambassador's armor-plated limousine is allowed to enter, Mr. Dillon said he could only speculate that a car packed with explosives crashed through the checkpoint at the end of the driveway and into the entrance. Unlike other American embassies in dangerous locations, the Beirut mission is not guarded by any substantial outer wall. Visitors just walk past a Lebanese Army checkpoint, up the driveway and into the main lobby. **********The explosion shook all of West Beirut, spewing glass and metal in all directions and breaking windows up to a mile away. A Navy medical officer from the United States Navy ship Guadalcanal, which was resting off the Beirut coast about five miles out to sea, said his entire ship ''shuddered'' from the blast tremor. **********All of the cars parked around the embassy were blown apart, with fenders, hubcabs and license plates coming to rest 50 yards away. A tree in front of the American mission was cut in half by a piece of flying metal, while a nearby traffic light was melted by the heat of the explosion. 'A Flash and Fireball' **********''I saw a flash and fireball shoot up into the sky,'' said a United States Navy seaman, Michel Paridom, from Doylestown, Ohio, who was walking toward the embassy when the blast occurred. ''I knew immediately what happened.'' **********The brunt of the blast went straight upward, bringing down the eight stories in the central portion of the building on top of one another like a fallen house of cards. The entryway where the Marine guards have their main sentry post was obliterated by the falling rubble, and the always crowded counselor section next to it was gutted by a ball of fire. **********''I was in the political section,'' said an embassy secretary, Catherine Nylund, wiping away streams of blood from cuts on her cheeks. ''All I know is a bomb went off and things started to fly in every direction.'' **********''One of the men near me - he was new from Washington and I don't know who he was - got hit with a piece of flying metal,'' she continued, with a stunned look in her eyes. ''He had a severe head wound, and I am not sure what happened to him. We started to walk out and saw that some of the floor was just gone. A marine in a flak jacket helped me out the back.'' Relatives of Missing Gather **********Friends and relatives of people believed to be inside the embassy gathered around the building, wrestling with Lebanese Army soldiers who tried to prevent them from getting near the burning structure to search for their loved ones. The more hysterical among them stood about screaming the names of their missing family members, while others leaned against a wall, gripping handkerchiefs or a purse and weeping silently. **********Lebanon's President, Amin Gemayel, came to the smoldering embassy two hours after the blast and walked through the ruins discussing the rescue operation with Col. James Mead of the Marines, the commander of the American peacekeeping unit in Lebanon, who was helping to supervise the cleanup. **********President Gemayel also sent a message to President Reagan saying he was ''deeply grieved by the criminal act perpetrated against'' the American Embassy. **********The Lebanese President, clearly concerned that the bombing might raise an outcry in Congress to pull out the 1,300 United States marines stationed in Beirut, added in his message that ''those responsible for this crime have united in death innocent Lebanese and American citizens and have strengthened the determination of our two countries to continue to work together in restoring unity, freedom and independence to this tortured land.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.main_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Fund's Success Spurs Growth
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.print_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Fund's Success Spurs Growth
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********PETER LYNCH, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund, retains his big bet on Chrysler, the fund's spectacular winner last year, and he has also been building portfolio positions in Ford and General Motors, along with certain chemical stocks. Currently, he is very keen, too, on regional banks and savings and loan associations. **********In a telephone interview yesterday, the 39-year- old Mr. Lynch discussed the strategies behind his giant Boston-based fund, which owns more than 700 stocks. His views are of more than passing interest to investors, thanks to Magellan's record. For the year ended June 30, the fund's total return - market appreciation plus dividends and capital gains reinvested - more than doubled. **********Moreover, its total return for the five years ended June 30 amounted to 582 percent, the best showing among all 530 domestic equity funds monitored by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. Only two mutual funds of any type topped that performance and both stress investments in gold. They were United Services Gold Shares, with a total return of 644 percent, and Strategic Investments, showing a total return of 636 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had a total return of 129 percent over the same time span. **********Magellan's performance record has proved a remarkable spur to its growth, including contributions from Keogh plans and Individual Retirement Accounts. Net assets totaled $230 million last Sept. 30, when the portfolio contained 275 stocks. By March 21 of this year, when Magellan owned 547 issues, assets had swelled to $821 million and, as of the middle of this year, assets reached $1.29 billion. The current total is $1.34 billion. **********Although Magellan is popularly regarded as a growth fund, it actually incorporates several investment philosophies. This, in effect, provides a cushion when particular sectors turn downward, as technology and small-company growth stocks have done since June. **********''Part of the fund represents a growth orientation,'' Mr. Lynch said, ''but other parts reflect cyclical stocks, as well as special situations and companies with undervalued assets.'' **********Heavy inflows of money create problems for the fund, which carries a sales charge of 3 percent. At Magellan the solution is to plow 75 percent of its equity money into 200 stocks and to distribute the remainder in more than 500 issues. **********As for Chrysler, Mr. Lynch said: ''I still think it's a $50 stock within the next 12 to 18 months.'' His original play in Chrysler encompassed the common stock, preferred stock and bonds of the nation's third-largest automobile maker. He has taken long-term profits in the bonds and increased holdings in the common and preferred issues. **********Meanwhile, in other industries, the portfolio manager has added to holdings in the Ethyl Corporation, Monsanto and PPG Industries in chemicals. Earlier this year, the fund raised its stake in foreign stocks and a recent newcomer in chemicals was Montecatini Edison, an Italian company. **********Elsewhere, the fund has built a substantial position in Ryder System. Because of Magellan's own rapid growth, portfolio newcomers and additions to existing positions tend to be the norm. However, it has sold Prime Computer and greatly reduced holdings of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Inco. ''We sold Inco too soon,'' Mr. Lynch said. ''The same goes for Resorts International, where we showed a profit of 30 percent but missed the easy part, which was the next 50 percent.'' **********In terms of broader strategy, the fund has cut back holdings in consumer nondurable stocks recently, while significantly expanding its exposure to regional banks and savings and loan issues. The latter now account for 12.5 percent of the equity portfolio as the largest single category, substantially bigger than, say, the 7.1 percent in office and building equipment. In the latter category, however, the position in International Business Machines has been expanded. **********Banks, both big and small, now account for some 100 issues in the portfolio. Many of Mr. Lynch's favorites here are regional banks, where low earnings multiples are one attraction. Portfolio newcomers among the regionals include Meridian Bancorp, PNC Financial, Ameritrust Corporation, Corestates Financial and First Kentucky National.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.main_headline: A NEW POLYMER PROCESS AT DUPONT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.print_headline: A NEW POLYMER PROCESS AT DUPONT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********The Du Pont Company said yesterday that it had discovered a new process for manufacturing polymers, the molecular building blocks for plastics, paints and synthetic fibers. It said it expects to use the process in manufacturing new automotive finishes that could be brought to market within two years. **********The company said its polymer process could also be used to improve the quality of plastics, fibers and other products. At the same time, it said the technology would enable its scientists to search for entirely new synthetic substances. **********''It is clearly too early to tell how broad the commercial applications will be, but we are convinced that this is an important scientific advancement,'' said Charles Bottomley, research director for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's research and development department. **********Jay Meltzer of Goldman, Sachs agreed that because of the large number of products that Du Pont makes with polymers, a more advanced production technique ''could ultimately be a big plus.'' But he cautioned that the new process was ''going to take many years to roll out.'' **********First Major Change in 20 Years **********Polymers are long strands of molecules that are linked to form synthetic substances. They are sometimes likened by chemists to freight trains in which the cars are changed to produce different payloads. Synthetic polymers were first used in the early 1930's with the commercial introduction of nylon and since then have been used to manufacture a wide range of other products. **********Mr. Bottomley said the new process, which has been under development at Du Pont's laboratories since 1979, ''represents the first important change'' in the way polymers are manufactured in more than 20 years. The company said its process gives it increased control in linking specific molecules, and therefore enables it to produce polymer chains that are at the same time more uniform and more complex than ever before. **********''It means we can pursue complex polymeric structures that heretofore only existed on paper,'' said Richard Quisenberry, a director of research and development at Du Pont. **********He added that ''the odds are long'' that the new process will produce ''an entirely new substance with big commercial potential.'' Instead, he said, Du Pont expects the process to be used to improve the quality of existing products. **********The company said the automotive finishes it hopes to make with the new polymer process would require less solvent - the chemical agent that keeps paint in a liquid form - than finishes now available. **********Reduction of Energy Costs **********Mr. Bottomley said automobile manufacturers would benefit because of a reduction in their energy costs for baking away solvents to dry the car finish. And because solvents become a pollutant when they dissolve into the air, the new auto finishes would lessen environmental problems, he added. **********Du Pont said it has begun construction of a pilot plant to produce the new auto finishes in Philadelphia. It added that the plant would be in operation by the end of this year. **********During the first half of 1983 Du Pont said its polymer products generated sales of $1.65 billion, or 9 percent of its $17.5 billion in total revenues. It said the polymer products contributed operating income of $91 million in the six-month period. **********Du Pont's other major businesses include the production of a wide range of chemicals that do not contain polymers and the oil and natural gas operations it obtained through its acquisition of Conoco Inc. in 1982. Over all, its net income for the first half of the year declined 4.6 percent, to $474 million, or $1.98 a share, from $497 million, or $2.09 a share. Its revenues rose 4.1 percent, to $17.5 billion, from $16.8 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.body_text: **********A proposal by Nicaraguan opposition groups that talks be held among all political factions was strongly denounced today in the pro-Sandinista press. **********A front-page headline in the newspaper Nuevo Diario called the proposal an ''insult to sovereignty'' and a ''sellout.'' **********Last week, both the Social Christian Party, which is aligned to Christian Democratic parties in Latin America and Europe, and the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, known by the acronym Cosep, issued statements suggesting talks between the governing Sandinistas and their adversaries. The groups recommended that Panama, Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela, the countries in the Contadora Group, be asked to observe the discussions. . **********The president of the Nicaraguan Episcopal Conference, Bishop Pablo Antonio Vega, also called last week for national discussions ''to seek answers to internal social and economic problems.'' **********Free Election Sought **********In a visit to Nicaragua last Thursday, President Reagan's special envoy for Central America, Richard B. Stone, reportedly urged the Sandinistas to reach an accord with their adversaries.  Under the Social Christian plan, negotiations between the Sandinista Government and the opposition would be aimed at calling a free election for a national assembly in November 1984 ''with the technical assistance of the Contadora countries and/or the Organization of American States.'' The assembly would name a five-member junta to rule the country for up to two years while direct presidential elections were being organized. **********''We believe it is the role of the Contadora Group to help create a climate in which such a dialogue can take place, a dialogue which would take into account all internal and external groups involved in the Nicaraguan problem,'' the Social Christians declared. **********Nuevo Diario today condemned the Social Christian proposal as ''an affront to the nation, an insult to our sovereignty, and a subversive attempt to turn back the conquests of the revolution.''  'A Matter for Nicaraguans' **********Domingo Sanchez, a Socialist Party official who served as vice president of the Sandinista-dominated Council of State, was quoted as having said, ''The electoral process is a matter for Nicaraguans alone.'' **********''The proposal of the Social Christians, the declarations of Msgr. Pablo Antonio Vega and the statement by Cosep, when taken together, represent a direct and arrogant attack on the revolutionary Sandinista Government,'' Mr. Sanchez told Nuevo Diario. **********Mr. Sanchez, according to the newspaper, also rejected Social Christian proposals that political prisoners be freed and that the Law of Emergency, which restricts the political rights of Nicaraguans, be repealed. **********He denied there were any political prisoners in the country, saying that ''the only people being detained are criminal ex-guardsmen and counterrevolutionary elements who have been caught violating the public security law.'' He said the Law of Emergency was necessary ''while we confront a dirty, undeclared imperialist war and an imminent invasion.''  Proposals 'Must Be Rejected' **********Eli Altamirano, who heads the Nicaraguan Communist Party, told Nuevo Diario that it was impossible for the Government to reach an agreement with ''enemies of the revolution, some of whom act in the political arena and others who carry weapons in the mercenary army financed by the United States Government.'' **********The third pro-Sandinista political leader quoted in the Nuevo Diario report, Cesar Delgadillo Machado, said the Government ''cannot negotiate with domestic reactionaries who have clandestine links to the counterrevolution, the C.I.A. and the traitors.'' **********''Reconciliation between classes in conflict is never possible,'' he said. **********The Sandinista Government has given no official response to last week's proposals. According to Western diplomats, the proposals coincided with efforts by the Contadora Group to press the Nicaraguan Government to accept some form of dialogue with its adversaries. Nicaraguan officials and foreign ministers from the Contadora countries are expected to meet in Washington this week. **********After Mr. Stone's vsit to Managua on Thursday, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the coordinator of the governing junta, did not explicitly rule out talks with opposition groups here. But he rejected suggestions that the Sandinistas should negotiate with armed groups that are fighting to bring down the Government.  ''We have nothing to negotiate with mercenaries, who are artificial forces created by the United States,'' Mr. Ortega declared. **********The leader of the Social Christian Party, Agustin Jarquin Anaya, said in an interview that the statements published today in Nuevo Diario were ''extremely radical,'' but that he was encouraged that no such condemnations have been heard directly from Sandinista leaders or from the official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada. **********''We are still hopeful that the Sandinista leadership will try to resolve the political situation within the Contadora framework,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin told his Cabinet today that he had been invited to a meeting with President Reagan on July 27, the Israeli radio quoted Cabinet sources as saying. **********Mr. Begin, whose talks in Washington are expected to include a possible redeployment of Israeli forces in Lebanon, said he planned Monday to accept the invitation, the radio said.   Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, June 19 - A White House spokesman said today that there was no formal announcement yet of a meeting between Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Reagan next month. **********''We've been discussing a meeting with Begin,'' the spokesman said. ''However, we made no official date.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Company earnings continued to fall on a year-to-year basis in the fourth quarter, although profits have been moving higher from one quarter to the next. **********A New York Times compilation of the earnings of 276 companies shows some bright spots in the latest three months, including a decline of about $1.5 billion in interest expenses. But over all, the recession continued to exact a heavy toll on earnings. **********Leading the retreat were cyclical industries such as automobiles, energy, steel, chemicals and building products. (The full list appears on page D14.) **********Oil companies - battered by oversupply worldwide and consequent lower prices - were the hardest hit. Of the 24 energy concerns on the list, 22 showed declines in net income from the 1981 quarter, ranging from 3 percent at the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) to 99 percent at the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. **********Chemical producers, especially those with extensive international holdings, also were hurt as the dollar gained strength. Of the 19 companies listed in this category, only 4 managed to increase their earnings. Earnings of the three largest chemical concerns set the mood: Du Pont's net fell 38 percent, Dow Chemical's plunged 81 precent and Union Carbide's 78 percent. **********Many industry experts remain pessimistic about the earnings outlook for the basic cyclical industries. But the communication, electronic and pharmaceutical industries will continue to show strength, the experts predict. **********''I don't believe earnings in the first quarter of 1983 for cyclical companies will show major gains,'' said Stephen Weisglass, president of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. ''However, the quarterto-quarter comparison on technology companies, such as telecommunications, business systems and consumer electronics, will show strong advances,'' he said. **********David Saks, pharmaceutical analyst at A.G. Becker, said, ''the drug industry had a strong fourth quarter, with results at record levels.'' The current quarter, he said, should be another good one for the industry. But he cautioned that two companies would be exceptions: Johnson & Johnson, because it will continue to feel the impact of the Tylenol tragedy, and Upjohn, because of its depressed chemical operations. **********Richard Scott-Ram, vice president and economist at Chemical Bank, said, ''Corporate profits have been recovering since the first quarter of 1982, well before the overall economy started to recover.'' **********He said the industries currently recovering are housing, including appliances, furniture and construction materials; autos, including steel, rubber, and chemicals and plastics, and military-related industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Alexander N. Brainard, president of the Consolidated Cigar Company, is head of a group negotiating to buy the company from Gulf and Western Industries for about $120 million, G.& W. said yesterday. The MacAndrews & Forbes Group had agreed last summer to buy the company for about $105 million, but the deal collapsed. **********If concluded, the Brainard venture would be the third in which G.& W. has sold a holding to company executives. Last year, it sold most of the New Jersey Zinc Company to a group headed by William E.  Flaherty, then executive vice president of G.& W, for an estimated $50 million. It also sold its Providence Capitol International Insurance Ltd. and Famous Players Realty Ltd. units to a new group headed by Don F. Gaston, former executive vice president of G.& W., for an estimated $300 million. **********In a separate development, the American Financial Corporation, controlled by Carl H. Lindner, said it owns 7,094,362 shares, or 9.4 percent, of G.& W.'s outstanding shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/world.main_headline: ISRAELI PRESIDENT TO VISIT U.S. AMID TALK OF A POLITICAL RACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/world.print_headline: ISRAELI PRESIDENT TO VISIT U.S. AMID TALK OF A POLITICAL RACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/world.body_text: **********President Yitzhak Navon of Israel starts a visit to the United States on Tuesday amid speculation by politicians and journalists that he might become a challenger to Prime Minister Menachem Begin. **********Mr. Navon, a 61-year-old Labor Party veteran, holds a largely ceremonial post.  He served as head of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's office from 1952 to 1963.  President Navon is scheduled to see Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Tuesday and President Reagan on Wednesday in Washington, then meet with leaders of American Jewish groups, A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, and mayors and other officials in visits to Baltimore, Boston and New York. **********The tour, which is scheduled to last nearly two weeks, comes against the background of a feud within the Labor Party between its present leader, Shimon Peres, who has lost twice to Mr. Begin, and his main rival, former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. **********Consequently Mr. Navon is being looked to by many Laborites as their party's best hope in elections that Israeli political analysts think that Mr. Begin may call sometime this year. Mr. Navon's presidential term ends this spring, and he is reportedly being pressed by some politicians to decide within a month or so to seek the chairmanship of the Labor Party and thus head its list of candidates. Possible Effect of Inquiry **********There are so many imponderables in this that experienced Israeli politicians and journalists are split on what is likely to happen.  Practically the only prediction that gains wide adherence is that Mr. Begin will call new elections if the state commission of inquiry finds that he and other officials were remiss in asking Lebanese Christian Phalangists last September to enter Beirut refugee camps, where the Phalangists killed hundreds of Palestinian men, women and children. **********Aides to the Prime Minister expect him to say, in effect, ''Let the people judge,'' and go to the polls. The commission's findings are expected in February, the same month that President Navon is due to make his plans known. **********After the Beirut killings, Mr. Navon made a public statement condemning the deaths, expressing sorrow to all the families of the victims and calling for a commission of inquiry, which Mr. Begin at first opposed. ''We must not pass on to business as usual,'' Mr.  Navon said. ''We have an obligation to ourselves, to our self-image, as well as to that part of the civilized world to which we feel we belong, to find out quickly and exactly what happened.'' Call for Calm in '81 Campaign **********In the election campaign of 1981, Mr. Navon spoke out for calm and tolerance among Jews of varied ethnic backgrounds, who were clashing at Labor Party rallies. Tension between Sephardim, Jews mostly from the Middle East and North Africa, and Ashkenazim, Jews with European backgrounds, have remained high. Some politicians think that Mr.  Navon's Sephardic origins could help Labor cut into Mr. Begin's substantial support among Sephardic voters. **********Other analysts express doubts, noting that Sephardim have not tended to vote for Sephardic candidates and that Mr. Navon's background would not make him a model for recent Sephardic immigrants. Mr. Navon is regarded as an aristocratic Sephardi; his family has been here for many generations. His father's family, originally from Spain, fled to Turkey and then settled in Jerusalem more than 300 years ago. His mother, born in Morocco, was brought to Jerusalem as a child in 1884. **********He has no real experience in raw political fights, and some Israelis who have known him for many years doubt that he will jump into a fight for the Labor Party leadership. He has indicated in recent conversations that he prefers to wait for a summons from Mr.  Peres and Mr. Rabin; Israeli political reporters are split on whether the two might step aside for Mr. Navon. **********Finally, there is the question of whether a Navon-led Labor slate would have a chance against a Begin-led Likud bloc. A good deal of Mr. Navon's attractiveness has been fostered by his aloofness from the contentious issues facing the country, and even some of his admirers wonder how he will look if he has to choose sides on such matters as Israeli sovereignty over the occupied West Bank, further Jewish settlement there and the complex economic problems facing Israel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported a 10.5 percent increase in its second-quarter earnings and announced a further cutback of operations at the Western Electric Company, its manufacturing arm. **********A.T.&T. said its net income rose in the three months ended June 30, to $1.93 billion, from $1.75 billion a year earlier. The earnings per share declined, however, to $2.03 from $2.04, because the number of shares increased 11.5 percent. **********The latest quarter's results included a $96.5 million one-time charge against earnings to account for a consolidation of Western Electric's distribution and repair operations. That was more than offset by a restoration of $217 million from a reduction in the Pacific Telephone and Telepraph Company's back tax liability, stemming from a resolution of a long dispute involving the company, the Internal Revenue Service and the State of California. Some Operations to Close **********Not counting those two changes, A.T.&T.'s net income for the quarter would have increased 3.6 percent, to $1.81 billion, and the per share figure would have declined to $1.90. **********Western Electric announced that it would close some distribution and repair operations in seven states during the rest of 1983. The move will eliminate 830 jobs, although the company said some employees might be transferred or retire rather than be laid off. **********The move is part of an effort to improve efficiency and factory utilization to prepare for the breakup of A.T.&T. next Jan. 1. After that, Western Electric will have to become more competitive because the local Bell operating companies will no longer be part of A.T.&T. **********In addition to yesterday's cutback, Western Electric earlier this year announced a series of plant closings that will eventually eliminate 11,000 jobs. Slow Economy Is Reflected **********A.T.&T.'s slow earnings growth reflected the nation's sluggish economy. Revenues grew 8.3 percent, to $17.5 billion, from $16.1 billion. Long-distance calling grew only 2.5 percent although WATS use increased 22.1 percent. The number of telephone lines in use grew by 180,000, in contrast to a decrease of 70,000 lines in the second quarter of 1982. **********''In earnings, as in other aspects of our operations, this is a time of transition for A.T.&T.,'' Charles L. Brown, the chairman, said in a statement. ''Indeed, we have a couple of difficult years ahead of us. Difficult as it may be, it in no way diminishes our expectations for the future.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 4.1 percent, or 6.1 million shares, in the month ended last Friday, to a record 153.7 million shares. The previous high of 147.6 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 103.6 million shares. **********In the latest period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange was up 568,221 shares, to a high of 14.4 million shares.
