https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Companies **********Eastern Air Lines and three of its unions reached an accord that is expected to save the airline $330 million in wages next year and bring it $87 million in productivity gains. In return, the unions will get a large say in management decisions and will eventually own about one-fourth of the company's common stock. Many hard- pressed companies have forged similar concession agreements in recent weeks, experts observed, but thus far none have given up so many management rights in the process. (Page A1.) **********U.S. Steel is warning some 4,700 employees that their jobs could be eliminated if they do not accept further concessions. (D5.) **********Dissident shareholders won control of GAF when a court decision calling for a new vote was overturned on appeal. Afterward, the dissidents' leader, Samuel J. Heyman, a Connecticut developer, met with Jesse Werner, the company's chief for the last 18 years, to discuss a transition. A new board is to be elected on Tuesday. (D1.) **********Lee A. Iacocca has agreed to remain as chairman of Chrysler for at least three more years in return for substantial bonuses of stock and stock options. The agreement appears to settle any questions about Mr. Iacocca's future with the auto maker. (D4.) **********I.B.M.'s revenue growth in 1984 will exceed the 14.5 percent pace of recent years, suggesting strong profits, a company official told analysts. He said I.B.M. expects to repurchase shares on the open market for employee and shareholder stock plans. (D5.) **********The Economy **********William F. Baxter will leave next week as head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, the department announced. He will be replaced by J. Paul McGrath, head of the civil division. Mr. Baxter, an outspoken official who has presided over far-reaching changes in antitrust policy, said he will resume teaching at Stanford. (D1.) Mr. Baxter will be remembered, experts agreed, more for intellectual reasons than for day-to-day policies. (D4.) **********International **********Bell Canada Enterprises has generated wide new interest by trying to acquire a major stake in TransCanada Pipelines. Bell has stressed that it does not want to acquire TransCanada altogether, but that it will do so if necessary. A full merger would make Bell the biggest company in Canada in terms of corporate assets and the second biggest in terms of sales, behind Canadian Pacific. (D1.) **********OPEC oil ministers formally agreed to maintain production ceilings and prices at current levels. Since those guidelines have been widely disregarded in recent months, the decision raises the possibility that oil prices may decline even further. Iran backed down for now from its demand for a $5-a-barrel increase. (D1.) **********Markets **********Long-term bond prices fell sharply and interest rates rose. Increasingly, traders appeared convinced that the chances of any near-term decline in rates are fading. The yield on the bellwether Treasury bond due in 2013 - a benchmark for many other interest rates, including home mortgages - rose to 11.92 percent from 11.80 percent. A week ago, it was 11.66 percent. (D1.) **********Stock prices dropped sharply as investors reacted to the rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.89 points, to 1,261.89, while the two other major indicators were also down. (D10.) Assets of money market mutual funds fell for the fourth consecutive week. (D4.) **********The dollar soared to a new high against the British pound, while gold prices plunged $14.25 an ounce, to $388.90, in New York. (D14.) The Comex opened its aluminum futures market. (D14.) **********Today's Columns **********Why have ''real'' interest rates remained so high?  The reasons no doubt include the widespread anticipation of a new inflationary surge and the rising total demand on credit. But banking deregulation may also have played a role and indeed may have led to a quantum jump in interest rates. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Many restaurant stocks have emerged as appealing investments alongside McDonald's, according to analysts. They say that restaurants such as Bojangles, Shoney's, Jerrico and Chi-Chi's are enjoying both an increase in the number of new stores and customer counts at existing stores. Market Place. (D10.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/24/busin.body_text: **********PRESIDENT REAGAN'S recent call for a defensive shield in space has b een roundly criticized, even ridiculed, as a high-level but fancifulw ish for a technological coup that would end the nuclear arms race.  Y et serious research efforts on exotic non-nuclear methods of d efense, such as lasers, have been proceeding steadily, if slowly, f or years. **********Although there is no certainty yet about specific technologies, the aerospace industry is poised to move ahead if Congress ever follows the President's advice. Some of the biggest names in the industry - Lockheed, TRW and Rockwell International - have already won laser defense contracts. **********Any space defense against a missile attack would almost certainly be built around a laser. A highly focused beam of light that could engage its targets at the speed of light, a laser could proceed from one target to another seemingly instantaneously. Particle-beam weapons are the other possibility. These direct highly accelerated and concentrated streams of charged particles, such as electrons, but they have received less research attention because they are slower, less easily concentrated, and are subject to disruption by the earth's magnetic field. **********''The President didn't specify the technology,'' said Edward Teller, an atomic scientist who played a leading role in in the development of the atom and the hydrogen bombs. ''He was talking about a whole new direction: defense rather than retaliation.'' **********A defensive laser weapon in space would destroy attacking missiles in the first few minutes after they were launched. Once it detected their heat trails, identified their purpose and tracked them, it would orient its focusing mirror and aim an intense energy that would melt, burn, or deflect them. But the action would have to be very fast. Each laser weapon would need to engage several hundred missiles in a full-scale attack and it could devote only a few seconds to each, meaning that military personnel would have to delegate decision-making to the weapon's computer. **********Despite the doubts of many notable scientists who are not participating in the work, the researchers say that a limited, startup laser system could be deployed before the end of the century. Such a first-generation system might cost as much as $100 billion, according to a Pentagon estimate. **********Most of the research activity in laser weaponry is both classified and proprietary. Companies that potentially will be leading contractors barely acknowledge their interest, much less their capital investments and lobbying efforts in the laser area. **********But the Department of Defense already has spent about $2 billion explicitly on devising laser weapons. About a third has been directed to space-based laser weapon spending. Much of that fraction has been devoted to three projects - ''the triad'' - administered by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. **********Two of the three projects have been led by the Lockheed Corporation, of Sunnyvale, Calif. These are known as ''Talon Gold,'' an experiment in high-precision tracking and pointing, and ''Lode,'' an attempt to build a large mirror for focusing the light produced by chemical lasers. The third project, ''Alpha,'' involves research into chemical lasers and is being led by TRW Inc. at Redondo Beach, Calif. **********A list of companies involved in laser-related research and development would read like an aerospace industry roll call. But several stand out by virtue of previous laser-related work performed for the Defense Department. In terms of funds already received, the ''top four'' contractors, said Pentagon spokesman Jack Powers, are TRW, Rockwell International, Hughes Aircraft and Lockheed. **********Fred Kittler, an analyst with the First Albany Corporation, notes that Lockheed, TRW, Perkin-Elmer and the Charles Stark Draper Laboratory are known in the trade as the ''gang of four'' because of aggressive lobbying efforts, several years ago, that helped inspire Congressional supporters of ballistic-missile defense. **********Other contractors include Avco, United Technologies, Westinghouse, Itek, Corning, Eastman Kodak, Boeing, Northrop, Ford Aerospace and Martin Marietta. **********A related set of players in laser research, with space weapons as the most likely application, are laboratories - national laboratories such as Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore and university facilities such as the High-Energy Physics Laboratory at Stanford and the Draper Laboratory, which is informally associated with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Some receive their funding from non-Pentagon sources, such as the Department of Energy, or from defense budgets other than those explicitly devoted to laser weapons. Also, some can independently contract out work to private companies. **********The Defense Department has requested $526 million - a 22 percent rise - for laser research in the fiscal year 1984, and it now expects to request $591.5 million for the following year. But the executive committee named by Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger on April 1 to study the President's call for an enlarged commitment could recommend a major revision of these figures. **********The secretive nature of the work has led some prominent researchers, such as physicist Lowell Wood, head of the special studies group at Lawrence Livermore, to decry the ''muzzling effect of overclassification.'' They say that open discussion of their ideas would aid public involvement and benefit the research, but they must remain silent. However, potential subcontractors, makers of specific devices or subsystems, as well as consultants are at least willing to disclose, albeit in general terms only, what they do for lasers. **********For example, the Ball Corporation's aerospace systems division in Boulder, Colo., makes electro-optical devices that could guide and control space-based lasers. And it produces electromechanical positioning devices that would control the optical controllers. It has designed mirrors for laser application and it makes a military television system that could be used to relay damage-assessment data back to the laser weapon. At W.J. Schafer Associates of McLean, Va., the products are mostly analyses running the gamut of laser options. **********Despite all the efforts, many informed scientists and engineers - such as Richard Garwin, a research fellow at the I.B.M. Research Center, Wolfgang Panofsky, director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, and Kosta Tsipis, director of the Program in Science and Technology for International Security at M.I.T. - say they are convinced that a laser weapon would not only be very expensive and politically destabilizing, but that it simply would not work. It is vulnerable, easily countered and of limited effectiveness. **********For example, the Russians could build rockets with reflective materials or launch them with a spin so that the laser would have to burn a ring, instead of a hole, in its surface, a feat that would require up to 10 times more energy. They could build mirrors in their rocket fields to ''blind'' the laser, or force it to deplete itself on decoys. Even Dr. Teller, one of the science community's foremost advocates of ballistic-missile defense, acknowledges the problem. **********''I'm convinced,'' Dr. Teller said in an interview, ''that to put up a system of laser-equipped satellites to destroy incoming Soviet missiles would take much more money than the Soviets need spend to counter it.'' **********But a more basic objection is what many scientists see as the system's impossible need for perfection. Anything less, they insist, would invite a pre-emptive strike, or surprise attack, by the Soviet Union. **********''It's an all-or-nothing proposition,'' Dr. Panofsky said. The Russians could launch some 10,000 nuclear warheads and even if only a few pierced the shield, it would mean disaster. And each ''kill'' could only be scored through unprecedented accuracy from thousands of miles away. As Dr. Tsipis points out, a laser must hit its target in order to destroy it, unlike conventional and nuclear weapons that merely have to explode nearby. **********But some researchers see value not only in less-than-perfect performance, but even in minimal laser-defense systems. Charles Brau, director of the Free-Electron Laser Program at Los Alamos National Laboratory, says that they could in fact be strategically stabilizing. ''A defense that could shoot down some Soviet missiles,'' he said, ''would insure that some of ours - enough to assure retaliation - would survive. The value of a Soviet pre-emptive strike would be gone. Thus, even if we never get from here to the Holy Grail, there's room for progress in-between.'' **********John Rather, a physicist and vice president of D.E.S.E. Research and Engineering in Arlington, Va., says that a ground-based system would relieve many of the concept's problems, such as reliability. It could cut the needed weight in orbit substantially and eliminate the need for fuel in orbit. ''It would be an important short-cut to optimal capability,'' he says. **********But there are still doubts about the system, whether it is in space or on earth, powered by chemical or free-electron lasers, or some dark-horse alternative (such as X-rays pumped by nuclear explosives, a highly classified option being studied at Lawrence Livermore), and even if effectiveness is achievable. **********Wallace Henderson, vice president for systems integration at the BDM Corporation, a technology consulting company in McLean, Va., talks of the ''opportunity costs'' of building such systems. ''Even under the most optimistic conditions,'' he says, ''they wouldn't be operational until the late 1990's. Such a massive long-term commitment, and the diversion of technical talent, might well eliminate projects that address current shortages and shorter-term payoffs.'' **********Congressional supporters of the concept, such as Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Kenneth Kramer, Republican of Colorado, hope for the equivalent of the Manhattan Project, the collaboration that produced the first atomic bomb. But opponents, such as Senator Daniel Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, dismiss it as ''yet another generation of destructive weapons.'' **********Mr. Henderson predicts that the effort will be somewhere inbetween: ''not a 'Manhattan Project,' but increased funding.'' In any case, Dr. Teller and Dr. Rather are strongly urging politicians to specify research and development on a broad range of alternatives and not commit the country, full-speed-ahead, to expedient but inappropriate technologies. **********Whether the research effort will make a difference in the strategic balance, or whether it will comprise a harmless but interesting rationale for maintaining the level of defense spending, remains to be seen. Yet if it turns out that ballistic-missile defense only beclouds arms-control efforts, it is perhaps a cloud with a silver lining. ''Even if we never put a single laser weapon in orbit,'' says Carolyn Meinel, a space-systems consultant based in Tucson, Ariz., ''the significant thing is that the President is talking about a whole new strategy. It's different from 'more nuclear warheads.' '' **********ZAPPING MISSILES IN SPACE WARS **********Laser is an acronym for ''light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation.'' It is a method of first inducing ''coherent'' light waves - of identical frequency that move in nearperfect synchronization - and then focusing them into beams millions of times more intense than ordinary light. **********A laser's effectiveness as a weapon - its ability to melt, burn a hole through, or fracture a target from afar - depends on the amount of energy it can deliver and on the ease with which a mirror can focus the beam on a target. **********But some lasers can be more sharply focused than others. Chemical lasers, known as long-wave-length lasers, are in the most advanced state of development but are considered less applicable as weapons than newer laser types, such as free-electron, or short-wavelength, lasers. **********Robert Center, vice president for research at Mathematical Sciences Northwest, a unit of Spectra Physics, stresses the relative ease of building a mirror that would focus a short-wavelength laserbeam to a greater intensity on its target. Long-wavelength lasers would require much larger mirrors in orbit to achieve the same effect; some critics, such as Kosta Tsipis of M.I.T., say such mirrors are beyond present capabilities. **********Another advantage of short-wavelength lasers, says John D.G.  Rather, vice president of D.E.S.E. Research and Engineering, is that they are more energy-efficient. A chemical laser is intrinsically limited to efficiencies of under 5 percent - that is, more than 95 percent of its energy is wasted -and thus requires large amounts of fuel in orbit. A free-electron laser, by contrast, could achieve efficiencies as high as 50 percent. **********But even though researchers say that their knowledge of shortwavelength lasers is still ''primitive'' - primarily, they say, because of limitations in funding - they are optimistic. For one thing, they say progress has been steady. Charles Brau, director of the Free-Electron Laser Program at Los Alamos National Laboratory, reports that a tenfold improvement in efficiency was achieved in the past year. Further, work already done on less-easily applied lasers would not have been wasted. ''The laser itself would only be one small part of the whole system,'' says Dr. Brau. ''Most of the funds would have to be spent on pointing and focusing the beam and on 'battle management' - the coordination of multiple lasers and targets.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.main_headline: SANDINIST OFFICIAL CALLS REAGAN CHARGES ABSURD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.print_headline: SANDINIST OFFICIAL CALLS REAGAN CHARGES ABSURD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Government, reacting to President Reagan's speech on Central America, said today that it had received an outpouring of international support and asked again for a dialogue with Washington. **********Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman accused President Reagan of ''working on the fears of the American people'' with ''absurd and deceitful charges against Nicaragua.'' **********Rather than averting a crisis, he said in an interview, the President ''is compounding an already explosive situation.'' The minister said Nicaragua had received ''a terrific amount of feedback and support from abroad,'' including important European nations. **********''But we are asking again for a dialogue with Washington,'' he said. ''We always have. It is they who have closed the doors.'' Speech Is Broadcast **********The President's address to a joint session of Congress Wednesday night, broadcast here on a Government radio station with simultaneous translation into Spanish, appeared to cause fear and anger among many people, including opponents of the leftist Sandinist Government. **********''Only the United States can change the course of this country,'' said a businessman who strongly dislikes the Government, ''but we are all Nicaraguans and we are dying in the secret American war.'' **********A number of people expressed relief at the President's statement that he did not intend to send United States troops to Nicaragua. But a foreign resident noted ''the not-so-secret war will clearly continue.'' **********''It may be far away, in the north,'' he said, ''but the dead soldiers are coming home all over the country.'' After the broadcast, the Government called protest marches for this evening in all provincial capitals. The announcement urged people to bring ''your rifles, your machetes, your sticks and your vigilante whistles'' to demonstrate ''anger and readiness against the aggression.'' **********Several European and Latin American diplomats familiar with the region made little effort to disguise their concern at Washington's new emphasis on its Central American policy. **********In the opinion of some, the President's assessment of Nicaragua's military and political designs in the region was overstated.  ''Reagan's story is too panicky, too exaggerated,'' said a European ambassador. ''It serves the Nicaraguan and not Washington's interests. What could be better for a small country to be threatened by the strongest power in the world, especially if that power cannot or will not back up its threats.'' ---- 'Frank Dialogue' Urged Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, April 28 - Hugo Tinoco, Deputy Foreign Minister of Nicaragua, said at a news conference here today that his Government was ''willing to engage in a frank and open dialogue'' with the United States over Central America, but that the Reagan Administration had consistently rejected the offers. He said that Nicaragua had proposed discussions with the United States ''on at least 14 occasions.'' **********A State Department official, responding to Mr. Tinoco's comments, said that the United States sought a regional approach in Central America. ''Bilateral discussions have thus far failed to address our major concerns,'' the official said. ---- Moscow Is Derisive Special to the New York Times **********MOSCOW, April 28 - The Soviet press today derided President Reagan's renewed warnings of Soviet designs on Central America as being ''obviously designed for simpletons.'' **********Lengthy rebuttals of the President's address in Izvestia and over the Tass news wires denied all Mr. Reagan's charges and accused him of fanning anti-Communism to win approval for his ''ventures'' in Central America. ---- Cubans Read Reagan's Speech **********HAVANA, April 28 (Reuters) - The official Cuban newspaper Granma published without comment today a translation of President Reagan's address and the Democrats' response. **********Diplomats said that the step was highly unusual and that it was unclear why the Cuban Government had given its people the opportunity to read completely uncensored attacks on their country and its allies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/busin.body_text: **********WHILE I agree with both the Keynesian and supply-side economists that the scheduled tax cut is n eeded to sustain the recovery, I believe that a modest adjustment c an be made that will make it both more effective and more equitable.L et's place an upper limit of $500 on the size of the tax cut, so t hat people with very high incomes will not get inordinate tax r eductions, while those at middle or lower income levels will get thef ull 10 percent reduction. **********Such an adjustment would not only provide the needed increase in consumer spending to continue the recovery, it would enhance the recovery by reducing the budget deficit. Moreover, a cap would begin to reverse the process that in recent years has shifted a much larger part of the nation's tax burden onto middle-and lower-income families. **********Several recent studies have shown this dramatic shift in the distribution of income in this country. The President's personal tax cuts already in place have reduced tax burdens more sharply for those with higher incomes, even when measured in percentage terms. And the interaction of inflation with our progressive tax system has further shifted the income tax burden in this direction. **********Recent sharp increases in the Social Security tax rate (and additional increases soon to occur) are regressive, as are many of the Federal tax increases enacted in 1982 and the recent increase in the gasoline tax. Increases in excise taxes by state and local governments, partly a result of lost Federal aid, are also regressive. Finally, additional increases in excise and energy taxes, and the President's contingent surtax on incomes would overly burden the lower wage earners and move us further away from a tax structure based on ability to pay. **********Moreover, cuts in spending for various social programs that benefit the poor, as well as the sharp growth in personal interest income in recent years caused by policies that create high interest rates, have also caused greater income inequality. **********In my view, the net effect of these tax measures and other changes is very unfair and a $500 cap on the tax cut would at least begin to restore more equity to the system.IT is now generally accepted that the Federal deficit will rise to very high levels in the years ahead u nless new deficit-reducing actions are implemented. Given our need t o reduce interest rates further, these future deficits must be s harply reduced. Otherwise, the large increase in Treasury borrowing t o finance deficits will collide with rising private credit demands, p ushing up interest rates and sparking a new recession. **********The main reason for the bleak budget outlook is that the 1981 tax cuts were too large in view of the enormous military buildup and continued growth in Federal entitlements. And while some spending cuts are desirable, these would be nowhere sufficient to come even close to reducing future deficits to acceptable levels. The expected revenue loss from the 1981 tax cut will have to be reduced, and capping the tax cut will rather painlessly begin that process. **********At the same time, capping the third year of the tax cut will not prevent the recovery from continuing. In fact, it could strengthen it. First, capping would reduce the magnitude of the July tax cut by only about $8 billion; nearly 75 percent of the tax reduction would still occur. This, combined with the military buildup, would provide ample fiscal stimulus for a recovery. **********Second, depending on how the withholding tables are adjusted in July, some or all of the ''increased'' tax liabilities resulting from capping the tax cut would be pushed into the spring of 1984. Last July 1, withholding reductions were limited to incomes below $35,000 - a repeat would mean that virtually all the added revenues from capping would come from smaller refunds or larger payments when 1984 tax returns are filed, and that income flows and purchasing power during the critical second half of this year would be relatively unaffected. **********Finally, the tax cuts on higher incomes will increase savings more than consumer spending. While this may be desirable from a long-term standpoint, the economy is currently suffering from a lack of spending rather than inadequate savings. Thus, scaling back the tax cuts on upper incomes will likely have little adverse effect on consumer spending. **********The net effect on economic activity could in fact be positive if some of the increased revenues associated with capping are used to finance jobs programs or transfer payments aimed at people with a higher propensity to spend. Stimulus from these programs will outweigh the lost spending from scaling back the tax cut. And, to the extent that capping helps reduce expected deficits and eases concerns in financial markets, lower interest rates that may result would further stimulate the recovery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Tax Preparers And Flat Tax
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Tax Preparers And Flat Tax
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.body_text: **********THE flat tax, or a uniform Federal income tax rate for all individuals, is a concept whose time may or may not have arrived.  But it stirs the rhetoric of Congressmen and occasionally receives comment from President Reagan himself. **********While the flat tax remains a matter of debate and conjecture, its discussion in high places can cause a ripple among stocks of publicly owned tax preparation services. **********One day last month, for example, talk of tax reform touched off a drop of 2 1/8 points, to 37 3/4, in H.& R. Block Inc., the largest preparer of Federal income tax returns for individuals. The rationale of the marketplace was that any drastic simplification of income tax laws could hurt Block. **********Economists have also debated simplification of the tax code. In pure form, a flat tax would sweep away deductions and exemptions and, instead, levy a tax on all income at a predetermined rate. **********It is an issue that generates heated argument, depending upon the viewpoint of respective constituents. One basic problem with a pure flat tax, critics have noted, is that it would place an undue burden upon the poor and lower middle class while providing a bonanza for wealthier citizens. **********Despite talk of possible disadvantages of a flat tax, the stocks of both Block and Commerce Clearing House Inc. - another important entity in the tax-preparation field - have hit record prices in the last several months. Yesterday, Block rose 1/2, to 41, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********In the over-the-counter market, Commerce Clearing House fell 3 1/4, to 60 1/2 bid. The stock dropped 3 1/4 last week after reporting 1982 profits that were below Wall Street estimates, and some analysts have lowered their 1983 earnings figures. **********Although dissimilar in their areas of operation, the two companies share certain characteristics. They are cash-rich and carry little long-term debt on their balance sheets, and their return on equity is far superior to that of the average company. Moreover, both are family-controlled businesses. **********Block prepares one out of every 10 tax returns filed in the United States. The company, based in Kansas City, Mo., also operates a temporary help subsidiary, a computer services company and a legal services management subsidiary. **********Its fiscal year ends on April 30 and, because of the seasonal nature of the tax-preparation business, it is the final fiscal quarter that provides the company with profits. Typically, the first three quarters of the fiscal year result in deficits. **********''Although Block's share of the tax preparation market is steadily growing, the percentage of taxpayers seeking professional guidance is declining,'' said Misia Celichowska of the Value Line Investment Survey. ''In fiscal 1981, the number of returns Block prepared fell for the second consecutive year. To help stem this tide, Block plans to limit its price increases for the coming season to 5 percent, compared with 13.5 percent a year earlier.'' **********For the fiscal year ended April 30, 1982, Block earned $3.17 a share. For the current year, Miss Celichowska expects net of $3.25 a share. **********In Kansas City, Jonathan P. Braatz of B.C. Christopher & Company, estimates earnings somewhat higher, at $3.40 a share. As for market timing, he said, a study of the last 15 years shows that the best period in which to sell Block's stock is the first and fourth quarters of the calendar year, while the second and third calendar quarters typically have offered buying opportunities. The principle here is to buy low and sell high. **********Value Line ranks Block and Commerce Clearing House as ''average'' market performers during the next 12 months. ''Investors may be concerned about eventual adoption in the United States of a flat rate income tax,'' said Kenneth C. Bohringer of the investment service.  ''But at present, such a possibility seems unlikely.'' **********Last week, Commerce Clearing House reported 1982 profits of $3.50 a share, up from $3.20 in 1981. Several estimates had called for earnings last year to reach approximately $3.70 a share. **********William Fischer, an analyst for the United States Trust Company, is estimating 1983 net at $4.05 a share, down from $4.35 predicted earlier. **********The Computax unit of Commerce Clearing House calculates Federal and other tax returns by computer from data submitted by professional tax preparers such as accountants and lawyers. Individual clients using this service generally are middle- and upper-income persons. Among its other various operations, Commerce Clearing House is a leading publisher of loose-leaf reports and books on current developments in tax and business law. **********J. Kendrick Noble of Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins rates the stock as a ''buy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/world.body_text: **********Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, was quoted here today as having said he thought the United States would soon move in the United Nations Security Council to seek an end to the Iraqi-Iranian war. **********Mr. Aziz, who met here with Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Tuesday, reported on the conversation today in an interview with Le Monde. He said the war was the main topic. **********The Foreign Minister added that, while he and Mr. Shultz did not talk about re-establishing diplomatic relations between Iraq and the United States, they considered it ''useful to establish better understanding between our countries.'' **********Le Monde quoted Mr. Aziz as saying it was time the Security Council adopted resolutions that ''have a constraining character'' so as to bring peace. He said ''Iran's stubbornness'' was responsible for the continuation of the war. **********''The resolutions, in case they are not followed, must include sanctions,'' Mr. Aziz said, according to Le Monde. ''Mr. Shultz welcomed my suggestion in a positive way and I think the United States is going to undertake an initiative.'' **********Mr. Aziz was in Paris to negotiate a settlement of Iraq's civilian and military debt to France, which is estimated at close to $2 billion. ---- Clarification of U.S. Stand Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, May 13 - A senior State Department official said today that although the United States would support United Nations moves to stop the fighting between Iran and Iraq, Washington was not inclined to take the initiative. **********The official said Mr. Shultz did not intend to convey to Mr. Aziz the idea that the United States would take the lead in the Security Council. Moreover, the official said, the United States was not in favor of sanctions in this case. Washington's official position is one of neutrality in the fighting, he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/busin.main_headline: HANOVER, CHEMICAL PLAN TELLER MACHINE LINKUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/busin.print_headline: HANOVER, CHEMICAL PLAN TELLER MACHINE LINKUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Chemical Bank are planning to share their automatic teller machines and to invite other banks in the metropolitan area to join the network. Under the plan, a customer of any bank in the group would be able to use the cash machines of any other participating bank. **********If the program works out as its founders plan, it could pose a significant threat to Citibank's dominance of the automatic teller machine business in the New York area. Citicorp has about 550 ''A.T.M.'s'' in operation, believed to be more than all other banks combined. Manufacturers Hanover has 141 and Chemical about 80. **********Leonard E. Malkin, vice president of Manufacturers Hanover, said the two banks had ''reached agreement in principle.'' William H. Turner, executive vice president of Chemical, estimated that the negotiations would be completed by the end of the year and that the program would go into effect in the first quarter of 1984, if not sooner. **********'Want to Keep It Simple' **********''Our initial intent is to offer cash withdrawals and balance inquiries,'' said Mr. Malkin. ''If the group wants to do more, we'll do more, but at first we want to keep it simple.'' **********The plastic cards held by customers of one bank will be used to gain access to the teller machines of other participating banks. Mr. Malkin said that initially individuals could not use their Mastercards or Visa cards to obtain cash advances from the machines of some of the banks in the system because not all the banks have their teller machines programmed for such services. **********Because it is not clear how many banks initially would participate in the proposed program, it is impossible to determine how many machines would be involved, Mr. Malkin said. Three or four other large banks in the area are taking part in the talks, he added, but declined to identify them. He indicated, however, that they include banks in New Jersey, Connecticut and upstate New York. **********If banks in more than one state do participate, Federal laws that prohibit interstate banking would bar a customer of a bank in one state from making a deposit at an automatic teller machine of a bank in another state. But there are no Federal restrictions on cash withdrawals across state lines. **********Several National Networks **********Shared teller machine networks are common throughout the United States, except in the New York area. There also are several national networks, such as Cirrus System Inc., which is based in Oakbrook, Ill. **********Bruce A. Burchfield, Cirrus' president, said that although 700 banks are hooked up, with 200 more to join by the end of the year, there is only one member in New York State - Manufacturers Hanover - and none in northern New Jersey or Connecticut. Mr. Burchfield said he did not understand why the New York metropolitan area has been slower than other regions in linking its automated teller machines. **********In addition to national groups, there are about 400 regional groups throughout the country, he said. **********Asked whether such linkages might raise antitrust problems, Mr. Burchfield said, ''There's always the possibility of antitrust actions, but if you look at linked A.T.M.'s as delivery systems in which each bank sets its own prices and terms, there should be no problem.'' **********Mr. Malkin said the group being organized for the New York area would probably charge membership fees to each participating bank and fees on a transaction basis. For example, if a Manufacturers Hanover customer used a Chemical machine, Manufacturers Hanover would have to pay a fee to Chemical for that transaction. **********Each bank would decide whether to pass these fees on to its customers. At present, Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical expect to absorb these costs. Elsewhere, according to Mr. Burchfield, most banks absorb the costs but some charge their customers. Many have set fees equivalent to those on traveler's checks, or $1 for every $100 withdrawn. **********Machines Cost $180,000 **********The reason most banks opt to absorb the costs is because it is cheaper than installing hundreds of their own machines. **********Mr. Malkin estimates that in New York each machine costs up to $180,000. Thus, by sharing their machines, other banks in the area might be able to compete more effectively with Citibank without having to spend tens of millions of dollars to install many more machines. **********William J. Heron, senior vice president of Citibank, said yesterday that the proposed system ''would represent a new competitive element.'' But he added, ''Its success will only be a result of effective marketing, and that requires each member of the group to subordinate its own marketing efforts to those of the group. In the past, that has not worked very well.'' **********Installing and operating the machines is more costly than hiring a teller, and the machines pay off only if they generate enough volume by working 24 hours a day, seven days a week. That is why marketing becomes so important, Mr. Heron said. **********Mr. Turner of Chemical said the proposed network would be open to all banks in the area, including Citibank. But at present Citibank cannot link its machines to those of other banks because Citibank's units are not compatible. **********A Citibank spokesman said, however, that it would be easy to adjust its machines to achieve compatibility. Citibank is considering joining or forming a shared network of its own, but no decisions have been made, according to Mr. Heron.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it lost $3.3 million in its fiscal second quarter this year, an improvement over a $13.2 million loss in the same period of 1982. It said it lost $5.7 million in the first six months of fiscal year 1983, compared with $7.7 million for the first six months of fiscal year 1982. **********For the latest quarter, revenues declined to $51.2 million from $58.5 million in the same period last year.  The company said it lost $727,000 from continuing operations for the latest quarter, compared with a $920,000 loss in the second quarter of 1982. Its loss from continuing operations was about $3 million for the first six months of the fiscal year, compared with $2.3 million in losses from continuing operations in the 1982 period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.body_text: **********TECHNOLOGY stocks have doubled in price since the bull market began in August. Since then, major market indicators have scored a creditable, but less heady, gain of 45 percent. **********Investors flocked to high-technology issues, typically found in such industries as data processing, communications and semiconductors, because they offered a faster perceived rate of earnings growth than available in many less glamorous companies. **********By February, however, the high-technology boom had taken on a decidedly speculative tone and brokerage firms soon scrambled to hoist warning flags. ''These issues,'' Merrill Lynch told clients, ''appear to us to be most vulnerable to a market correction, should one develop.'' **********At Shearson/American Express, John D. Connolly, the director of research, called attention to the ''froth'' apparent in the technology group. **********Decrying the scramble for high-technology issues, Raymond F. DeVoe, a strategist for Legg Mason Wood Walker, said that a long-term bull market depended upon ''the growth of controlled euphoria.'' **********Thus, by the end of February, a growing worry on Wall Street was that an unrestrained buying binge in high-technology issues could cause a sharp selloff for the entire market. But, so far in March, the high-technology issues have cooled off a bit and the bull market remains intact. **********''It is a healthy development,'' Mr. Connolly of Shearson/American Express said in an interview last Sunday. ''Strength in the technology group has been ebbing, so that for the last two or three weeks these stocks have ranked as average market performers.'' **********Meanwhile, for investors willing to look ahead six months, say, Mr. Connolly is convinced that high-technology issues ''will do better than the general market.'' ''The dynamics for higher earnings growth are present in selected high-tech stocks,'' he said, ''and that's what common stocks are all about -growth.'' **********Among the firm's current recommendations are such issues as Apple Computer, Digital Equipment, Avantek, California Microwave, Harris Corporation, Tymshare and M/ A-Com, as well as International Business Machines and NCR. **********Several factors, aside from the repeated warnings of investment firms, combined recently to help cool off the heated demand for technology stocks. In some cases, brokerage houses and investment advisers erased issues from their lists of purchase recommendations.  In early March, for example, Shearson/American Express removed Wang Laboratories as a recommendation, partly on the premise that ''the caution flag is out for word processing stocks in general.'' **********In Minneapolis, the Leuthold Group eliminated Advanced Micro Devices, a major semiconductor producer that was the largest holding in its equity model portfolio, citing a price-earnings ratio of 55 and ''the intensity of insider selling.'' **********At Dean Witter Reynolds, only three issues in the firm's list of 30 ''emerging growth stocks,'' replete with technology issues, are recommended currently as ''buys.'' These include Newport Corporation, the leading domestic producer of components for laser research, and Quotron Systems, the leading supplier in the United States for financial quotation display systems. However, the firm carries a ''buy/hold'' rating on a number of other technology stocks, ranging from Cullinet Softwear to the Systems and Computer Technology Corporation. **********''People's perceptions of valuation are undergoing a change,'' said William J. Ritger of Dean Witter. ''In effect, people are saying that it's time to be a little cautious.'' **********Historically, stocks with strong earnings growth have carried a much higher price-earnings multiple than the general market. Dean Witter's 30-stock, emerging growth list shows an average multiple of 26 times estimated earnings for 1983, compared with about 10 times for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********Meanwhile, some analysts say that, since high-technology stocks are generally twice as volatile in their price action as the average issue, any forthcoming correction in the market could, temporarily at least, produce correspondingly sharper downdrafts in the hightechnology group. **********One clue to the recent cooling-off period in the technology sector is apparent in the reception of several new issues deemed to be ''hot,'' or eagerly sought after. **********Diasonics, a producer of medical scanning equipment, went public on Feb. 13 at an initial price of 22. The stock rose nearly 5 points in its first day of trading. Yesterday, it gained 3/4, to 22 3/4 bid.  Fortune Systems, which makes a desktop computer system, made its debut on March 7, also at 22. It closed at 17 1/8 bid, down 3/4, yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan said today that he had no complaints about the performance of Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, in a separate appearance, said that, even if Mr. Volcker were replaced, it would not have the adverse impact on the financial markets and interest rates that some Wall Street bankers have predicted. **********Mr. Reagan, who addressed the convention of the American Newspaper Publishers in New York, was asked if anything bothered him about Mr.  Volcker's performance. ''Not a thing,'' he replied. **********Mr. Volcker's four-year term as chairman of the nation's central bank ends Aug. 6. Although there have been reports the President will replace Mr. Volcker or that most of Mr. Reagan's advisers support replacing Mr. Volcker, the President and his spokesmen have denied them. **********On other matters, Mr. Regan said in a morning meeting with reporters that a bill to delay for at least four years tax withholding on dividend and interest payments would be ''a nightmare of bureaucracy'' and worse than the current law that calls for withholding of 10 percent of dividends and interest payments to most people, effective July 1. He said that the bill, approved last week by the Senate, would result in having the Internal Revenue Service chase individual taxpayers ''more than anyone would want.'' **********Under the proposal to put off withholding until 1987, Mr. Regan said, people will violate its strengthened reporting requirements if they fail to report dividend and interest income, if they make a mistake of $50 or more or if their report disagrees with what banks and corporations report to the revenue service about payments of dividends and interest to individuals. **********When the revenue service finds such a violation, it would notify all the institutions paying the taxpayer dividends or interest to begin withholding at a 20 percent rate 61 days after the notice. At the same time, the taxpayer would be notified and has 45 days to make payment or clear up the error. After the 61 days, if the violation is not cleared up, 20 percent of the taxpayer's future interest and dividend payments would have to be withheld.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the broadcasting of pages of teletext services for reception by television sets. **********The system, now in operation on an experimental basis in Los Angeles, allows viewers with properly equipped television sets to look at news service reports, sports information, restaurant menus, stock quotations and other data at the touch of a button. **********Teletext, as a form of electronic publishing, will not be subject to most of the rules and regulations of broadcasting such as the ''fairness doctrine'' and equal time requirements, the commission said today. Those require broadcasters to allow airing of ''all responsible viewpoints.'' **********Services Could Start Soon **********Several major communications companies, including CBS and NBC, were awaiting today's authorization action by the commission, and are poised to offer various broadcast teletext services of their own.  Time Inc. has disclosed plans to offer similar services employing cable systems rather than over-the-air broadcasting. **********Using the teletext system, the broadcaster sends the printed material on the ''vertical blanking interval,'' a portion of the television signal that is sometimes seen as a black bar when the picture rolls. Thus, the broadcaster is able to air regular programs and the data at the same time, although only viewers with sets equipped with decoders will be able to pick up the teletext. **********Unlike videotex, normally conveyed over cable or telephone lines from a central computer, teletext is one-way and the viewer may not communicate in question-and-answer exchanges. The teletext viewer merely has access to prepared pages of information sent out over the air from a central transmitter. Any one of the pages may be called up on a TV screen through the touch of a button on a keypad similar to the keys on a push-button telephone. Teletext is expected to be accessible to more people than videotex because any existing television station can broadcast the necessary pages of information.  In addition, some experts say that because teletext is less expensive to receive than videotex, it is likely to eventually be used more widely than videotex as a means of providing news and other timely information to home receivers. Price Expected to Come Down **********With the approval today, the new medium could grow quickly, broadcasting officials said, reducing the price of decoders from ''several hundreds of dollars'' to little more than $100 per unit. **********Some broadcasters had hoped the F.C.C. would choose among several leading teletext systems. The commission declined to choose, saying it favored ''the open market approach that will allow licensees the freedom of choice necessary to operate teletext services tailored to their own specific situations.'' No Restrictions on Broadcasters **********In its action today the commission decided to permit both commercial and noncommercial stations to offer teletext. Most stations are expected to offer it on an advertiser-supported basis, F.C.C. staff specialists said. **********A spokesman for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting said today that teletext was seen as an opportunity to diversify and obtain new sources of support-revenue to replace dwindling Federal contributions. However, the spokesman, Don Veraska, said public broadcasters were concerned that the new technology would crowd out the closed-captioning signals now employed for the benefit of deaf viewers. **********The F.C.C. rejected a proposal by Anne P. Jones, one of the commissioners, to consider severing the teletext service from the existing broadcasters and delivering it to new operators as a means to enhance competition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.main_headline: LATIN PEACE UNIT GAINS FEW RESULTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.print_headline: LATIN PEACE UNIT GAINS FEW RESULTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.body_text: **********Nearly nine months ago the Foreign Ministers of Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela met to begin a process they hoped would lead to a rapid quelling of violence in Central America. **********The ministers, meeting on the Panamanian island of Contadora, agreed on the need to ''intensify dialogue at the Latin American level as an effective means of confronting the political, economic and social problems that threaten peace, democracy and stability'' in the region. **********They expressed ''deep concern'' over foreign intervention in the area; they warned it would be ''highly undesirable for such conflicts to be incorporated into the context of the East-West confrontation.''  Same Problems Exist **********Yet today the same political, economic and social problems exist, in some cases worse than before. The United States has sharply increased its military role in the area and involvement by Cuba continues. President Reagan holds fast to the idea that conflict in Central America is a battle between East and West, Communism and democracy. **********With signs of success in its original goals far from apparent, the role of the Contadora group, as it came to be known, has quietly evolved from one of trying to bring peace to the region to that of preventing a broader, international outbreak of war. **********''It is more what you don't see than what you see,'' Mexico's Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, said the other day. ''I am certain that if it were not for Contadora you would have seen a much graver situation.''  Achievements Hard to Define **********Indeed the group is credited within the region for having prevented Honduras and Nicaragua from waging war across their common border. But as the Contadora group seeks a ''mandate'' from the United Nations for its peacemaking efforts in Central America, other accomplishments are hard to define. **********The Presidents of the four Contadora countries - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela - have agreed on the conditions that would have to exist for peace to be attained, but the means to achieve those conditions have thus far eluded them. **********Earlier this month, in what the Contadora group hailed as a significant advance, all five Central American Foreign Ministers - those of El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica and Guatemala - agreed on the same document. The contents have not been revealed, but it is believed to state, in very general terms, a commitment to peace, again without any commitment on how to bring it about. **********The Latin American diplomats involved say diplomacy works that way, that merely being able to convene the five Central American countries to discuss their differences is reason for hope. By the same token, one person who often advises Congress on Latin American affairs said that getting the four Contadora group countries together to discuss things is also an achievement.   One Key Disadvantage **********From the beginning, the Contadora group's quest to bring peace to the area has suffered from at least one key disadvantage: it includes virtually no participation from the major forces doing or promoting the actual fighting. **********Neither those fighting the Nicaraguan Government - such as the leaders of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, which has been staging raids in the north of Nicaragua from bases in Honduras, and the Revolutionary Democratic Alliance, which bombed Managua's international airport a few weeks ago - have shown more than passing interest in becoming involved with the efforts of the Contadora group or in following its edicts. **********Nor do the rebels in El Salvador, who for nearly four years have been battling a succession of United States- backed governments there. The leader of El Salvador's opposition Democratic Revolutionary Front said recently that while the Contadora group had ''prevented a major aggression against the Central American region from the United States President, Ronald Reagan,'' its efforts had been modest. **********For its part, the United States, while repeatedly voicing support for the Contadora group's efforts, has shown little enthusiasm for actually following many of the key principles it espouses.   Viewed as Success by U.S. **********The Reagan Administration continues to view as a success, for example, its support for the Honduras-based rebels fighting Nicaragua's Sandinista Government. It has thus far given no indication it would comply with the Contadora group's admonitions about using the territory of one Central American country to attack another.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Nigeria has no intention of cutting oil prices but may have to trim its output this month to stay within its agreed production ceiling, according to an official source. **********Asked about rumors that the country had cut its $30-a-barrel price for its benchmark crude, a senior Nigerian official said they were ''nonsense.'' **********The official, speaking Friday, said that production during May was around 1.6 million barrels a day, up from April's average of 1.17 million. **********That May level would mean that production would have to drop in June for Nigeria to stay within its Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries quota of 1.335 million barrels a day, which Nigeria considers to be on a quarterly basis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/24/busin.body_text: **********The New Jersey Resources Corporation said today that its board had rejected unsolicited merger proposals from the NUI Corporation and South Jersey Industries Inc. **********Jersey Resources said its adviser, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, said the proposals were financially inadequate and would be too costly to finance. **********In addition, it said, natural gas distributors owned by NUI and South Jersey charge customers higher rates than those charged by Jersey Resources' subsidiary, the New Jersey Natural Gas Company. **********South Jersey had offered $30 a share, saying it would pay cash for up to 30 percent of the shares outstanding and stock with a value of $30 a share for the remaining outstanding shares. The proposal was valued at about $101 million. **********NUI had offered 0.475 share of its common and 0.475 share of a new preferred for each share of New Jersey Resources, with an indicated value of about $86 million. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, New Jersey Resources closed at $26.75, down 37 1/2 cents, after trading as low as $25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/15/busin.print_headline: POLAROID TRIES TO GET ITSELF INTO FOCUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/15/busin.body_text: **********THE scene, as recalled by Edwin H. Land, retired patriarch of the Polaroid Corporation, is surrealistic.  More than 30 years ago, after achieving the startling advance that made possible the first instant black-and-white photography, Mr. Land summoned his friend and associate, Howard C. Rogers, and told him to sit down ''and think about color.'' **********For several years, Mr. Rogers, now the 67-year-old director of research at the company, ''simply sat, and, saying very little, assimilated the techniques we were using in black and white,'' Mr.  Land relates in a collection of his papers recently issued by Polaroid. ''Then one day he stood up and said, 'I'm ready now.' '' A color laboratory was built and color film produced. ''My point is,'' Mr. Land writes, ''that we created an environment in which a man was expected to sit and think for two years.'' **********The anecdote says a lot about the way Mr. Land used to run Polaroid and perhaps it tells even more about why the company is troubled today. Its profits have plunged in recent years, its sales have been flat at best and its future direction is uncertain. It is no longer a place where scientists can sit around and think for a couple of years. **********''We don't have the luxuries we used to have,'' says Sheldon A.  Buckler, a Polaroid executive vice president. Echoing a plaint heard frequently among current and former Polaroid employees these days, Mr. Buckler adds: ''We don't have a, well, we don't have another Land.'' **********The 74-year-old Mr. Land broke off his last formal ties with Polaroid last July, when he resigned as chairman. Last week, for the first time in 46 years, the company's founder and the holder of 8.3 percent of its stock was absent from the annual meeting. **********To one typical stockholder, Roscoe Dwayne of Boston, a Polaroid without Mr. Land is difficult to imagine: ''I just can't picture it.'' **********But there are a lot of things new to Polaroid these days. The company is in the midst of changes so fundamental that no one, including its top managers, seems able to describe what kind of company Polaroid will be in the next few years. **********One thing seems certain, however. Polaroid appears poised to lessen its dependence on instant cameras, a market that caters to the amateur photographers whose appetite for the company's products once seemed insatiable and propelled its stock to as high as $261.75 a share in 1960. (The stock traded at about $32 last week.) **********In the process, say some analysts, Polaroid promises to become sleeker, trimmer and better positioned for broad diversification. ''I think the Polaroid of the future is going to be a much more stable and reliable company,'' says Louis Rusitzky, a securities analyst at Adams, Harkness & Hill, a Boston brokerage firm. BUT while its new leadership is to be lauded for trying to separate P olaroid from its old image as a one-product company, ''this place d oesn't have that old flair'' for inventiveness, says Robin S.  L incoln, a broker at the Boston securities firm of Tucker Anthony & R .L. Day Inc. **********Such criticism puts Polaroid's management on the defensive. At the annual meeting, one shareholder demanded to know whether Polaroid had lost its ''long tradition of creativity.'' William J. McCune Jr., Mr. Land's 67-year-old successor as chairman and chief executive, replied, ''It is a different kind of creativity.'' **********Tall, graying and angular, Mr. McCune in an interview quietly describes Polaroid's transition into tougher and potentially more fruitful fields outside amateur photography. He notes that Polaroid is spending about $100 million a year on research and development in technologies including a variety of specialized chemicals, ultra-thin plastic coatings and intricate precision lenses, all with potential industrial uses in electronics imagery, lasers, magnetics and fiber optics. **********Indeed, Polaroid's biggest competitor, the Eastman Kodak Company, began extending beyond photography years ago. Today, although Kodak has had troubles of its own, its amateur photography division accounts for only about a third of the company's sales and about half its earnings, leaving it less vulnerable than Polaroid to ups and downs in the consumer market. By comparison, amateur photography accounts for more than two-thirds of Polaroid's sales and more than 85 percent of its profits. **********While many outsiders and securities analysts say that Mr. Land's departure clears the way for the company to expand away from photography, others are skeptical. **********George S. Yip, marketing professor at the Harvard School of Business, says Polaroid's previous success raises some knotty questions about the abilities of the current leadership. ''It's a question of management transference,'' he says. ''Was Polaroid's past success based on the product or the management? If it was on the product, then you have to wonder whether the new management has the ability to manage what appears to be a new venture.'' **********Mr. McCune, a Land protege who joined Polaroid as a scientist in 1939, two years after it was formed, is considered a far more pragmatic manager than was Mr. Land. And he, like many others, believes that in producing an assortment of optical and electronics devices as well as a wide range of chemicals and plastics, Polaroid has already built up a treasury of technology for a broad array of commercial and industrial uses. **********Moreover, Mr. McCune is ready to use Polaroid's estimated $335 million cash supply to acquire other companies, something Mr. Land would not consider, to help advance the development of new technolgies. **********Even in areas connected with photography, Polaroid is still bringing out an array of new products, including a system to develop instant 35-millimeter transparencies for slides. The company estimates that each year in American business and industry, photographers take an astonishing 10 billion 35-millimeter slides. **********Actually, Mr. Land established Polaroid in 1937 not as a photography company but to make and market products from his new technology on polarizing, or filtering, light. **********The fledgling company experienced its first crisis early, when the United States auto industry turned down Mr. Land's proposals to install his polarizers on car headlights. Meanwhile, another use of the polarization process - sunglasses - did succeed, and later the company fared well selling goggles, filters and glasses during World War II. **********But it was the invention of instant photography that made his name famous around the globe.  ''I recall a sunny day in Sante Fe, N.M., when my little daughter asked why she could not see at once the picture I had just taken of her,'' he wrote in his collected papers. ''As I walked around the charming town I undertook the task of solving the puzzle she had set me. Within an hour, the camera, the film, and the physical chemistry became so clear to me.'' It was 1944, and Mr. Land was 35 years old. **********In the process, a negative is exposed and then brought into contact with a positive print sheet. Both are drawn between two rollers and a pot of chemicals is ruptured and spread across the positive print sheet. The first instant camera, which Polaroid began selling in 1948, weighed four pounds and carried a retail price tag of around $90. It was called the Land camera. **********THE very first one turned a profit, and tens of millions of Polaroid cameras, in more than 60 different versions, have been sold.  A worthwhile invention, Mr. Land once said, ''must be startling, unexpected and must come to a world that is not prepared for it.'' And his company produced several such innovations, not all of them rousing commercial successes. **********In 1972, Polaroid came out with the SX-70, which produced instant photos that popped out of the camera and completed the development process in the user's hand. It was a departure from the older system, in which the print emerged from the camera incomplete, then had to be peeled away from the negative and wrapper, which then were thrown away. But the development cost Polaroid $600 million, and the company's stock plunged. Yet today, analysts credit the simpler, ''garbage-free'' SX-70 with blunting Kodak's 1976 incursion into instant photography. **********Perhaps Polaroid's biggest misadventure was its instant movie system, Polavision, introduced in 1977 but withdrawn two years later. Analysts said at the time that Polaroid lost $200 million on the system, for which the company was forced eventually to take a $68.5 million write-down on inventory. The instant movie system, which was listed to sell as high as $700, produced movies on a two-and-a-halfminute cassette which was inserted into a television-like screening system. But consumers did not take to the system, which produced poor-quality images and lacked sound. **********The company's troubles mounted. Instant camera sales leveled off as consumers graduated to the higher quality 35-millimeter photo systems whose electronic gadgets had made them easy to operate. Polaroid's overall sales in 1979 flattened, at $1.36 billion, compared with $1.37 billion in 1978. In 1982, sales stood at $1.29 billion. Last year Polaroid's share of the total United States camera market, instant and conventional, plunged to 17.4 percent from 27.1 percent in 1978. **********Profits also began to plunge, slipping finally to $23.5 million, or 73 cents a share, last year from $118 million, or $3.60 a share, in 1978. Finally, years after a younger Mr. Land had spoken so confidently about a wealth-sharing plan for workers that he called ''semi-topia,'' Polaroid began the process of reducing its work force, bringing it from 17,900 in 1978 to 14,200 currently. **********The company offered workers a lucrative retirement inducement last year that resulted in a $30 million write-off against earnings.  Because of the retirement lure and in some cases concern about the Polaroid retrenchment, at least three key executive vice presidents left the company. Theodore N. Voss and Peter Wensberg both went to Atari Inc. and Richard W. Young became president of the Houghton Mifflin Company. **********In 1980, Mr. Land resigned as chief executive officer and director of research at Polaroid, saying he wanted to devote himself to pure science. Then last July he resigned as chairman and a director. He still holds the symbolic title of honorary chairman. **********''Dr. Land is a genius, and much of the creativity of the company came from his perceptions and convictions about things,'' says Mr.  McCune. ''We obviously do not have a genius of that caliber in the company anymore.''  EDWIN LAND:STILL SEARCHING, AT 74 **********CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Edwin H. Land is no longer an active part of the Polaroid Corporation, but he is still involved with the mysteries of light and color, among other things. **********Mr. Land, right, is head of the Rowland Institute of Science, a private, nonprofit center dedicated to basic, no-goal research. And the institute, founded and financed by Mr. Land, has made a discovery of sorts. **********Rowland researchers headed by Mr. Land have learned that perception of light and color is determined primarily by the brain's intelligence system. Previously, researchers believed color was perceived mainly through a spectrum system in the retina of the eye. **********Last year, Rowland moved into a three-story building in Cambridge, near the Charles River and about half a mile from Polaroid's headquarters. **********Other than Mr. Land himself, who would@n't be interviewed, few people know where the name Rowland comes from. ''Honest, I don't know of anyone who knows,'' says a spokesman for the institute. **********Still Polaroid's largest stockholder, Mr. Land owns or controls more than 2.6 million shares, or about 8.3 percent of the company's stock. While other members of his family also own some stock, neither of his two daughters is actively involved in the business. **********Besides his consuming interest in his work - associates say he often spends 12 hours a day in his laboratory at the institute - his time is occupied by his family and by the two mastiff dogs given to him by co-workers upon his retirement. **********Mr. Land, who lives in a rambling clapboard home on Brattle Street, in the heart of Cambridge near Harvard Square, is said to be a very private person - a trait that he apparently developed long ago. In 1928, when he was 18 years old, he dropped out of Harvard after discovering polarization of light and moved to New York City. There, according to company lore, he and his wife, Helen, continued his experiments clandestinely by climbing through a window of the physics laboratory at Columbia University and working long into the night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.body_text: **********A rally in bond prices, begun by professional dealers yesterday, faltered late in the day as institutional investors refused to join the buying spree. **********The reluctance of investors to purchase bonds was attributed to the lack of a clear-cut Federal Reserve policy at this time. While concluding that the Federal Reserve has not yet moved to tighten credit availability, several investors believe the Fed might do so if the basic money supply continues to grow beyond the Fed's targets. **********Wayne Lyski, vice president of the Alliance Capital Management Corporation, an investment management concern, said: ''My own feeling is the Fed hasn't done anything to tighten reserves. But we're taking a wait and see attitude.'' **********He added, ''We're concerned about what kind of growth we've seen in M-1 and would like to have a few more concrete facts that this growth was an abberation.''Awaiting Report on M-1 **********The level of M-1, the measure of currency and checking deposits readily available for spending, will be reported today for the week ended May 25. Several analysts have predicted a drop of about $500 million in M-1, but a decline that small would not make much of a dent in the sharp growth of M-1 in recent weeks. It is now about $16.8 billion above the Fed's 8 percent upper limit for 1983. **********Stephen Slifer, money market economist at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, said yesterday's price rally halted because ''on one hand Preston Martin gave the impression that the Fed would not respond to monetary growth, but there were reports that some Fed members were considering tightening.'' **********On Wednesday Mr. Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated before a Congressional panel that the Fed would not respond quickly to the monetary increase so that it could continue to accommodate the economic recovery. That statement was taken as a sign that the Fed would maintain its present policy of keeping interest rates stable despite the sharp money growth. **********However, other published reports quoted Fed sources as concerned about the surge in money growth and actively considering the possibility of marginally tightening bank reserves, which would raise short-term interest rates.Reaction to Rate Move **********The credit markets were on edge about any sign that the Fed was moving toward tightening its policy, and when the cost of overnight loans between bank - the Federal funds rate - traded at 8 3/4 percent and the Fed did not add reserves to the banking system to help lower the rate, some dealers took that as a signal of tightening and sold securities. **********One trader said: ''People began wondering if the Fed has snugged up a little. Their overall plan is a little uncertain.'' The trader said the market had rebounded earlier in the day because there was strong demand for the five-year, two-month note auctioned Wednesday. The note, due in August 1988, was offered at 99 27/32 to yield 10.53 percent, up from the 10.50 yield set at the auction. After dealers bought to cover previous sales, however, they found there was no retail demand to keep the rally going. **********Mr. Slifer said conflicting views about the Fed's policy is further complicated by M-1 growth. ''M-1 will be a problem for the Fed,'' he said. ''The real issue is: Does the Fed expect the growth to continue? If it does, the Fed will be forced to respond.''Outlook for Weeks Ahead **********However, Peter Treadway, economist at Cralin & Company, a securities trading and investment firm, believes interest rates are still headed lower. He does not think the Fed will move to tighten because he expects ''the money numbers will unravel in the next few weeks.'' **********Mr. Treadway said that private sector credit demand was still weak and that ''the real rate of interest is still too high for a really good recovery.'' **********But Henry Kaufman, the Salomon Brothers economist, told an audience at a University of Chicago economic dinner, ''While the Federal Reserve may hesitate to tighten markets in response to larger-thantargeted growth in money or credit, it cannot avoid doing so ultimately because fiscal policy appears straitjacketed on a course of large budget deficits.'' **********Thomas G. Gribbon, executive vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert,also expressed concern. He said: ''The market is in a tenuous situation. It is looking for something overt. The Fed did not show its hands, but people suspect some change in the wind, and people are not sure what form it will take.'' He said the market ''disciplined itself'' by trading lower yesterday.Offerings by Treasury **********Adding to the supply of short-term securities, the Treasury auctioned $5 billion in cash management bills yesterday. The average discount rate on the 73-day bills was 8.51 percent, and the average discount rate on the 164-day bill was 8.65 percent. **********Reflecting the slight increase in interest rates, the three-month Treasury bill was offered at 8.47 percent, up from 8.46 percent Wednesday. The 10 3/8 percent bond due in 2012 was offered at 95 10/32 to yield 10.91 percent, up from 10.89 percent Wednesday. **********The municipal market continued to suffer from the rate backup as well. In Illinois, Cook County had scheduled a $105.5 million bond issue that was to be awarded on a competitive bid basis. But the county rejected the only bid it recieved and negotiatated for a smaller issue with shorter maturities in an attempt to pay less for the bonds. **********Also Merrill Lynch repriced a $45 million Independence County, Ark., pollution control revenue bond issue, raising the yield on the one maturity due in 2013 to 11 1/8 percent, from 11 percent.
