https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.print_headline: REAGAN ASSERTS BLAME IS HIS IN MARINE SECURITY FAILURE; OPPOSES PUNISHING OFFICERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.body_text: **********President Reagan said today that he accepted full blame for the lack of security measures that permitted the terrorist bombing of the Marine headquarters in Beirut. He said he does not believe any of the Marine commanders ought to be punished. **********''If there is to be blame,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''it properly rests here in this office and with this President. I accept responsibility for the bad as well as the good.'' **********While acknowledging that the marines were ill-prepared to deal with the Oct. 23 terrorist truck bombing that took 241 lives, the President said their commanders ''have already suffered quite enough.''  Report's Conclusions Listed **********Speaking at a hastily called news conference this morning before leaving for his ranch in California, the President said he had read the report of the special Defense Department commission that has investigated the bombing. That 166-page report, which criticizes the marines' security precautions, has not been made public. But officials who have read the report, or who were involved in its preparation, discussed it today. They said these were among its conclusions: **********- The marines were in a difficult position in an increasingly hostile environment and were not adequately trained to deal with terrorists. **********- The entire military chain of command, including the Marine commander in Beirut and the admirals and generals above him, shares blame for failing to insure that proper security precautions were taken against terrorists. **********- The marines did not have the ability to analyze the mass of intelligence on possible terrorist threats that they were receiving. **********- The marines should not have housed so many men in one building, presenting a sizable target for terrorists. **********- United States personnel responded well immediately after the bombing and were correct in evacuating casualties to Europe rather than to closer Israeli hospitals that had been offered. **********- In the weeks following the attack, the marines did reduce their vulnerability to terrorist attacks, but their precautions were still inadequate.   'Felt It Would Be Unfair' **********Although the report did not advise disciplinary action, it recommended that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger take whatever disciplinary or administrative action he deemed appropriate. A White House official said today that after reading the report, Mr. Reagan decided he would override that recommendation. **********The official said the President wanted to make his own statement absolving the marines of responsibility before the report was made public because it was critical of them. **********''He felt it would be unfair to the guys out there to have a board of inquiry or a court-martial hanging over them,'' the official said. ''It would be unfair to discipline them for something nobody could anticipate.'' **********The President ''does accept that the marines' security precautions were lax,'' the official said. ''But you have to realize there are two terms: responsibility and culpability.'' **********Of the marines, he said the President believes: ''Responsibility, yes; culpability, no.''  Commission Member Pleased **********The official said Mr. Reagan received the commission report late Friday and reviewed it over the weekend. He was given a list of possible options for action by the national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, with no particular recommendation on which one to choose, the official said. **********At his news conference, Mr. Reagan said he had ''soberly considered the commission's word about accountability and responsibility of authorities up and down the chain of command.'' But, Mr. Reagan said, he did not believe that the marines' commanders ''should be punished for not fully comprehending the nature of today's terrorist threat.'' **********Adm. Robert L. J. Long, retired, who was chairman of the five-member commission, said he would not comment on the President's remarks today. But another commission member, Robert J. Murray, director of national security studies at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, said he was pleased with the President's statement. **********Mr. Murray, a former Under Secretary of the Navy, said he thought it was ''a good idea'' not to punish any of the commanders, and he said his views ''are a reasonable summation of the commission's point of view.''  Officers 'Did Best They Could' **********The Long Commission report ''did find things that could have been done better,'' Mr. Murray said, ''but we didn't offer recommendations on punishment.'' **********''We left it up to the Secretary of Defense to do as he saw fit.'' **********Mr. Murray said the commission found that the Marine commanders and their superiors ''did the best they could under difficult circumstances.'' **********''Basically,'' he said, ''no one who was guilty of sins was guilty of unreasonable sins.'' **********Of Col. Timothy J. Geraghty, who commanded the unit in Beirut at the time of the bombing, Mr. Murray said the commission concluded that ''it wasn't that he was being stupid or casual or indifferent'' to the security of his men. ''No one foresaw the chain of events that would occur.'' **********Mr. Murray said the findings of the Long Commission report were ''reasonably consistent with the findings'' of the highly critical report on the bombing issued last week by the House Armed Services' Investigations subcommittee.   'His Decision to Make' **********''Their conclusions are the same as our conclusions,'' he added, ''except on one point: General Kelley.'' The House report criticized Gen. Paul X. Kelley, the Marine commandant, saying his testimony to Congress a few days after the bombing contained many inaccuracies. **********But the Long Commission report ''does not mention General Kelley,'' Mr. Murray said. ''He was not in the operational chain of command.'' **********Representative William Nichols, the Alabama Democrat who was chairman of the subcommittee that investigated the bombing, said he would not comment on President Reagan's decision not to discipline any officers, saying ''that is his decision to make.'' **********But Representative Larry Hopkins, the Kentucky Republican who is the subcommittee's ranking minority member, said: ''I admire the President for accepting the blame, but I respectfully disagree. The President should not be held responsible for the failures of military commanders to exercise sufficient oversight on security matters.'' **********He added, ''I think the blame falls between the White House and Beirut.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/02/world.body_text: **********Many Latin American leaders today hailed the results of Argentina's elections Sunday and said they welcomed the nation's impending return to a civilian democracy after seven years of military rule. **********Many congratulated the winner of the presidential election, Raul Alfonsin, who led his Radical Civic Union to a sweeping victory over the Peronists, a dominant force in Argentine politics for nearly four decades. **********President Joao Baptista Figueiredo of Brazil, Argentina's traditional rival in South American political and economic affairs, quickly issued a note of congratulations to Mr. Alfonsin, saying ''friendship between the Brazilian and Argentine people will be even stronger and the cooperation between our countries intensified.'' **********The elections were closely followed in Brazil, where President Figueiredo, the fifth army general to rule since a 1964 right-wing military coup, permitted nationwide legislative elections this year. He may be succeeded by a civilian when he leaves office in 1985. **********In Chile, however, the right-wing military Government of President Augusto Pinochet was silent on the election results. But the opposition Democratic Alliance expressed ''the happiness of democratic friends in Chile for Argentina's return to democracy.''  Paraguay Is Silent **********There was no immediate comment either from Paraguay, another military-ruled nation bordering Argentina, where the President, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, has maintained an autocratic regime since seizing power in 1954. **********In Colombia, President Belisario Betancur said Mr. Alfonsin's election brought Latin America ''closer to the great purpose of our liberators, in the sense of affirming the sovereignty and material and intellectual progress of our nations.'' **********Venezuela's President, Luis Herrera Campins, expressed the hope that the Argentine elections would be a good omen for the entire region. **********President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru said that on the evening of the elections he was convinced ''Argentina will soon recover economically and democratically.'' **********''The people are the true victors,'' said the Mexico City newspaper Excelsior. ''It is a legitimate victory for democracy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/world.main_headline: AIDES SAY REAGAN IS READY TO OFFER ARMS COMPROMISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/world.print_headline: AIDES SAY REAGAN IS READY TO OFFER ARMS COMPROMISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/world.body_text: **********President Reagan has made a preliminary decision to propose to the Soviet Union an interim agreement limiting but not eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe, according to Administration officials and diplomatic sources. **********The officials and diplomats said that at a White House meeting last week, Mr. Reagan indicated he would propose that the Soviet and American sides each be limited to 100 missile launchers with a total of 300 warheads. One key official said it was his understanding that this interim offer would be dependent on Moscow's ultimate acceptance of Mr. Reagan's so-called zero option, which calls for the elimination of all intermediate-range missiles in Europe. Arguments by State Department **********The officials and diplomats explained that Mr. Reagan agreed with State Department arguments that he had to temper his zero-option approach or risk growing West European belief that he was not seriously pursuing arms control. **********Administration officials said there is a possibility that Mr.  Reagan will include this new proposal in a televised national security address he is scheduled to deliver Wednesday from the White House at 8 P.M. **********That would allow him to combine proposals for limiting nuclear arms with what officials said will be a defense of his Administration's military spending plans. In this way, the officials said, Mr. Reagan feels he can regain the political initiative in the United States and Europe and restate his fundamental theme that successful arms control agreements depend on a continuing American military buildup. Timing Is the Key Question **********Administration officials cautioned again today that Mr. Reagan has made no final decisions either on the new missile proposal or the speech for Wednesday night. But at this point, the officials and sources said there was no doubt that Mr. Reagan would offer an interim arms agreement to Moscow - the only question being when. **********Other Administration officials familiar with Mr. Reagan's speech drafts continue to insist that it will contain no new arms control proposals. A Pentagon official said it would deal only with the military budget and the movement to freeze the nuclear arms race as a preliminary step to arms reductions. The Administration has taken a strong stance against the freeze idea, even as it gathers momemtum in Congress. **********The speech drafts now being reworked in the White House are said to resemble Mr. Reagan's June address at Eureka College in Illinois in tone and in the theme of peace through military strength. What officials described as tough early passages about the continuing Soviet military buildup are counterpoised against later emphasis on real reductions in armaments. The speech drafts would have Mr. Reagan reiterating his argument that he could not agree to a freeze until the United States had achieved military parity, and that his military program was making long strides toward reaching parity. **********It was in the Eureka speech, just as he was preparing to go to Europe and face criticism about his tardiness in making new arms control proposals, that Mr. Reagan unveiled his plan for reductions in intercontinental-range nuclear forces. Trying to Please Right Wing **********A Eureka-style speech would also continue Mr. Reagan's pattern of making strident accusations for several weeks on a subject followed by more moderate presentations, trying to please his right-wing supporters and trying to appear centrist at the same time. Recently, Mr. Reagan has charged Moscow with being the focus of evil in the world and implied that Congressmen who seek to cut the rate of increase in military spending may be giving comfort to Moscow. **********The current round of Soviet-American talks in Geneva on intermediate-range forces is due to end on March 29. Whether the President should unveil his new proposal before the end of this round was not resolved at the White House meeting last week. **********There was said to be considerable sentiment, particularly by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, that Mr. Reagan should wait until April or May. The argument was that if Mr. Reagan shifted his position now, and the Russians rejected it - as they are expected to do - the Administration would fall under renewed pressure from the allies to make yet another compromise proposal before the start of the next round. **********As matters now stand, Moscow has proposed reducing its 500 SS-4, SS-5, and SS-20 missiles facing Europe to the current British and French level of 162 missiles, on the condition that no new American missiles be deployed. Some 108 SS-20 missiles facing Asia would not be included. Mr. Reagan's approach is for the Soviet Union to destroy all of its missiles in return for NATO's foregoing the planned deployment, starting late this year, of 572 new missiles. Pressure From Europeans **********Meanwhile, many Western European leaders have been increasing their pressure on Mr. Reagan to offer an interim solution. In Europe, it was common knowledge that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany had told Washington that even after the recent election of his conservative coalition, he did not believe he had support for new American missile deployments unless new American proposals were made. **********After the White House meeting last week, officials said Administration diplomats were dispatched to North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Brussels to brief the Atlantic allies on the options under review by the President and to signal that he was ready to move toward the idea of an interim agreement of 100 missile launchers with 300 warheads for each side. **********According to diplomatic sources and Administration officials, the American diplomats were to make clear that the 100 American missile launchers would include Pershing 2 missiles as well as cruise missiles. Fear of Pershing Missiles **********There is some sentiment in Europe and in certain circles of the Reagan Administration that Moscow might be tempted by a proposal that would forego Pershing deployments. These experts argue that Moscow particularly fears these missiles, which can reach the Soviet Union much quicker than the slow-flying cruise missiles. **********One Administration official said the new American proposal would also call for freezing or reducing the number of medium-range bombers on both sides. **********Mr. Weinberger has also been in Europe in the last days, and for the first time has spoken openly about the possiblity of an interim agreement. ---- U.S. Compromise Is Urged **********VILAMOURA, Portugal, March 22 (UPI) - European defense ministers called on the United States today to modify its zero option stance at the Geneva arms talks and break the deadlock with the Soviet Union. **********''Everybody has the feeling that there must be some movement in the Geneva negotiations,'' said the Defense Minister of the Netherlands, Jacob de Ruiter, at the close of the first day of a two-day meeting of NATO's nuclear planning group. **********A senior United States defense official conceded that the Europeans want to see new proposals put forward at Geneva, even though they continue to support the zero option as an ultimate objective.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.main_headline: MRS. THATCHER PLANS DEBATE ON DEPLOYMENT OF MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.print_headline: MRS. THATCHER PLANS DEBATE ON DEPLOYMENT OF MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.body_text: **********The British Government, worried about the impact of the invasion of Grenada on public support for the scheduled deployment of American cruise missiles here, has arranged for a special House of Commons debate on the missile issue on Monday. **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her senior ministers believe the debate will serve to drive home their argument that American actions in the Grenada affair have no bearing on the arrangements for the missiles. **********The Government has said that, as an ally, the United States was expected to consult more closely than it did on its decision to invade Grenada, but that it was under no obligation to do so or to be guided by Britain's views. **********By contrast, there is a longstanding and specific agreement giving the Prime Minister veto power over the use of the missiles. **********These arguments have been made repeatedly this week by Mrs. Thatcher and the Foreign Minister, Sir Geoffrey Howe. But they have been lost in the political furor surrounding revelations that the Government was poorly informed and unable to influence President Reagan's decision to begin the invasion.   U.S. Aware of Political Problems **********A senior Government official reviewing the events for foreign reporters said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated to Sir Geoffrey at a meeting Thursday in Paris that the United States was aware of the political problems that the lack of communication caused. The most serious lapse occurred when the British were not told of President Regean's preliminary decision Sunday to invade, leaving Sir Geoffrey in the embarrassing position of telling the Commons Monday afternoon that there was no reason to anticipate any such action. **********A report that President Reagan telephoned Mrs. Thatcher Wednesday night is being interpreted by some officials here as a sign that the White House has also become aware of the shock waves the invasion has sent through the British political scene. **********The Government's political opponents, some of whom dislike the cruise missile in any form, have united in the demand that the Government block deployment of the weapons unless they are under the physical control of British forces. They argue that the Grenadian action shows that the United States is prone to react more aggressively than warranted and that its promises to consult are not reliable. **********President Reagan's speech Thursday night, which was televised live here, did nothing to change the well- drawn battlelines. **********''There's no such thing as an international search warrant,'' said George Walden, a Conservative Member of Parliament, when asked whether the discovery of arms caches linked to Cuba and the Soviet Union was properly cited by President Reagan as a justification for the invasion. **********Bonn Rebukes Reagan on Move BONN, Oct. 28 (Reuters) - The Reagan Administration's decision to lead an invasion of Grenada has hurt its credibility in a way that could significantly tilt the public debate over deploying United States nuclear missiles in West Germany, Western diplomats said today. **********The scope of the damage was hinted at by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany in a special debate in Parliament on Thursday. **********Mr. Genscher said Bonn would have welcomed a chance to discuss United States plans that affected the West German Government ''politically as well as psychologically.'' But he added that the Government would resist ''those who seek to use the developments in Grenada to drive a wedge between us and our American allies or to strengthen their opposition'' to deployment of the missiles. **********A Western diplomat spoke of Mr. Genscher's ''visible pain'' as he delivered a public rebuke to Washington. **********Another diplomat said: ''The West German Government is far more concerned than even its public statements show. Credibility has been seriously damaged and it will be very difficult to recoup.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/world.body_text: **********Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that the nations of the world were spending too much money on arms at the expense of food aid to developing countries. **********Mr. Block also announced that the United States will provide $50 million in direct emergency food aid to 22 drought-stricken African nations, twice the amount originally planned. **********The Secretary is in Rome as chairman of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's biennial conference. **********In an address to the 100 delegates, Mr. Block reaffirmed United States commitment to international food programs, but added, ''The answer to the world's food problems does not lie in the United States. We could not single- handedly feed the world.'' **********At a news conference after the speech, Mr. Block said, ''In the world today, we are spending too much money on arms relative to food and assistance of other kinds.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/01/busin.body_text: **********THE stock market's long-running rally keeps rolling along, and where it will stop, nobody knows. But stockbrokers and their customers alike have turned that question into the favorite guessing game on Wall Street. **********A bear market, it seems, is unthinkable these days. Instead, the guessing hinges on the timing and extent of a temporary pullback in stock prices. ''Correction'' is the operative word here. After that setback occurs, the market will soar to new heights, according to the popular rationale. **********''The observation that a correction is overdue seems to be something of a consensus,'' said Robert J. Farrell of Merrill Lynch fully five weeks ago. ''The best we can say is that most observers have been predicting a correction for months simply because the rise has been so steep.'' **********At that time, the Dow Jones industrial average was at 1,052.98, having started its run at 776.92 on Aug. 12. Last Thursday, the Dow set a new closing high at 1,121.81. Yesterday, it dropped 8.32 points, to 1,112.62. **********In late January, Mr. Farrell also said that for three months about one-third of all investment advisory services had been looking for a correction. Meanwhile, of course, stocks kept rising. **********What might touch off a correction?  Block traders, analysts and other market professionals often respond by uttering two words: ''the unexpected.'' What unexpected event, then, might send stocks tumbling? **********One possibility would be a move by the Federal Reserve Board to tighten credit conditions and send interest rates sharply higher.  However, there seems little likelihood of such action since the Fed is leaning toward easier credit to stimulate the economy. **********Another possibility might be an early announcement by Paul A.  Volcker that he will retire as the Fed's chairman when his term expires in August. There is no hint this is going to happen, but if it did the stock and bond markets would sink because of the ensuing uncertainty. If world oil prices collapsed, that could jar the fragile balance of economies abroad and, perhaps, the fate of some banks in the United States. But, again, there is no evidence that oil at $20 a barrel is imminent. **********Some unexpected shock within the stock market itself could start a general price decline. One candidate might be a scandal in the hot new issue market. Speculation has become torrid in some technology and other companies selling stock publicly for the first time. **********One catch nowadays is that the so-called public, unlike the 1960's, consists mainly of institutions, hedge funds and well-heeled private investors. Hot issues are parceled out to these parties and they, in turn, often ''flip'' the stocks for a quick, almost sure-fire, profit. Thus, the new-issue market has become institutionalized just like the secondary trading market. **********Meanwhile, speculation in general has made the market more vulnerable to a correction, although some stockbrokers minimize the idea. **********One illustration of venturesome investor spirit is seen in a list of 35 stocks published on Jan. 5 by Standard & Poor's Outlook. This was clearly no roster of buy recommendations. The advisory service described the list as ''stocks you should avoid'' and it cited a reason in each case. **********When the market closed last Friday, all but eight of these issues carried higher prices than in early January. Most losers, moreover, were energy-related stocks, a particularly weak sector so far in 1983. **********People who say that some unexpected event will serve as the catalyst for a market correction could be dead wrong. Instead, stock prices might simply reach a level (''overextended,'' in the language of technical analysts) where they fall under their own weight. **********Some analysts have lately pointed to possible telltale signs of an impending decline. One example is the relative weakness in General Motors stock, which had been a market leader in the rally. **********What worries other analysts is a slowdown in trading volume. Record turnover accompanied the market's initial upthrust between August and November of 1982. **********A month ago, Prudential-Bache Securities forecast a 100-point correction in the Dow. Other brokerage firms, including Dean Witter Reynolds, have been predicting a pullback in prices. **********Merrill Lynch has talked of a correction for some time. In mid-February, it posed the possibility that the Dow could reach a new high ''of about 1,100 to 1,125.'' Moreover, since late December, the firm has cited the possibility of a 10 to 15 percent correction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/28/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Ad Hall of Fame Picks 4 More Industry Giants
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/28/busin.body_text: **********John Elliott Jr. of Ogilvy & Mather, Howard J. Morgens of Procter & Gamble, the late Clarence E. Eldridge of General Foods and the late Owen Burtch Winters of the Erwin Wasey agency will be the latest additions to the Advertising Hall of Fame of the American Advertising Federation, the selection committee announced last week. The committee is headed by Barton Cummings, chairman emertius of Compton Advertising. **********The installation will be at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria on March 27. **********Neither Jock Elliott nor Howard Morgens are at the top of their companies any longer, but each had been chief executive officer. Mr. Elliott, who started as a copywriter at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, then saw the light, transferred to the account side and began climbing the corporate heights at Ogilvy. Among his many claims to industry statemanship is service as chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. **********Mr. Morgens, who was with the country's largest national advertiser for 48 years, was its top executive from 1957 through 1974, a period when its annual sales grew from $1.2 billion to $4.9 billion.  The late Mr. Eldridge was close to marketing for more than 50 years as he moved from ad manager of the old Reo Motor Car Company to Young & Rubicam to Campbell Soup and, finally, to General Foods. **********And the final recipient of the honor, Owen Burtch Winters, known familiarly as Obie, was a writer who is credited with writing the presentation that convinced the founders of G.F. to create the company. **********On the advertising side, he was the man behind the line ''I'd walk a mile for a Camel'' and such exciting concepts as ''athlete's foot,'' ''contented cows'' and ''Singing Sam, the Barbasol Man.''

And, although it has an agency repository in mind for it, it is temporarily withholding that information. **********Myrddin Jones, vice president of marketing at C.B.M., said, ''We have already decided on our direction and now it's just a matter of consumating the arrangement.'' **********The figure of $17 million had been published as the ad budget for the introduction of the Commodore VIC-20, but the year's spending is believed to be more than that. **********''We took them from an obscure third place to the No. 1 seller of computers,'' said Amil Gargano, agency president, sounding resigned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Companies in Florida used to complain that the state's poor education system hindered business growth. But three weeks ago Florida acted to raise more money for education by taxing overseas corporate income, and major companies have been objecting bitterly ever since. **********The storm of protest is buffeting the state's carefully cultivated pro-business image and might lead to a legislative about-face. **********At issue is worldwide unitary taxation, which permits states to tax the worldwide income of multinational corporations on the basis of their presence there. On June 27 the United States Supreme Court ruled that unitary taxes are constitutional. It upheld a California law that had been challenged by the Container Corporation of America, a subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation. **********On July 12 the Florida Legislature narrowly approved a $237 million tax increase sought by Gov. Robert Graham to pay for improvements in the state's schools. Most of the increase, about $95 million, is to come from a worldwide unitary tax assessment.  Tax Also Applies to Exports **********While corporations in Florida previously paid state income taxes based on the percentage of their nationwide profit that was generated in the state, worldwide earnings will now be considered. And profits on exports by Florida corporations will no longer be deductible from state income tax returns. **********The new tax has infuriated the leaders of many large Florida businesses. **********''This law will almost completely negate the state's efforts to bring new industry into Florida,'' said Edward Bleckner Jr., president of Racal- Milgo Inc. in Miami. **********Racal-Milgo, a manufacturer of data communications equipment, is owned by Racal Electronics P.L.C. of Britain. Because the new law requires Racal-Milgo to consider exports from Florida and its corporate parent's earnings in calculating its state income tax, Mr. Bleckner said, the company's tax bill could more than double. **********The International Business Machines Corporation, which builds personal computers and robotic systems at Boca Raton, calculates that its Florida taxes will double, to $11.6 million, from $5.8 million. ''We are disappointed and dismayed with the enactment of the unitary tax in Florida,'' I.B.M. said in a statement that called the tax ''unfair and discriminatory.''  Prospects in Capital Unclear **********While business is lobbying vigorously for repeal of the tax, the outlook in Tallahassee seems mixed. **********State Senator Dempsey Barron, one of Florida's most powerful politicians, has called the tax ''exceedingly unwise and not very forward-looking.'' He has said he is ''reasonably sure the tax will be repealed.'' **********Lieut. Gov. Wayne Mixson has indicated that Governor Graham might be willing to consider an alternative source of revenue for the schools. **********But Steve Hull, the Governor's press secretary, has said Governor Graham has no plans to call a special session of the Legislature to repeal the tax. **********California is the only other major state that now taxes companies on the basis of worldwide income. Both Illinois and New York recently backed away from unitary taxation. If Florida keeps the new tax, critics maintain, the state's growth could be jeopardized. **********For two consecutive years a Chicago accounting firm, Alexander Grant & Company, has ranked Florida as the leading state in the nation for starting a business. Tom Cox, a researcher at the firm, said unitary taxation would put Florida at a ''competitive disadvantage.''  New Status for Subsidiaries **********Until now, a foreign company could set up a subsidiary in Florida and pay no state income tax until the new venture itself made a profit. Under worldwide unitary taxation, however, such a venture could owe taxes from the very beginning on the basis of non-Florida earnings. **********Exporters in Florida also must pay the new tax. Previously companies were allowed to deduct the profits from any sales made outside the United States. **********In the past decade, Miami and suburban Coral Gables have become home to the Latin American sales offices of nearly 100 multinational corporations. These units have paid virtually no Florida income taxes because most of their sales are in international markets. **********Florida's exports have already been hampered by economic troubles in Latin America. **********''This additional tax could well be the straw that breaks the camel's back,'' said Coleman Travelstead, executive vice president of the International Center of Florida, a nonprofit business association in Coral Gables. He is an organizer of the Florida Tax Coalition, an alliance of 13 business groups seeking to repeal the new law. **********''If the tax increase is substantial, there's no question we'd have to move,'' said Raymond Hagen, manager of the Goodyear International Corporation's office in Coral Gables.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/16/world.main_headline: Israel Denies Reneging On Prisoner Exchange
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/16/world.print_headline: Israel Denies Reneging On Prisoner Exchange
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/16/world.body_text: **********Israel has rejected a demand by the International Committee of the Red Cross to free several prisoners the committee says were left behind in last month's prisoner exchange with the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********Israel's Defense Ministry said in a communique Tuesday that it had honored all terms of the Nov. 24 agreement for the exchange of nearly 4,600 prisoners held by Israel for six Israelis held by the P.L.O. **********The statement also said the Red Cross had admitted making a mistake in the lists used by both sides in the exchange, and the mistake was compounded by an error on behalf of the Israeli official who coordinated the secret operation with the Red Cross. **********It said the name of Ziad Abu Eian, who was sentenced to life in prison for planting a bomb that killed two Israelis, was omitted from the Red Cross lists and he was therefore replaced by another prisoner - after the Red Cross agreed to the change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/25/busin.body_text: **********Poland's Western creditor banks are ready to reschedule Poland's debt over a three-year period, an official of the Dresdner Bank said today. **********The willingness of the banks to work out a debt-postponement agreement for the $16 billion that Poland owes in debt principal through 1985 would be a sharp departure from the policy followed by the 500 banks to date. **********Thus far they have agreed to year-to-year agreements, in which principal was postponed for 1981 and 1982, but most interest was collected. The debt principal for those years is now due in 1986 and 1987. **********Interest Still Being Negotiated **********Christoph von der Decken, a board member of the Dresdner Bank, which is the coordinator for Poland's Western creditor banks, said at a news conference in Frankfurt that the banks were ready to postpone payment of the $16 billion debt principal until 1989, when the entire amount would be due. But he said the banks were still trying to negotiate an agreement on the $9 billion in interest that would be owed on this principal this year through 1985. **********The Polish Government has said that it would pay the full interest for the three years if the banks agreed to return some of the $9 billion, a procedure they followed for interest payments owed last year. Mr. von der Decken said that the banks were still considering the Polish proposal. He said the main issue was how much of the $9 billion would have to be relent to Poland through 1985. **********Although banks often agree to stretch repayment of principal on outstanding loans, they rarely agree to postpone interest payments.  The decision to in effect postpone some interest payments last year and the readiness now to reach a three-year agreement on debt principal reflect Western concern that if these concessions are not made, Poland would default on its debt, Mr. von der Decken said. **********The proposed three-year rescheduling agreement was the subject of negotations in Warsaw this week between Polish officials and representatives of a six-member group of Western banks. Bank of America and Citibank represented American banks in the group. **********Mr. von der Decken said American banks insisted in 1981 and 1982 on rescheduling one year at a time ''to maintain pressure each year'' on the Poles. But he said all the banks had now agreed to the three-year plan ''in the sense of calming the markets.'' **********If an agreement is reached, he said, ''then we have an agreement on the entire volume'' of Poland's debt to Western banks.  Poland's military Government told the Parliament in Warsaw this week that the nation's external debt would total $28.5 billion at the end of this year, and would climb to $32.3 billion by the end of 1985. Roughly half that amount is owed the banks, with the rest owed to Western governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/25/world.main_headline: U.S. MISSILE OFFER DERIDED BY SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/25/world.print_headline: U.S. MISSILE OFFER DERIDED BY SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/25/world.body_text: **********A commentary in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda today dismissed President Reagan's new proposals on curbing medium-range missiles in Europe, saying they were a ''mockery of common sense'' and calculated to make agreement impossible at Soviet-American negotiations in Geneva. **********The Pravda commentary was one of a series of Soviet press articles that have derided the new United States proposals. However, Western diplomats said the articles were largely polemical and could not at this stage be taken as an authoritative response to measures that Mr. Reagan is expected to announce publicly in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Monday. **********(Soviet arms negotiators were informed of President Reagan's new proposals this week in Geneva, according to officials in Washington. But the officials said that the latest Soviet comment was not necessarily a considered response to the detailed proposal. They noted that the Russians have been criticizing the American proposals all week and that the criticism began as soon as there was some reporting on the proposals in the American press.) **********It appeared that the writers of the Soviet commentaries based their assessments on advance disclosures in the Western media. However, it seemed likely that the writers had been briefed on the outline of the proposals that was put to Soviet negotiators in Geneva last week when the missile talks resumed after a summer recess. The chief Soviet representative, Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, told reporters after the Geneva session that he had heard nothing to make him hopeful about a breakthrough in the talks.   Higher Global Limit **********Reagan Administration officials said Friday that the centerpiece of Mr. Reagan's proposals is a recommendation for a higher global limit on medium-range missile warheads than the United States had previously suggested. But the proposals are expected to hold out for an equal limit on the number of those warheads that may be stationed in Europe, at a level that would require a sharp cut in the existing Soviet arsenal. **********Pravda said the outline of the proposals in the Western press indicated that they were ''nothing new'' and that they still sought to secure the ''unilateral disarmament'' of the Soviet Union in Europe. In this context, the paper said, the proposals could only be seen as a bid to sabotage the Geneva talks and guarantee that new U.S. missiles would be deployed in Europe as scheduled, beginning in December. **********A Tass report from West Germany said that the American proposals still omitted ''one of the issues without a solution to which an agreement is impossible,'' the Soviet demand that British and French missiles be counted on the Western side at the Geneva talks. The Kremlin has offered to cut its missiles in Europe to the level of the British and French arsenals, 162 missiles, if the United States cancels plans to deploy 572 new missiles of its own.   Eroding Equilibrium **********''The United States, as before, is pressing the U.S.S.R. into consenting to a unilateral disarmament in the face of NATO's nuclear rearmament in Europe, clearly with the aim of eroding the military equilibrium existing there and acquiring superiority over the U.S.S.R. and its allies,'' Tass said. **********It added: ''Any well-informed person should realize that the 'new initiatives' of the U.S.A. are nothing else than an old version unacceptable to the Soviet Union.'' **********Another Tass item asked: ''Why did the White House need this cheap trick? The answer is clear: This is apparently being done with a view to abating the mounting wave of criticism in Western Europe and the United States itself of the U.S. Administration's irresponsible, aggressive course, and showing that the anti-Soviet hysteria launched by the United States does not prevent the President from remembering the main issues of war and peace, which are the subjects of negotiation with the Soviet Union.'' **********This apparently was a reference to demands by the United States over the last three weeks that the Kremlin apologize and pay compensation for the South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet fighter Sept. 1 with the loss of 269 lives.  Agreement Still Possible **********A recent series of apparently high- level pronouncements on the missile issue from Moscow have repeated that agreement in Geneva is still possible if the United States abandons its ''unrealistic'' course and accepts the principle of ''equality,'' as defined by the Kremlin. **********The pronouncements by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader; Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the chief of the Soviet General Staff, and Nikolai A. Tikhonov, the Prime Minister, have all implied that compromises at this point must come from the United States. **********The Kremlin has demanded not only that the British and French missiles be included in the Geneva count on medium-range missiles, but also that any agreement void altogether the plan for new American missiles in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.main_headline: East German Says Missiles Hurt Ties With West Germany

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Willi Stoph of East Germany said today that West Germany's decision to accept the deployment of American missiles had damaged relations between the two German states. **********Mr. Stoph said in a speech in Parliament that West Germany had been warned and must now take responsibility for the deterioration. He added that East German policy was to limit damage to the European treaty system and the 1972 treaty with West Germany. **********He said East Germany wanted to continue discussions with West German politicians. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/world.main_headline: ELECTIONS IN PARIS: OF CELERY STALKS AND SOCIALISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/world.print_headline: ELECTIONS IN PARIS: OF CELERY STALKS AND SOCIALISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/world.body_text: **********The city votes twice on Sunday: first, and officially, on things like garbage collection, noise and free boat rides on the Seine for old people; then, figuratively at least, in a national canvass on almost two years of French Socialism. **********The two concepts have constantly run together in the mayoral campaign here, one of the main events among the 36,400 municipal races that will be decided in two rounds of voting that end on March 13. There is a double pattern: one minute, a candidate for the City Council can roar about a dozen celery stalks left negligently on the sidewalk; seconds later, he may turn from garbage to national invective, insisting that Socialism's incompetence is driving France to ruin, or that returning Mayor Jacques Chirac to office means supporting a reactionary. **********According to a poll this week, the second, or unofficial, election is the one that interests Paris voters the most. Some 67 percent said they wanted to express their attitude about the national Government through their local ballot, and only 23 percent said they did not. **********A Long Maneuvering Process **********The points that will be scored now by Mr. Chirac or his opponents are not only part of a long maneuvering process, building and dismantling individual political reputations, but they also count as messages to the Government of President Francois Mitterrand from the electorate on his operating margins for the years until the legislative elections in 1986. **********The voting in Paris, where Mr. Chirac has held office for six years, is the reverse of the situation in a majority of French cities since the municipal elections of 1977, when left-wing gains began to open the route to the presidency. **********The capital's voting patterns are generally oriented away from left-wing candidates, and the national Government, apparently seeking to undercut Paris's status as a potential conservative bastion, talked early last year about a law that would have distributed many of the Mayor's prerogatives to district councils. The intent seemed transparent, and after considerable public resistance here, the Government switched course, settling for a limited revision of the city's statute that leaves the Mayor's office as a meaningful power base. **********Outside Paris the left expects to take substantial losses in the municipal voting but, according to a Socialist planner, it sees the capital as a potential windfall because any gains against the heavily favored Mr. Chirac would be impressive. The operative tactic appeared to be to concentrate on the so-called reactionary Mayor as a national symbol and avoid what would otherwise be a defensive or passive campaign. Attacks on Mayor Chirac **********The attacks on the Mayor have been two-tiered to fit the double sense of the election. On the national level, such a leading Socialist as Pierre Joxe described Mr. Chirac, a potential presidential candidate in 1988, as the ''most reactionary, the most frightening face on the French right.'' **********Calling him right-wing was insufficient for Le Nouvel Observateur, a weekly close to the Socialist Party; it painted Mr. Chirac, who leads the neo-Gaullists, as a man of ''the authoritarian right.'' And although the Mayor's powers fall far short of the intentions ascribed to him, Paul Quiles, the Socialist candidate, accused Mr.  Chirac of representing cuts in social services, an ''economic and social about-face.'' **********Mr. Quiles also attacked the weakest part of Mr. Chirac's local record, the city's acknowledged failure to build as much new housing as he said it would in 1977. The Mayor promised 5,000 new units a year, and the result is substantially less. For Mr. Quiles this is the symbol of Mr. Chirac's hardened attitude toward the world, and a situation that is making Paris into a city of the rich and the poor. **********Mr. Quiles, who is the third-ranking figure in the national Socialist Party hierarchy, has not turned out to be the ideal candidate. A handsome man at age 41, he became slightly ridiculous when an overeager poster campaign emphasizing his blue eyes gave the candidate the look of a hypnotized Paul Newman. Slogan Has Little Effect **********His trademark slogan, ''Paris - Tenderness,'' aimed at suggesting that Mr. Chirac is harsh by contrast, had little effect, because he got into arguments on radio and television and projected more of a cold grip than an embrace. Now Mr. Quiles is given virtually no chance of victory; more important, the **********Socialist Party in Paris seems less likely now than a month ago to do well.  Mr. Chirac has adopted the same local-national approach. He stopped by this week at the construction site of the Bercy Sports Palace, grinned furiously and left. The complex will not be completed for six months, but it seemed the right time for the Mayor to get his picture taken there. Most of his campaigning is done on busy shopping streets, where he reminds voters of his real successes, including advantages for the aged like boat trips, and a modernized sanitation department whose innovations include a motor bike patrol specializing in removing dog droppings. **********The link to national issues usually comes with a question, asked of a shopkeeper, such as ''How's business?'' Whatever the answer, it gives Mr. Chirac a chance to take his best shot at Socialism. **********''It's the system itself that's eating into our freedoms, our individual freedoms,'' he says. ''They hired 200,000 more civil servants nationwide, but I haven't a single new policeman or nurse in Paris. Where are these new functionaries? They're in the offices preparing the new laws that each day limit our individual liberties.'' Embarrassing the Socialists **********With his own victory seemingly assured - technically, the Mayor is elected by a vote of the City Council -Mr. Chirac has spent much time in districts where he thinks there is some chance of embarrassing other leading Socialists besides Mr. Quiles. **********With his help, City Council candidates allied to centrist and conservative parties have a chance at defeating Lionel Jospin, the secretary general of the Socialist Party, Culture Minister Jack Lang, and Edwige Avice, who is Minister for Leisure, Youth and Sports. **********Although Mr. Chirac does not say it, he is also running more than a just a little bit against the other two main opposition figures, former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and his former Prime Minister, Raymond Barre. Beyond the attention from news organizations that he has already received, an outstanding result in Paris would serve to give the Mayor more strength for the maneuvering within the opposition, likely to go for the next five years, to decide who it will run for President in 1988. **********Both Mr. Giscard d'Estaing and Mr. Barre have been campaigning hard, supporting allied candidates and attacking the Socialist Government in general. But Mr. Barre has no local constituency, and Mr. Giscard d'Estaing is not running for anything either; he has left that to his wife, a political debutante, who is seeking election to the Town Council of Chanonat, Pop. 649.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/busin.body_text: **********J.P. Morgan & Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose to $117.8 million, an increase of 37 percent over the $86 million earned in the first quarter of 1982. On a per-share basis, net income rose to $2.76, from $2.09. The company's primary subsidiary is the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank. **********The surge in earnings occurred despite a quadrupling of the provision for loan losses, to $70 million, from $17 million in the period a year earlier. In addition, Morgan said that problem loans almost doubled to $700 million, or 2.1 percent of total loans, from $386 million, or 1.8 percent of the total, in the comparable period of 1982. **********These loans, on which payments are not being made as originally scheduled, rose by $182 million since the beginning of the year.  Morgan attributed most of that increase to loans to Argentina, which could not be paid because of that country's shortage of foreign exchange. At the company's annual meeting yesterday, Lewis T. Preston indicated that a $1.5 billion loan being arranged for Argentina would make it possible to take most of these credits out of the nonperforming category. **********The biggest factor that contributed to the strong rise in Morgan's earnings was an unusually large increase in the spread between the average interest rate that Morgan paid for its funds and the average interest rate it received on its loans and investments. This widened to 3.2 percent in the first quarter of 1983, from 2.6 percent in the comparable period of 1982. In addition to the wider spread, Morgan's earning assets increased by $4 billion, to $50.1 billion. The combined result was a $73.8 million rise in interest income net of interest expense, to $302.9 million. **********Morgan's earnings from foreign exchange trading was also an important element in the rise in net income. In the first quarter of 1983, these profits amounted to $36.3 million, compared with a $2.5 million loss in the period a year earlier. The result was a positive swing of $38.8 million. **********Net income was also helped by a smaller loss, $3.9 million, from securities transactions. The loss amounted to $32.8 million in the first quarter of 1982. Until this quarter, gains and losses from securities transactions had been reported separately and most analysts had concentrated on net operating earnings before securities transactions. That was because banks often purposely take losses by selling low-yielding securities from their portfolios to reduce their taxes. The losses eventually are recouped because the proceeds from the sales are invested in higher-yielding securities. **********As a result of the $3.9 million loss from securities trading in the latest quarter, Morgan obtained a tax benefit of $2.7 million, while the tax benefit from last year's $32.8 million loss was $19.3 million, Morgan said. The change in accounting procedures was mandated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and all bank holding companies must comply with the new rules by the end of this year. Most, however, are putting the new reporting system into effect this quarter. **********Morgan said that its annual rate of return on each $100 of average assets, a key indicator of a bank's basic profitability, rose to 81 cents in the first quarter of 1983, from 64 cents in the period a year earlier. Its return on each $100 of common shareholders' equity rose to $16.95, from $14.28. Marine Midland **********The Marine Midland Banks Inc., the nation's 16th-largest bank holding company, reported that its first-quarter net income rose 17.6 percent, to $23.4 million, or $1.19 a share, from $19.9 million, or $1.04 a share, in the comparable period of 1982. **********Marine's provision for loan losses rose to $23.1 million, from $15.3 million in the first quarter of 1981, and its problem loans rose to $490 million, or 2.4 percent of total assets, from $320 million, or 1.7 percent of total assets. **********Its annual rate of return on each $100 of total average assets rose to 45 cents, from 42 cents in the period a year earlier. Irving Bank **********The Irving Bank Corporation reported a 15.5 percent rise in firstquarter net income, to $24.1 million, or $2.52 a share, from $20.8 million, or $2.37 a share. The provision for loan losses dropped to $6.8 million, from $8.8 million, and problem loans rose to $247.2 million, or 2.39 percent of total loans, from $193.1 million, or 1.92 percent of the total, in the first quarter of 1982. **********Irving's annual rate of return on each $100 of average total assets rose to 50 cents, from 46 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/14/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; UNCERTAINTY ON MONEY DATA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/14/busin.body_text: **********The importance assigned by the financial markets to changes in the nation's money supply has varied widely in recent years and is still in a state of flux. **********The afternoon money supply announcement Friday had little effect on interest rates, which had increased modestly earlier in the day. But in previous days' trading, rapid money supply growth was worrisome enough to cause yields for notes and bonds to rise more than a quarter of a percentage point. **********From October 1979 to October 1982, the weekly money supply annmouncement was often the biggest event of each week and would send prices up or down, depending on whether the money supply seemed to be growing slower or faster than the Fed's growth targets. **********Beginning last October, however, money supply data seemed to wane in importance as Fed officials stressed that the data were distorted by new kinds of bank accounts and an abnormal tendency of the public to hold money in checking accounts at a time of high unemployment and poor economic conditions. Watching the Money Supply **********Along with those explanations, the Fed encouraged lower short-term rates in the last months of 1982, even though most measures of money supply growth were far above target at the time. **********Last week, however, there were signs that yet another change of fashion might be in the offing when the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, referred on two occasions to rapid money supply growth as a problem. His most forceful comments were on March 8 when he told the House Budget Committee that money supply growth was faster than expected, was ''something we have to keep our eye on very closely'' and was not consistent with continued reductions in inflation. **********Robert S. Smith, an economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank, said in a recent issue of International Finance that the Fed might be less willing to tolerate faster-than-targeted money supply growth because of ''evidence from an as-yet-unreleased Fed survey of banks.'' According to Mr. Smith, the survey showed that the introduction of Super NOW accounts and money market accounts had ''depressed rather than stimulated'' the growth of M-1, the basic measure of the money supply. Signs of Fed Policy Sought **********Though there is a growing sense that money supply growth can not be easily dismissed as the result of new accounts, there is no agreement about what the Federal Reserve's response will be in coming weeks. **********Mr. Smith, for example, said that Mr. Volcker's comments ''may be a signal that a more stringent policy is in the offing.'' Elliott Platt, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, suggested that the Fed might keep its policy unchanged. He said: ''There is a lot of interest-sensitive money that is now parked in bank accounts because rates on other instruments have declined. The question is whether all this money will be turned into transactions accounts.'' **********If the money were to stay in the banking sytem and be used for spending and not as an investment, economists would conclude that the Fed has supplied too much credit to the banking sytem and thereby paved the way for more inflation in future years. **********Other economists expect lower interest rates in coming weeks. They reason that the Fed's primary concern is still the economy and that economic recovery will not be sustained without further rate declines. **********Traders keep track of the economic arguments, but their overriding concern is with the immediate condition of the market. Outlook for Short-Term Rates **********To many, Mr. Volcker's comments were enough to erase the last hopes for a decline in short-term rates before the Treasury's auctions later this month. Without declines in short-term rates, they reasoned that it would be more difficult to sell the heavy supply of forthcoming Treasury issues. The result was a decline last Friday in the price of the bellwether 10 3/8 percent bonds to 96 7/8 to yield 10.72 percent. As recently as March 4 the same issue was traded at 99 1/2 to yield 10.43 percent. **********Of course, money supply growth is not the only concern. Maury N.  Harris, vice president at Paine Webber Inc., said in a recent publication that ''the issues of the Fed chairmanship and the Federal budget are probably the two most important keys'' to a sustainable decline in Treasury bond yields to the 9 1/2 percent area. **********Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, urged last week that President Reagan reappoint Mr. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board when his term expires next August. Since the Fed's monetary policy is to be guided by judgments about the economy and inflation rather than to be a mechanical response to the money supply, it is important that the Fed chairman be someone of broad experience, Mr. Kaufman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/world.main_headline: Seoul Opposition Leader Ends a Hunger Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Seoul Opposition Leader Ends a Hunger Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/world.body_text: **********Kim Young Sam, a former opposition leader, said today that he had ended a hunger strike he began 23 days ago, but that he would press his struggle for democratic political changes. **********Mr. Kim, once rated a presidential contender, said in a statement that he had given up the fast because of pleas from supporters, family members and others. **********He said there had also been an effort by the South Korean Government authorities to bring an end to the hunger strike by moving him to a hospital from his Seoul home, where he began the fast on May 18, two days after he had issued a declaration outlining his demands for democratic change. **********The 55-year-old dissident lay motionless and feeble in his hospital bed, eyes closed, while his secretary read the statement to reporters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/busin.main_headline: PHONE RATES ARE IN MIDST OF UPHEAVAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/busin.print_headline: PHONE RATES ARE IN MIDST OF UPHEAVAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The plan by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to charge 75 cents for long-distance calls for directory information is the latest example of an idea that could radically change how telephone users pay for services. **********The idea is to charge separately for each component of service, so that those who use a particular service pay for it. It is similar to the process that took place during the oil shortage of the late 1970's when some gasoline stations began charging for road maps and for pumping air into tires. **********The changes are scheduled because of increasing competition in the telephone industry, spurred by the breakup of the Bell System scheduled for Jan. 1. This increased competition is ending the distortion of economics involved in setting fees for various telephone services that prevailed in the past, when the phone system was run as a monopoly of A.T. & T. **********The new directory assistance charge, which was announced last week and is to take effect on Jan. 1, would apply to 600 million interstate information calls each year now made at no charge by dialing the area code plus 555-1212. **********The charge, which still requires approval by the Federal Communications Commission, is only one such new charge that consumers will see, according to telephone company officials and industry analysts. **********In what would be an even more radical departure, some analysts expect the telephone company to move increasingly toward billing consumers for all their use of the phone system, even for calls that are not completed because the line is busy or the call is not answered. **********That is not likely to happen immediately for general telephone calls, but it is already starting to happen for special types of calls. The new cellular mobile telephone service that is scheduled to start in Chicago this week will bill by the minute, starting from the time the receiver is taken off the hook, so that even uncompleted calls will incur some charge. **********A.T.& T. has also been exploring the possibility of charging something for person-to-person calls, even if the call does not reach the intended party. The reasoning is that those who try such calls should pay something to cover the cost of the operator's time. **********Another example of the trend is the new $2 monthly access charge that will be added to phone bills starting in January. Telephone installation, once subsidized by general rates, is now being broken out separately, so that installing a phone in New York now costs as much as $98.20, compared to $10 in 1970. And consumers who can now make unlimited local calls for a flat fee are finding the telephone company is trying to convert to the type of system long used in New York, in which people pay by the call. **********Unbundling of Charges **********The process of charging separately for different services is known as unbundling, and economists say it is often fairer and more efficient than the old practice of bundling directory assistance into overall long-distance service or bundling road maps into gasoline service. **********''It's an inescapable consequence of competition and indeed, it's a virtue of competition,'' said Alfred Kahn, a professor of economics at Cornell and former chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission. **********Imposing a charge for something cuts down on the waste that occurs when something appears to be free, economists say. Also, those who do not use directory assistance end up paying higher rates for telephone calls to pay for those who do use the free services. **********Nevertheless, unbundling can provoke indignation because people get used to having certain things for free. ''Something that's been given away free for 20 years takes on the character of an inalienable right,'' said Lee Selwyn, president of Economics and Technology Inc., a Boston consulting firm on telephone rate matters. **********Verification Difficult **********Moreover, critics of A.T.& T. often charge the company with bundling or unbundling for its own competitive advantage and not for reasons of fairness. They say the phone system is so complex that it is impossible to verify independently what the phone company says it costs to provide individual services. **********Critics are already charging that the proposed directory assistance charge is too high and is unfair because there is little alternative. Unlike local directory assistance charges, consumers cannot easily avoid long-distance directory charges by using the telephone book. **********''People will be paying more money for a cost they can't avoid,'' said Samuel A. Simon, executive director of the Telecommunications Research and Action Center, a consumer group. **********A.T.& T. said the company will not make a profit on directory assistance. It said it will be billed an average of 64 cents by the local telephone companies in each city, which will actually provide the service and which will be separated from A.T.& T. on Jan. 1. A.T.& T. said it would cost the company 11 cents on average to transmit the directory calls over its long-distance lines to the destination cities. **********Wasteful Calling **********All the arguments in favor of unbundling are used by A.T.& T. in its defense. One is that it will cut out wasteful calling. **********''I had a roommate once that didn't know what a telephone directory was,'' said Robert Self, a consultant on long-distance rates. ''He didn't even remember his mother's number. Every time he'd make a call he'd call directory assistance because it was free.'' **********Another reason is fairness. A.T.& T. said that a survey it took shows that use of directory assistance is highly concentrated. Over a three- month period, only 2.3 percent of residential customers and 27 percent of business customers used interstate directory assistance. If A.T.& T.'s cost figure of 75 cents is valid, then long-distance rates for everyone are about 2 percent higher to pay for directory assistance used by a small segment of customers. **********Some large corporations with their own communications networks also may be using interstate directory assistance to avoid local directory assistance, for which there is a charge, according to Kenneth L. Phillips, a vice president of Citicorp and chairman of the Corporate Committee of Telecommunications Users, an organization of corporate telecommunications users. **********A company in New York could route its local directory assistance calls over its own lines to New Jersey and then send them back over A.T.& T.'s lines to New York as free interstate directory assistance calls, he said. ''This is a technique in the telecommunications business that has been known for many years and is called the rusty switch,'' Mr. Phillips said. **********While such arguments for a directory assistance charge might be convincing, they are not A.T.& T.'s primary reasons for acting. If A.T.& T. was solely interested in fairness and preventing waste, it would have started charging for directory assistance years ago. The new factor that tipped the balance is competition. **********Competitive Services Used **********When A.T.& T. was a monopoly it was advantageous to offer free directory assistance because it encouraged overall calling, which increased the company's profits. But now A.T.& T. is finding that some customers are obtaining numbers for free and then making the actual calls over competing long-distance services, such as those offered by the MCI Communications Corporation and GTE-Sprint. **********That means that A.T.& T. customers are paying higher rates to finance directory assistance used by customers of MCI and Sprint. It also means that A.T.& T. rates have to be that much higher than those of its competitors because it alone shoulders the costs of directory assistance. **********For consumers, there is little choice right now, other than trying to write down numbers so that they do not have to needlessly call directory assistance. **********Analysts expect corporations, which will incur the largest directory assistance charges, to take more stringent steps. They might order phone books from around the country and urge employees to use them. Some large corporations might even set up their own in-house operators to look up numbers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/15/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported net earnings for the fourth quarter rose 15.5 percent, to $428.9 million, or $2.61 a share, from $371.4 million, or $2.28 a share, for the comparable period a year earlier. **********Worldwide sales for the quarter rose 16.9 percent, to $3.59 billion, from $3.07 billion in the 1981 period.  For all of 1982, the company reported net income fell 6.5 percent, to $1.16 billion, or $7.12 a share, from $1.24 billion, or $7.66 a share, in 1981. Sales in 1982 rose 4.5 percent, to $10.81 billion, from $10.34 billion in 1981. **********The Rochester-based company said that sales included an additional $478 million covering two months of sales during the fourth quarter by Kodak's photographic subsidiaries outside the United States and Canada. The company did not say which two months were included, but said it was done to align the reporting periods of all photographic units. However, the inclusion resulted in a $22 million downward adjustment in net income, primarily because of losses resulting from currency translations. **********Kodak's stock rose $3.25 yesterday, closing at $88.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.  Peter Enderlin, an analyst with Smith Barney, said he was somewhat surprised by the market's response because ''there was nothing particularly bullish in the earnings.'' He added, however, that he was estimating an increase in 1983 earnings to approximately $7.95 a share. **********Kodak's chairman and chief executive officer, Walter A. Fallon, and the company's president, Colby H. Chandler, issued a joint statement yesterday in which they said that ''a combination of factors, including competition, currency exchange rates and the restricted economic activity put pressure on our prices and margins.'' **********Looking ahead, they said, ''It is now believed that the economic recovery, when it comes, will proceed at much more modest rates than would normally be expected.'' As a result, they added, 1983 would be ''a year of continued gains in Kodak sales, but we cannot realistically predict corresponding increases in earnings.'' **********The company's photographic division had total sales of $8.94 billion, up 8 percent from the previous year. Most of the increase was in the United States. Had the additional two months of foreign sales not been included, the company said that foreign sales would have shown a 5 percent decline. Dresser Industries **********Dresser Industries yesterday reported a loss of $7.4 million for its first fiscal quarter, which ended Jan. 31. This compared with a net profit of $76.9 million, or 98 cents a share, for the period a year earlier. **********Revenues for the quarter dropped 26.9 percent, to $833.6 million, from $1.14 billion for the 1981 period.  John V. James, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Dallas-based company, attributed the losses to ''the decline in U.S. oilfield activity and the worldwide economic recession.'' He described the near-term outlook as ''uncertain,'' adding that ''any improvement in operating results will depend principally on the timing and extent of the anticipated economic recovery'' and future policies of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********Dresser supplies a wide range of technology, products and services for the development of energy resources worldwide.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********Prof. Robert Dorfman (''A Nobel Quest for the Invisible Hand,'' Oct. 23) observes that it is not easy for a noneconomist to appreciate the fundamental and enduring problems of the foundations of the science of economics. Maybe, but maybe not. **********The invisible hand is thought ''powerful'' and ''subtle'' (Professor Dorfman's labels) because it promises to convert individualistic anarchy (''each to his/her own'') into equilibrium and social stability. Those who seek ''scientific proof'' that the achievement is possible are bound to reap such rewards as Nobels, and so they do. Professor Dorfman, however, would have done better to deal with the question he posed but then ignored: ''Where is the assurance . . . that a host of businessmen flocking to an industry that promises high profits will not so flood the market that their products sell for less than they cost?'' **********When many sellers compete for the favor of the same buyer, the result can be only the overcapacity and overproduction, which result in depression. The ''natural tendency'' of any unregulated market is to crash, not to approach equilibrium, a tendency hidden by the device of ''aggregate'' demand and supply. The probability that this will not occur is so low as to approach zero, an assertion easily demonstrated. **********Suppose that 10 makers of toothbrushes offer 10 different brushes to 10 customers, and each customer prefers a different brush than each other customer prefers. Making their choices simultaneously, all are satisfied, and no brushes are left over. ''Perfect competition'' becomes no competition at all, and I leave it to mathematicians to calculate the probabilities of this outcome. **********Economics holds that competition is efficient, but it is a fundamental principle of management that duplication is inefficient. Since competition and duplication are identical, both principles cannot hold. **********The only search worth making is for a science that could eliminate duplication without imposing centralized authority. This may be impossible, but no more so than seeking to prove that chaos and collapse are efficient. **********FREDERICK C. THAYER Washington, Oct. 24 **********Frederick C. Thayer is visiting professor at the University of Southern California's Washington Public Affairs Center.
