https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/world.print_headline: U.S. TO GIVE CHAD MORE AID; LIBYA SAID TO STRIKE DEEPER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that the United States would increase aid to Chad to $25 million from the present package of $10 million to help it fight a Libyan-backed insurgency. **********Robert Williams, a department spokesman, said the additional aid was intended to give the Chadian Government ''a reasonable chance to defend itself against Libyan escalation. **********He said the precise kind of aid to be given would ''depend on how the situation develops.'' The $15 million would come from a contingency fund and therefore would not require Congressional approval. **********The decision reflected the grave view of the civil war in Chad being taken by Administration officials, who fear that a rebel victory with Libyan aid could threaten other countries in the region. **********The aid decision came as the Government of Chad charged that Libyan planes were carrying out bombing raids deeper into the country.   Reagan Meets With Mobutu **********The situation there was discussed by President Reagan today with the visiting President of Zaire, Mobutu Sese Seko, who has sent 1,600 troops and six planes to help the Government of President Hissen Habre. **********Officials said later that Mr. Reagan had indicated to Mr. Mobutu that the United States was considering what further aid to give Chad besides the $10 million package, which included the sending this week of 30 shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles along with three instructors to train troops in their use. **********The Administration also sent two Awacs electronic planes, capable of monitoring Libyan air activity, to Egypt several days ahead of their scheduled arrival there to take part in military exercises. **********Joining Mr. Mobutu in speaking to reporters today after their meeting, Mr. Reagan said: ''I expressed our admiration for President Mobutu's courageous action in sending troops to assist the Government of Chad in its struggle against Libyan-backed rebels.'' **********In response to a reporter's question, President Reagan made it clear that the United States would continue its maneuvers in the southern Mediterranean despite warnings from Libya against entering the Gulf of Sidra. He said the United States and ''most of the entire world'' considered the gulf to be international waters. Chad Calls for Help **********NDJAMENA, Chad, Aug. 4 (Reuters) - The Government charged today that the Libyan Air Force had expanded its bombing raids in Chad, and it called again on ''friendly countries'' to provide air cover. **********Information Minister Soumalia Mahamat said that the oasis of Oum Chaluba and nearby Kalait, both of which were recaptured from rebel forces two weeks ago, were attacked today by Libyan fighter-bombers. **********The targets were 200 miles southeast of Faya-Largeau, which Government troops recaptured Saturday. **********The minister said that Faya-Largeau was subjected to heavy Libyan air raids for the sixth day. **********Medical sources here said the Libyan planes had used phosphorus bombs against Faya-Largeau. They based their statement on burns on civilians and soldiers evacuated from the town for treatment. They said the burns were typical of phosphorous bombs.   Quick Air Intervention' **********In his call for help, the Information Minister said: ''A quick air intervention from friendly countries is necessary to dissuade Libya from continuing its deadly air attacks.'' **********The Government has made repeated requests for air cover by France - the former colonial power here and Chad's principal supporter. But President Francois Mitterrand's Government has said many times that it will adhere to a 1976 military cooperation agreement barring outright intervention. **********Libya has repeatedly denied its troops and air force have been involved in the fighting. But diplomats here said there was little doubt that Libyan jets were raiding Faya-Largeau.   Libya Says It's Neutral in War **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 (Reuters) - Libya, which does not recognize the Government of President Hissen Habre, said today that it was neutral in the civil war in Chad. **********In a letter to Luc de La Barre de Nanteuil of France, President of the Security Council, the Libyan delegate, Awad S. Burwin, said his country rejected charges by Chad that it was guilty of aggression, including large- scale bombing attacks. **********The Libyan accused the United States and France of supporting what he described as the Habre rebellion against legality.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.main_headline: A Drive Against Thai Pirates Is Paying Off, U.N. Aide Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.print_headline: A Drive Against Thai Pirates Is Paying Off, U.N. Aide Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.body_text: **********A campaign in the waters off Thailand against pirates who prey on refugee boats fleeing from Vietnam is meeting with some success, a United Nations official said today. **********Poul Hartling, High Commissioner for Refugees, who is on a four-day official visit to Japan, said, ''We have been able to cut down the number of attacks, even though they are still going on.'' **********Refugees in flimsy boats encounter pirates off Songkhla, southern Thailand. Of 450 boats that landed in Thailand and Malaysia in the year up to last April, some 200 reported attacks, Mr. Hartling said. **********He said refugees were killed, clubbed, raped and robbed, and added, ''It's a horrible, appalling situation, one of the most violent acts against people seeking asylum in history.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.main_headline: Pope Talks of His Polish Trip Without Mention of Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.print_headline: Pope Talks of His Polish Trip Without Mention of Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II prayed to the Madonna of Jasna Gora today for all those who made possible his trip to Poland last month, but made no reference to the political situation in his native country. **********Speaking in Polish before a crowd of 125,000 in St. Peter's Square, the Pope said the madonna icon had represented a maternal presence in Poland for six centuries. **********''Once again I pray to you, o Mother, for all those who took part in this pilgrimage, who prepared it and who cooperated in it,'' the Pope said in reference to his eight-day visit to Poland. ''Take under your protection the whole nation.'' **********The central event of his visit was the celebration of the 600th anniversary of the madonna at the Jasna Gora monastery, where hundreds of thousands of Poles gave him a thunderous welcome on June 18.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Wayne Newton, the singer, has purchased the Aladdin Hotel-Casino in an estimated $55 million deal that prevents foreclosure of the gambling resort by the Teamsters Central States Pension Fund. **********The deal now must be approved by state gambling officials, who will hold hearings and decide as early as January whether the entertainer will be granted a gaming license. **********Mr. Newton and Ed Torres, a longtime Nevada gaming figure, purchased the Aladdin Hotel in 1980 for $85 million as equal partners. Mr. Torres then bought out Mr. Newton's interest in 1982 for $1.6 million cash and a $7 million note. Mr. Torres subsequently defaulted on numerous loans. **********Details of the sales agreement were not announced but sources close to the deal said the price was an estimated $55 million and that Mr. Newton would finance the deal with a $70 million loan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.main_headline: FOREIGN STUDENTS: BOON OR A THREAT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.print_headline: FOREIGN STUDENTS: BOON OR A THREAT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.body_text: **********AS MORE and more foreign students earn engineering degrees from American universities, their role in high-technology industry has become a hotly contested issue that pits engineer against engineer, educator against educator and nation against nation. **********More foreign students attended American universities last year than ever before, and nearly one-quarter of them studied engineering. And in 1981, for the first time, more foreigners than Americans received American doctoral degrees in engineering. **********Some universities say that without the foreign students, they would not have the faculty or the students to maintain engineering departments. And some high-technology companies say that the industry is in such dire need of engineers that without foreign engineering students they would be forced, as some already have been, to move some of their operations outside the country. **********This point of view was enunciated earlier this month by John Calhoun, director of business development at the Intel Corporation in Santa Clara, Calif. In testimony before a subcommittee of the House of Representatives considering immigration changes, Mr. Calhoun said: ''The problem is absolutely one of a shortage and not one of lower-cost labor. We in the industry have been forced to hire immigrants in order to grow.'' **********Some groups of engineers, on the other hand, say that there is no shortage, that in fact the foreign engineers who remain in the United States after having completed their education reduce the number of jobs and depress salaries. What is needed, they say, is not more engineers, but further training for engineers already in the work force. **********The position opposed to Mr. Calhoun's was voiced at the same hearing by Dr. David Lewis, chairman of the Career Activities Council of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.  Citing data from a nationwide survey showing that salaries had decreased in constant dollars, he said: ''If there were a shortage of engineers, their salaries would have risen.'' **********Now, the world's governments have entered the debate. Taiwan has taken steps to reverse what it calls the ''brain drain'' to the other nations. The United Nations has adopted a resolution calling upon its members to adopt policies to mitigate the damages caused by the reverse transfer of technology. And Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, have introduced immigration-reform bills that would require all foreign students to return to their home countries for two years after they complete their studies here. SUBCOMMITTEE hearings held this month on the Simpson and Mazzoli b ills have provided the most recent forum for the debate. But in t estimony from engineers, universities and industry, the statistics u sed to bolster one side of the argument often contradict those used f or the other side, and those involved say that much of the relevant i nformation is out of date. **********What is clear from the hearings, however, is that the increase in the number of foreign engineering students, and further projected increases, have fueled the debate over whether they should be allowed to remain in the United States after having received their degrees. **********According to the Institute of International Education, foreignstudent enrollment in the United States increased 6 percent in the academic year that started last September, from 307,696 in the 1981 academic year to 326,299 in 1982. Foreign students made up 2.6 percent of the total United States enrollment in higher education. A sharp decline in the number of Iranian students was cited as the reason why last year's increase lagged behind the 8 percent increase from 1980 to 1981. **********In 1982, 23 percent of all foreign students in American universities were majoring in engineering, the largest proportion since the institute began conducting its annual census of foreign students in 1950. There were also increases in the proportion of foreign students who chose business, management, mathematics and computer sciences over the natural and social sciences and humanitites. Such a distribution demonstrates ''the vocational orientation of foreign students,'' according to the survey. **********In the 1980-81 academic year were more doctoral degrees in engineering were awarded to foreign students than to American students, according to the National Research Council. The council reported that 49.1 percent of the engineering doctorates went to foreign students, while Americans earned 46.2 percent. The nationalities of the remaining 4.7 percent of the students was unknown. **********Just how many foreign engineering graduates have returned to their home countries in the last five years has not been documented. The most recent study was conducted by the United States Department of Labor in 1978. In a wide-ranging survey of the aliens holding nonimmigrant visas, it reported that one out of three foreign students did not return to their countries after having finished their education here. **********Both immigration bills introduced in Congress last month would require all foreign students to return to their home countries for at least two years if they wish to come back to the United States. Both bills include sections that would waive the two-year rule for foreign students who marry United States citizens or who, depending on their degree, receive an offer for a job that the Labor Department has certified no American is available to fill. THE Senate version of the bill, however, specifies that no more than1 ,500 aliens who marry citizens can apply for permanent residence andn o more than 4,500 aliens who receive job offers can apply. The Housev ersion also restricts the number of foreign students who can remain h ere by limiting it to those who apply before 1989. **********The Senate passed its version last August, but the House bill failed to reach a vote before adjournment last December. In reaction to last year's bills, a meeting at Snowbird, Utah, of the heads of computer-science and computer-engineering departments unanimously adopted a resolution that recommended that the proposed legislation be amended to retain or ease provisions of current immigration law in their fields. **********In the hearings in mid-March on the new bill before the House Subcommittee on Immigration, Refugees, and International Law, Dr.  Lewis, who said he represented the views of 43 engineering societies, testified that there should be no exemptions to the twoyear rule because there was no shortage of engineers here. **********''Some organizations have claimed that a critical shortage of engineers and computer scientists already exists,'' he testified.  ''They argue that the foreign engineering students should be allowed to stay in the country to replace the alleged critical shortfall of engineering manpower. The Engineering Affairs Council disagrees with that position.'' **********Dr. Lewis, who is the chairman of the Career Activities Council of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, argued that if there were a shortage of engineers their salaries would have risen. **********''In fact, the recent I.E.E.E. salary survey data for 1981 shows no significant escalation.'' he added. ''In fact, our data base shows that the second lowest-paid engineering specialty is computer science, the specialty in which the shortage is supposed to be most acute.'' **********The survey reported that the average salary among a group of 6,702 engineers was $36,867 in 1981. In 1972, the average for a similar sample group was $19,100. Adjusted to compensate for inflation, the 1981 salary corresponded to $17,733 in 1972 dollars. And the higher the income level, the more the engineers lost in ''real income,'' the survey reported. **********Mr. Calhoun, of the Intel Corporation, testified before the subcommittee on behalf of the American Electronics Association, a national trade association for more than 2,000 electronics companies. He said there was in fact a shortage of engineers, that salaries had increased to reflect the demand, and that industry and universities needed the foreign engineering students to meet the demand. **********A study by the American Electronics Association of 610 companies in 1981 projected that there would be an annual shortfall of 20,000 engineering graduates in electrical and computer-science engineering through 1985. In addition, a survey of 1982 salaries published this month showed that the average salary among 67,000 nonsupervisory engineers with degrees increased 9 percent from what it was in 1981. **********He noted that at Intel foreign engineers make up 50 percent of the M.S. degree graduates, and 66 percent of the Ph.D. graduates hired through the United States university system. **********''The shortage is so severe that Intel has already opened design facilities in Israel, France and Japan simply due to the availability of highly skilled technical talent,'' he added. ''Experience has shown that costs of operating an R & D (research and development) facility in these developed countries are no lower than for operating a similar facility in the U.S., but these other countries do have a better supply of engineers.'' **********Other high-technology companies including Atari Inc., National Semiconductor, Wang Laboratories and the Apple Computer Company have moved some of their operations overseas. Such moves by American hightechnology companies give an ironic twist to the political battles being waged over what many developing countries see as the drain of their highly skilled workers to countries where salaries and standards of living are higher. **********The most recent example was a resolution adopted by the General Assembly at the United Nations last Dec. 20. The resolution recommended that members ''should, as a matter of urgency, give due consideration to the formulation of policies with a view to mitigating the adverse consequences of the reverse transfer of technology.'' It also recommended that developed countries ''should assist and support the efforts of the developing countries towards the full utilization of their own trained personnel in promoting their economic and social development.'' The United States, Britain, France, Italy and many of the other developed countries voted against the resolution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Attorneys for the International Gold Bullion Exchange, the gold and silver dealer closed under court order last week, filed petitions in United States Bankruptcy Court here today, seeking to reorganize the company's corporations in Florida, Texas and California under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. **********Filed with the petition were eight cardboard boxes containing names and addresses, on the exchange's stationery, of an estimated 25,000 investors owed money by the company. **********Documents filed with the petitions list the firm's largest creditors as: Dr. Lam (no first name listed) of Boca Raton, Fla., in the amount of $400,000; Elsworth Decker, a trustee for Florence Decker, Elmira, N.Y., for the amount of $300,000; St. Michael's Church of Life in Unionville, Conn., for $278,000; the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for $270,931.97, and Edwin T. Saavedra, Cochabamba, Bolivia, in the amount of $230,419. **********Leonard Elias, consumer counsel for the Florida Attorney General, said today that he will ''vigorously oppose'' the exchange's petition for Chapter 11 reorganization, and try to force the company into Chapter 7 liquidation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/23/world.main_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO FIND OFFICERS AT FAULT IN BEIRUT BOMBING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/23/world.print_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO FIND OFFICERS AT FAULT IN BEIRUT BOMBING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/23/world.body_text: **********A Pentagon commission has concluded that serious failures in the Marine chain of command contributed to the Oct. 23 truck bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut, Administration officials said today. **********The report, which was prepared by a special commission headed by former Admiral Robert L. J. Long, is expected to made public Friday with some parts deleted for security reasons. **********On Monday a House Armed Services subcommittee said it had concluded that ''very serious errors in judgment'' by officers on the ground and up through the chain of command had left the marines vulnerable to attack. **********Advisory in Nature **********Both reports are advisory in nature, although Defense Department officials said they would consider the Long commission report more important because it was prepared by current and former military officers rather than civilians. Any disciplinary action would have to be taken by individual military branches. **********The Administration officials, who are familiar with the contents of the Long commission report, said the Joint Chiefs of Staff met today to review it and to consider what, if any, disciplinary steps should be taken against senior officers considered responsible for security of the Marine compound at Beirut International Airport. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger joined part of the discussion, the officials said. **********One official said the report included ''sharp criticism of the officers in the European Command'' who supervised the marines. The official declined to identify specific commanders mentioned but said that ''generals and admirals'' were involved. **********Two Who 'Will Feel the Heat' **********The commission report also criticizes the performance of Marine commanders in Beirut and their superiors in Washington, Administration officials said. ''General Kelley and Colonel Geraghty will feel the heat,'' an official said. Gen. Paul X. Kelley is Commandant of the Marine Corps and Col. Timothy J. Geraghty was the Marine commander in Beirut from May 2 to Nov. 19. **********''The commission concludes,'' an Administration official said, ''that little consideration was given by any military officers in Washington, Europe or Beirut to the issue of how terrorism might threaten a conventional military force.'' **********The truck bomb attack killed 241 American servicemen. **********Mr. Weinberger, interviewed today on the ABC-TV program ''Good Morning America,'' said, ''The report is critical and blames a number of people for not exercising what in hindsight would have been better judgment.'' He added, ''Whether or not there is culpability depends upon whether or not the individual services involved find that kind of culpability.'' **********According to experts in military law, Mr. Weinberger and senior civilian and military officials have the responsibility of deciding whether individual failures identified by the Long commission should be the subject of disciplinary proceedings.   A Court of Inquiry **********Serious offenses must first be reviewed by a court of inquiry, similar to a civilian grand jury, that is convened by the specific service involved, the lawyers said. This kind of court can recommend the initiation of court-martial proceedings, subject to approval by the Secretary of the service. **********If lesser forms of punishment appear appropriate, the chief of a service or a senior officer can issue a reprimand, suspend pay or take other actions that would block further advancement. **********Defense Department officials said that if the performance of General Kelley or any other service chief was questioned, the individual would not be involved in decisions about disciplinary action. The officials said they did not know whether General Kelley took part in the segment of the service chiefs' meeting today that was devoted to discussing the Long commission report. **********Mr. Weinberger, in his television interview, defended General Kelley on one issue stemming from the bombing, saying that the Commandant did not intentionally mislead Congress in testimony about the attack in the days after the explosion. **********In its report this week, the Investigations subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee challenged the accuracy of information provided by General Kelley in that testimony.   'Conflicting Materials' **********''Paul Kelley was reporting what was made available to him at that time, but he certainly wasn't reporting anything that he knew to be wrong,'' Mr. Weinberger said. ''Early reports are almost bound to be not only incomplete but occasionally contain a lot of conflicting materials.'' In another development today, 70 members of Congress urged the House leadership to give top priority to reviewing American military involvement in Lebanon when Congress reconvenes Jan. 23. **********In a letter addressed to the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, the lawmakers said the role of American military forces in the area had changed in the last three months from ''neutral peacekeepers to active participants in a civil conflict.'' **********''This is not the mission approved by Congress,'' the letter said. **********In a compromise with President Reagan this year, Congress authorized the marines to stay in Lebanon a maximum of 18 months, effective from Oct. 12, when Mr. Reagan signed the bill. But as casualties have mounted since then, pressure has increased in Congress to cut short the stay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/world.body_text: **********Lech Walesa has been summoned to appear at the Gdansk police headquarters after work Friday, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union said. **********''The summons doesn't say what it is all about, but they usually don't summon people after working hours if it is a routine questioning,'' said Mr. Walesa, reached by telephone after the summons was served today. **********The police have called him in repeatedly for questioning in recent weeks.  A spokesman for Mr. Walesa said earlier that the labor leader had issued an appeal for calm during the scheduled visit of Pope John Paul II to Poland next month. Mr. Walesa has repeatedly said he hopes to meet with the Polish-born Pope during the visit and Roman Catholic clergymen have said the Pope seeks a meeting with Mr.  Walesa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/busin.body_text: **********A certain type of algae, plants that grow in water, can be used to produce a useful amino acid that serves as medicine. Two patents on the process were granted this week to Richard I. Leavitt of Baton Rouge, La., and assigned to the Ethyl Corporation, Richmond. **********The desired product is L-proline, and the algae are named Chlorella sp. 580. They are cultivated under high-intensity illumination, which may be either sunlight or artificial light, according to patents 4,383,038 and 4,383,039. **********The process permits re-use of the algae from which the proline has been removed. The invention is part of the company's biotechnology research program, and has not yet been used for commercial production.To get a copy of a patent, send the number and $1 to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/world.body_text: **********Caribbean leaders called today for an end to foreign intervention in Central America and for talks among the nations to end the conflicts. **********In a communique issued after five days of talks here, the 13-nation Caribbean Community expressed concern at growing insecurity in the Central American and Caribbean region and called for a settlement of Venezuela's territorial claim on Guyana. **********The communique also announced a series of agreements on trade and economic issues. The meeting celebrated the English-speaking group's 10th anniversary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/world.body_text: **********Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that Africa, especially below the Sahara, had a serious food emergency and would require 3.3 million tons of food aid in the next year. **********At a hearing of the House Agriculture Committee, Mr. Block said farmers in 23 African countries faced drought that threatened their food production. **********Agriculture Committee members expressed concern about the growth in military aid in recent years compared with economic aid and said they would support an increase in money for food aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.main_headline: FOR REGIONAL SHARES, IT WAS A SLOW START
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.print_headline: FOR REGIONAL SHARES, IT WAS A SLOW START
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.body_text: **********Forty-five minutes before the start of trading yesterday, Robin J. Stonehill did not have a single buy or sell order for shares of Southwestern Bell. **********''Everything can change with one order,'' he said hopefully, his face clearly showing disappointment and his hands nervously tearing apart the top of a used pad. **********Mr. Stonehill, a partner in the firm of La Branche & Company, was the specialist designated to supervise trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in Southwestern Bell, one of seven regional holding companies being shed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Southwestern is the one that will serve Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas. **********Last week, Mr. Stonehill had predicted ''big volume'' in the stock - perhaps 400,000 to 500,000 shares - because there were so many opinions about the proper price of each of the regionals. **********That volume never materialized yesterday. Five minutes before trading began, Mr. Stonehill did get his first orders. But, for the day, he handled only 291,000 shares of Southwestern - the lowest volume for any of the seven regionals - and unexpectedly had time to trade other stocks for which his firm is a specialist. **********It was ''a bit of a letdown,'' Mr. Stonehill admitted. ''I think people sat back and waited for the smoke to clear,'' he said after the market's close. Still, he predicted that yesterday's low volume in all the regionals would increase in the coming months as A.T.& T.'s shareholders decide which of the regional shares to keep. Trading in the stripped-down parent was quite high yesterday. **********A.T.& T. will be divesting itself of the regionals on Jan. 1, with stockholders receiving one share of each regional for every 10 shares of the parent. The trading that began yesterday is on a ''when-issued'' basis because new stock certificates will not be sent out until Feb. 15. **********Trading in every stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange is supervised by a specialist like Mr. Stonehill, whose job is to smooth trading and keep prices from fluctuating too violently. The specialist does this by matching up the buy and sell orders of the brokers who congregate in front of him. And in about one of five trades, he buys or sells shares himself to expedite trading when there are more buy than sell orders, or vice versa. **********This trading for the specialist firm's own account, while sometimes risky, can be quite profitable because the specialist makes part of his money, like any other trader, on the rise or fall of a stock's price. The specialist also collects a fee for handling ''limit orders,'' clients' orders to buy or sell, but only at a specific price. **********Intense Competition for Listings **********An allocation committee of nine stock exchange members divided the new regional companies among the exchange's specialist firms after looking at their capital base and previous record at helping to smooth trading. Competition for the listings was intense, with La Branche winning the stripped-down A.T.& T. and Southwestern Bell, in addition to keeping the original A.T.& T. until its trading stops on Feb. 15. **********As intense as the competition was for listings, so, too, was the preparation for yesterday's trading. Each specialist had to be particularly familiar with his company because he had to set the opening price for his stock and did not have an initial offering price or a previous day's price on which to rely. **********Mr. Stonehill, a 47-year-old, second- generation specialist with 20 years of experience, said he had been studying Southwestern Bell for about three months, ''and certainly for the last two to three weeks on an ongoing basis.'' Recently, he had almost daily meetings with traders and analysts on Wall Street, the last of them on Friday. **********An Early Arrival **********After a weekend of ''getting rid of a lot of aggression on the squash court,'' Mr. Stonehill arrived yesterday at 8 A.M., almost an hour-and- a-half earlier than usual. He assured visitors that ''I'm all set,'' and accepted numerous wishes of ''good luck'' from floor brokers and exchange officials. **********By the time the stock exchange opened its computers to receive buy and sell orders at 8:30, Mr. Stonehill was anxiously awaiting his. **********At 9:15, there were still no orders, but Mr. Stonehill told R. Peter Sullivan 3d, a floor governor helping him to price the stock, that the ''consensus'' on Wall Street was an opening price of about $62, which would mean a 9 percent dividend yield. At 9:30, Mr. Stonehill issued his first price range for the stock, indicating it would open somewhere between $60 and $67. At 9:45, he had narrowed the range to $62 and $67. But there were still no orders. **********Finally, at 9:55, five minutes before the opening, they arrived. ''I knew it would have to come from the arbitragers, and they're always the last to come in,'' Mr. Stonehill said, referring to the professional traders. He admitted to being ''a little relieved.'' **********'A Shot in the Dark' **********Seconds after the 10 o'clock bell, Mr. Stonehill opened Southwestern Bell by handling a block of 49,500 shares - the second-largest opening block for a regional, behind BellSouth - at $62. ''It was what we would call a shot in the dark,'' he said later, adding, ''We were a substantial buyer.'' **********By 11 A.M., trading had already slowed for Mr. Stonehill, and during the rest of the day, it only picked up occasionally. But since his firm's trading in the stripped-down A.T.& T. and the original A.T.& T. got so frenetic, Mr. Stonehill had to pitch in elsewhere. He forfeited lunch out, eating a sandwich on the floor, and started working as the specialist in McDonnell Douglas, the aerospace company, and Arkla, a natural gas company, two of the three companies for which he had been the specialist last week. **********By the end of the day, Southwestern Bell had touched as low as $61 a share and reached as high as $62.125. It closed, in consolidated trading, at $61.625, the only one of the seven regionals to close below its opening price. **********Mr. Stonehill said his firm ended up long, or owning shares, at the close, and La Branche ''certainly'' lost money for the day, not surprising if it bought very much at $62. **********But will the company eventually make money on Southwestern Bell? ''I hope so,'' Mr. Stonehill said and headed home for Weston, Conn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/busin.body_text: **********A bit of Americana and one of the nation's most famous corporate mascots - the Goodyear blimp - will be updated to 20th-century standards, officials of the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation announced. **********The company disclosed plans to build a bigger, faster and modernized airship at a reunion of the Lighter-Than-Air Society in Pensacola, Fla. It will be the first blimp built in 20 years in Akron. **********Blimps were originally manufactured for the Government, and the last one was built in Akron in 1962 for the Navy. In 1958, Goodyear launched its first blimp for purely promotional purposes. The new blimp, estimated to cost $7 million, is to be finished in late 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********I was shocked to read ''Limiting Japan's Access to Our Research,'' (July 24) by William C. Norris, chairman of a major corporation, Control Data. He argues that most research in the United States is performed by universities accessible by Japanese graduate students, while Japan's research is carried out in Government labortories and private companies closed to American corporations. Since it is critically important that the United States be granted access to the markets and technologies of foreign countries equal to the access we provide, the most effective action would be to restrict foreign graduate students, he argues. **********As an educator in a university located near the headquarters of Control Data and as a Japanese who originally came to this country for study in a graduate school, I feel obligated to point out logical contraditions in his argument. First, let us recall that many inventions and discoveries in the United States have been made by immigrants from other countries. Foreigners residing in the United States and foreign-born Americans have played essential roles throughout the history of American achievements in science. **********Most graduate students from Japan or any other country are not sent by home companies to steal results.  They are here to study the truth of science in universities equipped better than those in their home countries. If they are offered good positions in the United States, they are more likely to stay here. Those who complain that graduate students steal results of basic research from American universities should have been hiring them. **********Second, it is conventional wisdom that basic research in Japan is hopelessly backward. What makes Japanese companies successful is their ability to apply widely known basic results into marketable products. A gripe about a closed Japanese market, such as the one described by Mr. Norris, is well taken, since the Japanese Government is notorious for mounting nontariff barriers on imports. However, this does not mean that results of the Japanese basic technologies are closed. Basic research (not R.& D.) is nonexistent compared with the United States. Mr. Norris confused basic with applied research when he argued that Japan's research in Government laboratories and in private companies is closed to Americans while the United States research conducted in universities is accessible to Japanese graduate students. **********It is one thing to gripe over a closed market but another to argue that graduate students are stealing results from American universities. Universities are open to any person who is dedicated to the arts, sciences or humanities, irrespective of nationality. It is a company's responsibility to transform basic research into marketable products. Academic freedom and basic human rights would be violated if students from Japan or any other country were barred from American graduate schools on the pretense of protecting American corporations. Let us not repeat a mistake which led to fellow Americans being sent into concentration camps just because they had Japanese ancestors. TAKATOSHI ITO, Assistant Professor, Economics, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, July 25

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that he would give the United States 12 to 18 months to remove its military bases from Greece if there was no agreement by the end of next week in talks on the bases' future. **********Mr. Papandreou told a meeting of his Cabinet: ''By the end of next week we must have a decision one way or the other. **********If a solution is not achieved, then we will give the United States between 12 and 18 months to remove the bases.'' **********The main sticking point in the talks is the question of grant aid from the United States, which Greece is demanding as part of any American military aid package. Government sources said Athens was also demanding a further half-billion dollars in American investments for the Greek military industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/19/world.main_headline: NEW CHOICE IN SALVADOR: A NEGOTIATOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/19/world.print_headline: NEW CHOICE IN SALVADOR: A NEGOTIATOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/19/world.body_text: **********Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, the man likely to be El Salvador's next Minister of Defense, is known in Government circles as an excellent administrator who enjoys the role of mediator. **********He was called on to replace Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, a military source said, because he is the one ranking member of the military who has the respect of the departmental commanders and is considered able to keep the military out of politics. **********Since October 1979 General Vides Casanova has been head of the national guard, which had the reputation of being the worst of the three security forces for human rights abuses. ''He was called on to clean up the guard,'' said a political source, who added that although the force's reputation has not improved greatly it is no longer considered the worst. **********During the general's tenure, five guard officers have been accused of being involved in the murder of four American missionaries and two have been implicated in the shooting of two American labor advisers. Considered an Outsider **********General Vides Casanova, a political source said, has had a difficult time as head of the guard because he did not come from within the ranks and was considered an outsider by the other officers. ''On different occasions there have been near revolts, but he has managed to maintain control,'' the source said. **********The 44-year-old general comes from a middle-class San Salvador family. His father served in the government's tax department, but both his grandfather and uncle were military men. ''It was considered a family tradition to join the military,'' a family friend said. **********The general graduated second in his class at the Military School in 1959 and since then has served primarily in administrative positions. From 1969 to 1970 he attended the Command and General Staff School in Peru, which was known at the time as one of the most anti-American institutions in Central America. **********''When he came back he was suspected of being leftist because of his ideas on land reform,'' a friend said. A Reputation for Honesty **********After several assignments at the Military School in San Salvador, the general was appointed director of the Salvadoran Institute of Industrial Development, a Government agency that processes large businesses loans. ''While he was there he got a reputation for honesty and won the respect of a lot of people,'' a politician said.  ''But some people see his desire to always talk and negotiate as a weakness.'' **********Some political and military leaders who applaud General Vides Casanova's administrative record are unsure if he will be able to manage the war any better than General Garcia, who is a close friend. His men refer to him as ''Se@norita Casanova'' because of his lack of military experience. **********The air force commander, Col. Juan Rafael Bustillo, who threatened mutiny if General Garcia did not resign by Friday, said the post of Minister of Defense ''would be a good test'' of the general's military ability. **********A military commander said that General Vides Casanova was ''a good man'' but not ''the right man for the job at this time.'' Changes Are Expected **********Others said that because he has the respect of both the rightist and moderate elements in the military he will be able to make the necessary changes and improve the country's military situation. **********General Vides Casanova lives in San Salvador with four children from his first marriage and a child from a second marriage. His first wife died of cancer in 1973. **********His second wife, Maria Lourdes Illach, is in her early 20's and comes from the oligarchy. She was described by a friend as an ''independent'' woman who runs the family coffee farm in Usulutan, is a licensed pilot, and is a political moderate. **********At a recent gathering of businessmen she stood up and asked if they would support Jose Napoleon Duarte, the moderate leader of the Christian Democrats, if he is elected president next December. **********''There was dead silence in the crowd because they were surprised by the frankness of her question,'' a friend said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.body_text: **********B y STEVEN J. MARCUS **********David I. Smith has worked for the General Electric Company for more than 40 years. Employed at the Transportation Systems division in Erie, Pa., he is an expert on the diagnosis and repair of locomotives and is considered one of the company's top field-service engineers. **********But Mr. Smith's expertise is a scarce resource. His help is often needed in many different places at once, and he is in great demand, far in excess of his availability, for training young engineers across the country. When Mr. Smith retires, moreover, his knowledge would normally leave the company with him. **********In this case, G.E. is trying to immortalize Mr. Smith. The company has developed a computer-aided trouble-shooting system, or CATS-1, that carries much of his knowledge and emulates what he would do on the job. **********This system, made public for the first time last week in Washington, at the annual meeting of the American Association for Artificial Intelligence, is by no means alone among serious attempts to apply the tools of computer science to formalizing and roughly reproducing certain kinds of human thought processes. **********Forerunners include Dendral, a system developed at Stanford University to help chemists identify unknown organic compounds; Mycin, Stanford's system to aid physicians in selecting antibiotics for patients with severe infections, and Prospector, a system developed by SRI International to help geologists evaluate sites for mineral deposits. **********But CATS-1 is a significant advance in the ''industrialization of artificial intelligence,'' says Francis S. Lynch, manager of the Knowledge-Based Systems group that developed it at G.E.'s Research and Development Center, because it is one of the first that is designed for routine operation on the shop floor. It may well inspire similar systems, he says, for a wide variety of products and processes, some of which the company is already investigating. **********Developing Rules of Thumb **********An expert system has two basic elements: the ''knowledge base'' gleaned from the expert and the ''inference engine,'' the logical structure within which the computer applies that knowledge in response to available evidence to draw conclusions and recommend actions. **********A major difficulty in building expert systems is that human experts are not usually aware of the exact mental processes by which they diagnose a problem; they apply their knowledge in subtle, seemingly instinctive, ways that elude codification. An effort is thus necessary to determine usable ''heuristics,'' or rules of thumb, that can be embedded into precise logical sequences that a computer can execute. **********For Mr. Smith, the design process, was a labor of love.continuous. **********''I brought the system home to go through its nooks and crannies,'' he says, ''and soon lost all track of time. It's very exciting, and I had a ball.'' **********The CATS-1 system now has 550 rules to cover about 50 percent of the problems that locomotive repair shops may encounter, says Mr. Lynch, and is expected to have about 1,500 rules within a year, enabling it to diagnose 80 percent of locomotive repair problems. **********The system is also unique, he says, in its portability. It is the first to be programmed on a microcomputer for industrial use. **********Other Systems Being Developed **********John H. Clippinger, president of the Brattle Research Corporation, a consulting concern specializing in artificial intelligence, says G.E. is ''one of the first to intelligently and practically exploit the technology,'' but it will not be the last. **********Bell Laboratories has been developing a comparable system, called Automatic Cable Expertise, to encode the know-how of experienced telephone cable-maintenance experts. And I.B.M., Fairchild, Digital, Texas Instruments, Xerox and Schlumberger have also been developing expert systems. **********Not all are limited to repair. Digital built a system to configure components of the company's VAX-11 line of computers for the specific requirements of each customer, and it has been successful enough - the company estimates savings in millions of dollars a year - to have inspired the development of expert systems for other company product lines. **********New Industry Developing **********Until recently, most of the systems were developed by in-house groups within organizations devoted to other pursuits. But artificial-intelligence companies are now forming expressly to design and install expert systems for corporate clients. They include Syntelligence, Smart Systems, Intelligenetics, Cognitive Systems and APEX (for Applied Expert Systems). **********The ''granddaddy,'' only two years old, is Teknowledge. Formed in Palo Alto by 20 computer scientists from Stanford University, Carnegie-Mellon University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it has developed 10 expert systems currently in operation. ''Drilling Advisor,'' for example, was developed for Elf-Aquitaine to diagnose the causes of sticking problems on oil rigs. **********Such a system can save clients a great deal of money, says John Vermes, director of knowledge-systems marketing for Teknowledge, but it costs them a great deal as well. He estimates that a basic core system can cost from $200,000 to $500,000, exclusive of the value of time spent interviewing the expert and training personnel. ''When all is said and done,'' he says, ''the cost of the first stage is about $1 million.'' And integrating the system with the client's data sources, he says, can make the price tag virtually ''open-ended,'' doubling or even tripling the cost. **********Job Elimination Feared **********In expert systems, as in robotics and computer applications in general, a common fear is that people will be replaced. Once Mr. Smith retires from G.E., for example, he will still be available in the form of CATS- 1. Therefore why expect someone else to grow into his position? **********G.E. officials say that its expert system simply assists in training - it is an ''explanation system,'' they say, not a magic black box - and just as students can eventually surpass their human teachers, trouble-shooters so trained may grow beyond the programmed approximation of one expert's knowledge. **********The G.E. expert, Mr. Smith, concedes that the original intent of the system was for any repair shop to plug it in and have an in-house expert like himself. But it evolved from a prompting aid to a teaching tool as field trials progressed, he says. **********''You could take a kid from the Pizza Hut and teach him how to approach maintenance problems,'' says Mr. Smith, ''and you could also retrain an experienced person in a subtle and polite way.'' **********Company officials contend, moreover, that the system will be attractive to professionals because it allows them to concentrate on more interesting tasks. ''It frees the expert from diddly problems,'' says Mr. Lynch, ''and enables him to choose the work he likes best.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.main_headline: Stock Index Contracts Decline With Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES; Stock Index Contracts Decline With Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.body_text: **********As usual, stock index futures prices yesterday followed the drop in the stock market. But the declines in the three indexes varied widely, much to the satisfaction of many traders who play the intermarket spreads in these futures. **********For example, the nearest Value Line futures contract, March, closed at 158.60, off 2.40, while the underlying index fell 1.24, to 157.70. The same Standard & Poor's 500 index futures contract fell 2.80, to 139, but the actual index declined 2.30, to 138.34. The New York Stock Exchange composite index contract finished at 80.15, down 1.80, while the actual index lost 1.24, at 79.79. **********Meanwhile, the narrower Dow Jones industrial share average dropped 19.50, to 1,027.04.  Because each of the three index contracts consists of 500 times the index, each full-point move represents $500 per contract. Each hundredth of a point is $5 per contract. This is also helpful to the spreaders who simultaneously buy and sell short contracts in at least two markets in the hope that the gains will exceed the losses. Most Popular Spread **********''The most popular spread is between the Value Line and S.& P. 500 index futures, because the Value Line has thus far proved to be more volatile than the S.& P. 500, or the Big Board's composite index for that matter,'' said Donald M. Selkin, a specialist in spread operations at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. **********One big reason is that the 1,680-share Value Line index covers more secondary issues than blue chips, but gives equal weight to all issues. By comparison, the S.& P. 500 contains mostly blue chips, with each issue weighed by its capitalization. Another reason is that the average investor tends to favor secondary issues with potentially more growth than the blue chips. **********''A declining market will impact more heavily on the secondary issues and discourage small traders,'' Mr. Selkin noted. ''Thus the Value Line, as our research indicates, tends to be a more emotional gauge than the S.& P. 500, most of whose issues are in institutional or other strong hands.'' Bigger Moves in Rising Market **********As a result, Mr. Selkin said, the Value Line index moves are bigger than the S.& P.'s in a rising market and tend to be slower in a falling one. ''For example, when the market turned upward last August, the Value Line index had an 800-point premium over the S.& P. 500, which widened to 2,150 at the market's peak in November,'' Mr.  Selkin said. At yesterday's close, the Value Line's premium over the same March 1983 futures contract was 1,960 points. **********Based on the performance of the three index futures since the first one, the Value Line, began trading last February, Mr. Selkin said those spreaders who believe the stock market is headed higher favor buying the Value Line and selling the S.& P. 500 short, and vice versa. **********At yesterday's close the March Value Line futures premium was 1,960 points (the Value Line closed at 158.60 and S.& P. 500 at 139.00).  Between last August's upturn in the market and yesterday's close, the premium on the Value Line's March index futures expanded 1,160 points (1,960 less 800), or $5,800 per spread. The initial cash margin brokers require for putting on a stock index futures spread averages $1,500, or roughly half that needed to buy two ''straight'' contracts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/16/world.body_text: **********The police stormed the cockpit of a hijacked Turkish Airlines jetliner at the Athens airport today and arrested a Turk who was holding the plane's crew at knifepoint. **********The police said no gunshots were fired when they overpowered the Turk, who was identified as Mahmout Kalkan. **********The plane was hijacked Friday while on a domestic flight over Turkey. **********Mr. Kalkan, whom police described as a member of the Turkish leftist group Dev Sol, had released all 112 passengers. But he had continued to hold the pilot, co-pilot and flight engineer in the cockpit at knifepoint, airport officials said. Those released included six Americans and several other non-Turkish passengers. **********The authorities said the Boeing 727 with 115 passengers and crew members was hijacked shortly after takeoff from Istanbul.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Tax Planning For Year-End
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Tax Planning For Year-End
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/busin.body_text: **********MANY individuals delay the start of their year-end tax planning until there are just a few weeks or days remaining in the year. But by that time, it may be too late to prepare the strategic moves that must be undertaken in 1983 to help save money when filing Federal income tax forms next April. **********So with about three months to go in 1983, you might consider looking over your tax situation now for steps that can be taken to reduce your potential tax burden. Such actions can be either in response to actions that have already occurred or in anticipation of those to come. **********''Chances are good that you spend less time planning for income taxes than you spend planning for your annual vacation,'' said Roy Harrill, a tax partner of Arthur Andersen & Company, a certified public accounting firm. ''In essence, then, your income tax liability may be determined by default.'' **********One way to prevent this is to first develop a mock-up or worksheet of your 1983 return. Calculate your projected tax - taking into account the changes in the tax law and your own financial situation that affect this year's computations - with a view toward examining the various categories on the sheet for possible alterations that would offer tax benefits.  For example, a look at your withheld and estimated tax payments could determine whether taxes have been significantly overpaid or underpaid. The former unnecessarily deprives you of funds, while the latter might expose you to a non- deductible penalty by the Internal Revenue Service. Your goal here, of course, is to have withholding and estimated payments total no more than that requred to protect against the underpayment penalty. **********If it appears that there will be a large enough underpayment, you could add to your final estimated tax payment or ask your employer to increase withholdings for the remaining months of 1983. In contrast, if you seem to be overwithheld, you could adjust withholding downward by filing a new W-4 form with your employer or lowering the final estimated installment. **********Taxpayers who underpaid the first two estimated tax payments in expectation of 10 percent withholding on dividend and interest income at midyear - a process that never actually took effect - will not be penalized by the I.R.S. for this underpayment. **********Another procedure that some people can follow to reduce taxes is to accelerate deductions and/or to lower taxable income this year. Accountants sometimes refer to this process as stop-and-go tactics, since you try to establish the time when expenses are deductible and income is reportable for tax purposes. **********Under the cash receipts and disbursements method used by most individuals, however, deductions are usually recognized when they are paid, rather than when they are incurred. Similarly, income is usually recognized when it is received, rather than when it is earned. **********Among the deductions that can easily be accelerated if necessary are charitable contributions, since the timing can normally be fixed to suit the needs of the donor. State and local income and real estate taxes due in 1984 can also be paid in 1983. As for medical expenses, if you use a credit card to pay the bill, the amount is deductible in the year charged, regardless of whether this charge is not paid until the following year. **********As for deferring income, some employees may be able to postpone a portion of their compensation until 1984, but this deferral will not be effective if the salary or bonus is available at the worker's option this year. **********In such cases, the revenue service will consider that the taxpayer had what is known as constructive receipt and will tax these funds as 1983 earnings. Business and professional people generally have much greater opportunities to delay income through techniques such as billing customers at a later date. **********The proper utilization of securities transactions is another means of obtaining year-end tax savings. The objective is to pay the lowest tax on realized capital gains and to use capital losses to the greatest extent so as to offset gains that would otherwise be taxable. **********Included in the possibilities when considering stocks and bonds for tax planning are selling short ''against the box'' to lock in an unrealized gain without currently incurring the tax consequences that would result from the sale of the securities. **********A sale against the box is made with borrowed securities, and the deal is not concluded until the taxpayer covers this sale next year with other securities that he or she owns. **********Among the other alternatives for tax savings efforts at this time are acquiring Treasury bills whose interest income is not taxable until maturity or sale next year, making an individual retirement account contribution early rather than waiting until April 15, 1984, or so and asking a dependent whose earnings are approaching the $1,000 income limit to work less until the end of the year. **********Mr. Harrill warned taxpayers, however, that year-end tax planning does not necessarily take precedence over everything else. ''It is always necessary that the results of such planning be consistent with the goals of the broader process of family financial planning,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********The Lockheed Corporation said today that its profit rose 8.2 percent in the third quarter, helped by falling interest rates and a reduced debt load. **********In a separate development, spokesmen for the aerospace company and the machinists' union said about 25,000 Lockheed workers would vote Sunday on a new three-year contract proposal worked out by union and company negotiators during a month of intense bargaining. **********Union leaders are recommending ratification. **********Earnings in the three months ended Sept. 25 came to $59.6 million, or 93 cents a share, compared with $55.1 million, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier, when fewer shares were outstanding. Sales were up 21.4 percent, to $1.59 billion, from $1.31 billion in the similar period a year ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/25/world.body_text: **********Cubana Airlines has been barred from American airspace for two weeks because of two violations of traffic routings that Washington has termed a ''serious breach of air safety.'' **********The State Department said that Cuban officials in Washington had been informed of the suspension on Monday and that it was to take effect at 7 P.M. Eastern standard time last night. **********The deviations from assigned routes occurred on March 4 and 5 and took the planes 27 and 13 miles east of the proper airway, which passes near Syracuse, according to Peter Bruce of the State Department's office of aviation. **********Mr. Bruce said the suspension had been suggested by the Federal Aviation Administration, which operates the air traffic control system, and had been made mainly on safety grounds. Air Force Base Is Nearby **********When asked about any national security implications, he said: ''Both flights passed near Griffiss Air Force Base near Syracuse.  We believe the deviations were intentional. But I cannot comment further about the security aspects of the incident.'' **********Griffiss, a Strategic Air Command Base, is in Rome, N.Y., 45 miles east of Syracuse. It is the base of the 416th Bomb Wing, which operates B-52's. **********Government officials speculated that the deviations might have been intended to save fuel.  Cubana Airlines normally flies six scheduled trips a week as well as charter planes between Cuba and Canada. Under international agreements, the airliners are permitted to fly over the United States so long as they abide by regulations. United States airliners, similarly, cross Cuban territory, mostly between Miami and Latin America. **********Mr. Bruce said that, after the March 4 and 5 deviations, the Cubans had gone back to flying the proper routings. He said the Cuban planes could still fly the runs by following offshore airways and, in doing so, could continue to avail themselves of F.A.A. traffic guidance.  But such routings would take the planes more than 100 miles offshore, and this would be costly in both time and fuel. **********The March 4 violation involved a scheduled flight from Montreal to Havana. The plane was under guidance from the F.A.A. Boston center, located in Nashua, N.H. When the plane entered unauthorized airspace, a controller radioed the plane to return to course, but it did not comply. **********The other violation involved a charter flight from Cuba to Montreal. The crew did not respond to inquiries from the controller as to the reason for the deviation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********When Robert L. Crandall took over as president of American Airlines in July 1980, the hard-driving executive who had made his mark in marketing and finance faced a formidable task. The airline had lost money in seven of the 11 preceding years. **********American had opposed deregulation, which took effect in 1978. When Mr. Crandall arrived, the airline was only beginning to work out a plan to cope with the low-cost, nonunion carriers that were then emerging. **********Also American had to find some way to raise $3 billion to $4 billion over the next five years, mostly to pay for fuel-efficient planes to replace its fleet, one of the oldest in the industry. **********To help Mr. Crandall set the airline on a new course, its chairman, Albert V. Casey, gave the new president a lot of leeway.  Yesterday the Justice Department indicated it thought there may have been too much leeway. In a civil suit, the department charged that Mr. Crandall had tried to fix prices with a competitor, Howard D. Putnam, chairman of Braniff Airways. Several Drastic Changes **********Nobody questions the fact that Mr. Crandall, now 47 years old, drastically changed the course of American Airlines. He quickly cut its staff to 35,000 workers from 41,000. He also met with union leaders and told them bluntly that they must make major concessions in work rules and accept a wage freeze so American could generate enough cash to modernize its fleet. **********The basis of the airline's strategy, however, remained the same: to build up its hub at Dallas.  The hub-and-spoke strategy had become the gospel for most major carriers confronted by deregulation. Since they usually could not compete with new carriers on the basis of cost, the large airlines instead offered more connections at hubs than smaller carriers could match. As part of this strategy, American had moved its corporate headquarters to Dallas from New York in 1979. **********Under Mr. Crandall, American rapidly restructured its routes, changing most flights from long-haul runs and shifting from the Northeast to the Southwest. By the end of 1981 the changes were well under way, with 50 percent of American's flights originating in Dallas, compared with 22 percent six years earlier. Braniff's Fares Slashed **********About this time, however, the struggling Braniff became an aggressive competitor. Under the leadership of Mr. Putnam, who took over as chairman in the fall of 1981, Braniff (also based in Dallas) began to cut some of its fares sharply to win new customers. **********Before Braniff filed for bankruptcy last April and suspended all flights, it resorted to two-for-one sales, offering travelers one free trip for every full-fare ticket. **********This maneuver hit American especially hard, since Braniff overlapped many of its routes. Both Mr. Crandall and Mr. Casey assailed the fare slashing, estimating that it was costing American about $12 million a month in lost revenues. **********About that time Mr. Crandall was accused by some Braniff people of using ''dirty tricks'' to try to weaken Braniff. The Civil Aeronautics Board opened an investigation into the complaints, which led to a grand jury investigation by the Justice Department and eventually to yesterday's complaint.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/05/busin.body_text: **********The nation's copyright and patent laws, which have protected literary works and inventions for nearly 200 years, apparently fail to safeguard much of the computer technology that many people hope will help revive America's economy, according to a growing number of legislators, judges and computer executives. **********They are wrestling with methods of protecting certain kinds of computer programs and the design of virtually all sophisticated computer chips. Both the programs and the chips are basic parts of the thousands of computers sold in this country every month. **********The degree to which present laws protect computer components against unauthorized copying and resale by competitors has become a troublesome legal issue for the computer industry, with possibly millions of dollars at stake. Computer technology has blurred the distinction between literary works such as a book (protected by a copyright) and inventions such as a gearshift (protected by a patent). **********Conflicting Court Decisions **********Numerous cases testing these issues have spilled into the Federal courts during the last year. The cases have yielded conflicting decisions, with some judges despairing because a computer program - a set of instructions telling the computer what to do - and the microscopic circuitry engraved on the silicon chips inside a computer resemble neither a book nor a gearshift. Some legal experts say the issues will not be settled until the Suprem Court deals with them. **********''Nothing has challenged the patent and copyright laws like this issue,'' said Ralph S. Brown, Baldwin professor of law emeritus at Yale University. ''It raises the question of whether we need a whole new system just to deal with computer chips.'' **********To Professor Brown and others, the courts have been forced to choose between protecting a vital new industry and preserving the carefully constructed line between copyright and patent laws. **********Adding urgency to the legal debate is an increasingly bitter rivalry between American and Japanese computer manufacturers. In the last few years Japanese dominance has been established in the market for mass-produced semiconductor chips. And in recent months Japanese companies have begun to move into the growing United States market for personal computers, until recently the sole preserve of American manufacturers. **********Already there have been charges that Japanese producers are copying American computer designs, and industry analysts say the struggle is swiftly moving into the courtroom. **********''In some ways it is locking the barn door after the horse is stolen,'' said Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, a Wisconsin Democrat and chairman of a subcommittee considering a bill that would let companies copyright the ''masks,'' or circuitry, of computer chips. He said that ''we have about six months'' to enact legislation before the absence of protection could harm American companies in producing the next generation of high-capacity memory chips. Problem of Obsolescence **********United States companies have hesitated to rely on patent laws to protect many chip designs because in their fast-paced industry a design could be obsolete before the two-to-three-year process of patent approval is completed. Moreover, there is a legal question of whether chip designs are like dress fashions - simply variations on a single idea and thus unpatentable. **********Hampering the efforts to solve the legal puzzles are disagreements within the computer industry. The strongest protection is sought mostly by large companies such as the Intel Corporation, a manufacturer of semiconductors, and Apple Computer Inc., with a fastselling personal computer that has spawned numerous ''look-alikes'' in this country and abroad. **********Some smaller companies complain that their ability to create new programs and peripheral equipment to fit the most popular personal computers will be impeded if they are denied access to basic designs needed to make their wares compatible with other companies' products. The Franklin Computer Corporation, involved in a legal battle against Apple, contends that Apple is trying ''to use the copyright laws to create a monopoly position'' in the market for compatible equipment. Caution on Over-Protection **********A few major companies, including Texas Instruments Inc., suggest that the problems have been exaggerated and that over-protection could ''reduce the dynamism of the industry.'' **********The flurry of legal action has surprised people who thought Congress had already resolved most legal protection problems in the computer field. Under an amendment to the copyright law that went into effect in 1980, originators of computer programs were permitted to register their works the way they might register a book or magazine article. ''Copyrights protect literary works,'' said Dorothy Schrader, general counsel to the copyright office, ''and computer programs are clearly a subspecies of those works.'' **********But experts say the amendment leaves unanswered two critical questions - one involving computer programs and the other involving the computer chips themselves. **********The first question concerns whether one can copyright a set of highly specialized computer programs, called operating systems, which constitute the most fundamental instructions to a computer about the order in which it should process information. Operating systems are crucial because their structure dictates what other kinds of programs a computer can use, from a word-processing program to one that enables users to perform statistical analysis. Translated Into a Code **********The systems are derived from ordinary computer programs, which can be read by the naked eye. For use in most computers, however, they are translated into a code of ''one'' and ''zero'' or ''on'' and ''off.'' These instructions essentially constitute switches, and they are often engraved on the silicon chips that are built into computers. In their coded form, operating systems are generally unintelligible to most human readers. **********Until last year, most companies assumed that the code was simply another way of expressing a program and thus could be copyrighted.  It appeared to make little difference whether the program was printed on paper, stored electronically on computer disks or engraved on a chip. **********That view was challenged, however, in the case that has pitted Apple against Franklin Computer. Franklin manufactures a computer that is very similar to Apple's, and Apple charges that the logic and structure of its system was copied by the smaller company. In Federal District Court in Philadelphia, Apple sought an order to prevent Franklin from selling its ''look-alike'' model. Injunction Request Denied **********The court denied the request for a temporary injunction, ruling that there was significant doubt whether Apple's operating system was designed to explain or communicate information, a usual test of whether a work is worthy of copyright. **********The court found it was not clear that the code, ''which was not designed to be read by a human reader and can only be read by an expert with a microscope and patience, is a language of description.'' Judge Clarence C. Newcomer said instead that the code was an ''essential element of the machine,'' thus implying that it could not be copyrighted. **********The case is being appealed. Jack Brown, a partner in Brown & Bain, the law firm that represents Apple, points out that other court decisions handed down since Judge Newcomer's ruling have determined that the code is an expression of the computer program and could be copyrighted. **********''Our position is that we are copyrighting the program, and it does not make any difference what form it is in,'' Mr. Brown said. Problem of Unreadable Code **********Although the Copyright Office in Washington accepts computer programs in coded form, it cautions applicants that it cannot certify that the program is a work of original authorship because the code is not readable. **********Nonetheless, some companies are reluctant to file readable versions of their programs, for fear that competitors might use the Copyright Office's open files to gain access to proprietary information. Texas Instruments, for example, registers both the coded and uncoded forms of its programs but ''deletes proprietary information,'' according to Mel Sharp, the company's patent counsel. **********Such practices have brought objections from people who regard the copyright system as a method of preserving open access to information while protecting the rights of the author. ''The notion of secret copyrights is abominable,'' said Professor Brown of Yale. ''Companies are trying to have it both ways: to deposit something in the Copyright Office and to keep it inaccessible.'' A Question on Circuitry **********As for computer chips themselves, there has been less litigation but much debate over the question of whether the circuitry etched on the chips are copyrightable. Congressional hearings are scheduled to open this month on a bill introduced by Don Edwards, Democrat of California, that would permit copyrighting of the chips' distinguishing masks. **********''These chips can cost millions to develop,'' said F. Thomas Dunlap Jr., Intel's corporate counsel. ''Someone who decides to copy them can produce them on a large scale for less than $100,000.'' **********Intel accuses two Japanese companies, NEC and Mitsubishi, of having copied some of Intel's most popular microprocessors. One of them powers the personal computer made by the International Business Machines Corporation. **********The dispute with NEC over the copying of the code imbedded in the chip was settled out of court in March. The dispute with Mitsubishi, involving charges that the company copied masks of the chips, is still unresolved. Neither of the Japanese companies would comment. **********So far, Japanese companies have expressed little opposition to the proposed Congressional legislation, provided it is amended to permit ''reverse engineering,'' the dissection of a product to learn its operating principles. **********The Copyright Office has proven less enthusiastic. ''A chip is a utilitarian article, and it is not good policy to protect utilitarian articles under the copyright act,'' Mrs. Schrader said. **********Some members of Congress and the computer industry favor a compromise by creating a system that would protect chips immediately (like a copyright) but would give them limited-term protection (like a patent).
