https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/17/world.body_text: **********Canada's Indians and Eskimos have been trying for two days to tell Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau that God gave them the land that became Canada, and that it will always remain theirs. Mr. Trudeau was not entirely convinced. **********''God also sent Columbus across,'' the Prime Minister said. ''When do you stop reading history? Only when the white man came?'' The issue was at the core of a discussion between Indians, part-Indians and Eskimos and leaders of Canada's federal and provincial governments. The goal is to define the rights of these groups under Canada's year-old Constitution, something that has not been done in any form. The stakes include spiritual satisfaction, the status of Indian women and land claims potentially running into the billions of dollars. **********The result could eventually lead to the first amendments to Canada's Constitution, which was adopted last April. 'It All Belonged to Us' **********''We have thousands of years of history on this land; you have 200 years of history,'' said Clem Chartier, vice president of the Metis National Council, which represents bands of part-Indians in the prairie provinces. ''It all belonged to us, and we shared it.'' **********Even the Indians suggested much of this talk was simply polemics, readily conceding they do not expect Canada to be returned to them anytime soon. Rather, they asked that their ''aboriginal title'' to the land be accepted as a theoretical basis for agreements to be negotiated over the next decade. Making up only about 3 percent of Canada's 24 million people, they seem keenly aware that their main weapon is moral suasion. **********The conference today and Tuesday -despite such colorful events as Mr. Trudeau's puffing a peace pipe and Indian shamans' chanting prayers - provided ample indications of the difficulty Indians may face in gaining land claims and increased self-government. **********The presence of the premiers of all 10 provinces of Canada, each with differing priorities, promised stumbling blocks. In particular, Quebec, whose government wants to secede from Canada, refused to vote on any matter concerning the new Constitution, which it has consistently refused to accept. Statement by Levesque **********''We cannot participate in this striving towards progress, because in all conscience we cannot stand by to see our own rights stolen,'' Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec said, while maintaining that his province supported greater protection for Indian rights. He warned Indians of the ''pitfalls'' of constitutional negotiations. **********The difficulties posed by bringing the provinces into Indian and Eskimo affairs, which until the new Constitution had been exclusively a federal prerogative, was even more apparent from a group of protesters standing in the rain outside the conference center. **********''Our business is strictly with the federal Government,'' Louis Stevenson, the befeathered chief of the Peguis Indian Reserve said.  ''Pretty soon the municipalities will get involved, and there will be no end to it.'' **********The Indians welcomed Ottawa's endorsement of limited selfgovernment.  Mr. Trudeau rejected the idea that Indians should be assimilated into the larger culture and also rejected ''full independence or absolute sovereignty.'' He said ''these two extremes lie outside the range of options that we are prepared to contemplate.'' Premier Is 'Puzzled' **********Premier Peter Lougheed of Alberta said, meanwhile, that he was puzzled by the Indians' claim that they held original title to the land, while Premier Brian Peckford of Newfoundland said he was confused. **********The premiers as a group appeared to backtrack on a preliminary agreement reached Tuesday evening to meet some of the Indian demands and provide regular channels to meet others in the future. **********Indeed, all that the participants could agree on as the conference ended this evening was to state that future meetings on Indian rights could be held.

BUSINESS FORUM;
INDUSTRIAL POLICY AND EAST COAST MYOPIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
INDUSTRIAL POLICY AND EAST COAST MYOPIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/busin.body_text: **********SUNSET, like the TV evening **********news, comes three hours later **********to us on the West Coast. Perhaps that is why the concern over ''sunrise'' and ''sunset'' industries, which occupies such an important place in the East Coast debate on industrial policy, hasn't captured our attention in the West. **********East Coast economic strategists have proposed a national industrial policy to shift resources, workers and America's future out of the sunset, heavy industries that they feel can no longer compete, such as textiles, garments, steel, machinery (the list has no boundary) and into high-technology sunrise industries such as microelectronics, computers and biotechnology, that they've seen on their visits to Silicon Valley. **********Such a policy makes no sense politically. It pits the few folks working in ''officially'' designated, high-technology sectors against the battalions of auto workers, steelworkers, textile workers - in fact, almost everyone - and tells that vast majority to organize its own demise. **********Worse still, it makes no sense economically. Doing something to improve industrial performance - the purpose of any industrial policy - is not a question of making lists that have textiles, apparel, ordinary consumer goods and metal bending nearing the end of their day and robotics, microelectroncis and biotechnology proudly hailing the dawn's early light. Unfortunately for such simplicity, exports in textiles recently surged while high-tech Atari has moved substantial employment abroad, and American producers of numerically controlled machine tools have lost much of the world market and much of our own market to foreign competitors. **********Even putting aside the thorny difficulties of how to pick winning industries from losing ones, the usefulness of organizing an industrial policy on the basis of what different industries make dissolves in the face of a simple question: Who is going to buy a robot or a bag of silicon chips? Much of what American high-tech industries make is bought by American business, not by consumers. Success for American producers of robots, CAD systems or industrial lasers depends upon manufacturers of automobiles, pens, washing machines, pants and electric motors buying and using the advanced technology and adjusting their manufacturing operations to the possibilities those technologies represent. **********Unless American manufacturers - principally those classified in the East as sunset - adopt the new technologies, they will not remain competitive. Unless they remain competitive, the high-technology industries will not attain their growth or promise. The workable strategy, economically as well as politically, is to bring high technology into the production of traditional products. The serious question is how to do it. **********INDUSTRIAL revitalization is vast and complex. There is no single **********best policy. Our options do not boil down to two simple but impossible alternatives: a blind faith ''let-the-markets-work'' approach, or a huge central investment and subsidization fund that will reconstruct the economy according to the judgments of its directors and the strengths of the political sectors that will converge on them. There is, in fact, no simple, single solution. We confront a multitude of problems and we will need a multitude of policies. **********Among others, new policies are needed to increase the flow of long- term capital into productive investment, and to improve the technical skills of the American work force. **********But above all, we must shift resources toward internationally competitive industries without adopting the simple-minded and politically impossible approach of industry-by-industry targeting. For example, it is not intuitively obvious to a planner that pushing dirt or sewing pants would be an American industrial strength. But Bechtel and Levi Strauss do very well internationally. **********Tax incentives based on performance are an excellent and traditional tool toward this end. We should institute a tax credit for research and development, with tax credits kicking in at a threshhold of, say, 8 percent of total spending - thus rewarding companies that are making an extraordinary effort in R.& D. and not simply to reward business as usual. **********A Factory Extension Service is another policy that does not require any centrally organized industrial triage. A modern industrial equivalent of the Agricultural Extension Service, it would aim at introducing advanced technology into a broad range of manufacturing industries and helping those industries, especially the small and middle-sized companies, to begin to reorganize their basic approach to manufacturing in order to apply microelectronics and other new technologies effectively in the workplace. **********The farm program with its research centers and extension agents was, arguably, America's most successful industrial policy. It brought a host of advanced technologies into use by very small, very unsophisticated farm enterprises. It contributed mightily to a dramatic and sustained improvement in farm productivity and to our national prosperity and power. It was also an invaluable aid, far more than a simple capital infusion would have been, for the growing industrial giants of its time, especially farm machinery and chemicals. What we did on the farm, we should do in the factory. Sweden has such a program; so does Japan. The State of New Jersey is making some interesting experiments in this area. A national effort should follow. **********No industrial policy will do much good in the absence of successful overall fiscal and monetary policy: Sustained recession, high interest rates and a disastrously overvalued dollar will nullify even the best trade and industrial revitalization efforts. But a successfully coordinated macroeconomic policy, by itself, will not solve the very real problem of declining international competitiveness. **********For the first time in our nation's history we no longer have the luxury of doing nothing. Foreign competition - not American politics - is setting the pace as it devastates sector after sector of our industrial capacity. The United States has been unwilling and unable to confront the kind of strategic choices it must now make. **********All debate over technique and the details of policy aside, the choice is basic. We can avoid the dubious business of selecting sunrise and sunset sectors and promote the international competitiveness of American industry by introducing high technology into a broad range of industries. **********It is quite possible that we will continue to fail to act. In the process, and most likely in the name of free trade and free markets, we will bring down open trade and the system of alliances we created over the past generation. **********Stephen S. Cohen is professor of planning at the University of California at Berkeley, where he is co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy (BRIE).

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/05/world.body_text: **********The bombing of Fort Frederick in St. George's, Grenada, on the first day of the invasion and the occupation of Pearls Airport, the only functioning airfield on the island before the invasion, has created a host of problems for the 200 to 400 reporters trying to cover the action. **********The bombing damaged a transmission center, severing telephone and cable links with the world, while closing the airport meant that nonmilitary access to the island has been possible only by boat. Thus, every day, hundreds of reporters depend on military C-130 cargo planes to reach the island and return to Barbados to send their stories. **********This cumbersome procedure has been further complicated by what experienced reporters here say is one of the least adequately informed military offices they have ever encountered. Information is often released in Washington many hours before shorter versions are offered here. **********Restoring Communications **********The transmission situation may change soon, according to Ronald McKenzie of the Cable & Wireless Company in Bridgetown, who has been seeking to restore outside communications with Grenada. ''We've shipped over the last bits of equipment we had to order from abroad, and maybe service will be restored tonight or tomorrow,'' he said today. **********Communications experts have had to rebuild the transmitter atop Fort Frederick, and that should restore voice and cable links. But television news teams will still have to beam their ''feeds'' through an earth station here in Barbados, meaning continued dependence on the military shuttle, for which the rules change every day. **********And until all the wires on Grenada are put back up, reporters there will continue to function as they did before telephones, visiting each source of news personally or depending somewhat on others' accounts of events. **********News coverage of the Grenada invasion has, so far, meant spending half a day visiting a few places and another half a day trying to get the story out of Grenada. Some newspapers, magazines and television teams have organized a relay system, taking turns carrying material to Bridgetown, where it could be transmitted.   Nervous Tension in Newsrooms **********This has elevated the ''pigeon'' system - finding someone to carry a news story out to a colleague or depending on someone to actually send it - to new heights, while creating nervous tension in newsrooms around the world. **********One reporter was cut from the list of those on the last plane to Bridgetown a few days ago, when seats were commandeered by the State Department for diplomats and others. He stood on the tarmac writing his story by hand so that another reporter could read it and send it to New York. **********The magazine reporter who had volunteered to help was himself cut from the same flight. Both newsmen were placed aboard another cargo plane a half-hour later and made it back just in time to file their stories. **********The reporters' day begins typically at 5:30 or 6 A.M. in the former air terminal departure building here in Bridgetown, which now serves as the Joint Information Bureau operated by the United States military. Processing begins only at 6:30 or 7 A.M., but the tendency is to get in early because the flights are limited to about 90 reporters. Most flights are full, and some reporters are usually left behind.   Concentrated Press Corps **********The press corps is more concentrated here than it was in Vietnam, according to those who covered both wars, in part because of the limited access to the island and to the news. The corps is also somewhat larger than it might be, because Grenada is near to the United States. **********On the first flights to the island, only one dozen or two dozen reporters went, and news organizations were designated by name. Wire services were always on the list, although that included Reuters but not Agence France- Presse, and later only a half-dozen major newspapers and magazines were allowed to go before the list was opened to everyone. Among the early choices was The Washington Times, which is owned by the Unification Church. The choice of that newspaper's correspondent infuriated representatives of major daily newspapers that were not on the list. **********The foreign press was not represented on the flights for three or four days. When a Canadian television team was again rejected, the correspondent followed the military press officer around the room, shouting, ''We got your hostages out of Iran; why can't you get us onto Grenada?'' **********Press credentials are checked and correspondents are moved into another waiting area. All luggage, including cameras, sound equipment and sometime television editing gear, go with the passengers into the plane's belly.   An Envelope of Earplugs **********Passengers sit facing each other in double rows on woven plastic seats. Flying in a C-130 is like riding under the hood of a car, with each operation, the lowering of wheels or moving of flaps, easily heard. An envelope of earplugs is passed down the aisle. **********The first flight gets to the Point Salines airport, which the Cubans were building but did not finish, at about 9:30 or 10 A.M. It is always noisy and dusty. The airport is still designated a war zone, so the planes do combat turns, which means keeping the engines going. Most of the time small Army buses arrive for the half-hour trip into St. George's, but sometimes they do not appear. **********There have been military briefings, but they are dwindling because newsmen who had been in touch with their offices overnight or who receive telex summaries of morning newspaper stories found the briefings offered very little. The sessions have become more administrative, offering news of press conferences in town, for example, or the details of a visiting congressional group. **********The airport itself can produce news. One morning press flight arrived just before the repatriation of wounded Cubans. The reporters who stayed to cover it got on the 1:30 flight back to Bridgetown, certain they had seen something of news value and uncertain about the availability of the late afternoon flight.   Accommodation of TV Teams **********The midday flight was added, according to military personnel, to accommodate television teams seeking to edit their film in time to beam it to the United States in the afternoon, when the $1,000-a-minute satellite is more available for transmissions - and in time for the evening news. **********But Thursday, the midday press plane was requisitioned for the repatriation of Libyan diplomats. Frustrated television teams watched, a major news story in their cameras. Space was found for them on another plane that left at 3 P.M. **********There are no telephones linking the airport and the town. Taxis are available but since Thursday they have been forced to wait at some distance because the United States military is trying to clear the airport of the chaotic bargaining for rides. **********In St. George's, reporters have been sleeping on mattresses in the lobbies of hotels packed with reporters. An estimated 100 reporters have taken up residence on the island.   New Precautions **********Returning to Bridgetown means showing up an hour and a half before the 1:30 and 5:30 P.M. flights, a change demanded by Barbadian authorities since one passenger, described by a military spokesman as a ''soldier-of-fortune type,'' tried to bring back a gun belt with live ammunition. **********Reporters now wait in a roped enclosure on the field, once they've been checked in, making the ''pigeon'' work that much more difficult as guards discourage the passing of notes, television tape or other paraphernalia. The return flight arrives at Bridgetown at about 7 P.M. On Thursday night 10 reporters were unable to get on. **********Barbadian customs is now checking shoulder bags, television equipment and other luggage, adding a half-hour to the six or seven hours of transportation daily. And, as the news crews file through the terminal they are handed two- or three-paragraph news releases. **********The releases might disclose that United States forces swept the island of Carriacou looking for Cubans, an announcement that had been made in detail in Washington eight hours earlier. At their hotels, another half-hour away, the reporters talk to their editors, who are asking questions about events that officials in Washington say are happening in Grenada. Sometimes the reporter knows about it, sometimes not. Because there are no phone links with the island, there is no way to check it out, until tomorrow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/23/busin.body_text: **********Although most New York savings institutions have viewed commercial lending with trepidation, the Dime Savings Bank has run counter to this trend by aggressively pursuing small and medium-size businesses as loan customers. **********In early 1981, shortly after Governor Carey signed into law a bill allowing savings institutions to invest up to 5 percent of their assets in commercial loans, the Dime formed a 10-man commercial lending department. The savings bank, with slightly more than $5 billion in assets at that time, was authorized to make about $250 million of commercial loans. **********James Bolster Jr., head of the Dime's commercial lending deparment, said it recognized quite early that, to succeed in New York's highly competitive market, it would have to specialize. The initial strategy, he said, was to carve out a special niche among small and medium-size busineses, mostly on Long Island. **********''Although Dime is significant in New York City as a mutual,'' Mr.  Bolster said in an interview last week, ''it would have been foolhardy to try to compete with the big money center, regional or even foreign banks in New York. I didn't want to waste two years ringing doorbells on the Fortune 500.'' Balance Sheets Scrutinized **********The Dime also decided to limit its corporate loans to mature, seasoned businesses. ''We wanted to see substantial balance sheets, fully audited, and we wanted five years of profitability,'' Mr.  Bolster said. **********In the fall of 1981, as part of its campaign to win business customers, the Dime invited about 150 company executives to a ''social hour'' of introductory presentations. According to Mr.  Bolster, about 115 of those companies are now Dime customers. **********A major hurdle for most thrift institutions considering commercial lending has been duplicating the costly back-office operations that already exist in most commercial institutions. The Dime leases its commercial lending computer system, including software and microcomputers, from the First Boston Corporation for $2,500 a month. **********So far, Mr. Bolster says, the Dime's commercial lending operations have performed far above expectations. The savings bank now has about 200 corporate customers, with an average loan size of about $1 million. At the end of 1982, its commercial lending operations had an average return on assets of 185 basis points, equal to 1.85 percent, and a 45 percent return on allocated equity. **********''With figures like that and no more than 15 people in the department,'' Mr. Bolster said, ''we really ought to be looking for some profit sharing.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/world.main_headline: ARGENTINA LINKED TO RISE IN COVERT U.S. ACTIONS AGAINST SANDINISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/world.print_headline: ARGENTINA LINKED TO RISE IN COVERT U.S. ACTIONS AGAINST SANDINISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/world.body_text: **********United States involvement in covert guerrilla activities against Nicaragua increased sharply last year after Argentina largely halted its assistance to the rebels, according to Administration officials. The Argentine move was in reaction to President Reagan's support for Britain in the Falkland war, the officials said. **********Until the early months of 1982, the officials said, Argentina had primary responsibility for financing and training the anti-Sandinist guerrillas to intercept military supplies going through Nicaragua to El Salvador and Guatemala. Beginning last fall, the officials said, United States dollars, personnel and direction were added, first to sustain the interdiction operations and later to expand them. **********As a result, the officials said, the United States found itself providing direct aid to a guerrilla operation whose aim - the overthrow of the Sandinist Government - went beyond Washington's goal of intercepting arms. The United States was thus brought into a potential direct confrontation with Nicaragua. **********To prevent precisely this outcome, the officials said, a number of Administration members had fought hard but in vain to persuade Mr.  Reagan not to side openly with Britain against Argentina. Argentina attacked the Falkland Islands on April 2, 1982, and surrendered on June 14. Complicated and Confusing **********The Administration officials related these details over the past few days in an effort to show there was no deliberate effort within the Reagan Administration to violate the law barring actions to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua, as some Congressional critics have suggested. **********The officials described complicated and often confusing accounts of more than three years of covert American actions in Nicaragua and against its Government. **********The centerpiece, the officials said, was an arrangement worked out between the Reagan Administration and the Argentine ruling junta led by President Leopoldo Galtieri. **********Under the pact, Argentina would be responsible, with some American funds and intelligence support, for attacking the flow of supplies moving through Nicaragua to El Salvador and Guatemala. Guatemala, El Salvador's neighbor to the north, had been battling a leftist-led guerrilla movement that predated by several years the one in El Salvador. The United States took for itself the tasks of curtailing Nicaraguan actions against Honduras, for providing money to political opposition groups in Nicaragua and for maintaining liaison with Nicaraguan exiles. **********The officials said the Administration was clear about the difficulties inherent in the arrangement. General Galtieri's support for the anti-Sandinist guerrillas predated the Reagan Administration. His goal, never hidden, was to entice the former Sandinist commander Eden Pastora Gomez to lead the guerrillas in an attempt to overthrow the Sandinists. According to Administration officials, this goal was shared by a number of Reagan policy-makers and Central Intelligence Agency operatives, but it was never adopted as official policy. 'It Was Convenient' **********''It was convenient to run the operations through the Argentinians,'' a high-ranking intelligence agency official said.  ''We didn't have to ask questions about their goals that we couldn't escape asking about our own goals when we took over.'' **********In 1979 and 1980, the Carter Administration had undertaken to expand American intelligence collection activities in Central America and to provide funds and other support to anti-Government, democratic individuals and groups in Nicaragua. By this time, relations had already begun to cool between Washington and the Sandinists, whom President Carter had backed in the closing days of their revolution against the long-time dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle. **********On March 9, 1981, President Reagan was said to have reaffirmed these covert programs and to have taken an important step beyond them, authorizing the start of covert military action to intercept arms supplies moving through Nicaragua to El Salvador and Guatemala.  The budget for these efforts was set at $19.5 million. **********Against the backdrop of what officials said they saw as a stalemated situation at best, but more likely a deteriorating one, the President and his senior advisers met on Nov. 16, 1981. Mr.  Reagan adopted a 10-point program, later to be embodied in National Security Decision Document 17. It called, in general, for increasing economic and military aid to the region. A Concession to Haig **********The document also approved the development of contingency plans to deal with ''unacceptable military actions'' by Cuba. This was described as a nominal concession to Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr. **********Mr. Haig had proposed going further and taking unspecified actions against Cuba, which he termed ''the source'' of trouble in Central America. **********But the 10-point program, the officials said, also called for issuing a ''finding'' to Congressional intelligence committees notifying them of plans to step up covert intelligence actions in the region. Such a finding, or document, is required by law and gives Congress an opportunity to raise objections. **********When the finding was submitted in December, several members of the intelligence committees were said to question whether the covert operations could be limited to interdiction of arms supplies or might evolve into a broader campaign against the Nicaraguan Government. **********The finding granted the C.I.A. broad authority to support and conduct ''political and paramilitary operations against Cubans and Cuban supply lines'' in Nicaragua and elsewhere in Central America.  The C.I.A. was also empowered to work with other governments. The other Governments mainly involved were Argentina and Honduras, although Venezuela and Colombia showed interest as well. Restrictions on Spending **********Under the finding, the C.I.A. was allowed to spend $19.95 million for all covert actions in the region. It was not clear from the officials' comments whether this figure was related to the similar amount mentioned in connection with the March 9, 1981, meeting. In any event, some of it was to serve as ''seed money'' to finance a 500-man force of Latin Americans. This force would later be joined with a 1,000-man unit then being trained and financed in Honduras, largely by Argentina. The finding told the C.I.A. to work ''primarily'' through third parties, but authorized action by C.I.A.  personnel ''in some circumstances'' against special Cuban targets. **********The larger part of the funds was to continue backing what was described as nationalistic, anti-Cuban and anti-Somoza groups, and intelligence collection. **********At the Nov. 16 meeting, there was said to have been considerable discussion of how to accomplish covert military actions without getting involved with the former supporters of Mr. Somoza. On the one side, it was generally recognized that identification with the Somoza forces would doom the operation politically. On the other side, it seemed that the operation could never get off the ground militarily without them. Taking Sides Over the Falklands **********Planning went forward on a large scale with the Argentines and Hondurans until Argentina's attack on the Falklands. General Galtieri, who would resign after the war ended, made clear that American endorsement of the British position would be the end of his cooperation in Central America. A number of Administration officials, particularly Thomas O. Enders, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, argued that this was strong reason for avoiding taking sides over the Falklands. But Mr. Reagan was to choose otherwise, and General Galtieri withdrew almost all Argentine advisers and funds. **********In mid-April 1982, during the fighting over the Falklands, Mr.  Reagan and his senior advisers convened again on the subject of Central American strategy. According to a summary of this meeting, Mr. Reagan agreed on ''increasing pressure on Nicaragua and Cuba to increase for them the costs of interven. The summary also showed a decision to increase funds by $2.5 million to expand covert operations in Guatemala. **********It was the operations approved in November and the further increases approved in mid-April that led to the general expansion of American covert actions in the region and to charges that the Administration may have violated the spirit, if not the letter, of the law barring covert action to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/22/world.main_headline: REAGAN IS URGED NOT TO PUBLICIZE ARMS ACCUSATIONS AGAINST SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/22/world.print_headline: REAGAN IS URGED NOT TO PUBLICIZE ARMS ACCUSATIONS AGAINST SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/22/world.body_text: **********Two former Carter Administration officials and two Democratic senators said today in interviews that possible Soviet arms violations should be discussed through diplomatic channels. They said a public airing would risk disrupting the 1979 arms accord and current talks. **********Former Defense Secretary Harold Brown said that, if the 1979 pact were to become nullified, the Soviet Union was better poised than the United States to develop new intercontinental missiles. **********An arms control official in the Carter Administration, William E.  Jackson Jr., said one reason for ambiguity about a possible Soviet violation in a missile test Feb. 8 was that not all intelligence systems were functioning on that day. **********Mr. Jackson, who is a former executive director of the General Advisory Committee of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, is now a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution. **********In mid-March, President Reagan was told by an interagency committee that there might have been a Soviet violation involving either the coding of test data or testing of a new type of missile. **********Mr. Jackson said Soviet telemetric information from the Feb. 8 test indicated that the SS-13 missile either had been modified to carry multiple warheads or had been enlarged more than permitted by the 1979 treaty. **********Conservative senators favor wide publicity, but the White House said the issue would first be studied by a new task force headed by William P. Clark, the national security adviser. **********Senator Clairborne Pell of Rhode Island, top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said publicity ''would be widely interpreted as a cheap shot tactic to build support for the Administration's arms programs.'' **********Senator Alan Cranston of California, a Democratic candidate for the 1984 Presidential nomination, said the ''floating'' of suspicions about Soviet violations was ''a ploy conveniently timed'' to help Mr. Reagan persuade Congress to approve the MX missile. **********The two senators and Mr. Brown said the United States should raise the compliance issue in the Soviet-American committee set up for that purpose. It has met twice a year for 11 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/world.main_headline: English-Language China Daily To Publish in North America
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/world.print_headline: English-Language China Daily To Publish in North America
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/world.body_text: **********The official English-language China Daily is to publish a North American edition starting June 1, the newspaper said today. **********The new edition, which will be identical to the eight-page newspaper now published in Peking and Hong Kong, will be printed in New York and distributed by mail and through agents in major cities in the United States and Canada. **********China Daily, the sole English-language newspaper in China, first appeared in June 1981 and rapidly built up a sizable readership among foreigners in the country, among tourists and among Chinese. **********Though printed on the presses of People's Daily, it bears little resemblance to the austere Communist Party paper, either in appearance or content.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/22/world.main_headline: TOP P.L.O. OFFICIALS ARE MEETING IN TUNIS ON RIFT WITH JORDAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/22/world.print_headline: TOP P.L.O. OFFICIALS ARE MEETING IN TUNIS ON RIFT WITH JORDAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/22/world.body_text: **********Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, opened a meeting today of the P.L.O.  executive committee that will focus mainly on Palestinian-Jordanian relations, a P.L.O. spokesman said. **********Mr. Arafat returned to Tunis from Rumania on Wednesday night.  Ahmed Abdel Rahman, chief spokesman for the P.L.O., said the executive committee discussions would be mainly aimed at ''surmounting the obstacles'' that came up during talks between Mr.  Arafat and King Hussein of Jordan. **********King Hussein withdrew from talks with the P.L.O. on April 10 after Mr. Arafat refused to sign an agreement that would have given the Jordanian the go-ahead to join in negotiations based on President Reagan's peace plan. **********The Reagan plan calls for Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank in association with Jordan, but does not call for an independent Palestinian state. **********Mr. Arafat on Wednesday joined the Rumanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu, in calling for an international conference to discuss peace in the Middle East, Rumania's press agency Agerpres reported. **********The P.L.O. chairman and Mr. Ceausescu suggested an international conference ''which should be attended by all sides concerned inclusive of the Palestine Liberation Organization,'' according to the news agency. **********The two agreed on the ''right of the Palestinian people to selfdetermination, to the setting up of a state of its own,'' the agency said. ---- Egyptian Supports P.L.O. **********LONDON, April 21 (UPI) - The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Butros Ghali, says there is no crisis in relations between Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization but urged the P.L.O. to reconsider its opposition to President Reagan's peace plan. **********Mr. Ghali, interviewed by London's Arabic-language weekly At Tadamon, said reports of a crisis were an ''exaggeration.'' Mr. Ghali said Egypt did not like some statements made by P.L.O.  officials during the Palestinian National Council meeting in Algiers in February and viewed the statements as interference in Egypt's internal affairs. But he said Egypt fully supported the P.L.O.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/world.main_headline: POLAND TO AMEND CHARTER TO MAKE SPECIAL POWERS PERMANENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/world.print_headline: POLAND TO AMEND CHARTER TO MAKE SPECIAL POWERS PERMANENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/world.body_text: **********Parliament began work today on legislation that would amend the Constitution to give all Polish Governments the special powers that the regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski assumed when it declared martial law on Dec. 13, 1981. **********The Jaruzelski Government sent the draft legislation to Parliament, reportedly in preparation for the formal lifting of martial law next week. **********The draft amendments would apparently empower the Government to deal with future crises without declaring martial law. They would empower the Government to declare a state of emergency instead and do so without having to go through the formality of obtaining parliamentary approval. **********This would apparently complete a process of making the special governmental powers that were instituted last December, when a partial suspension of martial law was formally announced, the law of the land. The suspension order came as many martial-law edicts were incorporated into Poland's criminal code, making it illegal, for example, to strike, incite anti-Government demonstrations and distribute literature officially considered subversive. **********Polish sources said the Government would order a selective amnesty for several hundred political prisoners on July 22, Poland's national day, and formally announce at the same time the abolition of martial law. But it is widely expected here that the independent trade union Solidarity will remain outlawed and many of its jailed leaders behind bars. **********Underground Solidarity leaders took note of this expectation today in a statement that said, ''A merely formal lifting of martial law and amnesty will in no way induce us to halt our activities.'' **********They also demanded that the laws passed since the December 1981 crackdown be canceled.  ''The character of further struggles for worker and civil rights will be contingent on the sense of political realism displayed by the authorities,'' the underground leaders said. The statement was signed by Zbigniew Bujak of Warsaw, Wladyslaw Hardek of Cracow, Tadeusz Jedynak of Katowice, Bogdan Lis of Gdansk and ''Witold,'' believed to be a pseudonym for a union leader in Wroclaw. **********At today's session of Parliament, a draft amendment permitting the delaration of a state of emergency without parliamentary approval was referred without debate to a committee. It is expected to be given final approval at a session next Wedesday or Thursday. **********The draft provides that the Council of State or its president - in effect the Government - ''may introduce for a definite period of time a state of emergency if the interior safety of the nation is threatened or in the case of a natural disaster.'' **********The 460-member Parliament also gave overwhelming approval - there were 3 negative votes - to a new law creating a centralized system of command for the police and the security police, apparently patterned on that in the Soviet Union. It puts control of local police units in the hands of the Interior Minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, an ally of General Jaruzelski. **********The official press agency P.A.P. said Parliament would also receive draft legislation at its session next week that would provide new regulations to ''overcome the socio-economic crisis.'' This suggested that when, as expected, General Jaruzelski appears before Parliament to propose formally the lifting of martial law, he would also outline more tough measures to maintain security and keep the economy running. **********Parliament sent back to committee for further study today a new press law that would replace censorship regulations predating martial law with self-censorship.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/world.main_headline: SOVIET DISSIDENTS FEAR NEW LAW MAY ADD TO SENTENCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/world.print_headline: SOVIET DISSIDENTS FEAR NEW LAW MAY ADD TO SENTENCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Government has added a new law to its books that dissidents fear will be used to stretch the labor-camp terms of political prisoners. **********The law, which went into effect in the Russian republic of the Soviet Union on Oct. 1, provides terms of up to five years for prisoners who disobey or oppose labor-camp administrators. **********The measure is applicable to all prisoners, but dissidents believe that it will be applied primarily to human rights activists who refuse to renounce their activities or causes while in camps. **********Both dissidents and Western diplomats who monitor human rights in the Soviet Union saw the measure as a new weapon in the tough crackdown on dissidence that began about three years before Yuri V. Andropov became the Soviet leader and has continued unabated under him. **********'Malicious Disobedience' **********The law, Article 188-3 of the criminal code of the Russian republic, states that ''malicious disobedience to lawful demands made by the administration of a corrective labor institution, or any other opposition to the administration in the execution of its functions'' by a prisoner who has been sent to an isolation cell or transferred to prison in the preceding year can bring up to three more years of imprisonment. **********Prisoners considered ''especially dangerous recidivists'' or those convicted of a ''grave crime'' can be sentenced up to five additional years. **********Dissidents say the measure codified and simplified a practice that has become increasingly frequent in recent years, when a number of dissidents nearing the end of their terms have found themselves sentenced to new terms, often on charges of slandering the state while in camp. **********In December 1982, for example, Valery Abramkin was nearing the end of a three-year term for publishing an underground magazine when he was transferred to jail to face new charges of ''orally spreading slander against the Soviet state.''  Others Also Charged **********Similar charges were brought against Vyacheslav Bakhmin, who had campaigned against the abuse of psychiatry, and a number of other dissidents. **********The new law, however, apparently relieves authorities of the need to compile a new case against a dissident who is nearing the end of his or her term. Diplomats said it appeared, in effect, to give prison authorities arbitrary power to extend the sentences of dissidents, a practice that was commonplace under Stalin but was largely abandoned in the 1960's and 1970's. **********The stipulation that the law is applicable to those prisoners who have been punished in the course of their term, either by spending time in isolation cells or in prison, would make most of the prominent dissidents now serving time liable to extended terms. **********Anatoly B. Shcharansky, for example, was sent from a labor camp where he had served several stretches in a punishment cell, to Chistopol Prison in November 1980, reportedly for refusing to acknowledge his guilt.   Similar Route Followed **********Viktor Nekipelov followed a similar route to Chistopol. Yuri Orlov, Aleksandr Podrabinek, Gleb Yakunin, the Russian Orthodox priest, and numerous other imprisoned dissidents have spent their terms in and out of punishment cells. **********Each of these dissidents now stands to receive added years in camps for the same alleged infractions that sent them to isolation cells or to prison. **********Mr. Shcharansky, who was convicted of espionage and is therefore considered to have committed a ''grave'' crime, is liable to receive five more years in prison. **********The new law appeared in the official gazette of the Russian republic, the largest of the Soviet republics and the one in which most dissidents are serving terms. The measure could be adopted by other republics.   Dealing Harshly **********To dissidents and Western diplomats, the measure represented further evidence that Mr. Andropov will continue dealing harshly with dissidents. **********He is generally believed to have been responsible for the stringent measures taken against the human rights movement under Leonid I. Brezhnev, when Mr. Andropov was chief of the K.G.B. Mr. Andropov became the Soviet leader when Mr. Brezhnev died in November 1982; if anything, the treatment of dissidents has grown more repressive over the past year, when sentences handed down to dissidents have been severe. **********Leonid Borodin, a writer who was arrested before Mr. Brezhnev died, was rearraigned on a tougher charge after Mr. Andropov came to power and was sentenced to 10 years in camps and 5 in exile. **********Iosif Begun, a Jewish activist, recently received the maximum term for anti-Soviet activities, 7 years in camp and 5 in exile. A special campaign has been under way to crush the Solzhenitsyn fund, which dispenses money to families of political prisoners.   Lithuanians Sentenced **********In Lithuania, two Roman Catholic priests, the Rev. Alfonsas Svarinskas and the Rev. Sigitas Tamkiavicius, have been sent to camps for participating in the Catholic Committee for the Defense of Believers' Rights. In Russia, a Russian Orthodox publicist, Zoya Krakhmalnikova, was sentenced to a year in prison and five in exile. This is only a partial listing of the trials and arrests reported over the past year. **********In the meantime, emigration of Jews and ethnic Germans has almost ceased. **********One increasingly frequent element that has disturbed many Western experts over the past year has been the publicity given some of the more prominent trials by the Soviet press agency Tass, a practice that to some smacks of the show trials of the Stalin era. **********Tass has reported on several trials over the past year, invariably beginning with the words ''at an open trial in'' and going on to denounce the activities of the defendant, whether the trial has finished or not. **********In the case of Father Tamkiavicius last week, Tass denounced the priest as a ''vain and money-loving man'' who systematically ''slandered the Soviet political and social system,'' even before the court had reached the inevitable guilty verdict.   Subversion From the West **********A similar report on Mr. Begun's trial in October in the city of Vladimir was issued by Tass the day before the trial opened. At the same time the press has taken increasingly to saying that dissidents are agents of the C.I.A. or motivated by other ''Western subversion.'' **********The most common source of such articles has been a book entitled ''C.I.A. Versus U.S.S.R.'' by Nikolai Yakovlev. The third edition of the book, issued last February, traced the entire dissident movement to a C.I.A. conspiracy that began with the ''thaw'' after Stalin's death. **********The most prominent dissidents were portrayed in the work as corrupt and debauched, and some of the most brutal attacks were focused on Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident and Nobel Prize-winning physicist who was sent into internal exile in the city of Gorky. **********Excerpts from the book have been published in Pravda, the Communist Party daily, and a number of other journals and newspapers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.main_headline: LOW-KEY DENG CULT SEEN EMERGING IN CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.print_headline: LOW-KEY DENG CULT SEEN EMERGING IN CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.body_text: **********A poster displayed last month in the Shanghai newspaper Liberation Daily looked familiar. It showed a phalanx of soldiers, sailors, fliers and technicians marching forward to the slogan, ''Build powerful, modernized and standardized revolutionary armed forces.'' **********Looming above them larger than life in an army uniform, Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, peered into the future, with one hand shading his eyes from tomorrow's sunshine. **********The poses evoked the kind of posters that once idealized Mao Zedong and his red-bound quotations. This one even bore another slogan at the top heralding ''The Selected Works of Deng Xiaoping,'' a collection of Mr. Deng's writings and speeches that was published last July. **********As with a picture published in September of Mr. Deng floating in the waters off Beidaihe, a seaside resort, in the manner of Mao's celebrated swim in the Yangtze River in 1966, the resemblance seemed intentional. **********Because nothing appears by accident in the controlled press, such pictures of Mr. Deng, like the frequent paeans to his wisdom and courage, seem intended to tap the kind of fervor that used to be generated by the personality cult of Mao. **********A new cult of personality is prohibited by the 1982 party charter, which ''does not allow any member to become divorced from the masses or place himself above them.'' It is also inconsistent with Mr. Deng's own reticent posture, since he has declined opportunities to hold formal high office. **********But Mr. Deng represents the new orthodoxy now being promulgated in a party purge. Such campaigns fall back on the proven format of citing one individual's words and deeds to inspire everyone else. **********Mr. Deng's writings are at the core of the purge, which will entail political study and self-criticism over the next three years and wind up with a review of party membership rolls. A list of required reading includes some of Mao's old writings dating from before 1957, when he began committing what are now viewed as the errors of the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution. **********The current leadership still pays lip service to Mao, in part because outright repudiation would alienate many conservatives and throw into question the party's legitimacy. **********''Mao Zedong's theory of democracy within the party and of a people's democracy is still the criterion guiding the political life of the party and country today,'' Liao Gailong, a party historian, said this week at a symposium. But he also listed Mao's mistakes, including an overemphasis on class struggle, as in the Cultural Revolution; the expectation of fast economic results, as in the Great Leap Forward, and a disregard for what are now regarded as the correct views of other leaders. **********Mr. Deng has been praised for ridding the party of the ''two whatevers'' - the dogmatic conviction that whatever Mao thought or whatver Mao did must be blindly followed. **********Mr. Deng has been careful not to appear a claimant to Mao's mantle. In mid-1981 Mr. Deng reportedly urged his protege, Hu Yaobang, the party's general secretary, to insure that a party assessment of Mao's rule show his merits outweighing his faults. **********The official line is still that Mr. Deng is enhancing Mao's philosophy, not replacing it. The magazine Beijing Review in September disparaged the ''myth of de-Maoification'' circulating in the West as ''ridiculous'' and ''totally groundless.'' **********But Mao's celebrated little red books have long disappeared from store shelves, while more than 40 million copies of Mr. Deng's new book have been published. **********Mao's mausoleum is to be converted into a memorial hall that will include other leaders like Zhou Enlai and Zhu De, according to Chinese sources. The spotlight on Mao's portrait hanging over the archway to the Forbidden City has been turned off.

The winners are all existing Procter agencies with international capability. **********The Leo Burnett Company got various assignments for all of the Middle East; Hong Kong; Europe and Britain; Germany and Belgium; Canada and Mexico, and Japan. **********Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide picked up Austria and Spain; Switzerland and Sweden, Hong Kong and Singapore. **********Grey Advertising will do some of the work in Britain, Belgium, Austria, Germany and Switzerland. **********Benton & Bowles also will handle some products in Britain, France, Italy and Switzerland. Dancer Fitzgerald Sample gets Oxydol in Canada, and Dentsu is handling additional assignments in Japan and the Middle East.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/busin.body_text: **********The problem that has led to the removal of some 10 of the General Electric turbofan engines that power the new twin-engine Boeing-767 airliner has been pinpointed and a solution worked out, a G.E.  spokesman said late yesterday. **********A Government-approved modification will be made on all 76 engines that have been produced so far, the spokesman, Leonard Dalquest, said. **********The program should be completed within two months. **********Meanwhile, American Airlines will continue to inspect its affected engines after each 767 flight and Delta Air Lines at the end of each day's flights, he added. **********The problem, which caused one in-flight engine shutdown in December, has been traced to alumininum-oxide contamination of a seal and an adjacent turbine-bearing area. Under the maintenance program, the aluminum oxide will be removed and larger clearances provided, he said. **********The cost of the program could not immediately be determined, Mr.  Dalquest said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/13/busin.body_text: **********Kuwait's National Assembly has approved a Government bill aimed at settling billions of dollars of debts from last year's stock market crash. **********The bill, approved Thursday, calls for settlement of share dealings at their original market prices plus a premium of no more than 25 percent, which the Government said would help reduce the number of potential bankruptcies. **********The crisis on Kuwait's unofficial stock market arose from forward dealing in shares through postdated checks that included massive premiums over prevailing market prices, dealers said. **********Unofficial estimates put gross debts at more than $90 billion. The Government has already paid out $1.7 billion to reimburse small investors for their losses. **********Previous efforts to unravel the affairs of major debtors failed because of the complex web of claims and counterclaims. **********Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, said he hoped the bill would solve the crisis and end the complications it had created.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/busin.main_headline: THE NEW YEAR'S NEW TAX PROVISIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; THE NEW YEAR'S NEW TAX PROVISIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/busin.body_text: **********THERE have been so many changes in the tax laws in the last few y ears that it is almost impossible for the average person to keep on t op of them. And on Jan. 1, a host of further changes -including a n ew system for withholding taxes on pension payments - went into e ffect and will have a widespread impact on millions of taxpayers.  H ere's a rundown of some of those new provisions. **********PENSION WITHHOLDING. The new withholding system for pensions and annuities, the provision that has attracted the most attention, is designed to make sure that pensioners and others do not escape paying the Government at least some of the taxes they owe. (Waiters and waitresses have also become subject to withholding on part of their tip income, and investors are scheduled to come under the collection net too, when withholding on dividend and interest income goes into effect on July 1). **********In seeking the new rules, the I.R.S. argued that billions of dollars worth of tax revenues go uncollected each year because many people fail to pay tax on their pension, tip and investment income. **********Under the new rules, pension payments exceeding $5,400 a year that are paid periodically, as opposed to those paid in a lump sum, will have taxes withheld on a sliding scale as if those payments were wages. The amount withheld is determined by a pensioner's marital status and the number of exemptions claimed. (The pending interest and dividend withholding, by contrast, will be on a flat 10 percent rate.) **********The amount of the total tax due has not been changed by the new law - only the timing of making the payment. Taxes on pension payments now will be deducted automatically, unless the recipient opts out of withholding. Under the old rules, taxes were withheld only if pensioners requested it and most chose to make quarterly estimated tax payments instead. **********While it is still too early to tell, preliminary indications are that the majority of retirees receiving modest pensions are opting for withholding. ''Between 80 and 90 percent'' of pensioners receiving average pensions of $5,000 to $10,000 a year are choosing withholding, according to Donald E. Tegeler, a consultant with Hewitt Associates, a Lincolnshire, Ill., employee benefits consulting firm. ''It's really not surprising,'' he says. ''They're comfortable with withholding because it was something that was done with wages.  They aren't used to making estimated tax payments, and they don't want to worry about the I.R.S. knocking on their door.'' **********Mr. Tegeler gave an example of how withholding might affect a married person who earned $50,000 to $60,000 a year while working and who now receives an annual pension of $24,000. If the person claims three exemptions - two exemptions for one of the spouses who is over the age of 65 and one for the other, who is younger than 65 - the monthly withholding would come to $273.40. That would reduce the $2,000-a-month pension to $1,726.60. **********But people who receive substantial dividend and interest payments, and already are used to making estimated tax payments, may decide to opt out of withholding. ''It comes down to psychology,'' says Harold Danker, a partner in the Washington office of the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand. ''Do I want to hold that money or do I want the Government to hold it? And if I hold it, how am I going to budget for my tax payments?'' **********The decision on withholding becomes even more complicated when it comes to ''nonperiodic'' payments, such as lump sum distributions from pension or profit-sharing plans. If the distribution represents the return of a person's entire interest in a plan, it may qualify for 10-year forward averaging. But to qualify, a person must satisfy one of several tests, such as being 59 1/2 years old or over. **********New withholding tables, reflecting 10-year averaging, have just been published by the I.R.S. Recipients may be able to delay paying tax altogether if they reinvest the distribution into a qualified plan, such as a corporate pension plan or a Keogh plan, or into an Individual Retirement Account, within 60 days of receipt. **********LOWER INTEREST CHARGES. The good news is that it now costs less to be late paying your taxes. On Jan.1, the interest rate the I.R.S.  charges on unpaid taxes dropped to 16 percent from 20 percent. **********The bad news is that the revenue service, which used to charge simple interest, is now compounding daily. The result: Someone who is a full year late in settling up will pay an effective rate of 17.346 percent for the privilege of being tardy. **********Several years ago, when the I.R.S. interest rate was in the single digits, many people took a dilatory attitude toward paying their taxes. They figured that because the charge was tax-deductible anyway, it was tantamount to getting an interest-free loan from the Government. **********''But things are not that simple anymore,'' says Sidney Kess, director of tax policy with the accounting firm of Main Hurdman.  ''You've got to be careful when you take an aggressive position on your return, because the I.R.S. may not come in to audit you until 18 months after you file, and the interest clock will be running all that time.'' **********One way to stop that clock from running is to make use of a new, but little-publicized, I.R.S. procedure. It allows taxpayers who are being audited to make an interim deposit with the I.R.S. as soon as they find out they are being audited. The deposit is considered a cash bond, and stops interest charges from piling up on a possible tax assessment resulting from the audit. The bond can be paid even after an auditor has announced the result of the examination, so long as a formal notice of a tax deficiency has not been sent to the taxpayer. **********William G. Brennan, the publisher of Brennan Reports, a Valley Forge, Pa., monthly newsletter on tax shelters, notes that while interest will stop running on the tax underpayment once the bond is paid, the I.R.S. ''will not pay interest on the deposit'' if the taxpayer is ultimately successful. **********SIMPLE TAX FORM. Some 20 million taxpayers may find settling up with Uncle Sam easier than ever this year because of a new tax form dubbed the 1040EZ (pun intended, says the I.R.S.). **********There are some restrictions on its use, however. You must be single, have no dependents and claim only one exemption. You must also have less than $50,000 in taxable income from salaries, wages and tips. No more than $400 of that can be from interest, with none of it coming from All Savers certificates. **********The new form has only 11 lines, half the number of the short form, 1040A. The I.R.S. says it can be filled out in three-fourths of the time it takes to complete the short form, or about 21 minutes versus 28 to 30 minutes. ''But that assumes you've gathered all records and documents, and are now sitting down to prepare it,'' adds I.R.S.  spokesman Wilson Fadely. The form is tailor-made for children and college students with modest amounts of income.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/17/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: If Jean Meger of Anaheim, Calif., considers placing her Gold Card or her Visa Preferred card ''discreetly'' on the table (neatest trick of the week) before she orders at a restaurant good business strategy, she's refined the company-client dining out relationship to a point that makes a shambles of etiquette and severely debases the intelligent guest's sense of propriety (''Spending in Gilded Style,'' June 26). **********I feed not herewith on sour grapes because I've never been invited to join the Gold Club. I have, but I've chosen to reject separate offers because (1) I feel secure enough without plastic flash, (2) I won't pay additional fees to impress people who couldn't care less or, for various reasons, those who don't know which end is up on the status scale, and (3) because good old simple green happens to blend well with the color of my eyes.  NORMAN READER **********Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., June 27

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/30/busin.body_text: **********TOKYO WHEN Minoru Ohnishi talks about Eastman Kodak, the Goliath of the photographic industry, he respectfully applies the Japanese honorific form, calling it ''Kodak-san.'' **********''We don't dream of really competing with the giant Kodak,'' said the 58-year-old president of the Fuji Photo Film Company. **********These are strange words coming from a man whose company has not shown much awe of Kodak in the marketplace. **********Indeed, Fuji, the world's second-largest producer of photographic film, has recently outperformed its big rival. Even though its recent earnings have been uninspired, Fuji has fared far better than Kodak, whose profits are off sharply. Fuji grabbed the corporate sponsorship as the official film of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles away from Kodak with a quick bid of $5 million, a move the Japanese company hopes will help establish its name in the United States market. **********And while amateur photographic products are Fuji's mainstay, representing half its business, in recent years Fuji has moved much more forcefully than Kodak into new fields - high-technology areas such as videotape and floppy disks for computers - that boast enviable growth rates. **********Indeed, a company founded in 1934 as Japan's first manufacturer of motion picture film is being steadily transformed into a high-technology enterprise. ''Fuji has moved into higher growth areas, based on electronics, optics and magnetics technologies, much more so than Kodak has,'' said Robert Burghart, an analyst at W. I. Carr Sons & Company in Tokyo. ''Fuji is extremely well placed for the 1980's.'' There is, to be sure, little danger that Fuji will, David-like, topple Kodak from its pre-eminent position in the amateur film market in the foreseeable future. Its total sales have about doubled in the past five years, reaching $2.5 billion in 1982, figured at the recent exchange rate of 235 yen to the dollar. But the American company is still more than four times Fuji's size, and the century-old Kodak remains the standard-setter in the industry: Fuji must follow Kodak's lead with each change in technology or film processing, since Fuji's products must be ''Kodak-comp- atible.''   Still, Fuji has come a long way in recent years, pulling about even with Kodak in product quality, manufacturing efficiency and technology. When he joined Fuji in the mid-50's, Hirozo Ueda, senior managing director in charge of research and development, recalled, ''Kodak's products seemed like things made by God. Their technology was so far ahead of ours. But today, our overall technological level is comparable to that of Kodak.'' **********Fuji's advance includes some of the classic elements seen in previous gains made by Japanese companies against American rivals in what is now a litany of industries, from steel to semiconductors. For example, the path for Fuji was made easier because it followed in Kodak's footsteps. Typically, Kodak has spent generously on research and development to come up with new products, which Fuji could then either license or imitate. **********IN addition, the Japanese Government protected Fuji at home with **********high tariffs on imports and curbs on direct investment by foreign companies in the 1950's and 1960's, when the Japanese market for amateur film began to sprout. These barriers were eventually abolished, but not before Fuji was firmly in control. **********Today, Fuji holds 75 percent of the $500 million in yearly amateur film sales in Japan, while Kodak claims about 15 percent of that market. In the United States, Fuji has about 6 to 7 percent of the $1.1 billion market for consumer color film, while Kodak has about 85 percent. **********But the Fuji-Kodak case differs from the usual pattern of Japanese- American competition. In autos, steel and other industries, Japanese companies were helped by significantly lower labor costs. Their cost edge dictated their international strategy: slashing prices to gain market share. **********Yet Fuji seems unlikely to resort to the same aggressive tactics. First, amateur shutterbugs tend to shun budget-priced film, preferring a high- quality image, a lesson Kodak has apparently learned in Japan (see box). **********Second, Mr. Ohnishi contends that Fuji's production costs are higher than Kodak's, and industry analysts agree. They say that the chemicals used in making film and photographic paper are cheaper in the United States. And lower labor costs, which have helped the Japanese in other fields, are not so important in the photographic industry. **********''Making color film is not a labor- intensive process,'' says Eugene Glazer, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. ''It is a capital- and materials-intensive process. So Kodak's production costs are probably lower than Fuji's.'' **********Moreover, conventional photography is a silver-based technology, and Kodak has the advantage of buying the metal domestically. **********Still, Fuji could fight a price war with Kodak if it chose to, because the profit margins in the photographic business are thick enough to allow plenty of shaving. But Mr. Ohnishi insists, ''We won't cut prices to increase our market share.'' **********Yet American analysts note that while Fuji's suggested retail prices in America are about the same as Kodak's, the Japanese company has selectively offered discounts to large retail chains and other film dealers to try to grab business from Kodak. **********Given the strength of Kodak's brand name in the United States, a gradual advance is the most Fuji can hope for. One American says, ''No matter what Fuji does, I doubt that there is a big retail chain in the country that would have the courage to go with Fuji's film alone.'' **********Until now, Fuji's gains in the United States had come at the expense of film producers other than Kodak, such as 3M, Agfa-Gevaert and G.A.F., which dropped out of the amateur film business in the late 1970's. **********Analysts speculate that Fuji may someday snatch 15 percent of the huge American film market, but they agree that getting American consumers to break the habit of reaching for one of Kodak's yellow boxes every time they want film will be a formidable task. **********Fuji's Olympic sponsorship is a step in that direction, although Kodak has seized the right to advertise its photographic products during televised broadcasts of the Games. **********Internationally, Fuji's prospects are brighter outside the United States, where brand loyalty to Kodak is weaker. Fuji already holds nearly half the film and paper business in Southeast Asia. **********Fuji's share of the West European market is a bit more than 10 percent. To aid its European effort, Fuji is building a manufacturing facility in the Netherlands, to open next August. **********But although Fuji opened an operation in Anaheim, Calif., last year to develop film, it has no plans yet to build a manufacturing plant in North America. First, Mr. Ohnishi stresses, Fuji must reach a higher level of ''stable sales,'' but he does not say what that threshold is. Analysts place that critical market share at 10 percent or slightly more. **********''Fuji will be careful,'' predicts Yuichi Kohasi, an analyst for the Daiwa Securities Company in Tokyo. ''But exports should be one of the company's major forces for growth over the next several years.'' **********Mr. Ohnishi says his company's growth over the long term will depend on its ability to wed developments in chemistry and optics with microelectronics to create ''hybrid technologies'' with commercial applications in video, semiconductors, office equipment and medical instruments. **********Fuji has been laying the groundwork for its tilt toward microelectronics since the mid-1970's, when its top management decided a shift of course was needed and began hiring more electronics engineers. In Japan, bringing such expertise into the corporate fold is not a matter of bidding for people with money. **********Instead, it is a slow, painstaking process of nurturing contacts with university professors, whose recommendations are the most important factor in determining where their students will work after graduation. ''It has taken us nearly a decade to develop close relations with professors at Japan's leading universities,'' Mr.  Ueda said. **********Fuji's research and development spending has increased steadily: Today the company's budget for it amounts to 6.5 percent of sales, up from 5 percent five years ago. Of the 140 or so engineers Fuji hires every year, about 100 now go into its research laboratories, compared with 65 five years ago, Mr. Ueda says. **********Recently, Fuji's fastest-growing line has been videotape, a product that Kodak does not make. In the late 1970's, Fuji came into the field forcefully, intent upon fashioning a high- quality image, often pricing its products slightly higher than its rivals'. **********Today Fuji is among the world's largest producers of videotape, analysts estimate, closely trailing only TDK, Hitachi, Maxell and Sony. But analysts note that, thanks to aggressive marketing efforts, the growth in Fuji's sales during the past six months has been faster than that of the other big videotape producers. **********Videotape accounts for an estimated 80 percent of Fuji's magnetics products division, which also includes audio tape, and floppy disks and memory tape for computers. From 1978 to 1982, the division's sales jumped nearly fivefold, to $297 million. So far, the videotape business has yielded high profits, helping Fuji's overall profitability to outpace its revenue growth. In the five-year span, when sales about doubled, to $2.5 billion, Fuji's net income nearly tripled, to $243 million. **********Fuji began making floppy disks three years ago, but only within the past year or so has a sizable market developed, and now it is a leading Japanese producer. Mr. Ohnishi expects the growth of floppy disk sales to average nearly 50 percent annually over the next five years. **********Earlier this year, Fuji introduced a computerized radiography system that is essentially an advance over the conventional X-ray. It requires far less X-ray exposure for the patient, and computerization improves the image as well as storing and processing information about patients. **********By 1987, some analysts predict that yearly sales of Fuji's system could be as much as $250 million. Yet others warn that the prospects may be far more limited. **********In the current fiscal year, ended Oct. 20, analysts estimate that the company's not-yet-reported earnings were flat or slipped slightly for cyclical reasons. But while Fuji's profits have leveled off, Kodak's have fallen sharply. Still, ''comparing Fuji's financial performance with that of Kodak recently is like comparing apples and oranges,'' said Darrel E. Whitten, an analyst for Prudential- Bache Securities in Tokyo. **********For 1984, analysts estimate Fuji's earnings will rise 15 to 20 percent. **********Of greater long-term significance is the drastic improvement in Fuji's profit margins, as it improves its production efficiency and introduces new products. According to Prudential- Bache, Fuji's pretax operating margins widened to 20.4 percent in 1982, up from 12 percent in 1978. By 1986, the company's operating margins should reach 27 percent, Prudential- Bache predicts. By comparison, Kodak's operating margins are put at 28.3 percent in 1978, 22.5 percent in 1982 and 25 percent in 1986. **********KNOWN as an efficiently managed company that executes well-thought-out plans, Fuji has a style very much in the Japanese mold, with the emphasis on collective endeavor. Its corporate history does not include a charismatic leader of the stature of Konosuke Matsushita, founder of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, or a chief executive whose face is instantly recognized like Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation. For his part, Mr. Ohnishi discourages questions about his hobbies or other personal matters. **********An anecdote involving Mr. Ueda, the 53-year-old senior managing director and chemist, seems representative of the attitude at Fuji. Last year, the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers in Los Angeles gave Mr. Ueda the 82d Herbert T. Kalmus Award, named for the inventor of Technicolor, for his work on developing special color movie film. **********In his home, Mr. Ueda has a gold- plated copy of the medal. The real one, which is all gold, hangs in the Fuji laboratory in Ashigara, west of Tokyo. ''The technological advances were the result of group effort,'' Mr. Ueda said. ''The real medal is where it belongs.'' **********SELLING JAPAN ONKODAK'S YELLOW BOX **********TOKYO Kodak, giant of the world's photographic industry, is a small-time operator in Japan. The problem Kodak faces here is the same one confronting Fuji in the United States - the difficulty of making headway against an adversary in a market where the rival brand name is all but synonymous with film. **********''People are not about to switch from the green Fuji box to that Kodak yellow here,'' said Robert Burghart, an analyst for W. I. Carr Sons & Company in Tokyo. **********Analysts estimate that Kodak's share of the Japanese market for amateur color film and paper is about 15 percent, compared with 75 percent for Fuji. **********Kodak's products have been sold in Japan for more than eight decades. Yet its early start and high-quality products did Kodak little good when the Japanese market for amateur photography genuinely began to develop in the 1950's and 1960's, largely because of the prohibitively high tariffs on imported film and restrictions on direct investment by foreign companies. Today, these market barriers no longer exist. **********To explain why price-cutting will not be part of Fuji's international strategy, Minoru Ohnishi, Fuji's president, points to Kodak's experience in Japan earlier this year. The price of Kodak film, Mr. Ohnishi said, was cut but Japan's camera-toting throngs were not impressed. ''We heard some people say that Kodak film must not be as good as before since it is cheaper,'' he said. **********Of the Kodak price-trimming, one Japanese analyst said, ''It was not a successful tactic at all.'' **********The Japanese distributor of Kodak's amateur film, Nagase Sangyo, replies that there was no formal program of price-cutting for market share. Rather, retailers sold film at reduced prices to do a little ''inventory clearing'' after Kodak introduced new lines of film, according to a Nagase Sangyo official. The move was not extraordinary, he added, noting that Fuji had done something similar itself. **********Analysts say Kodak's price cuts were steeper and lasted longer. But one Japanese analyst agreed that Kodak's reductions were more likely cyclical shelf- clearing than an effort to strengthen its hand here.
