https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The BankAmerica Corporation reported yesterday that net income rose 15.3 percent in the second quarter, to $141.9 million, from $123.1 million in the comparable period a year earlier. **********On a per share basis, net income increased only 2.4 percent, to 84 cents a share, from 82 cents a share. The per share increase was smaller because the $141.9 million net income figure for 1983's second quarter was not lowered by the $15 million that was paid in preferred stock dividends. Such dividends were not paid in last year's second quarter. **********Samuel H. Armacost, BankAmerica's president, said in a statement that the bank profited from increases in both noninterest revenue, including a $44 million gain from its venture capital portfolio, and net interest margin, which is the difference between the cost of the bank's money and what it charges on loans. **********Net interest margin increased to 3.43 percent in the latest quarter, from 3.21 percent a year earlier.  ''On the other hand,'' Mr. Armacost said, ''flat loan totals and high levels of loan charge-offs had a negative impact on our earnings.'' **********BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, is the parent company of the Bank of America. Its second-quarter results do not reflect its purchase of the Seafirst Corporation, the Seattle banking company, which took effect on July 1. **********In the latest quarter, BankAmerica's provision for loan losses rose to $141.3 million from $95.5 million in 1983's first quarter and $100.8 million in 1982's second quarter. Actual loan losses were $144.5 million, compared with $71 million in the first quarter this year and $88 million in the second quarter last year. **********Assets as of June 30 were $121 billion, down from $121.7 billion in June 1982. The annual return on each $100 of assets, which many analysts use as a key indicator of a bank's performance, increased to 47 cents, from 42 cents last year. Continental Illinois **********The Continental Illinois Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest banking organization, said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter totaled $31.2 million, or 78 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $63 million in the period a year before. **********The deficit reported in last year's second quarter was one of the largest quarterly losses ever reported by the banking company. It resulted largely from Continental's purchase of about $1 billion in loans fromthe failed Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City. **********Despite the improved earnings, Continental said its nonperforming credits, or problem loans, stood at $2.08 billion in the latest quarter, and accounted for 6.6 percent of its total loans outstanding. About a quarter of these problem loans were purchased from Penn Square before it was closed on July 5, 1982, the bank said. Continental owns the Continental National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. **********A year ago, Continental said its nonperforming credits totaled $1.3 billion, or 3.7 percent of its total loan portfolio. Analysts said the larger amount of problem loans reported for this year's second quarter mean that the Chicago-based banking organization will continue to have difficulties. **********''The direction of the magnitude'' of the nonperforming credits ''runs counter to other major banks and could be a source of concern,'' said James Wooden of Merrill Lynch. He added that no other major banks have problem loans that comprise as high a percentage of their loans porfolios as Continental. **********At the same time, however, other analysts said they expect the economic recovery and improved business conditions among many of the banks customers to result in a rapid improvement in its loan portfolio this year. **********John J. Mason of Interstate Securities Inc. maintained that Continental's problem loans are a ''finite problem.'' Even if the bank is only able to recover ''25 cents on the dollar from the Penn Square loans,'' he said, many of the other loans it has now classified as problems will be repaid in full. The companies that have those loans, which include many heavy industrial concerns in the Middle West, are only beginning to feel the effects of the recovery, and their balance sheets will continue to improve, he added.Part of the reason for Continental's improved earnings in the latest quarter was increased income from interest payments and a wide profit margin on those payments. It said its interest was $242.1 million, or $6.1 million more than in the 1982 second quarter. Its margin on interest payments, or the amount left after deducting the costs to service loans, was 2.66 percent, compared with 2.28 percent a year earlier, the company said. operating costssthe if **********The company said its provision for credit losses in the second quarter was $95 million. This compared with a provision of $262 million in the 1982 second quarter that resulted mainly from the writing off of $220 million in Penn Square loans. ---- Bank tables, page D21.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/world.print_headline: KREMLIN AIDE SAYS US. IMPERILS TALKS ON STRATEGIC ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/world.body_text: **********A Soviet official said today that the same American tactics that led the Russians to break off talks on medium-range nuclear weapons were now threatening the talks on intercontinental nuclear weapons. **********The official, Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the general staff, said that efforts by the United States to achieve military superiority were moving the talks on limiting strategic nuclear weapons ''in the same direction'' as the negotiations on medium-range weapons in Europe that were broken off by the Kremlin on Nov. 23. Another session of the strategic arms talks is scheduled Tuesday in Geneva, where the talks on medium-range arms were also held. **********Andropov's Health Is Discussed **********The warning of a possible breakdown in the talks on strategic weapons came at a news conference at which a senior Communist Party official made the fullest statement yet on the health of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. **********The party official, Leonid M. Zamyatin, said that Mr. Andropov, who has been absent from public occasions for more than 15 weeks, was recovering from what he implied was a cold and was attending to ''party and state affairs in their full scope.'' The news conference also featured the Kremlin's clearest statement yet on its refusal to resume negotiations on medium-range nuclear weapons unless the new American missiles are withdrawn from Europe. **********'False Optimism' Derided **********Georgi M. Korniyenko, a First Deputy Foreign Minister, derided Western leaders' ''false optimism'' that these negotiations would resume. **********With these and other remarks, the Soviet officials set out a position on the arms talks that seemed to be tougher than the statement issued by Mr. Andropov after the Soviet walkout from the medium-range talks. **********Marshal Ogarkov, nine rows of ribbons on his khaki uniform, set forth the military's position on the missile talks against a backdrop of a multicolored chart showing the arms of the two sides and the proposals that each has made in two years of talks at Geneva. He said President Reagan's proposals on medium-range weapons had been absurd and said they were intended from the outset to block agreement so the United States could achieve the ability to inflict a ''disarming nuclear strike'' against the Soviet Union with Pershing 2 and cruise missiles close to Soviet frontiers. **********He said a first-strike strategy was senseless since both sides had many nuclear weapons with many basing systems and redundant command systems that made a return blow certain. ''Retaliation will be inevitable in all cases,'' he said. **********The marshal said that Washington, having blocked agreement on medium- range weapons to clear the way for deploying them, appeared to be ''pursuing the same goal'' in the talks on strategic arms. **********He said the Americans sought to exclude limits on bombers and bomber- launched cruise missiles, an area in which he said the United States had a lead of 7,000 warheads. Although his figure of a lead of 7,000 warheads agrees approximately with estimates published in the West, the Soviet Union has virtually ignored the bomber as a delivery vehicle for strategic nuclear weapons, concentrating instead on delivery by missile. **********In addition, Marshal Ogarkov said, Washington wanted cuts in the Soviet land-based missile force that would force a fundamental restructuring of the Soviet armory costing billions of rubles. **********Speaking of the end of the medium- range negotiations, the marshal said of the strategic weapons talks: ''I believe they are moving in the same direction.''  Andropov Said to Have a Cold **********The issue of Mr. Andropov's health arose in response to questions from Western reporters, and Mr. Zamyatin, head of the International Information Department of the party's Central Committee, responded with what appeared to be a prepared statement. **********His response was later carried in full by the official press agency Tass and on the principal evening television news program. **********''As Yuri Andropov has recently said in his letter of response to the leaders of the Physicians for Peace movement, he could not meet with them because of a cold,'' Mr. Zamyatin said, speaking of a message from the Soviet leader that was published in late October. **********''At the present time Yuri Andropov is recovering,'' Mr. Zamyatin continued. ''He is managing in full measure party and state affairs, including questions pertaining to the U.S.S.R. Defense Council.'' **********When a Western reporter asked whether there was any substance to reports that Mr. Andropov had an illness much more serious than a cold and had been in a hospital, Mr. Zamyatin responded: ''I do not believe your insinuations because they do not correspond to reality. Everything I meant to inform you about formally I covered in my statement, which is true to fact.''  Resumption of Talks Discounted **********In his statement on the medium- range missile talks, Mr. Korniyenko spoke scornfully of the prediction by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany that Moscow would eventually return to the negotiations. Mr. Kohl based his prediction on a message from Mr. Andropov that said the Kremlin did not like to think of the breakdown of the talks as irreversible. **********The Foreign Ministry official said it took ''an amazingly exuberant imagination'' to read this as a readiness to resume talks ''against the background of deployment'' of the American missiles. **********He said that when Mr. Andropov spoke of a return to the previous situation, he meant ''in the first place deeds,'' and this required the removal of the American missiles whose arrival in Britain, West Germany and Italy prompted the Soviet withdrawal from the talks. **********As for the possibility that the medium-range talks could be resumed in the context of the strategic arms negotiations, he said it would be pointless to talk of such a merger since the medium-range talks no longer existed. At this point, the official used a Russian idiom that translates roughly as died.   Countermeasures Discussed **********Adding some details about the military countermeasures announced by the Kremlin after it withdrew from the talks, Marshal Ogarkov said the additional seaborne missiles to be deployed against the United States would be placed adjacent to United States shores and would be ''adequate from the point of view of range, yield, accuracy and, which is particularly important, flight time to target'' to create a threat for the United States equal to that created for the Soviet Union by the new American missiles in Europe. **********Soviet statements have said that Pershing 2's in West Germany will cut warning time of an American strike to as little as six minutes, although American officials have responded that the time will be twice that. **********He also cited ''forms of military activity'' other than those involving nuclear weapons that would be adopted to counter the Western deployment, but he declined to give details. **********In further remarks about SS-20's, Mr. Zamyatin said that none of the 243 missiles so far deployed against Europe was aimed at population centers or against any nation not already deploying nuclear weapons against the Soviet Union, a statement that seemed to be intended to foster European protests against the American weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/world.body_text: **********The Justice Department said today that it would conduct a full investigation into allegations that the United States Government assisted Klaus Barbie, a twice-convicted Nazi war criminal, to escape to Bolivia after World War II. **********The department said that it viewed the allegations ''with deep concern'' and that an initial review of Government files indicated that the assertions ''have sufficient merit to warrant a comprehensive investigation.'' **********The announcement came after days of maneuvering that included a message from William P. Clark, the national security adviser, to Attorney General William French Smith urging him to reverse an earlier refusal and conduct an inquiry into the Barbie case. **********Extradited Last Month **********Mr. Barbie, 69 years old, the Gestapo chief of Lyons from 1942 to 1944, was extradited from Bolivia to France last month to face charges of wartime murders. He was twice convicted and sentenced to death in absentia. He is now in prison in Lyons awaiting trial. **********Recent published accounts have suggested that Mr. Barbie was protected and paid by American intelligence agencies after the war and that he made trips to several American cities in 1969 and 1970.  The report of his visits to New Orleans and Miami, made under the pseudonym Klaus Altmann, was supported by immigration records, Justice Department officials said last week. **********According to authoritative accounts by Justice Department officials, Mr. Smith last week overruled the recommendations of some aides and rejected an investigation into the Barbie case on the ground that after all the years no prosecution was likely to result. A Note From Clark **********Last Friday, however, officials said Mr. Clark wrote a note to Mr.  Smith suggesting that the Justice Department was the place for an investigation after all. The department issued an announcement this afternoon: **********''Recent allegations have been made that Klaus Barbie had a relationship with the United States Government in the years after World War II and that the U.S. Government assisted his travel to Bolivia in 1951. **********''We view these allegations with deep concern, and a preliminary review of pertinent Government files indicates that these allegations have sufficient merit to warrant a comprehensive investigation. **********''Therefore the Department of Justice is undertaking a full investigation. The object of this investigation is to develop a factual record of any relationship that may have existed between Klaus Barbie and the U.S. Government at any time. A report to Congress and the public will be made as soon as the investigation is completed.'' Special Office May Get Case **********Further word on the conduct of the investigation is expected to come Tuesday. An official familar with the matter said the inquiry would most likely be put into the hands of Allan M. Ryan, director of the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations. The special investigations office was formed in 1978 to examine cases of people suspected of being Nazis or collaborators illegally living in the United States. **********Should the special investigations office get the assignment, it was said, Mr. Ryan may leave the office to take on the Barbie case fulltime as a kind of special prosecutor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/world.main_headline: 'EVIL SCHEMES' SCORNED AT SOUTH KOREAN'S BURIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/world.print_headline: 'EVIL SCHEMES' SCORNED AT SOUTH KOREAN'S BURIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/world.body_text: **********The South Koreans killed in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma, were buried today after an outdoor funeral service that turned into a huge rally denouncing North Korea for what one speaker called its ''evil schemes.'' **********North Korea is generally assumed here to be responsible for the bombing, although the Government has not officially offered any evidence of this. **********Sixteen South Koreans were killed instantly in the explosion, which tore through a mausoleum in Rangoon dedicated to Burmese martyrs. It was announced this morning that a 17th person, Deputy Finance Minister Lee Ki Uk, had died at an American Air Force base in the Philippines where he was being treated for serious injuries. **********Perhaps a Million Mourners **********Hundreds of thousands of people, perhaps as many as a million, filled most of an enormous outdoor plaza often used for approved mass demonstrations. **********With its banners and orderly ranks, the crowd had the earmarks of carefully arranged gatherings that are familiar here. Nevertheless, it was the largest rally that many could recall in several years. And the grief etched into many faces spoke of jumbled emotions created by both the Rangoon incident and the downing by a Soviet fighter plane last month of a Korean Air Lines passenger plane carrying 269 people. **********The 17 slain South Koreans, who included some of the Government's highest-ranking officials, were eulogized in speeches as the ''proud pillars of this country.''  Portraits and Incense **********The speakers addressed the dead, turning their backs to the huge crowd and facing outsized photographs of the victims that were decked with black ribbons and almost enveloped by yellow and white chrysanthemums. The pictures lined a long platform thick with the smell of incense. **********Rain that had fallen all morning stopped the moment that the service began with a wail from a siren marking a minute of silence observed throughout the country. Representatives from more than 40 nations were here, among them the United States Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger. **********Not present, however, was South Korea's President, Chun Doo Hwan, who escaped harm in Burma, where he had been on a state visit. Security reasons presumably were a consideration, though some officials said Mr. Chun also did not want his presence to draw attention from the bombing victims. **********The speeches were ornate in language and few in number. After prayers, relatives of those who were killed mounted the platform to lay flowers by the photographs. Men in black suits and women in billowing white dresses bowed their heads, and from the platform there rose a loud wailing of the sort that has been heard often in South Korea in recent weeks. **********But as much as the ceremony was a prayer for the dead, it was also an opportunity to assail North Korea.   'Without Any Brotherly Feeling' **********For its part, the North Korean Government has dismissed the charges as ''preposterous,'' and its Central News Agency accused South Korea today of aggravating tensions on the Korean peninsula. **********The tightly controlled press here said today that Burmese and South Korean investigators had found ''physical evidence'' of North Korean involvement. This was said to include batteries for a remote-controlled explosive device, an unexploded bomb shell and a remote- controlled ''wave receiver.'' It was not made clear why this material conclusively implicated the North Koreans. **********''Without any brotherly feeling,'' Prime Minister Kim Sang Hyup told the crowd of mourners, ''they are jealous of our development and resentful of our growth, and have plotted countless evil schemes at home and abroad to foment internal confusion among us.'' **********After the funeral service ended and the familiies left, hundreds of large banners that had been kept hidden were suddenly unfurled. They carried such messages as ''There is a limit to patience'' and ''Let's avenge the barbarous act of North Korea.'' **********North Korea Reports Infiltration **********TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 14 (AP) - North Korea charged today that at least 10 South Korean soldiers crossed into the North Korean side of the demilitarized zone between the two countries around midnight Thursday and fired more than 500 rounds of ammunition. **********The state-run Korean Central News Agency, in a report monitored in Tokyo, said North Korea immediately placed a telephone call to South Korea protesting the ''armed attack.'' **********The incident occurred at a time of increased tension between North and South Korea following the bombing in Rangoon, Burma. The North Korean press agency said the infiltration of South Korean soldiers Thursday night ''is a premeditated military provocation for leading the situation to the brink of war.'' It did not say if North Korean troops fired back or if anyone was wounded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/23/busin.body_text: **********For the past quarter century Arkla Inc., owner of the powerful Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company, has been an aggressive acquisitor of gas and oil leases and a developer of those lands. **********But last New Year's Eve, Arkla's board of directors agreed to sell its leases on almost 15,000 acres in the gas-rich Arkoma Basin in northwest Arkansas. The purchaser was the Arkoma Production Corporation, a small exploration and drilling company owned by Jerral W. Jones, a former insurance executive who went into gas and oil drilling in the 1970's. He is a close friend of E. Sheffield Nelson, Arkla's board chairman and chief executive. **********The transaction had some unusual features that seemed very favorable to Arkoma. That raised questions by other executives in the industry about whether Mr. Nelson acted in the best interests of Arkla in dealing with his friend. Arkla has even acknowledged in a proxy statement the possibility of ''conflicts of interest.'' And W.T. Murphy Jr., an Arkla board member for more than 25 years, said in an interview that he had asked the company for ''10 reasons why this is a good deal for Arkla and I never got a list.'' **********Plans Race for Governor **********Both Mr. Jones and Mr. Nelson are millionaires who made their marks as salesmen. Mr. Jones, 40 years old, is a former University of Arkansas football player who became friendly with Mr. Nelson a decade ago as part of a group of half-a-dozen young businessmen who had become influential in Arkansas politics. Mr. Nelson, 42, is a lawyer who joined Arkla as a salesman while still in college and became chief executive in his early 30's. He recently announced plans to run for Governor. **********The sale price for the leases was $15 million. Bill Williams, the Arkansas State geologist, described that price ''as probably a real big bargain'' for gas land in this northwestern Arkansas-eastern Oklahoma area. The 15,000 acres are in the Cecil and Aetna gas fields, which have already produced almost half a trillion cubic feet of natural gas. According to Mr. Williams, they appear to have about that much more in untapped reserves. That would mean a potential market value of about $250 million for gas from the 15,000 acres. **********By comparison, within the last three years, gas land in the Arkoma Basin has been auctioned at $2 million for 640-acre sections, or the equivalent of $45 million for 15,000 acres. Arkla still has substantial additional holdings in the Arkoma Basin. **********Under the accord, Mr. Jones's Arkoma Production Corporation promised to sell the gas it produces to Mr. Nelson's Arkla Inc., whose Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company supplies more than 80 percent of the residential and commercial energy in Arkansas. ''The key for a producer, in this day and time, is not having the gas,'' Mr. Williams said. ''It's having somebody who will buy it.'' Accord on Drilling Costs **********Mr. Nelson made it clear in an interview that Arkla was likely to buy the promised gas from Arkoma, although a purchase contract did not exist. He said that Arkla had agreed to match all of Arkoma's drilling costs dollar for dollar up to $10 million a year on the 15,000 acres. That would be almost 12 percent of Arkla's annual drilling budget of $85 million. Mr. Nelson said that Arkla would pay $3.40 a thousand cubic feet, a ceiling price, for gas recovered from these new wells, each of which will cost $300,000 to $500,000 to drill. **********''The Arkoma deal increases our drilling budget by another $10 million,'' Mr. Nelson argued, in response to criticism in the gas industry that Arkla did not have to sell its leases in order to get $10 million drilling participations. Others with whom Arkla has partnerships in the Arkoma Basin would have put up this money, the critics say. Mr. Nelson acknowledges that this is true, but that only Mr. Jones approached with a deal. **********Arkla also agreed to finance $11.25 million of Arkoma's $15 million purchase price at 10 percent annually, an interest rate that was 2 percentage points below the prime rate when the deal was made and about 3.5 percentage points below what Arkansas banks then were charging many of their best corporate customers. **********Mack Norton, former chairman of the Arkansas Public Service Commission, said of the $15 million lease sale, ''I'm surprised that Nelson would sell the land without trying to get the best price possible.'' Mr. Norton said the commission had not been told of the deal in advance. ''Not necessarily as a matter of law, but as a matter of courtesy, the commission should have been apprised of the loan and a transaction of that size,'' he added. **********That type of comment has raised questions among some gas industry executives about Mr. Nelson's business relationship with Mr. Jones's Arkoma Production Corportion and Mr. Nelson's possible future involvement in Arkoma. 'One of the Best Deals' **********In the interview in his Little Rock office, Mr. Nelson, who resigned as president of Arkla in May at the company's annual meeting, but remains as chairman and chief executive, acknowledged his friendship with Mr. Jones. But he denied having ''any ownership whatever'' in Arkoma Production, which is privately held. He insisted that the sale of the leases to Arkoma was a good business deal. **********Mr. Norton, the former Public Service Commission chairman, was skeptical of Mr. Nelson's assertion that it was a good business deal for Arkla. ''Nelson probably doesn't own any part of Arkoma yet,'' Mr. Norton said in an interview, ''but he may in the future.'' **********The $15 million lease purchase actually represented Arkla's halfinterest in this acreage. The remaining 50 percent of the land in the Cecil field was held by the Stephens Production Company of Fort Smith, Ark. In addition, Stephens was one of the principal shareholders in the Aetna field acreage. The others were the Carter Oil Company, a wholly owned Exxon subsidiary; Continental Oil, and the Union Life Insurance Company, owned by Ray Hunt of Dallas, a son of the late H.L. Hunt. **********Exxon and the other small partners did not sell to Arkoma or try to buy the Arkla leases themselves, although they had a right of first refusal to match Arkoma's $15 million offer. Their principal problem presumably was matching that aspect of the Arkoma deal in which Mr.  Jones dedicated to Arkla all the gas produced on the 15,000 acres, plus the gas from 100,000 additional acres that he holds. **********In addition, Mr. Jones agreed to sell to Arkla, if that company wants it, any gas that his company produces from leases that Arkoma acquires over the next five years in a five-state area. These states are Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas. **********The addditional acreage appears to enhance the quality of the deal. But some experts question the location and value of that acreage, saying that at least some of it ''is raw wildcat land.'' Special Relationship a Factor **********Independent gas producers insist that only Mr. Jones, with his special relationship with Mr. Nelson, could be successful in getting Arkla to buy the gas that Arkoma Production produces. As Mr.  Williams, the state geologist, said: ''The secret of success in the gas fields today is not having the gas, but having a market for the gas. If you can make a deal where you can get reserves and also have a pipeline and a market, you have made a real good deal.'' **********Mr. Jones was recently elected to Arkla's board of directors, presumably putting him in a position to help assure that Arkla buys gas from Arkoma. Acknowledging this potential, Arkla said in a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that ''the business of oil and gas exploration and production engaged in by Arkoma Production Company and Mr. Jones may in the future involve conflicts of interest with the Company (Arkla) or its subsidiaries.'' **********In another major aspect of the Arkoma-Arkla deal, Stephens Production Company gave up to Mr. Jones a ''good portion'' of its 50 percent stake in the Cecil field leases, Mr. Jones said in an interview. It did so not for cash, but because Mr. Jones put together a deal that permits Stephens to sell its gas to Arkla's Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company for far more than the 55 cents per thousand cubic feet it has been receiving from Arkla under a long-term contract. **********Arkla has been paying other customers as much as $2.75 to $3.36 a thousand cubic feet for new gas, but Stephens Production was a special case involving not only low-priced, long-term contracts, but also animosity between Arkla's Mr. Nelson and Witt Stephens, the 76-year-old part owner of Stephens Production. Mr. Stephens formerly was chairman of Arkla and he took Mr. Nelson under his wing years ago, helping to train him and picking him to take over Arkla as chairman in 1972 at the age of 33. Jones's Advantages **********According to Mr. Jones, he began trying to put together his deal to buy the land leases from Arkla about 18 months ago and he acknowledged that his special relationship with Mr. Nelson gave him the advantage of knowing how to structure the deal successfully. **********He knew, for example, the details of the decade of animosity between Mr. Nelson and Mr. Stephens. The two men split shortly after Mr. Nelson became chairman of Arkla and none save the two participants seem to know exactly why. Mr. Stephens, a former state senator and longtime political power in Arkansas, has said he was unhappy with the way his successor operated the company. **********Mr. Jones knew that Stephens Production was an equal partner with Arkla on much of the Arkoma acreage leases. And he realized that both Arkla and Stephens Production were two of the largest gas and oil drillers and developers in the region and that neither needed assistance in drilling whatever land they had. **********But he also recognized that there would be no cooperation between the two unless Stephens gave up some of its holdings in order to get Arkla to take Stephens gas at more than the 55 cents per thousand cubic feet specified in the old purchase contracts. **********Since Stephens Production had difficulty selling new gas to Arkla, it also had difficulty convincing landholders that they should lease mineral rights to Stephens instead of to Arkla or to others who could sell into the Arkla pipeline at a higher price. **********So Mr. Jones, armed with such knowledge, bought into the Arkoma Basin properties with the idea of convincing Stephens that as one of three partners, he could put together a deal that Mr. Stephens himself could not. All Stephens Production had to do was give up to him a good portion of its lease holding. Neither Mr. Jones nor Stephens officials would say how much Stephens gave up to Mr. Jones. Political Plans **********Mr. Nelson has said he will leave Arkla at the end of the year and will most likely run for Governor in the 1986 election, as a Democrat. The incumbent, Bill Clinton, also a Democrat, could run again in 1986, but some politicians speculate that he will run for the United States Senate that year. **********Mr. Nelson is one of the highest-paid utility company executives in the country. In addition to his salary of $340,000 a year, he has exercised more than $1 million in stock appreciation rights in the past five years and has accumulated about $1.2 million more in such rights yet to be exercised. At a recent board meeting, he was granted additional stock appreciation rights on 60,000 more shares at $14 a share. **********Stock appreciation rights give the holder the option of selling his stock during designated periods each quarter without having bought the shares, thereby earning the differences between the exercise price and the market price. **********Arkla's stock closed Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at $26.50 a share, down 37 1/2 cents. It has traded between $12.75 and $28.50 in the last 52 weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/busin.body_text: **********Friday will see the virtual end of bearer bonds in the municipal market. Instead, state and local governments must offer all new issues in registered form, signaling what some say is the beginning of a computerized bond record-keeping system. **********The new law means that no bond issues over one year in maturity can be issued in bearer form, an anonymous form of trading where the ''bearer'' is presumed to be the owner. This change was designed to help the Federal government keep better track of interest payments made to individuals. Few municipals carry less than one-year maturity. **********Analysts said intitally that it would be more expensive to issue such debt because the issuers would have to designate a transfer agent capable of keeping track of bond ownership when the bonds are traded. Many analysts suggested this task would best be completed by a computerized system. **********Lawrence J. Newman, vice president in municipal bond research at Prudential Bache Securities Inc., said much of this anxiety had disappeared. **********Some analysts had predicted that a two-tiered market in municipal bonds will develop after Friday, with the bearer bonds commanding a premium price and lower yield over the registered bonds because the old bearer bonds will be easier to trade. **********But Mr. Newman said that the difference would be no more than 20 to 25 basis points, or one-fifth to one-quarter of a percentage point in the yields, and that this difference is expected to be temporary. **********Because the law requires that any bearer bonds be delivered by June 30, most of these bonds were issued three weeks ago to meet the paper work requirements. Therefore the schedule for this week is very light. **********The corporate schedule is light as well, reflecting the recent rise in interest rates. But analysts said if rates declined steadily, several corporations that have filed shelf registrations would rush out with their offerings. **********The following new fixed-income securities are scheduled this week: TAXABLE MONDAY **********Federal National Mortgage Association, $400 million of 12 percent mortgage-backed securities, no maturity and not rated, offered directly by FNMA but with 17-member selling group headed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/busin.main_headline: Former Morgan Officer In Waterhouse Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former Morgan Officer In Waterhouse Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/busin.body_text: **********Alexander M. Vagliano left the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in 1981 as head of its international banking division. Since then, among other things, he has been testing the feasibility of raising sheep commercially in New England. **********''That's going to take a while,'' he said yesterday of the experiment on his extensive acreage in northwestern Connecticut. In the meantime, he has embarked on another project. Mr. Vagliano has joined with three other international finance figures in a partnership with Price Waterhouse. **********The purpose is to provide international consulting services. Price Waterhouse & Partners, as it will be called, will be represented in London, New York, Paris, Zurich and Hong Kong and will use the resources of Price Waterhouse firms. **********Michael Coates, chairman of what used to be Price Waterhouse International and is now called the World Firm of Price Waterhouse, will be chairman of the partnership. Other members are the European bankers Andre George, Claude Hankes-Drielsma and Eugen Roesle. **********Mr. Vagliano, 56, said the group would assist lenders and borrowers in international funding and also help borrowing nations straighten out their books. ''One of the biggest problems,'' he said, ''is that people don't know how much they borrowed. Problems arise too quickly. Too much is borrowed on wrong terms and they get beyond themselves without even knowing it in some cases.'' **********To obtain a good credit standing, he said: ''The financial world is going to insist on credible statistical data, not only for the past but up-to-date controls and systems. I can't think of anyone who could do this kind of thing except for a world accounting firm.'' **********Mr. Vagliano left Morgan Guaranty after it merged its national and international banking divisions. He said he has been on a number of boards here and abroad in addition to his sheep-raising activities.  Earlier in his career, he left Morgan to serve three years with the Agency for International Development. **********Mr. Vagliano rejoined Morgan in 1964 and three years later was sent to Italy to run the bank's subsidiary there, returning to the international division as executive vice president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.main_headline: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL PLANS TO VISIT NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.print_headline: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL PLANS TO VISIT NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials said today that a senior State Deparment official would go to Nicaragua this week to probe the intentions behind recent Nicaraguan diplomatic moves and to caution Managua not to send its troops into Honduras or Costa Rica. **********State Department officials said that Langhorne A. Motley, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, would arrive in Managua Thursday on a two-day visit. He is to meet with Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of the ruling Sandinista junta, Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman and Interior Minister Tomas Borge. **********One official said Mr. Motley intended to caution the Sandinista leadership that if they engaged in cross-border warfare against neighboring countries, it could lead to invoking of diplomatic and economic sanctions against Nicaragua by the Organization of American States. **********This official also said there had been signs that the Sandinista leadership might be moving toward some regional agreement on the issues of curbing the flow of outside arms and military advisers into the region. **********Some Administration officials have interpreted these signs as indications that the Sandinista leadership was ''feeling the pressure'' from increased activities by Nicaraguan rebels and the show of United States forces in ground and naval exercises in the region. **********For these reasons, the Reagan Administration was eager to have Mr. Motley hold talks in Nicaragua. Mr. Motley was scheduled to visit Nicaragua last month for such talks but called off his trip when, according to the United States version of the incident, he was informed on the eve of his departure that no ranking Sandinista leaders would meet with him. **********Since then, several members of Congress, including critics of Administration policy, are reported to have advised the Nicaraguan Government that its leaders had made a mistake in not receiving Mr. Motley and his visit was rescheduled. He is to stop first, on Wednesday, in Belize to discuss the century-old border dispute between that country and Guatemala. **********On July 31, Richard B. Stone, the President's special envoy to Central America, met briefly with both Salvadoran guerrilla leaders and Nicaraguan Government leaders. But not since the spring of 1982 has the Administration held talks with the Sandinista Government at the policy-making level. **********Since then, Washington has worked to persuade the Nicaraguan Government to work on some regional agreements with other Latin American nations rather than negotiate directly with the United States. Officials said Mr. Motley did not want to supplant that process and would not engage in substantive negotiations. **********Washington is concerned about the risks of a border conflict between Nicaragua and either Honduras or Costa Rica, as anti-Sandinista rebels operating from bases in both these neighboring countries have stepped up activities this fall against the Nicaraguan Government.  The Nicaraguan Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, told a news conference on Oct. 1 that Nicaraguan troops would cross into border areas of its two neighbors in pursuit of ''counterrevolutionary'' guerrillas. He said Nicaraguan forces would not fire first but would respond to attacks. **********''Our soldiers are going to counter attacks at the points where they come from, with our artillery and our forces,'' he declared. ''We are not going to stand with our arms crossed.'' **********The Nicaraguan Defense Minister said Costa Rica and Honduras, by allowing Nicaraguan rebels to use their territories, had created a ''no man's land'' where international borders had little meaning. His statements caused some alarm in Costa Rica, which has very modest defense forces and no organized army. United States troops are on maneuvers in Honduras.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/busin.main_headline: FED WAS SPLIT BY 8 TO 4 ON ANNUAL POLICY GOALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/busin.print_headline: FED WAS SPLIT BY 8 TO 4 ON ANNUAL POLICY GOALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board, in an unusually sharp split, voted, 8 to 4, in setting its annual monetary policy targets for this year, according to the minutes of the annual policy meeting released this afternoon. **********The four members of the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee who dissented when the committee voted in February believed the Fed was not putting enough emphasis on the closely watched M-1 money supply figure or was not moving to slow the growth of this aggregate quickly enough. **********Three of the four who dissented in February also opposed the policy change last October when the Fed originally moved to put less emphasis on M-1 because of the distortions being caused by the end of the ''All Savers'' certificates. M-1 includes currency in circulation and checking accounts. **********The four dissenters were Karen N. Horn, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland; Robert P. Black, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond; William F. Ford, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, and Henry C. Wallich, a member of the board of governors of the Fed. Mr. Ford, Mr. Black and Mrs. Horn dissented from the October policy change. Growth Targets Set **********At the February meeting, the Fed set a growth range for this year of 7 to 10 percent for M-2, which includes M-1, the new money market deposit accounts and savings. The target range for M-3, which includes M-2 and large certificates of deposit, was set at 6.5 to 9.5 percent. The range for M-1 was set at 4 to 8 percent. **********As of this week's meeting, Mr. Black, Mr. Ford and Mrs. Horn were replaced on the committee as voting members by three other reserve bank presidents who are considered more pragmatic and unlikely to dissent if the Fed continues to encourage the recovery and does not move to rein in the money supply growth quickly. **********According to the minutes, Mrs. Horn and Mr. Black dissented because they wanted to put more emphais on M-1. Mr. Ford wanted to begin to reduce the growth rate of M-1 gradually. He also opposed the Fed's decision to use several money supply figures in guiding policy. Mr. Wallich wanted lower overall target ranges for 1983 than the majority of the committee approved. 4 Dissenting Votes Rare **********There are often dissenting votes on the committee, although the Fed likes to have unanimity. But four dissenting votes is rare, officials said today, although there was an 8-to-4 split on the Fed's short-term policy set last July, a course that aided the sharp drop in interest rates late last summer and fall. Mr. Black, Mr. Ford and Mr. Wallich also dissented on this vote. **********The 8-to-4 split reflects the debate that is going on over current monetary policy. On one side - which includes monetarists - many economists and market analysts are arguing that the Fed has to concentrate on M-1 again and move soon to slow the very rapid growth of this money supply figure to be sure that inflation is not reignited sometime next year. They are advocating this policy even if it means a rise in short-term interest rates. **********On the other side are other economists and market analysts who argue that the Fed cannot tighten now because a rise in short-term interest rates would threaten the recovery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/05/busin.body_text: **********When the McDonald's hamburger chain arrived in Japan in 1971, one of the last things company executives expected was trouble with its famous trademarks. **********The McDonald's Corporation had operated in the United States and other countries for years, and the company's golden arches had become an internationally known symbol of Americana. The company's lawyers had protected that hard-won name and symbol with a wall of trademarks, and as the company opened in Japan it anticipated little trouble in adding a few more. **********But when McDonald's lawyers walked into the national patent office here to apply for trademarks, they discovered to their dismay that, just the day before, a Japanese food distributor had registered as its own trademark the very same golden arches. Under Japanese trademark law, the food distributor, Marushin Foods Company, could become its owner. **********Little Progress Made **********After more than 10 years of negotiation and litigation, including a case that ended last year in Japan's supreme court, McDonald's has made little progress. Japanese trademark examiners have not yet approved the Japanese company's applications, and so McDonald's can still use its symbol. **********Legally, though, the Japanese company may still one day own the Mc-Donald symbol, although McDonald's lawyer, Mikako Fujiki, believes this will never happen, ''It would create quite a political problem,'' he said. **********Marushin wants the McDonald trademark to enhance its fast-food sales from vending machines.  As McDonald's and other American companies are discovering as they chase after a slice of Japan's huge consumer spending, the critical area of trademark rights is radically different from procedure in the United States, and for the unprepared, Japan can be a business nightmare. Difference in Laws **********In Japan, the first party to apply for a trademark usually ends up owning it, and that constitutes a major difference with American law. In the United States, a company or individual can apply for the Federal trademark protection of its words and symbols only after actually using them in interstate commerce. Once the Government grants a trademark registration, its owners gain strong protections against its use by others on a broad series of similar or related goods. **********But ''America is in a real minority here in its view of what a trademark should be,'' according to David S. Guttman, an American patent and trademark attorney in Tokyo and the former chairman of the licenses, patents and trademarks committee of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan. **********Japanese law does not require prior use for the application or registration of a trademark, and the law permits the use of the same trademark, registered to different owners, in 34 different classes of goods for which trademarks can be registered in Japan. **********Rather than group goods according to the standard international system, Japan groups them according to the kind of shop they would be sold in. Knives, for example, rather than falling in the class with forks and spoons, are in the same class as swords. If a company applies for a trademark in one class and not another, then anyone is free under the law to apply for the same trademark in another class of goods and to use it. Numerous Filings **********Domestic and foreign companies knowledgeable in the ways of Japan regularly file identical or similar trademarks in classes of goods even marginally related to their business, both as a defense against infringement and in anticipation of possible future use. Katsuyoshi Koyama, in-house counsel for Max Factor & Company, the cosmetics company that is a unit of Norton Simon Inc., said his operation has its major names and symbols registered in 10 classes, including medical products. **********Foreign - and especially American - trademarks are prizes in this competition, Mr. Guttman says, because so many Japanese travel abroad, particularly to the United States, and learn to respond to well-known foreign brand names and trademarks. **********American lawyers stationed here report that United States companies preparing to enter the Japanese market sometimes discover that a Japanese company already owns one or more of their trademarks. The areas of food and drink, clothing, sports equipment, toys, drugs, and highly specialized industrial and scientific equipment seem particularly vulnerable, according to Mr. Guttman. **********''I've heard of cases where some Japanese companies were accused of buying foreign marks for later profits,'' says George O'Haver, inhouse counsel for the Coca-Cola Company in Japan. ''But this isn't as much of a problem as 20 years ago.'' **********When it decided to sell its soaps in Japan, the Neutrogen Corporation, a soap-maker headquartered in Los Angeles, found its trademark Neutrogena already registered in Japan by an individual.  The American company was forced to acquire the name from the individual, even though he had not used it to market a soap. **********Hunter Hale, an American lawyer who has prepared trademark advisories for the United States Embassy, says the Japanese law firm that he works for, Ishii Law Office, takes on a new case almost every month to retrieve a trademark. Kent Gilbert, an associate with the law firm in Japan that handles McDonald's, says it is ''common'' for Japanese companies to own foreign trademarks without authorization from the overseas company. Mr. Guttman concurs. Coca-Cola Negotiating **********Mr. O'Haver says Coca-Cola here is negotiating to buy back one of its trademarks from a Japanese owner. But he would not identify either the trademark or the Japanese owner. He added that Coca-Cola faces ''a continuing problem'' with the unauthorized use of its trademarks to decorate T-shirts, ashtrays and other items. **********''If you have a mark like our mark that is commonly identified as a part of Western culture,'' he notes, ''they think they can use it to decorate anything. The Japanese people have not really been tuned into the concept of industrial trademark property.'' **********General Electric has run into a problem with Japanese companies that use trademarks that include the letters GE. In recent years, it says that it has sometimes purchased these trademarks from the companies, or has contested their registration as too similar to its own famous GE trademark, which is registered in Japan by General Electric. **********Some foreign companies can afford to take the trademark issue to court, but the chances of victory are slim if the unauthorized owner was clearly the first to apply for the trademark. **********Mr. Guttman says: ''Trademark law here is unforgiving.'' Japan's unfair competition prevention law allows the foreign owner of a trademark to stop its unauthorized registration if the trademark is well known in Japan and if its use would create confusion among consumers. But these are often difficult standards to meet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.body_text: **********A Federal court has overturned a $170 million award to three men who charged that Johnson & Johnson Inc. had suppressed a pain control device. **********A three-judge panel of the Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 2-to-1 Wednesday that the men failed to show that they were hurt financially as a result of Johnson & Johnson's purported violation of antitrust laws. **********The case centers on an electronic device invented by Norman Hagfors in the late 1960's. The pocket-sized Transcutaneous Electronic Nerve Stimulator uses electric current to relieve pain. **********But the judges ruled that the three men - Mr. Hagfors, Stanley McDonald and Clayton Jensen - were entitled to $6.2 million in damages from Johnson & Johnson, the nation's largest manufacturer of health care products, because of fraud and breach of contract. **********The panel also ordered a new trial to decide whether the men should receive up to $25 million in punitive damages from the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/02/busin.main_headline: DOLE SEEKS TO BAR BIG TAX RISES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/02/busin.print_headline: DOLE SEEKS TO BAR BIG TAX RISES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and chairman of the Finance Committee, threatened today to bottle up revenue legislation this year if the House-Senate conferees on the Congressional budget resolution called for ''huge tax increases'' and ''little or no spending reduction.'' **********The conferees will hold an initial meeting next week to try to resolve wide differences on spending and revenue-raising in the budget resolutions passed by a Democratic majority in the House and by a bipartisan, predominantly Democratic majority in the Senate. **********Senator Dole's threat was a further indication that he would work hard, publicly and behind the scenes, to encourage the Senate conferees to resist a resolution that requires more added revenues for 1984-85 than the Senate approved. Small Increases Urged **********In fact, both resolutions call for far more revenue than Senator Dole wants to legislate this year, aides have said. The Senator said again today that increases for the fiscal years 1984 and 1985 should be small, coming from measures to strengthen taxpayer compliance and to broaden the revenue base by shrinking deductions. **********Senator Dole, who will not be a conferee because he does not sit on the Budget Committee, made his threat in a press release issued by his office here in advance of remarks he made in Portland, Ore. **********The Senator and his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, were campaigning for the re-election in 1984 of Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, and will go on to Alaska tonight to urge re-election of Senator Ted Stevens, the Senate majority whip. **********On the other side of Capitol Hill, the House majority leader, Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, signaling a new Democratic battle cry, insisted to reporters, ''It's Ronald Reagan's deficit.'' The slogan apparently portended an unwillingness by some House Democrats to accede to nonmilitary spending reductions sought by Republican Senators and the Administration. **********Mr. Wright also threw his weight behind an emerging Senate-House Democratic effort to send to President Reagan a separate bill that put a limit, possibly $700, on the 10 percent tax cut that goes into effect July 1. If, as expected, Mr. Reagan vetoes it, Mr. Wright said, ''It's just going to highlight his intransigence about tax cuts for the wealthy.'' **********Senator Dole expressed opposition to limiting the July tax cut, the third of the three-stage tax cut sponsored by President Reagan in 1981 as a major element of his economic policy. ''Low-and moderateincome taxpayers get 72 percent of the benefit of the third-year tax cut,'' Senator Dole said. **********An aide said that a $700 cap would deny tax relief to a single person who did not itemize deductions on income above $31,000. For a family of four without itemized deductions, the ceiling would be $39,250, he said. Senator Dole's position is that such taxpayers are not genuinely rich, the aide said. **********Congressional aides said the House-Senate conference would start no earlier than June 8 and the prognosis was murky. ''The differences are clear - on spending and taxes - and they're large,'' a Senate aide said. ''We haven't really made any progress.'' Talks with the House staff have resolved some technical matters, he said, but with the Senate in recess and with some House members away this week there have been no talks between committee members on big issues. **********''It's hard to find Senators or Senate staff,'' a House aide said.  ''There's no real activity this week.'' Senator Dole's statement said: ''A budget conference that calls for huge tax increases will give the tax-writing committees an impossible job. If the conferees press for unrealistically high taxes, the result may be no revenue increase at all.'' **********Senator Dole regards as beyond consideration the Senate's target of $51 billion of additional revenues for the fiscal year 1986, which starts Oct. 1, 1985. He was said to regard as somewhat high the Senate targets of $9 billion for the fiscal year 1984, which starts Oct. 1, and $13 billion for the fiscal year 1985, although on the floor he said they were ''not unrealistic.'' The House-passed budget calls for increases of $30 billion, $40 billion and $50 billion, respectively. **********Senator Dole, looking ahead to Finance Committee legislation, said that the panel would hold hearings on spending reductions June 15-16. He announced tax hearings for June 22 on fringe benefits and employer-paid health insurance, June 23 on possible compliance actions and June 28-29 on ''assorted tax expenditures.'' **********As for broadening the taxable income base, Senator Dole and his staff have talked about disallowing sales tax deductions and some deductions for consumer interest payments. **********Other changes being considered at the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee include either lengthening the depreciation period for buildings that change hands or curtailing ''churning,'' the frequency with which they can be sold with full depreciation for the new owner. **********Senator Dole has said repeatedly that significant revenue can be raised from compliance actions. Ways and Means Committee aides are skeptical. A Dole aide said the revenue might be $1 billion to $2 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.main_headline: A BAILOUT PLAN FOR THE BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.print_headline: FORUM; A BAILOUT PLAN FOR THE BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.body_text: **********TELEGRAMS go out to banks around the world. Another country cannot pay its debts. What is to be done? The banks and the country's government start out on a well-worn path. The bankers get together to add up the country's debts. The government seeks help from the International Monetary Fund. The I.M.F. sends out a mission. **********After long discussions, the mission and government agree on a set of austere monetary and fiscal policies. The I.M.F. then approves a credit line on which the government can draw until its policy package has taken effect. **********Once that is done, the banks agree to reschedule some of the country's debt. Debts coming due during the next year are stretched out for an additional seven years or so, including a two-year grace period in which the country will pay interest but will not repay principal. The banks also agree to lend more money. Everyone sighs with relief. The crisis appears to be over. But no one should be happy yet. **********The banks have lent the country money so that it can pay the interest that it owed them anyway. To put it bluntly, they have added doubtful assets to their balance sheets in order to protect their income statements. They have done so, moreover, with the tacit approval of bank supervisors who are paid to keep this sort of thing from happening. **********The government has promised policy changes that are bound to create opposition at home. It has also given hostages to fortune.  Governments can promise to cut spending and raise tax rates and some can keep their promises. No government can promise firmly to reduce its deficit, because it does not control all of the events that influence its deficit. **********The I.M.F. has worrisome problems, too. It has put its famous ''seal of approval'' on the government's policy package and it faces a hard question if that package falls apart. Should it suspend the country's right to draw on its credit line or renegotiate the policy package? If it blocks the credit line, it may spark a new crisis. If it renegotiates the package, it tarnishes its seal of approval. **********No one talks about these problems and many bankers say that they should not worry us. Countries like Mexico and Brazil are good credit risks. They have liquidity problems but do not have solvency problems. When the world economy starts to recover, the debtors' export earnings will begin to grow again and they will be able to service their debts. **********Everyone agrees that recovery will help. It is indeed essential for solving the debt problem. But no one is forecasting the vigorous recovery that is needed to get the debtors out of trouble. Six months from now, Mexico may find that it has drawn all it can from the I.M.F. and used up its bank credits, too. Its budget deficit has fallen, but not by much. Its balance of payments has improved, but it has to borrow more to pay for its imports. Many questions come to mind. **********Will banks be willing to lend what Mexico needs to get through the year? Will they be willing to stretch out more debt at the end of 1983 and what new policies will Mexico have to provide in return?  When will some small bank declare that Mexico has defaulted, blowing down the house of cards? What will happen in three years, when banks are asked to stretch out debts that were stretched out once before? **********What will happen when a government decides it would be less costly to walk away from its debts? It would, of course, be cut off from all credit and punished in other ways, too. But it would save billions of dollars. Even more important, it would spare its citizens the social costs of prolonged economic austerity and spare itself the political costs. **********If we cannot shrug off these questions, we cannot dismiss the possibility of damaging debt crises in the next few years. We should therefore examine alternatives to the current case-by-case, year-byyear approach. **********ANY new approach must protect the banks' depositors, but it must do more. It must reduce the developing countries' debt burdens so that they do not have to pursue domestic policies that jeopardize internal stability and interfere with worldwide recovery. It must permit the banks to go on lending because developing countries must go on borrowing. **********My own approach is based on my belief that banks, debtors and the governments of the developed countries all share blame for the debt problem, and all must join in solving it. **********The governments of the United States and other developed countries should establish a new international institution - call it the International Debt Discount Corporation. They would subscribe to the capital of the debt corporation but would not have to put up cash if the I.D.D.C. did its job properly. The corporation would issue longterm bonds to banks in exchange for the debts of developing countries. It would do so at a discount, however, say 90 cents on the dollar. Finally, the corporation would reschedule the debts of developing countries on a one-time, long-term basis, using 5 cents of the 10 cents extracted from the banks for modest debt relief, charging lower interest rates or granting grace periods. **********The corporation should not buy up the debts of all developing countries. It should deal only with those countries that recognize it as successor claimant to the banks. It should probably limit its attention to those that have an I.M.F. ''seal of approval.'' The corporation should deal only in the debts of governments and debts guaranteed by governments. It should not take up debts that are already backed unilaterally by developed countries. **********Banks should not be allowed to choose the debts they discount with the corporation. A bank wanting to discount 60 percent of its claims on developing countries should be obliged to present 60 percent of its claims on all of the countries doing business with the I.D.D.C.  Otherwise, the corporation will inherit the claims that are least likely to be paid. **********Banks should not be allowed to decide when they will turn to the I.D.D.C. Otherwise, banks might be tempted to hold claims until they were worth less than 90 cents on the dollar. They would use the I.D.D.C. to minimize risks, not to resolve the debt problem. **********Should the I.D.D.C. attempt to treat countries differently according to their circumstances? In principle, yes. In practice, probably not. In fact, it might do best to publish standard terms on which it is willing to do business - to make an all-or-nothing offer to the developing countries. **********Should banks be permitted to lend again to developing countries?  Definitely. Developing countries have to go on borrowing. That is why it is important to prevent debt crises that can halt lending completely. But the I.D.D.C. must not be permitted to discount new debts acquired by the banks, and banks must be supervised more strictly than heretofore. **********Many other questions remain. Should I.D.D.C. bonds bear fixed or floating interest rates? What should be the share of each developed country in the capital of the new institution? But these questions are subordinate to another. Is there any other way out of the debt problem? I do not think so.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.body_text: **********''Your gesture will remain in my heart forever,'' said Gen. Paul X. Kelley as he awarded a plaque with his stars to Lance Cpl. Jeffrey Nashton of Rome, N.Y. The plaque, too, read ''Semper Fi,'' - short for Semper Fidelis, the Marine motto, meaning always faithful. **********Last month, as General Kelley was visiting marines wounded in the Oct. 23 bombing, he stopped at Corporal Nashton's bed at a United States Air Force hospital in Frankfurt, West Germany, to present him with a medal. **********The corporal, who suffered a broken leg, collapsed lungs, a crushed arm and a fractured skull, couldn't see because his eyes were full of concrete dust. **********''I told him I was the Marine Commandant,'' said General Kelley, ''and before he believed me, he reached up and touched my four stars to make sure it was me.'' **********Then, the General related, Corporal Nashton asked for a piece of paper and a pencil and wrote ''Semper Fi.'' **********''When I left that hospital, I realized I had met a great human being,'' General Kelley told a news conference at Bethesda Naval Hospital. ''I took off those stars because I realized they belonged more to him than me.'' **********''Why I wrote it is hard to say,'' Corporal Nashton said. ''It's hard to express a feeling. I just wanted the general to know not to give up the faith.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/world.body_text: **********NORTH KOREA LEAFLET PAINTS U.S. DEFECTOR IN 'A CONTENTED LIFE' **********SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 16 (UPI) - North Korea has been scattering leaflets over the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas that say an American soldier who apparently defected last year is leading ''a contented life'' and is ''full of happiness and hope.'' **********Military officials said the leaflets, which include a message in English purportedly written by the soldier, Pfc. **********Joseph T. White of the Army, were picked up by patrolling G.I.'s in January. **********Personnel at the frontline United States base Liberty Bell recently permitted United Press International to examine and photograph the leaflets, which were posted on a bulletin board. The United States military has not commented on the material. Accompanied by Women **********Some of the pamphlets showed pictures of Private White accompanied by North Korean women on a tour of Pyongyang, the capital, where he reportedly lives. Others showed him reading a book with Korean women at either elbow. **********The leaflets say the 21-year-old native of St. Louis wrote a letter reproduced on other leaflets describing his life to his former comrades, who help patrol the demilitarized zone. **********''Dear old fellow friends,'' the text begins, ''I have been leading a contented life under the warm care of the DPRK.  I have become fond of life in the capital, seeing the sights and visiting the institutions of culture. My seeking asylum is a very right conduct.'' **********Private White, on guard duty in the zone last year, shot off a lock on a gate on the South Korean side and crossed over to the North. He was the fifth American soldier to defect in Korea since the signing of the 1953 armistice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/busin.print_headline: TIGER SETS SALE OF ITS RAIL CAR UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/busin.body_text: **********Tiger International Inc., which has reported a string of large losses in recent months, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell a large portion of the assets of its only profitable operating unit to a subsidiary of the General Electric Company for about $140 million. **********Tiger said the sale, which had been rumored for some time, would be the first step of a liquidation of the subsidiary, the North American Car Company, which leases rail cars. **********Although North American was Tiger's only profitable operating unit in 1982, earning $7.5 million before taxes on sales of $254.5 million, a spokesman for Tiger said the unit's operations were too capital intensive for the debt-plagued company to maintain. **********About $900 million of Tiger's $1.8 billion in debt - including an estimated $750 million to $800 million owed by North American - is being restructured, the company said. Tiger, based in Los Angeles, also operates a trucking unit and an air cargo carrier, The Flying Tiger Line. **********Efforts to Halt Losses **********In efforts to halt the losses and ease the debt problem, the company has sold other units and last month announced an exchange of $112.5 million in outstanding debt for a combination of debentures, common stock and common stock warrants. **********Analysts said the sale of the North American assets, which needs the approval of the boards of both companies, as well as the approval of North American's lenders will effectively terminate Tiger's plans to develop a diversified transportation network with integrated air, truck and railroad units. **********''Given some of their grandiose plans, this is clearly not something they want to do,'' said John V. Pincavage, an analyst at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. ''Had the economy been in better shape, and the company's losses not been as great, we never would have seen this.'' **********Tiger lost $50.8 million in the first quarter of 1983, and $136.2 million in all of 1982, more than half of it the final quarter. It has not yet reported its second-quarter 1983 earnings. **********''We built this company up, and now, in effect, we're cashing it in,'' said Wayne M. Hoffman, Tiger's chairman and chief executive officer in a telephone interview. ''We reached a point where that particular level of capital intensity didn't make sense for us.'' Tiger acquired North American in 1970, when it had assets of about $330 million. On June 30, the unit had total assets of $1.3 billion. **********Tiger said the sale to G.E.'s General Electric Credit Corporation subsidiary includes 4,175 rail cars, for $100 million in cash, and the assets of 16 of North American's 18 rail car servicing and repair centers in various cities in the United States, for another $40 million in notes. **********G.E. to Assume Debt **********The G.E. unit also agreed to assume certain debt obligations owed by North American in connection with its rail car repair operations, but the amount of that debt was not disclosed. **********Under the agreement, G.E. will take over management of most of North American's operations, which employ about 1,000 workers, and will in addition obtain an option to purchase all of North American's remaining assets - consisting primarily of another 38,825 rail cars - in 1988. North American currently manages some 63,000 rail cars, of which about 7,000 are leased, and 10,000 are owned by other companies. **********Tiger said it would retain North American's Bimodal Corpotation unit, which produces the Road Railer, a freight car which is usable on railroad beds as well as highways, and its Tiger Financial Services subsidiary. In addition, the company will keep two of North American's rail car repair facilities, one in Chicago, the other in Wyoming, for investment purposes. **********James D. Parker, a transportation analyst with Robinson Humphrey/ American Express Inc. in Atlanta, said that while Tiger's rail car leasing operations are in ''better shape'' than some of its other units, ''that means they have more market value, and Tiger needs cash.''
