https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/25/world.main_headline: PANEL ASKS SENATE TO BACK ADELMAN FOR TOP ARMS POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/25/world.print_headline: PANEL ASKS SENATE TO BACK ADELMAN FOR TOP ARMS POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/25/world.body_text: **********The Senate Foreign Relations Committee refused today to endorse President Reagan's nomination of Kenneth L.  Adelman as the chief arms control official. **********But the committee did not block the nomination entirely. It sent Mr. Adelman's name to the Senate floor with a recommendation that he be rejected, setting the stage for a filibuster by opponents to the nomination and for a debate over the wider issue of arms control. **********President Reagan said in a statement that he was pleased the committee had sent the issue to the floor. He said he remained fully committed to the nomination and was confident Mr. Adelman would be confirmed. **********Tsongas Pledges Filibuster **********Meanwhile, Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, pledged to filibuster the nomination of Mr. Adelman, who is now the deputy delegate to the United Nations. **********The committee first voted, 9 to 8, against the nomination and then decided, with three objections, to send it to the floor.  Two Republicans, Senator Charles McC. Mathias of Maryland and Senator Larry Pressler of South Dakota, joined seven Democrats in voting against the nomination. Mr. Pressler also voted not to send it to the Senate floor. **********Mr. Adelman has appeared before the committee on three occasions and each time has emphasized his support of arms control. However, his selection has taken on symbolic importance, with many senators viewing it as an indication that the Administration is not fully committed to arms talks. Effort to Muster Support **********The issue is likely to go to the Senate floor the middle of next month, after Republicans have time to muster support for Mr. Adelman, according to an aide to Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the majority leader. The aide said Mr. Baker expected that the filibuster would be defeated and that Mr. Adelman would be confirmed. **********The scheduling of action in mid-March would also have the effect of postponing the arms control debate until after the West German elections March 6. **********Senator Tsongas said he expected opposition to Mr. Adelman to grow.  ''This thing has a certain momentum, and there is a certain dynamic to it,'' he said. ''We want to make people vote on whether they really are for arms control or not.'' Mr. Adelman, who was called back before the committee today, said that he would be a strong advocate for arms control within the Administration and that he believed ''deep reductions'' in arms could be negotiated with the Soviet Union this year. **********He appeared after Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, raised questions last week about remarks attributed to the nominee in a May 1981 article in a New York newspaper.  Mr. Adelman said under oath that he did not recall a telephone interview in which he was quoted as having called arms control negotiations a ''sham.'' **********''I do not recall making any such statement at any time in my life,'' he said. Adelman Refers to Writings **********Mr. Adelman said the remarks attributed to him ''do not reflect my views then or now.'' ''There is nothing in my writings, which have appeared in the most respected journals, to substantiate the remarks attributed to me,'' he added. **********His comments came after Ken Auletta, a columnist for The Daily News, in testimony before the committee, displayed copies of his notes, distributed telephone records and said Mr. Adelman had made the statement, which appeared in his column on May 24, 1981. **********''I believe he is not telling the truth on remembering speaking to me,'' Mr. Auletta said.  Mr. Adelman was quoted in the column as having said that the Administration favored arms talks for their public opinion value.  ''My policy would be to do it for political reasons,'' Mr. Adelman was quoted as having said. The quotation continued, ''I think it's a sham.'' Records Show 25-Minute Call **********Mr. Auletta's telephone records showed a 25-minute telephone call to SRI International, a policy study center in Arlington, Va., where Mr. Adelman worked on strategic issues. Copies of Mr. Auletta's notebook showed notes of the comments Mr. Auletta said Mr. Adelman had made, including the word ''sham.'' The notes indicate, and Mr.  Auletta confirmed, that he originally wrote the word ''shame'' and later changed it to ''sham.'' **********''This is a common practice among journalists when you make rapid notes,'' he said. ''I distinctly remember hearing Mr. Adelman use the word 'sham.' '' **********It is rare for Congressional panels to summon journalists to testify on their articles and unusual for journalists to accept such invitations. **********Mr. Adelman, confronted with Mr. Auletta's notes and telephone records, said his views on arms issues had been consistent. He said he had written 116 articles in 52 journals that presented ''my views on foreign policy very, very clearly.'' Lugar Discounts Importance **********Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who has supported Mr. Adelman, discounted the importance of the Auletta article.  ''The idea that all Mr. Adelman has written is somehow overtaken by a remark he may or may not have made is extraordinary,'' he said.  The committee put off a vote on the nomination earlier this month when it became clear that it would not endorse him for confirmation.  Since then, the Administration has accelerated its activity in the arms control area, with the President seeking to indicate flexibility on the issue of limiting medium-range missiles in Europe. **********However, neither that activity nor Administration lobbying on Capitol Hill won further support for Mr. Adelman in the committee.  Besides Senators Pressler, Mathias, Tsongas and Cranston, Mr.  Adelman's nomination was opposed by Senators Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, John H. Glenn of Ohio, Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, all Democrats. **********Senator Edward Zorinsky of Nebraska was the only Democrat to support the nomination.  Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who heads the committee, said the nomination should be regarded as an important trump for the cause of arms control. **********''If he is confirmed, this puts the Administration in a position to move really forward,'' he said. ''It puts the ball in their court.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge has turned down a request from the Paradyne Corporation that a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit against it be dismissed. He said that a possible violation of securities laws was indeed at issue in the agency's complaint. **********United States District Judge William Terrell Hodges ruled on the matter Wednesday. Afterward, Paradyne officials downplayed the importance of the decision. **********''It's obvious that the ruling is procedural and is not a ruling on the merits of the S.E.C. complaint,'' said George Pressly, senior vice president of Paradyne. **********The commission has accused the company of using fraud to win a contract to supply computers to the Social Security Administration. **********Judge Hodges ruled that the commission's complaint was ''founded upon Federal security laws and seeks relief not for fraudulent acts in the procurement of a government contract but for violations of those Federal security laws.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.body_text: **********Syria said its forces opened fire today on an Israeli bulldozer and an armored personnel carrier that had advanced on a Syrian position in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern Valley. **********The Syrian announcement, the first military communique by Damascus since August, when the war in Lebanon ended, was the first item on the Damascus radio's newscast, ahead even of news about President Hafez al-Assad. The Syrian intention appeared to be to draw the attention of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and underscore the importance of Syria in American efforts get foreign troops out of Lebanon. **********For the last month there have been almost daily small-arms clashes between Syrian and Israeli troops in the Bekaa. But only today did the Syrians suddenly decide to issue a formal military communique about an event an Israeli Army spokesman in Lebanon dismissed as a nonincident. **********The communique said that at 11:30 A.M. an Israeli bulldozer and an armored personnel carrier advanced 500 yards toward the Syrian position at Al Saaluk, about 18 miles southeast of Beirut, entering a no man's land between the two armies. It said the Israelis began to build a fortification. **********''Our forces opened fire against the enemy vehicles, forcing them to retreat,'' the statement said.  The Israeli version of the incident was that an Israeli military tractor was reinforcing a position near Aammiq just south of Al Saaluk when it took small-arms fire and an unidentified shell from a Syrian area. The Israeli spokesman said no Israelis were hurt, no equipment was damaged and the Israelis did not return the fire. **********For the last month, Syria's state-controlled news organizations have been highlighting what they call an Israeli military buildup in the Bekaa. **********According to Western military sources in Beirut, Israelis have been flying over Syrian positions in the Bekaa frequently to try to induce the Syrians to turn on the radar for their SAM-6 antiaircraft missiles. Israel used the same tactic a year ago to learn the frequencies of Syrian radar and antiaircraft equipment before knocking them out with sophisticated jamming devices and missiles. **********Secretary of State Shultz, who was in Cairo, was reportedly considering including Damascus on his itinerary, which so far includes Egypt, Lebanon, Israel, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria visited Saudi Arabia on Monday. His trip was believed to be related to a visit by Mr. Shultz to Damascus. **********With the possibility that the Lebanese-Israeli talks on withdrawal may bear fruit soon, the Syrians have had daily declarations in their news reports on their conditions for pulling out of Lebanon. They have made it clear they will not withdraw if Lebanon permits Israel to keep a residual military force in southern Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/world.body_text: **********Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq fought off a large-scale assault on their base area at Shene on Friday, killing 70 Iraqi soldiers and shooting down a helicopter gunship, a spokesman for the rebels said in London tonight. **********A statement issued by the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan said the Kurds had wiped out an Iraqi commando unit that landed by helicopter on the summit of Manende Mountain, which overlooks the Qala Diza area. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/busin.print_headline: STEEL MOOD: HOPEFUL BUT WARY; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Steelmakers may be emerging from one of their darkest periods since the Depression, but they are having trouble believing that the trials of their battered industry are at an end. **********The elements of a recovery are beginning to fall into place. Orders for flat-rolled steel have rebounded sharply, discounting is moderating and a recent price increase seems to be sticking. In addition, imports have dropped significantly - down 44 percent in January from the level of a year before. And European steelmakers have agreed to cut their shipments to this country. **********In the latest good news, local leaders of the United Steelworkers of America have overwhelmingly approved these major concessions: a cut in wages of $1.25 an hour and a freeze on cost-of-living payments until July 1984 as well as reduced vacation time. **********The contract, which will run from next Aug. 1 until July 31, 1986, is likely to increase the cost of employment by only 11 percent, far less than the 41 percent increase over the course of the last contract. Those Idle Blast Furnaces **********But the steel industry is still running scared.  Pete Love, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, said in an interview yesterday that his company would soon restart one of its five banked blast furnaces because of the pickup in orders. But he added, '''We're being very cautious about it.'' **********Mr. Love said, ''Geez, you light one of these up and begin to call people back - it's important that we fully realize that we are in a sustained type of recovery.'' **********One reason for all the caution is the sharp and unexpected drop in steel shipments last year. After both analysts and industry executives had predicted 80 million to 90 million tons, the steel mills wound up shipping only 60 million tons. **********''The poor results of '82 tend to make you overly cautious,'' said Peter Anker, steel analyst for the First Boston Corporation.  Indeed, some steel companies are continuing to operate their plants at only 50 percent of capacity while orders pour in at a rate that would justify using 90 percent of capacity. **********''The order entry rate in the past month has been at a 90-millionton annual shipment rate,'' said Peter Marcus, steel analyst at Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins. ''Yet the industry is still producing at a 57-million-ton shipment rate.'' Demand From Basic Sectors **********The surge in ordering has come from basic industries such as autos and appliances as they benefit from the beginning of a general economic recovery. But Mr. Marcus said the steelmakers ''all fear it's temporary.'' **********If the recovery continues, however, analysts and some steel executives agree that the steel companies, whose losses from steelmaking operations totaled $3.3 billion last year, could benefit greatly from the new labor agreement and the cost-cutting and phasing out of old plants accomplished during the downturn. **********Mr. Love said the new labor contract represented ''a milestone type of settlement'' that could allow his company to show a profit by the second quarter if the recovery runs strong. National Steel had an operating loss of $53 million from steel operations in the fourth quarter, and he said it would have a loss in the first quarter as well. **********He also said that, if the orders warrant, National and other steelmakers would be able to increase output with fewer workers than would have been required in the past because of productivity achievements. Personnel Patterns Noted **********''We've got the plants leaned out so they will support more volume without incurring more fixed costs,'' he said. **********Mr. Anker of First Boston said that in 1981 the steel industry had 361,000 workers - 258,000 steelworkers and 103,000 salaried employees. By the end of 1982, layoffs and permanent cuts had reduced the total to 235,000, of which 156,000 were steelworkers and 79,000 were salaried employees. **********''The companies will not put as many people back to work,'' he said, even if shipments go back to the levels of 1981. The industry shipped 87 million tons of steel that year. **********Joseph Wyman, steel analyst for Shearson/American Express, said in an interview that the contract concessions might enable many steel companies to return to profitability by this year's second quarter rather than the third quarter, as he had projected earlier. He estimated that the labor concessions could bring a 3 percent reduction in production costs. **********Analysts and steel executives remain conservative in their estimates of shipments for 1983, with most predicting a range of 71 million tons to 75 million tons. A Projection of Shipments **********Mr. Marcus of Paine, Webber, for example, predicts that the industry will ship 71 million tons and that imports will amount to about 14.5 million tons. This would compare with the 60 million tons shipped last year, when imports totaled 16.6 million tons. **********He predicted that the demand for flat roll would fall off later this year, since the underlying demand was not as high as current rates indicate. **********Meanwhile, the demand for steel products from the capital goods sector remains sluggish. At large integrated producers, such as the United States Steel Corporation, the capital goods sector accounts for three of every four tons of steel shipped. **********But Mr. Marcus projected that, even with only a modest recovery, operating losses for the steel industry would be cut significantly this year, to about $900 million. **********Despite the industry's hesitance, there is general agreement that it could recover much faster than was expected a few months ago, when the threat of a steel strike stirred fears that major domestic customers might turn to foreign producers. ''I'm more optimistic about the opportunities now,'' Mr. Love said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/busin.body_text: **********Computer Associates International Inc., a Jericho, L.I., maker of software for large mainframe and minicomputers, said it had entered into an agreement to buy Information Unlimited Software Inc. of Sausalito, Calif. The company said it would acquire Information Unlimited, which markets several popular programs for the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer, for $5 million. The deal calls for an additional payment of up to $5 million, depending on Information Unlimited's performance in the next two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1983; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/04/busin.body_text: **********Major retailers reported strong sales gains in January, apparently because of good weather and heavy promotion. Sears's sales were up 5.5 percent, while K Mart's rose 2 percent and J.C. Penney's 9.2 percent. Analysts said the gains could be the consumer spending rise many see as the key to recovery. But they noted that January sales a year ago were especially weak. (Page D1.) **********President Reagan has ordered a study of whether the Government should speed its construction projects to make more jobs available.  (A1.) Mr. Reagan told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to oppose any more cuts in the arms budget. (B5.) An Air Force panel said that even if the funds are not cut, there won't be enough money for the new equipment sought by Mr. Reagan. (B5.) **********New car sales by the Big Three auto makers rose 10 percent in the Jan. 21-31 sales period, marking the 10th consecutive 10-day period of improved sales. G.M.'s sales were up 18.2 percent, while Ford's fell 7.9 percent and Chrysler's rose 12.4 percent. Analysts said the industry is making progress, but slowly. (D3.) **********The strike by independent truckers entered its fourth day with no major disruptions of commerce reported. (A10.) Companies **********Alonzo L. McDonald Jr. has been forced out of his job as president of Bendix, according to Wall Street sources. The abrupt departure of the 54-year-old Georgian, who had served in the Carter Administration, followed final approval of Allied's acquisition of Bendix. Mr. McDonald reportedly was told that William M. Agee, Bendix's chief, would run Bendix with no second-in-command. (D1.) **********Pan Am reported a $272.9 million loss in the fourth quarter. The deficit was far greater than the $82.8 million it lost in the 1981 period and somewhat worse than analysts had expected. The carrier said it will not extend the $99 one-way fares that it instituted in domestic markets early last month, setting off a fare war in the industry. (D1.) **********Grumman had a net loss of $5.6 million in the fourth quarter. (D3.) Dow Chemical's net fell 80.2 percent, while Greyhound's dropped 21.9 percent and General Dynamics' nearly doubled. McDermott International lost $239,000 in its third fiscal quarter. (D4.) **********MCI Communications bought 24 satellite channels for its telephone network in one of the largest satellite purchases ever. (D3.) The Justice Department withdrew a court appeal that had blocked introduction of cellular mobile telephone service. (D15.) International **********Thyssen is merging its specialized steel-making operations with Krupp's. It will vote soon on a plan to spin off its bulk operations into a separate unit, which might then merge with Krupp's. The move comes a week after a panel of independent experts urged that West Germany's steel industry be regrouped into two huge entities. (D1.) **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz told off some members of the American business community in Peking after hearing complaints that U.S. policy was blocking potential deals with the Chinese. Mr.  Shultz, reporting on his two days of talks with Chinese officials, expressed satisfaction with the outcome. (A9.) **********Gulf Oil has reduced purchases of North Sea oil in a move intended to put pressure on Britain to reduce oil prices, according to traders. In a seperate move, Egypt cut its oil prices. (D3.) Markets **********Stock prices rose moderately, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 2.02 points, to 1,064.66. (D8.) The Treasury sold $3.5 billion of 10 3/8 percent long-term bonds at an average yield of 11.01 percent. (D7.) Assets of money market funds fell $2 billion in the week ended Wednesday. (D8.) The market for securities backed by home mortgages is being expanded. (D7.) The dollar was mixed, while gold prices fell $10 an ounce, to $496, in New York. (D11.) Precious metals futures prices fell sharply. (D11.) Today's Columns **********President Reagan is staying with his economic program despite the disappointments of the past two years. In particular, he still believes that sooner or later his ''supply side'' tax cuts will start to spur investment and growth. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Debt-free companies tend to be relatively good performers in the stock market. They are especially attractive in a deflationary economy, analysts say, since they can usually generate cash flow and often show a high return on equity. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/world.main_headline: Quakes Shake Japanese Isle After the Volcanic Eruptions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/world.print_headline: Quakes Shake Japanese Isle After the Volcanic Eruptions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/world.body_text: **********Earthquakes rattled the small Pacific island of Miyakejima today as ships and helicopters brought emergency supplies for hundreds of residents whose homes were buried under molten lava by volcanic eruptions Monday. **********No one was hurt, but the eruption of Oyama, a 2,686-foot volcano on the island, forced about 1,000 people from their homes, cut off water supplies in 90 percent of the island and halted all normal air and road traffic. **********A vessel of Japan's Maritime Safety Agency was en route to the island with a load of water.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/23/world.main_headline: U.N CHIEF EXPRESSES ALARM OVER IMPASSE IN ARMS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/23/world.print_headline: U.N CHIEF EXPRESSES ALARM OVER IMPASSE IN ARMS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/23/world.body_text: **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that a failure by the United States and the Soviet Union to reduce their nuclear arsenals would inevitably produce ''a serious escalation in nuclear confrontation.'' **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar's unusually strong statement was seen here as part of an effort to put pressure on the two countries whose negotiations in Geneva on reducing nuclear weapons are reportedly at a standstill. **********In another unusual move, Mr. Perez de Cuellar called in the chief United Nations delegates of both the United States and the Soviet Union, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick and Oleg A. Troyanovsky, to deliver the statement to them. **********The statement, issued on behalf of Mr. Perez de Cuellar, said, ''Unless agreements are achieved in the current negotiations between the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A. which will bring about the limitation and reduction in intermediate range and strategic nuclear weapons there will almost inevitably be, in his view, a serious escalation in nuclear confrontation.'' **********The statement went on, ''The Secretary General is profoundly concerned that negotiations in Geneva on intermediate range nuclear weapons may be at the point of failure.''  A Change in Outlook **********The urgent and forceful tone of Mr. Perez de Cuellar's statement contrasted with the guarded optimism he expressed in earlier remarks on nuclear disarmament. At a news conference in January, Mr. Perez de Cuellar, welcoming the agreement of the United States and the Soviet Union to negotiate arms reductions, said there had been ''real progress'' in lessening tensions. **********In a telephone interview today, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said his statement was prompted by the general deterioration in East-West relations. **********''I have been monitoring the situation and reached the very unpleasant conclusion that the situation is getting worse,'' he said. **********He said it was ''coincidental'' that his statement came just after the West German Parliament voted to deploy new American Pershing 2 missiles. **********''As the Secretary General of a body where virtually all of the nations of the world are represented,'' Mr. Perez de Cuellar said, ''I felt it was my duty to express the concern of the international community.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/world.main_headline: WHITE HOUSE WARNS A WAR POWERS FIGHT HURTS U.S. INTERESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/world.print_headline: WHITE HOUSE WARNS A WAR POWERS FIGHT HURTS U.S. INTERESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/world.body_text: **********The White House warned today that attempts to require President Reagan to get Congressional approval for keeping United States marines in Lebanon would send an ''extremely dangerous'' signal to the Middle East and the Soviet Union. **********A senior White House official told reporters that the dangers would arise even though Congress appears disposed to authorize the presence of American troops in Lebanon. **********The official said ''any restrictions'' placed by Congress on the American commitment of troops to the multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon ''are certainly read and understood beyond the shadow of a doubt by the Syrians and by the Soviets.'' **********He said requiring Congressional approval for the troops' presence would ''enable the Syrians and the Soviets to sit back and simply wait'' for a time when Congress might be less willing to extend its approval. **********The official's comments, which came at a briefing today, were immediately rejected by Senator Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, as ''a false way for the Administration to attempt to avoid its responsibility of the law.'' **********Mr. Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat, is leading a largely Democratic effort to force Mr. Reagan to acknowledge that the Marines are in Lebanon subject to Congressional approval under the War Powers Resolution of 1973. **********At the center of the struggle between the White House and the Congress are interpretations of the war powers statute, which stipulates that the President must notify Congress when American troops face a combat situation, and must then withdraw the troops within 60 days unless Congress authorizes them to remain. The 60-day period can be extended by 30 days. **********The exchange between the White House and Mr. Byrd introduced a new note of contentiousness into the delicate negotiations to achieve some form of legislative authorization for the troops that met the institutional demands of Congress and the White House.   Attempt to Play Down Incident **********This evening, a senior Administration official sought to play down the confrontational tone that arose today. He said that the White House was not trying to accuse the Congress and that there would be no new attacks in the future of the sort that occurred today. **********He characterized the White House's attitude this way: **********''No one wants to concede the principle that the Congress should determine exactly how those troops should be deployed and for how long. It's also important, particularly in sending a signal to the Syrians, that we not have a plan that promises that the troops are going to be out of Lebanon on a given day.'' **********Mr. Byrd and other Democrats, as well as some Republicans, say they feel the requirement for Congressional approval came into effect last month when the first of four marines was killed in shelling by Syrian-backed Druse militiamen outside Beirut.   The White House View **********The White House argues that despite the onset of more violence, there is no requirement under the War Powers Resolution that Mr. Reagan seek Congressional approval to keep about 1,300 marines committed to the multinational force in Lebanon. **********Because both sides agree with the principle that the marines should be there, a battle has emerged over institutional prerogatives and constitutional questions. **********Today the White House seemed to be trying to sweep aside the complicated questions of prerogatives and assert that, in general, requirements for Congressional authorization for the troops damage American interests in the Middle East. **********Meanwhile, negotiations continued today between the White House and Senate leaders on compromise language in a possible Congressional resolution backing the use of the troops.   A Signal From Reagan **********Mr. Reagan seemed to signal today what White House aides had said before, that the Administration would be able to accept some form of resolution as long as it did not embody the idea that the troops were in Lebanon under Congressional authorization. **********Asked by a reporter in the Oval Office whether he could ''live with'' some sort of war powers resolution, Mr. Reagan said, ''I am sure I can.'' Asked to be more specific, he said, ''I can't get into that while it's being discussed.'' **********He was apparently alluding to the talks on Capitol Hill today involving James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, as well as Senator Byrd and Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Tennessee Republican who is the Senate majority leader.  Mr. Reagan's comments came at a picture-taking session in the Oval Office before a meeting with supporters of tuition tax credits.   No Progress Reported **********The meeting with Senator Baker, Senator Byrd and Mr. Baker of the White House broke up this evening with no apparent progress in achieving a compromise. **********Aides indicated that Senator Byrd was still insisting that the President ackowledge that the troops' presence in Lebanon is subject to Congressional approval. **********An aide to Senator Baker said the Senator was ''tired of shoveling smoke'' and getting bogged down in a battle of prerogatives, and would try to break the impasse by introducing his own version of a compromise on Monday. **********There were few details tonight of that compromise, which the Baker aide said would be drafted over the weekend. The aide said Senator Baker wanted to ''precipitate Senate action'' by coming up with a resolution simply authorizing the President to continue to keep the troops in Lebanon for a period of time.   The Zablocki Approach **********This has been basically the approach of Democrats in the House of Representatives led by Representative Clement J. Zablocki, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee. Mr. Zablocki favors a resolution that would permit the troops to remain in Lebanon for up to 18 months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.print_headline: NEW TORY LEADER AHEAD IN CANADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.body_text: **********The common feeling among many Canadians these days is that Brian Mulroney will be the next Prime Minister of Canada. **********''All he has to do is keep breathing'' until a federal election is called in late 1984 or early 1985, Richard Gwyn, a political columnist for The Toronto Star, said. **********The Progressive Conservative Party, which Mr. Mulroney heads, is far ahead in the polls, leading the Liberals by a 2-to-1 margin, according to the most recent Gallup poll. And although inflation has fallen to an annual rate of about 5.5 percent from twice that level a year ago, average family income has fallen for the past two years and unemployment is persisting at nearly 12 percent, the worst rate since the Depression.  No one is prepared to write off the possibility that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau might stage a comeback, as he has several times in the past, or that perhaps another Liberal might do the same thing. **********But Conservatives as well as many Liberals, including the Prime Minister, are watching with attention as Mr. Mulroney begins to learn the ropes as the Tories' parliamentary leader. After a career as a lawyer and businessman, he was elected to Parliament for the first time last month, after being chosen as party leader in June.   Phone Call From Reagan **********Mr. Mulroney has publicly agreed that he is deliberately vague on some issues - particularly those which might later be the subject of negotiations - to avoid jeopardizing his subsequent position. **********But he has generally endorsed conservative positions. He received a phone call from President Reagan congratulating him on his election as the party leader. **********He has displayed cleverness in turning his wit against Mr. Trudeau and has been able to deflect criticism. **********Little of the bantering between the two bilingual leaders has been in French. But the area of rights for French-speaking Canadians has been perhaps the most ticklish issue Mr. Mulroney has had to confront so far.   Dispute on Language Services **********The topic grew out of a dispute in Manitoba about the extension of French-language services. During debate, Mr. Trudeau asked Mr. Mulroney to help draft a resolution supporting the Manitoba provincial government's plans to promote French. Mr. Mulroney agreed to meet with the Prime Minister to discuss the matter. **********For both parties, the stakes are the votes of French-speaking Canadians. The Liberals won 74 of Quebec's 75 seats in the 1980 election, while Mr. Mulroney's appeal to Conservatives was partly that as a Quebec native he could deliver more seats. **********But for Mr. Mulroney, the Manitoba issue is complicated by the fact that the provincial Progressive Conservative Party opposes the changes, and Tory policy is generally to give as much leeway as possible to the provinces, most of which are governed by Conservatives. **********Consequently, Liberals derided Mr. Mulroney when he agreed to the meeting, seeing the situation as one in which the Tories could not win. After two meetings between the two men, Mr. Mulroney has still not announced the position of his party's caucus.   Parliamentary Gaffes **********Mr. Mulroney has made other parliamentary gaffes, most of which do not appear to have been taken very seriously, including the Tory leader's misquoting of an International Monetary Fund report. **********On another occasion he asked the Transport Minister a question in Parliament about freight subsidies for the Maritime Provinces, only to be told the subsidy had already been granted earlier that day. **********This brought Liberal cries of ''Bring back Joe!'' referring to Mr. Mulroney's predecessor as Tory leader, Joe Clark. Mr. Mulroney appeared to take it well. **********Critics say they pardon Mr. Mulroney's reluctance to lay out details on his views, partly because the job of his party is to oppose the Government's initiatives, not to develop its own. **********But they do suggest that he might be clearer on such issues as the nature of economic relations with the United States and the proper balance between fiscal conservatism and the high level of social services Canadians have come to expect.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Nestle S.A. of Switzerland, the world's principal seller of infant formula, said today that it had made several changes in its marketing practices to make them conform to an international marketing code. **********Carl L. Angst, executive vice president of Nestle, said the company had responded to recommendations made by a Nestle-financed commission headed by former Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, who served briefly as Secretary of State in the Carter Administration. **********Mr. Muskie released the commission's fifth quarterly report, which confirmed Nestle's assertion that it has curtailed the distribution in developing countries of free samples and commercial quantities of its powdered milk formula, which is sold in 140 countries. **********The commission also said Nestle had stopped distributing product information that was outdated. **********Mr. Angst said the changes in marketing practices would be completed by the end of year, would cost $10 million to $20 million and would bring Nestle into compliance with voluntary standards adopted by the World Health Organization in 1981. **********(In Minneapolis, Douglas Clement, director of international programs for the Infant Formula Action Coalition, sponsor of a 10-nation boycott of Nestle products, disputed the assertions of Mr. Muskie and Mr. Angst. He was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that Nestle had not stopped its practice of giving free formula samples to mothers or supplies to hospitals. He said Nestle was still not in compliance with W.H.O.  standards.) **********Critics have contended that Nestle and other international corportations violated the W.H.O. code by promoting the powdered milk formula as a more desirable alternative to mother's milk when it was less desirable and a financial burden to many families in third world countries. **********Critics also say that unsanitary mixtures of breast-milk substitutes have been associated with higher infant-mortality rates in these countries. **********Nestle created the Infant Formula Audit Commission, headed by Mr. Muskie, in 1982 to monitor the company's marketing practices. Mr. Muskie said Nestle pays $100 an hour for his time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Housing Group Sells $413.8 Million of Bonds **********Home builders around the country are learning how to raise funds for the housing industry by selling securities in the capital markets directly, besides using such traditional intermediaries as mortgage banking concerns or Federal agencies. **********The most recent financing by home builders is $413.8 million of bonds sold yesterday by the American Southwest Financial Corporation through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. American Southwest is a special financing company based in Phoenix that is owned by 22 home builders in five states. The home builders will use proceeds of the bond issue to repay debts they incurred in accumulating the Government National Mortgage Association pass-through certificates, which are collateral for the bonds. **********''Home builders are a new and increasingly important player in the capital markets,'' Thomas A. Kasper, vice president at Salomon Brothers, said. ''They have the final product.'' **********Mr. Kasper said American Southwest, which has grown rapidly in recent months, has a potential for issuing ''billions'' of dollars of mortgage- collateralized securities each year. Within a month, he said, the group expects to sell bonds collateralized with a pool of conventional home mortgages. **********Like other recent issue of collateralized bonds, the American Southwest financing makes use of sequential pay bonds, where all principal payments are applied to the shortest maturity until those bonds are retired. Then principal payments are applied to the next longest maturity. **********The exact maturity and yield of the bonds is not known, because of the uncertainty surrounding the rate at which the mortgages underlying the Government National Mortgage Association pass-through certificatres will be prepaid. **********For example, the 10 7/8 percent bonds priced at 99 3/4 have a final maturity of 1993 if no mortgages were prepaid, but assuming that prepayments occur at 75 percent of the historical average for Government- guaranteed mortgages, the issue has an average life of about 2.4 years, with a yield of 11.015 percent. The longest-term 12 percent bonds due in 2013 have an estimated life of 20 years and were offered at 92 3/8 to yield 12.57 percent. **********Yields for the AAA-rated bonds were well above those on Treasury issues, which ranged from about 10 1/2 percent on issues due in two years to 11.69 percent in 20 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.body_text: **********uf813 **********A narrow, 600-mile-long stretch of land just north of the Japanese archipelago, Sakhalin Island has long been a source of disputes over its control. Two Chinese dynasties declared suzerainty over the island before the modern era, and for the last two centuries, the Japanese and the Russians have contested each other's claims. **********In 1905, as a result of defeat in a war against the Japanese, Russia ceded the southern half of Sakhalin to Japan, which named the area Karafuto. The Soviet Union regained southern Sakhalin as well as the nearby Kuril island chain in 1945, at the end of World War II, when Soviet troops swept southward and in nine days defeated 20,000 Japanese defenders. **********Since then Sakhalin and the Kuril Islands - some of them still claimed by Japan - have formed an oblast, or province, within the Soviet Union's Russian republic. Dotted with airfields and missile installations, it is a strategic Soviet position facing the Pacific. **********Sakhalin is a cold, inhospitable land - in the winter battered by icy storms and in the summer graced at best by cool damp weather. At the end of the last century, Anton Chekhov assayed the island: **********''I have seen Ceylon, which is paradise, and Sakhalin, which is hell.''  Producer of Coal, Oil and Timber **********The island produces oil, coal, timber, wood pulp and paper. In recent years, Japan has been working with the Russians in exploring additional oil and gas resources off shore. **********Sakhalin Island was first conquered in the 13th century when the Mongols' Y"uan dynasty in China subdued the indigenous Gilyak and Ainu people. The succeeding Ming dynasty, preferring trade over arms, developed sputtering commercial ties with the island. **********In 1635, a Japanese survey expedition sent by the lord of Matsumae on Hokkaido landed on Sakhalin. Nine years later, Vasily Poyarkov and a band of Cossacks wintered at the mouth of the Amur River, opposite Sakhalin. The Japanese then established scattered settlements in the south, and the Russians in the north. **********In 1875, when all of Sakhalin was overrun by Czarist forces, Japan ceded all claims to the island in exchange for rights to the entire Kuril chain. **********In the years between 1875 and the outbreak of the Russian-Japanese War in 1904, the Russians used the island as a penal colony. In his ''Sakhalin Diaries,'' Chekhov chronicled the meanness and brutality of life on the island. **********After the division of Sakhalin in 1905, the Russians ultimately opened up oil deposits in the sparsely settled north while the economy in the more developed Japanese south, with a larger population, was based on coal and timber. **********After Sakhalin was reunified under Soviet rule in 1945, most of the Japanese settlers were repatriated and were replaced by Russian migrants. Sakhalin now has a population of more than 600,000, 80 percent of them Russians. The last Soviet census, in 1979, also reported the presence of 35,000 Koreans in southern Sakhalin, where many of them had moved while the area was under Japanese rule. **********Except for occasional visits by Japanese groups over the years, the island has been virtually closed to foreigners. In 1979, the Russians allowed a closely supervised visit by delegates attending a Pacific Science Congress at Khabarovsk, on the Siberian mainland. **********A Japanese member of the group, Hiroshi Kimura, a political scientist of the University of Hokkaido in Sapporo, found that the island capital, Yuzhno- Sakhalinsk, known as Toyohara under Japanese rule, had greatly expanded during the Soviet period and displayed little evidence of the Japanese times. **********In an account of the visit, published in the February 1980 issue of the American journal Soviet Geography, Professor Kimura noted that Yuzhno- Sakhalinsk, like many Soviet provincial cities, now had a main square named for Lenin, with a Lenin statue dating from 1970. **********On a visit to the regional museum, the Japanese traveler found that it was still housed in the original building, modeled after a Japanese castle with tile roof and stone dog guardians at the gate. The Soviet State Bank, too, is still housed in the old building of the Karaf uto branch of the Hokkaido Colonial Bank, Professor Kimura said. **********He reported a few chance encounters with resident Koreans and Japanese who had remained under Soviet rule and who welcomed the opportunity to speak Japanese and asked for books and records in Japanese and Koreans to be sent to them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/world.print_headline: BRZEZINSKI BELIEVES SOVIET WAS INVOLVED IN SHOOTING OF POPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/world.body_text: **********Zbigniew Brzezinski, the White House national security adviser during the Carter Administration, said today that he believed the Soviet Union was involved in the shooting of Pope John Paul II. **********''I'm reasonably satisfied that there was some sort of Turkish-Bulgarian connection,'' Mr. Brzezinski said in a brief interview. **********He added, ''In turn, anything of that historic magnitude couldn't have been undertaken by Bulgaria without the knowledge of the Soviet Union.'' **********Italian authorities are investigating whether Mehmet Ali Agca, the man convicted of shooting the Pope, received assistance from Turkish and Bulgarian accomplices and whether their was any involvement of the Bulgarian secret service. Mr. Agca, according to unsourced Italian press reports, has told Italian authorities that members of the Bulgarian secret service helped him plan the shooting. **********Mr. Brzezinski's comments echoed remarks he made in an interview published Sunday in Italy by the Turin daily La Stampa. The paper quoted him as saying ''there is no doubt the investigation made by Italian authorities has established the complicity of Bulgaria in the attack against the Pope.'' **********''Those who know the reality of Eastern Europe,'' he went on, ''automatically deduce that the Soviet Union was in command of the operation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Egypt and the United States had identical views on the need not only for all foreign forces to be withdrawn from Lebanon but also for them to be withdrawn in a way that ends local resistance to Beirut's rule over the countryside. **********Speaking to reporters after four hours of discussions with President Hosni Mubarak, most of which was spent alone, Mr. Shultz said that when he talks with the Israelis on Wednesday and the Lebanese on Thursday, ''I am going to spend a little time listening first of all,'' before presenting any American suggestion for resolving the remaining issues holding up a troop withdrawal agreement. **********Mr. Shultz said Mr. Mubarak and Mr. Reagan had indentical views on ''the urgency of arriving at a solution and the importance of the removal of all foreign forces if you're really going to have a solution and in a manner that is consistent and honors the necessity of a sovereign Lebanon, able to rule itself.'' **********American officials said the continued presence in southern Lebanon of Israeli troops or those of Maj. Saad Haddad, the former Lebanese Army officer who now heads an Israeli-equipped militia along the border, would raise doubts about Lebanon's control of its own territory and would make it more difficult to arrange a complete withdrawal of Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization troops. Mubarak Sees Reporters **********Mr. Mubarak, clearly pleased by the talks, met with reporters afterward, the first time he has done so after receiving a foreign minister, although President Anwar el-Sadat did so regularly. **********He said Egyptian-American relations were ''very good'' and the discussions with Mr. Shultz on the Lebanese negotiations and the Middle East were ''very fruitful.'' **********An American spokesman said Mr. Shultz was very pleased that Mr.  Mubarak said the two countries saw eye to eye on virtually every issue. **********In public, Mr. Mubarak repeated his support for President Reagan's Middle East initiative and again urged the Palestinians to join Jordan and help advance the plan. **********Mr. Mubarak and Mr. Shultz also discussed their concern about Soviet activity in the Middle East, particularly the flow of Soviet arms to Syria and Soviet efforts to block the Reagan plan, an American spokesman said. Meets Envoys Again **********After the meeting, Mr. Shultz again met with several American ambassadors to Middle East countries to review tactics for the coming weeks. An aide said Mr. Shultz, who has never met Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, recognizes that the success of his mission depends to a large extent on Israeli concessions. **********The Americans believe Israel has to drop its insistence on security arrangements in southern Lebanon. The Americans also expect Lebanon to agree to normalize relations with Israel, even without a formal treaty. **********After the session with the Ambassadors, Mr. Shultz attended a memorial service at the American Embassy for those who died in the Beirut bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Until 1981, when his company's earnings headed downward for the first time, Michel C. Bergerac, chairman of Revlon Inc., was eager to talk about the cosmetics and health care giant he was building. **********Then Revlon's glamour faded. The company's market share in cosmetics began to slide as more aggressive companies moved ahead in such growing areas as skin care treatment. A rapid diversification accompanied by the acquisition of several companies that make health care products, analysts said, distracted Revlon from its cosmetics operation. Add to that the recession. **********Suddenly Revlon, like the rest of the industry, discovered that regardless of the advertising budget, the days of rapid growth in cosmetics were over. And Mr. Bergerac's romance with Wall Street ended. **********A Long and Rich Contract **********Until then, Mr. Bergerac could do no wrong. From 1975 to 1980, the company's earnings quadrupled. Wall Street analysts praised his Gallic charm and strategic plan to diversify Revlon, which is still the nation's leading cosmetics company, into health care. **********They noticed, but said little about, the 51-year-old executive's long-term contract, signed in 1974, that would make him one of America's best-paid executives until his 60th birthday. **********He was equal, they said, to the task of replacing the flamboyant company founder, Charles Revson, who lured him away from the ITT Corporation's European business in 1974. Mr. Revson wanted a man to build Revlon's health care business as a balance to its cosmetics business. **********Mr. Bergerac did. But in the view of some analysts, he failed to go far enough in reorganizing the company's cumbersome management, revising distribution or creating new products to captivate the cosmetics shopper. ''I think there is a lot more to do,'' said Jack Salzman, an analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********And even now, in his first interview with a daily newspaper in more than a year, Mr. Bergerac makes no solid prediction about when Revlon might recover from its three-year slump. ''Being optimistic, I would tell you it will happen in 1984,'' he said. **********Sitting in his large corner office overlooking Fifth Avenue and Central Park at 59th Street, Mr. Bergerac now says that the heady excitement of nearly a decade ago has come back to haunt him. ''The pendulum has swung too far both ways,'' he said. ''We got overpraised and we got overblamed.'' **********Earnings Drop **********By the principal measure that matters to investors - earnings - Revlon has slipped with the rest of the cosmetics industry. Even Mr. Bergerac's rapid diversification into health care could not prevent a slide in profits from a record $192 million on sales of $2.2 billion in 1980, to $111 million on sales of $2.4 billion in 1982. **********And in this year's first nine months, Revlon's earnings were down 17 percent from the period a year earlier. Its earnings per share were up 33 percent in the third quarter, but that was because the company repurchased its series A stock in July. The repurchase of the stock, which had been issued in 1980 for an acquisition, cost the company $287 million. . , **********The repurchase will also help the fourth quarter by about 8 cents a share, the company said. Revlon's common stock closed yesterday at $33.375, down 12 1/2 cents. **********Focus on Health Care **********If it had not been for health care, which accounts for about 55 percent of Revlon's sales, the company might be faring worse. **********Since Mr. Bergerac joined Revlon in 1974, he has diversified the company to prepare it for the inevitable slowing of growth in the cosmetics field. He has chosen companies in a variety of growing health care markets, including diagnostic, proprietary and ethical drugs and vision care. The common thread among them, he said, is that they are in ''less regulated'' areas of health care. **********Revlon has done relatively well in this field. Most of the acquired companies have developed successful new products, such as the Oxy line of anti-acne preparations. Mr. Bergerac is proud of the company's rapid rise to 55 percent of the market in extended wear contact lenses. **********But he is embarrassed by Revlon's salt substitute, which was introduced last year. ''No Salt started like a house on fire,'' said Mr. Bergerac, who takes responsibility for developing the product. ''But people didn't like it.'' No decision has yet been made about the product, and it is still on supermarket shelves. **********A Gain in Market Share **********Although health care represents Revlon's future, the company is still the country's largest cosmetics retailer. Its market share dropped to close to 17 percent in 1982, but now stands at nearly 20 percent. **********Revlon, long used to being the biggest and the best, was not prepared for the change in the cosmetics industry. The company's chief mistake, analysts say, was its failure to change its policy and sell to the mass market at popular prices. In cosmetics, the prestige and discount markets are the areas of growth and Revlon was in the middle. **********''The marketplace changed and they didn't understand it,'' said Allan Mottus, publisher of the Informationist, an industry newsletter. According to Mr. Mottus, Revlon has failed to identify the new Revlon woman. It has been 10 years, he said, since Mr. Revson, who personally believed that women should not wear pants, created the industry's most successful life-style fragrance, Charlie, and ignored his own feelings for the sake of exploiting a new market. **********'Gut Instinct' **********''Revson had an unbelievable gut instinct,'' Mr. Mottus said. ''With Charlie, Mr. Revson put a man's name on a woman's fragrance and made a wide-striding, confident young female in white slacks, jacket and hat its image. ''Since then Revlon hasn't done enough to turn the consumer on.'' **********Mr. Bergerac is aware of the criticism. That is why Revlon will spend the bulk of its more than $250 million in advertising and promotion this year on its major cosmetics lines. **********Mr. Bergerac is quick to dispel the notion that he is not intimately involved in cosmetics. He is not running a holding company, he said. In fact in 1979 he said he had found a new fragrance in Kenya. That fragrance, from the African lantana bush, is now the basic scent in the company's new Ebene men's cologne, which was introduced in France a few months ago. **********And next month, the company will introduce its Hair's Daily Requirement products, which include four shampoos and four conditioners. The new products will have a $25 million advertising and promotion budget. **********But again, the company will not be first with a new product line. Revlon will face stiff competition from Finesse, made by Helene Curtis, Jhirmack, which is part of Esmark, and Silkience, made by Gillette, among others. **********Next year, Revlon will also move more aggressively into skin treatments, one of the fastest-growing sectors in cosmetics. ''In treatment, we have never had the strongest position,'' Mr. Bergerac said. **********''But what we were gaining in color and treatment we lost in fragrance,'' he added. According to Joe Koloff, an industry analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, Revlon's mass-market fragrances had a 15 percent sales decline in the third quarter. **********Mr. Bergerac is optimistic about Revlon's fragrance plans, however. ''In fragrance I think the hard times are behind us,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.main_headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE LATIN POOR VS. POOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.print_headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE LATIN POOR VS. POOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.body_text: **********The old house crouched comfortably on the hillside overlooking a valley. The long porch was cool, even in the midday heat. The family, originally from Canada, talked casually in Spanish, French and English about land redistribution, the personality of the Archbishop and political trivia. **********Lunch featured none of the specialties of the country. Served on Spode china, the food would not have been out of place in an English vicarage: roast beef, mashed potatoes and carrots and peas. Dessert was a coffee-flavored cream with whipped cream. **********Later the party moved to another of the three houses on the estate for coffee. The conversation meandered on. The scene was not unlike that at the start of ''War and Peace'' when a group of trilingual Russians discuss the French and Napoleon and the prospect of war.  They are people who better appreciate the amenities of life than its sacrifices. **********The war was closer here. The party could hear the hollow thud of mortar fire perhaps eight miles away. No one seemed disturbed. People such as these do not like the war, but they are learning to live with it. **********The dowager saw no need for panic. After all, she said, as a girl in Paris in 1914 she waited for the arrival of the German armies - ''and they never came.'' She could recall walking down the Champs-Elysees to the Place de la Concorde the day the Battle of the Marne began without seeing a single automobile. Now, with another war just over there in those hills, her serenity was unshakable. **********The war also seems very far away in the city. People seldom speak of it in restaurants and bars. They seem to concentrate more on the politics of the war than the war itself. Perhaps this is because few have a direct personal stake in the fighting. **********''The people you see here,'' a young Salvadoran said, looking around a well-filled restaurant, ''don't contribute their sons to the army. Oh, no. Their sons are out of the country at colleges in the States.'' **********The insurgents have proclaimed that they are the poor fighting the rich. But the soldiers of the Salvadoran Army are drawn mainly from the poverty-stricken villages. It is, one American said, a war of the poor against the poor. **********About 50 percent of the enlisted men are illiterate, an officer said. Inured to hardship in early life, they will march ''forever'' if ordered. The insurgents turn back captured enlisted men. In most cases the army sends them back to their units - twice. If they are captured a third time, an American said, they are shot. **********The guerrillas' psychological warfare often backfires. Not long ago the insurgents took a village in the north after a brief fight. They proclaimed to the shaken villagers that they were fighting for them, for all Salvadorans and for the good of the country. ''You have burned our trucks and our carts, on which we depend for a living,'' a villager said. ''Is that for our good and the good of the country?'' **********The hatred lies just below the surface here. People from the extreme and moderate right talk about the guerrillas in voices dripping with hate. Any story about guerrilla terrorism, no matter how flimsy the evidence, is believed. Nor do people try to excuse the killings carried out by the army and the national guard. The foreigner is told that he just doesn't understand the depth of feeling, as though that were an excuse. **********Oddly, the brutality is often unplanned. It is hard to think of the army planning to shell a city, but it is easy to envisage a patrol annoyed by one shot impulsively turning its rifles on anyone nearby. **********At night the Americanization of San Salvador is all too evident.  The streets are bright with signs advertising soft drinks and other American contributions to civilization. A McDonald's is doing fairly well. The Government has forbidden the importation of wine, but that is about the only drink lacking. Bars are stocked with liquor from all over the world. **********And there is even wine around. One party of three Salvadoran businessmen drank four bottles of champagne during a festive lunch. **********An American businessman long stationed here was asked if the land program and other measures introduced by the Government would change the nature of the people. **********''Nothing really changes down here,'' he said. ''The reforms will do some good for the peasants. If the Government wins the war, come back in five years. You'll see that the people who have the money now will have it then. The peasants will be a little better off - but not much. And the army? The junior officers will be holding back the men's pay just as they do now, and each senior officer will be seeing himself as the next President. Don't expect to change 400 years of history in five.'

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/12/busin.print_headline:
PATENTS;
Method of Containing Nuclear Waste in Glass
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/12/busin.body_text: **********A new method of containing nuclear waste in glass has been invented by James M. Pope and Don A. Harrison for their employer, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in Pittsburgh. **********Patent 4,376,070 was granted for the method this week. **********The waste is mixed at room temperature with alkoxide compounds instead of being mixed with glass formers, which require homogenation at high temperature. The alkoxide compounds are partially hydrolyzed and then mixed with the nuclear waste. The mixture is heated to remove the alcohol and water and dry the composition. Finally, the mixtures melted in place are poured into ingots and cooled. The process has been tested at various waste facilities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Thomas C. Hayes states (''Good Buys in the Thrift Business,'' May 8) that state-chartered Florida S.& L.'s have considerable advantages relative to federally chartered S.& L.'s in Florida because, in part, the state-chartered institutions are permitted to invest as much as half of their total assets outside of mortgages, whereas Federal thrifts are subject to a 5 percent ceiling on such investments. **********Mr. Hayes is in error in this belief. **********The enactment of the Depository Institutions Deregulation and Monetary; secured or unsecured commercial loans up to 5 percent of assets, and leasing up to 10 percent of assets. Moreover, the Garn-St Germain Act increased the percentage of assets an S.& L. may invest in consumer loans to 30 percent from 20 percent. **********Thus, while the demand for state-chartered S.& L.'s in Florida may exceed the demand for federally chartered units, it is in no way related to any 5 percent ceiling imposed on Federal S.& L.'s' lending authority outside of mortgage loans. If indeed the demand for state-chartered institutions is greater, the answer lies elsewhere.  JOHN J. DI CLEMENTE Regulatory Economist Research Department Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago Chicago, May 12 ---------------------------------------------------------------------  The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/02/busin.body_text: **********The Baldwin-United Corporation averted possible bankruptcy when five groups of creditors agreed Thursday night to a new accord covering more than $1 billion in short-term debt. **********The agreement, announced yesterday, paves the way for a series of moves, including asset sales and write-offs, that are likely to be made in the next 10 days. **********''This is the first step toward a restructuring and revitalization of the company,'' Victor H. Palmieri, Baldwin's president and chief executive officer, said in an interview yesterday. On Thursday, the company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to suspend trading for 10 days in its securities in primary and secondary markets to calm speculation about the debt negotiations. **********Under the terms of the agreement with the creditors, some of the company's debt payments will be deferred until Sept. 30. That new deadline extends and expands a 90-day moratorium on debt payments that was due to expire in mid-July. That moratorium had covered $630 million in overdue debt. **********The new accord covers certain collateral arrangements for Baldwin debenture holders, who were not party to the debt moratorium reached last April. **********Mr. Palmieri said the debenture holders would receive $9 million in interest payments during the period, contingent on the sale of assets that are part of the company's restructuring program. **********Another group of creditors, those holding $440 million in debt owed by Balunit, a Baldwin subsidiary, and the MGIC Investment Corporation, Balunit's principal holding, will receive interest and principal payments during the period. **********Aside from the Balunit-MGIC group of creditors and the banks holding $233.5 million in Baldwin-United and D.H. Baldwin debt, the other parties in the agreement are the debenture holders, who have $106.2 million worth of Baldwin debentures; a group of banks led by Bankers Trust, which made a $116.8 million revolving credit available to MGIC on Thursday; the Prudential Insurance Company, which has a $40 million loan outstanding to Baldwin-United, and Merrill Lynch, which holds $74 million in obligations from the company. **********The agreement provides for an extension of the collateral package offered to banks holding debt of Baldwin-United and D.H. Baldwin, another subsidiary, until Sept. 30. The company has 15 days after that to work out another accord, a period designed to placate anxious debenture holders, who are unsecured lenders. Asset Sale Planned **********The agreement sets in motion a process that Mr. Palmieri has said would include the sale of assets, projected to raise $500 million in cash. An announcement of the sale of the company's mortgage and leasing affiliates may be made in the next few days, Mr. Palmieri said. A series of announcements on corporate write-offs would also be forthcoming, he added, without elaborating. **********''The combination of good will and deferred acquisition costs will be very large,'' Mr. Palmieri said.  The basics of the agreement were worked out in a marathon meeting that began last Sunday and stretched into Monday morning. ''The next three days were spent negotiating the fine points and bringing in the holdouts,'' Mr. Palmieri said. **********But it was a near thing. According to banking sources, the last of the recalcitrant creditors did not sign until 11:30 Thursday night, only half an hour before the negotiating authority of some of the creditors was scheduled to expire. **********In an interview, Mr. Palmieri said the company would have moved for voluntary bankruptcy before any creditor could have forced it into involuntary reorganization. ''We had until the next morning when the judge woke up,'' Mr. Palmieri said. **********In at least one case, some outside assistance may have been a key factor in reaching the agreement.L?ate Thursday afternoon, the president of BancOhio, a Columbus-based bank that is a creditor of D.H. Baldwin, received a phone call from Ohio's Governor Richard Celeste. A 'Courtesy Introduction' **********''The Governor spoke with BancOhio as a courtesy to Mr. Palmieri,'' said Paul Costello, a spokesman for the Governor. He said the conversation was not ''substantive,'' but merely a ''courtesy introduction.'' In the Carter Administration, Mr. Celeste served as director of the Peace Corps while Mr. Palmieri headed the State Department's refugee program. **********Baldwin-United, based in Cincinnati, has 10,000 employees nationwide, 2,500 to 3,000 in Ohio, whose jobs could have been jeopardized by a Baldwin bankruptcy. With $3.6 billion in revenues last year, Baldwin-United is one of Ohio's largest corporations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/19/busin.main_headline: Chief of Enterprise Oil Prepares to Build Team
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief of Enterprise Oil Prepares to Build Team
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Graham Hearne, newly appointed first chief executive of Enterprise Oil P.L.C., the company recently created by the British Government to take over the North Sea oil interests of state-owned British Gas, says his first priority is ''to recruit a team of high-quality people.'' **********At the moment, the company is still so embryonic that it is operating out of an office at Kleinwort Benson, the merchant bank organizing its securities sale. Mr. Hearne, 46, takes up his new job March 1. **********Issuing of the company's shares is expected in the spring or summer. **********''It is most important that Enterprise was able to appoint someone who is an entrepreneur and understands the mechanism of making acquisitions, because that is exactly what Enterprise is about,'' said a London stockbroker who asked to remain unidentified. **********''With training as a corporate lawyer and merchant banker, and considerable experience in the oil industry, Mr. Hearne has an excellent pedigree in that respect.'' **********Mr. Hearne practiced law in Britain and New York with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson from 1963-66. In 1967, he joined the Industrial Reorganization Corporation as an executive before moving, in 1970, to N. M. Rothschild & Sons Ltd., merchant bankers. Seven years later, he moved to Courtaulds Ltd., where he served four years as the textile company's director of finance. **********In 1981, Mr. Hearne moved into the oil industry as chief executive officer of Britain's Tricentrol P.L.C. Tensions with Tricentrol's board led to his departure earlier this year. He joined Carless, Capel & Leonard P.L.C., a smaller London-based oil company, as managing director.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/world.main_headline: MARCOS BEGINS A NEW INQUIRY ON FOE'S DEATH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/world.print_headline: MARCOS BEGINS A NEW INQUIRY ON FOE'S DEATH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that a new commission would investigate the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. **********The panel will replace the five-member presidential commission that resigned on Monday, citing widespread doubts that its inquiry would be impartial. **********The presidential palace announced that two of the new panel's members would be appointed by Parliament and that three to five others would be named from among people recommended by ''various sectors of society, such as legal associations, civic and service organizations and the business, education, student and labor sectors.'' **********The President's action was immediately criticized by the opposition leader Jose Diokno, who said that as long as Mr. Marcos was President there could be no impartial inquiry. Parliament, which would appoint two members of the panel under the decree, is overwhelmingly controlled by the President's supporters. **********Foreign Minister Present **********Mr. Marcos signed the decree on television, in the presence of Government members including Arturo Tolentino, the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs. Mr. Tolentino said on Monday that he could not accept a presidential appointment as chairman of the original commission because the panel lacked independence and apparently had prejudged the case it was investigating. **********Mr. Tolentino said in an interview today that the commission envisaged in today's presidential announcement was ''a sort of compromise'' between the body he had recommended, composed only of nominees of the private sector, and one over which the Marcos Government would have more control.  In his television appearance today, President Marcos also formally abolished the original commission. In a letter to the four former justices on it, he said that their resignation Monday had been compelled by the ''present morbid atmosphere.'' **********Ever since they resigned, their staff members have criticized the Government for the reports it had presented to the commission on the death of Mr. Aquino, who was shot on Aug. 21 soon after arriving at the airport from three years of voluntary exile in the United States. **********One such document, which was submitted to the commission on Sept. 20, was described by a staff lawyer as substantially ''inconsistent with the technical reports'' that other Government investigators had compiled a few days after Mr. Aquino's death. **********''I don't believe that report,'' the lawyer, Amadeo Seno, said of the 11-page document bearing the signature of Maj. Gen. Prospero A. Olivas, who had been named by Mr. Marcos to conduct the Government's investigation. **********The report said a civilian named Rolando Galman had been proved ''scientifically'' and ''indubitably'' to have killed Mr. Aquino. Mr. Galman, officially identified as a hired assassin with leftist connections, was shot dead at the airport by security guards. **********According to Mr. Seno and other commission sources including its general counsel, Rustico V. Nazareno, the original commission's staff had been hampered by what was described as limited distribution of police and military findings. The sources complained also about the lack of funds with which the panel might have been able to engage independent investigators. **********The report said that Mr. Aquino, seconds before his death, had been followed down an airport stairway by four soldiers, including an intelligence operative who was evidently wearing civilian clothes. **********Mr. Aquino was shot in the back of the head from a distance of between 6 and 18 inches, according to the report, immediately after he reached the bottom of the stairs. **********Opposition leaders have contended that Mr. Aquino must have been shot by someone on the stairs. But military investigators have said he was shot by an assailant - Mr. Galman - who had dashed out from behind the stairs Mr. Aquino was descending. **********Dr. Bienventio Munoz, a police doctor, who had performed an autopsy on the body of Mr. Aquino, testified before the original commission on Sept. 7 that Mr. Aquino must have been looking upward at the time. That, the doctor said, would explain how the bullet had emerged through Mr. Aquino's chin. **********The Olivas report leaves many questions unanswered. For example, of the four military guards who are said to have followed Mr. Aquino down the stairs, only two are mentioned as having witnessed the killing. **********One, Constable First Class Rogelio Moreno of the paramilitary Philippine Constabulary, is never mentioned again in the report. The other was identified as Sgt. Filomeno Miranda, ''an intelligence operative.'' He ''ran for cover,'' the report says, when the shooting started. **********Constitutional Amendments **********MANILA, Oct. 14 (AP) - President Marcos also announced plans today for new constitutional amendments providing for parliamentary elections by district rather than by region. **********These were apparently a concession to critics who said current laws gave an edge to the Government party, the New Society Party, over the poorer opposition groups, since it costs more to campaign in the larger areas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/busin.body_text: **********The James River Corporation announced that it had completed the restructuring of its $525 million of debt and credit lines. **********The company said the restructuring included the exchange of $39 million of preferred stock in a subsidiary for James River preferred stock, the conversion of $11.1 million of James River preferred stock, and the redemption of $5 million of convertible preferred stock. **********James River said it had also completed a private placement of $55 million of new long-term debt having a fixed interest rate of 12.25 percent, a term of 15 years and a five year moratorium on principal repayment; that debt replaces bank revolving credit.
