https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/world.print_headline: THOUSANDS BATTLE RIVERS IN CHINA; THREAT BY YANGTZE CALLED 'GRAVE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/world.body_text: **********The rain-swollen Yangtze River has begun to subside around the industrial center of Wuhan in central China but authorities have warned that danger of serious flooding downstream persists. **********At the same time, residents along the Yellow River, China's second largest, after the Yangtze, have also been put on flood alert after heavy rains in the interior earlier this month. **********The New China News Agency reported that the flood waters were measured at 3,920 cubic meters a second in the Yellow River's upper reaches at the western province of Qinghai. This is slightly less than last summer, when the overflow of the Yellow River was diverted to avoid widespread flooding. **********The threat of flooding remains ''grave'' on the Yangtze 200 miles downstream from Wuhan, which was briefly inundated earlier this month after officials neglected to close a sluice gate. Soldiers Work on Embankments **********In the area of Poyang Lake, which drains north into the Yangtze, army units have been called out to work on embankments jeopardized or breached. **********The central flood control headquarters was quoted by the New China News Agency as having reported that water had already broken through 53 protective embankments in the Poyang Lake area and that the situation was ''critical'' for several communities with a combined population of 317,000 and nearly 100,000 acres of farmland. **********Soldiers and rubber boats have been sent to the area to rescue inhabitants if the water breaks through.  The English-language China Daily said Wednesday that Jiangsu Province, further downstream, had mobilized 500,000 along its 250 miles of the Yangtze, where the water has been recorded two to four feet above danger level. Casualty Figures Not Complete **********The casualties so far from the floods, which were caused by torrential rains over the last few weeks, have yet to be made public in full. The China Daily reported that 90 people in Anhui Province, north of Jiangxi, had died and several hundred others injured there in recent weeks. **********But the flood peak, which was measured at 63,500 cubic meters a second, passed Wuhan, a city of nearly 4.2 million, late Tuesday. By Wednesday afternoon, the level of the Yangtze at Wuhan began dropped slightly, to about 92 feet, flood control officials reported. **********The Yangtze and Yellow rivers have a history of catastropic flooding but recent construction of heavier embankments, sluice gates and diversion channels has lessened seasonal damages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Bank Stocks' Growth Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Bank Stocks' Growth Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/busin.body_text: **********PLUMMETING interest rates last summer touched off a dramatic increase in stock prices and a corresponding expansion in priceearnings ratios. But now, with interest rates apparently stabilizing, the consensus on Wall Street is that the continued rise of most stock groups henceforth must depend upon higher profits, rather than the willingness of investors to push up multiples. **********Banks, however, offer a notable exception to this situation, in the opinion of Thomas H. Hanley, who heads bank stock research at Salomon Brothers. ''We believe multiple enrichment is inevitable for bank stocks,'' he stated. **********While he envisages gradually improving profits for banks in 1983 and 1984, Mr. Hanley based his optimistic case mainly upon earnings multiples. The 22-bank stock index of Salomon Brothers, as of July 1, carried an average yield of 5.4 percent and a multiple of 6.7 times earnings for the trailing 12-month period. This compared with a yield of 3.72 percent and an earnings multiple of 14.6 for Standard & Poor's 400-stock industrial index. **********''It means that the relative multiple of bank stocks to the index was 45.9 percent, or the lowest level of the entire postwar period,'' Mr. Hanley noted. ''We remain convinced that the industry's relative valuation will improve and approach 80 percent during the next 12 to 18 months.'' **********Among New York City banks, Salomon's current picks include Citicorp, J.P. Morgan and Bankers Trust, all of which are expected by the firm to outperform the general equity market. **********''Within this group, we now recommend banks which either have a clearly defined proprietary presence, or those which we regard as turnaround situations,'' the analyst said. ''In terms of a proprietary presence, Citicorp's bet on the consumer is paying off, Morgan is traveling the merchant bank route and Bankers Trust is out of the retail business and its strategy is to stress wholesale banking. In the turnaround camp, we advise accumulation of both Irving Bank Corporation and Marine Midland.'' **********Conversely, Salomon has lowered its investment opinion on Chase Manhattan, which now is expected merely to match the performance of the general market over the 12-to-18 month time horizon. The firm has reduced its 1983 earnings estimate for Chase to $11 a share from $12. **********''We're also leaning heavily towards regional bank stocks,'' Mr.  Hanley said. ''Our enthusiasm for bank securities is predicated partly on the 1983-1984 outlook for two economic variables -domestic inflation and short-term interest rates - which appear more favorable than at any recent time. Secondly, we foresee continued improvement in the emotional environment as credit quality worries, particularly concerning overseas borrowers, recede. **********''In addition, the banking industry's profit dynamics should gain momentum as 1984 unfolds. Finally, bank stock multiples typically advance during the second year of an economic recovery.'' **********E.F. Hutton & Company remains positive on the outlook for bank stocks, with a preference for the big money-center banks, such as those in New York City, according to Harold M. Levine. ''We think that, over the longer term, money-center banks will be more favorably affected by lower inflation rates,'' the analyst said. **********What about the huge amount of problem loans to foreign countries?  ''I believe these problems already are reflected in the price of bank stocks,'' Mr. Levine replied. ''I foresee no disaster on this front.'' **********Hutton is keeping four money-center banks on its recommended list - Bankers Trust, Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and First Chicago - although Mr. Levine acknowledged that these issues probably will underperform the general market ''over the next month or two.'' **********Two New York City banks - Citicorp and J.P. Morgan - are picked by the Value Line Investment Survey as among its most-favored issues to outperform the market over the next 12 months. Of problem loans abroad, the advisory service said, ''We think the borrower countries, and their loans, will muddle through.'' **********Stephen Berman of L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin dissented sharply. ''I took money-center banks off my recommended list last October following a big run in their stock prices,'' he said. ''We encourage performance-minded investors to reduce holdings in large bank stocks. But if the Dow goes to 1,500, I'd be the last to say that these stocks won't go up.'' **********Meanwhile, he recommends two regional banks, Manufacturers National Corporation in Detroit and First Jersey National Corporation in Jersey City. **********Since the start of the bull market last August, one index of major New York City bank stocks, advancing 63 percent, has performed slightly better than the Dow Jones industrial average.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.main_headline: COSTA RICA TELLS ANTI-SANDINISTAS BORDER ATTACKS WILL BRING OUSTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.print_headline: COSTA RICA TELLS ANTI-SANDINISTAS BORDER ATTACKS WILL BRING OUSTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.body_text: **********Members of a key rebel group fighting the Nicaraguan Government ''are very close to being expelled'' from Costa Rica because of their military activities in the country, according to an official close to Costa Rica's Security Council. **********The official, who asked not to be named because of the sensitivity of the situation, said Tuesday night that a Cabinet minister had given a ''stern warning'' to Alfonso Robelo Callejas, a leader of the Democratic Revolutionary Alliance. Mr. Robelo was told, the official said, that every member of the rebel group would be ejected if the Government found any evidence of ''armed military action against Nicaragua'' from Costa Rica. **********The warning, officials here say, is the result not only of growing tension between Costa Rica and Nicaragua, but also between some top Costa Rican officials and Mr. Robelo. ''We have told ARDE,'' the official said, using the group's acronym in Spanish, ''that they can use Costa Rica as a political space, but they are trying to use it as a military space. If it's a choice between ARDE and Costa Rica's neutrality, Costa Rica's neutrality will prevail.'' **********Costa Rican sensitivity to the rebels' activities was heightened by an incident Sept. 28 in which a rebel attack on a Nicaraguan border station at Penas Blancas was answered hours later by a Nicaraguan attack on a Costa Rican rural guard station. Two days later, the Nicaraguan Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega, warned that Nicaraguan troops would pursue rebel attackers into neighboring countries if necessary to stop their attacks. **********A Costa Rican official said that the Government was receiving daily complaints from Nicaragua's Sandinista leaders that rebel attacks were being staged from Costa Rican territory. He said that there were only two airstrips in the country from which offensive action could be undertaken and that these were ''under constant surveillance.'' He conceded, however, that the border was more difficult to patrol. **********The Costa Rican Government has been trying to demonstrate its wish to control the rebel activities by arresting members of the Democratic Revolutionary Alliance found with illegal weapons and supplies.  One Government report, which has not been made public, listed the arrests of 64 of the group's officials in September, including Orion Pastora, brother of Eden Pastora Gomez, the exiled Nicaraguan military commander, who is now said to be leading rebel troops in southern Nicaragua. Some of those arrested, the report said, were jailed and some were released. **********These arrests have led to a sharp increase in tensions between the Government and the rebels. Mr. Robelo, according to the official close to the Security Council, made ''veiled threats'' recently to two members of the Cabinet, asserting that if the arrests continued he would ''go to the media and expose that they were collaborators of the Sandinistas.'' **********That was said to have infuriated the Costa Rican President, Luis Alberto Monge, who was quoted as having said that if any military attack from Costa Rican territory was detected, the rebels would be expelled ''hasta el gato de la casa'' - ''down to the house cat.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.main_headline: Afghan Rebels Mount A New Round of Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Afghan Rebels Mount A New Round of Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.body_text: **********Afghan rebels have opened their most intensive attacks in two years against the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul, Western diplomatic sources said today. **********The sources said that the increased fighting broke out a few days before the resumption of indirect talks in Geneva last Thursday between Pakistan and the Soviet-backed Afghan regime and that the battles were continuing. **********According to the reports, fighting erupted almost every night last week in the Afghan capital and its suburbs, reaching a peak during the night of June 14-15. Casualties were not known. **********It was ''the most intense and prolonged fighting in two years,'' according to one report. The rebels mounted an attack on the area where the Defense Ministry is situated and, according to one account, captured a large quantity of ammunition and some prisoners. **********The first rebel attack occurred on the night of June 11-12, when the guerrillas hit a Soviet command headquarters from positions in the east and northwest, the sources said.

Pierce Company of Dundee, N.Y., for an undisclosed price, the executives said. **********The acquisition includes Lincoln's apple-processing plant in Highland, N.Y., one of the oldest apple- pressing plants still operating in the Hudson Valley. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.main_headline: Punjab Reported Quiet On 3d Day of Delhi Rule
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Punjab Reported Quiet On 3d Day of Delhi Rule
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.body_text: **********The troubled northwestern Indian state of Punjab was reported quiet again today, its third day of central Government rule, as the neighboring state of Haryana and the Union Territory of Delhi prepared for strikes called by opposition groups to protest the killings of Hindus by Sikh terrorists. **********Leaders of the Sikh campaign for autonomy in Punjab issued a warning to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi that violence could ''engulf the whole of northern India'' if she failed to stop reported Hindu assaults on Sikhs in Haryana. **********At least 15 people have reportedly been wounded in sectarian battles and clashes between Sikhs and the police. **********The Press Trust of India, a news agency, said 50 people were arrested in Haryana in connection with the clashes there and that the authorities had banned people from carrying arms and other weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/06/world.main_headline: Hundreds of Ghanaians Expelled From Nigeria
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Hundreds of Ghanaians Expelled From Nigeria
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/06/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of Ghanaians have been arriving daily at the border town of Aflao in the last few days after being expelled from Nigeria, the Accra radio reported today. **********It quoted the Ghana News Agency as saying Nigerian authorities had begun arresting aliens who had no residence permits and valid travel documents. It said Nigeria had given such aliens 30 days to leave voluntarily and would expel those remaining after Nov. 15. **********In January the Nigerian authorities gave 2.2 million West Africans, mostly Ghanaians, two weeks to leave the country. In April Nigeria said thousands had returned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.main_headline: Uniguard Mutual Gets New Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Uniguard Mutual Gets New Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.body_text: **********Richard S. L. Roddis says he will miss teaching tort and insurance law at the University of Washington in Seattle because ''I love law and my students are very bright.'' **********He has been named chairman and chief executive of the Uniguard Mutual Insurance Company, effective Feb. 1, replacing Jay D. Porter, who retires in January at age 65. The company, based in Seattle, wrote $220 million in earned premiums in 1982, with the bulk of business focused in Western states. Mr. Roddis has served as a director of the company and its subsidiary, the Olympic Life Insurance Company, since 1971. **********Mr. Roddis said that he enjoyed working in public service business, ''ones that society needs.'' He added: ''I'm a Christian and I believe very strongly in involving myself in human institutions that show concern for people and their well-being in life.'' **********He gravitated toward the public sector in 1954 when he took a job as Deputy State Attorney General in California, upon his graduation from law school from the University of California at Berkeley. In 1961, he was named chief of the Attorney General's business law section and chief of the investment fraud and business crime unit. ''I was attacking major business crimes such as land and securities fraud cases,'' he said. **********A client, a California insurance commissioner, hired him as chief deputy in 1964, and in 1966 he was named commissioner. But in 1968, the University of Washington lured him to Seattle as a law professor. In 1970, he was named dean of the law school but relinquished the position in 1978 so he could return to full-time teaching. **********''I prefer activities that benefit people, whether they are in government, business or education,'' Mr. Roddis said. But he added that insurance was an increasingly competitive industry. **********''It's rigorous out there,'' he said.

Production is to begin in July. **********---- MONTREAL, June 2 (Reuters) - Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said it would reactivate a potline at its Arvida-Jonquiere, Quebec, smelter this month, raising annual production by 21,500 metric tons. **********The potline has been shut since February 1982, Alcan said. With its reactivation, Alcan's three Canadian smelters will be operating at 85.5 percent of their annual rated capacity of 1,075,000 tons. The smelters had been operating at 83.5 percent of capacity. **********Alcan said it still had 155,500 tons a year of unused capacity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.main_headline: ANDROPOV OFFERS BAN ON SPACE ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.print_headline: ANDROPOV OFFERS BAN ON SPACE ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.body_text: **********Yuri V. Andropov said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were approaching a crucial time when failure to negotiate a ban on weapons in outer space would make an extension of the arms race inevitable. **********The Soviet leader made the comment in a reply to a group of American scientists who have been campaigning for a ban on space weapons. The Americans had sent a cablegram to Mr. Andropov last month as part of an appeal addressed to the leaders of all countries with space programs. **********Mr. Andropov, in his reply, made public by the press agency Tass, spoke of ''the extremely dangerous consequences of saturating space with deadly weapons.'' He noted that the Soviet Union had submitted a draft treaty on the subject to the United Nations in 1981, and charged that progress had been blocked by the United States and its allies. **********''Moreover,'' he said, ''recent developments have demonstrated that the use of space-based military technology is being assigned an ever greater role in United States strategic plans, including those announced by the top United States leadership. **********''Now a crucial moment is really coming: Either the interested states will sit down at the negotiating table without delay to begin drawing up a treaty prohibiting the placement in space of weapons of any kind, or the arms race will spill over into space.'' **********Mr. Andropov did not elaborate on his allusion to high-level American pronouncements, but President Reagan last month called for an American research and development effort aimed at producing hightechnology space systems capable of destroying offensive missiles before they reached the United States. **********The President said such an effective defense against missiles would render them useless and thus help put an end to the threat of nuclear war. **********Mr. Reagan's announcement focused attention on the potential of laser technology and particle beams, which some scientists believe could be developed into an effective antimissile defense. United States officials contend that the Soviet Union already has a program under way on such defensive weapons. **********The appeal of the American scientists concerned over the use of space for military purposes was drafted and circulated for signatures before Mr. Reagan's speech about the need for effective antimissile systems. **********The signers included Hans A. Bethe and Isidor I. Rabi, Nobel Prize winners in physics; Carl Sagan, astronomer; Christopher C. Kraft, former director of the Johnson Space Center in Houston; Lee A.  Dubridge, honorary president of the California Institute of Technology; Richard L. Garwin of I.B.M.; Wolfgang Panofsky, George W. Rathjens, Herbert F. York, former weapon development or arms control officials, and two retired naval officers, Adm. Noel Gayler and Vice Adm. John Lee. **********In his reply to the scientists, Mr. Andropov called the effort to prevent the militarization of space ''one of the priority tasks facing mankind.'' He depicted the Soviet Union as favoring accords to that end, saying that it had initiated all the agreements now in force seeking to insure that space be used only for peaceful purposes. **********''As scientists and specialists, you are well aware of the extremely dangerous consequences of saturating space with deadly weapons,'' the Soviet leader wrote. ''Statesmen, politicians and scientists really ought to start doing everything possible even now to prevent the use of the achievements of the human intellect, the accelerating progress of science and technology, to the detriment of the people.'' **********The Soviet leader said the draft treaty submitted to the United Nations would have ended the threat by banning weapons of any kind from space. He said the draft had been supported by ''an overwhelming majority'' of member states, but the Disarmament Committee had been barred from starting work because of Western opposition. **********''I would like to hope that the scientists and public figures of the whole world will make a contribution of their own to making certain that space will forever remain free of all weapons, that it will not become an area of military clashes and that there will be no threat coming from space to those living on earth,'' Mr. Andropov said. ---- Leader in Antisatellite Work **********WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -The State Department said today that the Soviet Union was the leader in developing a satellite interceptor as part of a military space program. **********''The Soviets possess the world's only operational ASAT interceptor, which they continue to test,'' a spokesman, Alan Romberg, said, using the abbreviation for ''antisatellite'' weapons. **********''That, plus the wide scope of their other military activities in space, belies their pose as champions of peace in outer space.'' Mr. Romberg said that, since the Soviet Union was developing a weapon system for space, the United States was forced to respond.  ''Other than a commitment to develop an ASAT capability to match the Soviets', we are not planning any space weapons systems,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.main_headline: HYATT SUBMITS PLAN IN BRANIFF HEARING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.print_headline: HYATT SUBMITS PLAN IN BRANIFF HEARING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The Hyatt Corporation submitted a final proposal on restarting part of Braniff Airways yesterday, meeting a deadline set earlier in the day by the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the case. **********In an attempt to stop what he called ''endless bickering,'' Judge John Flowers of Forth Worth had directed Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, to make his best offer by sundown so that the judge could determine if the creditor groups could agree on a plan. **********At a hearing requested by Braniff, the judge also told representatives of Braniff's creditor groups to meet with him today at 9 A.M., with the authority to negotiate on Mr. Pritzker's offer.  The details of the latest offer, which were worked out yesterday between representatives of Braniff and Hyatt, were not released.  Howard D. Putnam, Braniff's chairman, declined in a press conference yesterday to give the terms, which he said would be delivered to Judge Flowers this morning. **********Dan Lewis, a lawyer representing Braniff, asked the judge to extend a June 20 deadline for Braniff executives to file their own final bankruptcy reorganization plan. **********The judge said that he would not rule on the request to extend the deadline, however, until there was some resolution in the negotiations between the various creditor groups over the Hyatt proposal. Mr. Pritzker's proposal, involving a $70 million investment, would put 30 Braniff planes back into service. The planes would be leased from the secured creditors, who hold liens on them. **********The judge, who has presided over the Braniff case since the airline shut down and filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code in May 1982, made it clear yesterday that he wanted a quick resolution of the bankruptcy proceedings. **********''There will either be an agreement or not be an agreement,'' the judge said in ordering today's meeting. ''Essentially there is going to be a pie, and you are going to negotiate on how to divide it.'' **********The alternative to put Braniff planes back into service would be liquidation of the airline's assets, primarily its planes. Braniff would then emerge as a small ground maintenance company. **********Leaders of a major group of secured creditors made up of 38 banks and insurance companies, which hold $367 million of Braniff's secured debt, said on Tuesday that they were making progress in the talks with Mr. Pritzker. However, the secured bondholders, some 3,000 small investors who hold about $100 million of secured debt, have consistently opposed Mr. Pritzker's offers, unless he agrees to assume responsibility for payment of the bonds. Bondholders File Suit **********In a separate action, which could further complicate the attempt to re-start the airline, the bondholders yesterday filed suit in Federal District Court in Fort Worth. They accused Braniff's major lenders of conspiring since the beginning of 1980 to ''dominate, control and manipulate'' the airline's financial affairs in such a way as to benefit themselves and shortchange the bondholders. **********The suit seeks payment of nearly $100 million of principal as well as deferred interest and other costs that have been incurred since the airline filed for bankruptcy in May 1982. **********The suit argues that the lenders had got some proceeds from various assets sold by Braniff since 1980 but had not given any to the bondholders. The suit also says that the lenders allowed Braniff to keep some of the money to lessen the amount they would have to lend to the airline. **********James W. Toren, a vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, who has been one of the leaders of the institutional investor group, was at meetings yesterday and not available to comment on the suit, a company spokesman said. **********Braniff also said yesterday that it had named Dale R. States, former vice president of flight operations, president and a director on an interim basis. Mr. States takes over day-to-day operations from Howard D. Putnam, who will remain chairman of the board. Mr.  Putnam resigned this week as chief executive officer. **********Braniff also named Steven S. Turoff, formerly a vice president and controller, to the post of chief financial officer. Mr. Turoff succeeds Phil Guthrie, who will remain a director.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.main_headline: Chief Executive to Stay At the Boston Exchange
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Executive to Stay At the Boston Exchange
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.body_text: **********Charles J. Mohr has agreed to remain as chairman and chief executive officer of the Boston Stock Exchange for another two years.  Mr. Mohr, 35, became the Boston Stock Exchange's first paid fulltime chairman in October 1981. He had been vice president of planning for the New York Stock Exchange. **********In the past 20 months he has been able to help make the board profitable for the first time in years. He says he was able to do it ''not because of the bull market,'' but by cutting $2.6 million of expenses out of an $8.5 million total expense budget. **********''We've done that primarily by releasing 120 to 130 people in the last 18 months,'' he said. ''What people don't realize is that a year ago we could have done the same volume we've done in the last six months, even twice the current volume, and we still would have lost $50,000 to $100,000 a month.'' **********The real reason the Boston Stock Exchange is alive today, Mr. Mohr said, is because most of its processing has been automated. Through automation, the exchange is giving execution reports back to the customer in 30 seconds. **********Beside its accelerated reporting, Mr. Mohr has persuaded the governors of the exchange to guarantee execution on up to 1,200 shares on any single order. He stressed that the New York Stock Exchange would guarantee executions only of up to 500 shares. **********Mr. Mohr, who was born in New York City, was graduated cum laude from Niagara University in 1969. He got his M.B.A. in economics from the University of Vermont in 1970. During his college years he worked as a back-office helper for several brokerage firms, including Bache & Company. Other than 11 years with the Big Board, Mr. Mohr's only previous employer was Johns Manville & Company, where he was a financial analyst.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/18/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; INTEREST RATES DROP SHARPLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates declined in all sectors of the credit market yesterday, as good investor demand led to price gains of a point or more for many Treasury, corporate and tax-exempt bonds. **********The sharp rise in prices - as much as 5 1/2 points since early last week - reflects the return to the bond market of some major investors who were either inactive during the past three months or were selling rather than buying. Although dealers cautioned that reports of several major purchases of a few hundred million dollars of Treasury issues might be exaggerated, they concluded that sizable amounts of notes and bonds have moved out of dealer inventories and into investor hands in recent days. **********''A lot of pension fund managers have taken a look at the bond market and decided that yields of 12 percent look good against the stock market,'' commented Jay Goldinger, a broker in Beverly Hills, Calif. Demand for Treasury issues has also been strong from foreign investors, he said. **********The Herd Instinct **********Richard Davis, head of fixed-income research at the First Boston Corporation, said the rally owes some of its strength to the herd instinct of investors, rather than to any change in the outlook for the Federal deficit, Federal Reserve policy, the strength of the economy or the prospects for inflation. As bond prices fell almost 15 points between early May and early August, and sent yields rising on 30-year Treasury issues to more than 12 percent from about 10 1/4 percent, many market participants were convinced that the bond market was due for a rally. **********''Few people want to be the first to buy when things are unsettled,'' Mr Davis said. ''Investors would rather buy in an atmosphere of rising prices.'' **********Including yesterday's gain of almost 1 1/2 points, the newly issued 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013 had climbed to an offered price of 103 5/8, to yield 11.56 percent by late yesterday. They traded as low as 98 3/8 early last week, to yield 12.20 percent. **********Demand Strong for All Issues **********Demand has been good for shorter- term issues, as well as long-term bonds, traders said. The 11 3/8 percent Treasury notes due in 1986 rose more than 3/8, to 101, with a yield of 10.98 percent, while the 11 7/8 percent notes due in 1993 rose more than 3/4, to 101 3/4, and a yield of 11.46 percent. **********''The bond market is being prompted by hopes that first, the Federal Reserve will not have to tighten in the near term, and second, the interest rate levels already in place will be sufficient to cool off the economy,'' commented Wayne Lyski, a vice president at Alliance Capital Management Corporation. **********But Mr. Lyski added: ''I'm not convinced that either of those two conditions will be true this year.'' **********Many analysts are hoping that growth in the nation's basic money supply is on the verge of a significant slowdown from the 16.1 percent annual growth rate of the past three months. After last week's smaller- than-expected $400 million rise in the basic money supply, many forecasters said that the money supply number to be announced tomorrow may be unchanged from last week. **********As for the impact of higher interest rates on the economy, there are many forecasts that the pace of the recovery will slow from the second quarter, when the real gross national product expanded at an 8.7 percent annual rate. A slight decline in retail sales during July has so far been the strongest evidence that a slowdown is under way. **********Funds Rate Prompts Speculators **********Some analaysts said yesterday that a modest decline in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, to about 9 1/2 percent from 9.67 percent, helped prompt speculative buying of Treasury issues. Although Federal funds trading can be erratic on Wednesday, the last day of the banking system's statement week, some analysts said that allowing the benchmark rate to drop as low as 9 1/4 percent was a sign that the Fed is not trying to gradually raise rates. **********The rise in industrial capacity utilization during July to 75.8 percent from 74.6 percent in June was another sign that the economic recovery is proceeding, but it does not necessarily imply that inflation will heat up. The latest issue of the Griggs & Santow Report noted that after the 1974 recession, inflation ''did not become a major problem until the beginning of 1979'' - after industrial production had increased about 30 percent from its 1975 low and capacity utilization had increased about 25 percent from its low. **********''In current circumstances, percentage gains of this magnitude would take the industrial production index to about 180 and the capacity utilization index to about 85 percent,'' the report said. The industrial production index currently is only 148.6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.body_text: **********AGAINST a backdrop of Disney World's elaborate new celebration of American history and technological achievement, President Reagan earlier this month added his voice to the many who believe America's technological superiority is waning. **********''The number of scientists and engineers engaged in research and development in the United States increased by only 25 percent between 1964 and 1979,'' he said to an audience that included 500 of Florida's top math and science students. ''The increase in France was 90 percent; a 125 percent increase in Germany and 145 percent in Japan,'' he continued. Moreover, he added, Japan, with roughly half the population of the United States, is producing more engineers. **********The Soviet Union, Mr. Reagan said, which introduces basic concepts in geometry and algebra in its elementary schools, turns out five times as many engineering specialists each year as the United States. ''Obviously,'' he concluded, ''we must do better or we will be overtaken. In math and science instruction, the United States is a slow learner among the major industrial nations.'' **********As the President demonstrated in those remarks as well as in his State of the Union address on Jan. 25 and in a trip to Massachusetts in February, growing political capital is being made from support of math and science education and its beneficiaries, high-technology industry and research. The effect all the commotion will have on the problem is anyone's guess at this point, according to scholars, scientists and industrialists. But they say they are cheered by the interest, and especially by the President's enlistment in the battle. ''The nation is waking up,'' said Simon Ramo, a scientist and industrialist who has advised several Presidents, including Mr.  Reagan. **********''If it is sustained,'' said Richard N. Foster, a director of McKinsey & Company, the management consulting concern, who specializes in chemical and electronics industries, ''it could be terrific, bringing a significant change in the economy. But then we'll have to stick with it for more than four years at a time. The Congress has a responsibility for insuring that these programs being talked about continue from Administration to Administration.'' **********Legislators on Capitol Hill, who are also attuned to problems with science and math education, have been reading signals such as falling math and science test scores and a high percentage of unqualified high school math and science teachers as an erosion of the nation's technical prowess. As a result, the House of Representatives approved legislation earlier this month to spend more than $1 billion over the next five years to improve the teaching of math and science in public schools. The vote was an overwhelming 348 to 54. Yet the President's proposal was for much less, a $200 million commitment. **********Meanwhile, Senate Democrats are seeking to add $1 billion more in Federal and matching industry funds to upgrade science and engineering resources and curriculum in colleges. ''I have no desire to see high technology, the base my state now depends on, lost to the Japanese,'' said Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, who sponsored the amendment. **********Dr. Marvin L. Goldberger, president of the California Institute of Technology, is among those who express dismay over the quality of the nation's secondary-school education, and said he felt the problem lay with the low nationwide level of scientific comprehension. ''I want to emphasize,'' he said, ''that in the debate over science and technology, all aspects of high school education are lousy, not just the education in mathematics and science. The problem is not that the kind of kids we get at Caltech won't keep coming along. The guys who win Nobel Prizes, who go to Caltech will always keep rising through the system, no matter how bad it is.'' **********Asked what the result would of an increase in the number of scientists and engineers in the American work force, he questioned how automatic such correlations actually were. ''Everyone knows instinctively,'' he said, ''that there should be an enormous correlation between the rate of technological innovation and the transfer of basic research into commercial applications. But it becomes very difficult to prove in a quantitative way.'' **********Dr. Goldberger acknowledged that innovations such as the transistor, the silicon chip and xerography had all created large industries, but added, ''When you go beyond these flashy examples, the case is more complex.'' **********Dr. Charles Falk, director of the division of science resource studies at the National Science Foundation, agreed with Dr.  Goldberger that it is difficult to say in quantitative terms how an increase in research and development improves productivity. But referring to President Reagan's speech warning of a decline in science and math training, Dr. Falk emphasized that the comparative figures in Mr. Reagan's speech were for scientists and engineers in research and development, not total number of scientists and engineers. Other countries do not have reliable figures on total scientists and engineers, he said. **********Dr. Falk said that the United States continued to lead Western nations in its total of research and development scientists and engineers as a percentage of the labor force. In 1979, he said, the last year for which figures are available, the United States had 58 research and development scientists and engineers for every 10,000 people employed in the labor force. In Japan, the figure was 50. The National Science Foundation estimated that the Soviet Union's rate was 80 per 10,000. **********To be sure, most analysts still regard the United States as the world's technological leader. It is significantly ahead in key growth areas, such as telecommunications and computer programming, according to Mr. Foster, the management consultant, and other experts. Richard Cyert, president of Carnegie-Mellon University, in Pittsburgh, said the nation's biggest problem in technology was not innovation but bringing new ideas to the marketplace. ''In terms of knowledge and research, we still are ahead,'' he said. ''What we've got to do is get those things off the drawing board and into reality more quickly.'' He faulted business schools for stressing finance, accounting and marketing at the expense of manufacturing in the last 15 years. But he added that most had since improved their manufacturing courses. Carnegie-Mellon's solution was to merge elements of its graduate engineering and industrial admininstration schools, with a two-year course leading to a combined degree in engineering and management. ''By having bridges we are going to have a much better integration with technology and management issues,'' said Angel Jordan, the engineering dean. ''The beauty of the thing is that it is not going to produce an M.B.A. type.'' **********Dr. Ramo said the Federal Government could take several steps to bolster the nation's technological competitiveness. As a former chairman of TRW Inc. who testified recently before several Congressional committees on technology issues, he called for a cut in the defense budget, saying that the Administration's proposals would spread the nation's technical resources too thin for many of the defense projects to be achieved efficiently. **********He backed an increase in Federal spending on basic research in universities and an extension of the present year-to-year budgeting practice. ''No civilized nation other than the United States has year-to-year funding on research,'' he noted. **********In one of his most strongly held views, Dr. Ramo advocated paying bonuses to high school math and science teachers, financed by the Federal rather than state or local grants, with matching dollars coming from local industry. ''The typical local school board does not know whether we need more math in high school, just like the typical school board does not know how many more ICBM's we need, '' he asserted. **********''There needs to be a Federal education crash program that requires money and organization, but it's totally do-able and it's going to happen,'' Dr. Ramo added. ''We've got a disaster impending if we don't change.''

Some analysts contend that the recent rise in the Federal funds rate -the cost of overnight loans among banks - is an indication that the Fed has tightened th...
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/busin.body_text: **********The credit market continues to focus on trying to judge the Federal Reserve's policies.  Some analysts contend that the recent rise in the Federal funds rate -the cost of overnight loans among banks - is an indication that the Fed has tightened the availability of credit. They point to an increase in this rate over the past week, from 8.84 percent to 9.14 percent, as a sign that the Fed wants higher short-term interest rates over all. **********Others look at the bank reserve position as a sign of Fed policy.  Based on the data supplied Friday by the Fed, banks ended the banking week with $78 million in net free reserves. This meant banks had more in surplus deposits at the Fed than was needed to meet reserve requirements. **********Since the Fed can control the amount of reserves in the banking system, analysts said this free position indicated that the Fed was freely supplying reserves and not restricting credit availability.  This, they say, suggests that Fed policy remains unchanged.Concern Over Money Supply **********Underlying the debate is concern over the growth in the nation's basic money supply, M-1, which measures funds readily available for spending. **********In recent weeks M-1 has mushroomed some $20 billion above the desired target growth pattern set by the Fed. Despite the $3.2 billion decline for the week ended June 15, M-1 growth is still $17 billion above target. Analysts say rapid money growth such as this must be reined in, if the Fed's inflation-fighting credibility is to be preserved. However, many analysts forecast that M-1 growth will slow significantly in the next two weeks, mitigating the need for Fed action. **********Fear that the Fed had tightened credit, or would soon do so, prompted investors to retreat from the market last week, when security dealers were trying to absorb a heavy $14.25 billion in new Treasury securities. Their anticipation of credit-tightening caused rates to rise. **********In addition, dealers are entering this week still looking for buyers of the new debt, and should investors' perceptions of Fed tightening keep them on the sidelines, yields may rise further. **********Compounding the problems are additional signs of a robust economy, with economic data suggesting greater demand for housing and automobiles and an accompanying increased desire for credit among businesses and consumers. These pressures could continue to push rates higher.'The Fed Has Firmed' **********Against this background, Phillip Braverman, an economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said he believes that ''the Fed has firmed.'' He said the Fed is pushing the Federal funds rate higher as a way to slow money growth. ''They are coming back to setting policy by M-1, and while M-1 is better this week, it is still bad.'' **********He added that ''even though the situation looks less desperate, investors were unwilling to buy the auction. That's why I believe market interest rates are not high enough, and the yield levels are a reflection of all the problems the market faces.'' **********Michael L. Tindall, a money market economist at Republic Bank in Dallas, said, ''The changes in component factors in the monetary base to smooth out the seasonal effects are what's causing money to drop.  Those who look at the funds rate see a tightening; those who look at reserve position don't see a tightening.'' **********But, he says, the Fed is playing a hedging strategy. ''The Fed has allowed rates to move up, but it has not contracted reserves. So what we see is that the Fed has not tightened explicitly, but it has made a conscious decision to let rates rise, hoping that rising rates will contract money.''Analyst Sees no Policy Change **********Marc Wanshel, a financial economist at Crocker National Bank, said he believes that, based on the reserve position, ''there has basically been no fundamental policy change that has occurred yet. '' He said the increase in the Federal funds rate ''reflects technical factors associated with tax payment date rather than any significant change in Fed policy.'' **********Merrill Lynch wrote in its weekly credit market bulletin: ''The Federal funds rate is a very poor barometer of Fed intentions during the month of June, as it is deeply influenced by such seasonal factors as quarterly tax and dividend payments and end-of-quarter window-dressing practices.'' **********The auction of $12.4 billion in three-and six-month Treasury bills today should indicate the investors' perception. Last week the threemonth bill rose to 8.98 percent at the auction; it was offered late Friday at 8.96 percent. The six-month bill rose to 9.02 percent at last Monday's auction; it was offered late Friday at 8.97 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS UPDATE; SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS, AFTER LEWELLYN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/15/busin.body_text: **********For Safeguard Scientifics Inc., 1982 would have been bad enough without Gary Lewellyn. **********Battered by the economy, the tiny Pennsylvania machine parts manufacturer lost $6.7 million on sales that fell to $38.9 million from $39.1 million. Then because of Mr. Lewellyn, a previously unknown stockbroker from Des Moines, Safeguard found itself an unwitting party to one of the most bizarre stock manipulation schemes in Wall Street history. **********In early 1981, Mr. Lewellyn began secretly accumulating Safeguard stock on margin, apparently hoping to drive up the price; at one point he had accounted for 85 percent of the activity in Safeguard shares. **********The buying spree went bust on March 19, 1982, when Mr. Lewellyn's lawyer told several Wall Street brokerages that he was unable to pay the $22 million he owed. He had purchased 2.65 million shares, or 58 percent, of Safeguard's stock. Mr. Lewellyn was convicted last November on 15 counts of fraud and embezzlement, including charges that he took up to $16 million from his father's bank in Humbolt, Iowa. He is now serving a six-month prison term in New York for criminal contempt, but was returned last week to St. Paul, where hearings will begin Thursday on an appeal of his conviction there. **********Things have now quieted down at Safeguard's suburban Philadelphia headquarters. ''I'd say that basic operations were never disturbed to any significant extent,'' said Adolph A. Paier, the president. ''The bigger issue is that someone owns 45 percent of our stock, and people wonder what's going to happen to it.'' **********Mr. Paier was referring to the stock involuntarily assumed by Swiss American Securities, a small New York brokerage, when Mr. Lewellyn defaulted on his heavy margin debt after using his securities as collateral. Swiss American has spent the last year trying to sell the stock, but investor uncertainty remains and it has not had much luck. Swiss American officers would not comment. **********Safeguard shares recently traded at $6 on the Big Board; they fetched $14 a share when Mr. Lewellyn began buying, dropped to $5.75 and then rose to a peak of $16 when he was found out. **********Some good may come of the matter. Mr. Paier is hoping that the nationwide visibility Mr. Lewellyn brought will attract business in the long run. ''Hopefully, people will remember our name,'' he said, ''but they won't know why they remember us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company's proxy fight came to a subdued ending today at the company's annual meeting here, but the outcome will not be announced for a week or more. **********John G. Phillips, the company's chairman, moved quickly through the business of the meeting, announcing the names of the contesting nominees for the board. **********He then opened the meeting to questions, and received just one, from a disgruntled stockholder. **********After that, 20 minutes into the meeting, Mr. Phillips said the session would be adjourned ''for the purposes of counting votes.'' The meeting will resume June 8 at the company's New York offices. **********Mr. Phillips said later that ''it's our belief'' that stockholders had voted for management, He said he based his belief on ''the proxies that have been returned'' to the company and the fact that ''individuals have supported us very strongly.'' He also said that Carl H. Lindner, a large stockholder from Cincinnati, had supported the company and that ''there has been a strong show of support from institutional holdings.'' **********Delo H. Caspary, the Texan who has built oil service businesses and is trying to gain control of the company, exuded confidence, saying: ''I think the meeting was well conducted and I'm pleased with the outcome of the meeting. In this particular type situation, there's no need to go into long speeches.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/world.main_headline: FRENCH BISHOPS TO BACK NUCLEAR DETERRENCE POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/world.print_headline: FRENCH BISHOPS TO BACK NUCLEAR DETERRENCE POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/world.body_text: **********The Roman Catholic bishops of France are preparing a document on the nuclear arms race that promises to differ in significant ways from the American bishops' pastoral letter on the issue. **********The Rev. Gerard Defois, who is overseeing the preparation of the French episcopate's letter, said in an interview published today that the French bishops did not expect ''directly to condemn and judge from the exterior'' the actions of poltical and military leaders. **********He also suggested that the French bishops intended to support France's nuclear force by defending the concept of nuclear deterrence. **********By contrast, the American bishops' document, ''The Challenge of Peace,'' was widely interpreted as a criticism of American nuclear policy. **********First Major Pronouncement **********Father Defois's comments, published in Le Monde, represented the first major pronouncement of the French bishops' intentions. His statements, however, were in line with views expressed earlier this year by the Archbishop of Paris, Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger. **********The French contribution to the Roman Catholic debate on nuclear weapons, a debate heavily influenced by the deliberations of the French bishops, has been awaited with particular interest, partly because France also posesses nuclear weapons and because the disarmament movement has been less powerful both in French politics and within the French church. **********The French statement is likely to bear some similarities with a pastoral letter issued in January by West German bishops. The West Germans said ''nuclear deterrence is not a reliable instrument for preventing war in the long run'' but also defended ''the choice of the whole range of arms,'' including nuclear weapons, to help prevent war. **********In the interview, Father Defois said that ''deterrence, which is the response to a threatening situation, is but provisional security.'' 'Paradox of Peace' **********But he added that ''the paradox of peace in the nuclear era is precisely that one can only prevent war by evoking the horrors of the destruction of humanity.'' **********Father Defois was careful not to criticize the American bishops, noting that their statement was ''the point of departure'' for the wide discussion of the arms race in the Roman Catholic Church. He also appeared to go out of his way to minimize what will likely be seen as substantial differences of opinion between the French and American Catholic leadership. **********Echoing the views of many American Catholic leaders, he said the American bishops' statement had been misinterpreted as supporting unilateral disarmament. In fact, he said, the American bishops' statement, and the European hierachy, supported bilateral disarmament agreements. **********''All is in the term 'bilateral,' '' he said. ''I'd say that the American position is less new than people have said.'' Church's Role in Politics Cited **********Father Defois also argued that the variance between the expected French statement and the American pastoral letter could be partly accounted for by differences in the political and military situations of the two countries. One of the biggest differences, he said, was the important role played by churches in American political life. **********Another, he said, is ''the movement of strategic ideas'' since ''the arrival of President Reagan in the White House.  ''In particular,'' he said, ''a certain number of voices have been heard in that country extolling limited nuclear intervention, and even a 'first use' of that arm, that is to say, a crossing of the nuclear threshold.'' **********Thus, he said, ''what was in play in the American debate was not deterrence itself, but the fact that there was a tendency to banalize the recourse to nuclear weapons in public opinion.'' **********On the other hand, he said, the French discussion ''is situated in the context of deterrence in order to prevent nuclear war.'' Suggesting that the French nuclear force was too small to be used to start a worldwide nuclear war, Father Defois said that for France, ''a strategy of using atomic weapons is absolutely unthinkable for political, ethical and even technical and military reasons.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.main_headline: I.M.F. NEAR ACCORD ON QUOTA RISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.print_headline: I.M.F. NEAR ACCORD ON QUOTA RISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Financial leaders from around the world neared agreement today on a 50 percent increase in the resources of the International Monetary Fund, the 146-nation organization that lends to countries hard pressed for cash. **********An accord on the amount of the increasse, which is being negotiated at a conference of the I.M.F.'s policy-making Interim Committee here, should be completed before the meeting ends tomorrow, conference sources said. **********The United States, the I.M.F.'s biggest contributor, originally opposed any increase in the contributions -known as quotas - that member countries make to the agency's pool of lendable money. But now, the conference sources said, Washington would accept a rise of 48 to 50 percent. **********Most European countries want at least a 50 percent increase. Japan is said to be ready to accept 65 percent. The developing countries, which caucused yesterday as the Group of 24, issued a statement after their meeting asserting that anything less than a doubling of the quotas would be insufficient. **********The United States, which has been easing its position in the last few months, recently drew the line at a 40 percent increase, according to Administration officials. That would have meant an American contribution of $6 billion or $7 billion. **********Once an agreement is signed, it will require approval by the legislatures of the participating countries before going into effect. The outlook for ratification is least promising in the United States, which explains the tough American bargaining position. **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who has already urged Congress to authorize American participation, will go to Congress Monday, according to Treasury officials, with a specific request if agreement is reached at the I.M.F. meeting. **********He is expected to argue that the increase is important to strengthen the world economy and therefore to encourage a recovery in the United States. Testimony from the United States Chamber of Commerce in support of the quota increase is awaited. **********Bankers have testified for the quota increase, which would help the I.M.F. to make new loans to countries having difficulty meeting debt payments to Western banks. But they declare that they are not seeking a handout. Like Administration and Chamber of Commerce officials, bankers say the money is needed to bolster the global economy. **********''In a sense the I.M.F. quota increase proposal is, in part, 'a jobs bill' affecting the growing numbers of our workers and farmers who depend on healthy foreign markets for their livelihood,'' said George J. Clark, executive vice president of Citibank. **********But many Congressional liberals and conservatives alike have already expressed grave doubts about any American contribution.  Conservatives do not like the idea of public subsidies; liberals insist the money would be better spent producing jobs at home. The Senate minority leader, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said in a breakfast interview Wednesday that he did not expect to vote for the increase. **********Secretary Regan brought a dozen Congressmen for lunch with the I.M.F.'s managing director, Jacques de Larosiere, on Wednesday. A spokesman for Representative Stephen L. Neal, chairman of the House trade subcommittee, said the North Carolina Democrat would ''probably be willing to support the quota increase, depending on what his hearings show.'' **********The United States would contribute both to a quota increase and to a rise to $19 billion, from $6.6 billion, in a line of credit that the 11 richest industrial countries provide the I.M.F. That line of credit is now available only for lending by the 11 nations, but would now be made available to all I.M.F. nations. So altogether, officials said, the United States would provide somewhere between $8 billion and $10 billion. **********Such money does not count as a Federal budget outlay, but as an exchange of assets, since the United States would get enlarged borrowing rights in return for its new contributions. **********Another part of the agreement still being worked out related to the percentage of quotas that members may borrow. The current limit is 450 percent, meaning that a country like Brazil with a $1 billion quota may now borrow $4.5 billion. **********The United States wants to lower the borrowing limit. Mr. Regan's initial position, officials said, was that the ceiling should be lowered to 300 percent. But some of them said the United States might settle for a 400 percent ceiling.
