https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/busin.main_headline: HOW TO SPOT THE TURNAROUND STOCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; HOW TO SPOT THE TURNAROUND STOCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/busin.body_text: **********IN this age of last-minute debt rescheduling, corporate turnaround artists and Government loan guarantees, it should be no surprise that companies like Chrysler are alive - indeed, are thriving. But who would have thought that Chrysler's stock, written off by analysts as a dog in 1981 after trading as low as $3, would rise from the dead - it closed at $25.50 on Friday - and become one of Wall Street's biggest winners this year? **********Or consider International Harvester, the troubled maker of farm machinery and construction equipment. In August 1981, the prognosis on Wall Street was that Harvester might not survive the year. Negotiations with lenders, however, enabled the company to carry on. Since then, its stock has risen from a low of $2.75 last year to $8.88 now. **********Such increases are, of course, the exception in the stock market. For every Chrysler there is a W.T. Grant that slips into bankruptcy and is never heard of again. But the fact is that many American companies that fall into financial distress each year - including those flirting with insolvency - stage remarkable comebacks that send their stocks soaring. And although spotting these turnaround candidates is a difficult business, buying the shares or bonds of a company on the ropes can be enormously profitable for investors with courage and staying power. **********''Is it profitable? It can be fantastic,'' said Max L. Heine, chairman of Herzog Heine Geduld Inc., a Wall Street firm that invests heavily in the stocks of low-rated or bankrupt companies. **********''It's a high-risk game but an extremely rewarding one if you are right,'' said Martin D. Sass, president and chief executive of the M.D. Sass Investors Services Company, a Wall Street firm that invests in ''fallen angels'' - blue-chips experiencing temporary financial distress. ''It's hazardous, but I know many people who make a business out of it successfully.'' **********How, then, can one spot companies with a good chance of recovery? What steps can an investor take to find turnaround candidates among a ward of corporate basket cases? **********Probably the first thing to realize, investment experts say, is that it is generally safer to back large blue-chip institutions instead of small, lesser-known concerns. That is because the blue chips have greater access to capital and with their large payrolls, they often have the strong political support that might be needed to keep them afloat. **********And, said William H. Pike, portfolio manager of the $220 million Fidelity High-Income Fund, keep in mind that a company is not necessarily in trouble if its sales are falling. In fact, he said, if it is cutting costs faster than its receipts are falling, its financial situation could be improving. **********General Motors is a good example. A year and a half ago, when the American auto industry was in a deep slump, G.M. was busy paring costs in anticipation of a recovery late in 1982. Throughout this period, the auto maker's financial situation was said to be improving - despite flagging auto sales. Financial experts call this relationship between sales and costs the gross margin, and say that one of the best ways to spot a turnaround candidate is to look for a rising gross margin. **********Mr. Pike also suggests studying an ailing company's selling and administrative expenses - known in accounting circles simply as ''S.&A.'' - to see if a recovery is in the cards. S.&A. typically consists of such expendable items as travel and entertainment costs, executive perquisites, office supplies and public relations expenses. These costs should be listed clearly in a company's income statement and it is wise to study the trends, analysts say. If a troubled company is moving to right itself, Mr. Pike says, S.&A. costs should be falling. If they're not, he says, it means management has not done any necessary belt-tightening. **********THERE are other checkpoints of equal import, experts say, such as cash balance. **********Cash, after all, is the vital body fluid that supports operations once lenders cut off credit. If cash balance falls dangerously low, the company could be forced into bankruptcy by a single creditor. But if its cash balance is rising, a troubled company is more likely to be able to pay its bills and sustain itself until recovery sets in. **********Mr. Heine, who has spent his career investing in troubled or bankrupt concerns, including Manville, Braniff and AM International, says he looks almost immediately to the cash balance to size up an investment prospect. He looks at the most recent quarterly report to get the balance and to prior reports to see the trend in cash. **********This policy, part of a broader investment strategy to spot corporate Phoenixes, has paid off handsomely. In late 1981, for example, Mr. Heine paid $300 for AM International bonds with a face value of $1,000 when the company, now reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, had $10 million in cash. Now AM has about $80 million in cash, Mr. Heine says, and its bonds have more than doubled in value, to $700 each. **********Other balance-sheet items can also be telling in spotting companies ripe for a reversal, says Mr. Sass. In particular, he looks for ''obvious strengths'' on a balance sheet such as a debt-to- equity ratio less than the industry average, and a current ratio - the difference between a company's short-term assets and liabilities - that is above industry average. He also prefers to deal in well-known companies that are experiencing what he considers temporary financial distress rather than in companies on the brink. Among his favorites are Kodak, Nike and SmithKline. **********And he advises investors to look for companies with dominant market positions in one or two products because one highly successful product with strong consumer allegiance can pull a company out of the doldrums even when its industry lags. ''Leaders have more control over their customers and prices than followers,'' Mr. Sass said. **********Still another thing to consider is the attitude of institutional investors. If pension funds and insurance companies decide to buy the stock of a troubled concern, it means ''some sophisticated, knowledgeable people think there is hope for the company,'' said Mr. Pike. This is particularly true, he says, if bankers agree to share in a company's equity. Money Manager Portfolios, a Huntington, N.Y.-based publication of H.F. Pearson & Company, tracks institutional holdings and is available at many large public libraries. **********Finally, Mr. Pike and others encourage investors to look at management. If top management is replaced, they say, that could be a good sign because lenders, key to a companys' survival, are in control. But if fraud is uncovered in top management, most agree that a turnaround is a long shot - and that investors should steer clear.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/busin.body_text: **********Mickey Mouse has come a long way since Walt Disney introduced him in 1928: Now, Mickey and his cartoon friends are featured in a line of home computer software being offered by a division of Walt Disney Productions. **********Disney, which almost adopted the advertising slogan ''Mickey Turns Micro,'' is but one of the unlikely companies showing new software at the International Winter Consumer Electronics Show here. Other new providers of software, which are the instructions that run computers, include such well-known entertainment companies as CBS, 20th Century-Fox, Parker Brothers and Thorn EMI. **********The push into software mirrors the broad move into the home video game market in the past year, and with good reason: Just as home video games have been the fastest-growing consumer electronics product in the past two years, so home computers are perceived to be the up and coming products for 1983, as the growth rate of the game market slows. **********Cost of Machines Has Fallen **********Most ''personal'' computers, such as the Apple and I.B.M. machines, sell for more than $1,000 and have been used mostly for business.  But machines selling for less than $1,000, and usually for less than $400, have been doing extraordinarily well in building a market for use in the home. **********Sales of such home computers in the United States rose to about two million units in 1982, more than triple the 1981 sales, according to Future Computing Inc., a market research firm in Richardson, Tex. The total is expected to grow to at least five million this year. **********Until now the home computer market has been a battleground for only five suppliers - Texas Instruments, Commodore International, Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack division, Warner Communications' Atari Inc. and the team of Timex and Sinclair Research Ltd., a British company.  In addition to manufacturing the computers themselves, these companies also sold much of the software. Newcomers to the Market **********That is no longer the case: A host of newcomers introduced lowprice personal computers here. Some, such as Mattel and Japan's Nippon Electric and Matshushita, which markets its products in the United States under the brand name Panasonic, are well known; others are virtually unknown, such as Spectravideo Inc. of New York, which is marketing a computer made in Hong Kong. Its president, Harry Fox, used to market watches made in Hong Kong. **********It will be difficult for the newcomers to catch up. Texas Instruments and Commodore International are already shipping more than 100,000 machines a month, meaning they can get production costs way down. They also have huge catalogues of software. **********The newcomers' entry is likely to worsen the price war. Some analysts say supply will exceed demand this year, leading to sharply reduced prices and profits. **********The home computer market has already broken into three segments: **********- Computers selling for $100 or less, used basically to learn about programming. Timex and Sinclair have been the only companies in this field until now. Timex has sold more than 500,000 of its $100 computers since introducing them last summer. **********- Computers selling for $150 to $400, typified by the Texas Instruments 99/ 4A and the Commodore VIC20, and used mainly for games and educational purposes. **********- Business-oriented computers, a category that is growing as the machines decline in price. The Commodore 64, which cost $600, has many of the capabilities of the Apple, which costs nearly twice as much. By the end of the year, Apple and I.B.M., which exhibited at the show for the first time, are expected to introduce computers selling for less than $1,000. Aggressive Pair of Leaders **********The current leaders in the low end of the market are Texas Instruments and Commodore, and they are expanding aggressively.  Texas Instruments introduced here a small portable computer and a $100 machine to learn programming. ''We designed this as a Timex killer,'' said Donald P. Bynum, manager of Texas Instruments' personal computer division. And Commodore introduced two computers - a tiny briefcase-size machine and a larger but still portable computer selling for less than $1,000. **********For its part Timex, whose traditional turf is being invaded by Texas Instruments, countered by going into T.I.'s marketplace with a more powerful computer selling for $200. **********Falling behind are Radio Shack and Atari, whose machines are considered somewhat high priced and outdated. In particular, Atari, which once led the whole market, is sorely in need of a replacement for its Atari 400, whose flat keyboard has proved unpopular. ''Until they get something to replace the 400, they're going to be left in the dust,'' said Egil Juliussen, chairman of the board of Future Computing. Software as Source of Profits **********With the drop in prices for basic computers, which consist of a keyboard with electronic circuits, the profits for both manufacturers and retailers will come increasingly from the software, and from peripheral equipment such as printers, game paddles and data storage devices that attach to the main computer. **********Software already accounts for 25 percent of total sales and peripherals for 50 percent, according to Future Computing. The software share is expected to grow dramatically in the years ahead. **********This explains the entry of CBS, Walt Disney and other companies, as well as companies that have specialized in home video games, such as Activision Inc. and Imagic Inc. **********The movement of the video game software companies into computer software illustrates what many in the industry think will happen - the video game will be replaced by the more versatile home computer.  Home computers, analysts argue, can also be used to play games, but they do other things as well, and they cost little more than the game machines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/world.main_headline: FRENCH SAY NEW RAPID REACTION FORCE IS TO STOP THRUST INTO EUROPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/world.print_headline: FRENCH SAY NEW RAPID REACTION FORCE IS TO STOP THRUST INTO EUROPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/world.body_text: **********The French Defense Minister revealed details of the country's new rapid reaction force today.  The decision to create this 47,000-man mobile intervention force was announced in April when the Government unveiled a five-year military spending program. In a long interview with Le Monde, Defense Minister Charles Hernu said the force's principal mission would be to stop, in cooperation with other allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, ''an armored thrust'' into Western Europe outside France's own frontiers. **********In addition, Mr. Hernu said he was sending 100 extra tanks to reinforce the three French armored divisions stationed around Baden-Baden in southeastern West Germany. He also announced the redeployment of sections of the First French Army so that it will be better placed to fight an attack against northern France through central Germany, where the bulk of the United States' NATO forces are stationed. Integrated Command Is Rejected **********Mr. Hernu insisted there could be no question of the rapid reaction force, or any other part of the French armed forces, being placed back under NATO's integrated command, which France left in 1968.  Indeed, he said the fact that the force would remain exclusively under French control made it more effective as a deterrent, presumably because an adversary could not predict for certain where or whether it would be used. **********Mr. Hernu acknowledged, however, that France would need to make contingency plans with other NATO commanders for the force's possible deployment. ''Of course, this eventuality supposes preparation with our allies,'' he said. **********In addition to infantry, the new rapid reaction force is to include an armored division, a special force of 140 antitank helicopters and an infantry regiment trained in antitank warfare. ''It will thus be a large unit capable of opposing the armored thrust of an aggressor and engaging defensive combat wherever we decide,'' the Defense Minister said. **********Ever since the announcement of the plans for the rapid reaction force, officials and military experts have been saying it implies a greater willingness to fight a forward defense of Europe in West Germany and abandonment of Charles de Gaulle's strategy of trying to defend France at its frontiers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/world.main_headline: Soviet Scientists Call Missile Defense Plan By U.S. an Illusion
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/world.print_headline: Soviet Scientists Call Missile Defense Plan By U.S. an Illusion
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/world.body_text: **********Soviet scientists said today that President Reagan's plan for an effective defense against nuclear attack was an illusion. **********An appeal by 244 scientists, published by the press agency Tass, said: ''Proceeding from the understanding of the basic nature of nuclear weapons, we declare in all responsibility that there is no effective defensive means in nuclear war and their creation is not practicably possible. **********''The attempt at creating so-called defensive weapons against the strategic nuclear force of the other side will inevitably grow into the emergence of a new element strengthening the American firststrike potential. By his statement the President is creating a most dangerous illusion that may turn into an even more threatening spiral of the arms race.'' **********In a speech on March 23, Mr. Reagan called on scientists to create the means to remove the threat of nuclear attack by destroying incoming missiles through high-technology weapons, possibly including space-based and laser devices. The idea has been termed impracticable by some Western scientists, **********Among the Soviet signers were Nikolai G. Basov, laser specialist; Pyotr L. Kapitsa, physicist; Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, cardiologist; Viktor A. Ambartsumyan, astrophysicist; Georgi A. Arbatov, specialist on the United States, and Bruno Pontecorvo, the Italian-born physicist who has been living in the Soviet Union since 1950.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/world.main_headline: ARENS SAYS ISRAEL WILL RESIST A WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/world.print_headline: ARENS SAYS ISRAEL WILL RESIST A WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Moshe Arens said today that Israel would resist being drawn into battle with Syria.  ''They will certainly not scare us,'' Mr. Arens said in a speech in Tel Aviv. ''We will not be dragged into any hostilities. We will not lose our nerve.'' He added: ''We can sit quietly, watch events and reach a correct assessment. We cannot be provoked.'' **********The pledge of firm restraint followed a pattern of public and private comments by Israeli officials in recent days as tension has mounted over the military situation along the Israeli-Syrian ceasefire line in eastern Lebanon. **********Israeli Army Reported on Alert **********The Israeli Army was reported today to be in a state of alert after the Syrians began maneuvers near Israeli lines. The maneuvers, officials said, could easily develop into an attack. They followed two reported incidents earlier in the week of Syrian missiles' being fired at an Israeli helicopter and a reconnaissance jet over the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley. Neither aircraft was hit, the Israelis said. **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin briefed leaders of the opposition Labor Party on the situation.  Despite the rumblings of war, Defense Minister Arens sounded a note of calm; he welcomed a comment from the Syrian Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Mustafa Tlas, that Syrian measures were purely defensive. **********''I hope that this is correct,'' Mr. Arens said, ''and if it is correct, this is good news.'' Apprehension and Uncertainty **********Still, there was apprehension and uncertainty here about Syrian intentions. Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said: ''We hope that Syria will not commit a terrible mistake. We are watching carefully this situation, and we are taking the necessary measures.'' **********The jittery mood of the army was indicated by an increased monitoring, by the military censor, of foreign correspondents' incoming and outgoing telex communications. The censor blocked the receipt by the Jerusalem bureau of The New York Times of a message from The Times's foreign desk reporting the contents of a dispatch from Beirut by The Associated Press on waves of Israeli tank transporters clogging the roads from Israel into Lebanon. Only after the censor was persuaded, in a protracted argument, that the bureau was receiving the message, not sending it, did he clear the telex line and allow it to be conveyed. **********Correspondents who tried to report from Israel on the army's movements in the north were told by the censor that they would not be allowed to do so. Theory of Brinkmanship **********One theory among officials in Jerusalem held that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria was engaging in a familiar game of brinkmanship to strengthen his position in negotiations with Lebanon on a possible pullout of Syrian and Palestinian forces. **********Since Israel and Lebanon signed their security agreement providing for an Israeli withdrawal, Syria has denounced the accord and has pledged to prevent it from being put into effect. Israel has said it would withdraw its forces only as Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization withdraw theirs. **********But many officials here believe that Mr. Assad might ultimately agree on a pullout if he receives extensive security arrangements in Lebanon, money from Saudi Arabia and perhaps political concessions from the United States, such as a pledge to press Israel to give up the Golan Heights, which it captured from Syria in the 1967 war. **********The atmosphere on the eastern Syrian-Israeli front two days ago was considerably more relaxed than the tense mood on the political front in Jerusalem. No Flak Jackets or Helmets **********While officials were issuing warnings, soldiers at Israeli outposts were calling and waving to their Syrian counterparts. Troops on both sides were going around in full view of the others without flak jackets or helmets, sometimes even without weapons. **********Some Israeli soldiers asserted that the only tension was in the newspapers, and one officer said that soon after he arrived two weeks ago he arranged to call home to reassure his family that things were calmer than they appeared on television. **********Nevertheless, the Israelis' stated approach is to fortify positions in case the Syrians attack. There has been no hint, in any public or private statements, that Israel plans to initiate an attack on the Syrians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/busin.print_headline: FINAL WORD; PSYCHIC INSECURITY AND QUARTER-POINT SPREADS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/busin.body_text: **********I know people who spend all their time ''putting their money to work.'' They run from bank to bank - putting money in, taking it out - all to earn higher interest. Their days are consumed with following rates as investors' days are filled with following stocks and bettors' with horses. **********I suppose this is a good thing: Even ''the little guys'' (those with $2,500 to fool with) have a chance to make money on their money. But there seem to be a few problems: **********1. Psychic insecurity: A new neurosis seems to be developing.  People wonder if they are earning every possible penny on their pittance. Ads are scanned each day, banks called and visited, friends and relatives consulted. I never thought I'd regret the passing of the 5 percent rate, but the worried faces of people at the bank have given me second thoughts. **********2. Fine Print Shock: Customers find high rates are not all they are cracked up to be. Charges and penalties are levied where they never were before. Caveat emptor, always a bit of a joke in a society where the growth of consumer information never kept up with the increase in commodities, seems emptier of substance than before. **********3. Social loss: The personal waste of time and energy involved in shopping for the extra quarter point of interest is compounded by the social loss. There is less time for other things, for people. What we didn't need was a reinforcement of the already ubiquitious greed or of the tendency to think only of accumulation. **********4. Problems at banks: Banks seem to be busier than ever, but more are failing than at any time since the Depression. Bankers, who pay lip service to competition and deregulation, say in the next breath that they pay out more in interest than they should. **********5. Fruits of Success Syndrome: Many people busily running from bank to bank don't need that extra one-quarter percent - and don't know what to do with it once they have it. Worse, it creates larger tax burdens for them. So they spend the little energy left in costly tax avoidance strategy sessions with a multiplying army of ''advisers'' seeking ways (let us be plain) to cheat the Government, legally, illegally, or ''by not saying anything.'' The only economic growth is in the underground economy. **********6. Growth of nonproductive activity: There is another area of growth, in the numbers of bankers, lawyers, accountants, brokers - of whom we had already more than enough. So far as is known, not one new factory or useful product or service has been developed from this activity. Money is just being moved around. **********7. Growth of cynicism, skepticism and the ''you can't win'' attitude: Some pressures for deregulation came from consumer groups wanting the middle class to have the investment opportunities of the top 2 percent. But the middle class can't afford the tax avoidance specialists of the rich. So it ends up a bit richer, more than a bit harried and more envious. **********When I see former hippie and radical friends shopping for interest and avoiding taxes (not this time from principle), I grow sad.  ''Everyone else does it,'' says one, or ''The Government wastes money, I might as well spend it on myself.'' **********What has happened to the idealism of the 60's? One thing is that more energy goes into getting more. It isn't just bank deregulation.  And it isn't just President Reagan. In fact, deregulation was started by President Carter. His intentions were doubtless benign.  And a little of this is good. But, as usual, it's gone beyond reason. Maybe it's all a plot to get us to trivialize our lives even more. **********St. Thomas would have called all of this usury. Today, we find even the Vatican involved in banking scandals. Perhaps it is time for Christ to chase the money-lenders out of the temple again. The problem is that if He came they'd probably try to sell Him a new money market account with access to his funds 24 hours a day, at high rates, F.D.I.C. insured, with a minimum investment of $2,500 plus a $25 premium or an iron. Given such a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity He might be tempted. Except that He probably won't have the $2,500.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/world.body_text: **********Some critics of Reagan Administration policy toward El Salvador say they see very strong analogies between the United States involvement in the guerrilla war here and the American role in Vietnam. **********Some Administration officials, rejecting that comparison, argue that there are virtually no parallels between the two wars. **********A visit to the country and interviews here and in Washington indicate that there are, without much doubt, some similarities between the two wars and between the policies pursued and the problems encountered by United States officials in the two conflicts. There are also, without much doubt, some significant differences. **********Perhaps the most striking analogy between the experiences in Vietnam and El Salvador has little to do with the situations that prevailed on the ground in both countries. Instead, it involves the world view and political instincts of policy makers in Washington. **********United States officials in the 1960's initially viewed the war in South Vietnam as a challenge originating in Peking and Moscow, and the more direct support of the Vietcong from North Vietnam as international aggression. Soviet Union Blamed **********In much the same spirit, early in his Administration President Reagan said: ''The Soviet Union underlies all the unrest that is going on. If they weren't engaged in this game of dominoes, there wouldn't be any hot spots in the world.'' His first Secretary of State, Alexander M. Haig Jr., said the problem in El Salvador ''is external intervention in the internal affairs of a sovereign nation in this hemisphere - nothing more, nothing less.'' **********Another apparent similarity grows from the fact that in both situations the United States began by trying to fight a proxy war and assume an advisory role. **********In this connection, both the South Vietnamese Government of 1961 and the Salvadoran Government of 1980 did not seem to many critics to be the most suitable instruments or proxies with which to wage a war. **********In Vietnam much of the American advice was not taken. When the advice was taken it usually involved decisions that were the least painful politically and socially for the South Vietnamese ruling elite. Loyalty Was First Priority **********One example involved military promotion policy. For more than a decade a series of Governments in Saigon fought a stubborn and successful battle against United States pressure that selections of commanders be based on military merit. **********The successive South Vietnamese Governments could grasp the argument but would not agree with the priority. To them the first priority always remained the political loyalty and reliability of division and corps commanders to the leaders in Saigon. **********In the Vietnam War some of the leading thinkers on counterinsurgency used to say the early stages of a guerrilla war tend to skew priorities. The leader of the embattled nation knows that the fledgling guerrilla army cannot storm the presidential palace and depose him. But his own army clearly can. The more competent a commander is militarily, the less attractive he may seem to the political leader. **********The final collapse of South Vietnam in 1975 began when an incompetent, but politically loyal, division commander panicked and began a headlong retreat from the Central Highlands to the coast. **********''You could argue,'' said an official who served in Vietnam, ''that, in the end, promotion policy lost the war.''  Promotion by Politics **********Until recently, at least, it seemed to some United States officials involved in El Salvador's guerrilla war that a clear parallel existed here. **********El Salvador's small army had fewer than 500 commissioned officers until recently. It also had, a United States expert said, ''an automatic promotion policy.'' **********There was also a tendency much like that in Vietnam to give key command jobs to officers on the basis of political reliability rather than merit, according to United States analysts. **********There have recently been some signals in El Salvador that a more wholesome policy on military promotions may be evolving. But even optimists tend to agree that it is too soon to declare that a fundamental change for the better is under way. **********A variety of analysts agree that while Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova, who became the Defense Minister this spring, has been more receptive than his predecessor to advice on tactics and humane treatment of civilians by the army, little change has been made among unit commanders.   Resisting U.S. Advice **********Until recently, another similarity seemed to involve other forms of military and political advice. **********The South Vietnamese Army was in many ways a very competent military organization. But much of the time it resisted adopting the tactics and aggressive spirit that United States advisers pleaded for. A United States officer who served in Vietnam and El Salvador recalled what he bitterly called Vietnamese ''search and evade'' missions, which substituted for search- and-destroy operations. **********As late as this spring, the situation in El Salvador seemed to be similar. United States advisers told visitors that many Salvadorans were fighting a ''9 to 5, five day a week war,'' and giving up the night hours to the guerrillas. **********But since early summer there seems to have been a change, close to dramatic, in the Salvadoran willingness to accept military tactical advice.   Elections Considered Important **********Another striking parallel between Vietnam-era officials in Washington and Reagan Administration officials involves a strong and persistent belief that the holding of elections in the proxy nation, and the creation of what they regard as a legitimate government, will cripple the rebel movement.  Some experts in counterinsurgency are dubious about the validity of this premise. In some third world nations, various measures such as stamping of identity cards at polling places tend to coerce people to vote. But elections do not seem to coerce guerrillas. After the March 1982 elections in El Salvador, the leftist guerrillas regrouped and by October were stronger than ever. **********Many United States officials again seem to believe that presidential elections in El Salvador, most likely to occur early next year, will significantly affect the ability and persistence of the leftist coalition. **********There seems to be another analogy in the reluctance of United States officials, particularly those far away in Washington, to apply strong pressure on the host countries when they ignore United States advice or pursue what the Washington officials consider to be self-destructive policies.   Withdrawal Not an Option **********United States officials sometimes did apply heavy pressure in Vietnam but would not press their point of view to a serious confrontation. ''Suppose they ask us to leave?'' officials sometimes asked. **********The ultimate sanction of United States withdrawal was regarded as unthinkable and not a serious option. Much the same situation seems to prevail in El Salvador, according to officials here and in Washington. **********While there seems to be more willingness here recently to accept purely military advice, there has been less inclination by the Salvadoran authorities to adopt social policies repugnant to the economic oligarchy, the upper middle class and the army. And United States pressure to do so has been timid. **********Despite promises to see justice done in the cases of eight Americans slain here, almost certainly by right-wing, Government-controlled gunmen, El Salvador has not brought anyone to trial. It is not thought likely that if trials are finally held officers who ordered the killings will be tried.   Human Rights an Issue **********More important to the course of the war is the continuing abuse of human rights involving Salvadoran civilians. **********Salvadoran church officials believe that at least 40,000 civilians have been killed since late 1979 and that the great majority were the victims of right- wing ''death squads.'' **********Although officials in Washington put the figure much lower, the former United States Ambassador here, Deane R. Hinton, put the death total at 30,000 in a speech in San Salvador this year. **********In that speech Mr. Hinton warned that the Government's behavior was hurting the war effort. He said the ''gorillas'' of the right-wing ''Mafia'' were destroying El Salvador as surely as the left-wing guerrillas in the mountains. **********Although Mr. Hinton's speech had been cleared by officials in the State Department, it was repudiated by White House officials as too strong and unsuitable in its nearly anguished call for an end to official thuggery.   Distance Is Emphasized **********Moreover, a variety of experts believe that the statutory requirement that President Reagan certify every 180 days that El Salvador is making progress in improving human rights, disciplining its security forces and in carrying out land redistribution and other social changes has tended to give ''Salvador the leverage, not us.'' **********As certification has routinely followed cerification, it seems to have become apparent to Salvadoran officials that only cosmetic measures are required on their part. Much the same situation applied in Vietnam, although the South Vietnamese authorities and security forces never showed the same callousness that prevails here. **********Reagan Administration officials who argue that there is almost no analogy between the two crises tend to emphasize heavily an argument that Vietnam was very distant and El Salvador is very close to the United States and that El Salvador more clearly represents a vital United States interest. **********Among the differences between the two conflicts, the intensity of combat stands out. The troops of North Vietnam and of main force Vietcong units were among the best assault infantrymen in the world. They had an awesome willingness to climb over barbed wire under the muzzles of Government machine guns. The Salvadoran rebels are apparently not in the same league.   Fighting Is Less Intense **********Moreover, the disparity in firepower, whether used discriminately or indiscriminately, in the two wars is hard to exaggerate. It may be that more steel and powder was expended in a day or two in Vietnam than in the entire Salvadoran conflict. This, some American experts think, may be to the good. **********But it also seems to be one expression of a vast difference in mood and confidence on the part of policy makers in Washington. President Kennedy met little domestic opposition when he undertook a program of ''combat support'' in South Vietnam that soon had 16,000 advisers actually living and fighting with Vietnamese forces. **********And the Vietnam War began on a euphoric, ''we don't lose'' mood. That kind of optimism seems less evident today. If policy makers in Washington feel certain that they can win in El Salvador, few of them explicitly say so. **********President Johnson began direct United States involvement in Vietnam with a 98-to-2 vote of confidence from the Senate. **********President Reagan has had no such blank check, but he has not seemed to want a blank check. The Administration's moves here have been on a much smaller scale than its vigorous policy statements might indicate. **********Although Vietnam-era officials have often been accused of waging the Vietnam War halfheartedly and too cautiously, they seem in retrospect much more aggressive in their policies than carefully proscribed efforts in El Salvador, where there is no combat support, no field advisers and little military aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The Celanese Corporation said it would merge its three United States fiber divisions in a streamlining move at the company's division offices here. The Celanese Fibers Company, Fiber Industries Inc. and the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company, which employ about 10,000 people, are joining to form the Celanese Fibers Operations. **********There are about 1,400 employees at Celanese's offices in Charlotte. Some jobs will be eliminated, but Celanese did not say how many. **********The action follows the elimination of about 400 salaried jobs last summer at Fiber Industries Inc., which the company attributed to poor business conditions. Demand for polyester fiber, the division's main product, has improved but continues to suffer from consumer preference for clothing made with natural fibers, a chemical industry analyst in New York said. Celanese lost $34 million on sales of $3.1 billion in 1981. Synthetic fibers provide half the company's sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Inventories held by American businesses rose seven- tenths of 1 percent in September, and sales jumped 1.5 percent, the Commerce Department reported today. **********The closely watched inventory-to- sales ratio edged down to 1.35 in September, from 1.36 in August. The September level, which matched the record low set in June, ''bodes very well for future increases in production,'' said Robert Ortner, the department's chief economist. **********The inventory-to-sales ratio measures the number of months it takes to sell inventories at the month's sales pace. A low ratio during a period of economic recovery often indicates that factory production would have to increase to keep up with orders. **********The $3.39 billion increase in stocks was the third consecutive monthly rise. It brought the total value of inventories held by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers to $513.82 billion, the Commerce Department said. Sales during the month grew by $5.59 billion, to $380.03 billion. **********As consumer buying plunged during the recession that ended last November, the nation's businesses slashed their production and the amount of their stocks. During the current recovery, production and hiring have risen to meet growing demand, but inventories have not risen as quickly as sales.   Strengthening Since July **********The seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in inventories in September followed gains of nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, a revised figure issued today, and six-hundredths of 1 percent in July. The August increase had previously been reported as 1.2 percent. **********Mr. Ortner said the three monthly gains ''reflect the early stage of a typical business cycle expansion.'' But he added that the process of restocking ''has a considerable way to go,'' given the sales pace. **********Michael Evans of Evans Economics Inc. said he does not see ''a great amount of enthusiasm'' on the part of the business community to build the inventory-to-sales ratio back up. **********''I think for a while we will see people are going to be very cautious'' and it is ''probably going to take them a year or so until they feel comfortable pushing this back to level of before,'' he said. **********Trend to Lean Inventories **********Bill Dunkelberg, a spokesman for the National Federation of Independent Business, said that although inventory investment is likely to continue, companies may try to keep the inventory-to-sales ratio lower than in past recoveries. He said many companies are experimenting with techniques to reduce inventories, finding it less profitable to hold large stocks because of the high cost of financing them. **********The September inventory rise included a 1.2 percent gain for retailers, 0.6 percent for wholesalers and 0.4 percent for manufacturers. **********The sales rise included a 1.3 percent increase for retailers, 1.4 percent for wholesalers and 1.7 percent for manufacturers. Over all, sales have been up in six of the past seven months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/world.main_headline: RUSSIANS LEARN THERE IS A WAR ON IN AFGHANISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/world.print_headline: RUSSIANS LEARN THERE IS A WAR ON IN AFGHANISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/world.body_text: **********Soviet citizens accustomed to reading about their soldiers distributing rice or helping build a new life in Afghanistan have begun to learn that their men in the ''limited contingent'' there are facing hardships, danger and even death. **********A number of articles, particularly in February, have marked a shift in press coverage from the previous sparse diet of glowing accounts.  Instead, the public has been offered reports on a lieutenant shot dead in an ambush, on infantrymen feasting on knishes in the shadow of the armored personnel carrier on the eve of a hazardous mission, on the Islamic insurgents plunging Kabul into darkness by sabotaging power lines, on Russian nurses stranded in dangerous outposts, or on a popular rock group refusing to travel to distant bases. **********The coverage is still remote from anything resembling a credible picture of what the soldiers are doing in Afghanistan or why. The Soviet force is described only as doing its ''international duty'' against counterrevolutionaries waging an ''undeclared war'' at the behest of the United States, China, Pakistan and Egypt. Nothing is published about the size of the force, the operations it conducts, the scope of the opposition or the casualties. **********Better Feeling for Conditions **********The difference has been in an attempt to give some feeling for the conditions and dangers of Afghanistan, with sweltering lowlands and freezing mountain passes, stalking rebels, loneliness, nostalgia and the other travails of men in combat far from home. **********The trade union daily Trud, for example, depicted the heroic death of a young infantry lieutenant and aspiring poet, killed while trying to hold off guerrillas. Krasnaya Zvezda, the armed forces daily, wrote of a decorated sergeant preparing to lead a column through three rebel-infested provinces. **********These and other soldiers are shown, if not in combat roles, at least in military roles - as infantrymen, sappers, sentries. And the terms used seem to echo military activities, with ''counterrevolutionaries'' giving way to ''basmachi.'' a term used in the 1920's for anti-Soviet guerrillas in Central Asia, or ''dushman,'' the Afghan word for insurgent. **********Some Soviet press accounts, though disparaging the Afghan rebels' claim to uphold Islam, have even cited their term for Soviet soldiers - ''nevernye,'' meaning ''infidels.'' **********The unusual expansion of Soviet press coverage followed the ascendancy to power of Yuri V. Andropov, and Western diplomats suggest that it may reflect the wishes of the military establishment, eager to receive some credit for a major and costly operation. **********According to Western estimates, more than 100,000 Soviet soldiers have been in Afghanistan for more than three years now, and the diplomats surmise that they, their relatives and the military in general must be generating pressure for recognition of their role. **********''The military must chafe at having to read only about troops planting flowers down there,'' said a diplomat who follows Afghan affairs. ''They simply cannot like that image.'' Catching Up With Western Radio **********He said the more candid reporting may also have been caused by the need to counter rumors and Western radio broadcasts.  A report in Izvestia on Feb. 24 about three bomb explosions in Kabul, for example, merely acknowledged incidents already reported by Western radio stations and made a point of denying that Soviet saboteurs could be responsible, a rumor possibly afoot in Kabul. **********The expanded coverage does not seem to reflect any great curiosity about the war among the Soviet populace in general. The war rarely comes up in conversations among Russians, and few Russians in meetings with Westerners display much interest in learning what is being reported abroad. Some diplomats think that military frustration with this apathy may lie behind efforts to publicize the Afghan operation. **********An example was Trud's account of the death of Lieut. Aleksandr I.  Stovba. Like most Soviet accounts about military activities, Trud said Lieutenant Stovba had been on a training mission, and the paper used quotation marks around the words ''attack'' and ''defense'' as if to suggest maneuvers. **********In the story, the detachment was ambushed in a gorge, and the lieutenant confronted the attackers alone after having ordered his men to seek safety. **********The account included the ''zing, zing'' of bullets and described how the lieutenant was hit in an arm, the stomach and finally his heart while his comrades clambered up cliffs to his aid. **********The story was unusual not only in the account of a soldier's death, of which the press has acknowledged only about half a dozen, but in the report of the posthumous honors accorded the lieutenant in his hometown of Dneprodzerzhinsk, the Ukrainian steel center. Lieutenant's Family Background **********Trud said Lieutenant Stovba's grandfather had fought against the original ''basmachi'' in Central Asia, and his father had served in World War II in a Red Army unit that drove the Germans from the Soviet Union to Vienna. **********On Sunday, Krasnaya Zvezda, the armed forces newspaper, told about three mines being set off in Kabul on the eve of Soviet Army Day, which falls on Feb. 23, and about calls for a general strike that the paper said went unheeded. It said that guerrillas had placed the mines in areas where Soviet soldiers were not likely to be to insure that the casualties would be Afghan civilians. **********''It was a primitive scheme,'' the paper said. ''intended to set Afghans against the Soviet people. It was as if they said, 'Behold, countrymen, the Russians are celebrating while you are mourning your dead, victims of the 'holy war against the infidels.' '' **********Describing Kabul, the paper cast unusual light on the Soviet military presence. On the streets, it said, brightly colored buses and trucks mingle with Soviet jeeps, while a bridge across the Kabul River is manned by the police and Soviet soldiers. The paper spoke of dangers outside Kabul - mines uncovered by Soviet patrols, a sergeant preparing for dangerous convoy duty. **********Among the more unusual press reports was one about the visit of the Blue Guitars, a Moscow rock group. Army officers complained in a letter to the editor that not only did the group produce noise with no ideological content, but it kept complaining about accommodations, and, under various pretexts, refused to visit remote and presumably dangerous outposts. **********A followup to the letter said the Blue Guitars had conceded their wrongdoing and had been penalized by being barred from foreign tours and from appearing in Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.main_headline: MRS. GANDHI LOSES GRIP ON 2 STATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.print_headline: MRS. GANDHI LOSES GRIP ON 2 STATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi suffered a major political defeat today when her Congress Party lost control of two southern states it had dominated since India became independent in 1947. **********Opposition parties swept to stunning victories in legislative elections held on Wednesday in Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, the only states in India where the Congress Party had not previously been defeated. **********An election was also held in the northeastern state of Tripura, where Gandhi nominees failed in their effort to oust a coalition of leftist parties. **********While the outcome in the three state elections was a jolt to Mrs.  Gandhi's prestige, her party still controls 15 of India's 22 states, and it has a two-thirds majority in the national Parliament. But the setbacks led to some speculation that she might decide to call a general election before it is due in January 1985. **********The setbacks appeared to be especially stinging since Mrs. Gandhi campaigned heavily in both Andhra Pradesh and neighboring Karnataka, declaring that only a national party like hers could adequately tackle national and regional problems. She was elected to Parliament from a district in Andhra Pradesh in 1980, when she was returned to power with her large majority in Parliament. **********Control of the Andhra Pradesh legislature was won by a seven-monthold party led by a popular film actor, Nandamuri Taraka Rama Rao. Mr. Rao campaigned on pledges to clean up public life and restore the honor of the Telegus, as the people of Andhra Pradesh are known. He charged that Mrs. Gandhi interfered too much in local affairs and appointed corrupt politicians to powerful posts. Chief Minister Resigns **********Late tonight it was already clear that his Telegu Nation Party had won a majority in the 294-seat legislature, capturing at least 150 seats, while the Prime Minister's followers had about 40. In the previous house, the Congress Party had 250 members. **********In Karnataka, no single party appeared to have won an outright majority in the 224-seat legislature. But Gundu Rao, the Congress Party Chief Minister, resigned after he lost his race for a legislative seat. At least five of Mr. Rao's Cabinet colleagues also lost. **********With 215 of the 224 races decided, Gandhi candidates had won 76, while 98 had been captured by an opposition alliance made up of the Janata Party of former Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai, two Communist parties and a regional group. The National People's Party of former Foreign Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee took 18 seats, and the 23 others were won by independents and rebel Congress Party candidates. **********Adding to the bitterness of the Congress Party defeat in Andhra Pradesh was the victory of three nominees of a group led by Maneka Gandhi, the Prime Minister's rebellious daughter-in-law. **********Maneka Gandhi, whose husband, Sanjay, was killed in a plane crash in 1980, was ordered to leave the Prime Minister's official residence last spring after she participated in a convention of rebels in the ruling Congress Party. She was not a candidate in the elections, which marked her party's debut in Indian politics. Mrs. Gandhi and Son Campaigned **********Her candidates were aligned with Mr. Rao, who allotted them five seats, apparently to embarrass the Prime Minister and her other son, Rajiv Gandhi, who also campaigned. But Mr. Gandhi, a 38-year-old former airline pilot and Member of Parliament who is regarded as his mother's closest adviser, failed to make much of an impression in the campaign, while his sister-in-law drew large crowds. **********As a result of the elections, Andhra Pradesh will become the second southern state to be ruled by a successful film actor who has moved into politics. An actor named M.G. Ramachandran heads the administration in the neighboring state of Tamil Nadu. **********Mr. Rao is a 59-year-old veteran of 300 films and is revered by some of his fans as a Hindu god. In 1981 the villagers of Pumuru built a temple and installed an image of the actor as their chosen deity. In his films he has often portrayed Hindu gods; other roles have included those of honest, poor men and patriots. **********In his campaign he traveled in a sturdy van, equipped with loudspeakers, microphones and floodlights, and he spoke on street corners and at mass rallies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/busin.body_text: **********A Federal court, in a move that may mean a $900 million refund for natural gas suppliers and consumers, threw out a Government pricing regulation today. **********The ruling by the United States Court of Appeals here was a defeat for natural gas producers and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. **********Rachelle Patterson, a representative of the agency, said it had not decided whether to appeal the decision. **********The three-judge appellate panel threw out a rule that had been adopted by the F.E.R.C. under the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978. The rule established a new approach for measuring the energy content of natural gas. **********The commission's formula required that energy content be measured under so-called ''dry'' conditions for gas delivery instead of ''wet'' conditions in which the gas is saturated with water vapor. The rule made the wellhead price of natural gas higher than it was under the old system. **********The judges said today: ''We find the commission's dry rule to be inconsistent with the (1978 law's) language, structure and legislative history. Although one of the purposes of the act was to increase the financial incentives for producing various types of new gas, Congress did not intend for the commission to raise the effective wellhead price of gas as much as possible.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.main_headline: PANAMANIAN URGES REAGAN PANEL TO SEEK NEGOTIATIONS FOR REAGAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.print_headline: PANAMANIAN URGES REAGAN PANEL TO SEEK NEGOTIATIONS FOR REAGAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.body_text: **********President Ricardo de la Espriella of Panama told members of President Reagan's commission on Central America today that the solution to the region's political, economic and social problems must come through negotiations. **********''The real solution to these problems must be accomplished through dialogue and negotiations, as becomes civilized nations in a world that has to walk the path of progress and universal peace,'' Mr. de la Espriella said. **********The Panamanian President made his remarks to nine members of the 12- member commission. Panama is the first stop in the delegation's weeklong visit to meet with officials from six Central American countries before it prepares its final report in January. **********President Reagan created the commission in July in response to Congressional criticism that the Administration is relying too much on a military solution in Central America. It is charged with developing a long-term approach to United States policy in Central America.   Solution Based on 'Sovereignty' **********Henry A. Kissinger, the head of the commission, told Mr. de la Espriella that the United States sought solutions ''based on respect for the sovereignty of countries.'' The commission, Mr.  Kissinger said, ''doesn't want a program manufactured in the United States, and hopes that the people and governments of Central America will feel we have made a contribution to a future only they can change.'' **********Mr. de la Espriella told the commission that it was becoming increasingly difficult to seclude Panama from the regional crisis. He noted that the country's high unemployment rate aggravated Panama's social problems and ''if not promptly solved could derive into social unrest.'' **********Mr. de la Espriella has been active in the so-called Contadora group, a body of four Latin American countries that has been attempting to bring about a negotiated settlement to the Central American conflicts. **********The group, comprised of Panama, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela, is concerned that the hostilities in El Salvador and between Honduras and Nicaragua will spread to other Latin American countries. **********After meeting with Mr. de la Espriella, the commission members spent the rest of their day meeting with other Panamanian political officials.
