About 4,000 work at its Amsterdam plants. Coleco, based in West Hartford, Conn., produces the Adam home computer system, the Cabbage Patch Kids dolls and other toys. Mr. Handel emphasized that the layoffs are not a result of any financial troubles. ''It's an annual event that we've been doing for 20 years,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.body_text: **********-based airline company, announced yesterday that it had ordered 20 newly developed, short-haul jets for $300 million from British Aerospace to compete more effectively in the West Coast market. **********Paul C. Barkley, president and chief operating officer of PSA, the parent company of Pacific Southwest Airlines, said in an interview that the plane would not only strenghten PSA's position on hard-fought California routes but would also reduce fuel costs. **********PSA offers ''no frill'' flights and emphasizes keeping its costs low. It and other smaller carriers are engaged in an intense battle with the full-service United Airlines, which has increased flights in large markets such as Los Angeles and San Francisco, between which two million passengers flew last year. Full- service carriers offer drinks, meals and other amenities not usually provided by their no-frills competitors, which charge less for tickets. **********Four-Engine Craft **********The new plane, the BAe 146-200, has four engines that are considered among the quietest and most fuel efficient. It is thus well suited for some of the airports in suburban communities, such as Long Beach, Calif., which have strict noise restrictions and are part of PSA's route system. The first eight aircraft will be delivered in 1984 and the remainder in 1985. PSA has an option on 25 more aircraft. **********Mr. Barkley said the first 10 aircraft, each of which will seat 100 passengers, would be leased from British Aerospace. He said the company expected to receive British export financing to purchase the remaining 10. PSA estimated that the cost of the total order, including lease charges, spare parts and engines, would be about $300 million. **********Leslie Tuck, president of British Aerospace Inc., the American subsidiary of the British company, said in an interview that the order was a major coup for the company and would greatly aid it in marketing the plane to other airlines. **********'A Very Large Order for Us' **********''It's a very large order for us,'' he said. ''Its the largest civilian order that we have had for some time.'' **********The plane is already being flown by four other airlines in the United States, including Air Wisconsin, and is in service in Europe and Africa. Total orders for the plane stand at 38, and there are options to purchase 45 more. **********Mr. Barkley estimated that the new planes burned about 600 gallons of fuel an hour, compared with the Boeing 727-200's 1,550 gallons and the McDonnell Douglas Super 80's 1,100 gallons. **********PSA plans to phase out its 727's next year. According to Mr. Barkley, that would give PSA one of the most fuel-efficient fleets in the country. **********He said the fuel efficiency and fast turnaround time of the plane at airports would enable PSA to increase the frequency of its flights. PSA has 17 flights a day between Los Angeles and San Francisco, a route that in its earlier days generated much of its profits and growth. United recently increased its flights between the two cities from 15 to 24. **********Mr. Barkley said the only alternative to the BAe 146-200 would be the MD-90, a similar plane in size and fuel efficiency made by McDonnell Douglas. That craft would not have been available until 1987. The board of McDonnell Douglas recently voted to stop work on the MD-90 and the larger MD-100 for lack of orders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/world.main_headline: MARCOS PANEL TO STUDY ISSUE OF RESTORING VICE PRESIDENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/world.print_headline: MARCOS PANEL TO STUDY ISSUE OF RESTORING VICE PRESIDENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his ruling party decided today to set up a seven-member parliamentary committee to study the question of whether to restore the office of Vice President. **********With no deadline set for the committee to make its recommendations, the decision amounted to postponing indefinitely action on the succession issue, which is increasingly occupying the nation. **********But since Mr. Marcos has said that this period of financial stringency is no time to be tinkering with the governmental system, today's decision was also seen as something of a concession to increasing demands that the question be settled. **********Meeting Held at Palace **********The widely supported proposal to restore the office of Vice President was taken up at a three-hour meeting held at the presidential palace by Mr. Marcos and National Assembly members who belong to his New Society Movement. The nation's top military officers also attended, in line with a new Marcos policy to have the military present at important policy-making sessions. The President began it last week by inviting the military men to a Cabinet meeting that also dealt with the succession issue. **********Mr. Marcos, who has been in office for 18 years, has been opposed to restoring the vice presidential office, which he abolished during martial-law rule in the 1970's. He said at today's caucus that the legislators should give priority instead to the country's serious economic problems. **********The committee that is to take up the succession question is to include two Assembly members, Arturo Tolentino and Emmanuel Pelaez, who have argued vigorously in public for restoration of the No. 2 post. Mr. Pelaez, now 68 years old, held the position under President Diosdado Macapagal, whom Mr. Marcos defeated in the 1965 election.   Constitutional Provision **********Under the so-called martial-law Constitution of 1973, the Government's 15- member Executive Committee, consisting of Cabinet ministers, military officers and others, would take over if the President should die or become incapacitated. This group would govern for a few months until an election could be held. **********Last month, Mr. Marcos countered increasing pressure for restoration of the vice presidency by announcing that the presidential powers would pass to the Prime Minister, ''whoever he many be,'' as chairman of the Executive Committee. This statement seemed to add to the dispute over the issue. **********Mr. Tolentino, Mr. Pelaez and others criticized the President's statement, saying his idea was at variance with the law, which gives power to the Executive Committee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/world.main_headline: ON ARCTIC ICE, CANADA SEEKS TO EXTEND RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/world.print_headline: ON ARCTIC ICE, CANADA SEEKS TO EXTEND RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/15/world.body_text: **********As 36 scientists and technicians in this well-insulated tent camp work long into the cold, sunlit nights wresting secrets from an opaque ocean, issues of sovereign boundaries and international politics, involving Canada, the Soviet Union and the United States, are riding on many of their experiments. **********The scientists are part of the Canadian Expedition to Study the Alpha Ridge. The expedition began in late March and is to continue until the ice breaks up in two or three months. **********The expedition, known by its acronym Cesar, is being sponsored by the Canadian Ministry of Energy, Mines and Resources to chart and explore a huge underwater mountain range that looms below the slowly creeping ice. On charts prepared by the United States Navy, the ridge covers an area larger that that spanned by the Alps. **********''The ridge is the last relatively unknown and uncharted major geological feature left in the world,'' explained Hans Weber, the camp's chief scentist. **********His reddish beard was whitened and thickened by the icicles of frozen breath. At this point only 240 miles from the North Pole, the weather has hovered during the last four days around 40 degrees below freezing. **********''We have a fantastic opportunity here to gain data we will all be analyzing for years,'' said the Swiss-born geologist whose own high level of excitement was clearly sustained by the pure challenges of pursuing new knowledge in a harsh and largely unknown environment. **********But Christopher Bunting, a spokesman for the Canadian ministry, did not hide the more practical hopes of the Canadian sponsors.  Mr. Bunting, who accompanied a small group of reporters on a 3,000-mile northward journey from Montreal, said, ''An Arctic presence is important to us if Canada is going to be competitive as a northern nation, and sovereignty is obviously one of our concerns.'' **********Mr. Bunting was alluding to several scientific tests that may establish if the Alpha Ridge is an extension of the Canadian continental shelf, or whether the chain of submerged peaks rose up in an ancient volcanic eruption. **********Under the Law of the Sea Treaty, which Canada, unlike the United States, has initialed, a nation has 10 years in which it can make a claim to an exclusive economic zone lying beyond the submerged geological extensions of its national land masses. **********The fine points of the recent treaty have not yet been tested or honed but, according to interpretations offered on the ice, it is at least technically possible for Canada, whose maple leaf flag temporarily flies here, to assert title and control over much of the Arctic, almost to the pole. At the moment, these are international waters. **********Among the key ongoing experiments whose results could enhance a Canadian claim are chemical and geological analyses of sediment and borings brought up from the Alpha crests and their comparison with samples from the shores of Canada's Arctic islands. Pieces of the Puzzle **********Also, seismic tests, movements of currents, electromagnetic flows and the gauging of relative variations in gravity are being studied in a broad survey. **********''These different approaches may supply us with different pieces of the whole puzzle of the Alpha Ridge,'' Dr. Weber said, explaining the multidisciplined effort going on in the laboratory huts and tents scattered around the ice runway. From a mound of glacial ice, 42 chimneys can be counted, each with its own comforting plume. **********After a daylong storm on Saturday in which wind-churned surface snow cut visibility to inches, and days and nights of numbing temperatures that induced grateful thoughts on duck down, some of the trespassing nonscientists wondered how anyone could feel possessive about this place. An Awesome Expanse of Ice **********The ice station lies at 85 degrees 45 minutes north latitude and 110 degrees 53 minutes west longitude. From the 42-year-old DC-3 that carried the visitors on the final, 700-mile leg from Resolute Bay, the flat, occasionally crinkled ice appears awesome in its scale but largely undifferentiated in its features. **********Mr. Bunting again expressed the long view. ''What scientists find out here could perhaps give initial indications of mineral or energy resources which could prove valuable to future generations,'' he said. **********Ruth Jackson, a 32-year-old geophysicist from Halifax who is supervising the extraction of cores and sediment from the ridge below, noted over freshly baked apple pie in the mess tent that the acquisition of Alaska by the United States was ridiculed at the time the territory was purchased from the Russians. **********Miss Jackson alluded to to current geopolitical concerns with the Arctic when she mentioned that advance warnings were given to all the interested authorities before she set off blasts to obtain seismic profiles of the slopes of the Alpha Ridge. **********''There are Soviet and U.S. submarines poking around here all the time,'' she said. A Permanent Soviet Station **********For an area that appears so remote and desolate, there is indeed quite a lot of activity going on. Just 250 miles northwest of here, the Soviet Union has a permanently staffed ice station called North Pole 25. **********Mr. Weber, the chief scientist here, has hoped to arrange exchanges of scientists with the Russians. But after some diplomatic overtures to the Soviet Embassy in Ottawa, the prospects of contact seemed remote this week. ''Even in their literature on Arctic studies the Russians don't give much away,'' Miss Jackson said. **********The Russians are apparently concentrating their efforts on the Lomonosov Ridge, another submarinal chain, which the Canadians studied in their last high Arctic expedition three years ago. The scientists here are all in agreement that the Soviet effort is far more costly, although not necessarily more sophisticated, than Cesar, which has a budget of $1.7 million in Canadian currency, or about $1.4 million in United States dollars. **********That there is also some current United States involvement in the region beyond the deployment of submarines below the ice was made clear by the receipt here of a radio message on Sunday from the crew members of a specially modified, three-engine DC-3, the only one of its kind. They sought to land here because a fuel leak. Runway Damaged by Storm **********The pilot mentioned that he was flying south from Crystal City, which scientists here explained was a small encampent at the North Pole staffed by American civilians under contract to the United States Navy. The three-engine plane, operated by a California company identified as Pol-Air, could not land here because the storm had damaged the 5,000-foot runway. **********The landing strip was bulldozed and then glazed into smoothness with water pumped from below by Canadian troops who parachuted in last month to start building this camp. **********The troops have long since gone and camp discipline now functions solely under the laws of good sense and politeness. Sources at the camp say the Crystal City plane, which operates from a United States base at Thule in Greenland, went on to land at Alert, a Canadian military base about 350 miles from here. Two Adventurers on the Ice **********In addition to such flurries of national activity, there has been concern for individual Arctic enterprises. Two adventurers, a Briton and an Italian, have taken advantage of the firm ice and what is said to be relatively good Arctic weather to begin separate journeys by foot to the North Pole. **********Although earlier rumors contended that David Hempleman-Adams, the 26-year old Briton, had radioed for a plane to take him off the ice, a message from Resolute Bay on Sunday said both Mr. Hempleman-Adams and the Italian, Ambrogio Fogar, a 41-year-old former sailor, were still heading for the top of the world after several weeks of solitary hiking. **********Their efforts coincided with the 74th anniversary of Comdr. Robert Edwin Peary's dog-sled dash to the Pole. On April 6, 1909, Commander Peary, who was escorted by Matthew Henson, wrote in his diary: ''The Pole at last! The prize of three centuries, my dream and goal for 20 years, mine at last! I cannot bring myself to realize it.'' **********During some meals at the Cesar camp, the exploits of the two contemporary walkers on the ice brought the conversation around to the old Arctic adventurers. Several of the old hands who had spent years above the Arctic Circle indicated that they could not bring themselves to realize Commander Peary's achievement. 'It Could Not Be Done' **********''You don't think that Peary really reached the pole, do you?'' Mr. Weber asked. ''No one could have traveled 50 kilometers a day with dogs as he says he did. It could not be done.'' **********Leif Lundgaarde, a 52-year-old Arctic survival expert who serves as superintendent of the camp, was similarly skeptical.  ''I just don't know how Peary could do some things he wrote, but as a Norwegian my hero was of course, Nansen,'' he said, referring to the Norwegian Arctic explorer Fridtjof Nansen. **********If the views of a new Arctic hand matter, it is hard to see how anybody could walk 50 blocks up here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.main_headline: MILITARY AIDE SAYS REAGAN CRITICS DAMAGE U.S. STAND IN ARMS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.print_headline: MILITARY AIDE SAYS REAGAN CRITICS DAMAGE U.S. STAND IN ARMS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.body_text: **********A senior Pentagon official charged today that critics who questioned President Reagan's seriousness about arms control were damaging the American position in arms negotiations. **********Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, said the critics were urging concessions that would leave Moscow with ''a vastly larger strategic arsenal'' than the Administration is proposing. **********Mr. Perle told a Congressional subcommittee that the Administration would move ahead with such new weapons as the MX missile, the B-1 bomber, the Stealth bomber and the Trident 2 submarine and its new missile even if an arms reduction agreement was reached with the Soviet Union. **********''We won't get stability with an aging force'' of American strategic weapons, Mr. Perle said, because the Soviet Union has modernized so many of its nuclear weapons in the last decade. He said that 77 percent of the United States' strategic weapons were on launchers over 15 years old and a comparable part of the Soviet strategic forces were on launchers less than 5 years old. **********''Our strategic deterrent,'' Mr. Perle told the arms control panel of the House Armed Services Committee, ''is approaching obsolescence and would need to be replaced under any set of circumstances.'' **********Under questioning, he added, ''The most useful thing we can do is to agree on quantitative limits that will allow the U.S. to modernize.'' Harder Position on Talks **********The brunt of his prepared testimony, however, was directed at people who question the President's seriousness on arms control and press for changes in the American position to make an arms agreement more likely. **********That charge, he declared, ''is damaging and unworthy - damaging to our efforts and unworthy of those who make the charge.'' ''Without Congressional support,'' he warned, ''we cannot hope to prevail in negotiations.'' President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other top officials have been emphasizing flexibility in the Administration's position to ease criticism from Congress, but Mr. Perle struck a harsher posture. He advocated firmness and castigated people who are too ready to make concessions to Moscow, evidently including some in the Administration. **********''Our national consideration of arms control matters is in danger of deteriorating into an exhange of epithets between 'good guys' and 'bad guys,' '' he said. **********''Is it a sign of seriousness to make concessions to the Soviet desire to accumulate and preserve significant advantages in nuclear weapons?'' he asked. ''Is the ease with which we abandon our objectives and make 'progress' toward an agreement - any agreement - a sign of seriousness?'' **********''The burden of advice we are receiving from many of our critics amounts to little more than that we should modify our proposals so as to permit the Soviets to retain a vastly larger strategic arsenal than the levels the Administration has proposed,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/29/busin.body_text: **********Today's annual meeting of Dome Petroleum Ltd.  here marked the end of an era for the company that John P. Gallagher built into one of Canada's top oil and gas producers. **********Amid speeches and slides extolling the career of ''Smiling Jack'' Gallagher - so named for his courtly charm - control of the company he founded 33 years ago passed to John Howard Macdonald, a chartered public accountant whose financial skills may help end nine months of negotiations over a billion-dollar rescue plan intended to save the company from bankruptcy. **********Mr. Macdonald, now treasurer of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, will become Dome's chairman and chief executive officer on Oct. 1.  ''I've always been interested in challenge,'' said Mr. Macdonald, a Briton.  He may have come to the right place. Dome has been in trouble since its $4 billion (Canadian) purchase of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company in 1981. Because of rising interest rates, Dome was almost crushed by the burden of the debt it incurred to make that purchase. **********Although there were some indications at today's meeting that Dome is making headway in reducing its debt, analysts still perceive the company's difficulties as mainly financial. They suggest that Mr.  Macdonald's worldwide expertise in high finance may well prove helpful. **********By contrast, Mr. Gallagher was known for his pioneer drilling in the inclement Beaufort Sea and the zeal with which he proselytized these efforts to Wall Street investors. **********Mr. Gallagher will continue to serve Dome as a director and consultant. He said that the resolution of the leadership question - left dangling since he resigned as chief executive officer in April - might help bring a deal with the 56 banks Dome has been negotiating with over a rescue plan. **********''Bankers logically wanted to know who they would be dealing with,'' Mr. Gallagher said. Until Mr. Macdonald assumes control, Dome will continue to be managed by the company's executive committee. **********Dome executives suggested repeatedly today - both to the 400 shareholders who were present and at a news conference following the meeting -that talks with the banks were making progress. Because of the delicacy of the negotiations, however, they declined to provide any details. **********''Progress has been made, but with difficulty,'' said F.W.  Sellers, chairman of the executive committee.  Dome's leaders implied that negotiations were helped by falling interest rates, a better operating performance, some Government policy changes and the sale of nonessential assets. **********In the last six months Dome's debt has been reduced by $750 million, to $6.35 billion, Mr. Gallagher said.  Dome's problems result directly from its strong push to take advantage of the National Energy Plan, which was intended to increase Canadian ownership of the oil and gas industry in Canada by discriminating against foreign oil companies. **********Dome paid $4 billion of Canadian money in a two-step acquisition of the American-controlled Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas, with the purchase financed by taking on debt. This heavy debt load, when combined with soaring interest rates and plunging energy prices, pushed Dome to the brink of financial collapse. **********''We obviously reached for Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas at the wrong time and got caught,'' Mr. Gallagher said today.  Dome found itself unable to make repayments of $1.35 billion of principal due last year to four big Canadian banks. The banks and the Government in Ottawa then stepped in with a rescue package that could give them effective control of the company. **********Both the banks and the Government agreed to purchase $500 million of convertible debentures. Private shareholders could subscribe for a further $500 million of the convertible bonds. The package called for the long-term debt to be rescheduled over a period of at least 10 years. For the first 18 months, the conversion rate would be $2.50. **********Shareholders have been sharply critical of the plan for these reasons: The number of shares outstanding would be greatly diluted, control would pass to the Government and the banks, and the price of $2.50 seemed too low at a time when shares have risen greatly. **********Accordingly, Dome's officials are believed to be trying to alter the terms in the talks with the bankers, although they would not comment on whether they were trying to persuade the bankers to raise the $2.50 conversion price. For their part, bankers privately suggest that Dome still needs the money and may, in fact, not be able to avoid any of the rescue plan. **********Dome, however, makes a powerful case that it is doing a more effective job. Some $2.2 billion in assets have been sold. The office staff has been slashed 22 percent, and salaries have decreased 10 percent. **********''Within the scope of the agreements, there is ample opportunity for the company to help itself,'' said William E. Richards, the president. Moreover, luck seems to be running with the company again. a recent re-evaluation of the company's oil and gas resources indicated that they amount to 15 percent more than an estimate made less than a year ago, Mr. Richards said. **********A final factor in favor of Dome seems to be the enthusiasm shareholders feel for the company. ''I want to give Dome some money,'' David Pearce, 89 years old, said today, stirring applause.  ''If the other shareholders give $1,000, I'll give $1,000.'' **********Mr. Gallagher, smiling broadly, said, ''Thank you for your faith in Dome.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Over the last two years, a dark shadow has fallen over the onceglamorous world of international finance. Developing nations in Latin America, Africa and Asia plus a number of Eastern European countries have amassed total debts of about $700 billion. A large portion of these loans cannot be paid on time. **********At stake, should a significant amount of these debts be repudiated, would be the solvency of some of the world's largest multinational banks in the United States and elsewhere. **********If losses from international lending were to trigger widespread bank failures, recovery from the longest postwar recession would be in jeopardy all over the world, as would the system of international finance that serves to channel savings from the mature industrial economies to those that are just beginning to emerge. **********''Failure to manage and diffuse these strains,'' according to the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, ''could deal a serious blow to the recovery of the United States and the world economy.''Divergent Interests **********The interests of the debtors and creditors are sharply divergent, but nonetheless so far they are cooperating in renegotiating the terms of the loans. They are finding common ground in the overriding need to get the world economy moving again. **********No one can predict the eventual outcome, but to Martin S.  Feldstein, President Reagan's chief economist, ''it is surely true, as Benjamin Franklin said in quite a different context, that 'We must all hang together, or we shall all hang separately.' '' **********Politically, the crisis over international debt is inextricably interwoven with the long-standing confrontation over distribution of the world's resources between the rich industrial nations of the Northern Hemisphere and their poor cousins in the developing world to the south. If loans were to be repudiated, and not paid, the result would be a transfer of wealth to the debtor country. **********The debtors have had to endure severe belt tightening to obtain resources to make payments on their loans. ''Unduly harsh adjustment,'' warns the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, ''would raise the risk of a moratorium on repayment of principal or interest.'' **********The crisis, which is far from resolution, is now moving into its second round. In the first round, the scope of the problem was delineated. Now bankers and borrowers are starting to wrestle with a far more difficult question: How, if at all, to repay the loans. **********As much as some individual bankers might want to pull back from the precipice of lending to developing countries, there is a consensus that more, not less, credit to these nations will be required before the world economy can recover and the loans now on the books be brought up to date. The bankers are trapped on a treadmill. **********Some critics, in fact, charge that the bankers were foolish and greedy, and have only themselves to blame for forcing money on countries that obviously could not repay. Not surprisingly, the bankers reject this charge. **********''Implicit in the criticism,'' says the head of a major New York bank, ''is that banks loaded up on loans to the developing countries, secure in the knowledge that they'd get bailed out if things went sour. It simply isn't so.'' **********If and when the crisis subsides, the critical factor is likely to be largely outside the control of either the borrowers or the lenders - namely, the strength of the world economy. As one banker put it: ''The only sure route out of this mess is through economic growth in the industrial countries.'' **********Following is a summary of the basic issues in the international debt crisis: Q. What was the origin of this problem? A. The roots of the debt crisis go back to 1973, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began to increase the price of oil from about $3.50 a barrel to a peak of $34 in 1981 and 1982. These increases created huge financial surpluses in some of the OPEC countries and equally huge deficits elsewhere. These deficits had to be financed with borrowing. **********Q. Does the oil shock explain all the cases? A. No. Mexico, as one example, is both one of the largest debtors and, in recent years, a major oil exporter. Greatly oversimplified, the Mexicans were borrowing to develop their oil resources as well as overall economic growth. And in Poland, political upheaval compounded the difficulty of adjusting to the shock of higher oil prices and worldwide recession. **********At the same time, the accelerating inflation of the 1970's made borrowing seem attractive. Although interest rates were rising rapidly, there was always the hope that inflation would go up even faster so that loans would be repaid with depreciated currency.Banks Were Acting As Classic Middlemen **********Q. Why did the banks get involved? A. The banks played their classic role as middlemen. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, to cite three examples, deposited their surplus funds in the banks. The banks in turn lent the money to countries whose bills for imported oil were rising rapidly. **********Not only did the petrodollars have to be recycled, but also in 1979 demand for credit in the industrial countries began to slacken, reflecting the onset of worldwide recession. Moreover, bankers found the interest rates on these loans to be attractive relative to the other lending opportunities that were available at the time.  Typically rates on bank credits of this type have been linked to the fluctuating cost of short-term credit in the London-based market for dollars deposited in banks overseas. In 1980 and 1981 this rate surged to around 20 percent. **********A senior economist at a major New York bank said, ''There was a relaxed atmosphere in the late 1970's.'' In effect, he added, bankers fooled themselves into thinking that the short-term loans they were making were somehow ''safer'' and that loans to other nations were ''riskless'' because ''countries don't go bankrupt.'' **********The bankers, who were increasing their loans to developing countries at a rate of more than 20 percent annually, seemed reluctant to press the borrowing countries to tighten up. Warnings about possible future problems ''were clearly in the minority,'' said Rimmer de Vries, chief international economist at Morgan Guaranty.  ''Most monetary experts, from both public and private sectors, expressed confidence in the ability of the private banking system to continue playing the dominant role in recycling.'' **********Q. How heavily involved are the banks in overseas operations? A.  William M. Weiant, who is the chief banking analyst at the First Boston Corporation, estimates that almost half the $3.3 billion profits of the nation's 10 largest banking companies last year came from international business. Only part of these earnings came from lending to developing countries, but over the last decade the trend has been toward greater international involvement. **********During 1982, Citicorp, the nation's largest international lender, had domestic earnings of $299 million, or 40 percent of the worldwide total of $747 million. The next largest contributor was Brazil, where profits came to $153 million, or 20 percent. **********Put another way, loans to Mexico, Brazil and Argentina - many already overdue - by the nine largest American banks come to 113 percent of their total stockholders' equity. If these loans were to be repudiated, the largest banks would all be in serious trouble, and would probably require government assistance to stay open. **********Q. How big is the international debt problem? A. The staff of the International Monetary Fund in Washington, which probably has the best information on this subject, estimates that the total external debt of the 115 ''non-oil developing countries'' came to $612.4 billion at the end of 1982 and will total more than $664 billion at the end of this year. Mexico, notwithstanding its oil wealth, is arbitrarily defined by the I.@M.@F. staff as being part of the ''non-oil'' group. It is also the second-largest debtor in the crisis, after Brazil. In addition, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union owed an estimated $81.5 billion in convertible currencies at the end of 1982. **********Q. Has all this money been lent by the banks? A. No. The banks appear to be the largest lenders, but governments and international lending agencies are also major participants. According to the I.M.F., the numbers break down this way:PU FIRST ADDFIRST ADD DEBT **********Almost $113 billion, or 18 percent of the $612 billion, was shortterm financing, primarily related to the movement of goods in international trade. The balance of roughly $500 billion is in longterm credits, of which almost two-fifths, or $193 billion, is owed to other governments or international organizations, while $306 billion was provided by private creditors. **********About two-thirds of the amount lent by private organizations, or about $202.2 billion, has been guaranteed by the recipient's government. This leaves an unguaranteed portion of $104 billion, which is the segment where bankers are concerned that their biggest losses may lie. **********Q. How many countries are in trouble? A. At last count 34 nations were seeking to ''reschedule'' - that means postpone - payments on their foreign debts. But Edward P. Neufeld, chief economist of the Royal Bank of Canada, says that ''from the point of view of the real risks to the stability of the international financial system, the problem is centered in perhaps seven countries - Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Venezuela, Chile, Yugoslavia and Poland. They account for 81 percent of debt of the 24 countries engaged in private debt rescheduling.'' **********Keep in mind also that while it is convenient to talk about loans as though they were a homogenous total, this is not the case. There are tens of thousands of individual loans, each with its own terms and conditions. The common element in the debt problems of most developing countries - if there is one - is that the central bank controls the availability of hard currency, usually dollars, to service the debts. **********Q. What would happen if many of the developing countries were to repudiate their debts all at once? A. Such a development could largely wipe out the capital of many multinational banks in the industrial countries. In this event - which one banker described as an ''irresponsible doomsday scenario'' - many analysts expect that Western governments would take over the affected banks, rather than allow a general financial crisis to spread. **********At the same time, a country that repudiated its international debts would find itself cut off, not only from an influx of fresh capital, but also from access to the world banking system. Under such circumstances, bankers say, normal trade transactions would become very dificult to finance. **********Q. Could the world blunder into a general repudiation of debt? A.  The consensus among most experts is that, just because the problem has been widely analyzed, an accidental banking collapse is unlikely. In addition, bank regulators, as well as the bankers and the borrowers, are beginning to take actions designed to insure against any recurrence. **********The regulatory response is still uncertain, but the United States banking authorities have just announced new rules governing the required level of capital for 17 very large banks that the Fed has defined as being ''multinational.'' Then, too, the central banks of the industrial nations - meeting as a group - have recently clarified the ground rules concerning who would be responsible for what if one of the major banks should get into serious trouble. **********Q. Did governments encourage the banks to lend to developing countries? A. Governments all over the world not only encouraged banks under their jurisdiction to make these loans, but they participated in the process directly by lending money themselves.  The two most important reasons appear to have been a desire to soften the economic blow from higher oil prices by helping to recycle the petrodollars, and to protect export markets. The developing countries are among the largest customers for products sold by the industrial nations. **********Q. But wasn't this a colossal mistake? A. Perhaps it appears so in retrospect, but given the massive financial imbalance created by the surge in oil prices and rapid inflation, it seems improbable that the buildup in debt could have been prevented. However, there were serious errors. **********Mr. Feldstein charges that there was too much bank lending after the second oil price surge in 1979 and not enough belt-tightening by developing countries. There was too much lending, he says, to finance ''unproductive imports rather than finance productive investments that would contribute to the development process.'' **********Q. Do private bankers agree with Mr. Feldstein? A. Lewis T.  Preston, chairman of Morgan Guaranty in New York, concedes that both borrowers and lenders were slow in adjusting to the consequences of the severe drop in world commodity prices and trade. They erred, he said, in ''misjudging the capacity of sovereign countries to carry their debt in a protracted recession.'' **********Q. What role has the International Monetary Fund played? A. The I.M.F., which was formed in 1944 to stabilize the currency values of the industrial nations, has been in the forefront in dealing with the crisis of the developing nations. A 50 percent increase in the I.M.F.'s resources has been proposed, and legislation to authorize the United States's share in this increase, about $8 billion, is now working its way through Congress. **********The Fund often holds the key in specific loan negotiations. It sets the belt-tightening conditions for the debtor governments to achieve to have their debts renegotiated or to receive a loan from the I.M.F. **********In February, for instance, Brazil agreed to a strict austerity program that included a devaluation of the cruziero, cuts in the rate of inflation, government spending cuts and a reduction in the current account deficit in its balance of payments. Complex negotiations between Brazil, the Fund and the banks are now going on to determine if and when Brazil will get its next loan installment. **********Jacques de Larosiere, the former French civil servant who is now managing director of the I.M.F., admits that such economic castor oil has a nasty taste, but like any stern parent, he argues that in the long run it will be beneficial. He told the United Nations Conference on Trade and Developmnent in Belgrade this month that ''the policies undertaken in the context of a Fund program help borrowing countries to restore domestic and external balance, thus setting the right conditions for sustainable growth and giving renewed confidence to foreign creditors.''Central Banks Play Major Role in Crisis **********Q. Are central banks also involved? A. Very much so. The Federal Reserve in particular has been active in helping to head off crises by providing temporary credit, and by playing a backstage role in the complex loan negotiations. Among other things, Federal Reserve officials, including Mr. Volcker, have pushed medium-sized regional banks in the United States to continue lending to developing countries. Many of these institutions, which have only a limited commitment to international banking, tried to pull out after the crisis broke. **********According to Fritz Leutwiler, president of both the Swiss National Bank and the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland, the central banks have been following two courses that ''at first sight may appear inconsistent.'' On one side, he said, they have been pressing for adequate loan loss reserves on credits already outstanding, and at the same time pressing the banks to provide ''adequate total new financing'' to these same countries. **********Clearly, the fear is that if the bankers are forced to increase their loss reserves too much - and nobody knows how much that is - they will stop lending to the developing countries. **********Q. What are the basic political issues in the international debt crisis? A. The most important controversies concern the age-old divisions between rich and poor. The developing countries, which by definition are relatively poor, argue that they are carrying a disproportionate burden as a result of the efforts of the industrial countries - the United States in particular - to control inflation.  They are already poor, and the effect of recession, high interest rates, the drop in world trade and now credit tightening by the banks has been to make them much poorer, they say. **********Q. Can a sovereign nation actually go bankrupt like a company? A.  Experts on international debt generally believe the answer to this question is ''no.'' There is no agreed-upon body of international laws that would govern such a situation, nor is there a world bankruptcy court that could order a country to make specified payments or give it immunity from future claims. The important question is whether the country is willing politically to pay its debts.PU 2D ADD DEBT2D & LAST ADD DEBT **********By the same token, says Lawrence J. Brainard, vice president of Bankers Trust Company, the concept of ''default'' has only limited meaning when it involves a sovereign government. In everyday language, he said, ''default simply means that a country is not doing what it agreed.'' **********Q. Speaking in practical, not legal, terms, how much international credit is in default? A. Nobody knows for sure. No formal, legal defaults have been declared against a sovereign government, but bankers say that for the foreseeable future the major part of the $210 billion in long-term credit extended to borrowers in Central and Latin America will have to be renegotiated. The same is true for smaller amounts in Africa, Asia and Eastern Europe. **********To deal with the lack of information, more than 100 major banks recently formed a new Institute of International Finance, based in Washington, which would act as a joint fact-finding organization. **********Q. Why have so many developing countries gotten into financial trouble all at once? A. Most experts would agree with Wilfried Guth, chairman of the Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, that the most important causes reflect ''the cumulative effect of prolonged recession, extremely high interest rates and growing protectionism in the industrialized world.'' **********The fight against inflation - which has been very successful in the last two years - has necessarily included a sharp drop in basic commodity prices. This has cut deeply into the earnings from the export of such products in many developing countries. **********There has also been a chain reaction effect. Brazil, for example, said one banker, ''is like a patient who goes to the hospital for a checkup and catches pneumonia from the guy in the next bed. They have a gross national product of nearly $300 billion, one of the dozen largest in the world. They have a reasonable balance between short-and long-term debt. But when the Argentines and the Mexicans got into trouble last summer, and the banks started cutting back on new credit, Brazil was in the soup, too.'' **********Then, too, the vast bulk of the $700 billion in the credit crisis is denominated in United States dollars. This means, according to Mr. Feldstein, that the rise in the real, inflation-adjusted, value of the dollar in the foreign exchange markets has led to a corresponding increase in the real resources that these already poor countries have to allocate to international debt service. **********Q. Will these loans ever be repaid? A. In one sense, no, and in another sense, hopefully. Bankers say there is no likelihood that the total amount of credit extended to developing countries will ever be repaid, any more than there is chance that the United States Government will ever retire its $1.2 trillion debt. As old loans are retired, new ones will be extended. **********The same principle applies to international credits. The issue is not whether Brazil as a country will ever repay the more than $80 billion that it owes to its international creditors. It probably will not. Rather, the question is whether the Brazilians - as well as other developing countries -will have sufficient earnings from their exports to service individual loans as they come due. **********Q. But what about foreign loans to the private sector? A. These are clearly different. Bankers have generally recognized that credit extended to private companies in other countries could carry higherthan-normal risk, and as economic conditions deteriorated they reflected this in increased provisions for loan losses. Last year, a sample of 160 large American banks surveyed by Robert Morris Associates, the national organization of bank credit officials, charged off almost $520 million in bad international loans, most to private borrowers. Comparable charge-offs in 1981 came to $316 million.Debt Rescheduling Modifies Terms of Loan **********Q. What is a debt rescheduling and how is it related to the problem of loan losses? A. A debt rescheduling is simply a deal to modify the terms of a loan with one or more of the following provisions: A grace period during which no payments are required; a longer maturity date; a reduced interest rate, and an additional loan that could be used for current payments or to make the required interest payments. **********The impact of such an agreement on the lenders plainly could be to cut into the flow of income from the loan. However, some of the largest banks have been able to obtain handsome fees for managing the loan renegotiations. How big the eventual effect would be on an individual bank and its stockholders is very hard to measure; that depends on the size, character and number of the concessions that are made, and what offsetting actions the bank can take in other areas. **********Arthur P. Soter, bank analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, says that ''some of these reschedulings have improved the banks' reported earnings because the stated interest rates on the loans have been increased. But over a period of time, the actual payments on these international loans have to be brought up to date, or the banks have just been fooling themselves and there will be some real losses.'' **********Q. Why don't the bankers simply cut off credit to the third world and the East bloc and stop the negotiations? A. Because it would be counterproductive to do so. There is wide agreement that the only way the debt crisis can ever be resolved satisfactorily is through economic growth - first in the industrial nations and then in the developing countries. This will require more, not less, credit. **********Q. Have any plans been proposed to try to deal with the international debt crisis in an overall way, all at once? A. Yes.  Felix G. Rohatyn, partner at Lazard Freres and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, worries that if there is a ''unilateral repudiation'' of external debt by a major country, this could require ''drastic write-downs of the capital of many large banks, possibly impairing the capacity of several to function.'' **********Mr. Rohatyn doubts that the United States is at a point where international debts have to be restructured in such a fashion.  ''Because we don't have to do it in a crisis atmosphere,'' he says, ''I would be in favor of doing it now.'' **********Greatly oversimplified, Mr. Rohatyn's plan for dealing with the crisis calls for an exchange of the short-term loans held by the banks for long-term, low-interest paper that would be issued by a new government agency, either national or multinational. Such a swap, he says, would involve ''the recognition of significant costs and losses.'' To backstop banks that might get into trouble in such a circumstance, Mr. Rohaytn has proposed creation of an agency similar to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which aided shaky banks during the Depression. **********Q. What are the objections to this plan? A. Opposition to this approach has come from bankers and from conservatives in Congress.  William S. Ogden, who is interim chairman of the Institute of International Finance, charges that it represents a ''radical solution to a problem that does not exist.'' He says that the developing countries are not insolvent or unable to ever pay their debts, but rather are illiquid, or temporarily unable to pay.  Congressman Jerry Lewis, Republican of California, among others, is opposed to the creation of a new government agency to deal with what he sees as a temporary problem. **********Q. What is the outlook? A. There is no way to predict the final outcome of the debt crisis, but several consequences are coming into view. First, bankers, chastened by their experience of the last two years, have become much less venturesome in their international lending. Some economists are concerned that the bankers' new-found caution could put a damper on economic recovery in the developing countries. **********Second, there is pressure for governments to assume more of the lending, and hence more of the credit risk in providing financial support for the developing world. **********Finally, banking supervisors, in the United States and abroad, have received a liberal education in international banking over the last two years, and do not like everything they have learned. They plainly would like to tighten their regulations, even if they are not quite sure how to do it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/busin.body_text: **********WHEN First Lady Jackie Kennedy needed a new wardrobe during her W hite House years, she went to Halston, a designer who built his r eputation on creating glamorous and expensive clothes for celebratedw omen. Today, his client list, which includes Nancy Reagan, ElizabethT aylor and Liza Minnelli, reads like a Who's Who of the rich and f amous. **********But now you don't have to be either to own a Halston frock. In fact, if J.C. Penney has its way, every woman in America will soon be able to wear a Halston dress or coat - and for as little as $200 rather than the $5,000 that it can cost for an original. **********Penney, attempting to shed its low-priced, Middle America image while bolstering its recently sluggish sales, has signed an exclusive contract with the designer. Under its terms, Halston has agreed, for what is rumored to be an eight-figure price, to produce a collection of men's and women's fashions, called Halston III, for Penney's 600 largest suburban mall locations. **********The move toward such stylish but affordable fashions is a significant -though somewhat risky - coup for the usually low-key and cost-conscious mass merchandiser. Yet, the Halston deal is only part of Penney's bold new strategy for the 80's. The company, which started as a tiny country store in Kemmerer, Wyo., 81 years ago, is now pushing hard to transform itself into what the outgoing chairman, Donald V. Seibert, called ''the only truly national department store chain in the country'' - one with big stores in major malls from coast-to-coast, and all operating under the same corporate logo. **********While other more traditional department-store chains, such as R.H.  Macy & Company and the May Department Stores Company, also have nationwide operations, their stores are run mostly under different local names. **********Most retailers do not categorize Sear's Roebuck, the nation's biggest retailer, as a department store because its sales are dominated by home furnishings. The sales mix in a typical department store is more heavily weighted toward soft goods, retailers point out. **********Penney's gamble is big, and it is not coming without some sacrifice. Some of its recent maneuvers have caused violent swings in its stock price this year, as well as somewhat lackluster sales.  Undaunted so far, the company has committed about $1 billion to remodel several hundred of its largest stores - considered the most substantial investment of its kind ever in the retailing business; it has also carved out additional space for its more upscale, highermargin clothing by dropping most of the things that made Penney Penney, including household durables, paint and hardware and automotive and auto-service centers. **********Penney has already remodeled stores in Atlanta, Columbus, Ohio, and Davenport, Iowa, which it considers prototypes for its new direction in style and content. Meanwhile, it is expanding and stengthening both its catalogue division and its financial services operation. AND while all this is going on, the company is in the midst of a m ajor management shuffle. At 60, Mr. Seibert is facing mandatory r etirement in September (see box) and will be succeeded by 4 7-yearold William R. Howell, one of the company's two vice chairmen.B ut, said Mr. Siebert, who has been the Penney chairman since 1974: ' 'I can see no change occurring from the shift in officers.'' **********Regardless of who is at the helm, by 1990 the nation's third largest retailer will be battling head to head with the big, entrenched local department store branches of such companies as Burdine's in Miami and Bamberger's in New Jersey, whose customers traditionally have tended to be young, affluent and mostly women. **********In the past, Penney's principal competition had come from mass merchandisers like Sears and K Mart, which have generally catered to a lower-income, less fashion-conscious clientele. **********Its major push, the concentration and upgrading of apparel with its greater profit potential, should do the most to enhance the company's bottom line. For example, adult female apparel in large stores typically carries a 51 percent markup, whereas appliances have a markup of about 27 percent, floorcoverings run about 43 percent and furniture ranges between 48 to 51 percent. Markup is the percentage difference between the wholesale and retail prices. **********One obvious concern, however, is Penney's ability to adequately compete with the big mall anchor stores, especially in so-called ''designer'' or name-brand clothing. ''Logistically, they can do it, but it's a question whether the consumer will perceive them the way they want,'' observed David C. Taylor, retail analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities. **********Mr. Howell, who had started with Penney as a trainee in Tulsa, Okla., in 1958, said that repositioning of its mall stores was ''a monumental undertaking. But we're very fortunate that in the 60's the company began opening stores in some of the country's top centers.  There will not be another 600 malls in which we or anyone else can open, so we have an edge.'' **********Penney's other 1,030 stores are smaller and generally located in maturing urban and suburban markets.  A niggling question remains: As the economy improves along with the consumer's spending power, will Penney's policy of offering apparel at 15 to 20 percent less than most department stores mean as much to mall customers? According to Prudential-Bache's Mr. Taylor, ''Penney's price differential won't mean as much. But, as I see it, they could not do anything else but what they are now doing.'' **********And in light of its most recent sales performance, Penney management would readily agree. Just last week, the company reported only a 7 percent increase in June sales, continuing a year-long trend of similarly small gains. Meanwhile, nearly every other major chain posted double-digit increases. Penney's lackluster showing has generally been attributed to the shift in its merchandise direction. **********The new strategy has also dramatically affected the valuation of the company's stock. This year, Penney's stock rose to 67 3/8, fell to a low of 34 3/8, and then rose again to about 60. But, according to Bruce M. Missett, security analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, New York, because Penney earned a disappointing $5.87 a share last year, its stock in 1983 is being valued by investors at only about 10 times earnings; the overall Standard & Poor 500 index has a price-earnings multiple of 14. BUT Penney's financial woes have earlier roots. Its profit margin o n sales has been erratic in the last decade, variously reaching a bove 3 percent but mostly falling below it. Its return on equity, w hich management considers perhaps the key measure of performance, h it a high of 15.2 percent in 1972, but declined to as low as 10 p ercent before recouping to 14.7 percent last year. During this p eriod, it slowed its expansion pace and soon surrendered its r anking as the nation's second-biggest retailer - after Sears - to K M art. **********Profits, too, have been erratic since the mid-70's. But in 1982, Penney posted record profits of $430 million from continuing operations, up from $393 million the year before. Last year's sales also rose to a record $11.4 billion, though it was only 2 percent above 1981 figures. **********In the last few years, concerned with its sales slowdown, the company surveyed mall customers and found that for most major items of apparel, shoppers went to the mall's anchor department store. In an effort to correct this, the apparel upgrading program was launched in the mid-70's and has picked up steam ever since - while some of the low priced goods on which Penney made its reputation have been retained. **********Mr. Seibert said the company's survey also found that department stores were getting 17 customer visits a year versus only nine at Penney's. ''Think what would happen if we could narrow the gap. If we could get just one more $20 sale from each of our customers, it would boost our sales by more than $2 billion. Opportunities don't come much bigger than that.'' **********As of Sept. 1, however, it will be Mr. Howell who will try to turn these opportunities into black ink. At the same time, the company's Office of the Chairman, created in 1981 as a training ground for future leaders at Penney, will be expanded to five members from three. **********Will the change in command make a perceptible difference? ''It is very tough to see whose stamp in any big company is precisely on what,'' said Mr. Missett of Oppenheimer. ''But my impression is that Mr. Howell is a strong man with a definite sense of where Penney is going. It remains to be seen what kind of an executor he is.'' **********One thing, however, is clear: Mr. Howell, like Mr. Seibert, has complete confidence in Penney's current game-plan. And they both concede that the department store competition has larger individual stores and a long, built-in clientele. But Penney, they say, has many more stores and will have far more selling space allocated to apparel than it ever had before. **********''I think that Penney's can do it,'' said Walter K. Levy, a retail marketing consultant in New York. ''They have already made their stores look like department stores and customers see them in a department-store context.'' PENNEY'S thrust to assume the premiere, national department store r ole is not the only one in Mr. Seibert's legacy. The company is alsos triving for continued expansion in its catalogue division and in itsf inancial services operation. ''The catalogue business, now a ccounting for about 15 percent of total Penney's sales, is growing f aster than our retail sales,'' said David F. Miller, executive vice p resident. As a result, Penney opened a sixth distribution center l ast year in Manchester, Conn., and updated a new point-of-purchase c omputer system. **********As for financial services, Penney's already offers life, health and casualty insurance through many of its stores and by direct marketing. And in May, it opened Family Financial Centers in five Northern California stores. The centers are a a joint venture with First Nationwide Savings and Loan of California that provide a range of banking services, including consumer loans and discount brokerage advice, said Thomas J. Lyons, a Penney's executive vice president. **********But probably nothing that the company has done recently has drawn more attention than its announcement about Halston. Mr. Seibert, speaking recently at the American Museum of Natural History, where 1,000 viewed the new line, hailed the introduction of the collection as ''one of the most important events in Penney's history.'' **********But last week, Bergdorf Goodman, a key Halston retail account, said it would discontinue Halston's ready-to-wear and cosmetics lines because of the designer's licensing deal with Penney. Bergdorf's president and chief executive officer, Ira Neimark, asserted, ''We decided that designers, as well as retailers, have to decide who their customers are and proceed in that direction. Halston made his decision and we have made ours.'' **********When asked for comment, Halston said that he thought there was room for ''everyone in retailing'' and he hoped that ''a solution agreeable to all can still be worked out.'' Mr. Neimark said flatly, ''That's not possible. It is all over.'' **********For Penney, the Halston-Bergdorf flap will probably figure as no more than a slight blip on its corporate strategy screen. The stakes in Penney's push are just too big. And perhaps nothing indicates this more than the huge red banner with bold block lettering draped in front of its New York headquarters. It says simply: HALSTON III, J.C. PENNEY.   AND AFTER RETIREMENT?A DIFFERENT TUNE **********Donald V. Seibert, who will wind up a 36-year career with the J. C. Penney Company when he retires in September, sat last week in his office staring at a Telex video display terminal. The chairman was studying information on weekly store sales and the daily news summary. Occasionally, he deftly tapped out a message on the keyboard. **********But this fall he will be sitting before an entirely different instrument.  Reverting to a pursuit he was drawn to as a youth in his hometown of Hamilton, Ohio, and has enjoyed over the years, Mr. Seibert will compose music for the church. ''I like to write anthems and 'introits', which are short selections for a chorus,'' he said. **********Before joining Penney in 1947 after studying at the University of Cincinnati, Mr. Seibert took music lessons, intending to be either a musician of ''serious jazz'' or a classical clarinet player. ''But I learned when I was quite young that you made more money if you played either the saxophone or the piano,'' he said. ''So I took up both.'' But in a few years, he learned, there was money to be made in business. **********Music was not, however, his first or only calling in his early days. As a 15-year-old, he had ''a little printing business'' and, along with another little boy, publishing a tiny local newspaper called ''The Weekly Noose.'' The two boys listened to the latest news on the radio, then set it into type and printed it on a miniature printing press, often delivering the paper to neighbors' homes before the town's ''real'' newspapers did. **********Mr. Seibert will continue to serve on five boards, all at New Yorkbased companies, and will remain active in several nonprofit activities. He says that he and his wife, Verna, will ''of course'' continue to live at their home in Murray Hills, N.J., where they have been since 1960. **********''I am looking forward to a happy blend of activity, with more personal time with my wife,'' he said. And with some background music, too, it might be added.
