https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/04/world.main_headline: ISRAEL REJECTS LEBANESE REQUEST FOR PULLOUT TIMETABLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/04/world.print_headline: ISRAEL REJECTS LEBANESE REQUEST FOR PULLOUT TIMETABLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/04/world.body_text: **********The American special envoy to the Middle East conveyed a Lebanese request to Israel today that it publish a timetable for the withdrawal of its forces from Lebanon. Israel rejected the request, officials here said. **********The special envoy, Robert C. McFarlane, who is on his first Middle East trip since his appointment July 22, arrived here Tuesday from Beirut, where he talked with President Amin Gemayel. Israeli officials had expected him to go to Damascus for talks with Syrian leaders before coming to Israel. **********A senior Israeli official who summarized the talks here today said that Mr. Gemayel had stressed a concern that Israel's plan to pull its troops in Lebanon back to the Awali River would create the impression that the country was being partitioned. Mr. McFarlane, the official said, wanted to clarify Israel's position on the pullback before going to other Arab capitals. **********''That was the main reason he came here, so before he went to Damascus he could say that he had a full community of views on the matter of redeployment,'' the official said. **********The official added, ''He wants to find a way whereby the redeployment can take place and at the same time the Lebanese fears can be alleviated.''  No Plans for Partition **********According to Israeli officials, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir told Mr. McFarlane that Israel stood behind its many declarations that it does not intend that Lebanon be partitioned. **********The two men met this morning in Jerusalem for an hour before Mr. McFarlane went to Tel Aviv to see Defense Minister Moshe Arens. **********According to Israeli officials, both Mr. Shamir and Mr. Arens reiterated Israel's statements that it would withdraw all of its forces from Lebanon only when Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization troops in the country also leave. **********''Shamir also said, 'Listen, we are ready to clarify this stand of ours directly to the Lebanese Government,' '' an Israeli official said. Mr. Shamir, according to the official, said one reason for Lebanon's fears about the Israeli pullback was the absence of a direct communication link between Israel and Mr. Gemayel.   First Stage of Withdrawal **********Israel's redeployment was the subject of talks in Washington last week between Mr. Shamir, Mr. Arens and senior Reagan Administration officials. Israel said then that the redeployment was the first stage in a complete withdrawal but that all other foreign forces would have to be withdrawn simultaneously. **********Mr. McFarlane is expected to meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin on Thursday. Israeli officials said they understood he would go to Saudi Arabia next, then Syria. **********Mr. McFarlane has made no public statements since his arrival in Israel. **********At the talks today, Mr. Shamir expressed Israel's interest in exchanging instruments of ratification of the withdrawal agreement with Lebanon that was signed in May. Both countries' Parliaments have approved the agreement but it will not take effect until the documents have been exchanged.   Lebanon Questions Timing **********Mr. McFarlane, according to Israeli officials, conveyed to Mr. Shamir Lebanon's belief that, while it would adhere to the agreement, the time was not appropriate for a formal exchange of documents. **********The Israelis are believed to want the treaty to go into effect as a way of convincing Syria that its refusal to withdraw from Lebanon will not interfere with an eventual normalization of relations between Israel and Lebanon. **********Mr. Gemayel, however, is said to fear that moving ahead with the Israeli-Lebanese agreement could increase Syrian pressure on his Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/21/busin.main_headline: Betting on Turbocharged Cars; Detroit Hoping To Sell 300,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/21/busin.print_headline: Betting on Turbocharged Cars; Detroit Hoping To Sell 300,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The 1984 model year is being seen as the year of the turbocharger for the American automobile industry. **********The Big Three auto makers, betting that buyers will pay more to have extra power available on demand, are projecting combined sales of nearly 300,000 turbocharged cars for the model year, compared to just 15,700 in the 1983 model year. **********To attain that goal, Detroit will have to overcome resistance to turbocharging that developed during the late 1970's, when the few domestic turbo models on the market proved to be unreliable and difficult. **********And there will be price resistance to consider - turbochargers increase power without greatly reducing fuel economy, but they are a complicated, and expensive, accessory. **********A survey published recently by J.D. Power & Associates, an industry consultant, found that only 7 percent of new-car buyers this year think they might be interested in purchasing a turbocharged vehicle. **********Company officials acknowledge that their combined sales goal of 300,000 turbo-equipped cars is ambitious. Nevertheless, the units are an important part of the marketing strategy of both the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation this model year. **********"The long-term potential for turbocharging is not those folks who will buy a Mustang with a turbo option," said Ford's general marketing manager, Thomas J. Wagner. "It's getting people that would never buy a turbocharged car to understand what turbocharging is all about, and that it is a very viable product for the wife of the chariman of the board." **********Turbocharging has a number of advantages that the auto companies will push heavily in the next 12 months. **********The devices increase engine power on demand by forcing more air and fuel into each cylinder at higher than normal pressures. This increase in pressure causes the fuel to burn more efficiently and produces more power - 50 percent more in the case of the Ford EXP subcompact, for example, to 120 horsepower from 80. **********A turbo model also has a profit advantage for the dealers and car companies. The equipment package, which usually includes heavy-duty suspension and high-performance tires, can add as much as $2,000 to the price of a car. Although the companies will not reveal their margins, they do acknowledge that the accessories substantially incrase their profit on turbocharged models. **********Ford and Chrysler - with only three American-made engines each - have a special interest in promoting turbochargers because the units allow a power plant to be used several different ways, creating a range of profitable new models with a minimum of investment. **********During the 1984 model year, both companies plan to market some 20 turbocharged cars, ranging from the Escort subcompact to the more luxurious Chrysler New Yorker. In the 1983 yeear, Ford offered three turbo models while Chrysler had none. **********G.M., with 14 American-built powerplants, is taking a quieter approach to turbocharging. It will offer the option on only four cars in the 1984 model year - specialty versions of the Buick Skyhawk, Regal, Riviera and the Pontiac 2000. Last year, only the Regal and Riviera had the option. **********"It's an important element in Buick's strategy to attract new customers, but we don't plan to sell turbos in volume," said Lloyd E. Reuss, general manager of G.M.'s Buick Division. **********G.M. estimates that it will deliver about 23,500 turbo models in 1984, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication. Ford and Chrysler, however, plan a much more ambitious 125,000 apiece. Some analysts think the Ford and Chrysler projections may be unrealistic. **********"They sound awfully high to me," said David Healy, auto industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York. "But as gasoline prices have come down and the economy and personal income have improved, people are more willing to consider buying these performance options. It goes with the recovery." **********Foreign auto makers have used the concept successfully on expensive sports models like the Porsche 924 and Datsun 280 ZX, and sales of imported turbo models have grown from about 20,000 in 1980 to more than 80,000 last year. **********But American auto makers have had less luck with turbocharging. G.M. and Ford introduced the systems in the late 1970's on a limited number of models. Initially successful, thanks in part to a steep rise in gasoline prices, deliveries during 1979 totaled about 100,000 units. **********But the early units quickly developed problems and, by the 1982 model year, sales fell to about 3,000 units. The units were unreliable and few customers or dealers understood how they worked. The additional engine pressure and higher temperatures required by turbocharging required frequent oil changes, sometimes as often as every 3,000 miles. And many customers ignored the service instruction, ruining their engines. **********The experience soured many dealers and customers on the systems. Even though the auto companies and their suppliers have spent millions in the last three years refining the turbocharging process, executives admit it won't be easy to resell the systems to a suspicious public. **********To pave the way for the new models, the auto companies this year began their marketing campaigns with dealers. Chrysler and Buick sent prototype units to their field offices for evaluation and training. And Ford created a 102-page manual on the Thunderbird turbo model especially for its sales force. **********"There's resistance there," said George L. Lowe, specialty car market plans manager for Ford Division. "People are naturally concerned about things they don't understand."

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/world.main_headline: THE MARINES IN LEBANON: A YEAR OF CHANGING ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/world.print_headline: THE MARINES IN LEBANON: A YEAR OF CHANGING ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/world.body_text: **********Following is a chronology of the use of Marine forces in Lebanon: Aug. 20, 1982 - President Reagan orders 800 marines to participate in three-nation force, with French and Italian forces, to insure order during evacuation of Palestinian and Syrian fighters from Beirut after Israeli siege of the city. Sept. 10, 1982 - Marines depart after last guerrillas leave. **********Sept. 29, 1982 - Marines return in multinational force after massacre of Palestinian civilians in Sabra and Shatila refugee camps at Lebanese invitation to ''restore Lebanese Government sovereignty and authority over the Beirut area'' and occupy positions near Beirut airport. President Reagan says ''there is no intention or expectation that U.S. armed forces will become involved in hostilities.'' Aug. 29, 1983 - Marines come under attack from unidentified militiamen and, for first time since their arrival, shoot back. Aug. 31, 1983 - Secretary of State George P. Shultz says, ''If attacked, the Marines will take care of themselves with vigor.'' Sept. 1, 1983 - President Reagan orders an additional 2,000- man Marine force into the Mediterranean off Beirut so that ''all necessary measures'' can be taken to ''assure the safety'' of the force ashore.   Sept. 8, 1983 - United States warships shell an artillery emplacement in hills southeast of Beirut after gunners there fire at Marine positions near the airport. Sept. 13, 1983 - Reagan Administration says the President has decided that ''the Marines could use firepower - their own and offshore firepower - in defense of the Marines, the other members of the multinational force and the Lebanese armed forces.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/world.main_headline: LEBANESE PHALANGISTS URGE FORCES TO END PROTEST OVER ISRAELI MOVES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/world.print_headline: LEBANESE PHALANGISTS URGE FORCES TO END PROTEST OVER ISRAELI MOVES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/world.body_text: **********The Christian Phalangist militia called today on its supporters in southern Lebanon to end their protest against moves by the Israeli occupation forces to close Phalangist offices in the area. **********Both Phalangist and Israeli officials said the situation in the south was quiet today and that Christian villagers had ended demonstrations and removed burning cars and tires used to block the entry of Israeli troops into Phalangist-dominated villages around Sidon and Nabatiye. **********Negotiations to settle the dispute continued between Israeli and Phalangist representatives in Beirut.  ''Because of the positive atmosphere of the talks yesterday,'' said the spokesman of the Phalangist Lebanese Forces, Fadi Hayek, ''we have asked the population to call off the strikes and remove the roadblocks in order to prepare the atmosphere for further positive talks. We are sure we can reach an agreement which will safeguard the interests of the population in the south and the security imperatives of the Israel Defense Forces.'' **********24 Hours to Shut Offices **********According to Phalangist officials, Israeli troops went to two Phalangist barracks and one Phalangist Party office near Sidon Wednesday evening and told their commanders they had 24 hours to close. An Israeli statement said, however, that the Israelis wanted only one office closed, the Phalangist military police barracks in Kafr Falus, three miles east of Sidon, because it was not coordinating properly with the local Israeli commander. **********Phalangist military sources said negotiations between the Phalangists and the Israelis were now focusing only on the Kafr Falus office and that the Christian militia had ''absolutely no intention'' of allowing the Israelis to close it. **********Defense Minister Moshe Arens, in an interview with ABC News, explained that the Israelis wanted Phalangist bases in southern Lebanon closed because ''it is not healthy to have independent militias running around causing troubles.'' **********An Israeli military spokesman in Yarze, just outside Beirut, said tonight: ''We have asked the Phalangists to evacuate the place at Kafr Falus and we assume that they will. We will give them ample time to leave by themselves.'' **********The Israelis are planning to withdraw their forces from the Beirut area into south Lebanon in coming months and apparently want to remove potential sources of tension beforehand as much as possible.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/25/world.body_text: **********The city of Calgary has received praise from top Olympic officials for its preparations for the 1988 Winter Olympic Games, Frank King, chairman of the organizing committee, said in a telephone interview this week. **********Mr. King said that during a visit in late June, Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, expressed pleasure that the event was ''progressing on all fronts on a very favorable basis.'' **********Although he said there were ''no guarantees,'' he added that local speculation this year that the Games might be moved to an alternate site outside Canada had amounted to ''long-shot speculation.'' Mr. King pointed out that Calgary had a firm contract and that ''there is no reason'' to believe the Olympic committee might break it. **********The New York Times, in a story last Sunday from Banff, Alberta, referred to economic, political and management problems connected with the preparations and mentioned the possibility that the International Olympic Committee might move the Games elsewhere. But that information was several months old and was not sufficiently updated before it was published. **********Among the problems discussed were cost overruns and wrangling between the federal and provincial governments over financing.  But the article did not take into account a meeting this summer of a task force of provincial experts that examined the Saddledome stadium, now under construction, for cost overruns. The task force made a variety of management criticisms and projected that the total cost might prove to be as much as $16.5 million over budget. **********In addition, the Canadian Government has also made its commitment to help finance the Olympics more definite. On June 29 Parliament passed legislation to set up a federal sports lottery, modeled on Britain's soccer lottery, to raise money for the Games. Details remain to be worked out. **********On July 5 Ottawa also announced that it would spend $110 million to help pay for three projects. It has already spent $5.5 million and may spend another $84.5 million for operating expenses. Talks are continuing on the exact amount and form of this aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/busin.main_headline: REAGAN AND O'NEILL SPAR ON TAX BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/busin.print_headline: REAGAN AND O'NEILL SPAR ON TAX BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/busin.body_text: **********On the eve of consideration by the House of Representatives of a Democratic bill to limit the July 1 reduction in income taxes, President Reagan and Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.  traded angry accusations today over whose policies were hurting the middle class. **********Mr. Reagan, speaking to the National Federation of Independent Business, said the Democrats were shedding ''an ocean of crocodile tears'' over Federal deficits and were seeking to impose a ''graveyard philosophy'' of higher taxes and spending. **********The Democrats, he said, were practicing ''the politics of envy'' and were trying to pit one group against another with their proposal to place a ceiling on the tax cut so that families in higher tax brackets would benefit relatively less. **********''It takes a great leap of faith to trust the motivation and wisdom of the self-proclaimed champions of fairness who are now attacking the middle class,'' Mr. Reagan declared. ''The tax 'cap' is not a fairness bill. It's a jobs-destruction bill. It would cut off our nose to spite our face.'' **********After Mr. Reagan's speech, Mr. O'Neill retorted that the limit was ''a long overdue step toward fairness'' aimed at overcoming the ''windfall for the rich'' that he said came from the tax cut. The 10 percent cut in income tax rates scheduled July 1 is the third and last step in a rate reduction that began with a 5 percent cut on Oct. 1, 1981, and was followed by a 10 percent cut on July 1, 1982. **********Mr. O'Neill accused Mr. Reagan of distorting statistics in attacking the Democrats' tax program, and he added: ''The hardworking people of this country do not want crocodile tears or cook-up numbers. They want a fair shake. They want the rich to bear the burden as well as the benefits of Reaganomics.'' **********The sharp words between the President and the Speaker set the stage for a showdown that the Democrats, at least, hope to use as ammunition between now and the 1984 election. **********Although Mr. O'Neill predicted that the tax cut limit would be approved by the House Thursday and had a good chance of passing in the Senate, few expect it to be able to survive Mr. Reagan's promised veto. Thus the debate was an attempt by each side to use the symbolism of the issue. Saving Would Be Held to $720 **********The bill now calls for a maximum tax saving of $720, depending on the tax status of the filer. This means that a married couple, one of whom works, with two dependents and $46,000 or more of gross income would not get the full benefit of the tax-rate cut. **********Democrats in the House estimate that their plan would limit the tax cut for about eight million families and that more than half of them make more than $50,000 a year. But nearly 90 percent of the revenue yielded by the limit would come from families making more than $50,000, according to these calculations. Thus the Democrats view the proposal as punishing those in the upper income brackets. **********Mr. Reagan asserted today, however, that ''capping the third year of the tax cut won't soak the rich, but it will drown millions of taxpayers in the middle class.'' He said a working married couple making ''just over $35,000 in taxable income'' would be pushed from a 33 percent tax bracket into a 37 percent bracket by the Democratic plan. Effects of Inflation Noted **********''I question whether that couple, working to make ends meet, would consider itself rich,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''Let's remember that, just to keep up with inflation, that couple had to double its income in the last 10 years. The couple which earns $35,000 is no more wealthy today than when it earned $16,000 in 1973.'' **********Mr. O'Neill responded that Mr. Reagan was ''playing with the numbers.'' The Speaker said: ''He spoke today of a two-earner family making $35,000 a year that he said would be 'drowned' by the cap. The fact is, just 2 percent of those in that income category will be affected. These are people who do not itemize or have few or no dependents.  They are not a fair example, and the President knows it.'' **********Mr. Reagan also noted that it was the Democrats, not his Administration, who took a key step in 1981 that benefited wealthy people. He was referring to a Democratic amendment, eventually signed into law, that reduced the maximum tax rate on investment income to 50 percent from 70 percent. Tactics That Proved Futile **********The Democrats had advocated the cut in the maximum tax rate in what turned out to be a futile attempt to defeat Mr. Reagan's overall program. **********''Funny how they all forgot about that,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''Well, I haven't forgotten about it because I think it was a great thing to do.'' **********Much of the President's speech was devoted to a spirited, and even spiritual, defense of capitalism and the profit motive.  Speaking of a businessman's willingness to risk his money for investment, Mr. Reagan said business ''works best, creates the greatest wealth and produces the most progress for all'' when it follows ''the teachings of Scripture: Give, and you will be given unto. Search, and you will find. Cast your bread upon the waters, and it will return to you manyfold.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.body_text: **********Gerry Adams, an Irish nationalist who was once considered one of Britain's most wanted guerrillas, went to the House of Commons today but refused to take his seat as a newly elected Member of Parliament. **********It was Mr. Adams's first time in London since 1972, when he was one of seven Irish Republican Army leaders flown in from Northern Ireland under conditions of extreme secrecy for cease-fire talks with the Government. **********The 34-year-old vice president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the banned I.R.A. Provisionals, met with left-wing city leaders and Labor Party Members of Parliament but did not take a seat won June 9 to represent 60,000 people in West Belfast. Sinn Fein supports the I.R.A.'s campaign of violence to oust British troops from Northern Ireland. **********His three-day visit, which is scheduled to end on Thursday, has raised protest from Conservative Party Members of Parliament, who called it a ''total disgrace,'' and from Protestant politicians in Northern Ireland, who denounced him as an ''apologist for gunmen.'' **********''I can not understand any objections to my visit to London when the Irish people have to suffer 30,000 fully armed British troops in their midst,'' Mr. Adams said on his arrival at Heathrow Airport. **********''What am I here to try to start is a dialogue with the British people over the situation in Northern Ireland, which has been disturbed by the British Government,'' he said. **********His visit has been seen as an attempt by the I.R.A. to upstage a British-Irish conference in London Wednesday between the Irish Foreign Minister, Peter Barry, and Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland, James Prior, but Mr. Adams said the timing of his visit was ''totally coincidental.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/world.body_text: **********The United States and Mexico agreed today to promote negotiations in Central America but failed to bridge their differences on resolving the strife in the region. **********A vaguely worded communique issued at the conclusion of two days of talks between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepulveda said: **********''On the subject of Central America, Secretaries Sepulveda and Shultz exchanged views on the situation in the area. They agreed to promote processes of dialogue and negotiation for the purpose of avoiding armed conflict and fostering peaceful conditions and economic development.'' **********The communique said that President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado would meet this year in Mexico. No further details were given. **********Differences Reported Unresolved **********Mexican and American officials indicated after the meetings that longstanding differences over the region remained largely unresolved.  These differences center on Mexico's support for the Sandinist Government of Nicaragua and its recognition of the leftist rebels in El Salvador as a legitimate political force. The United States has sought some form of pressure by Mexico on Nicaragua to blunt what officials say is its export of terrorism to other Central American countries. **********Mr. Shultz, speaking to reporters tonight on a refueling stop at Tampico Airport, said that he saw ''some encouragement'' in Mexico's position toward Nicaragua. Discussing his meetings with Mr.  Sepulveda, Mr. Shultz said: ''He does see as important the cessation of arms from one country to another. That's really what's taking place from Cuba and Nicaragua to El Salvador.'' **********Another source of contention has been Mexico's insistence that all foreign involvement in the area stop. According to United States officials, Mr. Shultz told Mr. Sepulveda that the Reagan Administration was determined ''to continue to support friends and allies and be engaged in the area until a peaceful solution can be achieved.'' **********United States officials sought tonight to play down the differences. One official said the United States and Mexico differed more on means than ends. **********But other officials, both American and Mexican, conceded that essential differences over Central America marked the talks, at which the United States maintained that Nicaragua was a central source of subversion in Central America and was providing major help to the Salvadoran guerrillas. 'Results Will Be Seen in Actions' **********A Mexican diplomat said Monday night that both sides sought ''mutual comprehension in our outlooks in Central America.'' ''The results will be seen in actions, not words,'' he said.  What the two sides appeared to agree on, diplomats said, was the need for some form of regional approach.  Tonight, Mr. Sepulveda flew to Panama to join eight other foreign ministers from the region for a two-day meeting. Asked about the gathering, Mr. Shultz said at a news conference, ''We hope they will succeed.'' **********''The key to this meeting,'' Mr. Shultz went on, ''is that all five Central American countries will be there,'' which he called ''a recognition of the basic fact that the issues are regional.'' **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldridge, who were here with Mr. Shultz, discussed with Mexican officials trade and economic issues. The three Cabinet officials left Mexico City early this evening for Washington after meeting President de la Madrid. **********Central America was a key theme at the meetings, but Mexico's economic situation appeared to dominate them. 200,000 Jobs Reportedly Lost **********Mr. Regan said at a news conference this morning that 200,000 jobs were lost in the United States last year because of the financial crisis in Mexico and the resulting decline in its purchases of American goods. He noted that Mexico, the third largest customer for American exports, bought about $12 billion in United States products last year compared with $18 billion in 1981. **********''We're trying to see what can be done to encourage more trade,'' he said.  Mr. Regan said Mexico was ''definitely'' succeeding in adopting the austerity measures imposed by the International Monetary Fund to gain a $3.9 billion emergency loan last year. The loan was crucial to help tide over Mexico - the largest source of United States oil imports - when it faced default on its $80 billion foreign debt. The largest part of the debt is owed to United States banks. **********''Had they failed,'' Mr. Regan said, ''the hit to our banks would have been awesome.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Oil Futures And Global Disruptions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Oil Futures And Global Disruptions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/busin.body_text: **********NOWHERE is the disarray in the global petroleum market more visible than in the heating oil and gasoline futures trading pits of the New York Mercantile Exchange. **********Not only have the futures prices reflected the sharp drop in oil prices this winter. Last week they also showed that unless the oil refiners take measures to halt the rising surpluses of fuel, their operating losses will be even greater than they have been. **********Last Friday one major refiner, the Exxon Corporation, decided to take action and raised its wholesale price of heating oil by 2 cents a gallon, to 81.5 cents, despite the fact that all big integrated oil companies have been benefiting from the recent price cutting among the contentious members of OPEC as well as among suppliers who do not belong to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********The price increase seemed an anomaly but traders said, in effect, that Exxon had decided to recover its earlier high crude oil costs regardless of the risk of driving away customers. **********Exxon's move caused the spot March futures to rally 1.30, to 75.65 cents, leaving the contract showing a gain of 0.44 cent on the week.  But the near March futures are still well below the 97.25 cents of last Oct. 1, when most retailers had completed ordering for the winter, and the 95 cents posted Nov. 1, the nominal start of the winter heating season. **********''Obviously, the uncommonly mild winter, the recession, consumer conservation and an increase in non-OPEC oil supplies all contributed to the decline in cash and futures prices this season,'' said Steven Errera, president of Energy Futures Inc. ''But the same factors have caused the big oil companies to sustain huge refinery operating losses, which they may not want to let continue much longer,'' he said yesterday. **********In fact, Mr. Errera pointed out, ''It is more profitable today for many refiners to buy heating oil and gasoline on the open market for resale to their customers than to buy crude oil and refine it.'' **********The reason: The market prices of oil products have fallen to levels that make refining uneconomical in this country.  As a rule of thumb, a 42-gallon barrel of crude will yield the following products: 44 percent gasoline, 21 percent in No. 2 grade distillate heating oil, 11 percent in No. 6 and other heavy industrial heating oils, 5 percent in jet fuel, 3 percent in petrochemical feed stocks, 2 percent in asphalt and the remainder in other products. **********Although each refiner has a different mix, the bulk of the refined products - heating oils and gasoline -must be profitable to offset the cost of the raw petroleum and any losses that may be incurred in selling the byproducts. **********According to Mr. Errera's calculations, which were supported by several other oil specialists last week, a $30 barrel of crude is worth less today than the value of all the products extracted from it. Mr. Errera explained: **********''If the average mid-America refiner gets crude at $28 or $28.50 a barrel, it would have to sell heating oils today at between 80 and 82 cents a gallon and gasoline at 81 to 83 cents in order to break even. Last Friday, the cash price for No. 2 heating oil in New York harbor was 78 cents, with leaded regular grade gasoline at 80 cents.  However, cash prices for both fuels have been selling at discounts, which may deepen if retailers can not dispose of heating oil to make room for the gasolines they have ordered for the motoring season.'' **********With the winter two thirds over and the motoring season still a few months away, refiners are not getting anywhere near these break-even prices, Mr. Errera said. **********''Crude would have to be priced at $25 a barrel for most refiners to show profits on today's product mix,'' he said. ''Thus, we may yet see prices move up, surplus supplies or not, until the cheaper wellhead crude prices refiners are now paying move through the industry's pipelines.'' **********Joel Faber, president of a energy futures brokerage house bearing his name, agreed. He noted: ''The oil futures market has been sagging in recent weeks because buyers are waiting for all the cheaper prices they read about to work through the industry's product mixes. How much further will crude prices drop? It depends on each refiner's product mix, competitive factors, how friendly the refiners want to remain with their crude oil suppliers and other imponderables.'' **********While futures traders wait, they have been increasingly engaging in spreading operations, he said. ''The most popular spread today is to buy May heating oil and sell May gasoline, because many think the price spread in favor of leaded gasoline is too wide, despite the seasonal factor,'' he added. **********Last Friday, May heating oil futures closed at 72.89 cents a gallon and May leaded gasoline at 79.72 cents.  Because the gasoline pricing situation has been far less clear than that of heating oil in recent weeks, trading in gasoline futures has soared. Last month, for example, the open interest in leaded gasoline futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange was 6,782 contracts, up more than fourfold from January 1982, while the volume jumped a similar amount, to 22,900 contracts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/21/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; And Policies Did Gyre . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/21/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; And Policies Did Gyre . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/21/busin.body_text: **********THE British economist D. H. Robertson published a little book in 1922 called ''Money'' that made him famous because of his use of quotations from Lewis Carroll's ''Alice'' books as chapter headings. **********The connection between Alice in Wonderland and economics was no accident, no mere whimsy on Robertson's part. Lewis Carroll, who was a professor of mathematics and a most original logician, knew the slipperiness and arbitrariness of applying words and scientific models to the confusion of the social world. **********Carroll in fact appears to have been an amateur of economics. In the first chapter of ''Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There,'' he writes that Alice had never in all her life seen such a face as the White King made ''when he found himself held in the air by an invisible hand'' - an ironic reference no doubt to Adam Smith's most famous metaphor. Kings, presidents and the rest of us are still astonished or even outraged when we discover what the invisible hand of the market can do to us in working its miracles. **********Since Professor Robertson is no longer alive, it must fall to other hands to demonstrate to rising generations the continued relevance of ''Alice'' to economics. Here are some notes on the meaning of ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' today: **********It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the birds and animals that had fallen into it: There was a Duck and a Dodo, a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures. Alice led the way, and the whole party swam to the shore. **********Useful for the coming meeting in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. All the countries, debtor and creditor, are in the Pool of Tears together. Somebody (the United States) must lead them out of it. But that is not to say that the others will listen to the leader. When the bedraggled creatures gathered ashore for a consultation on how to dry out, the Lory, a small parrot, turned sulky and would only say to Alice, ''I am older than you, and must know better.'' **********''The cause of lightning,'' Alice said very decidedly, for she was quite sure about this, ''is the thunder - no, no!'' she hastily corrected herself, ''I meant the other way.'' ''It's too late to correct it,'' said the Red Queen: ''When you've once said a thing, that fixes it, and you must take the consequences.'' **********Once the financial markets are convinced that the growth of the money supply determines the growth of the economy, that fixes it, and there is no point in trying to regulate anything but the money supply. Similarly, once you say that deficits don't cause inflation, don't cause high interest rates, in short don't matter, you can't say deficits do matter and start raising taxes. It's too late; you must take the consequences. **********Well, then the books are something like our books, only the words go the wrong way. **********Everything is reversed now that we are on the other side of the looking glass. A strong recovery is bad for the stock market, a weak recovery is good for the stock market. For with a strong recovery, the Federal Reserve will have to tighten the money supply and interest rates will rise, but with a weak recovery, the Fed can ease up and interest rates will decline. **********''Will you walk a little faster?'' said a whiting to a snail. ''There's a porpoise close behind us, and he's treading on my tail.'' **********Unless the European economies grow faster, unemployment will increase, because productivity is rising and the labor force is growing faster than real output. This is a better quotation than the one about Alice's running to stay in the same place, for the level of unemployment, with different rates of real economic growth, may increase, decrease or remain the same. **********'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves **********Did gyre and gimble in the wabe. **********Explaining the poem ''Jabberwocky,'' Humpty Dumpty said a word like slithy, meaning lithe and slimy, was a ''portmanteau - there are two meanings packed into one word.'' **********Hence, stagflation - stagnation plus inflation. The important thing is to see stagflation as one state, not two states, requiring a different treatment from stagnation or inflation alone. Robert Triffin, professor emeritus at Yale, prefers a different portmanteau: infession, a combination of inflation and recession, suggesting a different diagnosis, with inflation coming first. ''When I use a word,'' Humpty Dumpty said, ''it means just what I choose it to mean - neither more nor less.'' **********'' 'Tis so,'' said the Duchess, ''and the moral of that is, 'Oh, 'tis love, 'tis love, that makes the world go round.' '' **********''Somebody said,'' Alice whispered, ''that it's done by everybody minding their own business!'' **********''Ah, well! It means much the same thing,'' said the Duchess. **********More economic philosophy by Adam Smith out of, as they say at the race track, Ronald Reagan. Champions of the poor, blacks, women and the jobless disagree. This could be a major issue in the electoral campaign of 1984. **********This barely scratches the surface of what Lewis Carroll has to offer political economy. His greatest irony was probably the line, ''Oh, dear, what nonsense I'm talking.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/18/world.body_text: **********As the Nicaraguan Government embarks on a policy of accommodation with its domestic critics, two new opposition leaders have emerged who seem dedicated to liberal democracy and determined not to flee the country. **********One of them is Bishop Pablo Antonio Vega Mantilla from the central province of Chontales. He was recently elected to head the Nicaraguan Episcopal Conference, which governs the Roman Catholic Church here. **********The other opposition leader is Enrique Bolanos Geyer, who has been chosen to head the country's largest business organization. Both have shown themselves to be adroit activitists and critics of the Sandinista Government. **********'The Right People' **********''We sense that the moment of definition of the revolution is coming soon,'' said Ramiro Gurdian, a businessman who helped Mr. Bolanos win election as head of the Superior Council of Private Enterprise. ''We want to be sure we have the right people in there throwing the ball.'' **********Mr. Bolanos is known here as an outspoken anti-Communist who, unlike many Nicaraguan businessmen, has never supported the Sandinista movement. In the months since he has taken over the Superior Council it has become one of the main centers of opposition to the Government. **********When the Sandinistas asked a variety of opposition leaders last month to testify about how ''Yankee aggression'' was affecting them, many were ready to accept. But Mr. Bolanos persuaded them not to do so, arguing that the limitations on subject matter and the low level of the commission that would hear the testimony constituted an insult to the opposition. **********When the Government invited Nicaraguan exiles to return home through a decree issued two weeks ago, Mr. Bolanos was quick to argue that the decree was in no sense an amnesty since it offered no guarantees of security to anyone who took advantage of it. His sharply worded statement was published in full in La Prensa, the opposition newspaper.   Testing the Sandinistas **********Mr. Bolanos's newest idea is to test the Sandinistas' proclaimed policy of dialogue by asking that the Superior Council be permitted to sponsor a daily program on radio and a weekly one on television in which political and economic topics would be discussed. At present, independent radio news programs function under censorship, and the opposition has no access to television. **********''The goals have changed,'' Mr. Bolanos said in an interview. ''There was a time when we thought we could make the Sandinistas come fairly close to their original Government programs. But now they have made very clear that they are Marxist-Leninists who are moving toward creating a totalitarian state.'' **********The coordinator of the Nicaraguan junta, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, was asked about his Government's commitment to Marxism in a recent interview and replied: ''We do not use cliches, and we do not accept that cliches should be imposed upon us. Our roots are profoundly Nicaraguan, though we do not deny our relationship with the universal ideology.'' **********Mr. Bolanos represents a significant number of businessmen who, though disaffected, have chosen to remain in Nicaragua. On his wall is a poster carrying an outline map of Nicaragua and the legend, ''I Need You, Don't Abandon Me.''  'Setting an Example' **********''We have the moral credibility to speak out because we have remained here,'' Mr. Bolanos said. ''Our counterparts in Cuba fled, and that did not work. We are setting an example for many people who might otherwise give up hope. And we give our employees more freedom than they have in government enterprises, since they do not have to perform guard duty or follow any political line.'' **********Bishop Vega, who at 64 is 9 years older than Mr. Bolanos, is a critic of a different sort. **********''We are not a political opposition,'' he said recently, ''we are believers in any regime based on Christian values. In Nicaragua today, people feel an excessive control and are unable to realize their full human potential. **********''Much of the creative dynamism of the revolution has been lost,'' the Bishop went on, ''and it has been replaced by a scheme imposed from outside. The church in Latin America has a great radical potential and can be more revolutionary than any political movement because it is interested in human liberation, not power.''  News Conference Creates a Stir **********Bishop Vega, who in October replaced Archbishop Miguel Obando y Bravo as president of the Episcopal Conference, impressed many Nicaraguans who had barely heard of him with his statements at his first news conference last month. Copies of the transcript are circulating in religious and diplomatic circles. **********Asked by a pro-Sandinista reporter whether he was firmly opposed to a foreign invasion of Nicaragua, Bishop Vega replied, ''The church rejects any invasion, whether it is an ideological invasion through repressive violence or whether it is an armed, military intervention.'' **********He also repeated the hierarchy's criticism of the so-called popular church, whose priests function independently and, in Nicaragua, support the Sandinista Government. **********''What is called the 'popular church' is neither popular nor a church,'' he said. ''It is not a church because it does not lead to God, and it is not popular because it is allied with power instead of man.'' **********Both Mr. Bolanos and Bishop Vega have emerged at a time when the Sandinista Government is seeking to show a commitment to democracy. They have taken advantage of the freer climate that has lately prevailed in Nicaragua to press their criticism of the Government.   Opposition Weak and Fragmented **********Opposition political parties in Nicaragua are small and weak, and they have not managed to unite behind a common program. For this reason, the actions of anti-Government activists in the church and the private sector, together with those of La Prensa, are the principal forms of opposition in Nicaragua. **********Mr. Bolanos and Bishop Vega have never met, but a Latin diplomat who knows both of them said they complement each other. **********''One represents political opposition, the other speaks from a spiritual point of view,'' the diplomat said. ''Both of them seem to sense that in their new positions, they have serious responsibilities to history.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/17/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. INTRODUCES COMPUTER TO REPLACE SYSTEM 34 MODEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/17/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. INTRODUCES COMPUTER TO REPLACE SYSTEM 34 MODEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/17/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new medium-sized general purpose computer today as an eventual replacement for its existing System/34 model. **********The new computer, called the System/36, will have 20 percent to 70 percent better performance than the System/34, which was introduced in 1977 and will now be phased out of production, I.B.M. said. The company made its announcement at the National Computer Conference, which opened here today. **********I.B.M. has sold or leased more than 60,000 System/34 computers, according to analysts' estimates and trade press reports. Many users, however, have run out of capacity and were being sought as customers by I.B.M. competitors such as Wang Laboratories and the Hewlett-Packard Company. The System/36 should give these customers ''a little more breathing room,'' said George Weiss of the Quantum Science Corporation, a New York market research firm. **********Shipments of the System/36 will begin in July, I.B.M. said. The price will start at $21,000 for a basic unit with 128 thousand characters of internal memory and 30 million characters of disk storage. A large unit, with 512,000 characters of memory and 400 million characters of disk storage, will sell for $62,000. With printers and displays added, a total large installation might sell for as much as $176,000, I.B.M. said. Western Electric **********Also at the computer conference, the Western Electric Company, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, took a further step into the computer business. It announced that it had entered into agreement to produce versions of its computer operating system for microprocessor chips made by the Intel Corporation, Motorola Inc. and the National Semiconductor Corporation. **********An operating system is a program that directs the flow of data within a computer. Western Electric's system, which was developed at Bell Laboratories and is known as Unix, has been finding increasing popularity among manufacturers and users of computers ranging from the more powerful desktop computers to large mainframes. **********Today's agreement is expected to help Unix become a standard for use on computers that use Intel, Motorola and National Semiconductor chips. Intel and Motorola, in particular, are the leading manufacturers of microprocessors, the so-called computers on a chip that are the heart of most desktop computers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.main_headline: U.N. STUDY SEES SLOWER GROWTH IN POPULATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.print_headline: U.N. STUDY SEES SLOWER GROWTH IN POPULATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.body_text: **********A worldwide effort to limit population growth is beginning to achieve results, according to a United Nations study. **********The report, issued Thursday by the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, said the rate of population increase since 1965 will have fallen by 16.7 percent by 1985. **********From 1965 to 1970 the number of people in the world increased by 2.4 percent a year, the study said. In contrast, it said, the rate of increase is expected to be 2 percent a year for the years 1980 to 1985. **********The study predicted that global population would continue to grow until the end of the 21st century and then stabilize at 10.2 billion people, or more than twice the current total of 4.6 billion. 'The Notion of Having Fewer' **********The executive director of the United Nations agency, Rafael M.  Salas of the Philippines, said the pace of population gains had slowed because ''the notion of having fewer children has spread to the developing countries.'' National programs urging small families are exerting an influence, he said. **********The Fund for Population Activities, which is supported by voluntary contributions from United Nations members, provides technical aid to nations that operate family-planning programs. The fund issues annual studies on world population growth. **********Mr. Salas said the idea of smaller families had been ''largely accepted in the largest countries, India and China,'' whose people make up 40 percent of the world's population. He said the growth in China's population was now 1.5 percent and, in India's, close to 2 percent. **********Rising income levels have reduced the pressure on families in the developing world to have children as an insurance against old age, he said. In addition, better health services have reduced the rate of infant mortality, he said, thus decreasing the need for many births.  Finally, more women are entering the labor force in the third world and have less time to give to infants. A Gap Between Rich and Poor **********The report said the number of infants who die in their first year had fallen sharply around the world although there was still a huge gap between rich and poor countries. **********Among industrial nations, infant mortality has fallen from 56 in every 1,000 births in 1950 to 19 in 1980. Over the same period in developing countries the rate has dropped to 100, from 164, and is now estimated at 90. This still means 10 million infant deaths yearly in Asia, Africa and Latin America. **********In 1974 the fund organized a conference that set targets for, among other things, life expectancy in rich and poor nations. Next year another conference, to be held in Mexico City, is due to hear that the targets are not being met, Mr. Salas said. **********Participants at the 1974 meeting spoke of hopes that the average life span would increase to 62 years by 1985 and 74 years at the end of the century. Instead, Mr. Salas said, life expectancy is expected to reach 59.2 years in 1985 and 63.9 in the year 2000. **********''Economic development hasn't kept up to provide the medical and health facilities needed for longer life and reduced infant mortality,'' he said. The Key to Leveling Off **********The report singled out smaller families and fewer births as the key to leveling off population. In birth statistics, once again there were vast differences between rich and poor. Third-world rates of 33 births per 1,000 population are more than twice the 16 births per 1,000 people in industrial nations. **********However, the rate is dropping among the poor, the study said. From 1970 to 1975 it averaged 37 births per 1,000 population and it is expected to fall to 31.4 in the years 1980 to 1985. **********The growth of population in the third world, even at a slower rate, is too much for the available food. By the end of the century, developing countries may have 441 million more people than they can feed. But this problem could be eased, the United Nations report said, with greater use of fertilizer, pesticides and high-yielding seeds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.main_headline: A CHIEF EXECUTIVE ELECTED BY G.& W.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A CHIEF EXECUTIVE ELECTED BY G.& W.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Martin S. Davis, 56 years old, was elected chief executive officer of Gulf and Western Industries yesterday, succeeding Charles G.  Bluhdorn, who died on Saturday. **********The board of directors decided to leave the post of chairman vacant in memory of Mr. Bluhdorn, who founded Gulf and Western 25 years ago. Mr. Davis, who had been executive vice president and chief administrative officer, was named instead to the new position of vice chairman. **********In a prepared statement, Mr. Davis said: ''It is a tribute to Mr.  Bluhdorn that he left in place a decisive board and a strong management team. The course Mr. Bluhdorn and his senior management charted over the past quarter of a century resulted in unprecedented growth, and the long-range programs now being implemented are reshaping Gulf and Western into a company better positioned to not only continue this growth, but to capitalize on new opportunities.  This orderly transition insures the continuity of purpose.'' **********Conjecture among analysts who follow Gulf and Western had been that the board would elect David N. Judelson, the company's president, as chief executive. Mr. Judelson, 55, remains as president. In addition to Mr. Davis, two other executive vice presidents, Lawrence E.  Levinson, 52, and James I. Spiegel, 55, had also been considered strong contenders for the top job. **********Mr. Davis joined G.&W. as a senior vice president in 1969 after serving as chief operating officer at Paramount Pictures, a Gulf and Western subsidiary. Before his promotion yesterday, he operated under the title of executive vice president and chief administrative officer, a post he had held since December 1974. Mr. Davis has been a director of G.&W. since 1967. **********A native New Yorker, Mr. Davis attended the City College of New York and New York University.  The board also elected Yvette M. Bluhdorn as a director to fill the seat of her late husband.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/world.print_headline: Israel Pledges to Help Liberia In Ships, Roads and Farming
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/world.body_text: **********Israel has promised to provide agricultural, technical, medical and economic aid to Liberia, according to an agreement reached by leaders of the two countries here today. **********The accord signed by President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia and Prime Minister Menachem Begin does not entail commitments on military cooperation. **********At a news conference, Foreign Minister T. Ernest Eastman of Liberia said his country had no intention of procuring arms from Israel. **********Clauses in the agreement call for Israeli cooperation on Liberian road construction, shipping, air services and banking. Most of this assistance will come from private Israeli companies encouraged by the Government, rather than as direct state aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/busin.main_headline: Oppenheimer Chooses Top Official of New Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Oppenheimer Chooses Top Official of New Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Oppenheimer & Company, the investment firm, has set up a new subsidiary to expand its leveraged-buyout activities and has chosen a corporate executive, rather than a Wall Street man, to head it. **********Stephen M. McGrath, 47, will be president of the new unit, to be called the Oppenheimer Strategic Investments Corporation. **********He has spent 11 years at the Warner-Lambert Corporation, where his most recent position has been senior vice president for planning and development. Mr. McGrath was a major shaper of Warner-Lambert's recent strategic restructuring. **********''The classic leveraged buyout will be one of our activities,'' Mr. McGrath said. He added that the Oppenheimer subsidiary would also help companies redeploy assets and sell off divisions, in some cases buying them ''and creating some value for them.'' **********Oppenheimer has been a pioneer in the leveraged buyout, a strategy in which a company's assets are partly used to obtain the financing for its purchase. Two who refined the art were Leon Levy and Jack Nash, who sold their stakes in Oppenheimer last year to its new parent, Mercantile House Holdings of London. **********Messrs. Levy and Nash are now together in Oddysey Partners, whose most recent move was an unsuccessful attempt to get the Trans World Corporation to redeploy assets by spinning off its nonairline operations. **********At Warner-Lambert, Mr. McGrath was a major developer of a strategic restructuring that oriented the company toward professional and consumer health care. The program included the divestiture of 10 units. **********Mr. McGrath, a graduate of Iona College, joined Price Waterhouse & Company in 1957 and moved to Sterling Drug Inc. in 1962. He was controller when he left for Warner-Lambert 10 years later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Citibank has agreed to pay $323,000 to settle charges that it violated export laws aimed at prohibiting American companies from cooperating with a boycott of Israel by Arab nations. The Commerce Department, which announced the agreement today, said the fine was the largest ever imposed under the anti-boycott provisions of the Export Administration Act. **********The department said a Chicago manufacturer, the FMC Corporation, had also settled anti-boycott charges, agreeing to pay an $8.500 fine. **********Citibank and FMC neither admitted nor denied the allegations in settling the charges, the department said. **********Under the law, companies and individuals are forbidden to engage in restrictive trade practices and to give information about their business relations with boycotted countries or blacklisted people. They must also report promptly to the United States Government any requests they receive to do so. The Commerce Department said the companies had failed to comply with the requirement that they report such requests.  Reports Due on Compliance **********In addition to agreeing to the fines, both concerns have agreed to take ''corrective measures'' to insure future compliance of its branch offices and to report those measures within six months, the department said. **********Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, said Citibank had failed to report promptly that it received 337 boycott-related requests from Kuwait, Oman and Abu Dhabi over three years beginning in January 1980. **********Mr. Brady said the bank processed letters of credit covering goods intended for shipment to those countries that directed among other things that the goods not originate in boycot ted countries nor be shipped on carriers ineligible to enter Arab states. **********''If there were any actual or technical violations, they were inadvertent or unintentional processing errors,'' said Susan A. Weeks, assistant vice president in charge of press relations for Citibank. ''We're entering agreement because of our support of the anti-boycott statute and because any further litigation would have been excessively costly for Citibank and the Government.'' **********The department said FMC, which makes machinery, chemicals and power transmission equipment, failed to report 11 requests from Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain and Abu Dhabi for information.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/busin.main_headline: G.M. Will Reopen A Plant in Georgia
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/busin.print_headline: G.M. Will Reopen A Plant in Georgia
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation announced today that it plans to reopen its idled assembly plant in Lakewood, Ga., and transfer full-size car production from Oshawa, Ontario, to Wilmington, Del. **********G.M.'s president, F. James McDonald, said 1,625 indefinitely laid-off workers would be called back to the Lakewood plant. **********He said the plant reopening and production transfer were being made to make room for a fifth North American assembly line to produce the company's series of fuel-efficient midsize cars for the 1985 model year. **********Mr. McDonald said the Lakewood plant would resume production of Chevrolet Chevettes and Pontiac 1000 models on one shift in early 1984. The plant was producing those same models when it was closed in September 1982 as a result of poor market conditions. **********The Wilmington plant, which now produces Chevrolet Chevettes and Pontiac 1000 models, will be converted to assemble full-size models. Full-size cars are currently produced at one of two assembly lines at Oshawa, and that Canadian production line will turn out front-wheel-drive midsize cars. **********Mr. McDonald said changes at the two plants will be effective with production for the 1985 model year.  One of the two assembly lines at Oshawa already produces cars in the midsize series that includes Chevrolet Celebrity, Pontiac 6000, Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera and Buick Century. When the second Oshawa line is converted, it will raise to five the number of G.M. facilities producing those models. In addition to the two lines in Canada, the cars are produced in Doraville, Ga.; Framingham, Mass., and Oklahoma City.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; ITT Increases 1.3%; Grumman Up 83.9%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The ITT Corporation said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter edged up 1.3 percent from the year-earlier period and that sales slipped 8.9 percent. The company said the results were in line with its targets. **********ITT, which recently changed its name from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said net income in the latest three months rose to $151.5 million, or $1.01 a share, from $149.6 million, or $1.01 a share, in the quarter a year earlier, when two million fewer shares were outstanding. Revenues slipped to $5.1 billion, from $5.6 billion. **********''Their results were slightly better than I had expected, and the third quarter should also show some increase,'' said Larry Baker, analyst at E. F. Hutton Group Inc. ''I am projecting $4.75 a share fully diluted for all of 1983, up from $4.68 fully diluted last year.'' **********Included in ITT's second-quarter results was $9.8 million in income from a capital transaction by Standard Telephone Cables P.L.C., an associated company in Britain that is 35.4-percent owned by ITT. **********''Sales are down because of divestitures,'' said Harry Edelson, analyst at the First Boston Corporation. ITT has sold about 50 companies in the past four years. **********He added that ITT's cyclical businesses, such as insurance, pulp, automobile parts, hotels and telecomunications, which have been hampered by the recession, should rebound in 1984. **********''Second-quarter earnings were on target with our projections,'' said Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman, president and chief executive. ''As the economy continues its gradual upswing, we expect significant improvement in operating earnings for the full year.'' **********Mr. Araskog said that earnings for all of 1983 were expected to remain about the same as those in 1982, even though last year there were after-tax gains of $120.5 million resulting from the sale of ITT's majority holding in its British telecommunications unit. **********ITT, which derived about 47 percent of its sales and 56 percent of its net income from domestic operations in 1982 and the remainder from abroad, said foreign-exchange effects increased per-share earnings 6 cents a share in the second quarter, compared with an increase of 7 cents a share from such translations a year earlier. **********Grumman **********The Grumman Corporation, which recently sold its money-losing bus subsidiary, said its net income in the second quarter jumped 83.9 percent, to $26.3 million, or 93 cents a share, from $14.3 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up five-tenths of 1 percent, to $548.2 million, from $545.3 milllion. **********''The most significant improvement in net income resulted from the absence of losses on the discontinued operation of the Flxible bus program, which amounted to $21.2 million in the 1982 period,'' Grumman said. **********On Monday, Grumman, an aerospace company based in Bethpage, L.I., announced that it would receive $41 million from the sale of Flxible to the General Automotive Corporation. **********The Flxible subsidiary stopped manufacturing the troubled Model 837 bus a year ago. The bus had developed cracks in its frame soon after it went into operation in various cities, including New York City.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/busin.main_headline: Head of Two Divisions Named President of Izod
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Head of Two Divisions Named President of Izod
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Izod Ltd., the General Mills subsidiary with the alligator emblem, announced yesterday that Robert Tutnauer, hired five months ago to head the unit's small international and accessories divisions, had been named to the presidency and to a newly created position as chief operating officer. **********John B. Holmes, formerly president and chief executive officer of Izod, was appointed chairman and chief executive officer. Martin P.  Krasner, formerly president of Monet Jewelers, another General Mills unit, was appointed president of Izod's accessories division. **********Mr. Tutnauer, who is 48, will be responsible for most of Izod's day-to-day operations, including the men's, women's, children's and accessories divisions. He will report to Mr. Holmes, who will concentrate on strategy and long-range planning, the company said.  Izod is based in New York. **********Mr. Holmes, 53, has spent his entire career at Izod, which has annual sales of $400 million. He joined the company in 1959 as a sales trainee, and became president in 1973. He was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment. **********Jane Evans, a General Mills executive vice president who heads the company's fashion group, the major element of which is Izod, said the goal of the reorganization was to get Mr. Holmes ''out of the role of the firefighter and more into the role of thinker and strategy planner.'' She said Mr. Tutnauer, a former senior vice president at Parfumes Stern, had been hired in February with the idea of appointing him president. However, she added, ''we wanted to see first if he was as good as we thought he was.'' **********Mr. Tutnauer, a ''born and bred'' New Yorker who graduated from Brooklyn College in 1956 with a degree in economics, said there had been no understanding of a promotion when he was hired. As for what the changes will mean, he said, ''There wasn't a chief operating officer position, now there's a chairman and a C.E.O.'' in addition to a chief operating officer. ''I think we're pretty well situated,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/busin.body_text: **********An investors group headed by the Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs has pulled out of an agreement to buy the Kaiser Steel Corporation, a Kaiser official said today. **********Mr. Jacobs met with Kaiser officials in Oakland on Wednesday and told them that he was unwilling to go ahead with the deal under terms of a May 27 agreement, according to the spokesman, Montye Male. **********But she added that negotiations between Kaiser and Mr. Jacobs were continuing to see if an acceptable revision in the agreement could be worked out. **********The May 27 proposal was valued at $271.4 million, up from an earlier $255.6 million offer by the Jacobs group that was rejected by Kaiser's board as inadequate. **********The latest proposal called for holders of Kaiser's common stock - other than the Jacobs group - to receive $19.50 a share plus two new nonvoting preferred stocks worth $25. **********The Jacobs group already owns 16.3 percent of Kaiser's 7.27 million shares.  Kaiser, which has 5,400 employees, reported a pretax loss of $125 million last year and a loss of $11.4 million in the first quarter of this year. **********In Minneapolis, a receptionist at Jacobs Industries said no one was available for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.body_text: **********The new Salvadoran Defense Minister today defended the performance of his country's military forces, but he said he had begun a review of the command structure that might result in the replacement of some high-ranking officers. **********''Changes will come at the opportune moment,'' said the minister, Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova. **********He said he would soon start visiting military bases in various parts of the country for a firsthand view of their operations. **********On Wednesday, General Vides Casanova spent several hours at air force headquarters, reportedly meeting with the air force commander, Col. Juan Rafael Bustillo, and other top officers. A clash between Colonel Bustillo and the previous defense minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, led to General Garcia's resignation **********General Vides Casanova, who was named to his post less than two weeks ago and was confirmed in it last week by Salvador's Constituent Assembly, said he wished Salvadoran insurgents had ''the courage to face the armed forces directly'' instead of resorting to guerrilla warfare. **********Gesturing toward the reporters facing him, the general, who in the past has appeared retiring and reserved in public, said, ''I challenge the heads of guerrilla groups to face me personally in front of all of you.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/world.main_headline: SRI LANKA ROUNDS UP LEFTIST PARTY MEMBERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/world.print_headline: SRI LANKA ROUNDS UP LEFTIST PARTY MEMBERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/world.body_text: **********The Government rounded up members of three banned leftist political parties today and temporarily lifted a nationwide curfew, giving people the chance to buy food after a week of ethnic fighting in which more than 200 people have been reported killed. **********Douglas Liyanage, secretary of the Ministry of State, said orders had been issued for the arrest of a number of members of the Communist Party, which has one seat in the 168-member Parliament, and of the Janatha Vimukthi Peramus and Nova Sana Samaj Parties, which have none. He refused to say how many people were being picked up. **********Mr. Liyanage and other officials have indicated that the Government believes the three leftist parties caused the violence between the minority Tamils and the majority Sinhalese by taking advantage of Sinhalese anger over the killing of 13 soldiers on July 23. Tamils were blamed for the killings. The Government is said to believe the leftists want to overthrow President J. W. Jayewardene. **********Cabinet ministers have also said there is evidence that ''foreign elements'' are behind the disturbances. In an editorial today, The Colombo Sun called for the closing of all Soviet bloc embassies, specifically those of the Soviet Union and East Germany.   Curfew Lifted for 9 Hours **********The two-day-old nationwide curfew was lifted for nine hours, from 5 A.M. to 2 P.M., and no violence was reported. The Government said the curfew would be lifted for 10 hours on Tuesday. **********Trade Minister Lalith Athulathmudali said in a speech tonight that Sri Lanka should forget past violence and put the unity of the nation above individual differences. **********Mr. Liyanage announced a broadening of censorship to include ''other materials'' - presumably photographs - in addition to news reports. He said that the use of cameras would be restricted and that during the curfew hours journalists could go only to and from their hotels and the Ministry of Information. **********2 Islanders Die in Paris **********PARIS, Aug. 1 (Reuters) - The running battle between two Sri Lanka ethnic groups, the Tamils and the Sinhalese, has spread from their country to Paris, where the police said two people died in weekend violence. **********The police said extra forces equipped in riot gear were sent to areas inhabited by the two groups after a Tamil was reportedly pushed to his death from a window on Saturday night and another Tamil was stabbed to death in a subway station Sunday night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The J. C. Penney Company, citing an extraordinary gain in last year's second quarter, said yesterday that net income in the three months ended July 30 fell 8.3 percent, while sales edged up 3.1 percent. **********But five other retail chains, buoyed by the general upturn in the nation's economy, reported sharply higher earnings for the latest quarter. **********The Allied Stores Corporation and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation reported that profits more than tripled. Carter Hawley Hale Stores said its earnings nearly tripled. The May Department Stores Company reported a 50.5 percent increase, and the Dayton Hudson Corporation said earnings rose 36.7 percent. **********Penney, the nation's third largest retailer of general merchandise through its stores and a catalogue business, said net income in the latest quarter fell to $55 million, or 74 cents a share, from $60 million, or 82 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales edged up to $2.62 billion, from $2.54 billion. **********Results in last year's second quarter included a $13 million gain on the nontaxable exchange of common shares for a portion of sinking-fund debentures outstanding. **********Excluding this nonoperating item, operating earnings in the latest quarter rose 14.6 percent, to a record $55 million, from $48 million a year ago.  Per-share operating earnings jumped to 74 cents, from 67 cents last year, when there were about 2 million fewer shares outstanding. **********David V. Seibert, chairman, said gross profit margins continued to increase as a result of ''a more fashionable mix of merchandise'' and no LIFO, or last-in first-out, inventory accounting provisions. Associated Dry Goods **********Associated Dry Goods, citing continued strength in both its department store and discount store businesses, said net income advanced to $17.4 million, or 87 cents a share, from $5.2 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. Associated, which operates Lord & Taylor among other stores, said sales rose 17.4 percent, to $832.8 million, from $709.2 million. Allied Stores **********Allied Stores, whose chains include Jordan Marsh and Stern's, said net income in the quarter rose to $16.1 million, or 77 cents a share, from $5.1 million, or 25 cents a share. Sales increased 16.5 percent, to $799 million, from $685.9 million. Carter Hawley Hale **********Carter Hawley Hale said net income in the period rose to $4.7 million, or 13 cents a share, from $1.7 million, or 4 cents a share, including debenture gains, a year before. Sales rose 18.7 percent, to $769.5 million, from $648.2 million. The company, with units including John Wanamaker in Philadelphia and Bergdorf Goodman in New York, attributed much of the gain to a decline in expenses. May Department Stores **********May, citing strong store-for-store earnings increases, said profits in the quarter rose to $31 million, or $1.07 a share, from $20.6 million, or 70 cents a share. Revenues climbed 15.7 percent, to $921.1 million, from $796.1 million, the St. Louis-based retailer said. Dayton Hudson **********Dayton Hudson, based in Minneapolis, said net income rose to $36.1 million, or 37 cents a share, from $26.4 million, or 27 cents a share. Revenues rose 24.2 percent, to $1.54 billion, from $1.24 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Venezuela will argue for restraint when OPEC's market monitoring committee meets on Sept. 13 in Vienna to review production quotas, senior officials of the Ministry of Energy and Mines said today. **********The meeting was advanced from Sept. 25, but the officials played down suggestions that this had resulted from pressure by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for higher quotas. **********One official said it was felt that the original date was a little late to decide fourth-quarter policy. **********Although there are signs of increasing demand, the officials said, it was too early to raise the OPEC production ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day. Pressure for this has come more from outside OPEC than from within, they said.
