https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.main_headline: U.S. AGRICULTURAL SHOW OPENS IN MOSCOW PARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.print_headline: U.S. AGRICULTURAL SHOW OPENS IN MOSCOW PARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********An exhibition of American agricultural and food- processing equipment, the first American trade show in the Soviet Union since 1977, opened in a Moscow park today with 105 companies displaying everything from giant combines to fast blini makers. **********Called ''Agribusiness USA-83,'' the exhibit was conceived last November by the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, an organization of American companies and Soviet enterprises, after President Reagan said he would keep agricultural exports free of sanctions and boycotts. **********Clustered in a 5,500-square-yard pavilion in Moscow's Sokolniki Park, a diverse group of exhibitors that included International Harvester, John Deere, Dow Chemical, Monsanto, Ralston Purina and the state of Nebraska set up their slide shows, samples, snack bars and pamphlets to attract a share of the billions of dollars that Moscow is expected to spend on its crash ''food program.'' The program was started 18 months ago by the late Leonid I. Brezhnev and accelerated by his successor as Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov. **********The goal of the food program, as Mr. Brezhnev put it, was ''to have adequate food and fodder resources of our own which would put us beyond the reach of chance.'' The creation of agricultural associations at various governmental levels is the centerpiece of the program. **********The political significance of the exhibition, after the strains between the two countries in the last few years, was evident in references by speakers to the long gap since the last American show, an oil and gas exhibition in 1977, and in veiled questions about the United States' reliability as a trade partner. **********The senior American spokesman, Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company of Decatur, Ill., and a director of the trade council, spoke strongly against political interference in trade at a news conference and at the opening ceremony. Government sanctions, he argued, had proved ''notoriously ineffective'' and had served only to throw trade to America's competitors. **********''We are here more or less out of fear,'' he said, ''fear of losing business to someone else.'' Mr. Andreas also argued for trade as a way to ensure peace ''Our trade efforts may be even more important than arms controls,'' he said.  Soviet Trade View **********Vladimir N. Sushkov, the Soviet co-chairman of the trade council and Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade, avoided direct criticism of American trade policies. But he said, ''Our position is that if a government has given export licenses and contracts have been signed, nobody, not even God, could violate this.'' **********Mr. Sushkov focused on the Soviet food program, under which large sums have been earmarked to upgrade the foundering Soviet food-supply industry. ''There are good opportunities in this market,'' he told exhibitors. ''If you brought good machinery and good technology, you can look to good success.'' **********A sign of Soviet reserve, however, evidently reflecting the tensions in current relations with Washington and the history of American curbs on trade with the Soviet Union, was the fact that the opening ceremonies were not shown on Soviet television. Hard Bargaining Foreseen **********Officials of the trade council said they expected tough bargaining because the Russians seemed more intent on importing technology, while the Americans were looking largely to export finished equipment. **********Organizers said they expected 10,000 Soviet trade and agricultural officials to visit the exhibition through Oct. 25. They said that $10 million worth of equipment had been brought to Moscow for the show, and that the Commerce Department had endorsed the exhibition as being ''fully consistent with U.S. policy on trade with the U.S.S.R.'' **********At the exhibit, large combines and plows made by International Harvester and John Deere dominated the interior of the glass-walled building, while Caterpillar bulldozers stood outside. Booths in the building offered equipment ranging from potato chip makers to chicken eviscerators. **********American Cyanamid, Stauffer Chemical, Du Pont, Monsanto, Dow and other chemical manufacturers displayed fertilizers. Other companies showed models of silos, potato harvesters, poultry and livestock feeding systems, irrigation equipment, agricultural laboratories and hundreds of other commodities. **********The De Francisci Machine Corporation, of Brooklyn, attracted curious first-day visitors with its blini maker, which turns out 1,000 of the thin pancakes an hour. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/world.main_headline: IN JAPAN, A CRIME WAVE IS MEASURED IN DROPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/world.print_headline: IN JAPAN, A CRIME WAVE IS MEASURED IN DROPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/world.body_text: **********To hear the national police tell it, Japan had better start worrying about crime. **********The number of ''wanton murders'' - usually known as senseless street killings in the United States - nearly doubled in 1982, the police said. There was also what they called a surge in ''vicious'' crimes by foreigners, as well as more homicides and robberies by teen- agers and a new array of crimes involving the illicit use of computers. **********''These kinds of crimes are rooted in the changing society, and there are indications that they will be on the rise,'' the National Police Agency said in a new report on criminality in Japan. **********But a look at the figures from a different direction tells another story. **********True, there were nearly twice as many ''wanton murders'' than in the previous year. That brought the total all the way up to 13, in a population of 118 million. New York City records about that many murders on especially rough holiday weekends.   18 Cases of Computer Crime **********Yes, young people committed many more murders and robberies. But the number of reported rapes declined appreciably, and the total of arrests for teen-age criminal offenses, 2,344, was hardly high by American standards. **********As for computer crime, the frauds that the police fretted about came to a grand total of 18 cases - the electronic thieves making off, all told, with less than $425,000. **********If anything, the very worrying about the numbers in the report underscored a phenomenon as unvarying as cherry blossoms in spring: Japan may be the safest country in the world, and if it isn't, it will do. **********Homicides totaled 1,764 last year, 10 more than in 1981 but 98 fewer than in 1978. According to these figures, the murder rate is 1.5 per 100,000 people, compared with 9.8 per 100,000 in the United States and 2.8 in Britain. The robbery rate here was 2 per 100,000; it is 125 times greater in America.   Don't Cross on the Red **********A basic fact of life here is that concern about crime is not a basic fact of life. Not only are people unafraid about walking streets late at night, but they are also so law-abiding that they do not even cross the street against a red light, leaving that to more anarchic Westerners. **********Many reasons are offered for Japan's safety, the most common being the tight family structure, the ethnically and culturally homogeneous population, the stern gun and drug laws and the fear of disgrace that an arrest would produce. This is combined with a high degree of cooperation with the police, leading, for example, to a 97 percent solution rate for homicides and 75 percent for robberies. **********But the crime statistics also suggest that no matter how glacially Japanese society may change, there are noticeable shifts. **********Some reflect Japan's affluence and a willingness to spend money in eye- catching ways. In the trendier sections of Tokyo such as Roppongi, it leads to the greatest display of Gucci and Louis Vuitton initials west of Rodeo Drive.   Bogus Fancy Labels **********In just one year, the number of cases involving bogus fancy labels and copied brand names jumped nearly five times from 1981, the police said. On a similar note, fraudulent use of credit cards rose by 50 percent and the incidence of stolen cards for cash-dispensing machines went up 60 percent. **********While cocaine is not the rage that it is in the United States, and heroin and marijuana use is fairly insignificant, various illegal stimelants are being experimented with more and more, particularly by young people. One popular substance is hiropon, a benzedrine derivative often smuggled in from South Korea and Hong Kong. Last year's arrests for possession or sales of stimulants, 23,365, were nearly three times the total of a decade ago. **********Most troublesome for many Japanese is youth crime. The numbers, though small compared with the United States', are rising inexorably and, some adults fear, ominously. **********Among the most violent crimes - homicide, rape, robbery, assault and arson - people under the age of 18 accounted for 43 percent of all arrests. And the age of these offenders seems to be dropping, with 14-year-olds comprising 21.3 percent of all youth arrests, the largest single group. **********Since World War II, Japan has experienced two big waves in teen-age crime, one starting in 1951 and another beginning in 1964 as the economic boom gained steam. ''Now,'' the police report said, ''we're in a third wave.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/29/busin.body_text: **********Three West German currency dealers were found guilty today of fraudulent transactions contributing to the 1974 collapse of Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt in this country's biggest postwar bank crash. **********Herstatt went into bankruptcy in June 1974 after suffering losses of $495 million in currency trading that its major shareholder, the Gerling insurance group, refused to assume. **********The private bank listed assets of about $800 million at the time, but its collapse led to the fall of several larger institutions, including the Franklin National Bank in New York. **********After four years of litigation, a Cologne criminal court said today that Bruno Heinen, 40 years old, a former Herstatt currency dealer, was guilty of fraud for covering illegal transactions by two Frankfurt-based dealers who traded for Herstatt on international currency markets. The court sentenced Mr. Heinen to four and a half years in the state prison. **********The Frankfurt dealers, Norbert Arden, 46, and Bruno Blaeser, 44, were convicted of aiding and abetting Mr. Heinen. The court sentenced Mr. Arden to seven and a half years, and Mr. Blaeser to four years and nine months. **********The Cologne court has been criticized for a decision to suspend proceedings against two principal figures, Iwan D. Herstatt, the bank's president, and Dany Dattel, its chief currency dealer, who were judged unable to stand trial for health reasons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/02/world.main_headline: TEXT OF ANDROPOV'S REPLY TO REAGAN'S LETTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/02/world.print_headline: TEXT OF ANDROPOV'S REPLY TO REAGAN'S LETTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/02/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of an interview by the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency. **********Q. What is your attitude to the U.S. President's letter to the people of Europe, in which he proposed that the U.S.S.R. and the United States sign on American terms an agreement on the elimination of medium-range land-based missiles? **********A. First of all, I must say quite definitely that there is nothing new in President Reagan's proposal. What it is all about - and this all the world's news agencies have immediately taken note of - is the same ''zero option.'' That it is patently unacceptable to the Soviet Union now is already generally recognized. Really, can one seriously speak about a proposal according to which the Soviet Union would have to scrap unilaterally all its medium-range missiles, while the United States and its NATO allies would retain all their nuclear weapons of this category. **********It is precisely this unrealistic position of the United States that blocked, and this is well-known, progress at the talks in Geneva.  That now the U.S. President has reiterated again his position indicates one thing: the United States does not want to look for a mutually acceptable accord with the Soviet Union and thereby deliberately dooms the Geneva talks to failure. 'For a Different Road' **********As I have said already, the U.S.S.R. will not agree to unilateral disarmament. If things are carried to the deployment of new U.S.  missiles in Europe, we shall answer this in a due way. But this would not be our choice. **********The Soviet Union is for a different road. It would be best, and we suggest this, not to have in the European zone nuclear arms at all, either medium-range or tactical weapons. And it seems the United States does not agree to this, we are prepared also to such a solution under which the Soviet Union would have no more missiles than NATO already has in Europe. At the same time an arrangement should be reached on cutting to the equal levels by both sides of the number of aircraft capable of medium-range nuclear weapon delivery.  Thus, there would be complete parity in missiles and aircraft, and the parity at a far lower level than now. **********The Soviet Union is prepared to sign such an agreement now. Is the President of the United States prepared to sign such an agreement based on the principle of equality and equal security? **********Q. The U.S. President suggests meeting with you to sign the agreement which he proposes. What can you say on this score? 'Not a Propaganda Game' **********A. We have believed and still believe that summit meetings have special significance to resolving complicated problems. This determines our approach to them. **********For us this is not a matter of a political or a propaganda game. A meeting between the leaders of the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A., aimed at finding a mutually acceptable solution to urgent problems and at developing relations between our countries, would be useful both to the Soviet Union and to the United States of America, to Europe and to the whole world. **********But when the U.S. President makes the meeting conditional on the Soviet Union's consent to the patently unacceptable solution to the problem of nuclear armaments in Europe, proposed by him, this by no means testifies to the seriousness of the American leadership's approach to the whole of this issue. This can only be regretted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON ASATELLITE retrieval system, intended for use by such craft as the space shuttles, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The invention includes grappling equipment to be borne by a spacecraft for securing it to a satellite. **********Four communication and observation satellites have been put into orbit from two space shuttles.  Patent 4,391,423 was granted Edwin C. Pruett, Kem B. Robertson and Tomas E. Loughead, engineers in the Huntsville, Ala., office of the Essex Corporation. The research was done under an Essex contract with NASA. **********As the patent describes the invention, a satellite would carry a rectangular rod with a knob at the outer end. Mounted on the retrieving vehicle will be two pairs of parallel grappling bars.  After the necessary maneuvers, and alignment of the two structures, they can be firmly coupled by the bars and rod.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/30/busin.main_headline: U.S. BLOCKS BANK LOAN FOR NICARAGUA ROADS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/30/busin.print_headline: U.S. BLOCKS BANK LOAN FOR NICARAGUA ROADS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/30/busin.body_text: **********The United States today vetoed a $2.2 million loan by the Inter-American Development Bank to build roads that would serve a region of small coffee farms in Nicaragua. The 42 other members of the bank voted for the loan. **********The American representative said the loan was being vetoed for economic reasons, but other governments' representatives voiced skepticism, evidently mindful of the Reagan Administration's strong opposition to the Sandinista Government. **********The ''macroeconomic policies of Nicaragua are not propitious for the economic development of the country,'' the United States representative said, according to an unofficial summary of the debate prepared by someone who attended meetings of the executive board today and on June 22, when the loan was also discussed. **********Canada's representative, Harry Hodder, according to the debate summary, commented, ''Right now we're dealing with a case of finishing a small road. I don't see what relation this could have with the macroeconomic policies of the country.'' **********At a news conference Tuesday night, President Reagan once again condemned the Sandinista regime, saying, ''The Marxists took over and created their totalitarian form of government.'' **********The charter of the Inter-American Bank, in which 43 governments are members, stipulates that it is a nonpolitical development agency set up to make loan decisions on technical criteria alone. **********The loan to Nicaragua was to be made by the Bank's Fund for Special Operations. It grants 50-year, no-interest credits to the poorest countries in Latin America. The United States has 35 percent of the vote in the fund, enough to effectively veto action, since loans by the Fund require a two-third affirmative vote. **********Some European governments were represented collectively by a single offical. Carlo Binetti, an Italian official who spoke for Italy, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, West Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden and Britain, observed that the function of international development institutions is to promote social and economic development in the poorest countries, such as Nicaragua. **********''To depart from ideals of this nature causes great damage, with repercussions beyond our institution alone,'' he continued. ''I want to express our concern that yet again a project for Nicaragua is being delayed, the same as with the fishing project.'' **********The Inter-American Development Bank last year made loans totaling about $3.5 billion. At issue today was a loan approved in December 1976 for $18 million to construct local roads in Nicaragua. Last March 8 was the last day for disbursement of the money. Some $2.2 million was undisbursed. **********The proposal that the United States blocked today would have extended to Sept. 8, 1984, the time for disbursement of the $2.2 million. Nicaragua said that floods had forced it to delay construction of the roads. **********In November 1981, Nicaragua withdrew a request for a $30 million loan to buy 50 new fishing boats and spare parts for old ones. The withdrawal, according to reports at the time, came as a result of pressure by the United States, Argentina and Chile. An American Treasury official was quoted then as saying, ''We had an overall political problem with the direction'' of the Nicaraguan Government. **********The American position was stated by Ira Kaylin, a Treasury official who is temporary alternate executive director for the United States.  ''There clearly is a political content to the decision,'' said Caleb S. Rossiter, an assistant professor at Cornell University and also a consultant to the Center for International Policy. The Center is a Washington-based research organization concerned with human rights and economic development in developing countries. **********The United States has been putting a financial squeeze on Nicaragua in other ways. Last May 10 the White House announced that it was depriving Nicaragua of the right to sell most of its sugar crop to the United States. Sugar is its fourth-largest export crop, with virtually all of it exported to the United States. **********Nicaragua's entire public debt is nearly $3 billion, according to the Inter-American Development Bank's most recent annual report.  Recently there have been reports that the country is behind in its debt payments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.main_headline: FOR HEINEKEN, 3 WEEKS OF 'TRYING TO STAY ALIVE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.print_headline: FOR HEINEKEN, 3 WEEKS OF 'TRYING TO STAY ALIVE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/world.body_text: **********Alfred H. Heineken, the brewery chairman rescued this week from kidnappers, has recalled that in his three weeks of captivity he combed his hair with a broken plastic fork, made his bed and cleaned his concrete cell as much as his shackles would permit. **********Mr. Heineken, appearing in public Friday for the first time since he and his chauffeur, Ab Doderer, were kidnapped Nov. 9, said he followed a daily routine to shut out the uncertainty of a life in which ''you're never sure that there will be bread the next morning.'' **********Mr. Heineken, a 60-year-old millionaire, and Mr. Doderer, 57, looking tired but healthy, posed for pictures at Mr. Heineken's seaside home and gave written accounts of their ordeal to reporters. They refused to answer reporters' questions. **********'I Could Have Hugged' Rescuers **********But Mr. Heineken was overheard saying, ''I could have hugged the whole rescue team.'' **********Policemen rescued the two men Wednesday from concrete cells concealed in a warehouse on the outskirts of Amsterdam, after a ransom reported to be as high as $11.6 million was paid. As soon as they were freed the two men went to Mr. Heineken's villa south of Amsterdam where their families had stayed throughout the kidnapping. Mr. Doderer has worked for Mr. Heineken for 40 years.  Mr. Doderer, describing his ordeal, said: ''I thought, 'Don't lose my wits; I must keep busy to stay alive.' After a few days I made a program for myself to keep busy. I tried to do exercises despite everything. I had to keep busy.'' **********''At a certain moment I got a tangerine,'' he said. ''This I divided into small sections to have something all day.''  'A Very Emotional Time' **********Mr. Heineken said, ''It was a very emotional time, but not varied.'' He added, ''Three weeks of lying down, sleeping, reading, thinking, eating, drinking and, in the first place, trying to stay alive.'' **********''I was chained by my left hand, limiting my freedom of movement to almost nil,'' Mr. Heineken said. ''That was why I could only sleep on one side or on my back'' on a cot in a damp, unheated cell. ''Sometimes there was half a bucket of warm water, with which I could wash myself one way or another. I combed my hair with a broken plastic fork.'' **********''As far as the chain permitted,'' Mr. Heineken said, ''I tidied up my cell and every morning I made my bed. Trying to establish a rhythm gives you something to do.'' **********Mr. Heineken said the food was ''four slices of bread in the morning and in the evening there was a hot meal.'' He added, ''I always kept one slice of bread to eat at night or the following morning, because you're never sure that there will be bread the next morning.''  Forbidden to Speak to Guard **********The captives said they were forbidden to speak to their hooded and armed guard. ''I asked the guard for several items by way of a note, most of the time a page torn from a book,'' Mr. Heineken said. ''Eventually I got some of these items, for instance my reading glasses, something to read and sometimes a cigarette.'' **********At first, Mr. Heineken said, he did not know that Mr. Doderer had been kidnapped. During the abduction the two had been hooded, and Mr. Heineken was knocked briefly unconscious when they were abducted. **********''When, after about four days, the door of my cell was opened once again, another door in the corridor was opened and I could see him in his cell,'' Mr. Heineken said, referring to his chauffeur. ''Afterwards, now and then, we were allowed to talk from our cells for a few minutes a day.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/busin.body_text: **********The weekly output of patents has dropped recently. The average number for the last dozen weeks has been calculated at 715, almost 500 lower than the weekly figure of last year. **********The drop is ascribed to the adaptation of new examiners to their workload. **********The Patent and Trademark Office expects that, beginning in May, the weekly patent issuance will gradually increase to 1,330 by mid-September, bringing the total granted in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 to 56,400. In the 1982 fiscal year the total was 59,400. **********The drop in issuance has affected the 17-year patents on mechanical, chemical and electrical inventions, but not design patents, which cover only the appearance of an article and not its structure or utilitarian features.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********At Goldman, Sachs & Company the top people will get at least 25 percent of their annual salaries. At Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. they will collect as much as 20 weeks' pay. But at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company everyone will have to wait until February, when the firm's final fiscal figures are in. **********Once again, many Wall Street firms, some celebrating record profits, are spreading Christmas cheer with hefty December bonuses for their employees. **********Although business slowed for many of them in the second half, the first six months of 1983 were such a gold mine that some firms also handed out rare midyear bonuses. And now many are distribut ing record Christmas bonuses to secretaries and executives alike. **********Even clerks and maintenance personnel who have been with the company a mere six months will get an extra three weeks' pay at Drexel Burnham. Drexel is a privately held firm and does not release numbers but said it will finish 1983 with record profits. The Christmas bonuses are pegged to seniority: up to 20 weeks' pay for those who have been there for 10 or more years. **********That maximum is up from 13 weeks last year, and comes on top of a special bonus of a week's pay awarded to all employees last May. **********''Everyone was thrilled,'' Angela Zizzi Dailey, a company spokesman, said of the latest windfall. ''If they weren't, I don't know what they expect.'' **********Although stock-option plans, performance pay and other more modern compensation packages are becoming increasingly prevalent at Wall Street firms, bonuses are still traditional at this time of year. They are a throw back, insiders said, to the days when partners, looking to conserve as much of their capital as possible, would pay low salaries but then award holiday pay if the markets were good that year and profits permitted. **********This is the second Christmas since the bull market's birth in August 1982. And although rising interest rates ate into some firms' bond trading profits in the third quarter, the profits still look quite healthy compared to pre-bull market days. **********New York Stock Exchange member firms dealing with the public piled up profits estimated at $1.22 billion in the third quarter. That was the worst quarter of the year so far but it was still more than quadruple the $291 million earned in the second quarter of 1982. **********Christmas is also the time when high-level executives at many securities firms receive ceive an installment of the bonuses that are included in their employment agreement. Many of these are generally considered just another part of an executive's standard compensation, rather than something special. **********But these end-of-the-year bonuses also usually fluctuate with the firm's fortunes and are becoming increasingly tied to individual performance. An executive's base salary, for instance, might be $75,000, while his or her bonus package could total one to three times that. ''A low-paid managing director has to be worth at least $250,000,'' said an official at a major firm who asked not to be named. ''A million a year is no longer unusual.'' At the First Boston Corporation last year, George L. Shinn, who retired as chairman last April, got $2.4 million in salary, bonuses and other benefits. **********Wall Street's holiday spirit is also evident this year at the stock exchanges. For more than five years, employees ees of the New York Stock Exchange have received bonuses equaling 7 1/2 percent of their salary. This year, the Big Board is paying 7 1/2 percent to 12 1/2 percent. Senior people get the bigger slice. **********Over at the American Stock Exchange, 650 of its 725 employees - everyone except the officers - will receive a 15 percent bonus. That is up from 12 1/2 percent last year. **********Generous Goldman, Sachs **********Among this year's most generous payments on the Street are those from Goldman, Sachs. It will pay 25 percent - up from last year's record 24 percent - to all clerical and administrative employees who do not receive profit-sharing or commissions. That is on top of a special 3 percent bonus paid in June. And traders and other professionals will get a minimum of 25 percent. **********''The bonuses go up and down, and they reflect the profits of the firm,'' said Robert W. Burke, Goldman's personnel director. **********At Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., clerical and administrative employees will get an extra week's salary, except those with the firm three or more years, who will get two weeks' pay. The bonuses are the same as last year, according to Chester A. Piskorowski, a senior vice president. He added that bonuses for the professional staff would almost certainly be up from last year and would probably set a record. They will not, however, be paid until after the books are closed in January. **********Bear, Stearns & Company paid a midyear bonus to all its employees and is handing out another round this month. Carlton A. Holstrom, chief financial officer, would not say how big the payments have been, but taken together, he said, they were the largest in the firm's history. ''It has been a good year,'' he said. ''I think that's a story you'll hear all over.'' **********Still Unannounced **********Other bonuses, still unannounced or of undetermined size, will be paid at E. F. Hutton, First Boston, Salomon Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Kidder, Peabody. **********Shearson/American Express Inc. said it does not pay Christmas bonuses and has no plans to break with tradition. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest brokerage firm, is expected to announce a bonus any day. **********At Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., Christmas came early this year. The private company's fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, and its bonuses were paid then. ''It was a banner year.'' said James W. Hood, a spokesman. ''Bonuses were the largest they've ever been.'' **********In others cases, Christmas will come late. Smith Barney does not award its bonuses until February, after the year's final results are in. And employees of Oppenheimer & Company will have to wait for theirs until after the firm's fiscal year ends on April 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department said this evening that Assistant Attorney General William F. Baxter had agreed not to make an argument before the Supreme Court next week that would have put him at odds with Congress. **********In the Justice Department appropriations bill for 1984, signed by President Reagan today, legislators barred the department from using its funds to try to change the law that now makes resale price maintenance automatically illegal. Mr. Baxter, who is in charge of the antitrust division, believes that this form of vertical price-fixing by manufacturers should not be illegal per se, but should be judged on the circumstances of particular cases. **********A Justice Department spokesman, Mark T. Sheehan, said Mr. Baxter would go before the Court next Monday but that there ''would be no exposition of the theme that resale price maintenance should be treated under rule of reason rather than per se.'' **********The eagerly awaited case involves the Monsanto Company and the Spray-Rite Service Corporation. The question in the case is whether Monsanto could legitimately cut off Spray Rite's distributorship of herbicides because Spray Rite would not stop selling the Monsanto products below the manufacturer's suggested price. **********Friend-of-the-Court Brief **********The Justice Department has filed a friend-of-the-court brief in support of Monsanto, with arguments scheduled for next Monday. **********In signing the appropriations bill, Mr. Reagan issued a statement expressing reservations about the constitutionality of Congress's restriction in Section 510. **********''I interpret Section 510 narrowly to apply only to attempts to seek a reversal of the holdings of a certain line of previously decided cases,'' the President said. ''Even as narrowly construed, however, the provision potentially imposes an unconstitutional burden on executive officials charged with enforcing the Federal antitrust laws.'' **********Mr. Sheehan said that a letter to the Court being drafted tonight was silent on the question of whether Mr. Baxter felt free to answer questions that might be raised by the Justices about the per se illegality of resale price maintenance. **********'Deference to the Legislature' **********It was learned that the letter, signed by Solicitor General Rex E. Lee, would say that out of ''deference to the legislature'' Mr. Baxter would confine his presentation to issues not objected to by Congress. **********A spokesman for Senator Warren B. Rudman, who sponsored the restriction, expressed satisfaction with the decision but resisted what he said was the implication in the President's statement that Congress sought to change the law. The New Hampshire Republican is seeking to have the Administration enforce the present statute barring resale price maintenance wherever it can be shown.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/world.main_headline: MUGABE'S MILITARY AIDE CALLS NKOMO A COWARD GOING INTO EXILE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/world.print_headline: MUGABE'S MILITARY AIDE CALLS NKOMO A COWARD GOING INTO EXILE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/world.body_text: **********A Cabinet Minister said today that Joshua Nkomo had fled into exile because he was a ''paranoiac'' and a ''coward.'' The official denied that the Government had ever planned to arrest Mr. Nkomo or ban his party. **********The Minister, Dr. Sydney Sekeramayi, who oversees the armed forces, confidently discounted the possibility that Mr. Nkomo could manage to muster support for an armed insurrection against the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe. **********But Dr. Sekeramayi expressed concern that Mr. Nkomo, who crossed the border on foot into Botswana Tuesday night, might exploit recent accusations about indiscriminate killings by Government troops in rural Matabeleland in hopes of getting Western nations to use their aid programs as a political lever here. **********''He will cry human rights, and he knows he will have a sympathetic audience,'' said the Minister, a 38-year-old doctor who studied in Sweden. **********Dr. Sekeramayi, a Minister of State in the Prime Minister's Office, supervises the armed forces for Mr. Mugabe, the titular Minister of Defense. ''It is up to the Western countries to make up their minds whether, in their cool judgment, Nkomo has a positive role to play any longer,'' he said. Beyond the Pale **********By entirely blaming Mr. Nkomo for the worsening ethnic conflict between the Shona-speaking majority and the Ndebele-speaking minority, Dr. Sekeramayi left no doubt that the Government regarded Mr. Nkomo as being politically beyond the pale even before he put himself beyond its reach this week. **********In his first interview with a foreign journalist since the atrocity accusations were made last month, Dr. Sekeramayi traced the conflict to Mr. Nkomo's unfulfilled ambition to lead Zimbabwe. **********''He hoped to use acts of banditry to put pressue on the Government,'' he said. ''That was his trump card.'' The case that Dr. Sekeramayi presented was based on a chain of reasoning that made Mr. Nkomo ultimately responsible - as the dominant political figure in Matabeleland - for the local population's readiness to harbor armed deserters from the army and its hostility to Government troops. 'Totally Behind the Dissidents' **********He then blamed the people of Matabeleland, the western part of the country, for the harsh action of the soldiers who had been sent to the area to rout out the deserters - former members of Mr. Nkomo's pre-independence guerrilla force - after they had committed various acts of terrorism. **********''The situation was really gravitating to the point where the local population was totally behind the dissidents,'' Dr. Sekeramayi said, using the euphemism preferred by the Government for the deserters who left the army after Mr. Nkomo was ousted from the Cabinet last year.  ''At that point, you either abdicate or take stronger measures. We decided to take stronger measures.'' **********Church and welfare groups, in addition to refugees, have said hundreds of unarmed civilians have been brutally killed since the Government sent a unit called the Fifth Brigade into the area in January. Dr. Sekeramayi said the local population had actively condoned atrocities committed earlier by the deserters, such as the burning to death of a Government official. **********He emphasized that the Government did not approve the shooting of unarmed civilians, but added, ''I am quite clear that some people get quite bruised before they are willing to cooperate.'' 'Cases of Individual Excess' **********Most reports of atrocities by Government troops, he noted, are second- or third-hand, and more than a month old. He said there might have been ''cases of individual excess or indiscipline on the part of soldiers caught up in a very stressful situation,'' but he contended that these had been magnified out of proportion. **********Since the first reports, the Minister said, the Government has made ''strenuous efforts'' to see that the troops do not kill unarmed civilians. But, with an ironic edge to his voice, he said those who ''plead about all the poor innocent people, suffering and so forth,'' seemed ready to overlook the challenge presented by the ''dissidents.'' **********Mr. Nkomo and his party, the Zimbabwe African People's Union, are especially guilty of such double vision, Dr. Sekeramayi said.''On the political side in Matabeleland, there is overwhelming support for ZAPU,'' he said of Mr. Nkomo's party. ''ZAPU is organized at all levels. If orders had been given to all these structures not to cooperate with acts of banditry, you would not have the situation we have now.'' Breakup of Army Forces **********The Government had to rely on the Fifth Brigade, Dr. Sekeramayi said, because the regular army - a mixture of former guerrillas who backed Mr. Mugabe or Mr. Nkomo - tended to disintegrate when sent to Matabeleland, with up to three-quarters of the Ndebele-speaking troops deserting. **********''In that situation, what we were doing was simply reinforcing the recruitment of dissidents and negating the exercise,'' the Minister said. ''We decided to send a unit that we knew to be loyal to the Government.'' **********Dr. Sekeramayi spoke bitterly of the role that Botswana had played in opening its doors to refugees from Matabeleland, but not as bitterly as The Herald, the semiofficial daily here, which said this morning that Botswana was, ''in fact, declaring war on us'' by admitting Mr. Nkomo. ---- Relatives Reported Detained **********BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe, March 10 (AP) - Security forces arrested Mr.  Nkomo's wife today after detaining his daughter and son-in-law for questioning about the opposition leader's escape, official sources said. The sources, who requested anonymity, said Joanna Nkomo was taken into custody on a train en route to Harare, the capital. They said Mrs. Nkomo held an airline ticket to London.

Except for a few disgruntled competitors and the e verprickly trustbusters at the Federal Trade Commission, most e veryone seems to be toasting this marriage of Ea...
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/20/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
NO GREAT DEAL FOR THE U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/20/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
NO GREAT DEAL FOR THE U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/20/busin.body_text: **********GENERAL MOTORS and Toyota have formed a joint venture to build cars i n California. Except for a few disgruntled competitors and the e verprickly trustbusters at the Federal Trade Commission, most e veryone seems to be toasting this marriage of East and West, a nnounced appropriately on St. Valentine's Day. **********Should we be celebrating? After all, this marriage promises to spawn not only a fuel-efficient new car, but thousands of new United States jobs. **********Hold the bubbly. Check your invitation. This may be a closed party - for G.M. and Toyota only. What is good for General Motors in this case may not be good for America. **********When Americans begin switching from Chevettes to Toy-Chevies in 1985, will they be buying an American-Japanese hybrid - the best of both worlds? Hardly. From top to tires this will be an import. Look at the facts: **********Toyota will design and engineer the car, which will be a frontwheel-drive version of the Toyota Corolla. No laid-off designers from Fisher Body, and no engineers from G.M.'s Tech Center in Detroit need apply. The work has already been done in Japan. **********What about the car's components? According to the announcements, aren't these supposed to come from the United States and Japan in equal proportions? Not likely. **********By agreement, the engines and transmissions (some 20 percent of the value of the car) will be made in Japan. Much of the rest of the car, particularly the mechanical systems - the pumps, motors, carburetors, brakes and the rest - will also come from Japan. Only the bulkiest, lowest-value parts that cannot be shipped will come from the United States: springs, seats, glass, trim, batteries, body panels. **********The reason is simple: like Japanese cars, Japanese parts are generally cheaper. And low-priced components will be critical to the success of a new vehicle competing in the United States small-car market. **********In addition to their widely reported efficiency and wage advantages, Japanese suppliers are likely to have an even greater cost advantage over American competitors in this case. Why? Because they already supply Toyota with components that are compatible with the engine and drive train in the new vehicle. **********Unlike traditional G.M. sourcing, which has leaned toward domestic procurement for historic and strategic reasons, buying decisions at the Fremont, Calif., plant will be in the hands of an independent, cost-conscious management. Purchasing will be strictly on the basis of price, quality and delivery time. Should there be any doubt, the Toyota man in charge will make the final decisions. **********So when you look under the hood of the new vehicles rolling off the Fremont line, you will likely see the Nippondenso and Toyoda Gesei trademarks, not A.C. Delco's. Even the steel in the body panels, which General Motors has traditionally bought only in this country, is likely to come from Japan. Japanese sheet steel is several cents cheaper per pound than American steel. **********What about the tools, those specialized and expensive machines that make a modern automobile plant so capital-intensive and so productive? Most will come from across the Pacific.FOR example, the robots needed to fully automate the assembly line a nd the presses for the new stamping plant are sure to come from J apan. Again the reason is cost. For tools of equivalent productivitya nd quality, products from Japan are generally cheaper than American o nes. Even if this were not true, another reason points toward J apanese tools: Toyota is paying for them. Out of the total cash c ontribution, G.M. is kicking in $30 million, Toyota $150 million. Ift he past is any guide, Japanese auto makers will ''buy Japan'' when t heir money is in the checking account. **********Of course, some of the existing equipment in the plant can be reused. And G.M. is likely to install an automated paint booth - a technology in which it leads the world. But the bulk of the tooling will be Japanese. **********In sum, Japan will supply the highly skilled manpower, the sophisticated parts and the expensive tools. The United States will supply less-skilled (though highly paid) manufacturing labor, lower value parts, and the plant. **********Is this a harbinger of things to come, a glimpse of America's high-technology future? Strange. It looks more like automobile production in a developing country: an imported plant assembling mainly imported parts, with only the cheap, easy-to-make components procured locally. **********(Indeed it is ironic that arrangements such as this are no longer welcomed in the more sophisticated developing countries. This deal would be illegal in Mexico, Brazil or South Korea). **********Of course, the alternative to this arrangement is even less attractive. Toyota would eventually import the new Corolla itself, and G.M. would almost certainly build the replacement for the Chevette overseas. Either way, American automobile manufacturing will decline. **********For General Motors and Toyota, this venture makes perfect sense.  G.M. obtains a new subcompact to replace the Chevette at a fraction of the cost of developing its own vehicle. Toyota silences its American critics by establishing an American manufacturing presence.  In light of the intense competition in the American small-car market and the huge costs of developing new cars, it would be surprising if Ford and Chrysler were not considering similar arrangements. **********But though agreements such as this may help American car makers to survive, they will not help the American economy to prosper. By assigning to Japan the higher value, more technologically sophisticated share of production, this venture further undermines America's competitive position as producer of automobiles. **********If the United States is to remain the leading economic power in the world, it must consciously position itself on the leading edge of industrial change. **********This does not mean simply abandoning our mature manufacturing industries and pitching our tent in Silicon Valley. It means that we must be the designers of products, the developers of technologies, the suppliers of tools and the organizers of production systems for manufacturing industries. We cannot hope to prosper as the assemblers of imported parts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/world.main_headline: INDIA, WITH BITTERSWEET MEMORIES, AWAITS QUEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/world.print_headline: INDIA, WITH BITTERSWEET MEMORIES, AWAITS QUEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/world.body_text: **********Roughly 250 miles southeast of here, in the city of Lucknow, stand the ruined shells of a cluster of late 18th-century buildings. From them, the British once ruled a vast expanse of northern India. **********The Lucknow Residency, as the compound was called, crumbles hollowly, grass growing from walls and towers scarred by thousands of cannonball and bullet holes made a century and a quarter ago. **********More than 2,000 British men, women and children died there when Indian mutineers laid siege to the residency for 89 days during the 1857 Sepoy rebellion, the low point of the British adventure in India for both sides. **********Today, in a relatively undamaged part of the residency, there is a model of the place as it was during the siege. On the label, under glass that prevents frivolous alteration by unauthorized people, the besiegers are described as the ''enemy.'' That word has been scratched out and ''Indians'' penciled in - and then scratched out in turn and ''enemy'' put back.   Indians of Two Minds **********Indians have long been of two minds about their relationship with their former colonizers, and the ties are the subject of discussion again as Queen Elizabeth II prepares to arrive here tomorrow. It will be only the third visit to India by a reigning British sovereign. **********During the Queen's 10-day visit here, she will open a meeting next week of the heads of government of the Commonwealth, which grew from an association of nations formerly in the British Empire. **********''They bled this country dry,'' a young professional woman said of the British at a dinner party here last week. ''They had no right to be here,'' she pressed on, with some force. She said it, however, in fluent English, which since independence has become as close to a national language as India has. That is just one of many reasons, large and small, why the British imprint on India is widely recognized as deep and probably permanent. **********''They took away many things, but let's not dwell on those points,'' said Dev Kant Borooah, a former Cabinet minister and one-time adviser to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.   A Passion for Cricket **********Thirty-six years after British rule - ''the Raj'' - became history, many Indians are inclined not to make too much of the negative aspects of British rule, the undeniable economic exploitation, the sometime denial of human rights, the racism and condescension that Britons sometimes displayed, the denial of self-respect that, for the ruled, came with colonialism. **********It is no isolated symbol of what the British brought about in pursuing their duty - and also their self-interest - that on a grassy slope just below the residency, Indian youths were playing a game of sandlot cricket. It is India's national sport, a mania rivaling anything Americans have ever felt for baseball or football.  India today is studded with buildings, railway stations and government edifices that would seem very much in place by the Thames. Soldiers of the Indian Army still swing their arms far out when marching, like Tommies. Well-off Indian students still wear uniforms when they go off to the private schools that, in the British manner, are called public. Indian bureaucrats still use the same kind of file folders tied in red ribbon that the British used a century ago, ribbons that left in the English-speaking vocabulary the expression ''red tape.'' **********New Delhi itself is a monument to the Raj, its red-stone government buildings shouting ''empire'' to the world and its rambling bungalows (the word is one of many from India to enter the English language) and gardens reeking of imperial privilege even though they are now inhabited by egalitarian republicans.   Five Major Bequests **********But it is below the surface of style and appearance that the real legacy of the Raj is to be found. At least five tangible, major aspects of the British bequest are commonly cited as having been in some ways critical to India's independent existence so far: the institution of democratic, parliamentary government, a judicial system founded securely on the rule of law, railroads and public utilities - in Mr. Borooah's words, ''a certain infrastructure that was not perfect but could be built upon'' - a civil service devised to be incorruptible and efficient, and the English language. **********Some Indians fear that the institutions are deteriorating. Vigilante justice has taken over in many places where people perceive regular institutions to have broken down. And the civil service has become a symbol not of efficiency but of the worst kind of bureaucratic entanglement. **********Indian socialism, which in the past has almost approached the status of a secular religion even though it has been leavened and changed by significant doses of private enterprise, is also a British contribution. But some free-enterprise adherents, who see the economy has having been clamped in a straightjacket of government involvement that seriously hampers productivity, see this as a mixed blessing at best. **********''The worst thing the British did,'' said one Western advocate of free enterprise, only partly in jest, ''was to take unsuspecting youths like Nehru to England and let them sit at the feet of Harold Laski.'' **********Some consider the English language the most important bequest in some ways. ''Fortunately,'' says Romesh Thapar, one of Delhi's leading writers and intellectuals, ''it wasn't French, because French would only have linked us to France. But English links us to the world.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/busin.main_headline: A HIGH-TECH BEER FROM SILICON VALLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/busin.print_headline: A HIGH-TECH BEER FROM SILICON VALLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Silicon Valley seems about to produce another entrepreneural breakthrough: high- tech beer. **********The Palo Alto Brewery, which is really based in nearby Mountain View, is the latest of the ''micro- breweries'' that have sprung up over the past few years to produce a few thousand barrels of specialized beers each year for limited distribution. **********Most have been founded out of simple love of the brew, and a thirst by connoisseurs for an alternative to what many say is the bland nature of popular American beers. **********The West Coast has been especially active in spawning micro-breweries, likely inspired by the granddaddy of small California brewers - San Francisco's Anchor Steam Brewery, which produces 28,500 barrels a year. By comparison, the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the beer industry's largest, annually produces a bit more than 54 million barrels. **********Some Poor Products **********Despite admirable intentions and some pretty good products, many of the new beers are pretty awful - and the breweries shortlived. Most micro- brewery founders are just beer-lovers who want mainly to make their own idea of the perfect beer. They pick up most of their brewing experience in kitchens - with such resulting crude techniques as the use of new plastic garbage cans as fermenting tanks - and frequently have little interest in or ability to run a business. **********But in Silicon Valley, where billion- dollar companies such as Apple and Hewlett-Packard have started in living rooms and garages, one new micro-brewer is trying to meld a beer-lover's dream with the careful research and state-of-the-art manufacturing of a high-tech company. And Kenneth Kolance and his son, Jeffrey, know a lot about both fields. **********The elder Kolance is the co-founder of Bole & Babbage Inc., one of the first successful independent computer software companies and a pioneer in software engineering. Jeffrey is a recent graduate of the California Polytechnical Institute with a major in industrial technology and a minor in engineering management. His senior paper studied the organization of the physical plant of micro-breweries and the errors made by businesses already in the field. Armed with that knowledge, the Kolances decided in 1980 that they could make money in the micro-brewery business where others had failed. **********The result is a product that they call London Bitter, a draft, English- style beer, that costs between $2 and $2.40 at the half-dozen or so local bars where it is sold. They are selling 10 to 12 barrels a week of their brew and say that they will start making money when their volume reaches about 35 barrels a week. **********The Kolances say that making beer is not much different from making integrated circuit chips. The basics - marketing, management, manufacturing and capital - still must be covered. **********For the Kolances, the first decision was marketing: What kind of beer should they make? **********Local Market Sought **********''We wanted to produce a beer to market in the San Francisco area, not in the United States,'' said Jeff. They decided to make the traditional English unpasteurized beer, he said, based on census reports showing that ''California has the highest per capita sales of imported beer and the highest percentage of Brits in the U.S.'' **********Next, armed with Jeff's graduation paper, which included data on equipment, cost and operating techniques of micro-breweries in the United States, England and West Germany, they set about building their plant. **********While Kenneth raised $400,000 in capital from what he terms ''various sources,'' Jeff traveled to Faversham, England, near Canterbury, to the Fremlins Brewery, which conducts an intensive, six-week, course on running a small brewery. **********The younger Kolance also studied brewing equipment. No garbage cans for them. They wanted the state of the art in brewing, stainless steel tanks and sophisticated electronic controls. **********There were more decisions. Jeff went in search of ''the perfect beer,'' choosing Brakesther Best Bitter of Henley-on-Thames. Then came the decision on malt. To the horror of some purists, the Kolances chose to buy their malting from Edme's Malting House in England, rather than manufacture their own. To supply the yeast, the Kolances chose an unnamed, major British brewer. **********A potential problem, they say, is the inconsistency and inappropriateness of the local water supply. The Palo Alto Brewery therefore filters and purifies the water, adding chemicals to duplicate Burton-Upon- Trent's legendary brewing waters. **********Good Reception **********So far, a survey of the few local pubs carrying the beer indicates that it has been well received by the British locals. **********''We think it will be a best seller,'' said Colis Ball of the Churchill Arms in San Jose, where 60 percent of the clientele is British. ''One customer even said to me, 'it tastes like home.' '' But Mr. Ball also has a complaint: The quality of the beer varies. **********At the Prince of Wales Pub up the peninsula, the owner, John Curry, is still not wholly convinced, ''I'm hesitant at this time to pull out a good selling beer and replace it with an unproven one, particularly one that requires special handling,'' such as the temperature control that the Kolances insist upon. **********But David Neale, proprietor of two local British pubs, says his British patrons are amazed that such a beer could be produced in the United States and are quite enthusiastic about it. ''The Palo Alto Brewery has produced a more typical British product than we import from England,'' he said.
