https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/busin.main_headline: AdvertisingPamela G. Hollie One Woman Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/busin.print_headline: AdvertisingPamela G. Hollie One Woman Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/busin.body_text: **********ONE WOMAN is a public relations representative's dream and perhaps the ultimate in personalized publications. The new quarterly men's magazine devotes 100 pages, 95 photographs and 16,000 words to just one woman. The first issue in October belongs to television's ''Flamingo Road'' actress, Morgan Fairchild, who tells all - but does not bare all - for the readers. **********This is not another men's skin magazine, said Derick J. Daniels, president of One Woman, who added: ''I think that would be the ultimate in foolhardiness.'' **********Mr. Daniels, who was the president and chief operating officer of Playboy Enterprises until Hugh Hefner's daughter, Christie, took over last year, considers One Woman the next generation in men's magazines and a necessary response to the depersonalization that comes from computers. ''We're drowning in a sea of microchips,'' he said. ''That makes it even more important for people to talk to each other.'' **********One Woman, he said, will allow readers ample opportunity to get to know a single female star as she talks about herself. ''It is a personal magazine,'' he said, adding that Miss Fairchild was so delighted about having an entire magazine about herself that she did it for free. The writers and photographers were paid, but the magazine is a showcase for them, too. The six professional photographers were each given their own sections of the magazine to display their portfolios of the star. **********''Advertisers will get star treatment, too,'' Mr. Daniels said. The first issue has about 10 pages of advertising. The four-color page rate is $5,500. But because One Woman hopes to establish itself as a quality magazine for men, it will not accept mail order or sexually explicit advertising. **********The audience, Mr. Daniels said, will be the upscale male reader, ''not the blue-collar industrial man.'' In addition, he expects One Woman to emerge as a coffee table magazine with ''strong pass-along interest for women.'' **********''One Woman is not just the name of our new magazine but the dream every man has of finding one woman perfect for him, and the dream every woman has of being found,'' said the magazine's editorial architect, Mort Persky, former editorial director of new publications for Playboy. Mr. Persky, who has worked with Mr. Daniels on five other publications in Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Philadelphia and Chicago, devised the idea for the magazine last winter. **********At $3.50 a copy, Mr. Daniels said, the magazine is expected to attract enough newsstand readers so that it will be profitable by the end of 1984, when it becomes a bimonthly. The following year, One Woman will become a monthly. **********''This magazine will be supported by readers,'' Mr. Daniels said. ''The advertisers are not expected to carry it on their shoulders.'' There will be no subscriber mailing. Almost all of the 400,000 copies in the first run are destined for newsstands. **********Financed by a consortium of Chicago and Houston backers, Mr. Daniels, formerly a senior vice president of Knight-Ridder Newspapers and executive editor of The Detroit Free Press, believes he and Mr. Persky have simplified the male fantasy for One Woman readers. No cartoons. No letters. No advice. And no one to look at but Miss Fairchild.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/busin.main_headline: USING YOUR CHILDREN TO SHELTER INCOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; USING YOUR CHILDREN TO SHELTER INCOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/busin.body_text: **********TALK of tax shelters often brings to mind convoluted oil and gas d eals created by high-priced lawyers for the super rich. But there a re very attractive ways for people of more moderate means to s helter income from taxes while putting aside money for their c hildren. Although these tax shelters are available for virtually anya mount of money without steep legal fees, ''not enough parents fully u nderstand the options available to them,'' says Jeffrey Ashendorf, d eputy general counsel to the Bowery Savings Bank. **********There are several forms of trusts that can be created to shelter income and transfer it to a child, Dennis Cronin, senior vice president of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, says. But, he added, ''the custodial account is the most popular, particularly where you don't expect the amount of money to get so large that it makes anyone nervous.'' **********To establish a custodial account, you obtain a Social Security number for a child and then go to virtually any financial institution, mutual fund manager, or investment dealer and deposit funds under rules set by the Uniform Gift to Minors Act. **********There are no minimum amounts required for such accounts at many institutions. Federal law permits an adult to give a child up to $10,000 per year before incurring gift taxes. Because each parent may give each of his or her children $10,000 each year, and others may make similar gifts, sizable sums can be given without paying gift taxes. **********A custodian manages the account for the child until the child turns 18 and takes control of the money. The custodian is often a parent, but Mr. Cronin advises against that: He says this might ensnare the account in the donor's estate. **********Any income earned by the custodial account is taxable, contrary to what many parents believe, but it is taxed at a rate determined by the child's income. Thus, a child whose income is $5,000 in earnings on a bank account would be in a much lower tax bracket than an adult earning $80,000. **********While the tax advantages are clear, Mr. Ashendorf warns, ''when you put money into a custodial account, what you are doing is making an irrevocable gift to the child.'' While the money belongs to the child, that does not mean it cannot be spent instead of just accumulating until the child grows up. ''The most common thing these accounts are used for is to pay for a college education,'' says an I.R.S. spokesman. But he adds, ''the custodian may use the funds in the account for the benefit of a child in other ways that seem reasonable and prudent.'' **********However, he adds, ''that doesn't mean the custodian can use the funds for expenses that the parent would normally pay. A parent could not simply transfer the $2,000 a year that it would take to feed and clothe a child to one of these accounts and have the account pay for what he normally would pay.'' **********The custodian can use the funds for expenditures exceeding the legal responsibility of a parent. That might include private school tuition, elective or cosmetic surgery, or even a trip to Disneyland.  In determining what's appropriate, the I.R.S. takes note of a parent's income and standard of living. **********''If we're talking about an individual who earns $200,000 a year and who would in all likelihood send his children to a fancy Swiss boarding school,'' an I.R.S. official says, ''that would be ordinary support for the child,'' and an inappropriate use of a custodial account. However, he adds, ''for someone making $40,000 a year, who could obviously not afford such a school, but whose child has an account which maybe a rich relative contributed, that tuition payment probably would qualify.'' **********The I.R.S. official admits it can get ''fuzzy,'' but when in doubt, he notes, ''you can always ask the I.R.S. for a private ruling.'' Most financial institutions will let custodians move funds freely and custodians are required to keep records of what they do with the money. But the I.R.S. has no mechanism for monitoring use of the funds. If the I.R.S. raises questions about the use of the funds, ''as long as you're using it for the benefit of the child, it's just a question of paying taxes'' on the misused funds, Mr. Cronin says.  But if there is a pattern of using it for the custodian's benefit, he adds, in most states that is considered a form of embezzlement. **********Once the child turns 18, in many states the custodian loses control over the funds and this new adult can do whatever he or she wishes with the money. So, there is a risk that money carefully saved for college will instead be used to buy a fancy sports car. Legally, there is nothing the parent or custodian can do, although one banker says, ''if the child seems wayward, the custodian can let the child come looking'' for the funds. In New York State, a donor can specify before depositing funds that the age of distribution be 21 instead of 18. **********The two main negatives that some see in custodial accounts - giving up the right to use the principal for yourself and eventually giving the child control over it - may both be surmounted. **********For those who want to shelter income without letting go of the principal, one alternative is the Clifford Trust. In such a trust, earnings from the assets accumulate for the benefit of the child and in the child's tax bracket, but Frederick Lubcher, a partner of Fried, Frank, Harris, Schriver & Jacobson, a New York law firm, notes: ''At the end of 10 years, the principal reverts to you, so you've only given away the flow of income.'' However, he notes that if stocks put into a Clifford Trust are sold at a profit, you will have to pay the capital gains taxes at your own rate, even though you cannot get at the cash. Finally, it may cost several hundred dollars to establish a Clifford Trust, so it is practical only for those able to put sizable sums into it. FOR those who cannot wait 10 years to get the principal back, Mr.  L ubcher says there is another alternative, sometimes called the CrownL oan. Here, he said, ''the donor makes an interest-free demand loan t o a child or a trust established for the benefit of a child.'' E arnings on the borrowed funds accumulate in the child's name, yet t he donor can call the loan and get his money back at any time. This l oan, however, has been challenged by the I.R.S. People are still u sing it, Mr. Lubcher says, but ''whether or not it will hold up is u p in the air right now.'' He said the Supreme Court has agreed to r esolve the issue. **********Just as there are ways to get your assets back, there are ways to keep the principal out of the hands of your offspring. One device is a lifetime trust in which the beneficiaries receive only what a trustee doles out and never get the principal. **********Those who have the means and foresight to use any of these tax shelters will find that assets, like children, grow quickly. A $2,000 gift given to a newborn child and invested at 10 percent would grow to more than $11,000 by the time the child was ready for college. And the donor would have been spared 18 years of taxes that would otherwise have been incurred had he or she kept the money.  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Harvey D. Shapiro is a New York writer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/26/world.main_headline: A NEW FOCUS FOR U.S. JEWS: ISRAEL'S SLUMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/26/world.print_headline: A NEW FOCUS FOR U.S. JEWS: ISRAEL'S SLUMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/26/world.body_text: **********For years, many American Jews who cared deeply about Israel rarely visited the country except on group tours that took the well-worn paths to holy places, archeological sites and model kibbutzim. The official itineraries did not include the slums, and the visitors often left with the same idealized visions of Israel they brought with them. **********Now some Americans, West Europeans and others have become directly involved in the rehabilitation of slum neighborhoods in Israel through an effort called Project Renewal in which Jewish groups outside Israel establish affiliations with poor communities here. For the last several years, Jews outside Israel have been raising money at home and meeting with the slum residents to devise social programs, thrash out budgets and coordinate appeals to the Israeli Government to fight poverty more efficiently. **********''When American Jews used to go to a town like Hatzor,'' Martin Gallanter of New York City said, ''it was to visit an archeological site, not to look at the town. They ignored the mayor. **********''Now, some of the richest and most powerful American Jews meet with and support the poorest and least powerful Israeli Jews.'' Where the Money Comes From **********Mr. Gallanter is the national director of Project Renewal in the United States for the United Jewish Appeal, which has raised $52.6 million of the $85.3 million that has been contributed worldwide and earmarked for 69 poor neighborhoods in Israel. Private donors have pledged $34.7 million more, and other neighborhoods are to be added.  The Israeli Government has budgeted $200 million more, according to Moshe Katsav, Deputy Minister of Construction and Housing. **********The project's activities include the expansion and rehabilitation of apartments, youth activities to keep youngsters off the streets, educational enrichment during and after school hours, social programs for the old and adult courses in Hebrew for those who never learned it after immigrating. **********The success of the programs is disputed by Government, neighborhood and foreign participants, with both slum dwellers and foreigners often impatient about the bureaucracy delaying, for example, housing renovation. **********But on one point all seem pleased: In its three years Project Renewal has fostered community leadership in the slums, teaching the poor, once apathetic or intimidated, how to organize to demand their rights and to find the pressure points of Government. 'The Process' in Action **********The effect of ''the process,'' as those involved like to call this community activism, was seen this spring in the impoverished Hatikvah quarter of Tel Aviv. A dozen New Yorkers had come for a week of budget meetings with the residents on the neighborhood steering committee. **********They sat together for long hours around tables littered with papers and empty coffee containers, reviewing each program in detail, the New Yorkers drawing from their varied experiences in accounting, teaching, real estate and business and the residents speaking out of their intimate understanding of poverty. **********The New Yorkers said they were excited by the very fact that Tel Aviv city officials attended a ''town meeting'' at which Hatikvah residents criticized ineffectual government. It was raucous and rude, appealing to the New Yorkers' sense of what grass-roots participation is all about. ''Did you ever see a community board meeting in New York?'' Bobi Klotz said delightedly. ''Is there any difference?'' **********The next day the New Yorkers and the Hatikvah committee came to Jerusalem for a working session with Housing Minister David Levy, airing some disagreements with him about priorities and arranging for a $6 million revolving fund to make loans for the purchase of vacant land on which residents can build their own houses. **********In a sense, the Americans have given the Israeli poor some leverage on the Israeli Government. ''Would those Hatikvah people have been able to go in and see David Levy without the powerful New Yorkers?'' Mr. Gallanter asked. ''Eventually they will be able to go in and see him on their own.'' **********The program calls for the Government to provide all its money after about five years, and as that time approaches there is apprehension about the future. ''We want to see the financial relationship and the dependency end,'' Mr. Gallanter said. ''But we don't want to see the personal relationships end.  The purpose is to help to develop self-sufficient neighborhoods, not charity cases.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/busin.main_headline: BEECHAM A SUCCESS IN ITS U.S. MARKETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/busin.print_headline: BEECHAM A SUCCESS IN ITS U.S. MARKETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/busin.body_text: **********With its latest American acquisitions, Beecham, the British chemical and consumer product company, is stepping up a strategy of expansion that has served the company well for more than a decade. **********J.B. Williams, which Beecham bought from Nabisco Brands last September for $100 million, brought the British company such strong performers as Geritol, a vitamin preparation; Sominex, the sleep aid, and Aqua Velva after shave. With Ohio-based DAP, Schering-Plough's do-it-yourself subsidiary that Beecham purchased early this month for $70 million, the British group has acquired a third of the American market in sealants, caulks and fillers. Together, the two purchases are expected to double Beecham's sales in the United States, to an annual $500 million. **********DAP, formerly Dicks Armstrong-Pontius, extends the company's interests in adhesives; Beecham sells its UHU product line worldwide.  'DAP Is Step Two' **********''In acquisitions we tend not to move too far out of fields we're in,'' said Sir Graham Wilkins, the company's avuncular 59-year-old chairman, from his west London office, which overlooks a small garden. ''DAP is Step Two in building an international business based on this type of product - a specialty product with room for improvement based on research.'' **********Indeed, research is the keystone of operations at Beecham, which is Britain's 39th-largest company in terms of sales, according to Datastream International, a computer service company. Beecham markets its products in more than 200 countries and earned $213 million last year on sales of $2.5 billion, with 60 percent derived from foreign operations. **********The vigor of the company's pharmaceuticals, whose earnings slightly outrank consumer products, dates to research conducted in the late 1950's by a group of Beecham scientists. Experimenting at a stately country house 25 miles from London, they learned to manipulate the chemical structure of penicillin to produce a wide range of new antibiotics. These semisynthetic penicillins have proved to be the core of Beecham's pharmaceutical expansion. **********Most Americans are better acquainted with Beecham's aggressively marketed consumer products, like Brylcreem hairdressing, Sucrets lozenges and Calgon bath fresheners. One brand, Aquafresh, has been so expensively marketed that although it scrubs 12 percent of American teeth, it has yet to make a profit after two years. U.S. Market Stressed **********''You cannot claim to be an international company unless you are important in the United States,'' Sir Graham said. ''We've had five major acquisitions there since 1971 and the reason is that in whatever sphere we're in, the U.S. represents at minimum 20 percent of our market, and this can go up to 40 in some areas.'' **********Its first consumer product success in the United States was Brylcreem, which in 1960 became the largest-selling men's hairdressing in the country. Then a dozen years ago, Beecham took over Tennessee-based S.E. Massengill, a pharmaceutical and feminine hygiene company. It tripled its consumer products business in the United States overnight when it bought Calgon, with its bath products and Sucrets, in 1977. Two years later Beecham bought the fast-growing Jovan fragrance and cosmetics company. **********''On the consumer side, Beecham keeps finding and integrating acquisitions successfully,'' said Ian White, an analyst for W.  Greenwell & Company, stockbrokers. ''After two years you see they were good deals, and I expect such acquisitions at the rate of more than one per year from now on.'' **********In pharmaceuticals, however, ''America has been a bit of a headache for the company,'' according to Eile Gibson, who follows this sector for the brokerage firm of Scrimgeour Kemp-Gee. The international success of Amoxil, the antibiotic introduced by Beecham in 1972, led to considerable competition in the United States, most of which the company says was unlicensed. The battle forced down prices, depressing profits. A court case with Bristol-Myers over the subject still drags on after six years. Drug Approval Awaited **********One big question for the company is whether the Food and Drug Administration will approve the American sale of Augmentin, an antibiotic introduced with high hopes in Britain in 1981. Only a few forms of the drug have been allowed on the market, however, and sales have been slow. **********Augmentin contains the penicillin protector clavulanic acid, which Beecham discovered and has been combining into new antibiotic compounds like Ticar, which is used in thousands of American hospitals. **********''Augmentin is likely to achieve its greatest success in Japan and the United States, where it will get a large marketing push behind it,'' Mr. White said. ''In Europe, there are good reasons why Beecham wouldn't promote it so forcefully - it has a sizable business with Amoxil, which it wouldn't want to cannibalize.'' **********Increasingly, Beecham is also exploring other types of drugs.  Nabumetone, an anti-inflammatory agent that appears to have few side effects, may come on the market next year and will find a ready-made market in the expanding elderly population. A drug that combats blood clots and an anti-obesity drug are also in preparation.  Progress on the consumer front is expected to stem from the introduction of successful brand names to new world markets. **********Sir Graham refuses to predict results for the year ending March 31. Although Beecham has increased its profits in all but one of the last 17 years, the combination of recession and competition means that gains in the fiscal year 1983 are unlikely to match last year's 34 percent rise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Data General Corporation of Westborough, Mass., entered the personal computer market yesterday, introducing a series of desktop computers aimed primarily at business users. **********Some of the models will be able to run programs written for standard personal computer industry operating systems, as well as programs written for Data General's own minicomputers and superminicomputers. **********The new models can also be connected to larger office automation systems containing Data General computers. As a result, the company hopes to sell them to current users of its larger computers as well as to new customers. **********The least expensive computer, the Model 10, will start at $3,160.  It includes 128 kilobytes, or 128,000 characters, of internal memory, a floppy disk drive and monitor. It will run software written for the MS-DOS operating system, which is used in the I.B.M. personal computer, among others, and for the CP/M-86 operating system, which is used in several personal computers as well as several Data General operating systems. Other models in the series range up to a threeterminal office automation system that sells for more than $16,000. **********Data General is a latecomer to the personal computer business.  However, the new series was well received by Wall Street. The company's stock rose $2, to $67.875, yesterday after rising $5.125 on Tuesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/busin.main_headline: TEXACO NET OFF 13.1%, REVENUES FALL BY 21.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/busin.print_headline: TEXACO NET OFF 13.1%, REVENUES FALL BY 21.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported yesterday that first-quarter net income fell 13.1 percent, primarily because of depressed oil demand and falling petroleum product prices. **********Net income was $319 million, or $1.24 a share, down from $367 million, or $1.41 a share, in the first period last year. **********Revenues also declined 21.5 percent, to $10.2 billion, from $13 billion in the 1982 quarter. **********Texaco and other major oil companies with major refining and marketing operations in this country suffered during the first quarter from falling gasoline and heating oil prices that squeezed profit margins from refining and marketing, analysts have said. **********Referring to Texaco's announcement, Paul Mlotok, oil analyst for Salomon Brothers, said: ''On the whole, it was a respectable performance. The year-to-year comparisons can be quite deceptive for the oil companies. If you strip away the nonrecurring events, Texaco earned 70 cents last year and 96 cents this year. So if you look at it that way, the actual operating earnings increased.'' **********Texaco said that in the latest quarter, foreign currency translations -the listing in dollars of earnings abroad - resulted in a gain of $40 million, compared with a gain of $61 million in the period a year ago. In last year's first quarter, moreover, net income included a $43 million gain from an exchange of common stock held in the company's treasury for outstanding debentures with a face value of $95 million. **********The company also said that its worldwide capital and exploratory expenditures totaled $760 million in the first quarter. In the period a year earlier, Texaco spent $930 million for the same purposes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.body_text: **********Vice President Bush, on the first day of a two-day visit to Rumania, today stressed what he called the United States commitment to nuclear arms reduction. **********Departing from the text of a prepared speech at a luncheon in Bucharest, Mr. Bush said Washington's commitment might not have been properly conveyed to the rest of the world. **********''The United States will stay at that table as long as is necessary to obtain the reductions that all mankind truly wants,'' Mr. Bush said, alluding to the talks in Geneva on the reduction of nuclear weapons. **********Mr. Bush said at the luncheon, at which Vice President Gheorghe Radulescu and First Deputy Prime Minister Gheorghe Oprea acted as hosts, that Rumania and the United States must work together to improve human rights, especially on emigration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/busin.main_headline: DETROIT'S NEW PUSH TO UPGRADE QUALITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/busin.print_headline: DETROIT'S NEW PUSH TO UPGRADE QUALITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Against the backdrop of the Buick Motor Division's Factory No.3 here, a noisy, grimy workplace that has been turning out automobile springs since 1918, the flickering display of a modern video display terminal on the shop floor seems strangely out of place. **********Ask a question about its function, however, and Herman Bachman, a middle-aged worker in coveralls standing nearby, quickly demonstrates one of the ways in which Buick and other American auto makers are moving to wed sophisticated new technology to the task of building cars. **********Mr. Bachman, who operates a machine that tests every spring produced at Buick 3, explains that data gathered by his machine is computer-analyzed in different ways and displayed on the video screen. If the display on the monitor at Mr. Bachman's work station shows that parts are beginning to drift out of specification, he said, the production line is stopped and corrections made before a defective batch is shipped. **********The result: greater quality control and fewer complaints from buyers.  Factory 3 is just one part of Buick's sprawling manufacturing complex here, just as Buick is only a part of the General Motors Corporation and the American automobile industry. Yet the installation of computerized testing machinery in this aging plant, and Mr. Bachman's command of it, are indications of the sweeping changes now under way in the once complacent United States auto industry. **********Shielded Against Imports **********Until about 10 years ago, American auto makers were the unchallenged masters of their home market. Shielded against imports by low gasoline prices that allowed Americans to indulge their preference for large cars, the Big Three - G.M., Ford and Chrysler - were able to concentrate on styling gimmicks and short-term profits.  Few in the industry worried about the need to update plants. **********''Over the years American managers had grown so used to thinking of their major task as the marketing, under strict and analytic financial controls, of what their factories effortlessly brought forth, that they lost touch with the actual work of production,'' said Professors William J. Abernathy, Kim B. Clark and Alan M.  Kantrow of Harvard in their new book, ''Industrial Renaissance.'' **********Now, stunned by the success of Japanese cars in this country and aware that the Japanese production system gives manufacturers there a large cost advantage, the American car companies are pouring billions into new plants and machines. They are also trying, almost overnight, to erase 40 years of acrimonious relations with their factory workers. And there is a new emphasis on quality and a surprising tone of humility. A Change of Emphasis **********''We thought we were in business to make a profit,'' said Carlisle R. Davis, an executive with G.M.'s Assembly Division. ''Now we say we are in business to make automobiles; if they are good, customers will buy them and our reward will be a profit.'' **********There are some indications that this change in attitude is bearing fruit, despite the layoffs, losses and quality problems of the past few years. **********For one thing, as the result of tough cost-cutting, the auto companies are a lot leaner than they were just a few years ago. In the first quarter of 1983, the Big Three had combined profits of $1.04 billion on sales of 1,387,374 cars, compared with a combined loss of $458 million on sales of 1,760,175 cars in the same quarter of 1980. (Another indication of changing management attitudes is the decision by G.M., announced Tuesday, to delay the planned September introduction of its front-wheel-drive Cadillac DeVille, Buick Electra and Oldsmobile 98 luxury models to correct transmission problems.) **********''There are clear signs today that managements are correctly addressing problems with more creative solutions than the cliche responses of the past,'' said Maryann N. Keller, a Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins analyst who has often been critical of the industry. ''The auto industry is better managed today than it has been in more than a decade.'' PICKUP MOTORS ADD **********Analysts also note that its leaders have not deviated from their commitment to the car business. While companies in other basic industries, such as steel, have been investing in chemicals and other unrelated fields, the auto makers have concentrated on developing new models and equipping plants to make them. **********According to figures compiled by David Eisenberg of Sanford C.  Bernstein & Company, the Big Three has put over $43 billion into new plants and production machinery in the past four years. In the same four-year period a decade earlier, those investments only totaled $13.4 billion. **********But the process of modernizing an industry now into its eighth decade (Ford will celebrate its 80th birthday on June 16) is still under way. **********''At a cost of more than $80 billion, the American automobile industry will complete, by 1985, the retooling and re-equipping of 49 new engine and transmission lines and 89 new or fully re-equipped assembly lines,'' Ford's chairman, Philip Caldwell, said recently.  ''When the conversion has been completed, few machine tools or parts will remain unchanged in the industry's 260 domestic plants or in the plants of more than 5,000 U.S. suppliers of automotive components and materials.'' **********As a major part of its drive to upgrade to the state of the art, the industry is investing heavily in automated machinery, robots and computer-controlled processes. G.M.'s new robot painting system, for example, is considered as good as anything in the world. Rigid financial controls, once a hallmark of the industry, have been loosened to bring in the new technology. Sorting Out Priorities **********''You have to be careful not to confuse financial decisions with operational decisions,'' said John Betti, a vice president of Ford.  ''What looks good short-term financially, may not be the best longterm operational decision.'' **********Whether all this investment in new equipment will be enough for Detroit to counter Japan's formidable challenge remains to be seen.  In the meantime, American auto executives are employing a practice reputed to be a specialty of the Japanese - copying. **********Nowhere is that approach more evident than in Flint, long one of General Motors' more important production hubs. Meetings of worker quality circle groups are now common in Buick plants here, as is the use of statistical process controls to monitor their operations; both techniques were borrowed from the Japanese. **********And on a larger scale, the division plans to combine its separate engine, parts and assembly factories here into one integrated facility. The model for the consolidation is Toyota City, the tightly knit industrial complex developed by Japan's largest auto maker. 'Buick City' Project **********As part of its consolidation, Buick plans to take over the city streets alongside its assembly plant so trucks can feed parts directly to the assembly line where they are needed, reducing handling and storage. A conveyor link between the assembly plant and the engine plant two miles away will permit completed engines to be dispatched to to automatically meet the car for which it is intended. **********Herbert Stone, the manager of the ''Buick City'' project, said the result should be a major gain in efficiency. ''We'll take raw steel in one end and four hours later a car will roll out the other.'' **********Another auto industry practice that grew up over the years - one that made engineering subservient to styling - is also being discarded, Detroit executives say. Design and manufacturing engineers are now being invited into styling studios to make changes that will avoid later problems on the assembly line. **********''In the old days we did a design and threw it over a wall at manufacturing,'' said Howard Frears, one of Ford's chief design engineers. ''If it didn't come back in a few days attached to a rock, we assumed they could build it.'' More Attention to Production **********Styling remains important, of course, and Ford, for one, is counting on its new aerodynamic look to give it a clear distinction over competing models. But the difference, Detroit executives say, is that the process of actually producing the vehicle is receiving more attention these days. **********According to Mr. Frears, Ford formerly allowed only 28 months from the time a car's design was frozen until production commenced, so that it could match last-minute styling changes at G.M or Chrysler.  ''It's thirty-six months now, so we've got an extra eight months to engineer the car,'' he said. **********Those extra months can be important. Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said the quality problems of the Plymouth Volare/Dodge Aspen models of the mid-1970's, which helped push Chrysler to the edge of bankruptcy, came from trying to meet a deadline. **********''The engineering on those products wasn't that bad, but it was rushed,'' he said. ''Not doing any galvanizing on the Aspen/Volare cost us $100 million because of rust. That happened because somebody cut $7 a car out of the metal.'' **********This re-emphasis on engineering, production equipment and manufacturing techniques is an acknowledgement that the advantage of the Japanese auto companies lies not in design or marketing, but on the factory floor. Indeed, many modern Japanese autos were styled outside Japan and the major Japanese auto companies all have design studios in California, staffed largely by Americans. **********In a way, the American auto industry is returning to its roots, to the days when Henry Ford and David Buick, men who knew their way around a factory, ran automobile companies. Donald Petersen, the president of Ford, said recently: ''We need to restore the prestige and status of manufacturing jobs.'' To do that, he said, Ford will ''provide compensation and career advancement opportunities in that field which will be comparable to other areas of our organization.'' ---- G.M. Models Delayed Special to the New York Times **********DETROIT, May 11 - General Motors will delay the planned September introduction of a new series of high-priced cars to avoid quality problems, the auto maker's president said. **********In a speech Tuesday, the president, F. James McDonald, said the company's new, front-wheel-drive Cadillac DeVille, Buick Electra and Oldsmobile 98 would go on sale ''only after we're satisfied with the results of special verification testing of early production runs.'' **********The cars, to be produced at new plants in Lake Orion, Mich., and Wentzville, Mo., had been scheduled to begin production in mid-July for introduction in late September. Industry sources said problems with the cars' transmissions could delay production for as long as six months. **********G.M. has been plagued with recalls involving its X-body cars, the first of its front-wheel-drive models, which were introduced in 1979. ''We're taking this step to assure the highest quality,'' Mr.  McDonald said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.main_headline: A NEW PLAN TO REJUVENATE BROOKLYN ARMY TERMINAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A NEW PLAN TO REJUVENATE BROOKLYN ARMY TERMINAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.body_text: **********For almost two decades there have been a number of proposals to rejuvenate the old Brooklyn Army Terminal and use its four million square feet of space to create jobs and spur economic growth in the area. **********There were plans to develop the almost vacant site into a big general cargo terminal and expanded free port. There once was talk of constructing a major office building on the site to accommodate New York State workers. For a while a post office was in service there. At one time the city worked with Harry Helmsley, one of the city's most prominent private developers, to convert the terminal into an industrial site. That plan fell apart in 1981. **********The complex of warehouses, office buildings and railroad tracks was opened in 1919 at a cost of $30 million. During World War II it was used to accommodate service personnel. In the mid-1960's the Defense Department decided to shut it down in an economy drive. The city bought the 55-acre terminal site in 1981. The price was $8.5 million, but the cost to the city was only $4 million because it received a $4.5 million grant from the Federal Government. **********Now there is another plan for the waterfront terminal that looks out over lower Manhattan from Bay Ridge - and there are faint signs that it may actually come to pass. The city plans to use public and private financing to upgrade the buildings and lease space for light industry and warehousing. **********The total cost for rehabilitating the property, expected to take four years, is estimated at $36 million. But the city will initially rehabilitate only one building at a cost of $20 million. Ultimately, the city expects the rehabilitation to create 5,800 jobs. **********The city has hired Eastdil Realty, a nationally known real estate investing banking firm, to arrange the private financing. The $20 million package will include private funds and $2 million of city funds. The city also hopes to get an Urban Development Action grant of $5.6 million from the Federal Government. **********The use of tax-exempt Industrial Revenue Bonds in the financing package has been discussed, but Elliot Matz, a senior project manager for the city's Public Development Corporation, said that for technical reasons the bonds have turned out to be a difficult, if not impossible, proposition for the terminal project. **********One attractive lure for private financing will be the 25 percent Federal investment tax credit available for historic renovation.  Joel Goldfrank, Eastdil's executive vice president, said he expected the financing arrangements to take six to nine months. The project needs to have 25 to 35 percent of the space pre-leased before investors will commit themselves, he said, adding that the terminal plan ''is one of the most ambitious redevelopment projects in the country in terms of generating employment and the amount of space.'' **********The Public Development Corporation, which is overseeing the project, is handling the leasing. No leases have been made, but Mr.  Matz said the agency expected to have 25 percent of the space leased by the summer in Building D, the first to be renovated. Building D contains about 2 million square feet of space. **********''We're in a juggling act between preleasing and financing,'' Mr.  Matz said. ''We have handshake deals on about 500,000 square feet.'' The largest potential tenant would use about 250,000 square feet. The city is hoping to start construction this fall and to have tenants in place by the fall of 1984. **********Mr. Matz also said that the city would soon seek bids from real estate companies to act as both broker and managing agent for the terminal. **********About 50 percent of the space in the first building will be rehabilitated for manufacuturing and the remainder for warehouse use.  The plan calls for new sprinkler systems, a new power system to replace the old steam generating plant, new elevators and bathrooms.  Under discussion also are shops and services, such as a newspaper stand, post office, bank and coffee shop. **********The city's ''nonnegotiable'' rents in the terminal are $2.25 a square foot for manufacturing space, $1.90 for warehouse space and $3.50 for the ground floor, Mr. Matz said. **********Phil Aarons, president of the Public Development Corporation, said that the plan to make the city a joint venture partner with private industry was a new arrangement for the city. The only similar arrangement is the Teleport project for a satellite communications center and office park on Staten Island. **********In the real estate portion of the Teleport operation, the city basically will take 8 percent of the gross rentals from the office park and 50 percent of the project revenues after maintenance and debt service, he said. The project is a joint venture with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and Merrill Lynch & Company. **********How the city and private investors will split the profits from the Army Terminal project has not been determined.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/world.main_headline: LEBANESE TROOPS TRY BUT FAIL TO HALT ISRAELI PATROL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/world.print_headline: LEBANESE TROOPS TRY BUT FAIL TO HALT ISRAELI PATROL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/world.body_text: **********Lebanese troops tried and failed today to keep an Israeli patrol from going through their checkpoint on the outskirts of the city in a confrontation that lasted about 20 minutes. **********It was just Tuesday that the Lebanese Army extended its control from West Beirut to the entire city, and the incident today touched off warnings from both sides. **********An Israeli Army spokesman said, according to the Israeli radio monitored here, that the incident occurred in an area under Israeli control and that the Israelis would continue their patrols there as part of routine security. **********The Israeli spokesman said the patrol, commanded by an Israeli colonel, broke through a Lebanese barricade near the town of Monteverde, about three miles east of here, and continued on its way. **********(A different version was given by Lebanese military sources, who said, according to Reuters, that the incident took place at Sinn al Fil, an East Beirut suburb two and a half miles from Monteverde. The informants said three Israeli armored personnel carriers went a short way past the checkpoint toward central Beirut, then turned around and went back after negotiations.) 'Instructions to Shoot' **********Lebanon's Foreign Minister, Elie Salem , said at a news conference that Lebanese troops had ''instructions to shoot'' at any force encountering it ''in the greater Beirut area.'' No shots were fired, however, in today's incident, which some officials said was an attempt by the Israelis to test the Lebanese Army in its new deployment. **********The Foreign Minister said, ''Lebanon will not interfere with the logistical routes that Israel uses'' through East Beirut. But he said the Israelis would not be permitted elsewhere in the city. **********Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan told reporters Lebanon was working with the United States to try to eliminate problems between the Lebanese and Israeli forces. **********Meanwhile, French and Italian soldiers from the multinational force took up positions today alongside the Lebanese Army in two areas in East Beirut, Mekales and Nahr al Mot. Press reports here said United States marines would join the Lebanese Army there on Monday. **********Government sources said support from the multinational force, deployed mostly in West Beirut, would help the Lebanese Army stand up to the Israelis. Israeli Request Denied **********Foreign Minister Salem said at his news conference that on Monday night, hours before 4,000 Lebanese soldiers moved into East Beirut, the Israelis asked Lebanon to coordinate the movement of its troops in the eastern sector with the Israeli command. He said the Lebanese refused. **********''In the greater Beirut area, where the army has deployed, no military presence is permitted, neither Lebanese nor non-Lebanese, except for the Lebanese Army and the multinational force,'' Mr. Salem declared. **********''The army has instructions to shoot, has instructions to act like and army and not negotiate with outlaws,'' he said. ''Every force that will encounter the army in the greater Beirut area, whether it is formal or informal, is, in the context of the Lebanese law, an outlaw.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/busin.main_headline: PHONE PACT TO BRING RATE INCREASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/busin.print_headline: PHONE PACT TO BRING RATE INCREASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/busin.body_text: **********The tentative agreement to end the nationwide strike against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is likely to lead to slightly higher phone rates because wage increases will be passed on to consumers, company and union officials and analysts said yesterday. **********However, the rate increases, of perhaps a few percentage points, would be small compared with those already expected from the structural changes taking place in the telephone business as a result of the pending breakup of A.T.& T. and recent decisions by the Federal Communications Commission. Those changes are expected to lead to at least a doubling of local telephone rates in the next year or two. **********''It's fair to assume that if wages go up, rates will go up a commensurate amount,'' said Paul L. Gioia, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, which regulates telephone rates in the state. He added, however, ''If wages go up 5 percent in one year I don't think that's significant. That's in line with general economic circumstances.'' **********Bargaining Shifts to Locals **********The tentative nationwide agreement reached Sunday would end the 16-day nationwide strike involving 675,000 workers in three unions. Yesterday, bargaining shifted to the local telephone companies and union locals, which are trying to resolve issues specific to each region. That process is scheduled to be completed by late Wednesday, and could put workers back on the job Thursday. **********The agreement would provide a maximum wage increase of 5.5 percent the first year and additional increases of 1.5 percent plus cost-of-living adjustments in the following two years. Union officials estimated the total increase could be 16.4 percent over three years. The average hourly wage reportedly would increase to $14.35, from $12.33, **********A.T.& T.'s labor costs, including pensions, were about $26 billion last year, or about half of its operating expenses. A 5.5 percent wage increase, then, would make rates go up by about 2.2 percent, which would translate into a little more than $1 billion in annual revenue increases, assuming the ratio remains constant. **********By contrast, A.T.& T. and its local operating companies now have $7.2 billion in rate increases pending before state regulators, an A.T.& T. spokesman said. **********Swift Settlement Unexpected **********The settlement, reached late Sunday, was unexpectedly swift. Many analysts thought that A.T.& T. was in a strong bargaining position, were it not for the pending divestiture. Supervisors were able to continue running the company without the striking workers and, by some estimates, the company was improving its net income by about $100 million a week by not having to pay wages. **********Nevertheless, the longer the strike dragged on, the more inconvenient it became to the company. In addition, supervisors who were running the phone company were needed to help plan the divestiture. Had the strike continued, it would have endangered meeting the Jan. 1 target date. **********''The worst thing in the world that could have happened would be for anything to postpone the divestiture,'' said John Bain, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. Indeed, A.T.& T. has accepted many things it did not like - such as the loss of its Bell name and logotype - in order to get the divestiture in place and get on with business. **********Concessions Made on Both Sides **********Nonetheless, the agreement has elements favorable to each side. The unions won a continuation of company-paid health care benefits and won several new programs to help retrain workers or to compensate them as technological changes eliminate many traditional telephone jobs. **********For A.T.& T., the wage increases granted were smaller than in the last two contracts, negotiated in 1977 and 1980. ''That's a pretty good settlement,'' said Steven Chrust, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Also, despite the new job security programs, A.T.& T. apparently retains the prerogative to transfer or lay off workers, which could be important as it tries to become more competitive. **********The pending divestiture and the increased competition in the telephone business were essential background factors in the negotiations. **********When A.T.& T. spins off 22 operating companies and begins to compete aggressively in equipment manufacturing and long-distance services, there will be pressure on the company to adopt the most modern technology and to slash labor costs, especially since it will be competing against many companies without unions, such as the electronics companies in California's Silicon Valley. **********Technology Eliminates Jobs **********Those factors could lead to substantial layoffs at a company that was once known for its job security. **********''That's been the fear of the entire bargaining arena,'' said Arthur Perry, director of the telephone department for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which represents 100,000 striking employees. The two other unions are the Communications Workers of America, representing 525,000 employees, and the Telecommunications Intenational union, representing 50,000 employees. **********Technology is already cutting into many traditional phone company jobs, such as operators and installers. Many credit card calls no longer require operator assistance. In some cities, computerized voices provide numbers to callers seeking directory assistance. **********With more people buying their own phones, fewer installers are needed. And fewer workers are needed to repair and maintain the electronic central office switches that are replacing the electromechanical ones. The workers who are needed require different skills. **********''The company is becoming more of a white-collar company and less of a blue-collar company,'' said James M. McCabe, telephone industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/17/world.body_text: **********Church officials said tonight that two Roman Catholic priests, both Irish nationals, were expelled from Chile today for what the Government said was involvement in politics. **********The officials identified the expelled priests as the Rev. Brendon Forbe and the Rev. Desmond McGillicuddy, and said both had been put aboard a Chilean commercial airliner and flown to Buenos Aires. **********On Sunday, Raul Cardinal Silva Henriquez, the highest-ranking Catholic official in Chile, denounced the Government for threatening to expel the priests for running what he said the police had described as a ''politically oriented soup kitchen'' for the poor. **********On Tuesday, the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet formally accused the two Irish priests and an Australian, the Rev.  Brian McMahon, with disturbing public order and interfering in politics. There was no word on the status of Father McMahon.
