https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Markets **********The U.S. intervened in world currency markets for the third trading day in a row in an effort to slow the rise of the dollar. It was joined by West Germany, Japan, Switzerland and France. While the coordinated effort may cost Washington as much as $1 billion, some experts said, it could still fail to curb the dollar, which has been pushed upward mainly by rising U.S. interest rates. (Page A1.) The dollar fell slightly in foreign currency trading. Gold prices, meanwhile, rose $2 an ounce, to $414 in New York. (D5.) **********Long-term interest rates stabilized as the Treasury completed the first part of a three-part, $15.75 billion financing. It sold $6.5 billion of new 11 3/8 percent, three-year notes at an average yield of 11.43 percent. The yield, the highest since August 1982, was further evidence that investors and securities dealers are concerned about the direction of interest rates. (D1.) **********The American Stock Exchange has agreed with the Chicago Board of Trade to let members trade in each other's stock index products. The agreement would allow, for the first time, members of a stock exchange and a commodity market to trade each other's products without having to register. (D1.) **********Stock prices declined moderately as investors continued to worry about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.21 points, to 1,188. It was the Dow's fifth consecutive decline - for a total of 55.69 points. (D8.) Soybean futures prices rose, while corn was mixed and wheat fell. (D11.) Companies **********G. D. Searle has agreed to supply Coca-Cola with aspartame, its low-calorie sweetener, for use in diet soft drinks. Coca-Cola plans to combine aspartame with saccharin, starting this year, in products already on the market. Coca-Cola's rivals indicated they are also thinking of using aspartame. (D1.)  A merger agreement has been reached by the Bank of New York and Northeast Bancorp of Connecticut. The venture would enable the New York bank to become the first to move into Connecticut and, in particular, into the prosperous Fairfield County area. It will require a change in Federal or Connecticut law, however. (D1.) **********BankAmerica agreed to pay a $108,000 fine arising out of charges that it violated Federal regulations prohibiting assistance to the Arab boycott of Israel. (D5.) **********Security Pacific National has demonstrated the ''current confusion'' over the role of banks and securities firms by purchasing a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, according to the head of the Securities Industry Association. (D6.) **********Osborne Computer has closed its plant in Monmouth, N.J., leaving it with a single plant, in Hayward, Calif. According to analysts, the move indicates weaker demand for Osborne's products. (D16.) **********ITT reported a 1.3 percent rise in earnings in the second quarter, while Grumman's net soared 83.9 percent. (D16.) **********Esmark has arranged for a $1.2 billion credit with nine banks to finance its $1.05 billion acquisition of Norton Simon. (D4.) **********The fate of the U.S. operations of Marc Rich & Company was left hanging as talks continued with Federal prosecutors. (D4.) The Economy **********Sales of new single-family houses fell 2.9 percent in June from the May level, the Government reported. Even with the decline, it said, sales were up 87 percent from a year ago. Still, experts cited industry concern over recent rises in mortgage rates. The median price of a new house rose to a record $77,200. (D3.) **********New factory orders rose 3.9 percent in June, to $176.8 billion, the Commerce Department reported. The increase, the biggest since September 1980, was the eighth in the past nine months. Analysts noted, however, that much of the total was for military orders and that inventory liquidation seemed to continue. (D3.) Today's Columns **********Could jobless aid become a hiring-incentive program without endangering its crucial relief function? One way to do so might be to let workers convert their aid entitlements into vouchers redeemable by employers if they are hired. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Wholesale grocer stocks have been quietly performing well despite their relative obscurity. On the Big Board, for example, one has climbed from a low of 11 in early 1982 to a high of 31 1/4 this year, while another has gone from 11 5/8 to 30 3/4. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/04/busin.body_text: **********How Poll Was Conducted **********The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 24 through Sept. 28 with 1,587 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. **********The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. **********The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, permitting access to both listed and unlisted residential numbers. **********The results have been weighted to take account of household size and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education. **********In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on the entire sample will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by interviewing all adult Americans. The error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, the margin of sampling error for those respondents who said they had heard about the telephone company reorganization is plus or minus five percentage points. **********In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other errors into the poll. **********Edward R. Tufte, professor of political science and statistics at YYale University, assisted The Times with this survey.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today that it had record earnings last year and was making changes to broaden its activities in the future. **********Kenneth J. Thygerson, the corporation president, said 1982 ''was the best year ever for our earnings.'' **********The corporation, which buys mortgages from savings banks and savings and loan associations, had net income of $59.9 million in 1982, up from $30.9 million the year before. **********The corporation's purchase of mortgages, which are resold as investments, provides cash for the thrift institutions, which can then make more mortgage loans. **********Mr. Thygerson said the bulk of the corporation's earnings could be attributed to the new guarantor mortgage purchase program, under which certificates are issued that can be traded in the same fashion as stocks and bonds. **********Mr. Thygerson also said his agency was instituting a new program for adjustable-rate mortgages that will begin in mid-April.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Savers deposited nearly $4 billion more in savings and loan associations in July than they withdrew, more than twice the net gain in June, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today. **********It also said the institutions closed $12 billion in home loans last month, less than the record $13.9 billion of the previous month. **********In its new report, the bank board said the 3,123 federally insured savings and loan associations received nearly $60 billion in new deposits in July and savers withdrew about $56 billion. After $2.6 billion in interest was credited to accounts, the total deposit increase was pegged at $6.5 billion. **********July's increase in deposits marked the eighth in a row for savings and loan institutions, which have been recovering from a long earnings slump. **********The sharp pickup in deposits this year has been attributed largely to the introduction of the new money market deposit account. The money flowing into the $2,500-minimum account, though, was down $2.9 billion last month to a total of $102.3 billion. **********Balances in the Super-NOW checking account were $6.8 billion in July, under the $7.1 billion of the previous month.  The report also said the institutions' net worth was virtually unchanged in July, at about $27.3 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/busin.main_headline: IACOCCA ASKS DELAY OF WARRANT SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/busin.print_headline: IACOCCA ASKS DELAY OF WARRANT SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation will ask the Federal Government to postpone the sale of the 14.4 million Chrysler stock warrants it holds until the auto maker seeks a Congressional review of the matter, the company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said today. **********Mr. Iacocca said in an interview that he was sending a letter to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan asking for the postponement. Last Friday, Mr. Regan announced that the Government had decided to sell the warrants to the public through an underwritten offering. **********Each warrant can be converted into one share of Chrysler stock at a price of $13. At today's closing price of $26 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, down $1.625, the Government could earn $13 a share, or $187.2 million, by converting the warrants itself. It is expected to earn even more by selling the warrants to underwriters, and Chrysler itself has offered to buy them back for $17.36 apiece, or $250 million. **********The Government obtained the warrants from Chrysler in 1980 in exchange for the risk it took in agreeing to guarantee repayment of up to $1.5 billion in loans that the auto maker needed to avoid bankruptcy. At the time, the warrants were considered virtually worthless. **********Chrysler subsequently borrowed $1.2 billion with Federal guarantees and is now in the process of repaying the last of these loans, now that it is profitable again. **********During the interview at Chrysler's headquarters here, a visibly disturbed Mr. Iacocca said the sale of the warrants by the Government would violate the intent of Congress when it wrote the loan guarantee legislation. He said the sale of the warrants would depress the price of the company's stock until 1990, when they expire, even though the Government's risk is about to end with the repayment of the guaranteed loans. **********''It doesn't meet the test of fairness, or even decency,'' Mr. Iacocca said. ''You can argue about the technicalities, but the operative line is that when you pay back a loan of that size seven years ahead of schedule, you often renegotiate the terms because there is no more risk left.'' Warrants Good Until 1990 **********Several Wall Street investment houses have indicated that they are planning bids for the warrants. Since the warrants are valid until 1990, each is considered to be worth more than the spread between the $13 face value and the current price of Chrysler stock. That is because Chrysler stock is expected to sell above its current price over the next seven years. **********The Government has said that it has already been offered more than $17 a warrant by underwriters who believe they can make a profit by reselling the warrants to the public at a higher price. **********Mr. Iacocca said the company offered on July 13, the day he announced that the last of the loans would be repaid, to buy back the warrants for just over $17 each, or a total of $250 million. He suggested that the board's decision to seek what he termed a ''speculative'' profit stemmed from hostility on the part of Government officials toward him and Chrysler. 'Source of Bewilderment' **********''I've dealt with an Administration and people representing that Administration who ideologically didn't like our deal,'' Mr. Iacocca said. ''And now that we've succeeded, we're the source of some bewilderment - if not embarrassment - and I've gotten the feeling that they just wish I'd go away and maybe fail.'' **********Mr. Iacocca said Chrysler made a second proposal to the Government that the expiration date of the warrants be accelerated to this year if they were sold to the public. That way, he said, the Government would make a profit and Chrysler would get a quick infusion of $187 million in cash through the exercise of the warrants. **********He said it was his hope that a Congressional oversight hearing, which he acknowledged has not yet been set, would persuade the loan board to choose that option. Mishandled Earlier Talks **********Mr. Iacocca, who said he had ''harsh words'' with Mr. Regan when the sale plan was announced, also conceded that the auto maker had mishandled earlier negotiations on the warrants. He said the request, made earlier this year, that the warrants be given back to Chrysler once the loan was repaid was a tactic that backfired. The request drew widespread criticism in Congress and created the impression that Chrysler was attempting to get out of its part of the original loan agreement. **********The auto executive, who has often harshly criticized the Administration's economic policies, said he was hoping that a Congressional hearing would define what the original legislation meant by a ''fair'' return to Government for its guarantees. **********''You have to ask if a quarter of a billion dollars is an adequate return for 36 months of guarantees,'' Mr. Iacocca said. ''The fact that I paid off the loans changed things a bit, and, I was led to believe, changed what they felt would be fair. As it turned out, I was twisted in the wind.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; D.D.B. International Wins Michelin Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The New York office of Doyle Dane Bernbach International has won the Michelin Tire Corporation account. It will take over the passenger car tire assignment on Aug.1 and the truck, off-the-road and motorcycle tire business Jan.1. **********The Michelin people here would only say that the assignment was for domestic advertising, even though in May, when they announced that the account would be leaving the Al Paul Lefton Company of Philadelphia and New York, the reason given was that Lefton could not supply the marketing that Michelin needed in several international markets. **********Annual billings on the tires are about $15 million.  Michelin, a French company, ranks fourth in the United States in the replacement passenger tire market, the largest segment. Its share of this $7.3 billion market is 8 percent. **********D.D.B., the 10th largest American agency (Lefton is 68th), did advertising for Uniroyal from 1963 to 1974.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/world.main_headline: SHULTZ IS BRIEFED BY EXPERTS FOR VISIT TO CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/world.print_headline: SHULTZ IS BRIEFED BY EXPERTS FOR VISIT TO CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz met today with a group of China experts to prepare himself for his first visit to Peking early next month. **********Since taking office, Mr. Shultz has said little publicly about China, but in an interview he noted, ''China is important, and potentially, as it develops itself, extraordinarily important.'' **********''In any sort of comprehensive effort to think about our own strategy and how it may unfold, you are missing something if thinking about China isn't part of that,'' he said. **********Today's meeting on China was the latest in the so-called Shultz seminars at which outside experts meet with Mr. Shultz and senior officials from the State Department and other Government agencies.  The first dealt with the Middle East and others with the Soviet Union and Latin America. **********Kissinger at Session **********The China session was organized at Mr. Shultz's request by Winston Lord, a former State Department official who is now president of the Council on Foreign Relations. Mr. Lord served as the China expert for Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and accompanied him on his trips to China that paved the way to establishment of quasi-official relations in 1972. **********Mr. Kissinger, who led the discussion at Mr. Shultz's Middle East seminar last July, also attended today's session. Mr. Shultz has said he holds no one in higher esteem than Mr. Kissinger, who was also President Reagan's guest at lunch at the White House on Friday. **********Richard Solomon, a former University of Michigan professor who also served Mr. Kissinger and is now at the RAND Corporation, was invited to the seminar. According to the State Department, other outside experts invited included Michel Oksenberg, a White House China specialist in the Carter Administration, now at the University of Michigan; Lucian Pye, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; A.  Doak Barnett, Brookings Institution; Dwight Perkins, Harvard; Harold Brown, Defense Secretary in the Carter Administration; William G.  Hyland, a former government specialist on the Soviet Union, now at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace; Robert Scalapino, University of California, and Jeffrey Gayner, the Heritage Foundation. **********These were the Administration officials invited: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger; William P. Clark, the national security adviser; Robert C. McFarlane, his deputy; Kenneth W. Dam, the Deputy Secretary of State; Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs; Paul D. Wolfowitz, Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs; Stephen W.  Bosworth, director of policy planning; Gaston Segur, National Security Council staff expert on Asia; Richard L. Armitage, Defense Department; David Gries, State Department, and Donald Gregg, the Vice President's office. **********Mr. Shultz leaves Washington at the end of the month for Japan, from where he will travel to Peking for four days of talks with senior officials. He will then go on to South Korea. **********Administration officials said Mr. Shultz's priorities are to provide new momentum to relations with China, which have been under strain for most of the Reagan Administration over the Taiwan issue.  In a communique issued by the two sides last summer the United States pledged to reduce arms sales to Taiwan over time and China repeated its policy to unite with Taiwan by peaceful means. 'Big Emerging Developments' **********But since then the Chinese have become involved in negotiations with the Soviet Union on normalizing relations and have expressed concern that their ties with the United States have not brought them the economic benefits they had anticipated. **********In the interview Mr. Shultz said, ''China has to be something taken strongly into account in our own strategic thinking.'' In economic terms, he said, ''you can't help but see big emerging developments in Asia, with Japan on the leading edge, but by no means alone.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/busin.main_headline: WHEN PLANNING TO INVEST IN TREASURIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; WHEN PLANNING TO INVEST IN TREASURIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/busin.body_text: **********THIS week the Treasury is selling notes and bonds totaling $14.5 b illion, a record package that is needed to finance a record Federal b udget deficit. **********In advance of those auctions, which have been prominent in the minds of speculators and traders for several weeks, dealers in Government securities have already begun distributing and trading the securities. This pre-auction activity has the approval of the Treasury, since it gives dealers more time to find buyers - most of whom are speculators or large instititions - and thereby helps lower the interest rate, set at the auctions, that the Treasury has to pay. **********Although individual investors rarely make commitments before the auction, they watch the early activity for indications of what interest rates the auctions will produce. **********By late Friday, the $6.5 billion of three-year notes due Feb. 15, 1986, to be auctioned this Tuesday were offered by securities dealers with a yield of 9.78 percent, and the $4.5 billion of 10-year notes due Feb. 15, 1993, to be auctioned Wednesday were offered with a yield of 10.74 percent. In the long-term bond market, the $3.5 billion of additonal 10 3/8 percent bonds due Nov. 15, 2012 were offered with a yield of 10.85 percent. **********The specter of these borrowings has contributed to lower prices and higher yields for notes and bonds during the past month. However, many analysts say that even if the heavy supply of Treasury issues causes yields to rise further, the increase is only temporary. The slowdown of inflation and weak credit demands by businesses and consumers will leave room for yields on Treasury issues to come back down, they say. **********While the Treasury has little control over the most important factors that influence interest rates, such as inflation and the state of the economy, it tries to keep its interest costs low by not suprising the market with unexpected financings. That means selling bills, notes and bonds on a regular schedule, so that securities firms and investors know what issues will be available when. **********Over the years, the number of Treasury financings has steadily increased. Securities dealers who used to provide quotes on the telephone for every outstanding Treasury issue now do so only for the half-dozen or so most recent and actively traded issues. Price quotes for all 32 outstanding issues of Treasury bills and 149 outstanding issues of notes and bonds are normally provided only on request or on quote sheets compiled at the end of the day. **********Since budget deficits seem to be the rule rather than the exception, Treasury officials have found it necessary each year to borrow increasing amounts both to finance that year's deficit and to repay maturing securities that helped finance previous years' deficits. The size of weekly bill auctions has increased dramatically, from $5.8 billion at the end of 1975 to $12 billion currently. But Treasury officials have been forced to sell longerterm issues as well, if only to be relieved from the burden of selling even larger amounts every week. **********In 1975, for example, a $45.2 billion budget deficit led the Treasury to sell two-year notes every month to raise cash. ''We thought there was demand for securities with a maturity between oneyear and long-term,'' said Edward M. Roob, an executive vice president at the First National Bank of Chicago and former Under Secretary of the Treasury for Debt Management. ''By regular offerings, we thought we could build a market for two-year notes.'' **********The two-year note is now one of the most widely traded Treasury issues and is extremely popular with investors such as commercial banks who cannot bear the risk of longer-term issues. **********The evidence of investor demand for intermediate-term issues led Treasury officials to increase their sales of three-, four-, five-, seven- and 10-year issues, all now sold on a regular schedule. **********Quarterly refundings, such as this week's, used to be the focal point of Government borrowing in the note and bond market. They were so named because there was a time when Treasury securities due in more than one year were scheduled to mature on Feb. 15, May 15, Aug.  15 and Nov. 15. **********This week's three-part, $14.5 billion financing, for example, will raise $8.7 billion of new cash to finance this year's deficit, as well as retiring $5.8 billion of publicly held 8 percent notes that were sold in February 1976 to finance part of that year's deficit.  Similarly, the $7.5 billion of two-year notes auctioned Jan. 19, raised $3 billion of new cash and retired $4.5 billion of publicly held notes that had been sold in January 1981. **********The following pattern of Treasury financings is expected by dealers who say that it is subject to minor changes. The term of issues due in three years and more may vary by three months or so as the Treasury adjusts maturities to keep from having too many issues falling due on the same day. *********** Three- and six-month Treasury bills, which actually have maturities of 13 and 26 weeks, respectively, are auctioned every Monday. *********** One-year Treasury bills are auctioned every fourth Thursday, most recently on Jan. 20. *********** Two-year notes are auctioned in the second half of each month. *********** Three-, 10- and 30-year issues comprise the old ''refunding'' package, and are auctioned in the first week of February, May, August, and November. *********** Four-, seven- and 20-year issues were once auctioned at various times each quarter, but the current practice is to lump them together into a single week, in the second half of the last month of each calendar quarter. Thus, analysts expect four-, seven- and 20-year issues to be auctioned in late March, June, September and December. *********** Five-year notes are auctioned late in the second month of each calendar quarter. The next issue has not been announced, but is expected Feb. 22. **********A recorded message at the Bureau of the Public Debt provides information about Treasury securities 24 hours a day. For information about upcoming auctions of bills, notes and bonds, as well as results of recent auctions, call 202-287-4100. For general information about buying Treasury bills, call 202-287-4091. For information about buying notes or bonds, call 202-287-4088.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/08/busin.main_headline: BATUS NAMES HEAD OF RETAIL DIVISION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; BATUS NAMES HEAD OF RETAIL DIVISION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Batus Inc. said yesterday that it had appointed a new chairman and chief executive officer for its retail division, which operates such stores as Saks Fifth Avenue, Gimbels and Marshall Field. The division's sales total $3 billion a year. **********Arnold H. Aronson, 48 years old, will move to the top retail spot effective Sept. 1. M. Ronald Ruskin, 52, will succeed him as president of the division. **********Mr. Aronson succeeds Robert J. Suslow, 50, who announced in March that he was resigning. Mr. Suslow, who will stay on until September to help with the transition, has not disclosed his plans. **********Batus said reporting responsibilities would change, with Mr.  Aronson having direct charge of Saks, Marshall Field and the corporate merchandising office. **********Mr. Ruskin will have responsibility for Gimbels-East, Midwest and Gimbels-Pittsburgh, Kohl's Food Stores, Ivey's Carolinas and Florida, the John Breuner Company, Frederick & Nelson, the Crescent and Thimbles. **********Batus Inc. is the holding and management company for the United States interests of B.A.T. Industries of Britain.  Both Mr. Aronson and Mr. Ruskin began their retail careers at Bloomingdale's, a unit of Federated Department Stores Inc. In 1972 Mr. Aronson became executive vice president of the May Department Stores Company in California and later became chief executive officer for its Bullock's stores there. He joined Saks Fifth Avenue as president and chief executive officer in 1979 and became chairman the following year. Last July he was named president of the retail division. **********Mr. Ruskin, who has been vice chairman at the division since April, came to Batus in 1979 as chief executive officer of Gimbels-New York. Before that he was president and chief executive officer of May stores in Denver.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/31/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; TV Newscaster Quits On the Air in Nigeria
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/31/world.body_text: **********A television newscaster, protesting ''news full of falsehood,'' quit on the air and walked out of the studio in Enugu, the capital of Anambra state, The Lagos Daily Sketch newspaper reported today. **********It said the newscaster, Chuma Edozie, was doing the 7 P.M. news on the Nigerian state television Thursday and had just finished reading political items when he paused and said: ''I am sorry I cannot with my conscience continue to read this news full of falsehood. I hereby resign my appointment with immediate effect.'' **********He picked up his papers and walked out in front of the cameras.  After five minutes another announcer came on.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration has begun informal discussions with foreign governments on ways to improve the workings of the 88-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, following setbacks last November at a ministerial conference in Geneva, Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today. **********At a breakfast with reporters, Mr. Brock said that the United States had discussed such concepts as ''GATT Plus,'' ''Super GATT'' and ''GATT of the Like Minded'' in efforts to try to strengthen world trading rules. **********The idea is that some, but not all, GATT members might decide to negotiate further liberalization in certain sectors such as services, high technology or government purchasing. These countries would then be free to go ahead, creating a new institutional structure of benefits and obligations, instead of having to wait until a consensus emerges among all 88 GATT members. GATT moves into new ground now only when all members agree. **********Initial reactions of trading partners were guarded. Sir Roy Denman, Ambassador in Washington of the European Economic Community, said that he was ''skeptical of any new kind of magic solutions'' for GATT.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in July, only the second decline since they hit a low during the recession last October, the Commerce Department said today. **********The decline, which followed a 5.1 percent surge in June, reflected a falloff in durable goods. Orders for these ''big ticket'' items fell 3.5 percent, after climbing 7.6 percent in June and 1.6 percent in May, the department added. **********David Cross of Chase Econometrics said that ''evidence is accumulating'' that, as expected, the economic recovery began slowing down in July. Other reports have shown a weakening in the revivals in housing, retail sales and other areas of the economy during July. **********Mr. Cross added that the drop in orders could be partly attributed to the rise in interest rates during the summer and partly to the fact that the strong growth in the economy during the second quarter was not sustainable in the long run. **********Robert Wescott of Wharton Econometrics agreed, noting the declines in interest rate-sensitive durable goods - which are generally bought on credit. He said that it suggested that the Federal Reserve Board's credit- tightening moves over the summer ''are starting to bite into the economy a little.'' **********Shipments of goods were also down and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige called the slides in the two indicators ''most likely temporary setbacks.'' **********Mr. Baldrige also noted that inventories held by manufacturers rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the largest one-month increase since November 1981, and said it ''indicates that the recovery is proceeding in typical fashion.'' **********Mr. Baldrige warned that inventory rebuilding - and the increased short-term corporate borrowing needed to finance such stocks - could put further upward pressure on interest rates ''if Government borrowing is not reduced quickly.'' **********In addition to the slump for durable goods, the report showed a slowing in the rise in orders for nondurable goods. Such orders rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July after increasing 2.5 percent and 3 percent in June and May, respectively. **********Orders for durable goods totaled $87.7 billion compared with $90.9 billion in June. Orders for nondurable goods totaled $87.8 billion compared with $87.6 billion in June. **********Before July, the last decline in overall orders was the 3.1 percent drop in February. Last month's was the second decline since orders reached a low of $152.4 billion last October, the report said. **********The report also showed that the value of inventories held by manufacturers rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to $258.4 billion, offsetting the three- tenths of 1 percent decline in June. Inventories had fallen 13 consecutive months before hitting a low in March and ''since then the level has somewhat stabilized,'' the report said. **********Orders for capital goods industries - covering items used for future modernization and expansion - fell 12.2 percent, to $28.3 billion, including declines for transportation equipment and nonelectrical machinery. That also included a 15.1 percent drop for the volatile category of military capital goods such as aircraft and missiles. Such orders had surged 66 percent in June. **********Orders for nonmilitary capital goods fell 11.3 percent. **********The 5.1 percent June gain in overall orders is a revision from the previously reported 3.9 percent increase. **********All figures are adjusted to discount for normal seasonal variations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.main_headline: REGULATORS WILL SUBMIT BILL ON FOREIGN LENDING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.print_headline: REGULATORS WILL SUBMIT BILL ON FOREIGN LENDING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board and other bank regulators said today that legislation placing restraints on American bank lending abroad was unnecessary but that they would go along with it if it was ''not unduly rigid or inconsistent.'' **********Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, along with C.T. Conover, Comptroller of the Currency, and William M. Isaac, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, defended their own package of proposals to restrain lending abroad. They testified at a Senate Banking Committee hearing. **********In submitting their joint recommendations last week, the regulators had insisted that legislation was unnecessary because they already had a mandate under earlier legislation to tighten the controls. **********Under prodding, however, the regulators agreed to put their proposals, which impose higher costs on banks with large amounts of loans to financially troubled countries, into a draft bill by the end of this week. **********The Banking Committee is considering an $8.4 billion increase in the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund. This 144-nation institution lends to debtor countries willing to reduce their budget deficits and accept other conditions that would help them improve their international accounts. The American increase would be part of a $40 billion rise in I.M.F. resources sought by the agency to meet the demands of developing countries asking for new credits to help pay their huge foreign debts. **********The lending restraints on American bank loans abroad have become the quid pro quo of Congressional approval of the expanded American participation in the I.M.F. American banks now have more than $100 billion in loans abroad. **********Senator Jake Garn, the Banking Committee chairman, said he hoped Congress would not ''overreact'' but promised that there would be a legislated restraint package. **********''Believe me, there will be legislation,'' said Senator Garn, a Republican from Utah. ''The bottom line is that the legislation is necessary so we can go home and say we are not bailing out the banks.'' **********Critics of the I.M.F. bill have held that the extra money would be used by the debtor countries to repay or bail out the banks. Others argue that the fund requires that the banks put up fresh loans to countries that get I.M.F. credits and that thus it is a ''bailing in'' operation. **********Today's hearing brought out the fact that the regulators had been divided over some of the provisions of their joint proposals. Mr.  Isaac, the F.D.I.C. chairman, had wanted tougher action than the others. **********Mr. Isaac acknowledged under questioning from Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, that he ''personally would have liked to have seen something greater done'' on requiring banks to set up reserves against their nonperforming loans to financially troubled countries. **********Banks generally oppose greater reserves because the money is taken out of earnings and has to be set aside in accounts that bear no interest. Special Reserves Proposed **********The regulators' plan calls for initial special reserves equal to 10 percent of the problem loans, rising in 15 percent annual increments. Before these special reserves must actually be set aside, however, a debtor country would in effect have to be flat on its back, demonstrating in the words of the proposal ''protracted debt service problems.'' Among other things, it would have to miss interest payments for six months, fail to comply with I.M.F. or bank restructuring plans and lack prospects for the ''orderly restoration of debt service in the near future.'' **********Mr. Isaac said he would have begun to require special reserves at an earlier stage and at a lower threshhold.  Mr. Conover said he thought Mr. Isaac might have had a valid point, but he warned against precipitating huge withdrawals by banks from international lending. He noted, for example, the recent difficulties in getting banks to provide an additional $5 million in loans to Mexico as part of that country's adjustment program. **********''What we don't want to do is to cause international lending to come screeching to a halt at a time when it must continue,'' the Comptroller declared. **********Mr. Volcker emphasized that ''abrupt action by lenders to withdraw from lending can only be mutually self-defeating.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.body_text: **********Following is a glossary of military terms used in the Long commission report on the bombing at the Marine headquarters in Beirut:  B.I.A.  - Beirut International Airport.  B.L.T.  - Battalion Landing **********Team, the detachment, primarily of infantry, that constitutes the main force of a Marine **********Amphibious Unit.  Cincusnaveur - Commander, **********United States Naval Forces, **********Europe. **********C.J.C.S.  - Chairman of the Joint **********Chiefs of Staff.  Conus - Continental United **********States.  C.T.F. 61/62 - C.T.F. 61 stands **********for the commander, United **********States Forces, Lebanon, a Navy **********Commodore in command of the **********overall amphibious task force **********offshore and, also, technically, **********the embarked marines. C.T.F. **********62 is the ''landing force commander,'' a full Marine colonel **********in charge of the Marine Amphibious Unit ashore and on **********shipboard.  Humint - Human Intelligence, **********meaning the reports and surveillance of spies in such areas **********as Lebanon, as opposed to satellite and electronic intelligence.  I.D.F.  - Israeli Defense Forces.   Indirect Fire - High angle, or **********arching, fire from weapons **********such as mortars and howitzers **********that plunge into the targets, **********which may not be visible from **********the firing point. The opposite is **********direct fire, as from a tank cannon or a rifle, that is aimed on **********line-of-sight.  J.C.S.  - Joint Chiefs of Staff.  L.A.F.  - Lebanese Armed **********Forces. The regular army of the **********central Government.  M.A.U.  - Marine Amphibious **********Unit, includes a Battalion Landing Team, a composite air unit, **********in many cases, confined to **********armed and utility helicopters, **********support troops and administrative units.  M.N.F.  - Multinational force.  N.C.A.  - National Command Authorites, defined by law as the **********President and the Secretary of **********Defense or their duly deputized **********alternates or successors, authorized to issue military commands. Deliberate ambiguity **********has been maintained about this **********line of authority, especially in **********case of nuclear war.  Reconnaisannce by Fire - A **********method of reconnaissance in **********which a military unit fires at a **********suspected enemy position to **********draw fire and force the enemy **********to disclose his position.  Rules of Engagement - Military **********directives that instruct troops **********on the nature and intensity of **********force they may use in conflicts. **********One example would be an instruction to fighter pilots that **********they may not fire on an aircraft **********until making visual identification of that aircraft.  Tarps - Tactical Air Reconnaissance Pods, electronic and **********avionic equipment, contained in pods, placed on pylons of a combat aircraft such as a Navy F-14 **********to transform it into a reconnaissance aircraft that can photograph and gain electronic intelligence from the ground.  Uscincuer - United States Commander in Chief, Europe, the **********top of the operational chain of **********command to the Beirut marines.  U.S.M.N.F . - The United States **********component of the four-nation **********Multinational Force in Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Daisy Manufacturing Returns to the Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.body_text: **********The Daisy Manufacturing Company is back in the family - Cass S. Hough's family. **********Mr. Hough, who is 79, worked for Daisy for 50 years and served as its president for 14 years. His grandfather was a founder of the maker of air guns. **********Earlier this week a group led by Mr. Hough bought back the company from Kidde Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash. **********''I put in a lot of years and hard work,'' Mr. Hough said in explaining why he wanted the company again, ''and made a pitch to Kidde to sell it.'' **********Mr. Hough has lived in Naples, Fla., in retirement for 12 years, and Daisy is in Rogers, Ark. He said he would go to Rogers frequently in his new capacity as chairman, president and chief executive. **********''I don't have any plans,'' he said. ''We just reacquired it and we've got to pick up the pieces. We have a very capable group of people on the staff. I'll give them the responsibility, tell them what the goals are and let them do it their own way. If they don't produce, we'll find somebody who will. I'm not a looker-over-the-shoulder.'' **********Daisy began as the Plymouth Iron Windmill Company in Plymouth, Mich., a Detroit suburb, in 1882. It began making air guns in 1886. Today its sales are $40 million annually. **********''It's a relatively stable market,'' Mr. Hough said. ''We sell a lot of adult air guns now. There's been a slack-off in sales of firearms for one reason or another, and people who love to shoot at targets now do it with sophisticated air guns.'' **********Mr. Hough said he moved the company to Arkansas in 1958, and in the early 70's the company was sold to the Murchisons of Texas. **********''They wanted to build a pipeline across Australia and to raise money sold many of their companies,'' Mr. Hough said. Daisy was sold to Victor Comptometer, where Mr. Hough was in charge of Daisy and other recreational products before he retired. Victor Comptometer was acquired by Kidde in 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/24/world.main_headline: U.N. Envoy Pursues Afghan Talks in Pakistan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/24/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; U.N. Envoy Pursues Afghan Talks in Pakistan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/24/world.body_text: **********A special United Nations envoy arrived here today on the second stage of a diplomatic mission seeking a political solution to the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and said he had made a good start with talks in Teheran. **********Most Afghan guerrillas opposing the Soviet forces fight from rear bases in Iran and Pakistan. **********The envoy, Undersecretary General Diego Cordovez, said he had some very useful talks with Iranian officials.  He will have several discussions with Pakistani officials here before going to Afghanistan on Thursday.  Mr. Cordovez visited Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran last April and acted as an intermediary in indirect talks between the Pakistani and Afghan Foreign Ministers in Geneva in June. **********The talks were indirect because Pakistan does not recognize the Soviet-backed Afghan Government, which came to power in December 1979 when the Soviet Union sent about 100,000 troops into Afghanistan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/world.main_headline: SENATE UNIT VOTES POWER TO CUT OFF COVERT AID MONEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/world.print_headline: SENATE UNIT VOTES POWER TO CUT OFF COVERT AID MONEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/world.body_text: **********The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence approved a measure today that would enable Congress to cut off future financing for covert operations in Central America. **********The cutoff would take effect if the President failed to submit a plan for the region that met with the approval of the Congressional intelligence committees. But the committee, in a bipartisan vote of 13 to 2, approved the continuation of covert activities in Central America through this fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30. **********The action marked the first time that one of the Congressional intelligence committees had formally asserted what it considered its right to approve specific covert activities, according to a member of the committee. **********'Part of the Process' **********''We are no longer simply to be informed,'' Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said. ''We want to be part of the process.'' **********According to a compromise plan the committee adopted after three hours of briefings and deliberations in a secret session, $19 million for covert activities in Central America next year would be contingent on approval of President Reagan's assessments and goals for the region by the House and Senate intelligence committees. **********''We want a redefined program on Central America,'' said Senator Barry Goldwater, the chairman of the committee and the author of the compromise measure. ''I want him to tell us in plain language just what it is he wants to do relative to Nicaragua and other countries.'' At Odds With House Plan **********Under current law, the President is required to inform the intelligence committees of covert actions, but the committees have no right to disapprove them. The committee's action was based on its power to authorize money for the Central Intelligence Agency. **********The Senate committee deliberately chose not to embrace this week's plan by the House Select Committee on Intelligence to cut off money for covert aid by the C.I.A. to anti-Sandinist rebels. The House committee, voting along party lines Tuesday, authorized $30 million for the rest of this fiscal year and $50 million for the next fiscal year for overt operations intended to help friendly Central American nations stop the flow of weapons to El Salvador. **********The House and Senate proposals must now work their way through their respective chambers and, if approved, be reconciled in a House-Senate conference committee. **********The Reagan Administration has repeatedly argued that the purpose of covert operations in Central America is to stop the flow of weapons from Cuba and the Soviet Union through Nicaragua to rebels in El Salvador. Critics of the President's plan say the purpose is to disrupt the Nicaraguan Government. **********President Reagan, speaking in Phoenix, warned today that Congressional committees were ''indifferent to another Communist takeover on our doorstep,'' and added: ''Running away from this clear-cut responsibility would reward aggression and bring dishonor to the good name of the United States. It would swell the tide of political and economic instability, creating a new army of refugees and bring danger closer and closer to home.'' **********Meanwhile, Powell Moore, Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations, reaffirmed that the number of American military training officers in El Salvador had not exceeded 55 since the spring of 1981. He said, however, the Reagan Administration hoped Congress would not seek to restrict the training programs. A Letter to Percy **********''To the extent that available funds permit, we would be prepared to provide additional training at facilities outside of El Salvador,'' he wrote in a letter to Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''At the same time, we would strongly oppose any rigid legislative constraint that would preclude reasonable modifications to the structure of our training program that might be advisable.'' **********Mr. Moore said the Administration would ''reprogram'' $30 million in foreign military sales guarantees to El Salvador, the amount approved by the House Appropriations Committee's subcommittee on foreign operations and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The White House had requested $60 million. **********He said, however, that the Administration intended to proceed with allocating $140 million in economic support for the Government of El Salvador, $25 million more than the Senate Foreign Relations Committee advised. **********The two committee members who voted against the compromise were both Republicans - Senators John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming. **********Voting in favor of the plan were six Republicans: Senators Goldwater, William S. Cohen of Maine, Jake Garn of Utah, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and William V.  Roth Jr. of Delaware. The seven Democrats were Senators Moynihan, Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, Daniel Inouye of Hawaii, Henry M. Jackson of Washington, Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Walter D. Huddleston of Kentucky, who voted by proxy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Because of the difficulty of finding an agency to replace Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, its agency for 11 years, WABC-TV, Channel 7, has retained an interim agency to serve it for the remainder of the year while it completes its search for a permanent agency. **********Or permanent as an agency can be. **********Serino, Coyne & Nappi is the temporary shop, and according to Tim Miller, director of creative services at the station, it could even become the permanent agency if its work is that good. It is a specialty agency in theatrical promotion. **********The annual station budget is about $4.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/13/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; MARTIN MARIETTA MAKES $420 MILLION LOAN DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday announced the execution of a definitive long-term loan agreement with 13 major banks to refinance the remainder of the loans it took out last year in its takeover battle with the Bendix Corporation. **********The $420 million agreement, which has a term of five years, replaces the $930 million one-year loan negotiated last August, the company said. **********Martin Marietta said it had also executed an eight-year, $300 million revolving credit and term loan facility with 20 banks, replacing a similar one-year arrangement for general corporate purposes. The Bank of America is agent for both arrangements.
