https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Pressure on the Prime **********While the House is away, the banks will play. Now that Congress is out for its August recess, there will be no one on the Hill to cry foul if banks raise the prime rate. Any day now, say analysts, major banks may lift the 10.5 percent prime - the rate banks charge their best customers - to 11 percent.  ''The prime has been lagging for a while and there's a good chance that the Congressional recess will be a signal for the banks to go ahead and raise the prime,'' said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist for A. G.  Becker Paribas. In fact, a few small banks lifted their prime late last week. **********While they lobbied the House for an increase in the United States' contribution to the International Monetary Fund - so the Government would take on more of the weight of the world's debt - the banks had behaved themselves. **********Inflation Redux **********The best is behind us. When it comes to inflation, that's the message from many of the nation's economists. Expect bigger price rises ahead. **********Because of increased demand for goods and services, a slow restocking of inventories and more money chasing the same goods because of previously loose money policy, retailers are bound to start their markups soon, say the soothsayers. **********This means that modest rises in consumer prices, which edged up by only two-tenths of 1 percent in May to a 2.4 percent annual rate, will become just a memory. Economists predict a more sobering 6 percent and higher rate of increase for the rest of 1983, to an average of 3.9 percent for the year. **********''It is the inescapable outcome of high money growth,'' contends Robert R. Davis, vice president and economist at the Harris Bank in Chicago. **********Raymond T. Dalio, president of the forecasting firm of Bridgewater Associates in Wilton, Conn., says, ''Prices are going to come back up a lot quicker than people think. With the economy picking up so rapidly, people are going to get aggressive and start raising prices.'' In the final analysis? ''Inflation will approach 8 percent by the end of the year and turn higher in 1984 as labor gets stronger in its negotiating position.''Currencies Awry **********The French were shocked. Le Monde queried in a banner headline: ''8 francs pour 1 dollar?'' The Germans and Japanese were stunned, too. The almightly dollar flexed its muscle and roughed up a few of its trading partners last week. While the United States Government intervened - selling dollars to buy the weaker foreign currencies - the dollar stayed strong. Now analysts are saying that it will take another six to eight weeks to beat back the greenback. **********David D. Hale, chief economist for Kemper Financial Services Inc., Chicago, says it would take a change in fiscal or monetary policy to turn the dollar around effectively. He calls the intervention ''cosmetic.'' **********''People have decided that monetary policy will be restrictive and the dollar is the place to be,'' he says. Since the reasons to hold dollars are not entirely economic - they are also an investment in current political stability - he thinks that ''demand will continue for a while.''Casinos Playing to Win **********The tables are jumping at America's casinos. And if gamblers keep rolling the dice at the same pace as in the first half of the year, casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas will collect their highest revenues ever. **********Atlantic City, predictably, is ecstatic. Hotel bookings are up, car and bus traffic to the boardwalk is surging and gross casino revenues jumped to $804 million in the first half of this year, from $667 million this time last year. By 1987, four new casino hotels are slated to join the nine already in the game. ''We think it's fantastic,'' says Patrick Killian, programs coordinator for the Atlantic City Casino Hotel Association. **********Rossi Ralenkotter, director of tourism and research in Las Vegas, was equally pleased. ''It looks very strong,'' he said. Convention bookings in Vegas are up 25 percent and the number of convention goers may break the one-million mark for the first time ever this year. First-half gross casino revenue there is $930.7 million, up from $893.1 million this time last year. **********Mr. Ralenkotter credits the improved economy for the spending spurt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/world.main_headline: 3 Israeli Soldiers Slain In Ambush in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 3 Israeli Soldiers Slain In Ambush in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/world.body_text: **********Palestinian guerrillas ambushed and killed three Israeli soldiers today in an attack seven miles northeast of the port of Tyre, the Israeli command announced. It was the second fatal strike against the Israeli Army in Lebanon in three days. **********Residents of a nearby village said one Israeli soldier from the two-vehicle patrol chased the attackers off the narrow road into a lemon grove, and the guerrillas kidnapped him. Israeli troops on the scene also said one soldier was captured, but this was denied by an Israeli Army spokesman in Beirut. **********Contradicting the Israeli report, the Voice of Arab Lebanon, a Beirut radio station, said the Lebanese National Resistance Front had taken responsibility for the ambush and said one Israeli soldier was wounded in addition to the three killed and one captured. The front, believed to be made up of leftist Lebanese Moslem militiamen, also took responsibility for a car bombing in Beirut Wednesday that killed two Israeli soldiers and wounded two others. ---- **********TEL AVIV, June 10 (AP) - Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon called today for an inquiry into the Lebanon war to clear his name.  An inquiry commission ''should investigate the activity and the decisions taken by the Cabinet during the war,'' Mr. Sharon said on his return from the United States. Mr. Sharon was forced to resign in February after being found indirectly responsible for the massacre of Palestinians by Lebanese Christian militias at two Beirut refugee camps.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/busin.main_headline: Burlington Chief Takes a New Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Burlington Chief Takes a New Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Richard C. Grayson, chairman and chief executive of the Burlington Northern Railroad Company, has been named vice chairman of the parent Burlington Northern Inc. **********Walter A. Drexel succeeds him at the railroad. **********In the newly created post, Mr. Grayson, 62 years old, will have responsibility for the parent's rail, trucking and export-trading companies, along with some corporate staff functions. **********At the railroad itself, Mr. Drexel, 52, will continue as president, a position he has held since last April. He will also assume the title of chairman and chief executive. **********Rail operations account for some 80 percent of the company's assets and some 75 percent of its profits. The Seattle company is also in real estate, trucking, forest products, oil, gas and mining. It is currently seeking a controlling interest in the El Paso Company, an energy concern. **********Mr. Grayson began his railroad career in 1941 as a trainman for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company. He was its chairman and chief executive when it was acquired by Burlington Northern in 1980. **********Mr. Drexel joined Burlington Northern in 1981 as senior vice president for strategic planning. He formerly worked for the Atlantic Richfield Company. Richard M. Bressler, a former top executive of Atlantic Richfield, is Burlington Northern Inc.'s chairman and chief executive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The Missouri Public Service Company yesterday announced a tender offer to buy 2,894,000 common shares, or two-thirds of those outstanding, of the Gas Service Company for $14 apiece. Both utilities serve Kansas City, Mo. **********Missouri Public Service said that if its offer succeeded before the Sept.16 deadline, it would exchange its shares on a one-for-one basis for shares in a new parent company, the Mid-America Public Service Company. **********The common shares of Gas Service that Missouri Public Service did not buy would be converted into 0.7097 of a common share of Mid-America. Gas Services' cumulative preferred stock would be converted into cumulative preferred stock of Mid-America with ''substantially identical terms,'' Missouri Public Service said. **********If all the requested shares were tendered and the remaining shares swapped for Mid-America stock, the deal would be worth about $55.6 million. **********Missouri Public Service is a utility based in Kansas City, Mo., that provides electricity and some natural gas in western and northcentral Missouri. Gas Service is a natural gas distributor serving the Kansas City, Mo., area, as well as parts of Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Nebraska. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange Friday, Missouri Public Service closed at $15.375, down 12.5 cents, while Gas Service closed at $11.125, up 50 cents. **********In a letter to Gas Service, Missouri Public Service said the combination would create ''a large diversified utility'' that would be ''stronger financially and more efficient.'' **********Missouri Public Service said directors of Gas Service had rejected previous merger proposals without agreeing to discuss them. Robert Poindexter, Gas Service's senior vice president for finance, was not at home yesterday and could not be reached for comment. **********Missouri Public Service reported net income last year of $16.2 million, or $2.10 a share, on operating revenue of $187.5 million.  Gas Service Company reported net income last year of $5.1 million, or 73 cents a share, on operating revenue of $812 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.main_headline: DEMOCRATS EXPECT TO CAMPAIGN ON LEBANON ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.print_headline: DEMOCRATS EXPECT TO CAMPAIGN ON LEBANON ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/25/world.body_text: **********Aides to Democratic Presidential candidates and party officials said today that in the aftermath of the bombing of the Marine headquarters in Beirut the Reagan Administration's policies in Lebanon would serve as a major issue in the campaign. **********Although Democratic Party officials had expected Central America to dominate foreign policy issues in the campaign, the devastating attack in Beirut, in which at least 192 American servicemen died, led virtually all Democratic candidates to re-evaluate their strategies and to criticize the role of the United States in Lebanon. **********Perhaps the most outspoken Democratic Presidential aspirant, Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, said today that the ''deployment of American troops in this type of situation borders on the criminal.''  'Sitting There, Hunkered Down' **********''All they are doing is sitting there, hunkered down at the end of a runway, waiting to be killed,'' he said. ''We are showing not our mettle but our stupidity. Even in war you do not deploy your soldiers in such suicidal situations.'' **********Several other candidates echoed comments by Senator John Glenn of Ohio that the Reagan Administration must ''present to the American people and the Congress a clean and well-defined statement of our mission in Lebanon, including the likely scope and duration of our role.'' **********Unlike Mr. Glenn, however, such candidates as former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida and Senators Gary Hart of Colorado, George McGovern of South Dakota and Mr. Hollings urged the withdrawal of American troops from Lebanon. ''Our marines there are more target than deterrent,'' Mr. Askew declared. **********Senator Alan Cranston of California urged the withdrawal of the Marines ''to a more defensible position offshore.'' He said: ''We should not immediately abandon the peace efforts in Lebanon. But it is absurd to think that 1,200 U.S. Marines pinned down at the Beirut Airport can achieve the Reagan Administration's goal of establishing a sovereign Lebanon free of all factional strife.''  Mondale Withholds Comment **********Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, one of the Democratic Party's leading Presidential contenders, took a cautious stance and refrained from public comment today. Mr. Mondale canceled a luncheon speech before Jewish leaders in Washington and met with advisers throughout the day to weigh a response, which he will probably make Tuesday at a news conference in Chicago. The advisers included Robert Hunter, a Middle East specialist who served on the National Security Council in the Carter Administration. **********Maxine Isaacs, Mr. Mondale's spokesman, said that the candidate wanted to refrain from making a comment ''for a day or so, out of respect for the marines who were killed.'' She added: ''He doesn't sense any public receptivity to engage in a policy debate today. His views and disagreements are known.'' **********Several weeks ago Mr. Mondale said that in Lebanon ''we have troops but no policy,'' and urged ''negotiations and compromise from Lebanon's principal political and religious groups to broaden the base'' of the Government of President Amin Gemayel.   Major Issue, in Party's Eyes **********Bernard Aronson, director of policy for the Democratic National Committee, said party officials were convinced that the Administration's policies in Lebanon would emerge as a major issue in the Presidential campaign. **********''The conduct and purposes of the Reagan foreign policy have been a developing issue in this campaign, and the latest events in Lebanon will accelerate that trend,'' Mr. Aronson said.  ''If there's one lesson of the Vietnam War, it is, when you project American forces abroad you need to define a clear goal, muster the resources to achieve it and explain your purposes in a way that wins support from the Congress and the American people. **********''In many arenas, and most visibly in Lebanon, the Administration has failed to do any of these things,'' Mr. Aronson said. **********Mr. Glenn, who canceled a day of campaigning in Georgia and flew to Washington to attend closed briefings and meetings of the Foreign Relations Committee, said U.S. forces must be ''realistically sized'' to carry out their mission in Lebanon, and urged the use of United Nations and multinational forces to ''internationalize the situation.'' **********In an interview, Mr. McGovern said: ''The Administration's policy is to be resolute. Well, resolution isn't a policy. It's a style, a performance mode. Resolute for what? What are we resolved to do? That's the unanswered question.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/busin.body_text: **********The ads for overnight package delivery have a frantic quality.  Couriers and planes race to overtake rivals while hapless customers grow beards and miss business opportunities. **********For the industry, things are frantic, too. Just yesterday, Emery Worldwide started an overnight letter service that is now cheaper than the Federal Express Corporation's and handles up to four ounces, compared with two ounces for Federal. The day before, Purolator Courier, a subsidiary of Purolator Inc., had offered an overnight letter at a price that undercuts even that of the Postal Service. **********And all the companies involved in the overnight small package delivery business have also been offering discounts of up to 50 percent to lure big-volume customers. **********The reason for the fast-paced price cutting and discounting: The deliverers are awash in overcapacity following the rapid buildup of their aircraft fleets. At the same time, the weak economy has finally caught up with the industry. **********Even Federal Express, industry pioneer and giant, is concerned.  Although the company is handling 30 percent more packages than a year ago, Peter S. Willmott, president and chief operating officer, said, ''Growth has been slowed by the economy.'' Rivals Have Restructured **********Mr. Willmott also said that Federal Express faced greater competition since the restructuring of Emery and another rival, the Airborne Freight Corporation. Both have moved from being freight forwarders, which used existing airlines, into companies that, like Federal Express, have their own fleet of planes and hub operations.  They now compete directly for a larger share of the small package market - up to 70 pounds - and offer big discounts. **********Nonetheless, Federal Express apparently feels sure enough of its clientele that yesterday it raised the cost of an overnight letter of up to two ounces to $12.50, from $11. **********Adding to the pressure on the established overnight deliverers is an aggressive new entrant, the United Parcel Service of America Inc., which began overnight service to metropolitan areas last Sept.24, with 24 aircraft. Last November, United Parcel expanded its service to more major cities and now uses 33 aircaft to make deliveries by 3 P.M. the following day at about half the price of its rivals. Also, a Rival Technology **********With traditional competition growing, the industry is also facing a technological challenge: facsimile transmission. A nationwide network could offer delivery of letters and documents almost instantly, undermining the highly profitable air-delivery business.  Federal Express has already made preparations to maintain its edge; with 60 percent of the company's shipments made up of letters and documents, it will start its own transmission network if it has to. **********The U.P.S. challenge is having little direct effect on business so far, executives of Federal, Emery and Airborne said in interviews.  The executives said that their companies offer faster pickup, earlier delivery and superior ability to trace shipments than U.P.S. **********Also the discounts offered to high-volume customers have moved the rates closer to those charged by U.P.S. With the discount, the usual rate for overnight delivery for up to two pounds - about $21 - is reduced to $13 or $14, close to the U.P.S. $11. Large Customer Base **********But U.P.S. has a large customer base and a truck fleet that can deliver the overnight shipments sorted at its Louisville, Ky., hub to 29,755 communities. **********''U.P.S. has a history of being methodical and persistent and being extremely successful eventually,'' Peter R. Schlesinger, an analyst for the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said. ''They are a very profitable company with substantial amounts of capital available for a venture like this. They can take their time.'' **********As Mr. Willmott of Federal Express put it: ''U.P.S. will be in the overnight business for a long time. This is not a six-month drill.'' To meet the threat, Federal Express has moved up its overnight delivery time from noon, the industry norm, to 10:30 A.M. Mr.  Willmott said that the company may go to 10 A.M. **********Federal is also promoting its second-day delivery service, a market dominated by U.P.S., and has lowered its rates to volume shippers.  Mr. Willmott said that his company now handles 20,000 second-day shipments, up from 7,000 last year. A Major Effort **********Meanwhile, Emery will make a major effort this year to increase its share of the under-70-pound market, which its chairman, John C. Emery Jr., predicted would grow 25 percent this year for the industry.  Emery's forte is moving heavy air freight. **********To put itself in a better position, Emery in April will start the first same-day service. The service, under which a shipment will be picked up in the morning and delivered in the afternoon, will be costly - at least $150 more a shipment. **********Airborne has not made any changes recently. Its overnight service costs $19 for a single letter weighing up to three ounces. If there is also a shipment going with the letter, the letter costs $10. **********Purolator Courier, which up to now has handled mainly packages, and those mostly by truck, has also entered the overnight-letter market.  On Monday it began to ship up to two ounces for $8.75. Will Pick Up the Letters **********At that price, the new service undercuts the rates for express mail service of the Postal Service, which charges $9.35. And unlike the Postal Service, Purolator - and the other private companies - will pick up the letters from its customers. **********Arthur DeMelle, senior vice president of finance, said that the company had extra capacity in its fleet of 3,700 trucks and 90 chartered aircraft to absorb the new business. **********Emery and Airborne also have extra capacity, because of expansions forced on the deliverers by changes in airline service in the 1970's. As jumbo jets were phased in, most airlines cut back flights, particularly at night, when most overnight freight is moved. This made it difficult for a company without its own fleet of planes to remain competitive. **********Then in 1977, the air cargo industry was deregulated. Companies in the air freight business were no longer limited to aircraft that could hold only 7,500 pounds. **********Mr. Emery said that his company was forced to invest $120 million to build a sorting center, set up a hub in Dayton, Ohio, and buy its own air fleet. And to be competitive, Emery had to offer service nationwide all at once. **********''You couldn't say, 'I'll deliver to Los Angeles but not to El Paso,' '' Mr. Emery said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.main_headline: POPE WARNS 25 U.S. BISHOPS ON SEX MORALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.print_headline: POPE WARNS 25 U.S. BISHOPS ON SEX MORALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II repeated Roman Catholic teaching against abortion, divorce, the ordination of women, birth control, premarital sex and homosexuality today in a speech to 25 visiting United States bishops. **********Church sources suggested the Pope chose the Americans as his forum because he considers the United States a center of sexual liberalism and believes elements within the church in the United States to be sympathetic to such views. The prelates were here to pay the visit to the Pope that is obligatory for bishops every five years. **********In the meeting at his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, the Pope told the bishops that they must ''proclaim without fear and ambiguity the many controverted truths of our age'' and went on to list the Roman Catholic church's teachings on sexuality. **********The Pope reminded the bishops of the church's doctrine of the indissolubility of marriage, citing approvingly from a pastoral letter of the United States episcopate that said: ''the covenant between a man and a woman in Christian marriage is as indissoluble and irrevocable as God's love for his people and Christ's love for his church.''  Speech Appears Defensives **********The Pope condemned premarital sex and homosexual activity as incompatible ''with God's plan for human love.'' He urged the bishops not to be silent against ''the unpopular truth that artificial birth control is against God's law.'' **********He restated his rejection of abortion by citing ''the rights of the unborn, the weak, the handicapped, the poor and the aged, no matter how current popular opinion views these issuses.'' Vatican sources noted in all the strictures a particulary defensive tone and an acknowledgment of the widespread unpopularity of the Roman Catholic doctrine, which the Pope appears to believe is particularly unwelcome among Catholics in the United States. **********The Pope restated his absolute exclusion of women from priestly functions. He did so, it was believed, because it was in the United States that he was most openly confronted with opposition from within the church on this issue. **********After declaring his support for the dignity of women and their right to ''every legitimate freedom that is consonant with their human nature and their womanhood,'' he told the bishops to be firm in rejecting any claim that women could serve as priests.   Exclude Women Priests **********''In this regard he must likewise endeavor to explain as cogently as he can that the church's teaching on the exclusion of women from priestly ordination is extraneous to the issue of discrimination and that it is linked rather to Christ's own design for his priesthood,'' the Pope said. **********''The bishop must give proof of his pastoral ability and leadership by withdrawing all support from individuals or groups who in the name of progress, justice or compassion, or for any other alleged reason, promote the ordination of women to the priesthood,'' the Pope said. ''In so doing, such individuals or groups are in effect damaging the very dignity of women that they profess to promote and advance.'' **********In Washington, during his visit to the United States in October 1979, a nun turned an expected address of welcome into a demand for the admission of women to the ministry. The nun, Sister M. Theresa Kane, wearing street clothes despite the Pope's express wish, spoke of ''the intense suffering and pain'' of many women and urged John Paul ''to be open to and to respond to the voices coming from the women of this country who are desirous of serving in and through the church as fully participating members.'' **********The Pope cautioned the bishops today to expect criticism of their defense of the church's views. **********''Precisely because he cannot renounce the preaching of the cross, the bishop will be called upon over and over again to accept criticism, to sacrifice popularity, and to admit failure in obtaining a consensus of doctrine acceptable to everyone,'' John Paul said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The International Monetary Fund may have to borrow in the financial markets if Congress votes against an $8.4 billion contribution to the agency, Federal Reserve Board sources said today. **********Commercial borrowing by the I.M.F. would be an unprecedented step that most countries have opposed until now on the ground that it could weaken the fund's role as the linchpin of the world financial system. **********Besides the impasse in Congress, the agency has failed to persuade other Western industrial countries and Japan to lend it $3 billion to meet a short-term gap in its finances. **********The I.M.F., saying it had promised more money to borrowers than it has on hand, has asked its wealthier member countries for short-term loans to bridge a gap of $6 billion to $8 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/busin.body_text: **********A Ford Motor Company vice president, asserting that the company has left him to ''twist in the wind'' because of his involvement as a witness for Ford at a celebrated trial involving the accident record of Pinto cars, filed a $330 million lawsuit today against several senior company executives. **********Among those named in the suit were Henry Ford 2d, former chairman of the company and now chairman of the finance committee, and Philip Caldwell, chairman and chief executive officer of the auto maker. **********In his lawsuit, filed in the Wayne County Circuit Court in Michigan, Thomas J. Feaheny, Ford's vice president for vehicle research, said he had lost ''stock options, promotions and future opportunities'' because of a concerted effort by top management to isolate him. **********His suit charges that he has been ''held up as an object of scorn and ridicule within the company.'' Ford Says 'Claims' Lack Basis **********In a statement, Henry R. Nolte Jr., a vice president and general counsel for Ford, said: ''We have not had the opportunity to review Mr. Feaheny's complaint in detail, but we are generally familiar with this matter. We believe that the actions of the company and its officers were entirely proper and that there is no basis for any of the claims.'' **********Along with Mr. Ford and Mr. Caldwell, Mr. Feaheny's suit lists as defendants Harold A. Poling, executive vice president; Harold C.  MacDonald, a retired vice president; John McDougall, a retired executive vice president; Louis R. Ross, an executive vice president, and Peter J. Sherry, a vice president. **********In an interview today, Mr. Feaheny, who joined Ford in 1957 as a product planning analyst, said he believed that he was seen by Ford's top management as being ''tainted'' by his involvement with the Pinto. **********Mr. Feaheny, 51 years old, served as an expert engineering witness for Ford in a trial in Winamac, Ind., in 1980, one of many in which plaintiffs said that injuries that they had sustained in rear-end collisions were the result of design defects that Ford had ignored. **********Mr. Feaheny testified that while Ford believed the cars were generally safe, the company had decided to recall 1.5 million Pintos and Mercury Bobcats in 1978 to solve a public relations problem. At the time of the trial, Mr. Feaheny was vice president for car engineering. **********He said the management team brought in by Mr. Caldwell after Lee A. Iacocca was dismissed as president in 1978 wanted to rid the company of officials closely associated with products developed under Mr.  Iacocca. **********Mr. Caldwell succeeded Mr. Ford as chairman of Ford in March 1980, after being named chief executive officer in October 1979.  The Winamac trial ended in March 1980 with Ford's acquittal on criminal charges of reckless homicide stemming from a crash in which three young women were burned to death when their Pinto was struck from behind. **********Mr. Feaheny said today that he had no current plans to resign from Ford, but would ''wait and see'' what reaction his suit received at Ford.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/world.body_text: **********The Air Force's Chief of Staff says that evidence gathered from the Soviet downing of a South Korean passenger plane on Sept. 1 shows that Soviet air defenses are inflexible. **********''In my mind,'' the officer, Gen. Charles A. Gabriel, said in an interview on Wednesday, ''it confirms what we thought.'' **********The general, who said he had been given ''a pretty good rundown'' of what happened in the two and a half hours the airliner was tracked over Kamchatka, the Sea of Okhotsk and Sakhalin, also questioned the competence of the Soviet pilots. **********Moreover, a senior official of the Reagan Administration, who asked not to be identified, said today that it was ''quite possible'' that the Soviet pilot did not know he was shooting at a civilian passenger plane. This, the official said, made the Russians guilty of ''criminal negligence.'' **********Americans More Confident **********General Gabriel said the performance of Soviet air defenses ''gives us a little more confidence'' in the ability of the United States Air Force to overcome the defenses if necessary. **********In the view of some specialists, skepticism over the effectiveness of Soviet air defenses and tactical airpower may affect Congressional consideration of President Reagan's military budget. Mr. Reagan said the airliner episode showed the United States needed more military power. **********But critics in Congress have begun to put a different interpretation on the incident and to question the need for increased military budgets and especially the need for building both the B-1 bomber and the Stealth bomber, a jet that designed to evade radar detection. **********General Gabriel said Soviet pilots were held on ''a short leash,'' with commanders not trusting them to have radio frequencies with which they could have contacted the airliner.   Soviet Issued Denial on Radio **********Soviet authorities have insisted that the interceptor that shot down the airliner was equipped with a radio and an international emergency channel with which it tried, but failed, to contact the airliner. **********The general said one pilot had fired his guns well behind the airliner and out of range before firing the missiles that shot it down. **********He also said, ''I don't think he had tracers.'' Soviet spokesman have said the fighter pilot fired tracers from a cannon to warn the South Korean pilot he was off course. **********Earlier in the day, General Gabriel said in a speech before the Air Force Association, ''This barbarism and the Soviet lies to cover up their crime have clearly proven to the world what the Soviet leadership stands for.'' **********Speaking at the same forum, President Reagan's national security adviser, William P. Clark, scoffed at the paranoia often attributed to the Russians. Mr. Clark, a former judge, said, ''We should not let the insanity plea exonerate them.''  Less Formidable Than Believed **********On the question of Soviet air defenses, military analysts inside and outside the Government, having sifted through the evidence, said it revealed the air defenses to be less formidable than previously believed. They suggested Soviet actions had been a consequence of military confusion and rigidity rather than careful calculation. **********In the Soviet Union, the Air Defense Forces are a service arm separate from the Air Force, Army, Navy and Strategic Missile Forces. With 600,000 troops, it is divided into three branches - electronic detection, with 6,000 radars; aviation, with 3,000 interceptors, and missiles, with 12,000 surface- to-air missiles. **********According to some specialists, the need for the regional command in Far Eastern Siberia to communicate with Moscow accounted for the two and a half hours that the airliner was tracked before being shot down. Soviet spokesmen have said the decision to shoot down the plane was made by local commanders.   Border Regulations Tightened **********Under a recent law on Soviet national frontiers, the Air Defense Forces are understood to have received new regulations on guarding the boundaries. Specialists said the tightened controls undoubtedly governed Soviet actions against the South Korean plane. **********The specialists said radar was critical to Soviet air defense since all operations were controlled from the ground. **********''A Soviet pilot,'' said one specialist, ''is little more than a guided missile.'' **********Another said: ''The only thing a Soviet pilot does is to take off and land his plane. The rest is controlled from the ground.'' **********An Air Force officer said Soviet radar equipment, whether on the ground or in planes, lagged behind that of the United States and was not able to distinguish between the United States Air Force's RC-135 reconnaissance plane and the Korean Air Lines 747 in the same area, despite their differences in size and shape. **********Most Soviet radar operators are officers who have been given four years of training and hold the equivalent of engineeering degrees. Even so, an inexperienced operator could well have been confused by the appearance of two blips on his scope. **********Intelligence operations in the Soviet Union are highly compartmentalized, so that information from one unit is handed to another only slowly. Specialists speculated that information on air control radio transmissions from the South Korean plane, monitored by Soviet intelligence, was not made available to air defense radar operators.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/27/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of the cease-fire agreement in Lebanon as made public today by the Lebanese Government and translated by The Associated Press from the Arabic: **********- An immediate halt to fighting on Lebanese territory, on all fronts and demarcation lines. The truce will be policed by neutral observers. **********- Formation of a committee of representatives from the Lebanese Army, the National Salvation Front, the Lebanese Forces and Amal to draw the necessary arrangements and consecrate the cease-fire. **********- President Amin Gemayel calls for an urgent conference to begin a national dialogue among the following: **********From the National Salvation Front: Mr. Walid Jumblat, former Prime Minister Rashid Karami and former President Suleiman Franjieh. **********From the Lebanese Forces: former President Camille Chamoun and Mr. Pierre Gemayel. **********Also invited to the conference are former Prime Minister Saeb Salam, Mr. Adel Osseiran and Mr. Raymond Edde. **********- The President is happy to also welcome a representative from each of the brotherly nations of Syria and Saudi Arabia to attend the conference with the official Lebanese delegation, which will include, in addition to President Gemayel, a representative from each the executive and legislature authorities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union, which has said it might place new missiles close to the United States if America deploys new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe, will not install such missiles in Cuba, a Soviet official has told the French newspaper Le Monde. **********Vadim V. Zagladin, Deputy Chief of the International Department of the Soviet Central Committee, said Moscow would not deploy missiles in Cuba because ''there was an agreement on this subject and we do not intend to violate it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/16/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON THE inventors of a device with the trademark of Selectastation expect that it will permit remote listening to any local radio station in any American city where one of the units has been installed. Patent 4,393,277 was granted this week to Stuart D.  Goldberg, sales manager of WRKS-FM, a New York radio station, and Peter D. Besen and Don H. Shulsinger of Arlington, Mass., engineers with degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********Mr. Goldberg said the invention would allow subscribers to the network to monitor over telephone lines a selected radio station, day or night, for as long as desired. He expects broadcast programmers, advertising agency buyers and personnel in the record industry to be among the subscribers. The patent, entitled Remote Tuner Control System, is assigned to Selectastation Inc., a New York corporation recently formed by the inventors. **********According to Mr. Goldberg, the person using the new system monitors a remote station by dialing numbers on a standard Touch-Tone telephone. The user then enters the exact frequency of the station, and its broadcast can be heard on a telephone headset or other equipment. Selectastation Inc. hopes to market a network through one of the major independent long-distance telephone systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/world.body_text: **********The mother of the imprisoned dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky has said that after an unsuccessful effort to visit her son in prison she still has no evidence that he has abandoned his four-month hunger strike. **********The dissident's mother, Ida P. Milgrom, said Friday that she was still awaiting a letter that her son told her in a note he would send on Jan. 25 or 26 and that she believes would establish whether he is still fasting. **********Mrs. Milgrom said she was told by the prison authorities that her son was being force-fed two or three times a week, and she concluded from his note and from its handwriting that his health was critical. **********After Mrs. Milgrom returned from her trip to Chistopol Prison, 500 miles east of Moscow, last week, reports from Paris said Yuri V.  Andropov, the Soviet leader, had told Georges Marchais, the French Communist Party leader, that Mr. Shcharansky had had contact with his mother and had abandoned his hunger strike. **********Andropov's Letter to Marchais **********''Nothing endangers his life,'' Mr. Andropov reportedly wrote in the letter to Mr. Marchais. Mr. Andropov's letter was dated Jan. 21, a week after Mrs. Milgrom was alowed to exchange notes with her son at Chistopol. **********In his note to her, Mr. Shcharansky said that if he got confirmation that she had received his message he would end his hunger strike. The next five lines were blacked out by the prison warden, Mrs. Milgrom said, and then Mr. Shcharansky continued that he would write her on Jan. 25 or 26. **********After more than a year without any communication with her son, Mrs. Milgrom said she needed more evidence than Mr. Andropov's letter to convince her that Mr. Shcharansky had resumed eating. **********''What basis do I have to believe he quit the hunger strike?'' she asked. ''None. If he has, why don't they let his letter through?  Certainly they'd want to get out any confirmation that he had gone off the strike.'' Telegram to Andropov **********Mrs. Milgrom sent a telegram to Mr. Andropov on Thursday demanding confirmation that Mr. Shcharansky had ended his fast, that he be hospitalized and that she be allowed to visit him. **********Mr. Shcharansky, who is 35 years old and an activist in the human rights and Jewish emigration movements, was arrested in March 1977 and later sentenced to 13 years at hard labor on charges of spying for the United States. Last Sept. 27 he declared a hunger strike to protest that the authorities had totally blocked correspondence with his family, despite regulations that permit one letter per month. **********Mrs. Milgrom said the exchange of notes with her son was the first communication they had in 13 months, and she won it after 10 days of standing outside the walls of Chistopol and imploring officials to allow her a visit. **********The small, frail woman of 74 arrived in Chistopol on Jan. 3, expected an allotted visit - one is supposed to be allowed every six months - on Jan. 4. But the warden, Alexander N. Romanov, told her that because Mr. Shcharansky was still fasting he was denied the visit. Visit in July Was Denied **********Mrs. Milgrom's last meeting with her son was on Jan. 4, 1982. The next allotted visit, last July, was denied on grounds of unspecified misbehavior. When she was denied a visit again this month, Mrs.  Milgrom besieged the prison. She said she went daily to the gates and would stay until she could take the cold no more. After warming up at a store, she would return, again demanding to see the warden, the medical oficer and her son. **********At one point she was allowed an interview with the head of the medical section, who confirmed that Mr. Shcharansky was being forcefed. After 10 days, Mr. Romanov received Mrs. Milgrom, and he and a K.G.B. oficial told her that she could exchange notes with her son. As she wrote, they ordered her to scratch out any reference to Mr. Shcharansky's wife, Avital, who emigrated to Israel in 1974, and to include phrases urging her son to abide by prison rules. She acceded to the former and refused the latter. **********When Mr. Shcharansky's return message came, Mrs. Milgrom said the warden blacked out 5 1/2 of the 19 lines and let her keep the note only for a minute. When she saw the note, Mrs. Milgrom said, she was horrified by the handwriting. The lines were faint, shaky and uneven, the writing of an extremely weak person, she said. 'Anxiety and Pain' **********From her recollection, Mr. Shcharansky's note read, referring to his mother and his wife: ''Dear Mamochka, I know how much anxiety and pain you and Natalya have had over the past year, and it was because of my concern for your peace of mind that I took this extreme step.  If I receive confirmation that you got my note, I'll quit this hunger strike.'' **********Here the lines were blacked out, and then the note continued: ''I will write you a letter on Jan. 25 or 26. If I could still write after all I went through in 1981 that my health was good, then I cannot write this now. I have a total absence of strength, I have constant headaches, dizziness, fever, changes in blood pressure.'' **********From the prison Mrs. Milgrom traveled to Kazan, a regional capital, where she confronted the chief local medical officer with demands that her son be hospitalized. His answer, she said, was that he would consider hospitalization only if Mr. Shcharansky ended his fast.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.main_headline: JOHN PAUL SAYS FUTURE OF POLAND DEPENDS ON RESTORATION OF TRUST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.print_headline: JOHN PAUL SAYS FUTURE OF POLAND DEPENDS ON RESTORATION OF TRUST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II said today that the future of Poland depended on restoration of mutual trust in all fields, including politics. **********''The whole Polish nation must live in mutual trust,'' the Pope said in a homily delivered at the race track on the edge of this southwestern industrial city as huge crowds listened, mainly in reflective silence. **********''Indeed, it must regain this trust in the widest circle of its social existence,'' he said. ''I will not hesitate to say that there depends precisely on this - first and foremost on this - the future of our homeland.'' **********Regime Moves to Counter Pope **********Moreover, the Pope said, ''the existence of the Polish state'' depends on such trust.  The Polish Government, meanwhile, sought today to rebut some of the statements the Pope has made in his eight-day Polish tour, which began last Thursday. The Government had earlier made known its displeasure at the politicial effect of the Pope's homilies, warning through a spokesman that continued opposition protests would harm relations between church and state. **********Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski, apparently alluding to the Pope, charged in an interview published in papers around the country today that an educator was feeding Polish youths ''myths, legends and half-truths.'' (Page A6.) **********Some diplomats suggested that the reason the Deputy Prime Minister was the first official to criticize the Pope publicly, though obliquely, was that the Rakowski wing of the party is likely to come under attack from hard-line Moscow-backed elements after the papal tour ends for having allowed a propaganda setback. **********Late in the day, the Polish press agency P.A.P. distributed an unsigned commentary that left ''the implications of the statements made by the distinguished guest on Poland's domestic questions'' for future comment. But it said his statements about the ancient Polish character of the region ''cannot give reasons for any equivocal assessments.'' It added, ''There are no differences on this matter among Poles.'' **********John Paul seemed to speak directly to the people of this city, a stronghold of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, when he said, ''There are many people, a great many people, who hunger and thirst for righteousness.'' **********Later, the Pope flew by helicopter to St. Ann's Mountain for a visit to a 15th-century monastery and then to Cracow, where he is expected to meet on Thursday with Lech Walesa, the former Solidarity leader. **********The Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, where Mr. Walesa works as an electrician, has given the former union leader today, Wednesday and Thursday off to allow him to meet the Pope, an aide said today in a telephone interview. Mr. Walesa is expected to drive to Cracow on Wednesday. Some Compensation for Regime **********Whatever discomfort the Pope has given the Government by his continued defense of Solidarity, he may have compensated for partly with his references to the Polish character of Wroclaw, which was a German city called Breslau until 1945. The fact that the Pope came here is, for the Government, an affirmation of legitimacy for its postwar borders. **********Pointedly, the altar erected between two grandstands at the Wroclaw race track was flanked by the seals of all the major cities that were German until 1945 and are Polish today. **********In his homily, the Pope went beyond merely affirming Polish legitmacy. He also called for ''reciprocal understanding and reconciliation'' between the Polish and German peoples. **********After the mass, fewer than a hundred youths, carrying banners and shouting support for Solidarity, began a march through the city but dispersed on running into policemen armed with riot sticks and water cannon. **********(During the demonstration, the police took two British reporters and two others - Thomas Sancton of Time magazine's Paris bureau and a translator - into custody, holding them, according to Reuters, for more than two hours.  In Washington, Metromedia News said that its three-man television crew was detained while filming in the Wroclaw streets and that its film was confiscated.) **********For the mass at Wroclaw, John Paul flew by helicopter this morning from Czestochowa, landing at the race track, where crowds estimated at about one million were waiting for him. **********The Pope was understood by the crowds - and they showed it by applause at key passages - when he spoke of ''the hunger and thirst for righteousness that has been manifested in a particular way during these recent years.'' **********''I greatly desire,'' he said, ''as a pastor of the church and also as a son of my nation to confirm this hunger and thirst, which springs from the healthy resources of the Polish spirit, from a sense of the dignity of human work, from love of the homeland and from solidarity, that is to say, from a sense of the common good.'' 'Preserve This Just Hunger' **********His allusion to the labor movement became its defense when John Paul continued: ''At the same time, I would like to preserve this just hunger and thirst of the great multitudes of my compatriots from all that would distort it and weaken it. But at the same time, I would like also to liberate and defend it from all unjust objections and accusations, from wherever they might come.'' **********In his subsequent visit to St. Ann's Mountain, the Pope was greeted by tens of thousands of Poles who had walked to the monastery on the summit, 1,200 feet above sea level. At the shrine, he paid tribute to ''those who once in this land did not hesitate to sacrifice their lives on the field of battle.'' **********Besides affirming the Polish character of this Silesian region, the Pope's visit marked a major step in the Vatican's formal acceptance of Germany's loss of the territory. **********In 1966, a papal visit to Poland, after Pope Paul VI had accepted a church invitation to attend the celebrations of the millenium of Roman Catholicism in Poland, could not be negotiated because the Vatican refused to meet the Polish Government's demand that a visit be paid to Wroclaw in return for the right to visit the sanctuary in Czestochowa. **********In 1970, West Germany accepted the loss of Silesia, Pomerania and East Prussia, and two years later the Vatican reorganized dioceses to integrate those areas under Polish church administration. Today's visit by the Pope completed the church's recognition. **********---- Pope Visits Cracow Special to the New York Times **********CRACOW, Poland, June 21 - Pope John Paul II arrived today in Cracow, the ancient city of Polish kings, on the last leg of his Polish tour. **********Huge crowds massed around the field where his helicopter landed as dusk fell and along the route to his old residence, the palace of the Archbishop of Cracow, where he lived as Karol Cardinal Wojtyla until 1978. **********John Paul was born in Wadowice, in the hills west of Cracow. He came to Cracow to study at Jagiellonian University in 1938, and in his four decades here he served as priest, archbishop and eventually cardinal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/busin.body_text: **********The global debt crisis will persist unless industrial nations take steps to stimulate their economies, Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkel warned. Otherwise, poorer nations will never be able to earn the money they need to repay their debts, he said. (Page A1.) **********Eight OPEC members called for an emergency meeting next Sunday to head off an oil price war. The eight include several whose recent pricing and production policies have been at odds. (D1.) **********Japan's new Prime Minister will be greeted with complaints about his nation's trade policies when he arrives in Washington this week.  Tokyo announced some liberalization measures last week to smooth the trade talks, but American officials say the moves are insufficient.  (D1.) The Economy **********Declining mortgage rates have brought home buyers back to lenders for funds. Conventional fixed-rate mortgages have fallen to under 14 percent, from 17 percent just six months ago. This has helped sales of existing homes back over the 2.1 million a year rate, from their low of 1.8 million last August. (A1.) **********Revisions in Social Security will be approved by Congress, according to leaders there. The moves, required to restore the financial health of the pension system, include increased taxes and a delay in raising some benefits. The plan was approved by a bipartisan panel just before its deadline Saturday. (A1.) Companies **********The S.E.C. filed suit against First Jersey Securities, its founder and a senior executive, charging that they had manipulated the price of shares in Geosearch. (D1.) **********Philip Morris is catching up with R.J. Reynolds, for 25 years the leading cigarette maker. Analysts say the two rivals could change leadership positions this year. (D1.) Today's Columns **********NBC will pay the Soviet Union $14 million for unused rights to televise the 1980 Olympic Games. Payment will follow the expiration in February of the ban on American participation in the event. NBC lost $34 million because of the ban. Washington Watch. (D2.) **********Optimism outweighs concern on Wall Street. The market has been behaving as if recovery were well under way, and averages are setting new highs. Market Place. (D8.) **********A stock index futures market specialist says his new method of trading is much better than current systems. His ''shark'' approach basically ignores the stock market. Commodities. (D7.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/05/busin.main_headline: What's New in Lobbying; THE CANADIAN CONNECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/05/busin.print_headline: What's New in Lobbying; THE CANADIAN CONNECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/05/busin.body_text: **********In the past year, as the recession lingered and as protectionist forces grew in Congress, a vigorous new lobbying effort has emerged from an unlikely source: Canada. **********As the nation's largest trading partner and closest ally, Canada has always had an economic interest in political developments on the other side of the 49th parallel. Only recently, however, has Canada established an important presence on Capitol Hill, where each session hundreds of bills have a potential effect on that nation's 24 million people. **********''This is a new effort,'' said Marc Lortie, spokesman for the Canadian Embassy. ''We have to protect our interests on the Hill.'' Canadian Embassy officials are reluctant to describe their activities as ''lobbying,'' preferring to call them ''information gathering'' and ''information distribution.'' Even so, Canadian officials have publicly decided to step up their efforts on Capitol Hill and have sought to visit every member of Congress whose district borders on Canada. Meanwhile, Canadian officials have decided to funnel $650,000 of government funds to hire consultants and lobbying experts to protect Canadian interests. **********In recent months, those interests have included proposals for domestic-content legislation in the auto industry, action on the problem of acid rain, responses to Canada's energy policies and various other trade issues. **********Because the United States and Canada share a 3,000-mile border, Canadian interests often run parallel to the interests of certain groups of Americans, and the Canadian lobbying strategy is to capitalize on those shared interests. **********''Nobody in Congress is going to support the interests of a foreign nation over the interests of a colleague,'' said Jeremy Kinsman, the Embassy's political minister. ''So we try to identify areas of the American economy that would be hurt by punitive legislation against us.'' **********Canadian officials, for example, have stressed the implications of acid rain, a form of air pollution, on the economies of New York State and New Hampshire as part of their effort to encourage the United States to take steps to curb acid rain. **********The effort is complicated, however, by the multitude of domestic American issues that have a bearing on Canada and by the complex set of totems and taboos that animate Congress. ''There is no party discipline, there is no uniform command-and-response structure to Congress,'' said a Canadian official. ''And all of the action of Congress takes place in an atmosphere of logrolling,'' he said, referring to the practice by which local legislators cooperate with one another. ''It is a dangerous situation for us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.body_text: **********Opposition parties won elections in 12 northern cities, including 2 state capitals, dealing the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party the worst reverse in its 54-year history, official returns showed today. **********The official party won a big majority of municipal and state legislature races in the five states, but the opposition's advance in the elections July 3 was significant. **********The opposition's gains seemed to signal widespread dissatisfaction with the Institutional Revolutionary Party in the midst of Mexico's worst economic crisis in 50 years. **********Since its formation in 1929, the Institutional Revolutionary Party has monopolized Mexican politics, never losing a presidential or gubernatorial election and only a handful of local government races.  Until recently, the party won many elections with 99 percent of the vote on the national as well as the local level, often prompting charges of fraud by the opposition. **********According to official results, the Government party won 92 of 105 municipal elections of 5 states, and 56 of the 61 state legislative seats in those states -Chihuahua, Michoacan, Zacatecas, Durango and Campeche. **********Of the 1.8 million Mexicans who voted, 1.25 million, or 77 percent, voted for the Government party.  The Government party was set back in the northern states of Chihuahua and Durango, losing for the first time to the conservative National Action Party in those state capitals. The opposition's biggest victories were in Chihuahua, where it also won in the frontier town of Ciudad Juarez, across from El Paso. **********In all, the National Action Party won nine city halls and five state legislative races and brought the number of state capitals under its control to four, the largest number controlled by an opposition party since 1929. Political analaysts said the opposition's victories, although few, constituted the first real challenge to the Government party in its history.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/17/world.body_text: **********A magistrate has rejected a new appeal to release a Bulgarian held in connection with the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, judicial sources said today. **********Lawyers for the Bulgarian, Sergei I. Antonov, presented their appeal two months ago, citing what they said was new evidence against the testimony that led to his arrest last November. **********They said Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk who shot the Pope in St.  Peter's Square, had lied when he said Mr. Antonov's wife was at a meeting where he discussed the assassination attempt. **********The lawyers submitted evidence that Mr. Antonov's wife was in Yugoslavia at the time of the meeting.  Magistrate Ilario Martella ruled that there was sufficient evidence for Mr. Antonov's continued detention although no charges have been brought against him. The magistrate has refused to say when the case will be tried.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/busin.body_text: **********Thorn EMI Names A New Chairman Peter Laister, managing director of Thorn EMI P.L.C. since 1979, has been named to replace Sir Richard Cave, 63 years old, as chairman and chief executive of the British-based home entertainment and electronic equipment group. Mr. Laister will assume most of his new duties in October, the company said. **********As managing director, Mr. Laister, who is 54 years old, helped to carry out the merger of Thorn Electrical Industries Ltd. and EMI Ltd. in 1979. **********''We've put together two companies that come from different ends of the home entertainment spectrum,'' Mr. Laister said. ''The old Thorn companies were hardware-dominated, whereas EMI was software-dominated. We are one of the few major companies in the world in broad areas of home entertainment that have both software and hardware. The opportunity to build on that is significant.'' **********When asked about his plans for Thorn EMI, Mr. Laister said he was interested in ''first, dealing with the problems of the recession in the United Kingdom, and second, building the company to take advantage of what both the old Thorn and EMI had to offer.'' **********The recession restrained demand for company products such as video cassette recorders and domestic appliances and may have influenced the company's decision to end plans to market video discs after costly investment. **********Mr. Laister does not plan to make dramatic changes when he takes over, he said. ''We have a strategy and, after four years of working on it, I am unlikely to want to see it change too quickly,'' he said. **********The management change comes at a time when the company's prospects are improving. Pretax profits for the year ended March 31 rose to $187 million, from $161 million in the previous year, while sales increased to $4.16 billion, from $3.73 billion. **********Trained as a chemical engineer at Manchester University, Mr. Laister worked at Esso for 16 years before moving to the BOC Group, then the British Oxygen Corporation, in 1966. He became managing director of BOC in 1969 and helped to engineer the company's takeover of Airco Ltd., a New Jersey gas company, in 1973. From 1976 to 1979, he was managing director of Ellerman Lines, a British shipping company.
