https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/24/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Crime 'Quite a Problem,' Peking Official Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/24/world.body_text: **********China's new public security chief said in an interview published today that despite a three-year anticrime campaign, the nation has ''quite a problem'' with lawlessness in some areas of the country. **********In an interview with People's Daily, the security chief, Liu Fuzhi, said that China's crime rate was far below that of the United States but that public order was worse than in the years after the Communists took over in 1949. **********Despite an anticrime campaign, Mr. Liu said, ''there was no obvious decrease in major crimes such as murder, robbery, rape and larceny'' since 1981. **********Mr. Liu said the number of reported criminal cases dropped from 890,281 in 1981 to 748,476 last year. Over all, he said, China's crime rate is 7.1 per 10,000 people, compared with the United States rate of 500 to 600 per 10,000, but he added that there were differences in statistical methods used.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/19/busin.body_text: **********The Hewlett-Packard Company, citing strength in domestic orders, reported yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter increased 16 percent, while revenues advanced 12.5 percent. **********Hewlett, the country's largest manufacturer of electronic and test measurement equipment, said that net income in the three months ended April 30 rose to $109 milion, or 86 cents a share, from $94 million, or 76 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. **********Revenues increased to $1.17 billion from $1.04 billion. **********''We have seen little improvement in markets outside of the United States,'' said John A. Young, president and chief executive of Hewlett, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. ''Europe is especially weak, with order levels for the quarter essentially flat compared with a year ago.'' **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Hewlett jumped $3.875, to $83.125.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Bank Stocks And Bad Loans
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Bank Stocks And Bad Loans
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********ONE reason bank stocks typically sell at lower price/earnings multiples than the average equity is the potential exposure of bank portfolios to bad loans and the burden of ''nonperforming assets.'' As a rule, bank stocks now trade at slightly under 8 times their trailing 12-month earnings, compared with a multiple of just below 12 for the average stock. Loan-loss problems at several Texas banks underscore this fact. **********Earlier this month the Interfirst Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Texas, made an announcement that sent shock waves through Wall Street. Interfirst, generally held in high repute for its banking acumen, reported a $194 million operating loss for its third quarter, described as the biggest in a three-month period for any American bank. **********The quarterly loss at Interfirst reflected $334 million in charge-offs for bad loans, mainly in the oil and gas sector. Energy loan losses, in fact, have constituted a growing problem for a number of banks in the Southwest. Interfirst also raised its provision for loan losses to $430 million. **********In response to the third-quarter loss, which was in contrast to a profit of $1.05 a share a year earlier, shares of Interfirst dipped last week to 17 1/8, their lowest price since August 1982, before finishing at 18 1/4, down 1 1/2 points. Yesterday the shares were unchanged at 18 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange. The record price was 32 3/8 in mid-1981. **********Interfirst is expected to show a deficit for the calendar year 1983, and analysts have pared their 1984 earnings estimates for the company, although they generally describe the bank's annual dividend rate of $1.20 a common share as secure. **********In April of this year Charles H. Lott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., took a relatively optimistic view of the fortunes of Interfirst, despite the management's forecast of a drop in first-quarter earnings. He has followed the Dallas-based holding company for a quarter century. Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyzes more banks than any other Big Board member firm. **********''I think that if the stock is bought at current prices, it will become over the next 6 to 18 months one of the most rewarding investments in the banking industry,'' Mr. Lott said on April 12, when Interfirst's shares closed at 19 1/8. Later the stock traded in the low 20's, before its recent setback. **********When asked yesterday about his current appraisal, Mr. Lott acknowledged that ''the impact of loan losses for the third quarter was more severe than we had expected.'' **********He added: ''I would make the same general statement today about the company's prospects, but I would take a longer time horizon of one year to two years. Over the short term, the stock could be affected adversely by tax-loss selling, since it recently reached a 52-week low.'' **********Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc. was more prescient last spring about prospects for Interfirst's stock performance. The firm predicted then that the stock would drop ''into the mid- to high teens.'' **********At Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., Lawrence W. Cohn said yesterday that his firm had recently lowered its rating on Interfirst, along with that of the First City Bancorporation of Texas, from ''hold'' to ''hold/sell.'' He described the latter designation as ''a run-of-the-mill sell.'' The analyst added, ''We never dreamed that loan losses at Interfirst might run so high.'' **********Shares of First City traded last week at a 1983 low of 19 1/8 on the Big Board. This followed an earlier disclosure by the Houston-based bank holding company that it expected third-quarter earnings to fall about 85 percent, reflecting an extraordinary increase in loan-loss provisions. Yesterday First City's stock declined 1/4, to 19 1/2, on the Big Board. **********Dean Witter has published an estimate of $2.25 a share for 1984 earnings at Interfirst. But, like several other analysts, Mr. Cohn said precise projections are something of a guess at this time. **********Robert B. Albertson of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company is somewhat more optimistic. He estimated next year's profit at $3.10 a share. However, this is 45 cents a share below the firm's forecast before disclosure of the bank's third- quarter results. Meanwhile, Smith Barney has upgraded its opinion on the stock from ''avoid'' to ''hold.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.main_headline: U.S.-SOVIET TENSION BELIEVED TO BRING TIES TO LOW POINT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.print_headline: U.S.-SOVIET TENSION BELIEVED TO BRING TIES TO LOW POINT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.body_text: **********Soviet-American relations have reached one of the lowest points in a generation as the two nations trade recriminations over the Middle East, Central America, Afghanistan and missile deployments in Europe, according to many Government and academic specialists. **********The specialists regard the three years since the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979 as a time of protracted tension, sharp and acrimonious charges, diplomatic stalemate and mutual suspicion. Soviet visitors as well as American officials speak warily of the prospects for ''doing business'' with the other side. **********President Reagan suggested last week that a meeting with Yuri V.  Andropov could take place next year, and White House aides say that by sharply stepping up military spending and by speaking out forcefully against Moscow, Mr. Reagan has demonstrated resolve, bolstered American military strength and set the stage for what one official called ''a new season'' of more productive bargaining with Moscow. Talks on Grain Sales to Resume **********Senior Administration officials take comfort in the fact that the two sides have agreed to start long-term negotiations on grain sales. They also forecast more active probing in the Geneva negotiations on European nuclear weapons and strategic arms as a result of adjustments in American positions. **********Apart from arms talks, however, most cooperative activities have been shrinking. The volume of Soviet-United States trade has fallen from $4.5 billion in 1979 to $2.8 billion last year, to the point where the United States now supplies only 20 percent of Soviet grain imports, compared with 60 percent in earlier periods. 11 Commissions Suspended **********The activities of eight official groups set up under the Carter Administration to work on a treaty to bar satellite warfare, ban nuclear weapons in the Indian Ocean or develop a comprehensive underground test ban have lapsed. Eleven commissions set up a decade ago to work out exchanges in the fields of science and technology, seismic research, health research and developments in space have all been suspended. **********The downward trend began under the Carter Administration, but it has quickened during the Reagan period, in which a determined but unsuccessful drive was carried on to block the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe and to tighten curbs on Western trade with Moscow. **********''I don't know of a time when our relations have been worse at an official level,'' one experienced unofficial Presidential adviser commented. ''The mutual suspicions are very high. There's very little real dialogue going on. To cut through that will not be easy because I don't think either side wants to be seen coming to the other hat in hand.'' **********''The atmosphere is bad,'' said Helmut Sonnenfeldt, who was a ranking specialist on Soviet affairs in the Nixon Administration.  ''The Soviets are trying to heat up the Middle East and talk people into greater anxiety about the missile deployments in Europe. They're ominous in their tone. The arms negotiations are stalemated, though the nature of these negotiations is that they take five, six, seven years to succeed. The Russians are playing hard to get.'' 'A Period of Stalemate' **********''There have been periods of accommodation in the past and periods of sharp confrontation, but this is essentially a period of stalemate,'' said Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was national security adviser to President Carter. ''Both sides have openings which neither has exploited aggressively. They are like two weary boxers who have been slugging each other. They're hostile. They've backed off.  They're not really talking to each other but they're not pressing each other on the ground.'' **********Marshall Shulman, director of the Russian Research Center at Columbia University and former Soviet affairs specialist in the Carter Administration, compared the present climate to the cold war period and the time of the Cuban missile crisis in October 1962. **********''Relations are on a low plateau -poor communications, tension, dismantling of cooperative activities, sharp rhetoric,'' Mr. Shulman said. ''There aren't any signs for improvement in the near future. **********''Indeed,'' he went on, ''some factors could make relations worse - our nuclear force deployments in Europe and possible Soviet countermoves; second, the question of whether each side will deploy new strategic weapons systems; third, some third world event, say in Iran; fourth, the Middle East and particularily Syria. These add an element of unpredictability.'' Kennan Takes Grim View **********The grimmest assessment came from George F. Kennan, former American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, who said recently that Soviet-American relations were in a ''dreadful and dangerous state'' and changes were needed to halt ''a march toward war.'' **********Others, like Prof. Adam Ulam of Harvard University, temper pessimism with the reminder that for all the obvious strains, the two superpowers have avoided the sort of head-to-head showdowns they experienced over Berlin in the cold war in the late 1940's and during the Cuban missile crisis. But, Mr. Ulam added, ''things are more dangerous now because the Russians are more powerful and we are weaker.'' **********One saving grace, several analysts said, is that both President Reagan and the new Soviet leadership are preoccupied with domestic economic problems that tend to make them less activist and adventurous abroad. **********Moreover, the approach of the 1984 elections has engendered hope that the current stalemates will ease as President Reagan seeks to rebut criticism of his posture toward Moscow and arms control. 'Peace Issue' in Election **********''There might be some moderation,'' Professor Shulman said, ''as the Administration gets closer to the 1984 election and concludes that there is political advantage in moving toward the center to take the peace issue from the Democrats.'' **********Brent Scowcroft, the retired Air Force general who served as President Ford's national security adviser, said his recent informal contacts with ranking Soviet visitors indicated the Russians were interested in serious bargaining on arms control. The Russians, he told reporters at breakfast, are ''open at the present time'' for serious give-and-take but also are ''defensive'' and ''apprehensive about this Administration.'' **********''Official relations are really very bad and there are not a number of good contacts,'' the former general said. ''One way to break out of that, considering the depth of suspicion if not antagonism, would be to initiate some private kind of talks without each side having to worry about caving in or making concessions - to attempt to clear away some of the underbrush. I wouldn't say that it can't be done through official channels, but it's more difficult.'' **********During the Nixon years, Henry A. Kissinger, then national security adviser, engaged in what became known as exploratory ''back channel'' discussions with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F.  Dobrynin, that developed breakthroughs for the formal arms talks. Shultz-Dobrynin Meetings **********This year, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has held several meetings with Ambassador Dobrynin. Some officials see those meetings as a potential opening, but others report that Mr. Shultz has proceeded ''very carefully'' and that these contacts have so far been less ambitious and promising than Mr. Kissinger's earlier venture. **********''Shultz is a very capable guy but he's very careful,'' said one well-placed Reagan adviser. ''He likes to master his agenda. I don't think he's comfortable with that kind of exploration.'' **********Other officials contend, however, that even if this is the case now, Mr. Shultz will step up his role in Soviet-American relations in the coming months. **********Administration officials assert that Moscow cannot simply expect Washington to resurrect past agreements if they are unwilling to accept much of the burden for the current stalemate. The Russians, these officials charge, aggressively pushed pro-Soviet takeovers in Angola, Ethiopia, Southern Yemen and Afghanistan in the late 1970's, cut back sharply on the flow of Jewish emigration, took a tough line against dissidents and promoted the crackdown in Poland. **********''It would be easy to set up a summit and to move ahead if one essentially adopted the Soviet agenda of 'Let's have business as usual,' '' said Richard Burt, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs. ''The Soviet position is that the U.S. needs to resurrect the series of agreements and relationships that emerged in the 70's, known collectively as detente. Internal Crackdown Cited **********''But we have concerns that need to be taken into account as well if a durable U.S.-Soviet relationship is going to emerge,'' Mr. Burt went on in a meeting with reporters. ''We can't ignore the fact that there has been an increasing crackdown on different groups in the Soviet Union. **********''A lot of people say the reason detente broke down is Soviet behavior in the third world,'' Mr. Burt said. ''And there was a view in the 70's that signing arms agreements was going to lead to greater restraint on both sides. It did in the U.S. Our military spending slowed down in real terms. But Soviet spending did not. What we're asking the Soviets is to meet us half way.'' **********Some specialists contend the Administration is hampered because it lacks a top-level foreign policy-maker or strategist with the experience of Mr. Kissinger, Mr. Brzezinski or Mr. Scowcroft.  Neither Mr. Shultz, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger nor William P. Clark, the national security adviser, has a background in Soviet affairs or strategic policy-making. **********For specialized advice, officials say, the President draws indirectly on Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, a former Ambassador to Yugoslavia and close aide to Mr. Kissinger; Mr. Burt, a former specialist in national security affairs at the Institute for Strategic Studies; Fred C. Ikle, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, who is a past director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency; Richard Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, a longtime Congressional aide experienced in arms control and Soviet affairs; and Robert C.  McFarlane, the deputy national security adviser, a career marine officer who served several years on the National Security Council staff in Republican administrations. Roles for 2 Junior Specialists **********With the departure from that staff of Richard Pipes, a Harvard historian, responsibility for Soviet and East European affairs fell several months ago to two well-regarded but quite junior specialists, John Lenczowski and Paula Dobriansky. **********Within the Administration, Mr. Eagleburger and Mr. Burt have reputations as advocates of some flexibility in dealing with Moscow, whereas Mr. Ikle and Mr. Perle are known as proponents of toughness.  Mr. McFarlane was the key figure lately in helping President Reagan work out the outline of shifts in his arms control positions with key members of Congress. **********Outside specialists cite that sequence as symptomatic of the Administration's inadequate expertise in Soviet and strategic affairs. They note that the two new concepts now being incorporated into the President's strategic arms proposal originated outside the Administration. **********The idea of raising previous limits on missile launchers to make way for a new single-warhead missile emerged from Democrats in Congress and was adopted by a bipartisan commission headed by Mr.  Scowcroft. Another new idea, that of requiring each side to destroy two existing nuclear warheads for each new warhead on a new missile or submarine, came from Senators William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican, and Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/27/world.body_text: **********The chief of the Honduran armed forces says he hopes the close relations between Honduras and the United States will lead to a ''formal commitment'' by the United States to the security of Honduras. **********''I've always said that we are in business with the United States,'' the armed forces chief, Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, said in a recent interview. ''There's an important interest for the United States, which is regional security. For us it's a vital interest. **********''All this implies a price,'' the general added. ''With aid we can maintain peace. If you don't want to help us now, you'll have to pay a higher cost politically, logistically and in lives.''  Says U.S. Could Turn Elsewhere **********The general said if Washington increased military and economic aid to Honduras, ''the United States could devote itself to more important parts of the world.'' **********Although the general said he hoped coexistence was possible with the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua, high-ranking military and civilian officials in Honduras have said they are pessimistic about a peaceful solution with Nicaragua as well as with the Salvadoran leftist guerrillas. **********General Alvarez said Honduras was benefiting from the joint military exercises known as Big Pine II that began in August and are scheduled to end in March. ''We are learning to work jointly with U.S. troops,'' he said. ''Nobody knows what the future holds. We may have to work in the future with the United States.'' **********In recent weeks the Nicaraguans have charged that the United States, helped by Honduras, is planning to mount a military attack on their country. Nicaraguan fears were said to have risen during joint maneuvers last weekend, when 1,200 United States marines and 580 Honduran troops, supported by American tanks, helicopters and aircraft, landed on the northern Honduran coast. **********General Alvarez denied that Honduras had any intention of attacking Nicaragua. The reason for last weekend's amphibious exercise, he said, was that Honduras has a long, remote and poorly guarded coastline. He said the Nicaraguan armed forces and militia were larger than the combined armed forces of Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador. **********United States Embassy officials in Tegucigalpa estimate that the Nicaraguan regular armed forces number 25,000, supported by about 75,000 armed militia. According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in 1982, the armed forces of Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras total 49,500.   'Should Be Well Prepared' **********''History tells us about the record of Communist aggression,'' General Alvarez said. ''South Korea is suspected because it is armed by the United States. **********''In this case,'' he said, in reference to the political tensions in Central America, ''we should be well prepared.'' **********''Contadora is making a great effort,'' the general went on, referring to the negotiating group represented by diplomats from Mexico, Panama, Venezuela and Colombia. ''But no one can guarantee an acceptable arrangement with Nicaragua.'' **********General Alvarez spoke in his office with Seymour Topping, managing editor of The New York Times, and Bill Kovach, The Times's Washington editor. On the walls of his office hung pictures of American F-5 fighter jets and South African-made 155-millimeter howitzers, neither of which Honduras has. **********General Alvarez said the United States invasion of Grenada ''reinforced our faith in President Reagan.'' He said it showed Nicaragua ''that Cuba is not going to defend it.''  Wants Small, Mobile Army **********General Alvarez said Honduras needed small, well-armed and mobile armed forces instead of an expanded military force. He said his objectives were ''strategic mobility, air tactical mobility and firepower.'' **********Ultimately, he said, he hopes the armed forces of Honduras will increase from about 15,000 to 25,000. He said Congressional approval in Washington was essential to meet his goals. **********United States military sales and loans to Honduras totaled $38.3 million for the year, and economic aid was $95.8 million. Last summer the Honduran Army said it needed a minimum of $300 million over four years to modernize its armed forces. When the commission led by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger came to Tegucigalpa in October, the Government of President Roberto Suazo Cordova said Honduras would need $1.2 billion in aid in the next 10 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/busin.main_headline: TOKYO DEVELOPERS BET ON GOOFY AND SUSHI
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/busin.print_headline: TOKYO DEVELOPERS BET ON GOOFY AND SUSHI
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/busin.body_text: **********IN 1962, Chiharu Kawasaki, the first president of a two-year-old development company called Oriental Land, visited Disneyland and told Roy Disney, Walt Disney's brother and a Disney official, that one day he wanted to bring Disneyland to Japan. **********Next Friday, 21 years and millions of dollars later, Tokyo Disneyland, the first Disney theme park outside the United States, will officially open in Urayasu, 40 minutes from Tokyo. **********Indeed, Oriental Land, the project's developer, is betting $650 million -and some say its future - that Japan's age of leisure and affluence will guarantee that a Tokyo Disneyland, where Mickey Mouse bows to visitors, will have the same success as its two American counterparts. The park's master plan, design, technology and name were all purchased from Walt Disney Productions, which has not invested a cent in the project. **********''The economic and social situation here is much as it was in the United States in the mid-50's when Disneyland opened,'' says Frank P. Stanek, a Disney vice president who has supervised development of the site. Already many of Japan's existing amusement parks have begun upgrading facilities to try to compete with Disneyland. And analysts here say success for Tokyo Disneyland could result in eventual growth of new recreational sites, particularly theme parks, much as occurred in Los Angeles after the success of Disneyland. **********But success for the new park rests on some variables outside Oriental Land's control, including weather (Japan is colder and rainier than California and Florida, where Disney World is situated), transportation (direct train service will not be available for at least three years) and the entertainment whims of the Japanese. **********In addition, neither Oriental Land nor its joint owners, the Mitsui Real Estate Development Company, Japan's largest property concern, and the Keisei Electric Railway Company, has experience in running a large entertainment facility, although Disney is providing a fulltime team of American-trained consultants. **********But advance ticket sales so far have been brisk, with nearly 3 million sold, mostly for the period of April 15 to mid-July. Maximum daily admission to the park is 55,000 visitors, and Sundays and the upcoming Golden Week spring holidays in May are completely sold out. **********''Many people saw previews of Disneyland by special invitation and were quite impressed,'' says Hisamichi Sawa, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in Tokyo. ''We think it will be a big success.'' **********Oriental Land could use a big success. Since its inception in 1960, it has concentrated its energies on a huge land reclamation project in Chiba Prefecture, where Tokyo Disneyland is situated. **********According to the deal with Chiba signed in the 1960's, Oriental Land reclaimed 8.7 million square meters of land from Tokyo Bay and purchased, at a reduced price, 3.4 million square meters of that for the purpose of developing 2.1 million square meters into recreational facilities and the rest for residential and commercial use. The company has built a shopping center and a small tract of houses, but most of its energies have gone into Tokyo Disneyland. **********The company borrowed heavily for the project. Its $650 million investment, which covers virtually all costs, grew out of a 1979 estimate of $284 million. Interest rates hit hard, but company officials also acknowledge that the original figure was too low. **********LAST September, the company's president, Masamoto Takahashi, c onceded that the company lacked the necessary capital for its April c ompletion and asked to borrow $208 million more, bringing total l oans to an estimated $500 million. The consortium of 20 Japanese b anks financing it provided the money but reportedly demanded that t he company tighten accounting procedures. **********But analysts here say there were no real worries in the financial community because the project is backed by Mitsui Real Estate, which has helped guide its progress. Once part of the huge Mitsui conglomerate, Mitsui Real Estate was established in 1941 and later merged with other companies to become Japan's largest real estate company. For the fiscal year ended March 31, Mitsui Real Estate posted estimated earnings of $61 million on revenues of $904 million, both up about 15 percent, according to figures from Daiwa Securities. **********In contrast, Keisei Railway, established in 1909, has lost money for years and last year posted losses of $10.8 million on revenue of $267 million. Kiyoshi Kojima, an analyst for Daiwa Securities, said the company's rail division was profitable last year, but losses from inventories of unprofitable property are causing losses. **********Yet Disneyland may prove its salvation. Optimistic expectations for the park have lifted stock prices in recent months for Keisei and Mitsui, and analysts say more gains may come. **********''Keisei is the Tokyo Stock Exchange's best performer of the year,'' says Mr. Sawa. From a 1982 low of 122 yen in early September, Keisei reached 235 yen in late January and was recently trading around 490 yen. (One dollar is worth about 240 yen.) The price may continue to rise ''between 15 and 20 percent,'' says Mr. Sawa.  Analysts credit Keisei's leap with other factors besides Disneyland, including the recent lure here of speculative stocks. **********Keisei is still considered speculative, analysts caution, but success for Tokyo Disneyland could eventually make a big difference in the company's consolidated earnings. Keisei, which hasn't paid a dividend in five years and had a 9 yen per share deficit on a consolidated basis in the fiscal year 1982 is not expected to have a profit this year but could post a 13 yen per shape profit in the fiscal year 1984 and a 21 yen profit in the following year if Tokyo Disneyland is as successful as expected, says Mr. Sawa. **********Mitsui Real Estate's stock has also risen, from a 1982 low of 550 yen in August to its recent price of around 740 yen. Tokyo Disneyland was responsible for the price rise between October and December, says Mr. Kojima, but there were other factors involved as well since then. ORIENTAL LAND predicts the park will break even in the first year i f it draws 10 million visitors who each spend about $21 - $4 for f ood, $4 for souvenirs and $13 for a book of tickets for 10 rides.  B ut some term such predictions too conservative. ''We think visitors w ill spend at least $30, that first-year attendance will surpass 10 m illion and that Oriental Land will make a profit right away,'' says M r. Sawa. **********Further burnishing the two companies' stock prices is confidence that Oriental Land could sell some of its Chiba property if the park fails. According to its agreement with the banks, in the event the park does not profit after several years, Oriental Land will sell its Chiba property, with the housing land followed by the recreational areas. In the event this happens, legal authorities will step in, and the company will make some sort of financial arrangement with Chiba, says Kazumi Hirai, Oriental Land's assistant director of general affairs. **********But the deal has sparked controversy, with opponents claiming that Oriental Land will be able to sell at a huge profit land it bought cheaply from the Government. Last month a member of Japan's parliament accused the company of land speculation, claiming its loans were unsecured. A senior Finance Ministry official dismissed the charges. **********Disney officials maintain that Oriental Land's difficulties did not worry them. ''We knew they were running thin on cash flow, but we never worried that the banks wouldn't come through,'' says Mr.  Stanek. **********In the deal with Oriental Land, Walt Disney Productions agreed to provide at cost its technology and operational expertise. Disney will also receive a percentage of the gross, including 10 percent of admissions and rides and 5 percent from souvenirs, drinks and food.  The company also will get a portion of profits generated from hotels, restaurants and other recreational facilities that might eventually be built on the 60 acres surrounding the park. **********This attractive arrangement, the only conditions Disney accepted for opening a theme park in Japan, will serve as a precedent for any future theme parks the company may open outside the United States.  ''We felt this was a way to recoup some of the research and development money we've spent over the years on Disneyland and Disney World,'' says Mr. Stanek. ''This might be considered an infinite return on investment, and the terms could apply anywhere.'' **********Disneyland is a potent and popular image here. Disney characters have pitched countless Japanese products for years. Fashionable youths sport Mickey Mouse T-shirts, and Cinderella's castle has served as the model for dozens of so-called ''love hotels,'' where couples here go for privacy. An estimated 200,000 Japanese visit California's Disneyland each year. **********But some skeptics say attendance at Disneyland Tokyo could drop sharply once the park's novelty wears off. ''What will count are attendance figures five years from now,'' says a Tokyo analyst who asked not to be named.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.main_headline: SIKH HOLY LEADER TALKS OF VIOLENCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.print_headline: SIKH HOLY LEADER TALKS OF VIOLENCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/world.body_text: **********Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, who is considered a holy warrior by his followers, a fanatical preacher of violence by his adversaries, and the key figure in the Sikh uprising now flaring in the Punjab by many on both sides, looks as if he could have stepped right out of the ranks of Sikh warriors of another century. **********A white robe drapes the barefoot, six-foot-plus frame of the 36-year-old sant, or holy man. An untrimmed black beard reaches well down his chest. Piercing brown eyes peer out from under a towering saffron on blue turban. He carries a sword in a scabbard inlaid with what looks like silver, wears a pistol in a shiny black leather holster on his hip and slings a bandolier over one shoulder. **********On a late April day, as the afternoon sun conferred an extra-rich patina on the gilt-surfaced copper walls of the Golden Temple, Sikhdom's holiest shrine, Sant Bhindranwale reclined on a cot on the roof of a building with a magnificent view of the temple and its surrounding lake, and held court. **********Within the temple grounds, the strains of martial music played an accompaniment as hundreds of Sikh protesters, their heads wrapped in criss-crossed saffron strips, worked themselves up to march to the police station in one form of the daily, nonviolent protest action that has sometimes ended in shooting and killing in the last eight months. 150 Have Died **********More than 150 people have died, and more than 100,000 have been jailed, during the sustained direct-action protest by militant Sikhs on behalf of greater political autonomy for Punjab state, their homeland, and what they consider greater security for Sikhs as a religious minority in predominantly Hindu India. **********In the last week of April, in an act that heightened tensions considerably, a police inspector, a Sikh, who was worshiping at the Golden Temple, was shot and killed by an unknown gunman who has not been caught. **********High stakes are involved in what has become a bitter war of nerves, and sometimes of guns: The peace and security of the Punjab, which, as India's agricultural breabasket, is the country's main buffer against famine; the future of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's battered Congress Party in this part of India; the Sikhs' historic pride and sense of identity, and, not least, even the future shape and coherence of the Indian union. **********Sant Bhindranwale is widely regarded as the man who will have most to say about how nasty things ultimately get. And as followers gathered around his rooftop cot, pressing on him obeisance, attention and money, and as members of his heavily armed praetorian guards stood by, he invoked the names of the first and last Sikh gurus in explaining his philosophy of protest. Peaceful Protests Prescribed **********First, he said, the protest so far has followed the ways of peace prescribed by Guru Nanak, who founded Sikhism five centuries ago as a fusion of Hinduism and Islam. But if no solution is reached and Sikhs continue to be killed while protesting nonviolently, he said in Punjabi through an interpreter, ''We will have to adopt the part of Guru Gobind Singh, who taught us to take up the sword for the protection of religion and righteousness.'' **********If the sword is literally taken up, it would be in pursuit of a variety of religious and political demands, the mixture of which, wrapped in an appeal to Sikh chauvinism, has invested the situation with considerable emotion. **********Negotiations between the Akali Dal, a Sikh political party that is directing the ''morcha,'' or agitation, and Prime Minister Gandhi's Government have proceeded haltingly. The Government has said, however, that it will concede all religious demands, one of which would make Amritsar a holy city. **********The secular demands are more difficult. They include the transfer to Punjab of Sikh areas in neighboring Haryana; the transfer of Chandigarh, now the joint capital of Punjab and Haryana, to Punjab alone, and the restoration to Punjab of water from two of its rivers, the Sutlej and the Beas, that is now diverted to Haryana and Rajasthan. Federal System Demanded **********But the big demand, the one with perhaps the broadest implications, is that all governmental functions, except defense, foreign relations, communications, railways and currency, be transferred from the central Government to India's states. This would make India more of a true federal system, less the unitary system it mostly now is. **********Sant Bhindranwale said if he is not satisfied with any negotiated solution that might be reached on this point and all the others, he will ''make a program'' of action and announce it at an appropriate time. **********Most of the time, things are quiet in the Punjab. Each day ''jathas,'' or bands, of protesters drawn from Punjabi villages have been leaving the Golden Temple to march to the police station and be arrested in almost ritualistic fashion. **********Occasionally, some piece of direct action leads to real trouble, as happened earlier this month when Sant Longowal called for his workers to block the road. They did, successfully, but 21 people were killed after the police opened fire. From time to time, too, there are seemingly random murders and bombings. No one has been able to fix responsibility for them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/busin.main_headline: Manville Mine Investor Is Appointed Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Manville Mine Investor Is Appointed Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Peter D. Kyle, an accountant, has been named chairman and chief executive of Johns-Manville Canada, the soon-to-be-divested unit of the troubled Manville Corporation. **********Asbestos-related litigation forced Manville to shut down most of its mines and to file for protection from its creditors last August. **********Johns-Manville Canada operates Manville's only operating asbestos mine. **********In 1982, the Canada mine produced 300,000 tons of asbestos fiber and contributed $91.1 million in revenue to the parent company in the fiscal year 1982. Manville, once the nation's largest asbestos company, lost $87.7 million on revenue of $1.77 billion last year. **********Mr. Kyle's appointment, as well as the naming of Dimitry Poutiatine and Edward McKenna as executive vice presidents, precedes the acquisition of the mining unit by the three men and a group of investors for an undisclosed price estimated at between $75 million and $100 million. The sale is expected to be closed after July 15. **********Mr. Kyle, 45, who was previously a managing partner at Campbell, Sharp chartered accountants in Montreal, worked for eight years as an auditor at the Jeffrey asbestos mine, the Canadian unit's major asset. Mr. Poutiatine, who becomes executive vice president for sales, was formerly general marketing manager for Johns-Manville Canada. And, Mr. McKenna, who becomes executive vice president for production and operations, was the general production manager at the asbestos mine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.main_headline: FEARS GROW ON PLIGHT OF 200,000 UGANDA REFUGEES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.print_headline: FEARS GROW ON PLIGHT OF 200,000 UGANDA REFUGEES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.body_text: **********Concern is growing among Western relief agencies and embassies here over the plight of as many as 200,000 Ugandans displaced by fighting between Government troops and guerrillas. **********The fear, according to one Western source, is that thousands of people will die of malnutrition or disease if new crops are not planted to feed them and if supplies of water and medicine are not maintained. **********The focus of attention is the Luwero district, just north of the Ugandan capital, Kampala. In February Government forces launched a major drive there against guerrillas fighting under the banner of former Defense Minister Yoweri Musseveni. **********The campaign is reported to have broken the guerrilla presence in the area, forcing the insurgents, who contest the legitimacy of President Milton Obote's Govenment, to retreat westward into the Mebende and Mpigi districts. There is speculation those areas will soon be the target of a new Government offensive. Thousands Fled to Camps **********An opposition newspaper in Uganda, Munnansi, reported recently that North Korean advisers were helping Mr. Obote's troops in their campaign against the guerrillas. There has been no independent confirmation of the report. **********After the February campaign thousands of people fled to, or were forced into, makeshift camps where, diplomats said, there is a critical need for water and medicine. **********''It could become totally critical if they do not plant crops now,'' Canada's Ambassador to Kenya, David Miller, said today. ''The need for water and medicine is most urgent.'' **********Mr. Miller was one of a group of official representatives from Canada, Australia and Britain permitted to tour the Luwero area last week. Their visit was the first of its kind since the start of the February campaign. Mr. Miller's comments represented a rare public expression of concern. Villagers Fear New Fighting **********The Canadian envoy said villagers were not returning home to plant crops because they feared renewed hostilities. ''We only saw an estimated 45,000 people in 4 out of possibly 18 camps that we know about,'' he told reporters. Other reports say the refugees fear harassment by Government troops if they leave the centers. **********The Ugandan authorities have denied that the camps are internment centers, but witnesses who recently returned from Uganda say the installations are run by the army. **********Up to 500 civilians are reported to have been killed in the Luwero district in recent incidents, including 81 people who died in a massacre at a refugee center last month. Australia's Foreign Minister, Bill Hayden, said recently that if the reports were confirmed they would represent ''the most serious outbreak of violence in Uganda since the overthrow of the former dictator Idi Amin'' in 1979. **********Travelers from Uganda say the refugees in the Luwero district are desperately short of water, medicine, food and shelter. Aid organizations there are ferrying in fresh water, medical supplies and food, but recent visitors say measles has broken out and some adults are suffering from malnutrition. Prime Coffee Producer **********Under normal conditions Luwero is regarded as one of Uganda's most fertile districts and is a prime producer of coffee, a principle export crop. **********A Kampala resident who visited the area recently, however, said food shortages and other deficiencies in the district were so serious that ''in one month's time there will be no problem in Luwero.'' The inference was that there would be no people left to cause a problem. **********A further concern is that, if the army moves into the areas where the guerrillas have fled, a further refugee problem will be created among the million or so people who stand to be affected in Mubende and Mpigi districts. **********Aid agencies are reported to be working under political constraints, threatened with expulsion if they become the source of publicity deemed by Uganda's Government to be detrimental.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.main_headline: U.S. ROLE IN THE U.N. IS DEBATED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.print_headline: U.S. ROLE IN THE U.N. IS DEBATED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.body_text: **********Two Congressional hearings that were intended to examine whether the United Nations should stay in New York evolved instead into a forum on continued American involvement in the world organization. **********The House Subcommittee on Human Rights and International Organizations heard testimony from three speakers on Sept. 27 and Oct. 3. **********Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas; Elliot L. Richardson, chairman of the United Nations Association of the United States, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, expressed wide-ranging concerns about the United States' role in the United Nations. **********The hearings came in the aftermath of a statement by Charles M. Lichenstein, an American representative at the United Nations, who, in an angry retort to a Soviet criticism on Sept. 19, suggested that United Nations delegates consider leaving the United States if they were unhappy with American hospitality.   Comments Backed by Reagan **********His comments were subsequently endorsed by President Reagan. Later, in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 26, Mr. Reagan lent broad United States support to the United Nations' peaceful goals. **********Critics labeled Mr. Lichenstein's remarks arrogant and undiplomatic, and they clearly struck a nerve in some subcommittee members. **********''Seldom in my years in public office have I been more upset at the needless diatribe that has been sparked by representatives of the U.S. Government,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. **********In his testimony, Mr. Richardson read a five-sentence statement supporting continuation of a United States- based United Nations. It was signed by former Secretaries of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Henry A. Kissinger, Edmund S. Muskie, William P. Rogers, Dean Rusk and Cyrus R. Vance; by Zbigniew Brzezinski, McGeorge Bundy and Brent Scowcroft, all former national security advisers, and by George W. Ball, Arthur J. Goldberg, Donald F. McHenry, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, John A. Scali, William W. Scranton and Andrew Young, former representatives at the United Nations. **********The statement later appeared in an advertisement in The New York Times.   Survey Backs New York Site **********In addition, a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll showed that Americans favored, by a 3 to 1 ratio, keeping the United Nations headquarters in New York City. **********Despite the concern over where the United Nations should be situated, the focus of the hearings shifted to the United States' financial commitment to the international organization. **********Mrs. Kassebaum outlined an amendment the Senate had approved, 66 to 23, that would slash the United States contribution to the United Nations and its agencies by nearly $500 million over the next four years. The United States contribution represents 25 percent of the United Nations' budget, which was $722 million last year and is expected to be $784 million this year. 'New Thoughts About Priorities' **********''I would hope that this amendment would lead to new thoughts about priorities for and spending by the United Nations,'' Mrs. Kassebaum said. **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick voiced concern that a majority of countries were paying a disproportionately small share of the budget, leaving the United States to pay a lion's share despite its objections to the adopted final budget. **********''Those countries who have the votes don't pay the bills, while those who pay the bills don't have the votes,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.main_headline: AUSTRALIAN ASSURES U.S. ON USE OF JOINT BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.print_headline: AUSTRALIAN ASSURES U.S. ON USE OF JOINT BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Robert Hawke of Australia, ending a visit to the United States, has reaffirmed his country's determination to maintain joint military installations with the United States on Australian territory, even though this entails risk. **********''We are part of the United States system of alliances,'' Mr. Hawke said in an interview in New York. ''We acknowledge that the fact that we host these joint facilities does entail possible risk in the event of nuclear conflict.'' **********''Our judgment is that the advantages involved in the deterrent capacities of the United States of which these facilities form a part, outweigh the possible risks that are involved,'' the Australian leader added. **********Mr. Hawke was in New York as the last stop on his five-day visit.  After his election in March as Australia's first Labor Prime Minister since 1975, there was concern he might be pressed by his party's left wing to depart in some areas from the firm support of the United States given by the former Conservative Government. **********Before the election, William G. Hayden, Foreign Minister under Mr.  Hawke, said Australia needed to be ''more assertive and more independent'' in foreign policy. Pains to Assure the U.S. **********But Mr. Hawke, whose visit included meetings with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, seemed to take pains to reaffirm his Government's unwavering commitment to the Western alliance. **********Mr. Hawke said that he had told Mr. Reagan and Mr. Shultz that ''they will not find a firmer ally and alliance partner than us.'' ''I emphasized,'' he added, ''that if points arose where we perceived that our interests were perhaps being prejudiced by some actions of the United States we'd say so, and that's how friends should behave.'' **********The United States and Australia, allied with New Zealand in the Anzus treaty, jointly maintain radar and communications installations in Australia that help monitor Soviet ship and air movements in the Southern Hemisphere. The installations have been criticized by some in Australia, including members of the Labor Party, for making the country a possible target of a nuclear attack. 'An Exercise in Delusion' **********Acknowledging that there were some in Australia who wanted the bases closed, Mr. Hawke said in the interview: ''I believe I have a clear perception of global realities, and I would regard it as an exercise in delusion to think that we can engage in some unilateral processes of disarmament and detachment from the alliances of the West.'' **********''One has to say,'' he went on, ''that on all the evidence the Soviet Union is an expansionary power and is prepared to use, either directly or through its surrogates, force of arms.'' **********''One looks at Afghanistan,'' the Prime Minister continued. ''One looks at what the Soviet Union is prepared to do in Poland. One looks in Africa. One looks at the build-up of its capacities at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. One looks at the supply of arms in Central America.  These are not concocted ideas. These are indisputable facts.'' Labor Pledged Aid to Vietnam **********On other issues, Mr. Hawke seemed to put to rest the concern voiced immediately after his election that, on some issues, the policies of the Labor Government would depart from those of the United States. The Labor Party platform pledged the party to give economic aid to Vietnam and to withdraw its contingent from the multinational peacekeeping forces in the Sinai Peninsula. **********In the interview Mr. Hawke said there was no serious difference with Washington over Vietnam. ''It is the view of the Labor Party that it is appropriate that Vietnam shouldn't be isolated but should be brought back into the family of nations,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/16/busin.body_text: **********An aircraft patented this week is to be attached to the pilot's back in saddle fashion, fitting around his sides and shoulders. A support forward is to be provided for his head and one at the rear for his feet, with power supplied by two jet engines. **********Igor Dmitrowsky, an engineer who lives in Elmhurst, Queens, was granted patent 4,379,532 for the aircraft. He has organized Booster Technical Associates, which is having one of the craft constructed and hopes to arrange for manufacture. **********The pilot can regulate the jetstreams on the engines and adjust a pair of fins for directional control. As the inventor explains, the craft can be stood upright on the ground before it takes off vertically and goes into horizontal flight. Normally, he expects, landing will also be vertical. **********The patent says aircraft of this kind can go into, ascend from and land upon relatively small areas, rocky terrain, small islands, sand bars, rooftops, wooded lands and canyon floors. Accordingly, the craft is said to offer benefits in sporting, exploratory, emergency and warfare use. **********One of Mr. Dmitrowsky's earlier patents covers a design for a pilot-borne aircraft with a single engine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/07/world.main_headline: CHINA MAKES ISSUE OF SOVIET MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/07/world.print_headline: CHINA MAKES ISSUE OF SOVIET MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/07/world.body_text: **********China and the Soviet Union opened new talks today aimed at normalizing their relations amid indications that the Chinese will press the Russians to reduce the number of Soviet nuclear missiles deployed along China's northern frontier. **********The talks, which are believed to be taking place in a Chinese Government guest house, are the third round of the formal discussions that began last October to reduce longstanding tensions between the two Communist neighbors. **********As in the past, the details of the meetings are being kept secret, reflecting a penchant for confidentiality that Moscow and Peking share. The head of the Soviet delegation, Deputy Foreign Minister Leonid F. Ilyichev, declined to comment on the talks when he arrived in Peking on Tuesday. **********Qi Huaiyuan, the spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, said at a weekly news briefing Wednesday that no fixed schedule had been set for the latest round of consultations, which in the past have lasted about two weeks.   Concern About SS-20 Missiles **********The head of the Chinese delegation, Deputy Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, told visiting Japanese journalists earlier this week that he would be raising China's concern about the Soviet SS-20 medium-range nuclear missiles concentrated along China's border with the Soviet Union and Mongolia. **********Mr. Qi denied Wednesday that this constituted a fresh demand. He said it was part of the three conditions that China has set for an improvement in Chinese-Soviet relations. These include a withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, an end to Soviet support for the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia and a sharp cutback of Soviet border forces. **********''China hopes that the Soviet Union would reduce its troops along the Chinese-Soviet border, including conventional and nuclear weapons,'' Mr. Qi said. According to United States estimates, up to 500,000 well-equipped Soviet troops are arrayed against a million Chinese soldiers armed with inferior weapons. **********The recent attention given here to the Soviet SS-20 missiles has suggested Chinese preoccupation with a new facet of the border issue. The People's Daily newspaper on Sept. 17 demanded that the Soviet Union substantially cut back its missiles in Asia, saying that ''they pose a considerable threat to China and other countries of Asia.''  Unhappiness About Arms Buildup **********Last week in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly, Chinese Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian emphasized Peking's unhappiness over Moscow's and Washington's arms buildup. Mr. Wu proposed an international conference on disarmament for all states possessing nuclear arms, but only after the Soviet Union and the United States reduced their nuclear arsenals and delivery systems by half. China exploded its first atomic bomb in 1964. **********Hewing to its current policy of active alignment with the third world, China has accused both the Soviet Union and the United States of a lack of sincerity in their disarmament proposals. **********The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Mr. Qi, repeated Wednesday that ''China is particularly concerned about the dismantling of the nuclear missiles already deployed in Asia and the prevention of possible future deployment of such missiles in this part of the world.'' **********When another Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Mikhail S. Kapitsa, visited China last month, he relayed an earlier pledge by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, not to transfer nuclear missiles to Asia from Europe if a Soviet-American arms reduction pact was reached. This assurance does not appear to have assuaged the Chinese.   Change in Priorities **********The new stress on the missiles suggests a change in Peking's priorities in the current Chinese-Soviet consultations on normalization. Chinese officials used to say that the first step should be for Moscow to stop supporting the Vietnamese troops in Cambodia who are fighting guerrillas of the ousted Pol Pot Government, which Peking still recognizes. **********There has been no apparent progress on any of the issues in the first two rounds of discussions, which were held in Peking last October and in Moscow in March. Qiao Shi, a ranking Chinese Communist Party official, confirmed late last month that the Kremlin had rejected China's demands. **********China's decision two years ago to take a more independent course between the United States and the Soviet Union led it to accede to the Kremlin's requests for consultations on improving Chinese-Soviet relations. **********China has denied trying to play the Soviet Union off against the United States. Before he left for the United Nations, Foreign Minister Wu said that ''Sino-Soviet relations and Sino-U.S. relations are two different things and they cannot be linked together.''  U.S. Relations Improve **********But relations with the United States have improved noticeably. When Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger visited here last week, it was announced that China's Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, would go to the United States in January and President Reagan would visit China in April. **********Peking's contacts with Washington remain far more extensive than its dealings with Moscow. Chinese-Soviet border trade was resumed earlier this year in two frontier areas of Xinjiang and Heilongjiang, but overall trade remains a fraction of Chinese-American commerce. **********A handful of Chinese and Soviet students have enrolled this year in each other's universities, resuming an exchange that was broken off after relations soured more than two decades ago. Other contacts have also increased. **********Mr. Wu had planned to meet the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, at the United Nations this month, but Mr. Gromyko canceled his trip. Mr. Qi said the meeting would not be rescheduled because Mr. Wu had a lot of work to do.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.body_text: **********In the late 1970's, the Zenith Radio Corporation was known as much for its crusade against Japanese imports as for its television sets.  Lately, however, Wall Street analysts have been impressed because the company has abandoned this quixotic battle and refocused its energies on cutting manufacturing costs and capitalizing on its historically strong research efforts. **********But just as Zenith's fortunes appeared to be on the rise, the company was shocked Monday night by the unexpected death of its chief executive, Revone W. Kluckman, who died of a heart attack after playing golf at the Medinah Country Club outside of Chicago. **********Mr. Kluckman, who was 54 years old, had joined Zenith as controller in 1967, and became president in 1977, chief executive in 1980 and chairman in 1982. **********Confidence in Turnaround **********Analysts said yesterday that Zenith's new strategy was well in place, and expressed confidence that the company would continue its turnaround - if the economy expands, the electronics boom continues and inflation remains low. **********Zenith last year lost $21.8 million on revenues of $1.2 billion, although it has reported profits in the first two quarters this year.  Several analysts said that Zenith has sufficient management depth to find a capable successor to Mr. Kluckman and to Walter C. Fisher, 64, the executive vice president for sales and marketing who temporarily succeeds Mr. Kluckman as chief executive under the company's bylaws. Mr. Kluckman's tenure is expected to be short because he has already announced his retirement. **********''It's like losing a father,'' said Charles Ryan, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. ''It's a lot different if you're 12 than if you're 45. In this case, it's more like being 45.''  Reluctance to Make TV's **********As its name indicates, Zenith's roots were in radio. The company was incorporated in 1923 as a sales agent for the Chicago Radio Laboratory and ultimately became known as a manufacturer of highquality radios. Afraid of offending radio dealers, Zenith resisted moving into television and did not sell its first receivers until 1948. **********But if it was slow off the mark, Zenith went on to become the largest domestic manufacturer of televisions, first in black and white, and then in color. Then the Japanese pushed into the American market with low-cost sets, and by 1976, they had grabbed more than 44 percent of the color television market. And two years later, the RCA Corporation, which had trailed Zenith in sales of television sets, pulled out ahead of Zenith in domestic share, using pricecutting tactics. **********Zenith first began its complaints about the Japanese competition in 1968, contending that the Japanese were selling televisions below market value and that the Japanese Government was subsidizing their sale. It was an argument that John J. Nevin, who became Zenith's president in 1971 and chairman in 1976, continued to press widely. **********But Zenith and other domestic producers had little luck convincing the United States Government to stem the Japanese flow of sets. And it was not until 1977 that the Japanese, fearful of eventual trade repercussions, agreed to a modest limit on their exports. **********Meanwhile, Zenith accepted the fact that Japan was a permanent player in the domestic television market, and under Mr. Kluckman's tutelage, the company tried to compete by lowering its costs and expanding its product line into related but potentially more profitable areas. Focus Switches to Cost Cutting **********''They finally realized that you don't win the war in Washington; you fight the battle in the plants to get costs down,'' said Mr. Ryan of Merrill Lynch. **********To that end, the company moved the manufacture of its black-andwhite sets to Taiwan and its labor-intensive color television components and modules to Mexico. It has also closed several obsolete color television assembly plants in Chicago, substituting an automated plant in Springfield, Mo. **********The company has also added new products, including personal computers and high-resolution monitors or screens for computers, power converters for computers and ''addressable'' decoders, which let cable television companies change a customer's service without entering the home. **********Most of the growth, analysts explain, has stemmed from their television business and continued research in that area.  ''They felt that their business was TV, and they couldn't escape it,'' so the company kept its research spending high despite low profits and developed related businesses, said James I. Magid, an analyst with L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, a New York brokerage house. **********In 1979, the company also acquired the Heath Company, which makes and markets electronic do-it-yourself kits. And last January, it signed a five-year agreement to produce teletext receiving equipment, which displays editorial matter on a television set. Immediate Pay Off Not Seen **********But the efforts have not paid off immediately. The company lost money last year and omitted its quarterly dividend of 7 1/2 cents a share last September. The dividend has yet to be reinstated and the company's debt has remained higher than it has historically carried. **********Zenith's problem last year - and one that analysts say has the potential to be a problem again - is the company's heavy reliance on color television sales, which accounted for 60 percent of the company's revenues last year, only slightly lower than the 65 percent of revenues in 1980. **********This year, however, TV sets have been selling at a record pace, up 17 percent from last year, according to Television Digest, an industry newsletter, and Zenith has captured 18.5 percent of the market. **********One reason for the increase in the sale of sets is the use of sets for computer screens, games, videotape recorders and pay television, said David Lachenbruch, editorial director of the newsletter. ''Most people can't get by on just one set,'' he said. **********With television sales up, and Zenith selling relatively expensive sets, the company reported a profit in 1983's first quarter, and on Monday, reported second-quarter earnings of $11.5 million, or 59 cents a share, compared to a loss in 1982. Sales were up 11 percent, to $324 million, from $292 million. **********Zenith's stock was the 10th most actively traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. It closed at $28.125 a share, up $1.25 for the day, and a 52-week high.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/busin.main_headline: G.M. FACES A SNAG ON 'JAPAN STRATEGY'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/busin.print_headline: G.M. FACES A SNAG ON 'JAPAN STRATEGY'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Japanese auto makers will oppose allocating to the Isuzu Motor Company and the Suzuki Motor Company any shares in the quotas on imports to the United States, Takashi Ishihara, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said today. **********This opposition, if successful, could jeopardize the General Motors Corporation's plans to satisfy the bulk of its small-car needs through links to Isuzu and Suzuki, among others. **********At present, neither Isuzu nor Suzuki ships many cars into this country. But G.M. is planning to import about 200,000 cars from Isuzu and slightly under 100,000 from Suzuki next year. Thus, if Japan does not allocate a significant quota to the two companies, it could pose a problem for the American company. The quota system is to be revised next April. **********Mr. Ishihara, who is also president of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association, was here for the lavish formal dedication of Nissan's $660 million, ultramodern plant, which has been in limited operation since June, producing pickup trucks. **********In a breakfast interview in the plant's cafeteria, the 71-year-old executive said all Japanese companies should share equitably in any increase in auto shipments to the United States. **********Problem With Toyota, Too **********G.M.'s so-called Japanese strategy is also apparently in danger on another front. The proposed joint venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation to build 200,000 Toyota-designed subcompacts in Fremont, Calif., has been delayed by Toyota's reluctance to provide detailed cost and profit information to the Federal Trade Commission, which must rule on the legality of the venture. **********It appeared today as if all 1,200 of the workers at the Nissan plant here turned out to greet Mr. Ishihara. They stomped and cheered as he carefully read two speeches that emphasized the importance of the plant as an American venture. **********A local band struck up ''America, the Beautiful'' between the various speeches. Mr. Ishihara, conservative and elegant in a dark blue, pinstriped suit and aviator-style glasses, spoke from the loading dock at the back of the spotless beige plant, which was decked out in American flags. **********Mr. Ishihara's English is good enough for speech-making, but he preferred to be interviewed through an interpreter. Commenting specifically on the outlook for quotas, Mr. Ishihara said he hoped ''the two Governments would have a good talk about this,'' adding that Japanese auto makers ''have not talked about concrete numbers'' with their own Government yet. **********Higher Quotas Expected **********Most auto industry executives are projecting that the quota for the year beginning next April 1 will be increased to about 2 million cars, from the 1.68 million that has been the ceiling for the last three years. The quotas, or ''voluntary restraint agreement'' between Japan and the United States, began in April 1981 after American auto makers complained about losing a big share of the domestic market to Japanese imports. **********G.M. executives have urged Japanese and United States officials to include Isuzu and Suzuki in any quota increase, arguing that both companies have made sizable investments in products destined for the American market. But Mr. Ishihara said, ''Isuzu and Suzuki are not the only Japanese companies that have made investments, so there is no reason to allocate expanded quotas to Isuzu and Suzuki alone.'' **********Unless the two companies get substantial shares of the expected quota increase of 300,000 units, G.M. will be left well short of the import levels it had been counting on. Thus, if the Toyota plant is also delayed, G.M. would go into the 1985 model year next fall with its relatively old-fashioned Chevrolet Chevette, which has been fading in popularity, as its only subcompact model. **********In a recent interview, Roger B. Smith, chairman of G.M., declined to say what the company would do if its Japanese connections failed, but said the issue was one of the most important facing the company. **********Trucks 'Made in U.S.A.' **********Mr. Ishihara also acknowledged that a ''Made in U.S.A.'' label is a stronger selling point on a light truck than it is on a car. This, he said, was an important factor in making the pickup truck the company's first American-made product. **********''If the quality is the same in Japan and Tennessee, Americans will prefer Tennessee-made trucks,'' he said. **********Officials of the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation, the subsidary that operates the plant, conceded that some of the plant's machinery, which includes 220 robots, seemed more suited to auto than truck production. They also said there were empty spaces in the plant, apparently reserved for the installation of stamping presses for forming auto bodies. **********Mr. Ishihara said the company was studying adding automobile production to the Smryna plant, but had not decided when or what model. **********Nissan officials acknowledged that the company was not immune to the quality problems that have plagued American auto companies. **********A survey by J. D. Power & Associates, a market research firm, showed, for example, that Nissan had slipped behind Toyota in buyer satisfaction, to the level of some of the better American models. C. P. King, Nissan's senior vice president for sales, commented: ''We have brought out a lot of new vehicles over the last few years, and you don't always get the quality you want at first.'' **********Marvin T. Runyon, president of Nissan Motor Manufacturing U.S.A., said the Smyrna plant would reach full production of about 10,000 trucks a month about the middle of next year. About 42 percent of the parts and materials in the vehicles are made in the United States, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/world.body_text: **********6 African Lands Impose New Rule on Journalists **********HARARE, Zimbabwe, July 31 (Reuters) - Information ministers of the six black African ''front line'' countries announced today that in principle no foreign correspondents would be allowed to cover their countries from bases in South Africa. **********The ministers, from Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Zambia, Angola, Botswana and Tanzania, also agreed that any foreign journalist banned by one of them would be barred by the others. **********The ministers issued a communique called the Kadoma Declaration after the Zimbabwe town 100 miles southwest of here where they met. **********''Foreign correspondents accredited to South Africa and reporting to regional bureaus in South Africa will not be allowed, in principle, to work in front-line states,'' it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.body_text: **********The Provisional President of El Salvador said today that he would not comply with United States Congressional stipulations that his Government begin unconditional discussions with insurgents. **********The rejection could upset the Reagan Administration's efforts to win approval of an increased aid package for El Salvador.  The Salvadoran, Alvaro Magana, who was here for consultations with Reagan Administration officials, said he would rather suffer a termination in American military and economic aid than conduct openended negotiations with guerrilla leaders. **********Congressional committees that have approved aid requests for El Salvador this year linked the assistance to the Salvadoran Government's willingness to begin ''an unconditional dialogue'' with the insurgents. **********The Reagan Administration asked Congress in March for $110 million in extra military aid to El Salvador in the current fiscal year. Congress had already approved $26.3 million. Since March, foreign affairs and appropriations committees in the House and Senate have approved far smaller additional amounts than the Admministration had requested. Talks Within 90 Days Stipulated **********The House Foreign Affairs Committee, for example, which had jurisdiction over $50 million of the Administration's additional aid request, agreed to an increase of only $8.7 million. The committee stipulated that unconditional talks begin in El Salvador within 90 days of the legislation's final enactment. **********Mr. Magana, in his Government's most forceful response to the negotiation requirement since its adoption by several Congressional committees last month, said in an interview, ''We are not going to satisfy that condition.'' If necessary, he added, ''We are going to lose economic and military aid.'' **********Mr. Magana said that in the view of his Government, negotiations without conditions constituted an unacceptable opportunity for the insurgents to negotiate their way into power. ''We are a Government elected by the people,'' he went on. ''I don't have the right to discuss power sharing,'' adding that the Government was willing to talk to the guerrillas about their participation in free elections, but nothing more. **********Mr. Magana's statements added to an already complex debate about how and when the Salvadoran Government should talk to the guerrillas about ending the civil war. U.S. 'Can Live With' Terms **********Senior Reagan Administration officials have said they ''can live with'' Congressional conditions about talks because the requirements emphasize that free elections and the evolution of democratic forms of government should be key elements. **********The officials also hope that the legislative language spelling out the conditions will be softened before the bills reach a final vote by the Senate and House. **********The guerrillas, for their part, have refused to talk about taking part in elections, saying that the Salvadoran Govermment cannot guarantee the safety of leftist candidates or the integrity of the electoral process. Instead, they have called for discussions about broader political issues. **********Mr. Magana's flat refusal to consider an unconditional dialogue, combined with the guerrillas' unwillingness to limit discussions to their participation in elections, makes it unlikely that any direct talks will soon take place between the government and the insurgents about resolving the civil war. No Decision on Meeting Rebels **********President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Richard B.  Stone, has under consideration an offer by the guerrillas to meet with him. The White House said on Friday that no decision had been made about whether to proceed with such a meeting. **********Along with his rejection of Congressional requirements about negotiations, Mr. Magana complained today about the overall approach Congress has taken to aid requests for his country. **********He chided Congress for approving aid that is ''attached to so many conditions'' and is provided after ''so many delays.'' The delays, he added, forced the Salvadoran Army to put off for six months a plan to conduct a military sweep of San Vicente Province. The sweep, which is designed to force the guerrillas out of the area and make it secure it for economic reconstruction efforts, began last week. **********Mr. Magana also said that his Government has had difficulty meeting American expectations about rapidly improving its human rights performance. ''I would like to have a little more understanding,'' Mr. Magana remarked. ''They have to realize that at this time, in the middle of a war with all the violence, it is not easy to eradicate things. We can't do that overnight'' **********Mr. Magana departed for El Salvador late in the afternoon after spending the day meeting with numerous groups of reporters and recording interviews for the evening television news programs. ---- Army Reports Killing 115 **********SAN SALVADOR, June 18 (UPI) -The army has killed 115 leftist guerrillas in 11 days of counterinsurgency sweep of San Vicente Province, part of a United States-designed pacification program, military officials said today.

A FREEZE ON BANK DEREGULATION?;
