https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/busin.body_text: **********BIG changes are ahead for American banking. More competition, more s ources of credit, new technologies and new services are beckoning.  T he question is not whether these changes will occur, but how. Are wet o proceed in a disorderly rush? Or can we make an orderly transitiont o a more modern system? **********The disorderly rush has already started. New companies and new techniques are pouring through breaches that have been torn in regulatory dikes. Sticking fingers into the holes is not the answer.  Many of the changes are desirable. But change should happen in a systematic and predictable manner, with attention to equity and the public interest. **********Bankers work with other people's money, so banking must be supervised and regulated to insure prudent use of depositors' funds.  In the United States, banking is more heavily regulated than in most other countries. This reflects unhappy experience with past banking crises and various abuses. **********Thus, a major objective of banking regulation is prophylactic - to assure that principles of prudence and good sense prevail and that potential problems, like conflicts of interest, are avoided. When people put their money in banks, they need some degree of protection. So does the Government, when it insures those deposits, to say nothing of the economy as a whole, which needs to be insulated from the ripple effect of imprudent financial decisions.TODAY, much of the momentum for change comes from outside the b anking industry. Thrift institutions like savings and loan a ssociations, nondepository financial institutions like brokerage h ouses and insurance companies, and nonfinancial businesses like m ail-order or steel companies have found their way into some forms ofb anking. Through ''nonbank banks,'' which take deposits but do not m ake commercial loans and thereby escape many regulatory restraints, t hey can establish a base. **********These outsiders did not shoulder their way in because the banking business is so gloriously profitable; it is not. Rather, the combination of their own business, whatever it is, with some banking functions is the key. To get Federal deposit insurance, for instance, can be an enormous advantage to a nonbank financial firm.  It may also be very good for the customer. But if we have not done it all these years, why rush in suddenly without careful thought and legislation? **********The banks, who see their turf invaded, naturally are straining to counter-attack. Now that at last there is movement, they want to break out of the narrow confines of their present business, while the outsiders want to break in. If these forces prevail, the future shape of the banking system is not easy to foresee. **********Congress rarely enjoys banking legislation. There are few votes in it, and a lot of bitter lobbying. But sooner or later, Congress will have to come to grips with the headlong rush into a new financial services system. The nation has had too much grief with its financial institutions to allow a permanent free-for-all in this area. Currently, Congress is much exercised about what banks have done in international lending. It seems a peculiar occasion for uncontrolled experimentation in other directions. The question is not whether, but when, Congress will act. **********Congress may act late, after much of the rush is over. It would then confront a set of faits accomplis. It could roll them back only over the dead bodies of those who thought they had it made. It could also grandfather-in the claims that have been staked out, denying similar opportunities to latecomers. On the other hand, Congress could act early and hope that a quick job would be a good one. Or finally, Congress could impose a moratorium on new moves while it deliberated carefully. **********Some observers have looked at the bank holding company as a vehicle for change. This view would bring the banks into the securities business, into real estate development and into insurance. In an attempt to protect banks against recognized risks, such activities would be conducted only through subsidiaries of bank holding companies. Losses of the subsidiary would not fall upon the bank.  Unfortunately, this goes against the normal tendency of a bank to protect affiliates in order to protect its own name and credit standing. This is expected of banks, particularly in international banking, where the ''moral responsibility'' of banks for their foreign affiliates, however packaged, is taken for granted. This dilemma could be mitigated by recognizing such inevitable linkages, and by providing for a degree of supervisory oversight of the affiliate and the entire holding company to assure that basic public policy objectives are not circumvented or ignored. **********Matters such as these require careful Congressional consideration.  A good, quick job leading to definitive solutions no doubt would be best. Whether it is within reach is anybody's guess. A moratorium would provide time for study and reflection. The interested parties could have their say. The chances of a good job being done would greatly improve.
